headline: Giants vs. Eagles: What to Watch
text: Matchup to Watch: Eli Manning vs. The BlitzEli Manning takes a lot of time to adjust plays at the line of scrimmage, and that has caused some delay penalties and miscommunication. Coach Tom Coughlin has expressed his concern about too much "chess game." Coughlin and the offensive coordinator Kevin Gilbride said the Eagles blitz even more than before, and that was plenty. Should Manning dither further when presented with such challenges, the Giants could lose again to their N.F.C. East rival.

headline: In Race for Governor, Brown Is Hard to Ignore
text: The job of California governor is a political plum. Its occupant becomes an instant household name across the country, attracts worldwide attention and is typically considered a potential candidate for president. Yet with Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco’s departure from the race Friday, the Democrats now have no major candidates officially in the running for the job in 2010.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about an academic reassessment that challenges what is known about the 1415 Battle of Agincourt in France, where an exhausted English army defeated heavily armed French nobles, gave an outdated name for the academic institution where Kelly DeVries, an authority on medieval warfare who was quoted, is a professor of history. It is Loyola University Maryland; until Sept. 25, it had been “Loyola College in Maryland.”

headline: Mandates and Affordability
text: If Congress approves health care reform, virtually all Americans will be required to buy health insurance or pay a penalty. That raises a fundamental question: Will the policies be affordable?

headline: Family Baggage From the Oval Office
text: There may soon be a refreshing addition to the nation’s presidential historic sites: Billy Carter’s gas station in Plains, Ga. This is where the self-proclaimed redneck brother of the 39th president happily drank beer, expounded raffishly to the international media, and hosted Libyan officials who hired him to lobby an embarrassed Carter administration. “I have more influence over members of the U.S. Senate than I do over Billy,” President Jimmy Carter once despaired at news of his brother’s caperings.

headline: Recession, Revolution and a Leaner Times
text: IN his autobiography “The Good Times,” Russell Baker described the Times newsroom he joined in 1954 as “comically overstaffed.” Baker, a Pulitzer Prize-winning Washington reporter and columnist, quoted a colleague’s explanation for all the idle reporters playing bridge and working crossword puzzles:

headline: More Poetry, Please
text: More and more lately, I find people asking me: What do you think President Obama really believes about this or that issue? I find that odd. How is it that a president who has taken on so many big issues, with very specific policies  and has even been awarded a Nobel Prize for all the hopes he has kindled  still has so many people asking what he really believes?

headline: A Final Verdict on the Presidential Salute
text: FOR nearly three decades, I’ve felt conflicted about presidential salutes. After all, my United States Marine Corps instructors drilled into me the idea that “you never salute without a cover” which, in civilian, meant without a hat.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about demonstrations that call for a reduction in carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere to 350 parts per million, which some prominent scientists consider the limit to avoid disruptions from global warming, misstated the job at the Environmental Defense Fund formerly held by Michael Oppenheimer, a Princeton University scientist, who said it would be a herculean accomplishment to hold those levels below 450 parts per million. It was chief scientist, not scientist.

headline: Correction
text: An article on Oct. 11 about the revival of “Bye Bye Birdie” misstated the age of Lee Adams, who wrote the music. He is 85, not 75.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about electric-motorcycle racing misstated the cost to compete with one racebike, the KillaCycle. It is $20,000 a year, not $120,000.

headline: Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Report
text: And Then There Was One | You never want to ignore Jerry Brown. With the departure of San Francisco’s mayor, Gavin Newsom, from the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, the 71-year-old state attorney general becomes the presumptive nominee, explains Daniel Weintraub. Perhaps it’s not a surprise: Every California governor in the past half century has been either a veteran state officeholder or a celebrity. Mr. Brown is both.

headline: Corrections
text: A report last Sunday about the marriage of Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner misstated the bride’s relationship to Melania Trump. She is a stepdaughter, not the stepdaughter.

headline: Sabathia to Start Game 4; Burnett Lined Up for 5
text: PHILADELPHIA – When C.C. Sabathia started on three days’ rest in the American League Championship Series, he was still throwing 95 miles an hour in the eighth inning. Sabathia earned the victory in Game 4 that night, and he has a chance to repeat the feat on Sunday at Citizens Bank Park.

text: PHILADELPHIA - When C.C. Sabathia started on three days' rest in the American League Championship Series, he was still throwing 95 miles an hour in the eighth inning. Sabathia earned the victory in Game 4 that night, and he has a chance to repeat the feat on Sunday at Citizens Bank Park.

headline: Corrections
text: The “Living In” article and a map last Sunday about Castleton Corners, Staten Island, misstated part of the local name for Interstate 278. It is the Staten Island Expressway, not Parkway.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary last Sunday about the sculptor Ruth Duckworth omitted part of the name of one of the colleges for which she completed monumental bronze sculptures in the last decade. It is Lewis & Clark Community College in Godfrey, Ill.  not Lewis and Clark College. (There is a Lewis & Clark College in Portland, Ore.)

text: A view of the day in college football, full of touchdown catches (and interceptions).

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the use of historical news events to drive plot developments in the television drama “Mad Men” misspelled the surname of the president of the Ossining Historical Society, who is an unofficial props and location consultant for the show (the main character lives in Ossining, N.Y.). He is Norman MacDonald, not McDonald.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about the Medill Innocence Project, in which students at Northwestern University’s journalism school scrutinize the work of prosecutors and the police, misstated part of the name of a group at the university’s law school that has worked with the students. It is the Center on Wrongful Convictions, not the Center for Wrongful Convictions.

headline: Corrections
text: The Chess column last Sunday, about unpopular openings, misidentified the first move in the Sokolsky opening, one of those considered bad. It is 1 b4, not 1 g4.

headline: Former Cornhusker Sells Outland Trophy at Auction
text: Aaron Taylor’s career at Nebraska was successful by any measure. He helped the Cornhuskers win three national titles, was an all-American as a center and a guard and won the Outland Trophy as the nation’s best interior lineman in 1997.

headline: Not Your Ordinary Wedding Band
text: Wedding bands have been a source of embarrassment for those forced to play in them. The Dexter Lake Club Band has neatly subverted this construction by the simple expediency of creating a band that actually rocks.

headline: Getting Dirty Greasing the Wheels for Friends
text: In the Atlantic Diner in Queens on an afternoon two years ago, you could hear the sounds of a man peeling open the tin can around his soul. Tony Seminerio was a member of the State Assembly from Queens. He’ll do you a favor, get you a contract, what do you need, let me make a call for you, I know that junior commissioner who can send bursts of government cash into the sky  why, he’s a dear friend. Just hire me, Tony Seminerio. Send the money to my consulting company. If you don’t, I hate you, you’re no good.

headline: In War-Torn Liberia, Women Making Do
text: IF you walked into a room full of sex slaves, you might not expect to find role models. Unless you’ve already seen Danai Gurira’s new drama, “Eclipsed.”

headline: A Heroic Doctor, a Global Scourge
text: My Sunday column is about obstetric fistula, a horrendous childbirth injury that rarely gets attention or treatment because the victims are the most voiceless of the voiceless. Dr. Lewis Wall, the hero of the column, taught me about fistulas years ago, and so I've been writing about them periodically since my first column on the topic back in 2002.

headline: Albert York, Reclusive Landscape Painter, Dies at 80
text: Albert York, a painter of small, mysterious landscapes who shunned the art world yet had a fervent following within it, died Tuesday in Southampton, N.Y. He was 80 and lived in Water Mill, N.Y.

headline: Search Continues for 9 Missing After Military Crash Off San Diego
text: LOS ANGELES  Rescue teams continued searching on Saturday for seven Coast Guard members and two Marines whose aircraft collided off the coast of San Diego on Thursday night.

headline: Lionel Davidson, British Writer of Well-Traveled Thrillers, Dies at 87
text: Lionel Davidson, a noted British thriller writer whose novels brought to life far-flung settings like Prague, Tibet, Israel and Siberia, died on Oct. 21 at his home in London. He was 87.

headline: Peter Shellem, Investigative Reporter Who Wrote About Wrongful Convictions, Dies at 49
text: Peter Shellem, whose relentless digging into dusty court records, erroneous crime-lab reports and coerced confessions during his 23 years as a reporter for The Patriot-News in Harrisburg, Pa., led to the release of five wrongly convicted prisoners, died Oct. 24 at his home in Gardners, Pa. He was 49.

headline: An End to Columbia's Winning Streak
text: Columbia High School, which had been on a roll with eight straight wins dating back to last year, lost to West Essex, 12-15, on Halloween night.

headline: N.H.L. Scores: Isles Crush Sabres. Does a Sleeping Giant Stir?
text: Eleven games on Halloween, but perhaps nothing scarier that what’s happening on Long Island. Three games ago the Islanders were doormats with one regulation win to their credit. But then they beat the Rangers, got two points off the Capitals — and on Saturday night they obliterated Buffalo as if the Sabres were one of those scale-model Tokyos in an old monster movie. Something humungous may be awakening in the trackless depths off the East Coast, a Godzilla in blue and orange. Home teams listed first:

headline: Chapel Housing 9/11 Remains Is Set Afire
text: The inside of a temporary structure where the remains of those who did not survive the burning World Trade Center towers on Sept. 11, 2001, was itself set aflame on Saturday morning. A 26-year-old man was arrested.

headline: Officials Detail 5-Hour Gap Between Detective’s D.W.I. Crash and Blood Test
text: One day after the arrest of an off-duty police detective on charges he killed a pedestrian while driving drunk, the authorities provided more details about the five-hour gap between the accident and the time the police were able to obtain a sample of the detective’s blood, saying the detective’s case was processed more quickly than is normal in such cases.

headline: Knicks Fall to the 76ers in Overtime
text: The Knicks’ season showed fraying edges and frustration at the core even before their home opener. That arrived Saturday and ended with revitalized hope but also another loss in its own embarrassing fashion.

headline: Spam, When the In-Box Is My Ear
text: THE founding fathers cherished freedom of speech, but they could not have anticipated that political discourse would degenerate into rampant technoharassment  recorded telephone messages, known as robocalls, from candidates or their famous supporters.

headline: Catering to the Student in Amsterdam
text: Amsterdam is a city famously rich with cafes, bars and coffeehouses each with its own specialty — be it cannabis or just an old-time atmosphere. The Dutch love to categorize, so there are options for everybody. And with the new school year well under way, now is the time to take a look at a handful of spots that cater to the city’s extensive student population.

headline: The Times 'Women at Arms' Series
text: The Times's series "Women at Arms," investigates the unprecedented role that women are playing in the U.S. military during wartime and higlights the struggles they often face in combat and as veterans trying to readjust to civilian life. Today's story, " A Combat Role, and Anguish, Too," looks at women soldiers' experience with post-traumatic stress.

headline: Keflezighi’s ‘U.S.A.’ Breaks the Tape
text: The choice of jersey had not been entirely Meb Keflezighi’s, but in one triumphant surge in Central Park on Sunday, he became the perfect person to be wearing a U.S.A. shirt at the New York City Marathon. He was one of several Americans striving to break the 27-year men’s drought in the race, but he represented the American dream more than any of them.

headline: Growth and jobs: the lesson of the Clinton years
text: Just a quick further note on my growth and jobs post. To get a sense of what 3.5% growth does and doesn't mean, we can look at the Clinton years, viewed as a whole. (I'm using end-1992 to end-2000, but it doesn't really matter if you vary the start and end dates a bit).

headline: Westbrook and Manningham Are Out
text: Brian Westbrook of the Eagles, the veteran running back who often plays well against the Giants, did not dress for Sunday’s game at Lincoln Financial Field because of a concussion sustained in the previous game. His replacement in the starting lineup was LeSean McCoy. For the Giants, Mario Manningham was not in uniform because of a shoulder injury. Replacing him in the starting lineup was Domenik Hixon.

headline: What Is Johnson’s Future in Kansas City?
text: The Kansas City Chiefs are off this week, but will return to the field next Sunday against Jacksonville without running back Larry Johnson. In an agreement reached with the team and announced Saturday night, Johnson, who was suspended for two weeks by the Chiefs, will lose just one week of pay, around $300,000. What happens to Johnson once the suspension ends, though, remains an open question.

headline: Everyone’s a Drummer for This Hybrid Group
text: Even before the concert by the Hong Kong Chinese Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, a steady rush of rattling, whirring sounds, audible in the lobby, emanated from the auditorium. On entering the hall, every member of the audience was given a small Chinese hand drum with beads attached to two strings on the sides. By twirling the drum in your hand, you could produce a loud stream of rat-a-tats.

headline: Major University in Russia Eases Fears on Rules
text: MOSCOW  The authorities at St. Petersburg State University issued a statement last week announcing that researchers in the humanities and social sciences would not be required to submit to an export-control screening before publishing their work overseas, easing fears that new procedures would constrain academic freedom.

headline: Across a Field of Red, Six Couples Move to the Beat of a Romantic Heart
text: To begin his company’s second program at City Center on Friday night Christopher Wheeldon went back to basics with “Continuum.” Part of his trilogy of dances set to mysterious, prickly music of Gyorgy Ligeti, the work was created for the San Francisco Ballet in 2002  the same year Mr. Wheeldon choreographed “Morphoses” and one year after the premiere of his breakthrough “Polyphonia.” In “Continuum” he shows how experimentation begins and ends with the body, and as with all of his most enchanting ballets, there is a sense, wistful and profound, that one is leaving an old world and entering a new one.

headline: Memories of 9/11 Endure for Warship’s Crew
text: ABOARD U.S.S. NEW YORK, off New York — They were schoolchildren mostly, but also construction workers, police officers and military members, when two planes slammed into the World Trade Center eight years ago.

headline: No Regrets From Manuel, Just Decisions
text: PHILADELPHIA  Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel nodded along as a reporter asked about a recent strategic decision. He was paying close attention, or at least seemed to be, when he heard, “After sleeping on it, did you come up with the same answer today?”

headline: ‘This Is It’ Is Tops at the U.S. Box Office, but Not Thrillingly So
text: LOS ANGELES — Sony’s much-hyped Michael Jackson documentary, “This Is It,” failed to thrill a mega audience in North America, selling a solid if unspectacular $21.3 million in tickets over the weekend, for a five-day total of about $32.5 million.

text: A 41-14 victory at Oklahoma State, combined with an off week for Alabama, was enough to lift Texas over the Crimson Tide and back to the No. 2 spot in the Associated Press Top 25.

text: The world’s great orchestras buzz through and around New York every season. Their leading players have solo ambitions. Concert halls need product.

headline: Gilbert Finds Surprises in Familiar Orchestra Fare
text: By all rights the concert the New York Philharmonic presented at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night could have been a drowsy walk-through. After all it was not supposed to happen. The Philharmonic intended to spend the end of October in Havana, where it had been invited to perform. When that trip was canceled, after the State Department refused permission for moneyed patrons to tag along, the orchestra filled the gap in its schedule with concerts at home.

headline: Bite-Size Legal Trouble and Suspense
text: John Grisham had some story ideas that he didn’t think could sustain full-length narrative. So he did what he customarily does: whatever he wants to. Was anyone at Doubleday going to argue with that?

headline: On the Block: Traditional Offerings, Bargain Prices

All are well-known paintings and drawings by tried-and-true artists carrying estimates as low as sellers are willing to go.

headline: Wheelchairs, a Debutant and One ‘Old Lady’ Round Out the Field
text: Kurt Fearnley, a 28-year-old Australian, won the men’s wheelchair race in Sunday’s New York City Marathon in 1 hour 35 minutes 58 seconds. Krige Schabort, 46, of Cedartown, Ga., finished second in the same time. The actual difference was 15-hundredths of a second in a race of 26 miles 385 yards.

headline: Sunday’s News of Hockey, 11/1/09: O.H.L Player’s Skull Fractured by Check Into Boards
text: The Kitchener Rangers rookie Ben Fanelli remains in the intensive care unit at Hamilton General Hospital in critical but stable condition with a skull fracture after falling heavily into the boards during an O.H.L. game on Friday night. Fanelli, 16, went face-first into the boards after being checked from behind by Erie’s Michael Liambas. He was airlifted to Hamilton General after medical personnel tended to him on the ice for half an hour. Liambas was given a boarding major and a game misconduct on the play. O.H.L. Commissioner David Branch, who has led a movement to cut down on head injuries in hockey by outlawing all checks to the head, said he had not yet decided whether the hit on Fanelli warranted a suspension.

text: What you learn from “You Cannot Start Without Me  Valery Gergiev, Maestro”: that Mr. Gergiev is one busy guy.

headline: Did the Stimulus Work?
text: Many economists attribute the rise in the gross domestic product in the third quarter to the $787 billion federal stimulus package approved in February. But skeptics say the growth may be short-lived because government efforts to encourage consumer spending like the “cash for clunkers” program are expiring. At the same time, unemployment is still rising, though the Obama administration says 650,000 jobs have been created or saved by the stimulus funds.

headline: Reverberations of a Trial and Its Shocking Aftermath
text: “This case has it all,” someone will often say about a particularly gruesome or scandalous court proceeding  the O. J. Simpson trial, for instance, or anything involving John Gotti Jr. But you won’t find a case with more “all” than the one nearly a century ago surrounding an Atlanta pencil factory superintendent named Leo Frank. It is mesmerizingly recreated and explored Monday on PBS in “The People v. Leo Frank,” a film by Ben Loeterman that even those already familiar with this ugly piece of history are likely to find unsettling.

headline: From a Humble Artisan, the Race’s Crowning Glory
text: Jane Muhrcke has been a part of the New York City Marathon longer than have Brooklyn, the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island. Long before the race grew out of Central Park and expanded to include all five boroughs, Muhrcke was entrenched in its inner circle.

headline: Democrats Strive to Hold Governor Posts
text: NEWARK  President Obama swept into New Jersey on Sunday, pleading with his supporters to summon up the enthusiasm they poured into his election last November and deliver a victory for Gov. Jon S. Corzine.

headline: Grand Visions for a Faded Bronx Boulevard
text: Decaying freeways, high-speed trains, levees, bicycle lanes  ever since Hurricane Katrina, infrastructure has been the hot topic among architects and architectural curators across the country. The chatter only grew louder after the Obama administration unveiled its economic stimulus package, igniting hopes of a major national transformation. “Intersections: The Grand Concourse Beyond 100,” which opened at the Bronx Museum of the Arts on Sunday, is the latest show to pick up on this trend.

headline: Up for Auction
text: In a chastened auction season, buyers will find traditional works intended to appeal to today’s more conservative tastes, with prices topping out at $12 million.

headline: Out of Race, Karzai Rival Is Harsh Critic of Election
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan’s last presidential challenger, Abdullah Abdullah, dropped out of the race on Sunday, accusing the government of profound corruption and electoral fraud even as the Obama administration rallied around President Hamid Karzai.

text: PITTSBURGH  When he took office in 2006 after the sudden death of his predecessor, Mayor Luke Ravenstahl became something of a media sensation.

headline: Europe Still Likes Obama, but Doubts Creep In

text: SHANGHAI  The highly anticipated opening of China’s new Nasdaq-style stock exchange last Friday is already being seen as a watershed moment for the country’s capital markets, providing new opportunities for Chinese investors and an alternative source of financing for upstart companies.

headline: A Tweet Unleashes Vitriol on a User in Britain
text: LONDON  In the realm of Twitter insults, it was at the far end of mild. “Much as I admire and adore the chap, they are a bit ... boring,” a Twitter user called brumplum wrote Saturday, speaking of the tweets of Stephen Fry, the British writer, actor and television personality.

headline: An Application to Help Scrub Those Regrettable Photos From Facebook
text: You there, you who dressed as a sexy panther this Halloween, and are now clicking through the weekend’s photos on Facebook. What’s a hungover cat to do?

text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli police said Sunday that they had arrested a 37-year-old American immigrant, a West Bank settler, and charged him in an array of killings and terrorist attacks over the last 12 years, including the murders of two Palestinians, the bombing of a leftist Israeli professor’s home and the maiming of a 15-year-old boy who belongs to a community of Jews who believe in Jesus.

headline: Columnist Quits After Newsday Starts Charging for Its Web Site
text: There aren’t many journalists walking away from paying jobs these days. With news organizations struggling and newsroom jobs disappearing, each week brings new calls from writers and editors who believe their flagging employers should save themselves by charging for Internet access.

headline: Opposition in Iran Urges Continuing Challenge
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As Iran prepares for a major commemorative rally on Wednesday, the leaders of the opposition movement called over the weekend for a renewed challenge to the government, setting the stage for a possible showdown between protesters and the police.

headline: Seymour Fromer, Archivist of Jewish Contribution to West, Dies at 87
text: Seymour Fromer, who with his wife, Rebecca, opened a museum in California that eventually came to hold one of the largest collections of Judaica in North America, including archives documenting the history of Jews in the American West, died Oct. 25 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 87.

Still hazy from the previous night’s party, which involved a mariachi band, fireworks and a shaman-led wedding ceremony held above ancient Mayan limestone ruins, the partyers made a hasty exit.

headline: Many in U.S. Want Texting at the Wheel to Be Illegal
text: Nearly all Americans say sending a text message while driving should be illegal, and about half say texting while behind the wheel should be punished at least as harshly as drunken driving, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Philadelphians Reap Rewards from New York’s Trash
text: MORRISVILLE, Pa.  There has been plenty of trash-talking this past week by fans of the Yankees and Phillies. But for years, New Yorkers have been quietly doing more than talking trash about Philadelphians: They’ve been sending it, about 2,500 tons daily, to mega-landfills in Philadelphia’s northern suburbs.

headline: An Unusual Loss for U.S.C.

headline: Mother of Canadian Singer Killed by Coyotes Asks That the Animals Be Spared
text: Even in a country with a lot of wilderness, it was a shocking death. Taylor Josephine Stephanie Luciow, a promising 19-year-old folk singer from Toronto who performed under the name Taylor Mitchell, was attacked by two coyotes as she set out for a hike in Cape Breton Highlands National Park, one of Eastern Canada’s leading tourist destinations. She died late Tuesday night in Halifax, where she had been airlifted for treatment.

headline: Creditors Back CIT’s Bankruptcy
text: As the CIT Group sought desperately to avoid bankruptcy this summer, it argued that being forced into Chapter 11 protection would spell disaster for its customers: a wide swath of the nation’s small and midsize businesses who rely on the 101-year-old company for financing.

headline: Oregon and Coach Are Over Opener
text: As the sun rose in Eugene on Saturday, a man wearing the head of the University of Oregon’s duck mascot traversed the lines of fans gathered for ESPN’s “College GameDay” broadcast.

headline: With Karzai, U.S. Faces Weak Partner in Time of War
text: WASHINGTON  With the White House’s reluctant embrace on Sunday of Hamid Karzai as the winner of Afghanistan’s suddenly moot presidential runoff, President Obama now faces a new complication: enabling a badly tarnished partner to regain enough legitimacy to help the United States find the way out of an eight-year-old war.

text: Denbury Resources, an oil and natural gas producer based in Plano, Tex., said it would buy Encore Acquisition for about $4.5 billion, including the assumption of debt.

headline: In Playoffs, Tell-All Scouting Book Helps Guide Yankees
text: PHILADELPHIA  Joe Girardi has a bulky blue binder that he carries into the dugout for every game that he manages with the Yankees. It is filled with more than 200 pages of scouting reports, statistics and his observations.

headline: Not New, but Improved
text: Meet Stella.

headline: When Texting Kills, Britain Offers Path to Prison
text: OXFORD, England  Inside the imposing British Crown Court here, Phillipa Curtis, 22, and her parents cried as she was remanded for 21 months to a high-security women’s prison, for killing someone much like herself. The victim was Victoria McBryde, an up-and-coming university-trained fashion designer.

headline: Pollsters Report Latest Figures as Election Day Approaches
text: It may be an off year for elections, but there are still a lot of races on Tuesday. The big contests are the governors’ elections in New Jersey and Virginia, but there will be voting for mayors in several big cities, some states have referendums or ballot initiatives and there are a couple of vacant Congressional seats to be filled.

headline: With Some Coaching, Bloomberg Learns to Bite His Tongue
text: For years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called City Councilwoman Letitia James “Trish,” even though she is known as Tish and corrected him again and again. When the mayor spoke to her, his body language spoke volumes, she said: He would look up, down, around, anywhere but at her face.

headline: Inspiration for a New Crop of U.S. Runners
text: When Alberto Salazar crossed the finish line to win his third straight New York City Marathon 27 years ago, he did not think about who was coming behind him.

headline: On Assignment: New York City Marathon
text: Most years Fred R. Conrad is assigned to photograph the New York City Marathon and he has covered it from various vantage points along the 26.2-mile race that winds through all five boroughs. In the past, he focused the lens of his 4x5 camera on the Achilles Track Club Freedom Team, taking black and white portraits of this group of disabled war veterans. Last year, the marathon fell just two days before the election, and he shot runners emblazoned with political flair and slogans.

headline: Between Football and Baseball Stadiums in Philadelphia, a Mingling Most Rare
text: PHILADELPHIA  For a few hours Sunday, the center of the noisy sporting rivalry between New York and Philadelphia was a pair of neighboring stadiums and the parking lots that adjoin them.

headline: Off-Year Races May Provide Insight
text: WASHINGTON  One year after the election of President Obama, a handful of off-year political contests  including governors’ races in New Jersey and Virginia and a Congressional race in upstate New York  offer some clues about how Americans are viewing Mr. Obama, as well as an early measure of the landscape for next year’s midterm elections.

headline: For Mayoral Candidates, One Final Push to Rally Voters
text: As their aides fretted over the prospect of low turnout at the polls, the candidates for New York City mayor delivered last-minute appeals to voters on Sunday, with Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. urging New Yorkers to reject an incumbent “who thinks he’s above democracy,” and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg asking for a third term to “keep making progress.”

headline: Educational Video Games Mix Cool With Purpose
text: One of KC Phillips’s favorite video games is the Xbox shoot-’em-up Halo, because, he says, his dad taught him how to play it when he was younger.

headline: Turner Entertainment Sees the Broadcast Networks as Its Fattest Target
text: If there is a fault line between the big but shrinking broadcast networks and the small but growing cable networks, it would run right through Steve Koonin’s office in Atlanta.

headline: Children Watch More TV Than Ever
text: If there is a practical limit to the amount of television a child can watch, we have not yet discovered it. Nielsen reported last week that children ages 2 to 5 spent nearly 25 hours a week watching television, the highest figure on record. They spent an additional seven weekly hours watching DVDs, playing video games, and watching TiVo-style time-shifted television.

headline: With Payroll Tax, Feeling the Effects of an M.T.A. Bailout Plan
text: For subway and bus riders in New York, a $1.9 billion bailout in May from Albany meant that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority did not have to drastically cut service and raise fares.

headline: Neil Simon Flop May Be a Case of the Missing ‘Wow’
text: Neil Simon was the crossover comedy king of Broadway and Hollywood for three decades, beginning when “Barefoot in the Park” and three other major shows overlapped in New York in the 1960s.

headline: Once a Young Turk, Now Challenged by One
text: Albert Vann built his legend in Brooklyn from the ground up, first as an outspoken community leader during a fight with the teachers’ union in Ocean Hill and Brownsville in the late 1960s. By the early 1980s, he had transformed from a rebel assemblyman into a political power broker and a leader among black politicians who labored outside traditional Democratic politics.

headline: Sisterly Bonds, Tight Enough to Strangle
text: “By their nature people are talkers,” says Breda, one of three sisters presiding over a mad, mostly tea-less tea party in “The New Electric Ballroom,” a comedy written and directed by the singular Irish playwright Enda Walsh that opened on Sunday night at St. Ann’s Warehouse. “You can’t deny that,” she continues in an agonized, breathless mumble. “You can, but you’d be affirming what you’re arguing against, and what would the point of that be? No point.”

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Thursday, about the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, misstated the rank of the top American commander in Afghanistan, Stanley McChrystal. He is a general, not a lieutenant general.

headline: How the Kenyans Take On New York
text: Everything was upside down. The favored Kenyan and the preferred American were both out of contention. And now an afterthought, a last-second replacement, was at the front of the New York City Marathon.

headline: Denbury, an Oil and Gas Producer, to Buy Encore
text: Denbury Resources, an oil and natural gas producer based in Plano, Tex., said it would buy Encore Acquisition for about $4.5 billion, including the assumption of debt.

headline: Bruno’s Trial Is Seen as a Hearing on Albany
text: The 35-page, eight-count indictment filed by federal prosecutors names a lone defendant: Joseph L. Bruno, the former president of the State Senate and former Republican majority leader.

headline: On the Ballot: Parkland and Inmate Volunteerism
text: New York voters will be asked to consider two amendments to the State Constitution on Tuesday: One would approve a power line being built in the Adirondack Park; the other would allow prisoners of state correctional facilities to perform volunteer work for nonprofit groups.

headline: For Galleon Executive, Swagger in the Spotlight

headline: Soft Real Estate Market Is a Key Ingredient at Brooklyn Brewery
text: Less than two years ago, the Brooklyn Brewery found itself in a bind that had squeezed many companies out of New York. It wanted to expand, but the rapid gentrification of its neighborhood, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, had pushed rents beyond what it could afford.

text: General Electric and the cable giant Comcast have moved closer to a deal giving control of NBC Universal to Comcast, and a formal announcement could be made sometime next week, people briefed on the talks said Sunday.

headline: At Marathon Fluids Station, Days of Planning Precede Minutes of Chaos

It is “Showtime in the Afternoon”  not “Talking Black and Talking Back,” which is a slogan for the radio station.

headline: Too Little of a Good Thing
text: The good news is that the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, a k a the Obama stimulus plan, is working just about the way textbook macroeconomics said it would. But that’s also the bad news  because the same textbook analysis says that the stimulus was far too small given the scale of our economic problems. Unless something changes drastically, we’re looking at many years of high unemployment.

headline: Three’s Company
text: Most American elections aren’t particularly competitive. So an off-year election cycle with only a few important offices at stake doesn’t have any business being interesting.

headline: Recorded Calls to Voters From Brooklyn Bishop Praise a Democratic Leader
text: In an unusually overt step into politics by a religious leader, the Roman Catholic bishop of Brooklyn is urging voters, via robocalls, to support Vito J. Lopez, an assemblyman and the Brooklyn Democratic boss, whose hand-picked candidate is in a tough race for a City Council seat.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Six Tests for Equality and Fairness
text: Political battles this fall in six different parts of the country could have a profound impact on whether the United States will extend the promise of equal rights to those who are not allowed to marry simply because they are the same sex as their partner.

headline: The Court and Your Savings
text: The Supreme Court hears arguments Monday in a case about mutual funds and high management fees. Mutual funds are the main vehicle Americans use to save for retirement, and excessive mutual fund fees are another way an underregulated financial industry has been enriching itself at the expense of the general public.

headline: Cape Wind
text: After eight years of arduous state and federal environmental reviews, the promoters of Cape Wind, a wind energy project off the Massachusetts coast, had every reason to believe that they were home free. Then the Wampanoag tribes asked the Interior Department to declare all of Nantucket Sound, where the 130 wind turbines would be built, a “traditional cultural property” and, they hoped, block construction.

headline: Memphis
text: If I had to name the best short story in the form of a song lyric, I suspect the winner would be Chuck Berry’s “Memphis, Tennessee,” first released as a B-side in 1959. Lately, it has been haunting me  the metrical precision of the lyrics, its emotional realism and, of course, the revelation in the penultimate line. You know the one: that this is a father’s mournful love song to his daughter, Marie, who is only 6 years old.

headline: Fiscal Blood on the Tracks
text: LIKE a tsunami that follows an undersea earthquake, collateral damage from the collapse of credit markets is about to strike the millions of daily transit riders in America’s biggest cities. Public transit agencies in cities including New York, Atlanta, San Francisco and Washington are under pressure to surrender $2 billion from their budgets because financial institutions have spotted a chance to gain a windfall from complicated tax-shelter deals known as “leasebacks.”

headline: Yankees Seem Determined Not to Use Fourth Starting Pitcher
text: PHILADELPHIA  The Yankees seem very likely to finish the World Series having used only three starting pitchers, especially after Manager Joe Girardi announced Sunday that A. J. Burnett would start Game 5 on short rest.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing of credits on Tuesday with a television review of the documentary “Muhammad and Larry” on ESPN, using information from a publicist, omitted a producer. Bradley Kaplan, who was listed as a director of the documentary and as an executive producer of it for Maysles Films, is also a producer for Maysles Films.

headline: North Korea Presses U.S. to Agree to Bilateral Talks
text: SEOUL  North Korea has again pressed the United States for a decision about starting bilateral talks, with a diplomat warning Monday that the North was “ready to go our own way” with its nuclear weapons program.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about nonprofit “green” organizations spinning off for-profit enterprises referred incorrectly to the status of one organization. As the article noted elsewhere, SmartRoofs is a for-profit enterprise developed by a nonprofit group; it is not a nonprofit itself.

text: The presidents of the nation’s major private research universities were paid a median compensation of $627,750 in the 2007-8 fiscal year  a 5.5 percent increase from the previous year  according to The Chronicle of Higher Education annual executive compensation survey.

headline: Yankees Pull Away in the Ninth and in Series
text: PHILADELPHIA  The Yankees were so different nine years ago, when they won their last World Series, so different and yet somehow the same. They revolve now around a constellation of imported superstars with extravagant contracts, primarily Alex Rodriguez. But their grinding ethos is unchanged.

headline: Cisco’s Run of Spending
text: Cisco, the computer networking giant, has spent the last decade acquiring rivals and buying back stock. It’s time to acknowledge that this strategy isn’t working. Investors who bought Cisco’s shares a decade ago have received no return on their investment.

text: Don Ivan Punchatz, whose surreal art was splashed on popular horror and science-fiction paperbacks, magazines and the first “Star Wars” film poster, influencing a generation of illustrators, died on Oct. 22 near his home in Arlington, Tex. He was 73.

headline: The Mighty Mariano
text: Mariano Rivera said the Yankees do not have a "one-man show" in their bullpen. While that is true, the Yankees do have a one-man show in postseason save situations. In those spots, Rivera's show is as overpowering as any in baseball.

headline: Week 8: Eagles Overwhelm Giants
text: The Giants fell behind early at Philadelphia and never recovered, losing by 40-17. It was their third defeat in a row after a 5-0 start.

text: The Dolphins' Ted Ginn Jr. had two long kickoff returns for touchdowns in a 30-25 victory, spoiling a strong defensive effort by the Jets.

headline: Dance Award Winners
text: The winners of the 52nd Dance Magazine Awards have been announced. Allegra Kent, former New York City Ballet principal; Ohad Naharin, artistic director of Batsheva Dance; Sara Rudner, director of dance at Sarah Lawrence College; and Jason Samuels Smith, a tap dancer and choreographer, will be honored at a ceremony on Nov. 9 at Florence Gould Hall in Manhattan, an event that is open to the public and will include performances by dancers from New York City Ballet and Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet and the tapper Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards, among others.

headline: ‘Mad Max’ and ‘thor’ Round Out Principals
text: Charlize Theron, below, will join the British actor Tom Hardy in the fourth installment of the “Mad Max” post-apocalyptic franchise, according to Variety. Filming is scheduled to begin in August in Australia, but whether Mel Gibson, who played the title character in the first three films, will return or if Mr. Hardy will take over as Max is unclear. And the film’s producer-director, George Miller, who is also serving as screenwriter, is keeping details of the script close to the leather vest. ... Anthony Hopkins has been cast in Kenneth Branagh’s “Thor,” the film adaptation of the Marvel comic book, Variety reported. Marvel Studios expects to begin production in January, with Mr. Hopkins playing Odin, Thor’s father; Natalie Portman as Thor’s beloved, Jane Foster; and Chris Hemsworth in the title role.

headline: Grants Made to Benefit Young Dancers
text: American Ballet Theater has received a $500,000 matching grant from the Arison Arts Foundation, the ballet company has announced. The grant will help cover a fellowship for one dancer each year as part of a new partnership between ABT II and YoungArts, a national organization that supports 17- and 18-year-olds in the visual, literary and performing arts. Since 1996 eight American Ballet Theater dancers have been supported through the YoungArts program, Rachel Moore, the company’s executive director and herself a YoungArts scholarship winner, said in a statement. “Continued support is crucial to the future of young artists.” The grant will also be used to support American Ballet Theater’s other preprofessional programs, including the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School and apprentices in the corps de ballet.

headline: Footnotes
text: President Obama signed into law on Friday a bill increasing the budgets of the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities by $12.5 million each. The increase, passed in the House and Senate on Thursday, set the budgets for each agency at $167.5 million. ... The 59E59 Theaters will feature the playwright Alan Ayckbourn in a discussion Nov. 15 about his career and the intricacies of his writing. Details and tickets are at 59e59.org.

headline: In the Wings
text: Irish Repertory Theater has announced a one-week extension of “The Emperor Jones,” the Eugene O’Neill drama starring John Douglas Thompson, below, in the title role and directed by Ciaran O’Reilly. Performances at the West 22nd Street theater in Chelsea are now through Dec. 6. ... Lee Blessing, A. R. Gurney, Tina Howe  and Marsha Norman will participate in the Cherry Lane Theater’s master-class series on artists, their processes and their inspirations. The classes begin on Monday with the actress Tyne Daly. Information: cherrylanetheatre.org. ... Lincoln Center’s LCT3 initiative, devoted to producing the work of new artists and developing new audiences, has filled out its 2009-10 season with the New York premiere of “Graceland,” by Ellen Fairey and directed by Henry Wishcamper (May 3 to 29) and the premiere of “On the Levee,” a musical play conceived and directed by Lear deBessonet, with a book by Marcus Gardley and music and lyrics by Todd Almond (June 14 to July 10). The works will be presented at the Duke on 42nd Street.

headline: An Ill Elton John Delays Concerts
text: Elton John, 62, has postponed more concert dates because of E. coli and influenza, Agence France-Presse reported. After canceling the final dates of his Red Piano world tour in Britain and Ireland, Mr. John delayed concerts with Billy Joel scheduled this week in Seattle and Portland, Ore., as well. The two performers had already postponed concert dates on the American leg of their tour when Mr. Joel, 60, was ordered to rest after reporting flulike symptoms and fatigue. Mr. John is reportedly recovering in a London hospital, with no word on when he might return to work.

headline: 19th-Century Letters, 21st-Century Price
text: Sotheby’s of London has sold a collection of racy letters written by Lord Byron, below, for $455,466, more than $150,000 above the estimate and a record price for letters by a British Romantic poet. According to BBC News, an anonymous bidder bought the 71 pages of letters and fragments, dating from 1808, which include details of an affair with a servant girl and a disparaging reference to William Wordsworth. The documents came from the library of Archibald Primrose, prime minister from 1894 to 1895. Gabriel Heaton, a Sotheby’s specialist in British literature and history, told the BBC that the letters, to Byron’s close friend the Rev. Francis Hodgson, “offered a wonderful opportunity to reveal aspects of Lord Byron’s character that were either unknown or long forgotten.”

headline: Lupus Drug Shows Promise in New Trial
text: The debilitating disease called lupus has been a graveyard for pharmaceutical companies in recent years. One drug after another has had setbacks or outright failures in clinical trials.

headline: At Mile 19, a Runner From Texas Is Resuscitated by Firefighters
text: A 51-year-old runner from Texas who collapsed and stopped breathing near Mile 19 of the New York City Marathon on Sunday was resuscitated on the street by a group of firefighters, the authorities said.

headline: Quirky Play Leads to Lidge’s Unraveling
text: PHILADELPHIA — Brad Lidge has been around long enough to enjoy a perfect season and also blow some big save opportunities. But he had never been involved in a play quite like the one that preceded his unraveling in the ninth inning.

headline: Quirky Play Leads to Lidge's Unraveling
text: PHILADELPHIA - Brad Lidge has been around long enough to enjoy a perfect season and also blow some big save opportunities. But he had never been involved in a play quite like the one that preceded his unraveling in the ninth inning. So unfamiliar with it, Lidge did not even know what his responsibilities were supposed to be. With the score tied and two outs in the ninth, the Phillies were in a shift to the right side of the infield with Mark Teixeira at the plate batting left-handed, and Johnny Damon on first base after a classic nine-pitch at-bat single. Damon stole second base and third baseman Pedro Feliz had to take the throw from the catcher, leaving third base barren of defenders. (Watch the video of the play here.) So, what should Lidge have done? Cover third base? Back up the plate when the catcher covers third? Stand and watch? Run over too late? "To be honest, that's not something you really go over a lot," Lidge said. "I don't know who's supposed to cover third on that. It's kind of a weird play. No one ends up being there and it kind of ends up being a foot race, and he's faster than I am and he got there before I did." Damon saw the empty bag beckoning and sprinted to it. Lidge reacted off the mound too late, and now he had a runner on third base with two outs. What followed were three Yankees runs and a 7-4 victory that put them on the verge of their 27th World Series championship. "He's a heads-up player, and he was able to take an extra base there, which was obviously pretty big," Lidge said. Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel said catcher Carlos Ruiz should have covered, and shortstop Jimmy Rollins said he was at fault for not reminding Lidge to be wary of the play. Clearly the Phillies were in a defensive formation in which not everyone knew all the contingencies. But Lidge did know one thing. He had gotten two quick outs and looked strong. He still had a chance to get out of the inning after it all happened, and he did not claim to be flustered or distracted by it afterward. Still, the results were disastrous. Lidge hit Teixeira with a fastball that rode inside, and with runners at first and third, Alex Rodriguez drilled a fastball into the left-field corner, scoring Damon to give the Yankees a 5-4 lead. Lidge was asked if he was hesitant to throw sliders to Rodriguez with Damon at third, concerned perhaps that one of them might get away and allow Damon to score on a wild pitch. He said he was not. In fact, breaking balls were impending. "We would have gone to sliders real soon," he said. "I probably should have done it sooner."

headline: An Artist Who Makes the Viewer Work
text: LONDON | In July 1961, on London’s South Bank, Gustav Metzger put on a gas mask, rubber gloves and a hard hat and proceeded to spray hydrochloric acid in elaborate patterns all over three large screens of white, black and red nylon. Filmed up close, the quick melting and tearing away of fabric is beautiful, disturbing and captivating. Seen from 10 feet away, it looks like a hazmat worker messing around with tattered, ripped sheets.

headline: Can Citigroup Carry Its Own Weight?
text: Over the past 80 years, the United States government has engineered not one, not two, not three, but at least four rescues of the institution now known as Citigroup. In previous instances, the bank came back from the crisis and prospered.

headline: An Artist Who Makes the Viewer Work
text: LONDON | In July 1961, on London's South Bank, Gustav Metzger put on a gas mask, rubber gloves and a hard hat and proceeded to spray hydrochloric acid in elaborate patterns all over three large screens of white, black and red nylon. Filmed up close, the quick melting and tearing away of fabric is beautiful, disturbing and captivating. Seen from 10 feet away, it looks like a hazmat worker messing around with tattered, ripped sheets.

headline: Not So Random After All
text: The random coin toss must be one of society's most frequently used decision-making mechanisms. We use the coin toss to choose which movie to see, to determine team positions in major sporting events, to divvy up household chores, and even name cities. But it may be that the the random coin toss isn't so random. A 2007 study found that a vigorously flipped coin is likely to land on the same side it started on at least 51 percent of the time, possibly more depending on the person doing the flipping. (HT: Chris Blattman)

headline: Bay Bridge Is Open
text: At 9:20 a.m., twenty minutes after the bridge opened this morning, I drove across the span from the East Bay. Some drivers flew by, as if their pent-up demand for bridge access was what was fueling their cars, not gasoline. Others, like me, drove tentatively, politely, not wanting to jinx the long-awaited opening. That's all one needs today-to be the car in the first accident today on the bridge.

headline: The Shield and the Power: Will Bloggers Benefit?
text: Journalists have been watching with amazement as a federal shield law protecting reporters from revealing their sources, a long sought-after safeguard for investigative journalism, gained traction in Congress and may actually pass. But the air of optimism and expectation is not hanging over bloggers. Although as the law currently sits, citizen journalists and bloggers seem eligible for the same protections, some are worried about an amendment from Sen. Charles Schumer that would leave them behind. Writing in Mediashift.org, Rob Arcamona said:

headline: Knicks and Nets, Waiting for a Victory
text: The Knicks and Nets have had rough starts to their 2009-10 seasons. Both are 0-3, letting opportunities to win their first game slip past them. The Knicks have imploded early and late, sending their past two games to overtime before losing. The Nets led by 16 points with less than seven minutes remaining in their opener against the Minnesota Timberwolves, but lost on Damien Wilkins's last-second putback.

headline: 'Merchant of Venice' and 'Winter's Tale' Are Next for Shakespeare in the Park
text: You got Leontes in my Shylock! You got Hermione in my Portia! For its next season of Shakespeare in the Park, the Public Theater plans to attract audiences -- one hopes without perplexing its performers -- by staging two of the Bard's plays in repertory with the same company of actors. On Monday, the Public said that it would mount productions of "The Merchant of Venice" and "The Winter's Tale" that would run from June 9 through Aug. 1. Daniel Sullivan (who recently directed the Public's production of "Twelfth Night") is to direct "The Merchant of Venice," about a moneylender's notorious bargain, and Michael Greif ("Next to Normal," "Grey Gardens," "Rent") will direct "The Winter's Tale," the courtly romantic comedy containing the stage direction "Exit, pursued by a bear." The Public has previously staged repertory Shakespeare productions, including "Henry IV" Parts I and II in 1991, and a condensed version of the "Henry VI" plays and "Richard III," called "The War of the Roses," in 1971. Casting for the company that will perform "The Merchant of Venice" and "The Winter's Tale," including the bear, was not announced.

headline: Another Norwegian Teenager Emerges as a Threat
text: A 19-year-old Norwegian turned in an impressive performance at the 17th European Team Championships in Serbia, which ended on Saturday. A Norwegian teenager had been expected to do well at the tournament, but the surprise was that he turned out to be Jon Ludvig Hammer and not Magnus Carlsen, who does not turn 19 until the end of November.

headline: It’s Rodriguez’s World
text: The baseball playoffs have been going on for so long now that it is hard to pinpoint the exact moment that the Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez took over the world. It probably arrived during one of his towering late-inning home runs, but it could have been during some fateful moment when he declined to say something idiotic after a game, or when Fox’s cameras developed their suction-cup lock on Kate Hudson.

headline: The Day: Waiting for the Swine Flu Vaccine
text: Swine flu vaccine is dribbling into the three towns, slowly and seemingly randomly. Some doctors have it; some don't. Maplewood township has it, and Millburn township doesn't. In South Orange, the township will be vaccinating adults, then older children, at clinics scheduled for next Monday and Tuesday. Maplewood ran a clinic yesterday. Hundreds of parents in Millburn waited hours on Saturday to get their children vaccinated at the office of Dr. Donald N. Cotler, a pediatrician. Here is Susan Feinstein's report from the vaccination line.

headline: Top French Literary Prize Is Awarded
text: The novelist and playwright Marie NDiaye became the first woman in a decade and the first black woman ever to win the Prix Goncourt, the annual literary prize, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. NDiaye, who is of French and Senegalese descent, was awarded the prize on Monday for her book "Trois Femmes Puissantes" ("Three Powerful Women"), a three-part novel about various characters who struggle with transitions between Europe and Africa. In an interview with Agence France-Presse, Ms. NDiaye, who is 42, said that she did not see any symbolism in her victory. "I have never thought of it in those terms: 'black woman' and 'Goncourt'. I find it impossible to see things that way," she said. The author, who was raised by her mother in Pithiviers, a town south of Paris, and did not travel to Africa until she was in her 20s, added: "I grew up in a world that was 100-percent French. My African roots don't mean much, except that people know of them because of the color of my skin and my name." The prize comes with a ceremonial award of about $15.

headline: Guerrilla Marketing | A Hostage Store in Stockholm
text: Throughout her career, the Swedish designer Ann Sofie Back has embraced bad taste. Her ripped, stitched, tattered and generally askew aesthetic has been inspired by everything from Wildensteinesque plastic surgery to Lindsay Lohan's lack of underwear. As a result, the designer is no stranger to "worst dressed" lists. "My stuff has ended up on the Fashion Police site a few times," says Back, who recently moved back to Stockholm after 12 years in London. To pay for her style transgressions - and to boost her hometown profile - Back has introduced a new take on the guerrilla store concept: a hostage store.

headline: Monday Puzzle: The Case of the Mixed-Up Princes(s)
text: Mate selection. Perhaps the most difficult choice that we have to make in our lives: one that affects our future happiness more than any other. What young person has not had fantasies of finding his or her perfect life-partner? How does that translate into making a perfect or even good choice amongst the real potential mates available to you? Wouldn't it be nice to have a technique, a magic bullet, that guaranteed you the highest probability of making your best choice?

headline: Banksy Mural About Graffiti Is Tagged With, Yes, Graffiti
text: By the time a local council in south London completed its vote on the preservation of a mural by the street artist Banksy, the majority decision to keep the artwork was a moot point: vandals had already covered the mural in graffiti. BBC News reported that 93 percent of the 250 local residents who participated in the vote, which ended on Saturday, said that the Sutton Council should keep the work: a painting of a punk with spiky hair trying to assemble a slogan from the contents of an Ikea-style box, which appeared on a wall earlier this fall. Though the council generally has a zero-tolerance policy on graffiti, Councilor Colin Hall told the BBC: “We believe in democracy and wanted local people to decide what should happen to the Banksy. Sadly someone decided to take it into their own hands.” He added: “The image actually criticized mindless graffiti so perhaps it isn’t surprising that the sort of people who do that sort of thing should attack it.”

headline: Chickpeas: The Mediterranean’s Most Versatile Legume
text: Of all the many types of beans that I work with, chickpeas (also called garbanzos), the key ingredient in hummus, are the most versatile. They are good cold or hot, at home in a stew, soup or casserole, or without adornment in a salad or pasta. This legume has been cultivated in the Mediterranean for thousands of years, and I don’t know of a country in that region where chickpeas don’t figure in the cuisine.

headline: Searching for Themes in the M.&A. Market
text: Despite some recent activity, the figures for mergers and acquisitions in October are not particularly good. According to Dealogic, M.&A. activity in the United States was down 46 percent from September to October. These figures show not only a continued M.&A. slumber, but a deal market with few building blocks for any upward trends to build upon.

headline: What Makes Germans Laugh? Not ’30 Rock’
text: In the United States, “30 Rock” is regarded as a rapid-fire comedy whose ratings haven’t yet caught up with its awards and critical accolades. In Germany, it’s just another show that nobody watches. On Sunday night, the debut showing of “30 Rock” on the German channel ZDFNeo earned a 0.0 rating, The Hollywood Reporter said, meaning it was watched by fewer than 5,000 people. The channel, which is owned by the German broadcaster ZDF, was recently given a makeover in an attempt to attract more young male viewers, and its showings of “30 Rock” (along with series like “Miami Vice” and “The Sentinel”) were central to that mission. It was unclear if viewers there would be more or less receptive to a “30 Rock” episode in which Liz Lemon accidentally sells NBC to a group of German investors.
