headline: Art Buyers Bullish on Lehman Brothers Collection
text: A fire sale of artwork that once belonged to Lehman Brothers, the investment services company whose bankruptcy in September 2008 augured months of worldwide economic turmoil, raised $1.35 million at an auction Sunday, which is, at least, a start toward the billions in debt that the company left behind. In a news release, the auction house Freeman’s, which conducted the sale in Philadelphia, said that all of the 280 lots offered, consisting of works from Lehman Brothers offices in New York, Massachusetts and Delaware, were sold. Among the top sellers were a Roy Lichtenstein “I Love Liberty” print, which sold for $49,000; a set of 10 prints by Louis Lozowick that sold for $94,000; and a Georges Schreiber painting of the Financial District, which once hung in the company’s New York boardroom, for $20,000. (All sales figures include a 25 percent buyer’s premium on the first $20,000 hammer price and an additional 20 percent on the balance.) Freeman’s plans future sales of Lehman Brothers artworks on Dec. 6 and Feb. 12.

headline: Adaptec Chief Is Likely to Be Ousted From Board
text: After a long-running proxy battle, the activist shareholder Warren Lichtenstein said Monday that his hedge fund, Steel Partners II, had amassed enough support to remove Adaptec‘s chief executive, Sundi Sundaresh, from the board of the data storage company.

headline: Laugh It Up
text: Catch up with the latest in downtown comedy-nerdery tonight, when WitStream, a funny-people-Twitter-aggregate, sponsors a show at Comix. (Yes, Twitter-aggregating is one part of what it takes to make it in comedy these days.) The lineup includes Michael Ian Black, Michael Showalter, Morgan Murphy (a writer for Jimmy Fallon), Pete Holmes and more. If you’re truly humor-besotted, check out Leo Allen’s show Whiplash at the UCB afterward; it’s where all the local talent and executives who love them go.

headline: News of the Weird
text: Pimps, prostitutes, crackheads, criminals and weirdos  that’s what tonight’s readings have in common. At Bluestockings, Eric Ferrara, a fourth-generation New Yorker, shares his  “Guide to Gangsters, Murderers and Weirdos of New York’s Lower East Side,”  about the origins of mafiosos like Bugsy Siegel. And at the Barnes & Noble in Union Square, Augusten Burroughs offers his tales of perverse holiday woe in  “You Better Not Cry: Stories for Christmas.”  Thanksgiving’s right around the corner, after all.

headline: Day of the Dead
text: To celebrate Día de los Muertos  the Mexican Day of the Dead (today is All Souls’ Day)  head to St. Mark’s Church-in-the-Bowery for music and other performances. Or to Mayahuel, the dark, sexy tequila bar, for a special menu of all-you-can-drink cocktails and small plates for $50. Bring a date.

headline: Mount Holyoke College Names New President
text: Lynn Pasquerella, the provost of the University of Hartford, will become the 18th president of Mount Holyoke College this summer, succeeding Joanne Creighton, who has held the post since 1996.

headline: 10 New Ticket Machines Open at Grand Central
text: It’s a scene stolen from the nightmares of New York commuters: Thanksgiving Day, the evening rush, and you’re trying to catch a train for dinner in the suburbs. You make it to Grand Central Terminal with 10 minutes to spare (phew!) – but no ticket.

headline: Why ‘Falling Back’ Is Better Than ‘Springing Forward’
text: Yesterday we gained an hour, thanks to the end of daylight saving time. I love this transition out of daylight saving time during the fall, but I hate the transition into daylight saving time during the spring, when we lose an hour. And new research shows there is good reason for this preference: people are much less likely to get hurt at work when they “fall backward” than when they “spring forward.”

headline: Court Declines Case of Klansmen in ’64 Slayings
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday said it would not review a case arising from the 1964 kidnapping and killing of two black teenagers along the Mississippi-Louisiana border, an episode that continues to stir legal debate as it stokes memories of the ugliest racism.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: In The New Yorker, Jonathan Gold of LA Weekly gets his due with a six-page profile (for subscribers only). “Gold drives twenty thousand miles a year in search of food. ‘I go into a fugue state, like the Aboriginal dreamtime, when you go on long aimless walks in the Outback,’ he says, ‘That’s how I feel on the endless streets of Los Angeles County.’ ”

headline: Still Zapping Through Commercials? Decoder Wants to Know
text: In today’s New York Times, Bill Carter writes:

headline: Candidate’s Religion Is Point of Contention in Queens Race
text: Dan Halloran, the Republican candidate for a City Council seat in northeastern Queens, actively practices Theodism, a neo-pagan faith which attempts to reconstruct the pre-Christian tribal religions of the European Germanic people.

headline: No More Sir Allen: Stanford Loses Knighthood
text: The jailed Texas financier R. Allen Stanford is being stripped of his knighthood in the Caribbean nation of Antigua and Barbuda, the head of the government panel that approves the awards said Monday.

headline: BlogTalk: Countdown to Election Day
text: With less than 24 hours to go before votes are cast in several races around the country, the blogs are sizzling with chatter about New York’s 23rd Congressional District election, and about how much it will mean for the Republican and Democratic parties.

headline: Performa 09 | Food for Thought
text: It took the Biblical God seven days to make a new world. All the party designer Jennifer Rubell needed was Friday night. To benefit Performa 09, the three-week biennial of performance art under way on stages all over town, Rubell’s creation story involved an inspired D.I.Y. dinner that brought the R.E.M. front man Michael Stipe, the artist Cindy Sherman, the avant-garde director Robert Wilson, the chef Mario Battali and nearly 600 other unsuspecting guests to the X Initiative (formerly the Dia Art Center) in Chelsea.

headline: Clinton Denies Easing Pressure on Israel
text: MARRAKESH, Morocco  Struggling to stem protests from the Arab world, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday reiterated that the Obama administration still wanted Israel to freeze construction of Jewish settlements, even if it regarded Israel’s compromise offer as “unprecedented.”

headline: Giants’ Early Schedule: Too Easy?
text: N.F.L. coaches and players like to say that all opponents are the same, that a win against the 2009 Raiders is no different than a win against the 1972 Dolphins.

headline: On ‘Nova,’ Theories of How the Apes Became Us
text: Here’s some cheery news: that global warming thing everyone is so worried about is actually going to make us all a lot smarter. Unfortunately, it’s also going to leave us with heads the size of basketballs.

headline: Beethoven and Mendelssohn’s Scribbles for the Ages Enhance Juilliard Trove
text: The Juilliard School has finished the construction of a secure archival storage space for its collection of valuable music manuscripts, and you have to hope that the designers left a little extra room in the shoulders and hips. For at a concert-lecture event celebrating its completion  and with it, the completion of the school’s three-year, $200 million renovation and expansion  at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening, Juilliard is to announce the acquisition of two additional manuscripts, and there appear to be more to come.

headline: Sorry, I’ve Got to Go Save My Brain
text: A FEW months ago, my daughter Zoe came home from college and showed me a little word game she was playing on her iPhone.

headline: Let Scientists Write Drug Laws, Says Fired British Expert
text: David Nutt, a professor of pharmacology who was forced to resign on Friday as the head of an independent panel of experts set up to advise the British government on drug policy, accused Prime Minister Gordon Brown of overstating the dangers of cannabis and ecstasy to impress voters and suggested that drug laws should be written by scientists, not politicians.

headline: Health Bill Worse Than ‘Terrorist,’ Republican Says
text: The House is moving toward a health care showdown later in the week, and if comments by Representative Virginia Foxx are any indication, things might get a little rough.

headline: Panel Tries to Speed Warrant Process in Drunken-Driving Cases
text: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said on Monday that he had convened a committee to look at ways to speed the process of getting warrants for blood from individuals who refuse breath tests after they have been arrested on suspicion of driving drunk.

headline: Morgan Stanley Thinks Big With Loan for CF Bid
text: Morgan Stanley‘s agreement to lend $2.5 billion to back  CF Industries Holdings’ hostile bid for Terra Industries, a rival fertilizer maker, is the biggest leveraged loan commitment by a single bank this year, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: Telling Numbers for ‘Brighton Beach Memoirs': Poor Sales Despite Good Buzz
text: Last week’s box-office grosses for Broadway shows have just been released, and they provide another data point regarding the demise of the “Brighton Beach Memoirs” revival on Sunday.

headline: Processed Foods and Depression
text: The BBC is reporting on a study that links processed food and depression. (Hat tip: Kerri Conan.)

headline: The Morning Skate: Another Headshot, Gretzky’s Money and Plante’s TV Special
text: Are the N.H.L.’s rules and standards at odds with player safety?

headline: Patient Voices: Coping With and Without Insurance
text: Much of the debate about health care reform focuses on people who don’t have insurance. But as Karen Barrow explores during the latest Patient Voices series, even people with insurance coverage are struggling with bills, confusing policies and red tape.

headline: A Southern Mirrored Window
text: “The Help,” a novel about the relationships between African-American maids and their white employers in 1960s Mississippi, has the classic elements of a crowd pleaser: it features several feisty women enmeshed in a page-turning plot, clear villains and a bit of a history lesson.

headline: Giving Sight by Therapy With Genes
text: By the time Corey Haas was 7, the retinal disease he was born with had already stolen much of his vision. “He always clung to me or my wife,” said Corey’s father, Ethan Haas.

headline: As the Thermometer Falls, ‘Man Cave’ Décor Is Warming Up
text: COOLER temperatures often drive people indoors, but not everyone is disappointed by the change of seasons. Douglas Wright, an architect with Hart Howerton, a firm based in New York and San Francisco, said many of his male clients look forward to hibernating in “man caves”  cozy, masculine dens where they can pursue interests like spectator sports, woodworking or billiards.

headline: Natural Disaster Insurance: Do You Need It?
text: With the news media filled with stories lately about natural disasters like earthquakes, hurricanes and wildfires, many consumers may be wondering when to purchase additional insurance to protect their homes from Mother Nature. My husband and I certainly have been concerned with the topic since moving to California this year.

headline: Just the Basics (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: AIDS: Panel Warns That Without New Direction, Epidemic Will Remain Out of Control at 50
text: Unless there is a drastic change in approach, the AIDS epidemic will still be out of control on its 50th anniversary in 2031, a panel of AIDS experts predicted in an analysis being published Tuesday in the journal Health Affairs.

headline: A Mission to Mars (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: At the Negotiating Table for Next Year’s Rates
text: Travel management companies are in the midst of negotiating next year’s hotel and airline rates on behalf of their corporate clients, an annual ritual that was thrown into turmoil last fall when the economy collapsed, dragging down business travel with it.

headline: Excerpt: 'V'
text: The ABC science fiction series about alien visitors is based on the 1980s show of the same name.

headline: Neighbor Says Police Knew About Rapist’s House
text: The police in Cleveland were notified repeatedly about violence in the house of a convicted rapist where the decomposed bodies of six women were found last week, a neighbor said Monday.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'The Verdict'
text: A. O. Scott reviews Sidney Lumet's film about an alcoholic trial lawyer on a medical malpractice case.

headline: Tumors That Vanish (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: They Came From Beyond, Sexy and Media Savvy
text: A crowd gathers to gawk at a huge spaceship that has appeared in the sky over Manhattan. The bottom of the ship turns into a screen (à la “Blade Runner”) showing the leader of the alien visitors. She announces that they mean us no harm, that they just need some water and a mineral “common and abundant on Earth” before they shove off.

headline: A Life Apart, Without a Home, Friends or Regrets
text: “My goal is equanimity,” he said. “I’m not pursuing what the world calls success.”

headline: An Honest Day’s Work From Vienna
text: AS a child growing up in Vienna, Carlo Huber would sometimes accompany his father, Rupert E. Huber, to wine bars and heurigen, informal little buffets where Viennese wine estates sold their own produce. When his father had an especially pleasing glass, Mr. Huber recalled, he would exclaim, “Das ist ein ehrlicher wein!”  That is an honest wine.

headline: Russia Tries, Once Again, to Rein in Vodka Habit
text: MYTISHCHI, Russia  It was late on a Monday afternoon at the drunk tank in this Moscow suburb, but it could have been any day, at any hour, at any similar facility across this land. People would come. They always do. Such is Russia’s ruinous penchant for the bottle  and the challenge facing a new government policy to curb it.

headline: The Obama the Campaign Knew
text: One year after Barack Obama was voted into the White House, does the public want to relive the marathon 21-month campaign that began long before the snows of Iowa and New Hampshire and churned on through the seemingly endless calendar of primaries and the general election? After useful campaign books by Richard Wolffe (“Renegade: The Making of a President”) and Dan Balz and Haynes Johnson (“The Battle for America 2008: The Story of an Extraordinary Election”), is there anything illuminating left to say about the long, winding road to his historic victory?

headline: Stanley Works to Acquire Black & Decker
text: Two leading tool and equipment makers, Stanley Works and Black & Decker, said Monday afternoon that they had agreed to merge in an all-stock transaction that they valued at about $4.5 billion.

headline: Shopping With Douglas Wright
text: “It runs the gamut, from beautiful men’s rooms down to the nitty-gritty of workbenches and tools,” Douglas Wright said of the spaces his clients have increasingly been requesting in recent years.

headline: U.S. Options and the Karzai Brothers
text: Updated, Nov. 3, 10:20 a.m. | Vanda Felbab-Brown expands on the idea of stronger coercion. Scroll down to read her additional comments.

headline: Health Bill Worse Than a Terrorist, N.C. Lawmaker Says
text: Carl Hulse, our chief Congressional correspondent, reported just a short while ago on our sib-blog, Prescriptions, that remarks made on Monday by a North Carolina lawmaker may signal the tenor of a rumble looming when Republicans and Democrats in the House debate the health care overhaul later this week.

headline: Performa 09: In the Beginning, an Old Testament Feast
text: With its benefit dinner Friday night, Performa 09, the performance art biennial that gets underway in earnest Monday, definitely established a hard act to follow. Perhaps not for itself, but at least for the event planners of the world. Organized by Jennifer Rubell, the daughter of the collectors Donald and Mera Rubell and an experienced event planner herself, the evening was modestly titled “Creation.” It melded installation art, happenings and performance art with various Old Testament overtones, while laying waste to the prolonged ordeal that is the benefit-dining experience.

headline: Making a Phillies Fan: Patience and Luzinski
text: We invited readers to share their stories of how they became fans of the Yankees or the Phillies, and we will highlight entries as the World Series continues. Below, Lee Barber, 48, of Leesburg, Va., writes that the Phillies’ 1980 World Series victory over the Kansas City Royals, which she celebrated while attending college in Missouri, was worth the wait.

headline: Fathers Gain Respect From Experts (and Mothers)
text: It used to irk Melissa Calapini when her 3-year-old daughter, Haley, hung around her father while he fixed his cars. Ms. Calapini thought there were more enriching things the little girl could be doing with her time.

headline: Can’t We Retire the Business Card?
text: I have a stash of business cards that I’ve collected over the years at networking events, meetings, happy hours, etc. At this point, I could probably build a house out of all of the cards I’ve saved. I’m not typically a hoarder (well, maybe a little), but I just can’t bring myself to throw them out.

headline: Bear Stearns Manager Asks Judge for Acquittal
text: Matthew Tannin, one of two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers on trial on charges of securities fraud, has asked the judge to acquit him on all charges, claiming prosecutors have insufficient evidence.

headline: And So to the Park: ‘Winter’s Tale’ and ‘The Merchant of Venice’
text: You got Leontes in my Shylock! You got Hermione in my Portia! For its next season of Shakespeare in the Park, the Public Theater plans to attract audiences  you hope without perplexing its performers  by staging two of the author’s plays in repertory with the same company of actors. On Monday the Public said it would mount productions of “The Merchant of Venice” and “The Winter’s Tale,” to run from June 9 through Aug. 1. Daniel Sullivan, top right (who recently directed the Public’s production of “Twelfth Night”), will direct “The Merchant of Venice,” about a moneylender’s notorious bargain, and Michael Greif, right (of the Public’s “Romeo and Juliet,” as well as Broadway’s “Next to Normal”), will direct “The Winter’s Tale,” the courtly romantic comedy containing the stage direction “Exit, pursued by a bear.” The Public has previously staged Shakespeare in repertory, including “Henry IV” Parts 1 and 2 in 1991, and a condensed version of the “Henry VI” plays and “Richard III,” called “The War of the Roses,” in 1971. Casting for the company that will perform “The Merchant of Venice” and “The Winter’s Tale,” including the bear, was not announced.

headline: Uh-Oh, Sponsor Change for ‘Family Guy’ Special
text: Fox will be deleting the computer references and adding a sneak preview of the coming film “Sherlock Holmes” to next Sunday’s comedy special starring two of the voices of “Family Guy,” Seth MacFarlane and Alex Borstein. The network indicated on Saturday that the Warner Brothers “Sherlock Holmes” movie, scheduled to open on Christmas Day, would replace Microsoft for the special, which is titled “Family Guy Presents: Seth & Alex’s Almost Live Comedy Show.” In lieu of traditional commercial breaks, the special was to incorporate references to the Microsoft Windows 7 operating system into the script. But when Microsoft employees attended a taping of the special last month, they didn’t like what they heard  namely, Mr. MacFarlane’s sometimes outrageous humor. The company announced that the program “was not a fit” with the Windows 7 brand, sending Fox scrambling to sign up another sponsor. The special will now include a “sneak peek” at the film, Fox said.

headline: World Series Makes Everyone Desperate
text: Opposite Fox’s coverage of Game 4 of the World Series, which dominated the ratings on Sunday, “Desperate Housewives” helped give ABC a narrow second-place finish for the night. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Desperate Housewives” delivered 13.8 million viewers, far more than CBS’s new medical show, “Three Rivers” (7.7 million), in the same 9 p.m. time slot. The two networks were more evenly matched at 8, as CBS’s “Amazing Race” (11.1 million) outpaced ABC’s “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” (10.8 million), and at 10 when ABC’s “Brothers & Sisters” (9.4 million) edged ahead of CBS’s “Cold Case” (8.6 million). Final audience figures for the World Series game were not available on Monday, although preliminary estimates show that more than 20 million tuned in. NBC remained well behind in fourth.

headline: French Literary Prize Is Awarded
text: The novelist and playwright Marie NDiaye became the first woman in a decade and the first black woman ever to win the Prix Goncourt, the annual literary prize, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. NDiaye, right, who is of French and Senegalese descent, won on Monday for her book “Trois Femmes Puissantes” (“Three Powerful Women”), a three-part novel about characters who struggle with transitions between Europe and Africa. In an interview with Agence France-Presse, Ms. NDiaye, 42, said that she did not see any symbolism in her victory. “I have never thought of it in those terms: ‘black woman’ and ‘Goncourt.’ I find it impossible to see things that way,” she said. The author, who was raised by her mother in Pithiviers, south of Paris, and did not travel to Africa until she was in her 20s, added: “I grew up in a world that was 100 percent French. My African roots don’t mean much, except that people know of them because of the color of my skin and my name.” The prize comes with a ceremonial award of about $15.

headline: Footnotes
text: The New York Public Library said on Monday that it was acquiring the papers of the author E. Annie Proulx, whose works include “The Shipping News” and “Brokeback Mountain,” and that the writer and artist Hilary Knight, who illustrated the “Eloise” series of children’s books, had donated his papers to the library as well. The announcement was to be made officially at the 2009 Library Lions gala, which was paying tribute on Monday night to Ms. Proulx and Mr. Knight, as well as David Smith, a reference librarian; Julia Chang, its supervising librarian for children’s programs; and Janice Moore-Smith, a career specialist at the library.

headline: Lehman Brothers Art Makes Buyers Bullish
text: A fire sale of artwork that once belonged to Lehman Brothers, the investment services company whose bankruptcy in September 2008 augured months of worldwide economic turmoil, raised $1.35 million at an auction on Sunday, which is, at least, a start toward the billions in debt that the company left behind. In a news release the auction house Freeman’s, which conducted the sale, top right, in Philadelphia, said that all 280 lots offered, consisting of works from Lehman Brothers offices in New York, Massachusetts and Delaware, were sold. Among the top sellers were a Roy Lichtenstein “I Love Liberty” print, which brought $49,000; a set of 10 prints by Louis Lozowick, which went for $94,000; and a Georges Schreiber painting of Manhattan’s financial district for $20,000. (All sales figures include a 25 percent buyer’s premium on the first $20,000 of the hammer price and an additional 20 percent on the balance.) Freeman’s plans future sales of Lehman Brothers artworks on Dec. 6 and Feb. 12.

headline: Street Artist Tagged With, Yes, Graffiti
text: By the time a council in South London completed its vote on the preservation of a mural by the street artist Banksy, the decision to keep the artwork was beside the point: vandals had already covered the mural in graffiti. BBC News reported that 93 percent of the 250 local residents who participated in the vote, which ended on Saturday, said that the Sutton Council should keep the work that appeared on a wall this fall: a painting of a punk with spiky hair trying to assemble a slogan from the contents of a box branded with an Ikea-like name. Though the council generally has a zero-tolerance policy on graffiti, Councilor Colin Hall told the BBC: “We believe in democracy and wanted local people to decide what should happen to the Banksy. Sadly someone decided to take it into their own hands.” He added: “The image actually criticized mindless graffiti, so perhaps it isn’t surprising that the sort of people who do that sort of thing should attack it.”

headline: Travels in Cyberspace: The Monday Report
text: The AMC show “Mad Men” certainly seems to have an affinity for the travel industry. Last year’s plotline involved an attempt by the Sterling Cooper agency to win an airline’s lucrative business. This year, the famed hotelier, Conrad Hilton, turns up as a key character — one who approaches Don Draper about taking Hilton Hotels on as an account and then slowly insinuates himself into the adman’s life.

headline: One Voting Machine Vendor?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Domesticity, Strait-Laced With Dry Wit
text: I always thought that the Keen Company’s mission statement  that it “produces sincere plays”  could be improved to “sincerity forever,” to borrow a title from a Mac Wellman comedy. But that would be glib and maybe a little insincere, and the thing about the artists at the Keen is that unlike most every other theater, which cooks up a mission statement to sell an image, they actually mean it.

headline: Paying More Attention to Fathers
text: When it comes to raising children, most of the focus is on mothers. But a growing body of research shows that fathers play an essential, if often undervalued, role in a child’s development, as Laurie Tarkan explores in today’s Science Times. She writes:

headline: In Iowa, Second Thoughts on Obama
text: WILLIAMSBURG, Iowa  Pauline McAreavy voted for President Obama. From the moment she first saw him two years ago, she was smitten by his speeches and sold on his promise of change. She switched parties to support him in the Iowa caucuses, donated money and opened her home to a pair of young campaign workers.

headline: Clinton derangement syndrome
text: Oh, dear. In my previous post I used the example of Clinton-era growth to argue that even growth in the mid-3s wouldn’t be enough to bring unemployment down anywhere near quickly enough. And sure enough, many of the comments are along the lines of “Clinton doesn’t deserve credit for the growth” or “It was all the tech bubble.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Nov. 2
text: Pictures of the Day opens with a photograph of people identifying victims of a suicide bomber in a commercial district in Pakistan. The explosion killed at least 35 people and apparently targeted military personnel (Slide 1). In the slums of Rio de Janeiro, where a young student died during a shootout between the police and drug dealers last week, children protested (Slide 6) and celebrations in Haiti marked the Day of the Dead in Belladère (Slide 8). In New York, the U.S.S. New York swept under the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Monday morning. Before docking in Midtown, it paused at the World Trade Center site (Slide 10 and Slide 11).

headline: U.S. Unlikely to Recoup Auto Investments, Report Says
text: DETROIT  A government report released Monday concludes that taxpayers will probably never recoup all  or even close to all  of the $67 billion that the Treasury Department lent to General Motors and Chrysler in the last year to prevent their collapse.

headline: Sending Drugs to Specific Spots in a Tiny Cage
text: For years, biomedical engineers have been trying to develop ways to deliver tiny amounts of a drug to a specific target  anticancer compounds directly to tumors, for example. Much of the work involves microscale capsules or other hollow structures with openings that can be controlled from outside the body.

headline: A Scripted Bloomberg Goes Off Script Momentarily
text: For months now, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has managed to be on his best campaign behavior, displaying an unusually agreeable disposition, and avoiding saying something untoward or inappropriate.

headline: No saving grace
text: Brad DeLong catches Allan Meltzer claiming that there’s something nonsensical about the Obama administration making estimates of jobs saved thanks to its policies. But it’s not just Meltzer — Greg Mankiw has done the same thing.

headline: By Any Other Name, You May Not Fly
text: TWO weeks ago, I suggested here that I would rather get whacked upside the head with a baseball bat than have to visit either my state motor vehicle office or the passport office to make sure that the name on my driver’s license and passport was exactly the same on all my travel documents.

headline: Sampling Whitman and Art From the Civil War
text: An article on the Arts page in the Westchester section on Sunday about an exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art on Walt Whitman and American Art of the Civil War Era misidentified the institution that loaned two paintings by Sanford Gifford to the museum. "Camp of the Seventh Regiment, near Frederick, Maryland, in July 1863" and "Baltimore, 1862 - Twilight" are on loan from the New York State Military Museum and Veterans Research Center, not the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: The Role of Air Pressure in Starting a Landslide
text: Rain can set off landslides, as can earthquakes. But what about air? More precisely, what about the weight of air, better known as atmospheric pressure?

headline: A Venerable Ensemble’s Performance, Filtered Through a Hall’s Odd Acoustics
text: The Mozarteum Orchestra Salzburg, founded in 1841, is just a year older than the New York Philharmonic, but with its avowed specialty  music of the Viennese Classical era  this ensemble makes the conservative Philharmonic look like a wild-eyed new-music band. Still, the Salzburg group is updating its repertory: in one series this season it is focusing on the music of John Adams and Luciano Berio, as well as on Schubert and Schumann.

headline: Worst Idea of 2009
text: In my column on Thursday, I included the following observation about some Wall Street products:

headline: Back to Iowa
text: At the place where the presidential candidacy of Barack Obama first took life, it appears that the coalition he built in 2008 is showing at least some signs of fraying.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Verdict’
text: This week, A. O. Scott looks at Sidney Lumet’s 1982 film “The Verdict.” It follows a tarnished lawyer (Paul Newman) who seeks to redeem his reputation by winning a malpractice case. The standard courtroom drama story is given a dark twist with a screenplay by David Mamet. “The Verdict,” Mr. Scott says, “leaves you with the sense that justice can prevail, but when it does, it’s too little, too late, and it can’t compensate for the harm that’s already been done.” Please share your thoughts on “The Verdict” and other favorite courtroom dramas.

headline: Beethoven, and Plenty of It, in a Worldwide Sonata Tour
text: The Austrian pianist and composer Carl Czerny thought that Beethoven’s Piano Sonata in E flat (Op. 7) should have been nicknamed “Appassionata” instead of the Sonata in F minor (Op. 57). Till Fellner, an excellent Vienna-born pianist, illuminated the dramatic hues of the Opus 7 Sonata on Friday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in its PianoForte series.

headline: Schools vs. Guns in Afghanistan
text: In his Thursday column, Nick argued that building schools and educating people in Afghanistan and Pakistan would do more to stabilize these societies than military interventions. In response, a number of U.S. servicemen wrote in with their own stories about education as an effective counterinsurgency measure. One of the most detailed came from Lt. Col. Michael Fenzel. We post it here with his permission.

headline: Office Gossip Strategies
text: What’s the gossip in your office? What’s the gossip doing to your office? And what are the best strategies for gossips or antigossips to employ in the office?

headline: Afghan ‘Fiasco’
text: Opinionland has had little positive to say about the failed presidential run-off in Afghanistan, which ran off the road over the weekend when candidate Abdullah Abdullah withdrew, leaving the field to President Hamid Karzai, who earlier today was declared the official winner.

headline: A Shot in the Arm
text: Q. Why do some people get a sore arm at the site of a flu vaccine injection while others do not?

headline: Obama Lifts Ban on Visitors With H.I.V.
text: Fulfilling a campaign promise, on Friday the president moved to end a 22-year-long restriction he said was “rooted in fear rather than fact.”

headline: Geek Chic | Retail Therapy With Style Savvy
text: What’s more fun, working in fashion or pretending that you do with Style Savvy, a new video game that was released today? Tough call. For the past week, The Moment has been geeking out with a demo copy, and we’re somewhat embarrassed to admit the Nintendo DSi game is more fun than it has any right to be: you play a young, eager, fashion-forward girl trying to take the Horatio Alger route from retail sales assistant to world-famous stylist and entrepreneur.

headline: Prisoners of War and Sex in Liberia
text: NEW HAVEN  Subjugation and corruption are the grim options available to the women of “Eclipsed,” a new play by Danai Gurira (“In the Continuum”) at the Yale Repertory Theater here. Set in 2003 during the Liberian civil war, the play focuses on four women held captive by the brutal leader of a rebel faction fighting against the government.

headline: CRE and the CRA
text: Zombies, zombies, everywhere. One of the enduring myths of the financial crisis has been the claim that it was the result of (a) Fannie and Freddie (b) the Community Reinvestment Act, which forced poor, helpless bankers to make loans to you-know-who. It’s a myth that won’t go away — I get asked about it almost every time I give a public lecture — even though it has been extensively debunked. (See, e.g., here.)

headline: Russians Comment on Ways to Curb the Use of Alcohol
text: MOSCOW  How hard will it be for the Russian government to reduce the country’s alcohol consumption? The New York Times asked readers of its Russian-language blog on livejournal.com for their thoughts.

headline: A Tribute to ‘Nashville’ (Altman’s, not Parton’s)
text: A satire of a satire made with love: if that description of the revue “Daryl Glenn and Jo Lynn Burks Play and Sing Robert Altman’s ‘Nashville’ ” sounds self-contradictory (how many satires emanate from love?), it evokes the heartfelt nostalgia of a popular little show that has been playing at the Metropolitan Room on the first Sunday each month.

headline: Can You Believe How Mean Office Gossip Can Be?
text: Could adults gossiping in the office be more devious than the teenagers in “Gossip Girl”?

headline: A One-Man Band Plays Left-Coast Rock
text: “We’re Mount Eerie, from Anacortes, Washington,” said Phil Elverum, a compact, penitent-looking man with an electric guitar. His audience, on Sunday night at Le Poisson Rouge, cheered at him. “Yes,” he said. “Thank you. It’s a beautiful place.”

headline: A Marathon Run in the Slow Lane
text: After a 10-kilometer road race this summer, a friend apologized for missing me at the finish line. The truth was, she hadn’t lost me in the crowd. She just didn’t wait long enough.

headline: Running at the Back of the Pack
text: For the past five and a half months, I’ve been writing about training for my first marathon. My goal was to get off the couch, run consistently and complete a fall marathon.

headline: A Breathing Technique Offers Help for People With Asthma
text: I don’t often write about alternative remedies for serious medical conditions. Most have little more than anecdotal support, and few have been found effective in well-designed clinical trials. Such trials randomly assign patients to one of two or more treatments and, wherever possible, assess the results without telling either the patients or evaluators who received which treatment.

headline: Gene Therapy: Before and After
text: A child navigating an obstacle course test, first using only his untreated right eye, and then with his left eye, which received a gene therapy treatment three months before.

headline: Consumer Reports Opines on Electronics
text: While many videophiles dismiss the magazine’s findings, the fact is that millions of Americans rely on Consumer Reports’ evaluations of electronics to help them with their purchase decisions.

headline: Employment Looks Better
text: For those convinced the economy cannot be improving, job numbers are Exhibit No. 1. The expectation (according to a Bloomberg survey of economists) is that employment fell by 175,000 in October in the United States. (We get the number, or at least the first estimate of it, on Friday.)

headline: Bruno Corruption Trial Opens
text: ALBANY — The corruption trial of Joseph L. Bruno, the former Senate majority leader, opened in federal court here on Monday, with a who’s who of state lawmakers and lobbyists expected to take the stand over the next few weeks.

headline: Collecting Headlines Funnier Than This
text: Headlines in the satirical weekly newspaper The Onion tend to function both as punch line and setup, in that order. They are the heart of the paper, and not only the first thing anybody reads, but also, unlike headlines in real newspapers all over the world, the first things to be written. The staff devotes the first two days of every week to composing headlines, then assigns the articles that will run beneath them and provide a body of supporting jokes.

headline: Quandary With Mammograms: Get a Screening, or Just Skip It?
text: Here we go again. Another study raises questions about the benefits of mammograms, and another set of confusing statements issue forth from experts.

headline: Anti-Odor Silver Exits Textiles in the Wash
text: When it comes to killing bacteria, fungi and the like, silver is a thing of beauty. Silver ions are such effective antimicrobial agents, in fact, that there are now hundreds of consumer products that contain small amounts of the metal, in the form of nanoparticles that release ions slowly over time.

headline: Feinberg Says Pay Caps May Cause Some to Leave
text: Kenneth R. Feinberg, the Treasury Department’s special master for executive pay, acknowledged Monday that his decisions to cut executive compensation could encourage talented employees to leave seven companies that received tens of billions of dollars in government bailout money.

headline: A Powerful Identity, a Vanishing Diagnosis
text: It is one of the most intriguing labels in psychiatry. Children with Asperger’s syndrome, a mild form of autism, are socially awkward and often physically clumsy, but many are verbal prodigies, speaking in complex sentences at early ages, reading newspapers fluently by age 5 or 6 and acquiring expertise in some preferred topic  stegosaurs, clipper ships, Interstate highways  that will astonish adults and bore their playmates to tears.

headline: U.S. Unlikely to Recoup Auto Bailouts, G.A.O. Says
text: A government report released Monday concludes that taxpayers will probably never recoup all — or even close to all — of the $67 billion that the Treasury Department lent to General Motors and Chrysler in the last year to prevent their collapse, Nick Bunkley of The New York Times reports from Detroit.

headline: Mt. Kilimanjaro Ice Cap Continues Rapid Retreat
text: The ice atop Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania has continued to retreat rapidly, declining 26 percent since 2000, scientists say in a new report.

headline: Creationism, Minus a Young Earth, Emerges in the Islamic World
text: AMHERST, Mass.  Creationism is growing in the Muslim world, from Turkey to Pakistan to Indonesia, international academics said last month as they gathered here to discuss the topic.

headline: Hubbells, Promising Young Ice Dancers, Swap Coaches
text: The Olympic season coaching carousel continues in skating.

headline: In the Mediterranean, Killer Tsunamis From an Ancient Eruption
text: The massive eruption of the Thera volcano in the Aegean Sea more than 3,000 years ago produced killer waves that raced across hundreds of miles of the Eastern Mediterranean to inundate the area that is now Israel and probably other coastal sites, a team of scientists has found.

headline: Now Showing | Design, and Plenty of It
text: This is a busy week for design exhibitions. Opening on Tuesday at the Wright auction house in Chicago is “Timeless,” a collection of objects by Constantin and Laurene Boym. For the show, the New York-based Boyms, who won a 2009 National Design Award for their quirky, witty products, render everyday objects like tables and bottles in bronze, giving them a permanence they might not otherwise have.

headline: On Our Radar …
text: 1) The Washington Post’s gloomy take on the Senate climate bill.

headline: You Can’t Judge a Seatmate by His Foot-Stomping
text: I LOVE flying. Maybe that’s because I go into it with the expectation that I’m going to be delayed. Once I get through security, I go to the bar, ask for a wine, order some death-defying foods and then do some work, until my flight arrives.

headline: Kerik Moved Out of Jail’s Mental Health Unit
text: WHITE PLAINS  Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City former police commissioner, was transferred out of a special mental health unit in a Westchester County jail on Monday after psychiatric officials determined that he was psychologically stable.

headline: Justices Scrutinize Adviser Pay
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday appeared reluctant to allow judges to take on a major role in policing the compensation of mutual fund investment advisers. But some justices nonetheless suggested that pay arrangements could be so outsized that the courts may have to step in.

headline: Huge Audience for World Series Game, but N.F.L. Still Reigns
text: The question of the most popular sport on television has been long answered, but football put an exclamation point on it Sunday when a regular season N.F.L. game was far more watched than Game 4 of the World Series.

headline: Schwab to Offer Commission-Free E.T.F.’s
text: Charles Schwab said Monday that it was entering the exchange-traded fund business, with the introduction of eight new funds that undercut several competing E.T.F.’s on fees. But to top it all off, investors with Schwab accounts can buy and sell the funds free.

headline: Researcher Behind the Drug Gleevec
text: Dr. Brian J. Druker, 54, an oncologist at Oregon Health and Sciences University and a Howard Hughes Medical Investigator, is one of three winners this year of the Lasker-DeBakey Clinical Medical Research Award, often called the “American Nobel Prize.” Dr. Druker shared the honor with Nicholas B. Lydon, a former researcher for Novartis, and Charles L. Sawyers of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, “for the development of molecularly targeted treatments for chronic myeloid leukemia, converting a fatal cancer into a manageable chronic condition.” Here is an edited version of a conversation that took place last month in New York:

headline: Times Responds on Reporter’s Kidnapping
text: Several Web sites repeated Monday erroneous allegations that The New York Times had paid a ransom in the case of its reporter David Rohde, held by the Taliban for seven months. Bloggers also accused The Times of hypocrisy in reporting on a British couple kidnapped by Somali pirates while keeping quiet Mr. Rohde’s kidnapping.

headline: Understanding Your Credit
text: The government requires the credit bureaus to provide free copies of your credit reports once a year, but not credit scores or monitoring. Yet some companies offer free reports and scores on their Web sites, often to entice customers to sign up for monitoring. And not all scores are created equal – many free scores are meant as a guide for consumers and are not actually used by lenders to assess your creditworthiness.

headline: With Series Fever, Steroids Issue Fades to the Past
text: Aided by his bat and an astute apology, Alex Rodriguez is ending the baseball season not as a former steroids user but as a home run hero. In the process, he may be clearing a path forward for himself and his much-maligned sport.

headline: On Assignment: New York City Marathon
text: Most years Fred R. Conrad is assigned to photograph the New York City Marathon and he has covered it from various vantage points along the 26.2-mile race that winds through all five boroughs. In the past, he focused the lens of his 4×5 camera on the Achilles Track Club Freedom Team, taking black and white portraits of this group of disabled war veterans. Last year, the marathon fell just two days before the election, and he shot runners emblazoned with political flair and slogans.

headline: Jets’ Special-Teams Woes
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. – The Jets’ special-teams coordinator, Mike Westhoff, made a rare Monday media appearance, in order to explain how his unit yielded a pair of return touchdowns to Ted Ginn Jr. in a loss Sunday to Miami.

headline: Where the Swearing Is All About the Context
text: MEXICO CITY  Two teenage girls slurped iced coffee drinks at a sidewalk cafe the other afternoon and chatted away about boys, clothes, their weekend plans, whatever seemed to pop into their heads. They were clearly friends, but repeatedly referred to each other with a Spanish word meaning “ox” or “steer” or “stupid.”

headline: New Yorkers Have Their Say
text: Residents in five New York City boroughs speak out about their choice for mayor and what matters most this election.

headline: Supreme Court Addresses Pay of Fund Advisers
text: The Supreme Court on Monday appeared reluctant to allow judges to take on a major role in policing the compensation of mutual fund investment advisers. But some justices nonetheless suggested that pay arrangements could be so outsized that the courts may have to step in, Adam Liptak of The New York Times reports from Washington.

headline: Jets Look for Answers From Uneven Performances
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Throughout the Jets’ locker room Monday, the answers did not match the record. The rookie quarterback Mark Sanchez sounded giddy. Linebacker Bart Scott remained defiant. Player after player expressed satisfaction with his respective individual or unit performances halfway through this season.

headline: Video: In Iowa, Obama One Year After
text: To mark the one-year anniversary of the historic election of Barack Obama, we went back to the place where his campaign took life: Iowa.

headline: Date Set for Oral Arguments in Polanski Case
text: Let the arguments begin: a California appeals court in Los Angeles has scheduled oral arguments in its review of Roman Polanski’s three-decade-old sex case for Dec. 10.

headline: Iran: Reformist Newspaper Is Closed
text: The authorities on Monday shut down a reformist daily newspaper, Sarmayeh, on charges of “repeated violations of the press law,” the official news agency IRNA reported. No details were disclosed about the violations attributed to the newspaper, which has been critical of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s economic policies.

headline: Karadzic Promises to Attend War Crimes Trial Tuesday
text: PARIS  Radovan Karadzic was absent again on Monday, the third day of his trial, but he sent a letter to the chief judge of the international war crimes tribunal hearing his case saying that he would be “pleased” to attend on Tuesday.

headline: E. Coli Kills 2 and Sickens Many; Focus Is on Beef
text: Two people, one from New Hampshire and another from upstate New York, have died after eating ground beef that may be responsible for an E. coli outbreak linked to illness in more than two dozen people.

headline: Mayoral Campaigns Look Skyward, and Everywhere Else, for the Keys to Victory
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s campaign, having spent $100 million or more on ads and outreach, would love to be able to buy a 60-degree day. The higher the temperature, the thinking goes among Mr. Bloomberg’s staff, the wider the margin of victory.

headline: Suburbs Are Seen as Key in New Jersey Race
text: PARAMUS, N.J.  Finishing his morning coffee with three friends  like him, all retirees and registered Republicans  Leonard Reisner let it slip that he would be voting to re-elect Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic incumbent governor.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,346 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

headline: Biden Stumps in a Race Steeped in Ideology
text: WATERTOWN, N.Y.  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. threw the heft of the White House behind the Democratic candidate on Monday in a race for a vacant Congressional seat that both Democrats and Republicans view as significant tests of their political fortunes.

headline: House Harder on Drug Makers Than Senate
text: The health care bill that the full House may take up later this week is much tougher on the drug industry than what the Senate is considering. And that could prove one of the challenges for lawmakers when the legislation eventually reaches a House-Senate conference committee.

headline: Little Buzz for Thompson? Call It Larry Doby Syndrome
text: Win or lose on Tuesday  and the poll gods are not smiling upon him  William C. Thompson Jr. will no longer have to struggle with what might be called Larry Doby Syndrome.

headline: Forest Evashevski, Who Coached Iowa to Two Rose Bowl Titles, Dies at 91
text: Forest Evashevski, who revitalized a long-dismal football program at the University of Iowa and coached the Hawkeyes to two Rose Bowl championships in the 1950s, died Friday in Petoskey, Mich. He was 91.

headline: Happy Ending
text: In the spring of 2004 I took a flight from my home near Greenville, S.C., to New York to visit my dying step-grandmother. We had been close, and it would be one of the last times I would get to see her. As the flight was about to land, it abruptly ascended and headed toward the Empire State Building. The passengers on the plane became quiet; the aura of 9/11 was hanging in the air.

headline: Cellphones, Texts and Lovers
text: Since April 2007, New York magazine has posted online sex diaries. People send in personal accounts of their nighttime quests and conquests. Some of the diaries are unusual and sad. There’s a laid-off banker who drinks herself into oblivion and wakes up in the beds of unfamiliar men. There’s an African-American securities trader who flies around the country on weekends to meet with couples seeking interracial sex. (He meets one Midwestern couple at a T.G.I. Friday’s.)

headline: Scandal at Tower of London Over Treatment of Female Beefeater
text: LONDON  For centuries, the jailers at the Tower of London known as Beefeaters had a grim reputation. Guarding three Tudor queens who were beheaded and dispatching numerous others who had fallen foul of royal favor to the gallows or the scaffold, they helped make the tower’s bloodstained history.

headline: Economy Is Focus at End of New York Mayor Race
text: On the eve of Tuesday’s election, the top two mayoral candidates put aside their bitter arguments over term limits, campaign spending and the city’s schools to try to reassure voters about a more pressing worry: the economy.

headline: 2010 to Come in Plain and Fancy Versions
text: IN less than two months, a new year will arrive, along with a new decade. Each year in the current decade has been spoken the long way, as in “two thousand nine,” rather than the short way, as in “twenty oh nine” (or even “twenty ought nine”).

headline: Gore’s Dual Role: Advocate and Investor
text: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Al Gore thought he had spotted a winner last year when a small California firm sought financing for an energy-saving technology from the venture capital firm where Mr. Gore is a partner.

headline: No Rough Edges on Stanley’s Deal for Black & Decker
text: Leave it to the tool industry to engineer something like the perfect deal. The $3.5 billion Stanley Works purchase of Black & Decker, one of Stanley’s main competitors for hardware and hand tools, leaves almost nothing for investors in the two companies to complain about. The combination would create a powerhouse with $8.4 billion in sales. If only deal-making was always this simple.

headline: States Are Pondering Fraud Suits Against Banks
text: PHOENIX  Newly empowered by the Supreme Court, the attorneys general of several states hit hard by the housing collapse are exploring consumer fraud suits against major mortgage lenders.

headline: To Some, Winner Is Not American Enough
text: As soon as Mebrahtom Keflezighi, better known as Meb, won the New York City Marathon on Sunday, an uncommon sports dispute erupted online, fraught with racial and nationalistic components: Should Keflezighi’s triumph count as an American victory?

headline: Bloggingheads: Public Option Kabuki?
text: Tim Fernholz, left, of The American Prospect and Matt Lewis of Politics Daily debate whether the public option will be in the final Senate bill.

headline: For Girardi and Manuel, Three Days’ Rest Is the Right Call, and So Is Four
text: Philadelphia

headline: GlobalFoundries Chairman to Take Leave, Then Resign
text: Hector Ruiz, the former chief executive of Advanced Micro Devices, will step down as chairman of GlobalFoundries, the chip maker spun off from A.M.D. last year, the company said on Monday.

headline: Troy Smith, Founder of Sonic, Dies at 87
text: Troy N. Smith Sr., who turned ordering a hamburger by speaking into a microphone from a parked car into a national habit, died last Monday in Oklahoma City, Okla. He was 87.

headline: Lack of Paid Sick Days May Worsen Flu Pandemic
text: Public health experts worried about the spread of the H1N1 flu are raising concerns that workers who deal with the public, like waiters and child care employees, are jeopardizing others by reporting to work sick because they do not get paid for days they miss for illness.

headline: Fed Leaders Meet Bankers to Stress Limits on Pay
text: The heads of the nation’s largest banks were summoned by Federal Reserve officials on Monday to discuss what is perhaps the most contentious issue of the post-bailout era: pay.

headline: Appeals Court Rejects Suit by Canadian Man Over Detention and Torture Claim
text: A federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled on Monday that Maher Arar, a Canadian man who claimed that American officials sent him to Syria in 2002 to be tortured, cannot sue for damages because Congress has not authorized such suits.

headline: Costly Free Credit Reports
text: Federal law guarantees free credit reports each year, but many consumers who got theirs from FreeCreditReport.com unintentionally paid for an expensive credit monitoring service.

headline: Ethics Panel Investigates Free Tickets for Paterson
text: The State Commission on Public Integrity has begun a preliminary inquiry into the solicitation of free tickets for the opening game of the World Series by aides to Gov. David A. Paterson, an administration spokesman confirmed on Monday.

headline: A Free Credit Score Followed by a Monthly Bill
text: On television it’s hard to miss the wildly popular band of slackers singing ruefully from a shabby apartment or while waiting tables in pirate regalia. The ruined credit that led to their financial misfortune might have been sparkling if only they’d tracked their status on freecreditreport.com.

headline: U.S. to Allow G.M. to Use Federal Loans to Invest in Delphi
text: DETROIT The federal government has granted General Motors permission to use $2.8 billion in borrowed money to help its former parts division, the Delphi Corporation, G.M. said in a regulatory filing on Monday.

headline: Could You Keep Up?
text: Imagine you are on a treadmill at your local gym. You push the up arrow again and again, increasing your speed until you reach the machine’s maximum, 12 miles per hour. That’s a pace of five minutes per mile.

headline: The Man Who Opened the Gate
text: Twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the columnist Roger Cohen describes how a former East German border guard kept that fateful night peaceful, rather than filled with bloodshed.

headline: Two Views of Bruno Are Presented at His Trial
text: ALBANY  The corruption trial of Joseph L. Bruno, the former State Senate majority leader, opened in federal district court here on Monday, with a who’s who of state lawmakers and lobbyists expected to take the stand over the next few weeks.

headline: Slumping Giants Are Struggling to Communicate
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants defensive end Justin Tuck was blunt Monday when he expanded on comments made Sunday by middle linebacker Antonio Pierce about how the defense had a communication problem during a 40-17 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles.

headline: U.S. to Pay $1.2 Million to 5 Detainees Over Abuse Lawsuit
text: The federal government is paying $1.2 million to settle the cases of five Muslim immigrants who sued over their detention and treatment in a Brooklyn jail after 9/11, when hundreds of noncitizens were rounded up and held for months before being cleared of links to terrorism and deported.

headline: Nov. 3 Election Information
text: New York

headline: A Glimpse of the Future?
text: President Obama made an appearance in Florida last week that should have gotten more attention. At a time when many Americans are apprehensive about the state of the economy and uncertain about the nation’s long-term prospects, Mr. Obama delivered an upbeat speech that offered a glimpse of a broader overall vision and a practical way forward on the crucial issues of energy and jobs.

headline: New Advice on Swine Flu for Pregnant Women
text: One dose of swine flu vaccine protects pregnant women against the flu, but children under 10 still need two doses, federal officials said Monday, announcing further results of clinical trials of the vaccine.

headline: It Knows Where You Are, and What You’re Looking For
text: Big Web companies and start-ups alike are scrambling to create the best applications to allow users to search for surrounding businesses and events from a mobile phone. Loopt, a service that lets people find their friends on the go, is now entering the crowded field.

headline: Democrats Say House Bill Cuts Premiums for Many
text: WASHINGTON  As the House moved toward climactic votes on legislation to remake the health care system, the Congressional Budget Office said Monday that middle-income families might be required to pay 15 percent to 18 percent of their income on insurance premiums and co-payments under the proposal.

headline: One of the Three Green R’s
text: Today’s puzzle features a clever quote by a governor whose name tucks neatly into opposite corners of the grid. Crossword constructors like a name like that. Designers of campaign placards do too, being able to neatly stack one name atop the other. In presidential races, FORD DOLE was a good pairing. EISENHOWER NIXON wasn’t, but using IKE and DICK solved that problem.

headline: Joba Chamberlain Braces for Renewed Talk About His Role With Yankees
text: PHILADELPHIA  Giving up the tying home run with two outs in the bottom of the eighth inning of Game 4 was not the way Joba Chamberlain wanted to get his first World Series victory. But often when a late-inning reliever is the winner, it is because he did something wrong.

headline: Detective’s Alcohol Level Was 2 ½ Times Legal Limit
text: The New York City police detective who has been charged with killing a woman while driving drunk early Friday morning had a blood alcohol level more than double the legal limit, according to a law enforcement official.

headline: Lament on the Fading Culture of the Printed Word
text: Over the years, how many people have read Joan Didion’s pointed, moody, celebrated essays and come to New York in the hope of writing some of their own? The path of those would-be writers is patently stubborn, given the tone Ms. Didion strikes in the essay so many name as their favorite, “Goodbye to All That.” It is a famous elegy for the passing of youth, but also a catalog of Manhattan’s enervating clichés, and, implicitly, a rejection of the New York literary scene she inhabited.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about President Obama’s announcing the end of a ban on travel to the United States by people who test positive for HIV misidentified the document Mr. Obama was shown signing. It was the Ryan White H.I.V./AIDS Treatment Extension Act of 2009, which provides medical and support services for those with H.I.V./AIDS; it was not the order ending the travel ban.

headline: Corrections
text: The Talking Business column on Saturday, about the National Hockey League’s refusal to sell the Phoenix Coyotes franchise to a Canadian who would relocate it to Ontario, misidentified the North Carolina city that received a team under the N.H.L.’s so-called Southern strategy of the 1990s. It was Raleigh, not Charlotte.

headline: Election Day
text: Councilwoman Diana Reyna, a Democrat from City Council District 34 in Brooklyn, is battling two formidable foes in Tuesday’s election. One is a vengeful Democratic Party boss, who rails about her independence, and the other is the Roman Catholic bishop of Brooklyn, who has made robocalls supporting the party boss.

headline: The Mayor’s Bad Investment
text: MEMO to the 108th mayor of New York, Michael R. Bloomberg: You didn’t have to do it. You didn’t need to set a new national campaign spending record. You didn’t have to become a one-man stimulus program, employing costly campaign consultants, ad producers and all those “volunteers.” You didn’t need that barrage of television ads, those wasteful glossy mailings or maddening robocalls.

headline: Helping Spin Gold From a Pile of Garbage
text: Raj Kottamasu, 29, is a community coordinator for Freshkills Park, which is built above the Fresh Kills Landfill in Staten Island. Raised in West Bloomfield, Mich., he is the only member of his family who is not a doctor and thus describes himself as a black sheep.

headline: A Game 5 Dedication to Michael Goldsmith
text: In a quick and touching reaction, Major League Baseball paid tribute during Monday night’s World Series game to Michael Goldsmith, the law professor who died Sunday of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

headline: Toolmaker Deal Ends a 28-Year Courtship
text: For nearly three decades, Stanley Works and Black & Decker, two of the most recognizable names in home improvement, have talked about combining through a merger.

headline: Goldman Eyes Tax Credits Fannie Mae Doesn’t Need
text: WASHINGTON  It could be yet another opportunity for Goldman Sachs to come out a winner from the financial crisis that it helped create, but the Treasury Department appears poised to squash it.

headline: Dean Foods Cautions on Outlook
text: The Dean Foods Company, the dairy processor, said Monday fourth-quarter earnings might fall more than analysts estimate amid rising prices for raw milk.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about Citigroup misstated the terms under which Sanford I. Weill, the company’s former chief executive, left it in 2003. Mr. Weill retired; he did not resign.

headline: Corrections
text: A chart on Monday showing the standings for the Bowl Championship Series misidentified Iowa’s next college football opponent. Iowa is to play Northwestern on Saturday  not Indiana, which it beat last Saturday, 42-24.

headline: Corrections
World Series Game 5 Final: Phillies 8, Yankees 6
text: Times reporters David Waldstein, Ben Shpigel, Tyler Kepner, Jack Curry and Richard Sandomir provided updates and analysis during Game 5 of the Yankees-Phillies World Series in Philadelphia.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, schedule information on Saturday with an article about performances of music by the composer Herbert Howells in New York this month misstated the date of a concert at Trinity Church that included his Requiem. As the article noted, the concert was scheduled for last night not tonight.

headline: San Franciscans Will Vote on Street’s Touch of Flash
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Can neon save a neighborhood?

headline: Recalling ’96, Torre Empathizes With Girardi
text: PHILADELPHIA  Joe Torre thought his nervousness would subside, but it hounded him for hours. Needing one win with the Yankees to secure his first World Series ring in 1996, Torre remembered sitting in his office and being unable to relax. He had not been antsy about managing in the postseason, so he was surprised at how jittery he was.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about major art auctions in New York this week and next misidentified one of the sellers said to be offering works at Sotheby’s sale of Impressionist and Modern art on Wednesday night. He is Louis Reijtenbagh, a Dutch financier  not Matthias Rickenbach, a Swiss lawyer.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Tuesday about an experimental strategy for community-wide testing and treatment for H.I.V. misstated an indicator of illness. Generally, doctors begin drug treatment when the number of CD4 cells, the white blood cells attacked by the virus, drops to 350 per cubic millimeter of blood or lower  not per milliliter. The article also referred incorrectly to a white plastic stick used in rapid H.I.V. screening. The stick, tipped with filter paper, collects antibodies from liquid secreted by gum tissue; it does not collect cells from the lining of the mouth.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday about Elmer Winter, co-founder of the temporary agency Manpower Inc., misstated his date of death. It was Thursday, Oct. 22  not Thursday, Oct. 29.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary about the photographer Roy DeCarava misstated part of the title of a photograph of his from 1952. It is “Man Coming Up Subway Stairs,” not “Man Comin Up Subway Stairs.”

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Senate Pressing Insurers on the Amount of Premiums They Spend on Care
text: The health insurance industry likes to cite figures showing that 87 cents of every dollar in premiums is spent on medical claims.

headline: Perhaps a Point Guard Feud
text: New Orleans Coach Byron Scott brushed aside a verbal altercation between Hornets point guard Chris Paul and Rajon Rondo, the Boston Celtics’ point guard.

headline: Voices From the Boroughs: Port Richmond, Staten Island
text: Interminable waits for the ferry. Endless road repair projects. Astronomical tolls.

headline: Voices From the Boroughs: Flushing, Queens
text: Popularity has been a double-edged sword in Flushing, Queens, one of the city’s most diverse neighborhoods. Business owners welcome the droves of people who descend on its downtown sidewalks in search of scarves, massages and melons, as well as ginseng that can run a few hundred dollars an ounce.

headline: Voices From the Boroughs: Bay Ridge, Brooklyn
text: There are roughly six registered Democrats for every Republican in the city, but in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, Republicans are not hard to find.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Browns Say General Manager Kokinis Is Out
text: The Cleveland Browns announced late Monday night that the first-year general manager George Kokinis was no longer working for the team, following a day of reports that he had been fired. The Browns denied the juicy part of the reports that Kokinis had been escorted out of the building. Kokinis was Coach Eric Mangini’s hand-picked choice to be the G.M., and the order of their hiring indicates who had the real power in the franchise: Mangini, not Kokinis. It was Kokinis who took the fall for the Browns’ 1-7 start. For this he left the Ravens and Ozzie Newsome’s well-oiled scouting and personnel machine?

headline: Mistakes Are Making a Difference in the World Series
text: PHILADELPHIA  Home plate is still 17 inches wide and the pitching rubber stands 60 feet 6 inches away. Ninety feet separate the bases. Baseball’s sacred measurements have not changed this postseason, even if other things have for the Yankees’ opponents.

headline: Mount Holyoke Names New President
text: Lynn Pasquerella, the provost of the University of Hartford, will become the 18th president of Mount Holyoke College this summer, succeeding Joanne Creighton, who has held the post since 1996. Ms. Pasquerella, who graduated from Mount Holyoke in 1980 before earning her doctorate in philosophy from Brown, spent almost two decades as a professor of philosophy at the University of Rhode Island, before becoming associate dean, then dean, of the graduate school there. She joined the University of Hartford in 2008.

headline: Some Fans See Enemies Behind Every Microphone
text: If Facebook, blogs and other inventions of the Internet age had existed in the 1950s, would someone have created an IHateVinScully.com Web site to grouse about his bias as a Dodgers announcer during the Yankees-Brooklyn World Series that he called? Or how about a site called ShutUpMelAllen.com to gripe about his supposed pinstriped preference when he was calling some of that same series?

headline: President Karzai’s Second Term
text: We regret the decision by Afghanistan’s opposition leader, Abdullah Abdullah, to withdraw from this week’s runoff election for the presidency. After President Hamid Karzai’s supporters tried to steal the first-round vote, Mr. Abdullah had strong reason to mistrust the process. But Afghan voters deserved another chance. And Afghanistan’s government  under assault from the Taliban and its own corruption and incompetence  desperately needed the legitimacy of a cleaner vote.

headline: Freedom of the Press
text: The Obama administration and Congress appear to be moving toward agreement on a federal shield law, which would protect reporters who refuse to reveal confidential sources. The bill that is emerging is not perfect, but it would help ensure that Americans get the information they need about the workings of government, business and other institutions that affect their lives.

headline: The Halliburton Loophole
text: Among the many dubious provisions in the 2005 energy bill was one dubbed the Halliburton loophole, which was inserted at the behest of  you guessed it  then-Vice President Dick Cheney, a former chief executive of Halliburton.

headline: Before They Vote, New Yorkers Have Their Say
text: The two major candidates vying in Tuesday’s mayoral election have spent tens of millions of dollars flooding television, radio and mailboxes with ads and fliers, many of them attacking each other’s record and integrity. But voters across New York City say they care less about the attacks between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his Democratic opponent, Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., and more about issues big and small, like soaring rents, congested streets, parking tickets and a lack of garbage cans. In the days before the election, reporters for The New York Times went to three neighborhoods to talk to people about the concerns they want City Hall to address.

headline: John Burns Q. and A. on Karzai, Corruption and Afghanistan
text: John Burns, the chief foreign correspondent for The New York Times, is answering questions about a New York Times article about Ahmed Wali Karzai, the brother of Afghan President Hamid Karzai. Ahmed Wali Karzai, who is accused of having ties to the nation’s opium trade, has been on the C.I.A. payroll since 2001, according to the article.

headline: Questions Lacking in the Postgame Q. and A.
text: Fox needs a question coach for Mark Grace. One of the failings of many sideline/stadium reporters is that they do not jot down good, solid, clear questions to ask the stars of a game.

headline: Phillies Send Series Back to the Bronx
text: PHILADELPHIA  The championship was in the Yankees’ grasp on Monday night, and a reminder loomed over their heads at Citizens Bank Park before Game 5 of the World Series. As they lounged in their clubhouse, rolls of protective plastic wrap hung above their lockers.

text: Best Buy sells a lot of DVDs, but it is taking another step to get ready for the day when that business shifts online.

headline: Timeless Sport’s Final Moments
text: PHILADELPHIA  At the heart of baseball’s beauty is that anything is possible until the final out. There is no clock, no ticking away of the season. In theory, it could last forever. Nothing proves this better than the end of the World Series.

headline: 3 Contests on Election Day Could Signal Political Winds
text: WASHINGTON  In this supposedly quiet off-year election, three contests taking place Tuesday are filling the void. Voters in New Jersey and Virginia will elect governors, while voters in upstate New York are filling a vacant House seat in a race with national implications.

headline: After Not Finishing Game 5, Victorino Ready for Game 6
text: PHILADELPHIA — Anyone who saw a dismayed Shane Victorino pleading with his manager when he was taken out of Game 5 in the eighth inning Monday night may be a little surprised to know that no one in the Phillies’ clubhouse was happier after the game than he was.

headline: Mary Travers Memorial Is Scheduled for Nov. 9
text: A memorial celebration of the life and music of the folk singer Mary Travers will be held at 7 p.m. on Monday at Riverside Church.

headline: Teixeira Struggling to Find His Swing in Postseason
text: PHILADELPHIA — Mark Teixeira swung at Ryan Madson’s changeup, missed it, then tried to return to the Yankees’ dugout after making the final out of Game 5 of the World Series. But Teixeira’s march was briefly interrupted because he bumped into Carlos Ruiz, the Phillies’ catcher. Nothing is going right for Teixeira these days.

headline: News Quiz | November 3, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Knicks Rediscover Hughes and Find a Win
text: Starters became reserves, veterans were dusted off and everything was new again. The Knicks, in search of another fresh start, tried one more new look Monday night: winners.

headline: For Keflezighi, It’s Wait, Wait, Win
text: For all of Meb Keflezighi’s preparation and strategizing, his bid to win the New York City Marathon almost came undone before he reached the starting line.
