headline: Ford Posts an Unexpected Profit of $997 Million
text: While its crosstown rivals stumbled through bankruptcy this summer, the Ford Motor Company pressed its advantage, and delivered surprising news on Monday that its cost-cutting efforts and improving sales helped it earn nearly $1 billion in the third quarter, The New York Times’s Bill Vlasic reported.

headline: Stanley and Black & Decker: The Perfect Deal?
text: Leave it to the tool industry to engineer something like the perfect deal. The $3.5 billion Stanley Works purchase of Black & Decker, one of Stanley’s main competitors for hardware and hand tools, leaves almost nothing for investors in the two companies to complain about, Breakingviews says. The combination would create a powerhouse with $8.4 billion in sales. If only deal-making was always this simple.

headline: BetOnSports Founder to Serve 4 Years
text: The founder of the online gambling site BetOnSports.com was sentenced Monday to more than four years in prison, ending a prosecution of one of the world’s largest offshore sports gambling companies.

headline: In Myer, Shades of TPG Deals Past?
text: David Bonderman has achieved another impressive return for an investment in a department store chain.  TPG Capital, the private equity firm he oversees, has quadrupled its original investment of 500 million Australian dollars ($450 million) in Myer, the Australian retailer, in just over three years.

headline: Law Firm Seeks Dissolution as Lawyer Investigated
text: A prominent and politically connected South Florida lawyer was being investigated by his own firm for financial irregularities in an investment business that led his law partner to seek dissolution Monday.

headline: Cisco Enters China Cable Market With DVN Deal
text: Cisco Systems said Monday it would buy the set-top box business of DVN, a digital cable technology company in China, for up to $44.5 million.

headline: Karzai Vows Corruption Fight, but Avoids Details
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai, in his first speech since he was declared the winner of the much disputed presidential election, said Tuesday that he wanted to tackle corruption but made no specific commitments to reorganizing his administration.

headline: Kraft Results Could Help Its Case With Cadbury
text: Kraft Foods will need to show progress in cutting costs and improving organic revenue when it reports earnings on Tuesday, in a bid to convince Cadbury shareholders it is a viable deal partner, Reuters said.

headline: Peet’s Swallows Diedrich Coffee for $213 Million
text: Peet’s Coffee & Tea, the coffee chain retailer, said Monday it would buy the wholesale roaster and distributor Diedrich Coffee for $213 million in a move to enter the rapidly growing single-cup coffee market.

headline: States Are Pondering Fraud Suits Against Banks
text: Newly empowered by the Supreme Court, the attorneys general of several states hit hard by the housing collapse are exploring consumer fraud suits against major mortgage lenders.

headline: China Extends Dragnet in Xinjiang Region
text: BEIJING  Four months after ethnic rioting in western China’s Xinjiang region killed nearly 200 people, security officials there have started a fresh dragnet to track down accused rioters and other so-called terrorist elements, a state-run regional newspaper reported Tuesday.

headline: Gore’s Dual Role in Spotlight: Advocate and Investor
text: Former Vice President Al Gore thought he had spotted a winner last year when a small California firm sought financing for an energy-saving technology from the venture capital firm where Mr. Gore is a partner.

headline: Chinese Movie Studio Eyes N.Y.S.E. Listing
text: A third leading Chinese movie studio is aiming for a listing — this time on the New York Stock Exchange — as the country’s entertainment companies turn to the capital markets to raise funds.

headline: Deleb
text: A portmanteau term for (d)ead c(eleb)rities.

headline: It Knows Where You Are, and What You’re Seeking
text: Big Web companies and start-ups alike are scrambling to create the best applications to allow users to search for surrounding businesses and events from a mobile phone. Loopt, a service that lets people find their friends on the go, is now entering the crowded field.

headline: Ex-Broker Pleads Guilty in Dreier Ponzi Case
text: A former broker pleaded guilty on Monday to criminal charges of helping Marc S. Dreier, the Ponzi scheme operator, defraud hedge funds by selling millions of dollars of fictitious debt, Reuters reported.

headline: Frits Seegers Gives Notice at Barclays
text: Barclays announced a shake-up of its management structure on Tuesday inlcuding the surprise departure of Frits Seegers as head of the bank’s global retail and commercial banking.

headline: Tiger Teams Up to Start Private Equity Firm
text: Tiger Management, the hedge fund’s founder Julian Robertson, and Emil Henry Jr. have teamed up to start a private equity firm that will specialize in infrastructure deals in North America and Europe, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Bank of New York Unit Buys Stake in Siguler Guff
text: Bank of New York Mellon‘s asset management unit on Monday said it bought a 20 percent stake in the private equity firm Siguler Guff & Company, The Associated Press reported. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

headline: Former Enron Executive Sentenced to Probation
text: Kevin Howard, Enron’s former broadband finance chief, has received one year’s probation, including nine months’ home confinement, for falsifying company books.

headline: TPG Pays $500 Million for Valerus Stake
text: TPG, the private equity firm, has agreed to pay $500 million for a majority stake in Valerus Compression Services, a Houston-based maker of equipment used to process natural gas.

headline: Goldman’s Plan for Fannie’s Credits May Trip Up
text: It could be yet another opportunity for Goldman Sachs to come out a winner from the financial crisis that it helped create, but the Treasury Department appears poised to squash it.

headline: N.Y. Pension Aims $1 Billion at Hedge Funds
text: The New York State Pension Fund is pouring money back into hedge funds, planning to invest more than $1 billion by the end of the year, Crain’s New York Business reported.

headline: Bank of America Said to Extend Search to N.Y.-Based C.E.O.’s
text: Bank of America broadened its search for a chief executive officer to include candidates who want to live in New York, acknowledging the bank’s biggest units are no longer based in its home of Charlotte, N.C., Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Shares Regain Modestly on Manufacturing Uptick
text: Shares showed modest gains on Monday, the first day of trading since the market took one of its steepest plunges in months. Signs that manufacturing in the United States was on a path to recovery helped buoy shares.

headline: What Do Good Teachers Need to Know?
text: The Secretary of Education, Arne Duncan, wants to see “revolutionary” changes made to teacher training programs. How do you think teachers should be trained?An Op-Ed by the director of teacher education at Williams College proposes how to make the changes that Secretary Duncan called for, including this idea:

headline: New Loss at UBS, but Business Is Improving
text: UBS, Switzerland’s biggest bank, reported a fourth consecutive quarterly loss Tuesday because of accounting charges but said business was improving, Julia Werdigier writes in The New York Times.

headline: Summit: To Buy or Be Bought?
text: At time when many small independent film studios are struggling to stay in business, Summit Entertainment, the start-up studio behind the “Twilight” franchise, is hoping to take its business to the next level by expanding.

headline: Fed Leaders Meet Bankers to Stress Limits on Pay
text: The heads of the largest U.S. banks were summoned by Federal Reserve officials on Monday to discuss what is perhaps the most contentious issue of the post-bailout era: pay.

headline: Celebrating Light at the Palacio de Cristal
text: So subtle are the installations by the Belgian artist Joëlle Tuerlinckx in Madrid’s Palacio de Cristal (Parque de El Buen Retiro; 34-91-574-6614; free admission), that on entering the gorgeous light-filled glass pavilion, you might not even notice them.

headline: N. Korea Says It Has More Bomb-Grade Plutonium
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea put further pressure on the United States to start bilateral talks by declaring on Tuesday that it had completed reprocessing its spent nuclear fuel for use in a bomb.

headline: Justices Scrutinize Adviser Pay
text: The Supreme Court on Monday appeared reluctant to allow judges to take on a major role in policing the compensation of mutual fund investment advisers. But some justices nonetheless suggested that pay arrangements could be so outsized that the courts may have to step in, The New York Times’s Adam Liptak reported.

headline: U.S. to Allow G.M. to Use Loans to Invest in Delphi
text: The federal government has granted General Motors permission to use $2.8 billion in borrowed money to help its former parts division, the Delphi Corporation, G.M. said in a regulatory filing on Monday, Nick Bunkley writes in The New York Times.

headline: Toolmaker Deal Ends a 28-Year Courtship
text: For nearly three decades, Stanley Works and Black & Decker, two of the most recognizable names in home improvement, have talked about combining through a merger, The New York Times’s Michael J. de la Merced and Zachary Kouwe write.

headline: Equatorial Guinea Frees British Mercenary
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Equatorial Guinea said Tuesday that it had pardoned Simon Mann, a former British special forces officer jailed last year for plotting to overthrow the country’s president in a conspiracy that seemed as much a throwback to the continent’s past as a catalog of bungles.

headline: European Union Reform Moves Ahead
text: PRAGUE  A landmark agreement aimed at giving the European Union a global stature on par with major powers like the United States and China cleared its last major hurdle on Tuesday.

headline: Lloyds and R.B.S. Announce Major Shake-Up
text: In a major shuffle of the British banking sector on Tuesday, Lloyds Banking Group announced plans to keep the government from taking a majority stake, while Royal Bank of Scotland said it would give up even more control. Both banks were forced by the European Union to sell large parts of their businesses to comply with competition regulation, Julia Werdigier reported in The New York Times.

headline: An Entrepreneurial Life
text: I just celebrated my 30th anniversary. One wife, three kids, 10 business start-ups, five business successes, five business misfires. I started my company the year before I got married, right out of school. I have come to realize over the years that I have not had a normal life. That’s because I am not normal; I am an entrepreneur.

headline: G.M. Board Expected to Decide Fate of Opel
text: The board of General Motors is expected to decide Tuesday the fate of Opel and Vauxhall, ending more than a year of uncertainty surrounding its business and restructuring in Europe and the United States, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Free Online Sperm and Its Perils
text: Today’s idea: Priced out of expensive regulated sperm banks, prospective parents are turning to a “booming gray market” in unregulated sperm donation, an article says. Let us count the ways this may not be a good idea.

headline: Almost Famous | Fischerspooner
text: “I went to see Madonna’s dress rehearsal at the O2 arena in London. It was so boring because she didn’t make any mistakes,” announced Casey Spooner, one part of the electroclash (remember that?) duo Fischerspooner onstage at MoMA on Sunday evening as part of Performa 2009. “Between the Worlds,” the group’s three-hour performance supporting their newest album, “Entertainment,” celebrated the imperfections and rawness of a dress rehearsal. The audience literally entered through the back stage, getting a close-up of the dancers shimmying into their different D.I.Y. showgirl outfits: leotards accessorized with colorful knee pads, ripped-up gowns and silver running suits that looked liked they were issued from NASA.But it was Spooner who stole the show with his getups — from corsets to Kabuki — and his snarky running commentary. The singer arrived onstage in a bolero jacket and slicked back platinum hair — for a band that seems stuck in the ’80s, this seemed to be a subtle homage to Adam Ant. As he serpentined through his dancers, a veritable hall of mirrors and racks of clothes, he faced the room full of arty hipsters as if he were making his debut to a crowd of 50,000 at the Meadowlands. In fact, the whole performance, snafus and all, was about superstardom. There was the de rigueur talk of the current queen of all things pop, Lady Gaga, and of course the former king of pop, Michael Jackson — at one point Spooner changed into a silver sequined suit and black hat, looking like he stepped out of the “This Is It” documentary.

headline: Sampler: Water Plan, Dellums Debt, Camping at the Mall
text: Water Deal | The state Legislature moved closer to a water deal for the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta after the Senate approved a $9.9 billion bond bill for building new dams and other reforms.

headline: Want a Stronger Democracy? Invest in Education
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

headline: Toyota Engineers Flowers to Offset Production Pollution
text: Toyota has gone to some extreme lengths to offset the carbon dioxide emissions produced by its Tsutsumi plant in Toyota City, Japan, where it builds the Prius hybrid.

headline: With Trick-or-Treating Over, Candy Invades Office Cubicles
text: This week, surely, tops the year in terms of the number of calories hauled into the office by workers: calories in the form of leftover Halloween candy. Snickers, candy corn, Swedish fish, Sour Patch Kids, Whoppers, M&Ms, Junior Mints. Fun size, snack size, miniatures. Even now, on Tuesday, this plastic-wrapped bounty remains plentiful in the cubicles of the city.

headline: Berkshire Bets on U.S. With a Railroad Purchase
text: Update | 11:06 a.m. Berkshire Hathaway, the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, said on Tuesday that it planned to buy the 77.4 percent of Burlington Northern Santa Fe it did not already own for $26 billion in cash and stock, in the largest deal in Berkshire history.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday: Aliens, Anthropologists and Politicians
text: ABC, already the network of “Lost” and “FlashForward,” adds another speculative drama to its schedule with “V” (8 p.m.), an updated version of the 1980s show about allegedly friendly aliens who appear in the sky over earth’s major cities. In a concession to the high cost of interstellar fuel, they bring 29 ships this time, instead of 50 as they did in the original.

headline: How Credit Freezes Protect Your Identity
text: In Tuesday’s paper, I wrote about FreeCreditReport.com and its credit monitoring service. Several critics and consumers see its up-to-the-minute reports on changes in your credit report as overkill.

headline: Today’s Tip Sheet: Decision Day Arrives
text: And now, the moment New Yorkers have all been waiting for, maybe … the final Tip Sheet of the 2009 campaign.

headline: Al Gore’s Climate Choice
text: Former Vice President Al Gore’s third book centering on global warming is out. Titled “Our Choice: A Plan to Solve the Climate Crisis,” it centers on the same mantra at the core of his message for years now – that the only missing link holding back action is political will. The book is mainly a heavily illustrated guide to the technologies and policies that could, in Mr. Gore’s view, limit climate dangers. Nuclear is largely out, capturing and burying carbon dioxide is somewhat in. Gains in energy efficiency are a vital stepping stone, he says, along with vastly expanded deployment of renewable energy sources and improved storage and grid components to make sure the power is available where and when it’s needed.

headline: Friendsourcing the Quest for iPhone Apps
text: Recently, I asked a friend to show me his favorite new iPhone apps. He shrugged and said he didn’t have any. He said it was too hard to find ones he wanted, and he didn’t want to pay for anything he might not like.

text: With Election Day looming here, President Obama took time on Monday to both congratulate and admonish Afghan President Hamid Karzai, now the official winner of the disputed election there.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Plans Cuts
text: In what had already been a year of drastic job cuts in the drug industry, the health care giant Johnson & Johnson said Tuesday that it would eliminate 6 to 7 percent of its worldwide work force  about 7,000 to 8,200 jobs  as part of a corporate revamping.

headline: Karadzic Makes Appearance in Court
text: PARIS  The former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic appeared in court Tuesday for the first time since the start of his war-crimes trial and repeatedly asked the judges to give him more time to prepare his defense. Until he was ready, he said, he could not participate in his trial.

headline: Giants Stadium Countdown: Rodney’s Ramble at No. 9
text: John Maxymuk, author of “The 50 Greatest Plays in New York Giants Football History,” is helping us count down to the final game at Giants Stadium. His latest book is “Quarterback Abstract.”

headline: Ethics Panel Investigates Free Tickets for Paterson
text: The State Commission on Public Integrity has begun a preliminary inquiry into the solicitation of free tickets for the opening game of the World Series by aides to Gov. David A. Paterson, an administration spokesman confirmed on Monday.

headline: Obama and the conventional wisdom
text: Andrew Leonard asks when I’m going to “blow my top” over Obama’s statement that now is the time to “get serious” about reducing debt. Um, never?

headline: Qian Xuesen, Father of China’s Space Program, Dies at 98
text: BEIJING  Qian Xuesen, a brilliant rocket scientist who single-handedly led China’s space and military rocketry efforts after he was drummed out of the United States during the redbaiting of the McCarthy era, died on Saturday in Beijing. He was 98.

headline: President’s Arts Committee Names 25 Members
text: An eclectic roster of artists and entertainment industry figures were named to the President’s Committee on the Arts and Humanities, the White House announced on Monday evening. Among the 25 people who were named by President Obama as members to the committee were the talent agent Bryan Lourd, the managing director and co-chairman of Creative Artists Agency; the actors Sarah Jessica Parker and Edward Norton; the cellist Yo-Yo Ma; and Teresa Heinz Kerry, the philanthropist and wife of Senator John Kerry. Also named were the actors Kerry Washington, Forest Whitaker and Alfre Woodard; the director George C. Wolfe; Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue magazine; Damian Woetzel, the former New York City Ballet dancer; and the architect Thom Mayne. In September, the committee, which works with federal cultural agencies and in the private and public sectors to further the White House’s cultural objectives, named George Stevens Jr. and Margo Lion its co-chairs and Mary Schmidt Campbell its vice chairwoman.

headline: Races to Watch Across the Nation
text: It may be an off-year election, but there are a few important races for both Republicans and Democrats. Whether the results suggest that President Obama has lost influence and electoral pull heading into the 2010 midterm elections — or offer Republican conservatives a map for consolidating their base against a more moderate wing of the party — remains to be seen.

headline: Making Solar Power Mobile Power
text: In his work with the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Todd Myers has seen the importance of having mobile electricity supplies firsthand.

headline: Global Banking Fears Lead to Mixed Results
text: Wall Street wobbled on Tuesday amid indications that the global economy, particularly the banking sector, might be more frail than investors had believed. But positive sales reports from automakers stoked investors’ hopes in the final hours of trading.

headline: Short Rotation Puts Pettitte on the Spot
text: PHILADELPHIA  Fans would like to believe that players can will themselves to greatness, particularly those infused with that most intangible quality: grit. There is no way to measure grit, but we know it when we see it, or at least we think we do.

headline: Och-Ziff Earnings Beat Expectations
text: Och-Ziff Capital Management Group, the big publicly-traded hedge fund run by Daniel Och, said distributable earnings for the third quarter fell 35 percent on lower assets under management, but results topped Wall Street forecasts.

headline: Letter: Hotel Haggling
text: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column, “$855 a Night? Can We Talk?” (Nov. 1): The name of the game here is: It never hurts to ask.

headline: From the Pound to the Big Top
text: While every performer in the Big Apple Circus is a joy to watch, some are cuter than others. Among those are the nine crafty dogs that race around the ring, leap through the air and dance on two legs. It’s quite an act, particularly for a group of animals that might have met a grim fate had they not been rescued by their trainer, Luciano Anastasini.

headline: Letter: Argentine Attractions
text: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column “In Latin America, Luxe Costs Less” (Oct. 25): Even though Buenos Aires is not new on the “less expensive luxury” list, it still offers surprises. The last time I went, I found Miravida Soho, a recently restored 1930s mansion that has been turned into a small hotel and wine bar. It was probably the nicest hotel experience I have had in ages.

headline: Correction: Singapore’s New Breed of Bar
text: A map last Sunday with the Heads Up column, about new bars and clubs in the Dempsey Hill neighborhood of Singapore, misstated part of the name of one of the bars. As the article correctly noted, it is the White Rabbit, not the Wild Rabbit.

headline: Philadelphia Transit Workers Strike
text: The Philadelphia transit system’s largest union went on strike early Tuesday morning, crippling travel in the city.

headline: Case Study | The Secret to Seltzer
text: Case Study is a bimonthly posting on all things alcoholic by Toby Cecchini, T’s spirits columnist.

headline: Tuesday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appear in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Wonders of Science
text: At the Museum of the California Academy of Sciences, designed by Renzo Piano.

headline: Circumstances of Kokinis’s Exit in Question
text: Even in the often tortured history of the Cleveland Browns, the last 48 hours seem to have redefined dysfunction, with the first-year general manager George Kokinis leaving the franchise Monday, just halfway through the season. New details emerged Tuesday morning about whether Kokinis was fired or forced to resign, which is intriguing because the Browns are still paying millions to other fired former executives like Phil Savage and Romeo Crennel.

headline: Of China, Texas and Green Jobs
text: When a coalition of investors and wind developers from the United States and China announced plans for a large-scale wind project in West Texas last week, many of our readers expressed outrage that a portion of the financing might well come from the $22 billion set aside in the economic stimulus package for clean energy projects — and green jobs.

headline: N.H.L. Scores: Coyotes, Out of Bankruptcy, Draw Record Low Crowd
text: Three games on Monday, but the most interesting aspect of the evening is the attendance figures for the three games in question.

headline: Esther Hautzig, Author of Wartime Survival Tale, Dies at 79
text: Esther Hautzig, an author of children’s books whose true-life tale of surviving World War II in the labor camps of Siberia, told in a guileless teenager’s voice, became a classic of young people’s literature, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Electronic Billboards on Mid-Market: SF Voters To Decide Today
text: San Francisco voters today are deciding on Proposition D, a ballot measure that, if passed, would allow electronic signs on a neglected two-block stretch of Market Street.

headline: Sparano’s Two-Point Confusion
text: When Dolphins Coach Tony Sparano decided to go for a 2-point conversion after Miami took a 30-19 lead against the Jets on Sunday, it didn’t seem to make sense. With 8:48 left, an extra point would have forced the Jets to score two touchdowns to take the lead. When Miami failed to convert, the Jets had the chance to tie the score with one touchdown (with a 2-point conversion) and a field goal.

headline: For Sale: One Humanity-Wasting Robot, Answers to the Name ‘Terminator’
text: Someday, as the movie and television series predicts, the Terminator robots will become powerful enough to reduce the world to a pile of scrap metal and ash. But for now, they just need new owners. Variety reported that the Halcyon Company, which owns the rights to the “Terminator” movies and related assets, plans to sell the franchise at an auction in January as it goes through bankruptcy. When Halcyon purchased the “Terminator” property for $30 million in 2007, it became the latest in a series of owners that previously included the producer Gale Anne Hurd and the now-defunct production company Carolco. Though the latest entry in the film series, “Terminator: Salvation,” grossed $369 million worldwide on budget of $200 million, Halcyon filed suit in August against a hedge fund that had provided the money to buy the series rights, saying that a backer at the fund engaged in fraudulent dealings, and filed for Chapter 11 in September. The company’s founders, Derek Anderson and Victor Kubicek, told a bankruptcy court that the “Terminator” franchise was worth $70 million. In a satirical blog post, Joss Whedon, the creator of “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” said he would pay $10,000 for the series, proposing such new ideas as a “Terminator of the Rings” fantasy film and a “Terminator” musical.

headline: The Online Price War Over Books Has a Fresh Twist (Or Two)
text: Update | 2:04 p.m. In an e-mailed statement, Amy Lester, a spokeswoman for Walmart.com, said: “We remain committed to offering our customers the lowest prices online at Walmart.com, and will continue to adjust our pricing accordingly and as needed on these books.”

headline: Madoff’s Accountant Pleads Guilty in Scheme

headline: Making Room for Dad

headline: Obama echoing Gordon Brown?
text: We’re seeing a measure of disenchantment with Barack Obama, even among Democrats. Today the Times has a piece about that sentiment in Iowa, the New York Review of Books has a Gary Wills piece that is admiring but suggests that he become a one-term president, and environmentalists have a full-page ad in the NYT today decrying his interior department’s decision to allow a wolf kill. You see the same thing in the poll numbers and hear it in water cooler conversations.

headline: A Lawyer’s Untimely Death Rattles Courthouse
text: In a city of $750-per-hour lawyers and sophisticated criminals, Russell Paisley was the everyman’s attorney. He roamed the halls of New York courthouses, taking on any and every type of case, often representing clients without thick pocketbooks. He was a well-respected and well-liked figure among judges, court officers, his colleagues and many others working in the city’s courthouses. To them, he was one of the faces of an important, yet all too often overlooked cog in the city’s criminal justice system.

Was this a proud team that staved off defeat in its own stadium, only to become the backdrop to a heroic Yankees triumph in the Bronx? Or did the Phillies set themselves up for a comeback for the ages?

headline: A Fresh Twist in the Price War Over Books
text: The online price war that broke out last month between heavyweight retailers Wal-Mart, Amazon and Target took a new turn on Tuesday when Amazon chose to extend its $9 price tag on three hardcover books that were officially released Nov. 3. Originally, the price war extended only to certain books that had to be purchased online before their official release date. Now, it’s continuing — on Amazon, at least — after the books are published.

headline: Premature Births Are Fueling Higher Rates of Infant Mortality in U.S., Report Says

headline: Israel Says Hamas Test-Fired Rocket

headline: The Evening Snack Tradition
text: A few months ago, my wife, Jackie, and I spent a few days in Turin and Milan. The itinerary was chosen after consulting a very useful opera website, which lists opera performances worldwide – even in one-horse towns with tiny, two-production opera seasons – and gives links to theater websites so that you can have a stab at buying tickets. Besides being hot and humid in late June, the two cities have something important in common: generous snacks with after-work cocktails.

headline: Madoff’s Accountant Pleads Guilty in Scheme

headline: What Issues Should the Next Mayor Address First?
text: In the days before the election, reporters for The New York Times went to the five boroughs to talk to people about the concerns they want City Hall to address. The issues they raised were big and small, like soaring rents, congested streets, parking tickets and a lack of garbage cans. Voters in Port Richmond said that Staten Island felt like the “forgotten borough,” and they lamented the lack of public transportation options. In Flushing, Queens, residents complained about congestion and trash. And in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, there was a chorus of complaints that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is running the city like a business.

headline: Classical Theater of Harlem Founders to Step Down
text: Alfred Preisser and Christopher McElroen, who founded the Classical Theater of Harlem and made it a home for the likes of Samuel Beckett, Euripides, Shakespeare and Melvin Van Peebles, will leave that Off Broadway theater company this month. In a news release, Mr. Preisser, who served as its artistic director, and Mr. McElroen, who has been its executive director, said they created the Classical Theater of Harlem in 1999 to “nurture a new, young and culturally diverse theater audience, and to produce theater that truly reflects” the diversity of New York. During that time, the company has staged acclaimed productions of “Waiting for Godot,” “Marat/Sade,” “Medea,” “King Lear” and “Ain’t Supposed to Die a Natural Death,” Mr. Van Peebles’s 1971 Broadway musical. It has won several Audelco, Obie and Lucille Lortel Awards as well as a Drama Desk Award, and has featured actors like André De Shields and Wendell Pierce. In a statement, Mr. Preisser and Mr. McElroen said they were confident the company would “continue to thrive,” but did not name their successors.

headline: Manager of Queen’s Composer Is Sentenced for Fraud
text: Peter Maxwell Davies, the British composer who holds the title of master of the queen’s music, said that he was “delighted” after his former manager was sentenced to 18 months in prison for defrauding him of more than $800,000, The Times of London reported. Michael Arnold, who managed Mr. Davies’s business affairs for more than 30 years, was arrested in 2007 and charged in October 2008 with false accounting; he admitted last year to having stolen the money, much of which is believed to have been spent on online gambling. Mr. Davies, who has been honored this year with a global series of concerts celebrating his 75th birthday, said he had stopped composing for a few weeks and had to borrow money from friends after learning of the fraud. On Monday, after the sentence was announced, he said he was glad the episode was over, adding: “I may even set it all to music. Who knows? That would be the ultimate revenge.”

headline: Who Receives Sick Leave?
text: With the H1N1 pandemic raging across the nation, public health experts are voicing concern that many American workers do not receive paid sick leave — and may feel economic pressures to report to work even when they have the flu. This, public experts fear, might help spread H1N1, which is also known as swine flu.

headline: Where the Bad ’80s Has a Niche
text: YEARS ago, my clique habituated a Lower East Side restaurant called Hat (translated from El Sombrero for N.Y.C. natives). The enchiladas were O.K.; the main attractions were the cheap margaritas, the salsa jukebox and the nervy, unreasonable mood of the place, largely delivered by the indifferent goth waitress who always wore an enormous black turban. Hat was an oasis of counterculture that soothed feelings of general alienation and dismay by ramping them up a bit, into a pleasingly marginal sense of being beyond the strangling grip of the mainstream.

headline: Orszag: To Reduce Deficit, ‘Range of Options’ Being Considered
text: President Obama’s budget director said in a speech on Tuesday that the White House economic team is considering “a range of options” so the president can keep his promise to reduce federal budget deficits by the end of his term to half of the level he inherited.

headline: A Good Word for Big Farms
text: On Slate, Tracie McMillan argues that while small farms might have a romantic appeal to those who believe in sustainable agriculture, a worker might be better off at a large-scale farm.

headline: ‘Mom Always Liked You Best’
text: The notion that parents cherish all their children equally — or at least say they do — is so entrenched in our culture that colleagues warned Karl Pillemer, a gerontologist at Cornell University embarking on the first of many studies of family favoritism, that his research would prove futile. No mother, they insisted, would admit to caring more for one son or daughter than another.

headline: Hughes Likes the View From the High Road

headline: Tiffany’s Temporary Parisian Home

headline: Vain Glorious | Frédéric Malle’s New Madison Avenue Shop
text: Frédéric Malle’s new Upper East Side store — his first free-standing location in the states — is much like his fragrances: refined and multilayered. Nestled in a former doctor’s office at 898 Madison Avenue, the jewel-box boutique was designed by the French architect Patrick Naggar, who drew inspiration from the building’s storied Art Deco exterior. Malle first spotted 898 Madison while studying art at New York University 25 years ago. “I’ve always loved the swirling facade,” he says. “It’s reminiscent of Hoffmann’s Viennese pavilion.” Alongside 1930s French art, objets and furniture from Malle’s own collection (including a desk and chairs his grandfather commissioned from the atelier of Jules Leleu) are elements common to all of the perfumer’s shops, including futuristic-looking smelling columns, refrigerated display cases, photographs of his “noses” and bookshelves containing Malle’s archive of 18 fragrances. Also available: his new home collection, comprised of candles, rubber incense (sheets of recyclable rubber infused with scent) and the Fleur Mécanique, a red-cube wonder that diffuses the aroma of fresh flowers into the air. A specially designed venting system ensures that shoppers don’t experience olfactory overload.Editions de Parfums Frédéric Malle, 898 Madison Avenue; (212) 249-7941.

headline: Performa 09: Gooaaaaallll!
text: Viewers may have leaped intermittently to their feet at the finale of “Symphony n.1” at Performance Space 122 on Monday night, but it was mostly to fend off dozens of careering soccer balls. Part of Performa 09, the performance art biennial, the piece was a collaboration between the Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson and Alterazioni Video, an Italian collective. Mr. Kjartansson was present only on video while he continues to represent Iceland in an extended painting performance at the Venice Biennale. The Alterazionistas turned out to be five young men wearing tuxedoes of erratic fit.

headline: Guns, Butter or Both? Debating Troops vs. Development in Afghanistan
text: Overview | What actions can help mend and secure the situation in the war-torn nation of Afghanistan? In this lesson, students consider a proposal to build more schools in Afghanistan rather than sending more troops to secure the struggling nation, then conduct research and present their policy recommendations in a debate.

headline: Quick Enough to Swat a Bat
text: How quick is Spurs guard Manu Ginobili? Well, now we know he’s quick enough to swat a bat out of midair. On Saturday night the Spurs-Kings game had just been delayed for the second time because of a bat swooping across the floor when Ginobili slapped the bat out of midair, picked it up and handed it to an arena worker for disposal. The video of the incident has become an Internet hit and PETA weighed in with its displeasure.

headline: Is Al Gore Getting Rich Off of the Green Movement?

headline: Dream On | Sarah Silverman Meets Carl Jung
text: In 1914, after falling out of favor with Freud, C.J. Jung lost his mind. Some scholars say he lost it by design, cultivating a psychic crisis to plumb the depths of his unconscious. The “Red Book,” an illustrated manual of the Swiss shrink’s inner world, is the product of all that plumbing.
