headline: Buffett’s Record of Buying Railroad Stocks
text: Warren E. Buffett’s investments in railroads are relatively recent. In fact, it was not until 2006 that Mr. Buffett’s holding company, Berkshire Hathaway, began building a stake in the industry. Despite the economic downturn, Mr. Buffett continued to build his position in many of the major railroads in the United States – concentrating most of his investment in Burlington Northern Santa Fe, which he agreed to acquired fully on Tuesday for $26 billion in cash and stock.

headline: Gender Identity in Kids
text: The magazine Time Out Kids this month is all about sex and your children. Called “A Comprehensive Guide for Progressive Sex Ed for Kids 12 and Under,” it starts with the assumption that we all want to raise children who will be so comfortable with their sexuality that they won’t need how-to-guides like this one.

headline: M-16 vs. AK-47: Iraqi Viewpoints
text: Baghdad: To get another perspective on the debate about the reliability of the American military’s M-16 assault rifle, we asked some Iraqi soldiers in Baghdad. They have recently been issued M-16s to replace their old AK-47s.

headline: Green Bean Salad With Chickpeas and Mushrooms
text: A far cry from cafeteria-style three-bean salad, this fresh, lively dish is a mixture of crunch and softness, bright colors and earth tones.

headline: Senator Schumer’s Fix for Freecreditreport.com
text: In my article today about Freecreditreport.com and its credit monitoring service, I told of how the Federal Trade Commission had been trying for years to get the company to improve its disclosures. The commission (and, it turns out, many New York Times readers who commented on the article) believe that the company doesn’t make it clear enough that before you get your free credit report from the site, you first have to sign up for the monitoring service at $14.95 a month.

headline: Redgrave Uncorsets a Relative Long Gone
text: Lynn Redgrave explores the life of her maternal grandmother through the prism of her own in her reflective new solo show, “Nightingale,” which opened Tuesday night at City Center, courtesy of Manhattan Theater Club. Sound cozy? Well, any expectations that this will be a sentimental journey should immediately be deferred.

headline: Theme Parks Confront Flu Jitters
text: FOR many Americans, the fear of swine flu has made everyday acts like going to work, going to school or getting on a plane feel fraught with danger  even more so since President Obama recently declared swine flu a national emergency.

headline: Eloise Moves to the New York Public Library
text: Eloise, one of the famous residents of the Plaza Hotel, is finding a new home in the New York Public Library.

headline: Making a Yankees Fan: It Was All About Location
text: We invited readers to share their stories of how they became fans of the Yankees or the Phillies, and we will highlight entries as the World Series continues. Below, Jim Norchi, 61, of Pittsfield, Mass., writes that the Yankees’ home was his home, too.

headline: Chair for Sale: Runs Well, Low Miles
text: The bid on the famous “DWI Recliner” from Proctor, Minn., was up to $6,300 Tuesday afternoon, with two days left to the eBay auction.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Nov. 3
text: Today’s show opens with the tangled mess of a deadly train crash in Pakistan (Slide 1). In neighboring Afghanistan, American troops rushed for cover in the Pech Valley of Kunar Province amid an ambush by Taliban fighters (Slides 2 and 3). Back in the United States, public officials joined their constituents at the polls in New York (Slides 10 and 11), New Jersey (Slide 12) and elsewhere. And we end the presentation with the puzzling case of hair loss among two bears at a zoo in Germany (Slide 14).

headline: AT&T Declares Color War on Verizon
text: AT&T, the giant company with $124 billion in annual sales, has filed a federal lawsuit against its rival, Verizon. The issue: coloring, of the sort that you do in kindergarten.

headline: Iran’s Leader Faults U.S. ‘Arrogance’ in Nuclear Talks
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, lashed out at the United States in a speech on Tuesday, criticizing what he called an arrogant American attitude toward nuclear talks and saying the Obama administration had not followed through on its promises of change.

headline: What It Took to Sell a Book
text: My colleague Dwight Garner kicked off this blog two and a half years ago with a slide show of advertisements that he’d discovered in old copies of the Book Review. After that, his posts on vintage book ads became a semi-regular feature in Paper Cuts. And today his book on the subject hits stores: “Read Me: A Century of Classic American Book Advertisements.”

headline: Wall Street Journal to Add a New York Report
text: The Wall Street Journal plans to assemble a local news staff in New York, continuing to expand beyond its historic focus on business news by adding traditional city desk beats like courthouses, City Hall and the state capital.

headline: Submit Questions for A.C. Milan’s Clarence Seedorf
text: After a difficult start to the season, A.C. Milan has begun to climb the Italian Serie A table and earn impressive results in Europe, restoring the faith of the Rossoneri supporters and the confidence of the players.

headline: Radovan Karadzic’s Defense, the First Draft
text: On Tuesday in The Hague, my colleague Marlise Simons reports, the wartime leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, finally appeared at his trial — but only “to argue once again that he needed more time to prepare his defense against a list of grave charges, including genocide.”

headline: For Judges Standing By, a Quiet Election Day
text: There were plenty of people in the Manhattan training office of the New York City Board of Elections. There was lots of chatting and reading of newspapers and eating of chips and playing of Scrabble.

headline: Q&A: Napa and Sonoma in December
text: Q.

headline: On Our Radar…
text: 1.) Al Gore’s climate choice.

headline: At the National Trust
text: Richard Moe, the president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, is stepping down after 17 years in the post, the trust announced on Tuesday. Mr. Moe, 72, said he would stay on until a successor was named, which he expects will be by spring. During his tenure, the trust helped prevent Disney from building a theme park in the historic Northern Piedmont region of Virginia; championed the restoration of Lincoln’s cottage in Washington; encouraged the purchase at auction of the threatened Farnsworth House by Mies van der Rohe in Plano, Ill.; and focused on preserving the Gulf Coast after Hurricane Katrina. “I think we broadened the mission here significantly,” Mr. Moe said in a telephone interview, adding, “Preservation is much more on the American agenda than it was several decades ago.”

headline: World Series Is Winner
text: Game 5 of the World Series led Fox to a first-place finish on Monday night but ABC was a close second. Although Nielsen’s final ratings for the live baseball broadcast were not immediately available, preliminary estimates show it drew similar numbers as Saturday’s game, which earned 15.4 million viewers when final ratings were released. On ABC, a two-hour episode of “Dancing With the Stars” garnered an average of 16.2 million viewers, followed by “Castle” (9.7 million). CBS was third, drawing its largest audiences with the comedies “Two and a Half Men” (13.6 million) and “The Big Bang Theory” (12.7 million). NBC was fourth.

headline: A Composer Is Avenged
text: Peter Maxwell Davies, the British composer who holds the title of master of the queen’s music, said that he was delighted after his former manager was sentenced to 18 months in prison for defrauding him of more than $800,000, The Times of London reported. Michael Arnold, who managed Mr. Davies’s business affairs for more than 30 years, was arrested in 2007 and charged in October 2008 with false accounting; he admitted last year to having stolen the money. Mr. Davies, who has been honored this year with a global series of concerts marking his 75th birthday, said that he had stopped composing for a few weeks and had to borrow money from friends after learning of the fraud. On Monday, after the sentence was announced, he said he was glad the episode was over, adding: “I may even set it all to music. Who knows? That would be the ultimate revenge.”

headline: More Cat-And-Mouse in the Book Price Wars
text: The online price war that broke out last month among Wal-Mart, Amazon and Target took a new turn on Tuesday with Wal-Mart continuing to play the penny game. At first, Amazon appeared to be the low-price player when it extended its $9 price tag to three hardcover books that were officially released Nov. 3. Amazon had originally offered that price in response to price-cutting by Wal-Mart on its Web site for preorders of 10 titles that included the three that were released Tuesday: “Ford County” by John Grisham, “The Lacuna” by Barbara Kingsolver and “Kindred in Death” by J. D. Robb. As of Tuesday morning, Amazon still had those titles priced at $9 while Wal-Mart, which had offered them on preorder at $8.98, and Target, which had offered preorders for $8.99, had raised their prices. At Walmart.com, for example, “Ford County” was selling for $12, while “The Lacuna” was $13.50. At Target.com, “The Lacuna” was on sale for $18.89 and “Kindred in Death” was $17. But by late morning, Amazon had raised its prices  “The Lacuna” and “Kindred in Death,” for example, were offered for $13.50  while Walmart.com had cut them again. All three novels that went on sale Tuesday were on sale at Walmart.com for $8.99, but by the afternoon, Walmart.com had raised its prices to just one penny lower than the price for the three titles on Amazon. In an e-mailed statement, a spokeswoman for Walmart.com said that it would “continue to adjust our pricing accordingly and as needed on these books.”

headline: Arguments on Polanski Scheduled in California
text: A California appeals court in Los Angeles has scheduled oral arguments for Dec. 10 in its review of Roman Polanski’s three-decade-old sex-abuse case. Mr. Polanski and his lawyers have been asking the court to clear the way for consideration of claims that his case was tainted by judicial and prosecutorial misconduct, even though he has been a fugitive since 1978. Prosecutors have argued that Mr. Polanski, because of his fugitive status, has no standing to challenge his conviction. Mr. Polanski remains under arrest in Switzerland awaiting possible extradition to face sentencing in the United States. The appeals court could clear the way for a review of misconduct in the case, or could stand aside while the authorities here await his return.

headline: Robots for Adoption
text: Someday, as the movie and television series predicts, the Terminator robots, above, will become powerful enough to reduce the world to a pile of scrap metal and ash. But for now, they just need new owners. Variety reported that the Halcyon Company, which owns the rights to the “Terminator” movies and other related assets, plans to sell the franchise at an auction in January as it goes through bankruptcy. When Halcyon purchased the “Terminator” property for $30 million in 2007, it became the latest in a series of owners that previously included the producer Gale Anne Hurd and the production company Carolco, now defunct. The most recent entry in the film series, “Terminator: Salvation,” grossed $369 million worldwide on a budget of $200 million. The company’s founders, Derek Anderson and Victor Kubicek, told a bankruptcy court that the “Terminator” franchise was worth $70 million.

headline: President’s Arts Group Names 25 Members
text: An eclectic roster of artists and entertainment industry figures were named to the President’s Committee on the Arts and Humanities, the White House announced on Monday evening. Among the 25 committee members selected by President Obama were the talent agent Bryan Lourd, managing director and co-chairman of Creative Artists Agency; the actors Sarah Jessica Parker (top right) and Edward Norton; the cellist Yo-Yo Ma (top left); and Teresa Heinz Kerry, the philanthropist and wife of Senator John Kerry. Also named were the actors Kerry Washington, Forest Whitaker and Alfre Woodard; the director George C. Wolfe (above right); Anna Wintour (above left) of Vogue; Damian Woetzel, the former New York City Ballet dancer; and the architect Thom Mayne.

headline: Harlem Theater Founders to Resign
text: Alfred Preisser and Christopher McElroen, who founded the Classical Theater of Harlem and made it a home for the likes of Samuel Beckett, Euripides, Shakespeare and Melvin Van Peebles, will leave that Off Broadway theater company this month. In a news release, Mr. Preisser, who served as its artistic director, and Mr. McElroen, who has been its executive director, said that they created the Classical Theater of Harlem in 1999 to “nurture a new, young, and culturally diverse theater audience.”

headline: What Cole Hamels Really Meant
text: It has become another knock on Cole Hamels, the Phillies’ beleaguered left-hander who won the World Series most valuable player award last fall and has struggled this postseason. After Game 3, Hamels said, “I can’t wait for it to end. It’s been mentally draining.” And all sorts of people – including, perhaps, his teammate Brett Myers – have interpreted that as Hamels quitting on the season.

headline: Trying to Find Meaning in a Bolt From the Blue
text: In the wispy documentary “Act of God,” survivors of lightning strikes find metaphysical meaning in meteorological phenomena. The writer Paul Auster begs to differ.

headline: Performa 09 | Alterazioni Video and Ragnar Kjartansson
text: Adventurous audiences know to expect some intentionally elusive, off-kilter fare from Performa, the three-week biennial currently in its third edition in New York. But the Italian collective of Alterazioni Video and Ragnar Kjartansson offered something at least nominally classifiable in its free performance for a packed audience at Performance Space 122 on Monday evening: a concert. Specifically, “Symphony n. 1,” billed as “a live and multimedia piece based on joy, infinite profound joy.”

headline: More Tech for Older People
text: Last Thursday’s print and online article on tech solutions for older adults struck a chord with many readers, a number of whom wrote that the suggestions proved helpful in their quest to get their parents connected to the Internet.

headline: A Year After Obama’s Election, How Do You Feel?
text: One year ago, we asked NYTimes.com readers for a single word to describe their mood about the presidential election. The response was overwhelming (73,400 words) and varied widely, with “hopeful” and “anxious” as the top choices.

headline: ‘Million Dollar Quartet’ to Move Into the Nederlander
text: The next tenant for Broadway’s Nederlander Theater was announced late Tuesday afternoon: The new musical “Million Dollar Quartet,” based on a 1956 recording session that brought together Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins, and Elvis Presley.

headline: One Year In
text: Voters are voting today, and most pundits are punditing about what the races mean, especially what the big three — in New Jersey, Virginia and upstate New York — will say about Obama.

headline: A Return That Came Sooner, Not Later
text: The Boston Symphony Orchestra seems to be conducting a series of experiments to determine whether absence does, in fact, make the heart grow fonder. Its own music director, James Levine, is said to be testing the patience of the Boston audience with his particular brand of new-music programming, but this season he has been sidelined after surgery for a herniated disc. How fond his audience will be when he returns remains to be seen. But in the meantime, the orchestra ran a second, slightly more complicated test on Monday evening, when it performed at Carnegie Hall with Lorin Maazel on the podium.

headline: Hitching a Star to the Stardom of Cole Porter
text: Forty-five years after his death, Cole Porter has never truly left town. His songs are a staple of Manhattan’s cabaret scene: one performer finished a tribute at the Algonquin last month, while two others just opened shows that prominently feature his work.

headline: Achy, Breaky Heart but a Stiff Upper Lip
text: “This is a song for anyone with a broken heart,” Charlie Fink sang to start the set by his band, Noah and the Whale, at the Mercury Lounge on Monday. It was the first of three nights at the club for this English band. His voice was calm, and so was the music, a Celtic-tinged ballad with fingerpicking and fiddle. But it was the outward calm of depression, not of serenity.

headline: Creating Dialogue From Body Language
text: In “La Danse: The Paris Opera Ballet,” his 36th documentary in more than 40 years, Frederick Wiseman takes his camera into the stately and elegant Palais Garnier in Paris, observing rehearsals, staff meetings and, finally, performances of seven dances, including classics like “The Nutcracker” and spiky new work by younger choreographers. To say that the film, sumptuous in its length and graceful in its rhythm, is a feast for ballet lovers is to state the obvious and also to sell Mr. Wiseman’s achievement a bit short. Yes, this is one of the finest dance films ever made, but there’s more to it than that.

headline: Wonders of Science at the Golden Gate
text: SAN FRANCISCO  What should we expect from a science museum? Do we want to be carefully tutored in a scientific discipline? Do we seek to be entertained in a vaguely enlightening way? Do we hope to be urged to adopt particular policies or practices? My own desire is simpler than any of these, though far less often encountered. I hope for wonder.

headline: Religion’s Role in the Climate Challenge
text: A remarkable conclave of leading figures from nine of the world’s major religions is under way at Windsor Castle in Britain, under the auspices of Prince Philip and the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon. Called “Many Heavens, One Earth,” the meeting is intended to generate commitments for actions by religious organizations, congregants and countries that could reduce emissions of greenhouse gases or otherwise limit the human impact on the environment.

headline: Where’s the Agency? Freeman’s Shop Is No More
text: Cliff Freeman & Partners, one of the most successful New York advertising agencies of the 1980s and 1990s, is no more.

headline: G.M. Decides to Keep Opel Instead of Selling It
text: Update | 5:57 p.m. The new board of General Motors reversed course late Tuesday afternoon on the anticipated sale of the Opel division in Europe and decided that G.M. would retain the business and restructure Opel itself.

headline: G.M. Decides to Keep Opel, Its European Unit
text: DETROIT  The new board of General Motors reversed course Tuesday on the planned sale of its Opel division in Europe and decided that G.M. would retain and reorganize the business itself.

headline: G.M. to Retain Opel
text: Update | 6:34 p.m.  General Motors has confirmed that it will keep Opel and restructure the business itself, reports The Times’s Bill Vlasic. “This was deemed to be the most stable and least costly approach for securing Opel/Vauxhall’s long-term future,” Fritz Henderson, G.M.’s chief executive, said in a statement issued Tuesday evening.

headline: House Passes Gaza Measure After Dueling Critiques
text: The House on Tuesday approved a nonbinding resolution rebuking a United Nations report on last winter’s conflict in Gaza, after architects of both the U.N. report and the House resolution recently criticized the other’s work as inaccurate.

headline: It’s Nearly a Wrap for Hollywood Power Lunches at Orso
text: LOS ANGELES  Late last week the buzz around the tables at Orso, a film industry hangout since it opened here 20 years ago, was about, of all things, the imminent demise of Orso.

headline: Hard Drive Full? Archive Some Photos
text: The My Pictures folder on my Mac notebook holds a whopping 47.39 gigabytes of images. It’s nice to have so many photos of people, places and trips — except for the unfortunate fact that they consume about one quarter of my total hard drive space. And I am running very short on storage these days.

headline: A White House Chef Who Wears Two Hats
text: WASHINGTON

headline: App of the Week: 1Cast’s News-Video Aggregator
text: Getting TV news on your phone is a tricky business, as most mobile broadcastrs require a Wi-Fi connection. That’s not really mobile TV, that’s hot spot TV.

headline: A Renovation in Krakow That Evokes Its History
text: A duplex apartment in Krakow's city center is on the market for 1.4 million Polish zloty ($478,000).

headline: House Hunting in ... Krakow, Poland
text: A DUPLEX APARTMENT IN KRAKOW’S CITY CENTER

headline: Iraq Signs Contract to Develop Oil Field
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq formally signed a contract with a consortium of foreign oil companies Tuesday to develop its largest oil field.

headline: Wartime China’s Elegant Enigma
text: “The only thing Oriental about me,” Soong Mei-ling once wrote, “is my face.”

headline: Chrysler May Put On a New Badge
text: Chrysler is scheduled to detail its five-year sales plan Wednesday during a six-hour conference call with reporters. (Will bathroom breaks be permitted?) The automaker is getting ready to reinvent itself with a fresh look, and the first tweak could come in the form of a sleek new logo.

headline: Democrats Near Deal on Abortion Coverage
text: Struggling to finish their big health care legislation, House Democratic leaders signaled Tuesday that they were prepared to make several changes to the bill to satisfy abortion opponents, including many Democrats, who had threatened to block it.

headline: Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin to Host the Oscars
text: There will be dual hosts at the upcoming Academy Awards. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences just announced that Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin will co-host the event.

headline: Someone’s in the Kitchen With Michelle: The Secret Ingredient Is Politics
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Lower Wine Prices and a New Chef for Cru
text: Cru is lowering prices on its famous wine list by 30 percent across the board, said Robert Bohr, a partner in the restaurant. The prices will be cut by the end the week. And in two weeks the restaurant will have a menu from its new chef, Todd Macdonald.

headline: 3 Yemeni Officials, Along With Guards, Killed in Ambush
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Gunmen ambushed a government motorcade in the eastern Yemeni province of Hadramawt on Tuesday, killing three top provincial officials and three guards in an attack that had all the hallmarks of Al Qaeda’s regional arm.

headline: Time Inc. Layoffs Begin at Sports Illustrated
text: Layoffs have begun at Time Inc. Approximately 15 to 20 sales and marketing employees were dismissed from Time Inc.’s news group tonight, largely from Sports Illustrated, according to a Time Inc. executive who asked not to be named as the company had not given authorization to discuss the matter.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,347 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin to Host the Oscars
text: There will be dual hosts at the next Academy Awards. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences just announced that Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin will co-host the event.

headline: Live Blogging Election Night
text: The Caucus will be keeping tabs on election developments across the country tonight. Refresh the page often for the latest updates.

headline: Postcards From the Edge: Tocqueville’s Letters Home
text: Alexis de Tocqueville, the author of the landmark “Democracy in America,” was in many ways a typical Frenchman. Practically the minute he got off the boat, in Newport, R.I., on May 9, 1831, he started making generalizations: the only thing Americans really care about is making money. American women are good homemakers but boring wives. Southern men care more about honor than Northerners do. Americans drink no wine but stuff themselves with stupefying amounts of food.

headline: Tuesday’s News of Hockey, 11/3/09: Flames in H1N1 Vaccination Kerfuffle
text: Controversy flares in Alberta after Ken King, president of the Calgary Flames, reveals that the team’s players and their families received swine flu vaccinations at an undisclosed location on Friday through the intercession of the province’s health services board. The news comes as residents across Alberta have had to wait in lines or were unable to get H1N1 vaccination shots.

headline: Same Street, Different World: ‘Sesame’ Turns 40
text: IT is almost too perfect that the first African-American president of the United States was elected in time for the 40th anniversary of “Sesame Street.” The world is finally beginning to look the way that the PBS show always made it out to be.

headline: Cookbooks as Edible Adventures
text: LONG before Internet avatars, home cooks knew the way to self-transformation: cookbooks. Bonding with a new one means assuming a new identity, if only for a week or two.

headline: China Approves Disney Theme Park in Shanghai
text: LOS ANGELES  After a courtship of about 20 years, the Walt Disney Company has won approval from the central government of China to build a Disneyland-style theme park in Shanghai, Robert A. Iger, Disney’s chief executive, said Tuesday.

headline: ‘The Last Empress’
text: Chapter 1

headline: Groups Press U.S. and China on Carbon
text: BEIJING  Three prominent American research organizations that are pushing for greater cooperation between the Obama administration and China on the issue of climate change say the two governments should make a priority of supporting the use of carbon capture technology and the creation of a market for carbon.

headline: Africa’s Diamond Trade Under Scrutiny
text: JOHANNESBURG  The viability of an effort endorsed by the United Nations to halt the trading of the so-called blood diamonds that have fueled conflicts across Africa is on the line this week, and the test case is Zimbabwe.

headline: Student, 20, Jumps to His Death at N.Y.U.
text: A 20-year old student at New York University apparently took his own life on Tuesday morning, reviving concerns about the high number of suicides there in recent years.

headline: Fraud Accusations Against Florida Lawyer Set Off a Race to Return His Donations
text: MIAMI  Scott Rothstein relished his flashy persona  the spiky hair, the Ferrari, the multi-million-dollar mansion. He was Bronx raised, Fort Lauderdale rich, and the politicians, charities and businesses that accepted his money rarely asked where it came from.

headline: Lloyds and Royal Bank of Scotland Given More Aid
text: LONDON  A year after the financial crisis nearly upended the British banking industry, two major lenders here were thrown a second financial lifeline by the government on Tuesday and ordered to shrink their businesses.

headline: An Obama Relative Living in China Tells of His Own Journey of Self-Discovery
text: GUANGZHOU, China  Maybe it is the easy smile. Or perhaps the eyes, at once self-assured and searching. When Mark Okoth Obama Ndesandjo walks into the room, the similarities with President Obama, with whom he shares a father, are unmistakable if hard to pinpoint.

headline: New York City Goes to the Polls
text: The Times's Michael Powell takes a look at some of the issues motivating residents to vote.

headline: At Viacom, Profit Rises Primarily on Cutbacks
text: Viacom, the media company that controls MTV and Paramount Pictures, said its profit rose in the third quarter, but it was a performance achieved through cutting costs and shedding workers.

headline: Chinese Trial Reveals Vast Web of Corruption
text: CHONGQING, China  Wen Qiang had a fondness for Louis Vuitton belts, fossilized dinosaur eggs and B-list pop stars. For a public employee in charge of the local judiciary, he also had a lot of money: nearly $3 million that investigators found buried beneath a fish pond.

headline: Health Bills Aim a Light on Doctors’ Conflicts
text: As part of the health care overhaul under consideration by Congress, lawmakers have included so-called sunshine provisions intended to shed light on the financial relationships between the medical industry and doctors.

headline: Health Care Debate Focuses on Legal Immigrants
text: The debate over health care for illegal immigrants continues to percolate in Congress despite the Obama administration’s efforts to put it to rest, with lawmakers in both houses also wrangling over how much coverage to provide for immigrants who have settled in the country legally.

headline: Perhaps Some Pastries With Your Baubles? This Madison Avenue Boutique Can Help
text: François Payard, who closed his cafe, pâtisserie and bistro on the Upper East Side in June, has taken his talents to Mauboussin, the Parisian jewelry boutique on Madison Avenue, where he has opened a chocolate cafe on the fourth floor.

headline: Drop Those Chopsticks! Sushi Is Finger Food, He Says
text: Using chopsticks to eat sushi? Wrong, wrong, wrong, says Trevor Corson, the author of “The Story of Sushi” (originally published as “The Zen of Fish,” Harper Perennial, 2008). Mr. Corson, standing above, who calls himself a sushi concierge, is holding classes at Jewel Bako in the East Village to show Americans how to navigate the sushi bar as Japanese connoisseurs do.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Open Now

headline: Have a Sip of Seasonal Fruit
text: Hotlips Sodas from the Pacific Northwest do not make “good for you” promises, as some sodas do these days. They are made from fruit harvested in season and are lightly carbonated, sweetened with cane sugar and tarted up with a little organic lemon juice. Some flavors have a little murky fruit pulp in them.

headline: House Bill Would Assure Workers Paid Sick Days
text: In an effort to rein in the spread of the H1N1 flu, Representative George Miller, the chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, introduced legislation on Tuesday that would guarantee five paid sick days for workers sent home by their employers with a contagious illness.

headline: Recipe: Butternut Squash and Roasted Apple Soup
text: Adapted from Sam Kass

headline: The Daddy of All Rivals: Martinez Is Back
text: Apparently it is not just my own hyper sense of the bizarre that is stimulated by the presence of Petey.

headline: Through a Glass Less Darkly
text: In the fall of 1982, with a long recession ending but the unemployment rate heading toward 10 percent, The New York Times ran an article titled “The Recovery That Won’t Start.”

headline: Steve Martin and Alec Baldwin to Host the Oscars
text: LOS ANGELES  The coming Oscar show will have a pair of hosts who are not so much matched as deliberately mismatched: Steve Martin, the versatile comic, and Alec Baldwin, a straight man who sometimes reaches for a laugh.

headline: Pakistanis Seek Blame for Bombing
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  It has been a week since the bomb exploded at the women’s market here, but people still talk about the images of its aftermath: women’s bodies, naked and broken. A hand with hennaed nails. An arm still wearing bracelets.

headline: What to Make of a Big Deal Gone Sour
text: Early Tuesday, Suzanne Wasserman walked into the polling place on 18th Street at First Avenue in Manhattan, then voted in a flash, a straight Democratic ticket. And yes, she knew that it would take a colossal upset for her candidate, William C. Thompson Jr., to beat Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Buffett’s Bet on Trains
text: Updated, Nov. 4, 11:25 a.m. | Joining our discussion this morning are: T.J. Stiles, a biographer of Cornelius Vanderbilt; Jean Strouse, author of “Morgan, American Financier”; and Charles R. Morris, a former banker and the author of “The Sages: Warren Buffett, George Soros, Paul Volcker and the Maelstrom of Markets.”

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian
text: JOAQUIN BACA has cooked Asian-flavored noodles with David Chang at the Momofuku restaurants and has lived in the Philippines, Bolivia and Uruguay. But his roots are Texan, and he has never lost his touch with American comfort food: barbecued ribs, corn bread, chicken-fried steak.

headline: Civil Rights Groups Push for Public Option
text: Correction| 6:13 p.m., Nov. 5 An earlier version of this article gave the wrong age for the Urban League. It has been corrected below.

headline: Calendar
text: Fish Market as Art

headline: The Ultimate Consolation Prize
text: Mickey Mantle was crying. When Bobby Richardson flashes back to how Bill Mazeroski’s game-ending homer vaulted the Pittsburgh Pirates over the Yankees in the 1960 World Series, he remembers that Mantle wept. Richardson stared at his friend and teammate because he had never seen Mantle so distraught.

headline: Iraq Swears by Bomb Detector U.S. Sees as Useless
text: BAGHDAD  Despite major bombings that have rattled the nation, and fears of rising violence as American troops withdraw, Iraq’s security forces have been relying on a device to detect bombs and weapons that the United States military and technical experts say is useless.

headline: Congress Poised to Keep Homebuyers’ Tax Credit
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate and House are poised to agree on a compromise measure to extend unemployment benefits that also would expand a popular $8,000 tax credit for homebuyers, despite a recent government report on extensive mistakes and suspected fraud in the program.

headline: In the Shadow of Yankee Stadium, an Off Year
text: By all reckoning, this should be the moment Saeed Alawy was waiting for. His shop, Pin Stripe Collectibles, sits just beyond the right field wall of the new Yankee Stadium, where Game 6 of the World Series will be played Wednesday night.

headline: Damon Proves Toughest Out by Hitting It Fair and Foul
text: Johnny Damon stood on second base with two outs in the ninth inning of Game 5 and told Phillies third baseman Pedro Feliz not to worry about him.

headline: Sluggish Pace of Integration Still Echoes
text: The World Series between the Yankees and the Phillies has developed into an intricate matchup, with all sorts of revealing contrasts and surprises.

headline: The Matter of Phillies Closer Is Reopened to Question
text: Philadelphia Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel has referred to Brad Lidge as “our closer” no fewer than 900 times over the last two months, even on days Lidge does not even leave the bullpen bench to warm up while Ryan Madson pitches in a save situation.

headline: East River Commuter Ferry Service Could Be Halted, Again
text: For almost two years, city officials have extolled a proposal for a five-borough network of ferries, an ambitious plan that the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, said would make New York “a shining example of urban sustainability for cities all over the world.”

headline: Buffett Bets Big on Railroads’ Future
text: America’s best-known investor, Warren E. Buffett, is making his biggest bet yet on the nation’s economic future by buying, of all things, a railroad.

headline: The Earl Would Approve
text: LATELY, foods at the thrifty end of the dining spectrum have been reworked, renewed and sometimes completely reimagined: fried chicken, pizza and hamburgers have never tasted better.

headline: Harry Carson on Concussions
text: Harry Carson, the Hall of Fame middle linebacker for the Giants, said he had “about 10 concussions” when he played for the team in the 1970s and ’80s.

headline: Flu Shots for Students Begin Saturday
text: Beginning Saturday, middle and high school students can receive free swine flu vaccinations at weekend clinics throughout the city, health department officials said on Tuesday.

headline: A Pentagon Contract Revives Jobs at Oshkosh
text: OSHKOSH, Wis.  United States Patent No. 5,820,150, for a particular design of independent truck suspension, is just one of the dozens of patents the Oshkosh Corporation has filed in recent years. But as the military shifts its focus to Afghanistan from Iraq, that single invention is proving to be worth billions of dollars to the company and a potential lifesaver for American troops in Afghanistan.

headline: Hop Off the Wheel and Taste Paris
text: LE RELAIS DE VENISE L’ENTRECÔTE is a mouthful of a restaurant that opened a few months ago in a canyon at Lexington Avenue and 52nd Street, convenient mostly to hotel guests and hamsters on the Midtown professional wheel. It has no real menu to speak of. There is only salad and steak frites. Some wine to drink and a dessert after. Women in French maid outfits serve the stuff as if they were characters in an early Preston Sturges film. And you know what? It’s terrific.

headline: Chief Factor in Mayor’s Race: Bloomberg Influence
text: The White House switchboard lit up with calls from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s emissaries several weeks ago with a message that was polite but firm: The mayor is going to win re-election, they said. We think the president should stay out of the race.

headline: Difficulties for Prosecutors in Trial of Sect Leader
text: ELDORADO, Tex.  A year and a half after the state authorities raided a fundamentalist Mormon ranch here, the first of a half-dozen leaders of the sect has gone on trial on charges that he had sex with an under-age girl who state officials assert was one of several wives assigned to him by church elders.

headline: The Wild, the Innocent and the Springsteen Album Concerts
text: On tour this fall, Bruce Springsteen has been playing complete albums from his back catalog: for his shows last month bidding farewell to Giants Stadium, for example, he did “Born to Run,” “Darkness on the Edge of Town” and “Born in the U.S.A.” But that’s not all. On Tuesday Mr. Springsteen announced on his Web site that this weekend at Madison Square Garden he will be running through “The Wild, the Innocent and the E Street Shuffle” (Saturday’s show) and “The River” (Sunday) in their entirety, both for the first time.

headline: Honduras: Vote Postponed on Deal to End Crisis
text: Congressional leaders decided Tuesday to delay a vote on an accord signed last week that would restore the ousted president, Manuel Zelaya, and end the country’s four-month-old crisis. The leaders decided not to call Congress out of recess to vote on the agreement and requested opinions on it from the Supreme Court and the attorney general. Foreign governments have said they will not recognize the presidential election on Nov. 29 unless Mr. Zelaya is reinstated first.

headline: Toyota Pulls Out of Formula One
text: Update | 1:01 p.m.

headline: Kraft Earns $826 Million but Cuts Its Sales Forecast
text: Kraft Foods, the nation’s largest food manufacturer, reported quarterly profits that beat analysts’ expectations on Thursday, but at the same time cut its forecast for full-year revenue growth.

headline: G.O.P. Counters With a Health Plan of Its Own
text: WASHINGTON  House Republicans have come up with an answer to Speaker Nancy Pelosi, drafting an alternative health care bill that would reward states for reducing the number of uninsured, limit damages in medical malpractice lawsuits and allow small businesses to band together and buy insurance exempt from most state regulation.

headline: Outline of Republicans’ Health Care Vision
text: A draft of health care legislation by Republicans in Congress would make these changes in the insurance market:

headline: Zenyatta’s Chance to Dazzle in Cup Classic
text: ARCADIA, Calif.  Team Zenyatta got together the other night: the mare’s owners, Jerry and Ann Moss; her trainer, John Shirreffs, and his wife, Dottie, who manages the Mosses’ stables; and her rider, Mike Smith. They asked each other if they really wanted to do this, to throw their undefeated girl into the deepest end of the pool to take on the most accomplished boys in the thoroughbred world in the $5 million Breeders’ Cup Classic.

headline: License to Wonder
text: In the wake of my column last week about how the faces you make when speaking different languages might affect your mood, several people wrote and accused me of speculating. I admit it! Indeed, I said as much in the piece.

headline: No Walk in the Park: For Obama One Year Later, It’s the Slog of Governance
text: WASHINGTON  For a president elevated to power on the back of history, the tears and euphoria of Grant Park feel like a thousand years ago. It has been just one year, of course, since Barack Obama’s election, a year since that moment when supporters felt everything was possible amid lofty talk of “remaking this nation” and determined chants of “Yes, we can.”

headline: Profile of Virginia Voters
text: Results of exit polls conducted Tuesday in the race for Virginia governor between R. Creigh Deeds and Robert F. McDonnell.

headline: Profile of New York City Voters
text: Results of exit polls conducted Tuesday in the race for New York City mayor between Michael R. Bloomberg and William C. Thompson Jr.

headline: Profile of New Jersey Voters
text: Results of exit polls conducted Tuesday in the race for New Jersey governor between Jon S. Corzine, Christopher J. Christie and Christopher J. Daggett.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Record Seasonal Flu Shots Are Expected in U.S.
text: The United States will probably set a record for seasonal flu shots this winter, but there is continuing frustration over the slow rollout of swine flu shots, federal health officials said Tuesday.

headline: She’s Your Lover Now
text: My review this week is of a newish French place on Lexington Avenue and 52nd Street called Le Relais de Venise L’Entrecôte. It’s the first American outpost of a Paris institution (some would say tourist trap) that serves nothing but salad and steak frites. This is its great charm. The restaurant fights mightily against the tyranny of choice that so infects the world of restaurants in New York City. As David Carr — a media monster and Diner’s Journal consigliere — said in the place one night, leaning back in his chair and just getting started on the subject: “There are zero conversational hideyholes in this menu. I’m glad we’re friends and have something to talk about.” Have you been to the restaurant? Do you want to go? Tell us what you think below. Keep it clean. There are children present.

headline: A Vast Web of Crime
text: In the city of Chongqing, China, a mass public trial has exposed the unseemly relationship between gangsters, police officers and bureaucrats.

headline: Foreboding Cartoons?
text: The arrangement of black squares in this grid is unique, which I like. It makes the solving experience feel fresher since the words interlock and flow in directions a bit different from the norm.

headline: Democrats’ Fear: No Health Bill in 2009
text: Congressional Democrats and the White House seem increasingly nervous about the prospect that major health care legislation will not be completed by the end of this year.

headline: Toyota Exits Formula One
text: From our colleagues at Formula One:

headline: Illinois Curb on Minors’ Abortions Nears
text: CHICAGO  Illinois officials are expected to decide Wednesday when to begin enforcing a state law requiring doctors to notify a parent of anyone under 18 who seeks an abortion. The decision could prove to be a concluding chapter in the state’s debate, more than a quarter-century old, over parental notification.

headline: For a Men’s Body Lotion, a Rugged Messenger
text: IN a new television spot for Vaseline Men body and face lotion, Michael Strahan, the former New York Giants defensive end who stars on the Fox series “Brothers,” demonstrates a 15-minute workout in a hotel room, including push-ups and lateral jumps over rolled-up towels. Afterward, Mr. Strahan rubs lotion on his Popeye forearm.

headline: European Puck: Is Foppa Headed to Russia?
text: Russian news outlets reported on Tuesday that Peter Forsberg, the 36-year-old Swedish superstar, was on the verge of signing with the K.H.L. champions Ak Bars Kazan, adding to the intrigue over which club in which country Forsberg would land as he continues his comeback from chronic foot and ankle problems.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The exit polls were based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left election stations throughout New York City, New Jersey and Virginia on Tuesday.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission inspector general, H. David Kotz, into Bernard L. Madoff’s decades-long Ponzi scheme erroneously included one former S.E.C. chairman on a list of ex-chairmen interviewed by Mr. Kotz as part of his inquiry. Although he interviewed Arthur Levitt, William Donaldson and Christopher Cox, he did not interview Harvey Pitt. The error was repeated in a picture caption with the continuation of the article.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about a third-quarter expansion in the nation’s gross domestic product defined G.D.P. incorrectly. It is the government’s broadest measure of total goods and services produced  not the broadest measure of the government’s goods and services produced.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a decision by federal health officials to release the last of the national stockpile of liquid pediatric Tamiflu misstated the amount of time it would take the Indian company Cipla Ltd. to offer the United States a generic replacement. It is three to four months, not four to six weeks. (While Cipla has finished testing the powder used in capsules to ensure that the generic and brand-name versions are equivalent, its tests on the powder used in liquid suspensions are expected to take several months.)

headline: In Virginia, McDonnell Ends Democrats’ Streak
text: RICHMOND, Va.  Robert F. McDonnell, a Republican and a former state attorney general, won a decisive victory in Virginia’s governor’s race Tuesday, a stark reversal of fortune for Democrats who have held control in Richmond for the past eight years.

headline: Corrections
text: A music review on Tuesday about “Daryl Glenn and Jo Lynn Burks Play and Sing Robert Altman’s ‘Nashville,’ ” at the Metropolitan Room, misspelled the surname of a singer and songwriter who performed some of her own songs in the film “Nashville.” She is Ronee Blakley, not Blakely.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the success of the best-selling novel “The Help,” which included a comment from a co-owner of Rainy Day Books, an independent bookstore in Kansas, misidentified the town in which the store is located. It is Fairway, Kan., not Fairview.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about creationism and evolution in the Islamic world included an erroneous example for how views on these subjects might differ between countries with Shiite and Sunni majorities. The population in Iraq is majority Shiite, not Sunni, so that country is not a proper contrast with Iran, which also has a Shiite majority.

headline: Pakistanis View Market Blast With Disbelief
text: Even for Peshawar, a city that has long been pummeled by violent attacks, the bombing in the Meena market last week felt different; the violence was aimed not at soldiers or the police, but at poor women and children.

headline: Picked From a Lineup, on a Whiff of Evidence
text: HOUSTON  A dog’s sniff helped put Curvis Bickham in jail for eight months. Now that the case against him has been dropped, he wants to tell the world that the investigative technique that justified his arrest smells to high heaven.

headline: Corrections
text: The Second Opinion column on Tuesday, about new findings that raise questions about mammography, omitted part of the affiliation of Dr. Otis Brawley, who said the medical profession had overstated the benefits of cancer screening. He is chief medical officer of the American Cancer Society  not just “the society.”

headline: Corrections
text: A chart on Sunday with an article about academics on Facebook misspelled the given name of a Princeton professor with 1,938 Facebook fans (at the time the article went to press). He is Cornel West, not Cornell.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Rivera in Familiar Postseason Position
text: Joe Girardi said Tuesday that Mariano Rivera would be available to pitch more than one inning of Game 6 on Wednesday, which could have the effect of shortening the game to 21 outs for the Yankees, considering how reliable Rivera normally is.

headline: Tax Cuts and Recoveries
text: One big question about the 1983-84 economic boom (a boom I mention in my Wednesday column) is: Was it the tax cut?

headline: From Abandoned Brewery to Piazza, Philly-Style
text: PHILADELPHIA  When Bart Blatstein, a local strip-mall developer, acquired an abandoned brewery a few miles from Center City nearly a decade ago, the artists who had gravitated to the surrounding area in search of cheap housing feared he would plop an unwanted big-box shopping center into their gritty Northern Liberties neighborhood.

headline: Mayor Holds Onto Seat in Pittsburgh
text: Mayor Luke Ravenstahl of Pittsburgh won a resounding victory on Tuesday for his first full term.

headline: Exit Polls and Exit, Corzine
text: America — or least a few pockets of it — went to the polls on Tuesday, yet the politician facing the greatest test wasn’t on the ballot anywhere. So, did President Obama win or lose? Neither, according to a bunch of exit polls.

headline: Some Sense on Defense Spending
text: Presidents, and those aspiring to be presidents, routinely promise to reform the defense procurement process. And defense contractors, their lobbyists and the military services routinely ensure that never happens.

headline: Protection for Investors
text: Another day, another test of Congress’s will to reform the financial system.

headline: Driving Without English
text: Police officers giving drivers $204 tickets for not speaking English? It sounds like a rejected Monty Python sketch. Except the grim reality is that it has happened at least 39 times in Dallas since January 2007, according to The Dallas Morning News. At least six officers in several different patrol divisions wrote the tickets, each time citing a driver for violating a law that does not exist. All but one of the drivers were Hispanic.

headline: Questions for a Trade Official
text: When Islam Siddiqui appears for his Senate confirmation, possibly as early as next week, it will be time for some tough questions.

headline: The Lessons of the Good Teacher
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nation-Building at Home: A Call for Sacrifice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Christianity and Islam: An Egyptian View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Who Are You Calling a Narcissist, Rush?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Best Allies Money Can Buy
text: In 2003, I was on a trip to Iraq and had arranged an appointment in the Green Zone with a member of the then-Iraqi Governing Council. Security was tight. I was with my Iraqi translator, a middle-aged man who had once been a teacher. When we arrived at the council, after a long walk, I showed my ID to two young uniformed U.S. soldiers. They told me to wait, went inside and out came a man wearing civilian clothes, one of those fishing vests and an Australian bush hat.

headline: A Job Too Big for One Man
text: IN the year since his election, as he has since he first appeared on the national stage, Barack Obama has embodied the fundamental paradoxes of race in America: that we live in a still racially fragmented society; that we share a public culture with an outsized black presence, but that in the privacy of homes and neighborhoods we are more segregated than in the Jim Crow era; that we worship more fervently than any other advanced nation, in churches and synagogues that define our separate ethnic identities and differences, to gods proclaiming the unity of mankind. Why are we this strange way? Is President Obama the ultimate expression of our peculiarities? Has he made a difference? Can he? Will he?

headline: The Year of Living Postracially
text: ONE year ago today, we officially became a postracial society. Fifty-three percent of the voters opted for the candidate who would be the first president of African descent, and in doing so eradicated racism forever.

headline: Menino Coasts to Fifth Term as Boston Mayor
text: BOSTON  Mayor Thomas M. Menino easily won an unprecedented fifth term on Tuesday, relying on his popularity to neutralize charges that the city needed a change.

headline: Small Business Goes to Washington
Degas Pastel Is Highlight of a Tepid Christie’s Sale
text: French and Italian could be heard throughout Christie’s salesroom Tuesday night as the fall auction season began unsteadily: While there were some strong prices, there also expensive failures.

headline: Riding the Rails at a High Price
text: What does Warren E. Buffett see in railroads? Berkshire Hathaway, his investment company, is paying a big premium for Burlington Northern Santa Fe. Mr. Buffett says he thinks the business of transporting goods around the country is ready to rebound. But investors may want to delay hitching a ride on his caboose.

headline: Freedom From the Tyranny of Choice
text: Easy meals are what you want in this complicated time, right? Sam Sifton has one solution: Le Relais de Venise L’Entrecôte, “an assault on the tyranny of choice,” because it serves only a few things: salad, steak and fries. “The beef is fine,” he writes, the fries rate high on “the crazy-good scale” and the whole experience is “a perfect midweek dinner with a friend.” For more casual outings, visit the sandwich shops that Oliver Strand scouted out: Barros Luco for Chilean monsters like the beef empanada al horno; the Crosby Connection for classic New York monsters like the meatball hoagie; and the tiny Saltie in Williamsburg for outsize ambition. Run by three veterans of Marlow & Sons and Diner, it’s a high-achiever: the bread is baked in-house, the ice cream is made from scratch, and the sandwiches, like the vegetarian Clean Slate — quinoa and hummus with pickled vegetables, sauerkraut and yogurt in blistered naan — are culturally fearless.

headline: Culinary History
text: Curious about the history of the New York chophouse? William Grimes, a former restaurant critic of The New York Times, breaks it down  along with other tidbits like the oyster stalls and lobster palaces that were once dining mainstays  in his new book, “Appetite City: A Culinary History of New York.” “This vivid and vastly entertaining history,” Dawn Drzal writes in her review, chronicles the city’s “transformation from a Dutch village at the edge of the wilderness to what he sees as the most diverse restaurant city in the world.” Mr. Grimes reads from it tonight at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. For more arcana, head to the Union Square Barnes & Noble for a reading by John Hodgman, the veteran resident expert.

headline: Stiff Upper Lip
text: The English band Noah and the Whale closes out its three-night run at Mercury Lounge tonight. “They prize the stoicism of the British folk tradition, along with its fiddle tunes and vocal harmonies, without ruling out rock possibilities,” writes Jon Pareles. “Aching, unresolved, unironic heartbreak is at the core” of their songs, but it’s not overly emo: the singer, Charlie Fink, can sound like Lou Reed or Conor Oberst, and when they let loose, there’s psychedelic jamming and Springsteen-like antheming. Go Brittania.

headline: Dave Bing Wins Election to Full Term as Detroit Mayor
text: On Tuesday night, Dave Bing, a former National Basketball Association, star, won a full term for a job some people had wondered aloud why he would even wish for: mayor of Detroit, with a budget deficit of nearly $300 million, a dismal unemployment rate and a school system so troubled that an emergency financial manager has been called in.

headline: Conservative Loses Upstate House Race in Blow to Right
text: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y.  Democrats won a special election in New York State’s northernmost Congressional district Tuesday, a setback for national conservatives who heavily promoted a third candidate in what became an intense debate over the direction of the Republican Party.

headline: Microsoft Simplifies a Cluttered MSN
text: Three months after Yahoo revamped its home page, Microsoft will begin doing the same on Wednesday with the MSN portal.

headline: Phys Ed: Why Doesn’t Exercise Lead to Weight Loss?
text: For some time, researchers have been finding that people who exercise don’t necessarily lose weight. A study published online in September in The British Journal of Sports Medicine was the latest to report apparently disappointing slimming results. In the study, 58 obese people completed 12 weeks of supervised aerobic training without changing their diets. The group lost an average of a little more than seven pounds, and many lost barely half that.

headline: Showcase: Meet Richard Nixon
text: Richard Nixon, a 65-year-old retired Atlantic City firefighter, lives in Brigantine, N.J, with his wife. He said his name made him the subject of many jokes over 30 years in the firehouse, but it never got too vicious or mean spirited.

headline: Three Women Named to Board of Education
text: Thursday, Nov. 4, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: In October, Signs of Life at Retailers
text: October was far and away the best month American retailers have had since consumers put the brakes on spending last autumn. Major categories had robust sales growth for the first time in more than a year, new figures show.

headline: A New Mayor for Miami
text: MIAMI  Tomás Regalado easily defeated Joe Sanchez on Tuesday to become Miami’s next mayor, after promising voters a “back to basics” approach focused on improving city services and reining in developers.

headline: Pakistan Backs Off Amnesty Bill
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani government said Tuesday that it would not push an amnesty bill that would shield political leaders from corruption cases, a day after its closest political allies withdrew their support.

headline: Pakistanis Seek Blame for Bombing
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — It has been a week since the bomb exploded at the women’s market here, but people still talk about the images of its aftermath: women’s bodies, naked and broken. A hand with hennaed nails. An arm still wearing bracelets.

headline: Mayor No Longer Seems Invincible
text: For the first time in years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg finds himself governing New York City from a most unaccustomed vantage point: Vulnerability.

headline: For the Phillies, Charted Ground
text: The Philadelphia Phillies’ burden remains formidable: to complete a comeback from a 3-1 deficit in the World Series, they must win Games 6 and 7 on the road. Nevertheless, they would not be the first team to pull it off.

headline: Now Starring, Off Broadway and in the Peloton
text: EVEN on a bike, Mark-Paul Gosselaar can’t always ride away from his résumé.

headline: Dogs, Forensic Science and ‘Scent Lineups’
text: The story in today’s Times about dog-scent lineups describes a controversial forensic method of using trained dogs to link suspects suspect to crimes through “scent lineups.” The practice has come under criticism — in part because of the potential for cross-contamination of scents and bias affecting the result, either intentionally or through the dogs’ perception of the humans’ attention to the container with the suspect’s scent in it.

headline: Bloomberg’s Victory Speech
text: Below is the text of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg‘s victory speech on Thursday night, delivered at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers in Midtown Manhattan, as transcribed by The New York Times.

headline: Looking Smart
text: WHO is Danny Clark?

headline: Bloomberg Wins Election
text: Incumbent Michael R. Bloomberg's acceptance speech.

headline: N.H.L. Scores: What Happened to the Original Six?
text: Five games on Tuesday night, with five of the so-called Original Six in action. Late last summer, this season was being touted in some quarters as being all about the Original Six teams. But as the pucks were dropped on Tuesday, Detroit, Boston, Montreal and Toronto were all suffering; the Rangers, who had started strong, were slumping; and the only team not playing, Chicago, was the only old club consistently living up to its billing.

headline: Sought-After Speaker, With Script Outlines From Eli Lilly
text: In the first half of this year, the drug giant Eli Lilly paid 3,971 doctors and other medical professionals an average of about $11,230 each. The payments were for participating in an average of 12 speaking or consulting engagements during those six months, according to a company spokeswoman.

headline: G.O.P. Wins Two Key Governors’ Races; Bloomberg Prevails in a Close Contest
text: Republicans swept contests for governor in New Jersey and Virginia on Tuesday as voters went to the polls filled with economic uncertainty, dealing President Obama a setback and building momentum for a Republican comeback attempt in next year’s midterm Congressional elections.

headline: Word of the Day | functionary
text: functionary • \ˈfəN(k)-shə-ˌner-e\ • noun

headline: A Year After Dousing, Republicans’ Hope Rekindled
text: WASHINGTON  The Republican victories in the races for New Jersey and Virginia governors put the party in a stronger position to turn back the political wave President Obama unleashed last year, setting the stage for Republicans to raise money, recruit candidates and ride the excitement of an energized base as the party heads into next year’s midterm elections.

headline: Riding the Rails at a High Price?
text: What does Warren E. Buffett see in railroads? Berkshire Hathaway, his investment company, is paying a big premium for Burlington Northern Santa Fe, Breakingviews says. Mr. Buffett says he thinks the business of transporting goods around the country is ready to rebound. But investors may want to delay hitching a ride on his caboose.

headline: Race for Seattle Mayor Is Too Close to Call
text: SEATTLE  Early returns in the contest for mayor of Seattle showed a tight race, with Mike McGinn, an environmentalist, holding a narrow lead over Joe Mallahan, a businessman.

headline: California’s Democrat Is Elected to Congress
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Lt. Gov. John Garamendi of California, a Democrat, easily won election to Congress on Tuesday night, outpolling a little-known Republican in a suburban and largely liberal district east of San Francisco.

headline: News Quiz | November 4, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Early Vote Favors Domestic Partner Law
text: SEATTLE  Early returns showed voters in Washington narrowly approving a ballot measure that would expand legal protections for domestic partners.

headline: Italy Convicts 23 Americans for C.I.A. Renditions
text: MILAN  In a landmark ruling, an Italian judge on Wednesday convicted a base chief for the Central Intelligence Agency and 22 other Americans, almost all C.I.A. operatives, of kidnapping a Muslim cleric from the streets of Milan in 2003.

headline: At Johnson & Johnson, Merger-style Savings
text: Johnson & Johnson has found merger-size savings — in itself. The health care giant will eliminate about 8,000 jobs. But the benefits are likely to be as fleeting as the cuts accompanying most giant pharmaceutical mergers, Breakingviews says. That is because it is increasingly tough to find new drugs to replace lost revenue as sales of old products run down.

headline: 10gen Takes $3.4 Million
text: 10gen, the open-source database start-up, has obtained $3.4 million in a second-round of funding, led by Flybridge Capital Partners, VentureBeat reported.

headline: Buffett Said to Join Goldman Bid for Tax Credits
text: Just because Warren E. Buffett has been working on his railroad, doesn’t mean he’s taken his eye off other investment opportunities.

headline: Morgan Stanley Said to Shop Around C.I.C.C. Stake
text: Morgan Stanley is soliciting bids for its stake in China International Capital Corporation, the first Sino-foreign investment bank, three people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: Global Banking Fears Lead to Mixed Results
text: Wall Street wobbled on Tuesday amid indications that the global economy, particularly the banking sector, might be more frail than investors had believed. But positive sales reports from automakers stoked investors’ hopes in the final hours of trading, The New York Times’s Javier C. Hernandez.

headline: Bloomberg’s Campaign Spending Hampers Returns
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pulled out a narrow re-election victory on Tuesday, undermined in part, it seems, by the billionaire founder of Bloomberg L.P.‘s extravagant campaign spending against his vastly underfinanced challenger, William C. Thompson Jr.

headline: End of Fight Over Skype May Be Near
text: The bitter battle over the future of the Internet calling service Skype appears to be nearing an end.

headline: Cisco and EMC Form Venture to Serve Data Centers
text: Cisco Systems took another step to expand its computer hardware businesses on Tuesday by forming a broad partnership with EMC, a maker of storage equipment and software.

headline: Rajaratnam Said to Plan to Keep Sri Lanka Assets
text: Raj Rajaratnam, the biggest investor in Sri Lanka’s stock market, has no immediate plans to sell his holdings in the south Asian nation after insider-trading charges in the United States, a person familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

headline: Troop Deaths in Afghanistan Stir Outcry in Britain
text: This article is by Alissa J. Rubin, John F. Burns and Taimoor Shah.

headline: Delphi Names New Board Members
text: Update | 7:32 a.m. Delphi, the auto-parts maker that emerged from a four-year bankruptcy in October, on Wednesday announced the appointment of its new board members, led by the retired chief executive of Dupont, John A. Krol, as chairman.

headline: Landry’s O.K.’s $1.2 Billion Management Buyout
text: The chairman and chief executive of Landry’s Restaurants finally got what he was after Tuesday, as the restaurant owner’s board approved his $1.2 billion all-cash offer to buy the company.

headline: Attacking Corzine’s Wall St. Ties, Christie Wins Race
text: While Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s use of his personal wealth in his campaign for a third term in New York put a heavy dent in his margin of victory, Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s ties to business appeared to have helped unseat him entirely in New Jersey.

headline: Hedge Funds to See Less Seed Money
text: Despite reports of a surge in new hedge funds in 2009, those seeking to hang up their own shingle may be disappointed by a report that says institutional investors plan to allocate 44 percent less in seed capital for the rest of the year.

headline: Now Pay-Per-Viewing | The Ace for Adults
text: What at most hotels is a dirty (and lucrative) little secret, Ace Hotels has turned into another opportunity to explore the zeitgeist. The Portland-based chainlet recently announced it has struck a deal with Butt magazine, the pink-papered gay quarterly, to curate 16 homoerotic films for the video-on-demand service at its New York and Palm Springs, Calif., properties. Selected by the Butt staff writer Adam Baran, the video selections will include a range of rare and historic adult movies — some in 3-D! — that are in keeping with the magazine’s mission: to make titillation a cultural experience. A fixture in shops like Opening Ceremony, Butt regularly features the notable (Edmund White, Gus Van Sant) and the anonymous (Angel the Dominican carpenter) in various states of undress, which makes the Ace partnership no surprise. Since its start, the brand has aligned itself with independent tastemakers: Pearl’s Plus, Surface to Air, Arkitip, Doc Martens and Crush Fanzine are a few current collaborators keeping Ace among the avant-garde.

headline: Dissidents Mass in Tehran to Subvert an Anti-U.S. Rally

headline: Fill in the Blank: 10 Things ______ Should Never Do
text: In a post on the “You’re the Boss” blog, Bruce Buschel writes Part One of a list of “100 Things Restaurant Staffers Should Never Do.” What would you include if you were to create a list called “Ten Things Parents Should Never Do” or “Friends Should Never Do”? Fill in the blank with the role of your choice — whether “siblings,” “boyfriends,” “substitute teachers” or anything else. “Herewith is a modest list of dos and don’ts for servers at the seafood restaurant I am building,” begins this post. Here are the first five on his list:

text: Amid continuing reports of insider trading and Ponzi schemes linked to hedge funds, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday it had named Norm Champ, a hedge fund general counsel, to lead its New York examinations group.

headline: Berlin Wall Returns, in Human Form
text: BERLIN | At 8:27 p.m. on Nov. 9, 1989, the Berlin Wall was breached, parting the Iron Curtain to the joy of both East Berliners and the rest of the world.

headline: Buying a Business Instead of Starting One
text: Sam was typical of many aspiring entrepreneurs. He had a paper route as a kid and worked for several companies as a young man, including J.C. Penney, where he discovered a passion for retail. After college and a stint in the armed services, he decided to pursue the path of business ownership. Rather than start a business from scratch, he borrowed $20,000 from his father-in-law, added it to $5,000 he had in savings and bought an existing franchise location, a Ben Franklin general merchandise store.

headline: A Setback in Maine for Gay Marriage, but Medical Marijuana Law Expands
text: In a stinging setback for the national gay-rights movement, Maine voters narrowly decided to repeal the state’s new law allowing same-sex marriage.

headline: BofA’s General Counsel Wasn’t Legal, Report Says
text: Adding another a layer of complication to Bank of America‘s legal woes surrounding its deal to buy Merrill Lynch, the Charlotte, N.C. bank’s general counsel at the time the deal was being signed wasn’t authorized to practice law, The New York Post reported.

headline: Kraft Says It Won’t Overpay for Cadbury
text: Kraft Foods said it would not overpay for the British chocolatier Cadbury on Tuesday after disappointing investors by posting weaker-than-expected quarterly revenue and cutting its full-year sales forecast.

headline: The 7 Survival Habits of Byzantium
text: Today’s idea: The Byzantine Empire, which outlasted the western Roman Empire by centuries, points the way to preserving Pax Americana now, a historian says — through diplomacy and subterfuge rather than full-scale war.

headline: Inside the Beltway, With Baby Aboard
text: Buses are a frugal traveler’s best friend — cheap, ubiquitous and reliable. Except when they’re not, and then they’re a nemesis — slow and unpredictable. Things get worse when you factor in a seatmate, who might intrude on your personal space, insist on chitchatting or, most horrific of all, scream, squirm and throw Cheerios on the floor.

headline: Amazon Video vs. Netflix: Which Will Prevail?
text: Which business model for watching movies online will be the winner? Paying upwards of $8 a month for unlimited and instant online access to an older catalog of films and TV shows from a company like Netflix? Or paying $2 to $3 a film for access to newer releases from a service like Amazon‘s Video on Demand?

headline: Clinton Backs Peace Talks Before Israeli Settlement Freeze
text: CAIRO  Winding up a Middle East tour, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton repeated on Wednesday that while the Obama administration rejects the legitimacy of Israeli settlement expansion, it nonetheless believes that Israeli-Palestinian negotiations should precede a permanent freeze on such construction.

headline: Scripps to Buy Control of Travel Channel
text: Update | Nov. 5, 8:21 a.m. Scripps Networks said Thursday that it was buying a controlling stake in the Travel Channel, in a deal valuing the network at $975 million. It will own 65 percent of a new joint venture controlling Travel Channel, while current parent Cox Communications will own 35 percent.

headline: In a World of Automatics, a Rare Shift for Mazda
text: The Mazdaspeed 3 has a stylish exterior, a punchy turbocharged 4-cylinder engine and a transmission certain to strike fear into the hearts of many American drivers. You get a lot of car for your money with a Mazdaspeed 3, but no amount of checked option boxes or dealer haggling will get you an automatic transmission.

headline: Brooklyn Woman Finds Counterfeit Penny Made of Gold
text: One afternoon in March 2007, Jack Daws stepped up to a newsstand in Los Angeles International Airport with a handful of change, including a counterfeit penny made of 18-karat gold that Mr. Daws, a Seattle artist, had fashioned. He carefully put the counterfeit penny, dated 1970, down on the counter, counted out enough change to pay $11.90 for a Hustler magazine and left.

Schwartz, David Jolly and Bill Vlasic reported.

headline: Interactive: Assessing Barack Obama
text: A year after Barack Obama was elected president, he is juggling many of the issues that defined his candidacy — and then some. He is in the middle of lengthy debate over whether to expand the war in Afghanistan, and he continues to press for an overhaul of the health care system. While it will be years before it is possible to gauge the success of his governing agenda, Times reporters in an interactive feature offer assessments of his record on some of the issues so far.

headline: Bloomberg’s Influence May Be Diminished
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s strikingly thin margin of victory in Tuesday’s election could affect his influence. He ended election night in possession of a surprisingly modest margin of victory, five percentage points — far narrower than pollsters had predicted and with 100,000 fewer votes than he won in 2005. Voters seemed irritated by the term limits extension and his vast campaign spending.

headline: Canine Fill-In

The news outweighed investor optimism after the Federal Reserve said it planned to keep interest rates at a record low.

headline: Now Accessorizing | House of Waris
text: Waris Ahluwalia’s obsession with birds began at the Raphael Hotel in Paris — in the bathroom of Room 502, to be exact. “I fell in love with a bird on the wallpaper,” he says. (The hotel made a cameo in his friend Wes Anderson‘s prequel to “The Darjeeling Limited.) “And I realized that birds could be the perfect way to explore the fine, detailed work of enameling and pavé.” He designed six avian jewels under his House of Waris label and named them after famous love-seeking literary characters. Liberté, the diamond and gold peacock shown here, is $3,800 at Barneys New York.

headline: Wednesday Reading

headline: ‘Red Shoes’ Stirs Martin Scorsese’s Cinematic Passion

In between wrapping up work on a new film, “Shutter Island,” and starting production on an HBO series, “Boardwalk Empire,” Mr. Scorsese has found time for another passion project: extolling the virtues of a newly restored print of “The Red Shoes,” Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger‘s classic 1948 film about the intersecting desires of a young dancer, an aspiring composer and an unrelenting ballet impresario.

It would be a little bigger than Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., and on par with the parks in Paris and Tokyo. It is expected to open in five or six years. Read the full story.

headline: Gay Rights Rebuke May Change Approach

Yet gay rights supporters suffered a crushing loss when voters decided to repeal Maine’s new law allowing gay men and lesbians to wed, setting back a movement that had made remarkable progress nationally this year.

headline: Voters Roll Back Democratic Gains in New York Suburbs

headline: Following Up on Whether We Must Vote
text: On yesterday’s post about whether we should support nonpartisan efforts to get people to vote, some comments accuse me of “elitism” (No. 52), of being “against universal suffrage” (No. 26) and disdaining “the poor, young and nonwhite” (No. 99) — charges I repudiate utterly. But the way to muster those with whom we have fellow-feeling is not by some vague admonition to vote, not by some airy appeal to good citizenship, but by proposing ways to make their lives — our lives — better, or, as I wrote early in yesterday’s post: by rallying “support for a person or a policy you esteem.”

headline: Michael Jackson Takes ‘It’ to the Top
text: After dominating record sales for four months, Michael Jackson is finally at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. “Michael Jackson’s This Is It,” the companion album to the new movie — Epic, the label, is being careful not to call it a soundtrack, since it is mostly made up of old hits — sold 373,100 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Although Jackson has sold more than 5.6 million albums since his death in June, most of those titles have been too old to count on the Billboard 200, the standard album chart. But “This Is It” is a new title, and it becomes Jackson’s sixth No. 1; the film was the top box office draw last week, taking in $32.5 million in its first five days in the United States.

headline: Bloggers Back Behind the Shield?
text: Decoder wrote a bit about bloggers being left out of the federal shield law as the bill went through the process in a series of negotiations, but a spokesman for Senator Charles Schumer sent along a message that citizen journalists and bloggers would now be part of the legislation under consideration.

headline: Claude Lévi-Strauss, 100, Dies; Altered Western Views of the ‘Primitive’
text: Claude Lévi-Strauss, the French anthropologist whose revolutionary studies of what was once called “primitive man” transformed Western understanding of the nature of culture, custom and civilization, has died at 100.

text: In 2005, Michael S. Dell’s namesake company was getting pounded. His competitors were selling personal computers and servers built on cheap, popular and powerful chips from Advanced Micro Devices, while Mr. Dell had stuck loyally with slower chips from Intel.

headline: Not All Is Rotten in Denmark: ‘Hamlet’ Recoups
text: The current Broadway production of “Hamlet” no longer needs to concern itself with borrowers or lenders — the play has fully recouped its costs, its publicists said on Wednesday. In a news release, press representatives for “Hamlet,” which began previews at the Broadhurst Theater on Sept. 12 and opened on Oct. 6, said that it had earned back its initial Broadway capitalization of $2.5 million as of the week ending Nov. 1. The play, directed by Michael Grandage, is the latest in a series of hits that have transferred to Broadway from the Donmar Warehouse in London, which also yielded “Frost/Nixon” and “Mary Stuart.” The success of “Hamlet” might also have something to do with its star, Jude Law, who plays the melancholy Danish prince, and who has admirably held his own in a celebrity-filled season of Broadway neighbors like Daniel Craig and Sienna Miller. The limited run of “Hamlet” is to end on Dec. 6.
