text: Michael Psilakis works with local ingredients — in Crete.

headline: U.S. Diplomat Meets Myanmar’s Top Dissident and Urges Junta to Work With Her
text: BANGKOK  A senior American diplomat who completed a rare visit to Myanmar on Wednesday said that Washington would improve relations with the nation if its military government embraced reconciliation with Myanmar’s democratic opposition.

headline: Party’s Over: A New Tone for Chrysler

headline: Grant Could Assist Acquisition of Poet’s Papers
text: The papers of the poet Siegfried Sassoon are likely headed to Cambridge University following a grant from a British national fund for emergency acquisitions, BBC News reported. On Wednesday, the National Heritage Memorial Fund in Britain said that it would give about $900,000 toward the purchase of Sassoon’s archives, which includes notebooks he kept on the Western Front during World War I, as well as correspondence, poetry books, photographs and love letters to his wife, Hester. Sassoon, who dealt with the human toll of war in poems like “They” and “Suicide in the Trenches,” volunteered for military service just before Britain’s entrance into World War I, and was a decorated soldier before he refused to return to duty in 1917. (A manuscript of his statement of refusal is among the items contained in the archive.) In June, several authors including Sebastian Faulks and Sassoon’s official biographer, Max Egremont, started a campaign to acquire the poet’s papers following the death of Sassoon’s son George in 2006. With the grant, Cambridge is about $180,000 short of the estate’s asking price of about $2 million for the archive.

headline: Kosegare
text: The name given to a network of young farmers in Japan – used to mean, “farmer’s son.”

headline: Time Inc. Closes Fortune Small Business

headline: The Beatles Have Something Else to Sell You
text: If, when the Beatles released the remastered versions of their albums in September, you withstood the pressure to buy the stereo and mono boxed sets that contained their entire catalogs, your patience is about to be rewarded, sort of. Apple Corps Ltd. and EMI Music said that they were releasing a limited edition USB drive that contains the stereo versions of the Beatles’ albums, as well as the bonus materials that were included in their re-release, including short documentary films about the creation of the studio albums, photos and expanded liner notes. For the tech heads, the companies said that the audio files on the 16-gigabyte drives were in FLAC 44.1 Khz 24 bit and MP3 320 Kbps formats, and compatible with PC and Mac. For the people holding the credit cards, they said the drives would be sold at the Beatles’ online store for $279.99 and would be released in North America on Dec. 8. The USB drive’s design is presumably intended to evoke the Apple Corps. logo, and not the rotten fruit tossed by the villainous Apple Bonkers in “Yellow Submarine.”

headline: OLED TV Waits in the Wings
text: Anyone who’s seen an OLED TV display will be forgiven for thinking that they’ve wasted their money on an LCD or plasma set. A picture created using OLED technology is simply extraordinary, with deep, rich blacks and an extremely sharp image.

headline: On Comic-Con Web Site, a Tribute to a Founder

(“I just got lucky,” went his ritualistic response to almost any inquiry he got about it during a screening event of “The Red Shoes” at the DGA Theater.) But as soon as we said the words “30 Rock” and “Germany” to him, he knew what we were talking about.

headline: Groups Urge Opening of Vacant Condos to the Poor

headline: Barred for Drugs, Horse Trainers Return to Track
text: ARCADIA, Calif.  In 2007, Kentucky racing officials found cobra venom, a powerful painkiller, in the barn of Patrick Biancone, a horse trainer with prestigious victories from Hong Kong to France. He was barred from the sport for a year. Steve Asmussen, the nation’s leading trainer, served a six-month suspension in 2006 after one of his horses failed a drug test in Louisiana, and is appealing another six-month suspension handed down in Texas for another medication violation.

headline: Legislature Passes Historic Water Deal
text: As Colin Sullivan, Greenwire’s West Coast correspondent reports, the all-night session that started in the state Senate and ended in the Assembly authorized, among other things, an $11.14 billion bond issue to finance water projects.

headline: Fiorina Will Challenge Boxer in Senate Race
text: Carly Fiorina, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard who became a campaign adviser to Senator John McCain’s presidential bid, is formally announcing on Wednesday that she plans to run for the United States Senate.

headline: Answers About New York City Politics
text: Here is the first set of answers from Bruce F. Berg, a professor and the author of “New York City Politics: Governing Gotham,” (Rutgers University Press).

headline: G.O.P. Leader Relishes Victories
text: “The Republican renaissance has begun.”

headline: A New Way to Comment on Motherlode
text: Motherlode would not exist without you and your comments. That is where the real conversation happens, and where all the wisdom is shared.

headline: Playwright and Director in a Single Hair Shirt
text: PLAYWRIGHTS can easily run into challenges when they direct their own work. It’s hard to be objective when scenes aren’t clicking, dialogue is dragging, or actors question the play. But for Kenneth Lonergan the last few weeks of directing his drama “The Starry Messenger” have included moments of frustration and hope that go beyond the usual bumps of steering a new piece toward opening night.

headline: Good Sport: Creating Handbooks About Athletics
text: Overview | Why do people challenge themselves to participate in endurance sporting events? How can athletes-in-training keep their bodies healthy and injury-free? How do athletics engage and affect the body? In this lesson, students consider New York City Marathon runners and apply the principles of perseverance, endurance, health and training to other sports.

headline: Kouchner Urges Stronger Afghan Role for Europe
text: PARIS  Europe should take the opportunity of a new Afghan administration to coordinate its policies on Afghanistan and not wait for Washington to make all the decisions, the French foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner, said on Wednesday.

headline: S.E.C. Likely to Charge More People in Galleon Case
text: Update | 4:56 p.m. The Securities and Exchange Commission is likely to bring charges against additional defendants in its wide-ranging insider-trading case against Raj Rajaratnam, left, and his hedge fund firm, the Galleon Group, an agency lawyer said at a court hearing on Wednesday.

headline: Should India Worry About Jobs?
text: MYSORE, India –- American economists and policy makers are not alone in worrying about where jobs will come from in the future.

headline: What Are the Best Children’s Museums in the Bay Area?
text: When I take my kids to museums, I remember Joan Didion writing about her then 7-year-old daughter running to a Georgia O’Keeffe canvas at Chicago Institute of Art. In my mind, I conflated that essay with Ms. Didion’s on the old Getty Museum in Malibu and imagined the young girl running among the antiquities. No lines. No rules. No faux interactivity. Just going where her interests took her.

headline: Economists Concur on Threat of Warming
text: A New York University School of Law survey found near unanimity among 144 top economists that global warming threatens the United States economy and that a cap-and-trade system of carbon regulation will spur energy efficiency and innovation.

headline: SEMA Trends: That’s a Wrap
text: LAS VEGAS — Ever admire the look of the “Gravedigger” monster truck and wish you could get the same shiny, attention-grabbing treatment on the family’s Honda Odyssey?

headline: Handicapping the House Republicans’ Health Bill
text: House Republicans put forward their version of health care legislation on Tuesday, and Democrats immediately slammed it as too little, too late.

headline: Video of Protests in Iran on Anniversary of Embassy Seizure
text: As state-sponsored demonstrations in Iran on Wednesday marked the 30th anniversary of the seizure of the United States Embassy in Tehran by militants, a fresh wave of anti-government protests shook the streets of the capital and other cities across the country.

headline: Some Plays Can Twinkle Without Stars
text: WE live in a blockbuster age, when bigger is widely assumed to be better, or at least more important. Despite the clear failures of banks deemed too big to fail, it appears regulation will not stem the flow of steroids in the financial industry. The top-grossing movies have become a regular feature of news reports, encouraging Hollywood’s natural affection for megahits. We can now anxiously compare the growing totals of our Internet intimates on Facebook.

headline: Some Familiar Names Give Way to the New Faces
text: The N.B.A. has its own circle of life: as new blood enters the league, players must leave in order to make room. Look closely at the league rosters and you’ll notice a few familiar names that are nowhere to be found. Some have migrated to Europe to continue their careers. Others are waiting by the phone, hoping to nab one of the few roster spots that remain. A few have hung ’em up for good, and are now in search of a good rocking chair.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: 1. Why economics Nobel laureates say they first decided to study economics.

headline: Finding New Meaning in a Pageant of Dreams
text: EARLY in the first act of the new Broadway revival of the 1998 musical based on E. L. Doctorow’s novel “Ragtime,” arriving immigrants troop through an abstract, high-vaulted structure that evokes Ellis Island. So when it came time to arrange a photo shoot of the creative team behind the show, which opens Nov. 15 at the Neil Simon Theater, the real Ellis Island seemed the logical place to go.

headline: A New Comments Tool for At War
text: Since we launched the At War blog in August, we have tried to encourage and cultivate lively and informative discussions with you, our readers. From week to week we have been thrilled with your responses on our posts and regular features, such as Ask John Burns and Capt. Tim Hsia’s A Soldier Writes columns. With your comments, you have created one of the most important aspects of the blog: an incredibly engaging and enlightening conversation.

headline: J.P. Morgan Settles Alabama Bribery Case
text: J. P. Morgan Securities will forfeit hundreds of millions of dollars in fees on derivatives contracts that it sold an Alabama county, under a settlement announced Wednesday that could offer hope to other governments staggering under similar deals.

headline: A New Way to Comment on Moral of the Story
text: One way I see my task with Moral of the Story is to host a kind of salon. I choose a topic and write an opening statement, and the readers take it from there, discussing it among themselves in the comments section.

headline: And Now for Gordon Ramsay, a Cooking Competition Show
text: Too many cooks might spoil the broth, but there seems to be no such thing as too many cooking reality shows. Fox Broadcasting announced Wednesday that Gordon Ramsay, the British chef who already oversees “Hell’s Kitchen” and “Kitchen Nightmares” on the network, will host a new culinary competition series featuring people “who simply cook as a hobby and have absolutely no experience in the food industry.”

headline: PayPal Seeks New Ways to Use Its Payment System
text: PayPal, which transformed the way people pay on the Web, is about to have much bigger reach online.

headline: Koslowitz Will Return to City Council
text: She was one of the most visible members of the City Council, opposing topless bars, high-rise development, and gender-related price discrimination in businesses like hair salons and dry cleaners.

headline: The Scene on Halloween
text: We’ve been remiss in reporting on the Halloween party debacle at Tavern on the Green on Saturday. Last night, Channel 7 went to the videotape.

headline: On ABC, a Big Night for ‘V’
text: In what has to be considered a major surprise, the new ABC drama “V” began its run Tuesday night looking like the biggest hit of the television season.

headline: Cultural Dessert
text: The Big Gay Ice Cream Truck is on a winter break, so its staff is reaching out to the truck’s followers and local arts groups by using its Twitter feed to announce ticket giveaways for performances.

headline: On Comic-Con Web Site, a Tribute to a Founder
text: The Web site of Comic-Con International, usually a welter of whiz-bang graphics and news about the fan world, was topped on Friday by a simple black-and-white snapshot of Sheldon Dorf — the kind of fan who has fans. Mr. Dorf, a founder of San Diego’s annual Comic-Con fantasy convention, died on Tuesday, according to the San Diego Union-Tribune. He was 76.

headline:
Breeders’ Cup Organizers
Plan More Reforms
text: ARCADIA, Calif.  Organizers of the Breeders’ Cup said this week that they intended to redouble their efforts to catch drug cheats as well as keep any trainer with serious drug violations out of its world championships next year and beyond.

headline: Banned Cold War Play Comes to America
text: A remounting of a 1985 production of a cold war play that was shut down by Polish authorities because of its subject matter — life in Poland under martial law — will run Thursday through Saturday night at Yale Repertory Theater in Connecticut and Nov. 11-15 at the Abrons Arts Center in New York City.

headline: JPMorgan to Pay $75 Million in Alabama Case
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday that JPMorgan Chase had agreed to pay $75 million in penalties and as well as forfeit $647 million in termination fees to settle civil charges that its securities firm had engaged in an “unlawful payment scheme” to win municipal bond business in Jefferson County, Ala.

headline: Signs of a Bruised Body Image
text: How healthy is your body image? Today the PsychCentral Web site starts a new body-image blog called Weightless, which explores several signs you may have a poor body image. Here are some of the signals:

headline: How Biofuel Leaked Into the House Health Bill
text: At first glance, it might seem as if House Democrats were so overwhelmed by their ambitious legislative agenda that they confused their big climate change legislation with their big health care bill.

headline: Surgery at a Spa? Buyer Beware.
text: THERE is little to suggest that the TriBeCa MedSpa in Manhattan is a medical facility, at least in the traditional sense. In the waiting area, called the Tranquillity Room, a waterfall cascades down one wall. A client may have a pedicure or facial before entering a softly lighted space where a plastic surgeon performs laser Fraxel treatment or some other minimally invasive procedure that would cost twice as much in a harried doctor’s office.

headline: Update: Fortune Small Business Lays Off 11, Not 1
text: Earlier today, a Time Inc. spokeswoman said that only one staff member was affected by the closing of Fortune Small Business, but actually all 11 employees of the publication have been dismissed, said a senior Time Inc. executive who spoke on condition of anonymity. That is five full-time employees and six hourly employees, the executive said.

headline: Bloomberg Wins Third Term
text: The Times's Michael Barbaro reports on Michael R. Bloomberg's narrow victory for a third term as New York City's mayor.

headline: Questions for Mayor Dellums
text: Oakland Mayor Ronald Dellums and his wife owe the Internal Revenue Service $239,000, according to a lien put on his property and filed in Oakland and Washington D.C., where the mayor, a former congressman, still owns a house. But for at least one year, the tax liability exceeds the income of the mayor’s former lobbying firm. More information is needed to make the details known now add up.

headline: Russian Reports Tie Nationalists to 2 Killings
text: MOSCOW  Two people have been arrested in the killings of a human rights lawyer and a reporter who were shot in central Moscow in January, the Interfax news agency reported late Wednesday, citing unidentified law enforcement officials.

headline: Journal’s Bay Area Edition to Make Debut Thursday
text: The Wall Street Journal’s San Francisco Bay Area edition will make its debut Thursday, the newspaper announced on Wednesday, three weeks after The New York Times started its own Bay Area edition.

headline: North American Origins for the Falklands Wolf
text: The Falklands wolf has puzzled evolutionary biologists since Charles Darwin first encountered it during the voyage of the Beagle in the 1830s. It was the only native land mammal on the Falkland Islands, which are 300 miles off the coast of Argentina. No one knew how it got there or what mainland animals it was descended from  and it did not help that the wolf was hunted to extinction by 1876.

headline: Credit Card Offers 100,000-Mile Sign Up Bonus
text: British Airways and Chase Card Services will soon be offering 100,000 miles to people who sign up for the British Airways Visa Signature card, which is equivalent to two round-trip coach tickets from North America to London. Read the full post.

headline: Fed Sees No Need to Raise Interest Rates Soon
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve signaled on Wednesday it was not close to raising interest rates, saying that the economy remained weak even though the recession appeared to be over.

headline: Graphic Content | Diagramming Fritz Kahn
text: Steven Heller, a former art director at The New York Times, is a co-chair of the M.F.A. Design Department at the School of Visual Arts and a blogger and author.

headline: Five Tips for Reaching $1 Million in Revenue
text: Nell Merlino, the founder and chief executive of Count Me In for Women’s Economic Independence, a nonprofit organization, suggests five steps for business owners seeking to reach $1 million in revenue and beyond:

headline: Increasing returns in a comparative advantage world
text: That’s the title of my paper for Alan Deardorff’s festschrift volume. Draft here. Warning: largely incomprehensible.

headline: One in Four Businesses Calls the Owner ‘Ma’am’
text: The Center for Women’s Business Research was founded nearly two decades ago by a group of women seeking to win respect for businesses run by women. But even center officials were surprised by the findings in their own report: that those businesses play a significant role in the economy.

headline: I’m not sure what the moral of this is, but …
text: David Leohnardt unearths a Times article from 1982 that warned that we might never have a decent recovery. OK, although I’m with Calculated Risk: we’re really in a liquidity trap now, which means that it’s much harder for the Fed to turn things around.

headline: What Did the Election Mean?
text: Updated, Nov. 5, 11:30 a.m. | Amy Walter, editor in chief of the The Hotline, has joined the discussion.

headline: Statoil Sells U.S. Oil Interest to Chinese Company
text: Update | 3:43 p.m. Statoil, the Norwegian energy giant, said Wednesday that it had sold a partial interest in some of its American energy development leases to the China National Offshore Oil Corporation, known as Cnooc. It is the first time that a Chinese company would take an ownership interest in energy assets in the United States.

headline: Creative Confections for Woodwinds and Strings
text: Devoting a program to Minimalist and microtonal compositions could easily amount to an egghead agenda; leave it to the American Modern Ensemble to make it a party instead. Arriving concertgoers at the Galapagos Art Space in Dumbo, Brooklyn, for a program titled “m&m’s: microtones & minimalism” on Tuesday night were greeted with martini glasses filled with complimentary M&M candies. Flyers and announcements hawked the “American Modern-tini,” a custom-made concoction. (Diligence urged sampling; common sense dictated otherwise.)

headline: One Artist Journeys Down Another’s ‘Road’
text: LONDON | Ed Ruscha, an artist very familiar with the road culture of America, has dedicated a new project to the 1957 novel that brought that subject to the masses: Jack Kerouac’s “On the Road.”

headline: How Did Barca Fare in Russian Test?
text: Rubin Kazan has Barcelona’s number. The Russian champion held the European champion to a goalless draw in sub-freezing temperatures in the Tatar capital, a week after upsetting the Blaugrana in Spain.

headline: Technology Squeezes Jobs at Outsourcers, Too
text: From our colleagues at Economix:

headline: Evocations of Chinese Life and Traditions, the Real and the Imagined
text: You might have thought that the ambitious, idiosyncratic program of Chinese music the Kronos Quartet and the pipa virtuoso Wu Man presented at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening was part of Carnegie Hall’s Ancient Paths, Modern Voices celebration of Chinese culture. But you would have been wrong. Instead the concert was part of the series Perspectives: Kronos Quartet.

headline: Mikes Banished, Natural Sound Returns to City Opera
text: The New York City Opera  missing in action through the 2008-9 season as it grappled with a debilitating deficit and a chaotic leadership crisis  returns on Thursday evening with “American Voices,” a gala program at its extensively renovated home, the David H. Koch Theater. There is no doubt what the main question hovering over the proceedings will be: How are the acoustics of the renovated hall?

headline: The Morning Skate: Star Injuries, N.H.L. Attendance and the Flames’ Boogie-Woogie Flu Shots
text: The Rangers lost in Vancouver last night, dropping a 4-1 decision to a team missing three of its best players due to injury, goalie Roberto Luongo and forwards Daniel Sedin and Pavol Demitra. But the Canucks are not alone. Throughout the N.H.L., many of the top players in the league have been shelved long term for assorted medical reasons.

headline: Lives Gently Unscrolled Across a Stage
text: Bringing a painting to life is an idea that crops up from time to time in dance. Usually, though, the choreographer needs to invent a narrative to animate the frozen-in-time moment of the image and bring its characters to life. But not in “The Feast of Han Xizai” from the Han Tang Yuefu Music and Dance Ensemble of Taiwan, which opened Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Based on a Tang dynasty scroll painting by Gu Hongzhong, the dance doesn’t exactly tell a story.

headline: European Puck: 100 Days Till Vancouver
text: The countdown is on. One hundred days from Wednesday the 2010 Winter Games will open in Vancouver (although it is 101 days until the women’s tournament starts off the Games’ ice hockey program), so with a nod to the International Ice Hockey Federation’s Olympics page, here’s a roundup of the latest Olympic hockey news.

headline: Photo of the Week
text: A dancer at Caru’ cu Bere, a beautifully restored neo-Gothic beer hall, in Bucharest’s reviving Lipscani district.

headline: New Yorker Writer’s Book on Mass Extinctions Sells to Holt
text: Elizabeth Kolbert, the New Yorker writer, has sold a new book about mass extinctions to Henry Holt & Co. Holt paid a mid-six-figure advance for the book, which started life as a New Yorker article and is scheduled for publication in fall 2012.

headline: Still Bouncing Off the Fun House Walls
text: The disembodied voice, sounding like God with a hangover, lets us know in detail what we are about to receive. “Ladies and gentlemen,” the voice rumbles by way of a preshow announcement for Richard Foreman’s “Idiot Savant,” a play that is some kind of wonderful. “In the course of this evening’s performance the following objects will appear onstage.”

headline: The Concierge | The Blind Date
text: Christine Muhlke, T Magazine’s food editor and de facto concierge, is at your service. Have a dining or imbibing quandary for her? Leave your question in the comments section below.

headline: Reading the Election Tea Leaves
text: David Brooks: Gail, I love elections generally and this one was perfect. It cut through the great illusion of political life. The great illusion is that American politics is divided between people who read The Huffington Post on the one hand and people who listen to Rush and Glenn Beck on the other. We all know intellectually that this is not the case but it’s hard to keep it in mind day to day.

headline: Alto Alentejo, Unsung but Not for Long
text: IN 2002, Doug Smith was bored. Korakia Pensione, his Mediterranean-style boutique hotel in Palm Springs, Calif., that attracted a celebrity crowd like Annie Leibovitz, Gore Vidal and Brice Marden, pretty much ran itself. Mr. Smith was looking for a new project  a grand fixer-upper in an exotic locale  where he could show off his well-honed style and settle into a life of rustic ease with his new wife, Josie.

headline: Staten Island Elects Its First Black Council Member
text: Staten Island has long been unique in this racially diverse city: a borough where whites constitute the vast majority. But over the last few decades and particularly in recent years, people of other races have been increasingly calling the island home.

headline: Will the Phillies Change Their Lineup?
text: The easy answer to the question, “will the Phillies change their lineup?” is no way, no chance, not at all.

headline: On Baseball with Jack Curry
text: Either the Yankees will win the World Series, or the Phillies will force a dramatic Game 7. The Times's Jack Curry and Jane Bornemeier discuss how each of the scenarios may play out.

headline: President of New York City Transit Resigns
text: Howard H. Roberts Jr., the avuncular boss of New York City’s buses and subways, resigned Wednesday after a tenure of two and a half years.

headline: A Bountiful Buzz
text: A new type of visitor came to the National Mall this year, flitting past monuments and museums in favor of trees, flowers and plants. But this wasn’t just some horticultural tour; no, this was work. Each day they were abuzz, gathering and pollinating before returning home to modest quarters with tremendous security near Lafayette Park.

headline: Assessing Election Day 2009
text: The Times’s Adam Nagourney reports on what the elections might mean for the national political landscape.

headline: Stardust Memories: Woody Allen Puts This Ingmar Bergman Nonsense to Rest
text: Finally, some closure on the most important cinematic question of the moment (at least in our minds): Did Woody Allen and Ingmar Bergman ever share any meaningful interactions? The answer comes to us via the Woodman himself.

headline: Kerik Expected to Accept Prison Term in Corruption Case
text: Bernard B. Kerik, New York City’s former police commissioner, is expected to plead guilty on Thursday to a single conspiracy charge in an agreement that would resolve the three pending federal criminal trials he faces in New York and Washington, people with knowledge of the matter said Wednesday. The deal, they say, could send him to jail for almost three years.

headline: Reader’s Digest Closes Rick Warren Magazine
text: Less than a year after starting a hybrid magazine and membership organization, the Reader’s Digest Association and the minister Rick Warren said Wednesday that they were pulling the plug.

headline: Competing Rallies in Iran’s Streets
text: It was a day of scattered protests and violence across central Tehran, as the country marked the 30th anniversary of the takeover of the United States Embassy/

headline: Mavizen TTX02: Plug-and-Play Racing for the People
text: LAS VEGAS — It may seem strange for Azhar Hussain to introduce the electric racing motorcycle built by his London-based company, Mavizen, here at the SEMA Show. This is, after all, a convention for aftermarket parts for hot rods, tuners and pickup trucks on 26-inch wheels. But that’s the point: the Mavizen TTX02 is almost entirely aftermarket.

headline: How (Not) to Calm a Child on a Plane
text: Johanna Stein, a TV writer, who describes herself as a “first time parent and long-time neurotic,” read my post about the mother and child who were escorted off a Southwest flight last week, and sent me an essay she wrote about being that parent — the kind whose child won’t stop screaming.

headline: Maine Event
text: Progressive opinionators are trying to decipher the meaning of the vote yesterday in Maine to repeal the state’s new law permitting gay marriage, a vote that was expected to be close but one that gay-marriage proponents expected to win.

headline: BlogTalk: And Now, a Word From the North Country
text: The hardest fought race yesterday for the political right was no doubt the one to decide the congressional representative in New York State’s 23rd District.

headline: New Run for ‘The Temperamentals’ at New World Stages
text: The critically praised Off Broadway production of “The Temperamentals,” a play about the early gay rights movement in America that had two sold-out runs this year, will transfer this winter to New World Stages, the producers announced on Wednesday. The production stars Thomas Jay Ryan (“Henry Fool”) as Harry Hay, who helped build the Mattachine Society gay rights organization in the 1950s, and Michael Urie (Marc St. James on “Ugly Betty”) as his lover Rudi Gernreich, who became a prominent fashion designer. Both men will reprise their roles at New World Stages, on W. 50th St. The producers are talking to the three other actors from the original production about returning as well. Previews are scheduled to start Feb. 18, with an opening night on Feb. 28. The specific theater to be used at New World Stages is still under discussion. Daryl Roth and Stacy Shane are producing the new play, which is by Jon Marans and directed by Jonathan Silverstein.

headline: Off the Wall: White House Drops Painting
text: Update | 5:29 p.m. As Heidi Klum repeatedly and sternly intones on “Project Runway,” speaking of the fashion world: “One day you’re in and the next day – you’re out.” The same might be said of art, even, it turns out, at the White House. ARTnews has reported that the White House has quietly de-listed a painting by Alma W. Thomas that it chose last month, among some 45 pieces borrowed from several Washington museums, to decorate the private White House residence and the West and East Wings.

headline: ‘Gossip Girl’ Episode Draws Criticism from Parents’ Group
text: A coming episode of the CW’s headliner series, “Gossip Girl”, has drawn the ire of the Parents Television Council, leading it to call on local affiliates of the network to pre-empt the episode, which is scheduled to be broadcast Nov. 9.

headline: Fete Accompli | Mr. Chow’s 30th Anniversary
text: What: Michael and Eva Chow’s blowout to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Upper East Side chapter of the Mr. Chow empire.

headline: Obama Uses Malia’s Test Scores as a Teaching Example
text: MADISON, Wis. – President Obama marked the first anniversary of his election on Wednesday by calling on states to toughen their education standards – and wound up calling on parents to toughen theirs, too, as he confessed that his 11-year-old daughter, Malia, recently got a 73 on her science test.

headline: Intel's Antitrust History
text: Intel has been the target of antitrust investigations and lawsuits from around the world. A look at the cases that the world's largest chip maker has battled for years.

headline: Video: The Good, the Bad and the Elections
text: In a new video, Adam Nagourney, The Times’s national political correspondent, discusses the possible meaning of the recent elections in Virginia, New Jersey and New York for the landscape shifting into the midterm elections of next year. It was a good day for Republicans, but not necessarily a great day.

headline: Frank Seeks Stricter Derivatives Bill
text: Representative Barney Frank, the chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, is seeking stricter legislation for privately traded derivatives, and he wants to make it harder for banks to avoid trading the contracts on exchanges.

headline: Correction
text: The two organizations calling for more research into geoengineering but stipulating that it should not take the place of emissions-cutting efforts are the American Meteorological Society and the U.K. Royal Society; a previous version of the story incorrectly stated that the former of the two organizations was the American Geophysical Union.

headline: Modifying a Christmas Wish
text: In promising that Democrats would soon finish their big health care legislation, Senator Tom Harkin has done everything but put on a Santa Claus costume.

headline: A Place to Put Your Apps
text: Last week, I reviewed not one, but three new phones. You’d think that would be enough for a while, but fall is peak season for new mobile devices, and another major release — Motorola’s Droid — is upon us this week.

headline: Home Green Home: Fireplace Inserts
text: Tom Zeller Jr., editor of the Green Inc. blog, had an energy-efficient fireplace insert installed.

headline: Scots Aim Lasers at Landmarks
text: EDINBURGH  Come April a small team of experts from the Glasgow School of Art and the government heritage entity Historic Scotland will fly to South Dakota at the behest of an organization called CyArk and the United States National Park Service. They will make laser scans and computer models of Mount Rushmore.

headline: Cisco’s Results Offer More Hope to Tech Industry
text: Cisco Systems, the computer networking giant, supplied more evidence on Wednesday that technology sales were recovering along with the global economy.

headline: Ramsay Takes On Amateur Cooks
text: On Media Decoder, a look at Gordon Ramsay’s new culinary show for amateur cooks.

headline: Off the Wall: White House Drops Painting
text: At ArtsBeat, Randy Kennedy notes that the White House has decided against keeping a painting by Alma Thomas for display. Its selection had generated a bit of controversy. Read the full post.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Nov. 4
text: Emotions ran high on Wednesday in Iran, where crowds gathered on the 30th anniversary of the takeover of the United States Embassy. Tens of thousands of protesters braved police beatings and tear gas on the sidelines of a government-sponsored rally with an anti-American theme (Slides 1, 2, 3 and 4). In Moscow, meanwhile, Russian nationalists gathered outside the Kremlin for National Unity Day, which was created in 2005 to replace the traditional celebration of the Bolsheviks’ rise to power (Slide 6). The plight of child laborers drew attention in New Delhi, where activists and government officials raided a workshop (Slide 7). And Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York was spotted entering City Hall a day after his narrow re-election victory (Slide 12).

headline: The White House’s Other Foodmakers
text: While White House chefs help make food policy and promote healthy eating on Iron Chef America, the White House carpenter is making honey. Check out the audio slide show.

headline: 11/4/09: O.H.L. Suspends Player for Rest of Season
text: The Ontario Hockey League has suspended the Erie player Michael Liambas for the rest of the regular season and playoffs for checking into the end boards Kitchener defenseman Ben Fanelli, a hit that resulted in Fanelli, 16, being airlifted to a Hamilton hospital with skull and facial fractures. The check occurred on Friday; Fanelli’s condition was upgraded on Tuesday from critical but stable to serious but stable.

headline: Small Business Goes to Washington (Part 2)
text: As we reported last night, Senator Tom Harkin’s hearing in the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee on small-business insurance costs wasn’t the only small-business game in Washington on Wednesday. The liberal Main Street Alliance, along with the Consumers Union, U.S. PIRG, and the Small Business Majority, sent 134 small-business owners from 26 states to Capitol Hill to mingle with legislators and the press.

headline: The Very Quiet Season of Michael Vick
text: The biggest headline from the preseason has been little more than a footnote in the games that count. The Philadelphia Eagles did not need the publicity when they signed Michael Vick. What they needed, so they thought, was someone who could conduct a Wildcat offense. But in five games this season, their man for that job has rushed for just 25 yards on 11 carries, and completed only 2 for 6 passes for 6 yards.

headline: Going Tribal in Afghanistan
text: In Washington, the debate over Afghanistan seems to center around two broad ideas: counterinsurgency versus counterterrorism. Should the United States add troops for a more population-centric strategy, as Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal advocates? Or should it use a less ground-heavy approach, disrupting Al Qaeda with Special Operation Forces and unmanned drones, as Vice President Joseph Biden argues?

headline: Martinez Has a History in Elimination Games
text: When Pedro Martinez took the mound on Wednesday night at Yankee Stadium, it was the sixth time he was pitching in a postseason game in which a loss would send his team home for the winter.

headline: Adults Told to Hold Off Getting Seasonal Flu Vaccine
text: Healthy, nonelderly adults in New York should not seek vaccination for seasonal flu until the supply of vaccine increases, city health department officials said Wednesday.

headline: No Deal for Ticket Scalper
text: A man arrested outside Yankee Stadium last Thursday apparently thought he had a get-out-of-jail-free card in the form of World Series tickets.

headline: Fox News Takes Tuesday Night
text: On an off-year election night of local victories for Republicans in New Jersey and Virginia, the Fox News Channel had large gains in viewership, Nielsen ratings showed on Wednesday.

headline: Revenue and Profit Declines at Time Warner
text: Time Warner, the media conglomerate that was once the world’s largest but has lately slimmed down by shedding some businesses, said both revenue and profits declined in the recent quarter.

headline: Building With Whole Trees
text: STODDARD, Wis.

headline: Costumes for Designers
text: The New York Design Center Masquerade Ball held last week was that rare New York party in which shop talk was not paramount.

headline: Grant Could Help Acquire Poet’s Papers
text: The papers of the poet Siegfried Sassoon are probably headed to Cambridge University thanks to a grant from a British national fund for emergency acquisitions, BBC News reported. On Wednesday the National Heritage Memorial Fund in Britain said that it would give about $900,000 toward the purchase of Sassoon’s archives, which include notebooks he kept on the Western Front during World War I, as well as correspondence, poetry books, photographs and love letters to his wife, Hester. Sassoon, who dealt with the human toll of war in poems like “They” and “Suicide in the Trenches,” volunteered for military service just before Britain entered World War I, and he was a decorated soldier before he refused to return to duty in 1917. In June several authors, including Sebastian Faulks and Sassoon’s official biographer, Max Egremont, started a campaign to acquire Sassoon’s papers after the death of his son, George, in 2006. With the grant, Cambridge is about $180,000 short of the estate’s asking price of nearly $2 million for the archive.

headline: Not All Is Rotten in Denmark: ‘hamlet’ Recoups
text: The current Broadway production of “Hamlet” no longer needs to concern itself with borrowers or lenders  the play has fully recouped its costs, its publicists said on Wednesday. In a news release, press representatives for “Hamlet,” which began previews at the Broadhurst Theater on Sept. 12 and opened on Oct. 6, said that it had earned back its initial Broadway capitalization of $2.5 million as of the week ending Nov. 1. The play, directed by Michael Grandage, is the latest in a series of hits that have moved to Broadway from the Donmar Warehouse in London, which also yielded “Frost/Nixon” and “Mary Stuart.” The success of “Hamlet” might also have something to do with its star, Jude Law, who plays the melancholy Danish prince (above with Geraldine James), and who has held his own in a celebrity-filled season of Broadway neighbors like Daniel Craig, Hugh Jackman and Sienna Miller. The limited run of “Hamlet” is to end on Dec. 6.

headline: The Beatles Have Something Else to Sell
text: If, when the Beatles released the remastered versions of their albums in September, you withstood the pressure to buy the stereo and mono boxed sets that contained their entire catalogs, your patience is about to be rewarded, sort of. Apple Corps Ltd. and EMI Music said they were releasing a limited-edition USB hard drive that contains the stereo versions of the Beatles’ albums, as well as the bonus materials that were included in their rerelease, including short documentary films about the creation of the studio albums, photos and expanded liner notes. For the tech heads, the companies said that the audio files on the 16-gigabyte drives were in FLAC 44.1 Khz 24 bit and MP3 320 Kbps formats, and compatible with PC and Mac. For people holding credit cards, the drives will be sold at the Beatles’ online store for $279.99 and will be released in North America on Dec. 8. The USB drive’s green apple design, above, is presumably intended to evoke the Apple Corps logo and not the rotten fruit tossed by the villainous Apple Bonkers in “Yellow Submarine.”

headline: Footnote
text: The next tenant for Broadway’s Nederlander Theater was announced late Tuesday: The new musical “Million Dollar Quartet,” based on a 1956 recording session that brought together Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins and Elvis Presley. Preview performances are to begin on March 13, and opening night will be sometime in April. The show, now running in Chicago, will be directed by Eric Schaeffer and includes a book by Colin Escott and Floyd Mutrux. Casting is underway.

headline: ABC’s ‘V’ Rises to Top Spot in Ratings
text: ABC’s new science-fiction series, “V,” a remake of the 1983 mini-series, opened to strong ratings on Tuesday, leading the night over all in the advertiser-favored demographic of adults 18 to 49. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 13.9 million total viewers tuned in, helping make “V” one of the highest-rated new series this fall. That ABC show trailed CBS’s “NCIS” in its 8 p.m. slot, however, in total viewers (19.4 million) as CBS won the night’s largest audiences over all, leading the 9 and 10 p.m. hours with “NCIS: Los Angeles” (15 million) and “The Good Wife” (12.2 million). ABC was runner-up, garnering 14.5 million at 9 for “Dancing With the Stars,” but only 7.6 million for “The Forgotten” at 10. NBC earned third place with a two-hour installment of “The Biggest Loser” (9 million), followed by “The Jay Leno Show” (5.9 million).

headline: Michael Jackson Takes ‘It’ to the Top
text: After dominating record sales for four months, Michael Jackson is finally at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart. “Michael Jackson’s This Is It,” above, the companion album to the new movie, sold 373,100 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Although Jackson has sold more than 5.6 million albums since his death in June, most of those titles have been too old to count on the Billboard 200, the standard album chart. But “This Is It” is a new title, and it becomes Jackson’s sixth No. 1. The film was the top box-office draw last week, taking in $32.5 million in its first five days in the United States. Also on this week’s album chart, Creed’s comeback, “Full Circle” (Wind-Up), opened at No. 2 with 110,000, and Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine), rereleased in a deluxe package, jumped four spots to No. 3 with 109,000. Rod Stewart’s new album, “Soulbook” (J), a collection of covers of classic soul songs, bowed at No. 4 with 84,000 copies sold. Trans-Siberian Orchestra’s latest holiday album, “Night Castle” (Atlantic), opened at No. 5 with 83,000, and Sting’s new Christmas-themed album, “If on a Winter’s Night ...” (Deutsche Grammophon), sold 80,000 copies to debut at No. 6.

headline: Book on Mass Extinction Is Bought by Holt
text: Elizabeth Kolbert, a writer at The New Yorker, has sold a new book about mass extinctions to Henry Holt & Company. Holt paid a mid-six-figure advance for the book, which began as an article in The New Yorker and is scheduled for publication in fall 2012. Stephen Rubin, the new president and publisher of Holt, announced the acquisition on Wednesday, just two days after he started his job. Mr. Rubin was most recently publisher at large at Random House. Ms. Kolbert moves to Holt from Bloomsbury, which published her previous book, “Field Notes From a Catastrophe,” in 2006. Her editor, Gillian Blake, is now at Holt and acquired the new book, “The Sixth Extinction,” an intellectual and natural history of various species. Ms. Blake said she had been talking to Ms. Kolbert about the subject of extinctions for years. “The idea of mass extinctions as the next step after talking about the perils of global warming is the most crucial subject,” Ms. Blake said.

headline: The Off-Off-Year Elections
text: Tuesday’s vote  particularly the election of Republican governors in New Jersey and Virginia  has produced heated predictions about the revived power of Republican social conservatism and the declining fortunes of Barack Obama and his 2008 coalition.

headline: Payments in Ivory Coast Dumping Case at Risk, Lawyer Says
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Thousands of victims of one of the worst toxic dumping scandals in years could lose their hard-won settlement thanks to maneuverings by a shadowy but “influential” figure in Ivory Coast, where the dumping occurred, the victims’ lawyer said Wednesday.

headline: How to Respond to Debt Resolution Service Ads
text: I recently received a “personal and confidential” notice in the mail from the “debt resolution department” at a California law firm offering to help me restructure a debt I don’t actually have (or hope I don’t have) to a lower monthly payment. The letter urged me to call a toll-free number as soon as possible if I wanted to take advantage of the offer.

headline: Republicans Win 2 Council Races in Queens
text: Republicans picked up two City Council seats in Queens on Tuesday, defeating Democratic opponents, both Asian-American, who had survived grueling primaries. The hard-fought races were among the most expensive Council contests this year, in large part because the primaries had drawn numerous contenders.

headline: Ask Big Bird a Question
text: Tuesday, Nov. 10, will mark the 40th anniversary of “Sesame Street,” the PBS standby that taught multiple generations to read and count and gave many children perhaps their earliest glimpses of multicultural community.

headline: In China, an Apartment Renovation Presents New Challenges
text: Dalian, China

headline: Red Bulls’ Boss Speaks
text: The phone call came early Wednesday morning.

headline: Light, Birds, Action! Cunningham and Company in Rehearsal
text: Most of the dancers in the ballet paintings of Degas aren’t dancing. They’re stretching, resting, recovering, waiting, watching; and in several paintings there is a white-haired old man in charge, a ballet master whose name, Jules Perrot, remains bigger than those of any of the performers he is supervising. That situation came vividly back to mind as I watched Tacita Dean’s “Craneway Event.”

headline: Some TVs Go Directly Online for Streaming Movies
text: For more than a decade, tech and media companies have wrestled with how to deliver digitized movies directly over the Internet to consumers: how do you get the copy-protected files from the computer to the big screen in the living room?

headline: Game 6 Lineups
text: The lineups for Game 6 of the World Series are in and Shane Victorino is playing center field and batting second as usual. Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel said Victorino’s bruised finger was fine. The designated hitter is Raul Ibanez.

headline: Firing Bullets of Data at Cozy Anti-Science
text: “I always say that electricity is a fantastic invention,” the British economist Michael Lipton once told Michael Specter, whose bristling new book, “Denialism,” explores the dangerous ways in which scientific progress can be misunderstood. “But if the first two products had been the electric chair and the cattle prod,” Mr. Lipton continued, “I doubt that most consumers would have seen the point.”

headline: Safety Agency Rebukes Toyota Over Floor-Mat Issue
text: In a highly unusual move for an agency that prefers low-profile discussions, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has publicly rebuked Toyota, accusing it of putting out “inaccurate and misleading” information about the unintended acceleration problem that could affect 3.8 million of its vehicles.

headline: ‘Denialism’
text: The most blatant forms of denialism are rarely malevolent; they combine decency, a fear of change, and the misguided desire to do good — for our health, our families, and the world. That is why so many physicians dismiss the idea that a patient's race can, and often should, be used as a tool for better diagnoses and treatment. Similar motivations — in other words, wishful thinking — have helped drive the growing national obsession with organic food. We want our food to taste good, but also to be safe and healthy. That's natural. Food is more than a meal, it's about history, culture, and a common set of rituals. We put food in the mouths of our children; it is the glue that unites families and communities. And because we don't see our food until we eat it, any fear attached to it takes on greater resonance.

headline: What Your Phone Might Do for You Two Years From Now
text: By now we can probably all agree that the iPhone is the Model T, the Sputnik, the Lawrence Taylor of the mobile technology realm. We are still waiting for the offenses to adapt, the competition to catch up.

headline: Victorino Remains in Lineup
text: Shane Victorino vowed two nights ago that a bruised right index finger would not prevent him from starting in center field Wednesday night. True to his word, Victorino was in the Phillies’ lineup after assuring Manager Charlie Manuel that he could swing and throw without discomfort. An errant fastball by A.J. Burnett drilled Victorino in the first inning of Game 5, causing the finer to swell. But X-rays did not show a fracture.

headline: From London, an Example of Fakery Done Right
text: On some deals declarer will make his contract if he can guess what to do. Then the defense’s job is to paint a false picture of the distribution, hoping that declarer will guess wrong.

headline: Galleon Moves Its Portfolios to Nearly All Cash
text: The Galleon Group has converted nearly all of its hedge funds into cash, as the firm seeks return money to its investors in light of its founder’s arrest on insider trading charges, according to a letter to investors obtained by DealBook.

headline: For Thrillers, Glenn Beck Is Becoming New Oprah
text: Virtually every novelist in America fantasizes about being picked to appear on Oprah Winfrey’s talk show. But now an increasing number of writers have discovered a new champion: Glenn Beck, the outspoken media darling of populist conservatism.

headline: Satellite Radio for iPhone and iPod Touch
text: Sirius XM Radio, always on the lookout for ways to attract fee-paying younger subscribers, is now after the Apple crowd.

headline: Tech Is Back. And This Time, It’s Personal.
text: Today we released our redesigned online Personal Tech section. The old version wasn’t bad, but we thought we could do better. That means more video, easier navigation and more places to read about products and then research them with the help of our product-review partner, CNet.

headline: Milan’s No. 10 Responds to Times Readers
text: A day after he played in A.C. Milan’s 1-1 draw with Real Madrid in the UEFA Champions League, Clarence Seedorf answered readers’ questions from Milan. This is the the third edition of Seedorf’s monthly discussion with Times readers. You can read earlier discussions here.

headline: A Cheap Deadbolt Is No Bargain
text: DON’T forget to lock up  it’s a sound practice, yet something many people forget to do, resulting in millions of break-ins nationwide every year, according to the National Crime Prevention Council, a nonprofit organization in Washington.

headline: Chrysler’s Five-Year Plan in Six Bullet Points
text: Chrysler delivered an epic press conference/Web cast Wednesday to detail its five-year plan, including coming products. Here is the essential information in six bullet points:

headline: Older Bypass Method Is Best, a Study Shows
text: For decades, bypass surgery, in which surgeons improve blood flow to the heart by sewing new blood vessels to get around blocked ones, was done the same way. The heart was stopped while blood was pumped through a heart-lung machine to do the heart’s work.

headline: Karzai’s Top Rival Denounces Afghanistan’s New Government
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The erstwhile rival to President Hamid Karzai in the presidential election’s second round held a news conference on Wednesday in which he denounced Mr. Karzai’s newly anointed administration as illegal and said that the government would be unable to cope with the problems facing Afghanistan, including security and corruption.

headline: Other Voyages in the Shadow of Lévi-Strauss
text: His most celebrated work, “Tristes Tropiques,” begins with the words “I hate traveling and explorers.” But what made the anthropologist and philosopher Claude Lévi-Strauss one of the great intellectuals of the 20th century was precisely his eagerness to explore  not just remote jungles and isolated societies, but also the far reaches of the human mind.

headline: Better-Than-Expected Profit Is Reported by News Corp.
text: The News Corporation reported an unexpected rise in profit on Wednesday, driven by its cable channels, particularly Fox News, and its movie studio.

headline: After Mickey’s Makeover, Less Mr. Nice Guy
text: LOS ANGELES  For decades, the Walt Disney Company has largely kept Mickey Mouse frozen under glass, fearful that even the tiniest tinkering might tarnish the brand and upend his $5 billion or so in annual merchandise sales. One false move and Disney could have New Coke on its hands.

headline: Pogue & Friends 2009 Holiday Guide
text: The Times's personal technology columnist, David Pogue, teams up with travel columnist Michelle Higgins to share their favorite travel gadgets.

headline: Home, Alone
text: Leslie Williams lives in what was once her dream home. But it was also where her 14-year relationship ended.

headline: Australia Puts Its Refugee Problem on a Remote Island, Behind Razor Wire
text: CHRISTMAS ISLAND, Australia  Deep in the jungle on this small island lost in the Indian Ocean, Australia’s new $370 million refugee detention center reaches its full power after its lights come on at dusk. Bracketed by rain forest, steep cliffs and the sea, it rises from the enveloping darkness and becomes visible from the island’s only inhabited corner, about 10 miles away.

headline: Getting Serious About Your House and the Market
text: WHEN Matthew White, a landscape architect, decided two years ago to sell his 1,300-square-foot apartment in Philadelphia, he knew real estate prices were plummeting. Nevertheless, he thought he could get $760,000, about what he had paid two years earlier, because he had made many improvements to the space, an airy penthouse with two verdant terraces.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,348 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 902 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

headline: C.C. Sabathia Is Ready for a Possible Game 7
text: C.C. Sabathia will watch Game 6 between the Yankees and the Phillies a little differently than his teammates. If the Yankees do not beat the Phillies Wednesday, Sabathia must be ready to start a Game 7 on Thursday.

headline: Seeking a Right to Carol in the Classroom
text: SAN FRANCISCO  If Merry Susan Hyatt has her way, every public school pupil in California will have the voter-approved right to sing “Joy to the World” in the classroom.

headline: Yankees Win 2009 World Series
text: Times reporters David Waldstein, Tyler Kepner, Ben Shpigel, Jack Curry and Richard Sandomir provided updates and analysis during Game 6 of the Yankees-Phillies World Series in the Bronx.

headline: Week 9 in Fantasy Football Matchups
text: The Brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 9. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below. Also, scroll down for reading tips from the Fantasy Football Librarian.

headline: Beauty at the Ball
text: “MY clams are not in place,” the pregnant mermaid in the ladies’ room at the New York Design Center Masquerade Ball was saying, adjusting the homemade shell-and-string brassiere she was wearing over her clingy gown. Her long red hair was a magnificent Venus-rising mane, intertwined with seashells, and a blue-green fish tail trailed fetchingly from underneath her skirt. But her bra was somewhat askew and so was her extremely protuberant belly.

headline: A City of Mixed Emotions Observes Calvin’s 500th
text: GENEVA  On a recent afternoon, stagehands prepared the Protestant meeting hall on the Place de la Fusterie for a musical, “The Calvin Generation,” to be performed there that evening. Springtime for Calvin?

headline: A Dream Home Undone by Divorce
text: WELCOME to home interrupted, Leslie Williams said, opening the door to what appeared to be just the opposite: a bright TriBeCa loft with near-lapidary finishes.

headline: A Health Care Protest, by Invitation
text: House Democrats are bracing for a potential invasion of protesters in the Capitol complex on Thursday after Representative Michele Bachmann, Republican of Minnesota, urged opponents of the Democrats’ health care legislation to come to Washington to make their voices heard.

headline: You Call That Art?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Forester-Architect
text: Roald Gundersen, who founded Gundersen Design in 1991 and built his first house in the forest 10 miles east of the Mississippi River and 150 miles northwest of Madison two years later, has made a career of working with trees.

headline: Where the Boys Aren’t
text: MAN on the premises!

headline: The Gospel According to Sister Parish
text: Sister Parish, the influential American decorator who started working during the Great Depression and died in 1994, was an originator of what came to be known as the American country style, featuring much painted white furniture and homey elements like patchwork quilts, stenciled floors and mattress ticking pillows. Though Mrs. Parish herself was something of an autocrat, her ideas were eminently sensible, reflecting the very basic principle that the people in a room are more important than the objects in it. Call it humanistic decorating.

headline: Some Wall Street Year-End Bonuses Could Hit Pre-Downturn Highs
text: Now is the time of year when a Wall Streeter’s fancy turns, not so lightly, to thoughts of bonuses.

headline: Q&A: What the Goat’s Bones Knew
text: Artware Editions, a West Village gallery that produces objects designed by visual artists, recently introduced limited-edition Bone Cutlery by John Gerrard, an Irish artist whose show “Directions” opens Nov. 5 at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington.

headline: Wine, Held Stylishly Aloft
text: The Grapevine Wine Rack, designed by Ran Lerner for Umbra, is both sculptural and practical. Made of clear acrylic, it could create the impression from afar  especially after a few drinks  that your wine is levitating. But the rack, which is just over 15 inches tall and tapers slightly toward the top, securely holds six standard-size bottles.

headline: App of the Week: Mobile TV That Needs No Hot Spot
text: Getting TV news on your phone is a tricky business, as most mobile broadcasters require a Wi-Fi connection. That’s not really mobile TV, that’s hot-spot TV.

headline: Audiobook Choices for the iPod
text: Q. What companies sell audiobooks for the iPod Touch besides iTunes? Are there fees involved?

headline: From Germany’s Army, Luxury
text: When Darin Montgomery, the founder of Urbancase design studio in Seattle, spotted a surplus military blanket at a flea market on a visit to Berlin two years ago, he was struck by the beauty of its utilitarian gray-brown wool.

headline: Radio Program Interrupted? Bookmark It and Return Later
text: If you are a fan of NPR, you probably have run into this minor frustration: you are, say, heavily into a “Car Talk” discussion on how to repair a radiator when you suddenly have to pick up the children and pop in a Hannah Montana CD. By the time you get home, you have forgotten what it was you wanted to listen to.

headline: A Living Room, Discounted
text: Furniture from the 1930s and ’40s will be up to 70 percent off at Antiqueria Tribeca through Nov. 8 (a set of six dining chairs attributed to Dorothy Draper, originally $12,000, will be $3,600); 129 Duane Street (Church Street), (212) 227-7500, antiqueria.com.

headline: Restructuring Luxury at Versace
text: “I AM a survivor,” the designer Donatella Versace said matter-of-factly during a recent blitz of New York, a visit that made it appear little had changed in the world of the occupationally fabulous.

headline: A Camera Delivers the Joys of Auto Pilot
text: I usually think of superzoom cameras as ideal for vacations. I just didn’t know how exemplary until I packed a Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ35, with an 18X zoom lens ($399, $322 at Amazon), for a trip to Vienna a couple of weeks ago.

headline: Democrats to Use Election to Push Agenda in Congress
text: WASHINGTON  Blaming election setbacks on a drop in voter enthusiasm, Congressional Democrats said Wednesday that losses in governors’ races in Virginia and New Jersey  and a striking House win in New York  should give new urgency to their legislative agenda, including a sweeping health care overhaul.

headline: Report Faults Parole System in Abduction
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The California inspector general issued a scathing report on Wednesday on the state’s handling of the parolee who has been charged with kidnapping, raping and imprisoning Jaycee Dugard for 18 years in Antioch, Calif.

headline: S.E.C. Likely to Charge More People in Galleon Case
text: Prosecutors indicated Wednesday they intend to bring charges against additional defendants in the wide-ranging insider-trading case against Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group, and five others.

headline: In TriBeCa, a Face-Off Over City Tax Breaks and Rents
text: The special city tax breaks that the owner of a large apartment complex in TriBeCa received from 2004 to 2006 could hardly be described as a windfall  $17,879.42 for a cluster of buildings in Lower Manhattan worth tens of millions of dollars.

headline: Reports Show Conflicting Number of Jobs Attributed to Stimulus Money
text: In June, the federal government spent $1,047 in stimulus money to buy a rider mower from the Toro Company to cut the grass at the Fayetteville National Cemetery in Arkansas. Now, a report on the government’s stimulus Web site improbably claims that that single lawn mower sale helped save or create 50 jobs.

headline: Eagles’ Westbrook Is Set to Play Against Cowboys
text: Brian Westbrook is set to return from his latest injury when the Philadelphia Eagles host the Dallas Cowboys in a matchup of the top two teams in the National Football Conference East on Sunday.

headline: California Water Overhaul Caps Use

The water package is the most comprehensive to emerge from the state since the 1960s, when California last upgraded its system for what was a far smaller population of users.

text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: Michael Ronis, Manhattan Chef, Dies at 60
text: Michael Ronis, who helped conceive Carmine’s, an Italian restaurant that lures masses of New Yorkers and out-of-towners to Times Square and the Upper West Side with gargantuan portions and moderate prices, died last Thursday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 60 and lived in Stamford.

headline: Senate Approves More Jobless Benefits
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted unanimously Wednesday to offer up to 20 more weeks of unemployment benefits to those who have been out of work a long time, after weeks of delay in which hundreds of thousands of Americans exhausted their government aid.

headline: Costs Surge for Medical Devices, but Benefits Are Opaque
text: When makers of heart defibrillators wanted Medicare to vastly expand the types of patients eligible to receive the devices, which can cost upward of $25,000, agency officials were skeptical. It was not clear how many of those patients would actually need a defibrillator, a device that can deliver a life-saving shock to restore a faltering heart to normal rhythm.

headline: An Old Pro Delivers at the New Stadium
text: Sometimes it sounds presumptuous to use the name World Series for what is technically the baseball championship of the United States and Canada.
