headline: Perceptions Changed, but Rodriguez Hasn’t
text: Alex Rodriguez’s first act as a World Series champion was to raise his arms and jump for joy. As soon as Shane Victorino made the Phillies’ final out, Rodriguez ran toward the throng of Yankees teammates in the middle of Yankee Stadium and threw himself into the pack.

headline: In Postseason, There Is Only One Rivera
text: Mariano Rivera began warming up in the bottom of the seventh inning, earlier than he would during the regular season. But it was the perfect time for Rivera to do it in the postseason, especially because it was a postseason that he could end. Rivera was preparing to celebrate.

headline: Three Injured Giants Are Making Progress
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Three key members of the Giants’ defense reported progress in their recoveries from injuries Wednesday and expressed hope that they could play soon.

headline: Adults’ Dorm
text: Residences for women offer safe, affordable housing but no co-ed sleepovers.

headline: There Are Now 100,000 Apps for That
text: When Timothy Cook, Apple’s chief operating officer, remarked that people are just “trying to catch up with the first iPhone that was announced two years ago, and we have long since moved beyond that,” during the company’s most recent earnings release, he may have had a point.

headline: The Hospital of the Future
text: In The New York Times Magazine on Sunday, economics columnist David Leonhardt poses one of the more disturbing questions of the health care debate: If politicians cannot fix America’s fragmented, ailing health care system, who will? Physicians have reshaped medicine in the past, Mr. Leonhardt argues, and a few – like Dr. Brent James, chief quality officer of Intermountain Healthcare in Salt Lake City – already are leading the way to the future. Read the full article, and share your thoughts in the comments section.

headline: In Surprise Move, Casino Magnate Abandons Bid for Aqueduct Racetrack
text: Stephen A. Wynn, the Las Vegas gambling impresario, on Wednesday dropped out of the bidding to revive the Aqueduct racetrack in Queens with 4,500 electronic slot machines, just two days before competing operators were to deliver their final offers for the complex.

headline: Bus and Subway President Quits in M.T.A. Shake-Up
text: The avuncular chief of New York City’s buses and subways, Howard H. Roberts Jr., resigned on Wednesday after the new leadership at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority asked him to step down.

headline: 53 Indicted on Drug Charges in Sweep of 2 Bronx Housing Projects
text: Less than a mile from Yankee Stadium, two gangs had the run of adjacent public housing projects in the Bronx, openly running heroin and crack cocaine trafficking rings, the authorities said.

headline: Modeling and All That Came After
text: I FIRST met Léon Bing in Pasadena, in 1998, while working on an article about Rudi Gernreich, the California revolutionary who had shocked the world with his topless bathing suit. Ms. Bing, a model in the 1960s, had not worn the famous suit; that distinction belonged to Peggy Moffitt, who also saw herself as the keeper of Gernreich’s legacy.

headline: House Haggles Over Abortion in Health Care Bill
text: WASHINGTON  House Democratic leaders struggled Wednesday to strike a deal that would restrict the use of federal money to pay for abortions under sweeping health care legislation headed for debate on the House floor this week.

headline: Committee Allows a Break on Certain Auditing Rules
text: WASHINGTON  Legislation that its supporters say would provide greater protection to investors sailed through a House committee on Wednesday, but not before the lawmakers added a provision to ease new auditing standards for small and medium-size companies.

headline: Christie Pledges Fight on Taxes and Business Rules
text: Governor-elect Christopher J. Christie of New Jersey, basking in praise from Republicans who hailed him as the party’s new star, said Wednesday that he would move quickly to suspend new regulations on business and find ways to lower crushing property taxes, the nation’s highest.

headline: Fresh Idea From Recycle Bin
text: THE green movement in fashion, in which designers do go on about hugging the planet with their biodynamic cotton henleys, would appear to be at odds with the “pop up” shop movement in fashion, in which the very same designers open temporary stores, lavishly redecorate them and then, when they close a few weeks later, toss all the fixtures, lights and displays to the curb.

headline: The Morning After, Democrats Regret Lost Chances to Win
text: As the cheering dies down over at William C. Thompson Jr.’s headquarters, where close almost passed for victory on Tuesday evening, New York’s Democrats are left to consider a colder reality:

headline: Magazine by a Best-Selling Minister Closes
text: Less than a year after starting a hybrid magazine and paid membership organization, the Rev. Rick Warren and the Reader’s Digest Association said Wednesday that they were pulling the plug.

headline: Pentagon Expected to Request More War Funding
text: WASHINGTON  The nation’s top military officer said Wednesday that he expected the Pentagon to ask Congress in the next few months for emergency financing to support the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, even though President Obama has pledged to end the Bush administration practice of paying for the conflicts with so-called supplemental funds that are outside the normal Defense Department budget.

headline: Mayor Mends Fences After Slim Victory
text: Michael R. Bloomberg, stung by an election outcome that revealed resentment over his undoing of the term limits law and his extravagant campaign spending, moved quickly Wednesday to strike a conciliatory tone as he reached out to the Democratic establishment that backed his opponent in the mayor’s race.

headline: Questions on Accuracy Delay Much-Awaited F.H.A. Audit
text: A much-anticipated audit of the Federal Housing Administration was abruptly postponed just before it was supposed to be made public, after questions arose about its accuracy.

headline: A Dozen Things to Remember, or Maybe Just Forget, About the Election of 2009
text: It was, for New Yorkers, something of a civic embarrassment — spectacularly few people turning out to vote in a citywide election for mayor and a host of other significant offices. And it was, for Michael R. Bloomberg, something of a financial bust — spectacular amounts of money spent only to ultimately garner the most modest electoral mandate in nearly a century.

headline: Correction: Preserving a Modernist Way of Life
text: An article on Aug. 27 about the preservation of Modernist houses on Cape Cod referred incompletely to the restoration of the Kugel House, built in 1970 in Wellfleet, Mass. Besides the work done by Peter McMahon, who designs and builds houses, Fox Diehl Architects of Manhattan was also involved in the restoration. The firm acted pro bono as the architects of record, doing research and reviewing the restoration drawings with the first owners of the house to ensure that the work was faithful to the original. This correction was delayed for research.

headline: In 1968, Tigers Beat the Odds and the Cardinals’ Gibson in Game 7
text: The odds were heavily stacked against a Phillies comeback in the World Series after they fell down by three games to one. The Yankees were the 20th team to take such a lead with the final two games at home, and only three of those teams had lost the Series.

headline: Energized G.O.P. Looks to Avoid Party Feud
text: WASHINGTON  Republicans emerged from Tuesday’s elections energized by victories in Virginia and New Jersey, but their leaders immediately began maneuvering to avoid a prolonged battle with conservative activists over what the party stands for and how to regain power.

headline: Oceans Apart
text: Digging through the closet in a panicked state, I can’t find my uniform, my boots, my boonie cap, or my rifle. I know the bus is leaving; I’m supposed to be on it. I’m deploying to Iraq again.

headline: Fiorina Formally Announces a Hinted-At Candidacy
text: SAN FRANCISCO  As the dust settled from Tuesday’s elections, one of next year’s potentially bruising campaigns came into focus on Wednesday as Carly Fiorina, a former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard and a Republican, declared her candidacy for the Senate seat long held by Barbara Boxer, a Democrat.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Oct. 25 about the new Frederick Wiseman film “La Danse” misstated the date of its theatrical release. It opened on Wednesday; it does not open this coming Wednesday, Nov. 11.

headline: A Grotesque Romance
text: Patrick Blindauer often has something extra going on in his crosswords, and today’s was no exception. I won’t say outright what’s up until later in the post. For any of you who are still struggling, I encourage you to stick with it. There’s an amusing and clever payoff lurking when you figure it out.

headline: Bloggingheads: 'Mad Men' and J.F.K.
text: Emily Bazelon, left, and Hanna Rosin, both of Double X, discuss how "Mad Men" portrayed the Kennedy assassination.

headline: Not Just Another Plaque on the Wall
text: Elijah McNally started rooting for the Yankees in 2004, when he was 6 years old. Back then, the Yankees were only a year removed from a World Series appearance, and another championship seemed just around the corner.

headline: Cheers and Jeers Blended With Pride
text: The menu at El Nuevo Caridad features the Pedro Martinez  chicken stew, white rice, red beans, avocado salad and water. It costs $14. The Alex Rodriguez comes with chicken stew, rice and beans, too. But it also has fried plantains, a smoothie and cheesecake, and costs $18.

headline: Restaurant Review: Banh Mi Doner Kebabs, Hanoi
text: Over the last year or so, the Vietnamese banh mi sandwich has taken New York by storm, elevating the once humble pork and pickled vegetable sandwich to heights of gastronomic chic. In Hanoi, however, the typical banh mi (which translates simply as “bread” in Vietnamese and is written in English as banh my in Hanoi) is a pedestrian fried egg or pâté sandwich with a few slices of cucumber or a light smearing of chili sauce.

headline: Nation Is Facing Vaccine Shortage for Seasonal Flu
text: Even though the regular flu season has yet to start, the nation is facing a severe shortage of seasonal flu vaccine as well as swine flu vaccine.

headline: Bijagós, a Tranquil Haven in a Troubled Land
text: SOME tropical destinations have long since been discovered and made familiar; others may yet be found, by a few anyway, but are unlikely to change much anytime soon. Too much separates us from them, in culture, space and time.

headline: Tastes of Newly Fashionable Valparaíso, Chile
text: ON a July afternoon in the Chilean port city of Valparaíso, in the middle of the South American winter, I sat in the sunlit dining room at La Concepción, drinking a tart-sweet pisco sour and cutting into a perfectly seared and salted piece of grouper.

headline: Artists Lead the Way in the Oltrarno District of Florence
text: ON a midsummer afternoon in the courtyard of a former convent, a musical performance illustrated the shape of changes taking hold in the Oltrarno district of Florence. Using a pair of traditional items (a cello and a loom), a duo fashioned an entirely new sound  something like ambient electronica, only earthier  which issued into the twilight and drew enthusiastic reactions from onlookers.

headline: Hotel Review: Commune by the Great Wall, Near Beijing
text: THE BASICS

headline: James Up Next as Knicks Impress No One
text: The Knicks’ top priority this season, other than hoarding salary-cap space for LeBron James, is to impress LeBron James. They need him to believe they can be respectable, competitive and worthy of his presence when free agency opens in July.

headline: Budget Monitor Says G.O.P. Bill Leaves Many Uninsured
text: The Congressional Budget Office said on Wednesday that an alternative health care bill put forward by House Republicans would have little impact in extending health benefits to the roughly 30 million uninsured Americans, but would reduce average insurance premium costs for people who have coverage.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Fox Wins Election Night Ratings on Cable
text: An off-year election night of Republican victories in New Jersey and Virginia proved to be a big winner for the Fox News Channel, Nielsen ratings showed Wednesday.

headline: 36 Hours in Nashville
text: NASHVILLE isn’t nicknamed Music City for nothing. Singers, songwriters and pickers  not to mention their toe-tapping admirers  have been pouring into the Tennessee capital for decades. Yes, the city’s rhinestone-studded past still glimmers, especially downtown, where you’ll find Hatch Show Print, the legendary poster shop, Ryman Auditorium, home to the original Grand Ole Opry stage, and a slew of honky-tonk joints. But there’s more to Nashville than country music, especially in the once-sleepy neighborhoods that now beat to a different rhythm. Districts like East Nashville and 12 South thrive with lively bars, stylish restaurants and a young, eclectic crop of music makers, churning out everything from bluegrass to punkabilly.

headline: A Powerful Idea on Youth Violence
text: As a former beat cop, Ron Huberman, the new chief of public schools in Chicago, learned long ago that violence among young urban people could not be solved simply by hauling ever larger numbers of children off to jail.

headline: In Prague, Toasts to the Velvet Revolution
text: THERE will be sirens, the menacing growls of attack dogs and blinding searchlights. But this time the terror will be prerecorded, a staged reminder that in this part of Europe, free speech once had a terrible price tag.

headline: Classical Music Takes Center Stage at the White House
text: WASHINGTON  Wednesday was classical music day at the White House. The festivities and performances were sponsored by the President’s Committee on the Arts and the Humanities, created by executive order in 1982. The first lady serves as honorary chairwoman of the committee, and Michelle Obama, fully embracing that function, has created a White House Music Series.

headline: Take the Shot
text: The swine flu vaccine has encountered a remarkably mixed reception. Some people are railing against their doctors about the vaccine’s scarcity while others are waiting hours in line for their shots. But a surprisingly large number of people  even some health care workers  are holding back because they fear the vaccine or don’t view the virus as all that great a threat.

headline: U.S.S. Missouri
text: The rising sun over the Koolau Mountains cast a glow upon the ballistic missiles planted on the lawn of a submarine museum at the edge of Pearl Harbor, throwing long shadows across the water. They pointed at the bone-white memorial to the U.S.S. Arizona and, just beyond it, at the still-floating battleship Missouri, about to leave her pier.

headline: The Political Map After the ’09 Vote
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Dog’s Intelligence
text: To the Editor:

headline: Prompting From the Wings
text: To the Editor:

headline: Helping Older Americans: The View From AARP
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hark! The Voters Speak!
text: Cincinnati

headline: Unhealthy America
text: The moment of truth for health care is at hand, and the distortion that perhaps gets the most traction is this:

headline: Finally, an Authentic G.O.P.
text: Alexandria, Va.

headline: Relax, Democrats
text: TO hear Republicans tell it, Tuesday’s elections, in which their candidates captured the governorships of Virginia and New Jersey, were a repudiation of President Obama and indicated a voter shift toward their party. They should calm themselves down. The results don’t show this and, in fact, suggest some rather daunting challenges for the Republicans.

headline: Justices, in Aftermath of 2 Murder Cases, Hear Claims of a Process Gone Wrong
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments Wednesday in two cases involving claims that the criminal justice system had gone badly awry.

headline: Thousands Failed to Vote, for Just as Many Reasons
text: New Yorkers by the tens of thousands failed to vote on Tuesday. And their reasons and excuses for not doing so numbered almost as many  apathy, absent-mindedness, willful protest and, for a great number, a belief that their vote just wouldn’t count in a race that was not supposed to be in doubt.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the Paris public bicycle rental system’s problems with theft and vandalism referred imprecisely to the cost of the specially designed bikes. While each bike costs about $3,500 at current exchange rates when the system’s startup and maintenance expenses are included, the manufacturing cost of each bike is about $1,050.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about a bomb detection device used by the Iraqi security forces that is considered useless and costly by the American military misstated the surname of the leader of ATSC (UK) Ltd., the London-based company that has sold hundreds of the devices to Iraq’s Interior Ministry. He is Jim McCormick, not Mitchell.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: William Belton, Self-Taught Ornithologist, Dies at 95
text: Once upon a time, every tweet had an actual bird attached. If that bird happened to live in southern Brazil, a region whose rich avian life was long undocumented, chances are good that it was stalked repeatedly  and its tweets, coos and whistles recorded patiently  by William Belton.

headline: Saudi Arabia: Attackers Kill Border Guard
text: A Saudi border guard was killed and 10 were wounded Wednesday when gunmen from Yemen opened fire, the state-run Saudi Press Agency reported. The attack appeared to be the first on Saudi Arabia by the Houthi rebels, who have fought intermittently against the Yemeni government for more than five years, analysts said. The Houthis issued a statement saying they took control of the Jebel Dukhan area where the attack took place because Saudi Arabia had allowed the Yemeni Army to use the area for attacks on Houthis.

headline: Using Marijuana Stores to Market Food
text: AFTER Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced in March that he would end the Bush administration practice of frequently raiding medical marijuana dispensaries, the dispensaries have been growing, appropriately enough, like weeds.

headline: Britain: Conservatives Back Off Treaty Vote
text: A day after the Lisbon Treaty to strengthen the European Union cleared its last major hurdle, the leader of the British Conservatives, David Cameron, announced Wednesday that he would not hold a referendum on the accord if he became prime minister. Mr. Cameron had earlier promised to hold a referendum, but that was before it became clear that all 27 member countries would agree to the treaty. “A made-up referendum might make people feel better for five minutes,” he said in a speech in London, “but my job is to put together a plan that lasts five years.”

headline: The Vote for Mayor, Block by Block
text: Mayor Bloomberg won re-election, but voters were less enthusiastic about him than the last time he ran in 2005.

headline: Best Health Care in the World?
text: My Thursday column takes aim at one of the main arguments of the opponents of health reform, that we shouldn’t mess with the best health care system in the world. It’s a remarkably common delusion in the United States, while I almost never run into foreigners who would want to adopt the American system.

headline: Delaware Laws, Helpful to Arms Trafficker, to Be Scrutinized
text: A Russian businessman who investigators say is the world’s largest arms trafficker used secret corporations formed in Delaware and other states to finance his activities. Now, the state’s business and tax practices are coming under Congressional scrutiny at a hearing on Thursday.

headline: Offer Incentives, but Carefully
text: Frank A. D’Amelio may be worth the $6 million of compensation he received last year as chief financial officer for Pfizer. But it’s questionable for the drug company to also pay him a $1.2 million bonus  half in cash and half in stock  for his role in acquiring its rival Wyeth. Rewarding executives for going shopping is daft.

headline: Will the Yankees’ Victory Favor Wall St.’s Bulls?
text: Update | 11:56 p.m. Wall Street should be happy that the New York Yankees won the World Series — and not just because the team is from New York. A coincidental sports indicator shows that a Yankee victory in the series has historically been bullish for the stock market.

headline: Gustaf Mahler Unveils a New Philharmonic
text: Friday, Nov. 5, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: USAA: An Insurance Club That Just Got Bigger
Report Says Big Buyouts Are Likelier to Default
text: Apparently, bigger isn’t always better  especially on Wall Street.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the legal problems of Raj Rajaratnam, a hedge fund manager charged with trading on inside information, misstated an arbitration panel’s damage award to Mr. Rajaratnam and Gary Rosenbach, another Galleon executive, on their claim that they were misled by the creators and promoters of a tax shelter later disallowed by the Internal Revenue Service. Although the panel found that $10 million in damages and interest was due and that John Schrier, a lawyer and accountant who recommended the shelter, was 50 percent responsible, it did not award damages from Mr. Schrier, who was not a party to the arbitration. Mr. Schrier and KPMG, his former employer, had already settled a related lawsuit on undisclosed terms, denying wrongdoing. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to Mr. Schrier’s role in the tax shelter. He helped market the tax shelter to Mr. Rajaratnam and Mr. Rosenbach; he did not create it.

headline: George Na’ope, Master of Sacred Hula, Dies at 81
text: George Na’ope, whose mastery of the hula  the flowing, pantomimic dance of Hawaii  and its lilting chants made him a last link between an ancient ritual and modern entertainment, died on Oct. 26 at his home in Hilo, Hawaii. He was 81.

headline: Back on Top, Yankees Add a 27th Title
text: A sliver of time for other teams is an epoch for the Yankees, who define themselves by championships. For eight seasons, they led the majors in victories, payroll and drama. They built a ballpark, created a network and expanded their brand around the globe. But they did not win the World Series.

headline: Martinez Without Magic in Finale
text: In the shadow of his famed mango tree, survival skills came naturally to Pedro Martinez. His family slept on the floor of a tin-roofed house, two, sometimes three to a mattress. Instead of a bat, he would swing a broomstick. Instead of a ball, he would throw balled-up socks.

headline: Corrections
text: The two photographs in the Transactions column on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday were reversed. The top picture showed the building for sale or lease at 438 West 51st Street, Manhattan, and the bottom picture showed the building that was recently sold at 205 West 88th Street, Manhattan.

headline: Corrections
text: The Really column on Oct. 20, about the claim that garlic can ward off a cold, omitted the source for the study it cited in support of garlic’s benefits. It was performed by Peter Josling, a British researcher who also runs a Web site promoting garlic supplements.

headline: Corrections
text: An answer in the Q&A column on Tuesday about why some people get a sore arm at the site of a flu vaccine injection while others do not referred incorrectly to Dr. E. Yoko Furuya, assistant director of epidemiology at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center. Dr. Furuya is a woman.

headline: Francisco Ayala, a Spanish Novelist and Literary Scholar, Dies at 103
text: Francisco Ayala, an eminent Spanish novelist whose work explored societies in which there is much despotism and little benevolence, died on Tuesday at his home in Madrid. He was 103.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a proposal to remove Asperger’s syndrome from the next edition of psychiatry’s diagnostic manual misstated the educational affiliation for Temple Grandin, a well-known American with autism. She is a professor of animal science at Colorado State University, not the University of Colorado.

headline: Prices Far Surpass Estimates at Sotheby’s Auction
text: In an Impressionist and modern art sale that had all the right ingredients  quality, value and variety  Sotheby’s salesroom was teeming on Wednesday night with a United Nations of enthusiastic bidders from Latin America, China, the United States, Russia and elsewhere in Europe.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Saturday about the theater impresario John Kenley gave the wrong year for a production of “Picnic” in which Mr. Kenley cast the football star Joe Namath. It was 1979, after Mr. Namath had retired from football  not 1971, when he was “still near the height of his career as quarterback of the New York Jets.”

headline: A Celebration, Washington Heights Style
text: As Champagne celebrations go, the best one after the Yankees won the World Series might have been the one on the sidewalk of 191st Street in Washington Heights.

headline: Can You Get the Flu From Mickey?
text: WHOM do you know who has been affected by the H1N1 virus, or Swine Flu?

headline: South Korea Pension Buys 40 Grosvenor Place
text: South Korea’s national pension fund said Thursday it had agreed to buy two office buildings in central London as part of a plan to increase investments in overseas properties, the news service Yonhap reported.

headline: Word of the Day | dilate
text: dilate • \ˈdi-ˌlat, di-ˈ\ • verb

headline: U.N. to Relocate 600 Workers Temporarily
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United Nations office in Afghanistan has decided to send about 600 of its foreign staff members out of the country in the wake of an attack last week on one of its guesthouses while more secure housing is found, a spokesman said Thursday.

headline: Answers About Investor Behavior – Part 3
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you’ll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals on a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Matsui Leaves a Lasting World Series Memory
text: Hideki Matsui does not know if he will ever play another game for the Yankees. The Yankees do not know if he will, either. If Matsui has played his final game with the team, he left the biggest stage in baseball in the same way he moved across it for seven seasons: professionally and exceptionally.

headline: News Quiz | November 5, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: U.N. Relocates Foreign Staff in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The United Nations mission in Afghanistan announced plans on Thursday to relocate hundreds of foreign staff members, sending some out of the country, in the wake of a lethal attack on its workers at a guesthouse last week.

headline: Shopping for Gold
text: A young couple shopped for gold in Kadhimiya, under the watchful eye of the mother-in-law.

headline: Value Line Pays $45 Million to Settle Fraud Case
text: The investment adviser Value Line, two former executives and an affiliated broker-dealer agreed on Wednesday to pay $45 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission fraud case.

headline: Champions Again, Yankees’ Thoughts Turn to The Boss
text: George Steinbrenner always relied on Reggie Jackson to produce for him when he played for the Yankees, and Wednesday Jackson came though again, this time with an accurate and comforting prediction.

headline: Australian Toll Road Firm Rejects $6.2 Billion Bid
text: Transurban Group, Australia’s biggest toll road operator, rejected an unsolicited 6.8 billion-Australian-dollar ($6.2 billion) takeover offer from Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: French Minister Calls British Tories ‘Pathetic’
text: PARIS  In an unusual spat that may foretell choppy relations across the English Channel, a French government minister attacked Britain’s opposition Conservatives months before an election, calling their policy on Europe “pathetic” and reflecting a “bizarre sense of autism.”

headline: Evergrande Leaps in First Day of Trading
text: Evergrande Real Estate Group, the largest Chinese developer by third-quarter sales, rose as much as 20 percent on its trading debut in Hong Kong, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Big Buyouts Seen as Likelier to Default
text: Apparently, bigger isn’t always better — especially on Wall Street.

headline: Och-Ziff Tipped to Reap from Rebound, Goldman Says
text: It seems that Goldman Sachs likes the looks of Och-Ziff Management‘s prospects.

headline: Goldman Books Return in Sale of Shineway Stake
text: Goldman Sachs has agreed to sell half of its holding in Shineway Group, the Chinese meat processor that was among the first leveraged buyout targets in the country by a group of foreign investors, Reuters reported, citing sources with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline: Now Showing | ‘Dysfashional’
text: The world needs another fashion exhibition like Valentino needs another pug. But “Dysfashional,” which opened this week at the Passage du Désir in Paris, gives hope that despite the surfeit of recent shows, the subject matter may still have some bite. Although the show’s curators, Luca Marchetti and Emanuele Quinz, have tapped designers like Raf Simons, Hussein Chalayan and Gaspard Yurkievich to contribute, the pair has chosen not to exhibit clothing, preferring instead to focus on the ideas and spectacle that surround fashion. Explains Marchetti, “Dysfashional tackles the seemingly frivolous yet vital realm of fashion by examining the approach of designers and artists from various backgrounds, bringing us closer to a world in which the protagonists are not the objects but the creative process itself.”

headline: Should C.E.O.s Be Rewarded for Dealmaking?
text: Frank A. D’Amelio may be worth the $6 million of compensation he received last year as chief financial officer for Pfizer. But, Breakingviews says, it’s questionable for the drug company to also pay him a $1.2 million bonus — half in cash and half in stock — for his role in acquiring its rival Wyeth. Rewarding executives for going shopping is crazy, the publication suggests.

headline: For Kraft, What Price Cadbury?
text: Kraft, the Oreo-to-Cheez Whiz conglomerate, beat profit estimates for the third quarter but lowered its sales forecast for the year. That highlights the charms of Cadbury, the faster-growing British confectioner Kraft is circling. But Kraft would still struggle to justify making a hostile bid higher than its current offer, Breakingviews argues.

headline: Martinez Not in Mood to Talk
text: A crowd of reporters was waiting outside the Phillies’ clubhouse late Wednesday night, maybe 15 minutes after the game, when someone said that Pedro Martinez had just left and was walking toward the Yankee Stadium exit. It seemed bizarre — why would Martinez be leaving before his teammates (Shane Victorino, for one, didn’t know he was already gone), and before speaking to the news media? .

headline: Non-Fire Night
text: Health and safety inspired bonfire-less bonfire night celebrations.

headline: Should Gay Couples Be Allowed to Marry?
text: A Maine state law permitting same-sex marriage was repealed at the polls on Tuesday. What, if anything, do you think the Maine vote says about the national mind-set about gay marriage?On Wednesday, Abby Goodnough reported on the efforts to promote same-sex marriage to voters in Maine and what the outcome of the vote might suggest:

headline: Winston & Strawn Hires Nixon Peabody P.E. Team
text: Looking to crack the New York private equity market, law firm Winston & Strawn has nabbed a group of eight lawyers led by Dominick DeChiara from rival Nixon Peabody, to launch a core deal team in the city.

headline: Stocks Lose Steam at Close on Wall Street
text: The Dow Jones industrial average erased almost all of a 156-point rally after the House of Representatives passed a bill to curb rate increases on credit cards, touching off concern about bank earnings. The news outweighed investor optimism after the Federal Reserve said it planned to keep interest rates at a record low, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Sequoia Puts $6.5 Million into Eventbrite
text: Eventbrite, the online event management and ticketing site, has landed $6.5 million in fresh funding, led by a new investor, Sequoia Capital, TechCrunch reported.

headline: AOL Dents Time Warner Ahead of Spinoff
text: Time Warner‘s third-quarter results make it abundantly clear why the media conglomerate can’t wait to get rid of AOL.

headline: Riding the Roads as the Romans Do
text: How do Romans get that extra kick between espressos? They hop on a Vespa, take a deep breath and plunge into the city’s famously chaotic traffic. If the idea makes your hair stand on end, renting one of the motor scooters may not be for you. But if you know your way around on two wheels back home, once you get going, you’ll find there is an elaborate code of order on the roads.

headline: Solid Results for One Dealmaker: Cisco
text: Cisco Systems, the computer networking giant that has been on a bit of a shopping spree of late, supplied more evidence on Wednesday that technology sales were recovering along with the global economy.

headline: Google Offers Users a Peek at Stored Data
text: Update 2:25 PM Adds Comments From More Privacy Advocates

headline: Is Dodd on Collision Course Over Banking Bill?
text: Legislation being prepared by the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Christopher J. Dodd, would redraw how the financial system is regulated and could pit the Senate against the House and the Obama administration, which have backed distinctly different plans to overhaul the financial system, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Committee Allows a Break on Certain Auditing Rules
text: Legislation that its supporters say would provide greater protection to investors sailed through a House committee on Wednesday, but not before the lawmakers added a provision to ease new auditing standards for small and medium-size companies, The New York Times’s Stephen Labaton reported.

headline: Matsui Goes Wild, and So Do His Fans in Japan
text: TOKYO  For many Japanese, Hideki Matsui is a man of contradictions  a towering hulk with a sensitive heart, a player of fierce self-discipline known for lewd jokes and a national hero who refuses to play for his country at international tournaments, much to the chagrin of his home fans.

headline: Some Wall St. Bonuses May Hit Pre-Crisis Highs
text: Now is the time of year when a Wall Streeter’s fancy turns to thoughts of bonuses.

headline: Cuomo Files Antitrust Suit Against Intel
text: In 2005, Michael S. Dell’s namesake company was getting pounded. His competitors were selling personal computers and servers built on cheap, popular and powerful chips from Advanced Micro Devices, while Mr. Dell had stuck loyally with slower chips from Intel.

headline: On-Q-ity Lands $21 Million
text: On-Q-ity, a new cancer diagnostics business, announced that it has raised $21 million in venture capital. The round was led by Mohr Davidow Ventures and included Bessemer Ventures, Physic Ventures and Northgate Capital.

headline: Will the Real Larry Summers Please Stand Up?
text: There seems to be little doubt that Lawrence H. Summers is a polarizing figure.

headline: Is This the Droid You’re Looking For?
text: The latest hotly-anticipated “app phone”  a term David Pogue Twit-sourced  is the Motorola Droid. It runs on Verizon and Google’s Android operating system (the 2.0 version) and the design, Pogue writes, “screams ‘Star Wars,’ if not ‘Darth Vader.’ It’s jet-black, all sharp angles and industrial-looking edges.” It’s super-fast, with good audio quality, a pull-out screen and a stellar GPS. The Droid may not be an iPhone killer, Pogue writes, but it is “a killer phone.” Get it starting tomorrow for $200 after a $100 rebate (Pogue’s tip: “Get it at Best Buy, where you get the rebate on the spot”) and play with it in your man cave.

headline: Home Green Home: Burning Wisely
text: The following is the latest in a series exploring the ways Americans are improving the efficiency and reducing the footprint of their homes. Green Inc. readers are encouraged to share their thoughts and experiences in the comments section, or by sending e-mail messages to greeninc@nytimes.com.

headline: Unpublishable Name
text: The Canadian band ****** Up , led by a bearded, jowly  and surprisingly jolly  singer named Pink Eyes, builds “an ecosystem of gorgeous guitar harmony and ambient texture inside the gray rhythmic world of stomping eighth-note punk,” writes Ben Ratliff. So: they’re lovelier than they may seem. This will be especially true tonight, when they play the entirety of their latest, critically-beloved album, “The Chemistry of Common Life,” at the Brooklyn Masonic Temple with the help of special guests Andrew W.K. and Vivian Girls. Come early for the openers Titus Andronicus.

headline: ‘Idiot Savant’ at the Public
text: “Idiot Savant,”  the latest from the long-running downtown auteur Richard Foreman, stars Willem Dafoe in the title role, and allows its actors to speculate at length about what it means to be in a play about an idiot savant, and whether they’re idiots for even talking about it. Classic Foreman, writes Ben Brantley, but amped up by Dafoe, who wears a costume that is “unequal parts samurai warrior, 17th-century French courtier and contemporary businessman,” and brings “a star’s bright idiosyncrasy” to the part. “It raises the humor and humanity to heights rarely felt in a Foreman work,” Brantley writes. Get your tickets now; it’s at the Public.

headline: Obama in China: Breaking the Exchange-Rate Deadlock
text: Simon Johnson, a professor of entrepreneurship at M.I.T.’s Sloan School of Management, is the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Indonesia Officials Resign in Graft Scandal

headline: Unleashing Life’s Wild Things

There was a lot of speculation too about the size, composition and receptivity of the audience. Would children embrace it? Would adults be scared off? Who was this movie  so melancholy in its whimsy, so rueful in its sentiment  really meant for?

headline: Outsiders Are In
text: Where have all the outlaws gone? Not your everyday miscreants — the world has enough of those — but baddies who were revered as much as feared: Robin Hood, Marius Jacob, Blackbeard, Calamity Jane. There’s something refreshingly anachronistic about these old-school brigands, and their appeal is not lost on today’s artists. The indie rock band the Decemberists have populated an entire songbook with bandit queens, ne’er-do-wells and murderous rakes. And noirish biopics like “Public Enemies” reveal that not only are we perpetually captivated by outlaws, but their daring and style also seem increasingly remote from the present &#8212 no one’s casting Marion Cotillard to play Ruth Madoff.

headline: Boyle Moves Mountains for ‘Slumdog Millionaire’ Follow-Up
text: Choosing one’s next movie project after winning Academy Awards for best director and best film doesn’t always come quickly — just ask James Cameron — but Danny Boyle, whose film “Slumdog Millionaire” won eight Oscars in February, has figured out his follow-up. Variety reported that Mr. Boyle (whose films also include “Trainspotting” and “28 Days Later”) will next direct “127 Hours,” a biographical film about the mountaineer Aron Lee Ralston. Mr. Ralston made headlines in 2003 when, in his exploration of Robbers Roost in southeastern Utah, an 800-pound boulder fell on his right hand and crushed it; after being trapped for several days, he sawed off the trapped arm and hiked to his rescue. The project is expected to reunite Mr. Boyle with his “Slumdog Millionaire” screenwriter Simon Beaufoy and producer Christian Colson. Production is expected to begin next year; no casting has yet been announced.

headline: Conductor Slatkin Recovering After Heart Attack
text: Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, told The Detroit Free Press that he felt lucky to be alive after having emergency surgery on Sunday to unblock a clogged artery. Mr. Slatkin, 65, the former music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, had a heart attack while conducting the Rotterdam Philharmonic in the Netherlands, and is now resting in a hospital there after undergoing an angioplasty and stent procedure. In an e-mail exchange with The Free Press, Mr. Slatkin wrote that he experienced chest pains earlier in the week but dismissed them as indigestion. At the Sunday concert, he wrote: “I started having trouble with chest pain and I was sweating more than usual. Again, I thought it would go away but it stuck around. I sort of collapsed in the dressing room and a medical team from the hall was sent in. Five minutes later I was in an ambulance on the way to the hospital.” He added that he was scheduled to fly to Prague later that night, “and it is very possible that I might not have survived that long.” The Detroit Symphony Orchestra told The Free Press that Mr. Slatkin is still scheduled to conduct the orchestra in Detroit this month, but contingency plans are being made in case he is unable to perform.

headline: No. 1 Omission From Top 10 Book List: Women

headline: Teutonic Plates | Berlin’s Gastro Get-Togethers
text: Before the Berlin wall came down in 1989, the two Germanys each had their own culinary history. Spicy Russian stew in the East, maultaschen and sauerkraut in the West. This weekend, a couple of international gourmands are pitting the two sides against one another, inviting the culinarily curious to engage in a little exercise of gastro politics. Saturday, Sunday and Monday — the three nights leading up to the 20th anniversary of the fall of the wall — the writer and part-time Berlin resident Caroline Hobkinson, along with the Cordon Bleu-trained pastry chef Rachel Khoo, are hosting 30-euro, five-course dinners in an apartment just 50 yards from the old wall.

headline: Two More Billys for Broadway
text: Poor Mrs. Elliot may be gone to heaven, but somehow, she keeps reproducing. On Thursday, the producers of “Billy Elliot the Musical” said two more actors would be joining its Broadway cast to portray the title role. Dayton Tavares, 13, who has played the character in the musical’s Sydney and Melbourne casts, will become the sixth member of the Broadway Billy club, and Liam Redhead, 14, a student of the National Ballet School in Toronto, will become the seventh, the show’s publicists said in a news release. Additionally, Tommy Batchelor, who is leaving the Broadway cast to play Billy in the show’s Chicago production, will play his final New York performance on Dec. 11. The Broadway role was originated by David Alvarez, Kiril Kulish and Trent Kowalik, who won Tony Awards for their performances. Starting dates for Mr. Tavares and Mr. Redhead were not announced.

headline: The New Face of Ulcer Disease
text: When a former first lady, Barbara Bush, was rushed to a Houston emergency room late last year with terrible pain from a perforated ulcer in her stomach, she was in many ways the typical face of ulcer disease today in the United States. The source of Mrs. Bush’s trouble was not Helicobacter pylori, the notorious ulcer-instigating bacterium. Instead, as is true in a rising proportion of ulcer cases, the culprit was pain medications.

text: Expedia, the large online travel agency, is eliminating its $20 booking fee for travel reservations made by phone.

headline: Pregame Huddle: Expect the Unexpected
text: The surprising Iowa Hawkeyes are looking to stay undefeated, while Duke and North Carolina take their rivalry off the hard court.

headline: Texting as a Health Tool for Teenagers
text: Gina (not her real name) had been born with a defect in her liver, with ducts so damaged and narrow that the bile could not drain. In the first year of her life, she underwent two urgent operations. The first was an unsuccessful effort to convert a loop of intestine into a drainage system for her bile; the second was a lifesaving liver transplant.

headline: Texting for Better Health
text: Text messaging is widely viewed as an annoying and sometimes risky teen distraction. But new research suggests it can be a useful tool for encouraging teenagers to take regular medication, Dr. Pauline W. Chen reports today in the Doctor and Patient column.

headline: Medical Apps for the iPhone
text: Last week, I spoke at the TED MED conference. It's like the much higher-profile TED conference (you can read about it on my blog), but under different management and, of course, dedicated to healthcare topics.

headline: Iraqis Again Fail to Approve Election Law
text: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi Parliament failed again on Thursday to approve a law to regulate a national election in January, deepening doubts about whether the nation can hold the vote on schedule.

text: Last week, I spoke at the TED MED conference. It’s like the much higher-profile TED conference (you can read about it here), but under different management and, of course, dedicated to healthcare topics.

headline: Answers About New York City Politics, Part 2
text: Here is the second set of responses from Bruce F. Berg, a professor and the author of “New York City Politics: Governing Gotham” (Rutgers University Press), about city politics and the 2009 elections.

headline: Obama Announces Endorsements for Health Care Bill
text: President Obama made a surprise appearance at the daily White House press briefing on Thursday afternoon to announce that the nation’s leading advocacy group for the elderly as well as the largest doctor’s organization have endorsed the current health care plan being considered in Congress.

headline: Graceful Interchanges, Now Doubling as Civic Sculpture
text: NEW YORKERS maintain that Los Angeles is a city with no center. But Angelenos argue that the city of freeways has its core in the Stack, a tower of overpasses  the first four-level connector interchange, according to the California Transportation Department  where the Pasadena, Harbor, Hollywood and Santa Ana freeways intersect.

headline: Shake Shack to Open in Miami
text: The Shake Shack empire will expand to Miami next year, making it the first Danny Meyer restaurant outside of New York, according to his Union Square Hospitality Group. No firm date yet, but it will go up on Lincoln Road.

headline: Follow the Money, and the History
text: For bankers and brokers, Wall Street is not so much a place as perhaps a dream (or, last year, a nightmare): a churning pool of risk, debt, credit, and information that is best realized in the physical world as the blinking screen of a Bloomberg terminal. But for ordinary New Yorkers, Wall Street is a neighborhood, a neck of the city’s woods that more or less runs from ground zero to Battery Park. There, one finds the aorta of the nation’s financial heart, of course, but also shops and cafes and bits of history.

headline: Can Eventbrite Shine in Ticketmaster’s World?
text: For big rock concerts and sporting events held in huge venues, Ticketmaster dominates the landscape. For the kind of event you might find promoted with a flier on a telephone pole, there’s a budding start-up called Eventbrite.

headline: Going Beyond the Book Report With Literature Exhibits
text: Overview | Where do authors find inspiration? How can objects reveal and represent theme and character in an author’s work? How can creative assignments elicit understanding of literature in different ways from direct analysis? In this lesson, students consider the ways the author Orhan Pamuk uses objects as inspiration in his novel, “The Museum of Innocence,” and create museum exhibits to reflect the themes, characters and plot lines of works they are currently studying in class.

headline: Saudis Strike Yemeni Rebels Along Border
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi warplanes bombed a group of Yemeni rebels late Wednesday on the countries’ remote border, a day after the rebels overran a strategic hilltop and killed a Saudi border guard.

headline: Hiking Hong Kong? ‘Tis the Season
text: You get a very different perspective on Hong Kong if you get out of the city — and doing so is surprisingly easy. Indeed, hiking is a very popular pastime for Hong Kongers who want to substitute a bit of real jungle for the concrete.

headline: Snapshots From Hardlucksville
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: Details on Friday’s Yankee Parade and Ceremony
text: The Yankees return to the Canyon of Heroes for the first time since 2000 on Friday morning, when they will float up Broadway in a ticker-tape parade and share their 27th World Series victory with fans in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Ida Forms in Southwest Caribbean
text: On Wednesday afternoon, TD11 formed just off the northern coast of Panama. It doesn’t appear to have come from an easterly wave, but rather a persistent area of convection that sat and festered for a week or so. At such a low latitude, it takes quite a while for the Coriolis effect to influence the circulation of a low pressure. Later on Wednesday, an aircraft found that it had sustained winds high enough to warrant upgrading it to Tropical Storm Ida. On Thursday morning, it was again upgraded to Hurricane Ida (3rd hurricane of the season), with sustained winds of 65kts and a central pressure of 987mb. It’s presently located right on the east-central Nicaraguan coast and looks well-organized for being so close to land.

headline: Obama’s Remarks on the A.M.A. and AARP Endorsements
text: Following is a transcript of President Obama's remarks on Thursday in which he announced that the AARP and the American Medical Association have endorsed the current health care legislation in Congress, as released by the White House:

headline: Trailer Premiere: ‘The White Ribbon’
text: Today we are showing the trailer  for Michael Haneke’s latest film, ”The White Ribbon.” The drama, set on the eve of World War I, examines a group of families living in a village in northern Germany and a series of crimes that shake up the community. Manohla Dargis called the film, which won the Palme d’Or at the 2009 Cannes Film Festival, ”a meticulous examination of patriarchal domination.” In an Arts & Leisure piece, Stuart Klawans writes about  the ways in which the film anticipates Nazism.

headline: Marketing Madness: Coal for Children
text: The coloring book below, intended to teach children about the coal industry, was published by the public relations arm of the West Virginia Coal Association.

headline: Where Do These Yankee Champions Rank?
text: With three rounds of playoffs, one of them a best-of-five series, the modern postseason is designed to ensure that the best team in baseball only wins the World Series a small percentage of the time. This randomness inherent in the playoffs is the game’s built-in remedy for its competitive balance woes, and has felled four different Yankee squads this decade that posted the game’s best record but fell short of a title. Yet while the last Yankees club to bring home a championship, the 87-win 2000 team, reinforced the notion that the postseason is a crapshoot, the 2009 edition offers a different lesson: sometimes, just being really, really good is indeed good enough to win it all.

headline: The Plethore LC-750, a Canadian Supercar
text: LAS VEGAS — When you think Canada, you think supercar, non?

headline: Q&A: New York City for a Teenage Visitor
text: Q.

headline: A Chaminade Moment for LeMoyne
text: LeMoyne’s 82-79 victory over Syracuse on Tuesday was stunning in its own right.

headline: The lost generation
text: Matthew Yglesias catches Eugene Fama making a strange assertion:

headline: The Cat Who Got Swine Flu
text: A few days after two members of an Ames, Iowa, family came down with the flu, they noticed their 13-year-old cat wasn’t feeling too well either. The cat has since become the first documented case of a feline with the new H1N1 virus, commonly called swine flu.

headline: Melissa Johnson and Timothy Lagasse
text: MELISSA JOHNSON is known for her sardonic humor and love of dark, gory films and burlesque. So no one was more surprised than she when she fell for an endlessly upbeat designer and fabricator of puppets who spends his days on the sets of children’s television shows like “Sesame Street” and “Between the Lions.”

headline: 11/5/09: Blue Jackets in Jeopardy, Chamber of Commerce Report Says
text: A report commissioned by the Columbus business community adds the Blue Jackets to the list of N.H.L. teams on the financial brink, The Columbus Dispatch reports on Thursday.

headline: Gee-yoncé
text: Nickname given to Lady Gaga after filming the music video for Beyoncé’s single, “Video Phone.”

headline: U.S. Readies Jobless Aid and Help on Homes
text: WASHINGTON  In separate actions to address Americans’ continuing economic hardship, the government moved Thursday to assist long-unemployed workers and struggling businesses, as well as home buyers and homeowners facing foreclosure.

headline: Thailand Recalls Its Ambassador to Cambodia
text: BANGKOK  The Thai government announced Thursday that it was recalling its ambassador to Cambodia to protest Cambodia’s appointment of Thaksin Shinawatra, who was ousted as Thailand’s prime minister, to a high-profile position. The moves put new strains on already tense relations between the countries.

headline: Sugar High at Haunch of Venison
text: Topless women holding cocktail trays with bite-size servings of creamy cake by Creative Edge’s Bob Spiegel provided some of the insane sugar rush of last night’s dessert feast at Christie’s Haunch of Venison gallery. The art-world scenesters pounced with hypoglycemic glee on layered sweets designed by four Manhattan pastry chefs, who collaborated with four New York artists for an event commissioned by Kreemart, an organization that lets artists explore desserts as a medium (we kid you not), for the American Patrons of the Tate Museum in London.

headline: New York City Transit Gets New President
text: The New York City bus and subway system got a new leader on Thursday, as transit officials hope to move ahead with new technology while grappling with budget cuts and serious concerns about long-term financing.

headline: Pinnacle of the Past, Just $2.1 Million
text: MY mission today is to offer my clear-eyed take on the Bugatti Veyron 16.4 Grand Sport. But the price keeps getting in the way.

headline: Treating the Pain Epidemic
text: Chronic pain affects more than 70 million Americans, which makes it more widespread than heart disease, cancer and diabetes combined. It costs the economy more than $100 billion per year. So why don’t more doctors and researchers take it seriously?

headline: Governor Puts Same-Sex Marriage on Legislative Agenda
text: ALBANY — Gov. David A. Paterson has included gay marriage on the agenda of an extraordinary session he is calling for Tuesday, administration officials said Thursday.

headline: More Rules for Restaurant Staffers
text: Bruce Buschel’s back on the “You’re the Boss” blog with Part 2 of his 100 Things Restaurant Staffers Should Never Do post. Mr. Buschel is opening a restaurant in Bridgehampton, N.Y., his first. He knows something about publicity. Part 1 of his list of rules for staffers blew up on the Web last week in the manner of one of those articles about gay penguins or how to train your husband or indignities suffered by people of privilege. It was e-mailed, blogged, tweeted and retweeted, debated and hated and loved.

headline: A Hybrid Stakes Out High Ground
text: FOR every smartly realized hybrid like the Toyota Prius or Ford Fusion, there has been one whose combination of price, economy and practicality doesn’t quite add up.

headline: House Democrats Seek Allies for Health Care Vote
text: WASHINGTON  House Democratic leaders worked furiously on Thursday to secure the final votes for weekend approval of a sweeping health care overhaul as President Obama threw his weight behind the lobbying effort and Republicans dug in against the health plan.

headline: Profile in Style: Cynthia Rowley
text: The designer makes high-spirited fashion -- but that's nothing compared to her exuberant family life.

headline: Already Depleted Nets Wearing Thin
text: The Nets faced an uphill struggle this season after purging their payroll during the off-season. That trek is not any less steep with a medical roll call of early injuries.

headline: Top Palestinian Rules Out Race for Re-election
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, warned on Thursday that he would not seek re-election, the latest sign that the Obama administration’s drive to broker a Middle East peace accord, one of President Obama’s key foreign policy goals, has fallen into disarray.

headline: Rajaratnam’s Travel Restrictions Are Loosened
text: The Galleon Group‘s founder, Raj Rajaratnam, who has been charged with insider trading, can now travel around the United States so long as he informs prosecutors beforehand, a Manhattan federal judge ruled at a hearing of Thursday afternoon.

headline: Segregation as Social Progress
text: One of the hazards (or joys, depending on how you look at it) of being a journalist is that you end up on a lot of mailing lists. And so it was that a post I once wrote about the transgender wage gap earned me an influx of e-mail about transgender issues — including an invitation to check out a site that wrote about financial advice for transgender people.

headline: Casting News for ‘Next Fall,’ ‘Love, Loss and What I Wore,’ and More
text: Updated | 4:22 p.m.  So much theater news today that we have to deliver it in bullet-point form:

headline: Bank of New York Chief Shuns BofA’s Top Job
text: Robert P. Kelly, chief executive of Bank of New York Mellon, told his senior managers on Thursday that he was not interested in taking the top job at Bank of America, defusing speculation that he would leave his current post.

headline: Quiet on the Waterfront
text: WHO Chris Hallweaver, 52, a marketing consultant, and his wife, Betsy, 52, a school administrator in Yarmouth, Me.

headline: Meet the Parents, Again
text: My boyfriend’s parents always show up on our vacations. When we went to Washington, they visited. When we went camping, guess who stayed at the local hotel? I’ve talked with my boyfriend, but he says: “They always come at this time of year,” or “They had their vacation planned before ours.” How can I talk to his mother without upsetting her?

headline: Air Quality Is Now an Inside Job
text: WHEN the Ecology Center, a nonprofit environmental advocacy group, released its 2009 guide to toxic chemicals in cars in September, the results held a pleasant surprise. For the first time since the center began rating vehicle interiors in 2007, a car built in the United States by a Detroit automaker had the lowest levels of toxic chemicals among all the models evaluated.

headline: Officer Is Arraigned on Drunken Driving Charges
text: Updated, 4:20 p.m. | An off-duty police officer arrested after his vehicle struck and killed a woman in Brooklyn on Sept. 27 was arraigned on vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving charges Thursday morning, following a grand jury indictment.

headline: A Historic River Town Where the West Began
text: Marietta, Ohio — A DEEP current of history runs through this quiet town of 15,000 nestled in the arms of the Ohio and Muskingum Rivers. Indians first left their mark here, in great earthen burial mounds. Then, as the first chartered city in the Northwest Territory, Marietta felt the nation’s initial footprints as it strode west.

headline: Lobsters That Got Away, and Those That Didn’t
text: WESTPORT, Mass. — IN this little town on the south coast, people like me  summer folk  are known as skukes. I’ve never met anyone who knows the real derivation of the term, but it’s not a compliment. Skukes are annoying because they drive up the price of real estate and because they do for fun what year-rounders do for a living. Take lobstering, for example. Most of the summer there was a local man at the town dock selling lobsters for a very reasonable $4.99 a pound. Skukishly, I thought I would be more enterprising and try to catch my own. My goal was by the end of the summer to hear my family complain: “What? Lobster again?”

headline: Davis Considering a Future in Football?
text: Glen Davis, the Celtics forward also known as “Big Baby,” has always had a larger profile than his on-the-court production has warranted. That was one of the things that made it so interesting to see him play a vital role during Boston’s playoff push last season. Averaging 15.8 points a game in Kevin Garnett’s absence, Davis showed that he could be a viable N.B.A. player despite being on the short side (he’s at 6’9″) for a power forward.

headline: From Poland, a Light but Creamy Soup
text: My husband, Andy, and I went to Poland in September to visit some of his relatives, and they took us to the mountain region of Zakopane to a guesthouse that includes both breakfast and dinner. Traditionally, Poles eat simply for breakfast and dinner, often a spread of bread, cheese and meat to make sandwiches. Lunch is the large, hot meal. But at this guesthouse, dinner is more akin to lunch, with a first course of soup followed by a main meat dish served with potatoes and either a slaw of carrots or cabbage.

headline: Chefs Descend on Caymans
text: The Cayman Islands aren’t exactly a culinary destination like New York or Paris, but during one week in January, that’s where you’ll find some of the best chefs in America.

headline: A Ray of Sonnenschein for German ’30 Rock’
text: After its first broadcast on the German channel ZDFNeo drew a rating of 0.0, “30 Rock” had nowhere to go but up. And up it did go: The Hollywood Reporter reported that a second showing of the NBC screwball comedy on Wednesday saw a ratings increase of at least 500 percent: an average of 30,000 viewers tuned in this time. The series is also shown on German TNT.

headline: Mass Shooting at Fort Hood
text: Update | 9:15 p.m. At a news conference outside Fort Hood the base commander, Lt. Gen. Robert Cone, just revealed that earlier reports that the suspected gunman, Major Nidal Hasan, had been killed were incorrect. Major Hasan was wounded but remains alive, Lt. Gen. Cone said, adding that he is in custody and “his death is not imminent.” He added that 12 people, not 11, had been killed by whom the military authorities now describe as a single gunman.

headline: The Waterpod Artist Heads for the Roof
text: Now that she’s gotten her sea legs, Mary Mattingly, an artist who spent her summer living on an eco-art-barge floating around the city, is looking to move on up (to the sky). Ms. Mattingly has proposed that her next project, called “Air Ship Air City,” be installed atop the Metropolitan Exchange Building, a seven-story design and research cooperative in downtown Brooklyn, whose members have given the initial green light to the idea, according to the Brooklyn Paper. The plans for the structure include a chicken coop – the barge, the Waterpod, was home to four chickens – a research lab, hanging gardens, potential living quarters (called the Flock House) and a communal area featuring outdoor couches that Ms. Mattingly envisions as a sort of human nest.

headline: Donning Anew the Miniskirt of a Predator
text: IN the seven seasons Heather Locklear spent on “Melrose Place,” the vintage-1990s Fox soap opera, she was synonymous with ruthlessness, deviousness and hemlines that rose as high as prime-time television would allow.

headline: After Setbacks, Small Successes for Gene Therapy
text: Not long ago, gene therapy seemed troubled by insurmountable difficulties. After decades of hype and dashed hopes, many who once embraced the idea of correcting genetic disorders by giving people new genes all but gave up the idea.

headline: Buy Me Some Curry and Cracker Jack
text: If there is a single shrine to honor Hideki Matsui in New York City, it is located on a grimy corner in the garment center at 237 West 38th street.

headline: Screening: Many Doctors Do Unneeded Pap Smears, Study Finds
text: Many doctors are performing unnecessary Pap smears, ignoring guidelines issued by major medical organizations and adding to health care costs, a survey of physicians has found.

headline: Breeders’ Cup Picks for Friday
text: The Breeders’ Cup begins Friday at Santa Anita Park with six races. Combined with Saturday’s eight races, the weekend purse is more than $25.5 million. Here are Joe Drape’s selections for Friday’s card, which will be shown on ESPN2, all times Eastern.

headline: Follow the Money, and the History
text: For bankers and brokers, Wall Street is not so much a place as perhaps a dream (or, last year, a nightmare): a churning pool of risk, debt, credit and information that is best realized in the physical world as the blinking screen of a Bloomberg terminal. But for ordinary New Yorkers, Wall Street is a neighborhood that more or less runs from ground zero to Battery Park. There, one finds the aorta of the nation’s financial heart, of course, but also shops and cafes and bits of history.

headline: The Morning Skate: David Branch’s Harsh Decision
text: Wednesday’s decision by O.H.L. President David Branch to suspend the Erie Otters’ Michael Liambas for the balance of the season for his board check on Kitchener Rangers defenseman Ben Fanelli last Friday continues to reverberate loudly around the hockey world, and almost every reaction deems the punishment to be harsh.

headline: Fate of ‘Spider-Man’ Musical Could Be Determined on Friday
text: The producers of the multimillion-dollar Broadway musical project “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark,” have scheduled a meeting in Manhattan on Friday with the director Julie Taymor and other members of the creative team to discuss the future of the show, two executives involved in the production said Thursday. A spokesman for the producers confirmed the meeting but declined to discuss the agenda.

headline: The Motorola Droid
text: David Pogue discusses the new smartphone from Motorola, the Droid, on CNBC.

headline: A Contrary Indicator on M.B.A.’s and Stocks
text: Fewer Harvard M.B.A. graduates took jobs on Wall Street this year than in the past as a result of the sharp contraction in the financial services industry. But for Ray Soifer, a former banking analyst and Harvard Business School alumnus, the reduced number of graduates flocking to Wall Street isn’t a bad thing. In fact, it may actually be a positive signal for the market.

headline: Theater Listings: Nov. 6 — 12
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: ‘Green’ and Pony Cars on the Same Stage at SEMA Show
text: LAS VEGAS — The automotive aftermarket parts and accessories industry, which holds its biggest gathering here in early November each year at the Specialty Equipment Market Association’s trade show, would appear to be still alive, if not quite as well as it used to be.

headline: Explaining Why Mom or Dad Can’t Play
text: What to do when a parent is out of commission? How to explain that to a toddler?

headline: As Luck Would Have It ...
text: FIVE days a week, Michael Kiernan, 50, a computer network administrator, makes the 90-minute commute home from the Bronx County Courthouse, where he works, to suburban Long Beach on Long Island. Like a lot of New Yorkers, he has it down to a science. He leaves work at 4:45, walk-jogs across 161st Street, then hurries into the subway, where he gets into the first car on the D train. He stands by the door, riding two stops to 145th Street, then races up the stairs for the A train, a downtown express. Again he stands, in the first car, by the third door, which at 34th Street opens at the stairs to the Long Island Rail Road. If all goes well, he catches the 5:20 home.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Nov. 5
text: A Scottish soldier was laid to rest on Thursday, part of a toll in Afghanistan that has increased Britons’ concern about involvement in the war there.

headline: Touradji Capital Sues 2 Ex-Employees
text: Touradji Capital Management has filed a countersuit against two former employees who sued the commodities hedge fund firm, contending that they were owed $50 million in unpaid bonuses. Touradji’s suit accuses the two men, Robert Vollero and Gentry Beach, of lying about their abilities, stealing secrets and defaming the firm.

headline: Army Doctor Held in Ft. Hood Rampage
text: An Army psychiatrist facing deployment to one of America’s war zones killed 13 people and wounded 30 others on Thursday in a shooting rampage with two handguns at the sprawling Fort Hood Army post in central Texas, military officials said.

headline: Stimulus Is in the Eye of the Beholder
text: From ProPublica’s accounting of some of the “wackier” stimulus-funded projects:

headline: Crist, the Stimulus and White House Hugs
text: Though Republican Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida keeps distancing himself from support for the president’s economic stimulus package and the hug he shared with President Obama earlier this year, the White House sure hasn’t forgotten that embrace.

headline: Celebrating a Champion With Curry
text: Where better to celebrate the Yankees’ world championship and Hideki Matsui’s most valuable player award for the series than at Go! Go! Curry, a shrine to Matsui (number 55, or go go in Japanese). “During Thursday lunch, about 300 Matsui fans, Yankee fans and curry fans spilled out onto the sidewalk, waiting up to 40 minutes to get their food.”

headline: Does Technology Reduce Social Isolation?
text: Update | 11:19 p.m. Made slight clarifications throughout.Hundreds of daily updates come from friends on Facebook and Twitter, but do people actually feel closer to each other?

headline: When a Star Takes a Turn Awaiting a Star Turn
text: Nobody does exasperated like Julie White, the Tony-winning actress (“The Little Dog Laughed”) currently fabricating bountiful laughs from a sumptuous display of strained nerves in “The Understudy,” a scattershot backstage comedy by Theresa Rebeck that opened on Thursday night at the Laura Pels Theater.

headline: On Our Radar …
text: 1) Is the Prius ugly?

headline: 'The Understudy'
text: Mark-Paul Gosselaar and Justin Kirk in a scene from Theresa's Rebeck's new play. (Video: Roundabout Theater)

headline: For Imax, a Wall Street Ovation
text: After struggling for years to be taken seriously in Hollywood, Imax has broken through in the last year, lining up one movie behemoth after another – “Disney’s A Christmas Carol” on Friday, “Avatar” after that – for premium-price 3-D runs.

headline: A Minuet Between Sexual Predators
text: Passion burns cold in Robert Wilson’s trance-inducing production of “Quartett,” Heiner Müller’s ruthless reimagining of Choderlos de Laclos’s 18th-century novel “Les Liaisons Dangereuses.” Lights of many colors dye the all-too-mortal flesh of the figures assembled here to recall the blood-drawing games of lust they once shared. Sometimes their faces glow a reptilian green; on other occasions they are drenched in satanic red.

headline: The Yankees’ Peaceful, Easy Feeling
text: The line that kept coming to me on Wednesday night as I tried to crystallize the Yankees’ 27th championship, was “peaceful, easy feeling,” from the song by the Eagles. Whether this was a subconscious yearning for my Philadelphia Eagles to someday win a championship, too, I don’t know. But I think the words fit the moment.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Precious'
text: Lee Daniels, the director of "Precious," discusses a scene from the film.

headline: State of Distress
text: An article on Oct. 25 about the race for governor in New Jersey misidentified the native state of Joel Benenson, a pollster who worked for Gov. Jon Corzine during the campaign. It is New York, not New Jersey.

headline: Now Dishing | The Indochine Diaries
text: Indochine has proven that a true fashion restaurant never goes out of style. The palm-leaf wallpaper of the Lafayette Street boîte, opened by Brian McNally in 1984, has been the background for 25 years of beautiful faces, from the supermodels to the Roitfeld-Restoin clan. The new book “Indochine: Stories, Shaken and Stirred” (Rizzoli) serves as both eye candy and social document: there’s a photo of Andy Warhol, Jacqueline and Julian Schnabel, Kenny Scharf and Jean-Michel Basquiat at the opening; there’s a quote from Anna Wintour on the model-fest that was Grace Coddington’s 50th birthday party in 1991. The index alone, organized by first name, reads like a downtown primer, hopping from Arthur Miller to As Four, Susan Sontag to Suzanne Bartsch.

headline: Goodbye to Reforms of 2002
text: It took just five weeks after the WorldCom accounting scandal erupted in 2002 for Congress to pass, and President George W. Bush to sign, the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. That law required public companies to make sure their internal controls against fraud were not full of holes.

headline: Private Equity Fires Back at Moody’s
text: Moody’s Investors Service seems to have touched quite a nerve with a new report that was critical of the private equity industry. The Private Equity Council, the main lobbying group for the industry, fired back on Thursday afternoon, noting that the report’s conclusions were open to “significant interpretation.”

headline: 99 Weeks
text: Ninety-nine weeks: that’s the maximum length of time for which workers in high-unemployment states will be able to collect jobless benefits, under a bill that President Obama is expected to sign tomorrow.

headline: A New Editor for The Observer
text: The New York Observer will have a new editor next month: Kyle Pope, a former reporter and editor at The Wall Street Journal and Condé Nast Portfolio.

headline: Howls of a Life, Buried Deep Within
text: Claireece Jones, the Harlem teenager at the center of “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire,” lives in a world of specific and overwhelming horror. She goes by her middle name, Precious, which seems like a cruel taunt, since nearly everyone around her thinks she’s worthless and lets her know it.

headline: The Audacity of Precious
text: I had the opportunity to watch the trailer for “Precious” and was immediately taken aback by the cast members and the overall theme. Mariah Carey was unrecognizable, and Mo’Nique was just raw like I’ve never seen her. I am so glad that Daniels has taken on this huge responsibility of showing us the seemingly insurmountable obstacles that affect others.

headline: On Baseball With Jack Curry
text: Jack Curry talks about his impressions of the Yankees' victory in the 2009 World Series.

headline: Obama Promises Help for Native Americans
text: President Obama promised Native American leaders on Thursday that he would give more than “lip service’’ to their concerns, and instructed Cabinet agencies to report back to him within 90 days on plans that would establish “regular and meaningful consultation’’ between the federal government and long-ignored tribal nations.

headline: Faith and the Tempted Woman of a Certain Middle Age
text: Saints can be hell to live with. That’s part of the comedy of “Creature,” Heidi Schreck’s absorbing new play about character and faith at the Ohio Theater, loosely based on the life of Margery Kempe, a medieval Englishwoman who, after a difficult childbirth, saw visions of the Devil and Jesus.

headline: Video: Jack Curry’s World Series Recap
text: Jack Curry recaps the World Series.

headline: Stop Your Search Engines
text: Peggy Orenstein compares herself to Ulysses as she tries to resist the siren call of her online search engine, but the destructive force of the quest for knowledge antedates Homer. Go back to the very beginning of the Bible. When Eve ate from the forbidden tree and bit into the apple, she acquired the knowledge of good and evil and was cursed forever. And she didn’t even have Google.

headline: Simplifying One Life, Complicating Another
text: Richard Kelly, the writer and director of the much-loved “Donnie Darko” and much-loathed “Southland Tales,” has a thing for the apocalypse. Like those films, his latest, “The Box,” is sincere and sinister and inevitably ambitious, a serious work that insists on its own seriousness even when it edges toward the preposterous. As in his earlier films, he is again using genre (and pretty actors) as a vehicle to ask questions about the human condition (and conditioning) amid a thicket of high, low and trash cultural allusions and against a backdrop of impending doom. But the end isn’t nigh in Mr. Kelly’s world. It’s here.

headline: Explaining the Origins of Ms.
text: Ben Zimmer’s On Language column about “Ms.” makes The Times’s “embrace” of this honorific in 1986 sound gracious, if “slow.” The battle over “Ms.” was actually fierce because of in-house political resistance. The minutes of the Times stockholders meeting of April 30, 1986, show that the publisher at the time, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, recognized Paula Kassell, a stockholder and feminist publisher who had long been on this case. Kassell challenged the publisher to convene a debate with language experts to reach a “rational decision” on the question. He accepted the challenge.

headline: Is That All There Is?
text: Readers who commented on Todd May’s post, “Happy Ending,” wrote the role that death plays in their attitudes towards life, and some posted final thoughts on the Happy Days series. Excerpts from some are below.

headline: Ghosts of Technology Present
text: “Disney’s A Christmas Carol,” written and directed by Robert Zemeckis, a branded piece of shiny seasonal entertainment, uses the digital technique of performance capture and the enhancements of 3-D projection to deliver a big, noisy and sometimes terrifying version of the Charles Dickens tale on which it is based. That much is to be expected, and the casting of Jim Carrey as Ebenezer Scrooge (and some of the ghosts who haunt him) might also lead you to expect rubber-limbed clowning and a motor-mouth barrage of semi-crude humor.

headline: Money Transfers Between People Could Get Easier Soon
Appointment in Istanbul
text: Sometimes what you get is not what you thought you wanted. I had just broken up with my boyfriend of 10 years back in New York, and had flown to Istanbul to try to sightsee my heartbreak away. But then here, unexpectedly, was this very handsome Istanbul native sitting in the placid park just outside the Hagia Sophia: we’d been staring at each other admiringly from our respective park benches. After our glances grew less furtive, he waved me over. I feigned surprise, introduced myself and sat down. His name was Zia, he said, and he had been studying English for three years. He proudly pulled a Turkish-English phrase book from his pocket.
