headline: Like a Plant, His Roots Are Showing
text: IN the rambling Upper West Side apartment where the photographer Bruce Davidson has lived for almost 40 years, he and his wife keep an extra little bedroom reserved for their grandchildren, done up with flowery bedspreads and dolls flopped on a dresser. Showing a visitor through the apartment recently, Mr. Davidson stopped in the room and eased the closet door open carefully, as if a Fibber McGee-type avalanche awaited. Inside was a small museum’s worth of boxes of vintage prints from his storied career of more than half a century.

headline: Walking for Miles in New York City
text: Maggie Nesciur, a waitress in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, has structured her life around walking the streets of New York, covering as much as 43 miles in a day. Even during a year of treatment for rhabdomyosarcoma, a rare cancer, Ms. Nesciur walked. “I’m afraid of not being able to walk one day,” she says.

headline: Snow Zone
text: A haggard, bristly, undercaffeinated squirrel waits, palm open, for winter’s first flake. What is snow? He isn’t sure. Like a child, he can’t wait to find out. Unlike a squirrel, he does wait. In “Waiting for Winter,” the brilliant pencil work of the author and artist Sebastian Meschenmoser brings to sketchy, scratchy life a charming, idiosyncratic character. Squirrel is as unkempt and uncombed as a parent on Sunday morning, but as innocently impulsive as a child bouncing on the bed.

headline: A Young Champion of Women’s Colleges
text: Hannah Smith is a senior at University Laboratory School in Baton Rouge, La., who is currently applying to colleges.

headline: The Art of Sound
text: As I carefully open David A. ­Carter’s engaging new pop-up book, “White Noise,” I’m relieved my son is now 20 years old. If he were a small child, it would quickly become a heap of torn shreds. It’s hard enough for an ambidextrous adult like me not to tear its intricate feats of paper engineering after flipping through it a dozen times, which is what the book demands. This must be why the publisher calls it “A Classic Collectible Pop-Up”: If it survives the wear and tear of the pawing child and adult, it will indeed become a collector’s item.

headline: Taste Dept. | Will Cotton, Fabulous Baker Boy
text: This Sunday, and for the next two Sundays (Nov. 15 and 22), the artist Will Cotton will be baking some of the sweet confections that populate his paintings at Partners and Spade. “So much of my work in the studio has been about the smells and scents of baking that I wanted to bring that experience into a gallerylike setting,” says Cotton of his bakeshop-cum-quasi performance piece.

headline: Lineup Changes for the Giants?
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — At least two starting positions are likely to change on the Giants’ defense when they try to end a three-game losing streak Sunday against the San Diego Chargers at Giants Stadium.

headline: The Reading Life:  Turn On, Tune In, Walk Out
text: The literary magazine The Pinch, published by the University of Memphis, is like most small magazines a hit-or-miss (mostly miss) proposition. But The Pinch, founded in 1980 as the Memphis State Review, has published some good known writers (Bobbie Ann Mason, Linda Gregerson) and some good unknown ones and when I see it on newsstands it’s generally worth a pop-in.

headline: Must See: Videos Worth Watching
text: The subjects of this week’s videos include the Roan Valley in Colorado, a Swiss artist named Zimoun, a most unusual romantic relationship and some Winter Olympic hopefuls.

headline: Remembering Jack Binns, Heroic Radio Operator
text: The ticker tape parade today to mark the Yankees World Series victory is but the latest of nearly 200 processions held over the years to celebrate New York City’s individual and collective heroes. While the procession has been most often associated with sports teams, military commanders and heads of state, it has also been used to mark acts of valor by the lesser-known.

headline: D.W.I. Recliner Sells for $11,000
text: The now-infamous “DWI Recliner” of Proctor, Minn., has been sold in an eBay auction for $10,999.99, and no one is happier than the police chief of the small town.

headline: Teachers’ Pension Checks Are Canceled
text: Updated, 2:50 p.m. | Pension checks worth $187 million dollars for tens of thousands of retired New York City teachers and school staff members were electronically canceled as of Friday morning, just days after they had been deposited, according to city and union officials.

headline: Egyptian and German Officials to Meet About Nefertiti Bust
text: A German antiquities expert will attend talks next month to discuss Egypt’s demand for the return of a 3,500-year-old bust of Queen Nefertiti, Agence France-Presse reported. Zahi Hawass, head of Egypt’s antiquities council, said that a meeting planned in Egypt on Dec. 8 to discuss the possession of the statue would be attended by the director of the Egyptian antiquities department at the Berlin museum. The bust of Nefertiti, the wife of the pharaoh Akhenaten, is currently on display at the Neues Museum in Berlin; it was discovered by the German archaeologist Ludwig Borchardt in 1912, who said he had Egyptian approval to take it. But Egypt has been calling for its return since 1930, and Mr. Hawass said that at the December meeting he would present evidence that “proves the statue left in an illegal way,” according to Agence France-Presse. Mr. Hawass also said that the Berlin museum official would make the case “that the statue left Egypt through legal channels.”

headline: Democrats Gird for Health Debate, With No Deal on Abortion
text: WASHINGTON  House Democrats put the finishing touches on their health care legislation on Friday, but failed to bridge an internal divide over the politically treacherous issue of insurance coverage for abortions, as party leaders and the White House pushed to lock in votes on the eve of a historic floor debate.

headline: Paramount’s Flash-Drive Strategy: More Than Meets the Eye
text: Don’t plan on using your DVDs for Frisbees just yet, but Hollywood has yet another format for watching movies at home: the USB flash drive.

headline: Afraid of Flying? There’s an App for That (Kinda)
text: If you are afraid to fly, and happen to live in England, you can take the Virgin Atlantic “Flying Without Fear” program designed to help people overcome their travel terror. The company says Flying Without Fear has successfully treated tens of thousands of people, including celebrity aerophobic (and serial endorser) Whoopi Goldberg, who has (wait for it) endorsed the program.

headline: To Sell Beatles Songs Online, All You Need Is Legal Permission
text: “You Never Give Me Your Money” isn’t just a Beatles song — it’s also a compelling legal argument. A federal court in Los Angeles has issued a temporary restraining order against a Web site that the record label EMI said was selling the music of the Beatles without permission, Reuters reported. EMI, which releases the music of the Beatles, took legal action Tuesday against BlueBeat.com, which had been selling Fab Four tracks for 25 cents each. (The Beatles currently do not allow their songs to be sold online, individually or as complete albums, for any price.) In a statement, EMI said that it “did not authorize its content to be sold or made available on BlueBeat.com.” In response, BlueBeat had argued that it “sold entirely different sound recordings” that were created through a process called “psycho-acoustic simulation,” according to Reuters. The court is scheduled to hear arguments in the case on Nov. 20.

headline: An App That Keeps Gamers’ Orders in Order
text: GameFly, a video game rental company, has introduced an app that lets people manage their account, order games, read gaming news or even find cheat codes, all from an iPhone.

headline: Achilles’ Back Story
text: To the Editor:

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: AYN RAND AND THE WORLD SHE MADE,  by Anne C. ­Heller (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $35.) Heller maintains critical perspective while conveying the conviction and odd charisma of Rand, whose angry message resonates today among the anti-Obama right.

headline: Choice for Bear Trial Jury: Two Clashing Stories
text: When the noted litigator Brendan Sullivan represented former Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska in his public corruption trial last year, Mr. Sullivan told the jury that when prosecutors “look at life through a dirty glass, then the whole world looks dirty.”

headline: Obama on Fort Hood Shooting
text: President Obama made a statement on Friday on the shooting at the Fort Hood Army post. (video: MSNBC)

headline: ‘Mr. Bono, Tear Down This Wall!’
text: According to this report from UPI, MTV Networks International is denying building a wall at the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin for a concert by U2. Instead, MTV said it only built a fence to keep out people without tickets to the show.

headline: A Brief Visit From My Soldier Son
text: SEVERAL years ago, as Labor Day approached and parents nationwide began that end-of-summer ritual I know all too well  packing the children off to college  I found myself facing a new and particularly fraught task: preparing to return my son not to college but to war, to the mountain passes northeast of Kandahar, Afghanistan, near the border with Pakistan.

headline: Explaining the Big Jump in Unemployment
text: The unemployment rate jumped from 9.8 percent in September to 10.2 percent in October, an increase of 0.4 percentage points. That’s a pretty big leap. The previous month, it increased just a tenth of a percentage point, from 9.7 percent to 9.8.

headline: In Five Boroughs, Seeing Paris’s Famed Avenue
text: It’s longer than its Parisian namesake (and closer to Yankee Stadium), lacks a Napoleonic triumphal arch and, thank goodness, never suffered the tramp of Nazi boots. But the Grand Concourse and Boulevard, now celebrating its 100th year of traffic with a show at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, is often called the Bronx’s Avenue des Champs-Élysées.

headline: Pushing for Clearer Drug Labels
text: Amid the long and complicated health bills in Congress, there is one simple idea that would directly affect anyone who uses a prescription drug: easy-to-understand charts that could make medicine labels resemble the nutrition panels on the backs of food packages.

headline: Answers About New York City Politics, Part 3
text: Here is the third and final set of responses from Bruce F. Berg, a professor and the author of “New York City Politics: Governing Gotham” (Rutgers University Press).We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

headline: A.N.A. Hears Marketers Stress Fundamentals
text: Like managers of winning baseball teams, the first speakers at the 99th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers urged attendees on Friday morning to pay attention to the fundamentals of marketing, particularly as they grapple with the recession.

headline: Coverage of the Fort Hood Shootings
text: In the aftermath of Thursday’s deadly shooting spree at Fort Hood, the Texas Army base where 13 people were killed and 28 others were wounded by an Army psychiatrist facing deployment to Afghanistan, The New York Times is following the story from several angles:

headline: Living in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.
text: Croton-on-Hudson sits at the confluence of the Croton and the Hudson Rivers. The village, population 8,000, is about 35 miles north of New York and has an abundance of parkland.

headline: Senator Seeks to Break Up Banks ‘Too Big to Fail’
text: Senator Bernard Sanders, the Vermont independent, is taking aim at banks that are considered too big to fail. He introduced legislation on Friday that would force the Treasury Department to break up all financial institutions whose failure could cause a major disruption to the nation’s financial system.

headline: Worn in the U.S.A. | The ‘American Beauty’ Exhibition at F.I.T.
text: “American Beauty: Aesthetics and Innovation in Fashion,” the latest exhibition at the Fashion Institute of Technology (F.I.T.), opens today. Featuring 25 American fashion designers, the exhibit showcases the reigning bigwigs of yesteryear and the hot young things of today. Sponsored by 1stdibs, the exhibit includes some sizzling pieces like a Pauline Trigère evening coat and a sparkling Adrian gown once worn by Joan Crawford, as well as swishy numbers by Rodarte, Ralph Rucci and James Galanos. To learn a bit more about the exhibit, The Moment bent the ear of Dr. Valerie Steele, director of the Museum at FIT, about recession chic, hip-hop fashion and why the show isn’t called “American Fierceness.”

headline: Democrat Gives Up Single-Payer Measure to Back Party Leaders
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, Democrat of New York, a fierce champion in Congress of a single-payer health system that would be fully run by the government, said Friday that he had agreed not to insist on a vote on that issue, in an effort to help Democratic leaders pass their plan.

headline: ‘The Currency of Today’s Economy’
text: Monologue |  Aired Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: During his speech in Wisconsin yesterday, President Obama explained that he was upset with his daughter, Malia, after she got a 73 on her science test. When I heard that, I was like: “Seventy-three? I would have killed for a 73.”

headline: Villazón Says He’s Regained His Voice
text: In a video that was recently posted on his official Web site, the tenor Rolando Villazón offered his fans a couple of surprises. The first, he said, was that he had grown his hair long; the second, he said, was that “my voice is back.” In April, Mr. Villazón canceled several performances through the end of the year after announcing that he needed surgery to remove a cyst on his vocal cords; in July, a statement posted on his site, rolandovillazon.com, said that the surgery had taken place and gone “very well.” In the new video message, Mr. Villazón said he was “polishing little details to be able to come back as soon as possible next year to the stage and to sing for you,” and ended by singing the word “Ciao.” Agence France-Presse reported that the tenor had withdrawn from a planned performance in “Carmen” next year at the Vienna State Opera, but had not yet announced his decisions about scheduled performances in “Idomeneo” in Paris and “Manon” in London.

headline: ‘Casinos in Cleveland’
text: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: President Obama says that his economic plan has saved or created one million new jobs. Well, one million and two if you count the jobs he created for governors of Virginia and New Jersey.

headline: More Readers Air Their (Clean) Laundry
text: In a previous post about energy conservation and laundry, we asked you to show us your clotheslines, and we’ve been featuring your submissions. You can see our previous installments here, here, and here — and if you haven’t yet seen your image, fear not. Another collection will be coming soon. Send your images to: greeninc@nytimes.com.

headline: ‘Don’t Blame Me’
text: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: Well, if you are not happy about Mayor Bloomberg being mayor, don’t blame me, O.K.? If you are not happy about this, don’t blame me. I voted for — well, I don’t remember his name.

headline: U.N. Says U.S. Delays Led to Aid Cuts in Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  United Nations officials said Friday that the supply of critical food aid to Somalia had been interrupted and that rations to starving people needed to be cut, partly because the American government had delayed food contributions out of fears that they would be diverted to terrorists.

headline: Adding a ‘SixthSense’ to Your Cellphone
text: Many Indians bought their first mobile phones before they had their first experiences with personal computers. Pranav Mistry thinks that most of them might also skip keyboards and mice and go straight to more intuitive and interactive interfaces.

headline: ‘Screaming Incoherently’
text: Monologue |  Aired Thursday night on NBC: During a speech, President Obama embarrassed his daughter, Malia. Did you hear about this? Embarrassed his daughter Malia by revealing that she recently got a 73 on a science test. Yeah, yeah, then Malia embarrassed him by asking him how the governor’s races in Virginia and New Jersey turned out.

headline: EconoQuiz
text: Welcome to another installment of EconoQuiz, a regular quiz on economics issues in the news.

headline: Graffiti. It’s Good for Blight. Or Is It Bad?
text: On Tuesday, one of the Bay Area’s most prolific graffiti taggers is scheduled to be arraigned in San Jose. This could be interpreted as a welcome crackdown on a likely vandal, or another sign that art and the state don’t ever get along.

headline: Still Getting Better, but Slowly
text: Today’s jobs report was more important than usual, because it had the potential to tell us whether September’s disappointing report had been a blip or something darker.

headline: Are Same-Sex Couples Better Parents?
text: Just as voters in Maine were rejecting the legalization of gay marriage in the state, researchers from Massachusetts to California were releasing data showing that families led by same-sex parents are becoming mainstream.

headline: Gunman Shoots 6 and Kills 1 in Fla.
text: A former office worker opened fire in his old building in downtown Orlando on Friday morning, killing one person, injuring five others and setting off a frantic lockdown of nearby schools and buildings before the gunman, whom the police identified as Jason Rodriguez, was quietly arrested hours later at his mother’s home.

headline: Breeders’ Cup Picks for Saturday
text: The Breeders’ Cup concludes Saturday at Santa Anita Park with eight races. Combined with Friday’s six races, the weekend purse is more than $25.5 million. Here are Joe Drape’s selections for Saturday’s card, which will be shown on ESPN/ABC. All times are Eastern.

headline: Worry Less, Cook More
text: I recently did an interview with Time Out New York, and I thought that cooks who worry about perfection might find this part of it useful.

headline: Falling Under a Spell
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: Return of a Small Screen Siren
text: Heather Locklear returns to "Melrose Place" for the first time since 1999, but she's never been off of television for long.

headline: Now Booking | The Ermitage, St.-Tropez
text: Andre Saraiva, the Paris nightclub impresario and hotel entrepreneur behind Le Baron and Hotel Amour, has set his sites on another culturati playground: St.-Tropez. At his new Hotel Ermitage, a 27-room 19th-century villa in the heart of the seaside hot spot, Saraiva has commissioned the leading lights of design — Marc Newson, Jean Pigozzi, Christian Louboutin, Olivier Zahm — to individually create each room, and he’s stocked the rest of the place with pieces by Mathieu Matégot, Jean Prouvé and Ettore Sottsass, among others. Jean Pigozzi’s candid black-and-white snapshots of Hollywood stars line the walls of the downstairs Veuve Clicquot bar. And according to the guest book, Snoop Dogg takes up residence in the Belvedere Suite when he’s in town. (It does, after all, come fully equipped with its own private bar and entertaining area.)

headline: ‘I’m Sorry’ That Citigroup Exists, Ex-Chief Says
text: John S. Reed, who helped engineer the merger that created Citigroup more than a decade ago, is apologizing for his role in creating a bank that required a $45 billion government bailout.

headline: G.M. Recalling 53,000 Cars for Fuel Leak
text: General Motors is recalling almost 53,000 Chevrolet Cobalts, Saturn Ions and Pontiac G5s because a fuel leak could cause a fire.

headline: Surviving Fort Hood
text: Just as there is no way to explain the internal agony of war, there is no real way to explain what happens in its shadow. This is the domain of tortured minds that may never heal. This may very well be the legacy of Fort Hood.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Special Children’s Books Edition
text: This week: A special look at our fall children’s books issue with Adam Gopnik, Julie Just and Ryan Southerland; the pro wrestler Hulk Hogan on his memoir, “My Life Outside the Ring”; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Two New Lawmakers Join House Democrats
text: Bill Owens became the second of two new Democratic congressmen in the House of Representatives early Friday afternoon, as he was officially sworn in after a raucous special election in New York’s 23rd district.

headline: Family of Officer Who Committed Suicide Sues City
text: The family of a police lieutenant who committed suicide last year is suing the city, claiming that police officials drove him to kill himself. The suit maintains that the officials vilified the officer, Lt. Michael W. Pigott, after a confrontation in Brooklyn in which the lieutenant’s order to shoot an emotionally disturbed man with a Taser gun led to the man’s death.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Special Children’s Books Edition
text: This week: A special look at our fall children’s books issue with Adam Gopnik, Julie Just and Ryan Southerland; the pro wrestler Hulk Hogan on his memoir, “My Life Outside the Ring”; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: New York Honors the Yankees
text: It was a day for celebration in New York, at least for the Yankees and their fans. The Yankees returned to the Canyon of Heroes for a victory parade for the first time since 2000, celebrating their 27th World Series championship.

headline: The Risk of Home Fetal Heart Monitors
text: Internet advertisements and parenting Web sites often advise pregnant women to use a fetal heart monitor at home and be reassured by listening to their baby’s heart beat.

headline: Kerry on Afghanistan, Running Mates
text: Just a few outtakes from a wide-ranging interview John Harwood of CNBC and The Times conducted with Senator John Kerry, the Democrat from Massachusetts. For more, watch the video below.

headline: Dedicated, Caring, and Suddenly Lost at Home
text: The stress of American soldiers fighting in two wars is so intense that the military sends scores of mental health professionals overseas. Five of those were among the 13 people shot dead on Thursday by Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, an Army psychiatrist, who also treated traumatized soldiers.

headline: Cleaning Up the Clutter Online
text: Readability has changed my life.

headline: One Year Later: Grading President Obama
text: Overview | How is Barack Obama doing as president so far? How has he been, and should he be, assessed? In this lesson, students consider various evaluations of the Obama presidency since his election and compare them with campaign promises and official White House policies and statements to determine the fairness and thoroughness of the appraisals. They then “grade” Mr. Obama themselves.

headline: News of Hockey, 11/6/09: Elias Returning for Devils, and Neil’s Huge Check on Hedman
text: The New Jersey Devils prepare for the return of Patrik Elias, the club’s all-time leading scorer and the Czech player of the year for 2008-09. Elias, who has missed the Devils’ first 13 games of the season while recovering from hip and groin surgeries over the summer, is expected back either for Friday night’s game in Newark vs. the Islanders or Saturday’s in Ottawa.

headline: Answers About Investor Behavior — Part 4
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you’ll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals on a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Weekly Matchups: Playoff Time
text: In every other sport you have to wait for the playoffs. As the regular season winds down teams with leads rest starters and begin to prepare for the postseason. Not in college football. As the season winds down the pressure on the top teams grows. The better you’ve been through the course of the season the more pressure is on you. You need to perform week in and week out. No resting anyone. In college football, the regular season is the playoffs. Think about this weekend’s Alabama/L.S.U. game. A 3:30 p.m. game on a November Saturday at Bryant-Denny Stadium with the SEC West on the line definitely has a playoff feel about it. Ohio State/Penn State at Beaver Stadium is basically an elimination game in the Big Ten. At this point in the season, every week is a playoff game for teams like Iowa, Texas, Florida, Boise State, T.C.U. and Cincinnati. The more teams that are undefeated the more important it gets not to lose. No one can afford a let down. The weather is colder, the stakes are higher and total chaos always seems right around the corner. Gotta love the college football.

headline: A Satisfying, Speedy Braise
text: WHEN I think about braising, I think of carnivorous, all-day affairs. I think of browning a gargantuan slab of flesh, adding just enough liquid to partly cover it, and letting it stew for hours, steaming up the windows in a perfumed cloud of melting meat fat and oozing, succulent juices.

headline: Stirring Ska, Rock, R&B and Hip-Hop Into a Freak-Folk Stew
text: DEVENDRA BANHART: shaman, savant or sham? At times in the last few years he has been all of these things. From Venezuela via Los Angeles, Mr. Banhart became the figurehead for freak-folk, which, as it turned out, wasn’t that freaky after all, just folksy. “What Will We Be” (Warner Brothers), Mr. Banhart’s seventh studio album and first on a major label, is characteristically tender and contemplative, with a few devilish moments thrown in. The dominant mode is confident, charming naïveté.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: ‘The Messenger,’ ‘Sesame Street,’ Children’s Movies and More
text: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete stories.)

headline: Master of the Mutable, in an Idiom All His Own
text: ON a recent Sunday, in the home stretch of a concert at Roulette, a new-music institution in SoHo, Henry Threadgill shut his eyes and flashed an enigmatic smile. His longtime ensemble, Zooid, was nearing the end of a labyrinthine, nearly hourlong world premiere, and the atmosphere in the room  packed beyond capacity, with people crowded in the aisles  had become humid and heady. Mr. Threadgill swayed to the music’s layered pulse before picking up his alto saxophone. Then, as if cued by a secret signal, he and his musicians landed together on a sharp, culminating blare. There was a moment of startled silence before an eruption of applause.

headline: All-Star Caste | ‘To India With Love’
text: Waris Ahluwalia is the latest to explore the allure of India and its long history of sparking creativity with his book “To India With Love” (Assouline). India’s star has shone in film, literature, music, photography and fashion. Ahluwalia attempts to capture these experiences with contributions from creative types who have found inspiration on the country. The result is a scrapbook of sorts, with each page highlighting the jeweler-slash-actor’s friends’ experiences with India in prose, photography, drawings or a combination thereof. Highlights include Wes Anderson’s picture of teeth and dental instruments for sale (see Anderson’s India-infused Profile in Style here), James Ivory recounting the turning point that was his meeting Ismail Merchant — complete with a photo of Merchant’s first Indian passport — and a strange story about a beauty parlor and carnivorous dogs by Natalie Portman (see her T Screen Test here). Proceeds from the book, which was inspired in part by last year’s attacks on Mumbai, will benefit the Taj Public Service Welfare Trust.

headline: Exploring Bach for His Gypsy Side
text: SO this musicologist wants to establish that the finale of Haydn’s last symphony (No. 104) is based on a folk song. He goes into the fields, finds a group of peasants and calls them over: “Hey, do you guys know this tune? Dee-da-dah, dee-da-dah, duh-duh-da-ta-da duh-dah.” The peasants shrug their shoulders: never heard it before, sorry.

headline: Phoenix Couple Apparently Needed Extra Bags
text: Lost any luggage recently? If you’ve flown through Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport, you may have your answer. The Phoenix police have found nearly 1,000 pieces of luggage, along with plenty of other personal property, in the home of one couple, The Arizona Republic is reporting.

headline: The Morning Skate: What the Salary Cap Hath Wrought, Kings Gain Believers and Lafleur’s Film
text: The Red Wings got the postgame-skills-competition bonus point last night after tying the Sharks 1-1 through 60 minutes and the OT. Their defensive play won praise from Coach Mike Babcock, who said (quoted in The Detroit News): “We’re not going to win like we used to. We don’t have that kind of team any more. With the group we have right now, and the injuries we have, we have to grind out games like this. We have a veteran core here that understands that.”

headline: ‘South Park’ vs. GLAAD: Readers Respond
text: A post from earlier Friday, about an objection raised by the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation about “South Park” episode that made frequent use of an anti-gay slur, drew dozens of comments from readers. Some said they also found the episode troubling, and some said that GLAAD’s complaint missed the show’s satirical point.

headline: As Giants Slump, Coughlin Searches for Answers
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Ernie Bono said his friendship with Giants Coach Tom Coughlin was so close that “we always talk about doing each other’s eulogy; one of us is going to die first.”

headline: ‘Last Night in Twisted River’
text: Chapter 1: Under the Logs

headline: Alabama’s Ingram Keeps Family Close and Heisman Chatter at Arm’s Length
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  The conjecture that surrounds the Heisman Trophy has found its way to Mark Ingram, sophomore running back at Alabama, and all the hypothesizing embarrasses him. He wants to avoid it as eagerly as he wants to avoid talking about the long prison sentence facing his father, the former Giants receiver, also named Mark Ingram.

headline: Visiting Grave Sites, Imagining Worlds
text: The killing of five British soldiers on Tuesday at a checkpoint in Helmand Province by one of the Afghan police officers they were training was a reminder of how lonely death is in a foreign place and how intractable this part of the world has been for outsiders passing through. In Kabul there is a British cemetery, which in truth has only a few visible British headstones these days and mostly is filled with Europeans, but it stands as a statement of how poorly the West has done in this part of the world.

headline: A Production Called Home
text: STURGIS WARNER’S fifth-floor walk-up opposite the Public Theater in the East Village is filled with many amazing things. A bookcase made from a door hangs from the rafters. The washing machine tucked under the bed rolls over to the kitchen and plugs into the sink.

headline: She Ran to Gunfire, and Ended It
text: KILLEEN, Tex.  The police officer who brought down a gunman after he went on a shooting rampage at the Fort Hood Army base here was on the way to have her car repaired when she responded to a police radio report of gunfire at a center where soldiers are processed before being sent overseas, the authorities said Friday.

headline: On the Street | Vested
text: Bill Cunningham shows that the sleeveless topper is the choice of many women who aren't ready for a winter coat.

headline: Landry’s: The New Frankenstein?
text: In a clear sign of a healing in the financing markets, two leveraged deals terminated amid the financial crisis were resurrected from the dead this week. The first is Tilman J. Fertitta’s buyout of Landry’s Restaurants, terminated in January. The second is JDA Software’s buyout of i2 Technologies, terminated back in December 2008.

headline: Not All Are Tapped to Move With ‘Temperamentals’
text: The actor Tom Beckett contacted ArtsBeat on Friday morning to say that he has not been invited to reprise his role as Chuck Rowland and Vincente Minnelli in the transfer production of “The Temperamentals.” A spokesman for the show had said that the producers and creative team were talking to the actors in the earlier performances about reprising their roles.

headline: ‘South Park’ vs. GLAAD: Comedy Central Responds
text: Here’s the network’s response to the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, which has asked Comedy Central to apologize for a recent “South Park” episode that had numerous uses of an anti-gay slur. In a statement, Comedy Central says:

headline: Two Fish Poachers Arrested in Brooklyn
text: Here is good news for those who loathe the men who spend their days dragging umbrella rigs through the coastal waters of the New York Bight, hauling striped bass and bluefish into their boats by the dozen, then selling them illegally to unscrupulous fishmongers and restaurants throughout the city. Here, too, is bad news for those who feel people ought to be able to take what they can get from the sea, then sell it at fair prices to those who might not otherwise be able to afford the fare.

headline: Marketers Call for Multicultural Focus
text: If one way to outfox the economy is to stimulate growth, increasing the attention paid to multicultural or ethnic consumers is a smart strategy, according to speakers at the opening general session of the 99th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers.

headline: A Web Service Becomes a Library Service
text: Our series of posts about external uses of Times APIs continues. Today we’re highlighting the Dallas Public Library’s use of the Times Best Sellers API.

headline: A&E Sets Dates for Jackson Family Reality Series
text: Camera crews have tracked the Jackson brothers this year as they have mourned Michael Jackson‘s death and prepared for a reunion of the Jackson Five. Now the cable channel that bought the rights to the footage, A&E, has set a premiere date.

headline: Resurrecting a Fount of Invention
text: WEST ORANGE

headline: Adversities Await Iraqis Who Return Home
text: BAGHDAD  As Iraqis who fled their homes to escape sectarian violence are returning, many face high unemployment and poor access to electricity and water, according to a new report by the International Organization of Migration, an intergovernmental group operating in more than 100 countries.

headline: A Night Among the Landmarks and Living Legends
text: On Wednesday night, or to be more precise, on Thursday at 2 in the morning, I found myself at Elaine’s Restaurant, sipping vodka and talking with Elaine Kaufman, the proprietor. This was not unusual; I am often there dining with friends or agents or studio executives or actors. But the events that had unfolded that evening were anything but usual. It had started with a phone call from Ms. Kaufman a month ago.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: The Tide Gets a Test
text: The college football season has hit a bit of a late mid-season lull, at least on paper. With only two games that are top-25 matchups, this Saturday may seem like a bit of a yawner. But Louisiana State presents a significant challenge for its old coach Nick Saban and his undefeated Alabama team. Will the Crimson Tide be able to get past the Tigers and remain in the middle of the Bowl Championship Series conversation, or will a win by the Tigers brighten the chances of another team, perhaps even an upstart like Cincinnati or Boise State? And then there’s Terrelle Pryor’s first trip to Penn State with Ohio State. Joe Paterno certainly wanted Pryor to join the Nittany Lions, but he chose the Buckeyes and his career has been a little rocky thus far. Would a marquee road victory help turn things around? Perhaps the most unexpected matchup comes from Tobacco Road, where the fierce basketball rivals, Duke and North Carolina, find themselves in the middle of the A.C.C. race. Might there be a last-second finish, reminiscent of so many men’s basketball games between the Blue Devils and the Tar Heels? Our prognosticators have their thoughts but, as always, if you agree, disagree or merely feel their picks out laughable, feel free to chime in.

headline: Man Admits to Murder of Lawyer in Moscow
text: MOSCOW  The man suspected of murdering a prominent human rights lawyer and a journalist in January has admitted committing the crime, saying he did it out of “personal enmity” for one of the victims, his lawyer said Friday.

headline: Five Ways to Cook Chickpeas
text: The chickpea is a tasty and versatile legume. You may know it as the garbanzo bean or as the main ingredient in hummus. It’s also the hearty protein in the popular Indian dish Chana Masala.

headline: Tofu to Go
text: The railroad trestle near the Bridge’s one-story cinder-block plant in Middletown is a coincidence: The name is more about building a bridge to healthier eating than it is about any physical structure. In producing tofu and related vegetarian items, the company has been contributing to wholesome diets for nearly 30 years.

headline: In an Emergency, the Neediest Cases Fund Provides Relief
text: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund begins its 2009-2010 campaign today. The tradition of helping those who are struggling to provide for themselves and their families began 98 years ago, after Adolph S. Ochs, then the publisher of The New York Times, encountered a shabbily dressed man who was out of work and down on his luck. Their exchange inspired Mr. Ochs to begin printing profiles about the city's worst-off citizens in The New York Times. Since then, readers have responded to the articles printed every holiday season by sending in contributions by mail and, more recently, online at nycharties.org. All told, the Fund has raised over $244 million.

headline: New and Fresh and Full of Hope
text: EVEN in hard times hope seems to spring eternal for restaurateurs. In the case of Cafe Manolo, which recently opened in Westport on the site of the former Zest, there is a reason to be optimistic.

headline: Gift Guide | Bonus Round
text: Don’t we all deserve a little treat? Whether your idea of indulgence means limited-edition denim, cookware as beautiful as it is functional or good old standbys like jewelry and handbags, we’ve got you covered in our holiday gift guide. (If you’re feeling skittish about full-bore retail therapy, take a peek at our Chic and Cheerful list.)

headline: Who Needs Kentucky?
text: It’s bourbon season. I know this because we’ve drunk the last bottle of dry rosé, and because wild turkeys are lurking around the neighborhood again.

headline: Group Won’t Suspend Zimbabwe on Mining Abuses
text: JOHANNESBURG  An international body charged with stopping the illicit trade in diamonds that fuel conflict has decided not to suspend Zimbabwe, officials said Friday, though its investigators had concluded that Zimbabwe’s military had organized smuggling syndicates with the government’s permission and used “extreme violence” against illegal miners.

headline: Surprising Twists on Old Favorites
text: IN the current precarious economy, with menus squeezed to cut out expensive ingredients and chefs moving around in a culinary version of musical chairs, the Tap House in Tuckahoe is an example of how to shift gracefully amid the tumult.

headline: The Decline and Fall of the Bachelor Pad
text: BACHELORS always seemed to have it made. With only themselves to support, they could flash their cash and trick out their apartments in such a way that James Bond himself would feel at home shaking himself a martini in their ultra-cool, chick-magnet pads.

headline: White House Officially Endorses House Health Bill
text: The White House on Friday released a statement outlining its official position on the House health care legislation. And — stop the presses! — President Obama supports the bill.

headline: This ‘Green’ Is Not a Color
text: The name of the Green Door Cafe is meant not literally but figuratively, according to John Marsh, the co-owner and chef.

headline: Martin Gardner Prize
text: Since we began the celebration of Martin Gardner’s 95th birthday, TierneyLab readers have produced a plethora of tributes to him and his puzzles. They have also cleverly solved a few of his puzzles presented here, and we will get to those solutions below. But let’s start with the tributes, which were so good that the judges had a hard time awarding the prize.

headline: Like Son, Like Father, at JPMorgan Chase
text: Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, no longer has to look very far for parental advice. His father is joining the bank’s securities business.

headline: Long Island's Historic Houses
text: Two of Long Island historic mansions are on the market.

headline: An Artist’s Touch, in and Out of the Kitchen
text: LET’S get the jokes out of the way, shall we? No, they don’t serve squirrel at the Orange Squirrel  though I bet Francesco Palmieri, the talented, mischief-loving chef and owner, would do it if he could find a way. After all, this is the chef who offers a dessert called three-dirt tasting (more about that in a minute) and peels the blueberries  that’s right, peels the blueberries  that garnish a lemon tart.

headline: Now Recycling | The Uniform Project
text: The next time I declare that there is absolutely nothing in my closet to wear, remind me that I am an unimaginative loser. In fact, that goes for all of us. I am letting Sheena Matheiken’s Uniform Project be my inspiration when it comes to being way more creative with what I already have. As Rob Walker wrote in The New York Times Magazine in July, Matheiken has pledged to wear only one dress for an entire year in an effort to raise funds for the Akanksha Foundation, whose School Project pays for uniforms and other school expenses for kids in the Indian slums.

headline: Tabloid Auteur: Muscular Vision of Samuel Fuller
text: THE gruff, cigar-cured voice of Samuel Fuller remains one of the most distinctive in American movies. Born Samuel Rabinovitch in 1912, Fuller began his career as a New York tabloid journalist and pulp novelist but, like many of his colleagues on the lower rungs of the literary trades in the ’20s and ’30s, eventually found himself in Hollywood, pumping out screenplays for B pictures.

headline: Secret Weapon of Czech Opera’s Velvet Revolution
text: JUST as a diva regards her Metropolitan Opera debut as proof that she has arrived, a Met premiere confers on a work a lasting seal of approval. On Thursday, that honor will fall to Leos Janacek’s “From the House of the Dead,” based on Dostoyevsky’s chronicle of a Siberian gulag. Adding cachet are a star director, Patrice Chéreau, and a star conductor, Esa-Pekka Salonen, both making Met debuts. The international ensemble is led by the Slovak Stefan Margita as a sadistic confidence man, the Brit Willard White as a political detainee, the American Kurt Streit as one impenitent killer and the Swede Peter Mattei as another.

headline: Stove Pipes and Vent Pipes
text: A silver stove pipe now pokes through the cabin’s green roof. Ah, what a sight!

headline: Can a Boy Wear a Skirt to School?
text: BY now, most high school dress codes have just about done away with the guesswork.

headline: The Sunday Preview
text: To visit the Archipelago of the Bijagós — a spattering of 88 palm-fringed and thinly populated islands off the coast of West Africa — is to enter another world and another century. Adam Nossiter, the West Africa bureau chief for The New York Times, made the voyage last June and found a magical and beguiling place.

headline: Defending the Work of Female Comics
text: To the Editor:

headline: Baronial Charm and Treats
text: The Hidden Oak Café in the library and parlor of Westbrook, the 19th-century manor of the railroad baron William Bayard Cutting, retains the home’s period charm. Parquet floors, marble fireplaces and original Tiffany stained-glass windows adorn the space now as then.

headline: Correction: A Crime Show Charles Ponzi Could Love
text: A picture caption on Oct. 18 with excerpts of an interview with Jeff Eastin, creator of the television show “White Collar,” misidentified the actress shown with Matt Bomer and Tim DeKay. She is Marsha Thomason  not Alexandra Daddario, who also appears in the series.

headline: A Bistro Known by Word of Mouth
text: LUDLOW BISTRO is a beacon in Deer Park, and not just because its exterior is painted orange. It is a stylish restaurant in a sea of fast-food places, bagel cafes and pizza joints.

headline: Lessons From the War Over Skype
text: The dust has settled, the ink on the deal has dried, and one of the biggest sideshows in Silicon Valley this year appears to be over. The litigation between eBay, the buyers of Skype and its original founders has been dropped, and the deal, which values Skype at $2.7 billion, should close soon.

headline: Correction: December Movie Schedule
text: An entry in the holiday films listings last Sunday misidentified the author who wrote the historical novel from which the director Michael Hoffman’s movie “The Last Station” is adapted. The writer is Jay Parini  not Rose Tremain, who wrote the novel upon which Mr. Hoffman’s movie “Restoration” was based.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Nov. 6
text: Two images of the aftermath of Thursday’s shooting at the Fort Hood Army base dominate the show. The pictures, shot by Nicole Bengiveno and Michael Stravato for The Times, capture the grief and somber disbelief lingering a day after the rampage (Slide 1), as well as the face of one of the first-responders who acted quickly to administer first aid at the scene. In New York, hundreds of thousands of people joined the Yankees in celebrating their 27th World Series championship with a parade (Slides 10, 11, 12).

headline: Losing the Limo: New Fashion Dolls
text: RAPUNZEL has nothing on Avery, a 10-inch injection-molded mall princess whose flaxen hair cascades to her knees. Rapunzel might also have envied Avery’s smart wardrobe and her arsenal of styling tools, from thumb-size lip gloss to a tiny curling iron.

headline: Yemeni Rebels and Saudis Clash at Border
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As clashes continued Friday between the Saudi military and Yemeni rebels on the remote border between the countries, both sides claimed to have inflicted casualties and captured enemy soldiers.

headline: Chinese Agencies Struggle Over Video Game
text: BEIJING  It could almost be a World of Warcraft game session  two competing titans, plotting against each other, swapping blows, embarked on a quest for a single prize that only the stronger of them will claim.

headline: Jay-Z’s Bid for King of the Hill
text: JAY-Z started spreadin’ the news in September, and since then he has taken every prominent opportunity to remind us: he has a candidate for a new New York anthem, and he wants our votes.

headline: Lynn in Reel Time | Sexy Beasts
text: Lynn Hirschberg, the New York Times magazines’ editor at large, spends her days free-ranging in pop culture, on the lookout for what’s next in Hollywood and beyond. In this regular column, she tells the features associate Adam Kepler about what movies she’s seen at screenings, the movies she’s seen in the theater and those movies (or obsessions) that play only in her mind.

headline: Correction: The Newest Face in the Late-Night Party
text: An article last Sunday about the comedian George Lopez gave an outdated name for a golf tournament for which he is host. It is the Bob Hope Classic, not the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

headline: Punk’s Fresh Face
text: “MONEY is no object when it comes to punk rock,” said Thurston Moore, the frontman for Sonic Youth. He was flipping through stacks of vinyl at Academy Records in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with Jemina Pearl, his latest protégé, who had just unearthed a first pressing of “Raw Power” by Iggy and the Stooges, from 1973. “But it’s $40,” she sighed. “I’ll buy it for you,” said Mr. Moore, who is 51 and head of the label Ecstatic Peace. Ms. Pearl, 22, gave him an adoring, puppy-dog face. “Aww!” she mock-cooed.

headline: Correction: 50 Years Older, ‘Birdie’ Returns to the Nest
text: An article on Oct. 11 about the revival of “Bye Bye Birdie” misstated the age of one of its creators, Lee Adams, and a correction in this space last Sunday misstated Mr. Adams’s creative role. He is 85, not 75, and he wrote the lyrics, not the music.

headline: Not a Patriarch, but a Leader All the Same
text: TERE O’CONNOR exists in that weird arts-world black hole called midcareer. He’s been creating dance since 1982: too established for the sexy “emerging choreographer” label yet not august enough to be canonized and put away on a high shelf.

text: The Yankees celebrated their 27th World Series championship with a ticker-tape parade and ceremony.

headline: Howard L. Michaels
text: Mr. Michaels, 54, is the chairman and chief executive of the Carlton Group, a real estate investment bank that specializes in equity and debt placement. The company also has its own portfolio of properties and mortgages, and recently started the Carlton Exchange auction Web site, which lists real estate loans for sale.

headline: Car Buyers Come Back, but Not in Droves
text: THE American love affair with cars seemed to come to a sudden end this year, when car sales became less important to the economy than at any time since the government began counting more than 40 years ago. So far, there are only limited indications of a renewal of the relationship.

headline: A Makeover Plan, Up Close
text: NEWARK

headline: Actor Fired From ‘Orphans’ Home Cycle’ Is Compensated
text: Actors’ Equity Association said Friday that an actor who was fired from a Hartford Stage theater production after attaching reminders of his dialogue to his costume has been compensated for pay he says he was owed. The actor, Matt Mulhern, was appearing in Horton Foote’s “Orphans’ Home Cycle,” a nine-hour series of three plays, and was fired on Sept. 22 after he peeked at bits of dialogue that he had taped inside his character’s hat. In a statement, Actors’ Equity said that it had filed for arbitration with the League of Resident Theaters, which includes Hartford Stage, and that the claim would be resolved. Mr. Mulhern said in a video posted on YouTube that he had been paid the week’s salary that he said he was owed. Hartford Stage, which has not said why it fired him, said Friday in a statement that it “confirms that it made a business decision to resolve a dispute with Matthew Mulhern by paying him an additional week’s salary. That decision does not constitute or imply agreement that Mr. Mulhern had a valid claim.”

headline: Useful Stuff You May Have Missed
text: Though we try to choose the best content for classrooms every week, there is always far more published in The Times than we can possibly use.

headline: HUD Combats Discrimination
text: IN recent years, state and local governments have enacted laws to combat discrimination against lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgendered people seeking mortgages and housing. Now the federal government is poised to do the same with regulations that would cover loans backed by the Federal Housing Administration.

headline: Who’s Hurting the Most?
text: The job market is bad for almost everyone. But it is especially bad for those who are young, less educated, male or black.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Musical Announces New Producers, Star
text: After a meeting Friday to determine the fate of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark,” its creative team announced new producers as well as the actor who will portray the title character.

text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Madoff Trustee Drops $279 Million Merkin Claim
text: The trustee liquidating Bernard L. Madoff’s investment firm has dropped a $279 million claim against the New York financier J. Ezra Merkin’s Ariel and Gabriel hedge funds, which invested one-fourth of their money with the now-convicted swindler.

headline: Money Issues That Can Test Even a Rock-Solid Marriage
text: When a couple first gets together, they may not have the same approach to managing money. But it’s often easy enough to get past any differences when so much of the future is theoretical anyway.

headline: 'A Woman's Wit'
text: A new Jane Austen exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum presents letters and early manuscripts by the author.

headline: Gibbs on Protests, Jobs
text: Jewish groups and others have criticized some of the posters and characterizations invoking the Holocaust or depicting the administration as Nazis used by protesters during Thursday’s demonstration against the health care bill on Capitol Hill.

headline: Shopping With Kim Zimmer
text: While contemplating the future and planning a book on her life as a soap star, Kim Zimmer now has time on her hands — and a new apartment to furnish.

headline: When Suds Subside
text: AS the long-reigning diva of “Guiding Light,” the soap opera whose 57-year run on television ended in September, Kim Zimmer found herself so busy that she could seldom browse her favorite stores. But while contemplating the future and planning a book on her life as a soap star, she now has time on her hands  and a new apartment to furnish.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 6
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week. Subjects include a brewery in Brooklyn, the U.S.S. New York’s arrival in the city, and a kidnapped girl’s return home.

headline: ‘Fight Club’ Fight Goes On
text: CULT films, the critic Danny Peary wrote in his 1981 book “Cult Movies,” “are born in controversy” and elicit “a fiery passion in moviegoers that exists long after their initial releases.” By those measures David Fincher’s “Fight Club,” a movie that stirred vitriolic ire when it came out 10 years ago and today inspires obsessive, often worshipful scrutiny in both lowbrow and highbrow quarters, is surely the defining cult movie of our time.

headline: Fox News Channel Draws Large Audience for Coverage of Fort Hood Shootings
text: Viewership for the cable news channels surged on Thursday afternoon as news of a mass shooting at the Fort Hood Army base shocked the country.

headline: Where Rivers Meet, Ahh-Inspiring Views
text: ITS seven miles of waterfront afford striking views of storms barreling across the widest portion of the Hudson River  which is what makes Croton-on-Hudson the closest thing Silvana Cappabianca has found to her childhood home on the Adriatic Sea. For her husband, Claudio, the river at moonrise stirs memories of his first home in Naples, on the Mediterranean.

headline: Correction: Reclaiming Contaminated Sites

It is the master developer of the area; it is not the company that is finishing the stadium. (The stadium is being developed by the Austrian soft-drink maker Red Bull G.m.b.H., which owns the team.)

headline: Correction: Puzzling Over Home Prices
text: The “In the Region” article in New Jersey copies on Oct. 25, about residential pricing trends, misstated the length of time that a house at 88 Oxford Street in Glen Ridge was on the market. It was in contract after 18 days; it was not on the market for six months.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 6
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

text: Meghan Ann Moriarty and Christopher Max Colice were married Saturdayin Boston. The Rev. Susan Spector, an interfaith minister, officiated in the Abbey Room at the Boston Public Library.

headline: Changes of Heart
text: ONE Madison Park, the soaring 600-foot glass condominium that towers over East 23rd Street, opened to its first residents in August, but since then only five buyers have closed, according to city records. Other would-be buyers have walked away  raising questions, brokers at several firms said, about the prospects for the building in a depressed real estate market.

headline: Christine Pace, Andrew Ellner

headline: Destroying the Earth, Over and Over Again
text: ON Nov. 13, when his latest tale of the apocalypse, “2012,” arrives in theaters, the filmmaker Roland Emmerich will have waged more assaults on this planet than he can remember. He’s frozen it, drowned it and sicced aliens and Godzilla on it. The earth is his Jason Voorhees from “Friday the 13th,” and it just keeps coming back.

headline: Are Democrats, Too, Facing a Civil War?
text: “Republicans emerged from Tuesday’s elections energized by victories in Virginia and New Jersey, but their leaders immediately began maneuvering to avoid a prolonged battle with conservative activists over what the party stands for and how to regain power.” So writes Adam Nagourney of The Times this week, summing up the sense of many regarding an off-year election that saw, in addition to those gubernatorial races, the continuation of Mike Bloomberg’s reign in New York City, a defeat for gay marriage in Maine, and a Democratic pick-up of a House seat in upstate New York that Republicans had held since the Reconstruction Era.

A native New Yorker, she lives in the East Village with her partner, the artist Marlene McCarty, their 10-year-old daughter, Guthrie, and their three cats, Audrey, Freddy and Bea. Her weekends are a respite that she cherishes more than ever after recently undergoing chemotherapy and surgery for breast cancer. CARA BUCKLEY

headline: Permitted Behind Police Lines, but Not Welcome
text: “WELCOME to Police Headquarters,” announces the sign at the entrance to 1 Police Plaza in downtown Manhattan. That passes for humor to Leonard Levitt, a former police reporter and columnist for Newsday, who needed the help of civil rights lawyers to regain his press pass after being barred from the building a few years back. Now retired, Mr. Levitt, 68, still makes weekly rounds at Police Headquarters to feed his Web site, nypdconfidential.com, which recently broke the news that the department had removed a senior official from an antiterrorism unit over the disruption of a federal investigation.
