text: Elizabeth DeRosa and Robert William Hellner were married Saturday at the Point Pleasant Presbyterian Church in Point Pleasant Beach, N.J. The Rev. Carlos E. Wilton, a Presbyterian minister and pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Margaret Hoover, John Avlon
text: Margaret Claire Hoover and John Phillips Avlon were married Saturday at Stanford Memorial Church in Palo Alto, Calif. The Rev. Susan Scott, a Lutheran minister, officiated, with the Rev. Samuel Johnson Howard, the bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Florida, taking part.

headline: Almost Family
text: FOR much of his adult life, Joseph A. Olshefski has been bound up with a 150-year-old house with a white picket fence off Second Avenue on 58th Street.

headline: Jennifer Mengers-O’Brien, Daniel Siller Pinette
text: Dr. Jennifer Ruth Mengers-O’Brien and Daniel Alfonso Siller Pinette are to be married Saturday by the Rev. Ugo Nacciarone at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

headline: Patricia Meyer, William Stevenson
text: Patricia Jeanne Meyer and William Wheeler Stevenson were married Saturday at St. Andrew’s Episcopal Church in Tampa, Fla. The Rev. John Reese, the church’s rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Katherine Frato, Jeffrey Werbin
text: Katherine Frato and Jeffrey L. Werbin were married Saturday at the Castaways Beach and Bay Cottages, a resort in Sanibel Island, Fla. Robert W. Pitt, a notary public, officiated.

headline: Wanda Sykes Has a Show (or So They Tell Her)
text: LOS ANGELES  Wanda Sykes has trust issues.

headline: Obama Quietly Visits Wounded Troops
text: There were no television cameras trailing President Obama on Friday afternoon as he visited wounded soldiers and family members at Walter Reed Army Medical Center.

headline: Chronicle of a Changing City
text: CYPRUS CORNER, at 21st Street and 21st Avenue, just replaced Theresa’s pizzeria near Astoria Park on a block that includes a chicken slaughterhouse, a storefront Pentecostal church and the National Greek Soccer Team Fan Club. Andreas Andreou, 30, said that a month ago he was delivering pizzas in Bayside, but he “called in some favors” and borrowed startup money to open the small place, with its fast-food décor but serious Greek food and pizza. Mr. Andreou grew up working in the Astoria restaurants (most notably, Lemonia) run by his father (Erotokritos, nicknamed Rotis) and mother (Timothea, nicknamed Timi), immigrants from Cyprus. Dad became known for his shieftalia (Cypriot sausage) and Mom for her tangy tzatziki (yogurt sauce). Both are offered here  in fact some locals drip tzatziki on the pizza. The menu is handwritten by Mrs. Andreou on overhead panels. Andreas is still delivering the pizza.

headline: Nichole Stelma, Christopher Knott-Craig
text: Nichole Renee Stelma and Christopher Luther John Knott-Craig were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Christopher W. Garriott, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church.

headline: Real Rembrandts, and the Also-Rans
text: For years, the Wadsworth Atheneum was one of the premier museums in the nation. But as Hartford has gone into economic decline, so have the fortunes of the museum, with successive directors needing to severely cut staff and exhibition budgets to stay ahead of a broad drop in revenue. It is a story that many other regional art museum directors and board members know all too well.

headline: Combat Stress and the Fort Hood Gunman
text: Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the 39-year-old Army psychiatrist accused of Thursday’s mass shooting at Fort Hood, Tex., had recently expressed deep concerns about being sent to Afghanistan. His cousin, Nader Hasan, said that Major Hasan had counseled scores of soldiers with post-traumatic stress disorder and was “mortified” about being deployed.

headline: Going With Uncool
text: DAN SCHREIBER and Caroline Jeanjot took a one-bedroom sublet in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, after arriving in New York three years ago from their native Brussels. They chose it because of its low monthly rent, around $1,200, but knew little about the city’s geography.

headline: After 96 Novels, Still Waiting for a Best Seller
text: LARCHMONT

headline: With a Tranquil Air, a Respite From Fast-Paced Lives
text: One virtue of the scaled-back plan for the new Parrish Art Museum by the architecture firm Herzog & de Meuron is that it is only slightly smaller than the previous version. Although the new design is less ambitious architecturally, it encompasses approximately 37,300 square feet (the earlier version had 44,000), nearly twice the size of the current museum. Around a third of that will consist of dedicated galleries, including a permanent display of works from the museum’s collection, something the museum has not had before. The Parrish hopes to break ground early next year, according to museum officials.

headline: Yankees Return to the Canyon of Heroes
text: Jay Schreiber of The Times wears his Mr. Met hat at the ticker-tape parade in honor of the 27th World Series championship for The New York Yankees.

headline: Swirling Sonorities, With Asian Poems Translated Into German
text: The Viennese composer Alexander Zemlinsky modeled his opulent “Lyric Symphony” on Mahler’s “Lied von der Erde.” Both are orchestral song cycles for two alternating soloists, and both use German translations of poems by Asian writers.

headline: Looking Back, and Taking It Forward
text: Nancy Garcia and Chase Granoff take historical references seriously in two new works being performed at the Kitchen. Ms. Garcia’s “I need more” finds context in noise rock, while Mr. Granoff’s “Art of Making Dances” is more blatant, evoking the choreographers Doris Humphrey and Simone Forti and films by Jean-Luc Godard.

headline: Stranded in Dutch Harbor, Alaska
text: Pastor John Honan wants to convert a notorious former bar into a temporary shelter for people stranded in Dutch Harbor, Alaska.

headline: EBay Settles Suit Over Skype Sale
text: EBay has formally settled the litigation around its sale of the Skype online calling service, The New York Times’s Brad Stone reports.

headline: ‘South Park’-GLAAD Debate Rings Familiar
text: After the first ArtsBeat post on the South Park controversy appeared today, a commenter using the identifier “RW,” wrote, “Didn’t ‘queer’ used to be a derogatory name for homosexuals – and yet today many gay groups embrace the term.” RW is correct. Here’s a Times article from 1991 on efforts at that time to take the sting out of that slur. If you’ve been following the conversation today, a lot of it will sound familiar.

headline: Investigating the Fort Hood Shooting
text: Ray Rivera of The New York Times on the latest developments in the Fort Hood rampage.

headline: At the Morgan, the Jane Austen Her Family Knew
text: Who would not wish for a close relative like Aunt Jane? In early 1817, the year she died, suffering, perhaps, from lymphoma and beginning work on a novel she became too ill to finish, Jane Austen wrote a letter to her 8-year-old niece, Cassandra.

headline: Revs Seek to Make Playoff Game Blanco’s Last in M.L.S.
text: The second leg of the Major League Soccer playoff series between the Chicago Fire and the New England Revolution could become the first postseason victory in Chicago for the Revs, and if that happens it will almost certainly represent the last time Cuauhtemoc Blanco suits up for the Fire.

headline: Players Remain Deadlocked at Moscow Tournament
text: All games on second day of elite tournament in Moscow end in draws.

headline: European Bankers Defend Their Pay and Bonuses
text: LONDON  “Profit is not satanic,” John Varley, the chief executive of Barclays, told an audience at St. Martin-in-the-Fields church here this week.

headline: From Tokyo, a Stripped-Down Movement Style
text: “Butoh?” a friend said when I reported that I was off to the Cave New York Butoh Festival. “Is that the one where they are naked, with white body paint and move very slowly?”

headline: Peekskill to Cut the Ribbon on a Child-Crafted Trail of Tiles
text: Peekskill

headline: Secrets of the Stacks
text: The New York Public Library, with its headquarters at Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street, encompasses four major research libraries and 87 branches, with a total of 20 million books, 50 million cataloged items and a growing demand in this recession for loaner laptops and other free services. Only the Library of Congress and the British Library are larger. But even the Fifth Avenue landmark by itself is a marvel of big numbers. It is undergoing a $1.2 billion makeover in preparation for its 100th birthday. Built from 1899 to 1911, it cost $9 million, contains 530,000 cubic feet of white Vermont marble and 125 miles of shelving, and opened with an inventory of one million items. Here are some highlights of this fabled institution.

headline: All That Glitters
text: There are monkeys on your back and then there are gorillas, and when things are particularly bad, you have an entire zoo. But once in a while, something happens that sends them all back to their natural habitat.

headline: The Bridegroom Wore Eye Shadow, Petals and Lime Fishnet
text: Arguments in favor of gay marriage have taken many forms, from snappy phrases stretched across muscle T’s to miniature musicals on YouTube, op-ed pieces and learned essays. (My favorite, from a poster at a protest march: “We Can’t All Marry Liza Minnelli!”) But surely none can match the mad extravagance of “The Lily’s Revenge,” a scrappy spectacle written by and starring the drag artist Taylor Mac, now splashing across the stage of Here Arts Center in a swirling tide of tattered lime green fishnet, eye shadow and sequins.

headline: Treasury Rejects Sale of Tax Credits to Goldman
text: Update | 8:23 p.m. The Obama administration on Friday evening rejected a proposal by Goldman Sachs to buy as much as $1 billion in tax credits from Fannie Mae, saying the deal would have amounted to a net loss for taxpayers, The New York Times’s Edmund L. Andrews reports from Washington.

headline: On Health Care, Democrats Play Down Election Results
text: WASHINGTON  When Democrats lost races for governor in New Jersey and Virginia this week, officials in both parties suggested that the outcome could undermine President Obama’s push for a health care bill, scaring off politically vulnerable moderate Democrats at the very moment the White House needed them to get the bill through.

headline: Wages: A Comparison With Past Recessions
text: I’ve written before about the surprising patterns in pay during this recession. Those patterns continue in today’s report: hourly wages accelerated in October. The average hourly pay of rank-and-file workers, who make up about four-fifths of the work force, rose 5 cents, to $18.72 an hour.

headline: Bedtime? No, Curtain Time
text: Paige Simunovich, a wisp of a girl with almond-shaped green eyes, was scarcely out of diapers when she announced she wanted to be on Broadway. A couple of years later, she asked her mother, “When are you going to get that lady who gets me a job?”

headline: Regarding Tamiflu, Doctors and Patients Face a Question of When to Act
text: When Dr. Matt Thompson, a pediatrician at the Kids Clinic in Spokane, Wash., found about a month ago that his six children had come down with H1N1, or swine flu, he did not give them the antiviral medication that might have made their sickness a bit shorter.

headline: Truck Carrying Flu Vaccine Supply Is Stolen
text: CHICAGO  The swine flu vaccine has become a coveted commodity all over the country, but someone in Milwaukee appeared at first glance to carry the notion to a new level this week, stealing off in a refrigerated truck that was hauling 930 of the prized doses.

headline: Official Endorses Workplace Clinics for Vaccine Distribution
text: The federal health official in charge of immunization and respiratory diseases said Friday that swine flu vaccine should be distributed through many outlets, including workplace clinics, to get it to high-risk people as quickly and efficiently as possible.

headline: Prospect of More U.S. Troops Worries Afghan Public
text: CHARIKAR, Afghanistan  As Americans, including President Obama’s top advisers, tensely debate whether to send more American troops to Afghanistan, Afghans themselves are having a similar discussion and voicing serious doubts.

headline: Looking to Other Religions, and to Atheism, for Clarity in Faith
text: A month ago, when this column traced the argument of a book with the intriguing title of “Without Buddha I Could Not Be a Christian,” it was tempting to mention another recent book. “It’s Really All About God” (Jossey-Bass) carries the equally intriguing subtitle: “Reflections of a Muslim Atheist Jewish Christian.”

headline: Administration Rejects Plan to Buy Fannie Mae Credits
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday rejected a proposal by Goldman Sachs to buy as much as $1 billion in tax credits from Fannie Mae, saying the deal would have amounted to a net loss for taxpayers.

headline: Concierges and Marble Baths: For Some at Columbia, This Is Dorm Life
text: Last year, when Columbia University tried to interest Ben Cox, then a first-year M.B.A. student, in its new apartment building in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, he scoffed. It was too far from the campus in Manhattan, he thought, and the unit was a bit expensive. He did not even bother to look at it.

headline: G.M. Executive Quits Over Opel Decision
text: DETROIT  The head of European operations for General Motors quit on Friday after the automaker backed out of a deal to sell its Opel brand, a decision that has angered German workers and government officials.

headline: Prep Schools Face Cuts in Student Aid
text: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J.  For now, the nation’s biggest preparatory schools are protecting students like Ivy Alphonse-Leja, who depends on financial aid to attend the Lawrenceville School.

headline: Bellevue Natural-Birth Center, Haven for Poor Women, Closes
text: The Bellevue Birth Center was celebrated as a landmark achievement for the natural-birth movement in New York City when it opened in 1998. The luxurious natural-birth center, designed to feel more like a home than a hospital, was the only one of its kind dedicated not to Manhattan’s trend-conscious set, but to poor, mostly immigrant women on Medicaid.

headline: Job Cutbacks Rise by 1,200 at a Carrier in Britain
text: British Airways said on Friday that it would cut an additional 1,200 jobs in the coming months, raising the number of planned staff reductions to nearly 5,000 as the British carrier wrestled with what its chief executive called the toughest year in the history of aviation.

headline: Ivory Coast: Judge Rejects Request in Toxic Waste Case
text: About $45 million intended to compensate 30,000 victims of a toxic waste dumping scandal in Ivory Coast will not be diverted to a self-appointed community representative, a judge in Abidjan ruled Friday. The sludge was dumped in and around Abidjan in 2006 by the international commodities trading firm Trafigura; over 100,000 people sought treatment and 15 died. A recent United Nations report said there was “strong prima facie evidence that the reported deaths and adverse health consequences are related to the dumping of the waste.” In recent weeks, a man claiming to represent the victims, Claude Gohourou, sought to divert the money to his organization; lawyers for the victims dismissed his claim as false. On Friday, Judge Antoine Blé ruled that the money should remain in the lawyers’ account.

headline: Winner in Contest Involving Space Elevator
text: A start-up company from the Seattle area won $900,000 on Friday in a NASA contest to build a miniature prototype of a machine that could one day climb from Earth to outer space.

headline: Taiwan: Swine Flu Vaccination Program Begins
text: The Taiwanese government announced that by starting vaccinations against the H1N1 virus this week, it had begun the largest immunization program in Taiwan’s history. The first people to receive the vaccines were survivors of Typhoon Morakot, which wreaked havoc across Taiwan in early August, killing hundreds of people. Schoolchildren are scheduled to receive shots this month. The government said it hoped to administer 12 million doses by Feb. 14, the start of the Lunar New Year.

headline: ‘Free for All’
text: Chapter 1: Backstory 1921-42

headline: Long-Delayed Opening for History of, and by, Joseph Papp
text: If Joseph Papp had had his way, “Free for All,” the newly published oral history about him and the Public Theater he helped found, would never have seen the light of day. The memory of how Papp, more than 20 years ago, inexplicably turned on the project he initiated even now causes its author, Kenneth Turan, to wince.

headline: Israel: Ministry Assails U.N. Vote on War Conduct
text: Israel on Friday rejected a United Nations General Assembly vote endorsing a report accusing it of war crimes in Gaza last winter, saying the resolution did not have “the support of the moral majority.” The resolution, drafted by Arab member states, was approved Thursday on a vote of 114 to 18. The Israeli Foreign Ministry said in a statement that the Israeli Army had demonstrated “higher military and moral standards” in Gaza than any “of this resolution’s instigators.” Israel said the report was one-sided and failed to take into account Israel’s right to defend itself against Palestinian rocket fire.

headline: M.I.T. Considers Increase in Student Body by 300
text: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology is considering expanding its student body by more than 7 percent, or more than 300 students, if it is able to create additional student housing, the dean of admission, Stuart Schmill, said Thursday.

headline: Versailles or Kykuit?
text: “You have to spend money to make money” goes the adage, but that has not been true this season at Kykuit, the Rockefeller estate in Pocantico Hills. Attendance there has risen 4 percent this year over last, despite a 5 percent drop in spending on marketing.

headline: ‘Spider-Man’ Is Given a New Lead Producer
text: A rock concert promoter with ties to the Rolling Stones and U2 said on Friday that he was taking over as the lead producer of the coming Broadway musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark,” and that the troubled multimillion-dollar show would open sometime in 2010.

headline: Pension Checks of Retired New York City Teachers Canceled
text: The pension checks of tens of thousands of retired New York City teachers and school staff members were electronically canceled as of Friday morning, just days after they had been deposited, according to city and union officials.

headline: Rough Rider’s Easy Ride
text: Despite the troubled economy, Sagamore Hill, Theodore Roosevelt’s home, a federal historic site, is getting busier. Its staff members from the National Park Service conducted 36,400 tours there in 2007 and 39,500 tours in 2008, and they expect the number this year will be higher.

headline: Stress Beyond Belief
text: The authorities will deal with Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist who is accused of bringing the nightmare of mass murder into the sanctuary of a military base on American soil. But the rest of us need to look very closely at the stress beyond belief that is being endured by so many other men and women in the armed forces  men and women who are serving gallantly and with dignity, who have not taken out their frustrations on one another, and who deserve better from the broader society.

headline: Seeing Paris in 5 Boroughs of New York
text: It’s longer than its Parisian counterpart (and closer to Yankee Stadium), lacks a Napoleonic triumphal arch and, thank goodness, never suffered the tramp of Nazi boots. But the Grand Concourse and Boulevard, celebrating its 100th year of traffic with a show at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, is often called the Bronx’s Avenue des Champs-Élysées.

headline: Pelosi Faces Competing Pressures on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON  As House Democratic leaders were assembling their health care bill last month, Speaker Nancy Pelosi left Washington on a political fund-raising tour.

headline: Questions of Money and Tallies
text: Mayor Bloomberg’s top aides received generous bonuses after his 19.4-point victory in 2005. In light of Mr. Bloomberg’s not-so-big margin on Tuesday, will his campaign bonuses be as hefty?

headline: To Retain Its Bankers, Citi Offers Option Plan
text: Hoping to encourage bankers and managers to stay, Citigroup began dispensing several million stock options this week to more than a quarter of its workers in a way that could result in a sizable gain for them.

headline: Executives Are Wary After Arrests
text: Switchboards at law firms have been lighting up in recent weeks as hedge fund managers and technology executives deluge lawyers with one question: What information is safe to share, in case the feds are listening?

headline: The Shooting at Fort Hood
text: Some of the events in the rampage on Thursday at Fort Hood, Texas, according to base officials and witnesses.

headline: From Humdrum Day to a Scene of Chaos
text: FORT HOOD, Tex.   The Soldier Readiness Processing Center, a network of low buildings on Fort Hood, is as dreary as it sounds. It is where soldiers who are deploying overseas go to square away their medical paperwork. A visit means hearing tests, dental exams, shots and long, long lines.

headline: Fine-Spun Leaves and Other New Clothes
text: The current issue of Audubon magazine has a fairly comprehensive article on sustainable fashion. It’s worth checking out. Written by Gretel H. Schueller, the piece, “From Hippie to Hip,” looks at developments in new materials and focuses on the design companies that are doing interesting things. Ms. Schueller also has a sidebar that lists companies offering environmental friendly lines, like underthecanopy.com.

headline: Bonuses Uncertain for Bloomberg Election Aides
text: Michael R. Bloomberg prides himself on importing traditions from Wall Street to City Hall. But he did not count on introducing this one: end-of-year bonus anxiety.

headline: Questioning a Test for Cancer
text: Christopher Taylor says he never lasted more than a week when he tried to quit smoking in the past. But it has been four weeks and counting this time, since a genetic test indicated he had a much higher risk of developing lung cancer than the average smoker.

headline: Not Even Ribcage Injury Stopped Rivera
text: Mariano Rivera, one of the most indispensable Yankees, pitched with a ribcage injury during the postseason. If Rivera had faltered in Game 6 of the World Series and the Yankees had lost, would he have been fit enough to pitch in a Game 7 against the Philadelphia Phillies?

headline: Obama’s to Fix
text: What a difference a year makes.

headline: Young Broadway Debuts
text: Kids and teenagers new to the Broadway stage speak about their careers and get advice from more seasoned members of their casts.

headline: Gauging the Risks From a Smoker’s DNA and History
text: To take Synergenz’s Respiragene test, consumers swab the inside of a cheek to get DNA and send the sample to a laboratory in Kentucky. The Synergenz Web site says a physician is required to sign a form requesting the test. The Respiragene test looks at 20 spots in a person’s genome where DNA varies among people. It uses that data, as well as nongenetic information like the person’s smoking history, to compute a risk score.

headline: Wondering What to Lead? Listen Closely to the Bidding
text: The North American Open Pairs title is decided at the Spring North American Championships, which will be in Reno, Nev., in March. Every district of the American Contract Bridge League sends two pairs to compete in each of three flights (A, B and C).

headline: Following Many Famous Footsteps Through the 92nd Street Y
text: Seventy-five years is a lifetime for many people. But art, as the Donald Justice poem goes, “keeps long hours.”

headline: Same Booms, Different Terrain
text: The attack at the U.N. guesthouse in Kabul last week began at the first olive moments of daylight. I lay in my bed, having just closed my eyes after a long night. Boom-boom-boom-boom. There wasn’t much to do but wait for it to end. And as I closed my eyes and listened, I was transported to another place: Baghdad.

headline: Turning Happy Hour Into a Global Job Search
text: A baseball game was on television, the mechanical bull was waiting to thrash and dozens of women in business suits and heels were partaking liberally of after-work drink specials at Johnny Utah’s, a bar in midtown Manhattan.

headline: Nien Cheng, Memoirist, Is Dead at 94
text: Nien Cheng, whose memoir, “Life and Death in Shanghai,” offered a harrowing account of the Cultural Revolution in China and her years of imprisonment and torture at the hands of the Red Guards, died on Nov. 2 at her home in Washington. She was 94.

headline: The Forever War of the Mind
text: “EVERY day I was in Vietnam, I thought about home. And, every day I’ve been home, I’ve thought about Vietnam.” So said one of the millions of soldiers who fought there as I did. Change the name of the battlefield and it could have been said by one of the American servicemen coming home from Iraq or Afghanistan today. Wars are not over when the shooting stops. They live on in the lives of those who fight them. That is the curse of the soldier. He never forgets.

headline: Muslims at Fort Voice Outrage and Ask Questions
text: KILLEEN, Tex.  Leaders of the vibrant Muslim community here expressed outrage on Friday at the shooting rampage being laid to one of their members, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, who had become a regular attendee of prayers at the local mosque.

headline: Stacy Rowles, Jazz Musician, Is Dead at 54
text: Stacy Rowles, a jazz trumpeter, fluegelhorn player and singer who had been active on the Los Angeles jazz scene since the 1980s, died on Oct. 27 at her home in Burbank, Calif. She was 54.

headline: The Life and Career of Major Hasan
text: Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan was sentenced to death in the Fort Hood shootings.

headline: Happy Times at the Dog Run, Now Coming to an End
text: It’s considered impolite, yet everyone slips up occasionally. How can anyone be blamed for mixing up the name of a dog with that of its owner, especially when the dog is Henry and his owner goes by Rags?

headline: Weekend Sports Lineup
text: Here we are at the big Health Care Bill Weekend! The House of Representatives is actually getting ready to vote on legislation. How long has this been in the works, anyway? Was “Mad Men” on TV when the debate started? Had TV been invented?

headline: Lottery Numbers
Lombardi’s Life Heads for Broadway
text: The life of Vince Lombardi  one of the Seven Blocks of Granite at Fordham, the coaching saint, the mahatma of Green Bay  is the subject of a new play, and its producers plan to bring it to Broadway late next year.

headline: Dust Has Yet to Settle Over New Concrete Plant
text: Once it might have seemed a match made in zoning heaven: a concrete plant dropped into gritty, tumbledown Red Hook.

headline: Oh, I Don’t Know
text: “I’ve been Klahned! It was a knock-down, drag-out fight with Bob Klahn the victor in round 1, round 2 and round 3, until battered and bruised, I dragged this brawler of a puzzle to the canvas, right alongside me.” Could that description sum up your experience?

headline: Paul C. Zamecnik, Biologist Who Helped Discover an RNA Molecule, Dies at 96
text: Paul C. Zamecnik, a molecular biologist whose determination to unlock the secrets of how a protein is made led to his co-discovery of transfer RNA, a molecule that is essential to the process, died on Oct. 27 at his home in Boston. He was 96.

headline: John Mashek, Veteran Political Reporter, Is Dead at 77
text: John W. Mashek, a reporter and columnist who covered national politics for nearly half a century for U.S. News & World Report, The Boston Globe and other publications, died Tuesday in Rockville, Md. He was 77 and lived in Washington.

headline: Broader Measure of U.S. Unemployment Stands at 17.5%
text: For all the pain caused by the Great Recession, the job market still was not in as bad shape as it had been during the depths of the early 1980s recession  until now.

headline: Vows: Allyson & Gautam
text: Allyson and Gautam met when they were both working in a trauma unit at a Boston hospital. She knew he was special when he could make her laugh even at 5:30 in the morning after an all-night shift.

headline: Virtual Goods Start Bringing Real Paydays
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Silicon Valley may have discovered the perfect business: charging real money for products that do not exist.

headline: The View From the Wall
text: To mark the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, readers submitted their photos and memories.

headline: In a Child’s Company, Champions Become Gods
text: Before Game 5 of the World Series, in the visiting manager’s office at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, Joe Girardi admitted he had thought about the parade. His son Dante, then 7 years old, had been asking about it.

headline: 'Free for All'
text: Kenneth Turan's long-delayed oral history about Joseph Papp and the Public Theater will finally have a release.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Saturday about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s sparring with the Pakistani press during a recent trip to Pakistan misstated, in some editions, Najam Sethi’s relationship to The Daily Times, an English-language paper. He is the former editor in chief, not the current editor. (As the article correctly noted in some editions he is the editor of The Friday Times, an English-language weekly.)

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the Prescriptions column on Wednesday about civil rights groups’ unveiling a “war room” in Washington to push for a government-run health plan misstated the age of one of the groups, the Urban League. It is 99 years old, not 109.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about Fugitive Safe Surrender, a government program that promises leniency to those wanted for nonviolent crimes, misstated the name of the Newark church where officers ran computer checks on participants. It is Bethany Baptist Church, not Bethel Baptist Church.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: Comedy

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Oct. 29 about a blog by Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York misstated the given name of the bishop of Brooklyn, who does not have a blog. He is Nicholas DiMarzio, not Anthony (Anthony is his middle name).

headline: Corrections
text: A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Schubert Ascending mini-festival presented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center misspelled, at one point, the surname of a pianist who will perform. As noted elsewhere in the entry, he is Inon Barnatan, not Barnaton.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: Comedy

headline: Events on Long Island
text: Comedy

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about an experimental gene therapy procedure intended to improve vision misstated the name of a gene used in a treatment of five children and seven adults with a type of congenital retinal disease. It is RPE65, not REP65.

headline: All Along Broadway, Pinstripes, Proposals and Chants to ‘Go for 28’
text: The Yankees took one last ride together to celebrate their championship. It was a slow, joyous journey up Broadway, an outdoor party attended by hundreds of thousands of their closest friends. For the first time in nine years  and time is measured in dog years in Yankeeland  the Yankees and their fans could brag about being the best.

headline: Bloggingheads: Neglecting the Jobless?
text: David Corn, left, of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate President Obama's commitment to lowering unemployment.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a conference at Hampshire College in Massachusetts on creationism in the Islamic world referred incorrectly to a comment by the event’s organizer, Salman Hameed. In noting that researchers did not have much information about the teaching and perception of evolution in Arab countries, Dr. Hameed was citing the example of textbooks used by private Saudi schools in the United States, not in Saudi Arabia.

headline: 2,000-Year-Old Scrolls, Internet-Era Crime
text: Early one morning in March, the law banged on the door of an apartment on Thompson Street in Greenwich Village. Investigators had a warrant to arrest Raphael Haim Golb and seize his computer. He was caught red-handed.

headline: In Scientology’s Door, but Not Much Farther
text: For all the rumors that swirl around the Church of Scientology  the accusations that it is a cult, the hints about its supernatural teachings, the means by which it attracts so many celebrities  its center on West 46th Street, tucked between the soignée Paramount Hotel and the workaday Edison, is a rather straightforward presence.

headline: The Long Toll of Missing in Action
text: THE big news on July 15, 1969, was the countdown for the Apollo 11 mission to the moon. But the writer Lary Bloom remembers it as the day his boyhood friend Harmon Polster, a 25-year-old United States Air Force navigator, went down in a nighttime crash in Laos. Airmen in nearby jets thought they saw the fiery end, but they couldn’t tell whether Lieutenant Polster or the pilot had been able to eject. Their names were added to the country’s growing list of those missing in action.

headline: Beauty From Sometimes Shaky Hands
text: Those who attend the annual Full Circle celebration at the Matheny Medical and Educational Center, which casts a spotlight on the facility’s Arts Access program for its patients, show up for a spectrum of reasons.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: A Division Through Time
text: A historical look at points along the border that separated East and West Berlin from 1961 until 1989.

headline: Red Carpet: Latin Grammys
text: Glitz and heart-on-sleeve emotionality mingled, every so often, with political and social messages at the 10th annual Latin Grammy Awards.

headline: Don’t Worry, Be Happy: The Warranty Psychology
text: MANY people would not think of making a major purchase without doing research to find the best model and the lowest price. But at the checkout counter, all of that preparation often breaks down.

headline: The Horror at Fort Hood
text: It is always a shock  and a cause for deep sadness  when a gunman fires malevolently at crowds of innocent people. We have seen it far too often: at Columbine High School in Colorado a decade ago; on the campus of Virginia Tech two years ago; at a center for immigrants in upstate New York in April; and in downtown Orlando, Fla., where a gunman shot and killed one person and wounded five others on Friday.

headline: Investors Beware
text: Things turned Orwellian in the House Financial Services Committee this week when members  with the backing of the White House  passed an investor protection bill that would make it all too easy for thousands of publicly traded companies to cook their books.

headline: Coup, Uninterrupted
text: The Obama administration has worked hard, if somewhat episodically, to try to resolve the political crisis in Honduras. Last week, it looked as if the administration had pulled it off. The deal is now unraveling because of the obstinacy of Honduras’s ousted president, Manuel Zelaya, and the man who ousted him, Roberto Micheletti. But we fear Washington also miscalculated that obstinacy.

headline: After 40 Years, Age Discrimination Still Gets Second-Class Treatment
text: After working for a vending machine company for more than 20 years, James O’Connor was replaced with someone younger. He sued. He testified that his boss had disparaged older workers, including saying  two weeks before he was fired  “O’Connor, you are too damn old for this kind of work.” A federal court was unmoved, ruling in 1995 that he had not connected the bigoted comments to his firing.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:
