text: To the Editor:

headline: Bridging the Workplace Generation Gap: It Starts With a Text
text: IF we believe the advertisements, with plastic surgery and Spanx we can all look 25 until we drop. But apparently that’s not enough anymore  looking young doesn’t do you much good if you still act old.

headline: A Sign, Perhaps, in a Filly’s Victory
text: ARCADIA, Calif.  Horseplayers ignore omens at their own risk. And the ones who had been on the fence about the chances of the tough old mare Zenyatta beating a stout field of boys Saturday in the $5 million Breeders’ Cup Classic shivered with goose bumps Friday when Life Is Sweet rolled off the final turn, squared her powerful shoulders and took aim at the finish line.

headline: James Brings Buzz to Garden, but Keeps Plans to a Murmur
text: In one of LeBron James’s recurring Nike commercials, he played several characters simultaneously. The ad was merely fantasy for viewers, fodder for shoe aficionados.

headline: Rodriguez Savors First Title
text: A few minutes after Alex Rodriguez jumped off a parade float Friday, he stopped to answer questions about an embarrassing, challenging and, ultimately, victorious season. But, before Rodriguez talked too much about this season, he referenced 2004, a season that ended shockingly for the Yankees.

headline: Fans at Garden Were Thrilled, but Not by Knicks
text: LeBron James bade New York a warm hello and a fond farewell Friday, and in the hours between friendly greetings, pinned the Knicks with another defeat while soaking up their fans’ adulation.

headline: Driver Said to Have Used Marijuana Regularly
text: The sister-in-law of the woman who killed herself and seven others when she hit another car head-on while driving the wrong way on the Taconic State Parkway in July, told investigators that the woman smoked marijuana regularly and was a heavy drinker, according to a lawyer for the family of two of the victims.

headline: Women’s Suffrage Campaign at Full Tilt
text: Sunday, Nov. 7, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Mourning the Victims at Fort Hood
text: A day after an Army doctor shot and killed 13 at Fort Hood in Texas, soldiers and families mourned and questions multiplied about the deadliest shooting on a U.S. base.

headline: For Those Scoring at Home
text: O.K., policy wonks: fill a bowl of popcorn (or corn flakes), fluff the couch pillows and grab that remote control.

headline: Curative Medicine
text: We didn’t want to do Disney characters or wallpaper,” says Diane Brown, the founder of RxArt, a New York-based nonprofit organization that brings contemporary art into hospitals and health care settings around the country. “We want to offer challenging work to help get patients out of their heads, out of the hospital for a bit.” That’s a tall order, since RxArt often works with facilities that treat children, some with life-threatening and terminal diseases. All the more reason that Brown, a curator and private art dealer before starting RxArt in 2000, enlisted artists like Will Cotton and Rob Pruitt to create works for St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital in Memphis, one of the world’s largest childhood cancer centers, which — miraculously in this day and age — covers the exorbitant costs of treatment for uninsured families. Pruitt made a series of his signature pandas out of shimmering, sequinlike discs; Cotton created two of his Candy Land-style paintings, having invited a 3-year-old girl with a rare brain cancer to help him build the gingerbread house maquettes. These pieces now hang in St. Jude’s bright new cafeteria, where staff and patients all get to enjoy them. Cotton, along with artists like Assume Vivid Astro Focus and Mark Grotjahn, has also contributed to an RxArt coloring book.

headline: Reading List the Houses That Gehry Built
text: Frank Gehry is out of the house business, having moved on to bigger things. But it was a residential project  his radical revision of his own little Dutch colonial in Santa Monica, Calif.  that put him on the map in the late 1970s and allowed him to explore the ideas that came to define his architecture. This house and others are included in “Frank Gehry: The Houses” (Rizzoli), by Mildred Friedman, who in 1986, as the design curator at the Walker Art Center, mounted the first major museum exhibition of the architect’s work. (I contributed an essay to its catalog.) The book, which has an intimate, down-to-earth tone, features not only abundant visual material but also interviews with Gehry, his clients (including his wife, Berta), and current and former members of his firm. And seeing projects like his own home, the never-built extravaganza that he designed for the insurance magnate Peter Lewis or the guesthouse (right) that he completed in 1987 for Mike and Penny Winton in Wayzata, Minn., makes you hope Gehry still has another house (or two) in him.

headline: Child’s Play
text: Sitting on a shelf in the nursery at 2 Willow Road, in the leafy London suburb of Hampstead, is a wooden square containing cutouts of the 26 letters in the alphabet. It is slightly shabby, as if the letters have been pushed in and pulled out by lots of little hands over the years  which they have.

headline: Block Party
text: Devoid as they are of nostalgia, kids won’t really appreciate that the mustache included in the new wooden block set PlayShapes was inspired by Sgt. Pepper, nor that the toy has echoes of Alexander Girard, Enzo Mari and midcentury advertising illustrations. But what will please the little ones is that unlike that era’s blocks, which mostly encouraged the dutiful construction of towns and landscapes, the strange contours of the 74 PlayShapes will let them build whatever animal, vegetable or psychedelic ’60s pop star they please. “We spent ages looking at old toys and seeing what had been done before, how we could make it new,” says PlayShapes’ Brighton, U.K.-based co-creator Zoe Miller, who with her partner David Goodman also designs vintage-inspired kids’ toys and books for the Tate. “For us it became about open-endedness, the fact that every child should feel that they’re an artist.” $111; go to shhhop.com. [?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV

headline: Tot Spot
text: In-Store Sweet William Bronagh Staley’s two-year-old shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is filled with stylish clothing, accessories and toys for the seesaw set. “I’m drawn to small labels, especially European ones, that make traditional kids’ items with a little bit of an edge,” says Staley, shown here with her son and muse, Fiontan. (112 North 6th Street; 718-218-6946; sweetwilliamltd.com) SANDRA BALLENTINE

headline: Mother’s Little Helper
text: Once upon a time, kids who showed an interest in culinary arts were given a packet of instant brownie mix and a miniature oven powered by a light bulb. But if your budding Jacques Pépin is begging for the latest Viking combi, indulge him instead with the latest cooking utensils from Curious Chef. The tools  including a whisk, spatula and rolling pin  are all bisphenol-A-free and scaled down to fit a child’s hands; the nylon serrated knives are effective for chopping a tomato, not your little sous-chef’s fingers. The 27-piece Foundation Set ($60; curiouschef.com) even comes with an apron and a chef’s hat. Anyone for petits fours? [?][?][?] ANDREAS KOKKINO

headline: Instant Gratification
text: Who doesn’t have a digital camera these days? Not to mention a million unviewed images, eating up the memory on the hard drive? With that in mind, Fujifilm has introduced the adorable and already successful (in Europe and Asia) Instax Mini 7S camera. With its matte-white, bubble-shaped body, the camera was conceived not so much for those who pine for Polaroid as for the design-savvy iPod generation. The super-color-saturated, credit-card-size photos satisfy the current obsession for all things miniature  in a flash, no less. $96; go to fujifilmusa.com. [?][?][?] ANDREAS KOKKINO

headline: House Proud
text: Until now, the world of dollhouses has thrived on Tudors and Georgians filled with wicker, Windsor and chintz, forcing dolls  and the children who love them  to dwell in a land that time forgot. “They’re all furnished like my grandmother’s house, with terrible old brown chairs,” says Linda Stenberg, the creative director for the new Danish company Minimii (minimii.com). She and her partner Claus Hojer Hansen have come up with an antidote: a 1/16-size reproduction of Arne Jacobsen’s own 1929 house, approved by Jacobsen’s family and scheduled for release early next year. There are Egg and Swan chairs courtesy of Fritz Hansen, tiny Vipp trash cans and a working lamp by the Danish studio Design by Us. New pieces commissioned just for the house so far include a childlike scribble by the artist Poul Pava and prospective inhabitants by the dollmaker Maileg. Stenberg has already noticed a change in her kids since she let them play with the prototypes: “They recognize the furniture now,” she says. “When they see a Jacobsen, they say, ‘Oh, Mommy, those are your chairs, only bigger.’ ” [?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV

headline: Family Planning
text: The extended family is a wonderful thing, but so is privacy. It’s not easy to balance the two when designing a house, particularly if you don’t have the land or budget, or both, to build a compound. But with ingenuity and a little luck, even a modest house on a small site can accommodate three generations with breathing room to spare.

headline: Profile in Style: Cynthia Rowley
text: A CREATIVE MULTITASKER

headline: Now Showing Design for Living
text: London is known for top-quality design exhibitions, and this season doesn’t disappoint. Opening Nov. 18 at the Design Museum is a retrospective of the work of the German designer Dieter Rams, including his pioneering electronics designs for Braun, without which there might be no iPod (Apple’s Jonathan Ive is one of five designers who are interviewed for the show), and those for the furniture company Vitsoe. On Nov. 26, the Serpentine Gallery opens its first-ever contemporary design exhibition, “Design Real,” curated by the German industrial designer Konstantin Grcic. His selection focuses on objects (like Carlotta de Bevilacqua’s Yang light for Artemide, below right) that have a practical function, are accessible to all and have made a significant impact on the world. Grcic’s own work will be the subject of “Konstantin Grcic: Decisive Design,” starting Nov. 20 at the Art Institute of Chicago. [?][?][?] PILAR VILADAS

headline: On Top of Spaghetti
text: Getting kids interested in eating good food is one thing. How about getting them interested in cooking? Phaidon, which published the translation of the Italian food bible “The Silver Spoon,” has chosen 40 bambino-friendly recipes from the original 2,000-plus to create “The Silver Spoon for Children: Favorite Italian Recipes.” The colorful, cleverly illustrated book teaches kids 8 and up kitchen fundamentals and provides step-by-step instructions for everything from a simple prosciutto and melon to spaghetti amatriciana. (“Ask an adult to help you drain the spaghetti.”) Making meatballs is apparently a great way to practice math and learn about fractions. And cooking your parents chicken breasts stuffed with mascarpone is a great way to make them happy. Buon appetito. [?][?][?] CHRISTINE MUHLKE

headline: Funny Money
text: Warren Buffett is now a cartoon character. The Oracle of Omaha has a starring role in “Secret Millionaire’s Club,” a Web series produced by AOL and A Squared Entertainment that goes live in January. This is not a move to stanch his declining fortunes  the man’s still worth $40 billion, after all  but a pro bono effort to teach kids fiscal responsibility. (Adults, Buffett must think, are now beyond his help.) The “club” is made up of a group of young Nebraskans who sell baseball memorabilia online and use the profits to bankroll an investment business; an animated (and slenderized) Buffett serves as their adviser. Searching for a youth-friendly analogue, Andy Heyward, the show’s producer, says, “It’s a little bit like Monopoly.” Heyward first collaborated with Buffett on the animated introductions to Berkshire Hathaway’s annual shareholder meetings, in which the frugal tycoon has spoofed Batman and James Bond. “Warren is amazing,” Heyward says. “He does everything in just one take.” [?][?][?] STEPHEN HEYMAN

headline: Jamie Gray | Design Daddy
text: Children may not be able to recognize good design, but according to Jamie Gray (photographed with his girlfriend, Olivia Sammons, and their children, Cy and Levi), they can recognize beauty. Gray, who owns the less-is-more New York design shop Matter, recalls once waking up at 5:30 a.m. to find the 3-year-old Levi gazing through the window of their Brooklyn apartment. “Look at the sky, Papa,” Levi exclaimed. “It’s beautiful.” The first piece Gray ever built was a three-legged chair. His teacher told him it would never stand up. “But I made it anyway,” he said. “And it worked!” (Gray is seated above in a Victor armchair by Paul Loebach.) His company’s Web address, MatterMatters.com, speaks to the challenge of creating objects in a world that’s already glutted with them. “That’s the daily quandary: Do you create more?” he asks. “But, ultimately, if there’s a want, somebody has to take responsibility for it. My intention is to create heirloom pieces that won’t end up at the bottom of a landfill.’ [?][?][?] STEPHEN HEYMAN

headline: Nordic Track
text: Living in a winter wonderland.

headline: Empty Nest Syndrome
text: There isn’t much demand for minimalist design at my house. My 7-year-old twins have never seen a white surface they didn’t think could use a little color. ( Sol LeWitt, because he got to draw on walls, is already the boys’ favorite artist.) As for furniture, none of those spare, Modernist chairs, like Karim Rashid’s Oh or even Gerrit Rietveld’s Zig-Zag, will do. Their favorite place to sit is anywhere on Daddy, and that — they have explained just a bit too enthusiastically — is because Daddy is squishy all over.

headline: Bright Young Thing Emily Pilloton
text: If the initiatives that Project H Design has taken on seem largely geared toward young people  Learning Landscape playgrounds and sustainable food programs for public schools, to name but two  it may have something to do with the fact that Emily Pilloton, the founder of the not even two-year-old humanitarian organization, is herself only 27. With the help of nine volunteer-driven cells from Austin, Tex., to Johannesburg, Pilloton, who started the company with a laptop and $1,000 while living at home with her parents, aims to create local design solutions and apply them globally. (The playgrounds, for example, were conceived in Uganda and have since been installed in North Carolina and the Dominican Republic.) Pilloton is also the author of the just-released book “Design Revolution: 100 Products That Empower People” (Metropolis Books), which gives well-deserved shout-outs to everything from the Hippo Water Roller (a portable vessel that can carry a week’s worth of water for a family of seven) and Braille-based Lego-style building blocks to D.I.Y. soccer balls (left) and SkySails (which are large enough to help propel cargo ships). “If it’s any consolation,” she insists, “I’ve aged a lot over the last year.” [?][?][?] ALIX BROWNE

headline: The Best-Dwessed List
text: Before I had children, I had this delusional idea that their clothes would cost less than grown-up clothes. The proportionately smaller the outfit, the proportionately less expensive. Plus, they would be self-reliant little creatures, like Keebler elves, cozying themselves away in a tree somewhere during the day and knitting their own stocking caps.

headline: Short Orderers
text: Many moons ago I watched aghast as my young niece and nephew cheerfully masticated a lunch of French fries and ketchup during a family ski vacation in Utah. “How can they be allowed to eat like that?” I hissed sotto voce to my husband, who nodded in smug sympathy.

headline: Cool for School
text: As you drive past downtown Los Angeles on the 101 freeway, one building grabs your attention, its concrete and steel tower swooping and twisting like a roller coaster. A multitiered group of oversize geometric structures arranged around concrete and grass courtyards, this complex is not, in fact, an amusement park. It’s the new Central Los Angeles High School No. 9, which opened in September. The building, designed by the edgy Austrian firm Coop Himmelb(l)au, tosses aside any preconceived notion of what a school should look like.

headline: Wild Thing
text: Bring out the beast  in a good way.

headline: Family Planning
Mini-Mies (and Friends)
text: Now that more children are growing up with exquisite  if expensive  taste, the selection of minimodern classics keeps growing. Indeed, when Modernists preached that design should be accessible to all, they meant children, too. The Eameses created plywood elephants and kiddie stools, and designers like Verner Panton considered their furnishings equally viable at pint-size. Invest in these. MONICA KHEMSUROV

headline: The New Collectibles
text: SWEET DREAMS Worried that your baby’s bed won’t match your midcentury modern décor? The Nest Collection bassinet, by Scott Wilson for Offi, is a sleek walnut-veneered design with a chrome base. $999. Go to minijake.com.

headline: Just My Size
text: HAPPY HOME From Left: silhouette lamp by robert kuo for Mcguire, $3,791. Go to mcguirefurniture.com. cindy Lamp by ferruccio laviani for kartell,

headline: Family Planning
text: The extended family is a wonderful thing, but so is privacy. It’s not easy to balance the two when designing a house, particularly if you don’t have the land or budget, or both, to build a compound. But with ingenuity and a little luck, even a modest house on a small site can accommodate three generations with breathing room to spare.

headline: King of the Playground
text: When you think about it, the Rockwell Group has been in the business of playgrounds for years, creating a showy interior for a glamorous jeweler, a JetBlue terminal and Nobu restaurants from New York to Dubai. So the Imagination Playground at Burling Slip, which opens next summer in a former parking lot near South Street Seaport, is a logical next step. The peanut-shaped park is inspired by midcentury adventure playgrounds, where children used found objects and postwar debris. It features sand and water, Playground Associates to oversee the action, and more than 350 loose parts, including wheelbarrows, pool noodles and weather- and germ-resistant foam blocks (above, in Brooklyn). David Rockwell, the founder and C.E.O., has created a standard kit that can be deployed cheaply in open spaces across the country, but at Burling Slip he pays homage to its nautical past with pulleys, masts and periscope-like tubes through which children can talk from opposite ends of the park. “Each place encourages a kind of cooperative, self-directed fantasy play,” he says. “Or you can just run around like a maniac.” [?][?][?] JILL SINGER

headline: Watch This Space
text: For Faye Toogood, September’s London Design Festival was a coming-out party of sorts. After spending nearly a decade styling for the British magazine The World of Interiors and developing her signature raw-meets-refined look, she started quietly building her own full-service creative studio in 2008, remaining under the radar despite redesigning Dover Street Market’s shoe department and creating fanciful window displays for Liberty. But following two buzzed-about installations that she curated at the London festival and her high-profile work for Tom Dixon — which includes a catalog and a new London showroom — the design world is beginning to take notice of this multitalented 32-year-old. “There aren’t many stylists who have decided to transcend disciplines,” says Toogood, who studied fine art and art history. “It’s been a natural course for me.”

headline: N.H.L. Scores: Leafs Beat Canes in Battle of Tail-Enders
text: Six games on Friday night, but without question the feature attraction is the showdown between the two worst teams in the league: the Leafs, with one regulation win in their first 13 matches, vs. the Hurricanes, with one regulation win in their first 14. Home teams listed first:

headline: Obama Offers Sympathy and Urges No ‘Jump to Conclusions’
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama, extending condolences to the community at Fort Hood, Tex., reminded Americans on Saturday that people of “every race, faith and station” serve in the military  an oblique attempt to prevent a backlash against Muslims in the wake of Thursday’s shootings at the base that left 13 dead.

headline: Walter Payton’s Tribute
text: I had no luck searching for a YouTube clip of the halftime tribute to Walter Payton last Sunday in Chicago. It was the 10th anniversary of his death. CBS only showed a snippet of the ceremony in the game broadcast.

headline: Saturday Word: Fort Hood and Health Care
text: President Obama uses his weekly address this week to express sympathy for those who lost loved ones at the Fort Hood shooting and also to hail the valor of those on the scene.

headline: Stressing the ‘Friend’ Part of ‘Frenemy’
text: The business card of Eric Schmidt says he is the chairman and chief executive of Google. But another part of his job is ambassador to the marketing, advertising and media communities, reassuring them that if Google is a “frenemy,” in the parlance of Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of WPP, it is more “friend” than “enemy.”

headline: ‘Ways to Avoid the Flu’
text: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: I just want to mention, if anyone is here tonight for a flu shot, we ran out, so — I accidentally drank them, so sorry.

headline: The Lead Players, as House Debate Begins
text: The health care debate is under way on Saturday morning. Representative John Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, and the Dean of the House, is presiding as the speaker pro tempore.

headline: Abortion Fight Erupts in Health Care Debate
text: Updated After months of work by Congressional Democrats on major health care legislation, the floor debate on the bill was at risk of being overshadowed on Saturday by a fierce internal dispute among Democrats over the issue of insurance coverage for abortions.

headline: Marooned on Sea of Iraqi Oil, but Unable to Tap Its Wealth
text: BASRA, Iraq  The orange glow of the giant natural gas flares in the oil fields around Basra represents this bustling city’s wealth of natural resources. But for the impoverished people who live near them, the flames only serve as a reminder of their inability to share in the riches that lie beneath their feet.

headline: Jeremy Morris, Who Proved Exercise Is Heart-Healthy, Dies at 99½
text: Jeremy N. Morris, a British epidemiologist whose comparison of heart-attack rates among double-decker bus drivers and conductors in London in the late 1940s and early ’50s laid the scientific groundwork for the modern aerobics movement, died Oct. 28 in Hampstead, London. He was 99 ½.

headline: In the Bronx, Getting Back All 40 Winks
text: Poverty constricts how people live. For one family on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, it affected how they slept.

headline: House Debate: Objections
text: Curtain’s up.

headline: Ecosystem in Peru Is Losing a Key Ally
text: ICA, Peru  A small grove of huarango, the storied Peruvian tree that can live over a millennium, rests like a mirage amid the sand dunes on this city’s edge. The tree has provided the inhabitants of this desert with food and timber since before the Nazca civilization etched geoglyphs into the empty plain south of here about 2,000 years ago.

headline: European Puck: Forsberg, Blanked Again, Says He Played Better
text: Never has the Karjala Cup generated such interest in North America, but that interest continues to mount as Peter Forsberg furthers his comeback attempt in the Finnish tournament that until this week was virtually unheard of among hockey fans in Canada and the United States.

headline: With Wall Just a Memory, German Divisions Fade
text: BERLIN  “The Quiz of the Germans,” a lighthearted entry amid a crush of serious examinations of the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, pitted three West German celebrities seated behind the sloping hood of an old Volkswagen Beetle against counterparts from the East perched above the front of a clunky Trabant.

headline: Weighing Life in Prison for Youths Who Didn’t Kill
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- There are just over 100 people in the world serving sentences of life without the possibility of parole for crimes they committed as juveniles in which no one was killed. All are in the United States. And 77 of them are here in Florida.

headline: Spirally Rising Acrostic
text: I’ve heard this quote but have never read the book. However, the act of writing out the passage has given me the motivation to look for the book next time I’m at the library. Thanks Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon for the push!

headline: ‘Millionaires in Congress’
text: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: The unemployment rate went above 10% for the first time since 1983. Last week, economists were saying that the recession is finally over, but this week, all of the economists were laid off. So, it is tough.

headline: ‘She Took That Money’
text: Monologue | Aired Friday night on CBS: Sarah Palin’s new book, new memoir, is coming out next month. It’s called “Going Rogue.” Ooh, she was like Rambo, out there on her own, hiding in the trees, swooping down on vines.

headline: ‘Isn’t That Nice?’
text: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on NBC: Yesterday at the White House, President Obama met with Native American tribal leaders and they gave Obama the Indian name “He Who Cares.” Isn’t that nice? Then they gave Vice President Joe Biden the Indian name “Big Chief Running Mouth.”

headline: Labels and Gay Benefits in Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Lower taxes for gay couples who receive health benefits from employers. Nutrition labeling requirements for snack food sold in vending machines and many restaurants. A new program to teach parents how to interact with their children.

headline: ‘The Real Winners’
text: Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC: President Obama hosted a conference of all the Native American tribes. I don’t want to say the U.S. economy is in bad shape, but Obama told the Indians, “Look, you can have your country back. Okay, it’s fine.”

headline: In Republican District, National Party Takes a Hit
text: It is not often that a political party puts more than $750,000 behind a candidate in a high-profile Congressional race, only to see the intended beneficiary endorse the opposition.

headline: Fort Hood Muslims React
text: Members of a mosque near Fort Hood expressed shock at the killings.

headline: NATO Airstrike Said to Kill 7 Afghan Soldiers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan Defense Ministry and local officials in Badghis Province said on Saturday that seven members of the Afghan security forces had been killed in a NATO airstrike the day before that was part of an effort to aid a beleaguered Afghan and NATO operation against the Taliban.

headline: Windfall Seen as Bank Bonuses Are Paid in Stock
text: Even as Washington tries to rein in Wall Street pay, bankers are likely to make unusually large gains on the stock grants and options they received after shares in their companies fell sharply during the financial meltdown.

headline: UPDATED: Obama Rallies House Democrats
text: Update | 1:45 p.m.  President Obama made a last-minute appeal to Congress on Saturday, urging lawmakers to “answer the call of history’’ by casting their votes in favor of a health overhaul being considered on the floor of the House of Representatives.

headline: Sweeping Health Care Plan Passes House
text: WASHINGTON  Handing President Obama a hard-fought victory, the House narrowly approved a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s health care system on Saturday night, advancing legislation that Democrats said could stand as their defining social policy achievement.

headline: To Retain Its Bankers, Citi Offers Option Plan
text: Hoping to encourage bankers and managers to stay, Citigroup has begun dispensing several million stock options to more than a quarter of its workers in a way that could result in a sizable gain for them, The New York Times’s Eric Dash reports.

headline: When Soldiers Snap
text: “Every man has his breaking point,” said military doctors in World War II, believing that more than 90 days of continuous combat could turn any soldier into a psychiatric casualty.

headline: US tariff history
text: Mostly a note to myself, since I’m teaching trade policy at the Wilson School this spring. From the millennial edition of Historical Statistics,

headline: House Jumps One Hurdle
text: The House approved the rule governing debate of the big health care legislation by a vote of 242 to 192, suggesting — but not guaranteeing — that Democrats would have the votes to pass the bill itself later on Saturday.

headline: The President Whose Words Once Soared
text: WASHINGTON — As the most gifted orator of his generation, President Obama finds speechmaking perhaps his most potent political tool. It propelled him to national prominence in 2004 and to the White House in 2008. And whenever he needs to calm economic fears or revive stalled health care legislation, he takes to the lectern.

headline: Awesome Train Set, Mr. Buffett
text: For $50 or so, you can buy a Thomas the Tank Engine train set and feel as powerful as Sir Topham Hatt, the somewhat wooden overseer of the mythical North Western Railway Company. Or, if you are the investor Warren E. Buffett, you can purchase the complete set of the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation, for $26 billion or so.

headline: Invitation to Veterans and Families
text: The editors of Home Fires are requesting the participation of readers for a post on Veterans Day, Nov. 11. If you are a veteran, or friend or relative of someone who served during wartime and would like to share a written message or recollection, or a photograph recalling a veteran or their service, you can send it to Home Fires via e-mail at homefires@nytimes.com.

headline: Who Is a Jew? Court Ruling in Britain Raises Question
text: LONDON  The questions before the judges in Courtroom No. 1 of Britain’s Supreme Court were as ancient and as complex as Judaism itself.

headline: Medvedev Says Russia May Back Sanctions on Iran if Deal Falls Apart
text: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev said Russia might back sanctions against Iran if the Iranians did not take a “constructive position” on an international plan to temporarily diminish their stockpile of enriched uranium.

headline: For Russia’s Communists, Ousting Putin Is a Priority
text: MOSCOW  Along with the perennial calls for “land for farmers” and “factories for workers,” Communists who marched in Moscow on the Saturday anniversary of the 1917 revolution offered a slogan of more recent vintage: “Russia without Putin.”

headline: Heavier Americans Push Back on Health Debate
text: Marilyn Wann is an author and weight diversity speaker in Northern California who has a message for anyone making judgments about her health based on her large physique. “The only thing anyone can accurately diagnose by looking at a fat person is their own level of stereotype and prejudice about fat,” said Ms. Wann, a 43-year-old San Franciscan whose motto in life is also the title of her book: “Fat! So?”

headline: Reagan! Reagan! Reagan!
text: Aha. I see that some commenters insist that I was unfair or, some insist, intellectually dishonest in my post on the fact that advanced economies actually grew faster in the era before modern finance took hold. There have been assertions that it was all about rebuilding from the war, or that the picture looks very different if you look at per capita real GDP, with some flat assertions that if you look at the numbers right growth has been better since 1980s.

headline: The Recession’s Over, but Not the Layoffs
text: The Great Recession is over — not officially, but by popular acclaim — and in this accepted fact we are invited to take comfort, even as the unemployment rate last week rose into double digits for the first time in a quarter-century.

headline: N.F.L. Tries to Get a Grip on Tackling That Has Suddenly Gone Amiss
text: Jacksonville Coach Jack Del Rio was so disgusted by how many tackles the Jaguars missed last Sunday in a 30-13 loss at Tennessee that he took an unusual step in today’s N.F.L.: he had his team practice in full pads. Del Rio even considered, but ultimately rejected, having his players actually tackle in practice.

headline: Love in the Time of Cellphones
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Nov. 7, 2009
text: The midterm elections of 2010 are about a year away, but the guests on this Sunday’s talk shows will try to gauge what’s in store for Democrats and Republicans on the next election day. Plus, the Army’s highest-ranking officer talks about the shootings at the Army base in Ft. Hood, Tex.

headline: Claude Lévi-Strauss’s Two-Part Harmonies
text: Millions of words have been written trying to explain or apply the theories of the French anthropologist Claude Lévi-Strauss since the publication of his work “Structural Anthropology” in 1958. More than a few of the resulting texts in disciplines as varied as sociology and philosophy are dense, turgid and jargon ridden, or so the complaint goes. But Mr. Lévi-Strauss himself could be simple, direct and elegant when he wanted to be. Structuralism, he once said, is simply “the search for unsuspected harmonies” across cultures.

headline: Getting a Grip on Drugs and Horses
text: More than a half-dozen trainers who have been accused of doping their horses participated in this year’s Breeders’ Cup at Santa Anita Park in Arcadia, Calif., to compete in 14 races worth more than $25.5 million in purse money. Some of these trainers have been cited for multiple and serious drug violations; indeed, some have been barred and suspended from the sport for periods of time. But none of these punishments have deterred trainers from doping their animals.

headline: Correction: Lessons From Iraq
text: An article last Sunday about lessons a correspondent learned while reporting on the war in Iraq offered an incorrect contrast to the difficulties Iraqis face when crossing from Kurdish Iraq into their country’s Arab southern provinces. A comparison that illustrates the ease of traversing a state border in the United States would be a crossing from Michigan into Indiana  not into Illinois, with which Michigan does not share a land border.

headline: News of Hockey, 11/7/09: Canadian Women Beat U.S. to Win Four Nations Cup
text: Canada rallied from an early 1-0 deficit to beat the United States, 5-1, in the final of the Four Nations Cup in Tikkurila, Finland, the last international women’s tournament before the Vancouver Olympics in February.

headline: Britain and U.S. Clash at G-20 on Tax to Insure Against Crises
text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The United States and Britain voiced disagreement Saturday over a proposal that would impose a new tax on financial transactions to support future bank rescues.

headline: Manning and Rivers Share a Past, and Now the Present
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When San Diego chose Eli Manning first over all in the 2004 N.F.L. draft, the Chargers gave him a jersey that he handed to his mother.

headline: The House Debate Over Health Care Legislation
text: Prescriptions, The Times’s blog on the debate over health care reform, is following the floor debate over health care legislation in the House of Representatives throughout Saturday. Read the current coverage.

headline: Obama’s Remarks on the House Health Care Bill
text: Following is a transcript of President Obama's remarks on the health care bill being debated in the House of Representatives on Saturday, as released by the White House:

headline: Boxing’s Pac-Man, Back Home
text: Manny Pacquiao and his trainer Freddie Roach took their training regimen to the fighter’s home country, the Philippines, as Pacquiao prepared for another title bout.

headline: New York’s Cabbies Like Credit Cards? Go Figure
text: New York’s cabbies howled when the city began forcing them to take credit cards. Some even went on strike, calling the requirements a kowtow to tourists and a burden on drivers.

headline: The Yankees and the Cubs
text: If baseball were a country, rather than a sport, the North Side of Chicago would be in an uprising right now. “Are you kidding me?’’ Cubs fans would cry angrily as they took note of the 27 championships for the Yankees in the last 87 years and the lack of even one for their team since 1908. There would be protests in the streets, calls for a federal investigation, boycotts of products made in New York.

headline: Quotation of the Week
text: “I’m dumbfounded. After all these years, I still don’t get how Broadway works, or what to make of our culture.”

headline: 4 Are Killed in 2 Fires in Queens and Brooklyn
text: Three people were killed and four were injured in a fire that started in the basement of an illegally subdivided house in Queens early Saturday morning, according to neighbors and Fire Department officials.

headline: Prime Number
text: 58: The number of private colleges that now charge at least $50,000 a year for tuition, fees, room and board, according to The Chronicle of Higher Education. Last year, only five colleges charged that much. Generous aid packages mean many students pay far less, the Chronicle noted. Even so, the cost of a college education has grown much faster than the costs of other goods and services — up 4.3 percent this year at private colleges and 5.9 percent for in-state students at public schools.

headline: Ask Not What You Can Steal From Your Country
text: Call to armed robbers: stop your crimes. Please. For a little while at least. Please.

headline: Nov. 7, 1979
text: On the fourth day of the Iranian hostage crisis, the students seeking American extradition of the deposed Shah reported Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's refusal to meet with former Attorney General Ramsey Clark and William G. Miller, staff director of the Senate Intelligence Committee:

headline: Florida A&M Coach Has Faith in His Rebuilding Program
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  When Joe Taylor took over as the football coach at Florida A&M, barely a month after the Rattlers lost six of their last seven games to finish 3-8 in 2007, he summoned every returning player for an individual conference.

headline: Out of Chance Meeting, a Formidable Pairing
text: HOLLYWOOD  After the second typhoon hit, as the third crept closer, Freddie Roach had seen enough. Houses disappeared underwater. Boulders blocked the narrow, winding roads. Seventeen families packed into one room.

headline: Lawmakers Join Protest Over Bill
text: As the House began debate on President Obama’s top-priority initiative to overhaul the health care system, protesters outside the Capitol occasionally yelled or waved signs that said, “Have you heard us yet?”

headline: The Calm After the Storm
text: Peace has returned to the Yankees’ universe. The Champagne celebrations are over, the confetti has been cleaned up along the Canyon of Heroes and for the first time since last spring, the urgency has vanished from Yankee Stadium.

headline: Knock-Knock Joke?
text: Video | Quite possibly proof that the Internet has everything:

headline: At Ruby Tuesday, Casual Dining Dons a Blazer
text: Maryville, Tenn.

headline: Inside the Global Gold Frenzy
text: MENDRISIO, Switzerland

headline: Hill Gives Glimpse of Knicks’ Future
text: There was an intense focus on the Knicks’ future Friday night, and yet it was easy to miss one of the most critical pieces of that future.

headline: Ballet’s Mean Streets
text: Some movies you have to watch whenever they’re on.

headline: A Way Out of the Deep Freeze
text: FOR many holders of auction-rate securities  investments that Wall Street once peddled as safe, sound and as fully liquid as cash  life in the frozen zone drags on.

headline: Small Businesses Hunker Down to Survive
text: New data show that small businesses have battened down the hatches in response to the recession.

headline: Watch the Walk and Prevent a Fall
text: FALLS are so harmful to the elderly and so costly to society that if falling were a disease, it would be deemed an epidemic.

headline: Far From a Lab? Turn a Cellphone Into a Microscope
text: MICROSCOPES are invaluable tools to identify blood and other cells when screening for diseases like anemia, tuberculosis and malaria. But they are also bulky and expensive.

headline: Lawyer Cites Mental Illness in Shooting
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  The lawyer for the man accused of shooting six people, one fatally, at an Orlando office building on Friday told reporters after a court appearance on Saturday that his client was “very, very mentally ill.”

headline: Johnson Has Turned Nascar’s Chase Into a Stroll
text: Jimmie Johnson will probably make stock-car history this month by winning a fourth consecutive championship, but his coronation will culminate an anticlimactic Nascar Sprint Cup Series season.

headline: How to Stay Relentlessly Positive
text: Tobi Umodu is a junior fullback for the U.C.L.A. Bruins. He is blogging for The Quad periodically during the season.

headline: Putting the Negro Leagues in Play
text: The Strat-O-Matic Game Company, an old warhorse in an age of computer-driven fantasy leagues and high-tech video games, usually relies on detailed statistics to create ratings and tendencies for hitters and pitchers. But in creating a new 103-card Negro leagues set for its board game, Strat-O-Matic found that the data was not easy to come by.

headline: Hoisting Babies in Health Debate
text: Some lawmakers today used live props — infants and young children — to help make their arguments about health care as they take to the House floor on Saturday. As they did so, they were chastised by those presiding over the debate.

headline: Budget Fights Are Brewing at the United Nations
text: UNITED NATIONS  The fact that it costs the United Nations an average of $2,473 per page to create every single document in its six official languages, while outside contractors complete the same work for around $450, prompts diplomats to accuse the organization of running amok during a global financial crisis.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Colonization
text: Robert W. Harris has taken a popular puzzling convention, inserting several letters into an existing phrase, and created a pleasant and amusing Sunday afternoon picnic. In this case, the presence of six-legged interlopers only adds to the enjoyment. All of the theme entries were good and several were unexpected in their origins, but for my money, the inspired standout of the bunch was MADAM, I’M ADAMANT. Never has a palindrome been ruined to greater success.

headline: An Island Shelter Meets Resistance From Locals
text: UNALASKA, Alaska  This was a tumble-down frontier town not so long ago, known for big catches of king crab on the Bering Sea and big trouble when the boats came back to shore, spilling their crews into a raucous redoubt of drink named the Elbow Room.

headline: Call White House, Ask for Barack
text: The Israeli-Palestinian peace process has become a bad play. It is obvious that all the parties are just acting out the same old scenes, with the same old tired clichés  and that no one believes any of it anymore. There is no romance, no sex, no excitement, no urgency  not even a sense of importance anymore. The only thing driving the peace process today is inertia and diplomatic habit. Yes, the Israeli-Palestinian peace process has left the realm of diplomacy. It is now more of a calisthenic, like weight-lifting or sit-ups, something diplomats do to stay in shape, but not because they believe anything is going to happen. And yet, as much as we, the audience, know this to be true, we can never quite abandon hope for peace in the Holy Land. It is our habit. Indeed, as I ranted about this to a Jordanian friend the other day, he said it all reminded him of an old story.

headline: Army Concludes Shootings Involved Only One Gunman
text: KILLEEN, Tex.  Military investigators have concluded that there was only one gunman involved in the rampage at Fort Hood that left 13 people dead and dozens more injured, but they added that they were still trying to determine whether other people were involved in any plot, an Army spokesman said on Saturday.

headline: Degree Required, but You Don’t Have One
text: SOME job seekers harbor a secret that prevents them from applying for work they know they could do. Or they worry that if this fact comes to light in a job interview, it will explode and cause them to be led unceremoniously to the door.

headline: Painful Stories Take a Toll on Military Therapists
text: Many of the patients who fill the day are bereft, angry, broken. Their experiences are gruesome, their distress lasting and the process of recovery exhausting. The repeated stories of battle and loss can leave the most professional therapist numb or angry.

headline: In Fund Flows, a Caution for Stocks
text: MUTUAL fund investors have remained skeptical about the stock market rally over the last eight months, holding back on their purchases of domestic equity funds. That isn’t a promising sign for the stock market.

headline: Maybe a New Day for Doctors’ Pay
text: EVEN without a robust public option, any of the health care reform bills now under consideration would expand coverage greatly. But they would also start a competitive dynamic that would eliminate the fundamental conflict of interest that has made American health care so expensive.

headline: Bouquets That Bear Fruit
text: I WAS born in Pakistan and came to the United States in 1981, when I was 11. My grandfather owned a farm in Pakistan and we had been fairly well-to-do. We started at the bottom when we came here. My father found a job as a machinist during the day and worked at McDonald’s and Burger King at night.

headline: Jobless Recovery
text: If you are looking for an economic recovery you can believe in, the October employment report is not for you.

headline: Young, Talented and Unhappy Playing Basketball Overseas
text: HAIFA, Israel  Jeremy Tyler came to this scenic city overlooking the Mediterranean as a trailblazer. As the first American basketball player to skip his senior year of high school to play professionally overseas, Tyler signed a $140,000 deal to play for Maccabi Haifa this year. The grand plan revolves around his being a top pick, if not the top pick, in the 2011 N.B.A. draft.

headline: Looking Abroad for Health Savings
text: No matter what Congress does with health care legislation in the next few weeks, one thing is already clear: the result will not do much to control the climbing costs of medical care in the United States.

headline: Malcolm Gladwell, Eclectic Detective
text: Have you ever wondered why there are so many kinds of mustard but only one kind of ketchup? Or what Cézanne did before painting his first significant works in his 50s? Have you hungered for the story behind the Veg-O-Matic, star of the frenetic late-night TV ads? Or wanted to know where Led Zeppelin got the riff in “Whole Lotta Love”?

headline: The Benefit of a Boot Out the Door
text: This interview with Jeffrey Katzenberg, chief executive of DreamWorks Animation SKG, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Well, at Least the Phone Works Fine
text: HELLO and welcome to home-appliance madness week with the Haggler.

headline: Army Releases Names of All 13 Killed in Shootings
text: Michael G. Cahill spoke to soldiers all the time in his job as physician’s assistant, taking their histories and listening to their stories. In the times when he met soldiers who were too unstable to walk to psychiatric services, Mr. Cahill would walk them there himself.

headline: Letters: The Price to Pay for Health Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: City’s JobsNow Program Also Benefits Newsom
text: Arik Levy was not expecting to benefit from the federal economic stimulus package  until one day last summer when a city worker stopped him on Mission Street in San Francisco and offered to give him some money.

headline: After a Swim, Enough Energy to Entertain
text: Barbara Mulas, 49, is chef and part-owner of Sidebar, a “gastropub,” as she describes it, in the Lake Merritt section of Oakland. The San Francisco Bay Guardian recently named Sidebar the best new restaurant in the Bay Area. Ms. Mulas lives in Oakland with her husband, Mark Drazek, who is her longtime business partner as well as the restaurant’s pastry chef. (Her words have been edited and condensed.)

headline: Community Continues to Grapple With Rape
text: As Richmond High School tried to absorb the wrenching reality of a gang rape of a student on school grounds, the predominant reactions  horror or sympathy or even fear  were understood by the school’s principal, Julio Franco.

headline: Rangel and Boehner Tangle Over Ethics and Abortion
text: One of the sharpest exchanges in the House floor debate so far took place between Representative Charles Rangel, Democrat of New York and chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Representative John Boehner, Republican of Ohio and the House minority leader.

headline: Jeremy Tyler’s Rocky Overseas Trip
text: Brandon Jennings has emerged as perhaps the best rookie in the early going of the N.B.A. season His transition to the league has been seemingly seamless, and he’s created a buzz that hasn’t been seen around basketball in Milwaukee in years.

headline: After 8 Years, Work Starts at a Sept. 11 Site
text: SHANKSVILLE, Pa.  More than eight years after United Airlines Flight 93 crashed into a field here as passengers fought the terrorists at its controls, family members, friends and officials who have joined their cause returned to the site on Saturday to break ground on a permanent memorial to the victims.

headline: The Archbishop’s Blog
text: LATE last month, Paul Vitello, who covers religion for The Times, wrote a lighthearted feature about a new blogger: Archbishop Timothy Dolan, installed this year to lead the 2.5 million Catholics of the Archdiocese of New York. Little did Vitello know that before the day was out, Dolan would turn his blog on the reporter and his paper, citing news articles and a column by Maureen Dowd as examples of anti-Catholicism.

headline: A Torah Scribe Pushes the Parchment Ceiling
text: In Hebrew the word for Julie Seltzer’s arcane profession is soferet; she’s a scribe, a Hebrew calligrapher who writes sacred texts on parchment. A mere handful of women do what she does, and an even more select handful are practiced in the especially ritualistic craft of writing particularly holy scrolls, including the Torah, considered the foundation of Jewish life and thought.

headline: Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Report
text: Condoning Rape | The story of the gang rape in Richmond two weeks ago has two acts. First, the horrific crime itself. Second, the reaction of a group of students who are indifferent to the brutality or even blame the 16-year-old victim for the attack. Said one: “She got drunk one time and messed with the wrong crowd and provoked some dude and got raped, that’s it.”

headline: A Classic Ending to Zenyatta’s Perfect Season
text: ARCADIA, Calif.  Zenyatta is a headstrong girl, and a big one, too. So when she balked entering the starting gate here Saturday, a gasp rippled through the grandstand. As she was awaiting the start of the Breeders’ Cup Classic, against the best male horses in the world at a distance she had never run, did she suddenly not want to race?

headline: Pelosi Expresses Confidence Health Bill Will Pass
text: House speaker Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, expressed confidence a short while ago that the health care legislation being debated on the floor would pass.

headline: Harvard’s Victory Sets Up Ivy League Showdown Against Penn
text: Harvard Coach Tim Murphy says he is still looking forward to the day when he can pour himself a cup of coffee, saunter into the Crimson’s locker room and tell his team it played a perfect game. Saturday was not exactly that day, but Harvard seems to be getting closer.

headline: Paced by a 19-Year-Old Star, France Revives Its Reputation
text: In the 18th and 19th centuries, France was a center, if not the epicenter, of chess. Two of the greatest players of the era, Francois-Andre Danican Philidor and Louis-Charles Mahé de La Bourdonnais, were French, and the Café de la Régence in Paris was a gathering place for anyone who liked to play the game, including Benjamin Franklin and Napoleon Bonaparte.

headline: Little Evidence of Terror Plot in Base Killings
text: WASHINGTON  After two days of inquiry into the mass shooting at Fort Hood, investigators have tentatively concluded that it was not part of a terrorist plot.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about a deadly attack in October at a United Nations guesthouse in Kabul, Afghanistan, misstated the number of Afghan suspects arrested by that day. It was six, not eight.

headline: Alabama Gains Berth in the SEC Title Game
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  No. 3 Alabama remained unbeaten Saturday and did more than assure itself a berth in the Southeastern Conference championship game against No. 1 Florida. The Crimson Tide also escaped the grip of an offensive slump and, once again, looked like a legitimate national championship contender in a 24-15 victory over No. 9 Louisiana State.

headline: Corrections
text: An art review in some editions last Sunday about “Bold, Cautious, True: Walt Whitman and American Art of the Civil War Era,” at the Katonah Museum of Art in Westchester County, misidentified the institution that loaned two paintings by Sanford Gifford to the museum. It is the New York State Military Museum and Veterans Research Center, not the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Equality’s Ragged March
text: Last Tuesday’s Election Day results showed how far the nation has traveled in the struggle for gay equality  and the distance still to go. The returns also added fresh urgency to promising efforts in New York, New Jersey and the District of Columbia to legalize marriage for same-sex couples.

headline: Quick, Patent It!
text: The Supreme Court hears arguments Monday in a case about what kind of inventions deserve patents. The businessmen who came up with a method for hedging financial risk in energy trading sued the Patent and Trademark Office after it denied them a patent.

headline: Congress’s OMG Over the P2P Leak
text: Members of Congress who may enjoy sharing music on the Internet without understanding the technology behind it all are learning the hard way about the potential dangers of peer-to-peer software.

headline: Voting Equipment and the Way Elections Are Run
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yale’s ‘Innocent Mistakes’
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Battleship at Rest
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hawaii’s Education Gap
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Night They Drove the Tea Partiers Down
text: FOR all cable news’s efforts to inflate Election 2009 into a cliffhanger as riveting as Balloon Boy, ratings at MSNBC and CNN were flat Tuesday night. But not at Fox News, where the audience nearly doubled its usual prime-time average. That’s what happens when you have a thrilling story to tell, and what could be more thrilling than a revolution playing out in real time?

headline: Chemicals in Our Food, and Bodies
text: Your body is probably home to a chemical called bisphenol A, or BPA. It’s a synthetic estrogen that United States factories now use in everything from plastics to epoxies  to the tune of six pounds per American per year. That’s a lot of estrogen.

headline: Back From War, but Not Really Home
text: Holderness, N.H.

headline: The Savage Detective
text: CLAUDE LÉVI-STRAUSS, anthropologist, writer and adventurer, died just over a week ago at age 100. He died discreetly, which was as he had lived, though he was the most eminent and probably the last French philosopher. His ideas had as much influence on his contemporaries as the work of Jean-Paul Sartre and Albert Camus.

headline: Damned Yankees
text: IT is hard to find a bigger admirer of President George W. Bush than me. I support his policies; I believe in him; he’s a really good guy to be around; and he throws a mean fastball. As his press secretary, I stood by him through thick and thin. But recent events require me to speak out about my former boss: For eight long years, President Bush put a curse on my New York Yankees.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Sunday about the Long Island Latino International Film Festival misstated, using information from Rolando Sanchez, one of the participating directors, the year he saw the film “Saving Private Ryan,” which he credits with inspiring his interest in film. He saw the film in 1998, the year it was released, not 1996. The article also omitted the original source of a comment by Mr. Sanchez: “I don’t make movies for Latinos. I make films with Latinos in them.” Mr. Sanchez said he was repeating the words of another director, Franc Reyes.

headline: One Week After Defeating U.S.C., Oregon Falls to Stanford
text: STANFORD, Calif.  Stanford running back Toby Gerhart has the thick arms of a logger and they were covered with scratches and red welts Saturday after he toppled Oregon. Gerhart rushed for a team-record 223 yards and 3 touchdowns in the Cardinal’s 51-42 upset of the seventh-ranked Ducks.

headline: Corrections
text: An art review in some editions last Sunday about an exhibition of works by Avital Oz at Art Sites in Riverhead, on Long Island, referred incorrectly to the artist’s birthplace. Mr. Oz was born in 1942 in what was then the British mandate of Palestine, not Israel. (The modern state of Israel did not exist until 1948.)

headline: The Abortion Debate Flares Again
text: Updated: The House voted 240 to 194 in favor of a restrictive abortion amendment that signaled a shift in the political center on abortion rights. Opponents of the measure — including many Democratic female lawmakers — called it the most regressive provision on the issue of reproductive rights since the Henry Hyde amendment.

headline: Correction
text: Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the marriage of Mona Kelly and David Lopez misidentified the city in Mexico where the couple held a religious ceremony on Oct. 24. The ceremony was in Playa del Carmen, not Cancún. And also because of an editing error, the headline erroneously stated that the bride’s given name is Monica.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Correction
text: An article last Sunday about Zac Goldsmith, a multimillionaire environmentalist and Conservative Party candidate for Parliament in Britain, referred incorrectly to his campaign finances. Over the last 30 months, Mr. Goldsmith has spent £248,000, or about $400,000; he has not raised £248,000 this year.

headline: Is That a Plastic Bottle You’re Drinking From?
text: My Sunday column looks at chemicals that the government has been slow to regulate, even though they are suspected of pernicious effects on our bodies by disrupting the endocrine system. The results appear to range from malformed genitalia to premature puberty to obesity and diabetes. I focus on BPA, a chemical variant of estrogen that is often used in plastics and other consumer products. Two billion pounds are manufactured in the US each year — and as a result it is found in 92 percent of us. It’s one of a number of endocrine disruptors that appear to have adverse effects on the body’s hormone system.

headline: From the Arab Press: Coverage of the Fort Hood Killings
text: A look at discussions inside the Arab world, as played out in Arabic newspapers.

headline: Lawmakers Detail Obama’s Pitch
text: In an odd coincidence, the House debate on Saturday to overhaul health care took place on the third anniversary of the 2006 election that gave Democrats majority control after 12 years of Republican dominance. It fell to President Obama and to Congressional leaders to persuade those Democrats still sweating the final vote that it would not prove the party’s undoing in next November’s midterm elections.

headline: Chargers at Giants: What to Watch
text: Philip Rivers is one of the league’s better quarterbacks, and the Giants’ defense has been reeling from injuries and “communication” problems.

headline: College Football Replay: Nov. 7
text: Helmets were lost, balls were fumbled and touchdowns were celebrated on Saturday in college football.

headline: Lottery Numbers
G.O.P. Tries Tactic to Derail Bill
text: Update: Largely along party lines, a move that would have derailed the bill was defeated by a vote of 247 to 187.

headline: Led by Rookie, Bucks Prolong Knicks’ Sluggish Start
text: MILWAUKEE  For Mike D’Antoni, the early season seems a mirage. He has trouble telling whether the Knicks, after falling behind early, start to play better or if it is that their opponents simply relax. He does not know whether his younger players are earning minutes or if he is simply allotting them garbage time.

headline: All Afghan War Options by Obama Aides Said to Call for More Troops
text: WASHINGTON  Advisers to President Obama are preparing three options for escalating the war effort in Afghanistan, all of them calling for more American troops, as he moves closer to a decision on the way forward in the eight-year-old war, officials said Saturday.

headline: House Passes Health Bill
text: Squeaking just two votes past the required 218, House Democrats passed a major overhaul of health care after a marathon 14-hour day of floor debate. See this related article by Carl Hulse and Robert Pear, and find a complete roll call here.

headline: Robert Rines, Inventor and Monster Hunter, Dies at 87
text: Dollars to doughnuts, Robert H. Rines will be mainly remembered not for holding more than 800 patents, starting a law school or writing music for the stage, but for his dogged pursuit of the Loch Ness monster.

headline: Abortion Was at Heart of Wrangling
text: WASHINGTON  It was late Friday night and lawmakers were stalling for time. In a committee room, they yammered away, delaying a procedural vote on the historic health care legislation. Down one floor, in her office, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi desperately tried to deal with an issue that has bedeviled Democrats for more than a generation  abortion.

headline: Alice S. Rossi, Sociologist and Feminist Scholar, Dies at 87
text: Alice S. Rossi, a noted sociologist and feminist scholar who was a founder of the National Organization for Women, died on Tuesday in Northampton, Mass. She was 87 and lived in Amherst, Mass.

headline: Life in Black and White
text: A three-volume book and two gallery exhibitions explore the growth of the photographer Bruce Davidson.

headline: Windfall Seen as Bank Bonuses Are Paid in Stock
text: Even as Washington tries to rein in Wall Street pay, bankers are likely to make unusually large gains on the stock grants and options they received after shares in their companies fell sharply during the financial meltdown, The New York Times’s Louise Story reports.

headline: Health Bill Earns One Republican Vote
text: House Democrats were thrilled by the passage of their major health care legislation, but perhaps no development on Saturday tickled them more than winning the vote of a single Republican: Representative Anh “Joseph” Cao of Louisiana.

headline: Long Day on the Hill, Big Victory for Democrats
text: Legislation that would transform the nation’s health insurance system won approval by a slim margin in the House.

headline: Foot Notes
text: Can dancers and dances be disentwined in order to preserve the work?

headline: In Separate Episodes, 2 Are Shot by the Police
text: Police officers were involved in two shootings Friday, one of a 15-year-old boy the police said was brandishing a fake gun, the other of a man they said was trying to steal an officer’s car.

headline: Why Jerry Jones Can’t Be Like Steinbrenner
text: A Web roundup of the week. No weak links here …

headline: Celebrating the Virtues of Vice
text: PARIS | For its 15th birthday, Vice magazine, a free worldwide publication famous for its crude images of rowdy teens, is presenting a photo exhibition dedicated to underground culture and, well, vice.

headline: Jets and Bucs: No Guarantees When Rebuilding on the Fly
