text: Detailed table profiling the 39 Democrats who voted against a sweeping overhaul of the nation's health care system.

headline: Taylor Swift Plays It Safe on ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: When Kanye West injected himself into Taylor Swift’s acceptance speech during the MTV Video Music Awards in September, it wasn’t a fair fight — Ms. Swift was shocked, Mr. West belligerent.

headline: Why Ahmadinejad Voted Against Occupying the U.S. Embassy in 1979
text: This week, as opposition supporters in Iran marked the 30th anniversary of the takeover of the United States Embassy in Tehran by protesting outside the active Russian Embassy instead of the abandoned American one, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad failed to mention that, as a student leader in 1979, he had voted against the plan to seize the U.S. compound and suggested taking the Soviet Embassy instead.

headline: Jamie Gray | Design Daddy
text: Children may not be able to recognize good design, but according to Jamie Gray (photographed with his girlfriend, Olivia Sammons, and their children, Cy and Levi), they can recognize beauty. Gray, who owns the less-is-more New York design shop Matter, recalls once waking up at 5:30 a.m. to find the 3-year-old Levi gazing through the window of their Brooklyn apartment. ‘‘Look at the sky, Papa,’’ Levi exclaimed. ‘‘It’s beautiful.’’ The first piece Gray ever built was a three-legged chair. His teacher told him it would never stand up. ‘‘But I made it anyway,’’ he said. ‘‘And it worked!’’ (Gray is seated in a Victor armchair by Paul Loebach.) His company’s Web address, MatterMatters.com, speaks to the challenge of creating objects in a world that’s already glutted with them. ‘‘That’s the daily quandary: Do you create more?’’ he asks. ‘‘But, ultimately, if there’s a want, somebody has to take responsibility for it. My intention is to create heirloom pieces that won’t end up at the bottom of a landfill.’

headline: Questions as ‘Disney’s A Christmas Carol’ Tops the Box Office
text: An expensive, six-month marketing push helped “Disney’s A Christmas Carol” open at No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, selling an estimated $31 million in tickets. But the result was weak for a movie that cost about $175 million to make (not including marketing costs), starred Jim Carrey in a cluster of roles, and was given one of the biggest releases yet on higher-priced 3-D screens. Did families decide it looked too dark? Did the motion-capture filmmaking style lessen interest? Or did a lot of moviegoers figure they would catch the holiday movie in the weeks ahead? Disney, which noted that the film, directed by Robert Zemeckis, made an additional $12 million in 18 foreign markets, hopes the latter.

headline: N.H.L. Scores: Rangers Lose Game, and Drury and Dubinsky to Injury
text: Thirteen games on Saturday night, starting with a matinee in L.A. where the Kings, just four points off the Western Conference lead, hosted the faltering Predators.

headline: The Early Word: Bill Passage, Cao and Next Steps
text: Late Saturday night the House passed a health care bill. The final vote, 220 to 215, was Democrats’ attempt to answer what President Obama described as “the call of history” and marked the culmination of months of inter-party and intra-party squabbling, town hall meetings and tea parties, and 14 hours of passionate Saturday floor debate.

headline: China Pledges $10 Billion to Africa
text: BEIJING  China offered African governments a multibillion-dollar package of financial and technical assistance on Sunday, stepping up a courtship that already has gained Beijing wide access to oil and minerals across perhaps the most resource-rich continent in the world.

headline: Army Chief Concerned for Muslim Troops
text: General George Casey Jr., the Army chief of staff, said on Sunday that he was concerned that speculation about the religious beliefs of Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, accused of killing 12 fellow soldiers and one civilian and wounding dozens of others in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood, could “cause a backlash against some of our Muslim soldiers.”

headline: Top Three Remain the Same in A.P. Poll
text: While there was little movement at the top of the Associated Press Top 25 on Sunday, there were a few interesting developments at the bottom.

headline: Pakistan Blast Kills Anti-Taliban Mayor
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A mayor who publicly opposed the Taliban was killed in a suicide bombing in a cattle market near the northern city of Peshawar on Sunday, officials said, in what appeared to be an attempt to curtail grass-roots opposition to the militant group.

headline: Best Sustains Concussion After Scary Fall
text: Update | 10:23 p.m. By far, the scariest moment in college football on Saturday came when California’s Jahvid Best flipped in the air and slammed to the turf after scoring a touchdown against Oregon State. (The video of the play, which is jarring to watch, is below.)

headline: The Wedding of Melissa Johnson and Tim Lagasse
text: Melissa Johnson and Tim Lagasse were married Oct. 30 at the Picnic House in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

headline: Iraq Passes Crucial Election Law
text: BAGHDAD  After weeks of political stalemate, Iraq approved a law on Sunday to administer a critical national election in January, a significant milestone for its fragile democracy and a step that will allow the rapid withdrawal of American combat forces early next year.

headline: Obama’s Statement on House Health Bill
text: President Obama praised the House Sunday on its passage of a health care bill. Read the news article here.

headline: Edison the Inventor Revisited
text: The laboratory complex at the Thomas Edison National Historical Park in West Orange reopened last month after a six-year renovation.

headline: Why Would a Young Adult Get an Ulcer?
text: Last week on the Consults blog, Dr. Neena S. Abraham, a gastroenterologist at the Michael E. DeBakey V.A. Medical Center and associate professor of medicine at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, took readers’ questions about ulcers, a potentially life-threatening condition increasingly tied to Nsaid pain relievers. Here, Dr. Abraham responds to a 24-year-old reader who wondered how she could develop an ulcer when she only took Nsaids a couple days a month.

headline: Live Analysis: Chargers Beat Giants, 21-20
text: New York Times writers Joe Lapointe and William C. Rhoden will provide in-game analysis of the Chargers-Giants game at Giants Stadium on Sunday.

headline: Bugatti Veyron 16.4 Grand Sport
text: Only 150 Grand Sports will be built, tacked onto 300 editions of the Veyron coupe, making it the automotive equivalent of a Fabergé egg.

headline: Agassi Basks in His Own Spotlight
text: Andre Agassi often says in “Open” that tennis is a lonely game. But the writing of this autobiography was a team sport. Mr. Agassi’s memoir was put together by J. R. Moehringer, who wrote “The Tender Bar,” a shapely and expert memoir of his own. The same gift of gab that colored Mr. Moehringer’s tales of being a boy in a barroom now magically finds its way onto the tennis court and into Mr. Agassi’s much-analyzed, follicularly challenged head.

headline: 2010 Mercedes-Benz S400 BlueHybrid
text: The S400 BlueHybrid overcomes the shortcomings of previous mild hybrid cars.

headline: Obama Presses Senate to Pass Its Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON  The White House, growing concerned that the Congressional timetable for passing a health care overhaul could slip into next year, is stepping up pressure on the Senate for quick action, with President Obama appearing Sunday in the Rose Garden to call on senators to “take up the baton and bring this effort to the finish line.”

headline: Refreshing Ruby Tuesday
text: When people start to dine out again, Sandy Beall wants them to find his chain, Ruby Tuesday, transformed.

headline: Northrop to Sell Consulting Unit in $1.65 Billion L.B.O.
text: Northrop Grumman agreed on Sunday to sell its TASC government consulting unit to the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and General Atlantic for $1.65 billion in cash, in another sign that private equity firms are back to their core business of deal-making.

headline: Block Party
text: Devoid as they are of nostalgia, kids won’t really appreciate that the mustache included in the new wooden block set PlayShapes was inspired by Sgt. Pepper, nor that the toy has echoes of Alexander Girard, Enzo Mari and midcentury advertising illustrations. But what will please the little ones is that unlike that era’s blocks, which mostly encouraged the dutiful construction of towns and landscapes, the strange contours of the 74 PlayShapes will let them build whatever animal, vegetable or psychedelic ’60s pop star they please. ‘‘We spent ages looking at old toys and seeing what had been done before, how we could make it new,’’ says PlayShapes’ Brighton, U.K.-based co-creator Zoe Miller, who with her partner David Goodman also designs vintage-inspired kids’ toys and books for the Tate. ‘‘For us it became about open-endedness, the fact that every child should feel that they’re an artist.’’ $111; go to shhhop.com.

headline: Patriots Have Answer to Dolphins’ Offensive Tricks
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  A year ago, the Miami Dolphins unveiled the Wildcat against New England, sending the confused Patriots reeling. Coach Bill Belichick, bemoaning how often the Dolphins had given the Patriots trouble in the past, predicted last week that the Patriots would see more offensive wrinkles from the Dolphins when the teams met Sunday.

headline: New CDs
text: BON JOVI “The Circle” (Island)

headline: Creation in the Face of Intriguing Biography
text: What more do you want from Christopher Owens, anyway? Maybe a bloodletting, or some other sort of physical purge? A detailed retelling of the sadder days of his childhood growing up in the Children of God cult? For the tragedy underpinning his gamely optimistic songs to take over, corroding them and making them, and him, tougher?

headline: European Puck: Forsberg’s Future Unclear After Sweden’s 7-0 Loss
text: It was a sobering ending for Sweden in its finale at the Karjala Cup tournament in Helsinki as it fell to Finland, 7-0 — and Foppa’s comeback with the Tre Kronor wound up a floppa.

headline: Out of the Nursery, Movements of Desire and Narcissism
text: SYRACUSE  Nothing about dance is more mysterious than the diversity of ways in which it can connect with music. Paul Taylor’s latest work is set to Debussy’s “Children’s Corner.” But its characters aren’t children, and its stage incidents have nothing to do with the nursery exercises and lessons that Debussy had in mind.

headline: Nightingale and Garden With Hints of China
text: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra’s contribution to Carnegie Hall’s Ancient Paths, Modern Voices festival, on Saturday evening, looked at Chinese-Western musical hybrids in which the Western influence was dominant, the Chinese largely incidental.

headline: As Existential as Jaunty Old Pals Can Be
text: Monsters of Folk started playing before the curtain rose on Friday night at the United Palace, and they were playing when it came down nearly three hours later. They wore suits and ties like early-1960s folkies or a classic country band; their lighting was subdued and soft-focus, conveying vintage glamour in the gilded room. Yet within that theatrical haze the songs radiated sincerity, as the band members sang about seeking truth, purpose, faith or just reasons to go on. The songs were, mostly, about solitary quests, but they were delivered by a band of old pals.

headline: T.C.U. Is Fourth in B.C.S. Standings
text: Texas Christian moved up two spots to fourth in the latest Bowl Championship Series standings, released Sunday. Florida, Alabama and Texas remained the top three teams. The Crimson Tide and the Longhorns switched places for the second straight week.

headline: A Good Effort, but Hardly Worth the Payoff
text: We have all heard of a Pyrrhic victory. My dictionary says that the expression derives from Pyrrhus’s statement after defeating the Romans in the third century B.C.: “Another such victory and we are lost.”

headline: An Ethical Question: Does a Nazi Deserve a Place Among Philosophers?
text: For decades the German philosopher Martin Heidegger has been the subject of passionate debate. His critique of Western thought and technology has penetrated deeply into architecture, psychology and literary theory and inspired some of the most influential intellectual movements of the 20th century. Yet he was also a fervent Nazi.

headline: Mowing Down Bar Lines in Virtuosic Banter
text: Vijay Iyer’s trio lights up through improvised, viruslike rhythms. It’s not a situation in which the drummer’s steady swing underpins whatever the pianist is doing; that did happen sometimes at the Jazz Standard on Friday, but it wasn’t where the action was.

headline: Indian Leader Forecasts Growth
text: NEW DELHI  Prime Minister Manmohan Singh pledged on Sunday to spend more on health care and education and make it easier for foreign investors to take part in India’s $1.2 trillion economy.

headline: Gridiron Gladiators: Block That Metaphor!
text: It’s too bad Bob Hope isn’t part of the “Fox NFL Sunday” crew. He might have been able to do something with the odd incongruity of Sunday’s program, broadcast from Bagram Air Field in Afghanistan: a show glorifying fake warriors and their game, playing to a crowd of real warriors locked in an eight-year-old conflict.

headline: Reborn: Neglected Work and City Opera
text: With the New York City Opera’s production of Hugo Weisgall’s “Esther,” which opened on Saturday night at the David H. Koch Theater, this essential company, teetering on the brink of extinction not long ago, announced it was back. Not just up and running, but exuding purpose and confidence.

headline: Go in Without a Suit
text: It’s me, Jim Horne, back for another week. I confess I’m a little worried about today’s constructor. Lynn Lempel, anything we can do to cheer you up? Six weeks ago (Across Lite, Solution), you gave us TURKEY, DUD, BOMB, FLOP and BUST. Today, it’s literally another downer with five long answers that all lose altitude.

headline: World War I, Online
text: Oxford University will open its first online collection of Siegfried Sassoon’s manuscripts on Wednesday, Armistice Day, the university’s press office has announced. The manuscripts of Sassoon, right, whose writing was transformed by his experiences in World War I, will help complete Oxford’s First World War Poetry Digital Archive, www.oucs.ox.ac.uk/ww1lit/, begun last year and including the work of Wilfred Owen, Isaac Rosenberg and Vera Brittain. “Technology has enabled us to virtually reassemble Sassoon’s manuscripts, which for years have been dispersed across the United Kingdom and United States,” Stuart Lee, director of the archive, said. “It is fascinating being able to see the corrections and crossings-out he made to the manuscripts, invaluable to researchers studying the literature of the war.” The poetry archive was opened in conjunction with the Great War Archive, a digitization project involving World War I material collected from the public.

headline: A Soft No. 1 for ‘Disney’s a Christmas Carol’
text: An expensive six-month marketing push helped “Disney’s A Christmas Carol” open at No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, selling an estimated $31 million in tickets, according to the Web site Hollywood.com, which tracks box-office results. But the result was considered weak for a movie that cost about $175 million (not including marketing costs); starred Jim Carrey as Scrooge, right, and other roles; and received one of the biggest releases yet on higher-priced 3-D screens. Did families decide it looked too dark? Did the motion-capture filmmaking style lessen interest? Or did many people figure they would catch the holiday movie in the weeks ahead? Disney, which noted that the film, directed by Robert Zemeckis, made an additional $12 million in 18 foreign markets, hopes it will do better as the holidays approach. The Michael Jackson concert documentary, “This Is It” (Sony), held up well in its second week, placing second with about $14 million for a new total of $58 million. “The Men Who Stare at Goats,” a comedy from Overture Films starring George Clooney and Jeff Bridges, was third with about $13 million. Two horror movies rounded out the Top 5: “The Fourth Kind” (Universal) earned about $12.5 million while “Paranormal Activity” (Paramount) drew about $9 million (for about $97 million so far). Also of note, “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire,” the Lee Daniels film about an abused teenager in Harlem, grossed $1.8 million from just 18 theaters.

headline: Morgan Freeman Settles in Mississippi Car Crash
text: Morgan Freeman, below, has reached an out-of-court settlement with his passenger over a lawsuit revolving around an August 2008 single-car crash, Reuters reported. Mr. Freeman was driving Demaris Meyer to his home near Charleston, Miss., when the car, a 1997 Nissan Maxima owned by Ms. Meyer, swerved off the road and flipped several times. Mr. Freeman was taken to the hospital, and Ms. Meyer later sued, accusing him of failure to operate a car properly. A spokesman for Mr. Freeman said no further details on the settlement would be given, and court records were not made public, Reuters reported, but Ms. Meyer’s lawyer said she was “pleased that the matter is resolved and the case is settled.” At the time of the accident, Sgt. Ben Williams, a Mississippi Highway Patrol spokesman, said there was no indication that alcohol or drugs contributed to the crash.

headline: Michael Jackson’s Father Asks for Allowance
text: In a motion filed in a Los Angeles court on Friday, Joe Jackson, below, the father of Michael Jackson, argued that the administrators of his son’s estate should set up a monthly allowance for him, similar to the one established for the singer’s mother, Katherine Jackson, The Los Angeles Times reported. Mr. Jackson, 80, said that his son helped him with living expenses for years. Mr. Jackson suggested that a stipend should cover his estimated budget of $15,000 a month. Howard Weitzman, a lawyer for the estate’s administrators, John Branca and John McClain, told The Los Angeles Times: “It was quite surprising to learn of the request. Mr. Jackson’s petition will be considered, as are all requests for money from Michael’s estate.” The judge denied Mr. Jackson’s request for an immediate hearing. The estate gives Katherine Jackson $26,000 a month.

headline: In the Wings
text: Shakespeare on the Sound in Norwalk, Conn., announced that its summer 2010 production would be “Othello.” As with its staging this year of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” the play will be directed by Joanna Settle and feature music and songs by Stew. ... The original Off Broadway cast of “Next Fall” will return when it moves to Broadway next year. The Geoffrey Nauffts play, about gay lovers with differing views on faith and love, will feature Patrick Breen, Maddie Corman, Sean Dugan, Patrick Heusinger, Connie Ray and Cotter Smith. It begins previews at the Helen Hayes Theater on Feb. 16 and opens on March 11. ... The Classic Stage Company has announced the lineup for its First Look Festival, which runs Nov. 16 to 30 and will feature the work of Luigi Pirandello. First up is “Six Characters in Search of an Author,” directed by Tony Speciale; next will be “Right You Are if You Think So,” directed by Craig Baldwin; and finally John Turturro will appear in “Henry IV,” directed by Brian Kulick. Details are at classicstage.org.

headline: Footnotes
text: After canceling performances because of an illness caused by E. coli and influenza, Elton John has left the London hospital where he was recuperating, Reuters reported. His spokesman, Gary Farrow, said he planned to return to the stage with his tour partner, Billy Joel, on Saturday. ... Las Vegas is losing a star. Reuters reported that Bette Midler was ending her Caesars Palace production, “The Showgirl Must Go On,” after nearly 200 performances. The last show will be on Jan. 31.

headline: Honolulu Symphony Cancels Concert Calendar
text: The 109-year-old Honolulu Symphony announced on Friday that it would cancel this year’s remaining concerts and file for bankruptcy protection, The Associated Press reported. Though ticket sales had been holding steady this year, they accounted for only 30 percent of the symphony’s annual budget, and reduced donor contributions have left the company with almost $1 million in debt. In May 2008 the symphony was revived after receiving $1 million from an anonymous donor that covered back pay owed to musicians. And earlier this year $2.1 million was taken from the endowment as an advance. But on Oct. 30 the board of directors voted to file for protection under Chapter 11, and papers will be submitted to court next week. “We made payroll, even in this economy, through October,” said Peter Shaindlin, the board’s chairman. “But cash ran out and dried up.” The symphony hopes to resume operations early next year, said a spokeswoman, Kristin Jackson, though perhaps, because of salary costs, not with all 64 musicians.

headline: Musicians Who Poked at the Iron Curtain
text: Guitars, keyboards and drums did not topple the Berlin Wall. But for the young people who helped bring down Communist regimes across Eastern Europe in the fall of 1989, pop music was a profoundly subversive force, inspiration and vital tool of protest for challenging and undermining a totalitarian state stricter than any parent.

headline: Nancy Pelosi delivers
text: Do you remember how, earlier this year, there were lots of stories about how hopeless Nancy Pelosi was as Speakere, how everything was going to be a failure, etc., etc.? Here’s an example.

headline: News of Hockey, 11/8/09: Another Resignation From the N.H.L.P.A.
text: Yet another official has resigned from the troubled N.H.L. Players’ Association, the union announces on Sunday. Interim ombudsman Buzz Hargrove informed the players’ association earlier on Sunday that he was stepping down from the position.

headline: At 91, Mandela Endures as South Africa’s Ideal
text: JOHANNESBURG  The icon is a very old man now. His hair is white, his body frail. Visitors say Nelson Mandela leans heavily on a cane when he walks into his study. He slips off his shoes, lowers himself into a stiff-backed chair and lifts each leg onto a cushioned stool. His wife, Graça, adjusts his feet “so they’re symmetrical, and gives him a peck,” says George Bizos, his old friend and lawyer.

headline: Refining the Twitter Explosion
text: DOES Twitter have a T.M.I. problem?

headline: Economists Seek to Fix a Defect in Data That Overstates the Nation’s Vigor
text: WASHINGTON  A widening gap between data and reality is distorting the government’s picture of the country’s economic health, overstating growth and productivity in ways that could affect the political debate on issues like trade, wages and job creation.

headline: Sending a Message, Again and Again
text: The number of text messages transmitted in the United States grew by more than 80 percent over the 12 months ended in June, according to a report just released by CTIA, a communications industry group. That figure measures the number of messages sent or received, so a message sent from one person to another would count twice.

headline: News Erupts, and So Does a Web Debut
text: On Thursday afternoon, when word came about the shootings that left 13 people dead at Fort Hood, just up the road from Austin, it seemed like a made-to-order test for The Texas Tribune, a brand new 12-person Web-based newsroom.

headline: Young Offenders Locked Up for Life
text: Updated, Nov. 9, 5:15 p.m. |  Round 3: Kent Scheidegger and Marc Mauer on what the Supreme Court justices asked and what that might reveal.

text: With Oregon’s loss to Stanford on Saturday, the race in the topsy-turvy Pacific-10 will be one to watch over the final month of the season.

headline: Technology in daily life
text: One theme I’ve noticed in comments on my various posts on growth is the suggestion that the difference between more recent growth and growth in the postwar generation is that modern times have given us all these great things like cell phones and the Internet, which didn’t happen in the past.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,349 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 903 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Sunday:

headline: A Movie’s Budget Pops From the Screen
text: LOS ANGELES  Can a movie studio make money on a film based on an original and unfamiliar story, with no Hollywood superstars, a vanishing DVD market and a price tag approaching $500 million?

headline: Bill Would Limit Needle Exchanges
text: BANGOR, Me.  For years, the location of this city’s needle exchange program, in a nondescript strip mall close to highways and bus lines, was seen as a major asset.

headline: Saudis Claim to Beat Back Yemeni Rebels in Border Area
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Saudi Arabia said over the weekend that it had regained control of a border area seized by Yemeni rebels last week, and that it had halted its military campaign there.

headline: Fate of Same-Sex Marriage Bill in Albany Unclear
text: After a major setback in Maine last week, gay rights advocates and their opponents are shifting their focus to New York, where Gov. David A. Paterson has called legislators to Albany on Tuesday and asked them to pass a bill legalizing same-sex marriage.

headline: 24 Hour Plays: Pre-Gaming
text: The celebrity quotient is already pretty high on Broadway (Jude Law, Hugh Jackman, Daniel Craig, Sienna Miller, everyone in “God of Carnage”) but it is about to spike. The annual 24 Hour Plays event will take place Monday night at the American Airlines Theater, and the cast is especially luminous this year: Ashton Kutcher, Demi Moore, Jennifer Aniston and Julia Stiles are among the actors lined up to participate. Presented by Montblanc, the event –this is the ninth — will once again benefit the nonprofit Urban Arts Partnership, which provides arts in education programs to public school students in New York City.

headline: A Stratocaster for Max, and Other Mad Men Stories
text: PHOENIX

headline: F1 Season Review, and a Mosley Coincidence
text: Just had a few reasons for wanting to link to my F1 season review story. One is just to spread the news onto the blog – ie, alert you. The other is because I wanted to draw attention to the great quote contribution in the story from a frequent and enthusiastic reader and participant in the blog, Toof Brown, whose quote is the first in the story, and I thought it was very pertinent. And the third reason for drawing attention to the story in the weekend edition of the International Herald Tribune was for the WONDERFULLY odd and serendipitous event that meant that while my season review story mentions the Max Mosley sex scandal of last year and his subsequent battle with a British newspaper – the whole idea there were Nazi role playing connotations etc. – well, on page two of the print version of the same paper in which my story appeared was also a little piece from the same newspaper 75 years ago, in which a certain Oswald Mosley, Max’s father, won a case against another British newspaper in a libel case, in the second item of the story. Wonderful how these things happen sometimes. Not so often seen in the new media, I think.

headline: Zenyatta Shines Brightest in Sparkling Breeders’ Cup
text: ARCADIA, Calif.  What was there not to like about this edition of the Breeders’ Cup World Championships? The San Gabriel Mountains, haloed in rouge, were a perfect backdrop for the majesty of thoroughbred racing. Every horse came home safely, and the headlines belonged deservedly to a remarkable mare named Zenyatta, who in what might have been the last race of an undefeated career emphatically turned back some of the best male horses in the world in Saturday’s Classic.

headline: Louisiana Republican Breaks Ranks on Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON  House Democrats were thrilled by the passage of their major health care legislation on Saturday, but were particularly tickled by denying Republicans a solid wall of opposition with the solitary vote of Representative Anh Cao of Louisiana.

headline: An Oasis Is No Match for Bulldozers and Bureaucrats
text: MOSCOW  In the 1950s, the Soviet government set aside a bit of land on the Moscow River for Maria I. Gurlynina’s family and several dozen others to grow food. It was a barren plot, “nothing but sand and swamp,” Ms. Gurlynina said. But it was theirs.

headline: A Magazine’s Scoop Is Scooped by Its Reporter
text: When it was revealed that in a forthcoming autobiography, Andre Agassi would admit to using crystal meth, it caused a predictable stir in the space where sports and celebrity gossip intersect. It also caused commotions at Time Inc. and CBS News.

text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In his final moment on the field Sunday at Giants Stadium, San Diego quarterback Philip Rivers fired a dart through the heart of the Giants’ defense and maybe their hopes for the season.

headline: The Legacy of 1989 Is Still Up for Debate
text: PARIS  The historical legacy of 1989, when the Berlin Wall fell and the cold war thawed, is as political as the upheavals of that decisive year.

headline: Confusion on Where Money Lent via Kiva Goes
text: Last month, David Roodman, a research fellow at the Center for Global Development, pressed a button on his laptop as his bus left the Lincoln Tunnel in Manhattan and started a debate that has people re-examining the country’s latest celebrated charity, Kiva.org.

headline: If Anything, the Senate’s Task Is Trickier
text: Don’t tell the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, but that was supposed to be the easy part.

headline: Anthony Flourishes, and So Do Nuggets
text: Carmelo Anthony wanted the personal accolades. To be selfish, though, he had to be less selfish. For much of his first six N.B.A. seasons, Anthony settled on the wrong side of great. Great scorer, not a great player. Great shooter, not a gracious passer. Great athlete, not a good defender.

headline: After a Boss’s Fraud, Training for a New Job and Holding on to Hope
text: Few may recall the spectacular downfall of Marc S. Dreier, the prominent Manhattan lawyer who pleaded guilty to running an elaborate fraud scheme, because his house of cards fell just days before Bernard L. Madoff’s did.

headline: For Kelly, a Chance to Add to His Legacy

But perhaps the most visible vehicle used by the mayor that day was an old convertible, in which he greeted the crowds watching the New York City Marathon, sitting alongside his police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly.

headline: A Short-Lived Partnership Helped Leetch Seal a Legacy

headline: In Resilient Neighborhood, Morale Tumbles After Fire
text: A tilted plywood wall wraps around the northwest corner of Bainbridge Avenue and East 204th Street, where the air smells of smoke and the sidewalk glistens from broken glass. The wall tries to hide the ghastly sight of 10 storefronts burned to sooty brick and skeletal girders. But it only reminds all who pass of a local tragedy.

headline: Northrop Agrees to Sell TASC Consulting Unit
text: Northrop Grumman agreed on Sunday to sell its TASC government consulting unit to the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and General Atlantic for $1.65 billion in cash, in another sign that private equity firms are back to their core business of deal-making.

headline: Inspired by Obama, Navy Quarterback’s Sights Are Set on 2040
text: Ricky Dobbs would walk up to classmates he did not know at Douglas County High School in Douglasville, Ga., and playfully scratch their backs. He wanted to be everybody’s friend. Even with the students others ignored, he tried to get them out of their shells and make them feel comfortable.

headline: New York Clinics See Few Crowds for Free Vaccine
text: Perhaps it was fear of crowds that kept the crowds away on Sunday from the clinics offering free swine flu vaccinations to schoolchildren. Or, maybe, as some of the few who did show up suggested, the small numbers could be attributed to wariness about the new vaccine or a lack of knowledge about the clinics.

headline: Sober Mood at New York Post as Circulation Spirals Lower
text: Three years ago, Col Allan, the editor of The New York Post, pumped his fist and waded into a cheering crowd at a Midtown restaurant, celebrating The Post’s overtaking its rival, The Daily News, in weekday circulation. The Post trumpeted the news on a Times Square billboard and in its pages.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Samuel Heyman, a Corporate Raider, Dies at 70
text: Samuel J. Heyman, who stood out as a corporate raider who preferred to hold on to companies he bought and run them rather that sell them for a quick profit, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70.

headline: ‘Finian’s’ Children
text: Days can be hectic for the youngsters in the revival of the musical "Finian's Rainbow," another in a growing list of Broadway shows featuring child actors.

headline: Iran Said to Ignore Effort to Salvage Nuclear Deal
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, attempting to salvage a faltering nuclear deal with Iran, has told Iran’s leaders in back-channel messages that it is willing to allow the country to send its stockpile of enriched uranium to any of several nations, including Turkey, for temporary safekeeping, according to administration officials and diplomats involved in the exchanges.

headline: Complications Grow for Muslims Serving in U.S. Military
text: Abdi Akgun joined the Marines in August of 2000, fresh out of high school and eager to serve his country. As a Muslim, the attacks of Sept. 11 only steeled his resolve to fight terrorism.

headline: Fort Hood Gunman Gave Signals Before His Rampage
text: KILLEEN, Tex.  It was still dark on Thursday when Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan left his aging apartment complex to attend 6 a.m. prayers at the brick mosque near Fort Hood. Afterward, he said goodbye to his friends there and asked forgiveness from one man for any past offenses.

headline: Week 9 in Quotations: Nothing Beats That Winning Feeling
text: “His age really doesn’t matter at this point.” — Buccaneers Coach Raheem Morris, after giving the 21-year-old rookie Josh Freeman his first start. Freeman led Tampa Bay to its first win of the season.

headline: All They Need Is Love (and Freedom and Theater)
text: Luminaries of 17th-century England are resurrected and made to do the frug in “Or,” a playful, funny and inventive comedy by Liz Duffy Adams now playing at the Julia Miles Theater. The fruging is figurative, obviously. The pioneering female writer Aphra Behn, the celebrated actress Nell Gwynne and the king, Charles II, do not actually cavort in miniskirts, fringed vests and beads, making like Austin Powers and friends in this frisky historical romp produced by the Women’s Project.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about Africa’s diamond trade misstated the year that Venezuela suspended itself from the Kimberley Process, an international undertaking to halt trading in so-called blood diamonds. It was 2008, not 2004.

headline: Corrections
text: The Books of The Times review on Oct. 14, about “The War That Killed Achilles: The True Story of Homer’s ‘Iliad’ and the Trojan War,” by Caroline Alexander, referred incompletely to the translation of “The Iliad” used in the book. While most of it is Richmond Lattimore’s version, the book also includes translation by Ms. Alexander.

headline: For Abortion Foes, a Victory in Health Care Vote
text: WASHINGTON  A restriction on abortion coverage, added late Saturday to the health care bill passed by the House, has energized abortion opponents with their biggest victory in years  emboldening them for a pitched battle in the Senate.

text: The Avs entered Sunday night’s contest in Denver vs. the Oilers with an undefeated home record: five regulation victories and one shootout win. And they had October goalie of the month Craig Anderson in the nets, facing an Edmonton team that scored just eight times in their previous six games. For Colorado, it seemed like easy pickings. headline: Mouse Grounds Plane at Kennedy
text: A Delta Air Lines flight at Kennedy International Airport bound for London Heathrow Airport was delayed and the passengers were switched to another plane Sunday night after someone reported seeing an onboard intruder: a mouse in the cabin.

headline: No Clear Map for Democrats on Path to New Energy Plan
text: On health care, President Obama and fellow Democrats face a straightforward calculus: sign an overhaul bill into law or suffer grave political damage.

headline: Imprisoning a Child for Life
text: The United States could be the only nation in the world where a 13-year-old child can be sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole, even for crimes that do not include murder. This grim distinction should trouble Americans deeply, as should all of the barbaric sentencing policies for children that this country embraces but that most of the world has abandoned.

headline: Albany and the Budget
text: Gov. David Paterson of New York has commanded the Legislature to return on Tuesday. Fixing the budget must be their top priority. The state is in a fiscal crisis. There is no other word for it.

headline: Rody Alvarado’s Odyssey
text: After 14 years, Rody Alvarado finally has the full support of the United States government in her struggle to find safe haven here. She fled Guatemala in 1995 after enduring years of horrific beatings and sexual abuse by her husband. Though the facts of her suffering were not disputed, her case took a tortuous route through immigration courts, where the question of asylum for battered women has long been muddled by controversy, indecision and inaction.

headline: Last Act for the Bluefin
text: The international commission that sets fishing limits for tuna and other large migratory fish is meeting in Brazil. The commission faces a depressing reality: the bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean is headed toward commercial extinction.

headline: At the Scene of the Shooting
text: Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan is accused of killing 13 people and wounding dozens Thursday in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood. Here is what is known so far about the events, according to accounts of base officials and witnesses.

headline: Paranoia Strikes Deep
text: Last Thursday there was a rally outside the U.S. Capitol to protest pending health care legislation, featuring the kinds of things we’ve grown accustomed to, including large signs showing piles of bodies at Dachau with the caption “National Socialist Healthcare.” It was grotesque  and it was also ominous. For what we may be seeing is America starting to be Californiafied.

headline: Life After the End of History
text: For most of the last century, the West faced real enemies: totalitarian, aggressive, armed to the teeth. Between 1918 and 1989, it was possible to believe that liberal democracy was a parenthesis in history, destined to be undone by revolution, ground under by jackboots, or burned like chaff in the fire of the atom bomb.

headline: 20 Years of Collapse
text: TODAY is the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall. During this time of reflection, it is common to emphasize the miraculous nature of the events that began that day: a dream seemed to come true, the Communist regimes collapsed like a house of cards, and the world suddenly changed in ways that had been inconceivable only a few months earlier. Who in Poland could ever have imagined free elections with Lech Walesa as president?

headline: Kraft’s Hostile Bid for Cadbury Expected
text: Kraft is expected to make a hostile bid for the British confectioner Cadbury on Monday, making official its attempt to create an international food giant after more than two months of posturing, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: A Magazine Promises Ads Will Register
text: The Week magazine is making a new guarantee to advertisers: that its readers will remember an ad in its pages more than ads in most competitive magazines.

Nicholas Counter III, a lawyer who changed the face of labor relations in Hollywood during his long tenure as chief negotiator for hundreds of film and television companies, died on Friday after collapsing earlier at his home in the Bell Canyon community in Ventura County, California.

headline: News Quiz | November 9, 2009

headline: Madoff’s Prosecutor Is Joining Cleary Firm

Madoff for his huge Ponzi scheme, resulting in a 150-year sentence, is joining the New York office of the international law firm Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton, Benjamin Weiser writes in The New York Times.

headline: Intense Review Is Expected for Possible NBC Deal

headline: Dance on Film
text: Dance movie fans are probably doing a pas de deux right now: two stellar examples of the genre are in theaters. A favorite of Martin Scorsese, the restored version of the classic “Red Shoes” “has been the inspiration for countless bleeding feet and soaring artistic passions,” writes Manohla Dargis, who calls it “essential viewing.” And the documentary “La Danse: the Paris Opera Ballet,” from the veteran vérité director Frederick Wiseman, “is one of the finest dance films ever made,” A.O. Scott writes  worthwhile even if you don’t know a plié from a tutu. “The substance of Mr. Wiseman’s particular genius is the way it transfixes you with the inner workings of an institution you may not otherwise care about.”

headline: Dare to Underachieve
text: Released just over a decade ago, Benjamin Anastas’s debut novel, “An Underachiever’s Diary”, about the lesser of a pair of twin boys, was a sort of precursor to the smart, funny slacker-hipsters of today. (See: Jonathan Ames and his alter-ego Jason Schwartzman in “Bored to Death.”) Now that it’s been reissued in paperback, Mr. Anastas, also a journalist, gets to overachieve in lit form. He reads from it tonight at the Half-King.

headline: How to Rescue Wells Fargo From the Rescue?
text: John G. Stumpf, the chief executive of Wells Fargo, objected vocally to the federal injection of rescue funds into banks, saying taxpayers were benefiting at Wells Fargo’s expense. A year on, the government still owns $25 billion of Wells preferred stock. The bank’s boss has cooled his rhetoric, but still wants to pay back the Treasury’s Troubled Asset Relief Program investment “shortly.” He also wants to avoid damage to his shareholders. Reconciling the two objectives is not easy, Breakingviews.com says.

headline: Hedge Fund Hot Streak Cools in October
text: Hedge funds on average posted light losses in October, ending a seven-month winning streak, Reuters reported, citing new data.

headline: AXA Asia-Pacific Rejects $10.2 Billion Breakup Plan
text: AXA Asia Pacific, the Australian unit of the French insurance giant AXA, rejected an unsolicited $10.2 billion takeover bid Monday that was led by its parent, a deal that could be one of the biggest in the financial services sector this year.

headline: Kraft’s Hostile Bid for Cadbury Expected
text: Update | 8:59 a.m. Kraft made an official £9.8 billion ($16.3 billion) bid for Cadbury, setting up a potentially bruising fight for control of the British confectioner. Cadbury quickly rejected the offer.

headline: Taiwan Firm Positioned for E-Reader Takeoff
text: With the market for electronic book readers set to take off, things are looking up for a little-known Taiwanese company that will probably supply most of the “e-paper” they use, The New York Times’s Jonathan Adams writes.

headline: Red Sox Owner Cuts Staff at His Hedge Fund
text: John Henry, the principal owner of the Boston Red Sox, has fired more than a quarter of the staff at his hedge fund firm in Boca Raton, Fla., a result of declining assets and “the current market environment,’’ a spokesman told The Boston Globe.

headline: Buyout Shops Said to Bid for AXA’s Taikang Stake
text: Foreign and domestic private equity firms have made offers for AXA‘s 15.6 percent holding in the Chinese insurer Taikang Life, valuing the stake at more than $1 billion, Reuters reported.

headline: Sonova in Deal to Buy Advanced Bionics
text: Sonova Holding, a Swiss maker of hearing aids, said Monday that it had reached a deal to buy Advanced Bionics, an American developer of inner-ear implant devices, for $489 million in cash, The Associated Press said.

headline: Can a Boy Wear a Skirt to School?

headline: In Madrid, a Season of Setting Suns
text: Anyone who thinks that the churning clouds and dramatically colored skies of an El Greco masterpiece like “View of Toledo” might be a bit of artistic conceit has likely never been to Madrid in autumn. During these months the late afternoon skies can blaze astonishingly bright with vivid colors and cinematic effects.

headline: Wall Street Banks Wary of Rusal I.P.O., Report Says
text: Wall Street firms are reportedly in a quandary about getting involved with a planned public offering of United Company Rusal of Russia, the world’s largest aluminum producer, because its founder has been barred from obtaining a United States visa because of allegations that he is connected to organized crime.

headline: Yemen Rebels Routed, Saudi Arabia Says
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Fighting continued for a sixth day on Monday between the Saudi military and Yemeni rebels on their countries’ border, with the rebels releasing a videotape of what they said was one of several captured Saudi soldiers.

headline: Plowing Detroit Into Farmland
text: Today’s idea: Detroit’s “massive failure” makes possible a radical transformation of the blighted city, an article says, including shrinking it down to its urban core and turning much of the place over to crops. And an ineffective government is actually a plus.

headline: Opel Union Leader Sees Autonomy as Condition to Talks

headline: Britain and U.S. Clash at G-20 on Tax for Rescues
text: The United States and Britain voiced disagreement Saturday over a proposal that would impose a new tax on financial transactions to support future bank rescues, The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier reported.

headline: Britain and Australia Seeking Data From UBS
text: Authorities in Britain and Australia have requested information from UBS after the Swiss bank agreed in August to disclose some 4,450 client names to settle a United States tax case, the bank confirmed Sunday, according to Reuters.

headline: 24 Hour Plays: The Writing Hours
text: The celebratory mood of the first few hours of 24 Hour Plays activity at the American Airlines Theater Sunday night gave way to a more contemplative one shortly after 11:30 p.m. when only the writers, producers and a few others were left. After the actors took off, the writers had a chance to see the stage where their shows are to be presented Monday night. There is already a set on the stage, a big, English country house designed by Allen Moyer for “After Miss Julie,” and the writers will have to work with it or around it. This is not a simple matter, given the absurdly long wooden table, the abundance of what looks like delicate china and a number of other items that are not likely to fit every play that is being cooked up. “It would be tricky to not use this set,” Warren Leight said as the group of writers gapes at the big, crowded stage.

headline: Kraft Makes $16.3 Billion Hostile Bid for Cadbury
text: Update | 10:43 a.m. The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier and Michael J. de la Merced provide more details on Kraft’s bid for Cadbury.

headline: Brazilian Wind Power Gets a Boost
text: Early this decade, a drought in Brazil that cut water to the country’s hydroelectric dams prompted severe energy shortages. The crisis, which ravaged the country’s economy and led to electricity rationing, underscored Brazil’s pressing need to diversify away from water power.

headline: The Early Word: Calendar Crunch
text: The countdown is on. Excluding the Veterans Day and Thanksgiving recesses, lawmakers have just about four-and-a-half weeks to line up 60 votes in favor of the Senate’s plan to overhaul the health care system, hash out the differences — and there are plenty — between the two chambers’ versions and get a bill to President Obama’s desk by the end of the year.

The wall tries to hide the ghastly sight of 10 storefronts burned to sooty brick and skeletal girders. But it only  reminds all who pass of a local tragedy.

headline: TIPS and inflation expectations
text: Treasury inflation-protected securities — bonds whose payouts are indexed to consumer prices — are really useful for economic analysis: they give an objective, market-based measure of expected inflation. But you have to be a bit careful about using them to interpret recent events, because the same financial disruptions that wreaked havoc with many assets also did some funny stuff to TIPS.

headline: 24 Hour Plays: Get Up and Go
text: At 7 a.m. Lou Moreno, one of the producers of the 24 Hour Plays was in the lobby of the American Airlines Theater looking energetic. “I was reading scripts on the train on the way in at 5:30,” he said, pointing out that the writers had indeed finished on time, some of them early in fact. The writers are nowhere to be seen at the moment, the room some of them used last night is empty. They have gone to bed.

headline: Debate: Modern Pork Production and H1N1
text: Until now, debate over the relationship between the H1N1 influenza virus and large-scale concentrated animal feeding operations — defined by the Environmental Protection Agency as agricultural operations over a certain size “where animals are kept and raised in confined situations” — has been simmering outside the limelight.

headline: On Roosevelt Island, Less Work, More Babies
text: While Roosevelt Island’s leafy streets and lower-priced apartments have long offered New Yorkers a respite from the endless concrete and shoe-box size homes of city life, residents there have not been sheltered from the recession.

headline: Are These the 100 Best Movies of the Decade?
text: The decade isn’t quite over yet, but The Times of London made an early effort on Saturday at tying a bow around the last ten years with its list of the 100 best films of the decade. The Times’s proudly opinionated lineup feels more provocative than definitive, though it does make an effort to represent all sides of 2000s cinema, from art-house fare (“The Diving Bell and the Butterfly” at No. 28; “Dancer in the Dark” at No. 25) to hit crowd-pleasers (“The Devil Wears Prada” at No. 100; “Wedding Crashers” at No. 90) to cult favorites (“Shaun of the Dead” at No. 58), with at least one authentic “Huh?” moment in there (“Bad Santa” at No. 54?).

headline: Learning How Animals Regenerate Body Parts
text: The best possible kind of regenerative medicine would surely be to entice the body to use nature’s own methods to regrow a damaged limb or organ. The genes that made the structure in the first place are still present in every cell of the body but somehow repressed. Could they not be reactivated to make the patient as good as new?

headline: Digital Delights for Kids in the Caribbean
text: Kid-savvy resorts in the Caribbean, perhaps hoping to grab the attention of increasingly screen-addicted guests, are loading on the digital delights.

headline: An End Game for the Forever War?
text: The battle between CF Industries, Terra Industries and Agrium looks to be near a conclusion after the events of the past week. CF raised its hostile offer for Terra to $40.61 a share in cash and stock, an offer that was rejected about 48 hours later by Terra’s board. Meanwhile, Agrium raised its hostile offer for CF to $92.99 a share in cash and stock, an offer that was rejected less than 24 hours later by CF’s board.

headline: Cold Response to Kraft’s Cadbury Bid
text: LONDON  Kraft took its $16.7 billion bid for Cadbury, the British chocolate and chewing gum maker, directly to shareholders on Monday after the Cadbury board rejected the offer as too low.

headline: Ward Helps Biracial Youths on Journey Toward Acceptance
text: PITTSBURGH  Steelers receiver Hines Ward surrounded himself with old friends at the dinner table on a recent Saturday night. The bond was as obvious as the look on everyone’s faces  half Korean, half something else. The shared experience was far more than skin deep.

headline: The View From the Wall
text: Today is the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, which signaled the beginning of the end of communism in Europe. Times readers submitted their photos and memories of the wall, before and after its fall.

headline: Monday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Medical Center and associate professor of medicine at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, took readers’ questions about ulcers. Here, Dr. Abraham responds to readers concerned about ulcer symptoms and foods or drinks that may make ulcers worse.

text: Todd Jarvis, the associate director of the Institute for Water and Watersheds at Oregon State University, sees parallels between the planet’s dwindling oil supplies and groundwater depletion.

headline: Aerosmith Says Steven Tyler Has Quit
text: The sweet emotions that the members of Aerosmith once felt towards each other have apparently come to an end. In an interview with The Las Vegas Sun, the group’s lead guitarist, Joe Perry, said that the singer Steven Tyler quit after a concert in Abu Dhabi. “Steven quit as far as I can tell,” Mr. Perry told The Sun. “I don’t know any more than you do about it.”

headline: Special News Quiz | Berlin Wall History
text: New York Times reporter Robert McFadden called it “the foremost symbol of East-West confrontation” and “a monument to political control, a scene of gunfire and drama and tragedy, the stuff of spy novels and a physical and psychic barrier that divided Berlin, Germany and Europe.”

headline: Street Smart | Auckland’s Art Bandits
text: Street art in Auckland, New Zealand, is much more than just random acts of spray paint. Nearly every corner of the city is decorated with sophisticated graphic imagery, from stencil drawings (sharks, angels, aerosol-can characters) to murals (intergalactic space settings, muscle men portraiture) to “throw-ups” (elaborate, bubble-shaped letters forming the artist’s signature). The city council has even allowed electrical boxes to be used as 3-D canvases for street art. While some of the artists and collectives have achieved a certain visibility in the graffiti world — a local crew called TMD (The Most Def) has won the “Write For Gold” international competition in Germany for the past two years — many of the taggers are anonymous. And if you want to see their handiwork, you’d better be quick. Most of the art (excluding the electrical-box mainstays) is either torn down or painted over within a few days. As Andrew Beck, from the Auckland collective Surplus Bargains, says: “That’s what street art is — temporary.”

headline: Two Harlem Streets Named for Civil Rights Leaders
text: On Saturday, two streets in Harlem were named in honor of two civil rights leaders with ties to New York City: A. Philip Randolph and W. E. B. DuBois.

headline: Iran Accuses U.S. Hikers of Espionage
text: Three American hikers who were arrested in Iran this summer after straying across its border with Iraq have been accused of spying, an Iranian state news agency reported on Monday.

headline: Correction
text: An earlier version of this article misstated the number of stock options being issued and their total value. The bank will issue 200 million to 300 million options, worth about $1.1 billion, not two to three million worth $11 million.

headline: China Executes 9 for Their Roles in Ethnic Riots in July
text: BEIJING  Nine people have been executed for taking part in ethnic rioting that convulsed a western regional capital in July and left nearly 200 people dead, a state news agency reported Monday.

headline: Trial Begins for Baltimore Mayor
text: BALTIMORE  Mayor Sheila Dixon went on trial on corruption charges on Monday, the result of a state inquiry started in 2006 that has cast a cloud over Ms. Dixon’s administration despite her best efforts to keep the focus on running the city.

headline: Musicians Locked Out at ‘Tony N’ Tina’s Wedding’
text: Updated | 1:20 p.m. A long-running theatrical marriage has hit a major bump: a union that represents professional musicians has filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board, saying that the producers of the show “Tony N’ Tina’s Wedding” fired its contracted musicians and replaced them with recorded music. The Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, said that in 2008 it renewed a three-year agreement with the previous producers of that show, which covered its performers through May 2011, and stipulated that it must be honored if new producers came onto the show. The union said that the producers Kim and Sonny Ricciardi of Broadway Entertainment, which recently took over “Tony N’ Tina’s Wedding,” paid the musicians for the show’s Oct. 10 performance and asked them to learn a new song for Oct. 17. On that date, however, the union said the producers locked the musicians out of the performance space and have denied them access to their instruments and other property. A representative for Local 802 said a meeting had been scheduled for Monday afternoon to address the dispute. A message left at Broadway Entertainment was not immediately returned.

headline: The Fall of the Berlin Wall
text: NBC's Tom Brokaw returns to Berlin for the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall.  Brokaw was the only U.S. anchor in Berlin the night the wall fell.

headline: Vatican Keeps Celibacy in Rules on Anglicans
text: VATICAN CITY  The Vatican said on Monday that its new rules facilitating the conversion of Anglicans, including married Anglican priests, did not “signify any change” in its rules for priestly celibacy.

headline: High School Hot Rodder at SEMA Show
text: Race Safro played hooky from high school last week. Well, actually, the 16-year-old junior at Highland High School in Albuquerque, N.M., was away on a business trip.

headline: Zambia and Tanzania Seek Legal Ivory Sales
text: Zambia and Tanzania are requesting a reclassification for their African Elephant populations to enable legal sales of ivory.

headline: Gourevitch Stepping Down at Paris Review
text: Philip Gourevitch, the New Yorker staff writer who for five years has been doing double-duty as the editor of The Paris Review, will leave his editor’s post in April, The New York Observer reported. In an interview with The Observer, Mr. Gourevitch (whose books include “We Wish to Inform You That Tomorrow We Will Be Killed With Our Families” and “The Ballad of Abu Ghraib”) said that he wanted to focus more on his writing and a new book project about Rwanda. “I want to give that everything,” Mr. Gourevitch said. “You can’t take time off when you’re in charge.” A committee run by Antonio Weiss, the publisher of The Paris Review, and Terry McDonnell, the director of the Paris Review Foundation, and including Bob Silvers, the editor of The New York Review of Books, and Peter Matthiessen, a founder of The Paris Review, will search for Mr. Gourevitch’s replacement.

headline: What High School Seniors Might Learn From a Survey of 360,000 College Students
text: Every year since 2000, the National Survey of Student Engagement has sought to take the academic pulse of tens of thousands of college students at several hundred colleges. To me, their answers are almost beside the point. I’ve always thought the questions themselves provided an especially detailed road map for high school seniors and their parents, as they try to take the measure of a particular college.

headline: A Lowlight-Reel Weekend
text: As tempting as it might be to focus on the good teams in the N.F.L., to marvel at the undefeated Colts and Saints, to start etching the name Peyton Manning or Drew Brees on a most valuable player trophy, the league keeps throwing us these fabulous train wrecks every week: Atlanta Coach Mike Smith nearly brawling with the Redskins’ DeAngelo Hall; Green Bay not only losing to Tampa Bay, but losing to the Buccaneers in their Creamsicle uniforms (oh, the humanity!); the Giants capsizing to the quarterback they traded away for Eli Manning.

text: Step into formation this fall with new slicker versions of the classic workaday desert boot. headline: Fort Hood Suspect Is Conscious, Hospital Officials Say
text: FORT HOOD, Tex.  Major Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist accused of shooting to death 12 soldiers and a civilian here at Fort Hood, is conscious and able to talk, officials at an Army hospital in Texas said Monday. But they declined to say whether Major Hasan had been interviewed by Army or law-enforcement investigators.

headline: Infertility Film Diaries
text: The “In The Know” short film competition concluded last week, sponsored jointly by RESOLVE: The National Infertility Association, and the pharmaceutical company EMD Serono. Couples who have struggled with infertility submitted videos describing their journeys, and you can see the winners on the website www.fertilitylifelinesfilms.com.

headline: R.I.M. Woos BlackBerry App Developers
text: BlackBerry owners may be able to type circles around their iPhone-toting friends when it comes to speeding through e-mails. But when the work is over and it’s time to play with the latest useful or silly applications, their speedy thumbs have nowhere to go. By the latest count, the Apple iPhone has 100,000 apps and the BlackBerry has just a few thousand.

headline: 24 Hour Plays: Assignments and First Rehearsals
text: With only 24 hours to create six plays from start to finish, it is not surprising that things run on a strict schedule here at the American Airlines Theater. By 8 a.m. the directors had finished submitting their choices (Lucie Tiberghien said she thought the scripts were all good, and all funny. “Nobody tried to do a dark drama,” she said). It seemed only a few minutes had passed before Philip Naudé, one of the producers, gave the directors their assignments. Leigh Kilton-Smith is to direct Stephen Belber’s play, “Ramen Noodle,” and her reaction seemed unclear for a moment — was that pleasant shock or something more like horror that flashed across her face?

headline: Big Poker Bet Falls Short for Former Bear Executive
text: A former Bear Stearns senior executive bet it all and lost his entire $22 million in chips during the finals of the World Series of Poker on Sunday, but he still managed to take home a $1.6 million prize for coming in sixth place. The move eerily parallels the fate of financial firms on Wall Street that bet big with their client’s money and lost, but still ended up with a large chunk of change in their pocket.

headline: Palestinian Authority’s Future Is in Question
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The collapse of the Palestinian Authority, Israel’s negotiating partner, was raised as a possibility on Monday, as several aides to its president, Mahmoud Abbas, said that he intended to resign and forecast that others would follow.

headline: HR 3962 and the Serpent of Pulp
text: When opponents of the House health care bill attack it, they often bring up the length of the bill, as if the number of pages signifies nefarious intent. Lawmakers have gotten in on the act: just look at the photo of two Republican representatives, Steve King of Iowa and Pete Hoekstra of Michigan, crumpling a copy of the House bill, looking a bit like modern-day Laocoons, struggling against serpents of paper.

headline: An East Village Synagogue Gets a Jazzy Rabbi
text: At first glance, the term “jazz rabbi” might seem incongruous, but the recent installation of Greg Wall, a well-known jazz musician, as the rabbi at the Sixth Street Community Synagogue, a modern Orthodox congregation in the East Village, shows that the porkpie and the yarmulke are not necessarily mutually exclusive.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Ends Salary Freeze
text: The people at JPMorgan Chase have received some good news about their paychecks: The bank is removing a salary freeze for employees earning more than $60,000 a year, with raises taking effect early next year. The freeze was put in place at the height of the financial crisis last year.

headline: Did Unemployment Really Rise?
text: The economic reactions over the weekend to Friday’s employment report all started from the assumption that things grew much worse in October. The unemployment rate leaped to 10.2 percent from 9.8 percent. Another 190,000 jobs vanished.

headline: Reading Hussein’s Biography in Baghdad
text: One book not for sale on Mutanabi Street, this city’s ancient strip of booksellers, is a new biography of Saddam Hussein, written by his lawyer based on Mr. Hussein’s diaries and conversations, that was published in Sudan last month.

text: Tendinitis has again interrupted Sasha Cohen’s comeback to competitive figure skating, and is crimping her hopes to make the United States team for the Vancouver Olympics. Cohen announced Monday that she has withdrawn from this weekend’s event, Skate America in Lake Placid.

headline: Smart People Conclude ‘Twilight’ Sequel Will Be a Hit
text: With the help of a sophisticated mathematical formula, a group of highly trained academics has determined that the coming sequel to “Twilight” is going to make a lot of money. That’s the conclusion reached by a group of researchers who say they can predict how a movie sequel will perform compared to similar, non-sequel films, The Guardian reported.

headline: Colts Game Should Provide Test of Brady’s Health
text: Tom Brady looked a little weary and in need of a shave after the New England Patriots beat the Miami Dolphins on Sunday. Maybe he was just tired of everyone wondering if he was back to normal eight games into the season. It’s time to answer that question honestly.

headline: Metropolitan Home Will Close
text: The magazine Metropolitan Home will be closing, Hachette Filipacchi Media U.S. announced today.

headline: Now Viewing | Eye Candy in Paris
text: It’s clear that no food publication is recession-proof. Culinary photography, however, is bubbling over, with a new annual festival kicking off this month in Paris called the Festival International de la Photographie Culinaire. Its founder, a former cookbook editor named Jean-Pierre Stephan, has noticed a revolution in the quality of food photos over the past decade, thanks to the boom in cookbooks and foodie mags. “I want to show that culinary photography has become a true art,” he says, “one that can make its way in the marketplace the same as any other form of art or photography. You can hang it on the dining room wall like a 17th-century Dutch still life.”

headline: Katt Williams Arrested After Home Break-In
text: The comedian Katt Williams has been charged with burglary and trespassing and remains held in an Atlanta jail after he was arrested on Sunday night for breaking into a home, The Associated Press reported. Major James Yarbrough of the Coweta County sheriff’s department told The A.P. that the break-in occurred at a home in Newnan, about 38 miles southwest of Atlanta, where a homeowner called the police to say that Mr. Williams “gained entry by breaking into the home, and items were taken from the residence.” The name of the homeowner was not given. In July, gun charges against Mr. Williams were dropped after an incident in New York in November 2008 when the police pulled him over for driving a car without license plates and discovered a gun in the car. The comedian sought medical care later that month after he was seen behaving suspiciously in Sumter, S.C., where his family lives. The A.P. said that a magistrate was expected to set bond for Mr. Williams at an arraignment Monday afternoon.

headline: The Home Buyers’ Tax Credit: What You Need to Know
text: The president signed legislation last week that extended the tax credit for first-time home buyers and added a new credit for some existing homeowners.

headline: Man Arrested in Series of Subway Robberies
text: A man with a knife and wearing a Red Sox cap who robbed several young women on New York City’s subway system was arrested on Friday in Rocky Mount, N.C., according to the police.

headline: Club for Growth Endorses Rubio
text: The Club for Growth PAC, an anti-tax organization with considerable financial resources, announced on Monday that it is endorsing Marco Rubio in his Florida Republican primary battle with Gov. Charlie Crist for the United States Senate.

headline: Song of Remembering
text: Last week in Rome I walked through the Forum, parallel to the Via Imperiali, from the Colosseum to the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. I felt as if I were walking among the skeletal ruins of empire, one of history’s vast museums. Huge Corinthian columns rose up in marble, holding nothing but the sky’s blue sphere above, the buildings they once belonged to vanquished by centuries of dust, lime burners, thieves. Slabs of marble lay on the ground with the fragments of names and pronouncements chiseled into them.

headline: Big Bird Responds
text: On Tuesday, “Sesame Street” will celebrate its 40th anniversary with the usual array of songs and life lessons about numbers and nutrition and a special guest, the first lady, Michelle Obama, on hand to help out.

headline: Carlyle Group Buying OpenLink Financial
text: The Carlyle Group said Monday that it had acquired OpenLink Financial, a maker of financial software products, from TA Associates, another private equity firm, for an undisclosed amount.
