headline: ‘Bored to Death’ and  ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm': One-Two Punch?
text: This post contains spoilers. “Bored to Death,” which ended its first season in a twist, has served all along as a comic counterpoint on HBO to “Curb Your Enthusiasm” — balancing Larry David’s ever more outré and disgusting plot points (backsplash on the image of Jesus) with odd grace notes and unexpected swerves to decency.

headline: Disappointing ‘Carol’ May Take Toll on Disney
text: The disappointing $31 million opening for “Disney’s A Christmas Carol” over the weekend may force the company to take a hefty write down, according to Doug Creutz, a media analyst at Cowen & Company. “At least $50 million and potentially as much as $100 million,” he wrote in a research note. Doug Mitchelson of Deutsche Bank sent a similar advisory to investors.

headline: Google Set to Acquire AdMob for $750 Million
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In a push to expand its digital advertising empire to cellphones, Google has agreed to acquire AdMob, a fast-growing mobile advertising start-up, for $750 million in stock, the companies said Monday.

headline: Finance mythbusting, third world edition
text: And another: one assertion I keep hearing in comments is that well, maybe China never got much capital from abroad, so you can’t attribute its takeoff to modern finance, but lots of other fast-growing developing countries did.

headline: Commemorating the Fall of the Berlin Wall
text: Hundreds gathered in Berlin to observe the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall.

headline: European Puck: Remembering the Twilight of East German Hockey
text: Monday marks the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall and the beginning of the end of a divided Germany. That makes today a good time to remember the most successful sporting venture that emerged from the East and still thrives today: Eisbären Berlin, champions of the German DEL for four of the past five years.

headline: Pear Upside-Down Cake
text: Mark Bittman bakes a pear upside-down cake.

headline: Inverted Logic: Upside-Down Pear Cake
text: I’VE always been a fan of tarte Tatin, the French dessert that features deeply caramelized apples on a light crust, often puff pastry. I’m also partial to its simpler American cousin, the upside-down cake, which features a spongecake base.

headline: Google Strikes $750 Million Stock Deal for AdMob
text: Update | 2:05 p.m. Google has agreed to buy AdMob, a fast-growing start-up that developed technology to place ads on mobile phones, for $750 million in stock, the company said Monday, The New York Times’s Miguel Helft reported from San Francisco.

headline: Monday Puzzle: You Can’t Fight Density… er, Destiny
text: Last week, we had you imagine yourself to be a perfect princess who had to choose from among the world’s most eligible princes. This week’s fictitious story, about the break-up of Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman, is a reminder that even unions between seemingly perfect people can go horribly wrong. And both stories perfectly illustrate another recent TierneyLab topic: why we love to gossip. We enjoy the first case by vicariously living our lives through people who seemingly have it all; in the second case, we just let our bottled-up envy loose and thumb our noses at them: “You’re not so perfect, Mr. Celebrity. Nyah, nyah, nyah nyah nyah.” It’s something that we can enjoy with our baser instincts both going in and coming out.

headline: A Shoe Box Full of New York Arrives in Afghanistan
text: The first word came early last week, flashed to Manhattan from a British Army forward operating base in Helmand Province in a Facebook message. Then confirmation arrived in a phone call Friday at lunchtime. There was a short delay on the line, but the message was clear: The ultimate New York care package had arrived in Afghanistan.

headline: Former S.E.C. Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Dreier Case
text: Update | 4:00 p.m. A former lawyer with the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission pleaded guilty Monday to conspiring with Marc S. Dreier, a prominent Manhattan lawyer, to dupe hedge funds out of tens of millions of dollars.

headline: Should Jahvid Best Play Again?
text: The results of this gut-wrenching fall were better than expected: Jahvid Best, the star running back for the University of California, Berkeley was released from the hospital Sunday after suffering a severe concussion.

headline: U.S. Officer Revisits His Past in Vietnam
text: DA NANG, Vietnam  Cmdr. H. B. Le, the first Vietnamese-American to command a United States Navy destroyer, had just stepped ashore on a formal port call, making an emotional return to Vietnam for the first time since he fled as a young boy on a fishing boat at the end of the war in 1975.

headline: ‘On the Brink,’ New York Must Cut, Paterson Says
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson took the rare step on Monday of addressing a joint session of the Legislature during its traditional off-season and used the speech to underscore New York’s deepening financial crisis.

headline: Two Channels Buy ‘Enthusiasm’ Reruns
text: Larry David‘s fictional self is being sold to two cable channels. Both the TV Guide Network and TV Land have bought the rerun rights to “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” Mr. David’s acclaimed HBO comedy.

headline: Dame Edna, Michael Feinstein Slapfest Continues
text: Since September, observant theater fans have been noting the ever-so-slight resemblance between the titles of coming Broadway productions featuring Michael Feinstein (whose new show, “All About Me,” begins previews on March 6) and Dame Edna Everage (who is returning next year in a new show called “It’s All About Me.”) Last week, when Mr. Feinstein said he was “very surprised to learn of the similarity of titles,” perhaps he thought he’d have the last word on the matter. But no.

headline: Canada Breaks U.S. Women’s Winning Streak
text: It was a winning streak that the United States women’s hockey team hoped would continue until after the Vancouver Olympic Games, having not lost to their arch-rival, Team Canada, since 2007.

headline: Skimming and Scanning: Using The Times to Develop Reading Skills
text: Overview | How can you quickly identify the main idea of a text? When and how do you skim a text, and how does skimming differ from scanning? In this lesson, students practice and explore the reading skills of skimming and scanning with the front page of The New York Times and come away understanding how and when to use these skills.

headline: Against Time | Natalia Brilli’s Nolex
text: The Belgian designer Natalia Brilli puts a new spin on that old saw: If you have to ask how much, you can’t afford it. Among her catalog of curiosities is this fake Rolex watch, called a Nolex, which she covers in soft buttery leather, suggesting that if you have to know the time, you also can’t afford it.Brilli, who has designed accessories at Rochas, is hypersensitive to the conclusions people draw about the character and status of someone wearing a luxury product. So far, she’s encased everything from skateboards to medical alert bracelets in black or silver leather. But sometimes, she’ll pick a bright electric hue, further scrambling the object’s original associations. The Nolex is $295 at Project 8, (212) 925-5599.

headline: Fannie Mulls $5.2 Billion Write-off for Tax Credits
text: Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance giant, said Monday that it was reviewing whether it would have to write off $5.2 billion in low-income housing tax credits after the Treasury Department rejected its request last week to sell the credits to Goldman Sachs, Bloomberg News reports.

headline: D.C. Sniper Is to Be Executed on Tuesday
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday declined to block the execution of John A. Muhammad, the sniper who terrorized the Washington area seven years ago. The step cleared the way for Mr. Muhammad to be put to death on Tuesday unless Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia intervenes.

headline: Public Grooming Stirs Vigorous Debate
text: More than 200 commenters chimed in on Lion Calandra’s complaints about grooming in public — the argument that people should not make public spectacles out of private moments clearly hit a nerve. Most had their own horror stories to share (often involving nail clippings or tossed dental floss), though some even confessed to their own grooming indiscretions.

headline: Obscure Books, Part II
text: Last year, inspired by a piece in The Village Voice, I asked readers what their favorite obscure books were. Now The American Conservative, in its “Special Books Issue,” has asked 15 writers to name their favorite obscure books.

headline: Chron Is Glossy-ish: What Do You Think?
text: At first, I missed it.

headline: Universities Look for Heat Underground
text: In an effort to cut their carbon footprints, a handful of universities around the country are turning to ground-source heat exchangers and geothermal heating — sometimes with the help of federal financing.

headline: Bardot, France’s Lasting Passion
text: PARIS | She is known for her unadulterated beauty, feisty temper and French je ne sais quoi. Brigitte Bardot first graced the cover of Elle magazine in 1950, at the age of 15, and has remained in the public’s imagination ever since. “Brigitte Bardot: The Carefree Years,” an exhibition dedicated to the French star, now 75, celebrates her lasting popularity — which itself is a reflection of France’s own obsession with passion, rebellion and idealization.

headline: Justices Hear Patent Case on Protecting the Abstract
text: WASHINGTON  Supreme Court justices took up a case on Monday that could reshape the realm of what can be patented, and expressed skepticism about giving protection to abstract business innovations.

headline: When Jet Lag Comes With the Freebies
text: IT was really easy to convert my frequent flier miles into a free round-trip business-class ticket to Europe.

headline: Tagged.com Settles Disputes Over Deceptive Invitations
text: Update | 5:38 p.m.   Corrected post and headline to note that the state attorneys general had announced their intent to sue Tagged.com; they had not actually filed lawsuits.

headline: White and Davis’ Strong Season Picks Up Another Ice Dancing Victory
text: American ice dancers Meryl White and Charlie Davis qualified for their second Grand Prix final by winning their second competition of the season.

headline: New Ideas for Winter Squash
text: These days you don’t have to go to a farmers’ market to find several varieties of winter squash. Last week, as I walked into a Trader Joe’s, I passed bins of acorn squash, butternut, spaghetti squash and pumpkins of varying sizes. I bought one of each kind of squash, and I’ve been exploring new ways of working with them.

headline: Design Is the Key to Detroit’s Future, Study Says
text: In the 1920s, Alfred Sloan, who was the president of General Motors at the time, committed the automaker to the annual model change. But today, model changes are far less frequent than annual, and a recently released economic research paper argues that Detroit automakers have suffered because of it. Detroit’s share of the auto market fell from roughly 73 percent in 1996 to 47 percent in 2008.

headline: Injured Right Calf Forces Cohen to Withdraw From Skate America
text: Sasha Cohen, the 2006 Olympic silver medalist in figure skating, ran into another setback Monday in her effort to make the 2010 United States Olympic team.

headline: Dutch Views on Same-Sex Marriage
text: When I wrote about same sex parenting in the Times Magazine this weekend, one of the people I interviewed was M. V. Lee Badgett, who is both the director of the Williams Institute on Sexual Orientation Law & Public Policy at the UCLA School of Law and a professor of Economics at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst. She is also the author of “When Gay People Get Married: What Happens When Societies Legalize Same-Sex Marriage,” which focuses mostly on data from the Netherlands, where same-sex marriage has been legal for nearly a decade.

headline: Vitaly Ginzburg Dies at 93; Worked on Soviet H-Bomb
text: MOSCOW  Vitaly L. Ginzburg, the Russian physicist who helped develop the first Soviet hydrogen bomb and went on to win the Nobel Prize, died in Moscow on Sunday. He was 93.

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: 1.) Ezra Klein on abortion and the Stupak amendment.

headline: Findley Scores Salt Lake a Chance at the M.L.S. Title Game
text: Robbie Findley has the confidence of youth and the audacity necessary to be a successful striker.

headline: Wait, Are These Actually the 100 Best Movies of the Decade?
text: Earlier on Monday we noted an effort by The Times of London to enumerate the 100 best films of the 2000s, defiantly published before the Dec. 23 release of the “Alvin and the Chipmunks” sequel.

headline: Steroids’ Miracle Comes With a Caveat
text: Steroids  corticosteroids, that is, synthetic versions of the natural hormone produced by the adrenal glands  are indeed miracle drugs, capable of restoring the health and saving the lives of countless people with a wide spectrum of serious ailments. Prednisone may be the best known, but there are scores of others, some tailor-made to counter specific ailments.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Sun-Times has more on the Chicago roots of Sam Kass, the White House chef who’s a food policy adviser for the Obamas.

headline: Beckham’s Contributions to the Galaxy Amount to More Than Celebrity Stimulus
text: CARSON, Calif.  David Beckham curled a beautiful 50-yard pass to Landon Donovan, beginning a sequence that ended with Donovan’s penalty-kick goal in the 73rd minute and a 1-0 playoff victory for the Los Angeles Galaxy.

headline: Gathering at the Table, Bottles in Hand
text: FOR six consecutive years, the Dining section’s wine panel has gathered for an early Thanksgiving meal. The mission: to taste potential holiday wines, to determine what works and what does not with a representative feast, and to offer coherent answers to the annual question of what to serve with the bird.

headline: Wounded Soldier Recounts Shooting
text: N.B.C.'s Meredith Vieira interviewed Amber Bahr, a soldier who was wounded in Thursday's shooting at Fort Hood in Texas.

headline: Metropolitan Home Will Close After Its December Issue
text: Another home magazine has been demolished.

headline: The Morning Skate: A Headshot Hearing, a Union Adrift and a Lot of Hurting
text: TSN is reporting that the Flames’ Curtis Glencross has been suspended three games for this blindside head shot to Rangers captain Chris Drury:

headline: Setting Sail Into Space, Propelled by Sunshine
text: Peter Pan would be so happy.

headline: E.P.A. Intervenes on Video by 2 Employees
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has directed two agency lawyers to make changes in a video they posted on YouTube that is critical of the Obama administration’s climate policy. But the original video has already been reposted several times by other YouTube users.

headline: 24 Hour Plays: No Free Lunch
text: At noon there was an event in the lobby at the American Airlines Theater that the people in charge were referring to as “lunch.” Clearly there was a table piled high with food, but not a lot of actors spent much time sitting around eating. Some passed through quickly and went off to continue rehearsing, one cast was having its sole chance to be on the stage proper before tech and worked through lunch and others, well, who knows if all of these people even eat lunch.

headline: Hotels Find Keeping Travelers at Home Can Be Good Business
text: “If you can’t beat ’em, join ’em,” may be the best maxim to explain why travel companies are getting into the virtual meeting business, actually helping clients avoid flying halfway around the globe.

headline: Brooklyn Kitchen Labs Is Set to Open
text: Brooklyn Kitchen Labs, the Williamsburg cooking school/butcher shop/brewing and winemaking supply store featuring the work of the celebrity butcher Tom Mylan, will open on Nov. 16.

headline: U.S. Knew of Suspect’s Tie to Radical Cleric
text: WASHINGTON  Intelligence agencies intercepted communications last year and this year between the military psychiatrist accused of shooting to death 13 people at Fort Hood, Tex., and a radical cleric in Yemen known for his incendiary anti-American teachings.

headline: On Our Radar …
text: 1.) Harnessing bacteria to grow custom packaging.

headline: Dutch View of Choice in U.S. Care: It’s Limited
text: WASHINGTON  The health system in the United States may be twice as expensive as those in Europe, and the population may be less healthy, but at least Americans have access to many more choices of doctors and insurers. Right?

headline: Fearing a Flu Vaccine, and Wanting More of It
text: When I tell nonmedical friends that our clinic is vaccinating children against the H1N1 flu virus, here is what they say.

headline: Financial Regulations Chief Chides British Banks
text: LONDON  Many senior banking executives failed to accept responsibility for the financial crisis and neglected the need to change their behavior, Hector Sants, the chief executive at Britain’s financial industry regulatory body, said Monday.

headline: Buffett to Sell Stakes in 2 Other Railroad Firms
text: Update | 4:16 p.m. As Warren E. Buffett takes on Burlington Northern Santa Fe in his biggest-ever deal, he is looking to sell off his stakes in two other big railroad companies, Union Pacific and Norfolk Southern.

headline: The Claim: Magnetic Therapy Can Ease Arthritis Pain
text: THE FACTS For people with arthritis who seek an alternative to painkillers, magnetic straps and bracelets have become a popular option.

headline: In Africa, the Flight Is Just a Trip’s First Leg
text: AFRICA fascinates me. The land itself is magnificent, as are its people. Despite the hardships they have endured, they are hopeful about a brighter future.

headline: Seedy Lives of Citrus
text: Q. Lemons have lots of seeds, and most oranges, too. But I’ve never encountered a seed in a lime. Why?

headline: Stuck by a Needle, Not by a Decision
text: I didn’t think it would happen to me so soon, just a few months after beginning my second career as a nurse. I stuck my thumb with a large-bore needle filled with the blood of a patient with hepatitis C who had come to the emergency room with abdominal pain.

headline: Through 1 Woman, 20 Views of Life’s End
text: When Lance Armstrong learned he had testicular cancer, he assembled a top team of doctors for what he decided would be the race of his life. If he did not win, he would die.

headline: Exercise: Treating Sleep Apnea With a Golf Club
text: Many middle-aged men who have sleep apnea either do not seek treatment or are inconsistent about using the airway pressure masks prescribed to them. But what if they thought treatment might improve their golf game?

headline: Nutrition: Chocolate Milk May Reduce Inflammation
text: Move over, red wine. Make room for chocolate milk. A new study suggests that regular consumption of skim milk with flavonoid-rich cocoa may reduce inflammation, potentially slowing or preventing development of atherosclerosis. Researchers noted, however, that the effect was not as pronounced as that seen with red wine.

headline: A Dream Interpretation: Tuneups for the Brain
text: It’s snowing heavily, and everyone in the backyard is in a swimsuit, at some kind of party: Mom, Dad, the high school principal, there’s even an ex-girlfriend. And is that Elvis, over by the piñata?

headline: Impasse Over, Lebanon Forms Cabinet
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  More than five months after holding parliamentary elections, Lebanon formed a new cabinet on Monday, ending a long period of gridlock that illustrated once again the myriad dysfunctions of this country's bitterly divided political class.

headline: AIDS Divisions of 2 Large Drug Makers Form Company to Focus on the Disease
text: Two of the world’s biggest drug makers last week spun off their divisions that manufacture AIDS drugs and combined them into one company focusing on the disease.

headline: Magnets for Arthritis
text: In today’s “Really?” column, Anahad O’Connor explores whether magnetic therapy can ease arthritis pain.

headline: Parents Refusing the Flu Vaccine
text: When I found out my daughter’s school was offering the H1N1 vaccine last week, I quickly signed up. Given the scarcity of the vaccine in my community, I felt fortunate it was finally available through the school. But I was surprised how many parents chose not to have their kids vaccinated.

headline: Wall St. Bonus Season Likely to Be Hit or Miss
text: Bonus time on Wall Street will be very hit or miss this year amid a growing divergence in incentive compensation across the financial services industry, according to projections from Johnson & Associates, a consulting firm.

headline: Afloat in the Ocean, Expanding Islands of Trash
text: ABOARD THE ALGUITA, 1,000 miles northeast of Hawaii  In this remote patch of the Pacific Ocean, hundreds of miles from any national boundary, the detritus of human life is collecting in a swirling current so large that it defies precise measurement.

headline: E.P.A. Intervenes on Video
text: At our sib-blog DotEarth, Leslie Kaufman and John Broder report that the Environmental Protection Agency has directed two of its lawyers to make changes in a video posted on YouTube that is critical of the Obama administration’s climate-change policy. Read the full post.

headline: A New Look for the Public Library’s Lion Logo
text: The library lion has shed its shaggy mane for the digital age.

headline: Sandra’s Sources | Must-Visit Online Vintage Sales
text: T Magazine’s beauty/style director, Sandra Ballentine, opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.

headline: Fewer Banks Tightening Standards, Fed Says
text: Fewer banks tightened their lending standards for companies and consumers in the third quarter as the economy grew for the first time in more than a year, a Federal Reserve survey showed, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Things Publicists Send Us: ‘Up’ and Away
text: Walt Disney Pictures rarely does things small when it comes to marketing, but this piece of publicity material was as big as a house.

headline: The Seducer’s New Clothes (and Bad Old Ways)
text: In planning New York City Opera’s comeback 2009-10 season, George Steel, the company’s new general manager and artistic director, knew that the budget would allow him just one chance to make a statement with a new production of a standard repertory work. He approached the director Christopher Alden, known for revisionist stagings of the staples, filled with striking, often jarring modern imagery. They chose Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” as a project. They chose well.

headline: The Psychology of Needing a Touchdown
text: A reader, CA Giants Fan, made an interesting point in the comment section:

headline: Electronic Arts Buys Playfish, a Social Games Start-Up
text: Electronic Arts, the video game company, announced Monday that it had acquired Playfish, one maker of the social-network-based games that have become so popular this year.

headline: Power for U.S. From Russia’s Old Nuclear Weapons
text: MOSCOW  What’s powering your home appliances?

headline: The Meaning of Fort Hood
text: The attempt to sort out the meaning of the murderous actions of Maj. Nidal Hasan has consumed numerous blog cycles since Thursday. Does Hasan’s rampage signal an internal jihadi threat we’re ill-equipped to thwart, or was it just another meaningless moment of American lone-gunman violence?

headline: Shanghai Players Arrive, Driven On by Their Titan
text: SHANGHAI  Just over an hour into a rehearsal here last week, the maestro’s baton came down like the crack of a whip, and the music screeched to a halt. Long Yu, the imperious 45-year-old conductor of the Shanghai Symphony Orchestra, wanted perfection.

headline: Pigs Prove to Be Smart, if Not Vain
text: We’ve all heard the story of the third Little Pig, who foiled the hyperventilating wolf by building his house out of bricks, rather than with straw or sticks as his brothers had done. Less commonly known is that the pig later improved his home’s safety profile by installing convex security mirrors at key points along the driveway.

headline: Showing Them Some Love: ‘Dreamgirls’ at the Apollo
text: There is a moment at the beginning of this latest revival of “Dreamgirls” when reality and fantasy mesh, when the actresses performing onstage at the Apollo Theater in Harlem are as excited and anxious about their chance at stardom as the fictional ’60s-era singers they portray.

headline: Update: Judge Grants Extension in Google Case
text: After the parties to the Google settlement requested an extension on the deadline to submit a revised agreement that would address the concerns of the Justice Department and others, Judge Denny Chin agreed to set a new deadline of Friday, Nov. 13.

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead’ as Literature, Theater and Music
text: With the New York City Opera safely (one hopes) up and running again, the spotlight swings back to the Metropolitan Opera in a season unusually thick with new productions. Next up is Janacek’s “From the House of the Dead,” in a staging by Patrice Chéreau that had its dress rehearsal on Monday morning and opens on Thursday evening.

headline: Film From the Frontlines: New Glimpses of a War
text: When the Wehrmacht hanged 18 civilians in a World War II reprisal killing in Serbia, tugging on the victims’ ankles to hasten death, a German propaganda cameraman dutifully recorded the grisly sequence on color movie film. When Russian partisans executed a suspected German spy deep in the forest, that killing, too, was caught on camera.

headline: In a Sketchy Hall of Mirrors, Nabokov Jousts With Death and Reality
text: Given the shape of Vladimir Nabokov’s own life, it’s hardly surprising that death  and its cousin loss  permeated his fiction like a potent but noxious perfume.

headline: Six Years of Thanksgiving Wisdom
text: Are we really discussing Thanksgiving? People, I’m not only talking about it, but I’ve already eaten it, and I’ve already slurped it down.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'The Red Balloon'
text: A. O. Scott reviews the classic 1956 short film directed by Albert Lamorisse.

headline: Schubert’s Brief Candle, Burning Bright
text: In nearly any consideration of the truly great works that Schubert produced in 1828, the year of his death at 31, worshipful awe and breathless hyperbole go hand in hand. The awe is understandable: it is hard to fathom that pieces like the last three Piano Sonatas, the String Quintet in C and the song collection “Schwanengesang,” among others, were created in so brief a time and by a composer who probably knew he was terminally ill. The hyperbole can be less fortunate: how does a mere mortal form a personal relationship with art so invariably beatified?

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': Prisoner Dostoyevsky
text: One of the first and best questions about “The House of the Dead,” I think, is why Dostoyevsky wrote it as a novel, and not simply as autobiography.

headline: Woman on Verge of Creating the New
text: It would be easy to reduce “The Verge,” Susan Glaspell’s 1921 play, to a feminist tract. Society forces Claire Archer into the boxes it deems acceptable; in attempting to escape those boxes, Claire goes mad. But that summary ignores the work’s wild heart, which, like its fragile, monstrous heroine, is somehow irreducible.

headline: What ever happened to “Commie”?
text: A curious fact — one that I can attest to based on my own inbox, and is also borne out by more general observation — is that “Nazi” is the preferred term of abuse from today’s right wing. We get signs saying “Obama=Hitler”, not Obama=Stalin. I get mail calling me a “dirty Nazi scumbag”, not a Commie or pinko.

headline: Katt Williams Arrested After Home Break-In
text: The comedian Katt Williams has been charged with burglary and trespassing and remains in an Atlanta jail after he was arrested on Sunday night on suspicion of breaking into a home, The Associated Press reported. Maj. James Yarbrough of the Coweta County Sheriff’s Department told The A.P. that the break-in had occurred at a home in Newnan, about 38 miles southwest of Atlanta, where a homeowner called the police to say Mr. Williams, above, “gained entry by breaking into the home, and items were taken from the residence.” The name of the homeowner was not given. In July gun charges against Mr. Williams were dropped after an incident in New York in November 2008 in which the police pulled him over for driving a car without license plates and discovered a gun in the car. The comedian sought medical care later that month after he was seen behaving suspiciously in Sumter, S.C., where his family lives. The A.P. said a magistrate was expected to set bond for Mr. Williams at an arraignment on Monday afternoon.

headline: Aerosmith Says Steven Tyler Has Quit the Band
text: The sweet emotions that the members of Aerosmith once felt toward one another have apparently come to an end. In an interview with The Las Vegas Sun, the group’s lead guitarist, Joe Perry, near right, said the singer Steven Tyler, far right, had quit after a concert in Abu Dhabi. “Steven quit as far as I can tell,” Mr. Perry told The Sun. “I don’t know any more than you do about it.” Mr. Perry was responding to remarks that Mr. Tyler made in an interview with Classic Rock, a British music magazine, in which Mr. Tyler said he was preparing to focus on a solo career. “I don’t know what I’m doing yet,” he said, “but it’s definitely going to be something Steven Tyler: working on the brand of myself  brand Tyler.” Mr. Perry said he had had difficulty confirming this with Mr. Tyler because the singer had not returned his phone calls. “He’s notorious for that,” he told The Sun. “That’s one thing I’ve learned to live with. I try to overlook it.” Aerosmith canceled several concerts over the summer after Mr. Tyler fell from a stage on Aug. 5. A publicist for the band referred questions to its management, which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

headline: Easy Win for Football
text: A face-off between the Dallas Cowboys and the Philadelphia Eagles was the No. 1 draw on Sunday as NBC’s football coverage easily led the night. Although final audience figures were unavailable on Monday, Nielsen’s preliminary estimates show the game drew considerably higher ratings than the previous “Sunday Night Football” game, two weeks ago. That matchup, which was broadcast opposite Game 6 of the American League Championship Series, earned 15 million viewers when final numbers were released, and estimates indicate that this Sunday’s game may have exceeded 20 million. CBS ranked second for the night with its line-up of “60 Minutes” (19.1 million), “The Amazing Race” (12.9 million), “Three Rivers” (8.6 million) and “Cold Case” (8.2 million), as the network received a boost from an overrun of its afternoon football coverage. ABC was third, earning its best ratings for “Desperate Housewives” (13.3 million), while Fox finished in fourth place with its animated comedies.

headline: Musicians Locked Out of ‘tony N’ Tina’s Wedding’
text: A long-running theatrical marriage has hit a major bump: a union that represents musicians has filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board, saying the producers of the show “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding” had fired its contracted musicians and replaced them with recorded music. Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians said that in 2008 it renewed a three-year agreement with the previous producers of that show, covering its performers through May 2011 with the requirement that it must be honored if new producers came aboard. The union said that the producers Kim and Sonny Ricciardi of Broadway Entertainment, which recently took over “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding,” paid the musicians for the Oct. 10 performance and asked them to learn a new song for Oct. 17. On that date, however, the producers locked the musicians out of the performance space, the union said, and they have denied them access to their instruments and other property since then. A representative for Local 802 said a meeting had been scheduled for Monday afternoon to address the dispute. A message left at Broadway Entertainment was not immediately returned.

headline: U.S. and Europe Disagree on Sun-Oracle Deal
text: European Union regulators told the Oracle Corporation that its $7.4 billion purchase of Sun Microsystems might break antitrust rules even though the United States authorities have approved the deal.

headline: Gourevitch Is to Leave the Paris Review
text: Philip Gourevitch, the New Yorker staff writer who for five years has been doing double duty as the editor of The Paris Review, will leave his editor’s post in April, The New York Observer reported. In an interview with The Observer, Mr. Gourevitch, left (whose books include “We Wish to Inform You That Tomorrow We Will Be Killed With Our Families,” about the Rwandan genocide, and “The Ballad of Abu Ghraib”), said he wanted to focus more on his writing and a new book project about Rwanda. “I want to give that everything,” he said. “You can’t take time off when you’re in charge.” A committee to find Mr. Gourevitch’s replacement will be run by Antonio Weiss, the publisher of The Paris Review, and Terry McDonnell, director of the Paris Review Foundation, and include  Robert B. Silvers, the editor of The New York Review of Books, and the author Peter Matthiessen, a founder of The Paris Review.

headline: Two Channels Buy ‘Curb’ Reruns
text: The fictional self of  Larry David, below,  is being sold to two cable channels. Both the TV Guide Network and TV Land have bought the rerun rights to “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” Mr. David’s HBO comedy. The deal illustrates the TV Guide Network’s desire to transform itself from a channel listings service to an entertainment destination in its own right. It acquired repeats of the ABC series “Ugly Betty” earlier this year. “Curb” will begin on TV Guide in February. Three or more years later the rights will transfer to TV Land, a classics channel that is seeking 40-something viewers. The Hollywood Reporter said the channels were paying less than $600,000 per episode for the six seasons of “Curb.”

headline: Footnote
text: The Public Theater said it was extending by one week its production of “Idiot Savant,” the Richard Foreman play that features Willem Dafoe, above, in a variety of coats, duck masks, mouth plugs and imitation rowboats. The play is now scheduled to end its run on Dec. 20.

headline: Following in Famous Footsteps at the 92nd Street Y
text: Seventy-five years is a lifetime for many people. But art, as the Donald Justice poem goes, “keeps long hours.”

headline: Five Development Projects to Receive Stimulus Money
text: City officials have chosen five more development projects, one in each borough, to receive tax-free financing through the federal stimulus program.

headline: Uncompromising Iconoclast in All Her Forceful Glory
text: The dogged originality and eruptive energy encountered in the music of Galina Ustvolskaya, a Soviet-era Russian composer, are undeniable. Factor in the eccentricity and ego of her public pronouncements, as well as the spiritual streak that runs through her slender output, and you have the stuff of a formidable cult following. But so severe and uncompromising are the products of Ustvolskaya’s mature style that the Miller Theater, where the music of Iannis Xenakis and Elliott Carter draws capacity crowds, appeared to be just over half full for a Composer Portraits concert presented by the admirable Fifth House Ensemble of Chicago on Saturday night.

headline: U.S. and Europe Disagree on Oracle-Sun Deal
text: Oracle’s acquisition of Sun Microsystems would not be anticompetitive and consumers would have a variety of database products from which to choose, the Justice Department’s antitrust division said on Monday, a move that conflicts with a position taken by the European Union.

headline: A Classic Minimalist Score, Played at Maximal (and Electronical) Length
text: If you went to Le Poisson Rouge on Sunday evening to hear the Grand Valley State University New Music Ensemble, of Michigan, perform music from its new recording, “In C Remixed,” you got either more or less than you bargained for, depending on your point of view. The recording, a two-CD set, includes 18 reconsiderations of Terry Riley’s classic Minimalist score, “In C” (1964), by 16 composers, as well as a 20-minute performance of the work itself. Among the selections are new works built on allusions to “In C” and remixes, radically reconfigured, edited and electronically altered versions of the Riley work.

headline: Stateside Home Is Proposed for South Pole Dome
text: A geodesic dome that sheltered scientists and support workers at the South Pole for three decades is due to be demolished in the next few months, having outlived its usefulness at the bottom of the world.

headline: Senate Confirms Judge to 4th Circuit
text: The Senate on Monday voted 72-to-16 to confirm Judge Andre M. Davis to a seat on the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, which is based in Richmond.

headline: White House, Lobbyists Still at Odds
text: The lobbyists who went to the White House on Monday to complain about the administration’s policy of banning them from an international trade advisory board were all seasoned players in Washington. So it should hardly surprise them that the White House has used their meeting for its own purposes, as an opportunity to call attention to the virtues of its no-lobbyist ban.

headline: For Elephant Seals, a Restful Downward Spiral
text: Northern elephant seals are long-distance mariners, voyaging for two to eight months at a time without making landfall. And when they are at sea, they spend up to 90 percent of their time on underwater dives.

headline: The Table Is a Pedestal, as Performers Improvise
text: Improvisers are always getting themselves into jams. Often the fun of watching them is seeing how they get themselves out. Or fail to.

headline: In Shake-Up, Washington Times Ousts 3 Executives
text: The Washington Times has fired three top executives, the paper announced on Monday, and it refused to say whether the paper’s top editor would also leave.

headline: Potentially One Less Tax Penalty for Gay Couples
text: The health care bill passed by the House of Representatives over the weekend eliminates a tax penalty for same-sex couples who receive health benefits from employers, but whether the final legislation will include the provision is another story.

headline: Hogwarts Namesake Faces Loss of Status
text: The world seems awash in new dinosaurs these days.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Red Balloon’
text: In this week’s critics’ pick, A. O. Scott asks what it takes to entertain a child. Does it take 3-D, talking animals or CGI?

headline: What If You’re Gay? A New Feature.
text: Last month, we explored the many extra costs that same-sex couples incur because their unions are not recognized by the federal government. But we’d like that story to serve as a conversation starter. Now that we know the issues — extra health insurance costs, potentially higher tax bills, estate-planning hurdles, to name a few — we plan on exploring them in more detail. Right here.

headline: Giants’ Wilkinson Out 6 to 8 Weeks
text: The Giants announced Monday that Gerris Wilkinson, a linebacker who plays mostly on special teams, dislocated his right wrist Sunday against San Diego and would be out six to eight weeks after surgery.

headline: Jurors in Bear Trial  Ask for Evidence, and a Day Off
text: Jurors in the criminal trial of two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers have been deliberating less than a day, but they have already requested several pieces of evidence, the testimony of one witness and even a day off.

headline: Women’s Curling Team Opens Strong in Ontario
text: The United States women’s Olympic curling team won its first tour event of the season, beating Ontario’s Lisa Farnell rink 5-2 at the OVCA Fall Classic in Kemptville, Ontario, Canada.

headline: A Hunt for Seeds to Save Species, Perhaps by Helping Them Move
text: CHICAGO  Pitcher’s thistle, whose fuzzy leaves and creamy pink puffs once thrived in the sand dunes along several of the Great Lakes, was driven by development, drought and weevils into virtual extinction from the shores of Lake Michigan decades ago.

headline: News of Hockey, 11/9/09: Two Hits to the Head, One Suspension
text: As expected, the N.H.L. announced Monday afternoon that it had suspended Calgary forward Curtis Glencross for three games for a blindside hit that gave the Rangers’ Chris Drury a concussion on Saturday night.

headline: How to Read
text: E-readers like Amazon’s Kindle have caught on with the small set willing to buy a device just for reading. But pretty soon, most of us will read books — or at least parts of them — on our ubiquitous smartphones. For example, Shortcovers, a Toronto-based company, has created free reading apps for the iPhone, BlackBerry and Palm Pre, as well as for Google’s Android phones. There are many free books available. Newer best sellers cost $10.

headline: All in the Family (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Russian Mining Company Threatens to Sue a Paper
text: MOSCOW  A major Russian mining company has threatened to sue the country’s leading business newspaper for publishing leaked information before an initial public offering.

headline: 24 Hour Plays: Got the Lines? How ‘Bout the Lights?
text: The autograph seekers have been lurking on 42nd Street for quite some time already, one of the staffers at the theater informs me. This is no large gang, but rather just a trio of very eager-looking young men clutching envelopes we believe to be full of pictures of stars who are inside the theater. They stand obediently far enough from the door of the theater to seem nonthreatening, but the unblinking watching of the door is a little disconcerting anyway. Out of the blue, Emmy Rossum exits the theater to head back to her rehearsal studio next door and they bolt toward her (but not before she totally makes a point of saying hi to me!).

headline: A Vanishing Diagnosis (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Rules on Names Could Bend a Little
text: THE Transportation Security Administration and the airline industry are trying to address public anxiety over how the new Secure Flight identity-matching program will affect travelers. The program is rolling out smoothly, the airlines say.

headline: Electronic Arts Plans to Cut 1,500 Jobs
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Electronic Arts, the video game company, said it would lay off 1,500 workers and shrink its product lineup, even as it announced that it had acquired Playfish, a start-up that makes online games.

headline: Travels in Cyberspace: The Monday Report
text: When it comes to the Sunshine State, coastal cities like Miami, Palm Beach and Fort Lauderdale usually hog the spotlight. That might explain why The Washington Post, in its Florida special issue, turned its attention to the lesser-known Gulf Islands.

headline: A Weaker Storm Devastated El Salvador
text: MEXICO CITY  A devastating storm that struck El Salvador over the weekend was not the hurricane that roared through the region at the same time and, in fact, it did not even merit a name  which meant little after at least 140 people were killed when rivers burst their banks and hillsides collapsed under a siege of relentless rain.

headline: Bill Clinton Headed to the Hill
text: Former President Bill Clinton will attend the Senate Democrats’ weekly caucus luncheon on Tuesday to talk about the pending health care legislation, senior Democrats said.

headline: A Brand Favored by Muscle Men Wants to Appeal to More Women
text: SALES of vitamins and minerals are projected to grow more than 6 percent this year  to $11.2 billion, from $10.6 billion in 2008  according to Mintel, a market research firm, and that bump may come not in spite of the economic downturn, but because of it.

headline: Women Ascend to Iraq’s Elite Police Officer Corps
text: BAGHDAD  As one, the stony faces broke into a free-for-all of kisses, hugs and tears on Monday as the 50 women who called themselves the Lioness group became the first female graduates of Iraq’s police officer training academy.

headline: Poll: Americans Divided on Health Care Overhaul
text: Americans are feeling more doubtful about an overhaul of the health care system than they were in September, according to a new Gallup poll.

headline: Tensions in an Iranian Exile Camp in Iraq
text: CAMP ASHRAF, Iraq  There seems, as with many problems in Iraq, no good answer for Camp Ashraf, as tensions here rise and American soldiers get closer to leaving: what to do with the few thousand Iranian dissidents here trained in explosives and proficient with tanks and machine guns who have sworn to overthrow the government in Tehran?

headline: New York, Needing Cash, Pursuing Tax Delinquents
text: Desperate for cash amid the worst fiscal crisis in years, New York State is pursuing tax debtors more aggressively than ever before, doubling the number of cases it is investigating and seeking to collect from delinquents ranging from JPMorgan Chase to an out-of-business convenience store on the Bowery.

headline: Connecticut Governor Won’t Seek Re-election
text: Gov. M. Jodi Rell of Connecticut, who rose to the state’s highest office five years ago after her predecessor resigned amid a corruption scandal, said on Monday that she would not seek re-election.

headline: From 19th-Century View, Desegregation Is a Test
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Hinge Is Cited in Big Recall of Strollers
text: A baby stroller company voluntarily recalled about one million strollers Monday after reports that children had had their fingertips severed in a hinge, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said.

headline: From the House Leadership, Sighs of Relief
text: From coast to coast, House Democrats on Monday trumpeted their victory in approving the big health care legislation, even as they acknowledged with some trepidation that the fate of the legislation in the Senate is far from certain.

headline: As the Nation Grieves Over Fort Hood
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Next Battleground in the Health Care Fight
text: To the Editor:

headline: Money to Fight AIDS
text: To the Editor:

headline: Showcase: Falling Into Place
text: Patricia Lay-Dorsey, 67, wasn’t fond of the way she looked. Her wrinkles — the “dry creek bed” on her face — made her feel uncomfortable. So she made a series of close up portraits of her face. Ms. Lay-Dorsey wasn’t fond of her belly or her sagging breasts. So she photographed herself nude. Ms. Lay-Dorsey felt some shame over falling down because of multiple sclerosis. So she documented her daily routine. And, while exposing herself, Ms. Lay-Dorsey noticed something unexpected. “Somehow,” she said, “I began to feel more beautiful.”

headline: For Taliban Fighters, a Fading Memorial
text: TARAKHEL, Afghanistan  The locals call the place “The Taliban Cemetery,” a weed-clotted memorial to the men who died for the movement during its fiercest campaigns in the years before 9/11.

headline: Rubbish in the Pacific
text: The detritus of human life is collecting in a Pacific Ocean garbage patch that is believed to be twice the size of Texas.

headline: Barclays’ Remarkable Bargain
text: When is a good deal too good?

headline: On the Other End of a Hostile Takeover
text: Roger Carr, chairman of Cadbury, the British confectioner, was quick to dismiss Kraft’s $16.7 billion offer, calling it derisory. No less was expected from the leader of the Cadbury defense team. But it’s ironic that Mr. Carr’s resolve in an earlier hostile takeover battle may well have helped inspire Kraft’s latest move on Cadbury.

headline: Bloggingheads: Climate Change Odds
text: David W. Orr, left, author of "Down to the Wire," and Jim Manzi of National Review debate how much we should do to prevent climate change.

headline: Sony to Offer Film on Internet TV, Then DVD
text: In a nod to its vision of the future, Sony will make its animated hit “Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs” available to consumers directly through Internet-enabled televisions and Blu-ray players before the movie is released on DVD.

headline: Zimbabwe: Party Leader’s Trial Begins
text: The trial of Roy Bennett, a leader in the Movement for Democratic Change and its choice for deputy agriculture minister, started Monday amid signs that President Robert Mugabe and his ZANU-PF party were continuing to crack down on independent groups they see as political adversaries. In Victoria Falls, where two prominent civic leaders were arrested last month, four trade unionists, including the president of the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions, Lovemore Matombo, were jailed on charges of holding an illegal gathering, said Japhet Moyo, deputy secretary general of the labor federation. In Mr. Bennett’s case, his party claims that he is being persecuted and that he faces false terrorism charges. Mr. Mugabe has refused to swear him in as deputy minister in the power-sharing government with the M.D.C. unless he is acquitted.

headline: Trustee Seeks Billions for Madoff Investors
text: Jeffry M. Picower, a longtime investor in Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud scheme who died in his Palm Beach swimming pool last month, left an estate with assets far in excess of $1 billion  and that could be a spot of good news for Mr. Madoff’s victims.

headline: Striker Findley Stepped Up and Now May Get Shot With U.S.
text: Robbie Findley has the confidence of youth and the audacity necessary anywhere in the world to be a successful striker.

headline: Offering Hope in Haircuts for the Jobless
text: It was clear that Sunday was shaping up to be a rare shot of Indian summer, the ideal day for wandering through a park or lazing around on stoops or eating outdoors. But Theresa Cheung, 27, a fashion designer, had somewhere to be at 9:45 a.m., and a warm, golden day would not deter her. Freakishly perfect days are hard to come by in November, but they’re probably not as hard to come by as a good, free haircut at a New York salon. They’re also not as useful on a job interview.

headline: Australian Insurer Rejects Takeover Bid
text: HONG KONG  AXA Asia Pacific, the Australian unit of the French insurance giant AXA, rejected an unsolicited $10.2 billion takeover bid on Monday that was led by its parent.

headline: The Ban on Abortion Coverage
text: When the House narrowly passed the health care reform bill on Saturday night, it came with a steep price for women’s reproductive rights. Under pressure from anti-abortion Democrats and the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, lawmakers added language that would prevent millions of Americans from buying insurance that covers abortions  even if they use their own money.

headline: Foe of Gay Marriage in New York Says It’s Nothing Personal
text: ALBANY  Every Sunday morning, the deep, melodious voice of State Senator Rubén Díaz Sr. rumbles across the congregation at his Bronx church. On weekdays, it echoes across the Senate chamber as he rails against Medicaid cuts or abortion. Earlier this year, it enthralled thousands at a boisterous rally against same-sex marriage.

headline: Buying One, Buffett Aims to Sell Off 2 Railroads
text: Warren E. Buffett is looking to sell off his stakes in two big railroad companies, even as he recently announced a takeover of Burlington Northern Santa Fe.

headline: Week 9 Quick Hits: ‘Skins Are Bad to Bone
text: Andy Benoit has been writing the N.F.L. preview book series “Touchdown” since age 11. He is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: Charles P. Sifton, Judge in City Case on Term Limits, Dies at 74
text: Charles P. Sifton, a federal judge in Brooklyn whose rulings paved the way for women to join the New York Fire Department and for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to run for a third term, died Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 74.

headline: In Baseball, G.M.’s Meet Amid Signs of Austerity
text: CHICAGO  Baseball’s general managers and their staffs arrived throughout the day at the Hilton hotel in O’Hare International Airport on Monday, most of them walking through subway-style tunnels from the main terminals and up into the lobby. There, the view across the street was not of some lavish Pacific seascape, but of the two main concrete parking lots that serve the airport.

headline: Obama Seeks Revision of Plan’s Abortion Limits
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama suggested Monday that he was not comfortable with abortion restrictions inserted into the House version of major health care legislation, and he prodded Congress to revise them.

headline: A Squeeze on Customers Ahead of New Rules
text: Banks are struggling to make money in the credit card business these days, and consumers are paying the price. Interest rates are going up, credit lines are being cut and a variety of new fees are being imposed on even the best cardholders.

headline: Opening Up a Crowded Home After a Sister’s Death
text: The Fields household is jam-packed.

headline: Health Care Debate Moves to the Senate
text: As the health care reform bill moves to the Senate, Democrats will struggle to get the 60 votes needed to open the bill for debate.  David M. Herszenhorn reports.

headline: The Iron in the Fog
text: In the downtown dance world, the choreographer Tere O’Connor is “an essential figure, adored for his exquisitely constructed works, his mentoring and his fiercely articulated beliefs about all things related to dance,” writes Claudia La Rocco. His newest work, “Wrought Iron Fog,” uses different movement styles and a “delicately layered score” to give a glimpse, the choreographer said, of the “beauty you pass by quickly in the day,” the iron in the fog. The show opens today at DTW.

headline: Life Stories
text: The writer Zachary Lazar is adept at mingling real-life characters  like the Rolling Stones, the director Kenneth Anger and Manson family acolytes  in slightly tweaked situations; “Sway,” his second novel, “reads like your parents’ nightmare idea of what would happen to you if you fell under the spell of rock ’n’ roll,” Charles Taylor wrote. In his latest book,  “Evening’s Empire,”  Lazar investigates his own life; it’s a memoir about the murder of his father. He reads from it tonight at the KBG Bar’s nonfiction night, alongside  Sonja Livingston, the author of  “Ghostbread,”  about growing up poor in upstate New York.

headline: A New 'City'
text: Cue the farmboy extras:  “Cedar City Falls,”  a staged soap opera from  the “Sex and the City” writers, is “the sassy, salty story of a Midwestern town,” writes Patrick Healy, “where neighbors fall in and out of friendship (and bed) with one another and squabble over extramarital affairs, church choir rivalries, missing goats, DNA paternity tests  you know the drill.” Produced by Liz Tuccillo (a writer of  “He’s Just Not That Into You”) and three of her fellow SATC alums, it delivers snappy dialogue and special guest stars (like cast members from  “Mad Men”  and  “Law and Order” ) live every Tuesday this month at Galapagos. Go knock back a few beer-tinis.

headline: Bible That Vanished on Kristallnacht Is Heading Home
text: On Nov. 9, 1938, a two-volume black-leather-clad Hebrew Bible vanished from a library in Vienna after that city’s Jewish community came under assault from soldiers during Kristallnacht, the start of the Nazi pogrom against Jews.

headline: Sweets, by Hand and From the Heart
text: Chocolatier  now there is a delicious word a writer doesn’t get to use enough. But here is a chance, thanks to Kamila Myzel. A Polish asylum seeker who fled her country’s martial law crackdown before communism collapsed, Ms. Myzel, 50, opened her small sweets shop, Myzel’s Chocolate, at 140 West 55th Street, with her mother, Alina, in 1990 and has been provisioning Midtown’s sucrose-deprived ever since.

headline: Children Learn a Maxim in Case an Elevator Gets Stuck: ‘Ring, Relax and Wait’
text: It was the New York City version of elementary-school earthquake drills in small-town California: survival skills for vertical living.

headline: A Word, Mr. President
text: If I were a close adviser of President Obama’s, I would say to him, “Mr. President, you have two urgent and overwhelming tasks in front of you: to put Americans trapped in this terrible employment crisis back to work and to put the brakes on your potentially disastrous plan to escalate the war in Afghanistan.”

headline: Leetch and Lamoriello Take Place in Hall of Fame
text: The longtime Rangers defenseman Brian Leetch; the Devils’ president and general manager, Lou Lamoriello; and the former Rangers broadcaster John Davidson were among the inductees into the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto on Monday night.

headline: The Rush to Therapy
text: We’re all born late. We’re born into history that is well under way. We’re born into cultures, nations and languages that we didn’t choose. On top of that, we’re born with certain brain chemicals and genetic predispositions that we can’t control. We’re thrust into social conditions that we detest. Often, we react in ways we regret even while we’re doing them.

headline: Justices Consider the Role of Age in Life Sentences
text: WASHINGTON  A majority of the justices at two Supreme Court arguments on Monday seemed inclined to find a way to take account of the age of young offenders in deciding whether they may be sentenced to life without the possibility of parole.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Google and Authors Win Extension for Book Settlement
text: A federal judge in Manhattan on Monday granted an extension until Friday for a revised settlement of Google’s effort to legalize its plan to create a vast library of digital books.

headline: Financier to Head Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Unit
text: Joshua Gotbaum, an operating partner at the investment firm Blue Wolf Capital, is expected to be named director of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation by President Obama, the White House said Monday in a statement.

headline: Trustee May Win Billions for Investors in Madoff
text: Jeffry M. Picower, a longtime investor in Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme who died in his Palm Beach swimming pool last month, left an estate with assets far in excess of $1 billion — and that could be a spot of good news for Mr. Madoff’s victims, The New York Times’s Diana B. Henriques reports.

headline: Thought Experiment No. 1, and More Inappropriate Alarm Clocks
text: A short quiz, followed by responses to readers.

headline: After Fatal Fire, Many in Queens Denounce Illegal Apartment Conversions
text: After a fire in an illegal basement residence killed three men in Woodside, Queens, on Saturday came the refrain from borough residents: Not again.

headline: Associated Name
text: He was always very depressed. I think that if he’d been a successful criminal, he would have felt better. You know, he never made the “10 most wanted” list. It’s very unfair voting; it’s who you know. — Janet Margolin in today’s 1969 theme film

headline: The Short Life of a Diagnosis
text: Cambridge, England

headline: Surprising Victory in Seattle Mayor’s Race
text: SEATTLE  A former Sierra Club leader who rode his bicycle to campaign events and relied heavily on volunteer support claimed a narrow and surprising victory on Monday in the race for mayor of this environmentally friendly city.

headline: Flames’ Glencross Suspended Three Games for Hit on Rangers’ Drury
text: The N.H.L. announced Monday that it had suspended Flames forward Curtis Glencross three games for a blindside hit to Rangers center Chris Drury on Saturday night in Calgary.

headline: 24 Hour Plays: Intermission
text: Things got off to a very late start, and by the time introductions were over and the actual plays began it was close to 9 p.m.

headline: Fort Hood Struggles With Stressed Troops
text: The attack at Fort Hood, Tex., has focused attention on the level of crime and violence around the base since the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: Giants’ Bye Week Comes at Opportune Time
text: If the Giants (5-4) keep playing the way they did against San Diego on Sunday, they could win more games than they lose over the final seven and might even make the playoffs.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Sunday about the large gains for Wall Street bankers on stock grants and options awarded last year in lieu of cash bonuses misstated, in some editions, the value of some anticipated compensation, which the Treasury Department mandated be almost entirely in the form of stock. If performance goals are met, 19 executives at Citigroup will split $113 million, not $133 million, in stock this year, and 12 executives at Bank of America will share in $75.6 million, not $78.6 million. The article also misstated, in some editions, the value of the Citigroup options should the share value, which was around $4 on Friday, rebound to $12. The shares would then be worth $340 million, not $400 million.

headline: In So Many Words, the N.B.A. Redefined by Bill Simmons
text: It is nearly impossible to write about Bill Simmons’s new work, “The Book of Basketball,” without noting its heft: 697 pages, longer than his hero Bill Russell’s three memoirs (648 pages), weightier than Wilt Chamberlain’s two autobiographies (614 pages), but probably less wordy than Hubie Brown’s verbiage in any single game.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the police officer who shot the suspected gunman at Fort Hood misstated, in some editions, the make of the sports utility vehicle she owns. It is a Chevrolet Tahoe; there is no Ford Tahoe.

headline: At Army Base, Some Violence Is Too Familiar
text: FORT HOOD, Tex.  Staff Sgt. Gilberto Mota, 35, and his wife, Diana, 30, an Army specialist, had returned to Fort Hood from Iraq last year when he used his gun to kill her, and then took his own life, the authorities say. In July, two members of the First Cavalry Division, also just back from the war with decorations for their service, were at a party when one killed the other.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Sunday about the victims of the shootings at Fort Hood omitted the given name of the father of one victim. He is Juan Velez.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a new stock option program for Citigroup employees misstated the total number of options to be dispensed. Citigroup granted between 200 million and 300 million options, not two million to three million. As a result, the article also misstated the value of the options as of the close of trading Friday. The options had an expected value of almost $1.1 billion, not $11 million.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Monday with an article about Rent the Runway, an online dress rental company, reversed the identifications of the company’s founders in some copies. Jennifer Hyman is at the left and Jennifer Carter Fleiss is at the right.

headline: Corrections
text: Picture captions and credits in some editions on Monday with an article about the absence of a playoff system for college football were reversed in some copies. The top photograph showed Jordan Shipley of Texas and was by Brian Bahr of Getty Images. The bottom photograph showed Alabama’s Julio Jones after a 73-yard touchdown reception and was by Dave Martin of The Associated Press.

headline: Yanks’ Cashman Won’t Be Swayed
text: CHICAGO – Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman made it clear Monday that even if Hideki Matsui and Johnny Damon had gone 20 for 20 in the World Series with 10 home runs apiece, it would not change the team’s thinking about how it would deal with the two impending free agents.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a new lead producer for the coming Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” the troubled production that has ceased selling advance tickets, misidentified the firm that is handling those sales. It is Ticketmaster, not Telecharge.

headline: N.H.L. Scores: A Goal From Toews in Return to Blackhawks
text: One game on Monday, the night of the Hockey Hall of Fame induction ceremonies: the Los Angeles Kings, whose iconic player, Luc Robitaille, was among those being honored at the Hall in Toronto, vs. the Chicago Blackhawks, whose young captain Jonathan Toews was returning to action after missing the six previous games with a concussion. Home teams — er, home team listed first:

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Saturday with a dance review about the Cave New York Butoh Festival misidentified the performer in “Furnace,” which opened the festival. She is Stephanie Lanckton  not Ximena Garnica, an artistic director of the festival.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a newly published oral history of Joseph Papp and the Public Theater misspelled the surname of a collaborator who helped Papp create the theater. He is Bernard Gersten, not Gerstein.

headline: Corrections
text: A music review on Saturday about New York City Opera’s opening-night gala, using information provided by the company, misstated the title of one of the songs performed. It was “Soliloquy,” not “Billy’s Soliloquy,” from the musical “Carousel.”

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Navies of 2 Koreas Exchange Fire
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Naval patrol boats of North and South Korea exchanged fire in disputed waters off the western coast of the Korean Peninsula on Tuesday, the South Korean military said.

headline: When Women Rule, Things Are Just as Complicated
text: In the future foreseen in “What Once We Felt,” a new play by Ann Marie Healy that opened on Monday night at the Duke on 42nd Street, men are extinct, but Maker’s Mark is still readily available.

headline: Retirees Still Liable for Alimony, Massachusetts Court Rules
text: BOSTON  The highest court in Massachusetts ruled Monday that alimony should not automatically end when the paying spouse reaches retirement age and stops earning income.

headline: Antonio Luis Alves de Souza, Brazilian Drummer, Dies at 54
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Antonio Luis Alves de Souza, who led Olodum, a Brazilian percussion band notable for its social work as well as its music, and who lent his distinctive rhythms to a Paul Simon album and a Michael Jackson video, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Salvador da Bahia, Brazil. He was 54.

headline: Environmental Agency Warns 2 Staff Lawyers Over Video Criticizing Climate Policy
text: The Environmental Protection Agency has directed two of its lawyers to makes changes to a YouTube video they posted that is critical of the Obama administration’s climate change policy.

headline: Douglas’s Time May Have Arrived
text: Toney Douglas had his back turned to the news media as he slowly got dressed after the Knicks’ 95-93 loss to the Utah Jazz on Monday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Mets Will Look to Spend — On the Right Players
text: CHICAGO – Omar Minaya arrived at the general managers meetings with a specific shopping list for the off-season, and one that won’t surprise many people. The Mets need a thumper and a starting pitcher, badly.

headline: Democrats Raise Alarms Over Health Bill Costs
text: WASHINGTON  As health care legislation moves toward a crucial airing in the Senate, the White House is facing a growing revolt from some Democrats and analysts who say the bills Congress is considering do not fulfill President Obama’s promise to slow the runaway rise in health care spending.

headline: Counting Forward
text: More than three weeks after the official deadline, Iraq’s Parliament has approved an election law. That is very good news. It will allow Iraqis to hold parliamentary elections in January. And it should make it easier for President Obama to meet his pledge to withdraw all combat troops by the end of August.

headline: You Don’t Want to Be Downwind
text: More than eight years after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the House of Representatives has passed a bill to shore up security at this country’s chemical plants. The requirements are reasonable, vital and long overdue. If terrorists were to attack a chemical plant near an American city or large town, they could unleash a toxic cloud that could endanger the lives of hundreds of thousands.

headline: Promises on Open Space
text: In 1965, Congress came up with an elegant idea: Use some of the royalties from offshore oil and gas drilling to buy and conserve open space threatened by development. The dollars raised from depleting one natural resource would be used to protect another. Since then, the Land and Water Conservation Fund has invested more than $13 billion and added more than five million acres to the national parks, wildlife refuges and national forests.

headline: Abdul-Jabbar Goes Public With Leukemia Fight
text: In addition to his signature sky hook and a legacy of winning at every level, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was known for his stamina and fitness. During a 20-year N.B.A. career that included six championships and six Most Valuable Player awards, Abdul-Jabbar had one serious injury, a broken wrist. Other than that he had enjoyed a healthy career.

headline: As Knicks Look Ahead, the Present Sours Quickly
text: The Knicks are in a state of suspension, harboring a clear plan for the future with no one to bridge the gap. While they wait to sign someone from the heralded 2010 free-agent class, this season is quickly passing them by  even in its early stage.

headline: On Assignment: Fowl, but Photogenic
text: Chickens?

headline: Tweets Are Coming to LinkedIn
text: Twitter continues to spread its wings across the Web.

headline: Korean Navies Skirmish in Disputed Waters
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North and South Korean naval vessels exchanged fire in disputed waters off the western coast of the Korean Peninsula on Tuesday, leaving one North Korean vessel engulfed in flames, South Korean officials said.

headline: Are High-Tech Prostheses Fair?
text: The Issue

headline: Suffragettes Stone Lord Mayor’s Inaugural
text: Wednesday, Nov. 10, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Few Can Avoid Deployment, Experts Say
text: No matter how much a member of the armed services dreads being sent to a war zone, there is no easy option for an early discharge  especially when deployment is near.

headline: Trick for Democrats Is Juggling Ideology and Pragmatism
text: WASHINGTON  Democrats have displayed a striking degree of pragmatism in seeking to push the health care bill through Congress, embracing or rejecting ideological considerations as needed to keep the legislation moving.

headline: Report Says Foster System Keeps Children Too Long
text: Margaret, a 15-year-old, was placed in five different foster homes in a single year. Calvin, 18, spent 15 years being shuttled among his mother, aunt and a residential treatment center. Devin, a 13-year-old, has been in foster care his entire life, even though he wants to be adopted.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,350 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 905 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

headline: Evelyn Hofer, Subtle Photographer of People and Places, Dies at 87
text: Evelyn Hofer, a photographer whose searching, exactingly composed portraits imparted a grave serenity to her human and architectural subjects and who collaborated on a renowned series of travel books with eminent writers in the 1950s and 1960s, died on Nov. 2 in Mexico City. She was 87 and lived in Mexico City.

headline: 24 Hour Plays: And That Was That
text: Three more short plays went off without any noticeable glitches in the second act of the 24 Hour Plays (a curious one, a funny one and a very naughty one), and then it was off to a huge post-show bash at a nearby club. How are these people still standing up?

headline: 'Dreamgirls' at the Apollo
text: Backstage photos of the national tour of “Dreamgirls,” which opens at the Apollo Theater in Harlem.

headline: Working From Memory
text: WHO is the man in this photo?

headline: Amid I.P.O. Slide, Korean Bourse Attracts Listings
text: Even as Hong Kong begins to show signs of I.P.O. fatigue, several foreign companies have turned to Seoul, and are seeking to list their shares on South Korea’s secondary stock market in a bid to tap liquidity there, the operator of the bourse said Tuesday.

headline: California: Promise to Speed Naturalization Applications
text: Immigration authorities have agreed to complete 90 percent of naturalization applications from immigrants in Southern California within six months, in a lawsuit settlement that was approved by a federal judge in Santa Ana. The suit was filed in 2007 by the National Immigration Law Center and the American Civil Liberties Union, on behalf of immigrants seeking to become citizens whose applications had stalled for years because of delays with background checks. As a result of the suit, the court required the F.B.I. and Citizenship and Immigration Services to report regularly on their progress in reducing backlogs nationwide. Linton Joaquin, general counsel for the law center, said the agencies had significantly reduced the backlogs, with about 400 cases remaining in the Los Angeles area covered by the settlement.

headline: Word of the Day | sanctimonious
text: sanctimonious • \ˌsaN(k)-tə-ˈmo-ne-əs, -nyəs\ • adjective

headline: News Quiz | November 10, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Cadbury’s Cold Response to Kraft
text: Kraft took its $16.7 billion bid for Cadbury, the British chocolate and chewing gum maker, directly to shareholders on Monday after the Cadbury board rejected the offer as too low, Julia Werdigier and Michael J. de la Merced write in The New York Times.

headline: Big Week for Small-College Players
text: Some of the biggest plays Sunday were made by players from some of the nation’s smaller football programs.

headline: Morgan Stanley Seeks Buyer for Stake in China Bank
text: Morgan Stanley is seeking a buyer for its 34 percent stake in an investment bank, China International Capital Corporation, Wei Sun Christianson, the American bank’s China chief, said on Monday.

headline: Cadbury Chief Knows Both Sides of Hostile Bids
text: Roger Carr, chairman of Cadbury, the British confectioner, was quick to dismiss Kraft’s $16.7 billion offer, calling it derisory. No less was expected from the leader of the Cadbury defense team. But it’s ironic that Mr. Carr’s resolve in an earlier hostile takeover battle may well have helped inspire Kraft’s latest move on Cadbury, Breakingviews.com says.

headline: Barclays’ Remarkable Bargain
text: In the panic that swept the financial world last year, Lehman Brothers went bankrupt, and Barclays bought its securities for about $45 billion in cash. Now, some creditors to Lehman’s estate are saying that is about $5 billion less than they should have gone for, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: The TASC Deal: A New Old-Fashioned Buyout?
text: The private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and General Atlantic are going back to the future with their latest buyout. They are buying Northrop Grumman‘s defense consulting division, TASC, for $1.65 billion.

headline: South Korea Considers Allowing Poison Pills
text: South Korea, where foreign funds have increased their holdings in some large companies’ stocks, is seeking to introduce a poison pill scheme to protect companies from being taken over.

headline: Japan Pledges $5 Billion in New Afghan Aid
text: HONG KONG  Japan said Tuesday that it would sharply increase its nonmilitary aid to Afghanistan, pledging $5 billion for a range of projects that include building schools and highways, training police officers, clearing land mines and rehabilitating former Taliban fighters.

headline: Sands Seeks $3.3 Billion in Hong Kong I.P.O.
text: Shares of Las Vegas Sands rose 7 percent on Monday after the casino operator said it would look to raise up to $3.35 billion through an initial public offering of shares in its Macau business.

headline: Tweets Are Coming to LinkedIn
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: BioVex Said to Raise Another $30 Million
text: BioVex, a Woburn, Mass.-based biotechnology company that raised $40 million in venture capital in March to develop a novel cancer-fighting treatment, plans to announce Tuesday that it has raised another $30 million, The Boston Globe reported.

headline: Financial Regulations Chief Chides British Banks
text: Many senior banking executives failed to accept responsibility for the financial crisis and neglected the need to change their behavior, Hector Sants, the chief executive at Britain’s financial industry regulatory body, said Monday.

headline: Electronic Arts Buys Playfish — and Plans Layoffs
text: Electronic Arts, the video game company, announced that it had acquired Playfish, a start-up that makes online games, even as it said it would lay off 1,500 workers and shrink its product lineup.

headline: Talbots Said to Tap Perella to Advise on Debt
text: Talbots, the women’s clothing chain, has hired the boutique adviser Perella Weinberg Partners to help it refinance about $225 million in debt, Bloomberg News reported, citing two people familiar with the situation.

headline: Market Rally Continues in Asia
text: If the economy is getting stronger, why is the dollar getting weaker?

headline: Soshokukei Danshi
text: A Japanese term – “herbivorous males” – used to describe men who choose to engage in traditionally female pursuits.

headline: Are ‘Dark’ Movies OK For Kids?
text: When it comes to the movies, many adults would like to shield children and teens from difficult material, while others believe that watching “dark” movies is entirely appropriate — and even beneficial — for kids. What do you think? What kinds of movies do you like to watch, and why?This season’s movies for children include “Where the Wild Things Are,” “Fantastic Mr. Fox” and “Christmas Carol,” all of which explore dark themes and contain scenes that some may find frightening. Times movie reviewer A. O. Scott wonders whether including darker content in children’s films is not only appropriate, but also desirable. He considers “the interesting controversy that has enveloped ‘Where the Wild Things Are,’ and expanded into the latest wide-ranging adult argument about the feelings of children”:

headline: Blue Wolf Exec to Head U.S. Pension Agency
text: Update | Nov. 13, 5:29 p.m. Joshua Gotbaum, an operating partner at the private equity firm Blue Wolf Capital, is expected to be named director of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation by President Obama, the White House said Monday.

headline: American Airlines Chief Brings JAL Battle Public

text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.
