headline: Giants Stadium Countdown: Sehorn’s Interception
text: John Maxymuk, author of “The 50 Greatest Plays in New York Giants Football History,” is helping us count down to the final game at Giants Stadium. His latest book is “Quarterback Abstract.”

headline: Cisco Announces $5 Billion Debt Sale
text: Cisco Systems, the world’s largest maker of computer networking equipment, said Monday it would sell three series of senior unsecured notes worth a total of $5 billion.

headline: SAC Finds No Suspicious Trading, Report Says
text: SAC Capital Advisors, run by Steven A. Cohen, has reviewed trading documents cited in the Galleon Group insider-trading case, but the hedge fund has found nothing suspicious, Bloomberg News reported, citing one of SAC’s investors.

headline: HSBC and Barclays Earnings On Different Tracks
text: Britain’s two largest banks painted a strikingly different picture of their businesses in the third quarter Tuesday when HSBC said earnings rose as loan provisions fell, and Barclays reported the opposite.

headline: Qatar Fund to Sell Up to 25 Million VW Shares
text: Qatar Holding, part of the Gulf country’s sovereign wealth fund, plans to sell as many as 25 million of its preferred shares in Volkswagen, or about half its total stake in the carmaker, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Why Paper Receipts Won’t Die
text: Today’s idea: Paper receipts are vestiges of the analog past and ought to go the way of the dodo bird, a writer says. But they probably won’t any time soon because of the expense and privacy concerns.

headline: Wild Kingdom | Barber Osgerby for the Rug Company
text: Our fun-for-all-ages winter issue of T Design and Living is out, but the great designs for the young, not to mention the young at heart, just keep coming. (Stay tuned for more later in the week.) Case in point: the four witty, whimsical rugs that the London designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby have done for the Rug Company. Colorful and graphic, each rug depicts a different member of the animal kingdom and reflects its nature, from the solitary owl against its night-sky background to an acid-green snake that seems to slither off the edge of its rug. A pair of butterflies and an adorable school of fish round out the designs, which cost $3,285 or $4,725, depending on size. Barber Osgerby’s designs have the playful simplicity of children’s-book illustrations, but they’re so sophisticated that you’ll likely be seeing them in grown-up rooms, too.

headline: In Trial, Marriage Settlement Haunts Ex-KB Chief
text: A federal judge in Los Angeles has rebuffed an effort by the former chief executive of the building giant KB Homes to exclude materials related to his marriage settlement and other evidence during his upcoming trial for allegedly manipulating stock options.

headline: Cuban Says Fans Ask Him to Buy Dodgers
text: After failing to snag the Chicago Cubs, Mark Cuban is apparently still keeping his eye out for a baseball team to add to his stable.

headline: Better Cards From Credit Unions
text: When I read articles about aggressive price increases among the big players in the credit card industry, like the one Andrew Martin and Lowell Bergman wrote for the front page of Tuesday’s New York Times, I often wonder why consumers who borrow money using plastic are dealing with these card issuers in the first place.

headline: Hedge Funds to Top $2 Trillion in 2010?
text: The hedge fund industry may streak past its $2 trillion record high by the end of next year, as improved returns have lured back investors, said Barry Bausano, Deutsche Bank’s global co-head of prime finance.

text: Bay Bridge Changes | After Monday’s fatal big rig crash on the bridge, authorities will add more reflective striping and install radar boards telling drivers how fast they are going in an effort to slow them down.

headline: Lloyds to Cut Another 5,000 Jobs by 2011

headline: European Antitrust Inquiry Into Reuters Data Feed
text: European Union antitrust regulators launched an investigation on Tuesday into news and financial data publisher Thomson Reuters‘s use of its real-time market data feed, saying it might block users moving to rival firms.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday: Health Care Elsewhere, ‘NCIS’ and Ghost-Hunting
text: PBS’s “Frontline” offers a timely repeat of a 2008 program called “Sick Around the World” (PBS, 9 p.m. on most stations). In one fast-moving hour, it examines the health care and insurance systems of five countries, including Britain, Japan and Germany, and makes the case that supporters of health-care reform in America have failed to make over the last year. A review of the program is here.

headline: Gloomy Energy Report Sets the Stage for Climate Talks
text: As the world heads for tough negotiations over a global climate deal next month, an influential forecasting agency said on Tuesday that current energy policies were not sustainable, and that a vast transformation of energy use was required to fend off the worst consequences of global warming.

headline: Wanted: Grateful Dead Archivist
text: The unemployment rate may top 10 percent, but there is an opening at the University of California, Santa Cruz, for a Deadhead. The library is advertising for an archivist to handle the library’s Grateful Dead collection. A master’s degree in archives management is required, as is “expert knowledge in the history of and scholarship of contemporary popular music, or American vernacular culture, preferably the history and influence of the Grateful Dead.”

headline: Connecting Cars to Avoid Speeding Tickets
text: PARIS — Car-to-car communication is a dream of traffic researchers. Radar, video and other sensors in a car would understand the environment around it and communicate such information as sudden braking, rainfall and speed to the receptors in other cars, enabling other drivers to avoid accidents and congestion.

headline: Car Bomb Adds to Toll in Northwest Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  The third bomb in three days went off in a crowded intersection in a town in northwestern Pakistan on Tuesday, killing at least 34 civilians and offering a grim marker of the mounting violence around the northwestern Pakistani city of Peshawar.

According to Matthew Flamm at Crain’s New York Business, the online retailer flew a dozen of New York’s top literary agents out to its headquarters in Seattle for a friendly chat and to suggest that its aggressive discounting of books and sales of e-books is designed to help the business of publishing, not destroy it.

headline: Financing Challenges for Geothermal Power
text: With just over 70 operating plants offering capacity of around 3,100 megawatts, the United States is the global leader in generating electrical power from geothermal resources, according to a recent report from Islandsbanki, an Icelandic bank that provides investment and financial services to the sustainable energy sector.

headline: Entrepreneurs in Congress Say No to Health Care Reform

headline: The plural of anecdote is data
text: For various reasons I’ve been doing a lot of walking around the past few days, in both Princeton and New York, visiting areas I haven’t looked at for several months. And I’m not sure what to make of it, but casual observation suggests a stronger recovery than anything I see in published numbers. Lots of small-scale construction — home remodeling, tear-downs replacing old houses. Many new businesses and restaurants filling storefronts that were vacant a couple of months ago.

headline: Twitter Book and Now Twitter TV Show
text: Justin Halpern, the author of a rather tartly named Twitter account, has landed a book deal and a deal with CBS for a comedy based on the premise. Mr. Halpern’s Twitter account, rendered here as “(Stuff) My Dad Says,” has 700,000 followers. According to The Hollywood Reporter, Mr. Halpern signed a book deal with HarperCollins last month and CBS decided there must be a television show in there somewhere.

headline: Wanted: New Lead Singer for Aerosmith
text: Know any dudes who look like ladies? Aerosmith is looking for a new lead singer, the band announced late Monday, via the guitarist Joe Perry’s Twitter stream. The announcement follows an interview that the band’s frontman, Steven Tyler, gave to a British music magazine in which he said he was interested in pursuing a solo career, “working on the brand of myself – Brand Tyler.”

headline: Bronx Film Screening Fosters Nostalgia for ‘the Coops’
text: Eighty years ago, the United Workers Cooperative Colony in the Bronx was more than just a housing complex for an enclave of secular Jews — many of them communists, socialists, anarchists and their sympathizers. “The Coops,” as this community of two square blocks is commonly called, once housed their own restaurant, gym, youth clubs, grocery store and day care center. Built next to the spacious Bronx Park, the Coops still have lush gardens in their courtyards and the hammer and sickle adorning the doors.

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': Dostoyevsky’s Beasts

headline: An Uncomfortable Truth
text: JURM, Afghanistan – I got a lesson on a recent reporting trip in northern Afghanistan in what not to say to a mullah.

headline: Fresh Demands From ‘Front-Line States’ in Climate Fight
text: The “climate divide” between countries that are rich and poor, insulated from climate impacts and vulnerable to them, was on vivid display in the Maldives over the last few days. Countries that consider themselves most threatened by human-driven global warming — mainly places exposed to the sea or reliant on rainfall — concluded a forum there and issued a declaration of their concerns and demands. Mike Shanahan of the International Institute for Environment and Development sent the text, which I have included below.

headline: Now Listening | The XX, ‘Basic Space’
text: How long does it take for the Next Big Thing to actually become a big thing? We’ve been hearing whispers about the London band the XX since late summer, when they released their superb debut album, “XX,” in Europe — and a whisper is the appropriate register for this music, with its wispy vocals and sparse arrangements that echo a range of styles from old-school soul to modern-day trip-hop. The record’s October release stateside brought more praise (including this from The New York Times); and a month-long United States tour, kicking off tomorrow in New York, may be just what the band needs to bring the whispers to a roar.The four-piece band already seems wise beyond its years (each member is barely 20 years old), and for the video for their first single, “Basic Space” (above), they made a clever choice in hiring Anthony Dickenson, an up-and-coming British director and photographer. Dickenson recently picked up a UK Music Video Award for this music video from Speech Debelle and is currently at work on a photo project that will be exhibited next year. The “Basic Space” video warrants watching in high definition — it’s a cool experiment with light, speed and focus that fits perfectly with the XX’s minimalist aesthetic.

headline: Parade of Poor Play

headline: President, at Service, Hails Fort Hood’s Fallen
text: FORT HOOD, Tex.  President Obama took on the role of national eulogist on Tuesday for the first time since assuming office as he led the country in mourning 13 active and retired soldiers gunned down not on a foreign battlefield but here on their home post by one of their own.

headline: Travel Deals: Holiday Fare Sale
text: Airline experts have warned that airfare will be soaring this holiday season. But there are exceptions: Expedia is offering a Holiday Fare Sale for travel between Nov. 19 and Jan. 4, with round-trip fares as low as $102.

headline: Inside Out | Forging Ahead
text: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

headline: Hoodie Magic Wears Off for McDaniels
text: Perhaps the most significant development of the latest “Monday Night Football” game was the severe devaluation of the hoodie. Just a few weeks ago, Broncos Coach Josh McDaniels was the latest genius from the Bill Belichick family of geniuses and the one brave enough to mimic the master’s taste for haute couture. Now, we’ll have whatever Steelers Coach Mike Tomlin is wearing, please. If the master himself loses to the Colts this weekend, the hoodie might find its way back to the clearance rack at Big Lots. And the fashion world will rejoice.

headline: Tropical Storm Ida Weakens as It Moves Ashore
text: MIAMI  Tropical Storm Ida brought heavy rain and gusty winds to the Gulf Coast on Tuesday, arriving in Dauphin Island, Ala., just before dawn then weakening as it moved northeast through the Florida panhandle.

headline: City Prepares for Law Allowing Bikes in Buildings
text: In less than a month, office buildings in New York will begin to fill with bicycles. A new law requiring building managers to allow riders to take their bikes upstairs will go into effect on Dec. 11, and already, the city’s Department of Transportation is offering commuters some guidance on what to expect.

headline: The Massive Maclaren Recall
text: In announcing a recall of about one million strollers yesterday, the Maclaren stroller company has illustrated yet again that it’s not nice to mishandle parents online.

headline: Fiasco Theater’s ‘Cymbeline,’ Round 2

But a company called Fiasco (fiascotheater.com) made enough of an impression with its first full-scale production, a rousing “Cymbeline” in September, that it is already bringing it back for an encore.

Her older sister Judi learned that she had melanoma at age 46 and died eight months later. Her younger sister Peggy, who never smoked, received a diagnosis of nonsmall-cell lung cancer and died 14 months later, just shy of her 45th birthday.

headline: Jock Art | Andy Warhol Polaroids
text: There is a small gem of a show at Danziger Projects right now, featuring a little-known trove of Polaroids by Andy Warhol of famous athletes. They were commissioned by one collector in the late 1970s and early ’80s. The simplicity of Warhol’s method — straightforward portraits shot with the Big Shot camera — gives the tiny images (4 1/4″ x 3 3/8″) a purity and sincerity that belies the radiance and aura of greatness coming from the sitters. Even today, there is something tingle-inducing about seeing Muhammad Ali, Dorothy Hamill, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Chris Evert, Pelé, Tom Seaver and Wayne Gretzky captured at the height of their youthfulness and fame. These portraits, made by the ultimate connoisseur of fame himself, have aged beautifully. The show is up through Dec. 12 at 534 West 24th Street.

headline: An Evening Wine Bar Is Set to Open at Bouley Bakery
text: The white corner room of Bouley Bakery an elegant space where customers can eat breakfasts and lunches they purchased in the bakery, will morph into a wine bar during the evening, starting Nov. 17.

headline: Minorities in Iraq’s North Seen as Threatened
text: ERBIL, Iraq  The policies and tactics of Kurdish authorities could expose minority groups in northern Iraq to “another full-blown human rights catastrophe” unless the minorities receive better protection, according to a report released Tuesday by Human Rights Watch.

headline: No Boost in PC Sales After Windows 7
text: Did you put off buying a new computer after the launch of Microsoft’s Windows 7 operating system?

headline: Are Too Many Students Going to College?
text: The editors of The Chronicle of Higher Education have posed that potentially incendiary question and asked a collection of experts to engage in a rolling conversation in response. You can read the dialogue, which was posted Monday, by clicking here.

headline: App of the Week: A Streamlined Social Mash-Up
text: Dedicated social networkers practically have a full-time job jockeying a phone browser around Facebook, Twitter, texts, and who knows what else. But app makers are building virtual assistants to streamline those tasks. You may have seen ads for the Motorola Cliq with Motoblur, which consolidates all your communications on one screen.

headline: For G.M., Work at Opel Includes Mending Fences
text: A week after angering German politicians and labor leaders by calling off plans to sell Opel to a group backed by Berlin, senior General Motors executives promised more independence for the European unit.

headline: Parting Glance: Evelyn Hofer, 1922-2009
text: Evelyn Hofer, 87, was a flawless technician and a much sought-after teacher, who searched for an “inside value, some interior respect” in the people she photographed. She favored carefully composed scenes with a still, timeless aura, William Grimes notes, in reporting her death on Nov. 2.

headline: Divided Landmarks Panel Splits Decision on Midtown Buildings
text: After hearing objections from a property developer that is trying to build a tall luxury hotel opposite Carnegie Hall, a divided Landmarks Preservation Commission voted on Tuesday to give landmark protection to the century-old B. F. Goodrich Building in Midtown Manhattan, while shelving a proposal to give the same protection to a nearby eight-story building.

headline: ‘Opt-Out’ Proposal Puts State Leaders to the Test
text: ATLANTA  In the two weeks since the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, embraced a proposal that would allow states to opt out of a new government health insurance plan, state leaders have begun debating whether to take part, and the question has emerged as a litmus test in some campaigns for governor.

headline: Update: Another Tough Night for Leno
text: Another Monday, another night of low ratings for Jay Leno.

headline: Video of the Pikes Peak Audi TTS in Action
text: Last week, we reported on the autonomous Audi TTS being developed by a team from Stanford University, Volkswagen’s Electronics Research Lab and Sun Microsystems.

headline: N.Y. Senate Delays Vote on Gay Marriage Bill
text: The Times’s Jeremy Peters reports that the New York State Senate has indefinitely postponed a vote on the gay marriage bill. See full article.

headline: A Rabbinical Student and the Ring
text: Yuri Foreman, an undefeated professional boxer who will fight for the World Boxing Association 154-pound title, is studying to become a rabbi.

headline: Bomb Material Cache Uncovered in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  With fertilizer bombs now the most lethal weapons used against American and NATO soldiers in southern Afghanistan, the bomb-making operation in Kandahar was something close to astonishing.

headline: Letterman Suspect Wanted to Sell, Not Extort, Lawyer Says
text: Robert Joel Halderman was simply trying to sell a story, not extort money, when he delivered a one-page screenplay proposal and other evidence to David Letterman in September about Mr. Letterman’s affairs with women who worked for him, according to Gerald L. Shargel, Mr. Halderman’s lawyer.

headline: Know Your Market Before You Leap
text: While it is hard to argue with Peter Drucker’s much-quoted aphorism that “the purpose of a business is to create and keep a customer,” it does raise a question. What is the best way to discover whether customers want what you’re selling before you open your doors or before you add a new product or service to your line?

headline: Ads That Pat on the Back, or Slap on the Wrist
text: Liberal interest groups in favor of overhauling the health care system are taking different tacks in trying to advance their goals, at least as far as advertising goes.

headline: The Morning Skate: Will General Managers Act on Head Shots?
text: The N.H.L. general managers are meeting today and tomorrow in Toronto and David Shoalts in The Globe and Mail writes, “Head shots will dominate the agenda,” although he thinks that “adopting an on-ice penalty directed at them is still a long shot.”

headline: New Models for Environmental Communication
text: Even as the old “that’s the way it is” model of mass media is increasingly tested by the Web, there are interesting experiments under way that show how far-flung, yet important, issues like marine pollution can still be effectively covered. One surfaced today in a Science Times article by Lindsey Hoshaw, known on Twitter as @thegarbagegirl. The feature is an up-close examination of the Pacific Ocean’s vast patch of plastic flotsam, reported with travel money provided by readers of Spot.us.

headline: The Dusenberry Diary: Living the Dream? Or Just Living?
text: As some of you will recall, I have been following the progress of (and offering advice to) Debbie Dusenberry, the owner of a home-furnishing and gift store in Kansas called Curious Sofa. You can read “When Passion Meets Math” to see how Ms. Dusenberry built her store, garnered lots of media attention for her merchandising, ran smack into the Great Recession and began the journey from artist to businesswoman. This small-business journey is far more common than most people understand. Ms. Dusenberry is so good at the artistry that she is envied by other owners, one of whom has called her “retail royalty.” But as you will see in a moment, her retail reality is very different.

headline: Talks Begin to Move ‘The 39 Steps’ Off Broadway
text: The Broadway producers of “Alfred Hitchcock’s The 39 Steps” have opened negotiations to move the quick-witted play to the Off Broadway venue New World Stages next year, according to the show’s lead producer, Bob Boyett. “The 39 Steps” is scheduled to close on Broadway on Jan. 10 after almost three years.

headline: A Lift for a Planned  Financial Protection Agency
text: The creation of a Consumer Financial Protection Agency got another lift with its inclusion in a sweeping overhaul of the financial regulatory system proposed Tuesday by Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut and the chairman of the Senate banking committee.

headline: Art Show Shines Light on Sex Trafficking’s Victims
text: The room is recreated with exquisite attention to detail: a scribbled price list for sexual services on a whiteboard. A large bowl with condoms spilling onto the end table. Half-used lipstick scattered among twisted thongs, high heels and toilet paper. A sickly perfume-type smell that clings to the torn wallpaper. A grimy stained bed designed to shudder under the weight of invisible, moving bodies. Men’s voices that alternately issue commands and groans.

headline: Can the World Reach an Agreement on Climate Change?
text: Over the last three months, The New York Times has been asking stakeholders for their thoughts and predictions for on the climate change meeting in Copenhagen.

headline: Should the Government Pay People to Work Less?
text: My colleague Steven Greenhouse wrote last June about the record for work-sharing programs. Under such programs, employers reduce their workers’ weekly hours and pay. The government then pays workers some, or all, of their lost wages. The best-known work-sharing program is in Germany, but other developed countries have adopted it, as have many American states.

headline: A Photo Essay of Multiple Sclerosis
text: The Lens blog is featuring a moving photo essay of self portraits taken by Patricia Lay-Dorsey, 67, who learned in 1988 that she has chronic progressive multiple sclerosis. James Estrin, a photographer for The New York Times who wrote an accompanying story about Ms. Lay-Dorsey, explains:

headline: Remarks of President Barack Obama
text: Remarks of President Obama, as Prepared for Delivery for the memorial service at Fort Hood, Tex.

headline: Judge Rules Shepard Fairey Can Get New Lawyer
text: The street artist Shepard Fairey has won the right to a new lawyer in his ongoing suit against The Associated Press over the image that became his celebrated Barack Obama “Hope” poster. In a pretrial hearing, U.S. District Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein also allowed that lawyers for The A.P. can depose Mr. Fairey and his outgoing lawyers before the end of the year, The A.P. reported. The agency and the artist are countersuing each other over the rights to the image, a photo taken in April 2006 at an event at the National Press Club in Washington. Mr. Fairey recently admitted that he had lied publicly and to his own lawyers about which image he had used, which caused them to abandon his case.

headline: Former Astronaut Makes Plea Deal
text: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the former astronaut whose drive to Florida from Texas to confront a romantic rival briefly dominated the news and late-night comics’ routines, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to felony burglary of a car and misdemeanor battery as part of a plea bargain.

headline: Officials: U.S. Aid Chief Chosen
text: After months of delays because of tangled vetting procedures, the Obama administration plans to name Rajiv J. Shah as the administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, officials familiar with the appointment said on Tuesday.

headline: This Birth Annnouncement Coming to You Live from the Delivery Room
text: If you want to relive the magic or trauma — or both — of childbirth, you might want to check out the live streamed (now recorded) birth of Solveig, who was born on a live streaming video. Lynsee, his mother, is a former teacher and she decided to have her baby on live web video as an educational gesture. (She is a saint during the whole process, which may explain her generous nature.)

headline: On Saturday, Rabbi-to-Be Throws Jabs
text: Yuri Foreman stepped up to the top bench of the banya to embrace the soothing power of the heat. The beads of sweat bubbled and greased his skin. He shuttered his eyes and felt the problem immediately. The sauna was too hot.

headline: Cultural Bent Hangs Over Oracle’s Battle for Sun
text: Oracle’s battle with European regulators over its acquisition of Sun Microsystems boils down to a conflict about the importance of free software and the government’s role in protecting it.

headline: Getty Institute Will Work With Egypt to Conserve King Tut’s Tomb
text: The Getty Conservation Institute in Los Angeles said on Tuesday that it had entered into a five-year partnership with Egypt to help conserve and manage the tomb of Tutankhamen, whose striking wall paintings have been pocked with brown spots at least since the tomb’s discovery in 1922.

headline: Berth of a Cruise Ship: World’s Biggest Gets a Home
text: When the Oasis of the Seas, the world’s largest cruise ship, departed Finland on its maiden voyage on Oct. 30, it barely squeezed under Denmark’s Great Belt Bridge, with less than two feet to spare. There will be no such close calls when the Oasis, owned by Royal Caribbean International, docks in its new home, Cruise Terminal 18, a huge complex that opened Nov. 8, at Port Everglades, Fla.

headline: A Minimalist Christens a New Space
text: PARIS | Lucio Fontana was so handy with a knife he could probably have made a living as an old-school hit man. Instead he became an artist, and a pivotal one at that. Through what he called his “concetto spaziale,” or spatial concept, he exerted a huge influence on 20th-century modernist art.

headline: 10 Years of Selling Books in an Online Age
text: The seemingly endless recession, the growing attraction of Kindles and the steady shuttering of bookstores gave the owners of one bookstore in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, even more reason to celebrate today. They’re still open.

headline: There Are Three Kinds of Fool
text: Today’s idea: There are three types of fool, an essay says, and no one’s immune: You’re one, at one time or another. Sometimes it’s even smart to play the fool.

headline: Now Serving | PDT’s Humm Dog
text: What do you get when you cross a hot dog with a four-star chef? A Humm dog.

headline: Phelps Falters at a Meet in Stockholm
text: Michael Phelps’s presence on a United States team competing this week at a World Cup meet in Stockholm is akin to Meryl Streep’s gracing a traveling production of “Mamma Mia!” Phelps, a 14-time Olympic gold medalist, is a headliner among up-and-comers on the national youth World Cup team.

headline: Train the Mind to Run Right Through Winter
text: IN late summer, Sharon Henderson, the manager of the Lululemon athletic clothing store in my town, started organizing Saturday morning group runs. People had two options: three miles at a slower pace or six miles at a faster one.

headline: Backwater Borders and the Hikers Accused of Spying on Iran
text: Three graduates of University of California, Berkeley have been accused by the Iranian government’s top prosecutor of spying. The three were arrested after crossing into Iranian territory during a hike in northern Iraq at the end of July.

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': And the Visuals for Dostoyevsky?
text: The goat and the dog would be easy enough to get on stage, if Janacek had written them into the opera (preferably without the slaughter), and even the horse.

headline: Intel Sells Its Own Reader for the Health Care Market
text: Intel’s push into the health care arena has the company going some unusual places.

headline: Obama’s Remarks at Ft. Hood Service
text: On the eve of Veterans Day, President Obama spoke on Tuesday at the Ft. Hood memorial service for the victims of last week’s shootings. Here is the text of his remarks.

headline: 2 Bear Stearns Fund Leaders Are Acquitted
text: It was, prosecutors claimed, a clear case of Wall Street crime  and a chance to bring to account two culprits of the subprime age.

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': The Director’s Style
text: To most culture-friendly Americans, Patrice Chéreau, the French director of the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Janacek’s opera “From the House of the Dead,” is probably best known as a movie director with an eclectic, adventurous style and exotic tastes.

headline: Bear Stearns Managers Acquitted of Fraud Charges
text: Louis Lanzano/The Associated Press The former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers Ralph Cioffi, left, on Monday and Matthew Tannin on Tuesday.

headline: From Concrete to Memory: Scrapbooking the Berlin Wall
text: Overview | How can we best understand how and why historical events happened, as well as how and why they are significant? In this lesson, students consider how ordinary citizens contributed to and experienced the fall of the Berlin Wall. They then develop scrapbooks depicting how people experienced the wall and use the books as symbolic bricks in building a classroom Berlin Wall.

headline: From Peaceful Gettysburg to the Battlefield of Iraq
text: Two surprises are in store for those who tune in to “Return to Duty” on Wednesday night on MTV.

headline: So You Think You Can Balance the Budget?
text: So you think you can balance the budget?

headline: Iraqi Skeleton Athlete Taking Another Shot
text: Faisal Faisal, who tried to qualify in skeleton as Iraq’s only Winter Olympian in 2006, is racing again this season and trying to qualify for the Vancouver Games.

headline: A Cheap Nest for Fledgling Firms
text: When Lindsay Napor expanded her Manhattan-based development company earlier this year  moving out of free work space provided by an investor  she turned to the most logical place for the company’s new offices: New Jersey.

headline: Blair Hails Economic Steps in West Bank
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Palestinians marked two significant economic breakthroughs on Tuesday, counterpoints to the growing crisis in peace negotiations with Israel: a second cellphone company opened, with a planned investment of hundreds of millions of dollars; and a long-closed crossing point from Israel opened to limited motor traffic.

headline: Letterman Suspect Wanted to Sell, Not Extort, Lawyer Says
text: Robert Joel Halderman was simply trying to sell a story, not extort money, when he delivered a one-page screenplay proposal and other evidence to David Letterman in September about Mr. Letterman’s affairs with women who worked for him, according to Gerald L. Shargel, Mr. Halderman’s lawyer.

headline: In the Caribbean, Good Deals but Not a Fire Sale
text: AFTER a year of dismal bookings and deep discounts, travel to the Caribbean is beginning to pick up, allowing resorts to be more selective with sales this year. But it’s still possible for travelers to nab a deal, especially if they’re flexible.

headline: Bill Clinton Urges Fast Action by Senate Democrats
text: Former President Bill Clinton joined Senate Democrats for their weekly luncheon on Tuesday and urged them to band together and quickly pass health care legislation.

headline: Plunging Though Musical Thickets and Open Plains
text: During chamber music concerts, even if the whole performance is first-rate, there is sometimes one riveting moment in which the ensemble seems particularly cohesive. When the excellent Keller Quartet made its debut at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday afternoon, that moment came in the slow movement of Beethoven’s String Quartet in F (Op. 135).

headline: Kerik Released on Bail to Await Sentencing
text: WHITE PLAINS  Former Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik was released on bail Tuesday, five days after pleading guilty to eight felonies that included tax fraud and lying to White House officials.

headline: Prognosis: Lingering Pain After Surgery for Breast Cancer
text: Breast cancer patients often experience pain that persists long after surgery, and a new Danish study has found that the problem affects a large proportion of women. Almost half the patients reported chronic pain two to three years after treatment, and more than half reported discomfort.

headline: Kitsch of the Day | The Weezer Snuggie
text: No single piece of clothing says “neutered invertebrate” or “cult member” quite like the Snuggie (“the blanket with sleeves!”). For more than a year, these large, shapeless swaths of cheap fleece designed for lying on the couch and working the remote have inexplicably remained fixed in the kitsch cultural firmament. There are fan tribute sites, YouTube homages and pub crawls; Oprah, Ellen and Al Roker have worn them on camera. Most incredible of all, more than five million have been sold.

headline: British Premier Is Bowed by Mother of Slain Soldier
text: LONDON  Some public figures seem to do no wrong, deflecting scandal and potential misfortune as adroitly as if they were sheathed in Teflon jumpsuits. Prime Minister Gordon Brown is a Velcro politician, the kind who, it appears, can do no right.

headline: Performa 09: Tacita Dean and Merce Cunningham
text: In the second week of its three-week run, Performa 09 is unfolding at a fast and furious pace. Redefining the concept of over-booking, it is serving up more than any one person can see. The events I’ve managed to attend have ranged from great to less than, and run the gamut in terms of production values. It was production values to fore on Saturday in Tacita Dean’s sleek, gorgeously majestic “Craneway Event,” a 16mm color film that was unexpectedly hypnotic at St. Marks on the Bowery. Her second collaboration with the choreographer Merce Cunningham is a slow-moving documentary (100 minutes) of a rehearsal in the cavernous, many-windowed craneway of a refurbished factory in northern California. Ms. Dean’s themes center on the ineluctable movement of light — and to some extent the camera — through time and space. A great artist still at work at the end of his career, surrounded by acolytes and ever-deepening shadows, is the perfect subject for her relentless, elegiac art.

headline: Bill Clinton Urges Senate Democrats to Pass Bill Quickly
text: At our Prescriptions blog, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and David M. Herszenhorn detail the visit by former President Bill Clinton with Senate Democrats over the health care legislation. Afterward, Mr. Clinton described his message, saying that he concluded by noting that it would be worse to do nothing and that no bill is perfect.

headline: ‘Fly by Wire’
text: Prologue: The Inquest

headline: Correction:
text: The Practical Traveler column on Oct. 18, about deals available before the holidays in Mexico, Scottsdale, Ariz., and Florida, omitted part of the terms of a Walt Disney World offer of free dining with a five-night package from Oct. 1 through Nov. 24 and Nov. 29 to Dec. 17. The package had to be booked by Sept. 26.

headline: The Author Artist
text: The new issue of the Web journal Open Letters Monthly features a “cover” portrait of Marguerite Duras by the Swedish artist Carl Köhler, who died in 2006. It’s a pretty cool image — a sketchy double exposure showing Duras both as an old woman and in the prime of her life, with blocks of color that make it appear as if she’s emerging ghostlike from the gloom — but the main thing that caught my attention was the painter’s name. I’ve been looking at a lot of Carl Köhler’s author portraits lately. Earlier this year, the Brooklyn Central Library mounted an exhibition of them, which I missed, but after the show left Brooklyn for Washington, I heard from its curator (and the artist’s son), Henry Köhler, who forwarded a batch of his father’s work. Köhler was a neo-modernist who especially liked to paint writers and intellectuals: Kafka, Beckett, Joyce, Gide, Beauvoir, all in a rough, haunting style that captured their writerly moods as much as their physical appearances. The exhibition will travel early next year to Toronto and Vancouver, but you can peek at some of Köhler’s paintings in a slide show, here.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Nov. 1 about libraries with rare-book collections open to the public misstated the period of time covered by Oscar Wilde’s college notebook, at the William Andrews Clark Memorial Library in Los Angeles. It was written during 1876 and 1878, not 1876 and 1978. And because of an editing error, the article rendered incorrectly part of the Latin title of Galileo’s “Starry Messenger,” at the Linda Hall Library of Science, Engineering and Technology in Kansas City, Mo. It is “Sidereus Nuncius,” not “Sidereus Nucius.”

headline: Audrey Saunders Opening L.A. Bar with Mark Peel
text: In the four years since she opened the Pegu Club on Houston Street, Audrey Saunders has become the godmother of the New York cocktail scene. You could draw a diagram connecting every reputable young bartender in town back to either Pegu or one of Sasha Petraske’s bars, or both. The whole scene can feel a little inbred. Not to mention self-serious.

headline: A Cool Pilot, but the Plane Was Cooler
text: Uplift sells better than unpleasant facts, which is why, I suppose, William Langewiesche’s new book, “Fly by Wire,” has been published with an upbeat subtitle (“The Geese, the Glide, the Miracle on the Hudson”) rather than with the more cynical one its publisher initially intended to use. That original subtitle, “The Truth About the Miracle on the Hudson,” more accurately reflects this gripping book’s contents.

headline: A Few Additions to Enhance Bits
text: We know you love Bits, but we also know The New York Times is not your only source of technology news.

headline: Ahead of Copenhagen Climate Talks, Voices of Hope and Discord
text: With just under a month remaining before negotiations over a new global climate treaty get under way in Copenhagen, discord rules the day.

headline: ‘Wishful Drinking’ and ‘Circle Mirror Transformation’ Extend Runs
text: Update | 12:08 p.m. Carrie Fisher’s one-woman Broadway show, “Wishful Drinking,” has been extended for two weeks and will now close on Jan. 17, 2010, the Roundabout Theater Company announced on Tuesday afternoon. Ms. Fisher’s autobiographical monologue, based on her book of the same title, opened on Oct. 4 to strong reviews and performed well, if not spectacularly, at the box office during most weeks.

headline: Mary Travers Is Praised for Her Voice and Words
text: Mary Travers of the 1960s folk group Peter, Paul and Mary, who died on Sept. 16 at 72, was remembered on Monday night for both her music and her part in awakening the political consciousness of the baby-boomer generation.

headline: Europe’s Challenge to Oracle Deal Has Deep Roots
text: Oracle has spent much of the past decade lobbying to get European Union regulators to force one of its biggest competitors, Microsoft, to loosen its iron-like grip on software code and other intellectual property.

headline: Strong Starts for George Lopez and Wanda Sykes Shows
text: George Lopez created some big noise with his entry into the late-night competition Monday night, attracting more than 3 million viewers and faring better among many young audience groups than many of the established late-night stars.

headline: Gongs, Bamboo Flute and the Unexpected From China
text: Coming to grips with a great deal of unfamiliar contemporary music is a lot to ask of any group of musicians, but the New Juilliard Ensemble seems to take such things in stride. Consider the concert the group presented on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall: “Composers Living and Working in China Today,” among the final offerings in Carnegie Hall’s extensive festival Ancient Paths, Modern Voices. The concert’s placement made sense: when better to assess where Chinese composers are now than after several weeks of hearing what came before them?

headline: Removing a Barrier
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — This city, which once moved rivers to create a new urban design, is now moving a major highway away from its downtown and opening up approximately 20 acres for development. This newly accessible area is within walking distance of Providence’s historic waterfront and commercial downtown.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Nov. 10
text: For all of the conflict that swirls around any legislature — particularly one as famously balky as New York’s — there are relatively few images of direct confrontation; those moments that encapsulate all the battles waged behind the scenes. But Nathaniel Brooks captured such an instant on Tuesday (Slide 5), made even richer by the fact that one of the subjects, State Senator Rubén Díaz Sr., had just been profiled on the front page of The Times because of his stand on gay marriage, the issue in question.

headline: Flutist Evokes Poetry, Passion and Politics
text: To celebrate her 40th anniversary this season as a performer, the flutist Carol Wincenc devised a lively program for her appearance at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday evening, featuring works inspired by (among other things) the singing of a humpback whale, a nun who campaigns against the death penalty and Hasidic melodies.

headline: Obama at Fort Hood for Memorial Service
text: President Obama addressed the Fort Hood community on Tuesday at a memorial service for the 13 current or retired soldiers killed in attack. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: News of Hockey, 11/10/09: A K.H.L. Town Worse Off Than Detroit
text: If you think the Detroit Red Wings and the Nashville Predators have been buffeted by hard times, consider Lada Togliatti of the K.H.L. The club, from the southeastern city on the Volga, has been on financial life support the entire season because its main sponsor, the Russian automaking giant AvtoVaz, is near bankruptcy. Now Lada’s players, whose paychecks are overdue for a second straight month, have threatened to stop playing until they get their wages.

headline: Times Square Enters the Wi-Fi Age
text: Times Square is wallpapered with more than three dozen giant screens, which serve a range of functions, from disseminating news and streaming television to promoting earthly delights like candy and beer. But there hasn’t been one that allowed visitors to check e-mail, read restaurant reviews or buy tickets to a Broadway show.

headline: When Parents Disagree
text: Stephanie Klein and her husband, Phil, are at it again – fighting in public on her well-trafficked blog.

headline: Tierney’s Bid to Keep Control of Philadelphia’s Newspapers Gets a Boost
text: The struggle for control of the bankrupt Philadelphia newspapers took another sharp turn on Tuesday, as a Federal judge reversed an earlier ruling and removed a crucial advantage wielded by the bankers who want to become the papers’ owners.

headline: Properties for $800,000
text: Properties in Burien, Wash., Lynchburg, Va., and in Albuquerque.

headline: A Pairing of Bruckner and Glass Makes a Test
text: It takes only a moment’s reflection to recognize the musical appropriateness of juxtaposing works by Philip Glass and Anton Bruckner. Both composers trade in large-scale, sometimes numbingly repetitive explorations of rudimentary harmonies. Both tend to work in big structural blocks, often shifting abruptly from one to another.

headline: Fort Hood Shooter
text: NBC reports on intelligence officials saying that they knew Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan had contact with a radical Muslim cleric overseas.

headline: European Union Struggles to Select New Leaders
text: BRUSSELS  Days after securing the landmark treaty that will lead to the naming of the European Union’s first president, the bloc has lapsed into horse-trading-as-usual over the position  the kind of maneuvering that has often yielded the kind of bland leadership that the new presidency was supposed to overcome.

headline: Morgan Stanley Sees Possible M.&A. Rebound
text: Colm Kelleher, the chief financial officer of Morgan Stanley, said Tuesday that mergers and acquisitions appeared likely to rebound next year as the financial markets improve.

headline: Saving New Orleans Culture, One Sandwich at a Time
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: What You Get for ... $800,000
text: BURIEN, WASH.

headline: Lover of Birds and Opera Leaves Millions to Both
text: Mona Webster, a lighthouse keeper’s daughter who lived in Edinburgh and died in August at 96, had a love of birds, and warblers in particular  of the human kind. She demonstrated that affection by leaving most of her fortune to the Metropolitan Opera and a nature charity in Britain.

headline: ‘Ghost Hunters’ Seeks Spirits and Ratings
text: Jason Hawes and Grant Wilson are searching for ghosts. They walk toward a hallway inside Waverly Hills, a Kentucky sanatorium that attracts paranormal investigators like themselves.

headline: Madoff Homes for Sale, Now at Discount Prices
text: While Bernard L. Madoff’s beach house in Montauk, N.Y., sold quickly for more than the $8.75 million asking price, his other properties are not doing as well. After nearly 60 days on the market, the United States Marshals in charge of the sale of Mr. Madoff’s home in Palm Beach, Fla., and his Manhattan penthouse have needed to cut their prices.

headline: Honoring the Fallen
text: Victims of the Fort Hood tragedy will be honored Tuesday in a memorial service attended by President Obama and the First Lady. NBC Video.

headline: Historic Sounds of Newport, Newly Online
text: As the future of the Newport Jazz and Folk Festivals continues to unfold, its recorded past has suddenly been thrown open.

headline: Murdoch’s Google Gambit
text: On Sunday, the day before the 20th anniversary of fall of the Berlin Wall, Rupert Murdoch appeared in an interview on Sky News in Australia, and promised to erect pay walls around all his company’s Web sites and then block Google from searching and linking to them.

headline: Columbia Professor Charged With Punching University Employee
text: A Columbia University professor has been charged with assault and harassment after an another Columbia employee accused him of punching her in the eye at an Upper West Side bar Friday night.

headline: A Home That's 'Something Different'
text: Roman Rutkowski, 37, an architect with his own practice in Wroclaw, Poland, built a two-story 120-square-meter (1,300-square-foot) house in the prestigious Krzyki neighborhood on the south side of town.

headline: Senators Back Panel on Deficit Reduction
text: The Senate budget committee chairman said a group of lawmakers would agree soon to a proposal for a bipartisan commission to force reductions in federal deficits, hoping to attach it either to must-pass legislation raising the nation’s debt limit or, failing that, to the pending health care bill.

headline: Blackwater Said to Pursue Bribes to Iraq After 17 Died
text: WASHINGTON  Top executives at Blackwater Worldwide authorized secret payments of about $1 million to Iraqi officials that were intended to silence their criticism and buy their support after a September 2007 episode in which Blackwater security guards fatally shot 17 Iraqi civilians in Baghdad, according to former company officials.

headline: In Poland, Modern Among Traditional
text: WROCLAW, POLAND  Set among prewar traditional villas and a smattering of 1970s boxy apartments is the architect Roman Rutkowski’s home, a simple, rectangular bunker with an unpainted all-wood exterior, and even plainer interior with concrete floors and particleboard walls.

headline: No Consensus on Financial Crisis’s Legacy for City
text: The financial crisis that struck the country more than a year ago may have hit the hardest where it started: New York.

headline: Abortion Debate Divides Democrats
text: NBC examines the central role of abortion funding in the heathcare reform bill.

headline: A ‘Prisoner’ With New Questions
text: Ian McKellen had already read the script of a new version of the late-1960s cult television series “The Prisoner” when he met the author, Bill Gallagher, last year at a London restaurant to discuss the project. As Mr. Gallagher recalls their first encounter, Mr. McKellen hugged him, then gently patted him on the head and asked, “What goes on in that mind of yours, Bill?”

headline: ‘No Regrets’ for Cao
text: The sole House Republican to vote in favor of the health care legislation, Representative Anh Cao of Louisiana, said in an interview Tuesday that he had been getting some “pretty nasty responses.”

headline: Logitech Breaks Into Videoconferencing
text: In a move to break into the videoconferencing market, Logitech International has agreed to buy LifeSize Communications, a start-up that makes high-definition videoconferencing equipment, for $405 million in cash.

headline: After the Bird, Everything Else Is Secondary
text: YOU know how it is with family during the holidays. One smart remark and someone leaves the table in tears.

headline: Show-Off Sides to Rival the Pull of a Drumstick
text: A PERSON can only take so much.

headline: Viewers Love ‘Dancing’
text: A two-hour installment of “Dancing With the Stars” attracted 17.6 million viewers on Monday, helping ABC rank No. 1 on the night as the most-watched network, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although that reality show dominated the 8 and 9 p.m. time slots, ABC’s “Castle” lagged behind CBS’s “CSI: Miami” in the 10 p.m. hour with 10.7 million viewers compared with 13.8 million for the CBS crime show. ABC also struggled in the demographic most prized by advertisers, viewers 18 to 49, finishing third in that age group behind CBS and Fox, whose medical drama “House” delivered the night’s top ratings in the 18-to-49 set. “House” earned a more modest 12.8 million total viewers at 8 p.m., while Fox’s “Lie to Me” drew 7.5 million at 9. Second-place CBS garnered its highest ratings at 9 with its comedy “Two and a Half Men” (14.1 million). NBC was a distant fourth on the night with “Heroes” at 8 (5.3 million), “Trauma” at 9 (5.4 million) and “The Jay Leno Show” at 10 (4 million).

headline: Getty and Egypt to Work on Tut’s Tomb
text: The Getty Conservation Institute in Los Angeles said on Tuesday that it had entered into a five-year partnership with Egypt to help conserve and manage the tomb of Tutankhamen, above, in the Valley of the Kings, near Luxor, whose striking wall paintings have been pocked with brown spots at least since the tomb’s discovery in 1922. “King Tut has magic that we must conserve for future generations,” Zahi Hawass, secretary general of Egypt’s supreme council of antiquities, said in a statement. The first two years of the project will involve studying the condition of the tomb and examining the spots, whose nature and origin have never been determined. Then a conservation plan will be carried out and documented, along with a plan for long-term monitoring of the condition and maintenance of the entire tomb, including policies for regulating the number of visitors, said Tim Whalen, director of the conservation institute.

headline: Faux Ma Po Tofu
text: Last week, everything came together for a weird, accidental, successful vegan take on ma-po tofu.

headline: Twitter Book and Now TV Show
text: Justin Halpern, the author of a rather tartly named Twitter account, has landed a book deal and a deal with CBS for a comedy based on the premise. Mr. Halpern’s Twitter account has more than 700,000 followers. According to The Hollywood Reporter, Mr. Halpern signed a book deal with HarperCollins last month and CBS decided there must be a television show in there somewhere. David Kohan and Max Mutchnick, the creators of “Will & Grace,” are on board as executive producers, and Mr. Halpern, 29, a writer for Maxim who lives with his parents in San Diego, will serve as a writer and another executive producer. The name, which uses an unprintable word followed by the phrase “My Dad Says,” will need some retooling to meet network standards, but there’s plenty of funny in the sensibility. Based on aphorisms and pearls of wisdom from Mr. Halpern’s father, the Twitter feed usually consists of his father telling his son that everything he thinks is wrong: “Oh please, you practically invented lazy. People should have to call you and ask for the rights to lazy before they use it,” said a post from Nov. 1.

headline: Denzel Washington Is Broadway Bound
text: Another major film star is heading to Broadway: The two-time Academy Award winner Denzel Washington will play Troy Maxson in a revival of August Wilson’s “Fences” next spring, according to an executive involved with the production. James Earl Jones played the role of Troy, a former baseball player now working as a garbage collector, in the original 1987 Broadway production of “Fences,” which won the Pulitzer Prize for drama and the Tony Award for best play that year. “Fences” was one of Wilson’s biggest commercial hits on Broadway, running for 525 performances. Mr. Washington, 54, above, last appeared on Broadway in 2005 as Brutus in “Julius Caesar,” which was a box-office smash despite mixed reviews. He received an Academy Award for best actor in “Training Day” in 2002, and for best supporting actor for “Glory” in 1990. The dates of the revival have not been confirmed, said the executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the producers, Carole Shorenstein Hays and Scott Rudin, had not authorized comment. Kenny Leon, who directed “A Raisin in the Sun” and two Wilson plays on Broadway, “Gem of the Ocean” and “Radio Golf,” is in negotiations to direct.

headline: Brewing Battle
text: Getting healthcare reform passed this year may be a challenge for the White House, NBC reports.

headline: Alfred Hitchcock Steps Toward Off Broadway
text: The Broadway producers of “Alfred Hitchcock’s The 39 Steps” have opened negotiations to move the quick-witted play to the Off Broadway theater New World Stages next year, according to the show’s lead producer, Bob Boyett. “The 39 Steps” is scheduled to close at the Helen Hayes on Broadway on Jan. 10 after almost three years. “We’ve just started to have a conversation with them, but no decision has been made,” Mr. Boyett said on Tuesday. “The decision to move is going to be based on what kind of business arrangement we can come to. We think the show still has life in it.” “The 39 Steps” has been playing lately to houses that are only about two-thirds full, but the lower running costs off Broadway could yield lower-priced tickets  and potentially more customers. ... In other news, the Roundabout Theater Company, the producers of “Wishful Drinking,” Carrie Fisher’s wry one-woman show about the perils of growing up famous (and famously hair-bunned), said the production has been extended. It will run through Jan. 17 at Studio 54. ... And the critically acclaimed “Circle Mirror Transformation,” a play at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater on West 42nd Street about students in a drama class, has been extended with five additional performances through Nov. 22, a spokesman for the Playwrights Horizons show said on Tuesday.

headline: Shepard Fairey Wins Right to a New Lawyer
text: The street artist Shepard Fairey has won the right to a new lawyer in his suit against The Associated Press over the image that became his celebrated Barack Obama “Hope” poster. In a pretrial hearing Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of the Southern District Court of New York also ruled that lawyers for The A.P. can depose Mr. Fairey and his departing lawyers before the end of the year, The A.P. reported. The agency and the artist are suing each other over the rights to the image, a photo taken in April 2006 at an event at the National Press Club in Washington. Mr. Fairey recently admitted that he had lied publicly and to his lawyers about which image he had used, causing the lawyers to abandon his case. Mr. Fairey later added that he still believed his work fell under fair-use guidelines and did not infringe on The A.P.’s copyright, an assertion that his new lawyer, Geoffrey Stewart, supported, and that the agency rebutted.

headline: Dancing in the Streets to Celebrate a Toppling
text: Twenty years ago on Monday, the Berlin Wall fell, but it wasn’t only world leaders who celebrated the anniversary of its demise. The choreographer Nejla Y. Yatkin, a native of that city, offered her own site-specific homage, “Dancing With the Berlin Wall,” as part of Performing Revolution in Central and Eastern Europe, a festival in New York.

headline: House Hunting in ... South Africa
text: A 530-SQUARE METER (5,700-SQUARE-FOOT) FARMHOUSE IN PLETTENBERG BAY

headline: Making the Face of Modernism Familiar
text: The architect Eero Saarinen was often knocked for being the equivalent of a talented P.R. man. And on the surface at least, few architects did more to glamorize postwar corporate America. General Motors, I.B.M., CBS  all eventually came knocking at his door. His architecture offered them the veneer of a supremely confident, progressive America, with all the roughness smoothed away. It made it easier to forget about those Soviet warheads and mushroom clouds.

headline: Networking No-Nos and Third iWheels
text: In the last installmentof Internet Protocol, we helped readers rein in their emoticon use and talked about whether it’s appropriate or not for tweens to be using Facebook.

headline: In the Catskills, Holocaust Survivors Forge a Bond
text: The exuberant Jewish retirees gathering for their 26th summer at a modest Catskills bungalow colony in Andrew Jacobs’s documentary “Four Seasons Lodge” appear like any group of older Americans on vacation. They socialize, eat, argue, sing and dance, chortle at the risqué gags of cabaret entertainers, try their best to maintain the colony’s aging physical plant, care for ailing spouses and  like most people in their ’80s and ’90s  look death in the face on a daily basis.

headline: A ‘Gossip Girl’ Look, Pronto!
text: ON an average day at his Robert G. Salon in the West Village in Manhattan, Robert Gioria fields a variety of requests. One woman wants her brown hair blond, another wants her straight hair shaggy. As different as these requests may seem, Mr. Gioria finds they are often generated by the same goal: to have Blake Lively’s hair.

headline: Recession Upends German Zeal for Fiscal Prudence
text: It has come to this: Germany will almost certainly have a bigger budget deficit next year than Italy will.

headline: Dark Side of Heroism, Told in Four Wars
text: Picture a peacenik who in his private moments enjoys looking at pictures of horribly mutilated bodies. That is the vibe given off by “The Good Soldier,” a film whose benign-sounding title and Veterans Day release give a false impression of what it actually is: an attack on the military, drenched in blood.

headline: When Style Won’t Stay in Storage
text: Jamie Drake's temporary apartment faces south toward the still-under-construction "sky garage" designed by Annabelle Selldorf.

headline: Stars of the Astronomy Quiz
text: We have a winner — two winners, actually– of the prize for the Lab’s Beautiful Universe Astronomy Quiz. For the extra-credit questions, we asked you to expand the metropolis-sized model of the solar system that opened recently in Atlanta. In that model, which is scaled so that 1 kilometer represents 1 astronomical unit (the distance between the Earth and the Sun,) Neptune is located in a park 18 miles away from the Sun, which is at Bradley Observatory at Agnes Scott College.

headline: A Designer Brings Personality to a Temporary Rental
text: THE view from the living room of Jamie Drake’s temporary apartment on the 32nd floor of a glassy high-rise condominium on West 24th Street is due west. This means that Mr. Drake, the 52-year-old decorator to Michael R. Bloomberg and Madonna, has a bird’s-eye view of the glacial but ineluctably fascinating construction of what will eventually be his new home at 200 11th Avenue, the Annabelle Selldorf-designed tower in far west Chelsea.

headline: Something to Argue About at Thanksgiving
text: “I believe from a good turkey all Thanksgiving flows,” says Kim Severson.

headline: Writer Digs Up Gods From the Bayou
text: TARELL ALVIN McCRANEY enters. Miami, 1980s. He is a boy growing up in the Liberty City housing projects, among the nation’s worst. He stays with his father and grandparents on some nights. They feed him peanut butter and jelly, and he is content. They are devout Baptists and fill up the boy with God’s stories, and he is content.

headline: American Sues F.B.I., Saying He Was Detained in Africa
text: WASHINGTON  A New Jersey man who contends that he was detained and mistreated in Kenya, Somalia and Ethiopia in 2007 with the approval of the United States filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against F.B.I. agents and other unidentified American officials who he says interrogated him and threatened him with execution.

headline: Mourning the Victims of Fort Hood
text: President Obama played the role of national eulogist at a memorial service at Fort Hood, Tex., for the victims of a shooting rampage.

headline: A Challenge of Innocence and Experience
text: WHAT Alan Ayckbourn remembers from Ayesha Antoine’s audition for his play “My Wonderful Day” is that she didn’t look at him directly. That might not sound like a good thing, but since Ms. Antoine, who is 28, was reading with Mr. Ayckbourn for the role of an 8-year-old  and a thoughtful, reserved 8-year-old, at that  it definitely was.

headline: Tips for Cooks and Waiters
text: SO exclusive is this restaurant on an industrial stretch of Queens Boulevard in Long Island City that it isn’t open to the public and it doesn’t even have a name.

headline: Spaghetti Squash With Garlic, Parsley and Breadcrumbs
text: Spaghetti squash gets its name from the fact that once it is cooked, the flesh breaks down into long spaghettilike strands. I find spaghetti squash a bit dull on its own, as it does not have the sweetness and depth of many other winter squash. But it is hard to resist substituting spaghetti squash for pasta every once in a while, and the squash will pick up other robust flavors in the dish. Most spaghetti squash are pretty large; you will need only half of a 3 to 3 1/2-pound squash for this recipe. You can toss the leftovers with tomato sauce the next day.

headline: A Kiss to the United States of Burgers, Fries and Sugar
text: CHARLIE PALMER opened a huge new restaurant in Manhattan this year, Aureole, a big, sprawling series of rooms on the ground floor of the Bank of America building on 42nd Street. He has around a dozen more, in Las Vegas, Reno and California’s wine country, among others, as well as a hotel, a catering outfit and a shop in Sonoma County that sells the sort of candles and bowls that you see in the homes of people who spend a lot of time shuttling among New York, Sonoma and Las Vegas.

headline: Assault Charges for a Professor in a Bar Dispute
text: A Columbia University professor has been charged with assault and harassment after an another Columbia employee accused him of punching her in the eye at a Morningside Heights bar Friday night.

headline: Lloyds to Cut 5,000 Jobs; HSBC Says Profit Improved
text: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group, the British lender bailed out by the government, said on Tuesday that it would cut 5,000 jobs in its insurance, retail and administration departments by the end of next year.

headline: One-Year Term in Bribery Case
text: Frederic Bourke, a founder of the handbag maker Dooney & Bourke, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison and will have to pay a $1 million fine for conspiring to bribe leaders in Azerbaijan.

headline: U.S. Tries to Salvage Honduras Accord
text: WASHINGTON  Under fire from allies in Latin America and on Capitol Hill, the Obama administration moved Tuesday to try to salvage the American-brokered agreement that had been billed as paving the way for a peaceful end to the coup in Honduras. Instead, the accord seems to have provided the country’s de facto government with a way to stay in power until a presidential election scheduled for the end of this month.

headline: Prime Meats, Priced by the Ounce
text: PRIME MEATS

headline: What Happens in Vegas
text: My review this week is of Aureole, a restaurant that Charlie Palmer first opened in 1988 on the Upper East Side. This summer he closed it and reopened in much larger quarters on the ground floor of the Bank of America building on 42nd Street. It’s a very different restaurant, one that I feel better reflects Mr. Palmer’s experience cooking in Las Vegas, where he has yet another Aureole, than it does his past off Madison Avenue. What about you? Have you been to the new Aureole? Do you have memories of the old one, or of the high-flying wine sprites at the Las Vegas location? To join the conversation, post a comment below.

headline: Influence of Egypt and Saudi Arabia Fades
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Even before Mahmoud Abbas announced that he would not seek re-election as the Palestinian president, throwing the Palestinian Authority into chaos, America’s closest Arab allies, Saudi Arabia and Egypt, had begun to despair over Washington’s Middle East missteps, government officials and political experts said.

headline: How to Control Rising Health Care Costs
text: Updated, Nov. 11, 3:10 p.m. | Michael Chernew of Harvard Medical School joins the discussion. Scroll down to read his suggestion.

headline: Where the Cocktails Steal the Show
text: YERBA BUENA PERRY

headline: Motion Says Letterman Fostered Harassment
text: A lawyer for the man accused of trying to extort $2 million from David Letterman suggested on Tuesday that Mr. Letterman ran a workplace rife with sexual misconduct and contended that his client was simply trying to sell a story to the talk show host  not extort money from him.

headline: And Now, Brooklyn Gets a Kitchen Lab
text: When Taylor Erkkinen, left, and Harry C. Rosenblum opened Brooklyn Kitchen, a cookware shop, in Williamsburg three years ago, they had no idea their classes on pickle-making, knife skills and such would be sellouts. So a few months ago they rented warehouse space two blocks away so they could expand. The 7,000-square-foot space, Brooklyn Kitchen Labs, is to open on Nov. 16. The old scale at left came with the building.

headline: From Belize, and Extra Sweet
text: Laughing Bird shrimp are unlike many farmed shrimp, and that is a good thing. They are raised in the Caribbean, in inland ponds on the coast of Belize. They swim in filtered sea water, are fed a vegetarian diet, are not treated with additives or sulfites and are sold fresh and hand-peeled. The farm, the only one in Belize, has been given positive marks by the World Wildlife Fund.

headline: Pumpkin’s Got a Brand New Trick
text: Thinking of retiring the cranberry sauce this Thanksgiving? Not so fast. How about offering a choice instead, namely pumpkin pickle.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: Nissan Chief Plans a Low-Cost Car for India
text: NEW DELHI  The battle is heating up for bragging rights to the world’s least expensive car. On Tuesday, the top executive of Renault and Nissan said the companies would begin selling a small car in India in 2012 that would cost less than any other car sold in the country  and thus the world.

headline: House Health Care Debate Heads Home
text: Still hoping to undermine support for a health care overhaul, Republican House members are preparing for town hall-style meetings in their home districts during the Veterans Day recess between now and early next week.

headline: Online Ads Are Booming, if They’re Attached to a Video
text: News Web sites are starting to look a lot less like newspapers and a lot more like television.

headline: Al Cervi, Hall of Fame N.B.A. Player-Coach, Dies at 92
text: Al Cervi, a tenacious backcourt player in the early years of professional basketball and later a Hall of Fame coach who led the Syracuse Nationals to the 1955 N.B.A. championship, died Monday in Rochester. He was 92 and lived in Brighton, N.Y.

headline: Female Hotel Workers Injured More Than Men, Study Shows
text: A new study of workers at 50 hotels in the United States found that women were 50 percent more likely to be injured than men, and that Hispanic women had an injury rate two-thirds higher than their white female counterparts.

headline: Tastes of Authenticity
text: These places in and around New Orleans serve good po’ boys at a range of prices and styles.

headline: Mahony’s Beef Po’ Boys
text: Adapted from Benjamin Wicks

headline: Sanofi Taps Biotech Firm to Bolster Its Pipeline
text: Increasing its bet on biotechnology, Sanofi-Aventis said it would pay an additional $1 billion over eight years to Regeneron Pharmaceuticals for the discovery of new drugs.

headline: Corrections
text: A recipe for a green bean casserole with The Temporary Vegetarian last Wednesday omitted the oven temperature. It is 375 degrees. A corrected recipe is at nytimes.com/dining.

headline: Prosecutors Say Students Paid Witness to Aid Case
text: CHICAGO  Prosecutors on Tuesday accused former journalism students at Northwestern University of paying a witness to record a video statement to help them prove that a man had been wrongfully convicted of a 1978 murder in a Chicago suburb.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Wednesday about Sam Kass, the assistant White House chef who is closely involved with administration food policy and oversees the White House garden, referred imprecisely to the financing of the American Council on Science and Health, a consumer-education group that has criticized Mr. Kass for saying he would not use pesticides in the garden. The group is financed by various sources, including the food industry, foundations and private individuals; it is not solely financed by big food makers.

headline: Reid and the Onside Kick Not Taken
text: A quick follow-up to Monday’s entry about decisions by Tom Coughlin and Andy Reid in Week 9.

headline: Young Veterans Form New Groups, and Old Posts Fade Away
text: Prisco De Angelis, 77, who earned a Purple Heart in the Korean War, remembers when Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 2652 in Brooklyn had several hundred members and its own building. He also remembers when the rank and file began dying off, and how the few who were left sold the building. Now he can count on only four or five others to attend post meetings. Often, the gathering place is his living room in Carroll Gardens.

headline: Opposites on Ice Find a New Rhythm Together
text: DETROIT  It now seems like such a brilliant idea that it is a surprise no one had thought of it before: pairing figure skaters with hockey players for ice dancing routines in the ultimate ice rink reality show.

headline: Blackouts Plague Energy-Rich Venezuela
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  This country may be an energy colossus, with the largest conventional oil reserves outside the Middle East and one of the world’s mightiest hydroelectric systems, but that has not prevented it from enduring serious electricity and water shortages that seem only to be getting worse.

headline: Calming the Black Friday Crowds
text: A year after an unruly crowd trampled a worker to death at a Wal-Mart store, the nation’s retailers are preparing for another Black Friday, the blockbuster shopping day after Thanksgiving. Along with offering $300 laptops and $99 navigation devices, stores are planning new safety measures to make sure the festive day does not take another deadly turn.

headline: In Need of Cash, State Requiring Drivers to Buy New $25 Plates
text: ALBANY  New York drivers will start paying for new license plates next year  whether they want to or not.

headline: From Justice Kennedy, a Lesson in Journalism
text: WASHINGTON  The school newspaper at Dalton, a private school in Manhattan, contained a cryptic note from its editors last Friday.

headline: Stephen Curry Gets Rude Welcome on Warriors
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  After the worst game of his nascent N.B.A. career, Stephen Curry stood in the Warriors’ locker room and applied an ice pack to the knee of his extended left leg. He glanced warily over his left shoulder at his Golden State teammate Stephen Jackson, who was convivially holding court with reporters at his corner locker at Oracle Arena.

headline: France: Court Rules a Lesbian Can Adopt
text: A court in Besançon ruled Tuesday that a lesbian known as Emmanuelle B. could adopt a child, overturning two previous rulings and ending a decade-long legal battle. The government of President Nicolas Sarkozy responded by declaring its continued opposition to adoption by gay couples. French law prohibits same-sex couples from adopting but allows adoptions by individuals. Emmanuelle B., 48, who is in a long-term relationship, began adoption proceedings as an individual in 1998.

headline: Under Attack, Fed Chief Studies Politics
text: WASHINGTON  With the Federal Reserve under more intense attack than at any time in decades, Ben S. Bernanke, the professorial chairman of the central bank, was schooled last month in how to handle the increased political demands of his job.

headline: Is Younger Gotti’s Teflon Suit Better Than His Father’s?
text: The prosecution of John A. Gotti  a jurisprudential marathon of four trials, five years, countless hours of testimony and a cast of characters as enduring as a syndicated sitcom’s  is one of the city’s longest-running dramas, a sort of criminal “Cats,” that is comparable in complexity and length perhaps only to the four trials of his father, John J. Gotti, the Gambino family don who died in 2002.

headline: 3 Obama Advisers Favor More Troops for Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton are coalescing around a proposal to send 30,000 or more additional American troops to Afghanistan, but President Obama remains unsatisfied with answers he has gotten about how vigorously the governments of Afghanistan and Pakistan would help execute a new strategy, administration officials said Tuesday.

headline: Italy: Berlusconi Builds Support to Cap Length of Trials
text: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi gained support on Tuesday for a change that would reduce the length of Italy’s long trials, including his own. After weeks of tension, the speaker of Parliament, Gianfranco Fini, appeared to support a bill that would cap the length of trials at six years, from first judgment through two rounds of appeals. Mr. Berlusconi faces trials on charges of corruption and tax fraud.

headline: Powder Sent to 3 Missions Is Determined to Be Flour
text: Two United Nations foreign missions received envelopes containing white powder on Tuesday, a day after three others received mailings containing a similar substance that the police said was determined to be flour.

headline: Falling Far Short of Reform
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Administration Names Agriculture Official to Run U.S. Aid Agency, Ending Delays
text: WASHINGTON  After months of delays because of tangled vetting procedures, the Obama administration on Tuesday named a former executive with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation to run its main foreign aid arm, the United States Agency for International Development.

headline: View of the Mayor’s Race From One Who Opted Out: I Could Have Won
text: Rep. Anthony D. Weiner wants to clear up a few things.

headline: Maine Finds a Health Care Fix Elusive
text: BAR HARBOR, Me.  When his car repair shop’s health insurance premiums doubled between 2000 and 2002, David White saw the problem as akin to a sputtering engine. So he got under the hood of the state’s health system and tried to fix it.

headline: Social Medicine
text: “Wash your hands regularly.” “Cover your mouth when you sneeze.” “Throw away your used tissues.” These are some of the exhortations currently posted around London in an attempt to reduce the spread of flu. But one day, perhaps we’ll have public health campaigns of a different kind. “Be jolly: it’s catching.” Or, “Eat less: do it for your friends.”

headline: 25 Chicago Students Arrested for a Middle-School Food Fight
text: CHICAGO  The food fight here started the way such bouts do in school lunchrooms most anywhere: an apple was tossed, a cookie turned into a torpedo, and an orange plunked someone in the head. Within minutes, dozens of middle-school students had joined in the ruckus, and spattered adults were ducking for cover.

headline: Lives During Wartime
text: Last week, the editors of Home Fires invited readers to send their recollections and photographs of members of the United States Armed Forces in acknowledgment of Veterans Day. Below is a selection of those remembrances submitted by friends and family of veterans, and from veterans themselves.

headline: Pension Bonus for City Correction Officers Is Questioned in Bruno Trial
text: Ten years ago, when the union for city correction officers persuaded Republican leaders in Albany to ignore the stern objections of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and approve a major bonus to their pensions, it looked like nothing more than a great political victory for the union.

headline: Lottery Numbers
For All the Wrong Reasons, Women’s Soccer Is Noticed
text: Fairly or unfairly, women’s college soccer usually draws almost zero public attention. It is probably no exaggeration to say that most games produce more goals than news accounts.

headline: Some Object as Museum Shows Its Trustee’s Art
text: One day in the mid-1980s, Dakis Joannou, a Greek Cypriot industrialist, was exploring the art galleries of the East Village in Manhattan when he came upon a basketball suspended in a tank of liquid. Captivated, he invested $2,700 in “One Ball Total Equilibrium Tank” by a little-known artist named Jeff Koons. It was, he said, as if a whole new world had opened up to him.

headline: Damon May Face a Choice on His Next Contract
text: CHICAGO  In 2004, when the Red Sox finally broke all the hexes to win the World Series, many of their players became icons to the fans, and none more so than Johnny Damon.

headline: Reid Says Health Bill Will Be Done by Christmas
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Tuesday that he expected to bring major health care legislation to the floor next week and to complete work on the bill before Christmas. But other Democratic leaders said it was unlikely that a bill could reach President Obama’s desk by year’s end.
