headline: Leading the Way in a Different Kind of Transition
text: It is an unfortunate quirk of the media age that a career can be reduced to one play, one possession, one 10-second clip played on a maddening loop.

headline: Kenneth, What Is the Frequency?
text: Most crosswords have themes. The New York Times alone publishes more than 260 themed puzzles a year. That’s a lot for an audience expecting innovation, but as we’ve seen, not too much innovation. Novelty alienates some solvers and is especially tough for newbies, so there’s a balance.

headline: Power in Paraguay and Brazil Fails
text: RIO DE JANEIRO   A problem with the Itaipú hydroelectric power plant plunged Paraguay and large parts of Brazil into darkness on Tuesday night, virtually paralyzing the two countries.

headline: Curry Takes Step Forward, and Knicks Hope to Follow
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Eddy Curry’s road to recovery after professional setbacks and personal heartbreak is tinged with caution. Although he cleared another hurdle on Tuesday, he has many more on the horizon.

headline: Jeter and Teixeira Receive Gold Glove Awards
text: CHICAGO  Derek Jeter, whose defense has been criticized in recent years through statistical analyses, won a Gold Glove award for his defense, joining Yankees teammate Mark Teixeira on the list of American League recipients released Tuesday. No other team had multiple winners.

headline: No Penalty for FedEx Over Contract Drivers
text: The FedEx Corporation said Tuesday that the government would not require it to pay employment taxes for contract drivers in its ground-delivery unit for 2004 through 2006, supporting the company’s claim that they should not be treated as employees.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about difficulties for Muslims serving in the American armed forces described incorrectly the background of Michael A. Monsoor, a member of the Navy Seals. Mr. Monsoor was a Christian of Lebanese and Irish descent, not a Muslim. The article also described incorrectly the act that earned him a Medal of Honor. It was for falling on a grenade and saving at least three team members  not for pulling a team member to safety. (Saving a team member in an earlier incident earned him a Silver Star.)

headline: No Longer a Soldier, Shinseki Has a New Mission
text: It was a sad homecoming of sorts. On Tuesday, Eric Shinseki, the secretary of veterans affairs, returned to Fort Hood, Tex., where he was a division commander in the mid-1990s, to pay tribute to two veterans affairs employees who died in the shootings there last week.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about banks’ raising rates and fees on credit card customers ahead of new federal regulations misstated, in some editions, the current total of credit limits in the United States and those limits roughly a year ago. Total credit limits are now $3.4 trillion, not billion, which is a reduction from $4.6 trillion, not billion, a year ago.

headline: A Man Who Loves to Clean, if Only He Could Find a Job to Do It
text: Telmo Cerezo watched intently as the headlines of Univision’s news at 6 streamed across the muted television. “I watch it in English too,” he said quietly, adjusting his seat position so as not to be in the way.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Wednesday about Michael R. Bloomberg’s narrow victory in the New York mayoral race and a correction in this space on Friday misspelled the surname of a voter who said Mr. Bloomberg “ran a smear campaign against a nonexistent opponent.” She is Stav Birnbaum, not Brinbaum.

headline: Corrections
text: A Congressional Memo article in some editions on Sunday about the race for Congress in the 23d District in New York misstated the circumstances of an endorsement in The Watertown Daily News. The paper’s decision to endorse the Democratic candidate, Bill Owens, after the Republican candidate, Assemblywoman Dede Scozzafava, withdrew was based solely on internal discussions, according to the editor, John B. Johnson Jr. He said the paper was not “pressed for the endorsement” by Democratic officials. (Mr. Johnson also noted that the decision had been made by the time Mr. Owens asked for the endorsement.)

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Friday about the distribution of the swine flu vaccine to some major New York companies even as shortages continue referred incompletely, based on information from the city health department, to the 27,400 doses requested by Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Those doses are meant for patients, workers and volunteers  not just workers.

headline: Corrections
text: A subheading on Tuesday with an article about the use of old nuclear bomb cores to produce electricity misstated the source of the bomb material used to generate power in the United States. It comes from bombs dismantled by both the United States and Russia  not from Russian bombs alone.

headline: Recalculating the Tally in Swine Flu Deaths
text: About 4,000 Americans  rather than about 1,200  have died of swine flu since the disease emerged in April, according to new figures being calculated by epidemiologists for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Week 9 Passer Ratings: Orton Seeks His Level
text: Luis DeLoureiro, a self-described “schlep who is using a geeky Web site as a way to work through an early midlife crisis,” is building a better passer rating at NFLStatAnalysis.net:

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the planned Broadway musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark” and a correction in this space on Tuesday misstated the status of advance ticket sales. While there has been no general advance sale, tickets are still available through Ticketmaster to holders of American Express cards; it is not the case that advance tickets are no longer being sold. (As the correction on Tuesday noted, tickets for the production are being handled by Ticketmaster, not Telecharge.)

headline: Parade of Poor Play
text: A look at New York's other teams, which are not doing so well.

headline: U.S. Navy Officer Revisits His Past in Vietnam
text: A boy who fled a war becomes a naval star, with stripes.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a newly published oral history of Joseph Papp and the Public Theater misspelled the surname of one of Papp’s collaborators. He is Stuart Vaughan, not Vaughn.

headline: Chairman Says G.M. Can Repay Taxpayers
text: The chairman of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., said Tuesday that the automaker would be able to repay all of its government loans and would begin doing so soon.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing of credits on Saturday with a theater review of “The Lily’s Revenge” at Here Arts Center omitted the surname of a cast member. She is Kayla Asbell.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the production of “Dreamgirls” in previews at the Apollo Theater before it goes on national tour misspelled the current name of the theater where the production’s costume designer, William Ivey Long, was working in 1982 and which shared a wall with the Imperial Theater, where “Dreamgirls” was playing. (Mr. Long said that he had wanted to work on “Dreamgirls” since that time.) Formerly the 46th Street Theater, it is now the Richard Rodgers Theater, not Rogers.

headline: Survey Finds Deep Shift in the Makeup of Unions
text: A study has found that just one in 10 union members is in manufacturing, while women account for more than 45 percent of the unionized work force.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Communications Director Leaves
text: Anita Dunn, the White House communications director who has tangled very publicly with Fox News, is leaving the White House at the end of the month. Her deputy, Dan Pfeiffer, will succeed her, a senior White House official said. The switch had been expected; Ms. Dunn took the communications director job this year on an interim basis. She will return to Squier Knapp Dunn, the media consulting firm where she is a partner, but will stay on as a strategic consultant to the White House. This development was first reported by The Washington Post. Ms. Dunn, a longtime Democratic strategist who worked for Mr. Obama’s presidential campaign, kept a relatively low profile at the White House until recently, when she set off a war of words with Fox News by calling it “the research arm or the communications arm of the Republican Party.” Mr. Pfeiffer, 33, served as communications director for Mr. Obama’s presidential campaign, communications director for Al Gore’s presidential campaign in 2000 and aide to Tom Daschle, the former South Dakota senator who was majority leader.

headline: California: Immigration Conflict
text: Setting up a potential showdown with the mayor, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors reinstated an ordinance requiring that juvenile offenders who are in the country illegally be convicted of a crime before they are turned over to federal immigration authorities. The board passed the measure in October, but it was vetoed by Mayor Gavin Newsom, who said that it very likely conflicted with federal immigration law. On Tuesday, the board overrode that veto by an 8-to-3 vote. The mayor says that he has no intention of abiding by the board’s action and that the current policy of turning over juveniles at the time of their arrest would stay in place. A spokesman called the ordinance unenforceable. Supervisor David Campos, who sponsored the measure, urged the mayor “to follow the democratic process” and put the ordinance into effect.

headline: Two Share Lead in Elite Moscow Tournament
text: The current world champion and a former champion share the lead of the Tal Memorial after five rounds.

headline: American Wages Out of Balance
text: American workers are overpaid, relative to equally productive employees elsewhere doing the same work. If the global economy is to get into balance, that gap must close.

headline: At Christie’s, a Return of American Collectors, With an Eye on Price
text: Some of the great names in postwar and contemporary art were solid sellers at Christie’s on Tuesday night. And while American collectors were back, dominating the bidding, price mattered. Only one work  a 1996 painting by the Scottish artist Peter Doig  broke the $10 million barrier in a mixed sale that included property once belonging to Merce Cunningham, the dancer and choreographer, and his partner in life and work, the composer John Cage.

headline: Potential San Francisco Showdown Over Immigration
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Setting up a potential showdown with the mayor, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors reinstated an ordinance on Tuesday requiring that juvenile offenders who are illegal immigrants be convicted of a crime before they are turned over to the federal immigration authorities.

headline: Showcase: Don’t Mention the Tomb
text: Ulysses Grant, 63, is a retired postal worker. Named after his father, he lives alone in an apartment on the Hudson River in Ossining, N.Y., next door to Sing Sing Correctional Facility. Sharing the name of the 18th president hasn’t been easy, he said, as an alumnus of 12 anger management classes. His pride in the name has grown over the years. However, he added, “When somebody says a joke about Ulysses Grant or ‘Do you know who’s buried in Grant’s tomb,’ I just fly off the handle.”

headline: Phys Ed: The Best Exercises for Healthy Bones
text: Several weeks ago, The Journal of the American Medical Association published a study that should give pause to anyone who plans to live a long and independent life. The study looked at the incidence of hip fractures among older Americans and the mortality rates associated with them. Although the number of hip fractures has declined in recent decades, the study found that the 12-month mortality rate associated with the injury still hovers at more than 20 percent, meaning that, in the year after fracturing a hip, about one in five people over age 65 will die.

headline: Young John McCormack Makes New York Debut
text: Thursday, Nov. 11, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: 60 Years Later, ‘Rosies’ Have Their Day
text: Nearly 60 years later, Garnet Kozielec still marvels at the journey that took her from a job wrapping porcelain dishes to doing so-called “man’s work” making bombers and fighter jets and from her home in West Virginia to Michigan and then California.

headline: Mildred Cohn, Biochemist, Is Dead at 96
text: Mildred Cohn, a biochemist who overcame religious and sex discrimination to advance the study of metabolic processes, research that contributed to the development of medical technologies like M.R.I.’s, died on Oct. 12 in Philadelphia. She was 96.

headline: A National Disgrace
text: Two courts, one in Italy and one in the United States, ruled recently on the Bush administration’s practice of extraordinary rendition, which is the kidnapping of people and sending them to other countries for interrogation  and torture. The Italian court got it right. The American court got it miserably wrong.

headline: The Trouble With ‘Zero Tolerance’
text: Congress took a reasonable step in 1994 when it required states receiving federal education money to expel students who brought guns onto school property, but states and localities overreacted, as they so often do. They enacted “zero tolerance” policies under which children are sometimes arrested for profanity, talking back, shoving matches and other behavior that would once have been resolved with detention or meetings with the students’ parents.

headline: Cruel, Pointless Games
text: Iran’s mullah-led government seems determined to keep stoking tensions with the United States and the rest of the world. Despite President Obama’s offer to negotiate, it has blocked serious talks on its nuclear program and other issues. It has backpedaled on its agreement to ship enriched uranium out of the country, and it continues to threaten and abuse its own citizens who dare to speak out.

headline: Logitech Breaks Into Videoconferencing
text: In a move to break into the videoconferencing market, Logitech International has agreed to buy LifeSize Communications, a start-up that makes high-definition videoconferencing equipment, for $405 million in cash, The New York Times’s Claire Cain Miller reported.

headline: Homeless on Veterans Day
text: Gen. Eric Shinseki was famously shunned by the Bush administration for daring to state the true costs of occupying Iraq. As President Obama’s secretary of veterans affairs, he is, thankfully, no less candid about the grinding problems veterans face at home. They lead the nation in depression, suicide, substance abuse and homelessness, according to data that Mr. Shineski is delivering in salvos in his current role.

text: To the Editor:

text: WASHINGTON

headline: Trucks, Trains and Trees
text: Tapajós National Forest, Brazil

headline: Revolutionary Road
text: WITH the unemployment rate at 10.2 percent and job creation creeping along despite increased spending on infrastructure, we should look with new eyes at a resource we’ve failed to take full advantage of: the Interstate highway system.

headline: Prime Time
text: Prime Meats may not have a full dining room or menu yet; it may be cash-only, and its vintage-y bar may have no seats. But you will stand, and you will like it, because it’s still an excellent little spot, writes Sam Sifton, [LINK to Briefs] “a happy extension” of Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli’s mini-empire (Frankies 457 Spuntino, Frankies 17 Spuntino, et al). Go for the sautéed wild mushrooms with a poached Amish egg, the fine hamburger or quality steak, the cured meats, cabbage salads and excellent house-made pretzel. Order up a “crazy Prohibition cocktail ginned up by one of the mustachioed fellows behind the bar, some guy with absinthe in his eyes and a flaming goblet in front of him,” and soon enough you’ll find yourself chatting with the cook, David Colston, about hippos and Canadian Thanksgiving till 3 a.m. Or maybe that’s just us.

headline: It Lasts Longer
text: In an era of digital manipulation and trickery, documenting something with a photo is a lot more complicated than it seems. The  “New Photography” exhibit at MoMA explores this to great effect, writes Karen Rosenberg, evoking “the kind of debates about gesture, process and intent that used to coalesce around painting.” You can get good and liquored up and argue tonight, when the museum is open late for its PopRally series.Andrew Kuo, digital artist extraordinaire, supplies the beats; photo booths will be installed; creative dress rewarded.

headline: The Great Ghostdini
text: Ghostface Killah sings along to Billy Joel, refuses to smoke pot because it kills his mojo and hates ladies with rock-hard calves: these were the surprising facts we came away with when we sat with him in his car for an interview recently. Learn more about the erstwhile Wu-Tang Clanner tonight when he performs at BB King, in support of his new R&B-style album,  “Ghostdini Wizard of Poetry in Emerald City.”

headline: Word of the Day | slacken
text: slacken • \ˈsla-kən\ • verb

text: WHO are the people in this photo?

headline: A Cheap Nest for Fledgling Firms
text: When Lindsay Napor expanded her Manhattan-based development company earlier this year — moving out of free work space provided by an investor — she turned to the most logical place for the company’s new offices: New Jersey.

headline: News Quiz | November 11, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Carl Ballantine, Slapstick Magician, Dies at 92
text: Carl Ballantine, an inveterate quipmeister whose stand-up comedy persona, an incompetent magician known as the Amazing Ballantine or Ballantine the Great, predated and influenced the antic characters of Steve Martin and others, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Hollywood. He was 92.

headline: What Can Our Dreams Tell Us?
text: What do you think your dreams mean? Do you think they have a “crucial psychological purpose” in your life? What do you think of new research that argues that dreams are just the brain “warming its circuits”?Science Times writer Benedict Carey reports in “A Dream Interpretation: Tuneups for the Brain” on the latest findings by a sleep researcher:

headline: Parsing the Verdict on Bear Fund Managers
text: The case against two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers, Ralph Cioffi and Matthew Tannin, was the closest anything came to a trial over Wall Street’s role in the financial crisis. Their acquittal suggests that blame is not easily apportioned — and that mistakes, not conspiracies, offer the more likely explanation, Breakingviews.com argues.

headline: Loss at Singapore Air Is More Bad News for Temasek
text: Temasek Holdings, which in September posted a record 67 percent drop in net profit for the year ended March 31, is still getting bad news from its investments.

headline: Hong Kong Bourse Earnings Up, But Future Unsure
text: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing, the city’s stock exchange, faces increasing competition from China, posing a challenge for the world’s second-largest listed exchange operator to keep up the momentum on robust third-quarter profits.

headline: Wall St. Takes a Breather and Shares Close Flat
text: A day after a spirited rally sent the Dow to its highest levels since the beginning of the financial crisis, Wall Street took a moment to breathe, with stocks showing little or no gains on Tuesday.

headline: Baer Says Tax Fears Are Slowing Client Inflows
text: Julius Baer Group said Tuesday that an international clampdown on tax evasion had slowed the pace of money flowing in from wealthy clients since the middle of the year, Reuters reported.

headline: Curves and Surfaces
text: Images from “Eero Saarinen: Shaping the Future,” at the Museum of the City of New York.

headline: Cosmen Snubs National Express Rights Issue
text: National Express, the British bus and train operator, announced that it will raise about £360 million ($600 million) in a rights issue to pay down debt and avoid breaching loan terms, but said its largest shareholder, Jorge Cosmen, failed to back the cash call.

headline: Sanofi Taps Biotech Firm to Help Pipeline
text: Increasing its bet on biotechnology, Sanofi-Aventis said it would pay an additional $1 billion over eight years to Regeneron Pharmaceuticals for the discovery of new drugs.

headline: Boston Provident Executive Arrested for Fraud
text: Ezra Levy, the chief financial officer of Boston Provident Partners, was arrested Tuesday on charges of stealing more than $1.3 million from the Manhattan hedge fund, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Clawbacks Introduced at Commerzbank
text: Commerzbank, the second-largest German lender after Deutsche Bank, will introduce a clawback option to its bonus system next year as the banking industry tries to stop the short-term risk-taking that helped bring about the financial crisis.

headline: Ambac Warns of Possible Bankruptcy
text: Shares of bond insurer Ambac Financial Group sank 33 percent on Tuesday after the company warned it may be forced to seek bankruptcy protection if it cannot fix its liquidity problems, Reuters reported.

headline: F.D.I.C. Calls for Reserve Fund for Ailing Companies
text: A reserve fund must be established ahead of time to give the government the working capital it needs to dismantle large, troubled financial companies, a top United States bank regulator said Tuesday.

headline: Jury Out on Appeal for Lloyds Hybrids
text: Lloyds looks set to get investor support for a hybrid bond exchange into 7.5 billion pounds ($12.5 billion) of new enhanced capital notes, but it is not clear how much wider appeal these new securities will command, Reuters said.

headline: Military Divers Find Body of Missing American Soldier in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A week after two American soldiers disappeared in northwest Afghanistan, the body of one of them has been found by a military dive team, a NATO spokesman said Wednesday.

headline: For G.M., Work at Opel Includes Mending Fences
text: A week after angering German politicians and labor leaders by calling off plans to sell Opel to a group backed by Berlin, senior executives at General Motors promised more independence for the European unit.

headline: Grass Fed | Pop Some Coffee Cherries
text: Grass Fed features the culinary ramblings of the food writer Peter Meehan, the co-author of the Momofuku cookbook with David Chang and an all-around good eater.

headline: John Paulson Doubles Bet on Cadbury
text: John Paulson, the hedge fund manager whose wagers against the United States housing market earned him billions last year, has doubled his bet on Cadbury, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Chairman Says G.M. Can Repay Taxpayers
text: The chairman of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., said Tuesday that the automaker would be able to repay all of its government loans and would begin doing so soon.

headline: Senate Plan Would Expand Rules on Risky Lending
text: The chairman of the Senate banking committee proposed a financial overhaul on Tuesday that included consolidating bank regulators, creating a consumer financial protection agency and imposing new restraints on exotic financial instruments and credit rating agencies.

headline: Under Attack, Fed Chairman Studies Politics
text: With the Federal Reserve under more intense attack than at any time in decades, Ben S. Bernanke, the professorial chairman of the central bank, was schooled last month in how to handle the increased political demands of his job.

headline: A.I.G. Likely to Repay Bailout, Moody’s Says
text: The American International Group has made progress on its restructuring and will likely be able to repay a taxpayer bailout and buy back much of the government’s stake in the company, Moody’s Investors Service said on Monday.

headline: France and Germany Use the Remembrance of a War to Promote Reconciliation
text: PARIS  For the first time since the armistice that ended World War I with Germany’s defeat in 1918, a German leader joined French officials here to mark the moment the guns fell silent on the Western Front after a war that killed millions.

headline: A.I.G. Chief Is Said to Be Ready to Quit
text: After just three months as head of battered insurer American International Group, Robert E. Benmosche has threatened to leave his post as he struggles to deal with heavy government oversight and restrictions on what the bailed-out company wants to pay employees, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: How Does Prague Relax? Try Thai Massage.
text: After a day of traversing cobblestones, what could be better than getting jabbed in the back and pummeled on the head? Prague residents with that thought in their heads are in luck: the city is enveloped in a Thai massage craze. There are more than 40 Thai massage centers in the city, about half of which opened in the last five years.

headline: Toyetic
text: The potential of a movie or TV show to support spin-off toys and similar merchandising.

headline: TPG May Team With American for JAL Stake
text: TPG may be joining the fray in the battle over Japan Airlines.

headline: Q&A With Jeanne Dee, the Nomadic Family Traveler
text: Stories about traveling with children – like my column last week on taking my daughter, Sasha, on a frugal day trip to Washington, D.C.— always generate intense reader responses. For every positive comment (“Thanks for the great post!” wrote bklngirly), there’s invariably a negative one (“Maybe a visit from Child Protective Services is in order!” wrote Ellen Domeir). Which is why I’m amazed by SoulTravelers3.com, which chronicles the adventures of the Dee family — Jeanne, 57, Vince, 56, and their 9-year-old daughter, “Mozart” (they prefer not to give her real name).

headline: ING Swings Back to Profit in Third Quarter
text: The ING Groep, the bailed-out Dutch financial services company, said Wednesday it made a profit in the third quarter, ending a year of heavy losses, as financial market conditions recovered.

text: Kim Echlin is the author of several works of fiction, nonfiction and poetry. Her third novel, “The Disappeared,” will be published in January.

headline: Sampler: Sanctuary Vote, Trucker’s Family Speaks, Urban Casino
text: Big Rig Trucker’s Family | The family of Tahir Sheikh Fakhar, 56, of Hayward, who died Monday when his truck went off the Bay Bridge, says that Mr. Fakhar was a careful driver and that the bridge’s S-curve is unsafe.

headline: Does Silicon Valley’s Spending Spree Signal a Recovery?
text: This week brought acquisitions of three high-profile technology startups, a welcome break in the gloom that has enveloped Silicon Valley for the past year.

text: There are two major health threats in Park Slope at the moment, if you believe some of the neighborhood’s innumerable young and hyper-conscientious parents.

headline: ‘I Believe’ License Plate Banned by Judge
text: A United States District Judge has struck down a Christian-themed license plate that had been approved by the South Carolina Legislature, reports the BBC.

headline: Iran Executes Kurdish Activist Who Was Accused of ‘Armed Struggle’
text: TORONTO  Iran hanged a Kurdish activist on Wednesday morning in a prison in the Kurdish city of Sanandaj, his lawyer said.

headline: Steven Tyler Says He’s Not Quitting Aerosmith
text: The shortest rift in rock music history has been healed as the estranged Aerosmith band mates Steven Tyler and Joe Perry reunited on Tuesday night on a New York stage, where Mr. Tyler announced that he was not leaving the group.

headline: The Early Word: Soldiers and Wars
text: On Veterans Day, ceremonies around the country will honor members of the nation’s military who served in past and present wars.

headline: Somali Pirates Seize Cargo Ship
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia    Somali pirates said Wednesday that they had seized a container ship with 22 crew members on board after a five-hour chase across the Indian Ocean, reflecting both an increase in pirate activity after the end of monsoon storms and signs of increasing boldness among the hijackers.

headline: Spike Wants Viewers to Get ‘Schooled’ With New Football-Themed Series
text: Guys and sports, sports and guys. For cable channels trying to reach younger men, the gridiron, field, pitch and rink are where it’s happening.

headline: Switzerland Unveils Measures to Regulate Bank Pay
text: Switzerland announced watered-down measures to limit bank compensation Wednesday, imposing no caps on bonuses and excluding all but the country’s biggest financial services companies from mandatory compliance, David Jolly of The New York Times reported.

headline: G.M. Can Repay Taxpayers, Chairman Says
text: From our colleagues at DealBook:

headline: Crédit Agricole Profits Slide, and Chief Steps Down
text: Crédit Agricole, one of the largest French banks, said late Tuesday that it had taken in a profit of 289 million euros ($433 million) for the third quarter, down 21 percent from a year ago, and that its chief executive, Georges Pauget, would step down.

headline: The Morning Feed
text: What we’re reading on Wednesday morning.

headline: Study Says State Film Subsidies Underwrite Tobacco-Friendly Movies
text: A new report takes aim at state movie production subsidies for supporting films that depict smoking. Health researchers at the University of California, San Francisco, estimate that 60 percent of the $1.4 billion that states offered in 2008 to attract Hollywood filming went to movies with tobacco imagery.

headline: Team of the 2000s: Patriots, Colts or Steelers?
text: The Steelers’ 28-10 win over the Broncos on Monday night was their 100th in the regular season since the start of the 2000 season. The Steelers are the third team to surpass the century mark in the 2000s, joining the Colts (109) and the Patriots (108), but they will probably not be the last. The Eagles, who have 97 wins, should reach the milestone. But Philadelphia will most likely be the only member of the group to emerge from the 2000s without a Super Bowl title. (They would join the Bills of the 1990s, who had 103 wins but no titles.)Most Wins by Decade

headline: Forum Reflects Copenhagen Divisions
text: Speaking at a symposium organized by the Council on Foreign Relations in Washington on Tuesday, Atul Arya, the chief adviser for energy and climate policy for BP, the British oil company, said the odds of achieving a broad, global agreement at climate talks in Copenhagen next month were “very, very low.”

headline: Wednesday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Executors Named for Jackson Estate Over Objection of Singer’s Father
text: A Superior Court judge in Los Angeles made two longtime associates of Michael Jackson the executors of the singer’s estate on Tuesday, dismissing a challenge filed by Mr. Jackson’s father, Joe, Reuters reported. Judge Mitchell Beckloff named the lawyer John G. Branca and the music executive John McClain the executors of the estate, which is expected to take in $200 million this year in revenues from the Jackson concert documentary “This Is It,” as well as the accompanying soundtrack album and other business deals. Mr. Branca and Mr. McClain were already serving as the administrators of the estate. Joe Jackson had petitioned the court to say that it should set up a monthly allowance for him, similar to the one established for the singer’s mother, Katherine Jackson, but the judge said he had no standing to challenge his son’s will.

headline: ‘The Good Wife’ Watch: Ethics Testing
text: “The Good Wife” is packed with paradox the way that “Mad Men” thrives on cigarettes and Manhattans. But it’s paradox as parable: in every episode, the heroine, Alicia, learns that things are not as they seem.

headline: German Sentenced to Life for Killing in Court
text: BERLIN  The German man who stabbed a pregnant Egyptian woman to death in a Dresden courtroom was found guilty on Wednesday and given a life sentence.

headline: Reinvented Galaxy and Dynamic Dynamo Benefit From Consistency
text: For all of the L.A. Galaxy’s success this season, built on the explosiveness of a resurgent Landon Donovan and the savvy of a recommitted David Beckham, it’s difficult to escape the all-too-painful and all-too-recent past.

headline: Help Wanted: Operations Manager
text: In previous posts, I’ve shared some of the hiring mistakes we’ve made over the years. I think we are finally learning how to ensure that we hire someone who is the right fit for our culture. Hiring someone with the right skill set, though, is a different story. I’m still trying to figure this out — and learning a lot in the process. I’ve been fortunate to have found some pretty special people for my team, one of which is my current operations coordinator.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Remembrance Day in Toronto
text: Six games on Tuesday night, but it’d be hard to come up with a less intriguing slate of matchups; not a single contest featured two teams currently in a playoff position.

headline: At Arafat Memorial, Abbas Pushes Independence Fight
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Thousands of Palestinians turned out Wednesday for a rally here on the fifth anniversary of the death of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and to show support for his successor, President Mahmoud Abbas, who recently expressed an intention to retire.

headline: Obama Salutes Fallen Americans on Veterans Day
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama hailed the sacrifice and determination of the nation’s military on Wednesday as he delivered a Veterans Day tribute at Arlington National Cemetery, a hallowed place where he said the “grief remains fresh.”

headline: Flashback: On ‘Slow Drips,’ From Trash to CO2
text: On slow drips, from trash in the sea to CO2 in the atmosphere.

headline: Rupert Murdoch: Unalloyed, Unbound
text: Folks in the media are so used to considering Rupert Murdoch as a spectral presence that it is sometimes hard to remember that behind a name so freighted with meaning lurks a real actual guy. That’s why it’s fun spending time watching Sky News Australia’s 37-minute interview with him. There is no major news splash, but there is value in watching Mr. Murdoch’s mind and mouth work in the long on-camera interview with Sky’s David Speers last week.

headline: What to Watch Wednesday: ‘Glee,’ Country Music Awards, ‘Return to Duty’
text: What to Watch on Wednesday:

headline: Job Woes Exacting a Toll on Family Life
text: THE WOODLANDS, Tex.  Paul Bachmuth’s 9-year-old daughter, Rebecca, began pulling out strands of her hair over the summer. His older child, Hannah, 12, has become noticeably angrier, more prone to throwing tantrums.

headline: ‘Sesame Street’ Producers Respond to ‘Pox News’ Dispute
text: An executive for Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit organization that produces “Sesame Street,” said a segment on that show that upset political conservatives was “equal-opportunity parody,” making fun of CNN as much as it was making fun of Fox News.

headline: Officials Search for Answers in Extensive Brazil Blackout
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  A huge power failure involving the world’s largest operating hydroelectric plant this week was the worst in its 25 years of use, Brazilian officials said Wednesday, causing widespread blackouts that exposed the vulnerability of Brazil’s electricity infrastructure.

headline: A Revelatory Upside-Down Cake
text: I well remember the first time I ate tarte Tatin; it was a revelation. The first time I ate upside-down cake, its close relative, was not so stunning, but I was much younger and, after all, it’s not as surprising a creation. I believe, though, that the pear upside-down cake that is the subject of this week’s Mini narrows the differences.

headline: Performa 09: Dancing With Sculpture
text: Performa’s founder and prime mover, Roselee Goldberg, has great instincts for which artists might collaborate well together. Her instincts were right with Tamar Ettun and Emily Coates, who cooked up “Empty Is Also,” a dance with changing sculpture that was performed on Saturday evening at the X Initiative in Chelsea.

headline: Gift Guide | Small Packages
text: Our Winter Design & Living issue proved that good design needn’t be an exclusively grown-up affair. In that spirit, here we offer eight items perfect for discerning tots — they’ll be warm, stylish and comfy from play group to picture day.

headline: Going Vegetarian for Thanksgiving
text: Who needs turkey? Thanksgiving is an ideal time to test out new vegetarian recipes that could quickly become everyday favorites.

headline: Obama Pays Tribute to Veterans
text: President Obama placed a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknowns on Wednesday as he paid tribute to America’s veterans at Arlington National Cemetery.

headline: Travel Deals: Discounts on Holland America, Virgin America and British Airways
text: Lots of deals today: Holland America has a three-day cruise sale, Virgin America has discounted cross-country fares, and British Airways has dropped fares from 19 cities in the United States.

headline: Women in Charge at Tate Britain and Venice Architecture Biennale
text: The Tate Gallery said on Wednesday that it had appointed Penelope Curtis the director of its Tate Britain museum in London. In a news release, the Tate said that Ms. Curtis, who has served since 1999 as the curator of the Henry Moore Institute in Leeds, earned a masters degree and a Ph.D. at the Courtauld Institute of Art in London, and has overseen the acquisition of many works for the institute’s sculpture collection, including pieces by Rodin, Epstein and Calder. Dr. Curtis also served on the the British Council Committee for the Venice Biennale in 2008 and the Turner Prize Jury. Of the four museums in the Tate Gallery’s network, the Tate Britain is the oldest, with an emphasis on both historic and contemporary British art.

headline: Kids or Young Adults? Facing Life in Prison
text: In Washington this week, the Supreme Court heard arguments over whether judges should take into account the age of a convicted juvenile offender when considering issuing life sentences. The court may be leaning in favor of this outcome, some reports indicate.

headline: More Wordplay Changes
text: Now that our new co-blogger has settled in, it’s time to announce two more Wordplay changes.

headline: His Facebook Status Now? ‘Charges Dropped’
text: Where’s my pancakes, read Rodney Bradford’s Facebook page, in a message typed on Saturday, Oct. 17, at 11:49 a.m., from a computer in his father’s apartment in Harlem.

headline: Veterans and Journeymen
text: On days like Veterans Day, sports like to wrap themselves in patriotism, roll pictures of military members across their video boards and try to make you forget the sheer silliness of commonly referring to games as wars and to luxury S.U.V.-driving professional athletes as warriors. Sometimes sports gets it right, and there are stories like the Giants’ heartwarming two-way relationship with the injured Iraq veteran Lt. Col. Greg Gadson, which got an appropriate update Wednesday from ESPN.com’s Greg Garber, or the story of the Titans’ Marine turned fullback Ahmard Hall.

headline: China’s Tough Flu Measures Appear to Be Effective
text: CHANGGANG, China  Few farmers in this southern village gave much thought to the epidemic that had begun spreading rapidly in the United States early this summer until the authorities sealed its 100 residents off from the outside world for about a week. It turned out that a visitor from California had shown symptoms of the swine flu virus, or H1N1, when he arrived for a funeral.

headline: Wealth Manager Faces Charges in Madoff Case
text: Update | 1:35 p.m. A Swiss court has charged the head of a large investment firm with criminal mismanagement in connection with the multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme run by the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff.

headline: Carroll Shelby’s New Oil Comes From Olives
text: Car guys and oil just seem to mix well — and not just motor oil.

headline: Union Members Getting More Educated
text: My colleague Steven Greenhouse has an article today about this new report on the changing demographics of labor unions. The paper was released by the Center for Economic and Policy Research, a liberal research group in Washington.

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': Janacek’s Music
text: JIM OESTREICH: We’re going to want to hear more from Charles about Patrice Chéreau. But first let’s close the loop and begin to delve into the musical aspects of “From the House of the Dead.” Tony, why don’t you set the scene by telling us something about Leos Janacek, his career and this opera in particular. Maybe you could even let us a hear a sample or two.

headline: Breast-Feed the Baby, Love the Calorie Burn
text: WHEN Jessica Jochim returned to work after her three-month maternity leave, she was the envy of her co-workers at Babies “R” Us. Mrs. Jochim, who had gained 40 pounds carrying her first child, steadily slimmed until she was a size 4 again. Yet, exercise was a pre-baby relic. She wasn’t dieting, either. In fact, every two hours, she snacked as if on cue.

headline: Floating Flotsam: Studying the Causes and Effects of the Pacific Garbage Patch
text: Overview | Why do scientists seek evidence to support cause-and-effect relationships that seem obvious to the casual observer? What is the value of studying environmental problems in depth before acting to address them? How do public awareness and economic factors affect what actions are taken with regard to waste and pollution? In this lesson, students reflect on the Pacific garbage patch and recent scientific voyages to study the effects of plastic and other debris on water quality and oceanic life.

headline: Paris Dancers Headed to New York in Ballet Exchange
text: Over the years, France has given New York everything from the Statue of Liberty to Daniel Boulud, and now, in its latest act of trans-Atlantic generosity, it plans to lend the city a pair of dancers from the the Paris Opera Ballet. The New York City Ballet said that Aurélie Dupont and Mathias Heymann, both Étoiles with the Paris Opera Ballet, would perform at City Ballet’s opening-night benefit. Ms. Dupont and Mr. Heymann (who are among the dancers featured in the Frederick Wiseman documentary “La Danse: The Paris Opera Ballet”) are to perform the “Rubies” pas de deux from George Balanchine’s “Jewels.” The other half of the bargain (struck by Brigitte Lefèvre, the dance director of the Paris Opera Ballet, and Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of City Ballet) is that Paris gets to borrow Ashley Bouder and Gonzalo Garcia, principal dancers from City Ballet, who will dance the leading roles in “Rubies” for the Paris Opera Ballet on Thursday at the Palais Garnier. The City Ballet benefit will take place on Nov. 24 at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.

headline: Asked and Answered | Miss J of ‘Top Model’
text: J. Alexander, better known as Miss J on “America’s Next Top Model,” is a well-loved figure. We were in Savannah, Ga., together a few months ago for the SCAD graduation fashion show, and when we sat down at a quaint little ice cream parlor at least 10 people came up to our table, fumbling for cellphones to get a picture with the modeling coach diva. (He does not allow pictures taken with phones, only with cameras, thank you.) With the debut of his first book, “Follow the Model,” we are sure all those fans will be eager to learn a bit more about the man who modeled in drag in Japan, loves cake and hates the word “fierce.”

headline: The Iraqi Elections: Same Names, Different Teams
text: After much delay, the Iraqi Parliament finally passed a law on Sunday allowing for national parliamentary elections — the third since the American invasion in 2003. Voting is scheduled to take place in the second half of January.

headline: What War Is Good For
text: The confluence of the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall and Veterans Day (Armistice Day in Europe) has prompted numerous observations in opinionland, though perhaps none have proved so contentious as Robert D. Kaplan’s short meditation on “The Fall of the Wall,” at the Atlantic.

headline: Motorola Is Seeking Buyers for Mobility Unit
text: Update | 2:30 p.m. DealBook has confirmed that Motorola has hired JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs to explore a sale of its home and networks mobility division, according to people briefed on the matter. Several private equity firms have been approached, but the process is in the early stages, these people said.

headline: Answers About Entrepreneurship
text: Following is the first set of answers from Seth W. Pinsky, the president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation.

headline: Tuning Out the Taliban
text: The lyrics and videos of some Pakistani rock songs reflect widespread views among educated young fans that the West is more of a problem than the Taliban.

headline: Should School Newspapers Be Subject to Prior Review?
text: Many school papers are required to follow “prior review.” This means having to let their sources, and sometimes administrators, approve quotes and other coverage before going to print. Should student journalists be subject to different standards and practices than professional journalists? Adam Liptak reported today that the school newspaper at Dalton, a Manhattan private school, had to hold its coverage of a speech by Supreme Court Justice Anthony M. Kennedy:

headline: The New Museum’s Web of Connections
text: An article on Wednesday described concerns in the art world over the propriety of a coming show at the New Museum that will feature the private collection of a museum trustee, Dakis Joannou, and be curated by Jeff Koons. Mr. Koons is an artist whom Mr. Joannou collects extensively, and the article noted that critics of the museum consider it to be enmeshed in what can seem like a dizzyingly insular circle of art world insiders.

headline: Seeking Revival, City to Buy Land in Coney Island
text: After a year of ultimatums, threats and stop-and-go talks, the Bloomberg administration has agreed to pay $95.6 million to a developer for seven acres in the heart of Coney Island, according to executives on both sides of the negotiations. It is a crucial step forward for the city’s vision of turning the faded and mostly dormant seaside amusement district into an exciting destination reminiscent of its heyday.

headline: Shooting the Last Episodes of NBC’s ‘Trauma’
text: Correction | 11:30 a.m. Wednesday  An earlier version of this post and its headline incorrectly stated that the local shooting of “Trauma” had ended on Tuesday. The post now reflects NBC’s confirmation that the canceled show is currently shooting the 11th of its 13 scheduled episodes.

headline: Pogue & Friends 2009 Holiday Guide
text: The Times's personal technology columnist, David Pogue, teams up with Mark Bittman, author of The Minimalist column, to test gadgets for the kitchen.

headline: Answers About Home Buyers’ and Owners’ Tax Credits: Part 2
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you’ll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Hannity to Address Protest Video Questions
text: “The Daily Show,” which has become one of the media’s prime monitors when it comes to calling out misuse or manipulation of video, caught the Fox News Channel and one of its hosts, Sean Hannity, Tuesday night, in what appeared to be a blatant example of doctoring a report with inappropriate video to enhance an argument.

headline: Lessons From a Military Wife
text: Alison Buckholtz is spending this Veterans Day near home in Potomac, Md., with her son, Ethan, who is 6, and her daughter, Esther, 4, while her husband spends the day flying fighter jets in Iraq.

headline: Harlem Program Could Close Education Gap
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …Roland Fryer’s research on education indicates that Harlem Children’s Zone provides an effective model for closing the black-white achievement gap. [Freakonomics]

headline: Speech Gene Shows Its Bossy Nature
text: Of the 20,000 genes in the human genome, few are more fascinating than FOXP2, a gene that underlies the faculty of human speech.

headline: Thursday Matchup: Bears at 49ers
text: Bears (4-4) at 49ers (3-5)Thursday, 8:20 p.m.Line: 49ers by 3

headline: Bank of England Expected to Spend More
text: LONDON  The Bank of England said on Wednesday that it was open to pumping more money into the still-struggling economy, a warning to economists who had interpreted recent steps as a sign that the central bank would shift its focus to controlling inflation.

headline: ‘Waterfalls’ Artist Has a New Bridge to Sell You
text: Olafur Eliasson, the Danish-Icelandic artist who created the temporary waterfalls in New York’s East River last year, is at work on a project that will give the residents of another city a different way of looking at a nearby body of water. On Wednesday, the city of Copenhagen said that Mr. Eliasson would create a bridge there, called Cirkelbroen (“circle bridge”), which would provide a winding path across the city’s Christianshavns Kanal. In a news release, Mr. Eliasson said the bridge, whose design was inspired by the sailing ships that pass through the canal, would consist of five circular platforms with their own “masts.” In a statement, he said he hoped the bridge would “reduce speed” and “turn focus.” “Rather than offering the fastest possible passage across the canal,” Mr. Eliasson said, “the bridge will create small variations in the way we see the city and open for a renegotiation of public space.” The bridge is being given as a gift to Copenhagen from the Nordea-foundation, which promotes healthy living and outdoor activities. It is expected to be completed in 2012 and cost about $6.8 million; Copenhagen is contributing about $1.5 million.

headline: Pakistan Rock Rails Against the West, Not the Taliban
text: While Pakistani journalists, playwrights and even moderate Islamic clerics have boldly condemned the Taliban, the nation’s pop music stars have yet to sing out against the group, which continues to claim responsibility for daily bombings.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Prisoner'
text: Ian McKellen and Jim Caviezel star in this new version of the cult spy series from the 1960s, which begins Sunday on AMC.

headline: Carrie Underwood Is No. 1; Billboard Chart to Include Older Titles
text: Carrie Underwood’s new album, “Play On” (19/Arista Nashville), easily reached the top of the Billboard chart this week, outselling Michael Jackson and new releases by Andrea Bocelli and Weezer.

headline: La Guardia’s Tough and Incorruptible Police Commissioner
text: The swearing-in of Lewis J. Valentine for a third five-year term as police commissioner took just minutes. Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, who conducted the 1944 ceremony, declared curtly, “If it were necessary to make any speeches or statements you would not be reappointed.”

headline: S.C. Senator Gets Slammed Back Home
text: Senator Lindsey Graham, the Republican with a maverick streak, has been censured by local Republican Party officials in his home state of South Carolina.

headline: Feeling for … ’80s Shades
text: It seems that with every fashion season there is a new 1980s moment — it’s become as predictable as a catfight between the strong-shouldered demon ladies on “Dynasty.” Having said that, an interesting ’80s revival is happening on Abbot Kinney Boulevard, the nerve center for West L.A. style makers. Garrett Leight, a native of Venice, Calif., and the 25-year-old son of the Oliver Peoples eyewear founder Larry Leight, has started A. Kinney Court, a specialized eyewear gallery and boutique for men and women. The store’s centerpiece is a rare assortment of vintage Oliver Peoples frames, dating as far back as 1987. Classic clip-on sunglasses, as well as the famous O’Malley frame (based on retro shades from the 1950s), will be showcased along with a revolving selection of other rare finds rediscovered by Larry and Garrett after carefully sifting through boxes in multiple storage units. The frames come with original blue, green and brown vintage tint lenses to complete the period-perfect look; Garrett will soon complete his optician’s license exams to make sure his customers’ vision is as sharp as their look. The store, which opened this week and is situated around a vast courtyard hangout, carries other design-minded optical lines like Mykita, Thierry Lasry and KBL Eyewear, as well as shoes and apparel for men and women from Becca Moon and LnA, a casual sportswear line. I’m feeling for it!

headline: Mormon Support of Gay Rights Statute Draws Praise
text: The Mormon Church has been a target of vituperation by some gay rights groups because of its active opposition to same-sex marriage. But on Wednesday, the church was being praised by gay rights activists in Salt Lake City, citadel of the Mormon world, for its open support of a local ordinance banning discrimination against gay men and lesbians in housing and employment.

headline: The Self-Manufacture of Megan Fox
text: I.

headline: A Gallery Gadfly Revives His Act
text: ONE drizzly Friday night last month dozens of people had crowded into Invisible-Exports, a gallery on Orchard Street, to celebrate the opening of a show by the conceptual artist Stephen Irwin. Works on paper lined the long, hallwaylike space, starting out with white Minimalist abstractions by the front windows and progressing to more figurative imagery at the back.

headline: ABC Cancels the Kelsey Grammer Series ‘Hank’
text: It’s not just Hank Pryor who’s out of a job — Kelsey Grammer, who played that unemployed executive on the new sitcom “Hank,” will once again be seeking work. ABC has canceled the show, The Hollywood Reporter said. The network said it would halt production on the series after work is completed on a 10th episode. Five episodes have been broadcast, and ABC has not yet announced its plans for the five remaining episodes it will have on hand. “Hank” is the second short-lived series for Mr. Grammer, who played the unctuous Dr. Frasier Crane for 20 years on “Cheers” and “Frasier”. His sitcom “Back to You,” on which he and Patricia Heaton played rival television news anchors, ran for one season on Fox in 2007-8.

headline: How About Skipping Turkey Completely?
text: While writing and plotting my freedom-from-turkey manifesto in theDining section, I admit that I forgot my most obvious constituents:vegetarians.

headline: Snowboarding + Math = Olympic Success?
text: Who says that statistics and shredding don’t mix?

headline: Does Silicon Valley’s Spending Spree Signal a Recovery?
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: A Soprano’s Hat Trick: Puccini Triple Bill
text: LIFE is what happens while we are making other plans. Growing up in blue-collar Bedford, N.H., Patricia Racette sang jazz and played guitar, and when someone asked her to join the choir, her answer was “No, I sing alone.” Then she joined anyway, as a second alto.

headline: Benmosche Says He’s ‘Totally Committed’ to A.I.G.
text: The chief executive of the American International Group, Robert H. Benmosche, told employees on Wednesday that he was committed to leading the insurance giant despite disagreements with the Treasury Department over executive compensation, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

headline: In Concert: Talent, Style and Sequins
text: BEFORE an October recital at the First Presbyterian Church in Germantown, a run-down Philadelphia neighborhood, the organist Cameron Carpenter wandered through the audience, shaking hands and signing programs. Then he changed from black jeans and boots into tight trousers and a shirt covered in Swarovski crystals, which glistened under the lights as he played works of Bach and his own transcriptions, including a remarkable version of Schubert’s song “Der Erlkönig.”

headline: Photo of the Week
text: Members of a rare subspecies of giraffes known as Giraffa camelopardalis peralta walk through scrub brush near Koure, Niger.

headline: Provocateur at Home, a Monarch Abroad
text: WHEN the American choreographer D D Dorvillier told her mother about an exciting new job she had taken in France, working with Anne Collod and a cast of European choreographers to revisit Anna Halprin’s seminal 1965 dance, “Parades & Changes,” her mother had just one question: Did this mean Ms. Dorvillier would be taking her clothes off again?

headline: Sleazy Listening | Betty Davis Rides Again
text: Long before Lady Gaga, Beyoncé or even Madge, there was Betty Davis. Not the smoky-eyed “All About Eve” star, but the preternaturally funky 1970s diva whose high-voltage performances could melt the black off tar. She was light years ahead of her leisure-suited contemporaries, who didn’t get Davis’s piercing growl, far-out fashions and sexually charged funk-acid rock amalgam. But now, with Light In the Attic Records releasing two of Davis’s long-lost albums, “Nasty Gal” (1975) and “Is It Love or Desire” (1976), the time is right for us late adopters to catch up to this sassy soul sensation.

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': From Theater to Opera
text: JIM OESTREICH: Charles, back to you. You were discussing Patrice Chéreau’s work in theater, film and opera. Does that kind of crossover happen often?

headline: Overhaul at Disney Studios Picks Up Speed
text: The reorganization under way at the Walt Disney Studios accelerated on Wednesday with the promotion of several lieutenants and the jettisoning of over a dozen midlevel marketing, distribution and operations officials. The move comes after the dismissal of three top executives at the studio within the last two months: Dick Cook, the former chairman; Daniel Battsek, the president of Miramax Films; and, on Monday, Mark Zoradi, president of the Walt Disney Motion Pictures Group.

headline: D.I.Y. Stardom in London
text: LONDON | If you’re looking to get in touch with your inner performer, a handful of London venues are more than willing to provide you with a spotlight.

headline: Looking at NFL Network’s Lineup of Games
text: The NFL Network starts broadcasting its weekly game on Thursday.Here’s a peek at the schedule (my comments in parentheses)

headline: Brammo Cuts Price on Enertia Electric Motorcycle
text: The makers of the Brammo Enertia announced a significant price cut on Tuesday, dropping the electric-powered motorcycle’s price from $11,995 to $7,995. Subtracting the value of a federal income tax incentive, the company pointed out, can bring the price down to $7,195.

headline: Sounds From Around the World, Some Dark, Others Delicate
text: Ithamara Koorax & Juarez Moreira

headline: The Chronicler of Street Culture
text: For those who think that graffiti, such as the work of the recently-arrested tagger, Girafa, is vandalism, the work of Ari Marcopoulos is probably not for you.

headline: A Big Drop in Ad Pages for Condé Nast
text: Condé Nast’s ad-page numbers are in, and they explain why the company has had such a rough 2009.

headline: Here Comes Another Poor Boy
text: Some say the po-boy, the signature sandwich of New Orleans, is imperiled.

headline: Awed and Depressed by a Health Care Bill
text: Gail Collins: David, when I watched the House of Representatives pass the health care bill over the weekend, I felt the same combination of depression and awe I generally get when I watch Congress do something large. So ambitious! So deeply flawed! Why isn’t it better? But how did they ever manage to get it done?

headline: A Woman’s Tough Climb to the Police Force
text: The lot of police officers isn’t easy, and for black women on the force it’s much harder. That would be the view of “Savannah Black & Blue,” the tale of one such officer in the New York Police Department. The playwright, Raymond Jones, knows the milieu. According to press materials for this Negro Ensemble Company production, Mr. Jones, a lieutenant in the Bronx district attorney’s office, interviewed a number of women in the department for research.

headline: Museum Directors on Collectors and Exhibitions
text: An article on Wednesday described concerns in the art world over the propriety of a coming show at the New Museum that will feature the private collection of a museum trustee, Dakis Joannou. In interviews, the directors of the Brooklyn Museum and the Metropolitan Museum of Art discussed their recent exhibitions featuring private collections.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Nov. 11
text: If Pictures of the Day may be said to have a theme — and sometimes they do — today’s is most certainly: ritual. The observance of Veterans Day comes first and foremost, not just at Arlington National Cemetery but at Camp Eggers in Afghanistan (Slide 2). Elsewhere were the rituals of soccer ticket queueing — a dangerous contact sport in and of itself (Slide 3); of a visit from the Dalai Lama (Slide 4); and of parental anxiety over college admission prospects (Slide 8). There is also evidence, in Slide 12, of how rituals change to meet the realities of the day.

headline: Exploring the Softer Side of a Choreographer’s Skills
text: Tere O’Connor is a master of the quick fade, in which emotions and movement bubble up and vanish with little warning. In his dense choreography, transitions defy logic, meaning is made purposely hazy, and the art of subterfuge is omnipresent. As his new piece “Wrought Iron Fog” attests, this can work for and against him.

headline: Window Watchers in a City of Strangers
text: WHEN Suzi Jones and her husband purchased an apartment on the fourth floor of a brownstone in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, two years ago, Ms. Jones, a freelance art director from Atlanta, thought what she would like most would be the hardwood floors, the tin ceilings and the renovated kitchen and bathroom.

headline: Now Accessorizing | Ligia Dias for Club Monaco
text: Club Monaco has long been known for its no-frills basics, like affordable boyfriend blazers and men’s-wear-inspired button-downs. Perhaps realizing that savvy downtown girls have been wearing Tom Binns jewelry with tees and jeans, Club Monaco is introducing a jewelry collaboration with Ligia Dias, who designed baubles for Lanvin for three years before starting her own line in 2005. (Rei Kawakubo snagged her to embellish the knitwear for the fall 2006 Comme des Garçons collection.) The line for Club Monaco will consist of five pieces, combining the utilitarian with the refined — Dias mixed rope and brass with pearls and crystals. It is available at select Club Monaco stores and ranges in price from $149 to $399.

headline: Entrepreneurs Press On, and Obstacles Fall
text: MOST entrepreneurs gauge success in numbers like dollars and market share. Jennifer VanDerHorst-Larson measures it, in part, in the words her son speaks and writes.

headline: Producers of ‘Tony N’ Tina’s Wedding’ Say Union’s Claim Is ‘Untrue’
text: The producers of the New York stage show “Tony N’ Tina’s Wedding” disputed the account of a musicians’ union that said its members were locked out of the show, saying in response that the union is trying to force them to uphold an old contract using “untrue words and accusations.”

headline: Sounds of China, Unveiled Like an Iris
text: Over the last three weeks ensembles of all kinds have dropped into Carnegie Hall to explore the exchange of musical influences between China and the West as part of the hall’s festival Ancient Paths, Modern Voices. The concerts have had colorful moments, some in performances by traditional ensembles of various kinds, but most in works for Western orchestra drawing on Chinese themes and timbres.

headline: Farewell to the ‘Dollhouse’ As Fox Ends Show
text: Update | 5:09 p.m.  That shudder you felt through your computer keyboard was the Internet responding all at once to the news that “Dollhouse” has been canceled. The Hollywood Reporter said that Fox was shutting down the series, created by Joss Whedon (of “Buffy,” “Angel” and “Firefly” fame) and starring Eliza Dushku as an enigmatic special agent whose memories and identity can be completely altered from mission to mission. The series suffered low ratings following its debut in February, but Fox unexpectedly picked up the series for its 2009-2010 season, and the show seemed to be building an online fan base. Fox had pulled the show for its November sweeps period, but the network said it would broadcast the remaining episodes it had ordered. In a message posted on the Web site whedonesque.com, Mr. Whedon wrote that he was proud of the show and the people who worked on it, adding: “I’m grateful that we got to put it on, and then come back and put it on again.”

headline: In the Holidays, Hope for the Jobless
text: For job seekers, the news that the unemployment rate has risen to 10.2 percent is dispiriting, and may even tip a few into the “discouraged” category  those who feel so hopeless that they stop looking and are no longer included in that statistic.

headline: De-glitched, the C64’s Up and Running Again
text: The on-again, off-again Commodore 64 app for Apple is on again in the iTunes app store, now improved over the original version that appeared—but only briefly—in September.

headline: Bird-Watching Opera Lover’s Gift to Met Confirmed
text: The executrix for an opera lover in Edinburgh who willed much of her fortune to the Metropolitan Opera confirmed reports about the extent of the gift: around $7.5 million (less 40 percent in taxes), according to a Met official. The executrix said she did not have a precise amount but said that accounts in British papers about the bequest, left by Mona Webster, who died last summer at 96, were accurate. The Met official, Gail Chesler, the director of planned and special gifts, said she had dinner with the executrix, a lawyer from Edinburgh who was in New York, before Tuesday’s performance of “Turandot.”

headline: Sweet and Sour Winter Squash
text: This dish is based on a Sicilian recipe that I learned from the food writer Clifford A. Wright. The sweet and sour flavors are typical of Sicilian cuisine, though I have changed the technique used in the authentic version, which entails sautéing the squash in a lot more oil.

headline: Baked Acorn Squash With Walnut Oil and Maple Syrup
text: Acorn squash has a mild flavor and goes well with sweet and nutty seasonings. This makes a nice Thanksgiving side dish, though you might want to cut the baked halves in half again for smaller portions.

headline: Hands of Fate Diverge at Sealy and Simmons
text: Update | Nov. 12, 7:40 a.m. Divergent private equity strategies appear to be a big factor in explaining why two seemly identical mattress companies, Sealy and Simmons, came out of the financial crisis in such different shape.

headline: Other Voices on the New Museum’s Exhibition
text: Update | 6:28 p.m. The New Museum’s decision to feature the private art collection of one of its trustees has prompted coverage in addition to The Times’ article Wednesday, including numerous postings by Tyler Green, on his blog, Modern Art Notes, Wiliam Powhida’s graphic analysis of the insular interconnections of New Museum players on the cover of the November issue of The Brooklyn Rail, and an article, op-ed column and letter from the New Museum in The Art Newspaper.

headline: Now Showing | Sharon Core at the Gallery at Hermès
text: The photographer Sharon Core has accrued an almost cultlike group of followers, including yours truly and a handful of editors here at T. The Moment caught up with Core to talk about “Early American,” a new exhibition of breathtaking still lifes, which opens tonight at New York’s Gallery at Hermès.

headline: Illegal Immigration May Be a Rift Issue
text: Abortion will not be the only social issue dividing Congress as it seeks to construct a compromise health care bill capable of passing both houses. The legislation the House passed on Saturday by a narrow margin also sets up a looming confrontation with the Senate over the extent to which illegal immigrants should have access to public resources.

headline: Hewlett-Packard to Acquire 3Com
text: Hewlett-Packard said on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to acquire 3Com, a provider of computer network equipment, for $2.7 billion in a deal that H.P. plans as a springboard for an assault on the market leader in networking, Cisco Systems.

headline: Canadian Literary Prize Goes to ‘The Bishop’s Man,’ About Sexual Abuse by Priests
text: The Scotiabank Giller Prize, the annual Canadian literary award, was awarded to Linden McIntyre for his novel “The Bishop’s Man.” The novel, narrated by a priest who is charged with suppressing evidence of sexual abuse of children by other priests, was one of five finalists. Mr. McIntyre, a co-host of “The Fifth Estate,” an investigative journalism program on CBT, received an award of about $48,000. The prize garnered a flurry of attention in September when Alice Munro, widely considered a likely nominee for her short-story collection, “Too Much Happiness,” said she was withdrawing the book from consideration because she had previously won the prize twice and wanted to give younger writers a chance to win.

headline: Screen Test: Megan Fox
text: Lynn Hirschberg talks to Megan Fox about swimming, the X-Men and her cats.

headline: Candidates in Mass. Senate Race Spar Over Stupak Measure
text: It’s not surprising that the health care legislation, which the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy spent years fighting for, has become a large issue in the campaign for his Senate seat. The unexpected part is that two candidates are fighting about whether or not to support the legislation.

headline: For District 24 Qualifiers, One Deal Was a Standout
text: The three pairs that will represent District 24 (New York City and Long Island) in the North American Open Pairs Championship in Reno, Nev., next March will be Jared Lilienstein and Michael Polowan of New York; Alan Miller of New York and Alex Ornstein of Roslyn Heights, N.Y.; and Simon Erlich and Jeffrey Rothstein of New York. The qualifying tournament was played at the Vanderbilt Bridge Club in Lake Success, N.Y., on Sunday.

headline: Hits to Head Pressuring the N.H.L. to Change
text: With a rash of head injuries sidelining a number of N.H.L. players, including the Rangers’ captain, Chris Drury, the league’s general managers, in a change of position, said they would study measures to eliminate blindside hits to the head and shoulder hits to the head.

headline: Hewlett-Packard to Buy 3Com for $2.7 Billion
text: Update | 5:41 p.m. The New York Times’s Steve Lohr has more details on Hewlett-Packard‘s deal for 3Com.

headline: A Team, but Watch How You Put It
text: LAS VEGAS  Andre Agassi’s new memoir, “Open,” is an unusual addition to the shelves of jock autobiography. For one thing it’s honest in a way that such books seldom are. Mr. Agassi famously admits that he took crystal meth and lied about it, and that he sometimes tanked matches he had no interest in playing. He also reveals that to amuse himself he lighted fires in hotel rooms, that his notorious mullet hairdo was partly a wig, that after 1997 he gave up wearing underwear on the court and that at his first wedding, to Brooke Shields, he wore lifts in his shoes so she could wear heels.

headline: Now Reading | ‘Prada’
text: Prada addicts, rejoice: a 708-page catalogue raisonné of the nearly century-old brand has just been published. “Prada,” which was designed by Michael Rock and Sung Joong Kim of the New York firm 2×4, was fast-tracked over six months and orchestrated as a magazine would be, Rock said, in almost “cinematic” fashion.The book is slipcased in Prada’s signature navy with an embossed logo and is divided into sections like Past, Inside, Stage and Product that outline the company’s creative output from fashion design to runway shows, including Brigitte Lacombe’s black-and-white photographs of factory workers sewing, and lovingly cataloged swatches of fabrics and ensembles from seasons past. The Campaign section focuses on aspects like advertising, which, Rock explains, is the “mediating factor between the fashion house and the public.” The Place, Scene, Outside and Prada+ sections highlight the company’s architectural “epicenters” in New York and Los Angeles that were designed by Rem Koolhaas/OMA, its iconic building in Tokyo by Herzog & de Meuron and branding strategies that encompass sailing regattas, nightclubs, exhibitions and the art-centric Fondazione Prada. The book has been painstakingly translated into Italian, English, Chinese, Korean and Japanese, though Miuccia Prada exclaims that “fashion is instant language.”

headline: New Directors Named at Tate, Venice Biennale
text: The Tate Gallery said on Wednesday that it had appointed Penelope Curtis the director of its Tate Britain museum in London. The Tate said Ms. Curtis has served since 1999 as curator of the Henry Moore Institute in Leeds and has overseen the acquisition of many works for the institute’s sculpture collection. Elsewhere, Artinfo reported that the Japanese architect Kazuyo Sejima was named director of the Venice Architecture Biennale for 2010. Ms. Sejima, who with Ryue Nishizawa founded the Tokyo architecture firm Sanaa, has helped design buildings including the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Manhattan. She will be the first woman to oversee the architecture biennale, which is to run from Aug. 29 to Nov. 21.

headline: Disney Parks Releases Wait Time App
text: Want to find Mickey Mouse for an autograph? Want to know the wait time for Space Mountain? Well, there’s an app for that — sort of.

headline: Paris and New York to Swap Ballet Dancers
text: Over the years France has given New York everything from the Statue of Liberty to Daniel Boulud, and now, in its latest act of trans-Atlantic generosity, it plans to lend the city two dancers from the Paris Opera Ballet. The New York City Ballet said Aurélie Dupont and Mathias Heymann will perform at City Ballet’s opening-night benefit on Nov. 24. Ms. Dupont and Mr. Heymann (who are among the dancers featured in the Frederick Wiseman documentary “La Danse: The Paris Opera Ballet”) are to perform the “Rubies” pas de deux from George Balanchine’s “Jewels.” The other half of the bargain (struck by Brigitte Lefèvre, the dance director of the Paris Opera Ballet, and Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of City Ballet) is that Paris gets to borrow Ashley Bouder and Gonzalo Garcia from City Ballet, who will dance the leading roles in “Rubies” for the Paris Opera Ballet on Thursday at the Palais Garnier. The City Ballet benefit will take place at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.

headline: ‘V’ Audience Plunges
text: The audience for ABC’s “V” on Tuesday fell substantially from its premiere a week ago, attracting 10.6 million viewers compared with 14.4 million for its debut, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The CBS show “NCIS” dominated the night with 20.2 million viewers as the network finished in first place over all, with a lineup that also included “NCIS: Los Angeles” (16.2 million) and “The Good Wife” (12.9 million). ABC was runner up, garnering 15.5 million viewers for “Dancing With the Stars” and 9.6 million for “In the Spotlight With Robin Roberts,” a news special featuring interviews with country music performers. NBC was third and Fox finished in fourth place with a two-hour installment of “So You Think You Can Dance” (5.7 million).

headline: Tyler Says He Is Not Quitting Aerosmith
text: The shortest rift in rock music history has been healed as the estranged Aerosmith band mates Steven Tyler, far left, and Joe Perry, near left, reunited on Tuesday night, and Mr. Tyler said he was not leaving the group. Last week Mr. Perry, the band’s guitarist, said Mr. Tyler quit, after Mr. Tyler gave an interview to a British music magazine saying he was preparing to focus on a solo career. Mr. Perry went so far as to announce on his Twitter feed on Monday that Aerosmith was looking for a new lead singer. But on Tuesday night, the British music publication New Musical Express reported, Mr. Tyler made a surprise appearance at a performance by Mr. Perry’s band, the Joe Perry Project, at the Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza. There Mr. Tyler told the crowd, “I just want New York  New York, I just want you to know I am not leaving Aerosmith,” before a performance of “Walk This Way” with Mr. Perry and his group.

headline: Underwood Is No. 1
text: Carrie Underwood’s new album, “Play On” (19/Arista Nashville), easily reached the top of the Billboard chart this week, outselling Michael Jackson and new releases by Andrea Bocelli and Weezer. “Play On,” the third album for Ms. Underwood, below, and her second to reach No. 1, sold 318,000 copies in the United States last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The soundtrack to “Michael Jackson’s This Is It” (Epic), last week’s best seller, was No. 2 with 196,000 sales, a 48 percent drop, and the rest of the Top 5 was all new: Mr. Bocelli’s “My Christmas” (Sugar/Decca) opened at No. 3 with 149,000 sales; the soundtrack to the Fox show “Glee” (Columbia) reached No. 4 with 113,000; and Vol. 32 of “Now That’s What I Call Music!” opened at No. 5 with 102,000. Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine), released a year ago and recently rereleased with more songs, fell three spots to No. 6 with 70,000 sales, for total sales of just more than 4.2 million. Weezer’s latest album, “Raditude” (DGC/Interscope), opened at No. 7 with 66,000.

headline: Kingston: Trading Beach Chairs for Bar Stools
text: IT was a steamy Saturday night in Kingston, Jamaica, and the Sky Bar was jammed with its usual weekend crowd: professionals in their 20s and 30s, by all appearances fit for the next flight to South Beach. Ladies in strappy stilettos and sundresses mixed with men in jeans and crisp blazers while the R & B-heavy soundtrack veered from Stevie Wonder to Ne-Yo and Kanye West.

headline: App of the Week: Tightening the Strands of Your Network
text: Dedicated social networkers practically have a full-time job jockeying a phone browser around Facebook, Twitter, texts, and who knows what else. But app makers are building virtual assistants to streamline those tasks, including a new free app called Asurion Mobile AddressBook, which was released in a test version last week.

headline: Executors Named for Jackson Estate
text: A Superior Court judge in Los Angeles named two longtime associates of Michael Jackson as executors of his estate on Tuesday, dismissing a challenge filed by Mr. Jackson’s father, Joe, Reuters reported. Judge Mitchell Beckloff named the lawyer John G. Branca and the music executive John McClain executors of the estate, which is expected to take in $200 million this year in revenues from the Jackson concert documentary “This Is It” as well as the accompanying soundtrack album and other business deals. Mr. Branca and Mr. McClain were already serving as administrators of the estate. Joe Jackson had petitioned the court to set up a monthly allowance for him, similar to one established for the singer’s mother, Katherine Jackson, but the judge said he had no standing to challenge his son’s will.

headline: ‘Sesame Street’ Responds to Dispute
