text: An executive for Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit organization that produces “Sesame Street,” said a segment on the show that upset political conservatives was “equal-opportunity parody” that made fun of both CNN and Fox News. The skit featured Oscar the Grouch, above, as a reporter for the Grouch News Network (abbreviated as GNN). When his work upsets a female viewer and fellow Grouch, she tells Oscar: “From now on I am watching Pox News. Now there’s a trashy news show!” Some conservative bloggers called the comment a veiled shot at Fox News, and Michael Getler, the PBS ombudsman, wrote on his Web site, pbs.org/ombudsman, that “Sesame Street” producers should have avoided the joke. In a letter posted on Mr. Getler’s site, Miranda Barry, an executive vice president at Sesame Workshop, responded that “no political comment or comment about Fox News, subtle or overt, was intended.” Having the “grumpy, grouchy, contrarian Oscar” on “Sesame Street,” Ms. Barry wrote, “shows kids that you can listen to someone with a very different worldview, and even be friends with them, without losing your own perspective.”

headline: Moguls Skier Jeremy Bloom Retires
text: Two-time Olympic moguls star Jeremy Bloom, who aimed for a comeback in the Vancouver Olympics, has decided to retire from competitive skiing.

headline: The Anguish of War for Today’s Soldiers, Explored by Sophocles
text: The ancient Greeks had a shorthand for the mental anguish of war, for post-traumatic stress disorder and even for outbursts of fratricidal bloodshed like last week’s shootings at Fort Hood. They would invoke the names of mythological military heroes who battled inner demons: Achilles, consumed by the deaths of his men; Philoctetes, hollowed out from betrayals by fellow officers; Ajax, warped with so much rage that he wanted to kill his comrades.

headline: On Holiday, Considering the Plight of Homeless Veterans
text: There are nearly 10,000 homeless veterans in New York City, on Long Island and in northern New Jersey, according to estimates in a new report from the Department of Veterans Affairs, which also found that veterans returning from Iraq and Afghanistan are falling into homelessness earlier than those who served in Vietnam.

headline: A Satellite Radio Receiver That Works With the iPhone
text: Sirius XM Radio, always on the lookout for ways to attract fee-paying younger subscribers, is now after the Apple crowd.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: 1.) A “new normal” for unemployment?

headline: Stephen King’s Latest Cast Feels Real
text: “Under the Dome” gravely threatens Stephen King’s status as a mere chart-busting pop cultural phenomenon. It has the scope and flavor of literary Americana, even if Mr. King’s particular patch of American turf is located smack in the middle of the Twilight Zone. It dispenses with his usual scatology and trippy fantasy to deliver a spectrum of credible people with real family ties, health crises, self-destructive habits and political passions. Even its broad caricatures prompt real emotion, if only via the damage they can inflict on others. Though the book’s broad conspiratorial strokes become farfetched, its ordinary souls become ever more able to break hearts.

headline: Senate Candidates in Massachusetts Clash on Health Care Overhaul
text: It’s not surprising that health care legislation, which the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy spent years fighting for, has become a large issue in the campaign for his Senate seat. The unexpected part is that two candidates are fighting about whether or not to support the legislation.

headline: Weekend Swine Flu Vaccination Clinics Open to More People
text: Because of low demand among parents of school-age children, city health officials are opening their swine flu vaccination clinics to a broader group of people this weekend, city officials said.

headline: A Prototype for Your Thoughts
text: THE guests who appeared to be most productively working the room at the opening of the “Bits ‘n Pieces” design and digital technology show at Material ConneXion last week were four crickets in a glass-top box. They clambered up a thin wall, about four inches high, while their movements were captured by two cameras that converted them into graphic patterns.

headline: The New Museum’s Position on Its Show From a Trustee’s Collection
text: Earlier this week, as Deborah Sontag and Robin Pogrebin were gathering information for an article, published Wednesday, that described concerns in the art world over the propriety of a coming show at the New Museum, the museum sent them the following statement:

headline: French Embrace Sarkozy as Zelig Meme
text: In a development that may one day rank with The Onion’s shocking 2002 exposé, “Factual Error Found On Internet,” French journalists have apparently discovered that on Sunday a middle-aged man posted a 20-year-old photograph of himself on his Facebook wall that may well have been taken a few days after the man said it was shot.

headline: Lincoln’s History, Melded With a Choreographer’s
text: Past, present, future. History, memory, experience. The recasting of history through memory and experience. All of these slippery subjects are the matter of Bill T. Jones’s “Serenade/The Proposition,” an hourlong work that reaffirms this artist’s gift for creating powerful theater but reveals little of sustained choreographic interest.

headline: One Handy Way to Join an Endless Conversation
text: If you have an overwhelming need to tweet your every move, you’ll have a hard time resisting TwitterPeek, a device that looks a little like those low-cost phones made with texting in mind, but it sends messages only to Twitter (of course, it lets you read them too).

headline: Spike in 3Com Options Sets Wall Street Abuzz
text: Did someone know about Hewlett-Packard‘s $2.7 billion deal for 3Com before it was announced?

headline: More Answers to Your ‘Sesame Street’ Questions
text: The landmark children’s series “Sesame Street” celebrated its 40th anniversary on Tuesday with a visit from the first lady, Michelle Obama.

headline: Crossword | The Pilgrims
text: Play our new student crossword. You can find the answers here.

headline: Under the Spell of a Mirror
text: MIDDLETOWN, R.I.

headline: ‘People Believe This Stuff’
text: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: NASA’s been on a campaign to ease people’s fears about the end of the world in 2012. Does anybody really think this is going to happen? … NASA announced that the movie “2012” is fiction and the Mayan calendar is wrong. And there is no mystery planet headed towards Earth that’s gonna destroy it. People believe this stuff. They say the only thing that can really destroy the planet by 2012 would be, I guess, Countrywide Mortgage, A.I.G., and Wall Street.

headline: New Cars for the Subway, Old Ones for the Deep
text: Why is it that in a program about the construction of brand-spanking-new New York City subway cars, the most satisfying moment comes when we see some old New York City subway cars being hurled into the ocean?

headline: What’s the View Like From Your Window?
text: Matteo Pericoli has created an inside-out view of the vertical city.

headline: ‘New York City Will Be Broke’
text: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Bad news for New York. Governor Paterson, the governor of New York, announced that by the end of the year, New York City will be broke. Yep. So we’re going to have to make lots of cuts. The Midtown Tunnel. That will be by appointment only. Call ahead. Let them know you’re coming through. Metropolitan Museum has laid off three mummies. And the city temporarily has stopped constructing potholes.

headline: Bing Adds Features, Including Results From Wolfram Alpha
text: Like the ringing sound it is supposed to evoke, Bing has resonated with many users and advertisers. Microsoft‘s new search engine, first introduced in May, has made modest but steady gains in market share against Google and Yahoo.

headline: White House Endorses Paid Sick Leave Bill
text: The H1N1 pandemic is raising concerns about people reporting to work sick and spreading the disease. The pandemic has given momentum to Congressional efforts to enact legislation that would guarantee paid sick days to tens of millions of workers — although it is far from clear that such legislation will be enacted. Those legislative efforts received added momentum on Tuesday when the Obama administration backed the Healthy Families Act, which would guarantee seven sick days a year to workers in companies with 15 or more employees.

headline: Statistical Time Travel
text: That’s from a fascinating article in The Wall Street Journal on using math to ponder anachronistic scenarios. But forget sports heroes — the real accomplishment for these statisticians would be to settle, once and for all, the cultural arguments over W.W.J.D.

headline: ‘All Part of His Plan’
text: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: CBS News is reporting that President Obama has decided to send 40,000 more troops to Afghanistan. Obama says it’s all part of his plan to finally deliver on the campaign promises made by John McCain.

headline: The Next TV Technology Looms Ever Sharper, and Larger
text: Anyone who’s seen an OLED television knows that the technology is simply extraordinary, with deep, rich blacks and an extremely sharp image.

headline: ‘Free Internet Access in Airports’
text: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Google has announced that they’re going to give free Internet access in airports all across the country. It’s fantastic! Up until now, the only way to see something pornographic at an airport was to follow a senator into the bathroom.

headline: How to Market Your Business With Facebook
text: Business owner, you might want to friend Facebook.

headline: Timothy Oulton Creates the British Man Cave
text: Timothy Oulton, a furniture maker who lives mostly in China, was in town earlier this month to oversee the setting up of his new store at ABC Carpet & Home, making sure the vintage regimental drums ($795 to $995) were stacked just so, eyeing the vintage steamer trunks ($395 to $1,995), tweaking the rows of naval flag pillows ($99.95 each). There were brass drums fashioned into chandeliers ($1,495), enormous mirrors made from reclaimed timbers ($3,295) and vast scuffed leather Chesterfield sofas ($3,995), as well as tufted sofas and ottomans ($2,995 and $1,595) upholstered in the Union Jack.

headline: Gardens I Have Known
text: Books written by garden designers are often ersatz portfolios meant to promote the authors’ work. But the English landscape designer Dan Pearson’s new book does something different: “Spirit: Garden Inspiration” (Fuel; $45) provides a gentle ramble not through Mr. Pearson’s projects, but through his life and mind as a garden maker. The narrative can be hard to follow, and the photo captions are sparse or nonexistent, but the book’s impressionistic approach makes it stand out from its workaday how-to counterparts. And the photographs of gardens, art and landscapes  most taken by Mr. Pearson  have the feeling of something halfway between the introverted style of a diary and an idiosyncratic garden blog.

headline: Chandeliers, Blazing With Recyclables
text: Lucy Slivinski, a sculptor in Chicago who makes lighting fixtures out of salvaged metal scraps, attributes her affinity for recycling to her grandparents, who recycled as a matter of necessity during the Depression. Wonder Bread bags, with their red, blue and yellow polka dots, she said, were crocheted into rugs; even stray pieces of string would be collected and crocheted “into a container for a Kleenex box,” she said. “I was always picking up found objects, anything that caught my eye, little pieces of glass, pieces of metal wire.”

headline: Shaking It Out, in One Piece
text: Dolly, a new compact version of a salt and pepper shaker set, was designed by Ross McBride, an American who lives and works in Tokyo. The 1-piece porcelain shaker, which is 4 1/2 inches long and 3 inches wide, is casual and quirky enough to use in the kitchen but elegant enough to put on the dining table.

headline: Arena Wins M.L.S. Coaching Honor
text: In his first full season in charge of the Los Angeles Galaxy, Bruce Arena led the club back to the playoffs in Major League Soccer for the first time in three seasons. Amid the hoopla and distractions that come with having a guy named David Beckham on the team, Arena’s club won the Western Conference and is one game from playing for the league championship. For his efforts, Arena, who also coached the University of Virginia, D.C. United, the United States national team and the Red Bulls, was named the league’s coach of the year on Wednesday. Arena also won the award in 1997 and joins Sigi Schmid (Los Angeles in 1999; Columbus in 2008) and Bob Bradley (Chicago in 1998 and Chivas USA in 2006) as a two-time winner.

headline: Settling Naturally Into a Stage of Comfort
text: The guitarist Jim Hall imbues his music with a deep, companionable rightness. His tone, dry and warm, suggests an extension of his personality. His deployment of notes, economical but fluid, complements an unassuming spirit of inquiry. And there’s a naturalistic ease behind his relationship with the guitar, which partly explains his pull among inheritors like Pat Metheny and Bill Frisell, who have separately recorded with him. Everything about his playing is intuitive and rooted in modesty and humor.

headline: Big Sensors, Shrinking Cameras
text: Why can’t someone just build the perfect camera? I mean, come on  we’re not asking for the world, just a handful of prerequisites:

headline: Be Careful of How You Sit on the Pillow
text: Furniture, rugs and lighting will be 50 to 80 percent off at Lepere’s showroom sale from Nov. 12 to 14 (an Artelano Milan Paris Chair, originally $2,514, will be $838); 20 West 22nd Street (Fifth Avenue), (212) 488-7000, lepereinc.com.

headline: JetBlue’s New TrueBlue Program Arrives
text: JetBlue Airways marked a pair of milestones on Wednesday.

headline: Choices in Infiltrating a Terrorist Cell
text: No game this year will be more controversial and more easily misrepresented than Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2. That is because it revolves around the most provocative, forcefully uncomfortable and emotionally disturbing scene yet built into interactive entertainment. Rather than survey the battlefield from a clinical distance, the game thrusts the player into the harrowing experience of modern terrorism.

headline: Horse of the Year: Rachel or Zenyatta?
text: To give railbirds and racing fans a voice, The New York Times asks you to vote for one of the two standout horses in 2009, the filly Rachel Alexandra or the mare Zenyatta. Watch the special video feature making the case for each horse, cast your vote and discuss your selection in the comments area below.

headline: Filly vs. Mare
text: Which horse, Rachel Alexandra or Zenyatta, deserves racing’s top honor? Watch the debate and vote.

headline: A Better Day for Jay, a Slower Night for ‘V’
text: Tuesday again proved to be a bounce-back night for Jay Leno this week. After another weak Monday, facing opposition like “Monday Night Football,” Mr. Leno added almost two million viewers Tuesday night.

headline: Museum Shows and Collectors: Readers Respond
text: An article on Wednesday described concerns in the art world over the propriety of a coming show at the New Museum that will feature the private collection of a museum trustee, Dakis Joannou.

headline: Card-Carrying Movies
text: With video streaming an increasingly popular phenomenon, Blockbuster has apparently decided that there’s still a market to rent video discs.

headline: Modern Lines for the Eternal City
text: ROME  What would Pope Urban VIII have made of Maxxi, the new museum of contemporary art designed by Zaha Hadid on the outskirts of this city’s historic quarter? My guess is that he would have been ecstatic.

headline: Apps to Help Guard Against Flu, and Worse.
text: If just thinking about the H1N1 Swine Flu virus gives you the chills, Harvard Medical School may offer… well, not a remedy, but a safeguard.

headline: Weighing the Virtues of Credit Cards in Cabs
text: To all of the retailers who complain about how much it costs them to accept the credit cards, I always want to shout this: How much less would you be making if people couldn’t use cards at all?

headline: Performa 09: William Kentridge on Divided Selves
text: The South African artist William Kentridge was part of a successful puppet troupe before he became known as a visual artist who explored the painful legacy of apartheid in tragic-comedic stop-action animations. His films unfold in vigorously hand-drawn charcoal scenes that mutate as we watch, with images often emerging from and disappearing into small cyclones of sooty black. A frequent character in these tales was Soho Eckstein, a wealthy, sometimes guilt-ridden Johannesburg businessman with an active fantasy life who bears a striking resemblance to the artist.

headline: He Shoots, He Scores … in 2 Seconds
text: First came what is reputed to be the world’s fastest goal, then came the entertaining celebration.

headline: Bing, Now With More Wolfram
text: Microsoft today announced that it will begin integrating statistics and other data from computational engine Wolfram Alpha into its search engine Bing.

headline: Week 10 in Fantasy Football Matchups
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 10. They also answered reader questions earlier this week. Read their answers below. Also, scroll down for reading tips from the Fantasy Football Librarian.

headline: Lou Dobbs to Quit CNN
text: Lou Dobbs, the longtime CNN anchor whose anti-immigration views have made him a TV lightning rod, said Wednesday that he is leaving the cable news channel effective immediately.

headline: New Fame for the Everyday Donor
text: AFTER years in the shadows, the everyday donor is emerging as philanthropy’s newest hero, the driver of a more down-to-earth approach to charity. Sure, Bill and Melinda Gates, Warren Buffett, Bono and other celebrity mega-donors still have their place, but now high-profile charities are homing in on smaller donations, while new charities are being organized around the principle of modest giving.

headline: Searching for the Perfect Internet Business
text: Dan recently became an “accidental entrepreneur” — although my gut tells me it wasn’t completely accidental. In any case, he’s searching for an established Web site to call his own. And I’ve been asked to help.

headline: The Making of a Tintype
text: Using 19th-century guidebooks, a photographer uses the Civil War-era chemistry and technology to create his images.

headline: Letters
text: To the Editor:

headline: The World’s Most Colorful Video Artist
text: In a dark, silo-shaped room in the upscale Jardim Europa neighborhood of São Paulo, Brazil, last month, an impassioned aesthetic debate was underway, though it would have been tough for anyone walking into the room to tell. I was at a place called the Museum of Image and Sound, lying on my back with seven other people, all of us completely silent in brightly colored hammocks that had been hung around a circular scaffolding. Our feet angled together toward the center of the room and our heads radiated out like lotus petals. We were all staring up at the ceiling, where two video works were being projected, both featuring a pale, red-headed woman who looked like a Nereid sprung to life. In the first video, she navigates her way through a candy-colored world — a birch forest; a long airportlike corridor; a leaf-strewn sidewalk that the camera scuttles along low and fast, as if from the vantage point of a bug.

headline: Correction: Perversely Content, Ensconced in Chaos
text: An article on Oct. 22 about the writer Augusten Burroughs’s home in Battery Park City misstated a word in a quotation regarding his writing process. Mr. Burroughs said: “I write from memory. And I have my diaries” (not “dairies”).

headline: Correction: A Dream Home Undone by Divorce
text: An article last Thursday, about the renovation of a TriBeCa loft and the subsequent divorce of the couple who owned it, misspelled the surname of one of the project’s architects. He is Todd Rouhe, not Ruhe.

headline: Getting Photos Off Broken Cards
text: Q. Is there any way to get the pictures off a broken Secure Digital card?

headline: U.S. Envoy Urges Caution on Forces for Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  The United States ambassador to Afghanistan, who once served as the top American military commander there, has expressed in writing his reservations about deploying additional troops to the country, three senior American officials said Wednesday.

headline: Dress Codes | New Victorians
text: Many of today’s popular men’s styles have their roots in the late 19th century.

headline: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2
text: The game, developed by Infinity Ward and released by Activision this week, thrusts the player into the harrowing experience of modern terrorism.

headline: Performa 09: Joan Jonas Does Dante
text: One of the highlights of Performa 09 is Joan Jonas’s “Reading Dante II,” which began its five-night run (with one matinee) at the Performing Garage Tuesday night. It amounts to a 60-minute multimedia collage in the round with moving parts and a smorgasbord of audio accompaniment. This includes music, loud crashes, traffic noises, and voices reading fragments of the work’s inspiration: the Inferno, Purgatorio and Paradiso of Dante’s “Divine Comedy.”

headline: "I Couldn't Agree With You More"
text: Excerpt from "I Couldn't Agree With You More," 1999. Courtesy of the artist and Hauser & Wirth and Luhring Augustine, New York.

headline: "Pour Your Body Out"
text: Excerpt from"Pour Your Body Out (7354 Cubic Meters)," 2008, sound by Anders Guggisberg. Courtesy of the artist and Hauser & Wirth and Luhring Augustine, New York.

headline: "I'm Not The Girl Who Misses Much"
text: Excerpt from "I'm Not The Girl Who Misses Much," 1986, video & sound by Pipilotti Rist. Courtesy of the artist and Hauser & Wirth and Luhring Augustine, New York.

headline: "Ever Is Over All"
text: Excerpt from "Ever Is Over All," 1997. Courtesy of the artist and Hauser & Wirth and Luhring Augustine, New York.

headline: "Homo Sapiens Sapiens"
text: Excerpt from "Homo Sapiens Sapiens," 2005. Sound by Anders Guggisberg and Pipilotti Rist. Courtesy of the artist and Hauser & Wirth and Luhring Augustine, New York.

headline: Nabokov’s Last Puzzle
text: In the late fall of 1976, the year before he died, The New York Times Book Review asked Vladimir Nabokov (along with a number of other writers, including John Dean) what he’d been reading lately. He reported that while in a Lausanne hospital that summer, he’d read Dante’s “Inferno,” William H. Howe’s “Butterflies of North America” and “The Original of Laura,” “the not quite finished manuscript of a novel which I had begun writing and reworking before my illness and which was completed in my mind.” In his delirium, he continued, he “kept reading it aloud to a small dream audience in a walled garden. My audience consisted of peacocks, pigeons, my long dead parents, two cypresses, several young nurses crouching around, and a family doctor so old as to be almost invisible. Perhaps because of my stumblings and fits of coughing the story of my poor Laura had less success with my listeners than it will have, I hope, with intelligent reviewers when properly published.” I can take a hint: who’d want to pan Nabokov and end up among the “mediocrities” on his enemies list, to which he might still be adding over on the other side?

headline: For Causes, It’s a Tougher Sell
text: THE wretched economy has forced many consumers to, well, consume less, or at least less avidly than they did before the bubble  or bubbles, if you count Wall Street and real estate  burst.

headline: Performance Anxiety
text: But enough about you, Dear Reader, let’s talk about Philip Roth. Or Nathan Zuckerman or David Kepesh or Mickey Sabbath. Or any of the maddeningly, entertainingly and sometimes tediously self-involved heroes whose lives and loves mirror those of their author. A Roth by any other name would still suffer the affliction identified by O. Spielvogel, the fictional psychiatrist an excerpt of whose imagined article, “The Puzzled Penis,” introduced the reading world to “Portnoy’s Complaint.” A condition marked by “extreme sexual longings,” compulsive sexual behaviors and “overriding feelings of shame and the dread of retribution, particularly in the form of castration,” Portnoy’s complaint outgrew its eponymous novel and manifested itself in one Roth protagonist after another.

headline: The Morning After
text: You always knew Mary Karr wasn’t telling you everything. There were tantalizing hints of adult life in her two coming-of-age memoirs, “The Liars’ Club” and “Cherry.” But “Lit” is the book in which she grows up and gets serious, as serious as motherhood, as serious as alcoholism, as serious as God. And it just makes her funnier. In a gravelly, ground-glass-under-your-heel voice that can take you from laughter to awe in a few sen­tences, Karr has written the best book about being a woman in America I have read in years.

headline: The Silver-Screen Palate
text: I may be the only fan of “The Last Waltz” who regards it as a food movie. Directed by Martin Scorsese, it is an account of the Band’s last concert at the Winterland Ballroom in San Francisco in 1976, which began after an audience of 5,000 had sat down to a full Thanksgiving dinner. True, you never see the turkey, but then you hardly see the audience either. The hodgepodge, communal November meal seems to set the tone for the whole movie, as the performers on the stage lay out a hodgepodge feast of American music, from the blues to Tin Pan Alley.

headline: When All the World’s a Staged Game
text: In his imagination, Greg Trefry is building a golf course right in the middle of Manhattan where he will make his fortune charging everyone to play.

headline: Road Trip
text: Though many of us (Peter Ackroyd included) greatly would prefer common readers to learn just enough Middle English to begin enjoying Chaucer’s poetry in the original, that evades the way things are and the way they are going to be. Retelling Chaucer in our contemporary prose necessarily is a great loss, yet so rich is Chaucer that enormous value remains in Ackroyd’s robust versions of “The Canterbury Tales.”

headline: Outreach in the Age of Pullback
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Switzerland Limits Bank Compensation, but Not Too Harshly
text: Switzerland announced watered-down measures to limit bank compensation Wednesday, imposing no caps on bonuses and excluding all but the country’s biggest financial services companies from mandatory compliance.

headline: ‘Hank’ and ‘Dollhouse’ Out, ‘UneXpected’ In
text: The fall television season is winding down, which means that broadcast networks are beginning to clear out shows that have failed to attract audiences this year and scheduling some that they hope will do better.

headline: Dobbs Explains Decision to Leave CNN
text: The text of Mr. Dobbs’ announcement about leaving CNN:

headline: This Just in From the 1890s
text: IT’S usually easy to distinguish between clothes and costumes: either you’re Spider-Man, or you’re not.

headline: Japan Cools to America as It Prepares for Obama Visit
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama will arrive in Tokyo on Friday, at a time when America’s relations with Japan are at their most contentious since the trade wars of the 1990s  and back then, the fights were over luxury cars and semiconductors, not over whether the two countries should re-examine their half-century-old strategic relationship.

headline: I’m Innocent. Just Check My Status on Facebook.
text: The message on Rodney Bradford’s Facebook page, posted at 11:49 a.m. on Oct. 17, asked where his pancakes were. The words were typed from a computer in his father’s apartment in Harlem.

headline: Leaving a Bank for a Foundation Proved Rewarding
text: IN 1994, Marley Kaplan saw an ad for a half-time job at a not-for-profit organization. The pay: $25,000 a year.

headline: Swine Flu Clinics to Be Opened to a Broader Group of People This Weekend
text: Because of low demand among parents of school-age children, city health officials are opening their swine flu vaccination clinics to a broader group of people this weekend, city officials said.

headline: Two-Year Colleges, Swamped, No Longer Welcome All
text: Sonja Taylor applied to LaGuardia Community College this summer with every expectation of being admitted. She planned to study business, bringing her closer to her dream of owning a restaurant.

headline: At Christie’s, Return of American Collectors
text: Some of the great names in postwar and contemporary art were solid sellers at Christie’s on Tuesday night. And while American collectors were back, dominating the bidding, price mattered. Only one work  a 1996 painting by the Scottish artist Peter Doig  broke the $10 million barrier in a mixed sale that included property once belonging to Merce Cunningham, the dancer and choreographer, and his partner in life and work, the composer John Cage.

headline: Motorola Said to Explore Dividing Into 3 Companies
text: Motorola, which has said it wants to split into two separate companies, is exploring a three-way split instead in order to raise cash and pay down debt.

headline: Coming to Fox, ‘Our Little Genius’
text: Fox announced on Wednesday that it is seeking participants for a new game show that will allow parents of young geniuses – age 6 to 12 – to put their kids’ knowledge to use winning “life-changing money.”

headline: It Was No Walk in the Park
text: HIGH on the list of stock American fantasies  after winning the lottery, single-handedly saving the world from nuclear obliteration and telling off your boss  is becoming a model.

headline: A Patchwork of Food Assistance for Pets
text: ANIMAL shelters have reported a steep rise in the number of cats and dogs being surrendered as owners face unemployment, home foreclosures, evictions and other financial hardships. But animal welfare groups and even churches are stepping up with bags of kibble and containers of cat litter to help owners keep their pets and to prevent more from being sent to shelters, and sometimes death.

headline: John J. O’Connor III, Husband of Former Justice, Is Dead at 79
text: John J. O’Connor III, a lawyer whose struggle with Alzheimer’s disease was a large factor in the decision by his wife, former Justice Sandra Day O’Connor, to retire from the United States Supreme Court, died Wednesday in Phoenix. He was 79.

headline: Pull Up a Book and Have a Seat
text: THE last decade has seen such a glut of fashion monographs that it seems a designer is nobody if he or she has not yet been the subject of a 20-pound book. Like, it’s getting a little ridiculous when you have to ask what your coffee table is wearing.

headline: Okinawans Grow Impatient With Dashed Hopes on U.S. Base
text: GINOWAN, Japan  Okinawans like Zenji Shimada, who have spent most of their lives under the thudding of helicopters from a busy American air base, are accustomed to disappointment. Decades of complaints about the base here and others on the island have gone largely unheeded, and a painstakingly negotiated plan to move the Marines from populated areas remains years from completion.

headline: Senator Faces G.O.P. Rebuke Back Home
text: WASHINGTON    Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, has been censured by local Republican officials in his home state.

headline: Lemony Snicket’s New Series and Young Adult Novel
text: Lemony Snicket, the notorious pseudonym of Daniel Handler and the author of the bestselling “Series of Unfortunate Events” sequence, has agreed to sell the North American rights to publish a new four-part series to Little, Brown & Co., moving from HarperCollins.

headline: Something to Rah-Rah-Rah About for Christmas
text: GAP is celebrating the coming holiday season with glee  or perhaps that should be “Glee.”

headline: Kramnik Pulls Ahead Again at Moscow Tournament
text: A brilliant win in Round 6 allowed Vladimir Kramnik of Russia to take over sole lead at Tal Memorial tournament.

headline: Offering a Helping Hand, and Then Needing One
text: Nannette Perkins, 61, has a catalog of health problems. After she had a heart attack last year, doctors used a stent to open a valve. Because of a long-ago work-related injury, she struggles with a bad back and walks with a cane. A diabetic, she checks her blood sugar daily.

headline: Unlike Minaya, Cashman Stands on Solid Ground
text: CHICAGO  After two and a half days of meetings with colleagues and agents here, Omar Minaya and Brian Cashman were both headed back to New York on Wednesday, yet still somehow going in different directions.

headline: North Korea Warns South After Naval Clash
text: SEOUL — North Korea said Thursday that South Korea would pay a “dear price” for the naval clash on Tuesday that was the most serious between the countries in seven years, while South Korea sent additional warships near the site of the confrontation in a disputed sea border.

headline: Sanchez Returns to His Roots During Week Off
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Rex Ryan, the Jets’ first-year coach, is 46 years old. He came to work Wednesday with a gray stubble on his chin and cheeks. Mark Sanchez, the Jets’ rookie quarterback, turned 23 years old Wednesday. He came to work with much darker whiskers on his fresher-looking face.

headline: The Chain Store as Patron of the Arts
text: WHEN Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts opens its new visitor atrium this month, it will also inaugurate Target Free Thursdays: free concerts featuring professionals from Lincoln Center organizations like the New York City Opera and the New York Philharmonic as well as performances by students from the Juilliard School and other artists.

headline: Among Late-Night Writers, Few Women in the Room
text: In many ways, television today is about women more than men.

headline: Rep. Kennedy and Bishop in Bitter Rift on Abortion
text: Representative Patrick J. Kennedy of Rhode Island was to meet Thursday with Thomas J. Tobin, the Roman Catholic bishop of Providence, and perhaps start healing a bitter rift over whether health care legislation now before Congress should restrict abortion coverage.

headline: From an Idea by Students, a Million-Dollar Charity
text: THE titans of Wall Street are famous for star-studded galas that raise millions of dollars for a host of good causes. And for a tiny group of high school students on Long Island, taking a page out of these financiers’ books has made their own charity, A Midwinter Night’s Dream, a million-dollar success.

headline: San Francisco MoMA Finds a New Way to Expand
text: THE expansion of an art museum doesn’t typically galvanize the building of a fire station. But philanthropy at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in recent months has been far from typical.

headline: Thieves in Milwaukee Show a Patriotic Side, Declining to Rob Army Reservist
text: Kyle Windorski, a 21-year-old college student in the Army Reserve, was walking home Tuesday morning on the east side of Milwaukee when four men with stocking caps over their faces forced him into an alley at gunpoint and demanded cash.

headline: A Big Splash From an Upstart Medical Center
text: TO many people who suffer from the poorly understood illness called chronic fatigue syndrome, a recent study linking the disorder to a virus was a victory for the little guys.

headline: Charges Prompt Iraqis to Look Into Blackwater
text: WASHINGTON  A senior Iraqi official said Wednesday that he had ordered an investigation into whether top officials of Blackwater Worldwide approved of bribes to Iraqi government officials after shootings by Blackwater guards in 2007 left 17 Iraqi civilians dead.

headline: Push to Build Mosques Is Met With Resistance
text: COPENHAGEN  Paris has its grand mosque, on the Left Bank. So does Rome, the city of the pope. Yet despite a sizable Muslim population, this Danish city has nothing but the occasional tiny storefront Muslim place of worship.

headline: A Year After an Immigrant’s Death, Signs of Hope
text: PATCHOGUE, N.Y.

headline: After Criticism, the Administration Is Praised for Final Rules on Education Grants
text: Three months after provoking an outpouring of criticism with preliminary plans for the nation’s largest competitive education grant program, the Obama administration has added flexibility in the final rules, released Wednesday, drawing praise from a state governor who was initially critical and from leaders of the national teachers’ unions.

headline: Depression Haunted Goalkeeper Killed by Train
text: The official Web site of the Hannover 96 soccer club was blacked out Wednesday except for a simple statement: “Wir trauern um Robert Enke.” We mourn for Robert Enke.

headline: For Some N.B.A. Players, There’s No Such Thing as a Slam Dunk
text: Jason Kapono doesn’t dunk. That fact would be unremarkable were it not for his occupation and his height.

headline: A Net Reaches Out to Fans, Wherever They Are
text: NEWARK

headline: Lou Dobbs and the Facts
text: Look for the stories about Lou Dobbs’s departure from CNN to say that he was controversial figure. No doubt he is. But that’s not really the main point about Mr. Dobbs. The main point is that he has a long history of not telling the truth.

headline: Raising Real Money in a Virtual World
text: FOUR years ago, the visitors at SecondLife.com staged a virtual walkathon and raised $5,000 for the American Cancer Society by sending avatars walking in loops with mouse clicks and key strokes.

headline: Dollars That Turn Into Bees, and Other Gifts Given Twice
text: THIS holiday season, consumers are expected to cut back both their spending on holiday gifts as well as their giving to charity.

headline: Arbitrator Said to Doze During Teacher’s Hearing
text: The process of firing a New York City teacher on charges of incompetence could certainly be described as time consuming. Hearings take so long  hundreds of hours  and so many details are scrutinized that it might be enough to put someone to sleep.

headline: Shopping for Clothing, Donating Time
text: IN the newly expanded Banana Republic store opening in New York City’s SoHo district this month, shoppers may be surprised to discover, amid the displays of red double-breasted peacoats and cowl neck sweaters, a representative from a local volunteer group asking if they would like to donate some time. Think of it as consumerism meets volunteerism.

headline: Israeli and French Leaders Meet
text: PARIS  After meeting for 90 minutes, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France announced in a joint statement on Wednesday evening that they had agreed to work toward “immediately reviving the peace process” in the Middle East and discussed international efforts to stop Iran from enriching uranium.

headline: Somalis’ Money Is Lifeline for Homeland
text: PARIS  As Somalis struggle to survive the chaos that has overtaken their country, a network of companies that distribute money from the nation’s large diaspora has quietly expanded, providing a crucial safety net.

headline: Clicking for a Cause
text: BRAD SUGARS says he believes that cancer can be defeated, one birthday at a time.

headline: U.S. Plans Raw Warm-Water Oyster Ban
text: A federal effort to ban the sale of raw oysters harvested during the warm months along the Gulf Coast has kicked up a hurricane of opposition from oystermen and members of Congress and threatened to derail a signature food-safety initiative by the Obama administration.

headline: As Shipping Slows, Banks and Carriers Fear Loan Defaults
text: LONDON  When Eastwind Maritime, a medium-size carrier company, went bankrupt this summer, few banks in the United States took notice.

headline: A.I.G. Chief’s Mission: Save Executive Pay
text: The American International Group’s chief executive on Wednesday tried to calm fears that he was about to jump ship, with an open letter to employees announcing he was “totally committed to leading A.I.G. through its challenges.”

headline: Raising Morale Far From Home
text: A SURVIVOR of World War II’s infamous Bataan Death March, Dr. Lester Tenney endured over three years of slave labor as a Japanese prisoner of war, with no word from home. “I would have been so happy to get a package of any kind,” Dr. Tenney said. “I wouldn’t have cared what was in it  just the fact that someone would think of me and send something. Oh Lord, that would have been exciting!”

headline: In Leaning on Karzai, U.S. Has Limited Leverage
text: WASHINGTON  When President Obama delivered a rare and public call last week for President Hamid Karzai to crack down on corruption in Afghanistan, there was one glaring omission from his remarks  an “or else.”

headline: Questions, Not Alarms, Met Exchanges With Cleric
text: WASHINGTON  Last December, the vast electronic net of American intelligence captured queries that Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan of the Army was sending by e-mail to a radical cleric in Yemen who has long been a target of American surveillance.

headline: Galas Dispense With Some of the Froth
text: THE world of charity galas and fund-raising parties has always been a world of fantasy and illusion: white voile-draped dinner tents, towering long-stemmed centerpieces, big society bands and black tie or tails. A little buttery beef and champagne, a winning bid for a high-ticket auction item, and blow the check dry. From museums to hospitals to foundations and other not-for-profits, it’s New York’s institutional gravy train  over 275 events last month alone, from Carnegie Hall’s opening night gala to Project Migration’s wine-tasting party.

headline: The agony of Fox Business
text: James Wolcott is made of sterner stuff than I am: he actually has the fortitude to watch Fox Business, where the talking heads manage to find nothing but clouds in the silver lining of a huge stock rally. To make their point they bring on such market experts as … John Bolton. As Wolcott writes, “It takes more than a market rally to pull the wool over Bolton’s mustache.” (Now that’s writing!)

headline: Cavaliers Looking Good in Return to Orlando
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  For more than two hours Wednesday night, Shaquille O’Neal and Dwight Howard shuffled across the same polished floor boards, their paths similar but distant, like satellites traveling in separate orbits.

headline: Lou Dobbs Abruptly Quits CNN
text: Months ago the president of CNN/U.S., Jonathan Klein, offered a choice to Lou Dobbs, the channel’s most outspoken anchor. Mr. Dobbs could vent his opinions on radio and anchor an objective newscast on television, or he could leave CNN.

headline: U.S. Adviser to Kurds Stands to Reap Oil Profits
text: OSLO  Peter W. Galbraith, an influential former American ambassador, is a powerful voice on Iraq who helped shape the views of policy makers like Joseph R. Biden Jr. and John Kerry. In the summer of 2005, he was also an adviser to the Kurdish regional government as Iraq wrote its Constitution  tough and sensitive talks not least because of issues like how Iraq would divide its vast oil wealth.

headline: The Betrayal
text: ST. LOUIS – So long as Budweiser, the King of Beers, was enthroned in this pleasant and nobly resilient middle American city, the blows of corporate condescension from the other giants who abandoned the Gateway Arch could be endured.

headline: At Fort Hood, Witness Credits Second Officer
text: KILLEEN, Tex.  Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley has been applauded as a hero across the nation for shooting down Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan during the bloody rampage at Fort Hood last week. The account of heroism, given by the authorities, attracted the attention of newspapers, the networks and television talk shows.

headline: L.I. Harvests May Signal a Comeback for Scallops
text: GREENPORT, N.Y.  Bone-tired but grinning, Peter Wenczel and his son Ben eased their 26-foot work boat toward the dock here one recent afternoon, its deck piled high with bags of scallops.

headline: Billionaires Learn Giving Is Only a Start
text: “BILL GATES: The Real Secretary of Education,” ran a recent headline on the state of education reform in America, prompted by the unhappiness of teachers’ unions about the growing influence of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation in Washington, D.C.. This reflects a new phase in the development of this generation of megadonors, in which the success or failure of their philanthropic agendas may be determined by their ability to master the dark arts of politics.

headline: Charity Bankruptcy Leaves Many Donors in Distress
text: A CAUTIONARY tale for donors who entered into two time-tested, long-term giving arrangements  charitable gift annuities and donor-advised funds  has emerged from bankruptcy court.

headline: As Foundations Close, Anxiety for Charities
text: FOUNDATIONS that increase grants to spend down their endowment and then close are proving to be a boon to charities in the short run, but the trend is also causing anxiety among the charities about their future fund-raising.

headline: Gerrymandering, Pure and Corrupt
text: Of all the tricks that New York’s legislators use to hang on to office, the one that works best — for the politicians, that is — is redistricting. Mapmaking in Albany is a dark art form designed to make absolutely certain that incumbents in the majority party are safe from electoral competition (a k a democracy).

headline: In Charity Tax Filing, a Glimpse of Goldman
text: The latest tax filing for Goldman Sachs’s foundation is as thick as a phone book. The list of trades is more than 200 pages, single spaced. Goldman, it seems, invests like no other, even for its own charity.

headline: Liquid Marijuana Seized in Brooklyn
text: In what the police called an unusual drug arrest, a Brooklyn man was charged on Wednesday with selling liquid marijuana.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Bloggingheads: Afghanistan as Duty
text: Christopher Preble, left, of the Cato Institute and Peter Beinart of the New America Foundation debate public support for the Afghanistan war.

headline: Tycoon With a Reputation
text: Wah-wah-taysee, little fire-fly,Little, flitting, white-fire insect,Little, dancing, white-fire creature,Light me with your little candle,Ere upon my bed I lay me,Ere in sleep I close my eyelids!— The Song of Hiawatha by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

headline: Cozy Booths and Halls of Power: Peeks in Bruno Case
text: ALBANY  For decades, Jack’s Oyster House has been a favored haunt of the capital’s political elite, serving up healthy portions of gossip and deal-making along with its signature dish, sautéed calf’s liver.

headline: Ad Pages Drop For Magazines Of Conde Nast
text: Condé Nast’s ad-page numbers are in for its 2009 issues, helping shed light on why the company made sharp cuts this fall.

headline: Shuffled Lineup Can’t Avert Second-Half Slide
text: Mike D’Antoni has kept his hand on the lever, tweaking and tinkering with his lineup in search of a winning combination or at least one that makes a respectable showing.

headline: Mets Monitoring Safety of Prospect in Venezuela
text: CHICAGO  Amid kidnappings and war rhetoric in Venezuela, the Mets may recommend that the catching prospect Josh Thole return home from his winter league team there.

headline: Video Bingo Has Alabamians Yelling Everything But
text: ASHVILLE, Ala.  Everybody knows what this is: dozens of people, mostly retirees, hunched over paper grids in a smoke-filled American Legion hall on a Sunday evening listening eagerly to a woman recite numbers.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Thursday about a possible severe shortage of seasonal flu vaccine in the United States misattributed an assertion that Bush administration officials pressed Congress for money to develop vaccine technology but never got as much as they sought. The comment was by Michael T. Osterholm, director of the Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota  not by William Hall, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about plans by the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Manhattan to present an exhibition of art owned by one of its trustees, Dakis Joannou, referred imprecisely, in citing similar arrangements, to a collector whose old master drawings were exhibited by the Metropolitan Museum of Art this year. The collector, Jean Bonna, is an honorary trustee of the Met, not a trustee.

headline: Corrections
text: A Political Memo article on Saturday about the effect of last week’s elections on the health care debate in Congress misstated the middle initial for the Republican who is the governor-elect of Virginia. He is Robert F. McDonnell, not Robert H.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about the election defeat of New Jersey’s Democratic governor misspelled his surname at one point and misstated, in some copies, the number of political campaigns in which he spent more than $130 million of his own fortune. As noted elsewhere, he is Jon S. Corzine, not Cozine, and that sum was spent over three campaigns, not two  one for United States Senate in 2000, and two for governor, in 2005 and this year.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on the Itineraries page on Nov. 3 with an article about travel management companies’ negotiating rates for the coming year referred incorrectly to the Peninsula Hotel in Shanghai. It is a new hotel; it is not newly renovated.

headline: Warhol Fetches $43.7 Million at Auction
text: It was the sale of the season. When a seminal Warhol  one of the artist’s first silk-screen paintings  came on the block at Sotheby’s auction of contemporary art on Wednesday night, the auctioneer, Tobias Meyer, opened bidding at $6 million and was stunned when a bidder instantly doubled it.

headline: Corrections
text: The Mind column on Oct. 6, about the ability of nonsense to sharpen the mind, reported findings from a flawed statistical analysis. The authors of a study that was described in the column reported that subjects who read a Kafka-inspired short story were more accurate in seeing hidden patterns than people who had read a more coherent short story. After a reader questioned the analysis, the researchers repeated the experiment and found no significant difference between the groups. (A similar experiment reported in the same paper, in the journal Psychological Science, did hold up to re-analysis.)

headline: Bush Emerging for Speech to Kick Off Public Policy Institute
text: DALLAS  Nearly 10 months after leaving office, former President George W. Bush plans to emerge from self-imposed political hibernation on Thursday as he starts a new public policy institute to promote some of the domestic and international priorities of his presidency.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about an effort to collect seeds to save species, possibly by relocating them through a process known as assisted migration, misstated the surname of the plant conservation program manager at the Bureau of Land Management. She is Peggy Olwell, not Orwell.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: New York City Veterans Day Parade
text: Three servicemen attending the city's Veteran's Day parade shared opinions on the war in Afghanistan and the military's treatment of soldiers' mental health.

headline: Here He Is ...
text: Hmm, which will be more macho, the 11th Annual Mr. Lower East Side pageant or the 32nd Annual Empire State Golden Arms Tournament of Champions? Both involve flexing and posing, beer and possibly pizza, but only one is held at the Port Authority. Point to arm-wrestlers.

headline: Dress Code
text: Attention dandies and wannabes: you can outfit yourself and your man-cave on Thursday, just in time for, um, Call of Duty season. From Timothy Oulton’s naval flag pillows [LINK to Pulse in Home] at ABC Carpet to the “tweedy vests, woolen trousers, henley undershirts, dark wool ties, scratchy cotton shirts” that, David Colman writes, can be found in shops like Amoskeag XX or Hollander & Lexer, you’ll have all the accoutrements you’d need to make your way to a Tweed Ride  or, at least, a reading about obsolete technology.

headline: Author, Author
text: You think your relationship is complicated? Stephen Elliott, who chronicled his long-term San Francisco threesome, has covered murder, false confession and S&M in his new memoir,  “The Adderall Diaries” . >Brian DeLeeuw took on childhood bromances in his debut novel,  “In This Way I Was Saved,”  and inNancy Mauro’s ”imaginative” mystery  “New World Monkeys,”  a couple travels to their upstate refuge  only to discover a grave site. The authors read from their work tonight at KGB Bar.

headline: Breathing Room
text: Dawn Turro has cancer, but she still considers herself fortunate. Unlike many Americans who are sick, she has had good medical care and health insurance to help pay for it. Insurance covered her mastectomy, and when the cancer spread to her spine, it covered the cost of radiation and chemotherapy. After her husband, Robert, lost his job in December 2008, the company where he had worked for 27 years extended the family’s medical coverage, allowing Ms. Turro to continue treatment.

headline: Hannity Admits to Using ‘Incorrect Video’
text: On his show on the Fox News Channel Wednesday night, Sean Hannity admitted to using scenes from a different rally to illustrate a report on a health care protest last week.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,352 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 906 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

headline: Azerbaijan: Bloggers Convicted
text: Two bloggers in Azerbaijan who regularly posted video political parodies were convicted of hooliganism on Wednesday, prompting criticism that the government was clamping down on independent media. The bloggers, Adnan Hajizade, 26, and Emin Milli, 30, were arrested in July after a fight at a restaurant that they said had been orchestrated by the authorities. It occurred soon after Mr. Hajizade and Mr. Milli appeared to poke fun at the authoritarian government of Azerbaijan, a former Soviet republic, by posting a video in which a donkey holds a news conference. The prosecution said the arrests had nothing to do with the video. Mr. Hajizade received a term of two years in prison, and Mr. Milli received two and a half years. In Washington, the State Department assailed the verdict.

headline: New Levels of Inclusion at Country Music Awards
text: It’s safe to say that this is the first year in which the most important people at the Country Music Association Awards were an African-American man and a teenage girl, but so it went Wednesday night at the 43rd edition of the awards, celebrating a year of increasingly porous borders in Nashville.

headline: Where To Spend $100 Billion, Health or Helmand?
text: I’m theoretically on vacation, peddling my book on book tour, but with health care reform in the balance I just couldn’t bear to stay away from the fray. So I frantically sent last-minute word that I would file my column after all, and my Thursday column tries to compare the choices on health reform and Afghan troop deployments.

headline: More Foreclosures to Come
text: After a few months of some better than expected housing news, home prices are likely to fall again, driven lower by a renewed surge in foreclosures. By conservative estimates, another 2.4 million homes will be lost in 2010, while prices will fall another 10 percent or so. This should be a wake-up call for the Obama administration. Foreclosures are expected to surge, in part, because lenders have been delaying the process during the long rollout of the administration’s antiforeclosure plan. But according to Moody’s Economy.com, most troubled borrowers ultimately will not qualify for help, and a backlog of bad loans will soon enter foreclosure.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Take a Deep Breath
text: In troubled times, it is important to try to maintain a certain level of serenity. Right now we citizens have quite a lot on our plate and there is no reason to go completely crazy about the least little thing.

headline: America’s Defining Choice
text: President Obama and Congress will soon make defining choices about health care and troops for Afghanistan.

headline: Trading Women’s Rights for Political Power
text: Washington

headline: How the Scapegoats Escaped
text: THE quick “not guilty” verdict reached Tuesday afternoon by a Brooklyn jury in the federal criminal trial of two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers was at once surprising  for its failure to comport with the zeitgeist  but also entirely understandable, based on a close reading of the prosecution’s arguments and the evidence the judge allowed to be introduced. “There was a reasonable doubt on every charge,” one juror told The Times afterward. “We just didn’t feel that the case had been proven.”

headline: Showcase: See and Be Seen
text: It’s a difficult time for young photographers trying to make their way into photojournalism. There are few assignments and fewer staff jobs. It is unclear what paths — if any — might lead to success.

headline: One Lynching in Cairo, Ill.; Then, Another
text: Friday, Nov. 12, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Word of the Day | pacify
text: pacify • \ˈpa-sə-ˌfi \ • verb

headline: A 40-Cent Wings Special and Gunfire
text: It’s not uncommon for teenagers to flock to the mall at the end of a school day. But something went awry on Tuesday, when thousands of high school students descended on the Atlantic Center Mall in Brooklyn and a stabbing and shootings followed.

headline: As G.E. Struggles, a Rival Steps Up
text: It is only fitting that United Technologies is poised to buy assets from its cross-state rival General Electric. At least in the eyes of shareholders, United Technologies  the manufacturer of Otis elevators, Pratt & Whitney jet engines and Sikorsky helicopters  has emerged as the more successful of the two industrial conglomerates, both based in Connecticut.

headline: Mythical End for Legendary Route 66
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  The question of where the old Route 66 officially ended in the West has been the subject of debate among history buffs and roadsters. On Wednesday it was resolved in a quintessentially American way, by placing the terminus in a place where it can best be monetized.

headline: A Salute to Fallen Americans
text: WHOM does Veterans Day honor? WHOM do you know who is a veteran of war?

headline: Entrepreneurs Press On, and Obstacles Fall
text: Most entrepreneurs gauge success in numbers like dollars and market share. Jennifer VanDerHorst-Larson measures it, in part, in the words her son speaks and writes.

headline: LeBron James Says He’s Done Talking About Free Agency
text: LeBron James has declared a moratorium on free-agency questions, a gesture that is arguably overdue and perhaps a little hollow.

headline: Gene D. Cohen, Geriatric Psychiatrist, Dies at 65
text: Gene D. Cohen, a pioneer in the field of geriatric psychiatry who helped shift the emphasis in gerontological research from the problems of people as they age to their potential, died Saturday at his home in Kensington, Md. He was 65.

headline: Sheldon Dorf, Founder of Comic-Con, Dies at 76
text: Sheldon Dorf, who turned his passion for comic books and newspaper strips into a vocation by founding one of the world’s biggest annual comic-book conventions, died in San Diego on Nov. 3. He was 76.

headline: Donald Harington, Ozark Surrealist, Dies at 73
text: Donald Harington, who created a surreal rural mini-world in more than a dozen novels set in the fictional Ozark hamlet of Stay More, Ark., died Saturday in Springdale, Ark. He was 73 and lived in Fayetteville, Ark.

headline: Thomas J. O’Malley, Who Helped Launch Glenn Into Orbit, Dies at 94
text: Thomas J. O’Malley, the aviation engineer who pushed the button that launched the rocket that carried John Glenn into orbit in 1962, and who five years later played a major role in reviving the Apollo moon program after a launching-pad fire killed three astronauts, died Friday in Cocoa Beach, Fla. He was 94 and lived in Cocoa Beach.

headline: Dollar’s Drop Lifts Shares, Gold and Oil
text: It was supposed to be a quiet day on Wall Street: the bond market was closed for Veterans Day, and there were no economic reports on the calendar.

headline: Citigroup Stands by Deferred Tax Asset Valuation
text: A senior Citigroup executive said the bank is comfortable with its valuation for an asset that one accounting expert expects to be written down, Reuters reported.

headline: D.O.E. Hires V.C. to Run Loan Programs
text: The Department of Energy has tapped a venture capitalist to run its ts loan guarantee and green auto loan programs.

headline: In Charity Tax Filing, a Glimpse of Goldman
text: The latest tax filing for Goldman Sachs‘s foundation is as thick as a phone book. The list of trades is more than 200 pages, single spaced. Goldman, it seems, invests like no other, even for its own charity.

headline: A Bad Night at the Board
text: “Nobody told me there would be days like these, strange days indeed.” (John Lennon)

headline: China Merchants Says I.P.O. Subscribed at $161 Billion
text: China Merchants Securities, which plans to raise up to 11.1 billion renminbi through an initial public share offer in Shanghai, said its I.P.O. has been nearly 94 times subscribed, freezing up a huge 1.1 trillion renminbi ($161 billion), Reuters reported.

headline: China Bank Said to Eye Hong Kong Brokerage
text: Taifook Securities Group, a brokerage house based in Hong Kong, saw its shares soar after it said in a filing to the city’s exchange late Wednesday that its main shareholder might sell its controlling stake.

headline: Britain Probes Dynamic Decisions Hedge Fund
text: Britain’s Serious Fraud Office said Thursday that it has begun an investigation into a Cayman Islands-based hedge fund run by fund firm Dynamic Decisions Capital Management, following a referral by the Financial Services Authority.

headline: Small on the Outside, Big on the Inside
text: David Pogue tests the Panasonic Lumix GF1, Canon PowerShot S90 and Panasonic Lumix LX3: Three cameras that are coat-pocketable but have large image sensors.

headline: Gates Says Pay ‘Too High,’ but Hard to Tackle
text: Bill Gates said on Wednesday he believes Wall Street pay is “often too high” and that government ownership of American International Group worries him because it has devalued the giant insurer.

headline: Bain Capital Is Said to Bid $1 Billion for BellSystem24
text: Bain Capital has made a bid of more than $1 billion for Japanese telemarketer Bellsystem24 in a deal it hopes to wrap up by the weekend, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing a person familiar with the deal.

headline: As G.E. Struggles, a Rival Steps Up
text: It is only fitting that United Technologies is poised to buy assets from its cross-state rival General Electric, Breakingviews says. At least in the eyes of shareholders, United Technologies — the manufacturer of Otis elevators, Pratt & Whitney jet engines and Sikorsky helicopters — has emerged as the more successful of the two industrial conglomerates, both based in Connecticut, according to the publication.

headline: A.I.G. Chief’s Mission: Save Executive Pay
text: American International Group’s chief executive on Wednesday tried to calm fears that he was about to jump ship, with an open letter to employees announcing he was “totally committed to leading A.I.G. through its challenges.”

headline: Protesters Clash With Police in Nepal
text: HONG KONG  Communist protesters clashed with the police and surrounded the Singha Durbar, the seat of government in the center of the Nepalese capital, as they called for the resignation of the president, local news agencies reported Thursday.

headline: Motorola Said to Explore Dividing Into 3 Companies
text: Motorola, which has said it wanted to split into two separate companies, is exploring a three-way split instead in order to raise cash and pay down debt, The New York Times’s Saul Hansell and Michael J. de la Merced reported.

headline: Soros Helps Longfor Raise $912 Million In I.P.O.
text: The Chinese property developer, Longfor Properties, raised $912 million, pricing its Hong Kong initial public offering at the top end of an indicated range on Thursday, Reuters reported, citing two sources close to the deal.

headline: Calpers Chief Backs Rules for Placement Agents
text: The president of the California Public Employees’ Retirement System urged fellow board members at the biggest United States public pension fund on Wednesday to back his plan to require placement agents to be subjected to laws for lobbyists in response to events asserting their “undue influence” over investment decisions, Reuters reported.

headline: Paulson Increases Cadbury Stake (Again)
text: It seems that the hedge fund manager John Paulson has a real sweet tooth for Cadbury, currently coveted by Kraft Foods.

headline: Fête Accompli | Le Jardin Louis Vuitton
text: What: The debut of the Louis Vuitton 2010 ready-to-wear collection at its new shop-in-a-shop shop at Saks Fifth Avenue.

headline: 3i Asset Values Lag Market Surge
text: The 3i Group, the private equity firm, said asset values increased just 2 percent in the first half of its fiscal year as the real economy failed to keep up with rebounding stock markets.

headline: Dowd: Virtuous Bankers? Really!?!
text: The New York Times’s Maureen Dowd has a bone to pick with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Hollywood Reporter to Be Sold, Report Says
text: Several Nielsen entertainment titles, including The Hollywood Reporter, are about to be sold to News Communications, the media company run by James Finkelstein, The Wrap reported, citing an individual with knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: Royal Boskalis Buys Salvager Smit for $1.7 Billion
text: Royal Boskalis Westminster agreed to buy Smit Internationale, the salvage company that lifted the Russian nuclear submarine Kursk from the bottom of the Barents Sea in 2001, for about 1.1 billion euros ($1.7 billion), capping a yearlong effort to combine the two Dutch companies, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: News Quiz | November 12, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Chagall’s Colors of Love
text: When the wintry wind and rain descend on Istanbul, it’s great to head indoors for a dose of warmth, color and even romance. All three can be found at the recently opened exhibit, “Marc Chagall: Life and Love,” at the Pera Museum (Mesrutiyet Caddesi No. 65; 90-212-334-99-00; en.peramuzesi.org.tr; closed on Mondays).

headline: Sanofi May Launch Venture Fund
text: The top executive of the French drug maker Sanofi-Aventis reached out to Boston-area researchers and biotechnology start-up companies on Wednesday, offering “partnerships for innovation’’ that could range from investments in drugs to outright acquisitions, The Boston Globe reported.

headline: Buyout Shops Bid for British Car Dealership
text: A group of private equity firms is expected to progress to the second round of the sale of second-hand car dealership British Car Auctions, Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: The Case for Keeping Al Qaeda Alive
text: Today’s idea: Keeping Al Qaeda weak but alive for now is to the world’s advantage, an article argues, for if it dies, terrorism would be more fragmented, untrackable and lethal.

headline: Bear Stearns Trial: How the Scapegoats Escaped
text: The quick “not guilty” verdict reached Tuesday afternoon by a Brooklyn jury in the federal criminal trial of two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers was at once surprising — for its failure to conform with the zeitgeist — but also entirely understandable, based on a close reading of the prosecution’s arguments and the evidence the judge allowed to be introduced, William D. Cohan writes in The New York Times.

headline: The Great Shrinking American Dollar
text: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention, a research associate at the London School of Economics’ Center for Economic Performance, and a principal in Salute Capital Management Ltd. Simon Johnson, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economic, is the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

headline: The Confetti Machine Returns to Nasdaq
text: The recent flurry of start-up acquisitions could signal an economic recovery for Silicon Valley, as I recently wrote about. But is a real recovery possible without the return of initial public offerings?

headline: Group Accuses China of Abuses in Secret Jails
text: HONG KONG  China’s national government tolerates an extensive network of secret jails in Beijing operated by provincial and municipal governments to prevent citizens from complaining to national officials, according to a report released here Thursday by Human Rights Watch.

headline: Sampler: Intel Settles, SF Police Get E-Mail, Acorns Rain Down
text: Intel to Pay | Chip giant Intel will pay its competitor Advanced Micro Devices $1.25 billion to settle disputes over patents as well as anti-trust issues.

headline: Clues Emerge to Life of Irishman Buried Under Park
text: It is not easy to disappear in the age of the Internet. But, as the case of James Jackson shows, even in the age of the abacus, people sometimes left behind breadcrumbs marking the paths of their lives.

headline: EBay Motors Offering Free Vehicle History Report
text: Those considering buying a used car or truck through eBay Motors will now get a free vehicle history report provided by Experian’s AutoCheck.

headline: Do You Believe in a Crabtree Curse?
text: The Niners have nosedived since signing Michael Crabtree. Gregg Easterbrook, writing for ESPN, has taken to calling it the Crabtree Curse:

headline: Egypt Welcomes Life Sentence for Killing in German Court
text: BERLIN  One day after a German court ordered life imprisonment for a German man who stabbed a pregnant Egyptian woman to death in a Dresden courtroom, the Egyptian authorities on Thursday welcomed the sentence as a deterrent to “anyone who is incited by hate and bitterness to carry out such an outrageous crime.”

headline: Listen to an Interview With Brian Turner
text: The Army veteran, poet and Home Fires contributor Brian Turner appeared on the public radio program Here and Now. You can listen to the interview posted at their Web site.

headline: Wal-Mart Profit Up, but Key Indicator Slips
text: Even as more consumers flocked to Wal-Mart the last few months for deals on brand-name electronics, the company cut prices drastically to keep up with competitors, undermining its sales.

headline: E-Mailing Obama Backers in G.O.P. Districts
text: Democrats are trying to build popular support for health care legislation by enlisting people who voted last year for Barack Obama.

headline: Thursday Puzzle: What’s Wrong (or Right) With This Picture?
text: Does the picture above look natural to you? If you were standing in a lodge at Glacier National Park, is this how a jigsaw puzzle and the scenery would appear to your eye?
