text: Sight Gag | College Humor imagines the Google logo guy running into marital problems:

headline: G.E. Sells Security Unit for $1.8 Billion
text: General Electric said on Thursday that it will sell its fire alarm and security systems unit to United Technologies for $1.82 billion, continuing a sale of what the industrial conglomerate considers noncore businesses.

headline: Week 10 Game Probabilities
text: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior. His game probabilities for Week 10 are below, and his team rankings can be found here.)

headline: Aha Moment
text: A phrase that describes “flashes of understanding,” which has been the subject of a curious copyright battle.

headline: Campaigning for a Cause (and Customers)
text: In an effort to reform federal regulation governing toxic substances — and no doubt gain some marketing exposure in the process — Seventh Generation, the green household cleaning products manufacturer, recently started an ambitious campaign dubbed the Million Baby Crawl.

headline: Speed Read for Thursday, Nov. 12
text: Highlights from today’s media coverage:

headline: The Morning Feed
text: What we’re reading on Thursday morning.Swift Sweeps Country Music Awards: Jon Caramanica writes for The New York Times on Wednesday night’s Country Music Awards, where Taylor Swift won four trophies including Entertainer of the Year. That made her the first female artist to win the award since 2000 and the youngest performer to do so. FunnyOrDie.com had a summary of the events on its Twitter feed, too.

headline: Swamped, Community Colleges Close Admissions Early
text: Thousands of students were shut out this fall as most of New York City’s community colleges were forced to abandon their all-are-welcome admissions policies for the first time.

headline: Stephen Colbert Mops Up ‘Sesame Street’
text: The latest salvo in the war between “Sesame Street” and political ideologues has been fired, this time by the comic firebrand conservative commentator Stephen Colbert. On the occasion of the 40th anniversary of “Sesame Street,” Mr. Colbert took the show to task as “the most insidious socialist brainwashing program in our nation’s history.” He also weighed in on the long-running “Pox News” dispute and showed some great vintage “Sesame Street” clips:

headline: TomTom Adds Text-to-Speech to iPhone
text: A recent New York Times article on GPS Apps for the iPhone apparently got the attention of TomTom, the Netherlands-based navigation company. According to a company spokesman, the article was forwarded to the Amsterdam-based team of engineers to draw their attention to, among other things, the inability of its stand-alone units to properly pronounce place names, and the frustration of having the iPhone app announce an intersection after one has already driven through it.

headline: Clicker Aims to Be the Path to TV Online
text: The Web is increasingly filled with television shows, but finding them can be hard. Clicker, a well-financed startup, believes it can help. On Thursday, the company is rolling out its service, Clicker.com, which it calls a “TV Guide for the Web.”

headline: To Zell, the Commercial Real Estate Crisis Is a Myth
text: Is the pending commercial real estate crisis everyone seems to be afraid of nothing but a myth? Sam Zell thinks so.

headline: Flush of New iPhone Apps
text: A flurry of travel iPhone apps have landed in recent weeks. Here are some of the noteworthy ones:

headline: Californians Worry About Education, Sacramento Still Unpopular
text: Update | 1:54 p.m.  Our colleague over at The Choice blog, Jacques Steinberg, points out that Mark Yudof of the University of California system has been named one of Time Magazine’s “10 Best College Presidents.” Sure, he walked into “one of the toughest jobs in higher education” last year, but the article, which ran with a photo of Mr. Yudof rolling up his sleeves, suggests he’s the right man to guide UC to safe harbor. Thoughts on Mr. Yudof, anyone?

headline: The Early Word: Asia Bound
text: President Obama is announcing on Thursday that he will convene a jobs summit in early December, at a time when the unemployment rate has surpassed 10 percent.

headline: Cambodia’s Embrace of Thaksin Stirs Tensions
text: BANGKOK  In one of his most provocative moves since being ousted in a coup three years ago, Thailand’s fugitive former prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, is visiting neighboring Cambodia this week, stirring tensions between the nations and invigorating his political supporters at home.

headline: A.M.D.-Intel Settlement Won’t End Their Woes
text: The giant chip maker Intel, facing antitrust challenges around the world, announced on Thursday that it would pay $1.25 billion to settle its long-running disputes with its smaller rival, Advanced Micro Devices.

headline: Audrey’s Frocks, Another Pop-Up
text: While I prepare to trot off to the Manolo Blahnik sample sale (the notices are coming fast and furious), I thought I’d mention one or two strange and fantastic things. Some of you may have heard of the upcoming Audrey Hepburn sale. Don’t get terribly excited—they are still old clothes—but you might one to take a gander at the lots when they arrive in New York for a preview on Nov. 21 and 22 at Sotheby’s. Kerry Taylor Auctions will conduct the sale in London on Dec. 8. The sale will include 36 items of clothing, from 1953 to the late 60s, and, of course, there are quite a few by Givenchy.

headline: For Children With Flu, a Trip to the E.R.?
text: This past week, several friends contacted me about their children’s fever, cough and body aches, as symptoms once dismissed as “life with a preschooler” now raise the often unsettling question: “Could this be swine flu?”

headline: Obama Purposely Taking Time on Troop Decision
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama has not made a decision about his new military strategy for Afghanistan. And the White House is happy to say so.

headline: Acorn Sues Over Funding Vote in House
text: The antipoverty group Acorn filed a lawsuit against the federal government on Thursday, saying that the House violated the Constitution by passing a resolution barring the group from receiving federal aid.

headline: Obama Announces Jobs Summit
text: Updated President Obama announced on Thursday that he will convene a jobs summit at the White House next month, saying “the economic growth that we’ve seen has not yet led to the job growth that we desperately need.”

headline: Weekly Popcast: Wale, P.K. 14 and Carsick Cars
text: This week: Jon Pareles reviews “Attention Deficit” by the rapper Wale and, in a special segment, Ben Sisario talks to Yang Haisong of P.K. 14 and Shou Wang of Carsick Cars, both of Beijing, about the underground rock scene in China and their current United States tour.

headline: Group Urges Protection of Northern Forests
text: A coalition of conservation groups are calling on international climate negotiators in Copenhagen next month to develop land-use policy incentives intended to encourage governments to protect natural carbon storehouses — especially those in northern boreal forests and peatlands found in Canada, Scandinavia and Russia.

headline: Update: John King to Replace Lou Dobbs; Focus Will Be on Political News
text: John King will anchor an ambitious new 7 p.m. hour of political news for CNN beginning early next year, the network said Thursday.

headline: Bill Clinton Endorses ‘Mad Men’
text: Forget the Emmy Awards, the critical accolades, the official Brooks Brothers suit — “Mad Men” may have just received its biggest boost yet, from Bill Clinton, who has turned out to be an avid fan of the show.

headline: The i2-JDA Deal: Will History Repeat Itself?
text: Update | 12:35 p.m. The sudden return of the M.&A. market last week also heralded the resurrection of two deals terminated during the financial crisis: Landry’s management buyout and JDA Software Group’s $396 million acquisition of i2 Technologies.

headline: Thursday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Housing Agency’s Cash Reserves Down Sharply
text: The Federal Housing Administration, the government agency whose loan-insurance programs have become a crucial source of support for the housing market, said on Thursday that its cash reserves had dwindled significantly in the last year as more borrowers defaulted on their mortgages.

headline: A First Taste of the Peach
text: As Midtown Lunch notes, Má Pêche, the Momofuku outpost in the Chambers Hotel, is serving a limited menu from 6:30 a.m. to midnight, with a $10 lunch special in the hotel’s mezzanine.

headline: Barclays Capital Hires Co-Head of Global Healthcare
text: Barclays Capital said on Thursday that it had hired Rick Landgarten as the co-head of its global health care group, as the British bank’s investment banking arm continues to expand.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Detroit and New Jersey Reviving the Status Quo
text: Six games on Wednesday night, in which a couple of traditional powers continue to reassert themselves after slow starts this season. We are referring, of course, to the Devils and Red Wings. Home teams listed first:

headline: A Legal Venue for Doing Doughnuts and Racing in Oakland?
text: J. Douglas Allen-Taylor, in his Berkeley Daily Planet column, takes up the idea floated by Mayor Ron Dellums of creating a legal alternative to sideshows, the impromptu, often dangerous, late-night car gatherings.

headline: Divorce Risk Higher When Wife Gets Sick
text: When Dr. Marc Chamberlain, a Seattle oncologist, was treating his brain cancer patients, he noticed an alarming pattern. His male patients were typically receiving much-needed support from their wives. But a number of his female patients were going it alone, ending up separated or divorced after receiving a brain tumor diagnosis.

headline: Oil Slides, and Wall Street Pulls Back
text: Wall Street stocks fell on Thursday as investors reacted with caution to a drop in the price of oil. An announcement by President Obama of a job creation initiative failed to motivate investors.

headline: Response to the ‘Head Scarf Martyr’ Verdict in Egypt and Germany
text: As our colleague Nicholas Kulish reports from Germany, reaction has been mixed in Egypt to the conviction on Wednesday of a man who fatally stabbed a pregnant Egyptian pharmacist to death in July.

headline: Special Section on Giving
text: Today’s New York Times contains a special section on giving. Links to some of the stories are below. (For more information and links, check out the Times’ Topics Page on Philanthropy and send questions on charitable giving to giving@nytimes.com)

headline: Germany Ends Probe of Suspect in Litvinenko Case
text: MOSCOW  German prosecutors have abandoned investigations into one of the main figures suspected of involvement in the killing of a former K.G.B. officer in London three years ago without bringing charges, according to accounts on Thursday by the prosecutors and the man in question.

headline: ‘Dollhouse': Chronicle of a Cancellation Foretold
text: Reacting to the news Wednesday that Fox had canceled its science-fiction adventure series “Dollhouse,” viewers went through an abrupt grieving process. First, denial (see various blog comments and Tweets that take the form of “NOOOOoooo!!!”); second, hurling favorite expletives at the Fox network; third, a kind of acceptance, as if they had known from the start that “Dollhouse” was destined for a short run.

headline: Long-Held Vision for Toy Museum Is Realized
text: After her 4-year-old daughter failed to catch a handmade porcelain doll she had tossed into the air, Marlene Hochman went on a mission to have it repaired, setting her on an unexpected journey into the world of playthings. Thirteen years and three books later, she runs New York City’s only toy museum.

headline: Copia Is Set to Be Sold
text: Thursday is the deadline for bidders interested in buying Copia, the once-glamorous, now-defunct food and wine institute in Napa, Calif.

headline: Intel to Pay $1.25 Billion to Settle With A.M.D.
text: The giant chip maker Intel, facing antitrust challenges around the world, announced on Thursday that it would pay $1.25 billion to settle its long-running disputes with its smaller rival, Advanced Micro Devices.

headline: Vonn and Miller Prepare for Levi
text: The World Cup ski racing season resumes this weekend with men’s and women’s slalom races in Levi, Finland. The American Bode Miller has said he will make his season debut and it will be the first chance for Lindsey Vonn, the two-time overall World Cup champion, to show off her continued progress as a slalom skier.

headline: What to Watch Thursday: How Subway Cars Are Built and Cheyenne Jackson on ’30 Rock’
text: Ever wonder how they were able to make those seats on the new F and Q trains that uncomfortable? “Ultimate Factories” (National Geographic Channel, 8 p.m.) visits the plants in Brazil and Hornell, N.Y., where the subway system’s R160 cars are built. Neil Genzlinger’s review is here.

headline: Russian President Says Modernization Is Needed
text: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev issued a sweeping call on Thursday for Russia to modernize its economy, wean itself from a humiliating dependence on natural resources and do away with Soviet-style attitudes that he said were hindering its effort to remain a world power.

headline: Fun With Google’s Auto-Suggestion Feature
text: It began innocently enough: someone e-mailed me about a quirk of Google’s auto-suggestion feature. If you go to Google.com and type “why won’t” into the Search box, the auto-suggestion pop-up menu includes some pretty bizarre suggestions, including a particularly gross one involving a parakeet (don’t ask).

headline: Another Web Video Face-Off: Roku vs. Boxee
text: Roku and Boxee are two radically different companies pursuing the same goal: to bring the wide-ranging world of Internet video to the living room TV.

headline: ‘Glee’ Watch: Wheelchair Antics
text: This post contains spoilers.

headline: Bivalve Curious
text: There are two fascinating stories for the food-centric in Thursday’s edition of The New York Times, one about oysters from the Gulf Coast, the other about scallops from Peconic Bay.

headline: More Record Highs and Far Fewer Lows
text: Scientists sifting for trends in record high and low temperatures across the United States have found more evidence of long-term warming of the climate, with the biggest shift coming through a reduction in record low nighttime temperatures. That is a pattern long predicted by climate scientists using computer simulations. The researchers said they sifted data carefully to avoid possible distortion of trends related to changes in instruments or conditions at and around weather stations. The changing ratio of cold and hot records is shown below (copyright U.C.A.R., graphic by Mike Shibao):

headline: When Type Was Poured Hot
text: Newsmen are by nature good story­tellers, and no stories animate them quite so much as their own. Yes, they will say, that late-breaking piece turned the tide, and certainly that campaign against feckless bureaucrats landed nicely. But ask them how they got the goods in the first place, and be prepared to pull up a chair.

headline: High School Can Perform ‘Rent,’ ‘Laramie Project’
text: A ruling by a Nevada district court judge will allow a Las Vegas area high school to perform student productions of “Rent” and “The Laramie Project,” despite the objections of parents who were seeking an injunction to prevent them, The Las Vegas Review-Journal reported. Students at Green Valley High School in Henderson will be allowed to perform both shows, starting on Thursday with “The Laramie Project,” after Judge David Wall ruled against parents who objected to the productions’ content. Lawyers for the Clark County School District who represented the students said in arguments that the parents could not prove that performing the shows would cause “irreparable harm.” Lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union of Nevada filed a brief that supported the students as well, arguing that an injunction would violate the students’ right to free speech. Amanda Smith, a 16-year-old student who has a lead role in the “Rent” production planned for next year, told The Review-Journal, “I’m ecstatic.”

headline: The Confetti Machine Returns to Nasdaq
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Palestinian Officials Push for Delay in Elections
text: JERUSALEM  Palestinian presidential and parliamentary elections cannot be held on their scheduled date in January, Palestinian Authority election officials said Thursday. The announcement removed some of the immediate uncertainty surrounding the future of the current president, Mahmoud Abbas, who said recently that he would not run for a second term.

headline: The Octomom and Her Babies Prepare for Prime Time
text: The first thing you notice upon entering the house of a family with 14 children is — not surprisingly — the presence of 14 children. There was Jonah, jiggling around delightedly in his Deluxe ExerSaucer, staring up at me with big brown eyes and smiling with a cleft lip. Nariyah squirmed languidly in a second ExerSaucer next to the fake fireplace, drowsily listing to one side. Makai, Noah and Jeremiah were conked out on the carpet, like little sacks of beans. Maliyah, Josiah and Isaiah lay on the couch in varying states of gassy snuffling.

headline: Seeing Things | Uniqlo’s New Paris Store
text: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.

headline: How to Give the Gift of Charity
text: Just because consumers are cutting back on giving to charity and spending on holiday gifts, they don’t have to be stingy. In The New York Times on Thursday, I wrote about ways to combine giving presents with giving to charity, part of a broader report about philanthropy in today’s paper. (For more information and links, check out the Times’ Topics Page on Philanthropy and send questions on charitable giving to giving@nytimes.com)

headline: Playing Below the Rim
text: In “For Some N.B.A. Players, There’s No Such Thing as a Slam Dunk,” I write about the N.B.A.’s tallest players who have gone a full season without dunking the ball.

headline: F.H.A. Says Cash Reserves Are Down Sharply
text: The Federal Housing Administration said Thursday that its cash reserves had dwindled significantly in the last year after a record drop in home prices, The New York Times’s David Streitfeld reports.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: UNDER THE DOME, by Stephen King (Scribner, $35.) When an enormous transparent dome settles over a small town in Maine, separating its citizens from the world of Obama, it’s just fine with Big Jim, the local tyrant-in-waiting, and his pet goon squad.

headline: After Auto Bankruptcies, Lawyer Goes Back to Work
text: After working on two of the biggest bankruptcies in history — the Chapter 11 cases of General Motors and Chrysler — what was Matthew Feldman to do?

headline: Mythical End for Legendary Route 66
text: On the road’s 83rd anniversary, an “end of the trail” sign was erected at the Santa Monica Pier, a more convenient if not historically accurate terminus. Read the full story.

headline: ‘Happy to Travel’
text: Monologue |  Aired Wednesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: A huge week for the President. Obama leaves tomorrow for a ten-day trip to Singapore, China, South Korea and Japan. Meanwhile, today, Joe Biden ate breakfast, lunch and dinner at Panda Express.

headline: ‘Espionage in Iran’
text: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Three young Americans have been charged with espionage in Iran after straying into the country while hiking in Iraq. Now, obviously, we all pray for their safe return. But hiking in Iraq? I mean — you know, if you’re hiking in Iraq and Iran, you might want to get a you new travel agent. O.K?

headline: New Rules Would Restrict Overdraft Fees on Debit Cards
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve announced new rules on Thursday that would sharply restrict banks and others that issue debit cards from charging overdraft fees without the express permission of the cardholder.

headline: ‘City Is Broke’
text: Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Welcome to New York City, first of all, but bad news — city is broke. Yeah. No more money. And they’re cutting back on garbage collection. And I want to tell you, New York City, by the way, has one of the finest collections of garbage you’ll see anywhere.

headline: BA, Iberia Boards Meet Over Potential Deal
text: A merger between British Airways and Spain’s Iberia looked imminent on Thursday as their boards held separate meetings to discuss a deal to create the world’s third-largest airline by revenue, Reuters reported.

headline: ‘A Dangerous Drug’
text: Monologue |  Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Former President Bill Clinton talked to Senate Democrats about the health-care bill. And he told them not to make the same mistakes he and Hillary did. That’s what he said, yeah. As a result, the senators all went home and got a divorce.

headline: Evolution, Traced by the Lens
text: Photographic triptychs of New York buildings showing their evolution from the 1930s to today.

headline: After Slow Start, DIP Lending Is in Full Swing
text: When Lyondell Chemical filed for bankruptcy in January, the restructuring world was abuzz that the company received debtor-in-possession financing at all.

headline: Paperback Row
text: A QUIET ADJUSTMENT,  by Benjamin Markovits (Norton, $14.95.) “I fear very much you will find out you have married a devil,” Lord Byron confides to his new wife, Annabella Milbanke, at the start of their honeymoon — and she does. This eloquent novel, the second in a proposed trilogy, is presented in a third-person narration that seems to arise from Annabella, a beautiful 19-year-old. Her perspective is conveyed with a hesitant formality reminiscent of Henry James, and “phrase after phrase winks for readerly attention,” our reviewer, Jay Parini, said.

headline: Did Dame Edna and Michael Feinstein Find a Gullible Reporter?
text: Well, folks, it looks like we got snookered by the oldest trick in the P.R. handbook: a celebrity feud. In this case, the celebrities in question are Michael Feinstein and Dame Edna Everage, who have been sniping back and forth in recent days about two similarly titled Broadway shows, “All About Me” and “It’s All About Me.” (He: “Titles are not copyrightable. I wish Ms. Edna well. I’ve heard of her.”) (She: “I’m sure Mrs. Feinstein is very proud of her son.”)

headline: The Alternative Medicine Cabinet: Marigolds to Soothe Skin
text: Anahad O’Connor, who writes the Really column for The New York Times, explores the claims and the science behind various alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

headline: A Chance to See the City Change, Site by Site
text: At the start of the 20th century, Henry James pronounced New York “a provisional city,” a phrase echoed decades later by Le Corbusier. The architectural historian Max Page suggested that “creative destruction”  the intentional razing and rebuilding of New York  represented “a crucial dynamic of urban life.” O. Henry summed it up more succinctly. “It’ll be a great place,” he said, “if they ever finish it.”

headline: Playboy Stock Surges on Report of Sale Talks
text: Shares of Playboy Enterprises shot up more than 30 percent on Thursday after Bloomberg News reported that the men’s magazine publisher was in talks to sell itself to the Iconix Brand Group. It cited two unidentified people close to the situation.

headline: A Battle in Canada Over Drive-Through Idling
text: Canadians are debating whether or not the drive-through lanes at Tim Hortons, a doughnut and fast-food chain, should be part of an anti-idling ordinance in Kingston, Ontario.

headline: Big Bird on Birthdays and Tony Bennett
text: Tuesday represented the 40th anniversary of “Sesame Street,” and this week, Caroll Spinney, known to millions as Big Bird and Oscar the Grouch, and Carol-Lynn Parente, executive producer, have been answering readers’ questions about the show.

headline: Sri Lankan General Resigns
text: The powerful army general who led Sri Lanka’s bloody but successful battle against the Tamil Tigers resigned abruptly Thursday, heightening speculation that he will run against his onetime ally, Mahinda Rajapaksa, for president in next year’s election.

headline: Travel Deals: 50% off Starwood Hotels and Resorts
text: Starwood Hotels and Resorts is offering up to 50 percent off stays through Jan. 18 at hundreds of hotels worldwide. Rooms must be booked by Nov. 17. Sample rates:

headline: Scott Foundas Joins Film Society of Lincoln Center
text: The community of film critics just got smaller by one: Scott Foundas, the film editor and chief film critic for LA Weekly, will leave that role to become the associate program director at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the group announced in a news release. Working with the Film Society’s program director, Richard Peña, Mr. Foundas will help organize film series and other programs, including the annual New York Film Festival. He is expected to start next year.

headline: Guidance Office: Post a Question About Community Colleges
text: On Monday, The Choice will begin a weeklong Q&A for readers on the subject of community colleges. Each year, such institutions become a more crucial cog in the American higher-education system, as evidenced by the fact that nearly one of every two students in a for-credit undergraduate course is now enrolled in a community college.

headline: Verizon: How Much Do You Charge Now?
text: Starting next week, Verizon will double the early-termination fee for smartphones. That is, if you get a BlackBerry, Android or similar phone from Verizon, and you decide to switch phones before your two-year contract is up, you'll be socked with a $350 penalty (it used to be $175).

headline: New Overdraft Rules: What Consumers Need to Know
text: Big changes are coming to your checking account.

headline: Why Kids Watch Movies Again and Again and Again
text: I know every word of every song in “Les Miserables.” I knew them long before I had a chance to actually see the show, because my kindergarten-age son stumbled on a PBS special years ago, then watched a videotaped version of that special over and over and over and over again.

headline: Second Officer Gives an Account of the Shooting at Ft. Hood
text: KILLEEN, Tex.  Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley has been applauded as a hero across the nation for shooting down Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan during the bloody rampage at Fort Hood last week. The account of heroism, given by the authorities, attracted the attention of newspapers, the networks and television talk shows.

headline: Verizon: How Much Do You Charge Now?
text: Starting next week, Verizon will double the early-termination fee for smartphones. That is, if you get a BlackBerry, Android or similar phone from Verizon, and you decide to switch phones before your two-year contract is up, you’ll be socked with a $350 penalty (it used to be $175).

headline: Acorn Sues Over Funding Vote in House
text: Saying a resolution by the House of Representatives that barred Acorn from receiving federal aid violated the Constitution by singling out the antipoverty group for punishment, lawyers for Acorn filed a lawsuit on Thursday that seeks to restore the financing. Read The Times’s story.

headline: Now Shopping | Monki and Weekday, Hamburg’s Dynamic Duo
text: Monki and Weekday, the sister stores that are Sweden’s answer to Topshop and H&M, continue their march through Europe, most recently arriving in the German city of Hamburg, where the shops opened last week. Based in Stockholm, the company achieved international status with its Cheap Monday jeans — skintight numbers that the co-founder, Adam Friberg, says at first “no one liked and then they suddenly became really popular.” That kind of intuition is what led Friberg and his business partner, Orjan Andersson, to Hamburg: they just like the city’s odd mix of grit and wealth, its asymmetrical architecture and its flea-market subculture.

headline: Law School as an Investment
text: Is law school a good investment?

headline: The Lost World of Creedmoor Hospital
text: Founded in 1912 as a Farm Colony of Brooklyn State Hospital, the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens became, by mid-century, a world unto itself. At its peak, it housed some 7,000 patients. They tended gardens and raised livestock on the hospital’s grounds. The hospital contained gymnasiums, a swimming pool, a theater, a television studio, and giant kitchens and laundries where patients were put to work.

headline: Q. and A. With O.H.L. Commissioner David Branch
text: If the N.H.L. general managers wind up asking for stricter rules regarding checks to the head when they make their recommendations to members of the N.H.L. competition committee this March, much of the credit for influencing them to change their longstanding opposition will ultimately go to someone outside the league: Ontario Hockey League Commissioner David Branch. The rules he has imposed and strictly enforced in his league — penalizing all hits to the head, enforcing stern and consistent suspensions for flagrant violations of all safety-related rules — created a climate that changed the conversation in Canada, opening the way for traditional fans to begin thinking about a game that tries to reduce catastrophic injuries and promote mutual respect among players on the ice. The N.H.L. G.M.’s resisted that stance for a long time, but on Wednesday in Toronto they showed for the first time a willingness to consider adopting some of the principles Branch has championed.

headline: G.M. Agrees to Recycle Mercury Switches, for Now
text: Mercury, the only metal element that is liquid at standard room temperature, is notoriously hard to handle — in more ways than one. Until 2003, automakers used highly toxic mercury in switches that controlled trunk and under-hood lights, as well as antilock brake systems. Since then, carmakers have switched to benign alternatives, but an estimated 38 million mercury switches still remain in cars.

headline: Guilty Pleas Expected in Balloon Hoax Case
text: DENVER  The Colorado couple accused of lying to the authorities by saying that their 6-year-old son was aboard a runaway helium balloon last month have agreed to plead guilty, one of their lawyers said Thursday.

headline: Comparing Veterans’ Experiences With War Poetry
text: Overview | How do authors depict the experiences of soldiers returning home from war? How do these literary portraits mirror reality? In this lesson, students explore literary depictions of veterans and compare them to the lived experiences of soldiers. They then use recent Times war coverage to create found poems that comment on the theme of returning from war.

headline: F.A. Gives Sir Alex the Hair-Dryer Treatment
text: Sir Alex Ferguson, the manager of Manchester United, has two Premier League streaks going. His team has won three consecutive championships, and, for the third season in a row, the vocal Scot has been hit with a ban for berating the performance of referees.

headline: Something New Under the Caribbean Sun
text: IF you build it, they will come.

headline: Brother Gives New Meaning to ‘Guitar Hero’
text: Here is an update on what was perhaps the most surprising moment during the 99th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers.

headline: Gates Says Afghan Plan Will Mix Various Proposals
text: President Obama hopes to combine the best elements from among the several proposals he is studying on sending additional troops to Afghanistan, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said on Thursday.

headline: Behind the Fighter Manny Pacquiao, the Fight for His Favor
text: LOS ANGELES  The condominium looks like a fraternity house, not the resting place for boxing royalty. Stained carpets cover the floor. Dartboards hang from the wall. Bowls of food, half-eaten leftovers, line the kitchen.

headline: 36 Hours in Turks and Caicos
text: DANGLING at the southern end of the Bahamas island chain like an after-thought, Turks and Caicos was often overlooked as a Caribbean destination. But thanks to some of the swankiest names in hotels  Regent, Amanresorts and Meriden, to name a few  Turks and Caicos is now firmly on the map of those seeking a beach vacation with heavy pampering and a splash of indulgence. It is the kind of place where hotel staff members adjust your beach chair umbrella as the sun shifts and pass out cool towels to keep you from overheating. And moderately priced hotels have maid service a mere two times a day, instead of providing guests with a small army of personal servants. Technically, the islands are in the Atlantic, but with this level of coddling  not to mention some of the bluest waters in the world  who cares?

headline: Don’t Count Your Chickens
text: “Fantastic Mr. Fox” is a proudly analog animated entertainment, making its handmade way into a marketplace glutted with digital goodies. Next to the three-dimensional, computer-generated creatures that swoop and soar off the screen these days, the furry talking animals on display here, with their matted pelts, jerky movements and porcelain eyes, might look a little quaint, like old-fashioned wind-up toys uneasily sharing the shelf with the latest video game platforms.

headline: Two Disney Executives Will Switch Jobs
text: Two of Disney’s top executives are switching jobs – a shift that Robert A. Iger, the company’s chief executive, said in an interview had been in the works since last summer.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: On Thursday, a news article in The Times reported on the ties between Peter W. Galbraith, a former United States ambassador, and a Norwegian oil company that operates in the Kurdistan region of Iraq. According to the Times article, Mr. Galbraith "received rights to an enormous stake in at least one of Kurdistan's oil fields in the spring of 2004."

headline: First, a Tourniquet, then Preschool Pickup
text: A few months ago, we learned that when journalist Euna Lee was detained in North Korea, she asked her captors to allow her to send a most important message to her husband — a reminder to register their daughter for preschool.

headline: A Street Where Old Is New, Again
text: Fifty years ago, the shops along Atlantic Avenue between Hoyt and Bond Streets in Brooklyn earned the block its nickname, Antiques Row, but with the rising rents, many of the sellers up and vanished. In the last five years, however, a new class of creative entrepreneur has moved onto the avenue with a stylish take on the same mission: using old things for new purposes.

headline: Hotel Review: The Encore in Las Vegas
text: THE BASICS

headline: Mercado de Dulces in Morelia, Mexico
text: If you didn’t notice the concentration of bees near the Colegio de los Jesuitas, in Morelia, Mexico, you might think the complex was another one of the city’s signature pink-stone churches. But the bees aren’t going to Mass  they’re headed toward 28 stalls of gooey and chili-sprinkled delights that fill the corridors of the old cloister: a bazaar of regional sweets called the Mercado de Dulces.

headline: Paterson Is Counting on Obama
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: New Face of Mercado Santurce in San Juan, P.R.
text: “BUSINESS isn’t what it used to be,” Ramón Tellado Rosa said from behind a pile of bananas at his stall at the Mercado Santurce in the Campo Alegre district of San Juan, P.R.  for decades the place where Sanjuaneros have come for fresh produce.

headline: Underwater, Literally, With a $2 Million Bugatti
text: Eddie Griffin might finally be off the hook for the most ridiculous crash in a priceless supercar. On Wednesday, a man drove a Bugatti Veyron into a lagoon in Texas after avoiding a low-flying pelican.

headline: Sailing the Caribbean, the Frugal Way
text: CONSIDERING that none of us newbies had any idea what we were doing, the voyage south from St. Lucia was going well. At 10:30 a.m., amid gray but not ominous skies, the S.V. Illusion  the 75-foot, two-masted schooner on which I and two others were novice sailors  had weighed anchor off the coast of Vieux Fort, a sleepy city at the island’s southern tip, and steered into deeper waters. The sea was mild, with five-foot swells rocking us just enough to make walking a conscious effort, and when Norman Garnett, the Illusion’s 61-year-old English captain, gave the order, we scrambled to pull, feed, winch and cleat a series of ropes that unfurled our three sails, which caught and tightened in the wind. We were sailing!

headline: Zimbabwe: Opposition Lawyers Ask for New Judge in Bennett Trial
text: Lawyers for Roy Bennett, a senior leader in the opposition party Movement for Democratic Change, asked the trial judge Chinembiri Bhunu to recuse himself on grounds that his earlier comments in a related 2006 case showed a bias for believing the state’s case.

headline: Chef Dan Barber’s Kale Salad and Creamy Parsnip Rice
text: Diners at the Blue Hill at Stone Barns restaurant in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., rarely forget their first bite. Mine was a tiny floret of purple cauliflower, served raw, lightly marinated and bursting with fresh flavor. Although pork also was on the menu, the evening ended up being a celebration of vegetables, including beets, wild mushrooms and tiny carrots, and finishing with an enticing fresh herbal tea.

headline: Gates Angry About Defense-Related Leaks
text: OSHKOSH, Wis. — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates is normally a mild-mannered man, at least in public, but he unleashed a torrent on his plane on Thursday morning about leaks during the investigation of the Foot Hood shootings and President Obama’s deliberations on sending more American troops to Afghanistan.

headline: Senators Propose Prizes for Capturing CO2
text: Senators John Barrasso, Republican of Wyoming, and Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, have joined in introducing a bill that would establish awards for researchers who develop technologies that can economically extract carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and stash it away. In doing so, they are potentially upping the ante offered in 2007 by Richard Branson, the aviation and music magnate, for such an advance.

headline: Letter: The Ridgeway Trail
text: To the Editor: This past spring we experienced a slice of Henry Shukman’s walk (”Hiking Into History,” Nov. 1) along England’s ancient

headline: A Battle in Canada Over Idling at Drive-Throughs
text: From our colleagues at Green Inc.:

headline: Standing Room Only | L’Avant Comptoir in Paris
text: If anyone can make Parisians stand up for good food, it’s the bistro maestro Yves Camdeborde, whose new L’Avant Comptoir has been packed to the rafters since it opened a week ago. Just steps from the Odéon, this short, narrow, standing-room-only space with white tile walls, a broad pewter counter and an open kitchen is what Camdeborde calls an “hors d’oeuvres bar,” and it serves up an array of delicious small-plate Basque- and Béarnais-inspired nibbles and carving boards of superb charcuterie along with a great selection of wines by the glass (Lapierre’s luscious Morgon, great Côtes du Rhone, offbeat whites like UBY Colombard Ugni Blanc).

headline: Major Held in Fort Hood Rampage Is Charged With 13 Counts of Murder
text: FORT HOOD, Tex.   Military officials charged Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan on Thursday with 13 counts of premeditated murder, accusing him of a brutal one-man attack here at America’s largest Army post last week and setting in motion what promises to be a momentous court-martial proceeding that could end in the death penalty.

headline: Domestic Workers Unite in a Bad Economy
text: There is a movement afoot to organize domestic workers and improve their working conditions even as many face unemployment because of the weak economy. On Friday morning, people advocating better working conditions for such workers will gather at the 24th Street BART station for a march to the Women’s Building on 18th Street. The march kicks off the West Coast Congress of the National Domestic Worker Alliance, to be held at Oakland’s Laney College this weekend. Twenty-eight organizations will discuss how to better organize on national issues and get a domestic workers bill of rights passed in California’s legislature.

headline: Feinberg Will Consider Competitive Pay Offers
text: The Obama administration’s pay czar, Kenneth R. Feinberg, said on Thursday that he was concerned that pay cuts he ordered at companies that received the federal bailout could hamper their ability to retain talent, and that he would consider allowing new executives to be hired at competitive industry rates.

headline: The Cheating Game
text: Richard Nixon played poker well. His winnings in the Navy (there is no evidence that they were stowed in a specially built footlocker with a false bottom) financed young Nixon’s first, successful Congressional election campaign in 1946 against the admired incumbent Democrat, Jerry Voorhis.

headline: In Canada, a Royal Yawn for Prince Charles
text: PETAWAWA, Ontario  As things now stand, when Prince Charles succeeds his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, his many roles will include being the king of Canada.

headline: The Lies They Told
text: When Sept. 11, 2001, dawned, the Northeast Air Defense Sector in Rome, N.Y., went on full alert — to prepare for a training exercise that envisioned a sneak attack by Russian planes flying over the North Pole to bomb the United States, a prospect that Defense Secretary Robert McNamara had dismissed as outdated in 1966. Later that morning, after American Airlines Flight 11 and United Airlines Flight 175 had hit the World Trade Center and American Airlines Flight 77 the Pentagon, three F-16 fighter jets were scrambled from Langley Air Force Base to form a combat air patrol over Washington. But degraded radio transmission quality meant that the pilots were left clueless about the nature of their mission. On seeing the Pentagon in flames, the lead fighter pilot later explained, “I reverted to the Russian threat. . . . I’m thinking cruise missile threat from the sea. You know, you look down and see the Pentagon burning, and I thought the bastards snuck one by us. . . . You couldn’t see any airplanes, and no one told us anything.”

headline: The Way We Ate: Of Artichokes and Liberty
text: For more than a century and a half, The New York Times has been recording the pleasures and prejudices of the American palate. “The Way We Ate” is a weekly tasting menu of vintage food writing from the Times archives.

headline: A Street Where Old Is New, Again
text: Fifty years ago, the shops along Atlantic Avenue between Hoyt and Bond Streets in Brooklyn earned the block its nickname, Antiques Row, but with the rising rents, many of the sellers up and vanished. In the last five years, however, a new class of creative entrepreneur has moved onto the avenue with a stylish take on the same mission: using old things for new purposes.

headline: 10 Years Later, Looking at Repeal of Glass-Steagall
text: Update | 3:49 p.m. Ten years ago to the day, the government reversed one of the key elements of the Depression-era banking laws, knocking down the firewall between commercial banks, which take deposits and make loans, and investment banks, which underwrite securities. The repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 was seen at the time as a way to help American banks grow larger and better compete on the world stage.

headline: More on the Ethics of Prostheses
text: The case most commonly made against allowing some prosthetics into able-bodied competitions holds that I lack an imagination. It’s not hard to imagine, so this argument goes, that we could invent prostheses that would give the runner an advantage. Actually, it is. Unless we are adding energy artificially (robotics, engines, etc.), these prostheses replace what isn’t there. There are ways to test whether they enable competitors to run or to run better than they otherwise might (the unilateral test subjects were chosen precisely because their one natural leg provided a control). When I was a kid, anyone who owned a Guinness Book of World Records will remember the arresting photo of the football player who lacked part of a foot and, with a shoe shaped like a brick, kicked the longest field goal in pro football history. After he won the world record, the league adjusted the rules to say that everybody, including amputees, had to kick with the same-shaped shoes. That seems fair.

headline: Doom Loop
text: A virtueless circle in which banks take ever-greater risks to boost returns (secure in the knowledge the state will underwrite them), and governments are forced to break their promises “never again” to bankroll losses (further encouraging banks to take dangerous risks).

headline: Primary Care’s Image Problem
text: In my medical school class of 140, Kerry was one of the best and the brightest. Gregarious, unassuming and a dedicated fitness buff with a weakness for ice cream, she managed to sail through the weekly exams that most of us struggled with during the first two years. Later on, in the third year on the hospital wards, she quickly became what every one of us so wanted to be: the indispensable medical student.

headline: Giving Primary Care More Respect
text: In today’s Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline W. Chen writes about the image problem that primary care specialists face. Dr. Chen recounts the story of a respected medical school colleague who chose the primary care route, and the disparaging comments that followed.

headline: Broken Glass(-Steagall)
text: From President Clinton’s statement, 10 years ago today, when he signed the bill that dismantled Glass-Steagall and allowed commercial banks to engage in the investment business.

headline: Rational Irrationality
text: Two leading financial journalists have made worthy additions to the increasingly crowded shelf of books on our recent economic failure. In very different ways, John Cassidy and Andrew Ross Sorkin address the critical question of what exactly happened on Wall Street. Until we settle on at least a rough answer, we won’t have a prayer of preventing the next crisis.

headline: Warhol’s Eye for the Bucks
text: Whenever you stand back for a panoramic look at the contemporary art world — that confection of bucks, puff and street smarts — you realize afresh that Andy Warhol was the daddy of it all. And that was confirmed yet again at Sotheby’s on Wednesday night, when his 1962 silkscreen painting “200 One Dollar Bills” sold for $43.7 million (including Sotheby’s fees).

headline: Illness and Intimacy
text: Few people have written about their experience of manic-depressive illness from the inside as acutely as Kay Redfield Jamison did in her 1995 memoir, “An Unquiet Mind.” Among the things that distinguished that book was the fact that Jamison, a professor of psychiatry at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine and a co-author of the standard medical text on bipolar illness, knew the disease as both clinician and patient. Jamison’s outing of her affliction involved considerable professional risk. Some of her colleagues recognized the advantage of her uniquely intimate knowledge of the illness she treated, but others believed it cast a pall over her professional judgment — a prejudice that would probably not have come to bear on a cardiologist, say, who happened to have undergone heart surgery.

headline: Which to Preserve, the Chicken or the Egg?
text: IN the last 30 years, hundreds, perhaps thousands, of deteriorated high-stoop brownstones in New York have been restored as new generations of owners reinstalled stoops and recreated facades stripped off decades ago.

headline: Love Crimes
text: As soon as you finish Paul Auster’s “Invisible” you want to read it again. And not because, as sometimes with his novels — as with the novels of Georges Perec, one of a handful of other real authors mentioned in the book — you suddenly suspect, at the very end, that you haven’t properly understood a word of what has gone before. You want to reread “Invisible” because it moves quickly, easily, somehow sinuously, and you worry that there were good parts that you read right past, insights that you missed. The prose is contemporary American writing at its best: crisp, elegant, brisk. It has the illusion of effortlessness that comes only with fierce discipline. As often happens when you are in the hands of a master, you read the next sentence almost before you are finished with the previous one. The novel could be read shallowly, because it is such a pleasure to read.

headline: Quad Q&A: Tim Crothers
text: Tim Crothers is a former senior writer for Sports Illustrated and the author of “The Man Watching,” a biography of the North Carolina women’s soccer coach, Anson Dorrance. headline: Angels and Insects
text: “We are all outlaws in the eyes of America! In order to survive we steal cheat lie forge fred hide and deal!” Jefferson Airplane wrote these cheerfully absurd words for “We Can Be Together,” their 1969 anthem for a largely middle-class teenage audience playing at being revolutionaries; the lyrics would be a fitting epigraph for Rawi Hage’s second novel, “Cockroach.” Hage is a highly esteemed 45-year-old Beirut-born writer now living in Montreal. His first book, “De Niro’s Game,” won the 2008 Impac Dublin Literary Award, given for the best English-language book published anywhere in the world. “Cockroach” was a finalist for the Governor General’s Award and other Canadian prizes. Yet the Airplane anthem of teenage “revolution” is the perfect soundtrack for it.

headline: November Song
text: Narratives, Aristotle suggests in his “Poetics,” work best if they’re arranged around some pre-existing unit of time: sunrise to sunset, January to December. In his view, at least, human beings love symmetry, and repetition. We like being reminded, in fiction, of what we already know in fact. Maureen Howard has taken this advice both literally and extravagantly in her tetralogy of fictions based on the seasons: her novel “A Lover’s Almanac” (winter); a collection of three novellas, “Big as Life” (spring); another novel, “The Silver Screen” (summer); and now, finally, “The Rags of Time,” which comes described as a novel, but is more a kind of late, meandering overture, part meditation, part postscript, part appendix. Like autumn, it flares and fades, rages and dissembles, not wanting to give itself over to its inevitable end.

headline: The First Marriage

At first it was because I wanted my daughters to see that all families are fundamentally alike. Now it is because of the profound wisdom Michelle Obama has about her marriage. All couples struggle, and many couples evolve in the roles they play; in the end, though, it’s about making our own contributions to the relationship. Thanks to the Obamas for being honest enough to acknowledge this difficult but universal truth.

headline: Escalations

Our national obsession for militarism around the world doesn’t work and brings only resentment. Barack Obama shares a common strength with President Kennedy — the audacity to envision a just world, not by exporting our militarymight but by the richness of our own values.

headline: Lives: Car Thief
text: Michelle Huneven’s poignant portrayal of her aging father’s misadventures with driving is a tale that many more will be able to tell in the decades ahead. As people live longer, they drive longer. And in most communities, if you can’t drive, your world shrinks, health declines and life is over, figuratively if not literally. So what is a concerned son or daughter to do? Getting your parent’s doctor to contact the D.M.V. is not the end of the story. Just as some states have instituted vision requirements for older persons to renew their licenses, a brief standardized screening for physical and cognitive fitness to drive deserves serious attention in our national-policy discussions, along with support for alternative transportation options that enable safe and convenient community mobility. This won’t always be our parents’ problem.

headline: Delivering Bad News and Truths About War
text: At one point in “The Messenger” a soldier, just back from an overseas tour of duty, is telling a story during a welcome-home party with some friends. It starts out as a funny reminiscence of a local character he knew in Iraq, but when the anecdote takes a gruesome turn, the laughter is replaced by uncomfortable silence. Nobody gets the point of what he’s saying, or maybe nobody wants to hear it, and the happy mood of the reunion fractures.

headline: Rural India Gets Chance at Piece of Jobs Boom

headline: When the World Hangs in the Balance, a Reliable Calendar Is Needed
text: I know what I have against Roland Emmerich  “The Patriot,” for starters  but what does he have against us? He’s bombarded Earth with alien death rays, big-footed it with a rampaging reptile and put it into deep freeze. Now in “2012,” his latest apocalyptic folly, he cracks the planet like a nut, splitting its crust, toppling its mountains and cities, and laying its every creeping thing to inevitable tedious waste.

headline: Eating By the Book | ‘The Craft of Baking’
text: This Sunday’s Times Magazine features a story by Pete Wells with a recipe for spicy caramel popcorn from Karen DeMasco’s first book, “The Craft of Baking.” I was eager to get my hands on it; DeMasco is one of New York City’s most celebrated and talented pastry chefs. She baked at Fore Street in Portland, Me., at Chanterelle in Manhattan and then under Claudia Fleming at Gramercy Tavern. In 2001, she relocated a block south, where she shaped her baking style as Tom Colicchio’s pastry chef at Craft, Craftbar and ‘wichcraft. After a brief hiatus from the restaurant grind, she is back in it, this time as the pastry chef at Andrew Carmellini’s Locanda Verde.

headline: Compassionate Masters of the Universe
text: First, do no harm. That’s the bottom-line rule of Jainism, one of the three major homegrown religions in India. To believers, all living things, from whales to humans to flu bugs, have souls and, karmically speaking, all souls are equal. If you go thrashing and stomping your way through the average day, as most of us do, you’re bound to be injuring something. And if you injure something, you injure everything, including yourself. This is how karma works. So it pays to move with care.

headline: When Courageous Artists Ripped Holes in the Iron Curtain
text: IN 1985 a dissident troupe of Polish actors called Theater of the Eighth Day defied the ruling Communist Party and its censors by creating a play about the bleakness of daily life under martial law, imposed from 1981 to 1983. With ragged costumes and only a few props  most notably a sailboat that symbolized the dream of escape  the actors prepared to mount “Wormwood,” an unusually blunt and unvarnished work of protest theater.
