headline: Brief, Productive Love Affair With ‘Big Dog’
text: When Christopher Columbus first came to America, there were no natives on horseback to greet him. That is not only because he landed on an island in the Bahamas. It’s also because there were no horses in the New World. They originated here 40 million years ago and spread to other parts of the globe, but by 1492 horses had been extinct in the Western Hemisphere for 10,000 years. On his second trans-Atlantic voyage, in 1493, Columbus brought along 25 horses and reintroduced the species to America. Many more were brought later by French, English and Dutch colonizers.

headline: W.H.O. Rushes Drugs to Nations Hit by Swine Flu
text: Emergency supplies of antiviral drugs are being sent to Ukraine, Afghanistan and other countries in Eastern Europe and Central Asia, where hospitals report that they are being overwhelmed by patients with swine flu, the World Health Organization said Thursday.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Hollywood Swoons Over That Hair, That Baton
text: LOS ANGELES  They drew the line at the bobble-head doll.

headline: Lou Dobbs
text: I used to go on Lou Dobbs fairly often in the early years of this decade — and I liked him. We didn’t agree on much, but the on-air discussions were always even-tempered and kind of fun. I would never have expected him to snap the way he did.

headline: Unsnarling a Knotty Ball of Secrets, British Style
text: “Collision,” a two-week “Masterpiece Contemporary” mini-series beginning on Sunday on PBS, raises an old but always pertinent question: why are the British so much better at this sort of thing than we are?

headline: A Sentimental Tug
text: Several years ago, I noticed my sister’s daughter wearing two rings on her fingers. They were my childhood earrings, which I left with my parents for safekeeping. My sister took them and turned them into rings for her daughter. I felt really bad; those earrings have sentimental value. But if I confront my sister, I’m afraid I’ll lose the relationship. Should I just let the earrings go?

headline: Film Series and Movie Listings
text: MOVIES

headline: Trailer: 'The Prisoner'
text: Ian McKellen and Jim Caviezel star in this new version of the cult spy series from the 1960s, which begins Sunday on AMC.

headline: Rethinking of a Number Between 1 and 10
text: There was no single archvillain in “The Prisoner,” which was one of the many distinctions of that legendary late-60s spy series.

headline: Times News Service to Lay Off at Least 25
text: The New York Times News Service will lay off at least 25 editorial employees next year, and will move the editing of the service to a Florida newspaper owned by The New York Times Company, The Times and the Newspaper Guild said on Thursday.

headline: Arts and Crafts Items That Aren’t Often Seen
text: John H. Bryan, a former chief executive of the Sara Lee Corporation, owns an estate near Chicago that looks like a museum of early 1900s design but is not, at least not yet. On a 150-acre former dairy farm in Lake Bluff, Ill., named Crab Tree Farm, he has spent two decades setting up period rooms in 1910s barns and other scattered outbuildings. Almost every chair, bookcase, table, vase and rug was made by Arts and Crafts innovators from Britain and the United States, including Gustav Stickley, William Morris and Christopher Dresser.

headline: Laura Straus and John Alexander
text: SHAKESPEARE’S sonnets, Thomas Hardy’s poetry and Pasternak’s “Doctor Zhivago” seem to have little in common, but all played a part in the romance between Laura Straus and John Alexander.

headline: Workers Plead Guilty in ‘Man Cave’ Case
text: ALBANY  A warning to any slacker state employee who thinks it is wise to deal drugs, sleep and watch television just a few steps from the State Capitol while you are supposed to be working: You will probably end up in jail.

headline: White House Sides With C.I.A. in Turf Battle
text: WASHINGTON After a months-long turf battle between America’s top spies, the White House has sided with the Central Intelligence Agency in the dispute over who has the power to appoint the top spy in each country overseas, according to intelligence officials.

headline: Country Awards on Top
text: The Country Music Association Awards, at which 19-year-old Taylor Swift won the Entertainer of the Year prize, earned its most viewers in four years on Wednesday and lifted ABC to No. 1 in the night’s ratings. According to Nielsen’s estimates, an average of 16.8 million viewers tuned in to the awards show, nearly a million more than last year. CBS was second for the night, garnering its highest ratings for its crime dramas “Criminal Minds” (12.3 million) and “CSI: NY” (13.9 million). NBC was third with “Law & Order: SVU” (8.8 million) and “The Jay Leno Show” (4.6 million). Fox finished in fourth place as “Glee” attracted 7.3 million viewers.

headline: Art in Review
text: REGINA JOSé GALINDO

headline: Journalist Gets Book Deal
text: Euna Lee, a journalist who was arrested by North Korea and jailed for nearly five months, will write a book for the Broadway Books imprint of the Crown Publishing Group detailing her experiences. Ms. Lee, a producer for Current TV, was arrested with a colleague, Laura Ling, on March 17 while filming at the border between China and North Korea. In June, the women were sentenced to 12 years of hard labor for “committing hostilities against the Korean nation and illegal entry,” but were pardoned in August after the intervention of former President Bill Clinton. In a statement on Thursday, Broadway Books said that Ms. Lee’s memoir, called “The World Is Bigger Now: A Memoir of Faith, Family and Freedom,” would detail “her 140 days of imprisonment, her ongoing interrogation and her efforts to protect her sources and the subjects of her reporting,” as well as the importance of her religious faith during this time. A publication date has not been announced. Ms. Ling is presently pitching her own book with her sister, the journalist Lisa Ling.

headline: Alabama’s Bingo Halls
text: Video bingo has become increasingly popular in Alabama in recent years, leading to a legal backlash led by gambling opponents.

headline: American Art Fair at National Academy
text: A sale of paintings and watercolors by 19th- and early-20th-century American masters will be held at the National Academy, the artist-governed museum and school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan that provoked an outcry last year when it sold two Hudson River School paintings from its collection to shore up its finances. But this sale is different. The artworks, by the likes of Thomas Eakins, Thomas Hart Benton, George Inness and Whistler, are being offered by 11 dealers under the umbrella of the second annual American Art Fair, running Nov. 30 through Dec. 3. Part of the fair’s proceeds will benefit the troubled academy.

headline: Among Obama Aides, Debate Intensifies on Troop Levels
text: WASHINGTON  The disclosure that the United States ambassador in Kabul has expressed written opposition to deploying more American troops to Afghanistan lays bare the fierce debate within the Obama administration over the direction of the war, even after weeks of deliberations and with the president on the verge of a decision.

headline: Gates Condemns Leaks on U.S. Afghan Policy and Ft. Hood
text: OSHKOSH, Wis.  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates is normally a mild-mannered man, at least in public, but he unleashed a torrent on Thursday about leaks during the investigation of the Foot Hood shootings and during President Obama’s deliberations on sending more American troops to Afghanistan.

headline: E. Coli Outbreak Traced to Company That Halted Testing of Ground Beef Trimmings
text: A deadly outbreak of E. coli has been traced to a large producer of ground beef that stopped testing its ingredients years ago under pressure from beef suppliers.

headline: Paul Tagliabue, Former N.F.L. Commissioner, Selected to Lead U.S.O.C. Panel
text: The board of the United States Olympic Committee has appointed Paul Tagliabue, the former N.F.L. commissioner, to lead an independent panel that will examine whether the board, which has been criticized as being too insular, should change its governance structure.

headline: 3 Right-Hand Men Take a Turn at Center Stage
text: WASHINGTON  While he is a relatively new senator, Ted Kaufman, Democrat of Delaware, is deeply familiar with Senate folkways. Don’t talk too much too soon. Show great deference to committee chairmen. And always  always  treat staff members with the utmost respect.

headline: A Tough Dad, a Weak Son, a Dead Mom: The Usual
text: As soon as Ray, a working-class English brute wearing a white mask of skin cream, finishes off the first scene with the zinger “Let the freak show commence,” it’s clear that “Red Sea Fish” doesn’t take place in the dreary British flat onstage so much as in the imagination of the author. Would a thuggish thief say something so flamboyant? And would he use the word “commence”?

headline: Ill Will Grows in a Former Colonial Region
text: DAKAR, Senegal  A waiter, reacting to the mosquitoes plaguing a customer on a recent hot night here, said sharply, “Those aren’t mosquitoes; those are French people!”

headline: After Bankruptcy, G.M. Struggles to Shed a Legendary Bureaucracy
Two German Killers Demanding Anonymity Sue Wikipedia’s Parent
text: Wolfgang Werlé and Manfred Lauber became infamous for killing a German actor in 1990. Now they are suing to force Wikipedia to forget them.

headline: After Dobbs, CNN Makes a Bet on King
text: Replacing an anchor known for his outspoken political beliefs with a traditional Washington reporter, CNN on Thursday said a political news program led by John King would fill Lou Dobbs’s time slot early next year.

headline: Lovers Cross a Bridge, in More Ways Than One
text: “Uncertainty” is a taut, skillful exercise in cinematic clockwork concocted by Scott McGehee and David Siegel, the talented directors of “The Deep End” and “Bee Season.” Written by the two men, with dialogue largely improvised by the actors, the movie splits into parallel stories after an opening scene in which young lovers, Bobby Thompson (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), a Canadian musician, and Kate Montero (Lynn Collins), a Broadway dancer, meet on the Brooklyn Bridge one Fourth of July morning.

headline: Spurs’ Blair Is Lacking in Everything but Success
text: The unlikely phenomenon of DeJuan Blair begins with a checklist of everything that should disqualify him as an effective N.B.A. player.

headline: Hot Warhols Help Sotheby’s Top $134 Million at Auction
text: It was the sale of the season. When a seminal Warhol  one of the artist’s first silk-screen paintings  came on the block at Sotheby’s auction of contemporary art on Wednesday night, the auctioneer, Tobias Meyer, opened bidding at $6 million and was stunned when a bidder instantly doubled it.

headline: Newfangled Bank Capital
text: Contingent capital securities  known as CoCo bonds  have made their debut. The early reviews seem promising.

headline: New Turn in Debate Over Law on Marriage
text: WASHINGTON  The fight over a proposed same-sex marriage law here heated up this week as the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington said that if the law passed, the church would cut its social service programs that help residents with adoption, homelessness and health care.

headline: New York Times News Service to Cut Jobs and Relocate
text: The New York Times News Service will lay off at least 25 editorial employees next year and will move the editing of the service to a Florida newspaper owned by The New York Times Company, the newspaper and the Newspaper Guild said Thursday.

headline: Detective Accused of Providing Tips to Informers Is Acquitted
text: A New York City police detective accused of tipping off confidential informers about aspects of a federal drug investigation was acquitted on Thursday of charges of hindering prosecution and official misconduct.

headline: Motives, Choice and Fort Hood
text: To the Editor:

headline: Judge in Bruno’s Corruption Trial Chastises Him Over a Remark
text: ALBANY  The judge presiding over the corruption trial of Joseph L. Bruno, the former State Senate leader, angrily admonished him on Thursday after Mr. Bruno appeared to challenge one of his rulings at the end of a grueling day in court.

headline: Selling a Household Cleaning Product on Its ... Sex Appeal?
text: IN a new television commercial for Pine-Sol cleaner shot in an over-the-top film noir style, Diane Amos, who has starred in the brand’s ads for 16 years, drives a late-model convertible on the Pacific Coast Highway in California, moonlight dappling the ocean. When she reaches an opulent home, she climbs a stairway, then opens a door to reveal a shirtless, muscular man mopping the floor. Finally Ms. Amos, sprawled on a bed strewn with rose petals and bottles of Pine-Sol as the man mops beside her, purrs the slogan: “That’s the power of Pine-Sol, baby.”

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: 1) President Obama announces a jobs summit meeting.

headline: An Around-the-World Trip to Ask an Age-Old Question
text: Celebrities  Ringo Starr, Hugh Jackman, Bob Geldof and Seal, among others  get pride of place in the credits of “Oh My God?,” Peter Rodger’s picturesque but shallow inquiry into the meaning of God. The film, which Mr. Rodger directed, wrote, produced and photographed on location in nearly two dozen countries, is the documentary equivalent of a spiritually angled coffee-table book of world travels.

headline: For Comcast’s Chief, Content Led the Way
text: At a dinner 12 years ago in Redmond, Wash., Brian L. Roberts challenged the richest man in the world to invest in his business  cable TV.

headline: CNN Cuts Back on a Web Video Project
text: CNN laid off its four Web anchors on Thursday and said it had stopped producing continuous live video for CNN.com, curtailing one of the Internet’s biggest news experiments.

headline: Radical Lawyer’s Appeal (and Rebuttal)
text: For William Kunstler, the wild-haired, radical civil rights lawyer with the raspy voice who became a left-wing political star in the late 1960s, Michelangelo’s statue of David symbolized how he saw himself. A photograph of the statue that morphs into a drawing of David twirling his slingshot is a recurrent image in the crisply made, largely admiring documentary “William Kunstler: Disturbing the Universe.” To him, it embodied the moment everyone faces at some time or other when one has to stand up to injustice or keep silent.

headline: U.S. Identifies 111,000 Immigrants With Criminal Records
text: Federal authorities have identified more than 111,000 immigrants with criminal records being held in local jails, during the first year of a program that seeks to deport immigrants who have committed serious crimes.

headline: Despite Sales Slip, Nintendo Predicts Strong Season
text: Although October sales of Nintendo’s Wii console dropped 36 percent compared with the same period last year, company executives expect robust sales in the holiday season.

headline: Free to Lose
text: Consider, for a moment, a tale of two countries. Both have suffered a severe recession and lost jobs as a result  but not on the same scale. In Country A, employment has fallen more than 5 percent, and the unemployment rate has more than doubled. In Country B, employment has fallen only half a percent, and unemployment is only slightly higher than it was before the crisis.

headline: A New Cholesterol Study Puts Focus on Merck Drugs
text: Some of Wall Street’s leading drug industry analysts are scheduled to fly to Orlando, Fla., on Sunday afternoon. A junket to SeaWorld it is not.

headline: Meet John Thune
text: Some days the Republican Party seems to be going crazy. Its public image is often shaped by people who appear to have gone into government because they saw it as a steppingstone to talk radio.

headline: Rock Boys’ Adventure, With BBC as the Enemy
text: Boys will be boys and often at top volume in “Pirate Radio,” Richard Curtis’s fanciful fiction about rebel broadcasters who, in the mid-1960s, blasted British airwaves and eardrums with the Stones, the Kinks and the Who, among other youth-quaking greats of the era. Stuffed with playful character actors and carpeted with wall-to-wall tunes, the film makes for easy viewing and easier listening, even if Mr. Curtis, who wrote and directed, has nothing really to say about these rebels for whom rock ’n’ roll was both life’s rhyme and its reason.

headline: Zimbabwe: Lawyers Seek New Judge in Terrorism Trial of Opposition Leader
text: Lawyers for Roy Bennett, a leader in the opposition Movement for Democratic Change who faces terrorism charges, asked the trial judge, Chinembiri Bhunu, to recuse himself on the grounds that comments he made in a related 2006 case showed bias. In that case, against the man who is now the state’s key witness, and who says he was tortured to implicate Mr. Bennett, the judge denied bail and said there was “overwhelming evidence” against the man, who was later acquitted by a different judge. Judge Bhunu will rule on Monday.

headline: Pfizer to Leave City That Won Land-Use Case
text: From the edge of the Thames River in New London, Conn., Michael Cristofaro surveyed the empty acres where his parents’ neighborhood had stood, before it became the crux of an epic battle over eminent domain.

headline: A Murder Raises Hard Questions in Kentucky
text: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Steve Nunn was something of a golden child in Kentucky politics. The son of a former governor, he was a successful and well-liked politician who served in the State Legislature for 15 years.

headline: Georgia Tech’s Bedford Makes Time for Spread Option and D’Alembert’s Paradox
text: ATLANTA  It would be an easy ruse. Sean Bedford would belly up to a bar to watch a football game and wait for that inevitable moment when the fan on the next stool, a beer in one hand and a chicken wing in the other, sneered at the unfortunate offensive lineman who moved before the snap and drew a penalty flag.

headline: Drama of High School, Starring Eros and Anxiety
text: “Dare,” written by David Brind, directed by Adam Salky and based on their short film of the same title, stakes out familiar territory and, true to its name, strikes out in some risky new directions. This high school semi-romance, which blends comic and tearful moods, is at once more provocative and more contemplative than most of its big-screen counterparts. On television and in young-adult novels, candor  or prurience  about teenage behavior is the norm, but Hollywood movies tend to keep one foot firmly planted in a more innocent world.

headline: Wilpon Firm Challenges Finding by Trustee in Madoff Case
text: Lawyers for Sterling Equities, the investment firm controlled by Fred Wilpon, the principal owner of the Mets, said it lost money as a result of the Ponzi scheme orchestrated by Bernard L. Madoff, according to a filing Thursday in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.

headline: Man Jailed for ’91 Murder Is Cleared by Judge
text: A Manhattan judge ruled on Thursday that a man who had spent 18 years in prison for murder was innocent of the crime, sending a cathartic jolt through a courtroom packed with his friends and family members.

headline: Pretty Village, Gloomy Boy
text: “I wasn’t born here. I only live here. And I’m sure as hell not going to die here,” declares James Powers (Donal Gallery), the hormonally supercharged 16-year-old narrator of “Turning Green.”

headline: Scarred, Fort Hood Survivors Move On
text: KILLEEN, Tex.  It seemed unlikely that Christopher Royal was going to be delivering the sermon Sunday at Shiloh Baptist Church in the tiny town of Eclectic, Ala., as scheduled. Mr. Royal, a chief warrant officer in the Army, had been shot three times in the back during the rampage at Fort Hood.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Getting Into the Zone at Cornell
text: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team. As he did last season, Jon will be blogging for The Quad throughout this season.

headline: For Emily Hughes, an Opportunity to Impress at Skate America
text: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  When Emily Hughes received the news that she would be replacing the injured Sasha Cohen at this week’s Skate America, she could not help screaming into the phone.

headline: ‘Mad Men,’ Maddening Times
text: “Has Congress become like an episode of ‘Mad Men’?” California Congresswoman Linda Sanchez asked this week, after the House of Representatives approved a version of health care reform that contained what some pro-choice advocates are calling the toughest restrictions on women’s access to abortion since the Roe v. Wade decision.

headline: Eating by the Numbers
text: BURIED in the nearly 2,000 pages of the health reform bill passed by the House on Saturday is a provision requiring chain restaurants to post calorie counts on their menus. Given the worsening problem of obesity in the United States, and the superiority of disease prevention over treatment, calorie posting seems like a great idea. However, research by us and others suggests that it is unlikely to have much, if any, impact on eating or obesity.

headline: Information Highway: Camel Speed but Exotic Links
text: “You are about to make an unusual journey,” a wall label proclaims at the beginning of an exhibition that opens on Saturday at the American Museum of Natural History. Normally that promise would provide reason enough to be wary. But this is something different.

headline: Struggling With the Rent and Deferring a Dream
text: More than anything, Atavia Wilson wants to be Anthony Bourdain, the roving celebrity chef.

headline: The Knicks’ Struggles Leave Walsh Mystified
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Donnie Walsh observes Knicks practices with a watchful eye from a chair so close to the sideline he can whisper in his players’ ears.

headline: Pregame Tidbits: Slovakia vs. U.S.
text: One of the best things about an obsession with international soccer is the window it opens to the world. After all, how many Americans even knew where Slovakia was located before the announcement of the friendly match against the United States, which will be played in Bratislava on Saturday (10 a.m., Eastern, live on Fox Soccer Channel)?

headline: Where Credit Isn’t Due
text: SENATOR CHRISTOPHER DODD of Connecticut is trying to help consumers. Unfortunately, his plan is likely to backfire.

headline: Reid Mulls Medicare Tax Increase for High Earners
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, is considering a proposal to increase the Medicare payroll tax on high-income workers to help offset the costs of providing health insurance to millions of Americans, Senate aides said Thursday.

headline: Afghan Enclave Seen as Model for Development
text: JURM, Afghanistan  Small grants given directly to villagers have brought about modest but important changes in this corner of Afghanistan, offering a model in a country where official corruption and a Taliban insurgency have frustrated many large-scale development efforts.

headline: Love, Sex, Whatever
text: To judge by the swelling bosoms spilling out of the frame, the lingerie bill for “Women in Trouble” must have been estimable. An ensemble piece that never coheres despite a clutch of appealing actresses  notably Carla Gugino and Emmanuelle Chriqui  this movie was written and directed by Sebastian Gutierrez, whose screenplay credits include “The Big Bounce” (the remake), “Gothika” and “Snakes on a Plane.” It’s a discouraging list, true, but Ms. Gugino, an interesting actress who has yet to find a big-screen career worthy of her, seemed reason alone to take the chance. (And Robyn Hitchcock did the score.)

headline: Critique of a Critic
text: Fans of the writer and musician Robert Palmer, who was chief pop-music critic of The New York Times from 1981 to 1988, should not come to the documentary “The Hand of Fatima” expecting a comprehensive look at his life, his writing or his role in American music. The film’s director, Augusta Palmer, is Robert Palmer’s daughter, and she has a different  though perfectly understandable  agenda.

headline: How People Learned About Cholesterol
text: Although it is hard to imagine now, most people, doctors included, did not use to bother to have their cholesterol level checked or to take measures to lower it if it was high.

headline: Business Boosterism
text: Mary Mazzio’s “Ten9Eight: Shoot for the Moon,” a tirelessly inspirational documentary about teenagers competing in a nationwide business contest, is playing in seven cities in the theaters of one of its corporate sponsors, AMC Entertainment. (The screenings are tied to Global Entrepreneurship Week, which begins on Monday.) It’s the type of film you might expect to see at a fund-raising dinner or a convention banquet, not in a commercial theater. That said, it’s a very well-made piece of boosterism.

headline: Medicines to Deter Some Cancers Are Not Taken
text: Many Americans do not think twice about taking medicines to prevent heart disease and stroke. But cancer is different. Much of what Americans do in the name of warding off cancer has not been shown to matter, and some things are actually harmful. Yet the few medicines proved to deter cancer are widely ignored.

headline: A Possible Glimpse of Ebersol’s Future
text: Dick Ebersol has thrived under General Electric for 20 years as the head of NBC Sports. He has spent billions of G.E.’s dollars on the rights to show eight Olympic Games, from Atlanta to London.

headline: The U.S. Treasury Is on Their Backs
text: Why, oh why, oh why, oh —Why did I ever leave 59 Across?Why did I wander to find what lies yonderWhen life was so cozy at home?— Betty Comden and Adolph Green

headline: Spitzer Talks About, Well, Ethics
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer was invited to speak at Harvard University on Thursday about what first made him famous: policing Wall Street. Mention of the prostitution scandal that made Mr. Spitzer infamous, however, preceded  and followed  his address, which was arranged by a university ethics center.

headline: Councils in Jurm Valley Make Improvements
text: Recent successes in development projects in Jurm, Afghanistan, have raised hopes that it could be a model in a country where corruption and insurgency have impeded progress.

headline: Breaking Down Economic Breakdown
text: Why Philippe Diaz has titled his new documentary “The End of Poverty?” is unclear, because this guilt trip/history lesson is really about the beginning of poverty: how the economic and social systems evolved that have kept parts of the world wealthy and large swaths of it poor. The film spends so much time detailing its thesis that the roots of modern poverty are 500 years deep  going back to the explorers and conquistadors who first supplanted indigenous economic systems with Western ideas of property ownership  that it only briefly mentions what might be done about the problem. And then it cops out by not dealing with the many practical barriers to that solution.

headline: Brahms Alone, and With Schoenberg’s Big Tweak
text: Just 22 hours after the last notes were sounded in Carnegie Hall’s adventurous festival of Chinese music, Carnegie returned to its bread-and-butter business of presenting international orchestras in mostly standard repertory. But for listeners who found that prospect less exciting than further explorations of new music and exotica might have been, the hall offered a reminder of how thrilling its version of business as usual could be.

headline: U.S. Moves to Seize Properties Tied to Iran
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan began legal action on Thursday to seize properties in Queens and across the country where several mosques are located in a broad move against a nonprofit organization that was accused of illegally providing money and other services to Iran.

headline: A Condemned Princess, Freed With Global Voices
text: Handel, an artist with a strong claim to being the greatest showman of the 18th century, was under the gun when he created “Ariodante” for the first production mounted by his Italian opera company at its new home, Covent Garden, in 1735. Faced with a waning English taste for Italian opera and challenged by a new rival company that had lured away his stars, Handel hired a fresh ensemble of international singers, some of them remarkably young. (One tenor was just 17.)

headline: Bottomless Songbook With New Orleans Twist
text: Ten years ago, when the singer and producer Steve Tyrell released “A New Standard,” a modestly successful collection of pop chestnuts sung in a growly New Orleans style, who knew that it would be a cultural bellwether?

headline: Intel’s $1.25 Billion Settlement
text: Intel’s antitrust and patent settlement with Advanced Micro Devices is good news for A.M.D., which now finds itself $1.25 billion richer, but it is less clear what it does for the general public. Intel has been accused of stifling competition and driving up prices through a wide array of anticompetitive practices, which may or may not continue now that Intel has agreed to write a large check. Government agencies that have sued Intel or are considering it should not back away.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: David Lloyd, 75, Dies; Wrote ‘Chuckles’ Episode
text: David Lloyd, who wrote scores of scripts for some of the most popular television sitcoms of the 1970s, ’80s and ’90s  including the memorable Chuckles the Clown episode of “The Mary Tyler Moore Show,” which was revered by comedy connoisseurs for wringing belly laughs from a funeral  died Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 75.

headline: C.I.A. Didn’t Violate Rights, Court Says
text: The Central Intelligence Agency did not violate the free speech rights of a former operative, Valerie Wilson, when it prohibited publication of details of her work before 2002 for the agency, a federal appeals court ruled. Ms. Wilson, left, whose classified status was exposed by Bush administration officials, redacted portions of her 2007 book, “Fair Game: My Life as a Spy, My Betrayal by the White House” because of the ban, but argued that the information was already in the public domain and publication should have been permitted. The opinion from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, stated that “When Ms. Wilson elected to serve with the C.I.A., she accepted a life-long restriction on her ability to disclose classified and classifiable information.” Others may have disclosed it, and “may well have warranted investigation” for their disclosures, but “these circumstances do not absolve Ms. Wilson of her own secrecy obligations.” David B. Smallman, a lawyer for Ms. Wilson and her publisher, Simon & Schuster, said that an appeal was under consideration.

headline: Halladay a Test for New Blue Jays General Manager
text: CHICAGO  The first time Alex Anthopoulos called a baseball general manager was nine years ago. When Jim Beattie, then the general manager of the Montreal Expos, answered the phone, Anthopoulos, just 23, panicked and hung up as if he were a kid making a crank call.

headline: NASA Hopes Rover Will Rove Again
text: After six months of pondering their predicament, NASA engineers said that they would begin trying to drive the Mars rover Spirit out of a sand trap where it became stuck last spring. They acknowledged, however, that the odds were not good. “This could end up where Spirit remains,” said Doug McCuistion, director of the Mars Exploration Program at the headquarters for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Spirit and its twin, Opportunity, have been roving the surface of Mars since landing in 2004. Opportunity is still going strong, NASA says, but as Spirit was backing over some rocks in April near a feature known as Home Plate, a wheel broke through a crust on the planet’s surface and started spinning in the soft powder below. Fearful that the rocks could be a hazard to the undercarriage of the rover, the engineers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory stopped trying to extricate it while they studied the situation with a model in a sandbox. The strategy on Monday will be to try to drive Spirit out of the pit the way it came in, said Ashley Stroupe, a robotics engineer and rover driver.

headline: Impresario of and for the People
text: One of the best lines in “Free for All,” the big, bouncy new oral history of Joseph Papp and the Public Theater, isn’t about Papp at all. It’s about the mesmerizing effect the director Mike Nichols had  and still has  on playwrights. “I think if an Eskimo wrote a play,” the playwright James Kirkwood says, “he’d put it on an ice floe and push it toward Mike Nichols.”

headline: Arizona: Desalting Plant Is Approved
text: A 17-year-old desalting plant, largely mothballed since it was built and to many a symbol of government waste, is expected to spring to life in May to finally help provide water for Western states. The federal government has approved a proposal by three water agencies, including those serving the Los Angeles, Las Vegas, Phoenix and Tucson areas, to operate the plant, in Yuma, for a one-year trial. The agencies will pay $14 million of the $23 million cost for the test-run of the plant. The test will help determine if full-scale operation is viable and cost-efficient. The plant will use drainage water that normally feeds a wetland in Mexico. The government has averted court fights by agreeing to replenish the water for the wetland. The only hurdle left is a permit from the State of Arizona.

headline: Ed Hardy’s Tattoo Art Is Booty for Digital Pirates
text: Don Ed Hardy, the famed tattoo artist, must smell good. Make that really good. Ed Hardy-themed perfumes have become some of the most popular fragrances in the world with retailers buying $85 million worth of them so far this year.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a report on the adversities facing Iraqis who return home after having fled sectarian violence referred incorrectly to the International Organization of Migration, the group that compiled the report. It is an intergovernmental group, not a nongovernmental organization.

headline: ‘Tony N’ Tina’ in Union Talks
text: The musicians’ union and the producers of the New York show “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding” have made a preliminary move toward resolving a labor dispute, though the producers challenged the union’s account that its members were locked out of the show. Performers with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians have not played in the show since Oct. 10 after a disagreement with the show’s producers, Kim and Sonny Ricciardi of Broadway Entertainment, over a contract, which the union says is valid through May 2011. In an e-mail message, the Ricciardis said they have no “contract or tie to Local 802” under the show’s current terms. The Ricciardis also said the musicians were informed they could not play at the show until the dispute was settled, and allowed them to pick up their belongings from the Edison Hotel, where the show is performed. On Thursday, a union representative and the producers said there had been contact between each groups’ lawyers, which the union said “we interpret as a very positive first step.”

headline: An Unfortunate Event for Harpercollins
text: Lemony Snicket, the pseudonym of Daniel Handler, right, and the author of the bestselling “Series of Unfortunate Events” books, has agreed to sell the North American rights to publish a new four-part series to Little, Brown & Company, moving from HarperCollins. The first volume in the new series is scheduled to be published by Little, Brown Books for Young Readers in 2012. Mr. Handler has also signed a deal with Little, Brown Books for Young Readers to publish his first young adult novel. The book, as yet untitled, will be illustrated by Maira Kalman, who composes an occasional visual blog for the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, and will be published in 2011. As part of the deal, Mr. Handler’s longtime editor, Susan Rich, will join Little, Brown as an editor-at-large in the young readers’ group. The “Series of Unfortunate Events” books, which have sold 60 million copies worldwide, were published in North America by HarperCollins Children’s Books.

headline: School Can Perform ‘Rent’ and ‘Laramie’
text: A ruling by a Nevada district court judge will allow students at a Las Vegas area high school to perform “Rent” and “The Laramie Project” despite the objections of parents who were seeking an injunction to prevent them, The Las Vegas Review-Journal reported. Students at Green Valley High School in Henderson will be allowed to perform both shows after Judge David Wall ruled against parents who objected to the productions’ content. Lawyers for the Clark County School District who represented the students said in arguments that the parents could not prove that performing the shows would cause “irreparable harm.” Lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union of Nevada filed a brief that supported the students as well. Amanda Smith, a 16-year-old student who has a lead role in the “Rent” production planned for next year, told The Review-Journal, “I’m ecstatic.”

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a Bloomberg News article on Tuesday about Joshua Gotbaum, President Obama’s choice for director of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, misidentified Mr. Gotbaum’s mother. He is the son of Sarah C. Gotbaum, a retired sociologist and the first wife of Joshua’s father, Victor Gotbaum, a former municipal labor leader; he is not the son of Betsy Gotbaum, the New York City public advocate and Victor Gotbaum’s current wife.

headline: ‘Waterfalls’ Artist to Create a Bridge
text: Olafur Eliasson, below, the Danish-Icelandic artist who created the temporary waterfalls in New York’s East River last year, is at work on a project that will give the residents of another city a different way of looking at a nearby body of water. On Wednesday, the city of Copenhagen said that Mr. Eliasson would create a bridge there, called Cirkelbroen (“circle bridge”), which would provide a winding path across the city’s Christianshavns Kanal. In a news release, Mr. Eliasson said the bridge, whose design was inspired by the sailing ships that pass through the canal, would consist of five circular platforms with their own “masts.” In a statement Mr. Eliasson said that “Rather than offering the fastest possible passage across the canal, the bridge will create small variations in the way we see the city and open for a renegotiation of public space.” It is expected to be completed in 2012.

headline: It’s ‘All About’ Them
text: In recent days, Dame Edna Everage, below at top, and Michael Feinstein, bottom, have been sniping back and forth about their similarly titled Broadway shows, “All About Me” (his) and “It’s All About Me” (hers). (He: “Titles are not copyrightable. I wish Ms. Edna well. I’ve heard of her.”) (She: “I’m sure Mrs. Feinstein is very proud of her son.”) Turns out the two performers will be working together  and, one assumes, were in cahoots all along. On Thursday, publicists said the two would appear in tandem in a show called “All About Me,” to be directed by Jerry Zaks and written by Christopher Durang. In a statement, Mr. Feinstein said, “I have always been a huge fan of the Dame, and despite our previous friction, now that my mother has forgiven her, I couldn’t be more excited to be joining her on Broadway.” Dame Edna added, “Michael Feinstein is a performer of the highest caliber, I believe, and I couldn’t be more than excited to be sharing a Broadway stage with him, in moderation.” The show is to begin previews at a Shubert theater on March 6 and open on March 23.

headline: The Calipari Express, Baggage Included
text: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Coach John Calipari has held one of college basketball’s highest-profile jobs for only a few months, and he has yet to coach the first regular-season game. But he has attracted nearly a million followers on Twitter, more than 64,000 friends on Facebook, and legions more who expect Kentucky to win its eighth national championship  as early as this season.

headline: Dick Katz, 85, Jazzman of Many Gifts Over 6 Decades, Is Dead
text: Dick Katz, a pianist, record producer, educator and writer whose knowledge of jazz from the stride-piano era to 1960s modernism made him a valuable presence on New York’s jazz scene for six decades, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the departure of the editor of Caijing, a top Chinese business magazine, misstated part of the name of its parent company. It is the Stock Exchange Executive Council, not the State Exchange Executive Council.

headline: Residents Feel Victimized by Dealers, and by Housing Agency
text: 363 Noe Street was a haven for some of San Francisco’s most vulnerable residents, a small housing project reserved for the elderly and the disabled. Its design may be spartan, but for 22 residents  many of them proverbial little old ladies  it was a safe home.

headline: Small Signs of Optimism
text: If you live in the Bay Area, you hardly need reminding that you pay more for your home than most people. The region has the dubious honor of ranking No. 1 nationally in median home value, median monthly mortgage costs and median gross rent.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about efforts to make fund-raising galas less opulent misidentified the organization that held a spring ball at the Plaza Hotel in May. It was the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, not the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about increasing attention being paid by charities to individual donors misspelled the surname of the executive director of the Robin Hood Foundation. He is David Saltzman, not Salzman.

headline: The ‘Highly Qualified Teacher’ Dodge
text: Education Secretary Arne Duncan has been widely held in high regard since he was appointed in January, but no honeymoon lasts forever. Mr. Duncan’s came to an abrupt end earlier this week when he issued long-awaited rules that the states must follow to apply for his $4.3 billion discretionary fund, known as the Race to the Top Fund, and the second round of federal financing under the $49 billion federal stimulus package known as the state fiscal stabilization fund.

headline: A Farewell to Lou
text: Lou Dobbs has left CNN, or maybe the other way around. Whichever it is, an old, odd, infuriating-to-many mismatch of sober network and strident host is over. CNN, for now anyway, changes back to something closer to the nonpartisan, straight-up news network it wants you to think of it as, different from its ideologically branded rivals Fox News and MSNBC. The real question is the effect the change will have on Mr. Dobbs.

headline: Ethics Watchdogs Snarl at the Messenger
text: The House ethics committee is openly  and foolishly  sniping at its newly appointed ally in the difficult task of policing members’ behavior. A recent ethics committee report exonerated an accused congressman but blistered the new semiautonomous Office of Congressional Ethics, or O.C.E., for “fundamentally flawed” procedures in vetting the complaint for the committee.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Monday about the corporate raider Samuel Heyman included several errors. Mr. Heyman took over his father’s real estate development business when his father died, not because his father needed him to take it over. The Partnership for Public Service, which Mr. Heyman founded, works to encourage young people to pursue careers in public service, but it does not provide fellowships. Mr. Heyman died on Saturday, not Sunday, and he graduated from Harvard Law School in 1963, not 1964.

text: To the Editor:

text: The evening sale of contemporary art at Phillips de Pury brought a vibrant week of auctions to an anemic close on Thursday night.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Thursday about John J. O’Connor III, the husband of the retired Supreme Court justice Sandra Day O’Connor, misstated the title that William H. Rehnquist held on the court. He was chief justice of the United States, not chief justice of the Supreme Court. The obituary also misidentified the publication that was the source of a story about the O’Connors’ early days in Washington. It is The National Law Journal, not The National Law Review.

headline: Toronto’s New G.M. Hits the Ground Running
text: Alex Anthopoulos just concluded his first general managers’ meetings as Toronto’s new man in charge, and he left an impression on more than a few people that he is a capable and intelligent young executive.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Thursday with an obituary about Gene D. Cohen, a pioneer in the field of geriatric psychiatry, gave the incorrect year in some editions that Dr. Cohen was shown with a patient. It was 1990, not 1960.

headline: Short-Handed Rangers Can’t Answer Kovalchuk
text: Normally an early-season visit from the Atlanta Thrashers is not a special occasion, but Thursday at Madison Square Garden was different. The Thrashers welcomed back Ilya Kovalchuk, their captain and talisman  and a pending free agent  who had missed the previous six games with a broken bone in his right foot.

headline: Militants Hit Pakistan Spy Agency in New Escalation
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Militants stepped up their fight against the Pakistani government on Friday, striking a building belonging to the country’s main intelligence agency in the northwestern city of Peshawar, Pakistani television reported.

text: The two Jain shows currently in New York give an in-depth view of a great art tradition and a complex faith.

headline: Craig Steps Down as White House Lawyer
text: WASHINGTON  The White House counsel, Gregory B. Craig, has told associates that he intends to step down from his post on Friday, putting to rest long-running speculation about whether he would remain as President Obama’s top lawyer.

headline: A Threatened Fruit, Preserved in Amber
text: Driving back to San Francisco through Sonoma the other day, it was clear that apple season was in full swing. Every few miles along the aptly named Gravenstein Highway (State Route 116) was a different roadside stand touting apples and every apple product imaginable. To my wife’s dismay, I drove past them all.

headline: Highlights From Friday’s Bay Area Report
text: Art Theft | Thirty-five years after Don Ed Hardy opened his first San Francisco tattoo studio, his North Beach shop Tattoo City is known the world over as the place to go for vivid murals on flesh. The Ed Hardy moniker expect to move more than $700 million in merchandise this year. But now, writes Ashlee Vance, a business that was inspired by San Francisco’s nautical past is being hijacked by its digital present.

headline: Explosion Hits U.S. Base in Afghan Capital
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber struck Friday at a United States military convoy as it passed near a large American installation on the outskirts of Kabul.

headline: World Cup Playoff: France-Ireland Preview
text: France vs. Republic of IrelandGame 1: Saturday, Nov. 14 in DublinGame 2: Wednesday, Nov. 18 in Paris

headline: More Than Meets the Eye
text: Catch two movies this weekend that are more than what they seem. Though it’s beyond cute, Wes Anderson’s  “Fantastic Mr. Fox”  is not just a kid flick; it “is in some ways his most fully realized and satisfying film,” A.O. Scott writes. “Once you adjust to its stop-and-start rhythms and its scruffy looks, you can appreciate its wit, its beauty and the sly gravity of its emotional undercurrents.” And “The Messenger” is more than just an Iraq War movie; it is “remarkably textured, with room for humor as well as anguish,” Mr. Scott writes.

headline: Retro Returns
text: The Numero Group is a Chicago-based label that reissues obscure, unusual recordings, scoured from thrift stores and garage sales. Tonight at the Music Hall of Williamsburg they present their debut tour, the Eccentric Soul Revue, with artists including 1970s Midwestern R&B crooners and an early-period, female hip-hop M.C. from Harlem. For more retro sounds, hit the 35th anniversary party for Afrika Bambaataa on Sunday at SOB’s, with performances by Naughty by Nature and Grand Master Melle Mel.

headline: Slide Shows
text: Part D.I.Y. and part pro, the  Slideluck Potshow offers photographers  many of them highly paid professionals  a chance to show the stuff they love in another context: at a  potluck party. Bring a dish, grab a drink and watch the images float by tonight.

headline: Helping People By Helping Pets
text: WHO have had to surrender their pets to shelters this year and WHO are stepping in to help?

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Devils Win Again and Go Atop East
text: How about those New Jersey Devils? After beating the slumping Penguins at the Igloo, they have won all nine of their away games this season. The 2006-7 Sabres grabbed 2 points in each of their first 10 games via regulation, overtime or shootout wins, and that’s officially the N.H.L. record — although a more stringent standard might be the ’51-52 Red Wings, who went unbeaten in their first 15 games as visitors.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: On Thursday, a news article in The Times reported on the ties between Peter W. Galbraith, a former United States ambassador, and a Norwegian oil company that operates in the Kurdistan region of Iraq. According to the article, Mr. Galbraith “received rights to an enormous stake in at least one of Kurdistan’s oil fields in the spring of 2004.”

headline: Militants Hit Pakistan Spy Agency
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Militants stepped up their fight against the Pakistani government in western Pakistan on Friday, the same day the American national security adviser, Gen. James L. Jones, met with top Pakistani officials here in the capital.

headline: International Speedway to Sell Staten Island Land
text: International Speedway Corporation said Thursday it has agreed to sell its 676-acre parcel of property on Staten Island, N.Y., where it had once planned to build a racetrack, to KB Marine Holdings for $80 million.

headline: What Do You Think About ‘Octomom’?
text: Has the story of Nadya Suleman — widely known as “Octomom” after giving birth to eight children — interested you? Why do you think so many have been riveted by it? What do you think about family-oriented TV reality shows like hers — do they exploit the children, provide useful “cathartic” entertainment, or both?

headline: Obama Says U.S. Seeks to Build Stronger Ties to China
text: TOKYO  The United States is not threatened by a rising China, President Obama said Saturday, but will seek to strengthen its ties with Beijing even as it maintains close ties with traditional allies like Japan.

headline: Redfin, an Online Real Estate Brokerage, Raises $10 Million

text: At a dinner 12 years ago in Redmond, Wash., Brian L. Roberts challenged the richest man in the world to invest in his business — cable TV.

headline: Ex-Bankers Said to Mull Bidding for Failing Banks
text: Some former bankers are planning to bid for failing banks in the Federal Insurance Deposit Corporation auction process, with financial backing from Wall Street firms like Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing sources.

headline: TARP Likely to Be a Loss for U.S., Barofsky Says
text: Neil Barofsky, the special inspector general for the $700 billion U.S. financial-industry bailout, said the program will “almost certainly” result in a loss to taxpayers.

headline: Oil Slides, and Wall Street Pulls Back
text: Wall Street stocks fell on Thursday as investors reacted with caution to a drop in the price of oil. An announcement by President Obama of a job creation initiative failed to motivate investors, The New York Times’s Javier C. Hernandez reported.

text: The China Investment Corporation has hired a former manager at Tudor Investment to oversee its hedge fund portfolio, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: Ed Hardy’s Tattoo Art Is Booty for Digital Pirates

headline: North Korea Issues New Threat After Naval Clash
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea threatened Friday to take “merciless military measures” along a disputed maritime border with South Korea, escalating tensions as President Obama began a weeklong visit to Asia.

headline: Khan Tells Judge She Provided Insider Information

headline: Global Financial Panic Is Over, Buffett Says

headline: Big Japanese Banks Show Signs of Recovery
text: Corrected | Nov. 16, 2009, 9:25 a.m. Mizuho Financial‘s first profit in five quarters and the doubling of profit by its rival, Sumitomo Mitsui, signal that major Japanese banks are recovering from the economic crisis, albeit slowly, Reuters reported.

headline: Gift Guide | Flying American

Made in the U.S.A. isn’t just a political statement, it’s a fashion one, too.

headline: Getting the Most Out of the London Pass
text: LONDON | If you are the type of traveler who really likes to see the sights, the London Pass may be for you. Loads of special offers are at hand for reduced prices on theater tickets, accommodations, restaurants and attractions. You just have to know how to use it effectively.

headline: Liberty Global to Buy Unitymedia For $5.2 Billion

headline: The Most Important Films of the Decade
text: The first review A.O. Scott wrote as a film critic for The New York Times was in January 2000. The movie was “My Dog Skip,” which featured a Jack Russell terrier with a taste for bologna, Kevin Bacon, Luke Wilson and Frankie Muniz. Since then, he notes, more than 5,000 movies have come and gone and been reviewed in The Times. In The Magazine this week, Mr. Scott takes stock of the past decade in film and asks: “Which movies are sure to be remembered? Which movies deserve to be? Are these really two different questions?”

headline: Europe’s Environment Chief Still Hopeful for Global Climate Cooperation
text: The European Union environment commissioner, Stavros Dimas, on Thursday named and shamed countries, including Austria, Canada and Australia, for emitting excessive greenhouse gases and failing to meet their goals under the Kyoto climate treaty.

headline: For Forbes, Wall Street’s Most Powerful Player Is …
text: Update | 12:38 p.m. In Forbes’s latest list of the world’s most powerful people, some choices come as little surprise. President Obama, Hu Jintao of China and Vladimir Putin of Russia come out on top, and at No. 4 Ben S. Bernanke is confirmed as the world’s most influential central banker.
