headline: ‘FlashForward’ Watch: Tattoos and Lingerie
text: So now we’re working on the assumption that the future — or at least the glimpse of it that everyone received in their flashforwards — can be changed, even negated. That’s the lesson people are taking from Agent Gough’s swan dive off a building at the end of last week’s episode of “FlashForward.” If it’s true, does this new wrinkle make the show better — more complex and open-ended? Or does it drain the show of much of its dramatic tension and make the detective work, which has been more interesting than any of the relationships, seem irrelevant? Just asking.

headline: Path to Alternative Therapies Is Littered With Obstacles
text: WHEN Diane Klenke was told five years ago that she had pancreatic cancer, she was given three months to live. “The doctor told me to go home and put my affairs in order and that was it,” Ms. Klenke, now 52, remembered.

headline: The ‘Chuckles’ Writer: ‘A Little Seltzer Down Your Pants’
text: In Friday’s New York Times, Bruce Weber writes an obituary of David Lloyd, an incredibly prolific television comedy writer who contributed to programs like “The Bob Newhart Show,” “Lou Grant,” “Rhoda,” “Phyllis,” “The Tony Randall Show,” “The Associates,” “Taxi,” “Dear John,” “Amen,” “Wings,” “Cheers” and “Frasier.” Mr. Lloyd, 75, died of prostate cancer on Tuesday.

headline: President’s Top Lawyer Is Leaving White House
text: WASHINGTON  Gregory B. Craig, the White House counsel, said Friday that he would resign at the beginning of next year, ending a sometimes tumultuous tenure as President Obama’s top lawyer after 10 months at the center of some of the toughest issues and stormiest internal debates that have confronted the administration.

headline: S.F. Sanctuary Policy: Feds Not Going to Look the Other Way
text: San Francisco city employees may soon need a sanctuary policy of their own.

headline: Two Are Charged With Helping Madoff Falsify Records
text: Two computer programmers who worked for Bernard L. Madoff’s brokerage firm were arrested on Friday and accused of helping him sustain his long-running Ponzi scheme.

headline: Quashing Credit Card Reform for Small Businesses
text: Last week, small-business advocates once more tried, and failed, to get new consumer protections for credit cards extended to small-business cardholders. They were defeated, according to aides on Capitol Hill and others observing the process, by a surprising foe: Representative Nydia Velázquez, the New York Democrat who is chairwoman of the House Small Business Committee — though her own aide insists the other aides are wrong.

headline: Report on Yale Murder Outlines Suspicions
text: Raymond Clark III walked into Room G-13 in the basement of a Yale research center in New Haven and saw it sitting on a metal cart: a box of disposable wipes, splattered with blood.

headline: Craig Resigns as White House Counsel
text: The White House said on Friday that President Obama’s top lawyer, Gregory B. Craig, was stepping down from his post as the White House counsel, a departure that was timed to coordinate with a Justice Department announcement that five terrorism suspects held in Guantánamo Bay would face trial in New York.

headline: 2 Programmers Are Charged With Aiding Madoff
text: Update | 1:51 p.m. The New York Times’s Diana B. Henriques has more details here.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Seller List
text: “The merc with the mouth,” as Deadpool, the wisecracking mutant mercenary, is billed, hits No. 7 on our hardcover list with the collected edition “Deadpool: Suicide Kings.” When Deadpool is accused of a crime that — for once — he didn’t commit, he must avoid Daredevil, the Punisher and Spider-Man to prove his innocence.

headline: Best Move for Byron Scott Might Be Los Angeles
text: After a lackluster 3-6 start the New Orleans Hornets decided a coaching change was in order, and fired Byron Scott on Thursday.

headline: Two Debuts, Overdue and Overwhelming
text: After the Metropolitan Opera opened its season in September with Luc Bondy’s convoluted new production of Puccini’s “Tosca,” widely deemed a dismal failure, Peter Gelb, the company’s general manager, needed a comeback success.

headline: Paying for Alternative Treatments
text: The debate about alternative therapies rightly focuses on whether a particular herb or remedy actually works. But in today’s Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad explores a much-neglected aspect of alternative care: how do you pay for it? She writes:

headline: Friday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Filmmakers’ Controversy: Their Dad
text: At the charmingly retro Waverly Restaurant on the Avenue of the Americas in Greenwich Village, not to be confused with the stridently exclusive Waverly Inn nearby, a color headshot of one of the best-known legal figures of the 20th century hangs on the wall. His name was William M. Kunstler, and this celebrated civil rights lawyer, who for nearly two decades lived around the corner, ate lunch here nearly every day.

headline: Record Sales for Modern Warfare 2, but Gaming Business Declines
text: Like the start of a classic gaming cheat code, it was an up-and-down week of news for the video gaming business. On the upside, the debut of the highly anticipated shooting game Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 set a sales record for the industry, Variety reported: the game sold 4.7 million units in its first day of sale in the United States and Britain, taking in $310 million for the game publisher Activision Blizzard. (By comparison, the year’s highest grossing movie, “Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen,” earned $220 million in its first weekend.)

headline: Death’s Hit Man
text: “Maybe if he had one more drink they’d leave him alone.” That’s the chilling opening sentence of THE GHOSTS OF BELFAST (Soho, $25), a first novel by Stuart Neville so bleak and despairing — “noir” in the genuine existential sense — it would rattle the composure of a saint. Gerry Fegan, the solitary drinker tossing back shots of whiskey and peering into the shadows for ghosts, is a hard man, an I.R.A. enforcer during the Troubles and still a legend in West Belfast. But unlike former colleagues who cynically retooled their skills for successful careers as politicians and crime bosses, Fegan is haunted by the people he killed — “12 of them if he counted the baby in its mother’s arms.” The ghosts who stare back at him with accusing eyes may be only manifestations of his own guilt, but they won’t let him alone until he takes vengeance by executing the men whose orders led to these deaths.

headline: Mau-Mauing the Flesh Eaters
text: Back in 1990, when a scholar named Carol J. Adams published “The Sexual Politics of Meat: A Feminist-Vegetarian Critical Theory,” it was nominated for the Diagram Prize, an annual award given to the book with the most inherently ludicrous title. It’s coming out in a new edition next March, and at the right moment, too. These days, the meaning of meat is anything but a boutique academic concern. Bookstores are full of titles like Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson’s “Face on Your Plate” and Michael Pollan’s “Omnivore’s Dilemma,” which ponder the ethics of flesh-eating, while books like Scott Gold’s “Shameless Carnivore,” Bill Buford’s “Heat” and Julie Powell’s forthcoming memoir “Cleaving” — in which the author of “Julie & Julia” overcomes a marital crisis by training as a globe-trotting butcher (think “Chop, Flay, Love”) — explore what might be called its erotics. Rummaging around inside a pig carcass in gloves, Powell grumbles, “Now I know why men hate condoms.”

headline: Inside the List
text: PRESEASON’S GREETINGS: It’s not even Thanksgiving, and some Christmas-related books are already creeping up the list, like genetically modified mutant mistletoe. Mike Huckabee’s “Simple Christmas” enters the hardcover nonfiction extended list at No. 18, two spots ahead of “You Better Not Cry,” Augusten Burroughs’s more acid take on the holidays. Over on the fiction extended list, we’ve got “Knit the Season” (No. 20) and Glenn Beck’s “Christmas Sweater” (No. 29), a holdover from last year. (A preshrunk version of Beck’s book is also on the hardcover children’s list.) Those with an allergy to wool (or Glenn Beck) can curl up with Jennifer Chiaverini’s “Quilter’s Holiday” (No. 28) or Richard Paul Evans’s “Christmas List” (No. 31).

headline: Rajaratnam Moves to Unseal 2000 Case Against Informant
text: Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund executive accused of participating in a massive insider trading scheme, moved on Thursday to unseal a 2000 criminal case against the woman who admitted to giving him confidential information about a number of companies. (Read the motion after the jump.)

headline: Media Vampires, Beware
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Now Seating | Danny Meyer on Maialino
text: Maialino, the Roman-style trattoria that is the first collaboration between two restaurant-world titans — the restaurateur Danny Meyer and the designer David Rockwell — opened this week at Ian Schrager’s Gramercy Park Hotel. T asked Meyer a few questions about the eagerly awaited project.

headline: Saturday TV Funhouse: Barneys Does ‘SNL’
text: Holiday decorations seem to go up earlier every year, but in this case we don’t mind: the shopping blog Racked NY reports that as of Friday morning, Barneys has filled its windows with papier-mâché effigies of characters and cast members from “Saturday Night Live.” The display spans the 35-year history of that late-night show: we spotted versions of Roseanne Roseannadanna; King Tut; the Coneheads; Brian Fellows; Amy Poehler grasping the Weekend Update globe; the androgynous, long-forgotten Pat; and even Gilly, the badly behaved grade school student played by Kristen Wiig. (We couldn’t find Toonces the Driving Cat, but we haven’t been there ourselves.)

headline: Counting Ballots in N.Y.’s 23rd District
text: Updated Could the conservative candidate who conceded on election night in one of the country’s most intensely watched races really still squeak to victory?

headline: Sailing the Caribbean, the Frugal Way
text: This weekend’s cover story, “Sailing the Caribbean, the Frugal Way,” has been a long time coming—three years, to be exact. Back in September 2006 I visited Jost Van Dyke, a tiny island in the British Virgin Islands, for another Frugal Traveler story, and it was there, while staying on White Bay, that I met a Florida family of four who’d rented a sailboat and invited myself and a friend aboard for gin and tonics. Impressed by both their generosity and their freedom—with the boat, they could go wherever they liked, whenever they wanted!—I began to try to figure out how I, a non-sailor without sailboat-rental funds, could live their luxurious lifestyle.

headline: Answers About Entrepreneurship, Part 2
text: Following is the second and final set of answers from Seth W. Pinsky, the president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, on citywide entrepreneurship. This week, he has answered readers’ questions in areas including job training, competitions, investment funds and efforts to encourage industries like green technology, bioscience, fashion, media and technology, manufacturing and distribution, and the arts.

headline: Not All Co-ops Are Good at Math
text: Q.

headline: Individual Meters in a Rental Building
text: Q.

headline: Rent Stabilization Tied to Tax Abatement
text: Q.

headline: Satan’s Bibles
text: Over at Right Wing Watch, the progressive watchdog blog affiliated with People for the American Way, Josh Glasstetter has written about what he’s calling the “Worst. Book Burning. Ever.”

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': Misery, Hope and a Black Joke or Two
text: The new Metropolitan Opera production of “From the House of the Dead” had its premiere Thurday night. The review by Anthony Tommasini is here. Mr. Tommasini, Dwight Garner, Charles Isherwood and James R. Oestreich will be continuing their discussion of the production today on ArtsBeat.

headline: Madness or Method? Tough to Tell
text: THERE are any number of characteristic Nicolas Cage scenes in Werner Herzog’s “Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans,” interludes you watch with a now-familiar mixture of genuine appreciation and more than a touch of bewilderment. In one Mr. Cage, as the drug-addled cop of the film’s title, enters a room to join a stakeout. The cops are watching a house. And, crammed in the foreground of the shot, two iguanas are watching Mr. Herzog’s low-lying camera, their bodies stretched across the image.

headline: A Carrot for ‘Real’ Comment Contributors
text: I was walking our dogs through a blanket of crisp oak leaves this morning, pondering the state of Dot Earth after two years, nearly 800 posts and tens of thousands of reader comments that reflect the variegated, and deeply divided, state of thinking on many issues, but especially global warming.

headline: News From the Milan Motorcycle Show
text: Manufacturers and journalists met in Milan this week for the 67th International Motorcycle Exhibition, known as E.I.C.M.A., one of the largest motorcycle trade shows in the world, with scores of exhibitors and displays in six pavilions. Here are some highlights, garnered from the scattered coverage out there on the Web:

headline: Banker Seeks to Put a Price on Nature
text: According to Pavan Sukhdev, a banker working with the United Nations Environment Program, putting a price on the world’s trees, water stores and other natural resources will be the most cost-effective way of tackling the challenges posed by climate change — at least until cleaner energy technologies become available.

headline: Robert Johnson’s House to Rise Again
text: The fabled crossroads where Robert Johnson is supposed to have sold his soul to the devil in exchange for his guitar prowess has not been definitively located, but the musician’s birthplace has been determined and plans are in the works to restore it as a tourist attraction, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Johnson, the blues guitarist of “Sweet Home Chicago” and “Love in Vain,” who influenced artists from Muddy Waters to Eric Clapton, was born in 1911 in Hazlehurst, Miss., in a home built by his stepfather. The birthplace was verified in a letter from his half-sister, according to the cultural affairs office of Copiah County, which is seeking to raise $250,000 to restore the home as a destination for music fans and Johnson acolytes. “He was so good that he would literally turn his back when they were recording him,” said the screenwriter Jimmy White (“Ray”), who is working on a script about Mr. Johnson’s life. “He didn’t want the other musicians to see his fingering technique.”

headline: A Post-Mortem on the Opel Deal
text: After a crushing defeat, the losing team stews over replays. In the wake of the collapse of the Opel deal, Germany is no exception.

headline: False Colors: Bogus Military Honors Worn to School Reunion
text: You never know how people will turn out. But when some members of Alhambra High School’s Class of ’88 who did not remember Steven Douglas Burton as the athletic type saw him at the 20th reunion at the Concord Hilton dressed in a Marine uniform decorated with a Navy Cross, the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart and other medals, they got suspicious.

headline: What’s Old Is New Again
text: New York’s new license plate, unveiled this week, quickly earned the ire of some motorists who balked at paying $25, the state’s mandated fee, for the privilege of owning something they already have.

headline: Screening: One More Reason to Get Up Early
text: There are probably better ways to start the day, but a new study suggests that early morning is an ideal time to schedule a colonoscopy.

headline: Inspired | Keeping Warm With Rag Wool
text: As you get older, you realize how right your mom was about everything. Just as brussels sprouts begin to taste good (albeit with lots of butter and bacon) and Fleetwood Mac finds a space in the playlist, I’m starting to understand why I spent all those winters wearing bulky, Brillo pad-like sweaters. Nothing keeps you warmer.

headline: Weekend Competition: Squiffy, Sozzled, Smashed
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share the words and phrases they use to describe being drunk, drummed, daffy, decanted, or utterly Dean Martoonied.

headline: Reality Bytes
text: The action figures for James Cameron’s “Avatar” started appearing in stores last month. The movie won’t be out until December, but the toys have their own multimedia selling point: an “augmented reality” feature. This phrase has become one of the pervasive buzz concepts of 2009, and as is often true in such cases, it seems to describe a variety of manifestations from the practical to the pointless to the pie in the sky.

headline: The Cloak of Invisibility Comes Off
text: Franconia, N.H.

headline: With Change, Suzuki Tries to Lift Profile
text: AS the 2010 Kizashi comes to market, American Suzuki is promising sweeping changes not only in its vehicles, but in the way it operates. The goal is to raise Suzuki’s low profile and put its products on the shopping lists of Americans.

headline: That Hair, That Baton: Is Glitz Good for Classical Music?
text: Gustavo Dudamel has received a blast of publicity like few others in classical music in the past several years. He rode into Los Angeles as its orchestra’s music director last month on a wave of media and public relations hoopla. Mr. Dudamel, of course, is not the first classical musician to capture mainstream — read populist — attention. Yo-Yo Ma and Renee Fleming are exemplars now. Before them, we had Beverly Sills and Leonard Bernstein. Before them, John McCormack and Enrico Caruso. Before them, the castratos of Italy and superstar opera composers of the Viennese and Italian courts.

headline: White House Plan on Immigration Includes Legal Status
text: The Obama administration will insist on measures to give legal status to an estimated 12 million illegal immigrants as it pushes early next year for legislation to overhaul the immigration system, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said on Friday.

headline: Volvo Safety, 2011 Style: It Brakes for Walkers
text: Rockleigh, N.J.

headline: Overhead View of Pole Impact Crash
text: Video provided by the N.H.T.S.A. showing its new crash test.

headline: A Wall, a Shed and a Generator
text: Paul was busy most of last week picking up equipment and materials. He bought sheet rock for the kitchen wall behind the gas stove and sink, two-by-fours and concrete blocks to build a shed, and a beautiful eight-kilowatt propane-fired generator.

headline: New Side-Impact Test to Be Added
text: ONE attractive survival strategy for automakers in today’s strained business conditions is the development of a so-called world car. The plan is straightforward enough: create a versatile model that can be adapted for many world markets with minimal changes, allowing the cost of engineering, tooling and manufacturing to be spread over hundreds of thousands of automobiles.

headline: Fire Forces Evacuation of Stuyvesant High School
text: A fire broke out in a third-floor bathroom of Stuyvesant High School in TriBeCa on Friday morning. The school has been cleared, and so far no injuries have been reported, a spokesman for the Fire Department said.

headline: Dr. Andrew Weil’s Stress-Free Squash Soup
text: Dr. Andrew Weil is among the best-known doctors in America, an alternative health guru who espouses the power of healthful eating and stress reduction as the best way to improve health.

headline: A Swedish Smorgasbord of Collectible Saabs
text: ANY early, well-preserved Saab is desirable. Here are a few with special resonance for collectors:

headline: Stalking Saabs That Soared
text: SAAB is a relatively young and proudly offbeat automaker, and from the start it has appealed to those who appreciate the unconventional. For aficionados, “Find your own road” was more than a slogan.

headline: Researchers at Dartmouth Assess Health Bills
text: Dr. John Wennberg, who pioneered the Dartmouth research that shows the wide variation in the practice of medicine in this country, has teamed up with some colleagues to assess how the health care legislation in the Senate and House addresses “our dysfunctional, disorganized, and wasteful delivery system.”

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': Dostoyevsky’s Novel as ‘M*A*S*H’ Set in a Siberian Gulag
text: Charles, you’re definitely not alone in disliking Dostoyevsky when he’s at his most moralistic. “The more Dostoyevsky gets worked up about the tragic nature of the soul,” D.H. Lawrence snarked, “the more I lose interest.” And Vladimir Nabokov praised Dostoyevsky’s “flashes of excellent humor” but deplored the “wastelands of literary platitudes in between.”

headline: Key 9/11 Suspect to Be Tried in New York
text: Attorney General Eric Holder announced that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks, and four other men accused in the plot will be prosecuted in federal court in New York. (Video: NBC)

headline: Correction: Behind the Wheel | 2010 Mercedes-Benz S400
text: A review of the Mercedes-Benz S400 hybrid sedan last Sunday misstated a difference between that car and the conventional nonhybrid S550. Adaptive cruise control is offered on the S400, though two other features available on the S550  an active body-control suspension and Attention Assist, which sends a warning to drowsy drivers  are not.

headline: Do We Make Our Children Superstitious?
text: While our flight was taking off for a family vacation a few years back I noticed that my son had his fingers crossed on both his hands. I saw it as a tiny battle lost.

headline: Water Found on Moon, Researchers Say
text: There is water on the Moon, scientists stated unequivocally on Friday.

headline: Japan’s Budget Review May Rein In Whaling
text: There are hints that Japan’s review of government spending in a number of areas could diminish the billions of yen spent each year to sustain the country’s annual whaling excursions to the oceans around Antarctica. Greenpeace sent an alert around about the budget review just before President Obama flew to Japan. For the moment, it’s unclear whether the whaling program — which Japan has long cast as important scientific research but many biologists and activists decry — is in danger, according to our Tokyo reporters. There’ll be updates here as needed. [UPDATE, 11/19: This year’s hunt got under way as the fleet headed south. Presumably the chasers below are gearing up, as well.]

headline: World Cup Playoff Preview: Greece vs. Ukraine
text: Greece vs. UkraineGame 1: Saturday, Nov. 14 in AthensGame 2: Wednesday, Nov. 18 in Donetsk

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': The Orchestra Tells the Story
text: I’ll defer to Dwight as the house authority on the Dostoyevsky novel. What I do know from reading the book and studying the opera is that Janacek, who wrote his own libretto, took various characters and stories from the lives of the prisoners in the book and combined them into a smaller group of characters and incidents for the opera.

headline: The Last Tuna?
text: Barry Estabrook — a former editor at (sigh) Gourmet, the founding editor of the original Eating Well, someone who has been doing great work in the world of real food for at least 20 years, and the author of the best non-cooking food story of the year — is the first person, to my knowledge at least, to say, “There is a strong likelihood that someone in this generation will be the last human to eat a bluefin tuna.” Read it (and check out his other posts) at Politics of the Plate.

headline: Biden to Appear on ‘Daily Show’
text: Having hosted the likes of Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, and Ray Mabus, the secretary of the navy, “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” will take another step up the White House chain of command on Tuesday: that night, the satirical news show is scheduled to host Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. Comedy Central announced the booking Friday in a news release. It’s the first time that Mr. Biden has appeared on “The Daily Show” since he was elected vice president; he previously appeared on the show as a senator and presidential candidate on Aug. 8, 2007, and on Jan. 31, 2007, the day that Mr. Biden announced he was seeking the Democratic presidential nomination. Barack Obama last appeared on the show on Oct. 29, 2008, before winning the presidential election.

headline: Deluge of Pleas to Spare Oreo, Dog Thrown Off Roof
text: Animal rights supporters have bombarded the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals with phone calls and e-mail messages in a frantic last-minute bid to save Oreo, a pit bull that survived being tossed off a roof and is scheduled to be euthanized Friday afternoon.

headline: Dell’s Out-of-Town Tryout for Smartphones
text: Dell has finally confirmed what has been bouncing around the market for some time, that it is entering the smartphone business.

headline: Foo Fighters’ Pilot Roosts With Vultures
text: IN November 1991 Nirvana’s “Nevermind” was beginning its climb up the charts. The album had not yet sold more than 10 million copies, had not yet knocked Michael Jackson out of the No. 1 slot on the Billboard album chart, had not yet become the defining moment of the alternative rock movement or given Kurt Cobain the “voice of a generation” status that would help prove his undoing.

headline: Danny Meyer on His New Dinner Companions
text: On The Moment blog, Danny Meyer talks about working with the designer David Rockwell for the first time, on his newly opened restaurant Maialino.

headline: Readers Take Issue With Time’s ’10 Best College Presidents’
text: On Thursday, Time magazine published a package on its Web site that attempted to handicap the nation’s “10 Best College Presidents.” In response to our post on that feature — in which we gingerly raised the question of how one could possibly establish an objective ranking of college presidents — nearly 100 readers of The Choice submitted comments. Most of you sent nominations of your own, and others mirrored our skepticism about the value of such a list.

headline: Russian Story, German Director, Hollywood Film
text: SUMMER STORM

headline: Trial Venue Leaves 9/11 Families Angry or Satisfied
text: To many, it felt exquisitely right: This is where it began. This is where it must end.

headline: Corrections
text: A “Living Here” listing in the Escapes pages last Friday about a three-bedroom house in northeastern Pennsylvania misidentified the town where it is located. It is in Warren Center, not Warren.

headline: Taking a Man, Then Removing His Myth
text: THE filmmaker Alexander Sokurov is best known to American audiences for “Russian Ark” (2002), a dizzying tour through the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg that sweeps up several centuries of Russian history and culture into a single 96-minute Steadicam shot.

headline: The Roots of Fine Wine
text: Peter Liem is one of my favorite wine writers. He is meticulous in the best possible way, and always has something interesting to say. Most recently in the October issue of Wine and Spirits magazine he wrote a thought-provoking column in which he compared wines made from ungrafted vines with cheese made from unpasteurized milk.

headline: “From the House of the Dead': What About That Bird?
text: Guys, I’d be curious to discuss the eagle. I may be being a bit literal-minded here, but it seemed to me the creature was so obviously mechanical that it was actually meant to be a toy rather than a living thing. Obviously this could just be a matter of stylization – you can’t put a live bird onstage in an opera, let alone coach him to act wounded.

headline: Is Solar Power Expensive or Competitive?
text: “Solar is cheaper than coal today,” asserts Jigar Shah, the founder of Sun Edison who now heads the Carbon War Room, a new nonprofit group.

headline: Up Front: Steven Pinker
text: Malcolm Gladwell recently said that if he were trying to break into journalism today, he would start by getting a master’s degree in statistics. The Harvard psychologist Steven Pinker, who reviews Gladwell’s “What the Dog Saw” on this week’s cover, might second this advice. Asked via e-mail what is the most important scientific concept that lay people fail to understand, he responded: “Statistical reasoning. A difficulty in grasping probability underlies fallacies from medical quackery and stock-market scams to misinterpreting sex differences and the theory of evolution.”

headline: Correction
text: A picture caption on Nov. 1 with a review of “Enemies of the People” misidentified the book’s author, Kati Marton. In the photograph, showing her as a child with her sister and mother, she is sitting in the center, not at right.

headline: Readers in Asia: Share Your Thoughts
text: To foster discussion of President Barack Obama’s trip to Asia, the Times is inviting readers living in the countries he is visiting to share their views with us via video. If you live in Japan, Singapore, China or South Korea, we would like you to film yourself telling us what you believe Mr. Obama could do for your country.

headline: ‘A Trip to China’
text: Monologue |  Aired Thursday night on NBC: President Obama is traveling to Asia this week. He’ll be making a trip to China. While he’s there, Obama plans to visit the Forbidden City, the Great Wall, and America’s money.

headline: Ground Is Broken for New Barnes Foundation Home
text: After years of pitched battles over the Barnes Foundation’s plans to bypass its founding charter and bylaws and move its world-class painting collection from suburban Merion, Pa., to downtown Philadelphia, the foundation broke ground Friday for the Barnes’s new home, to be designed by the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien.

headline: ‘Crazy Astronaut Lady’
text: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: Remember the crazy astronaut lady who put on a diaper and drove cross country? She was in love with another astronaut. And I said to myself, well that’s what happens when you mix vodka and Tang.

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': Fright and Flight
text: That wounded eagle, in Dostoyevsky’s novel, is described as “full of solitary malice” and “waiting for death, trusting and forgiving no one.” The prisoners are in frightened awe of it. Few can get near it. The men debate trying to help it get out.

headline: In Dollar General’s Debut, a 2009 High for I.P.O.’s
text: Investors appear to be flocking to Dollar General on Friday after the discount retailer made its stock market debut, signaling that there is a lot of pent-up demand for initial public offerings. (Shares in the company were up nearly 8 percent in afternoon trading, reaching $22.70.)

headline: ‘Broke by Christmas’
text: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: Gov. David Paterson made a shocking statement today. He said, “New York will be broke by Christmas.” Today, Gov. Schwarzenegger said: “Christmas? What’s your secret? How’d you last so long?”

headline: EconoQuiz
text: Welcome to another installment of EconoQuiz, a regular quiz on economics issues in the news.

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': Pity for the Bird
text: Well, Charles, your idea that the eagle is meant to be a toy did not occur to me and is intriguing. I thought that the toy-like look of the mechanical eagle was a pitiable image. It made the prisoners seem like eager children who manage not to fight over a toy because it is so wondrous and special. This, for me, is what prevented the moment from being sentimental.

headline: Columns from Central America?
text: I’m thinking about a trip to Central America next month, perhaps Nicaragua and Honduras and I don’t know where else. I don’t know the terrain and would welcome suggestions for columns. As always, I’m looking for a micro example of a macro problem. For example, I’m unlikely to write about Nicaragua as such, but might use a program in Nicaragua to illuminate a global development problem. If you have suggestions, post them below — and thanks.

headline: Bought for a Song (Many, Actually)
text: THE entrance to the building on Anderson Avenue at 167th Street in the Highbridge section of the Bronx looks like something out of Hansel and Gretel. Two small stone guardhouses with peaked roofs frame a landscaped courtyard, with a mulberry tree hung with bird feeders in the center.

headline: The Right Way to Change Your Name
text: If you’re planning to change your name after getting married, making the change in a timely fashion is probably going to become even more important next year when a new program, called Secure Flight, will require that the name you use to make an airline reservation be exactly the same as the one you use on an ID, even if the rules may sometimes bend a little.

headline: On Our Radar…
text: 1.) The E.U. meets its Kyoto climate targets.

headline: First Responders' Story
text: Senior Sgt. Mark Todd and Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley describe how they stopped the shooting that took place at Fort Hood, Tex., one week ago. (Video: NBC Nightly News)

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: 1.) An argument for a jobful recovery.

headline: Can D.I.Y. Supplant the First-Person Shooter?
text: The face of the enemy flashed across a 20-foot screen. “That’s right,” Jason Rohrer announced. “It’s Roger Ebert.” There were a few boos, as several hundred people stirred in their seats. The film critic’s cherubic face stared at the audience. “Ebert said video games can’t be art,” Rohrer said. “He issued all of us a direct challenge. And we need to find an answer.”

headline: A New Cast Doesn’t Slow Peyton Manning
text: INDIANAPOLIS  After the season ended each year, Peyton Manning would walk into Tony Dungy’s office clutching a notebook with a list of his perceived weaknesses and things to work on.

headline: Chrysler Is Recalling Jeeps for Transmission Issue
text: Chrysler is recalling about 161,000 Jeeps because their automatic transmissions were assembled without a system to warn if the fluid is overheating.

headline: ‘From the House of the Dead': Supertitles
text: Tony, I’d be curious to hear your thoughts about the unusual projection of supertitles on the set itself. I’d never seen this before at the Met, and understood that James Levine had a strong antipathy to supertitles; hence the creation of the Met’s own title system, which has the titles on the seat back in front of every individual.

headline: Dear Abby in Need of Advice
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: Must See: Pakistan’s Anti-Yankee Rock
text: No rocking against the Taliban in Pakistan. Weird Al explains Auto-Tune. An artist courts controversy in Uganda. And a restaurant staff hits the jackpot.

headline: Teaching and Learning About Journalism
text: Occasionally, in lieu of a traditional lesson, we’ll give you a page of useful resources on an oft-taught subject, issue or skill set, as we did for the National Day on Writing.

headline: An Advocate for Prisoners Argues for Prisons, Too
text: There is a certain monastic quiet in the painter’s studio where the Rev. Stephen Chinlund sometimes spends hours at a stretch at his easel. Outside, along the streets of the garment district, noisy chaos reigns. But inside, in the soft light, he can easily slip into a trance as he paints.

headline: It’s Q & A With DP!
text: “Hi David, Why do people (including yourself) use URL shorteners in anything other than Twitter? I think it’s an unnecessary and unpleasant layer of opacity between you and your readers. I don’t know where the link goes to and I don’t like getting in the habit of clicking these things. Why not just do it the regular way of a link with text? I can see at the bottom of my browser window where it really goes.”

headline: Weekly Matchups: Respecting the Horned Frogs
text: What have I learned this season? (Not much if you look at my record picking games.) One thing I have learned, however, is that Horned Frogs can shoot blood out of their eyes. I have learned this because for the second time this season, the Texas Christian Horned Frogs are playing in the biggest game of the weekend. Despite the fact that Iowa and Ohio State are playing for a berth in the Rose Bowl, ESPN’s “GameDay” will be at Amon G. Carter Stadium and everyone seems to agree that the game to watch on Saturday is in Fort Worth.

headline: Blogging Imam Who Counseled Fort Hood Gunman and 9/11 Hijacker Goes Silent
text: Anwar al-Awlaki, a radical, American-born cleric who knew at least one of the 9/11 hijackers and exchanged e-mail messages last year with the Army psychiatrist charged in the Fort Hood shootings, abruptly stopped blogging this week, just days after writing that he approved of the psychiatrist’s attack on American soldiers.

headline: That Delicate Membrane, the Heart
text: I PULLED my eyes from the hospital window, from the view of snow-covered mountains, and watched as my father struggled to raise himself from his bed.

headline: Moving Sustainability Forward in Portland
text: It was standing room only as leaders from government, nonprofit, academic and business groups gathered for two days of meetings in Oregon last week — part of the Portland Metro Climate Prosperity Project, which seeks to promote sustainability in the region.

headline: Cotto’s Trainer Learned Outside the Ring
text: LAS VEGAS  Joe Santiago is 32 years old. He has never boxed, not once, never built a champion, never trained a fighter for a bout of the magnitude that awaits him Saturday.

headline: Bidding Wars Resume
text: A TWO-BEDROOM apartment on the Upper West Side is listed at $1.595 million and sells within two weeks after nine prospective buyers race to outbid one another, ultimately pushing the price to nearly $1.8 million.

headline: Lady Thatcher’s Dead (No, Not That One)
text: When it comes to text messages, sometimes less isn’t more. On Tuesday night, word swept through part of a crowd of 1,700 at a fund-raiser for military families in Toronto that Margaret Thatcher, the former prime minister of Great Britain, was dead. Its source, according to the Canadian Press news agency, was a text message reading: “Lady Thatcher has passed away.”

headline: The Price of Free
text: When, in late September, rumors surfaced that Comcast was trying to buy NBC Universal from General Electric, Wall Street reacted with dismay. Grandiose attempts to combine media production and distribution — programming and plumbing — are nothing new in the entertainment business, but they almost always end in disappointment. Witness AOL Time Warner. So what in the world could be prompting the Comcast chief executive, Brian Roberts, to start down this accursed path?

headline: A Steal at 'Bronx Prices'
text: Janna Baty and Doug Wamble paid $180,000 for an apartment that has three bedrooms and two full baths in the Highbridge section of the Bronx.

headline: Fourth-Wave Feminism
text: As the founder and editor of the blog Feministing.com, how would you rate the effectiveness of online activism compared to old-style models of political engagement like rallies and marches and displays of bra-burning?  Bra-burning never happened. It was completely made up by the media. A couple of women protesting a Miss America pageant threw some bras into a garbage can, and somehow that became this longstanding idea of feminists as bra-burners.

headline: Job Losses Mount, Enduring and Deep
text: THE rise in unemployment that has occurred in the current recession has been hardest on young workers, while having a smaller effect on older workers than previous downturns. Women have been more likely than men to hold on to their jobs.

headline: Samantha Morton in ‘The Messenger’
text: In “The Messenger,” out today, Samantha Morton plays an American woman whose husband is killed while fighting in Iraq. This dramatic turn is the latest in a motley succession of roles that began with Morton’s 1999 breakout performance as the devilishly adorable mute in Woody Allen’s “Sweet and Lowdown.”

headline: Vice President to Appear on ‘Daily Show’
text: Having hosted the likes of Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, and Ray Mabus, the secretary of the navy, “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” will take another step up the White House chain of command on Tuesday: that night, the satirical news show is scheduled to host Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. Read more on ArtsBeat.

headline: Pregame Huddle: Mountain West Showdown
text: All eyes are on the Mountain West as T.C.U. faces Utah while Florida and Alabama try to avoid upsets this weekend.

headline: Deluxe Apartment in the Sky
text: A Classic 8 corner apartment on Park Avenue that was  impeccably renovated -- back in 1971.

headline: A Quiet Start for Zach Lund
text: Zach Lund of the United States debuted the 2009-10 World Cup skeleton season with a fifth-place finish at the Utah Olympic Park in Park City, Utah.

headline: Modern Classics
text: NYRB Classics, that series of highly craveable paperback reissues of works in translation, half-forgotten gems and titles you can’t believe were ever out of print in the first place, celebrates its 10th anniversary, and 250th book, tonight at Greenlight Books in Fort Greene.

headline: Hey, Good Lookin’ . . . Free Stuff!
text: I have a very attractive wife. When she is out with our two cute baby girls, she often receives free groceries, free fast food — the guy at Dunkin’ Donuts loves her — and free clothes. Frequently she does not realize she has the gifts (or stolen goods) until she is in the car, driving away. Is it ethical for her to keep these gifts, or must she return them (which may get the giver fired)? CHRIS ALTMAN, ATLANTA

headline: Controllers Were Slow to Notify Defense Command of Errant Jet
text: WASHINGTON  Air traffic control supervisors delayed nearly an hour in notifying Norad, the military air defense command, that a Northwest Airlines jetliner was not responding to radio calls, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration said Friday. The delay was a violation of detailed procedures put in place after the hijackings of four airplanes on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: A Condo Hunter Remains True to the List
text: ERICA FRIEDMAN had a checklist. She knew exactly what she needed in her new home, and the importance of every feature. She went through her list methodically, dismissing buildings that didn’t make the cut.

headline: Maclaren Stroller Update
text: While we were discussing the Maclaren recall on Motherlode, The Harvard Business Review was offering online advice to the company.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: Kristen Stewart, Nicolas Cage, Dave Grohl and More
text: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete stories.)

headline: Changing Your Name After Marriage When You’re Gay
text: While changing a name after marriage can often be a struggle for heterosexual women and men, it’s a lot harder if you’re gay.

headline: Only Disconnect
text: Shortly after my girlfriend and I decided to rent a New Hampshire summer house together in 2007, we made a vexing discovery: Internet access wasn’t going to be possible. We could get it, sure, but balked at the one-year contract required. We couldn’t justify the expense and decided we would do without: surely our three acres of apple trees and old stone walls and wooded walks would offer ample distraction.

headline: Financial Decisions to Make as You Divorce
text: Divorce may be one of the most damaging financial events in the lives of those who go through it, but that isn’t always immediately clear to a couple about to split up.

headline: F.D.A. Says It May Ban Alcoholic Drinks With Caffeine
text: WASHINGTON  Top federal food regulators threatened on Friday to ban caffeinated alcoholic drinks unless their makers quickly proved that the beverages were safe.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Susan Cheever on Mary Karr’s New Memoir
text: This week, Susan Cheever discusses Mary Karr’s new memoir, “Lit”; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; David Carr tells us about the life and times of the British journalist Harry Evans; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

headline: Profiles of Four Terror Suspects
text: Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, mastermind of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, is believed to have had a cadre of al-Qaeda accomplices who were the money men, travel agents and deputies who enabled the hijackers in the United States from their posts overseas. These four will stand trial in United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

headline: New Jersey Brokers Seeking a Rush From a ‘Crawl’
text: IN many communities, the pace of condominium sales is just crawling along these days.

headline: Wireless Protocols Vie for Smart Grid
text: The market for ‘smart appliances’ is in rapid development, and wireless companies want to make sure they get a piece of the pie.

headline: What Unexpected Costs Did You Face in Your Divorce?
text: My “Your Money” column in Saturday’s paper encourages people whose marriages are ending to consider all the costs they may face in the future, from taxes to damaged credit to therapy.

headline: The Week Ahead: Nov. 15 — 21
text: Television

headline: Still Trying to Lure New Yorkers Across the Hudson
text: “Mass Exodus to New Jersey Underway” one headline screams from a Web advertisement. “Governor Plots Ginormous Tax Increases for New York City” another blares. The front page of the newspaper in the ad looks like a warning from “War of the Worlds,” but don’t panic. It’s merely another volley in the Hudson River border wars between New York and New Jersey.

headline: Filming a Friendship, Founded on Film
text: VILMOS ZSIGMOND and Laszlo Kovacs, whose cinematography would help change the look of American movies in the late 1960s and 1970s, first met in 1953 on a Budapest street corner near the Academy of Drama and Film, where both men were enrolled as cinematography students. Three years afterward  on Nov. 11, 1956, a week after Soviet troops poured into the city to crush the Hungarian uprising  they ran into each other again on the same corner.

headline: Moved for the Space; Stayed for the Food
text: THE house that Michael and Lori Hiller planned to buy in South Park Slope, Brooklyn, was a good size for the neighborhood, and on a pleasant block. But then a problem developed with the building’s certificate of occupancy.

headline: An Early Candidate for Dunk of the Year
text: Dwyane Wade might have made the dunk of the year this early in the season. While there have been some notable dunks early on, watch Wade sky over Anderson Varejao in Thursday’s loss to the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: Performa 09 | An Artistic Potluck
text: Thursday night, halfway through Performa 09’s three week run, the curatorial collective Kunstverein NY opened the doors to their “conceptual social club” called the Prompt, which runs until Sunday evening at White Slab Palace, a Scandinavian gastropub (77 Delancey Street) on the Lower East Side.

headline: Nobody Home but Us Gadgets
text: A NEW condominium conversion in southern SoHo celebrates 19th-century craftsmanship on the outside and 21st-century precision on the inside.

headline: Loan Ceiling Extended
text: BUYERS of homes in high-priced markets have some reason to cheer: the federal government recently extended through 2010 the maximum dollar amount for “conforming loans.” This will probably mean better options for borrowers who might otherwise have had to take out “jumbo” mortgages.

headline: The Best Way to Try Terrorists
text: Attorney General Eric Holder announced Friday that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other men accused in the 9/11 terrorist attacks will be prosecuted in federal court in New York City. Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, who is accused of planning the 2000 bombing of the Navy destroyer Cole in Yemen, and four other detainees also being held in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, will be tried before a military commission.

headline: Ochocinco Fined for Bribe Joke
text: Tim Donaghy, scourge of N.B.A. officiating, apparently hovers over the N.F.L., too.

headline: Fiscal perspective
text: It’s truly amazing, and depressing, how completely deficit-phobia has swept the field in Washington. The economy remains in deeply dire straits: here’s long-term unemployment:

headline: Oreo Is Dead
text: Oreo, a dog that was nursed back to health after surviving being thrown off the roof of a six-story building, was killed Friday by lethal injection.

headline: Director’s Suite
text: BRETT MORGEN  AGE: 41  OCCUPATION: Filmmaker NEXT PROJECT: "June 17, 1994," his documentary about the day of the O.J. Simpson low-speed chase, will be shown as part of the ESPN 30 for 30 film series.

headline: Robert Gladstone
text: Mr. Gladstone, 57, is the chief executive of Madison Equities, started by his parents, which has developed a wide range of buildings in Manhattan. Its most recent developments are two condominiums: Chelsea Modern and 57 Irving Place.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Friday, Nov. 13
text: Correction appended | The aftermath of natural and human violence is depicted in the first five photographs of Friday’s show, which chronicle the destruction caused by Tropical Storm Ida in Virginia and North Carolina and a suicide bomber in Pakistan. An older, aerial photograph of a Crowley Maritime Corporation barge gives some sense of the enormity of the vessel that has run aground in Virginia Beach.

headline: The Use Changes; the Look Stays
text: UNTIL two years ago, the boarded-up Ossining National Bank on Main Street served as a nagging reminder that a once-thriving business district was sliding downhill. The last bank tenant vacated the building, a three-story Renaissance Revival-style structure, in 1966, and it had been vacant ever since.

headline: Move Over Recliner, Here Comes the Snooker Table
text: If you can drive a leather recliner down the road, why not a snooker table?

headline: Fête Accompli | ‘NARS 15X15’
text: What: A party for “NARS 15X15,” a book featuring 15 celebrities made-up and shot by the beauty extraordinaire François Nars for the brand’s 15th anniversary.

headline: The View Inside the Gates
text: BETH TYNES wouldn’t consider living in a community that isn’t gated. From the very first, she said, “I liked the sense of community.”

headline: Anything He Can Do, She Can Do
text: IN September 1998, David Buechner, then 39, a prominent classical pianist, came out as a transgender woman, explaining that from then on, she would live and perform as Sara Davis Buechner. The pianist had been accustomed to rave reviews (at 24, David, in his New York City concert debut, was called “an extraordinary young artist” by a New York Times critic). But the debut as Sara, reported in a Times magazine article, was not so well received, even by loved ones.

headline: James Campaigns to Save No. 23 for Posterity
text: LeBron James of the Cleveland Cavaliers is calling on his N.B.A. comrades to join him in forsaking the No. 23 to honor Michael Jordan.

headline: Crossing the Concourse
text: Just over a decade ago, David Buechner, a classical pianist, came out as a transgender woman, Sara Davis Buechner. On the eve of the 25th anniversary of her debut, Ms. Buechner reflects on her life.

headline: Distilling the Best Comments From 100 Things Restaurant Staffers Should Never Do
text: “Lord, I know this will end someday…Please, please, no part three.” — Jocko McTeague

headline: Gallery Beat Meets Tracey Emin
text: Paul Hasegawa-Overacker interviews Tracey Emin at the Gramercy International art fair in 1995.

headline: Leaving on a High Note
text: THROUGHOUT the real estate boom, one commercial property after another in the West Village was sold and transformed into an expensive condominium or house. At the same time, Danta C. Raso and Ricard de La Rosa went about their business, Pro Piano, supplying German-made Steinway pianos to concert pianists out of an office and warehouse on a cobblestone section of Jane Street, just off Washington Street.

headline: A Stuffing Strategy Grandma Understood
text: CHESTNUT bread stuffing, thick with mushrooms and celery, has been such a fixture at my family’s Thanksgiving table that, like the great fowl itself, its presence was never questioned.

headline: Rooftop Ruckus
text: CONSTANCE HANSEN and her husband, Russell Peacock, both photographers, live and work in a loft in a co-op on West 31st Street, where they have long dreamed of building a rooftop extension made up in part of shipping containers hoisted up from the street.

headline: They Have to Live Somewhere
text: PERHAPS too much has been said about those tiresome kings of finance, macho bankers and hedge fund executives who have swooped in and picked up some of New York’s most valuable real estate in good times  and less good times.

text: Patricia Racette (Lauretta) sings “O mio babbino caro” to Paolo Gavanelli (Gianni Schicchi) at the San Francisco Opera.

headline: Sharing News of a Child’s Cerebral Palsy
text: David Sexton is a father coming to terms with the realities of his son’s cerebral palsy. He is exploring this unexpected landscape in incremental steps, and, as he writes in a guest post today, the most recent challenge was telling family and friends who did not yet know this news.

headline: Olives Irrigated With Blood
text: Earlier this year the NYT’s Iraqi reporter in Diyala visited one of Al Qaeda’s former strongholds in the province, after years in which it was too dangerous to go there. He recalls the scene.

headline: Philanthropy Thrives, Even With Reduced Resources
text: THE expectation in America is that people who do well give back to society. For the wealthy, it is one way to stave off charges of being greedy. And in the boom times, being seen as philanthropic seemed a social and political obligation.

headline: Showcase: A Room of Everyone’s Own
text: At first, the rooms look unbearably cramped. The walls squeeze too tightly around the dwellers and their possessions. Then, some creative solutions emerge into view: a ventilation strip neatly covered with McDonald’s wrappers, a raft of plastic bags hanging from clothespins, collapsible tables, stackable chairs.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Susan Cheever on Mary Karr’s New Memoir
text: This week, Susan Cheever discusses Mary Karr’s new memoir, “Lit”; Motoko Rich has notes from the field; David Carr talks about the life and times of the British journalist Harold Evans; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.(Podcast Archive)

headline: Accused 9/11 Suspects Face Federal Trial
text: Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other men accused in the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks will be prosecuted in federal court in New York.

headline: Bubbles at a Discount for Consumers Trading Down
text: ÉPERNAY, France  For generations of French Champagne makers, the threat of calamity has been a constant companion, whether it is winter freezes or spring frosts, phylloxera parasites or Nazi occupiers.

headline: Your Dot: On Mobbed Owls and Blog Discourse
text: On Dot Earth, reader comments that are particularly intriguing or illuminating have sporadically been brought “out front” to this space for a fuller airing. As I wrote earlier today, that process will now become a regular feature, Your Dot, used to focus the discourse on constructive commentary by readers who prefer to stand publicly behind what they say. I’m not endorsing the views expressed in these comments, and hope they will reflect a wide range of stances. Also, the full range of views and levels of anonymity will persist in the standard comment threads.

headline: Japanese Form Mixes Discipline and the Elemental
text: Butoh, like flamenco, is one of those dance forms that are either all or nothing. If the performer is not imbued with both technique and (less quantifiably) the right spirit, you simply get no idea of what the experience of watching these arts can be like. Happily for the Cave New York Butoh Festival, which opened its Butoh-Kan Masters series at Dance New Amsterdam on Thursday night, Ko Murobushi is the real thing.

headline: Sunday Preview
text: In this Sunday’s Caribbean issue, Matt Gross, who writes the weekly Frugal Traveler blog for The New York Times, sails the Caribbean on a shoestring budget. Without a boat to call his own or a budget to hire a yacht, he joins the crew of a 75-foot, two-masted schooner for a two-week immersion in the sailing world. For $55 a day, he learns the ropes, swims with sea turtles and, when all goes right, sleeps under the stars.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: Can the Undefeated Stay That Way?
text: For those of you itching to see a top team in action, you won’t have to wait for Saturday. Undefeated Cincinnati takes the field Friday night against West Virginia, hoping that its high-scoring ways will be enough to topple the Mountaineers. The marquee game of the weekend comes from the Mountain West, where unbeaten Texas Christian takes on Utah, which was the lone undefeated team at the end of last season. Will the Horned Frogs be able to make that claim this season? Elsewhere, Iowa travels to Ohio State for a game that could decide Big Ten supremacy, Notre Dame tries to bounce back from a loss when it faces surging Pittsburgh and Arizona takes on California in a pivotal game in the suddenly wild Pac-10. Our prognosticators have made their choices. If you agree, disagree or just feel the picks are laughable, feel free to chime in.

headline: Zhang Returns, With the Familiar and Otherwise
text: During her five years as assistant and then associate conductor of the New York Philharmonic, Xian Zhang proved a substantial musician with an energetic technique and a lively interpretive spirit. Just as her tenure was coming to an end last season, she was appointed music director of the Orchestra Sinfonica di Milano Giuseppe Verdi. But she has kept her ties to the Philharmonic, and on Thursday evening she was back at Avery Fisher Hall to lead it in works by Haydn, Martinu and Sibelius.

headline: Answers About Home Buyers’ and Owners’ Tax Credits: Part 4
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks in which you’ll have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Violence Flares Ahead of Algeria-Egypt Soccer Match
text: Update | Saturday | 2:35 p.m. ET Egyptian Win to Keep Hopes Alive for World Cup 2010. A remarkable last-minute goal for Egypt in Cairo, scored by Emad Moteab, gave the hosts the 2-0 victory they needed to stay in contention for a spot in next summer’s World Cup. Egypt and Algeria end the qualifying period tied and will now face off in a one game playoff at a neutral venue (in Sudan) on Wednesday, to decide which country will go to the World Cup. The goal came in the fifth minute of added time, just seconds before the match was due to end.

headline: Chief of NewYork-Presbyterian Will Retire in 2 Years
text: New York City’s largest private hospital announced Friday that its chief executive, one of the highest-paid hospital executives in the country, would be retiring in two years.

headline: Now Installing | Francesco Vezzoli Gets Gaga to MoCA
text: LOS ANGELES — Petit-point embroidery plays an important part in the artistic career of Francesco Vezzoli: his best-known works are serigraphs in which details of the images are hand-stitched in shocking colors. His big media debut was presenting Veruschka and himself embroidering in a three-day performance at the Venice Biennale many years ago.

headline: Invoking Departed Friends and the Flights They Took
text: Ulysses Dove, Rudolf Nureyev, Arnie Zane: these names and others fill a page in the program for Janis Brenner’s “5 Decades” show, which opened on Thursday night at the Joyce SoHo. And this list accounts for just a very few of the choreographers and dancers who died of AIDS during the 1980s and ’90s.

headline: New York on Less: Making Choices

headline: Chart: The Very Best’s Show
text: The Very Best is a band with a singer from Malawi and two D.J.’s and producers from London, and its music is a catchy blend of African, hip-hop and dance music. The band’s debut album, “Warm Heart of Africa,” was released last month and it’s one of the artist Andrew Kuo’s favorites the year. Here’s his report on the Very Best’s show at Santos Party House in Manhattan last week.

headline: More Than Ever, You Can Say That on Television
text: LOS ANGELES  On many nights this fall, it has been possible to tune in to broadcast network television during prime time and hear a character call someone else a “douche.”

headline: The Week in Pictures for Nov. 13
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week. Subjects include an artist at a dog run, the Veterans Day Parade, and the anniversary of the crash of American Airlines Flight 587.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 13
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: In This Ring of the Circus, the Amazing Risk Tamers
text: How much you enjoy “Inside Out,” the moody blend of modern and traditional circus by the Swedish troupe Cirkus Cirkör depends to a large degree on whether you’ve recently seen Cirque du Soleil. This tastefully appointed spectacle, which imagines two risk-averse ordinary people loosening up upon meeting a talented troupe of acrobats, jugglers and clowns, once again polishes up sideshow antics with an arty sheen. But next to similar efforts by Cirque du Soleil, a French Canadian juggernaut that is a frequent visitor to this city, this new production can seem beside the point. By comparison, the bag of tricks of Cirkus Cirkör’s jittery ringleader (Fredrik Deijfen, looking like Jeeves dipped in white paint) is skimpy, the show’s pacing slack, and the leaps and stunts awfully modest.

headline: Patricia Racette as Cio-Cio-San
text: Patricia Racette as Cio-Cio-San, with Maria Zifchak as Suzuki in Anthony Minghella's production of "Madama Butterfly," at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: New Web Services Turn Ticket Buying Into a Social Occasion
text: Nothing in the concert industry has evolved more significantly than how people buy tickets, from the days of walk-up box offices to Ticketmaster’s network of call centers to the almost entirely Internet-based technology of today, in which seats by the thousands can disappear in an instant.

headline: Wanted: People Willing to Lead the European Union
text: BRUSSELS  The position will undoubtedly bring prestige, limitless travel and the chance to head a network of European Union diplomats stretching around the globe. Yet none of Europe’s big three powers in foreign policy  Britain, France and Germany  appear to want it.

headline: Ex-Louisiana Congressman Sentenced to 13 Years
text: WASHINGTON  Former Representative William J. Jefferson, a New Orleans Democrat whose political career once seemed to hold high promise, was sentenced Friday to 13 years in prison for using his office to try to enrich himself and his relatives.

headline: For Madoff Auction, Even Jewels Lack Luster

headline: Classic Ad: Saab 95

In that spirit, this week’s classic ad comes from Europe, complete with a starchy early-’60s British-television voice-over.

headline: To Remain Unbeaten, Know When to Play Low
text: The Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Teams is one of the most enjoyable events on the Greater New York Bridge Association calendar. Each team has to lose twice to be eliminated. The winners this year, for the second time in three years, were Franco Baseggio, Andrew Stark, Simon Erlich and Jeff Rothstein of New York; Arch McKellar of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.; and Ken Jacobs of Upper Saddle River, N.J.

headline: Correction: A New Attack on the Iraq War Film
