text: Even after a $700 million settlement with the federal government, JPMorgan Chase still faces troubles in Alabama.

headline: Playing Connect the Dots, From Aphrodite to Lil’ Kim
text: In “SoloShow,” the second half of a diptych of solos, the choreographer Maria Hassabi plays with contrasting viewpoints so subtly that at first it’s difficult to see what has changed since the first piece. There are some cosmetic alterations: instead of the compact first-floor theater at Performance Space 122, where the first work, “Solo,” was presented in September as part of the Crossing the Line festival, the new dance takes place in the larger upstairs theater. A Persian rug is replaced by an austere platform stage, and gradually it’s apparent that the mood has painstakingly shifted from warm to cool.

headline: Suspect in Ft. Hood Case Is Said to Be Paralyzed
text: KILLEEN, Tex.  The Army psychiatrist charged with killing 13 people in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood appears to be paralyzed from the waist down as a result of his bullet wounds, his lawyer said Friday.

headline: That 1940s Feeling at a Poconos Roadhouse
text: Jim Farmer must have had some bizarre experiences in restaurants or in the Poconos  or both  over the years. At least that is the impression left by his daffy play “The Supper Club of Lost Causes,” a fractured look at faded glory that is being given a strange, smart production at Theater for the New City.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: Events in Westchester
text: Film

headline: Events on Long Island
text: Film

headline: Robert Johnson’s House to Rise Again
text: The fabled crossroads where Robert Johnson is supposed to have sold his soul to the Devil in exchange for his guitar prowess has not been definitively located, but the musician’s birthplace has been determined, and plans are in the works to restore it as a tourist attraction, The Associated Press reported. Johnson, the blues guitarist of “Sweet Home Chicago” and “Love in Vain” who influenced artists from Muddy Waters to Eric Clapton, was born in 1911 in Hazlehurst, Miss., in a home built by his stepfather. The birthplace was verified in a letter from his half-sister, according to the cultural affairs office of Copiah County, which is seeking to raise $250,000 to restore the home as a destination for music fans and Johnson acolytes. “He was so good that he would literally turn his back when they were recording him,” said the screenwriter Jimmy White (“Ray”), who is working on a script about Mr. Johnson’s life. “He didn’t want the other musicians to see his fingering technique.”

headline: Record Sales for Modern Warfare 2, but Gaming Business Declines
text: It was an up-and-down week of news for the video gaming business. On the upside, the debut of the highly anticipated shooting game Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 set a sales record for the industry, Variety reported: the game, which retails for $59.99, sold 4.7 million units in its first day on sale in the United States and Britain, taking in $310 million for the game publisher Activision Blizzard. (By comparison, the year’s highest-grossing movie, “Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen,” had earned more than $200 million domestically by the end of its first weekend.) On the downside, the industry saw its overall sales decline during October, compared with the same month last year, according to a report from NPD Group. Sales of hardware, software and accessories totaled $1.07 billion for October 2009, down 19 percent from the $1.32 billion in sales in October 2008. NPD predicted that the industry’s revenues for the year would be from $20 billion to $21 billion, most likely down from last year’s tally of $21.3 billion, though coming releases like New Super Mario Bros. Wii and Assassin’s Creed 2 could still turn things around.

headline: It’s Official: MGM Is Back in Play
text: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is officially back on the block.

headline: Biden to Appear on ‘Daily Show’
text: Having hosted the likes of Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, and Ray Mabus, the secretary of the Navy, “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” will take another step up the White House chain of command on Tuesday: that night Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is scheduled to appear on the satirical news show, Comedy Central said on Friday in a news release. It will be the first time Mr. Biden has appeared on “The Daily Show” since he was elected vice president; he has previously appeared on the show twice, including on Jan. 31, 2007, the day he announced he was seeking the Democratic presidential nomination. President Barack Obama appeared on the show on Oct. 29, 2008, just before winning the election.

headline: Barnes Foundation Breaks Ground For New Home In Philadelphia
text: After years of battles over the Barnes Foundation’s plan to bypass its charter and bylaws and move its art collection from suburban Merion, Pa., to downtown Philadelphia, the foundation broke ground on Friday for its new home, designed by the architects Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. A 2004 court ruling permitted the foundation, which has struggled financially, to go against the wishes of Albert C. Barnes, who built the collection and stipulated that no picture in it could be lent, sold or moved from the walls of the galleries that he built for it in Merion. Judge Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans’ Court said in the ruling that he considered the move “the only viable alternative” to save the Barnes from bankruptcy. But opponents  a couple dozen of whom protested on Friday morning outside the groundbreaking ceremony, above, waving signs with messages including: “Crime Scene. Do Not Enter. Destruction of National Historic Landmark in Progress”  contend that the collection’s financial troubles are surmountable and that the move is motivated primarily by the Philadelphia political establishment’s desire to generate more downtown tourism. “This is not about art  it’s about politics,” said Evelyn Yaari, a member of Friends of the Barnes Foundation, which organized the protest.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: Comedy

headline: Munch Work Is Stolen in Norway
text: Thieves in Norway stole a rare lithograph by Edvard Munch on Thursday, Agence France-Presse reported. A police spokesman said on Friday that the robbers broke an art gallery window, grabbed the work, called “History,” right, and escaped. Though several lithographs of the work exist, the one that was stolen had been hand-colored by Munch himself. It sold at an auction in 2001 for about $35,000, but Agence France-Presse reported the current value at more than 10 times that amount, about $355,000. Munch artwork has been targeted by thieves before: in 2004 two armed masked men burst into the Munch museum in Oslo in daylight and stole “The Scream” and “Madonna” paintings before escaping in a getaway car driven by a third man. Ten years earlier another version of “The Scream” was stolen from Oslo’s national gallery on the opening day of the Lillehammer Winter Olympics. The works were recovered in both cases.

headline: Third Time Lucky for ‘CSI’
text: CBS’s “CSI” earned its highest ratings of the season on Thursday with the conclusion of a crossover plot line that involved episodes of “CSI: Miami” and “CSI: NY” the same week. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the final episode of the “CSI” trilogy drew the largest audience of the three shows, with 16.9 million viewers at 9 p.m. on Thursday, enough to lead the night over all in the ratings. CBS’s “Survivor: Samoa” also delivered its best ratings of the season, leading the 8 o’clock hour with 13.2 million viewers. CBS won the night, and ABC placed second with “FlashForward” (8.3 million), “Grey’s Anatomy” (14.4 million) and “Private Practice” (10.2 million). Fox was third with “Bones” (9.8 million) and “Fringe” (5.9 million), and NBC was fourth with its comedy lineup.

headline: Washington: Gateses Give to Own Foundation
text: Bill and Melinda Gates, the couple behind one of the world’s largest foundations, said they would give the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation $350 million to help cover the costs of building its new campus in Seattle. The foundation broke ground on the 12-acre campus more than a year ago, and it is about 40 percent complete, The Seattle Times reported. About 11,000 of its total 90,000 square feet will house a visitors center, and roughly 800 employees will occupy the rest. The gift will cover 70 percent of the projected $500 million cost of the new facilities and means the foundation will have $350 million more to devote to its work to improve global health, global development and American education.

headline: Suicides Increase Among Troops
text: There have been 133 suspected suicides among active-duty Army troops this year, putting the service within reach of a new annual high. The suicides, between January and October and including the National Guard and Reserves, compared with 115 in the same period in 2008. That year the service recorded 140 by year’s end, an annual record, the Army said. The rate of suicide within the Army last year was 20.2 per 100,000 personnel, exceeding for the first time the age-adjusted rate in the civilian population, which was 19.2, according to the National Institute of Mental Health.

headline: Beyond White Meat and Market Freezers
text: THE centerpiece of the original Thanksgiving table was probably not a 20-pound roaster, but a much smaller, leaner game bird  like the ones that Connecticut farmers and a few select stores around the state are offering as alternatives to the big birds now crowding supermarket freezers.

headline: Food Agency Delays Ban on Oysters After Outcry
text: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration on Friday indefinitely delayed a ban on the sale of raw oysters harvested on the Gulf Coast during warm months in the face of opposition from the oyster industry and legislators from the region.

headline: Home of the Mouse Finds Box Office Success in the Land of the Bear
text: MOSCOW  They were all there on screen: Ivan and the mountain queen; Baba Yaga, the witch, who lives in a cottage perched on chicken feet; and even Kashchei the Immortal, who keeps his mortality locked in a goose’s egg.

headline: Worried About Losing Tax Revenue, Congress to Investigate Airlines’ Fees
text: When airlines charge extra fees, are they really just another fare increase in disguise?

headline: Bloggingheads: If Israel Strikes Iran
text: Joe Klein, left, of Time and David Frum of FrumForum debate the possible repercussions of an Israeli attack on Iran's nuclear sites.

headline: Exotic and Familiar at an Afghan Grill
text: WE were on our way to the Afghan Grill Kabob House in New Hyde Park when one of our party admitted that he knew nothing about Afghan food and was worried about whether he would like it. In fact, anyone who likes Greek or Turkish cooking will find similar dishes here: grilled meats, kebabs, hummus, lots of eggplant and chopped salads. Yet there is enough exotic fare to make a meal exciting, and the food is delicious.

headline: Struggling Japan Airlines Reports a $357 Million Loss
text: TOKYO  Japan Airlines posted a loss of 32.2 billion yen ($357 million) in the latest quarter and said it was in new talks to suspend loan payments as it awaited formal approval for a government-led bailout.

headline: Big Juicy Steaks, Hold the Guilt
text: THOSE lush expense-account-driven power lunches and dinners of the 50s and 60s portrayed so accurately in AMC’s popular TV series “Mad Men” may have something to do with a renewed interest in the steakhouse  the kind of place that was once de rigueur for carefree big spenders who favored them probably as much for the large portions of familiar ingredients (nothing hidden under fancy French sauces) as for the quality of the beef. A steakhouse meal in those days might include a tomato-and-onion salad, a mighty porterhouse, baked potato, creamed spinach and cheesecake, plus a few martinis to wash it all down.

headline: Terrorists on Trial; Counterterrorism, Too
text: One great thing about the Internet is that there is virtually no issue on which you could say bloggers are unanimous. Flat earth? Has its defenders. (And not just in the Friedmanesque sense.) Man on the moon? Has its skeptics. Boxcar Willie is a reptilian pedophile intent on ruling the earth? Of course!

headline: Saving Sea Turtles, One Nest at a Time
text: Global warming and coastal development are decimating Pacific sea turtle populations. In Costa Rica, a group of one-time poachers is giving baby sea turtles a chance at survival.

headline: State of Desperation
text: This helps put things into perspective:

headline: A World of Ways to Get That Grilled Taste
text: WHEN Carlos Teixeira bought Burnet BBQ in Union about 15 years ago, most of the customers for his heaping platters of flame-grilled chicken and ribs were Portuguese.

headline: Kramnik Retains Lead at Tal Memorial; Carlsen Notches First Win
text: Vladimir Kramnik closes in on title at elite Moscow tournament.

headline: To Offset the Fall Chill
text: Right around the time that autumn’s deepening chill calls for a warming red wine, Macari Vineyards is introducing a new Bordeaux-style blend, Dos Aguas ($26.99), or Two Waters, from 2007, a good vintage.

headline: Gooey, but Grown-Up
text: Provisions is a delightful eat-in and take-out cafe that specializes in made-from-scratch sandwiches like roast turkey with homemade cranberry sauce on apple-cranberry bread and tuna salad spread between thick slices of jalapeño cheddar. The only cold cut you will find in the place is the high-end prosciutto, served with roasted pears and goat cheese.

headline: Swiss Say Google’s Street View Is Too Revealing
text: Swiss officials said Friday that they had sued Google to try to require it to tighten privacy safeguards on its Street View online service. It is the latest of a series of European objections to the company’s handling of personal information.

headline: Recession Over in Euro Zone, Report Says
text: PARIS  After more than a year in the doldrums, the euro area emerged from recession during the third quarter, helped largely by export growth and improved industrial production in Germany.

headline: Going for the Bling: Hollywood Burglars
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Outsourcing Jobs Arrive in Rural Areas
text: A handful of entrepreneurs are bringing outsourcing jobs to rural areas in India that have been largely cut off from its economic rise.

headline: Finally, a Videophone That’s Practical for All
text: Over the years videophones have come and gone, like so many reruns of “The Jetsons.” But none has gained any traction among consumers because they have been impractical and costly. A couple of years ago, for instance, I was impressed with the $350 Motorola Ojo. Video call quality was great, but the device required that each user buy a videophone — and pay a monthly service fee.

headline: Philips Moves Into High-Tech Skin Care
text: Do women want to discuss their skin problems with online strangers? Philips, the Dutch lighting, health care and electronics company, is betting they do. Social networking about skin care is a key element in the company’s new consumer product, Crystalize.

headline: Oreo the Abused Pit Bull Is Euthanized
text: Oreo, a dog that was nursed back to health after surviving being thrown off the roof of a six-story building, was killed Friday by lethal injection.

headline: As the Rudes Get Ruder, the Scolds Get Scoldier
text: DO two rudes make a polite?

headline: A Product (You Think) You’ll Never Need
text: For middle-aged healthy adults, it’s disheartening the first time you realize you need reading glasses. Because once you do, you can no longer hide under the illusion that you’re young.

headline: 40 Miles of Creative Spaces
text: In 2001, six eastern Connecticut artists joined forces to do a little promotion, opening their studios to the public on the same weekend. Now, eight years later, their little promotion has become a big deal around Branford, Guilford and Madison.

headline: Sending Up Show Business, Not to Mention Politics
text: It’s tempting  very tempting  to share some of the laugh lines in the play Craig Wright has so tellingly named “Mistakes Were Made.” But it would be a mistake. Without the desperate delivery of the star of the Hartford Stage production, Will LeBow, the jokes would lose much of their zing. So I will refrain from quoting the text and quote the set instead.

headline: Navy’s Vieques Training May Be Tied to Health Risks
text: The federal agency that assesses health hazards at sites designated for Superfund environmental cleanups said Friday that it had reversed its conclusion that contamination at a former United States Navy training ground in Puerto Rico posed no health risks to residents.

headline: Fragile Care Worsened Swine Flu in Ukraine
text: LVIV, Ukraine  When patients began arriving in Vyacheslav Bonder’s intensive care unit two weeks ago, their lungs so saturated with blood that they could barely gasp, the only thing he could compare it to was a field hospital in wartime. As soon as he hooked one patient up to a ventilator, a second and third would appear in the doorway.

headline: Quite Big in Britain, Not Quite in the U.S.
text: That the artist Tracey Emin had asked to be interviewed at her hotel swimming pool and showed up in a bathing suit would probably mean more to readers in her native England, where her self-revelatory and at times exhibitionist tendencies are well known. They have helped make her an object of public fascination there  a national celebrity, in fact  for more than a decade.

headline: Deal on Quick Blood Test if Breath Test Is Refused
text: The New York Police Department and the city’s five district attorneys have reached a preliminary agreement on a new procedure they believe will allow the police to more quickly get warrants to take the blood of drivers who refuse breath tests, a department spokesman said Friday.

headline: Dell Will Introduce a Smartphone
text: Dell confirmed on Friday what has been bouncing around the market for some time: it is entering the smartphone business.

headline: Late-Night Revolution? In Taste, Perhaps
text: “The revolution starts right now!” George Lopez proclaimed on Monday on the premiere of “Lopez Tonight,” his new 11 p.m. talk show on TBS. After watching the program’s first week, it was hard to see what exactly the revolution consisted of.

headline: Obama Walks a Delicate Tightrope on His 1st Trip as President to China
text: SHANGHAI  Against the backdrop of a tentative global recovery, President Obama and China’s leaders will meet in Beijing next week to discuss how to improve relations between the world’s reigning economic superpower and its greatest challenger.

headline: Online Visions by Long Island Public TV
text: Sweeping aerial views, a documentary on going green locally and a three-part series examining the exodus of young professionals from Long Island are among the offerings produced by WLIW available at a new video portal on the public television station’s Web site.

headline: After Independence, the Search for Self
text: “Indian Art After Independence: Selected Works from the Collections of Virginia and Ravi Akhoury and Shelley and Donald Rubin,” a small but engaging show at the Hofstra University Museum, illustrates how Indian artists embraced modernity after the end of British rule in 1947. About 20 paintings and drawings are on view, a few predating independence and all on loan from two private New York collections.

headline: Mistrial Request Rejected in Ex-State Senator’s Trial
text: ALBANY  Lawyers for Joseph L. Bruno requested a mistrial on Friday, a day after the judge presiding over Mr. Bruno’s corruption trial scolded the former State Senate leader for appearing to criticize one of the judge’s rulings.

headline: The San Francisco Green Festival: Windy Web Hosting and Fizzy Chai
text: In today’s world of greenistential and omnivoric dilemmas, you’re no longer just what you eat, but what you buy, what you wear and what you consume.

headline: Vials of 5 Genzyme Drugs for Rare Diseases May Be Contaminated, F.D.A. Says
text: Vials of five different Genzyme drugs for rare diseases may be contaminated with tiny particles of steel, rubber or fiber that could potentially harm patients, the Food and Drug Administration warned Friday.

headline: Minister Grows Up, Yet Ministry Stays Young
text: One Sunday morning in 1994, Din Tolbert brought his gangly frame to the altar of a chapel in Queens. Then 12 years old, he wore a blue suit from the Salvation Army, his only decent church clothes, and the white tube socks were his unwitting trademark as a geek. In most parts of his life, he willingly took on the positions of listener and watcher, what he later termed “the back role in the back row.”

headline: Dysfunctional Delights
text: David Lee White’s “Blood: A Comedy” couldn’t be cleverer as it deals with the onset of Alzheimer’s disease, a soap-opera-style family shocker and reflections on the existence of God.

headline: Burdened by Billions in Debt, MGM Puts Itself Up for Sale
text: LOS ANGELES  Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is back on the block.

headline: Violence Flares Ahead of Algeria-Egypt Soccer Match
text: On The Lede Blog, The New York Times’s Robert Mackey examines the tense back-story behind the upcoming soccer match between Algeria and Egypt:

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 907 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following American on Thursday:

headline: A Teacher’s Dream Gets to the Screen
text: SUMMIT

headline: A Tribute to Kinship and Nostalgia
text: When the Smithereens play the Community Theater at Mayo Center for the Performing Arts in Morristown on Saturday, the front man, Pat DiNizio, expects the prevailing mood to be one of bonhomie and kinship.

headline: China Focuses on Territorial Issues as It Equates Tibet to U.S. Civil War South
text: BEIJING  The Chinese government had a special message for President Obama on Thursday: He is black, he admires Abraham Lincoln, so he, of all people, should sympathize with Beijing’s effort to prevent Tibet from seceding and sliding back into what it was before its liberation by Chinese troops: a feudalistic, slaveholding society headed by the Dalai Lama.

headline: Grieving, and Asking When the Pain Will End
text: Life looks normal at Becca’s house in Larchmont. She’s standing at the kitchen table, folding freshly laundered children’s clothes and listening to her single sister’s latest crazy anecdote.

headline: Ohio Is First to Change to One Drug in Executions
text: Breaking ranks with the 35 other states that use lethal injections to execute prisoners, Ohio on Friday became the first state to say it would switch to a single drug, rather than a three-drug cocktail, in its death penalty procedure.

headline: Young Star, Old Master and a Fresh Take on Mozart
text: AFTER more than four decades atop the musical food chain, Itzhak Perlman is not easily impressed. But when Mr. Perlman, the revered violinist and conductor, first heard the clarinetist Anthony McGill, he said, he was “kind of blown away.”

headline: Changing Sex With a Step, a Wink and a Video
text: There are times when a money-back guarantee for a new show would seem not so much a philistine idea as a vital safeguard. It wouldn’t apply to artists whose risks don’t pan out; audiences have to take risks, too, if they are interested in following an art form as it zigzags forward.

headline: A Recovery for Some
text: President Obama’s strongest supporters during the presidential campaign were the young, the black and the poor  and they are among those who are being hammered unmercifully in this long and cruel economic downturn that the financial elites are telling us is over.

headline: On the Street | Colors
text: Autumn’s last hurrah is to be seen all over the city, as pools of leaves fall to the ground. Stylish women are wearing many points of view -- so long as it’s black with a touch of white.

headline: Concern at a School in a Building Tied to Iran
text: Outside the Razi School on Queens Boulevard, a television truck idled all day. Images of the ordinarily quiet school were beaming across the nation, spotlighting it as the tenant of a building that federal authorities were trying to seize because they believed the owner illegally funneled money to Iran.

headline: 6 Therapists at Bellevue Forced Out Over Hours
text: Six therapists have been forced to resign from Bellevue Hospital Center, New York City’s premier public hospital, after an investigation into the falsification of time sheets, hospital officials said on Friday.

headline: Marijuana Moves Into the Open in a Ski Town
text: BRECKENRIDGE, Colo.  High-altitude partying is a deeply carved tradition in ski country, where alcohol in the open and illicit drugs in the shadows have been intertwined for years.

headline: Love for a Dog That’s No Bark and All Yodel
text: Donut the French bulldog was sitting outside Starbucks. Romeo was perusing the produce at the Korean market down the street, and Jack was going to see Oskar for a play date. Oh yes, Oskar was in his usual spot, sunning himself on his little red bed in the window of the Jumping Bulldog, the chic dog and cat boutique named after him.

headline: 9/11 Trial Poses Unparalleled Legal Obstacles
text: WASHINGTON  How do you defend one of the most notorious terrorist figures in history?

headline: Contract Talks Likely to Test Matsui’s Calm
text: Hideki Matsui has always been the good son. When he lost his temper as a youngster and was upbraided by his coach, Matsui vowed never get angry in a game again. When he came to New York for the first time before joining the Yankees, he visited ground zero to pay his respects.

headline: How New York May Tighten Security Vise
text: Convoys of heavily armed officers, fields of barricades and additional checkpoints are likely to sprout in and around the jail where the accused will be housed and the courthouse where they will be tried. Access to nearby streets and areas may be sealed off. And bands of plainclothes officers  “people in civilian clothes with earplugs,” as one former law enforcement official put it  will probably be scanning the crowds to spot anyone with ill intent.

headline: Obama Chooses an Inner-Circle Man
text: WASHINGTON  In being named White House counsel less than a year into President Obama’s tenure, Robert F. Bauer is reversing a longstanding trend.

headline: Once Again, Into the Apocalypse
text: A lot of people are worrying about the world coming to an end in 2012.

headline: Forces Aligning in Bid to Block Cuts in Albany
text: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson is imploring the Legislature to finally reckon with the state’s ugly financial reality.

headline: On a Digital Refrigerator, an Art Gallery for the Young
text: Since March, The Times has run two hyper-local blogs, one about Brooklyn and one about New Jersey, creating virtual community hubs where neighbors report on their own neighborhoods. A regular feature on The Local is a virtual “fridge” displaying children’s art, held up with digital magnets. “We promise they won’t fall off when the magnets get old, and they won’t get stained by the ice dispenser,” Tina Kelley, the anchor of The Local in Maplewood, Millburn and South Orange, N.J., wrote in announcing the series.

headline: An Arms Dealer Returns, Now Selling an Image
text: CAIRO

headline: Dangerous Substance: Sample With Care
text: He captured the world’s attention and it intoxicated him.

headline: The Passion of the Right
text: In 354 days, the dead will rise. Or so believe Republicans.

headline: The Young and the Reckless
text: ON Monday, the United States Supreme Court heard oral arguments in two cases that ask whether sentencing a juvenile to life in prison without the possibility of parole is a violation of the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition of cruel and unusual punishment.

headline: William Ganz, Catheter Inventor, Dies at 90
text: Dr. William Ganz, a cardiologist and medical inventor who helped develop a revolutionary catheter to measure blood flow and heart functions, died Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 90.

headline: T.C.U. Fans Are Singing Football Coach’s Praises
text: FORT WORTH  In seventh grade, Texas Christian Coach Gary Patterson was the lead singer and guitarist in a band named Walk On Easy.

headline: Bruce King, 3-Term Governor, Dies at 85
text: Bruce King, who rose from a rough-hewn, rural upbringing on the family ranch to become the only three-term governor of New Mexico, died Friday at his ranch, larger now but still in the same place, in Stanley, N.M. He was 85.

headline: Russian Deal on Afghan Supply Route Not Done Yet
text: WASHINGTON  When he met President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia in April, President Obama sought to open an important new supply corridor for Afghanistan by flying American troops and weapons through Russian airspace. Visiting Moscow in July, he sealed a deal for as many as 4,500 flights a year, in what he called a “substantial contribution” to the war and a sign of improving relations with Russia.

headline: Breaks of the Game
text: “THEATER dressing rooms are my home away from home  my second home, really,” Cheyenne Jackson said, surveying his 14-by-8-foot nook after a curtain call for the Broadway revival of “Finian’s Rainbow.” A round bed embroidered with the name Zora, for his Rottweiler/Lab mix, lay beneath a counter crowded with makeup and hair products. A childhood photo of Monte Lapka, his partner since 1999, hung on a wall.

headline: Polls Predicted a Bloomberg Blowout, but Expert Knew Better
text: More than three months ago, Bruce N. Gyory was telling anyone who would listen, including advisers to both mayoral campaigns, that while Michael R. Bloomberg was favored to win, his margin would not be more than five to seven percentage points.

headline: Lottery Numbers
President Obama Speaks in Japan
text: On his inaugural trip to Asia, President Obama told the Japanese that the United States is "a nation of the Pacific."

headline: A Return to American Justice
text: Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. took a bold and principled step on Friday toward repairing the damage wrought by former President George W. Bush with his decision to discard the nation’s well-established systems of civilian and military justice in the treatment of detainees captured in antiterrorist operations.

headline: Never Too Old to Act Young
text: A JUGGLER on a unicycle wobbles past a cluster of clubgoers, deftly avoiding a collision that might spill their candy-color cocktails down the front of premium-label jeans. A clown on stilts hobbles past a table full of neatly coiffed men with untucked dress shirts who don’t even look up from their drinks. It’s hard enough to project an air of unwavering cool at New York nightclubs. It’s even harder to do so in the presence of a clown.

headline: Deserves a Deal
text: Joe Krozel is like a figure skater who is always adding just one more dangerous twist in order to boldly go where no cruciverbalist has gone before. Today he tries his own version of the “Iron Lotus.” Will he survive? More important, will the crossword survive as a viable puzzle, meaning a fair and fun experience?

headline: Correction: Evening Hours | Lions in Autumn
text: The Evening Hours column last Sunday misspelled the surname of the longtime Manhattan district attorney, who was an honoree at a New York Landmarks Conservancy event on Nov. 4. He is Robert M. Morgenthau, not Morganthau.

headline: Turtles Are Casualties of Warming in Costa Rica
text: PLAYA GRANDE, Costa Rica  This resort town was long known for Leatherback Sea Turtle National Park, nightly turtle beach tours and even a sea turtle museum. So Kaja Michelson, a Swedish tourist, arrived with high expectations. “Of course we’re hoping to see turtles  that is part of the appeal,” she said.

headline: Campus Elections in Lebanon Mirror Society’s Politics
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  For a brief moment, it looked as if civil war would break out on campus. Two clusters of excited young people faced off as the student election results came in: Hezbollah allies on one side, and right-wing Christian zealots on the other.

headline: The Job of Finding a New Job
text: How do you know when it’s time to change careers? Perhaps you no longer feel energized about new projects or you’ve lost confidence in your boss.

headline: After Lubavitcher Tragedy, Spiritual Rebirth
text: Emissaries of the Chabad-Lubavitch movement are a hardy lot  part envoys, part pioneers  who agree to settle anywhere in the world where their leaders decide that Jewish communities need bolstering, whether in Anchorage or Bangkok or northern Kyrgyzstan.

headline: That $35 Cup of Coffee
text: Federal regulators have a long and distressing history of talking about predatory banking practices while doing little to end them. The Federal Reserve Board’s new rules aimed at protecting unsuspecting holders of debit cards from multiple overdraft fees are, at best, half-measures.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about questions over the shooting of Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan at Fort Hood referred incorrectly to an appearance on the “Oprah Winfrey Show” on Wednesday by Senior Sgt. Mark Todd, a police officer who was involved in stopping Mr. Hasan. Sergeant Todd had been interviewed previously by The Associated Press and had appeared on CNN; his interview with Ms. Winfrey was not his first public comment.

headline: Turkey Plans to Ease Restrictions on Kurds and Help End Decades of Conflict
text: ISTANBUL  After months of dialogue, the Turkish government announced a plan on Friday to help end the quarter-century-long conflict with a Kurdish separatist movement that has cost more than 40,000 lives.

headline: Trauma Surgeon of Wall Street
text: IRVINGTON, N.Y.

headline: Corrections
text: A chart on Friday with the continuation of an article about cancer prevention misstated the name of a widely ignored drug that has been shown to lower the risk of prostate cancer. As the article noted, it is dutasteride  not duasteride or cuasteride.

headline: Wild Spaces, Street Patterns and a Splashdown
text: IF Ken Burns’s recent television series on America’s national parks has you craving natural splendor, the city is a perfect if surprising place to look. For proof, look no further than to “Legacy: The Preservation of Wilderness in New York City Parks” (Aperture, $65), by Joel Meyerowitz.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about the Los Angeles Philharmonic’s new music director, Gustavo Dudamel, gave an incorrect date in some editions for the orchestra’s first performance last week of Verdi’s Requiem. It was Thursday night, not Friday night.

headline: Dallas Basketball Player Is Hero in Europe
text: TBILISI, Georgia  During the war between Georgia and Russia last year, many Georgians felt abandoned when their closest ally, the United States, did not enter the conflict. But they remained steadfast in their support of Tyrone Ellis, a basketball player from Dallas. On the court, Ellis did something his fellow Americans had not done during the war: He fought for Georgia, and he won.

headline: Rockaways Surf and Downtown Turf
text: Steve Rodriguez, 38, started skateboarding on the streets of Greenwich Village as a kid and never put his board away. He still skates every day (barring major cold snaps) and is an advocate for the skateboard community. In 1996, Mr. Rodriguez founded 5boro, which makes and distributes skateboards, wheels and clothing. Sundays for Mr. Rodriguez, who lives in the Village, typically start with a trip to Rockaway Beach with his wife, Hiroko Rodriguez. LIZETTE ALVAREZ

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Friday with an article about General Motors’ efforts to change its corporate culture misidentified the automobile shown. It is a Camaro, not a Chevrolet Cruze.

headline: Obama, in Japan, Says U.S. Will Study Status of a Marine Base on Okinawa
text: TOKYO  President Obama, seeking to mend fences with Japan, America’s most important Asian ally, announced Friday that he would establish a high-level working group on the contentious issue of the continuing presence of a Marine base on Okinawa.

headline: Corrections

The entry about a student in Philadelphia who attended the parade in the spirit of his grandmother, a Yankees fan who died during the All-Star break, was by Ravi Somaiya  not by Daniel E. Slotnik, who contributed another entry.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Page 25 this weekend about the organist Cameron Carpenter misstates the time of his concert next Saturday at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin near Times Square. The performance starts at 3 p.m.; it is not Saturday evening.

headline: Golfer Asks for Restraining Order on Doping Suspension
text: A lawyer for the suspended PGA Tour player Doug Barron said Friday that he was optimistic that a federal court judge would rule this weekend that Barron be allowed to compete in the second stage of PGA Tour qualifying school next week.

headline: Corrections
text: The Practical Traveler column on Page 8 this weekend, about deals and discounts on Caribbean hotels, using information from a publicist, refers incorrectly to the cost this year for the seven-nights-for-the-price-of-five deal at Parrot Cay in the Turks and Caicos. The price of $4,650 in January was the same as last year’s price  not higher. (The price quoted for last year, $3,875, omitted taxes and fees; with those, the cost comes to $4,650.)

headline: Better to Have Loved and Lost? Don’t Be So Sure
text: It’s impossible to describe that sickening mix of restlessness and lethargy  that apathetic frenzy  that comes with the loss of love. That’s why screenplays, dramas, novels and, especially, poems are constantly written about such stuff.

headline: Respect for Rape Victims
text: A promising bipartisan bill introduced this week in the Senate addresses a stubborn scandal: the enormous backlog of untested rape kits, which contain the physical evidence obtained from sexual assault victims.

headline: Root Hold
text: This time of year, I nearly come to terms with entropy. The grass has stopped growing, and so has the wild mint and spotted touch-me-knot. The snow hasn’t begun to fall. Most of the firewood is stacked, as is the hay. The thistle-down has blown, milkweed ditto. The leaves are down. That’s about as organized as it gets around here.

headline: Losing Shoppers in the City

headline: New Jersey: A Bad August

headline: Terms of Digital Book Deal With Google Revised
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Google and groups representing book publishers and authors filed a modified version of their controversial books settlement with a federal court on Friday. The changes would pave the way for other companies to license Google’s vast digital collection of copyrighted out-of-print books, and might resolve its conflicts with European governments.

headline: At Monmouth, Thomas Comes Close Enough to Hear Boos

headline: Mets Will Hire Backman to Manage Brooklyn Cyclones
text: After five years in exile, Wally Backman is making a return to a Major League Baseball affiliate with the Mets, the club that originally drafted him and brought him into professional ball. The Mets will name Backman, their fiery former second baseman, as manager of the Brooklyn Cyclones, their Class A affiliate, early next week.

headline: A Troubling Time for Turtles

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Kovalchuk on the Mend for Two More Goals

headline: China: Temple Web Site Attacked
text: The Web site of the famed Shaolin Temple was attacked this week by hackers looking to criticize the lifestyle of the temple’s abbot, Shi Yongxin, according to a report on Friday in China Daily, the official English-language newspaper. The temple’s home page was replaced with a fake home page early Wednesday that showed Mr. Shi sitting in yellow robes with text below him saying that he was apologizing for pursuing a material life. “I traded the monastery’s tranquillity and holy Buddhism for the fame of Shaolin and myself,” said one line. Mr. Shi has led the temple, a venerable martial arts academy, for 10 years. He has established at least five businesses using the Shaolin name, and started a kung-fu reality television show in 2006, China Daily reported. EDWARD WONG

headline: Earl Coleman, Publisher and Poet, Dies at 93
text: Earl M. Coleman was a fledgling short-story writer and poet fresh out of the Army when he got the idea for a custom translation business in 1946. At a poetry workshop he organized, he got to talking with two students, one a French teacher, the other a German engineer.

headline: ‘The Network Was Shocked’

headline: ‘The Political Landscape’
text: Monologue |  Aired Friday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Hey, you guys it’s Friday the 13th. A lot of people are superstitious about the number 13. President Franklin Roosevelt refused to travel on the 13th of every month, would never host 13 guests at a dinner party either, and President Bush wasn’t allowed to see any movie rated PG-13.

headline: ‘A Giant Spruce Tree’
text: Monologue | Aired Friday night on CBS: Anyway, opening today, the movie 2012. It’s about the end of the world, and fantastic computer generated special affects to show the destruction of every single living being and structure on the planet. The world is ending and the apocalypse has arrived and still no health-care reform. Well, that’s too bad. That’s too bad.

headline: ‘His Historic Trip’

Next week, when President Obama is in China, he’s going to hold a meeting where he takes questions from Chinese citizens. Isn’t that cool? Yeah. Yeah. Their first question for Obama is expected to be, why would anyone have two daughters?

headline: Leaders Will Delay Deal on Climate Change
text: SINGAPORE  President Obama and other world leaders have decided to put off the difficult task of reaching a climate change agreement at a global climate conference scheduled for next month, agreeing instead to make it the mission of the Copenhagen conference to reach a less specific “politically binding” agreement that would punt the most difficult issues into the future.

headline: Job Security? Consider a Career in Health Care
text: For all the hand-wringing about the weaknesses of health care, one aspect of it has remained strong: its ability to provide jobs. In fact, health care employment has increased during the recession, while employment as a whole has declined, according to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: Delicate Knee Surgery Saved Matsui’s Season
text: When the Yankees fashion their diamond-crusted rings to commemorate their 2009 championship, they might consider making one for Dr. Scott Rodeo. Without his delicate surgical work, Hideki Matsui might not have been able to earn the World Series Most Valuable Player award.

headline: Workplace Gossip? Keep It to Yourself

We provide quality control for print jobs, call local customers to notify them their orders are ready and send sample packs to potential clients. We also help other departments with special projects and take turns sitting at the front desk, greeting customers and answering the phone.

headline: Is There a Method in Cellphone Madness?

headline: No Parade for Hans

headline: Memoir Is Palin’s Payback to McCain Campaign
text: “Going Rogue,” the title of Sarah Palin’s erratic new memoir, comes from a phrase used by a disgruntled McCain aide to describe her going off-message during the presidential campaign: among other things, for breaking with the campaign over its media strategy and its decision to pull out of Michigan, and for speaking out about reports that the Republican Party had spent more than $150,000 on fancy designer duds for her and her family.

headline: In Assessing Agassi, the Title Tells It All

headline: Five Thoughts On Early Games
text: 5. The Heisman Trophy race is even more muddled with Central Florida’s upset of Houston. Houston quarterback Case Keenum had decent numbers, 33 of 57 for three touchdowns and an interception, but it’s unlikely a quarterback could win the Heisman after his team lost to Texas El-Paso and U.C.F. There had been a strong argument coming into the game that Keenum had been the most outstanding player in the country this year. But fair or not, team success has become a huge factor in the Heisman Trophy race.

headline: In House, Many Spoke With One Voice: Lobbyists’
text: WASHINGTON  In the official record of the historic House debate on overhauling health care, the speeches of many lawmakers echo with similarities. Often, that was no accident.

headline: A Contemplation of War
text: It was a week to think about war, to talk about war; to thank those who fight — and grieve for those who might have had they not been gunned down on their own Army post in their own country. President Obama traveled to Fort Hood in Texas on Tuesday to stand as national eulogist for the 13 killed there, even as debate stirred over what to call the massacre: The act of a terrorist? The murderous rage of a misfit? On Wednesday, Veterans Day, Mr. Obama was at Arlington, walking among graves where “grief remains fresh” and meeting mourners. Later he met with his war council. Should he send 30,000 more troops to Afghanistan? Ten thousand? And on Friday, a reminder of what started it all: an announcement that five accused plotters in the 9/11 attacks would be tried in Manhattan.

headline: The Evolution of the God Gene
text: In the Oaxaca Valley of Mexico, the archaeologists Joyce Marcus and Kent Flannery have gained a remarkable insight into the origin of religion.

headline: How Old Is Old Enough?
text: This past week the Supreme Court heard arguments about whether children should ever be sentenced to life without parole for crimes that don’t involve murder.

headline: Quotations of the Week
text: “I’m sure there are a lot of people sitting in the shade at the Aspen Institute — my brother being one of them — who will tell you what the ideal plan is. Great, fascinating. You have the art of the possible measured against the ideal.”

headline: When Sartre Talked to Crabs (It Was Mescaline)
text: In a conversation in 1971 with John Gerassi, a political science professor at Queens College in New York, Jean-Paul Sartre recalled an experience with drugs in 1929 while attending the École Normale Supérieure, where he met Simone de Beauvoir, also known as Castor. “Talking With Sartre: Conversations and Debates,” a selection of interviews from the ’70s, is being published this month by Yale University Press. Here is an excerpt from Harper’s:

headline: Can Public Aid Really Help Business?
text: THE global financial crisis is prompting huge government interventions to stimulate the economies of the United States and many other nations. The burning question is this: Can public-sector initiatives in the private sector be successful, or are they inevitably doomed to failure?

headline: James R. Lilley, 81, Envoy in Tiananmen Era, Dies
text: WASHINGTON  James R. Lilley, a former intelligence officer and ambassador to China who viewed that country with a rare blend of pragmatism and love because of his childhood there, died Thursday at a Washington hospital. He was 81.

headline: Norwegian, 18, Is Youngest to Be Ranked No. 1 at Chess
text: The chess world has a new No. 1 player, Magnus Carlsen of Norway, and he is only 18 years old  the youngest player ever to hold the rank.

headline: In Radio Address, Republican Pans House Bill
text: The health care bill passed by the House isn’t good for what ails Americans or their country, Representative Mark Kirk of Illinois said on Saturday on behalf of the Republican Party.

headline: At Least 13 Die in a Bombing in Pakistan

headline: Prime Number
text: 12.4: The percentage of workers in unions last year, down from 20.1 percent in 1983, according to "The Changing Face of Labor, 1983-2008," a study by the Center for Economic Policy Research in Washington. Union membership is far less blue collar and factory-based than it was during its glory days. Thirty-eight percent of union workers now have four-year college degrees. Just 11 percent work in manufacturing, down from nearly 30 percent in the 1980s. Women account for more than 45 percent of the unionized work force. And nearly half of all union members work in public-sector jobs, up from 34 percent in 1983.

headline: In Congress, a Predicament for Abortion Supporters
text: The abortion issue has put members of Congress who support abortion rights in a quandary over the health care legislation.

headline: Investigators Study Tangle of Clues on Fort Hood Suspect
text: WASHINGTON  When Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan took his two handguns and headed for Fort Hood on Nov. 5, he left behind in his spartan apartment his new business cards. Now they are one more clue for investigators of the 13 killings he is charged with, hinting at the road not taken.

headline: Broaching Birth Control With Afghan Mullahs
text: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan  The mullahs stared silently at the screen. They shifted in their chairs and fiddled with pencils. Koranic verses flashed above them, but the topic was something that made everybody a little uncomfortable.

headline: Forest People May Lose Home in Kenyan Plan
text: MARASHONI, Kenya  With the stroke of a pen, the last of Kenya’s honey hunters may soon be homeless.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Devils Displace Capitals Atop East
text: Twelve games on Saturday, including a matinee in Ottawa. Here’s an interesting factoid: since the N.H.L. installed the postgame penalty-shootout tiebreaker at the start of the 2005-6 season, the Senators have done worse at it than any other team. Going into Saturday’s game against the Rangers, they had won 12 shootouts and lost 24. What would happen if they got into another? Hmm …

headline: Portrait of 9/11 ‘Jackal’ Emerges as He Awaits Trial
text: WASHINGTON  Not long after he was rousted from bed and seized in a predawn raid in Pakistan in March 2003, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed gave his captors two demands: He wanted a lawyer, and he wanted to be taken to New York.

headline: Unusual Partners Study Divisive Jerusalem Site
text: JERUSALEM  At the heart of this contested city, the holy site known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as Haram al-Sharif, or Noble Sanctuary, has become, for many, the epicenter of the conflict between Israel, the Palestinians and the wider Muslim world.

headline: Group Warns of Failing Effort to Manage Tuna and Sharks
text: Officials from countries fishing for tuna, sharks and other denizens of the Atlantic Ocean and adjacent seas are gathered in Recife, Brazil, where they are wrapping up the 21st annual session of talks under an international agreement aimed at restoring depleted stocks. There are few signs that science is guiding their decisions, observers said on Saturday.

headline: Penn Knuckles Down and Harvard Buckles
text: BOSTON  Harvard needed to shove aside the Penn defense late in Saturday’s game to gain less than a yard, score a touchdown and extend the suspense. But these are precisely the situations in which the Quakers are at their surliest.

headline: Mock Funeral for Venice Dramatizes Flight of Residents From City’s Heart
text: VENICE  At high noon on Saturday, a gondola bearing a hot-pink plywood coffin decked with yellow flowers made its way down the Grand Canal. Onlookers watched from the shore and shouted greetings from the Rialto Bridge before the boat alighted nearby in front of the Venice city hall.

headline: 2 U.S. Soldiers and a Contractor Are Killed in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two American service members and an American contractor were killed in two separate bombing attacks in Afghanistan on Friday, according to a statement from a NATO spokesman.

headline: Maine Town Is Riven by Housing Dispute
text: MILBRIDGE, Me.  Down a rural road where wood smoke spirals from chimneys in the settling twilight, a five-acre lot thick with spruce trees is the unlikely site of a dream deferred.

headline: Changing Uniforms to Help Veterans
text: On Nov. 10, 2004, Staff Sgt. Dan Nevins was on a combat mission in Iraq when an improved explosive device detonated beneath his vehicle, killing the driver and necessitating the amputation of Nevins’s left leg.

headline: Having Little, but Thanking America for Every Bit
text: The small apartment in Midwood, Brooklyn, is sunlit and tidy, with unmistakable touches of home. Photographs on bookshelves and walls depict long lives, mostly lived somewhere else. A large television shows programs in Russian. And on the days when his knobby fingers are not swollen with arthritis, Lev Rotnitskiy, 86, hammers tunes on a piano while his wife sings.

headline: Obama Backers Fear Opportunities to Reshape Judiciary Are Slipping Away
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama has sent the Senate far fewer judicial nominations than former President George W. Bush did in his first 10 months in office, deflating the hopes of liberals that the White House would move quickly to reshape the federal judiciary after eight years of Republican appointments.

headline: A Feast for Stomach and Eyes
text: By all rights, the narrow public plaza carved out of Broadway between 38th and 39th Streets should have been empty last week beyond the scurrying city walkers, their jackets buttoned and their collars turned high against a damp November chill. But Monday was an unseasonable 70 and sunny, and the makeshift pedestrian mall, with its tiny chairs and tables, was the perfect place to enjoy what easily might have been the last outdoor lunch of the year.

headline: Highlights From Sunday’s Bay Area Report
text: Vistas: Lands End | A recovering techie finds a new way of looking at things — mostly avian things — when she goes to Lands End. Noreen Weeden’s preferred vista is a place where she goes 20 times a year and where, over time, she can see different moments in the migrations and life cycles of the birds she loves.

headline: Fight Over Fischer’s Estate Is Taking Shape in Iceland

headline: A Once and Future Bay Area Redistricting Conundrum
text: Phillip Burton, the legendary San Francisco congressman, famously called it his “contribution to modern art.” Nearly 30 years later, Burton’s quip is perhaps better remembered than the piece he was describing: a congressional district he drew after the 1980 census to keep a seat in the United States House of Representatives safe for his younger brother, John.

headline: Universities Turn to Consultants to Trim Budgets
text: When Holden Thorp, the chancellor of the University of North Carolina, was looking for ways to cut the university’s budget, he did what many executives in private industry do  hired a management consultant.

headline: Long Lines to Get Free Swine Flu Shot in New York City
text: Want a swine flu vaccination at a free clinic this weekend? Get in line.

headline: Seals in San Diego Get to Remain at the Beach
text: SAN DIEGO  A long-running legal battle over whether to evict a colony of harbor seals that inexplicably took over a popular beach here like a gaggle of tourists overstaying their welcome appeared closer than ever to ending Friday when a judge ruled that they can stay put.

headline: For 1-9 Knicks, Morale Could Expire Sooner Than Players’ Contracts

headline: Belbin and Agosto Don’t Need a Map to Excel at Skate America
text: LAKE PLACID, N.Y. — The ice dancers Tanith Belbin and Benjamin Agosto of the United States did not even know where Moldova was when they signed up to perform a Moldovian folk dance in the original dance this season. But geography lessons were not necessary for them to nail the dance Saturday at Skate America.

headline: One-Handed Player Makes Manhattan Debut
text: Kevin Laue, the 6-foot-11 freshman center born with a left arm that extends just below the elbow, made his regular-season college basketball debut in Manhattan’s 70-58 victory over the New Jersey Institute of Technology on Saturday at Draddy Gymnasium.

headline: Female Heart Down the Homestretch
text: Racetrack touts and gamblers  and equine savvy feminists  are celebrating an extraordinary year in thoroughbred racing. It has been dominated and galvanized by not one, but two females  the mesmerizing filly Rachel Alexandra and the overpowering mare Zenyatta. Both are undefeated in supreme tests. Both displayed thrilling championship form in beating fields of the world’s best males, Triple Crown leg winners included.

headline: Bidding on Madoff’s Trove While Helping Victims
text: A blue Mets jacket that once belonged to Bernard L. Madoff was sold for $14,500 at a government auction at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers in Midtown Manhattan on Saturday, while a ring buoy from his yacht went for $7,500.

headline: Reform and Medical Costs
text: Americans are deeply concerned about the relentless rise in health care costs and health insurance premiums. They need to know if reform will help solve the problem. The answer is that no one has an easy fix for rising medical costs. The fundamental fix  reshaping how care is delivered and how doctors are paid in a wasteful, dysfunctional system  is likely to be achieved only through trial and error and incremental gains.

headline: For Gators, Winning Margin Doesn’t Include Style Points

headline: Amir Pnueli, Pioneer of Temporal Logic, Dies at 68

headline: About That Bloomberg Runaway ...

headline: Corrections
text: A chart last Sunday with an article about the late-season leader for the Nascar Sprint Cup Series points title misspelled, in some copies, the given name of the driver aiming for his fourth consecutive title and misstated the driver’s final position in the 2005 standings. He is Jimmie Johnson, not Jimmy, and he finished fifth, not second. The chart also misstated, in some editions, Johnson’s points total in 2009, with three races remaining. It was 6,248  not 6,284.

headline: Dr. Tererai Trent
text: My Sunday column tells the extraordinary story of Tererai Trent, who grew up impoverished in northern Zimbabwe and was able — with the help of Heifer International and a number of other aid groups — to get an education. Next month she will receive her PhD from Western Michigan University.

headline: Corrections

headline: No Formal Climate Deal in Copenhagen, Leaders Say
text: World leaders, clearly trying to limit political damage given the lack of progress in climate-treaty talks, made it next to official over the weekend that no new binding accord would emerge in Copenhagen next month. [UPDATE 9:14 p.m.: We have a story examining how an end to hopes of “sealing the deal” on a new climate treaty reflects the constraints on President Obama and the political hazards he faces in tackling this issue.] Meeting with the Danish prime minister on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Singapore, President Obama and other leaders said Copenhagen would be a steppingstone toward some final eventual accord, as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton had described the impending session last week. (Presumably the pressure came mainly from the two dominant players in the global greenhouse, the United States and China.)

headline: The Onion on Oversensitive Quarterbacks

headline: In Punishing Fashion, Pacquiao Makes History
text: LAS VEGAS  Manny Pacquiao was fighting for those struggling in his home country, the Philippines, who were ravaged recently by a trio of typhoons. He was fighting for his family  for his father, who made a rare appearance  and for the millions of fans who follow his every move.

headline: Hollywood Gets Honest at Governors Awards

headline: Run, Don’t Walk, to Macao’s Big Race
text: Gambling may be Macao’s major activity for risk-takers, but every November, the city goes outdoors for a different set of thrills: the Macao Grand Prix, which runs this year from Nov. 19 to 22. The Macao GP is a Formula 3 race, essentially a feeder circuit for the elite F1 series. Although F3 cars are not as advanced or as fast as F1 cars, there’s plenty of what you expect to see from spectator racing: sleek cars traveling at ridiculous speeds, as well as the inevitable crash or two. And the tickets will set you back far less than a few losing hands at the table games at the Venetian.

headline: In China, Obama to Press for Tough Stance on Iran
text: SHANGHAI  President Obama, fresh from making progress in his efforts to get Russia on board for possible tough new sanctions against Iran, arrived in China on Sunday, where he will attempt the even more difficult task of prodding China’s leaders to get tough on Iran.

headline: Michael Feinstein to Lead Jazz at Lincoln Center Series
text: Jazz at Lincoln Center is bringing classic American popular song into its fold with the appointment of the singer and pianist Michael Feinstein as director of its new popular music series. Mr. Feinstein will create three programs as well as a family event, all focusing on the relationship between jazz and songwriting, for the spring of 2011. The concerts will be in the Allen Room in Frederick P. Rose Hall, at Broadway and 60th Street.

headline: Dance and Art Play Off Each Other
text: BEACON, N.Y.  For the past two years the Merce Cunningham Dance Company graced the galleries of Dia:Beacon here, where the site-specific Beacon Events series was born. Now the torch has been passed to the Trisha Brown Dance Company, which, over the weekend, presented a sharply edited program of Ms. Brown’s early works (pieces created between 1968 and 1975) that took audiences on a fast-paced trip through seven galleries. The residency will include appearances in February and May.
