headline: Rodge Cohen, the Trauma Surgeon of Wall Street
text: Earlier this fall, after a busy month of shuttling to Washington, H. Rodgin Cohen, the dean of Wall Street lawyers, settled into a table upstairs at the Red Hat, a favorite restaurant overlooking the Hudson River here in the Westchester village where he lives. He and his wife of 40 years, Barbara, ordered modestly (and identically) — salad, swordfish steak, glasses of Chardonnay — and the table talk was undemanding in a casual, nerdy way, The New York Times’s Alan Feuer writes.

headline: Sound and Vision: A Piano Recital With a Multimedia Heart
text: The remarkable Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes is a self-effacing, substantive and completely unflashy artist. You would not peg him as someone curious to explore multimedia and reinvent the piano recital.

headline: Citi Sells Stake in Japanese Call Center to Bain
text: Citigroup said Sunday that it was selling its controlling stake in the leading call center operator in Japan, Bellsystem24, to the private equity firm Bain Capital in a deal that values the operation at $1.1 billion, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Yowling and Yelping: Back-in-the-Day Soul Hits Become of the Moment Again
text: Some record collectors have moved from accumulating vinyl to salvaging careers. The Ponderosa Stomp in New Orleans, Dig Deeper in Brooklyn and the Light in the Attic label in Seattle have all tracked down fondly remembered names to perform again. On Friday night the Numero Group  a Chicago label that delves into obscure archives for meticulously researched reissues  brought its dapper, potent Eccentric Soul Revue to the Music Hall of Williamsburg in Brooklyn.

headline: Law Seeks to Ban Misuse of Genetic Testing
text: The most important new antidiscrimination law in two decades  the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act  will take effect in the nation’s workplaces next weekend, prohibiting employers from requesting genetic testing or considering someone’s genetic background in hiring, firing or promotions.

headline: Heisman Watch: The Picture Doesn’t Get Any Clearer
text: Tim Tebow, Florida quarterback

headline: And the Answer Is …
text: Hi. Patrick Merrell back behind the Wordplay desk, which I’ll be manning through Sunday. Today’s puzzle is a debut by the team of James Mulhern and Ashton Anderson. Is it just a coincidence that the four theme entries revolve around the beginning of Mr. Anderson’s last name? If so, they’ve compensated for that by giving Mr. Mulhern first billing.

headline: Maradona Suspended for 2 Months
text: Diego Maradona, the coach of Argentina’s national team, was banished for two months Sunday by soccer’s worldwide governing body because of his expletive-laced tirade unleashed after a victory that qualified the two-time champions for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.

headline: Florida’s Bizarro Season
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — In a fitting slice of symmetry that intertwines this most bizarre college football season and its top-ranked team, Florida is being perceived in some circles as an underachiever. The Gators are 10-0, finished the SEC regular season undefeated for the first time under Urban Meyer and are a favorite to win back-to-back national titles.

headline: Ryan Reynolds to Read From the Book of Loggins
text: The heartthrob actor Ryan Reynolds (“The Proposal,” “Definitely, Maybe”) will make his debut next week in the New York edition of the theatrical comedy “Celebrity Autobiography: In Their Own Words,” where stars read humorous snippets from memoirs of the entertainment world’s A-list through D-list.

headline: Common Grounds for Clinton and Palin?
text: We’ll skip straight to the obvious joke.

headline: It’s the Scent That Tickles the Memory
text: Only recently have companies begun assigning smells to everyday products: frangipani-scented sewing threads, tires that smell like roses. A paper soon to be published in the Journal of Consumer Research confirms the wisdom of this tactic, finding that scented products linger in the memory.

headline: Hobbes in Hebrew: The Religion Question
text: “Leviathan” is arguably the most influential work of Western political thought, and one of the most analyzed. Yet the first full Hebrew translation of Thomas’s Hobbes’s work was only published last month. While the first two parts have long been available in translation, the third and fourth parts — in which Hobbes addresses religion and the state — had not appeared in Hebrew.

headline: Jaguars Defeat Jets
text: A field goal as time expired gave the Jaguars a 24-22 victory over the Jets.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Canes Take 2 Points for First Time in 15 Games
text: Three games on Sunday, led off by a battle of bottom-dwellers in Raleigh. Home teams listed first:

headline: Experts Outline Hurdles for Defense of Hasan
text: Defending the man accused of premeditated murder in the Nov. 5 shooting rampage at Fort Hood is the kind of test that many lawyers dread, and that some live for.

headline: Prefatory Matters
text: Introductory posts are never terribly enthralling, so I’ll try to keep this brief. To anyone who followed my blogging at The Atlantic, thanks for showing up again. To anyone who didn’t, welcome – I hope you’ll stick around. And a heartfelt thanks to everyone at The Times who helped get this page off the ground.

headline: Losing a Chess Match, and a Game
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jets lost to the Jacksonville Jaguars, 24-22, on Sunday on a last-second field goal that ended a surreal two-minute drill filled with cold calculation by both sides.

headline: Hollywood Dinner Has Oscars on Menu
text: LOS ANGELES  Lauren Bacall admitted she had a thing for Gregory Peck, but his wife got in the way. Kirk Douglas said he tried to seduce Ms. Bacall, but she wasn’t interested. Warren Beatty confessed that all his best stories seemed to wind up serving himself.

headline: Illinois Site May Be Path to Closing Guantánamo
text: WASHINGTON  Top Illinois Democrats on Sunday wholeheartedly embraced the idea of sending terrorism suspects from Guantánamo Bay to a maximum-security prison about 150 miles west of Chicago, raising the possibility of a major breakthrough in the Obama administration’s efforts to close the military detention facility in Cuba.

headline: Art Prices (and Mood) Inch Back Up
text: Oh the drama of auctions: the salesrooms packed with smartly dressed collectors; the tension of having to decide in seconds whether to drop another million dollars on an artwork or let it go; the steely smile of the auctioneer trying gently to squeeze another hundred thousand from bidders. And the final results of the last two weeks of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art auctions in New York, which saw the return of a surprising number of collectors, their wallets open, but only if the price was right.

headline: MSNBC Presses Obama on Campaign Promises
text: If President Obama happened to glance at “The Rachel Maddow Show” last Monday, he might have winced.

headline: Reunion of the Group That Put Atlanta on the Rap Map
text: Depending on who is writing the history book, 1995 was either a great or frustrating time for Goodie Mob. That year the Atlanta foursome released its debut masterpiece, “Soul Food” (LaFace), one of its city’s defining hip-hop documents. The rest of hip-hop, though, was preoccupied with sounds from the coasts. While New York and Los Angeles were slugging it out, Atlanta was building its infrastructure, one that would eventually take over the genre.

headline: Footnote
text: Clint Eastwood has been made a commander in the French order the Legion of Honor, The Associated Press reported. At a ceremony hosted by President Nicolas Sarkozy, Mr. Eastwood, 79, was cited for “his body of work, his longevity and his ability to delight audiences around the globe.” This isn’t his first French title. In 2007 he was made a knight of the Legion of Honor by the president at the time, Jacques Chirac. The new appointment raises him to Grade 3 on the legion’s five-grade scale.

headline: Winnie-the-Pooh Returns to Court
text: The estate of Stephen Slesinger, the producer who acquired licensing rights to the Winnie-the-Pooh works and characters from A. A. Milne in 1930, has been suing Disney for rights infringement since 1991, and isn’t stopping now, according to BBC News. After a Los Angeles judge dismissed a case brought by the estate in 2004 (on the grounds that its legal team illegally obtained documents by trespassing on Disney property) and a federal judge dismissed another this September (ruling that Mr. Slesinger had transferred all rights to Disney), lawyers filed papers in Los Angeles last week arguing that Disney owes the estate hundreds of millions of dollars in royalties. The suit says that Disney combined profits from Pooh and Mickey Mouse merchandise, thereby concealing revenues owed to the estate. Describing the lawsuit as “baffling,” a Disney spokeswoman said that the issues had been settled with the September ruling.

headline: Another Celebrity for ‘Autobiography’
text: The actor Ryan Reynolds will make his debut next Monday in the New York edition of “Celebrity Autobiography,” the theatrical comedy in which actors read snippets from memoirs of the entertainment world’s A- through D-list. Given Mr. Reynolds’s popularity in films like “The Proposal” and on Sexiest Man Alive lists, two shows have been scheduled next Monday, one at 7:30 p.m. and one at 9:30 p.m. at the Triad Theater in Manhattan. Mr. Reynolds is to read from Kenny Loggins’s “Unimaginable Life: Lessons Learned on the Path of Love.” Other performers that night include Rachel Dratch, Carol Kane, Sherri Shepherd, Michael Urie and Kristen Wiig.

headline: More Recovery Time for Conductor
text: The conductor Leonard Slatkin, who collapsed after leading the Rotterdam Philharmonic in the Netherlands on Nov. 1 and underwent emergency surgery to unblock a clogged artery, has canceled appearances with the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, for which he is music director, for the next two weeks on the advice of his doctors, The Detroit Free Press reported. Mr. Slatkin, 65, is “back in America with his doctors, and they’ve said, ‘Go rest and come back at the end of November, and we’ll do a check-up,’ ”said R. Douglas Sheldon, Mr. Slatkin’s manager, adding, “We anticipate this will go smoothly and he’ll be back on the podium soon.” Andrew Grams will replace Mr. Slatkin in performances of Ginastera, Michel Camilo, Berlioz and Debussy this week, and the Norwegian conductor Arild Remmereit will take his place conducting concerts of Bach, Mozart, Hindemith and Ravel on Nov. 27 through Nov. 29. Mr. Slatkin is expected to return for the world premiere performances of Wlad Marhulet’s Concerto for Klezmer Clarinet in December.

headline: Iranian Musician Declares His Protest
text: Speaking out against the disputed presidential elections in Iran in June and the government crackdown that followed protests, the popular Iranian singer and composer Mohammad Reza Shajarian, left, a master of traditional Persian music,  has asked that state radio and television stop broadcasting his work, The Associated Press reported. “After what happened, I said ‘no way’ and threatened to file a complaint against them if they continued to use my music,” Mr. Shajarian said in an interview with the A.P. Though the broadcast services complied with his request, the government has responded to hundreds of other artist protests  which have included boycotting state-sponsored awards and appearing at international events wearing green, the color of the opposition  by banning their work, detaining them or forbidding them to travel. Narges Kalhor, the daughter of President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s culture adviser, Mehdi Kalhor, sought asylum in Germany last month out of fear of repercussions after screening her documentary “Rake,” which was inspired by the human rights violations she says routinely occur in Iran.

headline: Following Up Oasis
text: Liam Gallagher, former lead vocalist of Oasis, said that he and other members of the recently defunct band were forming a new group, Reuters reported. “Not Oasis  Oasis is done,” Mr. Gallagher said during a radio interview. “Everyone except for Noel,” he said, referring to his brother, Noel Gallagher, who left the group in August claiming he had been “forced to leave” through intimidation by his band mates. The new band will include most of the old one: Oasis’s rhythm guitarist Colin Archer, bassist Andy Bell and drummer Chris Sharrock. Liam Gallagher founded Oasis in 1991, and a short time later Noel joined as lead guitarist and main songwriter.

headline: Lou Dobbs to Visit ‘O’Reilly’
text: Lou Dobbs, below, the outspoken CNN anchor who abruptly resigned from his job last week, is scheduled to appear as a guest on Monday night’s edition of “The O’Reilly Factor” on Fox News, Variety reported. Fox News said he planned to discuss his on-air resignation as well as his opposition to illegal immigration. Though the interview may heighten suspicions that Mr. Dobbs is being courted by Fox, representatives from the network said there had been no discussions. Jonathan Klein, president of CNN’s domestic operations, agreed to release Mr. Dobbs from his “Lou Dobbs Tonight” contract after he refused to tone down his rhetorical style.

headline: In the Wings
text: The Actors Theater of Louisville, Ky., has announced the lineup of its 34th annual Humana Festival of New American Plays. Full-length plays will include “Ground” by Lisa Dillman; “The Cherry Sisters Revisited” by Dan O’Brien, with music by Michael Friedman; “Fissures (lost and found)” by Steve Epp, Cory Hinkle, Dominic Orlando, Dominique Serrand, Deborah Stein and Victoria Stewart; “Phoenix” by Scott Organ; “Sirens” by Deborah Zoe Laufer; and “The Method Gun,” created by Rude Mechs and written by Kirk Lynn. The festival runs Feb. 21 to March 28. ... Sarah Paulson (“The Glass Menagerie”) will join Linda Lavin (“The Tale of the Allergist’s Wife”) in Manhattan Theater Club’s Broadway premiere of Donald Margulies’s “Collected Stories,” to be directed by Lynne Meadow. Ms. Paulson will play Lisa, a young protégée of a celebrated New York author (Ms. Lavin). Previews begin April 6, with an opening scheduled for April 28 at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater. ... Debbie Reynolds will bring her one-woman show, “Debbie Reynolds Alive and Fabulous,” to Britain, beginning with a 15-date regional tour at Theater Royal in Norwich on April 7, and followed by a run in the West End of London at the Apollo Theater, opening on April 29.

headline: Distortion With Pop Peeping Out
text: Seven songs, 20 or so minutes, several hundred musical punches to the head and midsection: Sleigh Bells concerts are beginning to find a rhythm.

headline: Pacquiao-Mayweather a Match Made in Heaven (or Yankee Stadium?)
text: LAS VEGAS  Three hours after Manny Pacquiao dispatched Miguel Cotto on Saturday night to capture his record seventh title in seven weight divisions, he jogged onto the stage at the Mandalay Bay Events Center.

headline: Writing a Sports Column Far From Print, and the Game
text: In 1998, a Boston Globe profile of an obscure online sports commentator began simply: “Get used to this name: Bill Simmons.”

headline: U.S. Readies New Facility for Afghan Detainees
text: BAGRAM AIR BASE, Afghanistan  The Obama administration’s effort to remake the notorious American detention system in Afghanistan will take a critical step forward at the end of the month, when detainees move into a new facility on the edge of Bagram Air Base.

headline: In Detroit, Agencies Compete to Sell City as a Creative Haven
text: IT may not be the advertising version of “Mission: Impossible,” but it is certainly a challenging, if not daunting, task: produce a campaign to encourage young and creative people to consider Detroit as a place to live and work.

headline: Pac-10 Race Remains in Doubt
text: The Pac-10 championship may end up being decided by the “Civil War.”

headline: Antismoking Fight Proves a Pyramid-Size Task
text: CAIRO  Perhaps not since Egypt built the great pyramids of Giza, or more recently tamed the Nile with the Aswan High Dam, has the government embarked on as challenging a national project: wiping out smoking in public places.

headline: About Half in U.S. Would Pay for Online News, Study Finds
text: Americans, it turns out, are less willing than people in many other Western countries to pay for their online news, according to a new study by the Boston Consulting Group.

headline: At Checkout, More Ways to Avoid Cash or Plastic
text: For almost as long as Americans have been hearing about jetpacks and picturephones, they have been hearing that money  bills, coins and plastic cards  might cease to exist, or at least become a novelty.

headline: For Some Smokers, Even Home Is Off Limits
text: The movement to ban smoking in New York City has grown so quickly that no place seems immune  certainly not restaurants or bars, and public beaches and parks may not be far behind. Now the efforts are rapidly expanding into the living room.

headline: As A.L.-N.L. Gap Widens, General Managers Tread Cautiously
text: CHICAGO  His shoulders shrugged. His lips pursed. But Kenny Williams bit his tongue one syllable too late.

headline: A Writer Tries to Take the High Road as the Low Jokes Fly
text: This much was learned at a panel discussion last week about “The Future of Funny”: It is not Ken Auletta.

headline: Pushed on Budgets, Cities Push Back on House Cats
text: The question of whether to regulate the declawing of house cats has suddenly become a priority for lawmakers in several California cities, mostly because Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed a bill this summer to prohibit local bans on declawing beginning in 2010.

headline: Glimmers of Progress at a Leaner Newsweek
text: Six months ago, Newsweek embarked on a bold effort to stanch its losses in a brutal economic time, with a major redesign, price increases, a steep reduction in circulation, and a continuation in a long series of steps away from weekly news and toward commentary and analysis. From the legion of people in the media who write about one another’s organizations, there was plenty of skepticism, even some derision.

headline: Taking Aim at Student Muckrakers
text: Since 1992, Prof. David Protess at the Medill school at Northwestern University has worked with undergraduate journalism students to investigate cases in which prosecutors appear to have taken aim at the wrong people. That might be about to happen again, only this time the students themselves would be the targets.

headline: In Fleury’s Memoir, Rangers Years Are a ‘Nightmare’
text: When Theo Fleury was a Ranger, he said, he would stay out all night drinking, doing cocaine, going “below the streets of New York City” to “party with freaks, transvestites, strippers” or to “hang out with homeless guys around a burn barrel” on the West Side piers.

headline: Is Palm’s Comeback Losing Steam?
text: In a land of cellphone giants, Palm is a mouse.

headline: Obama Hobbled in Fight Against Global Warming
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama came into office pledging to end eight years of American inaction on climate change under President George W. Bush, and all year he has promised that the United States would lead the way toward a global agreement in Copenhagen next month to address the warming planet.

headline: From Treasury, an Invitation to Financial Bloggers
text: The Treasury Department opened its doors to economic bloggers this month, and the meeting was productive in at least one respect: as John Jansen of the blog Across the Curve concluded, “After meeting them, I feel I cannot refer to them as Timothy Geithner and his minions” anymore.

headline: Little Benefit Seen, So Far, in Electronic Patient Records
text: The nation is set to begin an ambitious program, backed by $19 billion in government incentives, to accelerate the adoption of computerized patient records in doctors’ offices and hospitals, replacing ink and paper. There is wide agreement that the conversion will bring better care and lower costs, saving the American health care system up to $100 billion a year by some estimates.

headline: Sullenberger Takes Issue With New Book
text: A new book addressing the role of automation in US Airways Flight 1549 is wrong, according to the pilot who safely landed the plane on the Hudson River in January.

headline: Stimulus and Exports Help Ease Japan’s Recession
text: TOKYO  Japan’s economy grew at a robust annual rate of 4.8 percent in the third quarter as stimulus spending and a rebound in exports appeared to bring the country firmly out of its worst recession in the postwar era.

headline: In Nicaragua, Opposition Sees an End Run
text: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Magistrate Sergio Cuarezma, a member of the Supreme Court, spent Oct. 19 like any other Monday, quietly catching up on e-mail and fingering through stacks of rulings by sunlight when the court’s power went down, as it tends to do without explanation here in Central America’s poorest country.

headline: A Deck of Lives
text: After the murder of his son, Tom Lucas created a special deck of playing cards, now used in South Carolina prisons. He hopes they will bring clues to cold cases.

headline: In Prison, Playing Just to Kill Time and Just Maybe to Help Solve a Murder
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.

headline: Yemen Finds Dreamland of Architecture
text: SANA, Yemen  It has been almost 800 years since Saleh Qaid Othaim’s house in the heart of the Old City was built from hand-cut stones and traditional alabaster decorations.

headline: U.S. Asks More From Pakistan in War
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is stepping up pressure on Pakistan to expand and reorient its fight against the Taliban and Al Qaeda, warning that failing to do so would undercut the new strategy and troop increase for Afghanistan that President Obama is preparing to approve, American officials say.

headline: A Sweet Union for Liberty Global
text: A Sweet Union For Liberty Global

headline: Governor Crist Becomes a Right-Wing Target
text: NEWBERRY, Fla.  In retrospect, even Charlie Crist admits that “the optics” of The Hug are not great.

headline: Money Trickles North as Mexicans Help Relatives
text: MIAHUATLÁN, Mexico  During the best of the times, Miguel Salcedo’s son, an illegal immigrant in San Diego, would be sending home hundreds of dollars a month to support his struggling family in Mexico. But at times like these, with the American economy out of whack and his son out of work, Mr. Salcedo finds himself doing what he never imagined he would have to do: wiring pesos north.

headline: After All That Bluster, the Jets Are ‘Barely Breathing’
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Grupo Mexico Wins Battle to Control a Copper Producer
text: A federal judge in Texas has issued final approval for Grupo Mexico’s plan to regain control of a copper mining company, Asarco, ending a lengthy takeover battle with a rival suitor.

headline: Drug Makers Raise Prices in Face of Health Care Reform
text: Even as drug makers promise to support Washington’s health care overhaul by shaving $8 billion a year off the nation’s drug costs after the legislation takes effect, the industry has been raising its prices at the fastest rate in years.

headline: Outlook Grim in South Bend, and Dim for B.C.S.
text: The one theme of this college football season has been its predictability. Just take a peek at next week’s feeble slate of games. There are no games between top-25 teams in the Associated Press poll, something virtually unheard of this late in the season. The top three teams in the country  No. 1 Florida, No. 2 Alabama and No. 3 Texas  play Florida International, Chattanooga and woefully underachieving Kansas. That means three teams that are 30-0 will beat up on three teams that are 14-16.

headline: At T.C.U., a Game Ball for Fashion
text: FORT WORTH — After his team trounced Utah on Saturday night, 55-28, Texas Christian Coach Gary Patterson had plenty of candidates to award the game ball to.

headline: Kim Shaky in Free Skate, but Still Wins
text: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  Just before Kim Yu-na of South Korea began her long program at Skate America, she stopped to adjust the shoelaces on her left boot.

headline: Senate’s Counting and Recounting Add Up to Delay
text: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, hopes to finalize the Senate version of major health care legislation this week.

headline: Cuomo Wants to Shape Ticket in Run for Governor, Advisers Say
text: ALBANY  Quietly plotting his campaign for governor, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo and his advisers have been discussing potential candidates to run alongside him, to present the most appealing Democratic ticket to the electorate, people with knowledge of those discussions said.

headline: Atlantic Avenue Entrepreneurs
text: In Brooklyn, a new class of creative business owners is reviving Atlantic Avenue’s commitment to old things.

headline: Using Celebrity Wattage to Fight City’s Planned ‘Garbage Garage’
text: In the old days, the industrial neighborhood just above TriBeCa was so forlorn that if Martin Sheridan spied someone four blocks away, he could be pretty sure it was an approaching customer.

headline: Lottery Numbers
$25 Fee for New License Plates May Be Repealed
text: A plan to start charging New York drivers $25 for new license plates will be scuttled, lawmakers said on Sunday. The fee had caused an uproar among upstate officials, who called it an unfair burden on drivers.

headline: Skee Brooklyn
text: The Crown Heights bar Franklin Park  home to Hasidic philosophy meetings, skee-ball tourneys and plain old outdoor boozing  adds another twist with its reading series tonight. Catch Amy Sohn, author of the lightly fictionalized neighborhood novel “Prospect Park West;” Said Sayrafiezadeh, author of the memoir “When Skateboards Will Be Free;” Jobie Hughes, the writing partner of James Frey; and Lianne Stokes, a comedian, sharing their work; challenge them to a game of drunken skee-ball afterward.

headline: Like a Cyclone Hit
text: Offstage, Neko Case can be shy; onstage, the flame-haired singer is “a honky-tonk heroine,” Nate Chinen writes, “even if her lyrics reveal literary designs.” Her latest album, “’Middle Cyclone” and her shows feature “songs of admonition, hurt and regret, delivered with a declarative gleam.” See (and hear) for yourself tonight, when she plays at the Beacon with  Joey Burns and John Convertino of Calexico

headline: Sex, Drugs and Rock ’n’ Roll
text: Follow two men with very distinct, if somewhat overlapping, obsessions tonight. The music critic Robert Palmer is the subject of the new documentary “The Hand of Fatima,” which explores his drug use and his family; his pioneering work [LINK to Palmer in Arts 11/16] will be honored at a tribute tonight at Le Poisson Rouge that benefits the Sufi musicians he championed. Meanwhile, at Pete’s Candy Store, the filmmaker Caveh Zahedi, who has investigated his own predilections forthrightly in “I Am a Sex Addict,” will present a lecture about his other love: psychotropic drugs.

headline: Study Raises Questions About Cholesterol Drug’s Benefit
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  For patients taking a statin to control high cholesterol, adding an old standby drug, niacin, was superior in reducing buildup in the carotid artery to adding Zetia, a newer drug that reduces bad cholesterol, according to a new study.

headline: Fewer Hasidim Backed Mayor, Study Finds
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was getting an earful. “He created this crisis so that he can take credit for fixing it and get our votes in exchange,” one commenter wrote on a Brooklyn blog, Vos Iz Neias, Yiddish for “What is News.” Someone else remarked, “I got to my store I got 2 tickets from the Sanitation police. I sure deserved it Bloomie. I will NOT vote for you.”

headline: Accounts, People & Miscellany
text: Accounts

headline: Programs to Certify Teachers May Grow
text: The State Board of Regents will consider letting alternative teacher training programs certify teachers, expanding the role that for decades has been exclusively performed by education schools.

headline: At CUNY, Mission to Elevate Science Begins to Bear Fruit
text: The most visible manifestation yet of the billion-dollar transformation taking place at the City University of New York might also be the most unassuming: a so-called science cafe series in a Japanese restaurant on the Upper West Side. There, the public listened as faculty members described their work in fields ranging from the global water crisis to the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

headline: Chase Is Said to Be Buying British Bank
text: JPMorgan Chase is in talks to take control of a prominent British investment bank after striking a deal for half the firm five years ago, a person familiar with the matter said Sunday night.

headline: Palin Finds One Bond With Clinton
text: Could there be a “coffee summit” in the future between Hillary Rodham Clinton  the secretary of state, runner-up for the Democratic presidential nomination, former senator and author  and Sarah Palin, author, former Republican vice-presidential candidate and former governor?

headline: Neediest | A Victim of Violence Recovers
text: Risto Prendzov, a Macedonian immigrant, is recovering after a violent robbery on the subway almost a year ago. He has received help from Catholic Charities, which is supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

headline: After Brutal Mugging, an Immigrant Rebuilds His Life
text: For five days last November, the 29-year-old man was John Doe, lying in Jamaica Hospital Medical Center with a bashed-in skull, a punctured lung, a broken jaw and eye socket and a crushed hand. After a brutal mugging in Queens, he had no wallet, no identification and no shoes.

headline: Stricter Transit Standards to Be Sought
text: WASHINGTON  Citing an increase in the number of subway and light-rail crashes and resulting passenger injuries, the Obama administration will push for legislation that would allow the federal government to set and enforce safety standards on the nation’s transit systems, officials said on Sunday.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: President Obama in China
text: Economy, Security and, Yes, Human Rights

headline: Whistling Past the Deficit
text: New York’s governor could not have spoken more plainly than he did last week before a joint session of the State Legislature. “Quite frankly, we are running out of money,” he said, as he asked members to help cut the budget. The plea has so far gone unanswered, even though, with each week, the fiscal problems get worse.

headline: Dr. No and the Wounded Veterans
text: A creative plan to help wounded veterans and their exhausted families adapt to the strain of long-term home care is on the brink of bipartisan approval  but for the familiar obstructionism of Senator Tom Coburn. This is one of the most deplorable displays by the lawmaker-physician, an Oklahoma Republican who relishes playing the self-styled budget hawk by putting attention-grabbing holds on crucial legislation.

headline: A Question About a Diagnosis
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Chemical Security Bill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Korean Adoptees
text: To the Editor:

headline: Getting to Know Christie
text: To the Editor:

headline: Protecting Open Spaces
text: To the Editor:

headline: Saving the Bluefin Tuna
text: To the Editor:

headline: World Out of Balance
text: International travel by world leaders is mainly about making symbolic gestures. Nobody expects President Obama to come back from China with major new agreements, on economic policy or anything else.

headline: Off the Chart
text: Ten months ago, at the beginning of the great stimulus debate, President-elect Barack Obama’s economic advisers produced an unfortunate chart.

headline: The Great Wallop
text: A FEW years ago we came up with the term “Chimerica” to describe the combination of the Chinese and American economies, which together had become the key driver of the global economy. With a combined 13 percent of the world’s land surface and around a quarter of its population, Chimerica nevertheless accounted for a third of global economic output and two-fifths of worldwide growth from 1998 to 2007.

headline: Liberate Iraq’s Economy
text: Bethlehem, Pa.

headline: JPMorgan Nears Deal to Buy Rest of Cazenove
text: JPMorgan Chase is in talks to take control of a prominent British investment bank after striking a deal for half the firm five years ago, The New York Times’s Eric Dash reported Sunday night, citing a person familiar with the matter.

headline: G.M. Is Said to Soon Begin Paying U.S. Debt
text: General Motors, which emerged from a government-ordered bankruptcy restructuring earlier this year, will begin paying back its debt to the United States and Canadian governments earlier than expected, a person with direct knowledge of G.M.’s plans said Sunday night.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Friday, about the credit-card law passed in May, misstated the date a provision of it became effective. While the full law will not take effect until February, its requirement that banks alert customers to rate increases 45 days in advance has been in force since August.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Oct. 29 about the photographer Roy DeCarava omitted five survivors. They include two sons, Leslie DeCarava of Playas del Coco, Costa Rica; and Vincent DeCarava of Paramount, Calif.; a grandson, a granddaughter and a great-granddaughter. (As the obituary noted, he is also survived by his wife, Sherry Turner DeCarava, and their three daughters, Susan, Wendy and Laura DeCarava, all of Brooklyn.)

headline: Glyde Aims to Simplify Online Sales of Used Media
text: SAN FRANCISCO  People whose old books, CDs, DVDs and video games are collecting dust on their shelves will soon have another way to resell them on the Web.

headline: Week 10 in Quotations: On Standing Tall and Taking a Knee
text: The best and worst from Week 10, in the words of the players and coaches who took part.

headline: A Snapshot of Today’s Community College Students
text: Update | 10:40 a.m. See below for a reference to an article in The San Jose Mercury News on the dashed hopes of many students at two-year colleges in California who had planned to transfer to four-year colleges.

headline: Caruso Is Back and So Is the Met
text: Tuesday, Nov. 16, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Colts Pull Off Improbable Win as Patriots’ Gamble Backfires
text: INDIANAPOLIS  For most teams, failing to score after an interception and fumble recovery in the end zone on consecutive drives would signal disaster and send everyone home shaking their heads about squandered opportunities. Everyone left Lucas Oil Stadium shaking their heads Sunday night all right, but it was over one of the most confounding coaching decisions imaginable, a stunner by Bill Belichick that gave Peyton Manning a short field to engineer a stunning 35-34 comeback victory.

headline: Showcase: The Sport of Photography
text: As Walter Iooss and Neil Leifer will tell you, sports photographers have good games and bad games. Like athletes, they get better through intense competition.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Nov. 4 about a lack of data on the benefits and relative performance of many medical devices described incorrectly the findings of a McKinsey Global Institute report on the rising costs of such devices. Current spending on the six highest-cost implanted devices alone is about $13 billion annually, not $76 billion. (While a chart in that report described current annual spending on medical devices as about $76 billion, McKinsey said that the figure reflected not just spending on implanted devices but also on other hospital products like X-ray film and surgical gloves.)

headline: Big Victory in Alabama
text: Jon Jaques is a senior on the Cornell basketball team. As he did last season, Jon will be blogging for The Quad throughout this season.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about accusations by the City Education Department that an arbitrator in a teacher competency hearing has on two occasions fallen asleep during testimony misstated part of the name of the union whose lawyers are representing the teacher, Darwin Bailey. It is New York State United Teachers, not the New York State Union of Teachers.

headline: China Is Sending More Students to U.S.
text: American universities are enrolling a new wave of Chinese undergraduates, according to the annual Open Doors report.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Defending Belichick’s Fourth-Down Decision
text: (Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.)

headline: John J. O’Connor, a Times TV Critic in Years of Industry Upheaval, Dies at 76
text: John J. O’Connor, who as a television critic for The New York Times for more than 25 years covered the medium as it expanded from a business dominated by three networks to a universe of hundreds of diverse cable and broadcast channels, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76.

headline: News Quiz | November 16, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Maurice Jones-Drew’s  Very Smart Play
text: First, credit  Jaguars Coach Jack Del Rio:

headline: Australian Leader Apologizes to the ‘Lost Innocents’
text: The children were gathered up by the tens of thousands, some of them as young as 3, taken from single mothers and impoverished families in Britain, then sent abroad for what was supposed to be a better start in life. What they found was isolation, physical and sexual abuse, and what the prime minister of Australia said Monday was “the absolute tragedy of childhoods lost.”

headline: Infosys Buys U.S. Back-Office Firm
text: Infosys Technologies, India’s second-largest information technology provider by revenue, has acquired McCamish Systems, an American back-office firm, for up $58 million.

headline: Co-Founder of Brevan Howard to Leave Firm
text: Jean-Philippe Blochet, a founding partner in Brevan Howard Asset Management, is leaving the $25.7 billion London-based hedge fund after seven years.

headline: Hitachi to Raise $4.6 Billion
text: Hitachi, Japan’s biggest electronics firm by sales, will raise up to $4.6 billion to shore up its capital, joining a scrum of Japanese firms tapping equity markets before a possible economic slowdown.

headline: A Sweet Union For Liberty Global?
text: John C. Malone, the American media mogul, has pulled off a piece of classic downturn deal-making, Breakingviews.com says. Mr. Malone’s Liberty Global agreed Friday to buy Unitymedia, Germany’s second-largest cable operator after Kabel Deutschland, for 3.5 billion euros ($5.2 billion).

headline: Glyde Aims to Simplify Online Sales of Used Media
text: People whose old books, CDs, DVDs and video games are collecting dust on their shelves will soon have another way to resell them on the Web.

headline: Talk at Riksbank, 11/16/09
text: From this day on, the official language of this blog will be Swedish.

headline: G.M. Is Said to Soon Begin Paying U.S. Debt
text: General Motors, which emerged from a government-ordered bankruptcy restructuring earlier this year, will begin paying back its debt to the United States and Canadian governments earlier than expected, The New York Times’s Micheline Maynard reported, citing a person with direct knowledge of G.M.’s plans.

headline: Dance and Art
text: Photos from the Trisha Brown Dance Company’s performance at Dia:Beacon.

headline: Pay Limits Said to Hamper BofA’s Search for Chief
text: Bank of America‘s search for a new chief executive has been hurt by federal pay limits that played a major role in the senior vice chairman of PNC Financial Services Group spurning overtures from the company, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Hong Kong Investors Boost Stake in British Gas Firm
text: Cheung Kong Infrastructure and Hongkong Electric said Monday that they would spend £76 million ($127 million) to increase their stakes in British gas distributor Northern Gas Networks.

headline: Carlyle’s Forestry Unit in China to Go Public
text: China Forestry Holdings Group, a forestry plantation operator backed by the Carlyle Group, plans to raise up to $203 million via an initial offering of shares in Hong Kong late this month, Reuters reported.

headline: Castle Harlan Sells United Malt for $655 Million
text: Castle Harlan said Friday that it had unloaded United Malt Holdings for $655 million, a deal that gives the private equity firm a nice return on its investment.

headline: Brightcove Expands Web Video Service
text: Five years ago, when Jeremy Allaire founded Brightcove, an online video company in Cambridge, Mass., he predicted video would someday be as common as text on the Web.

headline: Champion Seeks Chapter 11 For U.S. Operations
text: Champion Enterprises said on Sunday the company and its domestic operating subsidiaries filed for bankruptcy protection, and that it hopes to go through a court-supervised sale of its American operations.

headline: Sands to Restart Macao Casino Work After I.P.O.
text: The American casino operator Las Vegas Sands plans to resume work in January on its multibillion-dollar gambling resorts in Macao after suspending construction last year amid a massive funding crunch, the company said Sunday.

headline: Thread Counts | Comment of the Week
text: Every week we comb through the comments on The Moment, Facebook and our Twitter @replies to bring you something clever from readers.

headline: Citi Said to Reject Terra Firma Bid to Save EMI
text: Citigroup recently rejected a proposal from Guy Hands’ private equity firm Terra Firma Capital Partners to restructure the debt of the music group EMI, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Who Walked Off With Warhol’s ‘Bills’?
text: Guessing who the winning bidder was for Andy Warhol’s “200 One Dollar Bills” in a recent Sotheby’s auction is becoming something of a parlor game, with the names of several high-profile investors, including the hedge fund veteran Steven A. Cohen, being bandied about.

headline: Bristol-Myers to Split Off Mead Johnson Nutrition
text: Bristol-Myers Squibb is splitting off its holdings in the infant-formula maker Mead Johnson Nutrition in order to focus on its biopharmaceutical business.

headline: A New ‘Ragtime’
text: Photos from the new Broadway revival of “Ragtime.”

headline: Paulson Puts Money on Citi, Ditching Goldman
text: John Paulson, the hedge fund manager, has continued to build his stake in Citigroup, while jettisoning his investment in Goldman Sachs, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Is Vivendi’s GVT Deal a Signal on NBC Stake?
text: Vivendi said Friday that it had gained control of GVT in a deal that valued the Brazilian telecommunications company at about 2.8 billion euros ($4.2 billion) and gave the French media conglomerate a foothold in Latin America’s biggest market.

headline: South Korean Insurer Samsung Life Plans 2010 I.P.O.
text: Samsung Life Insurance, South Korea’s largest life insurer, said it was aiming to go public in the first half of next year and planning to pick lead managers in December, Reuters reported on Monday.

headline: Sun Capital Sells Off Timothy’s Coffee
text: As the markets improve, private equity companies continue to seek exits for their portfolio companies. Sun Capital Partners followed that trend by selling Timothy’s Coffees of the World, a specialty coffee supplier, to Green Mountain Coffee Roasters for about $157 million in cash.

headline: Can Public Aid Really Help Business?
text: The global financial crisis is prompting huge government interventions to stimulate the economies of the United States and many other nations. The burning question, The New York Times’s Harry Hurt III writes, is this: Can public-sector initiatives in the private sector be successful, or are they inevitably doomed to failure?

text: fetter • \ˈfe-tər\ • noun and verb

text: WHO is the top-ranked American woman in figure skating? WHO is the “gold-medal favorite” worldwide?

text: The City Room blog asks New Yorkers to “send your screeds, tirades and rants — no more than 500 words please” to their Complaint Box, and readers have complied with stories about public grooming, visible men’s underwear, and ipod volume. What are some of the things that drive you crazy?For example, maybe you agree with Tracey Lloyd, who writes in “I See London”:

headline: In Beijing, Obama Calls for ‘Strong Dialogue’
text: BEIJING  President Obama and President Hu Jintao of China met in private off Tiananmen Square here on a frigid Tuesday morning to discuss issues like trade, climate change and the nuclear programs of Iran and North Korea, in a session that signaled the central role of China on the world stage.

headline: Planes, Trains and Personal Porn
text: Today’s idea: Pornography displayed on personal devices for all to see (or hear) is becoming a nuisance on planes and trains and in other public spaces, an article says.

text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared their descriptions of (and euphemisms for) drunkenness.

text: Images from the comic-book artist.

headline: HSBC Sells London H.Q. for $1.29 Billion
text: South Korea’s National Pension Service, the country’s biggest investor, agreed to put up £772.5 million ($1.29 billion) for HSBC Holdings‘ London headquarters, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Buffett Knows His Railroad Is ‘Not a Bargain’
text: Warren E. Buffett admits that his $26 billion deal to Burlington Northern Santa Fe railroad is “not a bargain.”

headline: Gum Pitches Go Into New Orbit
text: It is not every day that marketers go into business with goons, but that is what the Orbit brand of gum sold by the Wm. Wrigley division of Mars is doing as of Monday.

headline: Canon to Buy Océ, Biggest Printer Maker in Europe
text: Canon, the Japanese maker of cameras, copying machines and other electronics, will make a tender offer worth 730 million euros ($1.1 billion) for Océ, the biggest European printer maker, the two companies said Monday.

headline: Cisco Raises Offer for Tandberg
text: Cisco Systems on Monday raised its bid for the Norwegian video conferencing equipment maker Tandberg by about 11 percent, gaining the acceptance of the target’s two largest shareholders with the new offer.

headline: G.M. Shows Signs of Recovery Despite New Loss
text: DETROIT  General Motors, whose very survival was in doubt this year, is showing signs of life after its brief tour through bankruptcy this summer.

headline: Sampler: Cat Claws, Money Flows and Tree Trimmers
text: Wine Plea Deal | A former Sausalito bon vivant who police say was responsible for a fire that destroyed more than $200 million worth of wine may be changing his plea from not-guilty in a hearing today, according to court records, the San Francisco Chronicle says. Mark C. Anderson’s arson trial is set to begin Tuesday, a case that has drawn international attention.

headline: Submit Your Funny Caption
text: Just Dessert? | Tell us what’s going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned images we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Live-Blogging G.M.’s Financial Results
text: General Motors reported Monday that it lost $1.15 billion in the third quarter on revenue of $28 billion. G.M. also announced it will start paying back $6.7 billion in senior debt to the American and Canadian governments, starting in late December, which is much earlier than planned.

headline: G.M. Reports $1.15 Billion Loss, but Cites Progress
text: General Motors said on Monday that it lost $1.15 billion in the third quarter after emerging from bankruptcy in July 10, but it increased its cash reserves by $3.3 billion.

headline: China’s Growing Military Might
text: As President Obama makes his first visit to China, he has stressed that a rising China can be a source of shared strength. In his latest column for At War, Capt. Tim Hsia considers what a more powerful China might mean for America’s military.

headline: Senate Begins Tackling Health Bill
text: With a Thanksgiving recess looming, the Senate this week will take steps to open debate on its own health care bill even though it remains unclear whether Senator Harry Reid, the Nevada Democrat and majority leader, has the votes to overcome even an initial procedural hurdle.

headline: Evernote Raises $10 Million From Investors
text: Imagine you are at a dinner meeting. You receive a business card from your guest and scribble notes about your conversation. You enjoy the wine, so you peel off the label. On the way out, you have the best idea ever and you jot it on the napkin so you don’t forget.
