headline: AltaRock Geothermal Gets New Boost
text: As part of a newly announced $338 million boost for 123 geothermal energy projects nationwide, the Department of Energy will sink $25 million into what is called an “enhanced” or “engineered” geothermal demonstration project in Oregon being developed in part by AltaRock Energy, which recently halted work on a similar venture in California due to drilling problems.

headline: The Early Word: In China
text: Early this morning in a town hall style meeting with Chinese students, President Obama said that a free Internet was a strength. The comment was a rare challenge to the Chinese government during the president’s Asian tour.

headline: Ask About Community Philanthropy
text: This week, Lorie A. Slutsky, president of the New York Community Trust, will answer questions on community philanthropy, the value of many different approaches to charitable giving, and their importance in maintaining a strong democracy.

headline: Speed Read for Monday, Nov. 16
text: Highlights from today’s media coverage:

headline: Markets Rise as Traders See Growth
text: Wall Street traders latched onto signs on Monday that the dollar would continue to remain weak and that the global recession was easing, riding a rally on three continents that helped push stock averages to their highest levels in more than a year.

headline: Landlords Move to Ban Smoking in Apartment Buildings
text: The movement to ban smoking in New York City has grown so quickly that no place seems immune — certainly not restaurants or bars, and public beaches and parks may not be far behind. Now the efforts are rapidly expanding into the living room.

headline: Unemployment and the Midterms
text: My column today focuses on the politics of unemployment, and the role that joblessness is likely to play in the run-up to the midterms. Last week, though, Matt Yglesias noted that the historical data doesn’t show a particularly strong correlation between unemployment and midterm election outcomes. Here’s the chart, from Seth Masket:

headline: Autos Help Spur Rise in Retail Sales
text: Retail sales in the United States increased by a higher-than-expected 1.4 percent in October from September, helped by a strong demand for cars, the government said Monday.

headline: Media Equation: Taking Aim at Student Muckrakers
text: In today’s Media Equation column, David Carr writes:

headline: Can Academics Be Entrepreneurial?
text: In a recent op-ed piece in The Wall Street Journal, Carl Schramm, Robert Litan and Dane Stangler of the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation called on policy makers to “unleash America’s academic entrepreneurs” as a way “to foster the creation and growth of new businesses.”

headline: Jets Open Thread: The Shoulda Won-Shoulda Lost Standings
text: If the N.F.L. had standings for shoulda won and shoulda lost, the Jets (4-5) would probably be tied for first in the A.F.C. East. New England (6-3) should have beaten the Colts last night, but the Patriots should have lost their season opener against Buffalo.

headline: In Crowded N.L. Rookie Field, Coghlan Stands Out
text: Baseball’s awards week begins Monday with the National League Rookie of the Year award, and if there’s ever been a closer field, I can’t think of it. Nobody stands out far above the pack, and that’s why this will be a fascinating vote.

headline: The Insider | Craig Thompson
text: The Insider profiles emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, the Catskills-based pastry chef Craig Thompson shares his essentials. A self-taught baker, Thompson began his career making lemon meringue pies based on the paintings of Wayne Thiebaud for the cafe at the the Kemper Contemporary Museum in Kansas City. He moved to New York and worked with high-end event-planning companies before settling in the Catskills, where he founded his bespoke bakery, Shandaken Bake.

headline: Talk to The Times: Editor for Digital Initiatives
text: Jim Schachter, editor for digital initiatives, answered questions from readers Nov. 16-20, 2009, in Talk to The Times.

headline: Congress to Investigate Airlines’ Fees
text: The additional fees that irk travelers, for the most part, are not taxed. The government says that fare increases in disguise are costing it extra revenue. Read the full story.

headline: The Morning Skate: Forbes Paints Bright Picture, New Florida Money and Ovie’s Return
text: Forbes magazine published its annual valuations of N.H.L. clubs last week accompanied by the usual package of articles on the hockey business. The team valuations always grab the headlines, and there were no real surprises at the top of the list, where the top five remained the same as last season (The Maple Leafs are first, followed by Rangers, Canadiens, Red Wings and Flyers).

headline: Motorsports Links: Mercedes Takes Over Brawn GP
text: Motorsports news from around the Web…

headline: If Bank Account Is Flabby, Tighten the Body
text: Just because your bank account has lost some of its muscle doesn’t mean your body has to suffer the same fate.

headline: What to Watch Monday: Bon Jovi, Cooking School, a Giant Shark
text: “Inside the Actors Studio” with … Bon Jovi? Over the course of more than 200 shows, James Lipton has interviewed actors, directors, comedians and talk show hosts, with only a couple of exceptions for nonacting musicians (Billy Joel and Elton John, as long as you don’t count “Tommy”). He breaks form to open his 16th season (Bravo, 8 p.m.) with a rock band. Jon Bon Jovi and Richie Sambora have done some acting (Mr. Sambora even got to play Eric Clapton on an episode of “American Dreams”); Tico Torres and David Bryan we’re not so sure about.

headline: Britain’s Climate Goals Unrealistic Without Planetary Tinkering, Group Says
text: The Institution for Mechanical Engineers, a British professional body, argues in a new report that Britain’s goal of slashing emissions by 80 percent from 1990 levels by 2050 shows the government using ambitious, yet distant, targets to mask its failure to tackle the problem adequately in the near-term.

headline: Five Questions for Justin Kirk
text: Justin Kirk would rather play an understudy than be one.

headline: Doing the Math on News Corp.’s Threatened Google Block
text: In a recent interview, Rupert Murdoch, the head of News Corporation, said that the company was considering blocking the searchbots of Google, making its content invisible or at least less visible to the search giant. So far it’s only talk, but Advertising Age decided to do some math to look at the implications of such a move.

headline: For Farmers, a Season to Forget
text: Months of rain, cold weather and crop blight made 2009 “one of the worst, if not the worst, growing seasons in memory,” Jan Ellen Spiegel writes in The New York Times. Most counties in New York and New Jersey have been declared agricultural disaster areas, and Connecticut is awaiting word from the federal government on the same declaration for nearly all of its counties.

headline: Ink Spot Strategy
text: A military maneuver whereby counter-insurgency and reconstruction efforts spread outwards from secured key areas – as an ink spot expands on paper.

headline: ZEUS Computer Program Supports Belichick’s Fourth-Down Bid
text: Frank Frigo and Chuck Bower, champion backgammon players and developers of the ZEUS computer program, have huddled with N.F.L. executives over the years, including with Bill Belichick. They can simulate hundreds of thousands of N.F.L. outcomes in seconds, and their program is customizable to account for the strengths and weaknesses of the offensive and defensive units of each team.

headline: Byrd Will Set Another Record
text: Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, who is already the longest-serving senator in United States history, is set to cross yet another milestone of longevity in the legislative branch. On Wednesday, he’ll surpass Carl Hayden as the longest-serving member of Congress in history, combining terms in both the House and Senate.

headline: Oakland’s Bailey Leads Strong Class of A.L. Rookies
text: Just like the N.L. field, the American League rookie class is crowded, too. When the A.L. award is announced on Monday, expect a flurry of debate.

headline: Pro-Lifers and the Patriarchy
text: Good for The New Yorker’s Avi Zenilman for thinking to turn to Claremont McKenna College’s Jon Shields, author of the excellent The Democratic Virtues of the Christian Right, for perspective on the Stupak Amendment and its attendant controversies. The whole interview is worth your time, but I wanted to pluck out this passage:

headline: Monday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: The A.P. Fact-Checks Palin’s Book
text: The blogosphere has been busy truth-squading “Going Rogue,” the book by the former Alaska governor and vice-presidential candidate Sarah Palin. But The Associated Press decided it had some skin in the game and did, what was for a wire service, a very sharp-elbowed dispatch about the book.

headline: More Coffee From California
text: Two more next-generation left coast coffee roasters just made their Manhattan debuts: Four Barrel Coffee and Ecco Caffè, welcome to New York.

headline: Simmons Files for Bankruptcy as Part of Sale
text: Update | Nov. 16, 5:19 p.m. — Corrects state of bankruptcy filing.

headline: The New Yorker Dines Out
text: The New Yorker’s annual food issue is out this week. Some highlights:

headline: Evernote Raises $10 Million From Investors
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: Looking Back at the Morgenthau Legacy
text: At the end of this year, when Robert M. Morgenthau leaves his job as Manhattan district attorney — the position he has held since 1975 — it will be not just the end of an era for the prosecutor’s office, but also the close of another chapter in the Morgenthau family’s complex, century-long legacy of public service.

headline: Stanford University and Google: Dissertation Process Goes Online
text: Students at Stanford University can now file their dissertations with the university’s registrar by uploading their dissertations and receiving approval online. Then, they can publish using Google and see their works accessible by anyone with a computer.

headline: Foreign Teams Coming to Red Bull Arena
text: This year, the so-called Summer of Soccer made a detour around the New York metropolitan area, save for one game — the Gold Cup final. Next summer, however, promises to be different, with the 2010 World Cup in South Africa dominating the international headlines.

headline: How to Listen
text: The sleek Zune HD should be a hit. It gives you choice: for a $15 monthly fee, the Zune pass service lets you subscribe to your music and stream it. Or download your music and own it. You can do both! Plus it’s pretty, and it’s got an HD radio. But pity the poor microsoft engineers who built this marvel. It’s got everything a music lover could want. Alas, it’s from Microsoft. The end.

headline: How to Surf
text: For 15 years, we’ve interacted with the web by leaning forward at our desks. But soon there may be a computer that departs from the metaphor of the typewriter. There’s a samizdat market in supposed spy photos of an Apple tablet computer, which is said to be a cross between An iPhone and a Mac. It looks like something you could use to surf the net while lying in bed. The primary market for tablets isn’t office workers but teenagers.

headline: How to Watch
text: Why figure out how to connect a snake’s nest of cables to a bunch of boxes just to watch stupid old television? JVC’s TeleDock line of TVs have an iPod dock on the front — right in the middle, where you can’t miss it. If you carry your movie library around in your pocket, now you can plug it in and watch it from your couch.

headline: Devon Energy’s Asset Sale May Draw China’s Interest
text: Devon Energy, the independent oil and gas firm, surprised many on Monday by announcing its plans to divest all of its offshore and international energy properties to concentrate on its domestic onshore energy businesses.

headline: Manufacturing Around the World
text: The Bureau of Labor Statistics recently released updated statistics on job markets around the industrialized world over the last 40 years.

headline: When Feedback Isn’t Just Noise
text: Album cover art has long held a fascination for music and visual art fans alike. But what if the process were reversed, and the musician composed an album inspired by its cover art?

headline: Proposed extensions of Godwin’s Law
text: Godwin’s Law — which says that in any sufficiently long online discussion, someone will compare his opponent to Hitler — is often interpreted to mean that if you do, in fact, start making Nazi comparisons, you’ve lost the argument and can no longer be taken seriously. I’m all for that. (Does this mean that we should no longer take any significant figure in the Republican Party seriously? Yes, it does.)

headline: Answers About Community Colleges, Part 1
text: Each day this week, the Guidance Office — the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts — will feature answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: Publication: Schott’s Almanac 2010
text: Co-vocabularists in Britain might be interested to learn that “Schott’s Almanac 2010” has today been published.

headline: Suntech to Open Plant in Arizona
text: Suntech Power, China’s largest solar panel manufacturer, plans to open its first American plant near Phoenix, the company announced on Monday.

headline: Now Emerging | ‘Bermuda Triangle’
text: With new commissions from “the UK’s hottest emerging talents,” the group show “Bermuda Triangle” opened last Friday at Spring Projects in London, and we’re happy to report that two artists making a splash there are recent T contributors.

headline: Wine Arson Suspect Pleading Guilty in Federal Court
text: The Sausalito businessman who has denied for years that he played any role in setting the 2005 fire that destroyed $250 million of premium wine will plead guilty to arson today in federal court.

headline: With Harry Carson
text: Harry Carson, the Hall of Fame middle linebacker, said he had about 10 concussions during his 13 seasons with the Giants in the 1970s and ’80s. He was found to have postconcussion syndrome in 1990. Carson, who turns 56 this month, says he wants to be sure that other former players receive help and that current players are educated about head injuries. JOE BRESCIA

headline: Vitamin D Shows Heart Benefits in Study
text: Got vitamin D? It may protect you from heart disease.

headline: With a Victory, Wie Comes of Age
text: Entering the weekend, Michelle Wie had never won an L.P.G.A. title and Tiger Woods had never won a tournament in Australia. That’s all changed.

headline: Paul McCartney Is Awarded Gershwin Prize
text: Update | 3:28 p.m. The Library of Congress has named Paul McCartney, prolific songwriter and former Beatle, as the third recipient of its Gershwin Prize for Popular Song. “It is hard to think of another performer and composer who has had a more indelible and transformative effect on popular song and music of several different genres,” the Librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, said in announcing the award on Monday. Mr. McCartney is the first non-American to win the prize, named for the songwriters George and Ira Gershwin: the previous honorees were Paul Simon and Stevie Wonder. The Library said that an all-star tribute concert is planned for the spring of 2010. Mr. McCartney, who has a new CD/DVD called “Good Evening New York City” coming out on Tuesday, said that “as a great admirer of the Gershwins’ songs” he was “highly honored” to be given the prize. The Library of Congress said that Mr. McCartney planned to perform at the tribute show.

headline: Correction
text: An earlier version of this column contained an incorrect statistic for the October unemployment rate. The correct figure is 10.2 percent, not 10.4 percent.

headline: Monday Puzzle: Conversion Factors
text: In a last desperate cry, a technician on an Antarctic expedition yelled out a temperature measurement he made as he fell into a crevasse. The number that he shouted out (covered by the penguin ) was clearly heard, but not the units. It turned out not to make a difference. What was the temperature?(Illustration: Justin Thyme)

headline: Rules to Gorge By
text: A blog called “Eating the Road” has an extremely detailed guide to all-you-can-eat buffets and how to get the most from them. “If you arrive just before the ‘changing of the guard’ or the breakfast to lunch, lunch to dinner time-frames you’ll not only pay the lesser dollar amount (typically $2 to $3) but may also have a wider variety to choose from.” And, “Allow other’s the right of way, especially women, children and the elderly.”

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'The Darjeeling Limited'
text: Wes Anderson, director of "The Darjeeling Limited," discusses how a scene from the movie was created.

headline: The Heartburn Ahead for Landry’s Chief
text: Two events late last week predict two alternative realities for the management buyout of Landry’s. The events show that the company’s chief executive, Tilman J. Fertitta, may have a much rougher time – or at least have to spend more money – acquiring the shares of Landry’s he does not already own.

headline: Larry Charles Signs on for an NBC Pilot
text: After devoting most of his energy in recent years to feature films and cable, the writer, director and producer Larry Charles is returning to network television. Mr. Charles, who wrote numerous episodes for the NBC hit series “Seinfeld” and “Mad About You” in the 1990s, is to write and direct the pilot of an as yet unnamed series for NBC. In this decade, Mr. Charles has directed Sacha Baron Cohen‘s “Borat” and “Bruno” films, and also directed, produced or written episodes for two hit HBO series, “Curb Your Enthusiasm” and “Entourage.” The new NBC show is to have an ensemble cast, be set in a small town and, as Mr. Charles told The Hollywood Reporter, will aim to depict “contemporary American life through the prism of a do-it-yourself homemade aesthetic that will mix mediums.”

headline: Defying Mayor, Council Approves Grace Period for Parking Enforcement
text: Updated, 5:12 p.m. | The New York City Council voted overwhelmingly on Monday to grant ticket-fatigued drivers a five-minute grace period before parking-meter regulations and alternate-side parking rules are enforced, boldly defying Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who hours earlier vowed to veto the measure, saying it would lead to “chaos.”

headline: The madness of the inflation hawks
text: Wow. Matthew Yglesias catches David Ignatius worrying that the Fed may not have enough political support in its efforts to raise interest rates and fight inflation. As Matt correctly notes, this is a remote issue — unemployment is high, inflation is low, and the Fed has no business raising rates any time soon.

headline: Giants Win Without Playing
text: The bye week was going to be good news for the Giants: They couldn’t lose again. It turned out they had a far better week than that.

headline: Cuomo Still Dominating Paterson Among Voters, Poll Shows
text: The footsteps of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo are growing louder for Gov. David A. Paterson.

headline: Amaranth Withdraws Lawsuit Against Touradji Capital
text: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that closed its doors three years ago after losing more than $6.6 billion on wrong-way bets on the price of natural gas, said on Monday that it had dropped its two-month old lawsuit against the hedge fund manager Paul Touradji and his firm, Touradji Capital Management. The suit claimed that Mr. Touradji breached two separate contracts signed in September 2006 that governed the transfer and purchase of Amaranth’s base metals portfolio. Mr. Touradji and his firm were accused of using confidential information about Amaranth’s trading strategy and its positions to unjustly profit. Touradji Capital denied Amaranth’s allegations, saying that its conduct in assuming the risk of Amaranth’s base metal portfolio was professional and lawful. “Amaranth has received and evaluated additional information regarding the transaction, including trading records and other information voluntarily provided by Touradji Capital, that is consistent with Touradji Capital’s position that it did not violate the agreement with Amaranth and did not misuse Amaranth’s proprietary information,” Amaranth said in a statement. “Accordingly, Amaranth has withdrawn its summons and notice and elected not to serve a complaint against Touradji Capital.” “Amaranth’s decision to withdraw its claims vindicates our position that we acted appropriately and with the utmost of professionalism,” Mr. Touradji said in a statement. “It also clearly validates our previous statement that the Amaranth suit was based on the misinformation of two disgruntled former employees involved in separate litigation with T.C.M.” The two former employees are Robert Vollero and Gentry Beach. The men sued Touradji Capital last December, contending that they were owed $50 million in unpaid bonuses. The hedge fund filed a countersuit against the men this month alleging that the two men had lied about their abilities, stole company secrets and defamed the firm. Touradji Capital is seeking more than $250 million as compensation for financial and reputational damage

headline: Godiva Rides in a New Direction
text: At a time when many consumers are drinking tap water rather than bottled water, shopping at Wal-Mart rather than department stores and eating in rather than dining out, a high-end chocolatier is making over its marketing to better fit in with the new mood.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences chose Media Storm, South Norwalk, Conn., as its media planning and buying agency of record for the coming Oscar broadcast on ABC, scheduled for March 7, 2010. Billings were not disclosed. The assignment had been handled by OMD, part of the Omnicom Group.

headline: Obama Walks China’s ‘Great Firewall’
text: While some American Twitter addicts reacted with real and feigned outrage on Monday to President Obama’s confession, during a forum with Chinese students in Shanghai, that he does not personally update the @BarackObama feed — which more than two million people follow on the social network — observers in China were more interested in what he said next: that he disagrees with China’s censorship of the Internet.

headline: F.D.A. Puts Off Oyster Ban
text: The Food and Drug Administration has indefinitely delayed a proposed ban on the sale of raw oysters harvested on the Gulf Coast during warm months in the face of opposition from the oyster industry and legislators from the region. The ban was intended to reduce the risk from Vibrio vulnificus, a bacterium that each year kills about 15 people in the United States each year.

headline: Belichick’s Latest Gamble Backfires
text: Forget the Barry Switzer references. Yes, Bozo the Coach, which is what The New York Post called Switzer in a headline in 1995 when his Dallas Cowboys failed to convert a fourth-down attempt at their 29 against the Eagles, made the same decision that Bill Belichick did Sunday night in New England’s 35-34 loss to Indianapolis.

headline: Attacks Threaten Fragile Security Gains in Cradle of Iraq Insurgency
text: RAMADI, Iraq  Maj. Gen. Tariq al-Youssef caught a fleeting glimpse of the man who wanted him dead.

headline: Coming Home for Thanksgiving
text: In about a week they will start to arrive &#8212 college freshmen home for Thanksgiving. They will be different people from the ones who left, re-entering families that have changed while they were gone. Home will feel embracing, yet confining. Parents will want to know everything, and not want to hear some things. It will be warm and wonderful &#8212 and stressful.

headline: On USA, Four More Years of WWE’s ‘Raw’
text: Pro wrestling will continue its long run as a staple of cable programming after World Wrestling Entertainment announced a new deal Monday to remain on the USA network for another four years.

headline: Travel Deals: 25% off ‘Christmas Spectacular’ in New York
text: The holiday season must be around the corner. A 76-foot Norway spruce arrived at Rockefeller Center on Thursday and “The Radio City Christmas Spectacular” kicked off shows the following night.

headline: A Hearty Thanksgiving Raviolo
text: During a stint on Bravo’s “Top Chef” reality show, chef Ariane Duarte won raves for her Thanksgiving turkey. But while dining recently at her Montclair, N.J., restaurant, CulinAriane, it was a seasonal vegetarian dish that made the biggest impression.

headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Examine 3Com Options Trading
text: Now that insider trading is again a hot topic on Wall Street, it is no surprise that the unusual trading in 3Com options before its $2.7 billion sale to Hewlett-Packard is being examined.

headline: To the MAXXI | Zaha Hadid’s Museum in Rome
text: It may take the nation that invented Fellini to truly embrace Zaha Hadid, the whirlwind architect who is by turns sugar and spitfire. Italians stress the “z” in “Zaha” as they do in “czarina,” and treated her like one during last weekend’s opening festivities for the National Museum of the XXI Century Arts (MAXXI) in Rome, the patient realization of a public commission won by Hadid in 1999. At a kickoff event, Hadid warned that her Italian “was nothing” but could not dissuade a crowd of journalists from lunging at her like Anita Ekberg rushing into the Trevi Fountain. With nearly 65,000 square feet of exhibition space, however, it is the Italian Ministry of Culture and Heritage that underwent a $224 million baptism, in the hopes of refreshing the ancient fonts of western art and architecture.

headline: College Ivy Sprouts at a Connecticut Prison
text: CHESHIRE, Conn. — In many ways it was just another day, another class of Wesleyan University, one of the more selective colleges in the Northeast. The topic was multiculturalism in schools. The discussion focused on methods of evaluating the rhetorical skills of various commentators, from Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. to Dinesh D’Souza.

headline: Balyasny Says Inquiry Found Nothing Improper
text: Balyasny Asset Management, the big Chicago hedge fund run by Dmitry Balyasny, discovered no signs of improper activity after conducting an internal review into trading records and communications of a former employee who recently surfaced in the insider trading case against the Galleon Group.

headline: Obama Walks China’s ‘Great Firewall’
text: From our colleagues at The Lede:

headline: Unlocking the Mercedes With Your Smartphone
text: Bit by bit (or byte by byte), carmakers are connecting their vehicles not only to Internet-based services but also to owners’ smartphones. The latest is Mercedes-Benz, which announced a new telematics platform Monday that beefs up its navigation system with traffic and weather information and lets drivers lock or unlock their cars using an iPhone or BlackBerry.

headline: In My Pantry
text: Kerri gathered up her garden and prepared it for the winter. –MB

headline: Q & A With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Study Ties Restrooms to Illnesses on Cruises
text: It is the perfect way to spoil a vacation, and it has happened 66 times since 2005: an outbreak of gastrointestinal illness aboard a cruise ship. Now a study suggests one possible culprit: dirty restrooms.

headline: Continuing Unemployment Is Predicted by Fed Chief
text: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, warned on Monday that high unemployment and a continued reluctance by banks to make loans were likely to slow the economic recovery for the next year.

headline: More New York High Schools Get A’s
text: In releasing the third annual round of A through F grades for New York City high schools on Monday, the Education Department produced a rather murky picture: The number of schools receiving A’s on the city’s report cards increased this year, but more schools received C’s and D’s. And just one school received an F.

headline: Small-Scale Butchers
text: Twelve rabbits lost their lives in Bushwick Sunday afternoon.

headline: Taliban Militants Fire Rockets on Crowded Bazaar Northeast of Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban militants fired rockets on a bazaar northeast of Kabul on Monday, near the site of a meeting between French soldiers and local tribal leaders, and police officials said 10 Afghan civilians were killed and 28 wounded.

headline: News of Hockey, 11/16/09: Ownership Change for Money-Losing Panthers
text: The Florida Panthers have new owners after it is announced on Monday that minority investors Stuart Siegel and Cliff Viner have bought control of the Cats from majority owner Alan Cohen. The pair take over a team that lost $14 million last season, the biggest loss from any club in the league other than the money-hemorrhaging Phoenix Coyotes.

headline: Taint of Corruption Is No Barrier to U.S. Visa
text: Several times a year, Teodoro Nguema Obiang arrives at the doorstep of the United States from his home in Equatorial Guinea, on his way to his $35 million estate in Malibu, Calif., his fleet of luxury cars, his speedboats and private jet. And he is always let into the country.

headline: Healthy Thanksgiving Favorites
text: Thanksgiving dinner doesn’t have to be the kickoff to a month of holiday overeating, ending with a regretful New Year’s resolution and a January diet. The holiday can be festive, even indulgent, without dishes loaded with fats and salt.

headline: Taking Questions on Money and Divorce
text: “Ask an Expert” is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs.

headline: Mercedes Grand Prix is Launched
text: The rumors were in the air, but Mercedes wanted to keep in quiet until the season ended, and no doubt the details were resolved. Now it’s news, now it’s done: Mercedes is leaving McLaren as a part owner of the team and going out alone as the principal shareholder of the Brawn team, relaunching as Mercedes Grand Prix.

headline: Inspectors Fear Iran Is Hiding Nuclear Plants
text: WASHINGTON  International inspectors who gained access to Iran’s newly revealed underground nuclear enrichment plant voiced strong suspicions in a report on Monday that the country was concealing other atomic facilities.

headline: The Washington Blade and Several Other Gay Newspapers Are Shut Down
text: Gay newspapers in several United States cities, including The Washington Blade, shut down on Monday, as the company that owned them, Window Media, abruptly went out of business. Window Media had been in serious financial trouble, but employees said they had expected a reorganization or sale — not a liquidation.

headline: Warriors Trade Stephen Jackson to Charlotte
text: The Golden State Warriors placated the disgruntled Stephen Jackson on Monday, trading him to the Charlotte Bobcats with Acie Law in exchange for Raja Bell and Vladimir Radmanovic.

headline: Can’t Complain? Writing About Pet Peeves
text: Overview | How can students express their complaints in articulate and constructive ways? In this lesson, students read The New York Times “Complaint Box” series and use descriptive and persuasive writing strategies to communicate their own pet peeves succinctly and productively.

headline: Scientist Says She Was the Call Girl Who Wrote the Diary
text: The debate over the authorship and authenticity of the books and blog posts that eventually became the Showtime series “Secret Diary of a Call Girl” — criticized for supposedly glamorizing prostitution — seems to be over. A British scientist, Brooke Magnanti, told The Sunday Times in London that she was “Belle de Jour,” the escort whose sexual experiences were recounted in the blog and in three books. Ms. Magnanti, who works as a child health researcher at the University of Bristol in England, said she started in the sex trade in 2003, when she was finishing her Ph.D, and continued for more than a year. She explained that she had decided to go public now because she feared an ex-boyfriend was about to expose her. She added on her blog that she was relieved “to be able to defend what my experience of sex work is like to all the skeptics and doubters.”

headline: A Climate Communicator’s Indian Journey
text: Eric Roston, a former Time magazine journalist and author of “The Carbon Age,” spent three weeks roaming India at the invitation of the United States State Department to explore and talk about north-south differences in talking about climate change. (He told me that his talks and interactions were not in any way shaped by government officials.) The journey wrapped up at a conference organized by the International Federation of Environmental Journalists.

headline: Drug Activist Leaves Kunstler Fund for Senate Bid
text: “Disturbing the Universe,” a new documentary on the civil rights lawyer William M. Kunstler, opened Friday at Cinema Village, in the East Village.

headline: Nuclear Plant Built for Iran Is Delayed, Russia Says
text: MOSCOW  Russia added a new note of discord to its relations with Iran on Monday, announcing that a Russian-built nuclear power plant in Iran would not come online at the end of the year as planned.

headline: More Families Struggled to Put Food on the Table
text: The percentage of Americans households that “had difficulty providing enough food for all their members due to a lack of resources” rose to 14.6 percent in 2008 from 11.1 percent in 2007, according to the Agriculture Department. That’s an increase of 4 million households, 17 million in total.

headline: An Adviser to Murdoch Is Leaving News Corp.
text: Gary Ginsberg, a close adviser to Rupert Murdoch for 11 years who often served as a liaison between the conservative Mr. Murdoch and the Democratic Party, will leave News Corporation at the end of the year.

headline: Warhol Children’s Book Illustrations to Be Sold at Auction
text: They surely will not fetch anywhere the $43.7 million that someone paid last week for one of his seminal silk-screen paintings. But illustrations that Andy Warhol did for a children’s book series in the late 1950s are to be offered by Bloomsbury Auctions on Dec. 9, along with work by other children’s authors and illustrators, including Beatrix Potter, A.A. Milne, Maurice Sendak and Edward Gorey. The early Warhol illustrations, conventional in both style and subject, accompanied the Doubleday Book Club’s “Best in Children’s Books” series, like a version of “The Little Red Hen” that shows the title character sowing seeds in a field as a lazy cat, dog and mouse look on. The estimated price is $500 to $600 for each copy.

headline: Bernanke Sees Tight Lending Weighing on Economy
text: The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, warned Monday that high unemployment and a continued reluctance of banks to make loans were likely to slow the economic recovery for the next year, The New York Times’s Edmund L. Andrews reports.

headline: Work-Related Injuries Underreported
text: Employers and workers routinely underreport work-related injuries and illnesses, calling into question the accuracy of nationwide data that the Occupational Safety and Health Administration compiles each year, the Government Accountability Office said Monday.

headline: Putting Jennings’s 55 Into Perspective
text: Two days after the rookie point guard Brandon Jennings set the N.B.A. abuzz with 55 points against the Golden State Warriors, the feat is still being put into historical perspective.

headline: Night and Day, in Tunisia
text: The North African country of Tunisia is known for its golden beaches, sunny weather and affordable luxuries. The new 280-room Radisson hotel, in the former French colonial port city of Monastir, is no exception.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: 1.) How hard is it to find a job in your city?

headline: Reaction to Newlywed’s Banking Complaint
text: Nicole Collins’s tale of how bank employees resisted her request to add her new husband to her savings account brought in a deluge of opinions — some who saw it as an issue of female financial independence, others who saw it as a function of pushy banking salesmanship.

headline: Community Cheers as New Library Opens
text: The opening of the new Lafayette Library and Learning Center on Saturday morning offered a needed respite from the doldrums of downbeat economic news along with some hope that communities can rise above the current bout of budget woes to create something amazing.

headline: Shuttle Atlantis Lifts Off for 11-Day Mission
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Atlantis vaulted into orbit on Monday and set off after the International Space Station, carrying 15 tons of spare parts and equipment as a hedge against failures after the shuttle fleet is retired next year.

headline: Have You Tried Marketing Your Business With Facebook?
text: We recently posted a guide to marketing with Facebook. One of the main points of the guide, written by Kermit Pattison, is that you now have the opportunity to target your customers at precisely the right moment. For example, from the guide:

headline: Hunger in U.S. at a 14-Year High
text: WASHINGTON  The number of Americans who lived in households that lacked consistent access to adequate food soared last year, to 49 million, the highest since the government began tracking what it calls “food insecurity” 14 years ago, the Department of Agriculture reported Monday.

headline: Solar Developer Abandons Water Plans
text: A solar developer caught in the crossfire of the West’s water wars is waving the white flag.

headline: Indie Math: More Releases, More Market Share, Less Revenue Per Film
text: Roger Smith, a New York-based analyst with Global Media Intelligence, let slip some interesting numbers while chatting in Santa Monica, Calif., where he spent some time during the recent American Film Market. Back in 1993, Mr. Smith reckoned, small independent film distributors like, say, Samuel Goldwyn Entertainment, captured about 1.9 percent of the domestic box-office receipts, or $96.3 million, with just 63 pictures, which then represented about 24.3 percent of the films released in the United States.

headline: YouTube + Univision = TuTube
text: YouTube said Monday that it reached an agreement with Univision, the most-watched Spanish language television network in the United States, to make a wide range of its programs available on the video sharing site.

headline: Jay-Z, Will and Jada Pinkett Smith Have Joined ‘Fela!’ as Producers
text: Jay-Z, Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith have signed on as producers of the new Broadway musical “Fela!” and will attend the show’s opening night at the Eugene O’Neill Theater next Monday, Nov. 23, a publicist for the production said.

headline: Airline Tests Retail Sales at 35,000 Feet
text: Air travelers in the United States are already paying for sandwiches and drinks, pillows and headsets. So, as airlines look for more ways to help their bottom lines, they have started asking the next logical question: Why not sell limousine services or even tickets to Broadway shows?

headline: An Exhibition Examines the Origins of Happiness
text: LONDON | “Whatever we can achieve through merit and effort cannot make us truly happy, wrote the Italian philosopher Giorgio Agamben. “Happiness can be ours only through magic.”

headline: Now Showing | Smoking in the Dressing Room
text: In the wake of our recent mayoral election, let’s take a moment to remember New York before Bloomberg cleared the air in bars, clubs and restaurants by banning smoking. Sales of Febreze aren’t the only thing that plummeted in the city: according to the photographer Susanna Howe, no one wants to be pictured smoking anymore. “Even those people who you wouldn’t think would be all squeamish about it dash to put the cigarette out when you raise the camera to your face,” she said.

headline: The Claim: A Person Can Contract Two Colds at One Time
text: THE FACTS The rhinovirus that causes most cases of the common cold comes in many strains  at least 99, to be exact.

headline: From Melrose Place to Broadway
text: After moving out of Melrose Place, Ashlee Simpson is ready to take on Broadway.

headline: Is There Such a Thing as Agro-Imperialism?
text: Dr. Robert Zeigler, an eminent American botanist, flew to Saudi Arabia in March for a series of high-level discussions about the future of the kingdom’s food supply. Saudi leaders were frightened: heavily dependent on imports, they had seen the price of rice and wheat, their dietary staples, fluctuate violently on the world market over the previous three years, at one point doubling in just a few months. The Saudis, rich in oil money but poor in arable land, were groping for a strategy to ensure that they could continue to meet the appetites of a growing population, and they wanted Zeigler’s expertise.

headline: Wesleyan’s New Satellite Campus? Cheshire Correctional Institution
text: Over on our sister blog City Room, my colleague Alison Leigh Cowan has just posted a fascinating article on an academic program that Wesleyan University in Connecticut is offering inside a nearby prison.

headline: The Science of Mysterious Maple Syrup Odors
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: Entertainment Industry Workers Urge That Nursing Home Stay Open
text: With the nursing home that has tended generations of actors, directors and crew members scheduled to close and evict many of its elderly residents at year’s end, a coalition representing entertainment industry workers has issued a public letter urging that the decision be reversed. “We know there is enough money to fulfill” existing commitments to the current residents, the coalition, Saving the Lives of Our Own, maintains. The group’s letter, addressed to Jeffrey Katzenberg, one of several Hollywood heavyweights who serves on the board of the Motion Picture and Television Fund, came after the fund published ads in trade publications last week playing down the impact of the proposed closing. To fail to “change the board’s direction,” the coalition also contends, would provide only “further evidence of the moral bankruptcy of the existing board.”

headline: A New Reactor Concept Inches Forward
text: The Energy Department plans to announce on Tuesday a significant step toward building a new kind of nuclear reactor that could be used to replace the fossil fuels normally needed to complete high-temperature processing at chemical plants, fertilizer factories and oil refineries.

headline: Behind the Retail Data, Cautious Consumers
text: The glory of the fall of 2009 — at least when it comes to economic statistics — is that the comparisons are so easy.

headline: Excerpt: 'Glee'
text: The Fox musical comedy, which follows a high school glee club, is a hit within the Broadway community.

headline: No Tuna Surprise
text: [March 19 | Updated  Few were surprised when the United States could not muster support for its call to halt international trade in Atlantic bluefin tuna at this year’s meeting of parties to the international convention on trade in endangered species.]

headline: A Few Final Tidbits From the Governors Awards
text: At Saturday night’s Governors Awards, the brand new ceremony for those getting honorary Oscars, this reporter was happily seated at a table with John Lasseter — one of many film academy governors who were distributed around the room to entertain the rest of us. Mr. Lasseter seemed a bit flustered by a suggestion that, with all the job-switching going on at Disney these days, he might swap his Pixar duties for a stint at ESPN.
