text: View Independent Retail Week in a larger map

headline: Dobbs-Menendez Match in N.J.?
text: After Lou Dobbs quit his perch as an anchor on CNN last week, there has been speculation that he would run for public office, including a New York Post account suggesting that he could run for United States Senate in 2012 against Bob Menendez, the Democratic incumbent from New Jersey.

headline: Congress Digs Deeper Into BofA-Merrill Deal
text: From Louise Story, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Ken Ober, ‘Remote Control’ Host, Is Dead at 52
text: Updated | 4:29 p.m. Ken Ober, a brassy comedian best known as the host of the 1980s-era MTV game show “Remote Control,” died this weekend, Mark Measures, an agent at Abrams Artists who worked with him, said on Monday. Mr. Ober, who lived in Santa Monica, Calif., was 52. The cause of death was not immediately known.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Flyers End Devils’ Quest for Record
text: A Monday night of uninteresting matchups, relieved only by Flyers-Devils, in which Jacques Lemaire’s men brought their eight-game unbeaten streak to South Philly. The Devils also went into the contest with a chance to make history by taking maximum points from each of their first 10 road games, matching a standard set by Buffalo in 2006-7. Could they do it? Home teams listed first:

headline: Obama to Form Financial Fraud Task Force
text: President Obama will issue an executive order on Tuesday that will create an administration-wide financial fraud task force, according to an official who has been briefed on the matter.

headline: Checking the Right Boxes, but Failing the Patient
text: The voice on the phone was authoritative, even brusque. A father was calling our after-hours line to ask about his teenage daughter.

headline: FIFA Employs Age-Old Method to Ensure Playoff Fairness
text: Egypt’s stunning, hard-fought, last-minute victory over Algeria on Saturday, marred by violence on the eve of the game, forces the North African rivals to face off in another “match of hate” to determine which team will advance to the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.

headline: How Will Your Philanthropic Giving Change This Holiday Season?
text: This week’s “Wealth Matters” column in The Times looks at some of the surprising ways giving is (and is not) changing amid the economic downturn.

headline: Past, Present and Future of the Parking Garage
text: Yes, there’s a parking meter — and parking time stamp machines and parking attendant hats. Just about everything you can imagine about the subject of parking is to be found in an exhibition at the National Building Museum in Washington.

headline: A Double Dose of the Cold
text: In today’s “Really?” column, Anahad O’Connor explores whether a person can have more than one cold at a time.

headline: Reducing Deforestation (and CO2) in Brazil
text: Brazil is among the globe’s top 10 greenhouse gas emitters — largely due to burning of forest land for other uses.

headline: Learning Math From the Rubik’s Cube
text: Can a Rubik’s Cube boost student confidence?

headline: A Powerful but Unknown Washington Player
text: The Congressional Budget Office and its mild-mannered director, Douglas W. Elmendorf, may not be well known, but they are playing a large role in the health care debate.

headline: Breaching a Barrier to Fight Brain Cancer
text: Dr. Howard Riina threaded a slender tube through a maze of arteries in Dennis Sugrue’s brain, watching X-ray images on a monitor to track his progress. At the site where a previous operation had removed a malignant tumor, he infused a drug called mannitol and unleashed a flood of the cancer drug Avastin.

headline: Capital Waits as Budget Chief Crunches Numbers
text: WASHINGTON  Most people have never heard of Douglas W. Elmendorf. But all of official Washington is waiting to hear what he has to say.

headline: A Dental Shift: Implants Instead of Bridges
text: If I have one serious regret about my age, it is that my permanent teeth developed before New York, my hometown, got fluoridated water. I first lost a permanent molar to decay in my early 20s, and the resulting bridge has had to be replaced several times in subsequent decades, ultimately as a four-part apparatus.

headline: G.O.P. Senator Supports a Filibuster for Judicial Nominee
text: Senator Jeff Sessions, the ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee, said Monday that he would support a filibuster on Tuesday in an effort to block an up-or-down vote on confirming David F. Hamilton to be a federal appeals court judge.

headline: Congo’s Army Accused of Striking Villages as Refugees Waited for Measles Shots
text: The medical charity Doctors Without Borders has accused the Congolese Army of attacking the villages of Rwandan refugees as they waited for measles shots offered by the charity.

headline: New Guidelines on Breast Cancer Draw Opposition
text: Karen Young-Levi has gone for a mammogram every year since she turned 40, and she would not skip the procedure any more than she would skip her spin classes at the gym or stop wearing her seat belt. “It’s my security blanket,” said Ms. Young-Levi, 43, of Medford, N.J.

headline: The 0-10 Nets Say They’ve Had Enough
text: The Nets are mad as heck and they aren’t going to take it anymore. They hope their fans are, too.

headline: When Illness Spoils the Cruise Vacation
text: Cruise ships conjure up visions of fine dining, entertainment and relaxation. But as Nicholas Bakalar explains in today’s Science Times, you may want to take special care to wash your hands thoroughly after visiting the restroom.

headline: Performa 09 | Guido van der Werve
text: Chess masters may insist that kings and queens and rooks and knights speak to them, but at the Marshall Chess Club on West 10th Street on Friday night, the game actually sang — or, at least, plunked tunefully.

headline: Fluoride, 1931
text: A dentist named Frederick S. McKay opened his practice in 1901 in Colorado Springs and soon noticed something odd about his patients: many of them had brown, mottled teeth, very ugly but also highly resistant to decay.

headline: Shopping With Palo Samko
text: It's not hard to find well-designed folding chairs -- especially useful for the holiday season -- if you know where to look.

headline: Dear Banker, Don’t Call Me
text: IN any marriage, there is a natural division of labor.

headline: To Park Your Pilgrims
text: WITH Thanksgiving fast approaching, many hosts face a perennial challenge: finding enough chairs so that a special someone isn’t relegated to the floor.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Nov. 16
text: What makes a photograph funny? The question can be debated endlessly, but let it suffice for this brief paragraph to note that Stephen Crowley’s picture of security personnel attending the presidential visit to China is amusing; in a droll, understated, Crowlian kind of way. As your eye scans the picture, most likely from left to right, you pass over figures from two cultures that are as alike in their composure as they are different in dress. Then you reach the punchline: that last pair of hands, clasped in an ever-so-slightly anxious fashion; as who wouldn’t be whose job was to protect the president of the United States? We can admire the formality of the first three figures and identify with the fourth.

headline: Volcker Criticizes Accounting Proposal
text: A proposal to give banking regulators authority to block accounting standards is “a terrible idea,” Paul A. Volcker, a former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said Monday.

headline: Double X Is Folded Into Slate Magazine
text: After only six months, the Slate Group is folding Double X, a Web site named after the pair of X chromosomes in women, and transforming it into one of the sections of the online magazine Slate.

headline: GMAC Chief Resigns as Firm Prepares for More Aid
text: GMAC, the troubled former finance arm of General Motors, said on Monday that its chief executive, Alvaro de Molina, had resigned and would be replaced by Michael A. Carpenter, a former top executive at Citigroup.

headline: BlogTalk: Detainees, Obama’s Asia Tour
text: Federal authorities on Monday are touring a maximum security prison in northwest Illinois that the government might buy to house Guantánamo Bay detainees.

headline: Video: Inside the Congressional Budget Office
text: The Congressional Budget Office is a serious player in the health care debate, but the people behind it are less well-known. That’s by design. They prefer working anonymously, and try to avoid much of the political back and forth that often characterizes deliberations in Congress.

headline: Buffett Discloses Stakes in Exxon and Nestlé
text: Warren E. Buffett‘s investment company, Berkshire Hathaway, on Monday disclosed its stakes in Exxon Mobil and Nestlé, as well as in the waste disposal company Republic Services and the Travelers Companies.

headline: Regulators File Lawsuit Against Alleged ‘Green’ Investment Ponzi Scheme
text: Post updated | November 18

headline: Panel Urges Mammograms at 50, Not 40
text: Most women should start regular breast cancer screening at age 50, not 40, according to new guidelines released Monday by an influential group that provides guidance to doctors, insurance companies and policy makers.

headline: A Market Segment ‘Glee’ Can Call Its Own: Theater Folk
text: Eleven o’clock is late for teenagers to start a party on a weeknight, but this was a special occasion. The high school-age cast of Broadway’s “Bye Bye Birdie” had gathered to watch “Glee,” Fox’s hourlong musical comedy series that has become a cult favorite among the theater community in New York.

headline: U.S. Says Kuwait Company Overbilled It by Millions for Troops’ Food
text: ATLANTA  A Kuwaiti company defrauded the United States government of tens of millions of dollars by exaggerating the cost of providing food to troops in Iraq, Kuwait and Jordan, federal prosecutors here said Monday.

headline: Cannabis Cafe Opens in Oregon
text: Update | Tuesday | 7:37 a.m. At precisely 4:20 p.m. last Friday afternoon, the Cannabis Café, the first coffee house in Oregon catering to licensed users of medical marijuana, opened for business in Portland.*

headline: After Microsoft, Bringing a High-Tech Eye to Professional Kitchens
text: BELLEVUE, Wash.  Inside a nondescript warehouse on a nondescript street of this Seattle suburb is a research laboratory that looks like it came out of a James Bond movie  had Q the gadget master been a gastronome.

headline: Correction: A Fulbright in Nigeria That Turned Into a Show
text: In a previous version of this article, a quote was incorrectly attributed. The playwright, Dan Hoyle, did not say, "When he met me, it was like a light to his life." The man he was writing about, Williams Ajayi, said it. Also, a passage may have left the incorrect impression that the author interviewed Mr. Hoyle about his reunion with Mr. Ajayi. The author heard the story at a post-performance discussion, not in a personal conversation with Mr. Hoyle.

headline: A Different Type of Senioritis
text: Alison Lacey is a 6-foot senior point guard for Iowa State. Alison, whose hometown is Canberra, Australia, is a communications studies major and, like she did last season, will give The Quad an inside look at the Cyclones this year.

headline: Getting Screened for Breast Cancer
text: Most women can wait until they’re 50 to have a mammogram, then get screened every other year. That’s the latest recommendation from an influential task force that reviewed dozens of medical studies and determined that routine mammographs in younger women often resulted in unnecessary tests and unneeded treatments.

headline: Perfect Fit: Young Actor and His Role
text: Franco Wicks is the sort of ferociously funny, privately pained character that any rising Hollywood star would love to play  and on Broadway no less, in this fall’s production of "Superior Donuts." Instead Franco is being played, to acclaim, by an actor who is virtually unknown in New York or Los Angeles, Jon Michael Hill. His is one of the few current Broadway play ensembles that lack a big-name star.

headline: The Long Count
text: An interactive calendar for converting between Mayan dates and modern dates.

headline: A Case in Antiquities for ‘Finders Keepers’
text: Zahi Hawass regards the Rosetta Stone, like so much else, as stolen property languishing in exile. “We own that stone,” he told Al Jazeera, speaking as the secretary general of Egypt’s Supreme Council of Antiquities.

headline: A Stand-Up Approach to Abortion Rights
text: The setting for a new television commercial by supporters of abortion rights is an unexpected one: a comedy club.

headline: On Our Radar…
text: 1.) How to rev up the electric-car revolution.

headline: Larry Charles Returning to Network Television
text: After devoting most of his energy in recent years to feature films and cable, the writer, director and producer Larry Charles is returning to network television. Mr. Charles, left, who wrote many episodes for the NBC hit series “Seinfeld” and “Mad About You” in the 1990s, is to write and direct the pilot of an as-yet-unnamed series for NBC. In this decade Mr. Charles has directed Sacha Baron Cohen’s “Borat” and “Brüno” films, and also directed, produced or written episodes for the HBO hit series “Curb Your Enthusiasm” and “Entourage.” The new NBC show is to have an ensemble cast and be set in a small town. Mr. Charles told The Hollywood Reporter that the show would try to depict “contemporary American life through the prism of a do-it-yourself homemade aesthetic that will mix mediums.”

headline: Writer of ‘Secret Diary’ Comes Forward
text: The debate over the authorship and authenticity of the books and blog postings that eventually became the Showtime television series “Secret Diary of a Call Girl,” criticized for supposedly glamorizing prostitution, seems to be over. A British scientist, Brooke Magnanti, told The Sunday Times of London that she was Belle de Jour, the escort whose sexual experiences were recounted in the blog and in three books. Ms. Magnanti, who works as a child health researcher at the University of Bristol, said she started in the sex trade in 2003, when she was finishing her Ph.D., and continued for more than a year. She explained that she had decided to go public now because she feared an ex-boyfriend was about to expose her, and added on her blog that she was relieved “to be able to defend what my experience of sex work is like to all the skeptics and doubters.”

headline: Football Rules TV
text: NBC’s coverage of the New England Patriots-Indianapolis Colts game delivered the highest ratings for a “Sunday Night Football” broadcast since September. Although final figures were unavailable on Monday, Nielsen’s preliminary overnight numbers were higher than every other “Sunday Night Football” game this season except the Sept. 20 matchup of the New York Giants and Dallas Cowboys, which drew 24.8 million viewers when final ratings were released. ABC was runner-up, led by its 9 p.m. drama “Desperate Housewives,” which had 14.4 million viewers, “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” (11.6 million viewers at 8 p.m.) and “Brothers & Sisters” (10.2 million at 10). CBS and Fox finished in a virtual tie for third place.

headline: Women Earn Less Than Men, Especially at the Top
text: In most jobs, the gap between men’s and women’s earnings narrows greatly when you adjust for factors like career path and experience. But at the top of the income scale — jobs paying more than $100,000 — the salary gap between equally qualified men and women is still vast.

headline: A Gershwin Prize for McCartney
text: The Library of Congress has named Paul McCartney, below, the third recipient of its Gershwin Prize for Popular Song. “It is hard to think of another performer and composer who has had a more indelible and transformative effect on popular song and music of several different genres,” the Librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, said in announcing the award on Monday. Mr. McCartney is the first non-American to win the prize; the previous honorees were Paul Simon and Stevie Wonder. The library said an all-star tribute concert was planned for the spring. Mr. McCartney said that “as a great admirer of the Gershwins’ songs” he was “highly honored” to be given the prize, and the library said he planned to play at the tribute show.

headline: Warhol Kids’ Drawings Get Their 15 Minutes
text: They surely won’t fetch anywhere near the $43.7 million someone paid last week for one of Andy Warhol’s seminal silk-screen paintings. But illustrations that Warhol did for a children’s book series in the late 1950s are to be offered by Bloomsbury Auctions on Dec. 9, along with work by other children’s authors and illustrators, including Beatrix Potter, A. A. Milne, Maurice Sendak and Edward Gorey. The early Warhol illustrations (one is above), conventional in style and subject, accompanied the Doubleday Book Club’s Best in Children’s Books series, like a version of “The Little Red Hen” that shows the title character sowing seeds in a field as a lazy cat, dog and mouse look on. The estimated price is $500 to $600 for the four-book lot.

headline: Entertainment Workers Plead for Nursing Home
text: With the nursing home that has tended generations of actors, directors and crew members scheduled to close and evict many of its elderly residents at year’s end, a coalition representing entertainment industry workers has issued a public letter urging the Motion Picture & Television Fund, which underwrites the home, to reverse its decision. “We know there is enough money to fulfill” existing commitments to the current residents, the coalition, Saving the Lives of Our Own, said. The group’s letter, addressed to Jeffrey Katzenberg, one of several Hollywood heavyweights on the fund’s board, came after the fund published ads in trade publications last week minimizing the impact of the proposed closing. To fail to “change the board’s direction,” the coalition contends, would only provide “further evidence of the moral bankruptcy of the existing board.”

headline: Ashlee Simpson To Play Roxie Hart On Broadway
text: After playing the Orange Bowl and “Saturday Night Live,” Ashlee Simpson is ready to take on Broadway. Ms. Simpson, 25, announced on Monday that she would play Roxie Hart in the musical “Chicago” for 10 weeks, beginning on Nov. 30. Ms. Simpson, best known for the hit CDs “Autobiography” and “I Am Me” and a much publicized lip-synching episode on television, has played Roxie before, on the West End in London, but is to be making her Broadway debut. Most recently, she has been a regular on the revived version of “Melrose Place” on the CW network, but that show’s producers announced last month that her character would be written out of the story.

headline: Palin Onstage, Still Moving Off Message
text: There were no questions about the Bush doctrine, but Sarah Palin’s appearance Monday on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” to promote her memoir looked less like a celebratory comeback than a redo of the presidential campaign.

headline: Travels in Cyberspace: The Monday Report
text: When a writer for the Travel section of The Washington Post was in Paris recently, he found culinary happiness in a somewhat unlikely place: a wine-shop-turned-bistro called Les Papilles, run by a man named Bertrand Bluy And he wasn’t alone. “During a recent lunch, all 15 wood-and-iron bistro tables were occupied mostly by Parisians stimulating their papilles (taste buds) with the delicately seasoned specials of the day — gazpacho of fresh mushrooms followed by slow-simmered duck flank in a sweet and pungent sauce with new potatoes and vegetables — as well as farm-made cheeses and Bluy’s inventive desserts,” writes Robert V. Camuto, in an article that appeared this weekend.

headline: Gruden Extends Contract With ESPN
text: Scratch Jon Gruden off your wish lists, N.F.L. owners and college athletic directors. At least for now, the former Bucs and Raiders head coach, who has made a widely praised debut this season as an analyst for “Monday Night Football,” plans to remain a talking head and stay off the sidelines. On Monday, ESPN announced that he had signed a multiyear contract extension with the network.

headline: Liberty, Equality, Gastronomy: Paris via a 19th-Century Guide
text: A marvelous painting of a gourmand at his table hangs in the Musée Carnavalet in Paris  a portly, pink-faced figure happily gorging on a regal casserole, with a bottle of wine at one elbow and a luscious-looking soufflé at the other. It is traditionally believed to be a portrait of Alexandre-Balthazar-Laurent Grimod de la Reynière, an aristocrat notorious in Napoleonic France for gratifying his palate with the same abandon as his contemporary the Marquis de Sade showed in indulging carnal desires. Whether or not the painting is actually Grimod’s likeness, it captures the eccentric, omnivorous spirit that made him not only a gustatory symbol in the Paris of his day, but the grand-père of all modern food writers as well.

headline: Christian Rock Borrows an Edge From iPhone
text: It only took a mere $8.97 for David Crowder*Band to demonstrate that it’s in a different league from its Christian rock peers. At Terminal 5 on Friday night, before playing “Church Music  Dance (!),” a surprisingly credible disco song, Mr. Crowder announced: “This one has New York City all over it. This is like Studio 54 right here.” (Give or take six blocks and three decades, but who’s counting?)

headline: Ponzi du Jour: S.E.C. Uncovers ‘Green’ Scheme
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Monday that it had uncovered yet another Ponzi scheme, this time with a company that purported to invest in environmentally friendly, or “green,” projects. The agency has been focusing attention on such fraud cases ever since Bernard L. Madoff‘s multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme went undetected for years and years.

headline: Auctions, Auctions Everywhere
text: In a column in The New York Times on Sunday, Richard Thaler explored what he called the diabolical economics of Swoopo, an online auction site. Swoopo sells merchandise, typically for below its price elsewhere, but charges 60 cents for every bid. Auction prices rise in one-cent increments, which means that Swoopo ends up making a lot of money off its bidders.

headline: Desperately Seeking Dad: A Murder Mystery
text: Zachary Lazar’s father died in 1975 of distinctly unnatural causes in a stairwell at a Phoenix parking garage. His name was Ed Lazar, and he was an accountant with ties to the once-booming land-fraud community in Arizona. Though Ed Lazar’s younger son, Zachary, did not know his father well, he has written a pungent-sounding but maddeningly vague book about Ed’s murder. Thanks to Mr. Lazar’s strenuously literary efforts, total strangers can now find themselves baffled by the Ed Lazar story, too.

headline: Hung Jury
text: “We’re certain to hear lots of arguments . . . all weekend long,” wrote my weekend counterpart, Tobin Harshaw, on Friday evening, of the then-nascent debate on the administration’s decision to try 9/11-plotter Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other men in federal court in New York City.

headline: Google ‘Lunch’ and Get David Chang
text: Most office workers have to be content with sandwiches at their desks or, if they’re lucky, something hot and not too awful from the company cafeteria.

headline: Who Should Own the Rosetta Stone?
text: Should the British Museum return the Rosetta Stone to Egypt? Should the export of a nation’s “cultural property” be banned? Should there be laws giving national governments ownership of any antiquity unearthed today within their borders?

headline: Why New Gift Card Rules Won’t Take Effect Until Next Summer
text: The Federal Reserve Board proposed rules Monday requiring more disclosure of gift card fees and more restrictions on expiration dates. While the final rules wouldn’t take effect until next August, an effort is already underway to get the rules in place in time for the holiday season.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Blazing Saddles'
text: A. O. Scott reviews Mel Brooks' 1974 film, which satirizes race relations both in Hollywood westerns and in American culture.

headline: Howard Marks on Lessons of the Financial Crisis
text: In his latest “chairman’s letter,” Howard S. Marks of Oaktree Capital Management takes a look back at the causes and lessons learned from the current financial crisis.

headline: A Revolutionary War Widow’s Estate Becomes a Preservation Battleground
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  In the mid-1980s J. Dennis Delafield and his cousins faced a hard fact: They could no longer afford to maintain the estate established in 1802 by their distant ancestor, Janet Livingston Montgomery, widow of Gen. Richard Montgomery, a hero of the Revolutionary War.

headline: Help for Gay Caregivers Who Look After Elderly
text: When Michelle Obama pitched the president’s health care reform efforts to a room of women at the White House last week, one group of New Yorkers present clung to every word.

headline: Is Doomsday Coming? Perhaps, but Not in 2012
text: NASA said last week that the world was not ending  at least anytime soon. Last year, CERN, the European Center for Nuclear Research, said the same thing, which I guess is good news for those of us who are habitually jittery. How often do you have a pair of such blue-ribbon scientific establishments assuring us that everything is fine?

headline: New GMAC Chief: We Need Less Aid Than Expected
text: For Michael A. Carpenter, stepping in as GMAC‘s new chief executive is an assignment he’s used to: nursing an ailing financial institution back to health.

headline: Repetitive Guitar Strums Rooted in Metal but Not Confined by It
text: Black metal and doom metal are musical styles, but they are also modes of being. They’re body and brain and nature. That furious black-metal clog of screams, strums and beats is rain or wind or anxiety or catatonic excitement. That deep-frequency doom-metal drone is the unfathomable drag of eternity: the Creator’s cello sawing away for a billion more choruses than you’ll ever get to hear. One’s a head sound, one’s a chest sound. They’re infinite wells of culture and meaning. They won’t go away.

headline: Cleric Reportedly Denies Ordering Fort Hood Attack
text: Last Friday The Lede reported that Anwar al-Awlaki — a radical, American-born cleric and blogger who knew at least one of the 9/11 hijackers and exchanged e-mail messages last year with the Army psychiatrist charged in the Fort Hood shootings — had suddenly gone silent, days after a post on his blog called the rampage the act of “a hero.”

headline: Mixing Contemporary (Cough) With Difficult (Cough) Classical
text: The brilliant French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard enjoys giving recital programs that mix old and new works in ways intended to intrigue, delight and even rattle audiences. He did so again, with fascinating results, on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall.

headline: Music in Review
text: RUMI SYMPHONY PROJECT

headline: Iridium Responds
text: A posting in this blog on Iridium caught the attention of the company, and its chief executive sends the following:

headline: A Gallery of Heroes, Up for Sale
text: Joe Kubert, a comic book artist since 1938, has little interest in the accumulated work of his last seven decades; his focus is on new projects, he said recently. But comic book fans who feel differently about this celebrated illustrator will have a chance to peruse and even own some of that older work this week, when 18 covers and interior pages, published from the 1940s to 1990, are put up for sale.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Blazing Saddles’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott discusses Mel Brooks’s controversial 1974 spoof “Blazing Saddles,” which looks at what happens when a black man (played by Cleavon Little) becomes the sheriff of a small town.

headline: In Search of the Geep
text: Q. I have a soft-drink bottle cap with a trivia item printed inside that says that if a sheep and a goat mate, the offspring is a geep. Can this be true?

headline: A Change at the Top of GMAC as It Negotiates for Another Government Bailout
text: DETROIT  GMAC Financial Services, the former lending arm of General Motors, replaced its chief executive on Monday as it negotiates for another round of bailout financing from the federal government.

headline: Audit Faults New York Fed in A.I.G. Bailout
text: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York gave up much of its power in high-pressure negotiations with the American International Group’s trading partners last year, according to a government report made public on Monday.

headline: Palin on Oprah, ‘Reloading’ Before 2012
text: Is she or isn’t she running for president in 2012?

headline: Obama Official and Goldman Assess Insurers
text: On the White House’s official blog, Nancy-Ann DeParle, the director of the Office of Health Reform, rebuts recent claims by the insurance industry that the proposed health care overhaul would actually increase the cost of premiums.

headline: When Mountain Lions Hunt, They Prey on the Weak
text: Predators do not always play fair. Sometimes they choose their victims based on physical condition, preferring young, old, sick or injured prey.

headline: S.M.U. Is Ready for a Luau
text: When Southern Methodist Coach June Jones lured the former Kansas City Chiefs coach Frank Gansz out of retirement last year to be his special teams coordinator, he made him a promise.

headline: At Least They Disclosed It
text: Should this company receive an award for Accidentally Honest Disclosure?

headline: City Ballet Names Chief to Oversee Business
text: In a reflection of the challenges many arts companies are facing, including a need to develop new audiences and balance the books, New York City Ballet on Monday announced that it was creating an executive director position to oversee all nonartistic matters and named Katherine E. Brown, chief operating officer of the public radio station WNYC, to the job.

headline: That Face of Protest in Iran, Fading Fast
text: Neda Agha-Soltan died one of history’s most-watched deaths. It was in the midst of the fury over the Iranian presidential election of June 12, and for a moment it seemed as if the young woman’s final moments — shot on a Tehran street on June 20 as a protest swirled around her, dying at the scene while a cellphone camera recorded it all in images soon flashed around the world — would be the start of something earthshaking.

headline: Report Faults Handling of A.I.G. Bailout
text: Two days before the Federal Reserve Bank of New York paid 100 cents on the dollar to the American International Group’s trading partners in return for tearing up contracts with the insurance giant, one bank volunteered to take a modest haircut — but never got the chance.

headline: With New Presses, Daily News Is Betting on World of Print
text: WITH advertising and circulation falling, and with publishers pessimistic about their prospects of bouncing back, newspapers are slashing expenses these days, not finding new ways to spend enormous sums of money. Industry executives and analysts regularly field questions about how much longer ink-and-paper media will be with us.

headline: Bristol Exchange Eases Downsizing
text: The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb has found a clever way to shrink. The company is offering its stockholders the chance to swap at a discount into shares of its publicly traded subsidiary Mead Johnson Nutrition. Reducing the number of outstanding shares would improve Bristol’s earnings per share, a move that should come in handy as patents expire and put up to a third of its revenue from drug sales at risk.

headline: N.F.L. Quick Hits From Week 10: Why Passing Is King
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

headline: After Quake in Italy, Seeking Greener Pastures
text: L’AQUILA, Italy  On a recent autumn afternoon, half a year after a devastating earthquake struck here, a small flock of sheep and goats made its way through the ghostly, ravaged center of this ancient hilltop city.

headline: Bloggingheads: American Anti-Scientism
text: Michael Specter, left, author of "Denialism," and Chris Mooney, author of "Unscientific America," discuss the power that unscientific beliefs hold in America.

headline: Bobby Frankel, 68, Trainer of Champion Horses, Dies
text: Bobby Frankel, one of the most successful American thoroughbred trainers of the last 40 years, whose horses included the champions Bertrando, Ghostzapper and Empire Maker, the winner of the 2003 Belmont Stakes, died Monday at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 68.

headline: Washington Blade Newspaper Closes
text: The Washington Blade and several other gay newspapers and magazines around the country learned on Monday that they had been shut down after a federal agency that oversaw them was unable to find buyers for them.

headline: Digging Into the Science of That Old-Book Smell
text: If you have torn yourself away from the virtual library that is the Internet long enough to visit a real library, you know that the smell of old books  musty, slightly acidic, even grassy  is instantly recognizable. But is it quantifiable? And if so, might old-book odor prove useful to librarians and conservators charged with preserving collections?

headline: Sharks’ Ortmeyer Keeps Playing Despite Risk of Blood Clots
text: When Jed Ortmeyer steps onto the ice, he shifts his focus to hockey — and those closest to him cannot help worrying.

headline: An Air-Traffic Upgrade to Improve Travel by Plane
text: EGG HARBOR, N.J.  Up in the cockpit, Larry Van Hoy, a Federal Aviation Administration pilot, was flying low-tech. Radar showed a bit of nearby cloud cover, and to learn about other aircraft, he talked to the ground controller or looked out the window.

headline: Changes in the Climate and a Windier Great Lake
text: Chalk up another effect of climate change: it’s getting windier over Lake Superior.

headline: U.S. Attorney Nominee Criticized Over Raids
text: Eleventh-hour criticism is arising over President Obama’s nomination for United States attorney in northern Iowa of a prosecutor who had a leading role in the criminal cases against hundreds of illegal immigrants arrested in a May 2008 raid at a meatpacking plant in Postville, Iowa.

headline: Chinese Solar Panel Firm to Open Plant in Arizona
text: Suntech Power, China’s largest solar panel manufacturer, plans to open its first American plant near Phoenix, the company announced on Monday. It would be the first time a Chinese solar company has built a manufacturing plant in the United States, experts said.

headline: Making Cryoseared Duck
text: Nathan Myhrvold, a former chief technology officer at Microsoft, and Chris Young demonstrate how to cryosear and cryorender duck. (StarChefs.com)

headline: Liberals Urge Reid to Keep Public Option
text: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, met on Monday night with a group of liberal Senate Democrats who urged him not to back down from his decision to put a government-run insurance plan, or public option, in the major health care legislation that he is working to complete.

headline: Manipulating Nature (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Do Stockholders Really Know What’s Best?
text: When news of Kraft’s hostile bid for Cadbury broke in England a couple of months back, it caused intense debate, including whether an American company should, by all rights, really be the new home of a well-known British brand that dates back to 1824.

headline: In Your Dreams (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Libyan Leader in Italy Seeks Tall, Leggy and Pious
text: ROME  The 200 women who answered a Rome modeling agency’s advertisement for tall, attractive party guests thought they would be attending an elegant soirée on Sunday. They were  only the host turned out to be the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and instead of hors d’oeuvres he offered them copies of the Koran and urged them to convert to Islam, the Italian news media reported Monday.

headline: Solar Journeys (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Disagreement Over Goals at U.N. Meeting on Hunger
text: A United Nations summit meeting on combating hunger that opened in Rome on Monday underscored the split between rich and poor countries on the issue, with the industrialized nations balking at concrete targets.

headline: Lehman Estate Sues Barclays Over 2008 Deal
text: Lehman Brothers’ bankrupt estate filed a lawsuit against Barclays Capital on Monday, saying Barclays improperly pocketed more than $5 billion when it bought most of Lehman’s North American operations last year. (Read the lawsuit after the jump.)

headline: Zambia Judge Clears Editor in Morals Case Over Photos
text: JOHANNESBURG  A Zambian newspaper editor was acquitted Monday on charges of distributing obscene materials with the intent of corrupting public morals, a case filed against her after she sent photos of a woman in childbirth to government officials and other prominent figures.

headline: Britain: Police Arrest Five Men in Antiterrorism Operation
text: The police arrested five men on Monday in connection with what was described as “the incitement of terrorism overseas.” The men, ages 21 to 62, were arrested in raids before dawn in the northern cities of Manchester and Bolton, and at a hotel near Heathrow Airport in London. The police statement gave no further details of the plot or the men’s identities. “This is a complex and ongoing operation, which has now reached the point where it was necessary to make arrests,” said Assistant Chief Constable Dave Thompson of the Greater Manchester Police.

headline: China: Police Detain an Advocate for Victims of Tainted Dairy Items
text: Zhao Lianhai, a father who has been organizing parents whose children suffered from drinking tainted dairy products last year, was detained by the police on Friday in Beijing, according to a report published Monday in The Global Times, a popular newspaper. Mr. Zhao was taken from his home by about a dozen police officers, his wife, Li Xuemei, told the newspaper. The officers also confiscated two computers, a camera, a video recorder and an address book. Parents whose children were sickened or died from drinking dairy products tainted with melamine, an industrial chemical, have been waging a campaign for justice, but local governments and the central government in Beijing have repeatedly harassed them.

headline: 30 Years After Murder, Is His Appeal Too Late?
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court agreed Monday to decide whether it is too late for an Alabama man to argue that the murder that sent him to death row was not a capital crime when he committed it.

headline: Investors Seem Unshaken After Study of Merck Drug
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Such are the fortunes of the Merck cholesterol drug Zetia that a study reporting a lack of medical benefit is considered good news for investors.

headline: Even in a Terror Attack, Seeing the Best of India
text: I FELL in love with India when I was a child. My parents were both born in Bombay, and we went back to India frequently.

headline: SUNY Weighs the Value of Division I Sports
text: New York’s state university system is among the largest in the country, but it has never been known for athletic prominence, unlike major public institutions in states like Florida, Pennsylvania and Michigan.

headline: New Zealand Group Has Plans to Retrieve Explorer’s Whisky
text: Specialists from New Zealand plan to recover two crates of Scotch whisky left more than 100 years ago by the polar explorer Sir Ernest Shackleton and trapped deep in Antarctic ice. A spokesman for the New Zealand Antarctic Heritage Trust said the whisky trove had been found under a hut built at Cape Royds, a promontory on McMurdo Sound, during Mr. Shackleton’s first South Pole expedition of 1907-9. The expedition ended in failure when the explorer was forced to turn back about 100 miles from the pole. A trust spokesman said the crates and the bottles would undergo conservation work in New Zealand before being returned to the hut, which is being restored as a museum. The spokesman, Al Fastier, said there were no plans to sample the McKinlay & Co. whisky, but the distiller Whyte & Mackay, owner of the brand, said it hoped to acquire a bottle with a view to recreating the century-old blend.

headline: A Constitutional Case in a Box of Cash
text: STEVE BIERFELDT had a little tin box, packed in plain view in his carry-on bag, when he went through airport security in St. Louis last March. He often carried the little box, he later told me. But this time, the box would become a big deal.

headline: Rookie of Year Honor Can Be the Beginning or the End
text: The fickle nature of the rookie of the year award was displayed on the Yankees’ roster all season. Derek Jeter was the American League winner in 1996 and is still among the best players in baseball. But two subsequent winners rarely got off the bench: the utilitymen Eric Hinske (2002) and Angel Berroa (2003).

headline: Get Your Samosa On
text: Start compiling those Hot Pocket jokes now: the  Samosa Crawl, starting off tonight near Curry Hill, should give you ample time to riff on the goodness of meat-stuffed pastry as you explore the city’s many varieties. A “samosa scorecard” will be provided; an appetite for hot sauce is expected.

headline: Jesus Lizard and Das Racist
text: There are still tickets available for tonight’s show by the Jesus Lizard, the recently re-formed ’90s alt-rock champions, at Irving Plaza. Still bitter over their appearance at the beyond-raucous Vice Halloween party? Check out  Das Racist, the jokey hip-hop act (“Combination Pizza Hut/Taco Bell”) that’s got art school cred. In a recent show, the duo was “characteristically shambolic and characteristically entertaining,” Jon Caramanica wrote, “holding together a half-hour set of half-performed songs with hyperliterate reference points and self-aware charm.” They’ll be at Santos tonight.

headline: Funny Ha Ha
text: How many hipster-writer-comedians can a few lit mags lure to do a show? Find out tonight at the Highline, when Eugene Mirman, Jonathan Ames, Todd Barry, Rick Moody, David Rees, Starlee Kine and more make appearances. (John Hodgman and Sarah Vowell must’ve been busy.) Mr. Ames will also be hosting another indie talkathon, the Moth Ball benefit, tonight; we had a blast last year, so pony up for tickets and tell Garrison we sent you.

headline: Scenes From a Marriage
text: Hello again from the land of sun and fun.

headline: One Victory Makes the Future Brighter for Wie and the L.P.G.A.
text: It was a good cellphone signal that bounced off the satellite from somewhere outside Guadalajara, Mexico, on Sunday night. It carried a voice that sounded much the way Michelle Wie’s voice used to sound, before all the pressure got to it and drained the youthful spontaneity right out of it.

headline: Lehman’s Estate Is Suing Barclays Over Unit’s Sale
text: Lehman Brothers’ bankrupt estate filed a lawsuit against Barclays Capital on Monday, saying Barclays improperly pocketed more than $5 billion when it bought most of Lehman’s North American operations last year.

headline: Another Late Loss Leaves Jets Baffled
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  As the Jacksonville Jaguars sliced up the field in the fourth quarter of Sunday’s game, the Jets’ defensive players signaled to one another and shouted between plays to restore some order. But the more they waved their hands and shifted before the snaps, the less effective they seemed.

headline: Thomas Already Creating Waves at Florida International
text: Isiah Thomas is no stranger to controversy, and it certainly seems to have found him again as the coach at Florida International, the latest stop in his basketball journey.

headline: A Racial Divide Is Bridged by Recession
text: McDONOUGH, Ga.  During the housing boom, Henry County, a suburb of Atlanta, had its share of racial tension as more and more blacks joined the tens of thousands of others pouring in, creating a standoffish gap between the newcomers and the county’s oldtimers.

headline: Can I Put You On Hold?
text: There is a class of utterances that, when encountered, produces irritation, distress and, in some cases, the desire to kill. You hear or read one of these and your heart sinks. Everyone will have his or her (non)favorites. Mine is a three-word announcement on the TV screen, “To Be Continued,” which says, “I know that you have become invested in this story and are eager to find out how it ends, but you’re going to have to wait for a few days or a week or a month or forever.” In the great order of things, it is only a minor inconvenience, but it is experienced as a deprivation; you were banking on something and now it has been taken away.

headline: Giants, Fresh Off Bye, Look for Turnaround
text: If quarterback Eli Manning needed inspiration during the Giants’ bye week, he received a double dose to go with some family football values to ease the pain of a four-game losing streak.

headline: Chicago Schools Chief Commits Suicide
text: CHICAGO  The president of the Chicago Board of Education, who had served in a variety of prominent posts here over three decades, was found dead early Monday morning on the banks of the Chicago River, in what the medical examiner ruled a suicide.

headline: A.I.G. - A Giant, Humbled
text: Once the world's dominant insurance company, American International Group has been diminished by disastrous bets on mortgage-backed securities to its current incarnation, one totally dependent on the Treasury and the Federal Reserve for survival.

headline: A Co-Founder of Microsoft Has Lymphoma
text: Paul Allen, a private investor and co-founder of Microsoft, has been told he has non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, according to an e-mail message sent to employees of his investment firm, Vulcan.

headline: No ‘Choice of Evils’ Defense in Oil Lease Case, Judge Rules
text: DENVER  A college student who bid on and won more than $1.8 million in federal oil and gas leases last year without the intent or ability to pay will not be allowed to argue in court that he acted out of necessity to protect the environment, a federal judge ruled on Monday.

headline: Yo Jude: Strong Passwords
text: Q. and A. columnist J. D. Biersdorfer and Personal Tech editor Sam Grobart on how to strengthen your passwords.

headline: N.A.A.C.P. Prods Obama on Job Losses
text: With unemployment among blacks at more than 15 percent, the N.A.A.C.P. will join several other groups on Tuesday to call on President Obama to do more to create jobs.

headline: All Systems Go
text: I loved this puzzle. It was novel, fun and had a nice, crunchy helping of non-theme entries. We were seeing double with a pair of constructors yesterday. Today, it’s John Farmer’s theme that has us seeing double — and with an added bonus.

headline: Commuters Overlooking Free Treasure
text: I might not have appreciated the marvel of the Grand Central Terminal water fountain if it hadn’t been for the notebook.

headline: Needing Proof She Had, Indeed, Embraced a New Home
text: It took all of three hours for Carmen Cruz to decide to leave her homeland behind in exchange for a new life in the United States.

text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  If an expression, like a picture, conveys much more than words, then Mike D’Antoni’s face reads like an encyclopedia of pain.

headline: Backman and the Mets, Together Again
text: Wally Backman returned to the embrace of Major League Baseball after a five-year exile Monday when the Mets appointed him the manager of the Class A Brooklyn Cyclones. He will be introduced at a news conference Tuesday at KeySpan Park in Coney Island, less than 25 miles from where, as the feisty second baseman on the 1986 World Series championship team, Backman enjoyed his greatest glories.

headline: Paterson Calls Obama Wrong on 9/11 Trial
text: Gov. David A. Paterson on Monday criticized the Obama administration’s decision to try five men linked to the Sept. 11 attacks in a civilian court in Manhattan.

headline: Despite Mayor’s Opposition, Council Approves a 5-Minute Grace Period on Parking
text: The City Council overwhelmingly approved a bill on Monday that would provide a five-minute grace period to drivers who are late to feed a meter or move their cars on street-cleaning days, setting the stage for a showdown with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who vowed to veto the legislation.

headline: In Brooklyn, Her Farmer’s Heart Is Happy
text: Kristen Schafenacker, 26, has the rare title of New York City farmer. Born in Fort Wayne, Ind., she attended Mount Holyoke College, where her devotion to food took root, and is now the senior farm assistant at Added Value, an urban farm located opposite the Ikea in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Albany, Inaction Trumps Spending Cuts
text: ALBANY  An agreement to cut more than $3 billion from the state budget remained well out of reach on Monday, as the governor and a top Democrat spent the day trading recriminations about bridging the budget gap.

headline: Gunfire by Police Officers Declined 16% Last Year
text: New York City police officers fired their weapons about 16 percent less last year than in the previous year, according to a Police Department report released on Monday.

headline: Ex-Secretary Describes How Bruno’s Jobs Intertwined
text: ALBANY  For nearly a quarter of a century, Patricia M. Stackrow was the self-described “gatekeeper” to Joseph L. Bruno, one of New York’s most powerful elected officials: She controlled his schedule, arranged his meetings and drafted his official financial disclosure forms.

headline: With Beckham in Final, No M.L.S. Regrets
text: David Beckham was conspicuously absent in the days before last year’s M.L.S. championship game, which was played at his team’s home stadium. League officials said he had previous engagements, but for Beckham, the league’s marquee player and its highest-paid on-field employee, it simply seemed like bad form and a slap in the face to the league.

headline: Retracing the Route of Shepherds, From L'Aquila
text: A small group of local activists, animal-lovers and dreamers have organized a 150-mile journey for a flock of sheep from the earthquake-ravaged L'Aquila to Foggia in the Puglia Region in Italy.

headline: New Rules to Begin for Hudson River Airspace
text: New rules for airplanes, helicopters and other aircraft operating in the congested air corridor above the Hudson River will go into effect on Thursday, the Federal Aviation Administration announced on Monday.

headline: Countdown Clocks for 3 Bronx Subway Stations
text: In London, Paris and Washington, subway riders need only look up at a digital sign to know how many minutes it will be until the next train arrives. New York’s straphangers usually resort to peering into a darkened tunnel.

headline: Coalition Vows Wage Fight Over Kingsbridge Armory Mall Proposal
text: Bronx Borough President Rubén Díaz Jr. stood before a raucous crowd and vowed to continue fighting a “new revolution.”

headline: Paying Extra for Green Power, and Getting Ads Instead
text: The solicitations have been flooding people’s mailboxes lately: pay a bit more on your electricity bill for 100 percent clean wind power. Or, the fliers say, buy “green power certificates” to offset your global warming emissions.

headline: Iverson’s Time With Memphis Ends and Future Is Uncertain
text: Allen Iverson’s playing days in Memphis proved short-lived, and his next destination is unknown.

headline: Obama’s Judicial Nominations
text: The Obama administration is off to a slow start on judicial nominations, but the Senate, which has delayed in confirming the choices President Obama has made, also bears a good part of the blame. The administration and the Senate leadership should pick up the pace of nominations and confirmations in order to restore some balance to a federal judiciary that was pushed sharply to the right by former President George W. Bush.

headline: Their Future Is Ours
text: There are 16 million children in immigrant families in the United States, one of the fastest-growing segments of the population. It’s an old American story made new in the age of globalization, when waves of human displacement in recent decades have led to immigration on a scale not seen since Ellis Island. But a country that has been so good for so long at integrating new Americans is stumbling under the challenge.

headline: Puppets in Congress
text: For a depressing example of how members of Congress can be spoon-fed the views and even the exact words of high-powered lobbying firms, consider remarks inserted into the Congressional Record after the debate and vote on health care reform in the House.

headline: The Human Moon
text: Over the past four months, NASA’s Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter spacecraft, which is in a low polar orbit over the Moon, has returned a series of images of Apollo landing sites showing the vessels themselves at rest on the Moon’s surface.

headline: The Nation of Futurity
text: When European settlers first came to North America, they saw flocks of geese so big that it took them 30 minutes to all take flight and forests that seemed to stretch to infinity. They came to two conclusions: that God’s plans for humanity could be completed here, and that they could get really rich in the process.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Tuesday about the scheduled execution in Iran of Ehsan Fattahian, a Kurdish activist who was accused of “armed struggle against the regime,” misstated his age. Mr. Fattahian was 26 years old, not 23. (He has since been executed, according to his lawyer.)

headline: What the Future May Hold
text: What will the United States be like in 20 years when today’s toddlers are in college or trying to land that first job or maybe thinking about starting a family?

headline: Corrections

He is the deputy director of the ministry’s department of Cultural Market, not deputy culture minister.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,353 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 909 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Nov. 5 about gay rights activists’ considering a change in approach after Maine voters blocked same-sex marriage described the federal Defense of Marriage Act incorrectly. It prohibits the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriage; it is not a “ban on same-sex marriage.”

Iverson Leaves Memphis and His Future Is Uncertain
text: Allen Iverson’s playing days in Memphis proved short-lived, and his next destination is unknown.

text: A picture credit on Monday with an article about opposition to a planned garage for city sanitation trucks in an industrial neighborhood just above TriBeCa misspelled part of the name of one of the architectural firms that created a rendering of the city’s proposal. It is Weisz & Yoes Architecture, not Weisz & Hoes.

headline: Corrections
text: A film review on Friday about “Fantastic Mr. Fox” referred incorrectly to the character Kylie, who becomes Mr. Fox’s accomplice. He is an opossum, not a mole.

headline: Inquiry Into Labor Leader Is Requested
text: Two conservative groups, Americans for Tax Reform and the Alliance for Worker Freedom, formally asked federal prosecutors in Washington to investigate what they said were potentially illegal lobbying activities by Andy Stern, president of the Service Employees International Union. With Mr. Stern visiting the White House more than 20 times during President Obama’s first six months in office, the two groups said he apparently had spent more than 20 percent of his work on lobbying, which would generally have required that he be a registered lobbyist. Michelle Ringuette, a spokeswoman for the union, criticized the move as an effort to deny working people a say in health insurance reform. “Andy Stern spends less than 20 percent of his time talking to elected representatives,” she said. “He spends 100 percent of his time trying to help workers get a better life.”

headline: Showcase: 12,000-Faceted Diamond
text: By the time the Yankees rushed the field to celebrate their 27th World Series victory, Robert Caplin had photographed the action — 12,000 times. The result is a romantic and captivating time-lapse presentation.

headline: Study Foresees an Increase in Obesity and Its Costs
text: While Congress searches for ways to slow the growth of health care spending, a new study suggests that its efforts may be overwhelmed by the surging prevalence of obesity.

headline: Edward Woodward, Star of Spy Series, Dies at 79
text: Edward Woodward, a British actor with a long résumé in television and theater who was best known in the United States as the star of “The Equalizer,” a dramatic series about an ex-spy turned righteous vigilante in New York City, died on Monday in Truro, Cornwall, England. He was 79 and lived in London and Cornwall.

headline: Ken Ober, Host of ‘Remote Control’ on TV, Dies at 52
text: Ken Ober, a brassy comedian best known as the host of the 1980s-era MTV game show “Remote Control,” was found dead on Sunday in his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 52.

headline: YouTube to Help Sites Gather News Clips
text: YouTube has signed up NPR, Politico, The Huffington Post and The San Francisco Chronicle for YouTube Direct, a new method for managing video submissions from readers.

headline: Zimbabwe: Judge Will Continue to Preside in Terrorism Case
text: Chinembiri Bhunu, the judge in the politically charged trial of Roy Bennett, a senator and former commercial farmer, on Monday refused to recuse himself, though Mr. Bennett’s lawyers accused him of bias. The trial got under way with Mr. Bennett pleading not guilty to terrorism charges, as the prosecution began to make its case against him.

headline: 1 Dead and 4 Hurt in Bronx Gunfire
text: One person was killed and four others were injured, two critically  including a 15-year-old girl whom the police called an innocent bystander  in two separate shootings in the Bronx on Monday, the police said.

headline: News Quiz | November 17, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: When Should a Person Be Considered an Adult?
text: At 18? At 21? Should you be able to fight in a war before you can rent a car? Is it cruel to sentence a teenager to life without parole? Why are our laws and rules on this issue so inconsistent, and how do they affect you?As the Supreme Court considers the question of whether children should ever be sentenced to life without parole for crimes that don’t involve murder, Catherine Rampell asks “How Old Is Old Enough?”:

headline: Will Bristol’s Exchange Ease Downsizing?
text: The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb has found a clever way to shrink, according to Breakingviews.com. The company is offering its stockholders the chance to swap at a discount into shares of its publicly traded subsidiary Mead Johnson Nutrition. Reducing the number of outstanding shares would improve Bristol’s earnings per share, a move that should come in handy as patents expire and put up to a third of its revenue from drug sales at risk, the Web site says.

headline: Cautioning JPMorgan on Cazenove
text: JPMorgan Chase and Cazenove appear to agree that the destination is better than the journey.

headline: Golden Gate Denies Playboy Rumors
text: Golden Gate Capital wants to make it clear: it is most definitely not bidding for Playboy.

headline: RockYou Rocks On With $50 Million
text: RockYou, a developer of social network applications, has landed a hefty $50 million in fresh funding, TechCrunch reported.

headline: AOL Spin-Off Is Set for Dec. 9
text: The media conglomerate Time Warner said Monday that it would spin off its AOL unit to shareholders on Dec. 9, almost nine tumultuous years after one of the most disastrous corporate mergers in history.

headline: India Energy Producer Set for $648 Million I.P.O.
text: JSW Steel, India’s third-largest steel maker, expects to open the initial public offering of its energy business next month, valuing the unit at about 200 billion rupees ($4.3 billion).

headline: PPR, a French Retailer, Plans I.P.O. for African Division
text: PPR, the French retail and luxury group, said Tuesday that it planned to raise as much as 1 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in the initial public offering of its African distribution unit, CFAO.

headline: Murdoch’s Democrat Liaison to Leave News Corp.
text: Gary Ginsberg, a close adviser to Rupert Murdoch for 11 years who often served as a liaison between the conservative Mr. Murdoch and the Democratic Party, will leave News Corporation at the end of the year, The New York Times’s Tim Arango reported.

headline: Volcker Criticizes Accounting Proposal
text: A proposal to give banking regulators authority to block accounting standards is “a terrible idea,” Paul A. Volcker, a former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said on Monday.

headline: Do Stockholders Really Know What’s Best?
text: Kraft Foods’ $16.7 billion hostile takeover bid for Cadbury, the British confectionery company, is an example of how shareholder democracy can go wrong, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: CIT Has $1.07 Billion Loss Before Bankruptcy
text: The CIT Group, the large U.S. consumer finance company, on Monday posted a $1.07 billion loss for the third quarter, the last full three-month period prior to its Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing.

headline: Banking Group Warns Congress on Breakup Power
text: Some of the world’s largest financial firms on Monday urged a top U.S. lawmaker not to pursue big bank break-up legislation, an idea attracting interest in Congress and causing alarm on Wall Street.

headline: Soros Fund Sees $2 Billion Increase
text: The hedge fund headed by billionaire investor George Soros reported holdings of $6.2 billion during the third quarter, an increase of $2 billion, after taking a stake in automaker Ford and boosting its holdings in communications services stocks.

headline: Paul Allen, a Co-Founder of Microsoft, Has Lymphoma

headline: Blackstone Shuffles Stakes, Selling Calpine
text: The Blackstone Group, the private equity firm run by co-founder Stephen Schwarzman, bought a $7.8 million stake in Southwest Airlines, cut its stake in Eastman Kodak and sold its holdings in Calpine during the latest quarter.

headline: Newmont Transfers Stake in Indonesian Venture
text: Newmont Mining has sold a 10 percent share of its Indonesian joint venture to a consortium of regional and local governments.

headline: Group Calls for More Investment in Electric Cars
text: A group of businessmen formed a coalition on Monday to urge the federal government to make a major investment in electric transportation, pointing to electric cars as the best way to confront the nation’s dependence on imported oil, The Associated Press reported.

headline: UBS Outlines Plan to Return to Profit
text: Presenting a plan to return UBS to profitability, the chief executive of the battered Swiss bank said on Tuesday that he expects the company to be earning nearly $15 billion a year no later than 2014, Julia Werdigier writes in The New York Times.

headline: After 6 Weeks, Somali Pirates Free Crew of Spanish Vessel
text: MADRID  Somali pirates released 36 crew members and their Spanish fishing vessel on Tuesday, the government here said, even as authorities said pirates had seized a tanker with a crew of 28 North Koreans.

headline: Macquarie-Oppenheim Talks Said to Collapse
text: Talks between Sal. Oppenheim and Australia’s Macquarie over the sale of Oppenheim’s investment banking operations collapsed late Monday, sources familiar with the matter told Reuters.

headline: Did Zach Braff Kill American Music?
text: Today’s idea: Ever since Natalie Portman popped headphones onto Zach Braff’s head and said, “This song will change your life,” American music has been dying a slow death, an essay says.

headline: Whitney Hasn’t ‘Been This Bearish in a Year’
text: Prominent banking analyst Meredith Whitney said on Monday that the stock market run-up was not supported by fundamentals and that she expects a so-called double-dip recession, where the economy would slip again before fully recovering.

headline: Obama Tours the Forbidden City
text: BEIJING — Millions of people come here to look at the delights of the Forbidden City. Now add President Obama to that list.

headline: Dynamic Decisions Founder Denies Fraud
text: The founder of Dynamic Decisions Capital Management, Alberto Micalizzi, said that any fraud allegations being leveled at his hedge fund are unfounded and investors will recover close to 100 percent of their money, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: PAI Partners’ Investors Said to Balk at Deal
text: Investors including the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board oppose PAI Partners‘ latest offer to let them halve their obligations to the buyout fund, saying the plan does not go far enough, three people familiar with the talks told Bloomberg News.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday: Neil Armstrong, Heather Locklear, Joe Biden
text: Now that the 40th-anniversary moon-landing specials produced by American television have come and gone, we’re getting to see some of the shows made for the occasion by the BBC. They’re uniformly more inventive and interesting than the clip-show history lessons churned out here. In “Being Neil Armstrong” (BBC America, 8 p.m.), the writer Andrew Smith profiles the Apollo 11 commander by talking to childhood friends, fellow astronauts, space program employees and other acquaintances of the first recluse on the moon.

headline: A Justice Shifts His Stance on Speeches
text: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy of the Supreme Court made headlines last month when his office insisted on approving any article about a talk he gave to an assembly of Dalton high school students in Manhattan on Oct. 28.

headline: No Peak in Oil Before 2030, Study Says

text: Lazard on Tuesday named Kenneth M. Jacobs as its new chairman and chief executive, succeeding the late Bruce Wasserstein as the head of the independent investment bank.
