headline: Presidential Bows, Revisited
text: The ongoing cable-and-blog dust-up over whether President Obama somehow dishonored America’s image by bowing to Emperor Akihito of Japan the other day was reminiscent of another argument over the exact same issue – 20 years ago.

headline: U.S. Wholesale Prices Show Few Inflation Pressures
text: Wholesale prices in the United States increased only slightly in October, the Labor Department said Tuesday, easing concerns that inflation might soon emerge as a threat to the economic recovery in a period of extraordinarily low interest rates.

headline: More High Schools Get A’s (and C’s, and D’s)
text: In releasing the third annual round of A through F grades for New York City high schools on Monday, the Education Department produced a rather murky picture: The number of schools receiving A’s on the city’s report cards increased this year, but more schools received C’s and D’s. And just one school received an F.

headline: China Holds Firm on Major Issues in Obama’s Visit
text: BEIJING  In six hours of meetings, at two dinners and during a stilted 30-minute news conference in which President Hu Jintao did not allow questions, President Obama was confronted, on his first visit, with a fast-rising China more willing to say no to the United States.

headline: Summers, the Chinese and the Deficit
text: Lawrence Summers, the top White House economic adviser, made a point recently that I have not seen anywhere else. Speaking at the New York Economic Club a few weeks ago, he said:

headline: Sophie Theallet Wins CFDA/Vogue Fund
text: The latest cash prize for talent has gone to Sophie Theallet, who won the $200,000 CFDA/Vogue Fund award last night. The prize, which includes a year of mentoring from a veteran in the industry, is especially deserved in Ms. Theallet’s case. Her clothes are not flashy or arty; she’s not everybody’s darling. But if you appreciate hand-done details like pin-tucking, if you like a certain friendliness in clothes, and if you’re surprised and delighted by non-generic reds and blues, then you are surely on Sophie’s side.

headline: A Solar Technology Seeks Its Day in the Sun
text: For years, concentrating photovoltaic technology, which uses mirrors or lenses to focus the sun’s rays on small, high-efficiency solar panels, has tantalized researchers as a potential source of low-cost, utility-scale solar power.

headline: West Side Accident Snarls Morning Traffic
text: At least two cars were involved in a serious accident on Tuesday morning on the West Side Highway, causing extensive traffic delays, a Fire Department official said.

headline: Stephen Colbert Wishes Aerosmith Well on Its Permanent Vacation
text: If last week you found yourself baffled by the rapid cycle of departures and reconciliations within Aerosmith, you’re not alone. On Monday night, Stephen Colbert took to the bully pulpit of “The Colbert Report” to comment on the singer Steven Tyler’s recent announcement that he would take a hiatus from that rock group. (Mr. Colbert called it “the biggest blow to the band since Alicia Silverstone quit in the mid-90s.”) Mr. Colbert also named the guitarist Joe Perry his “Alpha Dog of the Week” and called him a rock god, adding, “because, like God, you are rarely seen.”

headline: Some Mysteries in the BofA-Merrill Deal
text: Update | 1:29 p.m. For those who like mysteries, the testimony of Timothy J. Mayopoulos, the former general counsel of Bank of America, presents a few. Mr. Mayopoulos testified on Tuesday at yet another House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform hearing on the Bank of America-Merrill Lynch deal.

headline: 14,700 Disclosed Offshore Accounts
text: Fear, apparently, can be a powerful inducement.

headline: Analyst Doubts Health Overhaul Can Pass
text: Arguing that the political winds are shifting away from the support necessary for an overhaul, one Wall Street analyst is now predicting Congress will not pass any significant health care legislation anytime soon.

headline: Celebrating Revolution With Roots in a Rumor
text: PRAGUE  It was a revolution that began with a lie.

headline: The Uses of Defeatism
text: There’s a lot to chew on in John Judis’s essay on anti-statism in America, but I thought it was particularly interesting as an example of what you might call a “narrative of defeat” — a kind of story that both liberals and conservatives sometimes like to tell about our politics, which emphasizes the other side’s immense advantages, and their own side’s struggle against overwhelming odds.

headline: Giants Stadium Countdown: Tiki Honors Mara
text: John Maxymuk, author of “The 50 Greatest Plays in New York Giants Football History,” is helping us count down to the final game at Giants Stadium. His latest book is “Quarterback Abstract.”

headline: On Climate Change Efforts, China Is Key
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.It is time to accept that the choices of China and India, not the United States, will determine the world’s future carbon emissions.

headline: A New Way to Nab a Better Seat on the Plane
text: You don’t have to settle for that dreaded middle seat on your next flight. With a new tool from ExpertFlyer.com, you can nab a better one.

headline: Tuesday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Energy Plan From the Greenhouse Giants
text: President Obama and China’s president, Hu Jintao, announced a slate of partnerships and plans on Tuesday in Beijing, including projects related to expanding energy options while constraining greenhouse gases. The list is below. (More background on Environmental Capital.)

headline: Ausra Solar Looking for a Buyer
text: Disrupting trillion-dollar energy markets is expensive, as solar companies like OptiSolar and Solel have found. Both sold out to larger, deep-pocketed companies this year.

headline: ‘New Moon’ Fill-In
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first four paragraphs of this article from the Arts section, “Media Vampires, Beware.”  Use your own words, or click “read more” to choose from a scrambled list of the words that were removed.

headline: ‘Never Used Twitter’
text: Monologue |  Aired Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Hey, during a town hall event in China, President Obama admitted that he’s never used Twitter. Even John McCain was like, “Get it together, grandpa.”

headline: ‘Coffee With Hillary’
text: Monologue |  Aired Monday night on NBC: President Obama was in Japan. Some people are upset that Obama bowed to the Japanese emperor. It’s still better than when former President Bush high-fived the emperor and said, “Give me some skin, Mr. Miyagi.”

headline: ‘Plans for the Future’
text: Monologue |  Aired Monday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: I was watching “Oprah” on the TV. She had Sarah Palin on the show. Sarah was promoting her book, where she talks about her plans for the future. I think she wants to be the next leader of the free world, which is ridiculous, because no one can replace Oprah.

headline: When Cancer Muddles the Mind
text: I’ve become one of those people who, by the time I walk from the couch to the kitchen, can’t remember why I’m standing in front of an open fridge. Some people can laugh off these memory blips as old-timer’s disease. But I’m only 37. And it doesn’t feel funny staring into an abyss of cartons and containers unable to remember that I want a glass of orange juice.

headline: ‘The Big Trial’
text: Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: You know who’s coming to New York City? Khalid Sheikh Mohammed is coming here. He’s coming to New York City for the big trial, and also, he’s promoting his new book, “Really Going Rogue.”

headline: Russian Figure Skater Arrested in Lake Placid
text: Andre Lutai, the Russian figure skater who finished 10th in last weekend’s Skate America competition in Lake Placid, N.Y., was arrested late Sunday night after allegedly stealing a car and driving drunk, The Associated Press reported.

headline: ‘A Very Strange Press Conference’
text: Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC: President Obama in China this week, or as they call it, the People’s Republic of Wal-Mart.

headline: Gift Guide | Purely Cosmetic
text: When the holiday festivities begin, cameras will come out of hiding. Ensure that your loved ones are ready for their close-ups with our beauty gift picks for good boys and girls. (We’ve included fragrances too, just in case you find yourself caught under the mistletoe.)

headline: Josh Tyrangiel Named Editor of BusinessWeek
text: Josh Tyrangiel, who was an heir apparent at Time magazine, has been appointed the editor of BusinessWeek, its new owner, Bloomberg L.P., announced Tuesday morning.

headline: Who Was Really Bailed Out? We Still Don’t Know
text: Who were the ultimate beneficiaries of the Treasury‘s decision to make good on the credit default swaps written by the American International Group?

headline: Disputes Continue Over Jackson Estate and Public Memorial
text: Last week, when John G. Branca and John McClain were named the executors of Michael Jackson‘s estate by a Superior Court judge in Los Angeles, one estate expert was quoted as saying the decision would ensure “there won’t be any further challenge.” But now the singer’s father, Joe Jackson, is planning to challenge the decision, Agence France-Presse reported. Citing legal papers filed on Friday, Agence France-Presse said that Joe Jackson plans to appeal the appointment of Mr. Branca, a lawyer, and Mr. McClain, a music executive, in the California Court of Appeals. Joe Jackson was left out of his son’s will, and the Superior Court had said he had no standing to challenge it.

headline: A North African Battle for World Cup Glory
text: Stephen Constantine, 47, a native of England, is currently the coach of the national team of Sudan. He has also coached the national teams of Nepal, India and Malawi.

headline: Answers About Community Colleges, Part 2
text: Each day this week, the Guidance Office — the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts — will feature answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: Taliban Blame ‘Blackwater’ for Pakistan Bombings
text: On Monday, Al Jazeera reported that a spokesman for the Pakistani Taliban said the group accepted responsibility for only some of the recent suicide bombings in Pakistan, laying the blame for others, including a deadly attack on a market last month that killed more than 100 civilians, on the American security firm formerly known as Blackwater. The spokesman claimed that the firm, now called Xe, was involved in an attempt to discredit the militants by staging deadly attacks.

headline: More Fathers Are Getting Custody in Divorce
text: Working Mother Magazine published a package of articles on Tuesday called “Lost Custody,” about the new reality of divorce and child custody for working mothers.

headline: Crowdsourcing Comedy on Amazon Reviews
text: Every now and then, something for sale on Amazon.com seems so monumentally stupid that it inspires a spontaneous community comedy festival. One person after another leaves phony reviews, each more heartfelt and over-the-top than last, sardonically praising the Amazon item for its astonishing, life-changing abilities. Perfect strangers, entertaining each other in the comments, laughing their heads off—until Amazon gets wind of the stunt and shuts it down.

headline: Quinto Quarto Orders Takeout
text: It’s hard to say that Tables for Two mini-reviews in The New Yorker go on for too long. But in her mixed assessment of the Italian restaurant Quinto Quarto, did Andrea Thompson really need to say anything more once she revealed that during dinner one night she saw “the pizza-delivery guy who shows up with two large pepperoni pies for the staff”?

headline: A Spokesman Leaves: What Does It Mean for Gavin Newsom?
text: From afar, Nathan Ballard, who resigned yesterday as the director of communications for San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom, seemed at times to play Jeeves to Mayor Gavin Newsom’s Bertie Wooster.

headline: ‘Hair’ Extends From Broadway to London
text: Update | 11:39 a.m. It’s not quite Manchester, England, England, but the Broadway cast of “Hair” will soon be making its way across the Atlantic Sea to take the musical to London. In a news release, the Public Theater, the “Hair” producers and Cameron Mackintosh said they would transfer the production to the Gielgud Theater next year, along with the cast that originated the revival, which is now playing at the Al Hirschfeld Theater.

headline: SmartyPig Savings Accounts Come With Discount Vacations
text: Earlier this year, I signed up for a SmartyPig savings account. Then, as now, it was paying what appears to be the highest rates in the land, currently 2.01 percent.

headline: A Checklist for College Recruits
text: The N.C.A.A. basketball signing period ends on Wednesday and most of the big high school fish have already chosen a pond.

headline: ‘Strange Days’ Ahead for Bob Saget
text: Apparently the eight years that Bob Saget spent hosting “America’s Funniest Home Videos,” narrating clips of misbehaving kitties and people getting hit by footballs in tender areas, were simply a warm-up act. Now he’s turning the camera on himself. On Tuesday, A&E announced that it had ordered a new reality series starring Mr. Saget, the comedian and former “Full House” star, that is tentatively titled “Bob Saget’s Strange Days.” In a news release, A&E said that the new series would follow Mr. Saget as he explores “some of America’s most fascinating and mysterious worlds”; for Mr. Saget, that means an investigation of mail-order brides; meeting up with a survivalist cult that is preparing for the end of the world; and rushing a college fraternity. The show is expected to have its premiere next year; no word yet on which if any Olsen twin might be involved.

headline: Mets Balancing Two Sets of Off-Season Priorities
text: The Mets’ two biggest off-season objectives, to paraphrase Captain Obvious, are to acquire another slugger and to add a No. 2 starter behind Johan Santana. Not so obvious is how — and if — they will accomplish these goals and find creative ways to bring in a starting catcher, resolve issues in the bullpen and in the back end of the rotation, and decide if they should deal second baseman Luis Castillo.

headline: Below the Belt | Sparring in Y-3 Boxing Boots
text: There’s little in the boxing world that isn’t exploited for maximum impact — babbles, tassels and bedazzles have all made their appearance on the fingers and feet of fleet-footed pugilists. Jack Dempsey, the gentleman boxer and heavyweight champion from 1919 to 1926, was, to put it into our terms, a fashion-forward tastemaker. In our era, Paulie Malignaggi, Floyd “Money” Mayweather and Rickie “The Hitman” Hatton have paraded down the aisle in Technicolor robes. Boxing has always found a way of muscling itself into fashion.

headline: Day 2 of Second-Guessing
text: Because long ago the N.F.L. became the league that swallowed the rest of the sporting universe, we have surpassed the age of second-guessing. Now, second guesses have happened by halftime. By Tuesday, we’ve reached seventh or eighth guesses. We’re wondering whether Bill Parcells hacked into Bill Belichick’s headset system to call the fourth-and-2. We’re asking who left Tennessee’s owner, Bud Adams, unattended long enough for him to make an obscene gesture at Bills fans. We’re surmising that the H1N1 virus infected the brains of Cincinnati Bengals management when the thought hit them: we’re 7-2 and we need a struggling running back with a history of locker room conflict and arrests on charges of assaulting women!

headline: Dr. James Will Make It Better
text: To be sure, as David Leonhardt describes, Intermountain HealthCare’s model of using evidence-based medicine, led by Dr. Brent James, offers much to improve our current medical-care system and is in part an answer to our health care crisis. What must be kept in mind, however, is the limit of evidence-based medicine: what is good for a group, as a whole, is not equally good for each and every member of the group. This is why our medical-treatment system will never be able to achieve the same evidence-based safety and efficiency as our air-transportation flight-safety system; human beings vary, sometimes dramatically. Ultimately, medical care always comes down to the individual.

headline: China’s War on Low U.S. Interest Rates
text: Updated, Nov. 17, 6:35 p.m. | Moritz Schularick, an economic historian, says China is partly to blame for Americans’ addiction to cheap money.

headline: Secretary Describes a Scolding From Bruno
text: ALBANY — After 25 years as secretary to Joseph L. Bruno, the former Senate president and one of New York’s most powerful politicians, Patricia M. Stackrow finds herself testifying against her old boss who is accused of improperly mixing his political and business interests and trying to deceive the public about it.

headline: Lady Gaga Ineligible for Best New Artist Grammy
text: First, Blair Waldorf told us that Lady Gaga wrote her song “Poker Face” for her stepfather, Cyrus Rose, a revelation that we’re fairly certain is true only in the fictional world of “Gossip Girl.” Now comes more surprising (and authentic) news: Lady Gaga will not be eligible in the best new artist category at the Grammy Awards next year. Variety reported that although Lady Gaga (whose real name is Stefani Germanotta) has sold more than 1.5 million copies of her debut album, “The Fame,” her song “Just Dance” was nominated in the best dance recording category at this year’s Grammys, making her ineligible for new artist next year, according to the award’s regulations. Previous winners in the best new artist category include Adele, Amy Winehouse and Carrie Underwood; nominations for the 52nd annual Grammy Awards will be announced on Dec. 2 and awards will be given out on Jan. 31.

headline: Joining the Crowd at a College Fair
text: As we signaled to turn right into the high school parking lot, a man frantically waved his hands in the air alerting us that the lot was full. At 3:30 on a Sunday afternoon, I never expected there’d be several hundred eager parents — and students — streaming into a high school gym for a glimpse of, and perhaps a quick chat with, admissions representatives and alumni from 70 colleges and universities. But there we were, searching for a parking spot so we, too, could join the throngs of college seekers on a crisp fall day.

headline: Temporary Rape
text: Disturbing Chinese term for a sexual assault that was deemed to be less serious because it was apparently unpremeditated.

headline: Travel Deals: AirTran Flight Sale
text: AirTran announced a R&R flight sale this morning, with one-way fares as low as $39. Book by Nov. 19 for travel through Feb. 20. The lowest fares can be found for Tuesday, Wednesday and Saturday departures. Fourteen-day advance purchase required.

headline: Volvo Recalls XC60 for Seat-Belt Failure
text: Volvo is recalling 9,667 of its 2010 XC60s, most of them in the United States and Canada because in a crash test the driver’s seat belt came undone.

headline: From Dental Crowns to Implants
text: In this week’s Science Times, Jane Brody discusses the shift in dentistry away from bridges and crowns to permanent implants to replace decayed or missing teeth:

headline: Police Raid Newspaper Printing Plants
text: Updated, 1:19 p.m. | The New York City police raided the offices of three major city dailies and El Diario on Tuesday morning as part of an investigation into allegations of corruption within the union that delivers newspapers in the metropolitan area.

headline: Lawyer Held in Tax Case in Russia Dies in Jail
text: MOSCOW  A 37-year-old Russian lawyer for an international investment fund, Hermitage Capital Management, died in a pretrial detention center on Monday, nearly a year after he was arrested in an escalating feud between the Russian authorities and the company, Russia’s Interior Ministry announced on Tuesday.

headline: Layoffs Begin at The Associated Press
text: Layoffs began today at The Associated Press, according to employees there, as the company follows through on a commitment made a year ago to lower its payroll costs by 10 percent by the end of 2009.

headline: What We’re Reading …
text: 1.) The stimulus created jobs in Congressional districts that don’t exist.

headline: Bloomberg? Humble? Experts Suggest How Mayor Could Try
text: Perhaps Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg should spend more time in the Bronx and less in Bermuda, political analysts say. He could travel less like a rock star and more like a neighbor, showing up without television cameras to hear what is on the minds of residents, especially in poorer sections of the city.

headline: Winner of Wasserstein Playwright’s Prize Is Announced
text: A 28-year-old playwright from Chicago, Marisa Wegrzyn, has been named as the recipient of the third annual Wasserstein Prize for an emerging female playwright — a $25,000 award named for the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Wendy Wasserstein, above, who wrote “The Heidi Chronicles” and “The Sisters Rosensweig.”

headline: Another Vongerichten Goes to Work for Dad
text: “I guess I’m making this a family business,” said Jean-Georges Vongerichten, whose son, Cedric, is the executive chef at Perry St., and whose daughter Louise started working at Mercer Kitchen in the fall. A graduate of American University in finance, Ms. Vongerichten, 23, has held various jobs at the restaurant, including runner, and is now a junior manager there. Mr. Vongerichten’s brother, Philippe, manages the flagship, Jean Georges.

headline: Mia Dona Goes Chefless
text: Donatella Arpaia has had less to do with top chefs lately. Last year she left David Burke & Donatella (now David Burke Townhouse). And just before she closed Mia Dona for renovations last month, the chef and her partner in the restaurant, Michael Psilakis, left, saying he wanted to concentrate on their other places — Anthos and Kefi.

headline: During Visit, Obama Skirts Chinese Political Sensitivities
text: BEIJING  Whether by White House design or Chinese insistence, President Obama has steered clear of public meetings with Chinese liberals, free press advocates and even average Chinese during his first visit to China, showing a deference to the Chinese leadership’s aversions to such interactions that is unusual for a visiting American president.

headline: Licensing Deadline Looms for Pedicab Owners
text: Get licensed or get out, is the message from the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs to the city’s pedicab professionals, who have until Friday to obtain business licenses and register their vehicles or else close up shop. The Nov. 20 deadline marks the end of a 60-day period in which the city invited pedicab operators to apply to become licensed, a process that entails submitting their rickshaws to a rigorous inspection, and retrofitting them with things like seat belts and turn signals to bring them up to new safety standards outlined in the law.

headline: Winter 2010 Dates Set for Kander and Ebb’s New Musical, ‘The Scottsboro Boys’
text: Off Broadway’s Vineyard Theater announced performance dates on Tuesday for the world premiere production of a new musical, “The Scottsboro Boys,” with music and lyrics by John Kander and Fred Ebb (“Cabaret,” “Chicago”). It will be directed by Susan Stroman (“The Producers,” “Contact”).

headline: 14,700 Taxpayers Disclose Offshore Accounts
text: Update | 3:51 p.m. More that 14,700 taxpayers have disclosed secret foreign bank accounts, the Internal Revenue Service said on Tuesday, under an amnesty program that let them avoid prosecution for tax evasion.

headline: A Flood of Applicants to a Shrinking Police Dept.
text: After years of struggling to lure top-quality recruits, the New York Police Department has found that the prolonged recession  coupled with a significant increase in first-year salaries  has generated new interest in police careers.

headline: Shaming Tax Delinquents
text: New York state legislators have recently proposed a measure to publish the names of the state’s biggest tax deadbeats.

headline: Now Showing | Maremma, Italy
text: If the promise of the some of the best country’s best food and wine weren’t enough to make you book a plane ticket to the Maremma region of Tuscany right now, then these tantalizing images from Massimo Vitali and Albrecht Tübke will certainly do the trick. This coastal strip offers all sorts of sybaritic pleasures, from sunbathing to sipping Sassicaia — the award-winning wine is produced in the town of Bolgheri. These two photographers offer a lovely glimpse into the region with their traveling show “Vintage Green,” which is currently on view at the Core Club. While Vitali delivers his epic landscapes of the verdant area, the Leipzig-born Tübke offers endearing portraits of the local legends, from winemakers to hunters. The show continues until Dec. 9. Vitali has a new show opening at Bonni Benrubi Gallery starting Dec. 3.

headline: Hooked on Hockey From a Young Age in Omaha
text: Some might second-guess Jed Ortmeyer’s decision to keep playing with a blood clotting disorder, but one would be hard-pressed to find someone who doubts his heart.

headline: At Hearing, Questions About BofA C.E.O. Candidate
text: It appears even Congress is joining the Bank of America chief executive guessing game.

headline: After Chinese Turbine Controversy, Companies Plan American Plant
text: Two companies that encountered political backlash for their plans to use Chinese-made wind turbines to build a giant wind farm in west Texas have announced plans to build a new turbine factory — in the United States.

headline: David Waltuck Has Left Macao Trading Co.
text: David Waltuck is no longer involved with Macao Trading Co., the Chinese-Portuguese-inflected restaurant in TriBeCa.

headline: More English Translations on the Way for Nobel Winner’s Novels
text: Curious readers clamoring for more work from this year’s Nobel laureate in literature will be able to get their hands on two more titles in the next three years. Metropolitan Books has acquired the North American rights to two novels by Herta Müller, the Romanian-born German novelist and essayist who was awarded the Nobel Prize last month.

headline: Incivility, Indeed: Murdoch Insults Paterson
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: The 18 Million
text: Update: For a correction, and more on this topic, see above.

headline: Meatballs, Chinese-Style
text: (Ed indirectly raises the question, “Who invented ravioli nudi?” –MB)

headline: Police Investigate Suicide of Chicago Schools Chief
text: CHICAGO  The president of the Chicago Board of Education, who had served in a variety of prominent posts here over three decades, was found dead early Monday morning on the banks of the Chicago River, in what the medical examiner ruled a suicide.

headline: Deena Kastor’s Green Chile Pumpkin Pie
text: A Vegetarian Thanksgiving

headline: Pedro Martinez Gearing Up for 2010
text: When the Phillies shelled out $1 million for a partial season’s worth of Pedro Martinez, they really didn’t know what they’d get from the three-time Cy Young Award winner.

headline: A Woman-to-Woman Talk With a Would-Be Suicide Bomber
text: BAQUBA, Iraq — As a translator for The New York Times, I have met a lot of different characters and been in many new situations, such as meeting politicians, election candidates, students, mentally ill people, disabled people, injured people, bereaved mothers.

headline: Lynne Stewart Is Ordered to Begin Serving Sentence
text: A federal appeals court panel in Manhattan on Tuesday upheld the conviction of Lynne F. Stewart, the outspoken defense lawyer who was found guilty in 2005 of assisting terrorism by smuggling information from an imprisoned client to his violent followers in Egypt.

headline: Language May Begin Before Birth
text: How early does language — a particular language — begin?

headline: Richmond to Honor Teen Who Called Police in Gang Rape
text: At its meeting tonight, Richmond City Council will honor Margarita Vargas, 18, the woman who directed police to the victim of a gang rape outside the local high school’s homecoming dance.

headline: ‘Oleanna’ to Close on Broadway
text: The overlap between two Broadway productions of David Mamet won’t last very long. The Broadway revival of “Oleanna,” Mr. Mamet’s play about a university professor and the female student who believes he has harassed her, will end its run at the Golden Theater on Jan. 3, its publicists said Tuesday in a news release. The play, which stars Bill Pullman and Julia Stiles, was a transfer of a production that ran earlier this year at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. Directed by Doug Hughes, it opened at the Golden Theater on Oct. 11. Mr. Mamet’s new play, “Race,” which he is also directing, is to open at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Dec. 6.

headline: Libby’s Warns of a Canned Pumpkin Shortage
text: As if preparing for Thanksgiving wasn’t stressful enough for cooks, now comes this news: there is likely to be a canned pumpkin shortage.

headline: Inside Umi Nom
text: The chef King Phojanakon from the Kuma Inn brings his artfully composed Asian comfort food to Brooklyn.

headline: Santa Monica Wants Eli Broad Museum
text: The City of Santa Monica is poised to join what is shaping up to be a high-profile contest in Los Angeles, competing with Beverly Hills and possibly another municipality to become the home for a new museum to house the art collection of the billionaire Eli Broad.

headline: Is This Bishop Catholic?
text: I take issue with some of the statements made in Deborah Solomon’s interview with Robert Duncan. First, the name of Duncan’s organization, the Anglican Church in North America, may confuse some readers. The organization is not a part of the Anglican Communion. Duncan left the Episcopal Church, which is a constituent part of the Anglican Communion. The Episcopal Church is the sole Anglican presence in the United States recognized by the Archbishop of Canterbury.

headline: Correction
text: An article on Oct. 25 about the recent governor’s race in New Jersey misidentified the illegal activity that some Sephardic rabbis had been accused of and that the article characterized as part of the state’s infamous corruption. The rabbis were charged with money laundering, not with selling body parts and then using the money to bribe politicians. (There was a Brooklyn man accused of conspiring to broker the sale of a kidney, and several New Jersey politicians accused of corruption, all of whom were arrested the same day as the rabbis.)

headline: Makeover for a Star (the Twinkling Kind)
text: In New York, a world capital of makeovers, even the star that goes on the tree in Rockefeller Center has some work done every once in a while. But what happened this time was different from, say, liposuction, which usually leaves the patient a little lighter. The star gained 220 pounds.

headline: Details on U.S.-China Climate and Energy Plans
text: Appearing with President Hu Jintao, President Obama on Tuesday told reporters that the United States was determined to work with China and other countries to help produce a substantive agreement in Copenhagen climate talks next month:

headline: The Next ‘Oprah’ Spinoff: Her Interior Designer
text: Soon to join “Dr. Phil” and “Dr. Oz”: Nate Berkus? Oprah Winfrey‘s production company is proposing a new daytime talk show starring Mr. Berkus, who is an interior designer and a regular on “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” Broadcasting & Cable reported Tuesday. The publication said Ms. Winfrey is “finalizing plans” with Sony Pictures Television to distribute the show next fall.

headline: Correcting the Chatter: For Consumers, No Federal Tax Due on Clunkers Rebate
text: As we draw closer to the end of the year, there’s a bit of chatter on the Internet about whether the “cash for clunkers” rebates are taxable income.

headline: Q&A: Lyon for a 50th Birthday, a Festival and Food
text: Q.

headline: Anthropologie Comes to Regent Street
text: LONDON | Anthropologie, the American fashion and housewares chain, has opened its first overseas branch, on bustling Regent Street in London. Owned by Urban Outfitters, the brand that sells sort-of-edgy street fashion, Anthropologie is often described as its older, more sophisticated sister, targeting creative types with a sense of humor.

headline: The Morning Skate: Troubles in Hab-land, Blue in St. Louis and Hammer Time in Philly
text: Mount Royal shakes. The lava bubbles and steams, the smell of sulfur fills the air. Panic begins to grip the population as the volcano that is Montreal hockey is starting to erupt.

headline: MTV Acquires TV Rights for ‘This Is It’
text: MTV Networks has acquired exclusive television rights to the Michael Jackson concert film “This Is It” for six years beginning in 2011, the company announced on Tuesday. The deal allows MTV Networks to show the film on all of its channels, including MTV and VH1, as well as on BET Networks, which like MTV is owned by Viacom. In its announcement, MTV said it would also work with Sony Pictures Entertainment to market the DVD of the film, due early next year. “This Is It” has grossed $67 million in the United States and $129 million overseas.

headline: Jauron Is Dismissed as Bills Coach
text: The Buffalo Bills fired Coach Dick Jauron on Tuesday, making him the first coaching casualty of the season. In-season coaching changes are unusual in the N.F.L. because the short season means even a new coach can have little impact. The timing of the firing is especially odd because the Bills had a bye two weeks ago, a more natural time to make a change. But they were routed, 41-17, by the three-win Tennessee Titans on Sunday to drop to 3-6. Jauron was apparently surprised. He was called to a meeting with the team’s owner, Ralph Wilson, in Detroit and fired.

headline: New York Police Department Lures Recruits
text: The New York Police Department is now better educated and more qualified than in the past.

headline: News of Hockey, 11/17/09: Shanahan Retires; Naslund Unretires and Joins Forsberg in Sweden
text: Brendan Shanahan makes it official and announces his retirement after 21 N.H.L. seasons. The full story from The Associated Press is at this link.

headline: Millennium’s Englander Examines Hedge Funds
text: Israel A. Englander is known for keeping a very low public profile, even for a billionaire hedge fund manager. But recently, the founder of Millennium Partners  shared his views on the state of the hedge fund industry in a keynote address at the Absolute Return Symposium in New York.

headline: An Invitation to Read, Sniff and Taste
text: BOOKS about wine are no substitute for drinking wine. But these six new selections can help to better understand what’s in the glass, and what’s in the minds of those who make wine and consume it.

headline: Training of Afghan Police by Europe Is Found Lacking
text: BERLIN  Two and a half years after it was started, the European Union’s police training mission in Afghanistan is understaffed, lacks adequate security and transportation, and has yet to develop a uniform training program, according to diplomats and security experts involved in the mission.

headline: Thanksgiving Under the Sun?
text: If you haven’t made any plans for Thanksgiving weekend yet, Miami Beach may be a surprisingly affordable option for a last-minute vacation.

headline: Earning a Profit by Ending Energy Waste
text: The Community Preservation Corporation, a 35-year-old nonprofit lender that specializes in issuing mortgages to landlords of small buildings and properties receiving public subsidies, is offering $1 billion in credit to New York State apartment building owners.

headline: For Some TV Time, St. Peter’s Bumps Breakfast for Basketball
text: JERSEY CITY — Never mind that it was 5:58 a.m. and the sun would not rise for another 47 minutes. St. Peter’s College had a big basketball game Tuesday morning, and the reserve guard Brandon Hall took a spot at midcourt to give each of his starting teammates a lusty chest bump during introductions.

headline: Behind the Scenes: Lost Atlantis
text: The commenter GK was the only one who asked, but she or he couldn’t have been the only reader who wondered why there were no slides of the shuttle launch on Monday in Pictures of the Day; especially one so spectacularly photogenic that NASA described it as “picture perfect.”

headline: Indulging His Every Indulgence
text: WILLIAM FAULKNER once said: “The aim of every artist is to arrest motion, which is life, by artificial means and hold it fixed so that a hundred years later, when a stranger looks at it, it moves again, since it is life.”

headline: New York Sees Quick Rebound on Wall Street
text: Wall Street is rebounding from the financial crisis and has returned to profitability faster than many expected, according to a report released on Tuesday by the New York State comptroller’s office.

headline: A Century of Bugaboos
text: Language may change, but pedantry is forever. And as Jan Freeman demonstrates in “Ambrose Bierce’s ‘Write It Right': The Celebrated Cynic’s Language Peeves Deciphered, Appraised, and Annotated for 21st-Century Readers,” so too is the tradition of modern-day pedants’ picking apart the outmoded irritants of the quibblers who came before them. In the spirit of Theodore Bernstein’s funny and edifying “Miss Thistlebottom’s Hobgoblins,” Freeman, who writes The Boston Globe’s weekly language column “The Word,” has taken “Write It Right,” Bierce’s “Little Blacklist of Literary Faults,” published in 1909, and annotated it — thoroughly, fondly and wittily — for today’s usage obsessives.

headline: Who Knew I Was Not the Father?
text: I.

headline: Tokyo Tops Paris in Michelin Three-Star Restaurants
text: Tokyo now has more restaurants with three Michelin stars than Paris.

headline: Newly Renovated Paramount Hotel Is Now a Landmark
text: Updated, Nov. 18 | The Paramount Hotel, an ornate Times Square behemoth that is known for its double-height arcade along West 46th Street and was opulently revitalized this year, is the newest entry on New York City’s list of official landmarks.

headline: Oprah Looks to Sony For Nate Berkus Spinoff
text: Oprah Winfrey’s production company is proposing a new daytime talk show starring Nate Berkus, who is an interior designer and a regular on “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” Broadcasting & Cable reported Tuesday. The publication said Ms. Winfrey is “finalizing plans” with Sony Pictures Television to distribute the show next fall.

headline: South Africa Is Divided on Gesture by Educator
text: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa  For a speech about reconciliation it could hardly have been more divisive. Jonathan D. Jansen, the new head of the University of the Free State, spoke of the “place of infamy” just 100 yards behind him, the residence hall where four white students last year made a racist video that incited outrage across the country.

headline: Brown Vows to Continue War Effort in Afghanistan
text: LONDON  As President Obama moves closer to a decision on the United States military’s request for more troops in Afghanistan, the British government has made an unflinching commitment to continue its role as the second largest troop provider in the 43-nation coalition fighting the war.

headline: Biking Rules P.S.A.s
text: Selections from more than 40 short bicycle safety public service announcements from a contest being held by Transportation Alternatives, the cycling and pedestrian advocacy group.

headline: A Better Way to Navigate the Mall This Season
text: If your holiday shopping routine involves hitting up a mall or 10, MEDL Mobile has created an application called Mall Maps designed to make navigating through the seasonal madness a tad easier.

headline: J. B. Smoove on ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ and Michael Richards
text: J. B. Smoove was happy enough to return this season to “Curb Your Enthusiasm” as Leon Black, the houseguest who moved into Larry David‘s mansion and never took the hint that it was time to move out. But on Sunday night’s episode, Mr. Smoove got to play a central role in a story line involving this season’s (fictional) “Seinfeld” reunion, and a memorable scene in which Michael Richards received his comic comeuppance for a notorious 2006 incident in which he was filmed shouting racial epithets at hecklers at a comedy club.

headline: A Rustic Home in Ecuador
text: A three-bedroom, 3,000-square-foot house on a hilltop in Cuenca is on the market for $220,000.

text: From Floyd Norris on Notions on High and Low Finance:

headline: How to Conserve Art That Lives in a Lake?
text: In 1972, a year before his death in a plane crash at 35, the artist Robert Smithson wrote, “I am for an art that takes into account the direct effect of the elements as they exist from day to day.” And with the creation of his greatest work  “Spiral Jetty,” the huge counterclockwise curlicue of black basalt rock that juts into the Great Salt Lake in rural Utah  he certainly put that conviction to the test.

headline: Former SS Man Charged in 1945 Massacre
text: German prosecutors have indicted a 90-year-old man on 58 counts of murder over his suspected role in the March 1945 massacre of a group of Jewish laborers near the Austrian village of Deutsch Schützen.

headline: The Authors’ Hearts Beat Faster. Publishing Was So Close Now. . .
text: Got a romance novel in your desk drawer? Polish it up and get ready to become a Harlequin author.

headline: House Hunting in ... Ecuador
text: A THREE-BEDROOM, 3000-SQUARE-FOOT HILLTOP HOME IN CUENCA

headline: Swiss Textiles Award | Alexander Wang Wins
text: Winning the Swiss Textiles Award is always at the top of a young designer’s wish list. And these days, when even established houses are hurting, the 100,000 euro prize is sure to come in extra handy. Just ask Alexander Wang, this year’s winner, who beat out a talented field including Erdem, Ohne Titel, Peter Pilotto, Alexis Mabille and Thakoon.

headline: Finding Bohemian Influences in Baroque
text: Baroque music and Gypsy tunes may seem unlikely bedfellows on a program, but Matthias Maute, artistic director of the period-instrument Ensemble Caprice, argues that Bach and Telemann may have been influenced by itinerant musicians.

headline: Twice as Many Antics for the Duck, the Cat and the Wolf
text: The only problem with Prokofiev’s “Peter and the Wolf” from a theatrical point of view is that there is not enough of it. Or so, evidently, the London company In the Wings thought when it developed a 30-minute “prequel” to the 30-minute tale, with new music by Philip Feeney.

headline: Acting Your Age: Considering the Age of Responsibility
text: Overview | What standard(s) should society use to determine when a person should be treated as an adult? In this lesson, students participate in a fishbowl discussion about various legal situations related to the “age of responsibility” and contribute their ideas and arguments on the matter to a Learning Network Student Opinion blog post.

headline: Blankfein Sorry for Goldman’s Role in Crisis
text: It must be the sorry season.

headline: Starting a Chamber Series With a Bittersweet Brahms
text: Early in Pinchas Zukerman’s career, when he was best known as a star violin soloist and just starting to conduct, he carved out a place in his concert schedule for chamber music, often  though not always  with other headliners. More recently, the balance of his commitments has shifted from solo performance to conducting, as he has taken on music directorships, like that of the National Arts Center Orchestra in Ottawa, a post he has held since 1998. But he has maintained his devotion to chamber music, and as part of his work in Ottawa, he has established the Zukerman Chamber Players, drawing on members of the orchestra.

headline: Living With Music: Bill Cotter
text: Bill Cotter is the author of a novel, “Fever Chart.”

headline: President Obama Visits China
text: New York Times reporter David E. Sanger examines the success of President Obama's trip to China.

headline: Donation Will Aid Storm-Ravaged Section of Central Park
text: During a fierce thunderstorm on Aug. 18, an estimated 508 trees were either felled or broken beyond repair in Central Park, while another 500 sustained serious, but not fatal, damage. The city’s Parks Department and the Central Park Conservancy has called the storm the most severe destruction the park’s trees had suffered in decades. The grim destruction yielded some 90 tons of wood chips.

headline: Town Divided Over Terror Suspects
text: THOMSON, Ill.  Once federal officials said they might move terrorism suspects from Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to a nearly empty prison here, residents of this faded rural village began debating what they should fear most  the suspects or the downward spiral of the economy here.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Nov. 17
text: Beginning with Vadim Ghirda’s picture of commuters in Bucharest (Slide 1), which would not look entirely out of place in a gilded frame on a museum wall alongside 17th- and 18th-century group portraits, today’s report is particularly painterly, with tastes of modernism (Slide 5) and impressionism (Slide 14). One view (Slide 6), of the aftermath of a disastrous fire, even comes framed.

headline: Leveraging the Obama Brand
text: Earlier this month, almost a year from the day when Barack Obama rode the wave of history into Grant Park, he had one of those weeks that makes his presidency seem, at times, so confounding. First Obama endured an electoral embarrassment, watching his party lose off-year gubernatorial elections in New Jersey and Virginia, in part because many of the voters he had so successfully engaged in his presidential campaign, particularly younger voters, stayed home and made popcorn for “Dancing With the Stars” instead. The president had been exposed, the pundits solemnly declared, as having no “coattails,” which are something you really need, they said, if you want congressmen and senators to go along with you on hard votes. Then, just five days later, as Obama’s manifest political weakness was still being dissected on cable TV, the president stood in the Rose Garden and hailed the passage in the House of Representatives of the most comprehensive health care bill in the nation’s history — a bill he had helped pass, narrowly but solidly, by making a rare weekend visit to the Capitol to lobby for it personally. It was, as Obama acknowledged, just a first step, but it was a step no other president had managed to scale, and it seemed to confuse this issue of how powerful a president Obama really is. If Obama has no coattails, then how was he able to pressure nervous lawmakers into making such a perilous vote? And if he had enough influence to get health care reform done, then why were his coattails missing?

headline: A Princess Treats Her Suitors (and Audience) With Unflappable Cool
text: LONDON  Soon after Princess Aurora, the heroine of “The Sleeping Beauty,” appears, she must dance with the four strange men her parents have just introduced to her as prospective husbands. That segment is known as the Rose Adagio, since each man presents the princess with a single rose as he partners her in slow extensions to the side and revolves her in attitude turns on point, her back leg bent at waist height behind her.

headline: BlogTalk: Breast Cancer Screening, Magazine Covers
text: New guidelines that call for less frequent breast cancer screening for younger women are provoking anger and confusion on the blogs, with many people wondering if this is aimed at decreasing government costs just as Congress votes on a health care bill.

headline: Plan to Expand Jerusalem Settlement Angers U.S.
text: JERUSALEM  Israel said Tuesday that it had advanced plans to expand a Jewish district of Jerusalem in territory that was captured in the 1967 war and that the Palestinians claim as part of their future state. The move is likely to further complicate the Obama administration’s faltering efforts to restart peace talks.

headline: ‘Oleanna’ to Close
text: The overlap between two Broadway productions of David Mamet won’t last very long. The Broadway revival of “Oleanna,” Mr. Mamet’s play about a university professor and the female student who believes he has harassed her, will end its run at the Golden Theater on Jan. 3, its publicists said Tuesday. The play, which stars Bill Pullman and Julia Stiles, was a transfer of a production that ran this year at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles; directed by Doug Hughes, it opened at the Golden Theater on Oct. 11. Mr. Mamet’s new play, “Race,” which he is also directing, is to open at the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Dec. 6.

headline: New ‘Oprah’ Spinoff for Interior Designer
text: Soon to join “Dr. Phil” and “Dr. Oz”: Nate Berkus? Oprah Winfrey’s production company is proposing a daytime talk show starring Mr. Berkus, an interior designer and a regular on “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” Broadcasting & Cable reported on Tuesday. The publication said Ms. Winfrey was “finalizing plans” with Sony Pictures Television to distribute the show next fall. Mr. Berkus was the host of “Oprah’s Big Give,” a reality series last year. The plans for Mr. Berkus will probably heighten speculation about the future of Ms. Winfrey’s own talk show, as her syndicator, CBS Television Distribution, said this month that negotiations about a new deal were continuing. Ms. Winfrey may change syndicators or move her show to her coming cable channel, OWN.

headline: For Gay Couples, ‘Traditional’ Divorce Isn’t Always an Option
text: It’s divorce week here on the Bucks blog. Ron Lieber recently explored the financial consequences of divorce in a series of columns, and readers can send their questions to Lili A. Vasileff, a certified divorce analyst, about the financial aspects of splitting up.

headline: House Call
text: A first-term congressman from New Orleans, you are the one and only Republican in the House who voted in favor of the Democrats’ health care plan. Have you been scolded by the Republicans for breaking rank? Not my party leadership, but only by Republicans all over the United States who are disappointed with my vote. But not at all from the party leadership.

headline: ‘This Is It’ on MTV
text: MTV Networks has acquired exclusive television rights to the Michael Jackson concert film “This Is It” for six years beginning in 2011, the company said on Tuesday. The deal allows MTV Networks to show the film on all its channels, including MTV and VH1, as well as on BET Networks, which like MTV is owned by Viacom. In its announcement, MTV said it would also work with Sony Pictures Entertainment to market the DVD of the film, due early next year. “This Is It” has grossed $67 million in the United States and $129 million overseas.

headline: Dates Set for Kander and Ebb’s New Musical
text: Off Broadway’s Vineyard Theater announced performance dates on Tuesday for the premiere production of “The Scottsboro Boys,” with music and lyrics by John Kander and Fred Ebb under Susan Stroman’s direction. The musical, about the historic rape case in Scottsboro, Ala., involving a group of black teenagers who seek to prove their innocence, will begin previews at the Vineyard on Feb. 12 and open on March 10. The book is by David Thompson, and music direction will be by David Loud. “The Scottsboro Boys,” unfinished at the time of Ebb’s death in 2004, had been slated for a development lab production in 2009-10, but instead will be given a fully staged production. Casting has not been announced.

headline: Santa Monica Pushes for Eli Broad Museum
text: The City of Santa Monica is poised to join what is shaping up to be a high-profile contest in Los Angeles, competing with Beverly Hills and possibly another California municipality to become the home for a new museum to house the art collection of the billionaire Eli Broad, right. Several months ago Santa Monica officials approached Mr. Broad, who had already been in discussions with Beverly Hills about placing his museum there, The Los Angeles Times reported. In a report that was to be discussed Tuesday night by the Santa Monica City Council, P. Lamont Ewell, the city manager, said winning the museum, which would be built next to the Santa Monica Civic Auditorium, would “significantly advance the city’s goals of promoting the arts and enhancing cultural opportunities” in the area “with a relatively small expenditure of public funds.” Under the plan the city would lease land to Mr. Broad’s foundation for a nominal amount and contribute about $1 million for design, construction, parking and other costs. Mr. Broad’s foundation would pay the rest to build the museum, and would establish an endowment to cover its operating costs.

headline: More English Translations for Nobel Winner
text: Readers clamoring for more work from this year’s Nobel laureate in literature will be able to get their hands on two more titles in the next three years. Metropolitan Books has acquired the North American rights to two novels by Herta Müller, above, the Romanian-born German novelist and essayist who received the Nobel Prize last month. Only 5 of Ms. Müller’s 20-some books have been published in English. Metropolitan Books, a unit of Macmillan that previously released her “Land of Green Plums” and “The Appointment,” has acquired rights to “Everything I Possess, I Carry With Me,” a finalist for the 2009 German Book Prize, and “The Fox Was Always a Hunter” (1992). Metropolitan will publish “Everything I Possess”  “Atemschaukel” in German  in September 2011 and “The Fox Was Always a Hunter”  “Der Fuchs War Damals Schon Der Jager”  in September 2012. Sara Bershtel, publisher of Metropolitan, said Philip Boehm would translate the books.

headline: ‘Hair’ Extends From Broadway to London
text: It’s not quite Manchester, England, England, but the Broadway cast of “Hair” will soon be making its way across the Atlantic Sea to take that musical to London. In a news release, the Public Theater, the “Hair” producers and Cameron Mackintosh said they would transfer the production to the Gielgud Theater next year, along with the cast that originated the revival, which is now playing at the Al Hirschfeld Theater. The London production is to begin previews on April 1 and open on April 14, while a new Broadway cast will come into the Hirschfeld starting on March 9. A press representative said that the London production would be an open-ended run, but that the New York cast would remain with the show only through Oct. 2. Gavin Creel, above left, and Will Swenson, above right, among others in the New York cast, were expected to be part of the London transfer, but contracts had not yet been signed, representatives said.

headline: Case Study | The Beauty of Duty-Free
text: Case Study is a bimonthly posting on all things alcoholic by Toby Cecchini, T’s spirits columnist.

headline: Derring-Do Antics, All in Pursuit of Snow
text: Action is everywhere in “Wintuk,” the family-oriented holiday extravaganza from Cirque du Soleil. Emotion, however, is in somewhat shorter supply. That’s not necessarily a bad trade-off  not every show need be designed to stir deep feelings. Yet it does mean that those searching for a shot of adrenaline will have a far better time than those hoping to feel their heartstrings tugged.

headline: $500 Million and Apology From Goldman
text: How much good will can an apology  and half a billion dollars  buy? A lot, Goldman Sachs is hoping.

headline: Extending the Reach of a Great Yiddish Writer, Unto the Next Generation
text: The most moving part of “Sholom Aleichem: Laughter Through Tears,” Theodore Bikel’s one-man play with songs at the Baruch Performing Arts Center, comes near the beginning. “Ver bet blaybn, vos vet blaybn?” Mr. Bikel sings, and then translates: “Who will remain? What will remain?”

headline: Period Piece, Modern Issues: Dealing With Financial Woes
text: The treasure hunters at the Actors Company Theater have unearthed another jewel with “The Late Christopher Bean,” a comedy seldom seen in New York since its Broadway premiere in 1932. It’s a play that has remained fresh and funny, proving once again that a strong script is rarely tarnished by time.

headline: A Town Hall to Discuss Toy Safety
text: With the safety and regulation of children’s toys in the news — and in anticipation of a surge in toy sales in the next week — the federal Consumer Product Safety Commission‘s chairwoman, Inez Tenenbaum, on Tuesday morning held a town-hall-style meeting in Manhattan to discuss toy safety hazards and to assure parents of the agency’s efforts to protect American children this winter.

headline: When Dusk Finally Settled on the Emperor
text: At one point in the Russian director Alexander Sokurov’s beautiful and eccentric movie “The Sun,” the emperor Hirohito begins enthusing about a preserved hermit crab, the sounds of war planes having subsided. “What a miracle!” Hirohito (Issey Ogata) marvels, staring at the pale, pickled, seemingly unremarkable crustacean as an assistant transcribes the emperor’s comments. “What heavenly beauty!” As Hirohito gazes at the crab, you sense that he is acknowledging a fellow specimen, a communion accentuated by the smudged visuals and murky palette that suggest that all this is taking place inside a dirty aquarium.

headline: Goldman Promotes Small Business, and Its Image
text: Criticized for its plan to pay billions of dollars in bonuses this year, Goldman Sachs took steps on Tuesday to improve its battered image, The New York Times’s Graham Bowley reports.

headline: Fed Busting
text: Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner is once again facing the wrath of opinionland, this time over his actions as head of the New York Federal Reserve last year, when he agreed to pay “A.I.G.’s partners 100 cents on the dollar to tear up their contracts with the insurance giant.”

headline: A Town Ponders Controversial Prisoners
text: A plan to move terrorism suspects from the detention center in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to a state prison in Thomson, Ill., has sparked debate among residents.

headline: Sweet Potatoes With Prosciutto
text: Mark Bittman demonstrates how to prepare one of many dishes you can make in advance of Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: It’s Good Guys vs. Bad Guys on a China-Size Scale
text: In a six-year stretch beginning in 1986, John Woo released a series of balletic, ultraviolent crime thrillers that would rank among the most influential films of the last quarter-century. They took a hyperkinetic, Hong Kong style of action moviemaking out of the grind house and into the art house (and the suburban video store), from which it would eventually become the default mode for any number of big-budget Hollywood directors.

headline: Tokyo Tops Paris in Michelin Three-Star Restaurants
text: In October, Kyoto was awarded 110 stars in the city’s first Michelin guide and more three-star restaurants than New York.

headline: Service Announcements Serve Cycling Rules With Humor
text: Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the pedestrian and cycling advocacy group Transportation Alternatives is showcasing more than 40 public service announcements about bicycling and bicycle safety.

headline: Plot Twists Staged by a Choreographer
text: If you spend most of your time watching dance, it’s easy to feel taken aback by a certain staginess that actors can bring to performance, an “I am acting now” overtone that crops up even among the great and the good. (Recent experiences at “After Miss Julie” and “Finian’s Rainbow” spring to mind.)

headline: False Demons
text: Some solid books on wine are out this fall. “Been Doon So Long’’ by Randall Grahm, “The Châteauneuf-du-Pape Book’’ by Harry Karis, “The Finest Wines of Tuscany and Central Italy’’ by Nicolas Belfrage and “The Finest Wines of Champagne’’ by Michael Edwards are among those books that I suggest in my roundup of wine books.

headline: Mother and Child Reunion Onstage
text: Rhea Perlman can still remember when she realized her daughter Lucy DeVito was no longer her little girl. For years Ms. Perlman had bought her daughter’s clothes. But when she was 12, Ms. DeVito declared that she’d had enough of the Gap and wanted to start trolling secondhand shops.

headline: What Ails Public Schools? Better Ask, What Doesn’t?
text: A shocking chronicle of institutional dysfunction, “The War on Kids” likens our public school system to prison and its disciplinary methods to fascism. At least now you know why little Johnny won’t get out of bed in the morning.

headline: The Needle Nexus
text: Of all the mysteries posed by AIDS, perhaps the deepest and most damaging is a human one: why have we failed so utterly to stop its transmission? Most people with H.I.V. in the world, including a vast majority of the 22 million who are infected in sub-Saharan Africa, caught it from a sexual partner. Despite billions of dollars spent to slow this form of transmission, only a few countries have had significant success — among them Thailand, Uganda and Zimbabwe — and their achievements have been unreplicable, poorly understood and short-lived. We know that abstinence, sexual fidelity and consistent condom use all prevent the spread of H.I.V. But we do not yet know how to persuade people to act accordingly.

headline: Group Finds More Anti-Government Sentiment
text: The Anti-Defamation League, in a report released this week, has asserted that “a current of anti-government hostility has swept across the United States” since President Obama was elected just over a year ago.

headline: Slim and Slimmest for Your New TV
text: It’s one of life’s vexing little problems: you’ve just plunked down a sizable chunk of change for one of those super-slim LED side-lit LCD TVs, but when you go to mount it on your wall, it sticks out like a sore thumb.

headline: A Great Flash Add-On for Pets (and People)
text: Every time I use flash to snap an indoor photo of my dog Patti, her eyes are transformed into fluorescent turquoise headlights. It’s not a good look for a dachshund.

headline: 101 Head Starts on the Day
text: FOR cooks, most Thanksgiving problems are brought about by the sheer number of dishes competing for the stove: It’s not easy to roast a turkey and sweet potatoes for 20 at the same time. The best solution is to make food in advance, like one of the dishes that follow.

headline: The Holdouts
text: Three centrist Democratic senators have yet to agree to procedural approval to begin debate on health care legislation in the Senate. A look at them and the states they represent:

headline: Reid Says He’s Close to Unveiling Health Bill
text: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Tuesday that he was close to unveiling his health care bill and that Democrats remained committed to passing it. But when asked if he had the 60 votes needed to bring up the bill for debate on the Senate floor, Mr. Reid was not entirely certain.

headline: Daschle Plans Move to Global Firm
text: Tom Daschle, the former Senate majority leader and confidant to President Obama who would have been his health secretary but for a tax controversy, is jumping from one law firm, Alston & Bird, to a bigger one with global reach, DLA Piper, to play a larger role in international issues.

headline: B & Bs Seek to Be a Guy Thing
text: BED-and-breakfasts are starting to man up, doing away with the lace bedspreads and trading high tea for brewskies.

headline: McCann Responds to ‘Mad Men’
text: A real-life ad agency featured among the fictional ones on “Mad Men” is having a bit of fun with its central role in the final episode of season three.

headline: Economists’ Letter to Obama on Health Care Reform
text: This afternoon a group of 23 prominent economists — including two Nobel laureates as well as previous members of both Democratic and Republican presidential administrations — sent a letter to President Obama about the priorities for health care reform. The letter appears below.

headline: L.A. City Council and D.A. Spar Over Medical Marijuana Law
text: A haze continues to envelop state and local officials in California, as they try to figure out how to enforce drug laws in a state where medical marijuana is legal but there are no clear statewide rules for how its cultivation and sale should be regulated.

headline: App of the Week: Navigation as Heavy on Show as Go
text: I’ll admit that I have been less than impressed by recent offerings from the GPS maker Magellan. But all is forgiven.

headline: Properties for $600,000
text: A house in Hollywood, a house with an adjacent cottage in Pahoa, Hawaii, and a converted barn in Westport, Conn.

headline: Zino Attacks the Mini Space
text: Has the Mac Mini met its miniature match?

headline: What You Get for ... $600,000
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Court Upholds Restriction on Fifth Avenue Parades
text: Since the St. Patrick’s Day Parade first clomped down it in the mid-19th century, Fifth Avenue has become the most desirable parade site in the city.

headline: Overstock Amazes (Again)
text: Correction Appended

headline: Studios Spying On Redbox Kiosks
text: As it turns out, Fox has had a very close eye on an effort by Redbox, the operator of dollar-a-day DVD rental kiosks, to stock its movies, despite a refusal by Fox, Universal and Warner to sell new releases to the company and a pending legal fight over the dispute.

headline: Marcus Samuelsson To Cook White House State Dinner?
text: Citing unnamed “sources in the food world,” Marian Burros reports that Marcus Samuelsson has been invited to “cook the state dinner” being held at the White House on Nov. 24. He will work with the White House executive chef, Cristeta Comerford, Ms. Burros reports.

headline: A Genetics Company Fails, Its Research Too Complex
text: DeCode Genetics, a pioneering company that used the Icelandic population as its guinea pigs in detecting disease-causing mutations, filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday.

headline: Drake Hotel’s Prime Space Remains Undeveloped
text: Enclosed by a dark brown fence, the weedy lot at Park Avenue and 56th Street in Midtown Manhattan is a conspicuous reminder of how ambitions were shattered in the recent real estate debacle. This vacant site, where the Drake Hotel once stood, is likely to leave a gash in the middle of the nation’s costliest office submarket for years to come, real estate specialists say.

headline: Ripe for the Plucking, but Fewer Dare to Try
text: PETTAH, India  As he approaches his first tree of the day, S. Mohan presses his calloused palms together and bows his head.

headline: Gratitude’s Grace Can Be Itself a Gift
text: “It is a fact of life that people give dinner parties, and when they invite you, you have to turn around and invite them back,” Laurie Colwin wrote in her bite-size masterpiece, “Home Cooking,” published in 1988. “Often they retaliate by inviting you again, and you must then extend another invitation. Back and forth you go, like Ping-Pong balls, and what you end up with is called social life.”

headline: Lend Me Your Ear (and Some Money): Small Business Chats Up the Feds
text: Last month, when President Obama ventured out to a small storage company in suburban Maryland to announce new initiatives to free up capital for small business, he also made a less-heralded pledge: to hold a conference. The president intended to “bring together regulators, Congressional leaders, lenders and small businesses to determine what additional steps we can take to get credit flowing to small businesses that want to expand and create more jobs.”

headline: Hershey ‘Reviewing Its Options’ on Cadbury
text: Update | 6:37 a.m. Responding to reports that it was considering a bid for Cadbury, Hershey said Wednesday that it was “reviewing its options, and at this stage there can be no assurance that any proposal or offer from Hershey will be forthcoming.”

headline: The Argument for Free Classes via iTunes
text: The music, videos and mobile applications available through Apple‘s iTunes Store get all the attention, but it might be time to acknowledge the increasingly varied and popular offerings of iTunes U, Apple’s catalog of lectures from colleges and universities around the world.

headline: Money for a Once and Future Candidate
text: LOS ANGELES – That the A-list of Hollywood would be supporting the Democratic candidate for governor of California is probably not surprising. But holding a big fundraiser for someone who is not yet officially a candidate indicates just how badly some big names here want to end years of Republican rule in the state capital.

headline: Economic Insecurity and Bad Habits
text: A new study says that unemployment increases the likelihood that someone will resume or continue to smoke.

headline: Republicans Say Cancer Screening Guidelines Portend Medical Rationing
text: Call it death panel redux.

headline: House to Turn Up the Heat on Jobs
text: With Congressional Democrats in near-panic amid forecasts that unemployment will remain high through next November’s midterm elections, a party leader said on Thursday that the House will pass a new “jobs bill” before Dec. 18.

headline: World Cup Field to Be Completed on Wednesday
text: By the end of the day Wednesday, the full 32-team field for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa will be set. Four European playoffs and the second leg of the South America-North/Central America playoff will be completed. And a one-game African playoff in Sudan will determine whether Algeria or Egypt will make the tournament. Players, coaches and fans endure controversy, anxiety and some disturbing violence on what should prove to be a dramatic final day of qualifying.

headline: ‘The Gift of Thanks’
text: Today, we use paper to cover our gifts, and it is not primarily because they are in need of protection that we wrap them. If we mail a gift, we first carefully wrap it in special "gift" paper — the prettier, the better — and then enclose it, as a safeguard during the journey, in something sturdy and commonplace like brown paper or a plain envelope. Gift wrappings are folded with care. The string that binds a mere parcel becomes, for a gift, a ribbon, often with bows and rosettes added — anything to replace with embellishment the toughness of workaday knots. Extra trouble is taken because of the need to declare that, whatever it is, the thing thus enclosed is not a commodity.

headline: Lives in the Bayou Tap All the Realism of Dreams
text: Spinning stories becomes a blessed biological process in Tarell Alvin McCraney’s “Brother/Sister Plays,” as natural and necessary as breathing. It is said of one character in this gorgeous trilogy, which opened Tuesday night at the Public Theater, where it runs in repertory through Dec. 13, that she “breathes like the wind.” So do Mr. McCraney’s plays, which are pumped full of a senses-heightening oxygen that leaves you tingling.

headline: Deputy at Time Magazine to Be BusinessWeek Editor
text: Josh Tyrangiel, a longtime Time magazine editor and reporter, has been appointed the editor of BusinessWeek, its new owner, Bloomberg L.P., announced on Tuesday morning.

headline: Trying Tenderness in Las Vegas
text: PERHAPS the most curious thing about Twist by Pierre Gagnaire in Las Vegas  the American beachhead soon to be established by a legendary seigneur of Parisian cooking  is its intended humility.

headline: Storming Paris’s Burlesque Stages
text: PARIS | From the Moulin Rouge to the Lido, Parisian cabarets have enthralled generations of crowds. But there’s a new contender on the scene: Gentry Lane — stage name, Gentry de Paris — who has created one of the more ambitious and authentic burlesque shows in Paris.

headline: Comfort Food the Southeast Asian Way
text: THE chef King Phojanakong certainly has the frontier spirit.

headline: Come on in, the Water’s Fine
text: IT was almost the last lunch service at the old Oceana, on East 54th Street, in mid-July, a quiet affair. For some there were oysters to start, for others an icy midday martini. One man had scallops, simply sautéed. For dessert: plain fruit.

headline: Red Cross to Seek Donations Through Online Gifts Catalog
text: WASHINGTON  Hoping to reduce its reliance on major disasters to raise money, the American Red Cross is embarking on a holiday fund-raising campaign, complete with an online gift catalog and advertising.

headline: Pierre Harmel, Belgian Who Helped Reshape NATO, Dies at 98
text: Pierre Harmel, a Belgian statesman who advocated European disarmament in the late 1960s and was the leading proponent of a forward-looking NATO policy toward the former Soviet bloc that hastened East-West détente, died in Brussels on Sunday. He was 98.

headline: Nationalists Suspected in Russian Activist’s Death
text: MOSCOW  A young antiracist campaigner who frequently clashed with Russian nationalists has been killed in Moscow in what investigators and analysts suggest is probably part of an increasingly violent conflict between ultranationalists and groups that oppose them.

headline: Medical Schools Quizzed on Ghostwriting
text: Senator Charles E. Grassley wrote to 10 top medical schools Tuesday to ask what they are doing about professors who put their names on ghostwritten articles in medical journals  and why that practice was any different from plagiarism by students.

headline: Waterworld!
text: In this week’s restaurant review I take a look at Oceana, a venerable name in Manhattan seafood that moved this summer from small quarters on East 54th Street to enormous ones on the ground floor of the McGraw-Hill Building, across the street from City Lobster (which is looking a little quiet and drab these days, sadly). You can read my review here. If you’ve been to the place, you can tell us about your experience in the comments. You can also take part in a brief pop quiz, after the jump.

headline: Ohio Finds Itself Leading the Way to a New Execution Method
text: Prison officials in Ohio never planned to become pioneers in death penalty protocol. But the failed effort on Sept. 15 to execute Romell Broom, a convicted killer, forced the state to rethink how people are put to death and led Ohio officials to be the first in the nation to adopt a new approach.

headline: Before the Turkey Goes in the Oven
text: The 101s are not recipes, exactly, but recipe-like ideas. Putting together all of them is a chunk of work, believe me. But putting together one or two? That’s easy. I’ll bet the collective efforts of the Bitten community could generate another several hundred beyond these 101 before Thanksgiving.

headline: Traffic Agents and Politicians Debate Value of 5 Minutes
text: City Council members say that granting a five-minute grace period for alternate-side-of-the-street parking and certain meter violations would simply give wiggle room to drivers who may have lost track of time.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Notes and Notable Chefs

headline: Little Progress in Freeing a Rover on Mars
text: The NASA rover Spirit, stuck in sand on Mars, tried to move Tuesday for the first time since May. In less than a second, it stopped.

headline: Outfitting a Young Mother to Proudly Support Her Son
text: Four years ago, Jocelyn Morales’s biggest concerns were cheerleading and the science club. Now she has one overriding preoccupation: being a mother.

headline: Paterson Prepares Wage Bill for Construction Sites
text: ALBANY  In a bid to shore up his relations with labor unions, Gov. David A. Paterson is readying legislation that would require developers to pay prevailing wages on many construction projects that receive public financing, meaning that construction workers would have to be paid significantly more than minimum wage.

headline: Cellphone Apps Challenge the Rise of E-Readers
text: With Amazon’s Kindle, readers can squeeze hundreds of books into a device that is smaller than most hardcovers. For some, that’s not small enough.

headline: Grandpa Loved Horses, or How a Filly Got Her Name
text: Grandpa loved the horses.

headline: Conviction of Sheik’s Lawyer for Assisting Terrorism Is Upheld
text: A federal appeals court panel in Manhattan on Tuesday upheld the conviction of Lynne F. Stewart, the outspoken defense lawyer who was found guilty in 2005 of assisting terrorism by smuggling information from an imprisoned client to his violent followers in Egypt.

headline: Use of Statistics Helps Greinke to A.L. Cy Young
text: It might have been a watershed moment in baseball’s statistical revolution. When the voting for the American League Cy Young Award was announced on Tuesday, Zack Greinke of the Kansas City Royals did not just win. He did it in a landslide.

headline: New York Is Set for Strict Stand on D.W.I. Cases
text: ALBANY  New York State would make it a felony to drive while intoxicated with a child in the vehicle and would require first-time convicted drunken drivers to buy a device that prevents them from driving their cars if they have been drinking, under a bill passed by the State Assembly on Tuesday.

headline: UBS Plans to Be Making Nearly $15 Billion a Year in Profit by 2014
text: LONDON  Oswald J. Grübel, the chief executive of the Swiss bank UBS, presented a plan on Tuesday to return it to profitability, saying that he expected the company to be earning nearly $15 billion a year by no later than 2014.

headline: Officials Defend Handling of Flu Vaccine
text: As a nationwide shortage of swine flu vaccine stretched into its sixth week, federal health officials defended how they handled the program, arguing that the roots of the shortage were beyond their control and that they had made the right decisions on matters they could affect.

headline: Buffalo’s Jauron First Coach to Be Fired
text: The Buffalo Bills fired Coach Dick Jauron on Tuesday, making him the first coaching casualty of the season.

headline: Shanahan Retires After 21-Year Career
text: Brendan Shanahan, 11th on the N.H.L.’s career goal list, announced his retirement Tuesday, bringing an end to his 21-year career. Last season, Shanahan returned to the Devils, the team he started his N.H.L. career with in 1987, but was released at the start of this season. He had not caught on with another team.

headline: N.C.A.A. Lets Colleges Decide on a Protocol
text: The N.C.A.A. has no protocol with respect to concussion management; it allows each college that is a member to devise its own procedures, according to David Klossner, the N.C.A.A.’s director of health and safety.

headline: In Johnson’s Signing, Talent Prevails
text: Neil Irvin has carefully monitored Larry Johnson’s movement, from the time rumors began that he would sign with the Cincinnati Bengals until Tuesday, when the Bengals announced that they had signed Johnson, the problematic running back.

headline: Iverson Is an Option the Knicks Will Probably Decline
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Allen Iverson is a free agent again, and the Knicks are having a conversation about him, albeit only with themselves so far.
