headline: ‘Cash for Caulkers': The Details
text: At a meeting of President Obama’s board of outside economic advisers two weeks ago, the venture capitalist John Doerr said the following:

headline: Many Doctors to Stay Course on Breast Exams for Now
text: Despite new recommendations that most women start breast screening at 50 rather than 40, many doctors said Tuesday that they were simply not ready to make such a drastic change.

headline: New Mammogram Advice Finds a Skeptical Audience
text: LOS ANGELES In a world with few givens, there have long been a few health guidelines that every American woman could follow. Dental exams annually, from the time you get teeth. Pap smears every year once you are in your 20s. After age 40, 10 minutes of unpleasantness with a mammogram machine, also on a yearly basis.

headline: Coconut Pluckers in Short Supply
text: Kerala, India, is in the grips of an acute labor shortage that threatens to undermine one of its most important industries.

headline: Pakistani Military Encounters Little Fight as Militants Flee
text: SARAROGHA, Pakistan  This windswept, sand-colored town in the badlands of western Pakistan is empty now, cleared of the militants who once claimed it as their capital. But its main brick buildings, intact and thick with dust, tell not of an epic battle, but of sudden flight.

headline: A Stimulus That Could Save Money
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Paying More for Flights Eases Guilt, Not Emissions
text: In 2002 Responsible Travel became one of the first travel companies to offer customers the option of buying so-called carbon offsets to counter the planet-warming emissions generated by their airline flights.

headline: Germany Arrests Hutu Militia Leaders
text: The leader of a Rwandan rebel group accused of being responsible for the 1994 Rwandan genocide was arrested Tuesday in Germany. The leader, Ignace Murwanashyaka, left, has presided over the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda since 2001. He was arrested in the town of Karlsruhe on Tuesday afternoon by German police officers on suspicions of war crimes and crimes against humanity. One of his deputies, Straton Musoni, was arrested simultaneously in Stuttgart. Mr. Murwanashyaka’s group, known as the F.D.L.R., has been hiding out in pockets of eastern Congo since being driven out of Rwanda by the current government after the end of the genocide, in which nearly a million Rwandan Tutsis were killed in three months.

headline: Kurdish Legislators Threaten Boycott of Iraq Election
text: BAGHDAD  Only a week after Iraq’s leaders celebrated the passage of an election law that kept the country on course to hold its first national elections in four years, Kurdish lawmakers threatened Tuesday to boycott the election unless their demand for a greater share of parliamentary seats was met.

headline: Siblings on Stage
text: Buy your tickets now for "Brother/Sister Plays,"  a trilogy by the talented young playwright Tarell Alvin McCraney, a onetime assistant to August Wilson. Set in a housing project in a Louisiana bayou, the plays, running in rep at the Public, "are pumped full of a senses-heightening oxygen that leaves you tingling," Ben Brantley writes. "Mr. McCraney, who turned 29 in October, writes with a passion and urgency that can't be faked and in a style that makes artifice feel like instinct, even as it invests ordinary lives with the grandeur of ancient gods."

headline: Daft Brooklyn
text: The pioneering house music producer Todd Edwards, known for his contributions to the U.K. dance scene, also collaborated with Daft Punk and created a widely copied sampling technique. Tonight he makes a rare appearance in Brooklyn, at the free party at Littlefield. Go see what all the Euro-fuss is about.

headline: Filipino Spice
text: Once home to a Laundromat, the Bed-Stuy spot Umi Nom is now an outpost of sleek design and adventurous cooking — a destination worthy of a trip on the G train, courtesy of the pioneering chef King Phojanakong, of Kuma Inn on the Lower East Side. The menu at Uni Nom (tagalog for "to drink") "consists of artfully composed small plates of Asian comfort food, elevated by technique but primal in appeal," Ligaya Mishan writes. She likes the delicate crispy chicken wings, "the nearly deliquescent pork-belly adobo" and "the dizzyingly hot" papaya salad. "If you're daring, Mr. Phojanakong can be a guide to the wild side," she writes, offering the Filipino delicacy balut, a fertilized duck egg. Bring whatever you want to wash it down with — the restaurant is BYOB for the time being.

headline: Bio-Diversity
text: Turning autumn leaves take some strange turns indeed.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Scrapbook From the Tribal Areas
text: LADHA, Pakistan — These stunning photographs were seized in South Waziristan, the remote tribal area of Pakistan where Pakistani soldiers are fighting the Taliban. The vistas are beautiful. The terrain — rugged and hard to conquer — is rarely seen by outsiders.

headline: Now, Pressure Is for Players Not to Play After a Concussion
text: BERKELEY, Calif.  Messages sent to the University of California athletic office over the past two weeks have not implored team doctors to put the Bears’ star running back, Jahvid Best, back on the field to help Cal against archrival Stanford this Saturday.

headline: Claims of Child Abuse Remembered Divide Town and Lead to Charges Against 6
text: BATES CITY, Mo.  On a dead-end dirt road, through frosted crops and bales of hay in this sleepy town about a half-hour east of Kansas City, state investigators spent much of last week excavating the yard around a farmhouse, looking for decades-old evidence of sex crimes against children.

headline: Those Soccer Plays, in Context
text: ALBUQUERQUE  Nearly two weeks later, the University of New Mexico soccer player Elizabeth Lambert said she still could not fully explain what led her to yank an opponent from Brigham Young down by her ponytail in what has become a highly publicized incident of violent behavior.

headline: Philadelphia Gives Homeowners a Way to Stay Put
text: PHILADELPHIA  Christopher Hall stepped tentatively through the entranceway of City Hall Courtroom 676 and took his place among dozens of others confronting foreclosure purgatory. His hopes all but extinguished, he fully expected the morning to end with a final indignity: He would sign over the deed to his house  his grandfather’s two-story row house; the only house in which he had ever lived; the house where he had raised three children.

headline: And Now, the Encore: Yanks Charting Off-Season Course
text: General Manager Brian Cashman started assembling his scouts on Tuesday, beginning the annual brainstorming sessions that chart the Yankees’ off-season.

headline: Police Car Ahead of Biden Crashes
text: A police car assisting Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s motorcade collided with another vehicle on the West Side of Manhattan on Tuesday as Mr. Biden was on his way to appear on a television show, the police said.

headline: ESPN Rewards Jon Gruden Despite Flaws
text: On Monday afternoon, ESPN extended Jon Gruden’s contract as an analyst on “Monday Night Football,” affirming the deep affection the empire feels for the former coach midway through his first season in TV.

headline: Shot That Hit Bronx Bystander May Have Been Fired in a Revenge Attack
text: Friends of a 15-year-old Bronx girl struck by a bullet intended for someone else held a vigil for her on Tuesday as the police questioned two men about the shooting.

headline: City’s Largest Dailies Raided in Deliverers’ Union Inquiry
text: The police raided the offices of New York City’s three largest daily newspapers on Tuesday as part of an investigation into possible corruption within the union that delivers newspapers in the metropolitan area.

headline: Schools’ Grades Reflect Persistent Disparity
text: Over the last three years, high schools that received the lowest marks from the city have been the ones with the highest percentages of poor, black and Hispanic students, despite an evaluation system that was meant to equalize differences among student bodies, according to an analysis by The New York Times of school grades released this week.

headline: Like Some Cheddar
text: The theme of this puzzle by Paula Gamache remains veiled until arriving at the giveaway clue toward the end. When I got there, the crossings allowed me to piece together all but the first letter of its answer. I wasn’t sure of the crossing “Spanish eyes” answer.

headline: Prosecutors in Bruno Case Turn Heat on 2 Ex-Aides
text: ALBANY  Seeking to show that Joseph L. Bruno, the former State Senate majority leader, took steps to deceive the public about his private business while in office, prosecutors on Tuesday aggressively questioned two former Senate aides who helped draft official financial disclosure forms for him.

headline: Wall Street on Track for Record in Profits
text: Ten months ago, President Obama said a time would come for Wall Street to make profits and pay bonuses, but “now’s not that time.” But it appears that was exactly when Wall Street began to return to profitability.

headline: Peru: Officer Says He Spied for Chile
text: Officials in President Alan García’s government said an air force officer had confessed to spying for Chile, escalating a diplomatic dispute between Peru and Chile. Javier Velásquez, chief of Mr. García’s cabinet, said Víctor Ariza, 45, a noncommissioned air force officer, had passed national security information to officials in Chile’s armed forces. Additional proof included money transfers received by Mr. Ariza and Internet communications he had with contacts in Chile, Mr. Velásquez said. Chile’s government has disputed the espionage claims, which surfaced this month amid tensions over a maritime boundary dispute.

headline: 2010, Again
text: Allow me to reprise my role as The Man Who Stares At Votes to provide an addendum to my most recent column, “The Passion of the Right,” which warned that:

headline: Labor Fight Ends in Win for Students
text: The anti-sweatshop movement at dozens of American universities, from Georgetown to U.C.L.A., has had plenty of idealism and energy, but not many victories.

headline: After 5 Years, Backman Gets a Second Chance
text: As much as Wally Backman wanted to talk about his future, he knew he needed to discuss his past. So after showing off his new Brooklyn Cyclones uniform at his introductory news conference Tuesday, Backman, with little prompting, addressed the issues that cost him a job as a major league manager and kept him out of the majors for five years.

headline: 3 Democrats Could Block Health Bill in Senate
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, says he is not sure he is ready to help a Democratic health care proposal clear even the most preliminary hurdle: gaining the 60 votes his party’s leaders need to open debate on the measure later this week.

headline: Another Round of Regulatory Reform
text: Throughout the fall, lawmakers in the House have been drafting and reworking legislation to reform the financial system. Senate Democrats weighed in last week with a plan that is stronger than the House bills on aspects of derivatives regulation and consumer protection. It also invites healthy debate on other issues, like the role of the Federal Reserve in a reformed system.

headline: Hunger in the United States
text: Congress should make a priority of expanding federal nutrition programs that are aimed at helping millions of struggling families feed their children. The need to bolster these programs was underscored again this week in a dismaying Department of Agriculture study showing that a record number of households had trouble getting sufficient food at one time or another last year.

headline: The Drug Industry Cashes In
text: The drug industry has been ramping up its prices in advance of any health care reforms that might clamp down on its profits. The industry’s rapid price escalation over the past year threatens to make a mockery of its deal with the Senate Finance Committee and the Obama administration to contribute $80 billion over the next decade to help pay for covering tens of millions of uninsured Americans.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about testimony from the secretary to Joseph L. Bruno, the former State Senate majority leader, in his trial on corruption charges misidentified the court in Albany where the trial is being held. It is Federal District Court, not State Supreme Court.

headline: The Controversy Over Mammograms
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cast Heidegger Out?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Using Drones in Afghanistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rogue American Woman
text: WASHINGTON

headline: What They Really Believe
text: If you follow the debate around the energy/climate bills working through Congress you will notice that the drill-baby-drill opponents of this legislation are now making two claims. One is that the globe has been cooling lately, not warming, and the other is that America simply can’t afford any kind of cap-and-trade/carbon tax.

headline: Why We Should Put Jihad on Trial
text: THE Justice Department’s decision to try Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-proclaimed mastermind of the 9/11 attacks, in a federal court in New York City has elicited several criticisms. Most are pointless, but one  the idea that it will give a terrorist a platform from which he could stir up support in the Muslim world for his radical views  is well taken.

headline: Ben Franklin on Global Warming
text: Columbus, Ohio

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about General Motors’ early start to repayment of its debt to the United States and Canadian governments misstated, in some copies, the expected amount of the initial repayment at the end of December. It is $1.2 billion toward $6.7 billion in senior debt; the company will not pay the entire $6.7 billion.

headline: Corrections
In Ovechkin’s Return, a Teammate Is Key
text: The Rangers got another taste of how good the Russian Olympic team may be Tuesday night when Alexander Ovechkin burned them for a goal and was instrumental in setting up another in Washington’s 4-2 victory at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline on Tuesday with an article about quarterly earnings at the Lowe’s Companies misstated its results in some copies. The company reported a 30 percent lower profit; it did not report a loss.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Saturday with a review of “Inside Out,” a show by Cirkus Cirkör at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, misstated the given name of the performer shown. He is André Farstad, not Andr.

headline: After Outcry, 2 Companies Shift Their Turbine Plans
text: Two companies that encountered political anger for their plans to use Chinese-built turbines on a wind farm in West Texas have announced plans to build a new turbine factory  in the United States.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about foundations that spend down their endowments and then close misstated the taxability of some foundation investment earnings. Private foundations are subject to an excise tax of 1 to 2 percent on the earnings; they are not tax exempt.

headline: Transportation Dept. Bans Drug-Screening Company
text: Michael R. Bennett is not a doctor. But he played one when he signed off on thousands of drug tests for aviation and transportation companies, federal officials said Tuesday as they announced that his company had been banned from doing further tests for the industry for five years.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Monday about John J. O’Connor, a former television critic for The New York Times, referred incorrectly to his work for the Arts & Leisure section. Although he wrote essays for it under his own name, he did not also do so under the pseudonym Cyclops. That was the occasional pen name of another critic for The Times, John Leonard.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: New Sony Reader May Miss Christmas for Some
text: The Sony Daily Edition Reader might seem like a fine holiday gift. Unlike the other Sony e-reading devices sold in stores now, it has a spacious 7-inch touchscreen and wireless access to Sony’s online bookstore and newsstand.

headline: Republicans Seek Inquiry on Fort Hood
text: WASHINGTON  Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee on Tuesday called for an immediate Congressional investigation of what they called systemic intelligence failures before the shootings at Fort Hood on Nov. 5, saying the Obama administration was trying to block a full inquiry.

headline: Sacramento Utility Accuses Banks of Rigging Sales of Municipal Derivatives
text: A California utility, the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, has accused more than a dozen banks of rigging the sales of municipal derivatives and sharing illegal profits.

headline: Army Addresses Soldiers’ Suicide Rate
text: The Army said there were almost certainly to be more suicides of soldiers this year than last. Gen. Peter Chiarelli, the Army vice chief of staff, said that as of Nov. 16, the Army had reported 140 suicides of active duty soldiers this year, the same number as in all of 2008. Despite the overall statistics, General Chiarelli said he believed the Army was making progress because in recent months the rate of suicide was down.

headline: Movement on Federal Judicial Selection
text: The Senate voted to move forward on the nomination of a federal appeals court judge amid Democratic concern over the pace of filling judicial vacancies. The 70-to-29 vote will allow debate to begin on the appointment of David Hamilton, a federal judge in Indiana, to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago. The Senate has confirmed two appellate and four trial court judges nominated by President Obama. At the same point in George W. Bush’s presidency, 5 appellate and 13 trial judges had been confirmed, according to the Judiciary Committee.

headline: In Hollywood, Early Favorite for Governor
text: LOS ANGELES  That the A-list of Hollywood would be supporting the Democratic candidate for governor of California is probably not surprising. But holding a big fund-raiser for someone who is not yet officially a candidate indicates just how badly some here want to end years of Republican rule in the governor’s office  even if the incumbent, Arnold Schwarzenegger, is of Hollywood minting himself.

headline: New Leader at Lazard Is an Insider
text: For much of the modern era, Lazard was known for the internal strife that at times threatened to wreck the now 161-year-old investment bank. Few issues were more contentious than the firm’s leadership.

headline: This Poison Pill Aids Investors
text: Poison pills, or provisions to thwart takeovers, usually benefit management rather than shareholders. Mead Johnson Nutrition’s desire to enact anti-takeover provisions may be an exception.

headline: Sy Syms, Founder of Discount Chain, Dies at 83
text: Sy Syms, who pioneered selling off-price clothing and built his retail chain, the Syms Corporation, into a national brand, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Hershey and Ferrero Hold Talks on Cadbury
text: Hershey and the Italian chocolate maker Ferrero have held talks over a potential bid for Cadbury that would rival Kraft’s $16.7 billion hostile offer, a person briefed on the matter said Tuesday.

headline: Allen Hughes, Music and Dance Critic for The Times, Dies at 87
text: Allen Hughes, a longtime music and dance critic for The New York Times who was known for his encouragement of experimental dance companies and his love of the 20th-century French musical repertory, died on Monday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 87 and had lived in Sarasota since 2003.

headline: Showcase: The Adams Families
text: John Quincy Adams is a preacher in Brooklyn. He founded the New Frontier Baptist Church in Bedford-Stuyvesant, where he has been a pastor for 45 of his 87 years. Mr. Adams — the father of two, grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of two — said he never gave much thought to sharing the name of a former president. “My life has been fruitful,” he said. “Even though the presidents went further than I did, I think I kept pace with them.”

headline: Hulu Steps Into Music With EMI and Norah Jones
text: Hulu, the joint online venture between NBC, Fox and ABC that mostly offers free TV shows and movies, is about to start singing a different tune: music videos.

headline: Harvard Officials Are Fossilized Mollusks, Suffragist Says
text: Thursday, Nov. 18, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Phys Ed: Why Exercise Makes You Less Anxious
text: Researchers at Princeton University recently made a remarkable discovery about the brains of rats that exercise. Some of their neurons respond differently to stress than the neurons of slothful rats. Scientists have known for some time that exercise stimulates the creation of new brain cells (neurons) but not how, precisely, these neurons might be functionally different from other brain cells.

headline: A Local Push, Timed to Holidays, to Loosen Wallets
text: THROUGH the decades, marketers have veered between “Think global, act local” and “Think local, act global.” At one point, someone even coined a portmanteau word, “glocal,” which sounded like a variety of the Glo-Coat brand of floor wax sold by S.C. Johnson.

headline: Irving Kriesberg, Artist of Dreamlike Landscapes, Dies at 90
text: Irving Kriesberg, a much-admired American painter whose work combined the intense colors of Abstract Expressionism with haunting images of human and animal forms, died on Nov. 11 at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: Word of the Day | prude
text: prude • \ˈprüd\ • noun and verb

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Ovechkin Returns With a Goal in Win Over Rangers
text: Two featured matches among Tuesday’s six games, in a high-low kind of way. The high was Rangers-Caps, with Alex Ovechkin back in the Washington lineup after missing six games with an unspecified upper-body injury. And the low was Canadiens-Hurricanes, featuring the two teams with the league’s worst regulation records: Habs at 2-11-7, Canes at 1-12-6. Home teams listed first:

headline: Silicon Valley Firm Raises Big Fund for Mix of Deals
text: Norwest Venture Partners has raised $1.2 billion for a new venture capital fund, an optimistic sign for technology start-ups.

headline: Finder’s Keepers: Souvenirs on the Road
text: This Frugal Traveler is not big on souvenirs. Too often, the postcards, T-shirts and other tchotchkes hawked to tourists are kitschy and overpriced — the kind of junk that takes up space in your suitcase and gets filed away when you return home. Rarely do those things fulfill the French root of the word “souvenir” and help you to remember your adventure. Better, I say, to save your money and return home empty-handed but full of memories.

headline: 50 Years of Comic Art
text: WHO is Joe Kubert?

headline: News Quiz | November 18, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Love and Lore
text: Images from “The Brother/Sister Plays” at the Public Theater.

headline: The Virtual Fridge
text: A slide show of children’s artwork submitted by readers. Masterpieces made of paint, popsicle sticks, crayons and even food.

headline: Hermitage Capital Lawyer Dies in Russian Jail
text: A 37-year-old Russian lawyer for an international investment fund, Hermitage Capital Management, died in a pretrial detention center on Monday, nearly a year after he was arrested in an escalating feud between the Russian authorities and the company, Russia’s Interior Ministry announced on Tuesday.

headline: Gold Continues Its Rise, While Asian Stocks Gain
text: Gold hit another all-time high on Wednesday on worries about future inflation and economic uncertainties, while Asian stocks rebounded as the generally bearish dollar kept riskier assets in demand, Reuters reported.

headline: S.A.I.C. Reclassifies Shares Into Common Stock
text: Science Applications International Corporation, or S.A.I.C., the defense contractor, has completed the reclassification of its class A preferred stock into common stock.

headline: Tokyo Drift
text: A perception that Japan’s new government is distancing itself from the United States.

headline: The AIG report
text: At one level, there’s not much news in the SIGTARP (YHTMAAAIYP) report on the AIG bailout: officials asked bankers to take a haircut, bankers said Ni!, and that was that. But the report has renewed the debate over whether officials could have extracted something. I say yes.

headline: Will Mead Poison Pill Aid Investors?
text: Poison pills, or provisions to thwart takeovers, usually benefit management rather than shareholders, Breakingviews.com says. Mead Johnson Nutrition’s desire to enact anti-takeover provisions may be an exception, the Web site says.

headline: California Utility Says Banks Rigged Derivative Sales
text: A California utility, the Sacramento Municipal Utility District, has accused more than a dozen banks of rigging the sales of municipal derivatives and sharing illegal profits, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Trump Settles for 10% of Casino Company
text: Donald J. Trump ended his war with bondholders of the casino company that bears his name, settling Tuesday for 10 percent of Trump Entertainment Resorts once it emerges from bankruptcy.

headline: After Outcry, 2 Companies Shift Their Turbine Plans
text: Two companies that encountered political anger for their plans to use Chinese-built turbines on a wind farm in West Texas have announced they will build a new turbine factory — in the United States, The New York Times’s Kate Gabraith reported.

headline: Drake Hotel’s Prime Space Remains Undeveloped
text: Enclosed by a dark brown fence, the weedy lot at Park Avenue and 56th Street in Midtown Manhattan is a conspicuous reminder of how ambitions were shattered in the recent real estate debacle, The New York Times’s Terry Pristin writes. This vacant site, where the Drake Hotel once stood, is likely to leave a gash in the middle of the nation’s costliest office submarket for years to come, real estate specialists say.

headline: S.C. Johnson Considering Bid for Sara Lee Unit?
text: S.C. Johnson & Son may be eying Sara Lee Corp.‘s air-freshener business, in an auction that could fetch more than $700 million, according to a published report.

headline: Vain Glorious | Byredo’s Stockholm Store
text: With Vain Glorious, T Magazine’s beauty/style director, Sandra Ballentine, breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.

headline: Silicon Valley Firm Raises Deal Fund
text: Norwest Venture Partners has raised $1.2 billion for a new venture capital fund, an optimistic sign for technology start-ups.

headline: Veto of Iraq’s Election Law Could Force Vote Delay
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq was thrown into a fresh political crisis on Wednesday after a vice president vetoed a newly passed election law, delaying the vote, setting off fresh sectarian wrangling and possibly complicating plans to withdraw American troops.

headline: At Lazard, a Peaceful Transfer of Power
text: For much of the modern era, Lazard was known for the internal strife that at times threatened to wreck the now 161-year-old investment bank. Few issues were more contentious than the firm’s leadership.

headline: Obama Ends China Trip With Visit to the Great Wall
text: BEIJINGOn his last day in China, President Obama went to see the Great Wall.

headline: $500 Million, and an Apology, From Goldman
text: How much good will can an apology — and half a billion dollars — buy? Goldman Sachs is hoping it will be a lot.

headline: European Regulators May Take Swift Action on ‘Dark Pools’
text: European Union securities regulators will complete their review of “dark pool” share trading venues by year end and may ask the bloc’s executive to take speedy action, a top supervisor said Tuesday.

headline: Vivendi Said to Want More for NBC Stake
text: It seems Vivendi may be holding out for more in its negotiations to sell its 20 percent stake in NBC Universal to majority owner General Electric.

headline: Lawmaker Opposes Fed as Super-Regulator
text: Congress ought to clarify if a proposed super-regulator of the U.S. financial system should be an overlapping overseer of securities and futures exchanges, the chief futures regulator said on Tuesday.

headline: Obama Takes Stern Tone on North Korea and Iran
text: SEOUL, South Korea  President Obama delivered a stern message on Thursday to North Korea and Iran that they risk further sanctions and isolation if they do not rein in their nuclear ambitions.

headline: Citi Boosts Salaries of Some Senior Executives
text: Citigroup said on Tuesday it boosted the base salaries for its chief financial officer and a global markets co-head, but still plans to pay its chief executive, Vikram Pandit, $1 for the year, Reuters reported.

headline: Review Period Expires for Xerox-A.C.S. Merger
text: Xerox is a step closer to acquiring Dallas-based Affiliated Computer Services, now that the U.S. antitrust review period for the deal has expired, The Associated Press said.

headline: Judge Approves Charter’s Reorganization Plan
text: Charter Communications said Tuesday a bankruptcy judge has confirmed its reorganization plan, clearing the way for the nation’s fourth-largest cable TV operator to emerge from Chapter 11 in a few weeks.

headline: Week 10 Passer Rankings: On the Bright Side With Cutler
text: Luis DeLoureiro is building a better passer rating at NFLStatAnalysis.net:

headline: Filling a Hole in the Middle of Berlin
text: Smack in the middle of eastern Berlin is a grassy lawn measuring nearly five acres. Near it is a huge billboard showing a castle. What gives?

headline: MySpace Said to Be in Talks to Buy Imeem
text: MySpace, the social networking platform, is in talks to acquire struggling free music streaming site  imeem, The Associated Press reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Intrawest Sells Copper Mountain to Powdr
text: Intrawest, owned by the Fortress Investment Group, has agreed to sell its Copper Mountain ski resort in Colorado to Powdr, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Germany Approves Extension for Afghan Mission
text: BERLIN  The government of Chancellor Angela Merkel on Wednesday approved a one-year extension of Germany’s deployment of troops in the American-led coalition in Afghanistan, a government official said, but the number of troops will stay the same.

headline: Delta Offers $1 Billion to Tempt Japan Airlines
text: Delta Air Lines offered $1 billion in aid to beleaguered Japan Airlines on Wednesday, a proposal that American Airlines quickly said it would top as the world’s biggest air carriers escalated a war for influence.

headline: The Minimum Wage and Teenage Jobs
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: The Rise of ‘Algorithmic Authority’
text: Today’s idea: More and more, we place our trust in “algorithmic authority,” a new-media professor writes. We “regard as authoritative an unmanaged process of extracting value from diverse, untrustworthy sources.”

headline: Mitsubishi UFJ Plans $11.2 Billion Share Offer
text: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Japan’s largest bank, said Wednesday it would press ahead with plans to raise up to $11.2 billion to bolster its financial cushion even as it posted results that showed higher profits in the last six months.

headline: Is Icahn Swooping Down on MGM?
text: Is Carl C. Icahn buying  Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer bonds “like a bat out of hell”? That’s the word, according to Hollywood blogger Nikki Finke.

headline: Sampler: Dellums’ Trip, Palin’s Book, Jerry Brown’s A-List
text: Jerry’s A-List | A fundraiser tonight in Los Angeles for Jerry Brown, California’s attorney general and likely Democratic candidate for governor, will include Steven Spielberg, Larry Ellison, Magic Johnson and others, all expected to raise $50,000 or more each.

headline: Pirates Attack Maersk Alabama Again
text: LONDON  Seaborne raiders in a high-speed skiff tried again on Wednesday to commandeer the Maersk Alabama, the American-flagged ship seized by pirates in April, the United States Navy said.

headline: Andy Grove’s Prescription for Health Care
text: Andrew S. Grove, the 73-year-old former chief executive of Intel, has long brought a piercing intellect and a personal passion to the subject of health care.

headline: Ford Minivans Investigated for Transmission Failure
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has intensified its investigation into transmission failures on about 205,000 Ford Freestar and Mercury Monterey minivans from the 2004-2005 model years.

headline: Your Child’s Art on Our Virtual Fridge
text: Last week’s article, “On a Digital Refrigerator, an Art Gallery for the Young,” featured artwork from the  hyper-local blogs of The Times and included an invitation to parents to e-mail their own child’s art for display on nytimes.com.

headline: Is the Music You Listen to Dull?
text: “Ever since Natalie Portman popped headphones onto Zach Braff’s head and said, ‘This song will change your life,’ [in the movie “Garden State”] American music has been dying a slow death,” claims an essay quoted in the “Idea of the Day” blog. Do you agree that “youth culture is now practically sponsored by iTunes and Starbucks” and needs a jolt of something “hungry and desperate and raw”?

headline: The Early Word: Health Bill Buzz
text: People who are closely following the health care debate might not have to wait much longer for Senate Democrats to release their bill and for the Congressional Budget Office to assess its cost.

headline: On Our Radar…
text: 1.) What can’t you do with leftover food?

headline: Houston to Convert Priuses to Plug-Ins
text: Houston is America’s oil capital, with its sprawling oil company headquarters and highways so densely trafficked at rush hour that they sometimes feel like endless parking lots. But Houston’s city government and Reliant Energy are trying a modest new effort to green the city’s image with a program called “Power of the Plug-in.”

headline: Q.&A. With Kanjorski on Bank Breakup Plan
text: Representative Paul E. Kanjorski introduced his contentious amendment to the House financial regulatory reform bill on Wednesday that would allow the government to break up financial institutions that it believed were “too big to fail,” even if those firms appear well-capitalized and healthy.

headline: Five Arrested in Shooting of Bronx Bystander
text: Updated, 2:08 p.m. | Five young people have been arrested in a shooting that critically injured a 15-year-old Bronx girl — a bystander struck by a bullet intended for someone else — the New York City police announced on Wednesday morning.

headline: The Morning Feed
text: What we’re reading on Wednesday morning.RT @Pagliacci “Vesti la giubba”: The Culture Monster blog of The Los Angeles Times reports on a project recently started by the San Diego Opera, in which that company will recount the history of opera on its Twitter feed, at the rate of two posts a day. One recent post in the series reads: “1613: Monteverdi in Venice, maestro di capella at San Marco. Writes great church music, and more operas.”

headline: The Odd Couple | Heston Blumenthal at Shopsin’s
text: Hubris will get you every time. Why did I think I could take Heston Blumenthal to lunch at Shopsin’s and get away with it? The brilliant British chef behind the Fat Duck and the Hinds Head in Bray — just inked to open in the London Mandarin Oriental next fall with an Adam Tihany-designed space serving English food on a more historical scale — was in town on his way back from Venezuela, where he demonstrated his flaming sorbet. (First challenge: finding dry ice in a country with electricity shortages and an increasingly adversarial trade relationship with Colombia.) Where do you take a man known for snail porridge and bacon-and-egg ice cream? A chef so funny and articulate that you can basically print the transcript of his interview about roast chicken in the 14th century and call it a story? Duh.

headline: Assembly Moves to Toughen Law in D.W.I. Cases
text: New York State would make it a felony to drive while intoxicated with a child in the vehicle and would require first-time convicted drunken drivers to buy a device that prevents them from driving their cars if they have been drinking, under a bill passed by the State Assembly on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Home Building Unexpectedly Slumps in October
text: Home construction slowed unexpectedly in October to the lowest level in six months, the Commerce Department said Wednesday, resurrecting fears that the housing market may be slow to recover.

headline: American Express to Buy Revolution Money
text: American Express said Wednesday that it would buy Revolution Money, a provider of Internet-based payment services started by Steve Case, AOL‘s co-founder, for $300 million.

headline: Speed Read for Wednesday, Nov. 19
text: Highlights from Wednesday’s media coverage:

headline: Finder’s Keepers: Souvenirs on the Road
text: What makes a great souvenir, especially when you don’t want to spend a lot of money? And how do you find unique items of real value?

headline: The Conflicted Populists
text: Rod Dreher has one of the smarter reactions I’ve seen to “Going Rogue”: He zeroes in on the tension between Sarah Palin’s account of her experiences fighting crony capitalism in Alaska — where she saw firsthand “how badly Exxon screwed over the people of Alaska in the Exxon Valdez incident, and how the cozy relationship between Alaska’s government and the oil industry worked against the interests of ordinary hardworking people” — and the “business good, liberals bad” boilerplate (complete with a dig at Karl Marx) that she employs when it comes time to talk about national policy. Rod writes:

headline: Piecing Together Neda Agha-Soltan’s Death
text: Updated | 4:06 p.m. As my colleague Neil Genzlinger wrote in a review on Tuesday, a new documentary on the protests in Iran, produced for PBS and the BBC, pieces together the death, and life, of Neda Agha-Soltan, the 26-year-old protester whose last moments were caught on video on June 20 and posted online within hours.

headline: Ford Leads in Top Safety Picks
text: Ford leads automakers in the annual list of Top Safety Picks from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, which released its compilation of the safest passenger vehicles Wednesday.

headline: Health Care Reform and McKinsey’s ‘Client X’
text: Jonathan Cohn gets his hands on a McKinsey & Company report analyzing what health care reform would mean for a typical employer (and thus for the medical system as a whole). The employer is called “Client X” in the report. The conclusion is that reform is indeed likely to have a significant — and positive — impact on health care.

headline: The Role of Student Fees in Athletic Budgets
text: While the article in Tuesday’s New York Times about SUNY’s transition to Division I noted that the four State University of New York research universities have increased their contributions to athletics in recent years, it did not examine the role that student fees play in the athletic budgets, as Amy Perko of the Knight Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics noted in an e-mail message on Tuesday.

headline: What Will the Goldman Sachs Plan Mean to You?
text: Update | 2:23 p.m. We’ve received lots of requests from business owners who want to know more about the 10,000 Small Businesses initiative. Here’s a Web site dedicated to the plan. And here’s an e-mail address where you can send questions: 10000SmallBusinesses@gs.com.

headline: New Greenpeace Chief Calls for Sustainable, Nuclear-Free Power Supply
text: Kumi Naidoo was appointed executive director of the environmental campaign group Greenpeace International this month after two decades leading civil society groups in Africa and internationally. Mr. Naidoo, 44, who is from South Africa, takes over the role at a time when environmentalism increasingly enjoys mainstream status, although the agenda of groups like Greenpeace remains at odds with those of many governments in critical areas like nuclear power and biotechnology. Mr. Naidoo, who is based in Amsterdam, answered questions on energy and climate policy in an e-mail exchange with Green Inc.

headline: Shares Drop Slightly on Disappointing Economic Data
text: Hints of a slowdown in the housing market and a batch of dim forecasts from technology companies turned Wall Street traders cautious on Wednesday, with the major indexes retreating slightly from 13-month highs.

headline: ‘A Nice Break’
text: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Sarah Palin’s new book came out today. Well, she did “Oprah” yesterday. She did “G.M.A.” this morning. Having her out on the road is a nice break, if you are a moose in Alaska.

headline: ‘Not on Her Radar’
text: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Well, the President is in China now. And he had 71 cars in his motorcade drive from the airport to Beijing. There’s one car for the president, two for Secret Service and then 68 for Obama’s advisers on the environment.

headline: ‘Obama Made a Faux Pas’
text: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on NBC: The President of the United States is in China tonight. This is big. The Chinese president entertained President Obama by having a military band play “I Just Called To Say I Love You” and “We Are The World.” What I want to know is how did the Chinese president get hold of my college record collection?

headline: In Cuba, a Jobless Person Is a ‘Dangerous’ Person
text: A report released on Wednesday by Human Rights Watch on the human rights situation in Cuba takes the government of President Raúl Castro to task for, among other things, jailing those without jobs. The report cited the cases of dozens of people charged with “dangerousness” for being unemployed.

headline: Letters Lost, Meaning Found
text: The sign, more accurately, should have read “U R HURT.”

headline: Wednesday Reading
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: ‘More Than a Billion People’
text: Monologue |  Aired Tuesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: It’s a great day for America and a great day for one of our loveliest Americans, Sarah Palin. Her long-awaited book, “Going Rogue,” hit bookstores today. Last night, Sarah did a tell-all interview with Barbara Walters. I watched, but I couldn’t understand what either one was saying. “Did you cwy when you wost the election?” “You betcha.”

headline: You Play To Win the Game
text: This Joe Posnanski post should be the last word on the great “should Bill Belichick have gone for it?” controversy — and, indeed, on Belichick’s entire career.

headline: ‘Touring Him Around’
text: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Do you know where President Obama is right now? In China. Today he was over there. They’re touring him around. He got to see where they keep all our money.

headline: What to Watch on Wednesday: ‘Modern Family’ and the Kingdom of Mustang
text: It’s been a rough season so far for Det. Elliott Stabler (Christopher Meloni) on “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (NBC, 9 p.m.): he found out he sent the wrong man to jail, he was thrown off a roof and his groin was on the receiving end of an angry child’s foot. Now it’s time for Olivia Benson (Mariska Hargitay) to take her lumps: a biker turns up dead and sexually mutiliated and the DNA evidence points to Olivia.

headline: ‘In the Mayan Calendar’
text: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: President Obama arrived in China yesterday. And to foster the spirit of good will, he wore the traditional clothes made by the children of China. You know, L.L. Bean, J. Crew, Banana Republic, Nike, Reebok.

headline: Home Starts Look Good — Compared With Apartments
text: Who would break ground on a new apartment building these days?

headline: Playing the Health Care Lottery
text: In the short story “The Lottery,” the author Shirley Jackson describes a small farming community in 1940s America, as picturesque a scene as anything you’d find in Norman Rockwell. It’s “Lottery Day,” and families gather in the June sun, the adults chatting while their children play, gathering up small piles of stones.

headline: Countdown to the 60th National Book Awards
text: As you busily compile your year-end best-of lists and plan your 2010 schedule around the Grammys, the Oscars or the start of “American Idol,” it may have escaped your attention that the National Book Awards, in their 60th year, are to be handed out on Wednesday night. If the National Book Awards, presented by the National Book Foundation, seem to have generated less buzz than in previous years, it might have something to do with a roster of finalists that aren’t likely to be known by wide audiences: among this year’s nominees for the fiction prize are Colum McCann’s “Let the Great World Spin,” and Marcel Theroux’s “Far North”; the nonfiction finalists include David M. Carroll’s “Following the Water: A Hydromancer’s Notebook,” and Sean B. Carroll’s “Remarkable Creatures: Epic Adventures in the Search for the Origins of the Species.”

headline: In Africa, Capturing the Fight Against Climate Change
text: With the approach of the international climate talks in Copenhagen, the United Nations Development Program in conjunction with the Olympus Corporation and the Agence France-Presse Foundation created a photo competition aimed at profiling everyday Africans and their efforts to combat climate change. Below is a slide show of some of the winning photographs and the runners-up in various categories.

headline: Can Crispy Green Go National?
text: The Company: Crispy Green of Fairfield, N.J., a maker of freeze-dried fruit snacks sold in silver packages that has seven employees and had 2008 revenue of $2.2 million. The snacks are a gluten-, dairy- and nut-free alternative to chips.

headline: Feeling For … Brogues
text: They’re chunky. They’re clunky. They can chew your ankles when they’re being broken in. And yet I’m completely feeling for brogues this fall. They’re the 1960s wingtips with the heavy extended leather sole worn by businessmen in an era typified by philandering, booze and cigarettes in the workplace. They served as heavy anchors to the slender suits of the day that have been resurfacing thanks to “Mad Men” and the spinoffs hitting the floors at Brooks Brothers, J. Crew and Banana Republic. Duckie Brown’s brogue collaboration with Florsheim has reinvigorated its classic Royal Imperial collection with saturated colors and artful perforations; other stateside manufacturers like Alden and Allen Edmonds have classic versions of the shoe that originated in England with brands like Trickers, Church’s and Grenson. I prefer the cordovan color for the rich tone it adds to any gray suit, but black will do just fine. Best of all, brogues are not just suited for business — they are the perfect exclamation point for jeans, whether they are faded and worn, or dark and unwashed. Roll up those cuffs… I’m feeling for brogues.

headline: Dueling Alliances Make Aid Offers to Japan Airlines
text: TOKYO  Delta Air Lines and its alliance partners offered $1 billion in aid to Japan Airlines on Wednesday, a proposal that American Airlines quickly said it would top as the world’s biggest airlines escalated a war for influence over the ailing Japanese carrier.

headline: Patterns: Smoking in U.S. Declines but Not by Much
text: One in five Americans smoked last year, down from almost one in four a decade earlier. But the declines in smoking have recently stalled, with virtually no change in smoking rates since 2004 and even a hint of an increase last year, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are reporting.

headline: Nicolas Cage Is Sued by Former Money Manager
text: For the “Bad Lieutenant” star Nicolas Cage, the week just got a little worse. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Cage, the actor whose lavish spending habits have been widely discussed since he filed suit against his former business manager, is being countersued by that same manager. In October, Mr. Cage sued Samuel J. Levin for fraud, saying that Mr. Levin led him “down a path toward financial ruin.” In his countersuit filed on Nov. 12, The A.P. reported, Mr. Levin said he told Mr. Cage he would need to earn $30 million a year to maintain his life style, and that he warned the actor not to buy castles in England and Bavaria. (Mr. Cage did not heed the advice.) Mr. Levin also said in his filing that he devised a fund-raising plan for Mr. Cage that included the sale of a dozen classic cars and a $1.6 million comic book collection. A lawyer for Mr. Cage said that Mr. Levin had breached Mr. Cage’s privacy by releasing details about his asset sales. The A.P. said that the Internal Revenue Service has filed more than $6.6 million in tax liens against Mr. Cage this year.

headline: Obama Says Guantánamo Won’t Close by January
text: President Obama acknowledged for the first time on Wednesday that his administration would miss a self-imposed deadline to close the detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, by mid-January, admitting the difficulties of following through on one of his first pledges as president.

headline: ‘Setting the Table’ for Next Labor Negotiations
text: A decade ago, the N.B.A. and its players were embroiled in a labor dispute, culminating in a lockout which nearly led to the cancellation of the 1998-99 season. With the current collective bargaining agreement set to expire in 2011, the parties once again have begun to lay the groundwork for the negotiations toward a new agreement. The Los Angeles Lakers’ Derek Fisher, a veteran of the 1998-99 work stoppage and now the president of the N.B.A. Players Association, is the players’ chief representative.

headline: No Free (CO2) Lunch for Frequent Fliers?
text: A company promoting responsible travel cancels sales of “carbon offsets” to compensate for greenhouse gases from flying.

headline: Answers on Community Colleges, Part 3
text: Each day this week, the Guidance Office — the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts — will feature answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: 3Com’s Deal Maker of the Week?
text: The Am Law Daily named Michael Ringler of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati as deal maker of the week last week. The Web site did so based on his representation of 3Com in its $2.7 billion agreement to be acquired by Hewlett-Packard. Am Law’s profile could only be described as glowing and based on his “persistent” lawyering.

headline: Thursday Matchup: Dolphins at Panthers
text: Dolphins (4-5) at Panthers (4-5)Thursday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Panthers by 3

headline: Heston Blumenthal at Shopsin’s
text: On The Moment, Christine Muhlke takes Heston Blumenthal to Shopsin’s. Clever. But bringing a camera and a notepad when you’re about to dine with the notoriously cranky Kenny Shopsin? Not so smart. They’re lucky they got to eat. Blumenthal enjoyed it.

headline: Campuses Strike as U.C. Leaders Decide On Fee Hike
text: Today, the University of California Board of Regents meets to consider a 32 percent fee hike as well as fee increases for 44 graduate programs. The office of the student regent Jesse Cheng is live blogging the meeting, which is taking place at the university’s Los Angeles campus:

headline: Caucus Chatter: New Comment Features
text: Dear Caucus readers,

headline: 'My Wonderful Day'
text: Ayesha Antoine and Petra Letang in a scene from Alan Ayckbourn's play. (Courtesy of Applause Video)

headline: Glitter and Be Essential
text: A WARNING to sticklers for strict narrative: this column is a blatant mashup.

headline: In Basketball, Early Signs of Life
text: Perhaps we have been numbed by too many horrendous N.F.L. blowouts, or a baseball season that seemed to last an epoch, but the college basketball season already feels promising. Forget for a minute that Isiah Thomas is involved in any way, that tournaments are trying to outdo themselves with the ugliest courts ever conceived and that Memphis Coach Josh Pastner would be stopped and asked for a hall pass in most high schools. Heck, we can even live with a game at 6 a.m. on a crazy 24-hour television-conceived “tipoff day” when the season actually started last week.

headline: Jobless Benefits Will Expire Unless Congress Acts
text: About one million laid-off workers will see their unemployment benefits end in January unless Congress acts quickly to renew existing federally paid extensions, according to a new survey and legislators and state officials.

headline: Another View of Velvet Underground at New York Public Library
text: Got a burning question you’ve wanted to pose to the Velvet Underground since that down-and-out New York art-rock band broke up in the 1970s? Want to know who’s coughing on the recording of “Who Loves the Sun” or when we’ll see an official CD release for “Squeeze”? You may finally have a chance to get the answers: On Dec. 8, three members of the Velvet Underground will appear at the New York Public Library to discuss the group’s music and history as part of the library’s “Live From the NYPL” series, Billboard reported. The musicians Maureen Tucker, Doug Yule and, of course, Lou Reed (who we understand just adores being peppered with random questions by his fans) are scheduled to appear at the event, at which they will be interviewed by the journalist David Fricke. The interview will take place at the Celeste Bartos Forum in the library’s Stephen A. Schwarzman Building, and tickets are available online at nypl.org ($15 and $25). The Velvet Underground singer-guitarist Sterling Morrison died in 1995, and the co-founder John Cale left in 1968, though he reunited with Mr. Reed for a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony in 1996.

headline: Prospects for Large Houston Solar Plant Dim
text: Two months ago, the City of Houston announced that it planned to work with NRG Energy, the big wholesale power generation company, to build a $40 million solar power plant that would be the largest in Texas. But now The Dallas Morning News is reporting that prospects for the plant are dimming fast.

headline: From Simple Noun to Handy Partisan Put-Down
text: Call it a vast linguistic conspiracy: proponents of the major conspiracy theo­ries of the day — the truthers, the birthers, the deathers — share a suffix that makes them all sound like whackdoodles. “It looks like conspiracy theorists might acquire a permanent suffix in -er, just like political scandals now have a permanent suffix in -gate,” Victor Steinbok, a frequent contributor to the American Dialect Society’s online discussion board, observed recently in that forum. But unlike -gate, which merely names a scandal, he later noted, -er “makes fun of the participant” as an obsessive, “almost foaming at the mouth” advocate of a fringe political belief.

headline: Minister Says Iran Won’t Ship Uranium Abroad
text: CAIRO  Iran’s foreign minister said this week that his government would not ship its stockpile of low-enriched uranium out of the country, making him the highest ranking official so far to declare that Iran would renege on a deal aimed at defusing a confrontation with the West over its nuclear program.

headline: 101-Year-Old Man Buys a 426-Horsepower Camaro
text: Eight months older than General Motors, Virgil Coffman clearly is not whom Chevrolet had in mind when it decided to bring back the Camaro.

headline: A Library’s Century of ‘Hungering Imagination’
text: The Seward Park branch of the New York Public Library opened 100 years ago this month, on Nov. 11, 1909, and the library will mark the centennial with a program of public events starting at 2 p.m. Thursday. Perhaps what is most remarkable about the branch, which was most recently renovated in 2004, is the continuity of the immigrant aspirations — then largely Jewish, now mostly Asian and Hispanic — it embodies.

headline: Flush in a Recession, a Bronx Landlord Is Ready to Shop
text: In the feudal world of Bronx real estate, where a handful of landlords claim ownership to its skyline of cramped apartments, Jacob Selechnik is most certainly royalty.

headline: On Assignment: Asia in the Blink of an Eye
text: President Obama, whose motorcade has been as long as 71 vehicles, is always at least 30 cars ahead of the four-person photo pool trailing him as he tours Asia. I really wanted a whimsical picture of the president as he walked past the “No Smoking” sign in the Forbidden City, but his Chinese police escorts blocked the shot as his entourage swept by. (Note: Lark cigarettes are very popular in Asia and the gift shop in the hotel where Mr. Obama stayed in Tokyo sells Che ashtrays). That done, we were escorted at a quick trot — with the 35 pounds of gear it takes to be a live news bureau operation — to set up at the other side of the nearly-empty complex to record the president as he signed the visitor’s log. Throughout Japan, Singapore and China, I have met friendly and industrious people. The young woman at the Starbucks in Beijing took my debit card with a smile and never once mentioned the nearly $1 trillion of U.S. debt held by China. A helpful American journalist based in Beijing pointed out the spot where an unknown Chinese man heroically faced down a line of tanks during the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests. There’s little down time on these trips. Sleepless nights worrying about oversleeping take their toll. My hopes of going to the famous Silk Market in Beijing to haggle for Western cowboy wear — the exact item available in Aspen at four times the amount — have been dashed.

headline: ‘Precious’ to Be Honored With Kramer Award
text: “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire” took a step in the march toward Oscar recognition, as the Producers Guild of America chose to honor it with the group’s Stanley Kramer Award, according to a person briefed on the decision who spoke on condition of anonymity because it had not been formally announced. Established in 2002, the Kramer award is given to a movie, program, studio, executive or entity that tackles provocative social issues in a constructive way. “Precious,” about a young woman’s struggles to succeed despite her troubled and impoverished family, fills the bill, and will join such past recipients as “Milk” and “Good Night, and Good Luck,” both of which were nominated for best-picture Oscars.

headline: Hannah Returns: Responding to Comments on Women’s Colleges
text: Hannah Smith is a senior at University Laboratory School in Baton Rouge, La., who is currently applying to colleges. Here she responds to the more than 300 comments on an essay she wrote about her interest in women’s colleges, which was posted on The Choice.

headline: Greetings Line in the Cards for Taylor Swift
text: Suppose you’d like to send a friend a note in a time of need — perhaps she was recently embarrassed at a music awards show on national television? — but you can’t think of the exact right words to say to her. Taylor Swift may be able to help you out. American Greetings said that it has signed a deal with Ms. Swift, the 19-year-old country music superstar, to produce a line of greeting cards centered around her, The Associated Press reported. In a news release, American Greetings said that it planned to release cards, as well as gift wrap, stationery and online photo products and greetings whose design will be overseen by Ms. Swift in the spring. In a statement, the company’s chief executive, Zev Weiss, said that Ms. Swift’s “abilities as a storyteller and songwriter make her a natural at writing cards for consumers of all ages.” Ms. Swift said in statement, “My idea of a great song is a song that says how I feel better than I could. I feel the same way about greeting cards.” We’ll see if they measure up to the Garfield product line, which we feel are the best greeting cards “of all-time — of all-time.”

headline: Now Showing | Stuffed Animals, Cuddly No More
text: You’ll never look at those cute little mechanical stuffed bunnies the same way again. On Thursday, Moss unveils “Remains,” an exhibition by the artist Cathy McClure, whose particular passion is taking these mass-produced, eminently disposable items and redesigning them as precious objects. McClure strips away the plush motorized creatures’ furry coats and fluffy stuffing and then casts the animals’ plastic bodies and limbs in bronze, while leaving most of their mechanisms intact but exposed. A rabbit’s ears, for instance, are reduced to their antenna-like spring supports, while a formerly cocky rooster drags his now-heavy body around, crowing as if he were still king of the barnyard. If the movie “Mad Max” had had a toyshop, these half-whimsical, half-disturbing animals would have fit right in. But they’re strictly for big kids now, with their sumptuous bronze bodies and five-figure price tags. The exhibition continues through Dec. 31 at 150 Greene Street.

headline: A Conversion Experience: Using the Metric System
text: Overview | Should Americans employ and embrace the International System of Units (S.I., or the modern metric system)? In this lesson, students watch the documentary “Powers of 10” and then document their own connections between daily objects and metric measurements to create metric “anchors.” They then develop ways to help others learn and remember metric units.

Carrie Underwood‘s “Play On” (19/Arista Nashville), last week’s top seller, fell to No. 3 with 128,000 sales, a 60 percent drop, and Andrea Bocelli‘s “My Christmas” (Sugar/Decca) climbed one spot to No. 2 with 136,000.

She is currently part of the “Inferno” show at the Yautepec gallery in Mexico City, and in December her music video for the band Jessica 6 will premiere at New York’s Deitch Projects. Vivier is a Paris photographer who shoots fashion for magazines like Purple and Dazed & Confused. The art-book publisher Seems will issue a collection of her work in the spring, and Maison Martin Margiela has commissioned her to direct a video for its new fragrance being released early next year. Here, a look at some of their recent works.

headline: F.B.I. Kept File on Studs Terkel
text: While Studs Terkel was following around musicians, baseball players and other hardworking Americans in the course of his journalistic duties, it turns out that Mr. Terkel was being followed himself. The Chicago Tribune reported that Mr. Terkel, the prolific author, radio host and Pulitzer Prize winner, who died last year, was tracked for 45 years by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the suspicion that he was a Communist. According to a dossier obtained by the NYCity News Service of the City University of New York, the F.B.I.’s file on Mr. Terkel began in 1945, noting that he spoke at a Paul Robeson rally and worked with the BBC on a piece about the “sordid side of life in Chicago.” The last entry in the file was a 1990 article from The Wall Street Journal in which Mr. Terkel was quoted on the junk-bond scandal of the financier Michael Milken. (“We live in a corrupt, amoral moment,” Mr. Terkel said.) The dossier also showed that Mr. Terkel had applied for a job in the fingerprints division of the F.B.I. in the 1930s.

headline: Feeling Fluish? Call 311

headline: Who Fears a Free Mikhail Khodorkovsky?
text: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, once his country’s richest man, has resided in “gulag lite,” as he calls the Russian penal system under Vladimir Putin, for six years. Since the spring, on most working days he is roused at 6:45 in the morning, surrounded by guards and packed into an armored van for the drive to court. For two hours each way, the man who once supplied 2 percent of the world’s oil crouches in a steel cage measuring 47 by 31 by 20 inches. Convicted of tax evasion and fraud in 2005, Khodorkovsky now faces a fresh set of charges that add up to the supposed theft of $30 billion. In the dark of the van, Khodorkovsky tries to prepare for his trial, replaying in his mind his night reading, the daily stack of documents from his lawyers. But Russia’s most famous prisoner worries too about what would happen if a car slammed into the van. (Collisions are routine in Moscow’s clotted avenues.) “Your chances of making it out alive,” he wrote me one day this summer, “at any speed, are next to none.”

headline: Now Starring | Art in Los Angeles
text: For a city that often gets knocked for being starved for culture, Los Angeles served up an all-you-can-eat buffet this past week. For once the talk was focused on art and not on movies or on who is in rehab. The festivities began with an arty party on Thursday night for “mindthegap,” the inaugural show at Prism, a new three-story gallery on Sunset Boulevard. More stars than there are in paparazzi heaven — Carine! Dasha! Peaches! — showed up to support the owners, PC Valmorbida and Jared Najjar, and the featured artists, Barry McGee and Phil Frost. The following night Miuccia Prada held court at her Beverly Hills store for the publication of her new book, simply titled “Prada,” while the philanthropist’s philanthropist Eli Broad hosted an A-list dinner, which was in turn followed by an after-party at Benedikt and Lauren Taschen’s house. Tired yet? The bleary-eyed emerged the next day to make it to the Jeff Koons private reception and brunch at Gagosian before heading back to their hotels to get their glad rags on for MOCA’s 30th anniversary gala. Over 1,000 guests — everyone from John Baldessari to Brangelina and Gore Vidal — turned out for the black-tie-soiree-as-performance-art, which raised over $4 million for the resurgent museum. The highlight of the evening was “Ballet Russes Italian Style (The Shortest Musical You Will Never See Again),” a five-minute act created by the artist Francesco Vezzoli, starring the evening’s M.C., Michael York, dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet and Lady Gaga, who performed her new song, “Speechless,” on a rotating pink grand piano painted with blue butterflies by Damien Hirst. (Larry Gagosian later snapped up the piano at auction to the tune of $450,000.) As if that weren’t enough, what seemed like half of Los Angeles rallied for an after-party hosted by Pop magazine at Prism. By the end of the weekend, there were enough stories to fill a movie and more than one reveler looked in need of rehab.

headline: A Surprise Gets Buzz for Oscars
