headline: Going to Battle Against Autism
text: Any parent of an autistic child will tell you that their life is forever changed by their child’s condition. A recent study in The Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders quantifies exactly how different that life can be. Researchers from the University of Wisconsin at Madison followed a groups of mothers and their autistic children (adolescents and adults) for eight days. They were interviewed at the end of each day, and saliva samples were taken every four days.

headline: Button at McLaren
text: For me, excuse me, but it was a no brainer. If Jenson Button was offered a drive at McLaren, he had to take it – with the millions of dollars difference to that offered at Brawn or not. Brawn could not pay up what he was asking for? McLaren could? Button’s manager was talking recently about how his decision hinged not so much on money as on some feeling of belonging or being wanted – unless I misunderstood his words. Think of it, though. A driver wins the title after half a decade with the same team, in a fluke year, a year no one could have predicted, a jackpot of a drive for him. Then, with his newfound freedom, he is offered a drive at one of the two greatest teams in the history of the sport. Does he refuse that?

headline: Bush Library Design Chosen
text: Former President George W. Bush has settled on a modern brick-and-limestone design for his future presidential library and museum, complete with its own replica of the Oval Office and a “Texas Rose Garden” mimicking the original at the White House.

headline: A Pop-Art Cavern in Morocco
text: Emma Wilson and Graham Carter, British design partners, bought this 200-year-old four-story riad within the walls of the medina, the historic center of Essaouira.

headline: California Approves TV Efficiency Rules
text: California regulators on Wednesday approved the nation’s first energy efficiency standards for televisions, requiring their electricity consumption to be cut nearly in half by 2013.

headline: The Real Fred Flintstone
text: MARGARETVILLE, N.Y.

headline: A White Cavern in Morocco
text: Essaouira, Morocco

headline: Quiet, Innocent Child, Always on the Watch
text: A compellingly still center lurks within the farcical storm of “My Wonderful Day,” the charming, rueful new comedy written and directed by the indefatigable Alan Ayckbourn, which opened Wednesday night at 59E59 Theaters as part of the Brits Off Broadway festival. Well, not entirely still, since this eye of a hurricane blinks from time to time, and kicks its legs and squirms ever so slightly.

headline: Katie Finneran Will Fill In for Kristin Chenoweth in ‘Love, Loss’
text: The new group of cast members scheduled to start on Wednesday night in “Love, Loss, and What I Wore” will be absent Kristin Chenoweth.

headline: Shubert Reaches a Deal With Two Stage Producers
text: The powerful Shubert Organization, which owns the most theaters on Broadway, has struck a new business deal with two respected theater producers that may lead to greater competition among other producers for the best Broadway houses and spur more entrepreneurial stage ventures.

headline: Real Estate Shopping Is Used as Political Theater on Jerusalem’s Contested Ground
text: JERUSALEM  Dov Hikind, a member of the New York State Assembly, was in this disputed city on Wednesday looking for property to buy. He said he was most excited about a new apartment complex overlooking the Old City called Nof Zion.

headline: Pieces From Robert Isabell’s Collection
text: The floral and event designer’s trove of mid-20th-century furniture and sculpture will be up for auction at Sotheby’s.

headline: Leaving College to Start a Business
text: Our colleagues on the You’re the Boss blog have put up an interesting post about two young entrepreneurs who dropped out of college to start a new business that helps people get into college.

headline: G.O.P. Women Attack Mammogram Guidelines
text: A group of female House Republicans used the upset over new guidelines on breast cancer screening issued by an advisory panel earlier this week to highlight what they view as the dangers of government-administered health care and the Democrats’ bill to revamp the system.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Wednesday, Nov. 18
text: Our show opens with President Obama’s tour of a section of the Great Wall during his visit to China (Slide 1). It was part of a busy day of international dealings for the administration, as Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived in Kabul, Afghanistan, for a stern discussion with President Hamid Karzai about corruption in his country (Slides 3 and 4). In East Jerusalem, family members stood solemn watch over their belongings on the ground where their home once stood (Slides 6 and 7). A couple of stray dogs — one in India, the other in Russia — appear (Slides 9 and 10) in contrasting scenes. And, finally, we return to China, where an American instructor went over the finer points of spreading holiday cheer and portraying Santa Claus (Slide 14).

headline: Now Unloading | Yves Saint Laurent’s Country Estate
text: Yves Saint Laurent’s black-and-white French bulldog, Moujik, was at Christie’s in Paris this week, sniffing around the contents of his late master’s country estate, which are up for auction in a four-day sale that begins today. (Proceeds of the sale are to benefit medical research on H.I.V.) Saint Laurent (who died in June 2008) and his partner in life and business, Pierre Bergé, acquired Chateau Gabriel, a grand 19th-century house near Deauville on the Normandy coast, in 1983, and hired the interior designer Jacques Grange to recreate within its walls the hothouse atmosphere of a belle époque mansion.

headline: Opening Arms and Ears to Cuban Music
text: The Cuban band Septeto Nacional de Ignacio Piñeiro can legitimately claim to be inventors of salsa. But it last played in the United States when Franklin D. Roosevelt was president, and there was no telling when it might be able to return  until the very slightest hint of a thaw in cultural relations between the United States and Cuba quietly brought the band to New York early this month.

headline: Guilty Plea in Multimillion-Dollar Wine Arson
text: A wine entrepreneur accused of setting fire in 2005 to a wine storage facility in Vallejo, Calif., has pleaded guilty to arson  in a federal courthouse in Sacramento.

headline: UPDATED: Price Tag for the Senate Bill Is $848 Billion
text: Update | 12:38 a.m.  The official cost estimate is out, and the price tag is actually $848 billion with a reduction in future federal deficits of $130 billion.

headline: Player Ratings: Denmark 3, U.S. 1
text: The United States saved its worst game for its last game of 2009.

headline: Two Films, Two Routes From Poverty
text: AN African-American teenager, overweight and undereducated, a survivor of poverty and abuse, is rescued by the benevolent intervention of strangers. That, in a nutshell, is the plot of “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire,” which has attracted fervent praise, as well as some controversy, since its debut in limited release two weeks ago.

headline: Marvin Lewis on Larry Johnson
text: After a brief news conference on Tuesday to announce the signing of running back Larry Johnson, Cincinnati Coach Marvin Lewis spoke by phone with me about the controversial decision to make Johnson a Bengal after he was released by Kansas City, the subject of my column today. Lewis’s comments reinforce the complexities of coaching in the N.F.L., which demands that coaches win but also requires them to be psychologists, counselors, father figures and enforcers. Here is more from the interview with Lewis.

headline: K. Thomas Elghanayan
text: Q. Are you O.K. with the way the assets were divided up?

headline: Building Around the Rock
text: Photos of the builder and real estate developer John Carson’s Catskills home as it was constructed.

headline: Ryan Hasn’t Changed: He Still Believes in the Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  As Coach Rex Ryan stepped behind the lectern for his Wednesday news conference, he placed a box of tissues next to the microphone.

headline: Only Palin’s Stylist Knows for Sure
text: THE most elusive fashion stylist in America was nervous. Sitting on a reporter’s sofa, dressed in yoga pants and a hoodie, she tucked her slender legs underneath her, averted her eyes and explained why she had decided to out herself after avoiding the spotlight for so long.

headline: Library Leader in Era of Change to Step Down
text: After 16 years at the helm of one of the world’s largest library systems, Paul LeClerc announced on Wednesday that he would step down as president of the New York Public Library in the summer of 2011 to give the institution plenty of time to search for a replacement.

headline: Revealed: The Senate Bill
text: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, put forward his version of sweeping health care legislation on Wednesday, promising that it would reduce the federal budget deficit while covering most of the uninsured and adding new benefits to Medicare.

headline: Aptera’s High-Flying Plans Are Temporarily Grounded
text: The money is nearly gone, and the same can be said of the co-founders, at the fledgling electric-vehicle manufacturer Aptera.

headline: Money, Gender and Job Satisfaction
text: Sure, the typical woman earns less than the typical man, even when controlling for factors like career choice, education and experience.

headline: In Ukraine, ’04 Euphoria Has Turned to Despair
text: LVIV, Ukraine  It is not immediately clear why Vasily V. Humenyuk should be a candidate for president of Ukraine. A former customs official from the western city of Ivano-Frankivsk, he subscribes to no particular ideology, has the flimsiest of platforms and does not plan to tour the country before the vote, reasoning that “these trips cost a great deal and the people are sick of them.”

headline: Senate Says Health Plan Will Cover Another 31 Million
text: WASHINGTON  Democratic leaders in the Senate on Wednesday unveiled their proposal for overhauling the health care system, outlining legislation that they said would cover most of the uninsured while reducing the federal budget deficit.

headline: Water Feud in the White Mountains
text: ACHIN, Afghanistan — I had just bedded down for the night in this remote village near the Pakistani frontier when one of the American noncommissioned officers I’d been traveling with walked into my hut and told me to put my flak jacket on.

headline: Design for New Berkeley Art Museum Abandoned
text: The University of California, Berkeley, has decided to scrap its ambitious designs for a new Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, saying that it has been unable to raise enough money to pay for them, The San Francisco Chronicle reported.

headline: BlogTalk: Parsing Palin
text: Even her detractors concede that Sarah Palin will sell a lot of books. But what the book and her publicity tour will do for Ms. Palin’s political future, and the future of the Republican Party or the future of the conservative movement, are subjects that bloggers of all political persuasions keep on debating even as party leaders also try to capitalize on all the publicity.

headline: City Council Influences Landmarks Decision
text: Last week the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted 6 to 3 to give landmark protection to the 100-year-old B. F. Goodrich tire company building on Broadway just north of 57th Street, but not to a connected building around the corner designed by the same architect at the same time. Some commission members on both sides of that unusual divided vote cried foul, complaining that politics played an inappropriate role.

headline: Exulting in the Orneriness of a Composer’s Composer
text: The ingenious, curmudgeonly American composer Ralph Shapey, who died at 81 in 2002, wrote flinty works of uncompromising complexity. He expected listeners to bring their brains as well as their humanity to the concert hall, as he often said.

headline: Prizewinners Arrive, Displaying Their Energy
text: The Afiara String Quartet, a Canadian ensemble, won both the Concert Artist Guild International Competition and the Munich ARD International Competition in 2008 and became the graduate resident quartet at the Juilliard School this season. It clearly has something going for it. But at its concert at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening, it was not entirely clear what that something was.

headline: France Dashes Ireland’s World Cup Dream
text: Update | 6:00 p.m. France is through to the World Cup in South Africa after William Gallas’s controversial goal in extra time helped Les Bleus dash the hopes of a stalwart Ireland side.

headline: Dell Is Ready to Jump Into the Smartphone Market
text: Confirming longstanding rumors, the PC maker Dell has officially announced its entry into the smartphone market. The company announced last week that it would begin selling its first handset — the Mini 3 — in China through China Mobile by late November. It will go on sale in Brazil through the wireless carrier Claro (part of the América Móvil network) by year’s end.

headline: Casio Gets Tough With a Rugged Camera
text: Casio believes even tough guys can look really good, and it has built a rugged camera to prove it. The company’s first ruggedized point-and-shoot camera, the Casio Exilim G EX-G1, is a lean model that’s heavy on tough features.

headline: Week 11 in Fantasy Football Matchups
text: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 11. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below. Also, scroll down for reading tips from the Fantasy Football Librarian.

headline: Where Punchlines Pay the Rent
text: CAROLITA JOHNSON, 44, an illustrator, model and New Yorker cartoonist, has lived in some appalling places in her lifetime.

headline: In Marfa, Texas, Minimalist Art and Maximum Flavor
text: “The big empty” is how my seatmate describes the landscape as our plane makes its descent to El Paso. To me it is the opposite: this is a place I’ve visited and lived in for the last 13 years, and it is a land filled with memories, adventure and possibility.

headline: Building an Online Bulwark to Fend Off Identity Fraud
text: A clotheshorse racked up thousands of dollars in mystery charges on a friend’s credit card. Phantoms emptied your uncle’s bank account. Someone took out a car loan in your colleague’s name and stuck her with the bill.

headline: 2007 Memo Raised Concerns About Hasan
text: As my colleague Elisabeth Bumiller reported from Washington on Tuesday, it seems likely that the number of suicides by American soldiers will increase again this year. At the Pentagon, Gen. Peter Chiarelli, the Army vice chief of staff, said that as of Nov. 16, the Army had reported 140 suicides of active duty soldiers this year, the same number as in all of 2008. If that forecast proves accurate, this will be the fifth year in a row that suicides will have increased in the Army.

headline: Sharing History and a Stage
text: True artists tend to follow their own internal systems. But there is something to be said about being of the same generation, which often prompts a certain kinship of values and ideas.

headline: A Convergence, Somewhat Harmonic
text: ART and design collided, albeit gently, at the Park Avenue Armory on Nov. 12. Vladimir Kagan tables, Halston evening gowns, Chanel bracelets from the 1980s and some paintings by artists whose names you couldn’t quite catch all clamored for attention that evening at the “Modernism + Art20” show’s opening party.

headline: Answers About Divorce and Money
text: This week, Lili A. Vasileff is answering selected questions from Bucks readers about divorce and money. Ms. Vasileff is a certified divorce financial analyst and president of the Association of Divorce Financial Planners, and she and works out of an office in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Using Tapes and a Timeline to Trace the Mumbai Massacre
text: “The first 360-degree view of terrorism”  that’s the promise the writer Fareed Zakaria makes at the beginning of “Terror in Mumbai,” a new HBO documentary about the attacks in that Indian city last November that left more than 170 people dead. In addition to the usual eyewitness interviews and surveillance videos, the film, which Mr. Zakaria narrates, makes use of hours of intercepted telephone conversations between the 10 gunmen and their controllers in Pakistan. “This time you are with the terrorists,” Mr. Zakaria intones.

headline: Adding a Fee to the Shazam App Invites a Look at Competing Tools
text: Been to the iTunes App Store lately?

headline: Post-Punk Returnees, Definitely Not Unplugged
text: Can we put to rest this Talmudic thing about band reunions? In the right circumstances, with the right people, they can be very, very good. Does it matter whether the band makes more records, whether it is still a going concern, whether it is part of contemporary culture? Is it desecrating a legacy, blah blah blah? Stop. A band walks on stage, does its thing well or badly or somewhere in the middle, and goes home. Forget the aura: that’s your problem. Legit is as legit does.

headline: A Table That Stands on Its Own 2 Legs
text: Marsia Holzer’s new side table was made in what she calls “the George Nakashima style”  without a handle on the drawer. The drawer front extends three-quarters of an inch beyond the table on either side, so it doesn’t need one.

headline: Bulbs for Any and All Occasions
text: Any gardener who couldn’t put down Anna Pavord’s “The Tulip,” published by Bloomsbury in 1999, will probably devour “Bulb” (Mitchell Beazley; $39.99), which came out this month, just in time for planting some rare beauty before the ground freezes (or ordering summer-flowering bulbs for spring). The book includes 600 of her favorite bulbs, enough for a lifetime, writes Ms. Pavord, who gardens in Dorset, England. The gorgeous photographs are by Andrew Lawson.

headline: Duck! It’s the Holidays.
text: THE weather grows cold, the holidays are bearing down upon us and soon we will find ourselves in that seething caldron of unmannerly behavior: the family holiday gathering.

headline: Talking the Talk in the Cash Room
text: On the 21st day (of October) President Obama said, “Let there be a conference.” And so there was. This morning, small-business owners, their representatives, their lenders, and their lenders’ representatives — some 70 people in all — gathered in the gilded and marble-clad Cash Room of the United States Treasury. The venue was appropriate, since, after all, the whole point of the exercise was to figure out how to get more capital in the hands of small business.

headline: Marcel Wanders on Marcel Wanders
text: “Marcel Wanders: Daydreams,” a multimedia exhibition of works by the Dutch design star, opens at the Philadelphia Museum of Art on Sunday. The show, which includes personal objects, prototypes and various products Mr. Wanders created over the last 20 years (including the Soapstars bathtub, right), was curated and designed by none other than Mr. Wanders, who will receive an award from the exhibition’s sponsors at an event on Saturday night.

headline: For Dogs With Good Taste
text: The Inu House bowl ($95), left, hand-thrown ceramic dinnerware for dogs, is from a line of stylish pet accessories made by Mungo & Maud, a London company. Other items for modern cats and dogs offered by the company include beds (Igloo, in quilted cotton, is $250) and leashes (the leather Argyle is $150). Available at Bergdorf Goodman, 754 Fifth Avenue (58th Street), (800) 558-1855, or from mungoandmaud.com.

headline: Schumer Gives Support to Pool Party Concerts
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, has thrown his support behind an effort to keep the Pool Parties summer concert series at its latest home on the Brooklyn waterfront. Jelly, the group that began putting on the free shows at McCarren Park Pool in Williamsburg in 2006 and moved to the East River State Park in Williamsburg this year, wants to stay at the park but announced on Wednesday that state parks officials said it might not be able to return next year. Senator Schumer, who attended two Pool Party concerts this year, said he would work with state authorities to allow the concerts to stay. “When I heard that the concerts might be canceled, I couldn’t understand why, given that this is exactly what our parks are supposed to be for, and I am going to do everything I can to see that they continue,” he said. Not everything went perfectly smoothly at the Pool Parties this year. For a show in August featuring Girl Talk, an extension to the stage collapsed.

headline: Even With Locklear, ‘Melrose’ Lacks Bloom
text: The return of Heather Locklear, below, to “Melrose Place” did little to improve that CW drama’s ratings. A meager 1.5 million viewers tuned in to the show on Tuesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates, though that was its largest audience in six weeks. On CBS 20.2 million viewers watched “NCIS” and the network easily won the night. ABC was runner-up with its science-fiction drama “V” (9.3 million), “The Forgotten” (7.7 million) and an hourlong “Dancing With the Stars” episode (15.9 million). NBC’s lineup was led by a 90-minute edition of “The Biggest Loser” (9.5 million), helping “The Jay Leno Show” (6.1 million), which earned its largest audience in three weeks. Fox was fourth.

headline: From Sharp Edges to Soft Pillows
text: Broadway Panhandler will have a sale on cutlery and cookware from Nov. 18 to 22, and will offer knife sharpening to benefit City Harvest on Nov. 21 and 22 (three knives for $12); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434.

headline: Sarah Palin Generates High Ratings for ‘Oprah’
text: Giving support to people who have suggested that she become a television talk-show host, Sarah Palin delivered the highest audience in two years to “The Oprah Winfrey Show” on Monday. The hourlong interview with Ms. Palin  her first to promote her memoir, “Going Rogue”  was seen by 8.7 percent of households, according to Nielsen. Reflecting the curiosity about Ms. Palin, the former Alaska governor and Republican vice-presidential candidate, CBS Television Distribution said it was Ms. Winfrey’s highest-rated episode since the Osmond family came on her show in November 2007.

headline: Nicolas Cage Sued by Former Money Manager
text: For the “Bad Lieutenant” star Nicolas Cage, right, the week just got a little worse. The Associated Press reported that Mr. Cage, whose spending habits have been widely discussed since he filed suit against his former business manager, was being countersued by that manager. In October Mr. Cage sued Samuel J. Levin for fraud, accusing Mr. Levin of leading him “down a path toward financial ruin.” In the countersuit filed on Nov. 12, The A.P. reported, Mr. Levin said he had told Mr. Cage that he would need to earn $30 million a year to maintain his lifestyle, and that he warned the actor not to buy castles in England and Bavaria. (Mr. Cage did not heed the advice.) Mr. Levin also said that he devised a fund-raising plan that included the sale of classic cars and a $1.6 million comic book collection. A lawyer for Mr. Cage said Mr. Levin had breached Mr. Cage’s privacy by releasing details about his asset sales.

headline: Design Is Revealed for Bush Center
text: The design for the George W. Bush Presidential Center at Southern Methodist University, created by Robert A. M. Stern Architects, was officially unveiled in a ceremony Wednesday, The Dallas Morning News reported. In an interview Laura Bush told The Morning News that a year was spent discussing and planning the design for a 225,000-square-foot building that will be home to Mr. Bush’s presidential papers, as well as a museum and a policy institute. “We did not want this to be monumental like some other libraries are,” Mrs. Bush said. “We’re very aware that the presidents are men. They are people. We wanted it to be human in scale.” Mr. Stern said the building, which is scheduled to have its groundbreaking next year, was not designed to reflect on Mr. Bush personally. “It’s not a portrait or a defense of his policies,” Mr. Stern told The Morning News. “It is about the presidency, the dignity of the office.”

headline: In New World of Military Spending, Small Is Beautiful
text: AT one time, it may have been true that “an army marches on its stomach.” But with food supplies generally not a problem for modern armies, the proverb should probably be updated to something like this: an army marches on its laptops and the information flowing through them.

headline: Bon Jovi Album Is No. 1
text: Bon Jovi has scored its second No. 1 album in a row  and the fourth of its career  with “The Circle” (Island), which sold 163,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Carrie Underwood’s “Play On” (19/Arista Nashville), last week’s top seller, fell to No. 3 with 128,000 sales, a 60 percent drop, and Andrea Bocelli’s “My Christmas” (Sugar/Decca) climbed one spot to No. 2 with 136,000. The soundtrack to Michael Jackson’s “This Is It” (Epic) fell two spots to No. 4 with 117,000 sales, and Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) was No. 5 with 91,000 sales. Besides “The Circle,” the only other new album on the Top 10 this week was “Memento Mori” (A&M/Octone) by the young Texas metal band Flyleaf, which bowed at No. 8 with 56,000.

headline: At Library, a New View of Velvet Underground
text: Have a burning question you’ve wanted to pose to the Velvet Underground since that down-and-out New York art-rock band broke up in the 1970s? Want to know who’s coughing on the recording of “Who Loves the Sun” or when we’ll see an official CD release for “Squeeze”? You may finally have a chance to get the answers. On Dec. 8 three members of the Velvet Underground will appear at the New York Public Library to discuss the group’s music and history as part of the library’s “Live From the NYPL” series, Billboard reported. The musicians Maureen Tucker, Doug Yule and, of course, Lou Reed, above, are scheduled to appear. The Velvet Underground singer-guitarist Sterling Morrison died in 1995, and the band’s co-founder John Cale left in 1968, though he reunited with Mr. Reed for a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony in 1996.

headline: ‘Precious’ to Receive Kramer Award
text: “Precious: Based on the Novel ‘Push’ by Sapphire,” starring Gabourey Sidibe, above, took a step in the march toward Oscar recognition, as the Producers Guild of America has chosen to honor it with the group’s Stanley Kramer Award. Established in 2002, the Kramer award is given to a movie, program, studio, executive or entity that tackles provocative social issues in a constructive way. “Precious,” about a young woman’s struggles to succeed despite her troubled and impoverished family, fills the bill, and will join past recipients like “Milk” and “Good Night, and Good Luck,” both of which were nominated for best picture Oscars.

headline: The 18 Million Revisited
text: First, a correction. The concluding point in my earlier post is wrong: The House health care bill would not, in fact, effectively tax all 18 million of the remaining uninsured to pay for coverage for the other 36 million, because some percentage of that 18 million – in the draft of the Senate bill, it’s anyone who couldn’t find a health care plan costing less than 8 percent of income; in the House bill it’s still unspecified – would be eligible for a “hardship waiver” exempting them from paying the fine if they can’t afford coverage. And this exemption makes the House bill a better deal for the uninsured than I suggested.

headline: From a District 24 Qualifier, an Example of Pair Tactics
text: Bridge is played in two basic formats. There are the times when you worry only about making or breaking a contract; the overtricks are small fry. This is the case in rubber bridge, Chicago or team events. (Also, you bid game with the flimsiest of excuses. The higher your score on a deal, the better.)

headline: At Auction, the Secret Cache of an Icon
text: JAMES ZEMAITIS, the director of Sotheby’s 20th-century design department in New York, had been intrigued for years by the floral designer Robert Isabell and his adventurous auction purchases. But when he finally visited the West Village town house that belonged to Mr. Isabell in July, a few days after the designer’s death at 57 from natural causes, he said, he “was simply blown away.”

headline: A Camera That’s Svelte but Ready for Roughhousing
text: Casio’s first rugged point-and-shoot camera, the Casio Exilim G EX-G1, is a lean model that’s strong on tough features.

headline: Dell Is Ready to Jump Into the Smartphone Market
text: Confirming longstanding rumors, the PC maker Dell has officially announced its entry into the smartphone market. The company announced last week that it would begin selling its first handset  the Mini 3  in China through China Mobile by late November. It will go on sale in Brazil through the wireless carrier Claro (part of the América Móvil network) by year’s end.

headline: App of the Week: RoadMate Is Easy to Use, but Costly
text: Magellan’s new RoadMate iPhone app ($100, but on sale for $80) is one of the easiest navigation apps available, and it has the sort of graphics that you usually see on a dash-top GPS unit. Problem is, it costs as much as one.

headline: Skype via Videophone Rather Than PC
text: Asus is pitching its new videophone, the Asus Videophone Touch AiGuru SV1T, as a way to make free audio and video calls over Skype, no PC required. But there’s a gotcha: While a PC isn’t necessary, a broadband Internet connection and preferably a wireless network are.

headline: Former Nickelodeon Chief Has iPhone Plans
text: From Media Decoder:

headline: Conserving Power On a Netbook
text: Conserving Power

headline: No ‘System,’ but Music Housewide
text: “Multiroom sound system? There’s an app for that.”

headline: Fifteen Documentaries Eligible for Oscar Nod
text: Fifteen feature-length documentaries, the so-called short list, have qualified as possible Oscar nominees from a field of 89 films that were eligible for consideration. The list, announced Wednesday by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, includes:

headline: European Ombudsman Criticizes Inquiry Into Intel
text: The European Union’s ombudsman on Wednesday criticized the antitrust inquiry that led to a 1.06 billion euro ($1.45 billion) fine against Intel, saying investigators failed to note statements that might have been relevant to the chip maker’s case.

headline: The Queasy Side of Theodore Roosevelt’s Diplomatic Voyage
text: James Bradley’s incendiary new book about Theodore Roosevelt is not really packed with secrets. Much of the material it discusses has long been hidden in plain sight. But Roosevelt biographers often subscribe to certain orthodoxies, and one of them is this: When Roosevelt made noxiously racist and ethnocentric remarks about Anglo-Saxon greatness, so what? He was just voicing the tenets of his time.

headline: Wells Fargo to Repurchase $1.4 Billion of Securities
text: Wells Fargo & Company said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy back $1.4 billion in auction-rate securities it sold to investors before the market for those securities dried up last year.

headline: 2007 Memo Raised Concerns About Hasan
text: Robert Mackey has an interesting post on our sister blog, The Lede, about reports that Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist who has been charged over the deaths of 13 people at Fort Hood, had received an evaluation that might have prevented him from finding work in his field outside the military.

headline: A Taxing Time for Treasury Nominee
text: It’s one thing to carefully vet people being nominated to a top post at the Treasury, especially to make sure they’ve properly paid their taxes.

headline: Is the Spirit of Competition in the Soul of Yoga?
text: THE competitors stood nervously on stage, awaiting the judges’ decisions. As each name was called the crowd cheered, and the winner stepped forward to claim a prize, bowing his or her head to accept a medal.

headline: Seeking Wind Energy, Some Consider the Sea
text: LAST June in a fjord in southwestern Norway, a 213-foot-tall wind turbine did something large wind turbines normally don’t do: it headed out to sea.

headline: A Saudi Gamble to See if Seeds of Change Will Grow
text: THUWAL, Saudi Arabia  The $12.5 billion question is this: Can Ben Frevert change Saudi Arabia?

headline: ‘The Imperial Cruise’
text: Chapter 1: One Hundred Years Later

headline: Field of Documentaries for Oscar Consideration Narrows to 15
text: Fifteen feature-length documentaries, the so-called “short list,” have qualified as possible Oscar nominees, from a field of 89 films that were eligible for consideration. The short list, announced Wednesday by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, is chosen by a screening committee from the documentary branch of the academy. The full branch will now vote for the five Oscar nominees from that list. The list includes:

headline: Newly Released Books
text: The tug of family life is the thread running through many of this month’s newly published books. Novelists (and a short-story writer) have given us parents who go too far for their children, those who don’t go far enough and children whose relationships to each other are, well, complicated. It’s enough to make you believe that Philip Larkin was right.

headline: Companies Call Government Incentives the Key to Green
text: IN less than three weeks, world leaders will gather in Copenhagen to begin hammering out an agreement to cut greenhouse gas emissions and combat global warming.

headline: Some Organizers Protest Their Union’s Tactics
text: After six years working in the laundry of a Miami hotel, Julia Rivera was thrilled when her union tapped her to become a full-time union organizer.

headline: Making Renewables Reliable
text: FOLSOM, Calif.

headline: Senate Bill Would Require E. Coli Testing
text: Citing public concern that meat companies and federal regulators are not doing enough to make ground beef safe, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, has introduced legislation that would require companies to test for a deadly E. coli strain.

headline: A Soccer Match in Sudan Includes Soldiers and Guns
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan  The streets emptied at sunset. Twitchy-faced soldiers hit the pavement, literally thousands of them, wearing all stripes of camouflage, blues, greens, grays and browns. They twirled clubs and AK-47s and plastic pipes and ragged old beating sticks. Their giant trucks with four-foot-high wheels blocked the roads. This did not feel like a major sporting event. It felt more like a presidential coup.

headline: Storm Over the Chamber
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Surf’s Up, Waste’s Down
text: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.

headline: A Surplus of Energy That Might Even Last
text: AFTER years of widespread concern over how to refine enough gasoline, how to deliver enough megawatts of electricity and how to keep from drowning in carbon dioxide, the United States suddenly has fuel and energy in surplus, and the country is looking greener.

headline: Europe Haggles Over Filling Two Top Posts
text: BRUSSELS  The European Union has spent eight years trying to modernize its rules and become a bigger global player. But now, facing a vote on Thursday to finally pick a slate of new and more powerful leaders, it is falling back on old-fashioned backroom deal-making that critics say may produce two lackluster choices.

headline: Post-Mortems Reveal Obvious Risk at Banks
text: The coroner’s report left no doubt as to the cause of death: toxic loans.

headline: Slippery Definitions of Green-Collar Jobs
text: In the new, greener economy, some old jobs have simply been rebranded. A home builder who installs solar panels is suddenly green. So is the engineer who worked for the phone company and now installs parts of a smart grid.

headline: The Rooftop Garden Climbs Down a Wall
text: ROCHESTER

headline: Mideast Peace Talks Hang in Balance Over Abbas
text: JERUSALEM  Two weeks after the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, vowed not to run for re-election and hinted that he might resign, the Middle East peace process has sunk into a deep crisis amid urgent efforts to revive it.

headline: Russia: Bloomberg Donates $125 Million to Promote Global Traffic Safety
text: On the eve of a high-level international meeting on road safety in Moscow, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York announced a donation of $125 million to organizations that promote road safety in a group of low- and middle-income countries that represent half of all yearly traffic deaths. The donation, to be paid out over five years, is part of a push to frame traffic deaths as a global public health risk. The countries include Russia, India, Vietnam, China, Brazil and Egypt.

headline: California Imposes Rule for Efficiency on Some TVs
text: Recognizing that giant new flat-panel televisions have become major power guzzlers, California on Wednesday became the first state to impose energy efficiency standards on them.

headline: Japanese Bank Plans $11.2 Billion Share Sale
text: Japan’s largest bank, the Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, said Wednesday that it would press ahead with plans to raise up to $11.2 billion to bolster its financial cushion, despite results that showed a sharp jump in profit in the July-September quarter.

headline: Russia: Lawyer’s Friends Seek Inquiry
text: Colleagues of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a lawyer for the international investment fund Hermitage Capital Management who died this week in a Moscow prison hospital, have called on the authorities to open a criminal investigation. Dmitri Kharitonov, Mr. Magnitsky’s lawyer, told the Ria Novosti news agency Wednesday that his client’s death in a pretrial detention center appeared to result from negligence by prison authorities who, he said, failed to provide needed medical attention. Mr. Magnitsky died of toxic shock and heart failure on Monday.

headline: All Dressed Up for a Big Book Party
text: Putting aside worries about slipping sales, e-books and other would-be attacks on the literary establishment, the publishing industry put on its party face (and gowns) Wednesday night at Cipriani Wall Street, where the National Book Awards were being presented.

headline: To Build a Smart Grid, Start With Smart Meters
text: FOR nearly 30 years, Itron has dominated the American market in what had been a profitable but unglamorous field, automating power, gas and water meters. But with $8 billion in government and private money devoted to modernizing the power grid, meter automation is suddenly a growth industry. Without millions of new smart meters, no smart grid is possible.

headline: New York Regional Yoga Championship
text: Yoga as a competitive sport is on the rise, and an effort is under way to get yoga into the Olympics. Yoga enthusiasts recently competed at the New York Regional Yoga Championship.

headline: Prosthetics Gave Runner Unfair Edge, Report Says
text: Oscar Pistorius, a double-amputee sprinter from South Africa, was cleared to race against able-bodied athletes in the Beijing Olympics a year and a half ago. Now, however, a new study argues that his prosthetic legs may give him an unfair advantage after all.

headline: It Was Some Day in Court for Ampersands
text: Two commercial powerhouses regarded in New York as being the best at what they do came to share more than similar-sounding names on Wednesday. Both were slapped with allegations of wrongdoing.

headline: Clients Fuzzy Over What Bruno Did for Them
text: ALBANY  In the summer of 2005, top officials at a telecommunications company in Illinois exchanged a stream of befuddled and increasingly urgent e-mail messages.

headline: At This Market, Yankees Feeling No Rush to Buy
text: The baseball free-agent market opens Thursday night at midnight, but players will not have real estate agents on call for Friday morning. The market is expected to move slowly, and one reason is a lack of aggressiveness from the Yankees.

headline: Seeking Jolt, Knicks Show an Interest in Iverson
text: INDIANAPOLIS  If Allen Iverson is on his way to New York, he will find a slightly happier locker room awaiting him.

headline: Insurers Unlikely to Alter Policies in the Debate Over Mammograms
text: For years, breast cancer screening clinics have struggled.

headline: Screening Policy Won’t Change, U.S. Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration distanced itself Wednesday from new standards on breast cancer screening that were recommended this week by a federally appointed task force, saying government insurance programs would continue to cover routine mammograms for women starting at age 40.

headline: Reid Proposes a 5% Tax on Cosmetic Surgery
text: Senator Harry Reid’s health care bill included an array of new provisions that are being scrutinized Wednesday night, but one particular tax proposal in particular already has attracted a buzz — a 5 percent levy on elective cosmetic procedures that was quickly dubbed the “botax.”

headline: World Cup Fever for Algeria, in Paris
text: PARIS — Paris caught World Cup fever Wednesday night.

headline: Glenn Remick, Darts Promoter, Dies at 58
text: Glenn Remick, a beer-loving former construction worker who played a leading role in transforming the barroom game of darts into a national sport, with league members competing in large venues (though they could always still toss back a brewski), died on Nov. 2 in St. Louis. He was 58 and lived in Foristell, Mo.

headline: Scioscia and Tracy Are Managers of the Year
text: The Manager of the Year awards were announced Wednesday and, as usual, there were no surprises. The winners were Jim Tracy of the Colorado Rockies and Mike Scioscia of the Los Angeles Angels.

headline: Obama Demands Results From Afghan Reforms
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama sent his top diplomat to Afghanistan on Wednesday to press President Hamid Karzai to deliver “measurable results” on governance and corruption as the White House prepared specific new demands to accompany an American troop buildup.

headline: Rising Prices of Drugs Lead to Call for Inquiry
text: Democrats in Congress asked for two separate investigations of drug industry pricing Wednesday as they continue working on legislation to overhaul the nation’s health care system.

headline: Hand of Henry Sends France to South Africa
text: ST.-DENIS, France  Celebrations rang out around France on Wednesday as the French national team and the team from Algeria, which used to exist under French rule, qualified for next year’s World Cup in dramatic fashion.

headline: Mets Seeking Top Hitter, With Other Holes to Fill
text: The Mets need a new catcher, a starting left fielder, bullpen help and another quality starter and may try to upgrade at first and second base. Their general manager, Omar Minaya, has a busy off-season ahead, but he seems to have identified his priority: With a glut of starters and fewer sluggers available, the Mets appear more likely to make a free-agent splash on offense.

headline: Savoring the Mayoral Victory With a Dinner by the Seine
text: PARIS  Après la victoire, les vacances.

headline: It’s All a Blur to Them
text: “I’VE heard that in Australia, men are wearing tights,” Chuong Pham said. Tights for men, he acknowledged, may be extreme. But Mr. Pham, 28, an engineer in Manhattan, thought nothing of combining stalk-slim jeans with a sweatshirt pinched from his mom and sexily sheared à la “Flashdance.” Raking his fingers through a sheaf of hair that tumbled in waves past his collarbone, Mr. Pham said: “There is a whole transition of men getting into women’s wear. It used to be that the people who did it were just the edgier ones. Now it’s much more common.”

headline: A Bullet Takes a Toll in the Bronx
text: There were five young men in all, waiting on a street corner in the Bronx on Monday  two on bicycles, two with guns, and all with a specific target in mind: a 19-year-old rival who was inside a bodega.

headline: Mixed Reviews on Senate Bill From AARP
text: AARP, the association representing millions of retired Americans, offered a qualified endorsement on Wednesday night of the new health care bill produced by Senate Democratic leaders.

headline: Holder Defends Decision to Use U.S. Court for 9/11 Trial
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Wednesday defended his decision to prosecute five men accused as co-conspirators in the Sept. 11 attacks in federal court in Manhattan, declaring that while he believes “we are at war,” that the venue was the best place to pursue the case against them.

headline: Bomb Suspect Can’t Keep His Military Lawyers
text: A federal judge in Manhattan on Wednesday denied a request by a former Guantánamo detainee to keep two military lawyers who had been representing him now that his case has been transferred to federal court.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Assembly Backs Stricter Oversight for State Authorities
text: ALBANY  The state’s vast, often-impenetrable public authorities will get stricter oversight than ever under a measure that the State Assembly approved on Wednesday.

headline: Gore Vidal: Awardee, Storyteller, Godfather
text: Gore Vidal, the novelist, social critic, and bon vivant, received the award for distinguished contribution to American letters at the National Book Awards on Wednesday night.

headline: New York Burger Stand on Boston’s Seafood Turf?
text: BOSTON  First the reviled Yankees won the World Series; now Shake Shack, the New York burger stand, might stake a claim in one of Boston’s most sacred spaces.

headline: The Lineup
text: Photos from the New York Regional Yoga Championship, where yogis demonstrate seven postures.

headline: On College Football Game Days, Efforts to Deter Binge Drinking
text: MINNEAPOLIS  Shortly before the kickoff of the Minnesota-Illinois college football game at the new TCF Bank Stadium this month, two Minnesota students  one male, one female  slipped into an unmarked entrance about five minutes apart. They dressed appropriately for the unseasonably warm and sunny day, in short-sleeve maroon-and-gold Gophers attire. And they greeted Amy Barsness, a university official, like an old friend.

headline: Key Differences in the Health Care Plans
text: The health care proposals from the House and the Senate are broadly similar but differ on some major issues. Here is a look:

headline: El Paso Neighbor
text: Sometimes the best trick is no trick at all … when you think there is one. That could be said of today’s puzzle, a joint production from five-time crossword tournament champ Tyler Hinman and Jeremy Horwitz, who teaches math and computer science at Santa Clara University.

headline: Luxury Stores Trim Inventory and Discounts
text: All around Saks Fifth Avenue, merchandise is sold out. The $2,520 Marni shearling vest? Gone. The $5,295 Brioni leather bomber jacket? Only one left. The $1,995 over-the-knee Christian Louboutin boots?

headline: Bloggingheads: Terrorist Show Trials?
text: Dayo Olopade, left, of The Root and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate whether accused terrorists can ever receive a fair trial.

headline: What Jayne Anne Phillips Did on Her Summer Vacations
text: Jayne Anne Phillips, a finalist for the National Book Award for fiction, stood in a corner of the pre-ceremony cocktail party, a long black emu-feather boa draped around her neck. “No emu died to make it,” she said. “It’s emu feathers.”

headline: Fine and Inquiry Possible for Blackwater Successor
text: WASHINGTON  The international security company formerly called Blackwater Worldwide is facing large government fines for unlicensed arms shipments to Iraq, as a key Congressional committee is asking for a separate investigation into whether the company bribed Iraqi officials.

headline: A Touch of Luxury: Retro Bulb Atomizers
text: WITH overall fragrance sales down a good 10 percent, Noir, a midpriced perfume, has been a consistent top seller for Victoria’s Secret Beauty.

headline: For Men: Rub in, Say ‘Ahh’
text: MEN care about their skin, and they’re spending money on it. Purchases of premium priced ($70 and above) men’s skin-care face products increased by 8 percent in the first half of 2009 compared with the same period last year, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm. Luxury skin-care companies are taking note.

headline: First Aid for Distressed Nails
text: WE all know about products for aging skin, but what about aging nails?

headline: When a Laser Beats a Scalpel
text: WHEN it comes to treating aging skin around the eyes, laser resurfacing can often trump surgery, according to Dr. Michael McGuire, a Los Angeles plastic surgeon and president of the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. “If the skin is mildly wrinkled and/or pigmented, the laser can be a good option,” he said, adding that he frequently gives laser treatments to patients in their 40s to defer face-lifts.

headline: Writing About Pakistan,  but ‘No Beards, No Bombs’
text: As announcers urged the crowd at the National Book Awards party to take their dinner seats, Daniyal Mueenuddin, the Pakistani-American author of “In Other Rooms, Other Wonders,” hung back to chat briefly about his work and the wonder of being nominated for a prestigious literary award.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about revised guidelines on breast cancer screening misstated a statistic from the United States Preventive Services Task Force, which released the recommendations. The task force concluded that one cancer death was prevented for every 1,339 women aged 50 to 59 who were screened for 10 years  not 50 to 74.

headline: Ruling on Katrina Flooding Favors Homeowners
text: NEW ORLEANS  A federal judge found Wednesday evening that poor maintenance of a major navigation channel by the Army Corps of Engineers led to some of the worst flooding after Hurricane Katrina. The ruling was a major victory for homeowners who suffered damage in the aftermath of the storm.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline on Friday with an article about the tracing of an E. coli outbreak to AFA Foods, a large producer of ground beef, described the company’s testing procedures incorrectly. It tests its finished ground beef, but stopped testing the beef trimmings that are mixed into the beef; it has not “halted testing of ground beef.”

headline: Corrections
text: A map on Saturday with an article about the decriminalization of possession of small amounts of marijuana in Breckenridge, Colo., labeled a neighboring state incorrectly. The state directly south of Colorado is New Mexico, not Texas.

headline: The Senate’s Health Care Calculations
text: CRITICS of the health care reform plan often refer to it derisively as “ObamaCare.” On the policy merits, this is highly questionable: the White House has taken a hands-off approach toward the legislation that recently passed in the House and the version that is being worked out in the Senate. But when it comes to politics, “ObamaCare” could hardly be more apt: lawmakers’ support for or opposition to reform generally has less to do with the views of their constituents and more to do with the issue of presidential popularity.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the new White House counsel, Robert F. Bauer, misstated the relationship between President Richard M. Nixon and his third counsel, Leonard Garment. Mr. Garment had known Nixon for nearly a decade and had been an aide and adviser to him before taking the White House job; it was not the case that he and Nixon were not close.

headline: Deja Vu All Over Again
text: My Thursday column looks back at the arguments against Medicare and, before that, Social Security — and notes that they were the same as the arguments today against universal health care.

headline: Born in U.S., a Radical Cleric Inspires Terror
text: WASHINGTON  In nearly a dozen recent terrorism cases in the United States, Britain and Canada, investigators discovered the suspects had something in common: a devotion to the message of Anwar al-Awlaki, an eloquent Muslim cleric who has turned the Web into a tool for extremist indoctrination.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Task
text: There is no doubt that the prospects for success in Afghanistan are so bleak right now because former President George W. Bush failed for seven long years to invest the necessary troops, resources or attention to the war. But it is now President Obama’s war, and the American people are waiting for him to explain his goals and his strategy.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Monday with an article about support from Illinois politicians for a plan to send terrorism suspects from Guantánamo Bay to a prison in Illinois reversed the identifications of the two politicians shown. Senator Richard J. Durbin was at the left and Gov. Patrick J. Quinn at the right.

headline: Individualism, Identity and Bicycles in Northern California
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.

headline: Altering How We Use and Pay Doctors
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Children of the Recession, the Economy Hits Home
text: To the Editor:

headline: Breast Screening: Making Sense of the New Advice
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Breast Brouhaha
text: Everyone has been trying to come up with a good nickname for the 10 years we’re concluding next month. Terror Era really sounds like too much of a downer. How about the Decade of Medical Backtracking?

headline: The Wrong Side of History
text: Critics storm that health care reform is “a cruel hoax and a delusion.” Ads in 100 newspapers thunder that reform would mean “the beginning of socialized medicine.”

headline: Have Work, Will Travel
text: Whistler, Canada

headline: Corrections
text: The Religion Journal on Saturday, about a church for young people in Queens, misstated the chapter of a biblical passage that was the subject of the first sermon by Din Tolbert, now the church’s youth pastor. The passage, which says that nothing will separate Christians from the love of God, is Romans 8, verses 35-39  not Romans 35. (Romans has only 16 chapters.)

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about “virtual wallets” and other ways to avoid carrying money and credit cards, misstated the billing procedure used by Boku, a start-up company that lets people purchase goods online using their 10-digit cellphone numbers. Boku applies charges to its customers’ cellphone bills, not to their credit cards.

headline: Democrats Ask Republicans ‘Where’s Your Bill?’
text: The 2,074-page Senate health care bill, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, is now up on the Web available for public scrutiny.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about a decline in Champagne sales misstated the relationship between two of the people shown shopping for wine. Brenda Terris, at the left, is single; Ed Weltman is not her husband. (They were shown with Tamara Wick.)

headline: Academic Researchers’ Conflicts of Interest Go Unreported
text: Few universities make required reports to the government about the financial conflicts of their researchers, and even when such conflicts are reported, university administrators rarely require those researchers to eliminate or reduce these conflicts, government investigators found.

headline: Corrections
text: The Basics column on Nov. 10, about recent discoveries from the study of pig cognition, misstated the species of a wild boar. It is Sus scrofa, not Sus scrofus.

headline: High Tech Tries to Lift Veil on 18 ½ Tantalizing Minutes in Watergate
text: Stymied in its digital effort to fill in the mysterious 18 ½-minute gap in the Watergate tapes, the government will apply high technology to the paper trail to try to answer the scandal’s most intriguing question: What did President Richard M. Nixon know, and when did he know it?

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Thursday about foundations that spend down their endowments and then close misstated the percentage of the New York City Anti-Violence Project’s budget that comes from the Paul Rapoport Foundation. It is 1 percent, not “more than one-tenth.” The article also paraphrased incorrectly from comments by Sharon Stapel, the executive director of the Anti-Violence Project, about the project’s possible efforts to attract new donors. She said it might seek to broaden its base of donors, not to serve a broader audience.

headline: Col. Lewis Millett, Who Led ‘Bayonet Hill’ Charge, Dies at 88
text: Col. Lewis L. Millett, an Army veteran of three wars who received the Medal of Honor for leading a rare bayonet charge up a hill in Korea, died Saturday in Loma Linda, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Sept. 30 and The Books of The Times Review on Monday about “Going Rogue,” by Sarah Palin, misstated the role of Lynn Vincent, Ms. Palin’s collaborator on the book, at World, an evangelical magazine. She is a senior writer and former features editor; she is not the editor or the features editor. (The editor of World pointed out the errors in an e-mail message this week.)

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: In Letters Gone Dark, A Message To Ponder
text: The sign, more accurately, should have read “u r hurt.”

headline: Once Wary of the Web, Luxury Brands Embrace It
text: BERLIN

headline: Fire, Possibly Caused by Incense, Kills Man and 2 Children
text: A fast-moving fire that may have been sparked by incense swept through the top floor of a six-story apartment building in Brooklyn on Wednesday, killing a man and his two small children, fire officials said.

headline: Colum McCann, T.J. Stiles Win National Book Awards
text: Colum McCann won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night for “Let the Great World Spin,” a novel featuring a sprawling cast of characters in 1970s New York City whose lives are ineluctably touched by the mysterious tightrope walker who traverses a wire suspended between the twin towers one morning.

headline: New Cases of Flu Drop on College Campuses
text: For the first time since fall began, new cases of flu among college students have started to drop, hinting that this wave of the swine flu pandemic has peaked, the American College Health Association reported. The association does weekly surveys of more than 250 colleges and universities with a total of three million students, and new cases of flu in the week that ended on Friday dropped by 27 percent from the previous week. About 80,000 of the students have had flu symptoms, about 150 have been hospitalized and last week there were two deaths. Only a tiny fraction have had swine flu shots.

headline: Senate Wording Angers Abortion Opponents
text: In seeking to fend off a major revolt by supporters of abortion rights, Democratic leaders in the Senate have infuriated abortion opponents with their new version of health care legislation.

headline: Eugene Cotton, Labor Union Lawyer, Dies at 95
text: Eugene Cotton, a labor lawyer whose negotiating savvy helped improve the wages and conditions of tens of thousands of meatpacking workers, died Nov. 11 at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Obama Demands Afghan Reforms Produce Results
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s top diplomat privately pressed Afghan President Hamid Karzai to deliver “measurable results” on governance and corruption as the White House prepared specific new demands to accompany an American troop buildup.

headline: ‘Sunday Night’ Gives NBC No. 1 Prime-Time Program
text: NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” has achieved what ABC’s “Monday Night Football” never did, even in the 1970s: it is the No. 1 program in prime time. For now. It will almost certainly lose the race after the season ends and Fox’s “American Idol” returns to the air in January.

headline: Colum McCann Wins National Book Award
text: Colum McCann won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night for “Let the Great World Spin,” a novel featuring a sprawling cast of characters in 1970s New York City whose lives are ineluctably touched by the mysterious tightrope walker who traverses a wire suspended between the Twin Towers one morning.

headline: A Tough Job Now, But a Big Upside
text: What’s the best job in financial services? The available chief executive’s seat at the troubled Bank of America may not spring to mind.

headline: Zelaya Has Two Americans Shot in Nicaragua
text: Friday, Nov. 19, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: On Assignment: While Thousands Gather
text: Cloaked in a brown wool shawl and carrying a walking stick, the figure of a man emerges from a dense early-morning fog.

headline: Iran: Doctor’s Death Raises Questions
text: Judicial authorities in Iran plan to investigate the death of a young doctor who had testified before Parliament about prisoner abuses in the aftermath of the disputed presidential election. Reformist Web sites said that Dr. Ramin Pourandarjani, 26, was killed in order to silence him, as he was the only independent witness to be able to corroborate the charges of torture.

headline: Throw a Little Sauce on It
text: “The Cuban band Septeto Nacional de Ignacio Piñeiro can legitimately claim to have invented salsa,” Larry Rohter writes . But though their music has flourished, because of political machinations, they’ve had a hard time reaching our shores: the group last performed in the United States at the Chicago World’s Fair in 1933. Tonight the musicians  fourth-generation descendents of the original line-up, including the sole female member of the Buena Vista Social Club  will play what may be a once-in-a-lifetime gig at SOBs. Don’t miss it, or risk waiting another 76 years.

headline: Gender Neutral
text: Girl? Boy? Boi? Gurl? It no longer matters, at least as long as style is concerned. Androgyny is in, according to Ruth La Ferla. [LINK to Andro in Styles] Outfit your new gender-neutral wardrobe at the Steven Alan sample sale ( at the showroom, 87 Franklin Street, TriBeCa), where you can get striped sweaters, leather jackets, slouchy T-shirts and printed scarves for more than 50 percent off, along with a decent sampling of the people you’d want to attract while wearing them.

headline: Scribe Smackdown
text: Opium Magazine’s Literary Death Match drives another stake into the notion of bookish politesse [LINK to Award in National] tonight at the Bowery Poetry Club. Watch as comedy writers  including Jon Friedman of Jimmy Fallon and “The Rejection Show” and Edith Zimmerman, of these hilarious “Letters to the Editors of Women’s Magazines”  duke it out in the reading arena, which is a lot louder than you might think.

headline: Word of the Day | realm
text: realm • \ˈrelm\ • noun

headline: The Senate’s Sense on Savings
text: A constant source of frustration for Democrats in their efforts to develop sweeping health care legislation this year has been the budget-scoring rules of the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, which issues the official cost analyses of legislation pending before Congress.

headline: For Her, the Long and Winding Road Led to the Street
text: Suzanne Kaplan did not become homeless overnight. It happened gradually, beginning in 1993 with her mother’s death and becoming more or less a permanent condition four years later.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about Yveta Synek Graff, a translator and longtime champion of Czech opera, misstated the nationality of Willard White, who is appearing in the current Czech-language production of Leos Janacek’s “From the House of the Dead” at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. White was born in Jamaica and is a British citizen; he is not American.

headline: Review Finds Fraud in Contracts Awarded in Disabled Veterans’ Program
text: A program intended to help disabled veterans win government business awarded at least $100 million in contracts to firms that were either ineligible or committed fraud to obtain the work, a federal review has found.

headline: Beaky, the Blighted Brooklyn Bird
text: WHO is Beaky? WHO feeds him?

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Wednesday, about the founders’ debates about climate, misstated the status of the United States in the winter of 1783. It was an independent country, not a collection of colonies.

headline: Correction
text: The On Location article last Thursday about the Manhattan decorator Jamie Drake referred incorrectly to a building on West 24th Street where he is temporarily living. It is a condominium, not a rental building, although Mr. Drake is renting his unit.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Thursday about J. Alexander, who trains models to walk the runway, misspelled the given name of one of his students. She is Nadja Auermann, not Nadia.

headline: News Quiz | November 19, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Pathology of a Financial Crisis
text: The coroner’s report left no doubt as to the cause of death: toxic loans.

headline: Suicide Attack Is Pakistani City’s 7th in 2 Weeks
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A suicide blast near the judicial complex here on Thursday killed at least 17 people and wounded more than 30 others, a senior police official said.

headline: Karzai Sworn In for Second Term as President
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Tainted by a flawed election and allegations of festering corruption in his government, President Hamid Karzai was inaugurated Thursday for a second term, promising to remedy the country’s problems and to have the Afghan Army assume full control of security within five years.

headline: Gas Feud Escalates Between Russia and Ukraine
text: KIEV, Ukraine A dispute between Russia and Ukraine over natural gas supplies escalated on Thursday, with an aide to the Russian president calling Ukraine’s warnings of a possible gas crisis “political blackmail.”

headline: IPWireless Raises $15.5 Million
text: IPWireless, a mobile network equipment company, has raised $15.5 million in what marks the firm’s first round of funding since being sold back to its founders in 2008.

headline: BofA Chief: A Tough Job With a Big Upside?
text: What’s the best job in financial services? The available chief executive’s seat at the troubled Bank of America  may not spring to mind.

headline: Dueling Air Alliances in War of Influence for JAL
text: Just after Delta Air Lines and its alliance partners  offered $1 billion in aid to Japan Airlines on Wednesday, aAmerican Airlines quickly said it would top the proposal, as the world’s biggest airlines escalated a war for influence over the ailing Japanese carrier.

headline: Blackstone’s Pinnacle to Buy Birds Eye, Report Says
text: Pinnacle Brands reportedly has Birds Eye Foods in its sights.

headline: Simon Said to Explore Bid for General Growth

headline: To Build a Smart Grid, Start With Smart Meters
text: For nearly 30 years, Itron has dominated the American market in what had been a profitable but unglamorous field, automating power, gas and water meters. But with $8 billion in government and private money devoted to modernizing the power grid, meter automation is suddenly a growth industry, The New York Times’s Roy Furchgott writes. Without millions of new smart meters, no smart grid is possible.

headline: Do P.E. Shops Need to Mull Future as Asset Managers?

headline: Ambac Capital Exceeds Required Minimum

text: General Motors should focus on making money and repaying U.S. Treasury loans before turning to public markets to sell the taxpayer’s stake in the automaker, Ron Bloom, head of the Obama administration’s auto task force, told Reuters.

headline: New York, From the Pages of Look
text: Stanley Kubrick wanted the grit. Still in his teens, the future director photographed New York City’s underbelly in the 1940s and ’50s, shooting boxers and showgirls with stark shadows evocative of the city’s shady side. First as a freelancer and then as a staff photographer for Look magazine, his images were a dark counterpoint to the work of others who depicted New York as a gleaming world capital.

headline: A Dim View of U.S.-China Electric Car Plan
text: Should the United States and China be teaming up on clean urban transportation systems instead of clean cars? After the announcement of a suite of new energy partnerships between China and the United States, I sought feedback on the electric vehicle project from Lee Schipper, an energy and transportation specialist who splits his time between the University of California, Berkeley, and Stanford. He’s quite worried that the program is looking at cars mainly from an energy-efficiency context, instead of how they will shape and affect China’s fast-expanding cities in a larger sense. “Creating a zero-carbon car for China tomorrow won’t solve the much bigger problems of urban congestion, traffic fatalities and the paving over of once-beautiful cities to make room for more cars,” Dr. Schipper said. “The discussions should back up. Energy is only a means to an end. What are the ends, urban access and mobility, or cars for a small minority?”

headline: Feline More Secure?
text: Sight Gag | Ubiquitous recession sales pitch meets the LOLcat meme.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Surging Panthers Humble Sabres
text: Last season the Florida Panthers missed the playoffs because the N.H.L. awards as many points for tying a game and then winning a shootout as it does for winning a game outright. Because the Panthers did not do well in shootouts while Montreal did, it was the Canadiens who made the post-season while the Cats had to watch it on TV in the golf course snack bar.

headline: In the Cash Room, the Obama Administration Is All Ears
text: Lani Hay, daughter of Vietnamese immigrants, retired from the Navy as an intelligence officer, and then with her American Express card and some savings, opened a technology consulting business serving the federal government. By 2007, just four years after it opened its doors, Lanmark Technology had grown to bring in $12 million in annual revenue and employ 100 people.* Then the recession hit. “Along with L.M.T.’s annual revenues dropping, L.M.T.’s line of credit was also dropped, by a bank that bought out the bank that I was working with,” Ms. Hay said Wednesday in a conference in Washington, convened by the Obama administration to address the problems small businesses have had finding capital during the recession. Worse, she said, the bank canceled the credit line just before she was to receive a $500,000 contract from the Defense Department — and she had needed the credit to tide her firm over until the government paid its bills.

headline: What to Watch Thursday: Cameo Dads, Terror in Mumbai

It’s also patriarch night on ABC: Frankie Faison appears as Bailey’s father on “Grey’s Anatomy” (9 p.m.) and Stephen Collins plays Addison’s dad on “Private Practice” (10 p.m.).

headline: Comparing the House and the Senate Health Care Proposals

The proposals are broadly similar but differ on some major issues, like a new government insurance plan, abortion and how to pay for the expansion of coverage. A look at some key differences between the proposals:

text: The White House is still working on the invitation list for President Obama’s recently announced “Forum on Jobs and Economic Growth” on Dec. 3, but it has decided on the six panels that the business owners, experts and plain folks will break into.

text: While the sticker price for attending college continues to climb, the net cost — after taking into account grants and discounts — is actually lower now than five years ago, according to Sandy Baum, a former professor at Skidmore College and an economist at the College Board.

headline: South Africa Says Gender Controversy Is Over
text: On Thursday the South African government tried to end the controversy over the sex of Caster Semenya, the runner who was crowned world champion in August for the women’s 800 meters, by declaring that an agreement had been reached to let her keep her medal and not release the results of gender tests carried out after her victory.

headline: Voters Choose Flannery O’Connor in National Book Award Poll
text: Among the National Book Awards winners named on Wednesday night whose names may elude you, one honoree you’ve almost certainly heard of is Flannery O’Connor. In an online poll conducted by the National Book Foundation, her collection “The Complete Stories” was named the best work to have won the National Book Award for fiction in the contest’s 60-year history. The competition was steep: other finalists in the poll were “The Stories of John Cheever,” William Faulkner’s “Collected Stories,” “The Collected Stories of Eudora Welty,” Ralph Ellison’s “Invisible Man” and Thomas Pynchon’s “Gravity’s Rainbow.” (Then again, the O’Connor book bested some formidable contenders when it won the fiction prize in 1972, including John Updike‘s “Rabbit Redux,” Walker Percy‘s “Love in the Ruins” and E. L. Doctorow‘s “Book of Daniel.”) This year’s National Book Award for fiction was won by Colum McCann’s “Let the Great World Spin.”

headline: The Times to Begin Chicago Edition on Friday
text: The first Chicago edition of The New York Times, with added pages of local and regional news, will be published Friday, The Times announced Thursday, a month after the paper began publishing a similar regional edition in San Francisco.

headline: Weighing the Toll of Contact in Practice
text: This week, an article on NFL.com suggested that a group led by the Hall of Fame coach John Madden, charged with formulating ideas to make the game safer for players, had discussed the idea of suggesting that teams sometimes practice without contact or helmets in an effort to pare down the hard hits players take long before game day.

headline: U.S. Mortgage Delinquencies Reach a Record High
text: The economy and the stock market may be recovering from their swoon, but more homeowners than ever are having trouble making their monthly mortgage payments, according to figures released Thursday.

headline: Popcorn’s Dark Secret
text: Sitting in a dark movie theater with your friends and a tub of buttery popcorn sounds like a perfect way to spend a Saturday night – and it could be, if you are willing to share your popcorn with the entire row of moviegoers around you.

headline: Plan Ahead or Pay the Piper (and the Plumber and …)
text: Everything is happening at once. With winter close at hand, we are rushing to enclose the building — to hang doors, insulate walls and create some heat so the pipes don’t freeze. First, we need the pipes in place. And water to run through them. And R.P.Z. valves to regulate the water. And the D.E.P. to approve the R.P.Z. valves.

headline: City Building Agency May Farm Out Tests
text: Even as it faces a $5 billion budget deficit, service cuts and possible layoffs, the Bloomberg administration is preparing to spend several million dollars to hire a private testing firm to administer construction industry licensing exams that are currently overseen by city employees.

headline: Is This the Most Overpaid Man in Hollywood?
text: Will Ferrell may have had a lucrative season on Broadway in his George W. Bush show, but that comic actor is being called the most overpaid film star in a Forbes.com study, Reuters reported. In ranking the Top 10 movie stars who cost more than they deliver, Forbes.com looked at actors’ estimated salaries on their films, including DVD and television sales, and compared them to the revenues grossed by those films. According to this methodology, Mr. Ferrell’s films earned an average of $3.29 for every dollar he was paid. (The tally was dragged down by his 2009 release “Land of the Lost,” which cost $100 million to make and grossed $65 million worldwide.) The Forbes list of overpaid stars was rounded out by Ewan McGregor, Billy Bob Thornton, Eddie Murphy, Ice Cube, Tom Cruise, Drew Barrymore, Leonardo DiCaprio, Samuel L. Jackson and Jim Carrey.

headline: Madison Ave. Sees the Writing on the Wall

We’re going to have drinks, we’re going to have appetizers, and then we’re going to roast a moose and split it up between us. I got the recipe out of the new Sarah Palin book.

text: Take a break from your daily grind to browse our coffee-themed holiday gift guide assembled by Jill Santopietro. That ought to perk you up.

headline: Jeanne-Claude, Artist Who, With Christo, Wrapped Objects Large and Small, Is Dead at 74
text: Update | 12:59 p.m. Jeanne-Claude, who collaborated with her husband, Christo, on dozens of environmental arts projects, notably the wrapping of the Pont Neuf in Paris and the Reichstag in Berlin, and the installation of 7,503 vinyl gates with saffron-colored nylon panels in Central Park, died on Wednesday in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 74.

headline: Travel Deals: Luxury for Less
text: Heads up luxury bargain hunters: the online discount retailer Gilt Groupe has created a series of flash holiday sales that combine upscale hotels and fashion duds from its invitation-only sites Jetsetter, Gilt Man, and Gilt  at 30 to 50 percent off retail prices.

headline: Google to Add Captions, Improving YouTube Videos
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  In the first major step toward making millions of videos on YouTube accessible to deaf and hearing-impaired people, Google unveiled new technologies on Thursday that will automatically bring text captions to many videos on the site.

headline: ‘Fela!’ Broadway? Dance!
text: “MOVE!” Bill T. Jones commanded. “Rhythm, rhythm, rhythm!” He was airborne, being lifted and carried across the stage of the Eugene O’Neill Theater by four dancers, perfecting their timing in a climactic ritual scene. It was hands-on choreography while an actor who would actually be carried, Kevin Mambo, observed from the wings. Mr. Jones, a pre-eminent modern-dance choreographer who won a Tony Award for his work on “Spring Awakening,” was rehearsing his full-scale debut as a Broadway director: “Fela!,” based on the life and music of the Nigerian bandleader and political rebel Fela Anikulapo Kuti.

headline: Add Thierry Henry to List of Sports Villains
text: Move over Bill Belichick, the sporting world has a new lead villain. In the United States at least, he will seem an unlikely one, because beyond being the handsome soccer player in that Gillette ad with Tiger Woods and Roger Federer, Thierry Henry isn’t exactly a household name. But in the tiniest second it took Henry to nudge the soccer ball with his hand toward his foot to set up France’s winning goal in a World Cup qualifier against Ireland, he became globally hated.

headline: No Cheering, No Parade
text: President Hamid Karzai’s inauguration was a well-managed event. The Afghan presidential press handlers in their shiny tailored suits worked frantically to make sure that none of the local and foreign journalists and photographers got anywhere close to the president as he took the new oath of office.

headline: AOL to Cut 2,500 Jobs
text: AOL Inc., the once mighty Internet company, will cut about a third of its workforce, or 2,500 jobs, to cut costs as it prepares to be spun off from its parent company, Time Warner.

headline: What We’re Reading …
