headline: Sexual Harassment Is ‘No. 1 Quality of Life Offense’ on Subways, Police Say
text: Updated, 1:25 p.m. | The peak times in which women report sexual harassment or assaults on the subways are the late morning rush, roughly 8 to 10 a.m., followed by the early afternoon rush, 4 to 6 p.m.

headline: News of Hockey, 11/19/09: Attorney Says He Has Yet to Advise Fleury on Filing Complaint
text: Despite Theo Fleury’s declaration in New York earlier this week that he will file a complaint against Graham James, the hockey coach who sexually abused him when he was 14, Fleury’s Calgary-based attorney says he has not yet spoken with Fleury and that no complaint has yet been submitted.

headline: Europa League Referee System May Have Caught Henry Hand Ball

A new presiding judge will be be assigned to the case, which is not likely to come to trial for at least six months, or, more likely, a year.

headline: Answers on Community Colleges, Part 4

Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: University Weighs Tighter Limits on Stem Cell Research

headline: Correction

headline: Free Music at Lincoln Center

Target sponsors similar programs elsewhere around the United States.

headline: That Cozy New Cafe? It’s Starbucks
text: Yesterday, Roy Street Coffee & Tea opened in Seattle. It takes its name from its street location at the corner of East Roy Street and Broadway, but read the not-so-fine print and you’ll see the company behind the coffeehouse: it’s a Starbucks.

headline: New York, in the Pages of Look
text: On City Room, Mike Reicher writes about a new exhibition, “Only in New York: Photographs From Look Magazine,” at the Museum of the City of New York. “Based on a book with the same title, it is a compilation of the photojournalism magazine’s images published between 1938 and 1971,” he writes. “Editors and photographers at Look, which had its offices in New York, drew many of their subjects from the city’s streets, stages and back rooms.” Read more on City Room . . .

headline: Quote Unquote | Us, Too
text: —Alber Elbaz, sharing one of his fears at the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Gala. Boo!

headline: Kerry Still Optimistic on Copenhagen
text: President Obama is undecided as to whether to attend the Copenhagen climate meetings.

headline: The Daily Palin Fix
text: Just a few notes of interest on the Sarah Palin book tour that are out there early Thursday, in case you’re following along. Before some of you groan about overexposure caused by too much coverage, the takes below are a little different than stories about speeches or the book itself.

headline: Extensions for ‘Brother/Sister Plays’ and ‘Lady With All the Answers’
text: The Public Theater said on Thursday that it was extending its run of Tarell Alvin McCraney’s “Brother/Sister Plays.” The production will continue through Dec. 20, with all three plays running on Saturdays and Sundays.

headline: Cast Announced for ‘Lie of the Mind’
text: Ethan Hawke has assembled an estimable gathering of downtown denizens and fellow actors to star in a coming revival of “A Lie of the Mind,” the Sam Shepard play that he will be directing for the New Group. The cast of the play, about a man who believes he may have murdered his wife, will feature Josh Hamilton (who starred in Jonathan Marc Sherman’s “Things We Want” for Mr. Hawke), as well as Marin Ireland (Broadway’s “Reasons to Be Pretty”), Deirdre O’Connell (“Circle Mirror Transformation”), Alessandro Nivola, Maggie Siff and Frank Whaley. The production is to begin previews on Jan. 29 with an official opening planned for February, its publicists said in a news release.

headline: Rock on the Block | The Phillips de Pury Music Sale
text: Phillips de Pury is an esteemed auction house dating back to 1796. Its clientele includes Napoleon and Beau Brummell. A different ilk of bidders, however, will be raising their paddles this Saturday as the firm holds its inaugural Music sale.

headline: An Omnivore’s Mom: Corky Pollan’s Turnip and Pear Purée
text: The writer Michael Pollan, whose books “Omnivore’s Dilemma” and “In Defense of Food” have changed the way many of us think about food, has raved about his mother’s “amazing” Thanksgiving cooking. Recently I asked Mr. Pollan’s mother, Corky Pollan, about the role of cooking and healthful eating in her home during Michael’s childhood.

headline: Coming to TripAdvisor: Easier Click-On Hotel Access
text: Finding that hotel you saw on TripAdvisor may soon get a little easier.

headline: Childhood: U.S. Draws Low Marks on Premature Births
text: More than half a million babies, one out of eight, are born prematurely each year in the United States, prompting the March of Dimes to give the nation a D on its premature births report card.

headline: Sustainable Surfing Rides the Waves
text: As I wrote in a New York Times article on Thursday, the $7.2 billion surf business has become the latest industry to ride the green wave. Call it sustainable surfing.

headline: Giuliani Said to Decide Against Run for Governor
text: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided not to run for governor next year after months of considering a candidacy, according to people who have been told of the decision.

headline: College for Convicts? Considering the Value of Education for Prisoners
text: Overview | How does education humanize us? Why offer college educations to convicted felons? What is the value of both punishment and rehabilitation for criminals? In this lesson, students explore an interactive Times feature about higher education for prison inmates and consider these questions through reading, writing, and debate, and then create annotated reading lists for student prisoners.

headline: How Will Religion Evolve?
text: Does religion have a future? Who looks more like an evolutionary dead end: the religious American or the agnostic European? Or will both give way to some sort of compromise — people bound by new institutions that provide the social benefits of religion without belief in a traditional deity?

headline: Toyota Says Safety Report Is Misleading
text: When the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety issued its top safety picks for 2010 on Wednesday, no vehicles from Toyota, Lexus or Scion were on the list.

headline: European Puck: AIK Stockholm Entertains Invitation to Join K.H.L.
text: The board of directors of AIK Hockey Stockholm, one of Sweden’s most prominent clubs but one that is also strapped for cash and long stuck in the second division, has accepted an invitation from the K.H.L. to join the Russian league for the 2010-11 season. But the decision must first be approved by the club’s members — i.e., the dues-paying fans of AIK Stockholm — and by the Swedish Ice Hockey Association.

headline: A $25 App Phone? That’s Crazy Talk.
text: In June, the once-downtrodden mess of a company called Palm shocked the world by thrusting its arm from the grave, holding a gleaming, compact capsule called the Palm Pre. The Pre, of course, is an app phone like the iPhone, in fact designed by many of the same ex-Apple engineers, but with a slide-out keyboard, removable battery, and joyous touch screen software all its own.

headline: A $25 App Phone? That’s Crazy Talk.
text: In June, the once-downtrodden mess of a company called Palm shocked the world by thrusting its arm from the grave, holding a gleaming, compact capsule called the Palm Pre. The Pre, of course, is an app phone like the iPhone, in fact designed by many of the same ex-Apple engineers, but with a slide-out keyboard, removable battery, and joyous touch screen software all its own.

headline: 36 Hours in Rajasthan, India
text: INDIA is modernizing rapidly, sometimes too fast. You have giant malls, but grandmothers afraid to use the escalators. There are villages in the middle of nowhere, with ornate temples soaring into the hot sky. Still, old Rajasthan endures, evoking rulers with giant mustaches, harems of beautiful women in the finest colored silks and some of the most spectacular palaces ever built. They can be found in the state’s three biggest cities: Jodhpur, Jaipur and Udaipur.

headline: Low-Profile Leaders Chosen for Top European Posts
text: BRUSSELS  Leaders of the 27 countries of the European Union on Thursday night chose Herman Van Rompuy, the Belgian prime minister, as the European Union’s first president, and Catherine Ashton of Britain, currently the bloc’s trade commissioner, as its high representative for foreign policy. The vote was unanimous.

headline: Holiday Open House for the Sanfords
text: Call this another family reality show.

headline: Jeanne-Claude, Christo’s Collaborator on Environmental Canvas, Is Dead at 74
text: Jeanne-Claude, who collaborated with her husband, Christo, on dozens of environmental art projects, notably the wrapping of the Pont Neuf in Paris and the Reichstag in Berlin and the installation of 7,503 vinyl gates with saffron-colored nylon panels in Central Park, died Wednesday in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 74.

headline: Pirates Widen Range, Straining Naval Patrols
text: PARIS  Pirate attacks on shipping lanes around the Horn of Africa have shown no sign of relenting, and the nations policing the seas are struggling to find solutions in a mission that seems to be covering a growing area and time frame.

headline: Conyers Derides White House Strategy on Health Care
text: Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan and the second-most senior member of the House, today ripped into President Obama and Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, accusing them of “bowing down” to “nutty right-wing” proposals just to get a health care bill passed.

headline: The Morning Skate: No Olympic Head Shots and a ‘No Goal’ Call in Detroit
text: Sometimes you just need a good laugh…

headline: Asian Governments Indicate They May Take Action to Deter Speculation
text: As a tumultuous year for Asian real estate comes to an end, it seems that regulators are likely to try to cool the market next year — as hard as that might be to believe.

headline: A Lowly Grass Moves Up
text: The headquarters of the John Hardy jewelry house here surprises with carefully crafted, contemporary uses of bamboo: as furniture, structural detail and the basis for an unusual video wall in the reception area.

headline: Happy National Geography Week!
text: Here is our list of fun and useful tools from The Learning Network, The Times and around the Web.

headline: Iraq Sentences Sunni Leader to Death
text: BAGHDAD  A leader of a Sunni Awakening Council was sentenced to death for kidnapping and murder on Thursday, setting off charges that the Shiite-dominated Iraqi government was trying to weaken the Sunni movement, which is credited with much of the reduction of sectarian violence here since 2006.

headline: For Ailing Hospital Sign, Recuperation Is Planned
text: It shined briefly as a strange beacon of commiseration: the hospital sign that declared in large neon lights something that looks a lot like, “I’m hurt.”

headline: Regents Raise College Tuition in California by 32 Percent
text: As the University of California’s Board of Regents met Thursday at U.C.L.A. and approved a plan to raise undergraduate fees  the equivalent of tuition  32 percent next fall, hundreds of students from campuses across the state demonstrated outside, beating drums and chanting slogans against the increase.

headline: Google Says It Doesn’t Want to Be a Utility
text: Ed Lu, the former astronaut and now program manager for advanced products at Google, wants to be clear: Google is not interested in competing with utilities.

headline: Republican Governors Warn on Costs to States
text: LOST PINES, Tex. – There is one group of elected officials who are decidedly unhappy with the health care proposal unveiled by the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada — Republican governors.

headline: Goldman Promotes 272 to Managing Director
text: Goldman Sachs on Thursday named 272 executives who will become managing directors next year, rising to the second-highest ranking within the firm and entitling them to a bigger share of its profits, according to an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook. (Read the text of the memo at the end of this article.)

headline: What the Law Commands
text: The ostensible topic of a recent argument before the Supreme Court was lawyering, but the real subject turned out to be judging. An exchange between Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and one of the lawyers was illuminating.

headline: Now Showing | Marcel Wanders in Philadephia
text: The A/V team at the Philadelphia Museum of Art has been working double-overtime, installing “Marcel Wanders: Daydreams,” a multimedia exhibition that opens on Sunday. The exhibition, a retrospective of sorts of the Dutch design star’s career, is Wanders’s first solo show in the United States. Why Philadelphia? “We asked him,” said Kathy Hiesinger, the museum’s curator of European decorative arts. And to sweeten the deal, the museum’s modern design collaborative, Collab, will present Wanders with its Design Excellence Award on Saturday night.

headline: Pain Relief Through Photography
text: Can looking at the photograph of a loved one make pain go away?

headline: From the Left, Modest Praise for Senate Bill
text: Reaction to the Senate Democrats’ health care bill is starting to trickle in, now that various interest groups have had a little time to digest it. And even among some allies, the reaction is somewhat mixed.

headline: K.S.M.’s Day In Court
text: I’m pretty sure I agree with Chuck Schumer on the subject:

headline: Stimulus Under Scrutiny
text: The government official charged with monitoring the outlay of $787 billion in stimulus funds acknowledged on Thursday that he too found dubious the 640,000 jobs figure touted by the Obama administration as proof the stimulus was working.

headline: Managing a Portfolio With Hedgeable.com
text: Update | 6:20 p.m. Mike Kane, Hedgeable.com’s chief executive, said the company added a free rebalancing tool on Wednesday for investors who prefer to hold their investments for the long term. Investors can now receive email reminders — quarterly, annually, or another period — which will outline how much of each fund or security they need to buy or sell to rebalance back to their their original allocation.

headline: Flat Holiday Hiring as Jobless Rate Holds at 10.3%
text: The usual preholiday hiring by stores did not happen in October as the city’s unemployment rate held at 10.3 percent, its highest level in 16 years, the State Labor Department said on Thursday.

headline: Intiman Theater Announces 2010 Season
text: Kate Whoriskey’s first season as an artistic director of the Intiman Theater in Seattle will include a production of “Ruined,” the Pulitzer Prize-winning Lynn Nottage play that Ms. Whoriskey also directed in New York and Chicago. On Thursday, the Intiman announced that its 2010 season would open with a production of Clifford Odets‘s “Paradise Lost,” directed by Dámaso Rodriguez, which will begin previews on March 19 and open on March 26. The season will also feature “Ruined” (July 2 through Aug. 8) as the first play in a five-year International Cycle and Hawthorne’s “Scarlet Letter” adapted by Naomi Iizuka and directed by Lear deBessonet (Oct. 22 through Dec. 5) as the latest play in its American Cycle. Other productions include Molière’s “A Doctor in Spite of Himself” (Sept. 3-Oct. 10), adapted by Christopher Bayes and Steven Epp, and starring Daniel Breaker, a star of “Shrek the Musical” and “Passing Strange” (as well as Ms. Whoriskey’s husband). Ms. Whoriskey is currently sharing artistic directing duties with Bartlett Sher, who is departing after this season.

headline: Update: Cuts Come to BusinessWeek
text: While Bloomberg appears to be keeping a majority of the BusinessWeek workforce, about 100 of the magazine’s 400 or so employees have been cut.

headline: U.C.’s Fee Increase: Questions and Consequences
text: Today, the Board of Regents for the University of California voted to raise fees for undergraduates by 32 percent.

headline: Sanford Sighting
text: LOST PINES, Texas – This has not been the easiest year for Mark Sanford, the governor of South Carolina. Mr. Sanford found himself entangled in a public tale about an affair. His wife ditched him. He is facing an ethics investigations back home. He has withstood calls to step down at home, instead deciding to wait out the end of his term (he is barred from seeing reelection by term limits). And he arguably has not been particularly good for the Republican brand.

headline: A Reason to Check Your Withholding
text: Call it the case of a little tax credit that ended up a little too big.

headline: Answers About Community Philanthropy, Part 2
text: Following is the second set of answers from Lorie A. Slutsky, president of the New York Community Trust, on community philanthropy, the value of many different approaches to charitable giving, and their importance in maintaining a strong democracy.

headline: Suddenly, Iverson Could Be the Knicks’ Answer
text: Good news, Knicks fans: your team really is alive. It has a pulse and is actually breathing. The hierarchy has just been playing dead.

headline: Trying to Outrun the Snow
text: Each passing day brings the hill country closer to a snow storm. Once it comes, the cabin will no longer be accessible by car or truck. The boots or snowshoes will have to come out.

headline: Mia Feldbaum and Mark McGoldrick
text: MARK McGOLDRICK rocketed through his adolescence in Scottsdale, Ariz., on the highly combustible fuel of alcohol, drugs and trouble, he and his friends making impulsive trips in speeding cars. One ride ended in a car crash, leaving him paralyzed in his senior year in high school. Wiser but no less adventurous, he traveled extensively and graduated cum laude from Harvard Law School.

headline: Opening Wide His (Repaired) Heart
text: IT was nearly midnight in an upscale Atlanta hotel room, and Robin Williams was decompressing after a show at the nearby Fox Theater. Reclining in his dimly lighted suite, he was weary but in good spirits; the mechanical key hidden in his back was winding down, and the flow of free associations and zany voices that relentlessly emanates from him was slowing to a trickle.

headline: Leon Washington on Road to Recovery
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. -– Jets running back Leon Washington has sought small victories during the early stages of rehab for his broken right leg. On Monday, he reached another milestone, taking his first shower in three weeks.

headline: Mangino’s Seat Gets Hotter in Kansas
text: Kansas Coach Mark Mangino’s tenure seems a bit tenuous as the university looks into allegations that he verbally abused players and had physical contact with them, including poking linebacker Arist Wright in the chest during a walk-through practice in October.

headline: Giuliani Is Said to Have Decided Against Run for N.Y. Governor
text: The Times’s Danny Hakim learns that former New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani (and 2008 G.O.P. failed primary presidential contender) has decided not to seek the party’s nomination in the 2010 gubernatorial race, citing people who have learned about his decision.

headline: Lawmakers Call Ft. Hood Shootings ‘Terrorism’
text: WASHINGTON  A Senate committee on Thursday opened the first public hearings into the Fort Hood shootings, with several legislators asserting that the incident in which 13 people were killed was a terrorist attack by a homegrown extremist who may have slipped past law enforcement and military authorities.

headline: Ireland Cites Uzbekistan-Bahrain Decision in Appeal
text: Seeking justice, and a spot in the World Cup in South Africa, the Football Association of Ireland has demanded a replay of the playoff with France, which ended in France’s favor after Thierry Henry handled the ball before passing to William Gallas for the score.

headline: A New Term for Afghanistan's President
text: The Times's Kirk Kraeutler and Jane Bornemeier discuss the issue of corruption within President Hamid Karzai's administration.

headline: Analyst Discounts Chances of Bank Breakup Plan
text: Representative Paul E. Kanjorski’s amendment on government power to pre-emptively break up big banks may have passed a preliminary House committee vote on Wednesday, but Scott Valentin, the banking analyst at FBR Capital Markets, believes that there is little chance that the amendment in its current form will make it into the final bill that will go to President Obama.

headline: Amsterdam’s Seedier Side Lands in London
text: An uninformed visitor entering London’s National Gallery might be a bit confused upon finding a dimly lit street with rubbish scattered about and bicycles on racks. But soon, that visitor becomes a voyeur of sorts: “The Hoerengracht,” an installation by Ed and Nancy Kienholz, on view at the Gallery until Feb. 21, is a life-size reconstruction of a section of Amsterdam’s infamous red-light district, complete with scantily dressed mannequins peering out of nicotine-stained rooms.

headline: Edsel, 50 Years After Its Demise
text: It was 50 years ago Thursday that Ford announced it was ending production of the Edsel. Insert joke here.

headline: Insurance Industry Criticizes Senate Bill
text: The insurance industry lobby is panning the Senate legislation.The lobbying group, America’s Health Insurance Plans, said in a statement on Thursday that the bill would increase costs for individuals, families and employers; reduce benefits for older Americans; and threaten employer coverage.

headline: South African Runner’s Sex-Verification Result Won’t Be Public
text: One of the most public and controversial cases of sex verification in sports has apparently been resolved, at least in part, but the answers to some important questions have not been made public.

headline: Q&A: Hong Kong Highlights for Two 21-Year-Olds
text: Q.

headline: Worth Saving | The Brixton Pound
text: In what is surely one of the more interesting convergences of economics and design in recent memory, the multiethnic, small-business-dominated London neighborhood of Brixton recently started printing its own currency. The idea for the Brixton pound was cooked up by Tim Nichols, who wanted to stimulate local commerce and study how wealth circulates when bank notes are confined to single districts. Transition Town Brixton, a community organization that addresses energy issues and climate change, also pitched in on the project, with the intention of encouraging local consumption and helping shrink carbon footprints.

headline: Fox Apologizes for Second Incorrect Video Use
text: Fox News delivered an on-air apology to viewers Thursday after a second incident within a month when the news network illustrated a story by using video footage that was taken from a different event.

headline: Performa 09: Mike Kelley’s Extracurricular Activity
text: Mike Kelley’s invigorating occasionally hilarious 75-minute performance piece “Extracurricular Activity Projective Reconstruction #32, Plus,” will play twice more (Thursday at 8 and 10 p.m.) at the Judson Church on Washington Square Park South. If you want to see the half-time entertainment at a high school basketball game through a glass darkly, or at least dimly, accompanied by a medley of popular musical styles, avail yourself.

headline: Spots of Tranquillity Amid the Bustle
text: Emerge from the No. 7 train at Main Street in Flushing, and you will land on busy, jam-packed Chinatown streets with lots of colorful signs. You won’t find much English, written or spoken, but you will find an oasis of great food and  odd, given all the bustle  plenty of opportunities to slow down and relax at herbal emporiums, tea shops and a tranquil botanical garden.

headline: Performa 09: Black and White and Read in the Port Authority
text: In dire days for print journalism, it warms the heart to see a new newspaper appear. And one called, somewhat enigmatically, The First/Last Newspaper, began printing in Manhattan earlier this month. It’s offices are a barren looking storefront on the Port Authority Bus Terminal’s Eighth Avenue side, as it happens diagonally across from The New York Times building.

headline: Fidelity 401(k) Accounts Back to September 2008 Levels
text: Fidelity Investments said Thursday that the average balance for its customers’ 401(k) retirement accounts has returned to September 2008 levels.

headline: Readers Confess: I Was an Adult Twi-Hard
text: Earlier on Thursday, we asked ArtsBeat readers if any would dare confess to being late-life “Twilight” converts. Amazingly, some of you admitted that you had been drawn into the romantic entanglements of Bella and Edward, despite your best efforts to resist. And some of you firmly insisted that neither a non-stop media blitz nor an all-out war between vampires and werewolves could get you to change your mind about the “Twilight” books and movies. Here’s a sampling of the comments we received:

headline: Senate Confirms Judge to Appeals Court
text: After a protracted partisan struggle, the Senate voted 59-39 on Thursday to confirm Judge David F. Hamilton to a seat on the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals.

headline: ‘The Sound of Music’ Turns 50
text: Fifty years ago this week, a nun-in-training, seven frisky kids and their grumpy but lovable father do-re-mi’d their way across a Broadway stage.

headline: BigDeal Puts a New Spin on ‘Entertainment Shopping’
text: Update | 7:36 p.m.  Corrected spelling of Nicolas Darveau-Garneau’s name in one instance.

headline: General Growth Reaches Accord With Lenders
text: General Growth Properties, the giant mall operator that filed for bankruptcy in April, said Thursday that it had reached an agreement with its lenders to extend loan maturities on 70 loans and, in turn, those lenders would get all their money back.

headline: Invisible bond vigilantes
text: Back in 1993, James Carville — frustrated over the way fear of rising interest rates was crimping the Clinton agenda — declared,

headline: Study Shows Link Between Segregation and Subprime Loans
text: Researchers at New York University who examined the relationship between subprime lending and race released a report on Thursday that found that the probability that individual borrowers receive risky, high-cost subprime loans increases depending on the racial composition of the neighborhood or metropolitan area where they live.

headline: Let’s Go to the Tape
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cuban Blogger Posts Interview With Obama
text: Cuban blogger Yoani Sánchez.

headline: Alicia Keys Finds Her Own ‘Empire State of Mind’
text: Hey, have you heard that Jay-Z song “Empire State of Mind”? Maybe at Yankee Stadium, if not in every subway station and loud avenue in the entire city? You know, it’s the one where Jay says how great he is, and talks about the rough old neighborhood in Brooklyn. No, not that one. No, not that other one, either. It’s the one with the Alicia Keys chorus, soaring as high as a skyscraper: “These streets will make you feel brand new/Big lights will inspire you/Let’s hear it for New York, New York, New Yooooork!”

headline: A New Look at Overparenting
text: The many of you who nodded in agreement at my essay “The End of Overparenting” back in May will also find affirmation in the Time magazine cover story that reaches newsstands tomorrow. In “Can These Parents Be Saved?” Nancy Gibbs explores the same territory at greater length, concluding:

headline: Stemming Drinking on College Game Days
text: In today’s Sports section, Pat Borzi writes about a new program at the University of Minnesota to prevent binge drinking before football games:

headline: Malcolm Gladwell Responds to Steven Pinker
text: Steven Pinker’s recent review of Malcolm Gladwell’s “What the Dog Saw” prompted a flurry of response in the blogosphere.

headline: A Walk Among Vanished Guideposts
text: IN the middle of fourth grade, the spring of 1960, my mother allowed me to walk home from the Browning School at 62nd Street and Park Avenue to our apartment house at 56th and Sutton Place.

headline: Shrunken Cameras
text: David Pogue reviews two new cameras that have had camera aficionados' palms sweating for months: the Canon PowerShot S90 ($412) and the Panasonic Lumix GF1 ($870).

headline: The Case for a Job-Creation Tax Credit
text: John H. Bishop, a professor at Cornell University’s Industrial and Labor Relations School, was co-author of a recent proposal on temporary job-creation tax credit published by the Economic Policy Institute.

headline: On Our Radar …
text: 1) A dim view of the United States-China electric car plan.

headline: A Permanent Theater Festival on Puget Sound
text: SEATTLE— LIKE a reminder of theater’s past, the face of the playwright August Wilson stares out from a gleaming glass door set in a 12-foot steel portal at the top of August Wilson Way here, a sloping side street behind the Seattle Repertory Theater.

headline: Gauging the Thirst for Advance ‘New Moon’ Tickets
text: How many sold-out screenings are there already for “The Twilight Saga: New Moon”? It’s hard to say: MovieTickets.com and Summit Entertainment, the studio behind the wildly successful franchise, have made the unusual decision to stop releasing information.

headline: Time Is Right for Hedge Funds, Manager Says
text: Despite a tough run for hedge funds last year, at least one manager believes a number of factors have combined to create an attractive environment for hedge fund investing.

headline: A Dinner to Make Even Futurists Happy
text: I was lucky enough to be invited to this wacky dinner back in June, organized for Slate (and now featured in ReadyMade) by the writer Kate Bolick and the artist Karen Azoulay, with the idea of celebrating the 100th anniversary of the Futurist movement. The Futurists had ideas about food (and other things) that smack of Ferran Adria and Grant Achatz, and the two women had the idea not to recreate the actual recipes from the somewhat tongue-in-cheek Futurist Cookbook of 1932 (note very cool image here ), but the spirit of the same.

headline: BlogTalk: Miranda Rights and Health Care
text: Much of the blog discussion today is about the Senate Democrats’ proposal to overhaul the health care system, which was released late yesterday. Coming in at 2,000-plus pages, the document, available here, would be hard for anyone to read in its entirety between now and Thanksgiving. So we’ll lead you to some thoughtful discussions on the blogs about what to look for and how to analyze it in a while.

headline: Patient Voices: Rheumatoid Arthritis
text: Pain, inflammation and severe joint damage - rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic disease that can affect both adults and children. Here, six men and women speak about their experiences.

headline: A New Westin Each Week
text: The hotel industry may be suffering, but you wouldn’t know it by looking at the lineup of new Westin Hotels. Starting today, the upscale chain is planning to open about one hotel a week for the rest of the year.

headline: Large Hadron Collider to Restart
text: The champagne is in the refrigerator.

headline: Attention Shifts to China for Private Equity Industry
text: SHANGHAI  A few weeks ago, Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chairman of the Blackstone Group, the world’s biggest private equity firm, signed a joint venture here with Shanghai’s municipal government, creating the first Blackstone fund denominated entirely in Chinese currency.

headline: iPols
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — When the latest Sarah Palin sugar high wears off, leaving behind a new round of intraparty feuds and a woman with deep Nixonian grievances, Republicans can turn to California for a glimpse at another kind of future.

headline: Western Men Are Doomed
text: David Brooks: Gail, I don’t know if you had a chance to see my column Tuesday, but China always gets me thinking big. I look at the long history and bright future of that civilization-state and suddenly you’ve got to chase me down with a butterfly net to impose the grip of reality on my grandiose and free-floating ideas. It’s runaway Spengler Syndrome.

headline: Hoffman Claims Voter Fraud
text: The Conservative Party candidate who conceded defeat in New York’s 23rd district is taking it all back.

headline: The Guggenheim Grows a Restaurant
text: Details are thin on the ground at the moment, but based on an invitation to a preview that came by e-mail this afternoon it’s apparent that a new restaurant, named The Wright, is going to open in the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, at 1071 Fifth Avenue. Given the name, the location and the fact that they are going to the expense of giving a preview party, I’m going to speculate that this will be something a little more grand than the cafeteria at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. (Although the food there is not bad.)

headline: Introducing Opinionator
text: What is Opinionator?

headline: Spots of Tranquillity Amid the Bustle
text: Emerge from the No. 7 train at Main Street in Flushing, and you will land on busy, jam-packed Chinatown streets with lots of colorful signs. You won’t find much English, written or spoken, but you will find an oasis of great food and — odd, given all the bustle — plenty of opportunities to slow down and relax at herbal emporiums, tea shops and a tranquil botanical garden.

headline: The Pregame Huddle: Coaches Under Fire
text: While Jim Harbaugh has Stanford flying high, other high-profile coaches like Charlie Weis and Rich Rodriguez are taking heat.

headline: Though Dell’s Profit Slips, Its Outlook Turns Brighter
text: Once lauded for its nimble operations and quick decision-making, Dell continues to suffer from a sweeping reorganization that resembles something of an endurance test for investors.

headline: CF Industries and Agrium Trade More Shots
text: The “Forever War” goes on — at least for now.

headline: Sounds During Sleep Aid Memory, Study Finds
text: Science has never given much credence to claims that you can learn Chinese or French by having the instruction CDs play while you sleep. If any learning happens that way, most scientists say, the language lesson is probably waking the sleeper up, not causing nouns and verbs to seep into a sound-asleep mind.

headline: History, Sun-Drenched
text: THERE’S “old Florida”  and then there’s really old Florida. St. Augustine, the oldest permanent European settlement in the continental United States and a city of about 12,500 residents, was settled by the Spanish in 1565.

headline: Crosby Enjoys the Lighter Side of the Olympics
text: Sidney Crosby was all smiles when he carried the Olympic torch in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Wednesday night, which is barely a torch run away from his hometown of Cole Harbour. He wore the official torchbearer’s sweatsuit, ran about 300 yards and lit the torch of the snowboarder Sarah Conrad.

headline: Who You Gonna Call? Thanksgiving 911
text: I’m preheating the oven up here in the Dining kitchen, getting ready for the Thanksgiving holiday, getting ready to man the battle stations for The New York Times Thanksgiving Help Desk. I will be with you through most of the big day itself. Need help with the bird, the stuffing, the sides, the gravy, the wine, how to say grace (whether to say grace!), the timing, the desserts, the fact that you said you’d make butternut squash and now you’re looking at the things and realize you have no idea how to make butternut squash? The New York Times Thanksgiving Help Desk is here to help. Post a question below. I’ll answer it, until 3 p.m next Thursday. Watch for the later postings on Diner’s Journal for my responses.

headline: The Fight Continues, on the Today Show
text: Kim Severson and Julia Moskin will make their cases for which matters more at Thanksgiving, the sides or the turkey, Friday morning at 8:45 on NBC’s Today. The hosts will be their judges. Diner’s Journal hopes to have the video later on Friday.

headline: Cranberry-Orange Relish
text: This sweet and tart relish, affectionately named “pucker-up cranberry relish” by my friends, is much more refreshing than commercial cooked relish and takes about as long to make as it does to open a can. Leftovers are great for breakfast, with plain yogurt. The cranberry-orange combo is very high in vitamin C, much of which is lost in cooked cranberry sauce.

headline: At Ad Council Dinner, Tart Humor From Tina Fey
text: Despite, or perhaps because of, the serious messages of many Advertising Council campaigns — which focus on topics as varied as teen dating violence and hunger in America — the group offered some comic relief at its annual dinner Wednesday night by inviting Tina Fey to host the event, at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

headline: New Data Shed Light on Large-Animal Extinction
text: Whenever modern humans reached a new continent in the expansion from their African homeland 50,000 years ago, whether Australia, Europe or the Americas, all the large fauna quickly disappeared.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thursday, Nov. 19
text: President Obama wrapped up his trip to Asia on Thursday, without reporting any major policy breakthroughs. Among other news throughout the world, a suicide bomber caused death and injuries in Peshawar, Pakistan (Slides 4-5), and Britain braced for severe weather (Slide 7). In the United States, the architect Frank Gehry attended a ceremony at the Beekman Tower in Lower Manhattan (Slide 10), with his building scheduled to be completed in 2011.

headline: Private Equity Shifts Its Attention to China
text: A few weeks ago, Stephen A. Schwarzman, left, the chairman of the Blackstone Group, the world’s biggest private equity firm, came to Shanghai to sign a deal with the municipal government and create the first Blackstone fund denominated entirely in Chinese currency, a $732 million venture fund, The New York Times’s David Barboza reports from Shanghai.

headline: A People-Oriented Piece, Featuring Kierkegaard
text: Wally Cardona refers to “Really Real,” a new work performed on Tuesday night at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, as his people piece. Yet while there are many bodies in it, the idea mainly speaks to what is absent. In recent years Mr. Cardona has relied heavily on props, filling the stage with objects to create an architectural landscape; the dancers often seemed like accessories, and the choreography was dictated by their relationship to the set.

headline: Senate Health Care Bill Faces Crucial First Vote
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate version of sweeping health legislation would cover five million fewer people than a companion bill passed by the House, but it would cost less, in part because Senate Democratic leaders felt they had to win support from fiscally conservative members of their party.

headline: For the Volt, How’s Life After 40 (Miles)?
text: Milford, Mich.

headline: Comeback for Furniture at Carnegie Museum
text: The furniture galleries at the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh used to plod chronologically from medieval chests and Renaissance tapestries to Rococo chairs and early-19th-century clocks. Material was separated by nationality (mostly British, French and American) and set on pedestals in rows. The galleries, closed for a decade and used for storage, reopen on Saturday and now explore design trends that spread globally during the last five centuries, as well as some unsung, innovative furniture produced in Pittsburgh.

headline: An Upstart Art Scene, on Atlanta’s West Side
text: THE warehouses and industrial buildings to the west of Midtown Atlanta have not had the benefit of a concerted attempt by the city at urban revitalization. Instead, the West Side has lately given rise to a sort of ad hoc group of contemporary art galleries that have styled themselves as a more intellectual alternative to the city’s designated downtown art district, Castleberry Hill.

headline: A Place in Time, Not All Frozen
text: Matanuska Glacier, Alaska — THE temperature was soaring to 75 degrees, and I was walking on ice. Around me the Matanuska Glacier, about 100 miles from Anchorage, sparkled and shimmered in the afternoon sun. The only sound was an occasional rush of cool wind sweeping down from the towering Chugach Mountains and the crunch of my crampons as I made my way up a crevasse with a group of six other trekkers.

headline: ‘You Know That Chicken Is Chicken, Right?’
text: When you sit down to eat sushi or grilled sea bass, do you stop and think about Nemo the cartoon fish and his chatty little friends? When you order Chicken McNuggets at McDonald’s, do you picture Chicken Little fretting that the sky might fall? When you gorge yourself on spare ribs with barbecue sauce, do you pause to remember Babe the movie pig or Wilbur from “Charlotte’s Web”?

headline: Challenging the Laws of Physics
text: MONTICELLO, N.Y.

headline: An Intimate Concert, With Original Instruments
text: The American Classical Orchestra, an original-instrument ensemble celebrating its 25th anniversary this season, presented a concert on Wednesday night at the New York Society for Ethical Culture conducted by its founding director, Thomas Crawford. I liked almost everything about the program: the informed, earnest and lively if sometimes scrappy performances; the alluring tonal qualities of the period instruments, especially the mellow strings and the dark reedy woodwinds; the chance to hear a titanic work like Mozart’s “Jupiter” Symphony played in an intimate hall.

headline: A Newly Stylish Amman Asserts Itself
text: “AREN’T you going to check out the terrace?” Madian al-Jazerah said to me.

headline: Hopper Whopper | 400 Shots of the Sixties
text: One night in the mid-1970s, after fighting with his girlfriend, a drug-crazed Dennis Hopper picked up a machine gun and fired a few dozen rounds into the adobe walls of his house in Taos, N.M. We know about this incident because the longtime curator Walter Hopps was in Taos on that night, trying to secure a trove of Hopper’s artwork for a charity auction. (At the time, Hopper was drowning in back taxes, and needed an I.R.S. deduction almost as badly as detox.)

headline: Flashback! The Fastback Is Back
text: ROOFLINES, as important for car designers as necklines and hemlines are for fashion designers, are suddenly changing. The hottest new style did not show up simply on a whim.

headline: Glass Looks to the Heavens, Again
text: Philip Glass clearly enjoys examining ideas from just about every angle, and that applies as fully to opera subjects as to specific musical moves. His earliest operas, for example, were about historical figures who changed the way their societies thought: Einstein, in “Einstein on the Beach”; Gandhi, in “Satyagraha”; and the monotheistic Egyptian pharaoh, Akhnaten, in the opera that bears his name.

headline: Art in Review
text: CARL FREDRIK HILL

headline: Museum’s Gems Go for a Spin
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Abstinence Makes the Heart ... Oh, You Know
text: The big tease turns into the long goodbye in “The Twilight Saga: New Moon,” the juiceless, near bloodless sequel about a teenage girl and the sparkly vampire she, like, totally loves. When last we saw Bella (Kristen Stewart) and her pretty dead guy, Edward (Robert Pattinson), in “Twilight”  the series hadn’t been saga-fied yet  the two had pledged their troth, a chaste commitment solidified during moody walks in the woods, some exhilarating treetop scrambling and a knockdown fight with a pack of vamping vampires.

headline: Brees to Obama, Touchdown
text: Here’s something that doesn’t happen very often to Troy Polamalu: he got beaten for a touchdown. By the president of the United States.

headline: A Bit of Jive Stands Out at a Tribute to Mercer
text: Because it described Army life during World War II in bebop slang, Johnny Mercer’s “G.I. Jive,” one of the few songs for which he wrote both words and music, usually isn’t regarded as one of his great perennials, although it was a No. 1 hit for Louis Jordan and his Tympany Five in 1944.

headline: I Ordered the Ants!
text: While finishing a meal at a French restaurant that we frequent, I spotted a three-inch water bug making its way down a wall, inches from my 14-year-old daughter’s head. Happily, the bug ducked into a crevice.

headline: Now Serving | When in Maialino … (Recipe Included)
text: At Maialino in the Gramercy Park Hotel, Danny Meyer, the C.E.O. of the Union Square Hospitality Group, rather bashfully explained that opening a restaurant is a lot like having a child: the conceiving is fun, but the pregnancy and birth aren’t easy. The first couple of weeks after the baby is born, when you’re not sleeping through the night, you think, What the heck did I do? But in time, it becomes so gratifying that you actually consider doing it all over again. Meyer would know; he has opened 14 dining establishments and has four children.

headline: Saints at a Cultural Crossroads
text: At monasteries on Mount Athos in northern Greece, you wake in the night to the sound of Greek Orthodox monks chanting Byzantine prayers. It’s an unforgettable sound, distant and unearthly, but also inside you, like a buzz in the blood.

headline: Edible Walls of Green
text: Innovative planters enable efficient growth of vegetation on vertical surfaces.

headline: Shelby Opposes Dodd’s Financial Regulatory Bill
text: Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, the ranking Republican on the Senate Banking Committee, said Thursday that he would vote against the financial regulatory bill proposed last week by Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat who is the committee’s chairman, setting the stage for what could be a contentious and drawn-out set of negotiations.

headline: ‘Twilight’ by the Numbers
text: Total number of books by Stephenie Meyer sold worldwide: over 70 million

headline: Oreo, Abused Then Euthanized, Inspires Legislation
text: In the final hours before Oreo was put to death, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals was inundated with pleas to spare her life. Oreo, a pit bull, was nursed back to health after being thrown off the roof of a building only to later be deemed too dangerous to be kept alive.

headline: Almodóvar’s Happy Agony, Swirling Amid Jealousy and Revenge
text: Can there be such a thing as exuberant melancholy? I can’t think of another way to describe the spirit of “Broken Embraces,” Pedro Almodóvar’s latest film, the title of which carries a telling hint of paradox. It is grave and effervescent, tender and cruel.

headline: Inside the List
text: STORMY WEATHER I: I’m a sucker for tales of extreme weather, so my curiosity was piqued by Linda Howard’s “Ice,” new at No. 8 on the hardcover fiction list. (Amazon.com’s recommendation algorithm apparently knows me well: When I looked up “Ice,” it also tried to sell me Howard’s “Burn,” Sandra Brown’s “Rainwater” and Julie Garwood’s “Sizzle.”) Howard (inset), who lives in Alabama and is married to a professional bass tournament fisherman, has made almost a dozen appearances on the list, starting with “Everlasting Love” (1995). The new book is about a small-town cop’s son who finds himself trapped in the winter woods while protecting a local damsel in distress from a cold-blooded killer. Igloo-melting romance ensues, of course, not to mention the immortal line: “Lollipop, can I lick you?”

headline: Mercurial Jester, Revealing and Concealing
text: “One no longer remembers where Mr. Ray was born. After having been a coal merchant, a millionaire several times over and the chairman of a chewing-gum trust, he decided he was open to the Dadaists’ invitation to show his latest paintings in Paris.”

headline: Santa Claus at Risk of Swine Flu
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: … and Little Optimism
text: In Kabul and in the provinces, those who watched President Hamid Karzai’s inauguration to a second term viewed the event with skepticism, and many did not watch at all.

headline: K.K.R. Posts First Profit as a Public Company
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts began life as a publicly traded company by reporting a $656.6 million profit for its third quarter, a sharp turnaround from a $465.6 million loss one year ago.

headline: Is Goldman’s Charitable Gesture Enough?
text: When Goldman Sachs said this week that it was starting a $500 million charitable project to help 10,000 small businesses — a sum that represents 3 percent of the $16 billion the firm has set aside so far for employee compensation this year — the announcement was widely seen as a public relations move. The firm’s chairman, Lloyd Blankfein, who had earlier stoked popular anger when he said Goldman was doing “God’s work” in its business, also apologized for participating in “things that were clearly wrong.” A recent audit found that the government bailout of A.I.G., the insurance company, resulted in billions of dollars of benefit to Goldman Sachs.

headline: A Green Wave
text: A California start-up uses recycled material in their surfboard blanks, from which finished boards are carved.

headline: A New Orleans Mystery: A Cop So Bad, He’s Good
text: “Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans”  what an ungainly title for a movie. What does it mean? What kind of sense does it make? You might ask the same questions of the film itself, directed by Werner Herzog and related, by some equally puzzling movie-business genealogy, to another “Bad Lieutenant,” Abel Ferrara’s 1992 tour of New York law-enforcement hell. Neither remake nor sequel, this “Bad Lieutenant” is its own special fever-swamp of a movie, an anarchist film noir that seems, at times, almost as unhinged as its protagonist.

headline: Oprah Winfrey to End Her Talk Show
text: The media mogul Oprah Winfrey will end her daytime talk show, “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” in 2011 as she prepares to start a cable channel of her own.

headline: Restaurant Review: Estado Puro in Madrid
text: A hotel tapas bar located smack in the middle of one of Madrid’s busiest tourist hubs? Easy to pass up, perhaps. But then I took a closer look. An artfully stylized pattern of filigree mantilla combs  the restaurant’s logo  covered the ceiling and swept down the wall. The menu promised the classics, but with more than a whiff of innovation. I was hooked.

headline: Hotel Review: Copley Square Hotel in Boston
text: THE BASICS

headline: Hotels Blossoming in Berlin
text: CASA CAMPER, a 51-room hotel in the Mitte district of Berlin, was fully booked when it opened on Sept. 15. The hotel, run by the Spanish urban clothing label Camper, drew a youthful clientele that included fashionable Europeans in party mode and Monocle magazine-toting business travelers who would never stay at a prosaic hotel.

headline: Oscar Short List of Documentaries Draws Controversy
text: LOS ANGELES  “Tyson,” a critically acclaimed movie about the boxer Mike Tyson, was not among 15 feature documentaries that qualified on Wednesday for possible Oscar nominations, and James Toback, the filmmaker behind it, is fighting mad.

headline: House Democrats Approve ‘Doc Fix’
text: The House on Thursday approved a $210 billion measure to avert steep cuts in Medicare payments to doctors.

headline: Carlyle Group to Run Connecticut Rest Stops
text: The Carlyle Group said Thursday that it had signed a deal with Connecticut to refurbish and run the state’s 23 highway service stops in return for a share of their revenues over the next 35 years.

headline: ‘Lost’ to Return in February for Its Final Season
text: The sixth and final season of “Lost,” the ABC castaway mystery, will begin on Feb. 2, when the series moves to Tuesday nights for the first time.

headline: Google Says It Doesn’t Want to Be a Utility
text: From Green Inc.:

headline: Correction
text: An article on Nov. 8 about the Alto Alentejo region of Portugal misidentified the person buried in a tomb at the Convento da Flor da Rosa, now a pousada, where guests can stay. The pousada houses the tomb of Álvaro Gonçalves Pereira  not Nuno Álvares Pereira, who was one of his sons.

headline: The Mets Finished Last in 2009 Draft Spending
text: How much money the Mets intend to lavish on free agents to fill their many needs is unclear. What is clear is that the Mets, during a dreadful season and increased criticism of their minor league system, spent less money on the 2009 draft than any other team in baseball, according to figures compiled by Baseball America.

headline: Geithner Pledges a Quick End to TARP
text: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said Thursday that the government would end its $700 billion bailout program “as soon as we can,” and that part of the money would be used to lower the record deficit.

headline: Bourgeois Bohemians, There’s a Price to Pay
text: Don’t hate them because they’re beautiful. Don’t hate them because they’re thin and young and glowing with health. Don’t hate them because they live in a fabulous New York loft and have jobs that seem to give their lives meaning and, in one case, will soon make them wealthy. And especially don’t hate them because they have a little girl and  because Mommy wants to work as hard and as much as Daddy does  they employ a live-in nanny. Well, go ahead and hate them a little because they have a nanny. In fact, hate them a lot.

headline: Theater Listings: Nov. 20 — 26
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/theater.

headline: P.E.T.A. Eyes Prison Makeover
text: An idea you don’t see every day: The intersection of P.E.T.A. and Guantánamo Bay.

headline: The Indie Music Pillars of Athens, Greece
text: DUSK was descending softly on Athens as the sounds of bass-heavy noise pop drifted across Karitsi Square, a tucked-away cobblestone oasis near the city center. In the outside seating area of Use Bar (Karitsi Square 5; 30-210-323-5993), two tables of artist types were discussing a recent show by the local dark-wave band Phoenix Catscratch. Later, throngs of young men and women sporting skinny jeans and asymmetrical haircuts would fill the square and seep down winding Kolokotroni Street into a slew of new bars, galleries and other spots catering to the city’s growing indie and post-alternative scene.

headline: Heart of a Small Town, Vast in Its Loneliness
text: Two fresh-faced fishermen, wearing solemn expressions and suspenders, sit on a riverbank, looking as if they were waiting for Norman Rockwell to show up with his easel. “You’re on your own now,” one of them says.

headline: Letter: Library Treasures
text: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article “Rare Books Don’t Always Live in Glass Cases” (Nov. 1) on lesser-known libraries with extraordinary collections. I was reminded of the detour-worthy art collection housed in the library of my hometown, Charles City, Iowa, population about 7,500. The public library was bequeathed an important collection of works on paper in 1941.

headline: Letter: The Ridgeway Trail
text: To the Editor: The Ridgeway Trail (“Hiking Into History,” Nov. 1) in England has the mixture of nature, history, geology and village life that makes for extraordinary hiking and that seems to be missing in the trails in the United States. The United States seems to excel in wilderness trails that don’t have a hint of the domesticity described by Henry Shukman. However, it’s the contrast between the exertion needed to hike and the luxury of a village inn that brings the greatest pleasure.

headline: A World of Macabre Misfits
text: Tim Burton’s career is the ultimate revenge of the art nerd. Mr. Burton, the self-professed alienated child of a dysfunctional family in Burbank, Calif., who funneled his loneliness, pain and grief into drawing cartoons, has found fame, fortune and a beautiful companion (Helena Bonham Carter) by telling cinematic tales of sensitive misfits triumphing over, or succumbing to, a world of repressive mediocrity.

headline: Nickelodeon’s Stepchild, Eager for More Love
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.

headline: Bloggingheads: Aimless War?
text: Andrew Bacevich, left, of Boston Univeristy and David Frum of FrumForum debate President Obama's Afghanistan strategy.

headline: Gender Switch in Illyria, With Players 8 Inches Tall
text: Orsino emerges from a giant silver ice bucket. Sir Toby Belch and Sir Andrew Aguecheek straddle huge liquor bottles. Olivia makes an entrance in a loving cup big enough to hold her and a friend. Luckily, all the characters are played by eight-inch-tall marionettes; otherwise the set design budget would have been a monster.

headline: Malone Won’t Rule Out Phone Deal for DirecTV
text: John C. Malone, the chairman of the DirecTV Group, is not ruling out a possible takeover of his company by AT&T or Verizon Communications, saying they would probably have closer ties to DirecTV as they develop packages of phone and television service.

headline: Crime Pays for CBS
text: CBS finished first in the ratings on Wednesday with a crime-filled lineup. The network’s “Criminal Minds” drew 13.5 million viewers and “CSI: NY” grabbed 13.7 million, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC was second with its comedies, including “Modern Family” (9.2 million), as well as a news special, “In the Spotlight With Robin Roberts,” featuring an interview with Janet Jackson (6.6 million). NBC finished in third place with “Mercy” (7.8 million), “Law & Order: SVU” (8.4 million) and “The Jay Leno Show” (4.8 million). Fox was fourth with “So You Think You Can Dance” (5.7 million) followed by “Glee” (7.3 million).

headline: China Helps the Powerful in Namibia
text: BEIJING  Like parents everywhere, mothers and fathers in Namibia, an impoverished southern African nation, worry about college costs and opportunities for their children. The Chinese government has stepped forward to help  for a select and powerful few.

headline: U.S. Teaches Carmakers Capitalism
text: When the American auto industry was owned by investors, it acted like a government enterprise.

headline: Panel Sees No Need for A-Bomb Upgrade
text: In a new report, a secretive federal panel has concluded that programs to extend the life of the nation’s aging nuclear arms are sufficient to guarantee their destructiveness for decades to come, obviating a need for a costly new generation of more reliable warheads.

headline: Gateses Give $290 Million for Education
text: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation on Thursday announced its biggest education donation in a decade, $290 million, in support of three school districts and five charter groups working to transform how teachers are evaluated and how they get tenure.

headline: Panel Votes to Broaden Oversight of the Fed
text: WASHINGTON  In a display of populist anger toward the Federal Reserve, a House panel voted on Thursday to let Congress carry out sweeping new oversights of the central bank’s policy decisions and operations.

headline: ‘On the Green’ or ‘In the Park’?
text: Could it be called “Tavern in the Park”?

headline: For Tavern Name, a Backup Plan
text: Could it be called Tavern in the Park?

headline: For Tavern Name, a Backup Plan
text: Could it be called “Tavern in the Park”?

headline: Watchdog Urges Caution on Claims of 640,000 Stimulus Jobs
text: WASHINGTON  The government watchdog overseeing the federal stimulus program testified Thursday that he could not vouch for the Obama administration’s recent claims that the money had saved or created 640,000 jobs. He suggested that the administration should have treated the number with more skepticism.

headline: For Citi, Less Sting From a Painful Bet
text: Citigroup stopped dancing to the music of the credit boom shortly after it backed the leveraged buyout of EMI, the British music company, in 2007.

headline: Not Taking ‘Not Hiring’ for an Answer
text: BABY boomers have lived during an era of unparalleled prosperity. So when this deep recession hit  at a time when boomers were advancing to middle- and late-middle age  much was written about them being too spoiled to cope.

headline: Japan’s Fleet Departs to Hunt 900 Whales
text: Japan’s whaling fleet heads to sea, and a marine conservationist and scientist decries the impending kill.

headline: Fire Reveals Illegal Homes Hide in Plain Sight
text: For at least two years before a fire killed three men in an illegally divided house next door, Diane Ross and her family lived in an illegal apartment at 42-38 65th Street in Woodside, Queens.

headline: The Jonas Brothers Promote Xbox 360
text: IT’S all in the family, Madison Avenue style: a product aimed at families is teaming up with a famous name in family entertainment for an elaborate effort fronted by one of the biggest family acts in music.

headline: Gay Spouses Due Benefits in the State, Court Finds
text: ALBANY  The state’s highest court on Thursday upheld policies giving some government benefits to same-sex couples who are legally married outside the state, but did not rule on whether gay marriage should be legal in New York, leaving that issue for the Legislature to decide.

headline: Pentagon to Review Shootings at Fort Hood
text: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday announced a Pentagon review of the shootings at Ford Hood, Tex., to help ensure, he said, that “nothing like this ever happens again.”

headline: Google Offers Peek at Operating System, a Potential Challenge to Windows
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Google began lifting the veil on its planned Chrome operating system on Thursday, but it said that computers powered by the software would not be available for a year.

headline: Suit Accuses Hartford Courant of Plagiarism
text: Newspapers have tried many ways to cover the news with dwindling resources: dropping certain topics, having people do double duty, using more wire service work. Routine plagiarism is not usually an option, but a lawsuit contends that it was for a while at The Hartford Courant.

headline: Industrialized Nations Unveil Plans to Rein in Emissions
text: With less than three weeks remaining before negotiators gather in Copenhagen to hammer out a global response to climate change, a rapid-fire succession of countries are unveiling national plans that serve as opening bids for reining in heat-trapping emissions.

headline: Sex Offenses on the Subways Are Widespread, City Officials Are Told
text: The peak times in which women report sexual harassment or assaults on the subways are the late morning rush, roughly 8 to 10 a.m., followed by the early afternoon rush, 4 to 6 p.m.

headline: South Korea Trade Pact Is Revived by Obama
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama opened a potentially bruising battle within the Democratic party on Thursday when he pledged to complete a long-stalled trade agreement with South Korea that he inherited from President George W. Bush.

headline: Steamrolling Over Life’s Obstacles With Family as Cheerleaders
text: One of the many turning points in “The Blind Side”  a movie made up almost entirely of turning points and yet curiously devoid of drama or suspense  comes during a Memphis high school football game. Michael Oher, the offensive tackle whose remarkable life is the subject of the film (and of the nonfiction best seller on which it is based), is having trouble protecting his quarterback.

headline: Air Defense Push Inspired by 9/11 Gets a 2nd Look
text: COLORADO SPRINGS  The commander of military forces protecting North America has ordered a review of the costly air defenses intended to prevent another Sept. 11-style terrorism attack, an assessment aimed at determining whether the commitment of jet fighters, other aircraft and crews remains justified.

headline: The Pick-and-Roll Is the N.B.A.’s Old Reliable
text: With the basketball in his hands, Orlando’s Jameer Nelson performs the two-man two-step that the Magic and the entire N.B.A. have sought to perfect.

headline: Governors Don’t Call This Home
text: It is a 20-room Greek Revival mansion, with Italian gardens, a music room and a wood-paneled library. But no one seems to want to live in Drumthwacket, the governor’s residence in Princeton Township, N.J.

headline: Film Series and Movie Listings
text: MOVIES

headline: Can Iverson Restore Hope for Knicks?
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Four months ago, Allen Iverson was a free agent in search of a team. The Knicks were weak at point guard, devoid of star power and looking listless after a 32-win season. Yet Iverson never made their call list.

headline: Pakistani Politics Take on a Nationalist Tone
It Figures: Lincecum Captures Cy Young
text: When the Cy Young Award was introduced in 1956, the voting was simple. Baseball writers voted for one pitcher, and that was that.

headline: Treasury to Auction Off Big-Bank Warrants
text: A year after the federal government rescued the nation’s financial industry, the Treasury Department announced Thursday that it would auction off its remaining investments in three large banks, freeing the lenders from the federal bailout program.

headline: In New Orleans, Elation Over Katrina Liability Ruling
text: NEW ORLEANS  Since the first days after Hurricane Katrina, when the streets were still under water, many residents of New Orleans and its surroundings have maintained that the flood that wrecked their lives was the government’s fault, and that the government should pay for it.

headline: Flights of Mind, Brought to Life
text: Some of the models have the comforting feel of old acquaintance: the twisting, screw-like sail of a flying machine; the armored revolving saucer with cannons protruding through its port holes; the arched bridge that can swing aside for ship traffic. These wood, rope and cloth reproductions, along with glimpses of mirror-reversed Italian script on sheets marked by doodles and sketches  who could miss the distinctive traces left by the artist, inventor and scientist for whom the term Renaissance man seems custom made?

headline: Anglican Leader Defends Faith as Vatican Welcomes His Members
text: ROME  When the Vatican announced last month that it was creating a new Anglican rite within the Roman Catholic Church aimed at Anglicans uncomfortable with the ordination of women and gay clergy members, a headline in a British newspaper read, “Rome Parks Tanks on Rowan’s Lawn.”

headline: A Misunderstood Alien, but Not as Smart as E.T.
text: The agreeable but flagrantly unoriginal “Planet 51” belongs to the mix-and-match school of animated moviemaking that operates on the plaintive hope that familiarity is the surest path to the box office. Almost every element of the film, created by Ilion Animation Studios, based in Madrid, is borrowed from earlier films, then tweaked (and invariably softened) to become a reference rather than a copy.

headline: Obama Has a Job for Dana Perino. Really.
text: From the Department of Unlikely Events: George W. Bush’s press secretary has been asked to serve in the Obama administration.

headline: The Big Squander
text: Earlier this week, the inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program, a k a, the bank bailout fund, released his report on the 2008 rescue of the American International Group, the insurer. The gist of the report is that government officials made no serious attempt to extract concessions from bankers, even though these bankers received huge benefits from the rescue. And more than money was lost. By making what was in effect a multibillion-dollar gift to Wall Street, policy makers undermined their own credibility  and put the broader economy at risk.

headline: For Bruno, How Albany Works Is Also on Trial
text: ALBANY  The longtime secretary for one of the most powerful politicians in New York spent as much time on his private business, handling bills and correspondence, as she did on his public duties, like arranging meetings with lawmakers.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,354 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Thursday:

headline: Michigan Football Facing Hard Times on the Field and Off It
text: Late last week, Bruce Springsteen took the stage at a sports arena north of Detroit and greeted his Michigan audience with a cheerful “Hello, Ohio!”

headline: Ouster of N.F.L.’s Voice on Concussions Sought
text: The National Football League Players Association is calling for the removal of Dr. Ira Casson as co-chairman of the league’s committee on concussions, saying that he is too biased to lead the research and policy group.

headline: A Crown Jewel of Education Struggles With Cuts
text: BERKELEY, Calif.  As the University of California struggles to absorb its sharpest drop in state financing since the Great Depression, every professor, administrator and clerical worker has been put on furlough amounting to an average pay cut of 8 percent.

headline: Reid, as Legislative Tactician, Takes Ownership of Health Care Overhaul
text: WASHINGTON  Now it is Senator Harry Reid’s health care bill.

headline: With F.H.A. Help, Easy Loans in Expensive Areas
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In January, Mike Rowland was so broke that he had to raid his retirement savings to move here from Boston.

headline: With Ankle in a Brace, Wie Quits After a 72
text: RICHMOND, Tex.  Now that Michelle Wie had found her footing, not much was supposed to slow her down. She barely broke stride Thursday on the first fairway when she hiked up her left pant leg on the opening hole to show her playing partner, Christina Kim, the black brace wrapped around her ankle.

headline: Strauss, Neapolitan Tunes and a Festive Singalong
text: A chorus of bravos greeted the soprano Aprile Millo as she swept regally onto the stage at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Tuesday evening. Ms. Millo was making her New York recital debut and celebrating the 25th anniversary of her first appearance with the Opera Orchestra of New York, which presented the concert.

headline: Immigration Officials to Audit 1,000 More Companies
text: WASHINGTON  Immigration enforcement officials said Thursday that they were expanding a program for auditing companies that might have hired illegal immigrants and had notified 1,000 companies this week that they would have to undergo such a review.

headline: A Tilt Away From Social Issues
text: LOST PINES, Tex.  After two bleak years, Republican governors gathered here on Thursday to assess their political future  and they liked what they saw. With 37 governors’ seats open in 2010, the party is looking to topple some big-name Democrats.

headline: Facing Patriots, Jets Know It’s Now or Never Mind Playoffs
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The season is in a free fall and with New England next up on Sunday, urgency has replaced normalcy at Jets headquarters.

headline: What Geithner Got Right
text: It’s amazing to go back and read what people were saying about Timothy Geithner in the spring. Many people said he looked terrified as the Treasury secretary, like Bambi in the headlights. The New Republic ran an essay called “The Geithner Disaster.” Portfolio magazine ran a brutal, zeitgeist-capturing profile that concluded by comparing Geithner to Robert Redford’s hollow man character in “The Candidate.”

headline: Bronzino Is Given His Museum Moment
text: Over the years, several European museums have tried to organize an exhibition devoted to the work of Bronzino, the poet who was also one of the most important Mannerist painters and draftsmen in 16th-century Florence. But none were successful because loans were so difficult to secure.

headline: Winfrey Bets on Her Future With Cable
text: Oprah Winfrey is giving network television one of her trademark aha moments.

headline: Feelings Close to the Surface
text: Lee Yoon-ki’s “My Dear Enemy,” which opens on Friday for one week at the Museum of Modern Art, may confound your expectations of a South Korean film: no convoluted flashbacks, no doppelgängers, no puzzling narrative leaps, no violence or sex or ghosts. It’s an artful, slightly absurdist romance, reminiscent of the gender-war comedies of Hong Sang-soo (“Woman on the Beach”) but more straightforward, with its meanings, and its feelings, much closer to the surface.

headline: The Days May Be Grim, but Here’s a Good Word to Put in Your Pocket
text: “The Waterfalls” flowed in the East River. “The Gates” snaked through Central Park. Now New York’s latest large-scale public art project is being exhibited in an even unlikelier space: your wallet.

headline: Spare Times
text: ‘THE ART OF ARCHIE COMICS’

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: ICKYFEST!

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Free-Music Thursdays at Lincoln Center
text: A new series of free concerts started at Lincoln Center’s new visitor center on Thursday with a program that included the Asphalt Orchestra, a 12-piece street band; the Juilliard Jazz Ensemble; the Kubiak-Pakhomov Duo, a pianist and cellist; and the Sexteto Rodriguez Cuban-Jewish All Stars, who blend Cuban dance music with Jewish klezmer. Sponsored by the Target retailing chain, the series, Target Free Thursdays, is based at the David Rubenstein Atrium, which will also serve as a discount-ticket site for Lincoln Center starting Jan. 7. The concerts are to be held every Thursday, including Thanksgiving (featuring the Majestic Marching Knights of Ballou Senior High School in Washington, a Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade band), Christmas Eve (the Ted Rosenthal Trio) and New Year’s Eve (Champian Fulton Quartet).

headline: A Forceful Entry by Christie, and a Sober Exit by Corzine
text: ATLANTIC CITY  In a vivid contrast of their styles and standing, a soft-spoken Gov. Jon S. Corzine delivered a choked-up goodbye here Thursday while Governor-elect Christopher J. Christie vowed to “force change” on New Jersey even if it meant dragging his adversaries to the table.

headline: A Seattle Premiere for ‘ruined’ Next Year
text: Kate Whoriskey’s first season as an artistic director of the Intiman Theater in Seattle will include a production of “Ruined,” the Pulitzer Prize-winning Lynn Nottage play that Ms. Whoriskey, right, also directed in New York and Chicago. On Thursday, the Intiman said that its 2010 season would open with a production of Clifford Odets’s “Paradise Lost,” directed by Dámaso Rodriguez, which will begin previews on March 19 and open on March 26. The season will also feature “Ruined” (July 2 through Aug. 8) as the first play in a five-year International Cycle and Hawthorne’s “Scarlet Letter” adapted by Naomi Iizuka and directed by Lear deBessonet (Oct. 22 through Dec. 5) as the latest play in its American Cycle. Other productions include “A Doctor in Spite of Himself” by Molière (Sept. 3-Oct. 10), adapted by Christopher Bayes and Steven Epp.

headline: University of California Drops New Museum Plan
text: The University of California, Berkeley, has decided to scrap its ambitious designs for a new Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, saying that it has been unable to raise enough money, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. The building, to have been designed by Toyo Ito and estimated to cost from $143 million to $200 million, was to be constructed in downtown Berkeley and replace the museum’s current on-campus home, which was declared seismically unsafe a decade ago. Lawrence Rinder, the museum’s director, told the newspaper that the decision was a consequence of the economic downturn. The museum’s capital campaign, whose goal was $200 million, raised only $81 million by this month. “The gap was just too great, looking forward,” Mr. Rinder said. The museum hopes to announce another plan by early January. “While architectural plans are changing,” Robert Birgeneau, the university’s chancellor, said in a statement, “the goal of building a dynamic, welcoming and seismically safe new museum downtown is not.”

headline: Footnotes
text: The Public Theater said it was extending its run of Tarell Alvin McCraney’s “Brother/Sister Plays.” The production of the trilogy will continue through Dec. 20, with all three plays running on Saturdays and Sundays. ... The Cherry Lane Theater said it was extending its production of “The Lady With All the Answers.” The David Rambo play, which stars Judith Ivey as the advice columnist Ann Landers, will run through Dec. 20.

headline: Cast Is Set for ‘Lie of the Mind’
text: Ethan Hawke, below, has assembled an estimable gathering of downtown denizens and fellow actors to star in a revival of “A Lie of the Mind,” the Sam Shepard play that he will be directing for the New Group. The cast of the play, about a man who believes he may have murdered his wife, will feature Josh Hamilton (who starred in Jonathan Marc Sherman’s “Things We Want” for Mr. Hawke), as well as Marin Ireland (“Reasons to Be Pretty”), Deirdre O’Connell (“Circle Mirror Transformation”), Alessandro Nivola, Maggie Siff and Frank Whaley. The production is to begin previews on Jan. 29 with an official opening planned for February, its publicists said in a release.

headline: Raymond Carver’s Life and Stories
text: Raymond Carver, surely the most influential writer of American short stories in the second half of the 20th century, makes an early appearance in Carol Sklenicka’s exhaustive and sometimes exhausting biography as a 3- or 4-year-old on a leash. “Well, of course I had to keep him on a leash,” his mother, Ella Carver, said much later — and seemingly without irony.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Gazing Longingly at Manhattan
text: The writer-director James DeMonaco is a native Staten Islander, and if his film “Staten Island, New York” is an ode to what it calls “the forgotten stepchild of Manhattan,” it is a barbed and quirky one. Using a nonlinear, Tarantino-esque narrative, Mr. DeMonaco adroitly weaves violence, absurdity and sentiment, even an environmental consciousness, into a modest, appealing fable.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Rush Hour Restriction
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Many people think it’s impossible to solve a Friday or Saturday Times puzzle. “I’m lucky if I can get five answers,” they say. Sometimes, that’s all that’s needed.

headline: Texas: Plant Will Not Take Waste From Mexico
text: A southeast Texas industrial disposal facility has suspended its plan to import and incinerate up to 20,000 tons of hazardous waste from Mexico, a company official said. The company, Veolia Environmental Services, dropped its request to the Environmental Protection Agency for a permit to import polychlorinated byphenyls from Mexico and burn them in a plant, said Mitch Osborne, general manager of the plant. The agency had notified Veolia of its intent to approve the permit in March 2008, but the decision stirred controversy. Mr. Osborne cited “economic uncertainty” in abandoning the permit.

headline: Beyond Electricity, Toward Female Emancipation
text: Alert the authorities. Shocking sexual acts are taking place on the stage of the Lyceum Theater, right in the heart of the Broadway theater district, so recently scrubbed free of all smut and seeded with lawn chairs. Acts involving three people at a time, no less. A man and two women, a woman and two men, sometimes three men.

headline: Modern Art for Modern Museumgoers
