text: On a recent Thursday evening in Chicago a crowd was forming. Young women grasped the hands of balky children; aspiring artists with pierced eyebrows clutched pencils and sketchbooks. They were waiting to be granted entrance to the Modern Wing of the Art Institute. And they were getting restless.

headline: South Carolina: Sanford to Release Travel Records
text: Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina plans to release records to state legislators about previously undisclosed flights that he took on planes owned by friends and campaign donors, his lawyer, Butch Bowers, said. That announcement came a day after the State Ethics Commission charged Mr. Sanford, a Republican, with unspecified ethics violations  a factor for legislators considering whether to try to impeach him. Ever since Mr. Sanford’s five-day disappearance to Argentina and admission of an extramarital affair with a woman there in June, he has faced questions about his travel records. He took 35 flights, not including the Argentina trip, on private planes that he did not list on state ethics forms or campaign reports, The Associated Press has reported. But Mr. Bowers said the commission’s findings were “limited to minor matters that don’t include any allegations of criminal conduct.”

headline: Hamilton Confirmed for Appeals Court
text: The Senate voted 59 to 39 to confirm Judge David F. Hamilton to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Judge Hamilton, who sits on the Federal District Court in Indiana, was President Obama’s first judicial nominee. Republicans opposed the nomination, announced March 19, because of decisions Judge Hamilton made relating to abortion and prayers in the Indiana Legislature. Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana was the only Republican to vote for his confirmation.

headline: Probing Psychological Wounds
text: A moody, modern-day noir about derailed lives and suppressed memories, “The Missing Person” uses crime-novel clichés to probe psychological wounds.

headline: The Wet Side of the Moon
text: Moffett Field, Calif.

headline: Clinton Seen as Obama’s Key Link to Afghan Leader
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  It is far from clear that President Obama can depend on President Hamid Karzai to bring order to this violent country, but it is becoming clear that he will depend on Hillary Rodham Clinton to be his go-between in dealing with the mercurial Afghan leader.

headline: The Past in the Present
text: In his disorganized and somewhat annoying “Defamation,” Yoav Shamir, an Israeli filmmaker, tries to stir up a tempest with the notions that “anti-Semitic” has become an all-purpose label for anyone who dares criticize Israel and that some Jews’ preoccupation with the past  i.e., the Holocaust  is preventing progress in the here and now.

headline: Honduran Leader Says He’ll Briefly Step Down
text: MEXICO CITY  As the presidential election draws near in Honduras, the de facto leader, Roberto Micheletti, and the ousted president, Manuel Zelaya, continued their political jockeying on Thursday, with Mr. Micheletti announcing that he would briefly cede power to increase the vote’s legitimacy and Mr. Zelaya insisting that the election be pushed back.

headline: A Single, Frantic Day
text: Propelled by an eccentric cast of characters and increasingly seamy locations, “Fix” dashes headlong through Los Angeles with a little charm and a lot of verve.

headline: Russian Priest Killed in Church
text: MOSCOW  The Rev. Daniil Sysoyev, a priest in the Russian Orthodox Church who was known for promoting missionary work among Muslims, was shot and killed in his parish church late Thursday night, the RIA Novosti news agency reported.

headline: Sir John Crofton, Pioneer in TB Cure, Dies at 97
text: Sir John Crofton, a pioneering clinician who demonstrated that antibiotics could be safely combined to cure tuberculosis, a dread disease that once killed half the people who contracted it, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Edinburgh. He was 97.

headline: Teachers at Some Low-Performing Schools Get Bonuses
text: Teachers at W.H. Maxwell Career and Technical Education High School in Brooklyn were among those at 23 high schools citywide awarded a total of $3.5 million in performance bonuses on Thursday, even though the school received a D on its progress report earlier this week.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about the airline industry’s use of so-called carbon offsets, which are fees paid by passengers for environmental projects meant to compensate for carbon dioxide emissions from their air travel, misspelled the surname of the executive who heads the Carbon Disclosure Project, a consortium of companies that have pledged to report and reduce their emissions. He is Paul Dickinson, not Dickenson.

headline: Syracuse Feels at Home Again in Garden
text: When Syracuse was at Madison Square Garden in March winning its unforgettable six-overtime marathon against Connecticut in the Big East tournament quarterfinals, the Orange’s big three announced their presence loudly.

headline: F.A.A. Computer Problem Snarls Flights
text: WASHINGTON  Flights over much of the eastern United States were delayed Thursday by a pre-dawn failure in a fairly new communications system, which led to the shutdown of a computer that accepts flight plans from the airlines and feeds them to air traffic controllers.

headline: Stiegler Hurt in Training
text: Resi Stiegler, 24, one of the United States ski team’s most gifted slalom skiers, crashed in training at Copper Mountain, Colo., and was taken off the mountain on a sled with a left knee injury. The team said it would not announce the severity of the injury until Friday. After hitting a gate and tumbling forward, Stiegler lay on the side of the training course screaming in pain for several minutes.

headline: Corrections
text: The Patient Money column on Saturday, about ways to pay for alternative medical procedures and nutritional supplements, misquoted Dr. David Riley, a medical doctor who is editor of the journal Alternative Therapies in Health and Medicine. Dr. Riley said he was not aware of any mislabeling problems involving the nutritional supplement glucosamine. He did not say that a supplement promoted as supplying 100 percent of a daily dose of glucosamine might actually contain only a microscopic amount of the ingredient. The article also referred incorrectly to the Food and Drug Administration’s jurisdiction over nutritional supplements. The F.D.A. does in fact regulate nutritional supplements, although it does not oversee the supplements as extensively as it does prescription drugs.

headline: Company Piles Up Profits From City’s Parking Meter Deal
text: After a rocky start hurt their bottom line, Chicago’s new parking meter operators are raking in more than $1.1 million a week and expect even more revenue next year, according to internal company documents obtained by the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Census Bureau Opens Third Data Processing Center
text: The Census Bureau, along with Lockheed Martin, said that it had opened the last of its three data centers scheduled next spring to process the 10-question 2010 Census form. The 212,000 square-foot center will also operate as a call center for people who need help completing their forms. According to the Census Bureau, it will bring more than 2,800 new jobs to the Phoenix area. The other processing centers are located in Baltimore, Md., and Jeffersonville, Ind.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about an initiative to offer mortgages to landlords who fix wasteful energy and water systems misstated the frequency of energy audits for older apartment buildings under proposed New York City regulations. They would be conducted every 10 years, not annually.

headline: The Lessons of the Cy Young Awards
text: The intrigue of the baseball awards is over now, because the only question about the M.V.P. awards to be announced next week is whether Joe Mauer and Albert Pujols will be unanimous. I’m guessing they will.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about the upgrading of sports programs in the State University of New York system omitted two state university systems that did not have athletics programs in Division I of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in the 1980s. Besides Alaska and New York, North Dakota and South Dakota also did not have any state universities or colleges in Division I during that period. The article also misstated the title once held by the person who is investigating the Binghamton University sports program. Judith S. Kaye, who was not identified by name in the article, was New York State’s former chief judge; there is no “chief justice” in New York.

headline: Corrections
text: A chart in some editions on Wednesday with an article about Kansas City Royals pitcher Zack Greinke’s winning the American League Cy Young Award misspelled the surname of the Detroit Tigers pitcher who had 31 victories in 1968, nearly twice as many as Greinke’s 16 in 2009. He is Denny McLain, not McClain.

headline: Corrections
text: An art review last Friday about “Victorious Ones: Jain Images of Perfection,” at the Rubin Museum of Art, and “Peaceful Conquerors: Jain Manuscript Painting,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misspelled the Sanskrit term for the Jains’ commitment to nonviolence. It is ahimsa, not ahmisa.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Nov. 12 about the Sotheby’s auction of contemporary art in New York misstated Sotheby’s high estimate of sales before the auction. It was $97.7 million  not $67.9 million, which was the low estimate. (Actual sales totaled $134.4 million.)

headline: The Pulse: As Bulls Hit the Road, Clowns Stay Home
text: The Chicago Bulls’ record on their annual “circus trip” in the 10 seasons since Michael Jordan retired was 10-56 before their game Thursday night against the Los Angeles Lakers.

headline: Outside a World of Wealth Stands the Reality of Hunger
text: You can drive past the lovely North Side house of Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, and smack into Chicago’s invisible poor.

headline: Corrections
text: A music review on Tuesday about the pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, at Alice Tully Hall, misstated the Köchel catalog number of the Mozart Piano Sonata in D he performed. It is K. 284, not 282.

headline: After a Fire in Brooklyn, the Anguish of a Mother
text: Shaking as two relatives helped her onto a sofa, Rose Danielle Etienne, 26, sobbed Thursday afternoon as she spoke of a fire that had swept through her apartment in Brooklyn the day before, killing her longtime companion and their two young sons.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary on Wednesday about Pierre Harmel, a Belgian diplomat who formulated a new strategy for NATO in the 1960s, misattributed a quotation from a NATO statement about Mr. Harmel’s career. It was Anders Fogh Rasmussen, the secretary general of NATO, who commented on Mr. Harmel’s “distinguished and influential” career  not Jaap de Hoop Scheffer, a previous secretary general.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Five Youths Arraigned in Shooting of Two on Bronx Street
text: She was already crying when the 16-year-old youth stepped before a criminal court judge in the Bronx on Thursday, a “baby-faced” gunman to some in the news media, but only a son to her.

headline: Appeals Court Voids ’93 Murder Convictions
text: New York State’s highest court on Thursday overturned the murder convictions of two men imprisoned for 19 years, ruling that a Manhattan prosecutor had misled the jury and improperly withheld information from defense lawyers at their trial.

headline: Jobless Rate Got No Help From Hiring for Holidays
text: The usual preholiday hiring by stores did not happen in October as New York City’s unemployment rate held at 10.3 percent, its highest level in 16 years, the State Labor Department said Thursday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
After Other Hardships, Trying to Bounce Back From Unemployment
text: Once Andrea Combs sensed that layoffs were imminent, she went to her caseworker’s office with a sense of purpose.

headline: Oscar Question of the Day: Who Chooses the Documentary Short List?
text: Nobody can accuse the documentary branch of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences of crass commercialism. In all, the 15 feature documentaries on the academy’s short list of those eligible for Oscar nominations appear to have had about $9 million in combined ticket sales. That’s less than half the roughly $20 million in sales accumulated by just four of the films — “Capitalism: A Love Story,” “The September Issue,” “”Tyson” and “Anvil!: The Story of Anvil”—that were bypassed.

headline: The Controversy Over Mammograms
text: An expert panel’s recommendation that mammography screening to detect breast cancer be scaled back has caused consternation among women and doctors and prompted some attempts to connect the results to the debate over health care.

headline: Iraq’s Election Law Morass
text: Iraqis have quickly learned to play hardball politics. That was evident on Wednesday when one of Iraq’s two vice presidents, Tariq al-Hashimi, who is a Sunni, vetoed an important election law at the last minute. He demanded a change that would allocate more parliamentary seats for Iraqi Sunnis living abroad.

headline: A Gift to Credit Card Companies
text: Congress left consumers extremely vulnerable when it gave the credit card industry as long as 15 months to end the deceptive predatory practices outlawed in the spring in the Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure Act. The credit card industry, which clearly wants to make a killing in the Christmas season, used this unnecessarily long grace period to intensify its predations, doubling interest rates on people who pay on time and driving up rates by an industry wide average of about 20 percent.

headline: A Pill a Day to Keep Cancer Away?
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Breast Screening Advice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tehran States Its Case
text: To the Editor:

headline: Confirming Judges
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dimming Prospects for Mideast Peace?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Addicted to Mammograms
text: Philadelphia

headline: Tim Burton at the Modern
text: Images from the Museum of Modern Art's expansive retrospective of his noncinematic art.

headline: Inside the Mind of Leonardo
text: Images from the exhibition “Leonardo da Vinci’s Workshop,” at the Discovery Times Square Exposition.

headline: Icon Painting and Crete
text: A new exhibition at the Onassis Cultural Center is essentially a dual-purpose visual essay on the painter Domenikos Theotokopoulos, better known as El Greco.

headline: MSNBC: The New York Times Edition
text: This week, John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times discusses the health care vote in the Senate, President Obama's upcoming decision on troops in Afghanistan, Sarah Palin's book tour and more.

headline: Guidelines Push Back Age for Cervical Cancer Tests
text: New guidelines for cervical cancer screening say women should delay their first Pap test until age 21, and be screened less often than recommended in the past.

headline: Screening Debate Reveals Culture Clash in Medicine
text: This week, the science of medicine bumped up against the foundations of American medical consumerism: that more is better, that saving a life is worth any sacrifice, that health care is a birthright.

headline: Labor Denounces Judge in Gompers Case
text: Saturday, Nov. 20, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Ukraine: Putin Soothes Dispute Over Price of Sending Fuel
text: Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia took a more conciliatory stance toward Ukraine on Thursday in negotiations over the transit of Russian gas through Ukrainian territory. Mr. Putin suggested that Russia would be willing to renegotiate transit agreements so that they would be more favorable to Ukraine. He made his comments after a meeting in the Ukrainian city of Yalta with his Ukrainian counterpart, Yulia V. Tymoshenko.

headline: Mammogram Debate Took Group by Surprise
text: The federal Preventive Services Task Force, the group that created a political firestorm this week with its recommendation that women get less-frequent mammograms, was created to be insulated from politics.

headline: Moldova: Army Enlists Onions and Garlic to Ward Off Swine Flu
text: The Moldovan Army is issuing garlic and onions to help its soldiers ward off a growing epidemic of swine flu in Eastern Europe, The Associated Press reported Thursday. The chief medical officer for the Defense Ministry, Col. Sergiu Vasislita, was quoted as saying each soldier would get the equivalent of one small onion and two garlic cloves added to his diet as an immune-system boost. Moldova has about 6,500 troops.

headline: Russia: Moratorium on Executions
text: Russia’s Constitutional Court extended the country’s moratorium on the death penalty on Thursday, though it stopped short of fully abolishing capital punishment. In a statement, the Constitutional Court argued that permitting capital punishment would violate Russia’s commitments as a member of the Council of Europe. The moratorium on executions was imposed in 1996 and was set to expire in January.

headline: Rethinking the Pap Test
text: Days after new recommendations called for later, less frequent mammograms, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists has issued new guidelines for cervical cancer screening.

headline: A Tour of Childhood Flavors, Then a Michelin Star
text: It was disconcerting to hear one of the top chefs in the Bay Area squeal like a child over a package of Filipino cheese cupcakes. But squeal Jennie Lorenzo did.

headline: Christian Leaders Unite on Political Issues
text: Citing the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s call to civil disobedience, 145 evangelical, Roman Catholic and Orthodox Christian leaders have signed a declaration saying they will not cooperate with laws that they say could be used to compel their institutions to participate in abortions, or to bless or in any way recognize same-sex couples.

headline: A Cal-Stanford Score, Off the Field
text: For 111 years, Stanford and Cal, which play on Saturday, have battled for supremacy on the football field. Still, there is more than one way to compete.

headline: Word of the Day | resonant
text: resonant • \ˈre-zə-nənt, ˈrez-nənt\ • adjective

headline: Learning to Teach to Bridge the Achievement Gap
text: Kathleen Martin stood in front of a white board covered with math problems, her class clustered at her feet. As they talked through the solutions together, the students repeated the headings over each problem on the board: “Algebra and Function,” “Probability,” “Data Analysis.”

headline: Faith and Tolerance Collide in Vallejo
text: Drive through Vallejo and you will see a once-proud Navy town clearly down on its luck. A motel room goes for $30.99 a night, including HBO. Closed businesses proliferate; those that remain often have temporary vinyl signs held up by string, indicating a tentative investment in the future.

headline: Bay Area Report Highlights for Friday, Nov. 20
text: Give ’em the Ax | On Saturday, the Stanford and Cal football teams will meet in a game crucial to both teams’ postseason dreams. But there are other fields and other dreams, and the universities vie with each other in many other ways. Jason Turbow offers his own brand of fantasy football: The Big Game, in other leagues.

headline: News Quiz | November 20, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Sign of the Times?
text: WHO first noticed and photographed this sign to bring it to the hospital’s attention?

headline: The Burning Voice of Vallejo
text: While reporting this week’s Barbary Coast column on questions about religious and political influence in Vallejo, I found myself spending hours in the online pages of The Vallejo Independent Bulletin.

headline: Radical Lawyer Convicted of Aiding Terrorist Is Jailed
text: Defiant to the end as she embraced emotional supporters outside the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan, Lynne F. Stewart, the radical lawyer known for defending unpopular clients, surrendered on Thursday evening to begin serving her 28-month sentence for assisting terrorism.

headline: Does Exercise Reduce Stress For You?
text: How much do you exercise? What do you do? Do you notice that it makes you less anxious?

headline: UrbanEye: The City Is A Stage
text: Melena Ryzik reports from the 2009 Performa Biennial, a Performance Art festival that inhabits New York City for three weeks.

headline: Sears Holdings Narrows Its Loss
text: Sears Holdings on Thursday posted a smaller third-quarter loss than a year ago, helped by cost cuts and inventory controls.

headline: ‘A Pulpy, Glorious Mess’
text: “The Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans,” Werner Herzog’s sorta remake of the 1992 Abel Ferrara film, “is a pulpy, glorious mess,” writes A.O. Scott. And he means it in a good way: “Its maniacal unpredictability is such a blast that it reminds you just how tidy and dull most crime thrillers are these days.” The star, Nicolas Cage, is at the height of ravaged oddball: “Sometimes his loose-limbed shuffle and sibilant drawl suggest Jimmy Stewart as a crackhead,” Scott writes. Other times, he just freestyle-raps (“to the break of dawn!”). “What may seem like random, dissociated bursts of energy are in fact the brilliant syncopations of a player with a sure, if unorthodox, sense of rhythm,” Scott writes. Ditto for the movie itself. “It has a warped sincerity, and an energy that keeps going and going. To the break of dawn!”

headline: Last Call
text: It’s the final weekend for Performa, the interactive performance art festival that’s been taking over the city for the last few weeks. You can join in a video  like we did [LINK to UR vid]  catch the premiere of a theater piece that involves a rare appearance by a South Korean magician or hear a who’s who of experimental musicians perform their most out-there stuff. In any case, participation is part of the point, and much of the fun.

headline: Misfits Are His Muses
text: “Tim Burton’s career is the ultimate revenge of the art nerd,” Ken Johnson writes. -The animator of Pee-Wee and Beetlejuice, Edward Scissorhands and Jack Skellington, is the subject of a major retrospective at MoMA, which showcases the art  including drawings, sculptures and photos  that he has been making throughout his career. Freaks, of course, are his main subject (keep your eye out for Stainboy, “a superhero whose only power is leaving stains”); the exhibit also includes screenings of his films, from “Batman” to early shorts like  “Frankenweenie.”

headline: Media Mogul’s Battle With Deutsche Bank Escalates
text: German prosecutors said Thursday that they had filed fraud charges against Rolf E. Breuer, the former chief executive and chairman of Deutsche Bank, the latest development in Leo Kirch’s legal battle with the bank over the collapse of his media empire.

headline: Panel Votes to Broaden Oversight of the Fed
text: In a display of populist anger toward the Federal Reserve, a House panel voted on Thursday to let Congress carry out sweeping new oversights of the central bank’s policy decisions and operations.

headline: Schottcast: Oulipo
text: Co-vocabularists may be interested to know that the promised broadcast on Oulipo is now available online here.

headline: Chegg Gets $57 Million in New Round
text: Chegg.com, the textbook rental site, has raised $57 million in a fourth round of financing.

headline: BigDeal Puts a New Spin on ‘Entertainment Shopping’

headline: Could Citi’s Bet on EMI Come Out All Right?
text: Citigroup stopped dancing to the music of the credit boom shortly after it backed the leveraged buyout of EMI, the British music company, in 2007.

headline: Ex-McKesson Chairman Is Found Guilty of Fraud
text: A federal jury found the former chairman of McKesson guilty of fraud on Thursday, nearly 10 years after he played a central role in a costly corporate accounting scandal, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Exterminate! Exterminate!
text: Maybe you were feeling a bit safer now that evil megalomaniacs were no longer running U.S. foreign policy. Wrong! Be afraid, be very afraid: Catherine Ashton, who will be the EU’s new foreign minister, has a full-size Dalek — a gift from her husband — in her sitting room.

headline: Haute Lips | Delfina Delettrez Earrings
text: You can literally put your money where your mouth is with these enamel, silver and gold Seven Sins earrings by the Rome-based jeweler Delfina Delettrez, who must have accessories in her blood. (She’s a fourth-generation Fendi.) Her work, with its gothic bent and unusual combinations of colors and materials, is often inspired by the human body, especially as it’s depicted in paintings by Giorgio de Chirico and the work of Andreas van Vessel, the 16th-century anatomist. The earrings are about $1,600 at Opening Ceremony, 35 Howard Street, or go to openingceremony.us.

headline: Can JPMorgan Guard Cazenove’s Culture?
text: After 185 years on its own and five in shared accommodations, Cazenove, the British stockbroker, is moving into the House of Morgan.

headline: ABN Amro Gets Another Cash Injection
text: The Netherlands government said Thursday that it would spend an additional 3 billion euros to clean up ABN Amro, as it sought to put the problems at the collapsed lender behind it, The New York Times’s David Jolly reported.

headline: Treasury to Auction Off Big-Bank Warrants
text: A year after the federal government rescued the nation’s financial industry, the Treasury Department announced Thursday that it would auction off its remaining investments in three large banks, freeing the lenders from the federal bailout program, The New York Times’s Eric Dash reported.

headline: AOL to Cut One-Third of Its Staff Ahead of Spin-Off
text: In recent years, amid the fallout from its audacious merger with Time Warner, AOL has steadily become smaller through subscriber desertions and rounds and rounds of layoffs.

headline: Fidelity Begins Tool for ‘Breakaway Brokers’
text: Fidelity Investments has begun a service to help retail brokers determine how profitable it would be for them to leave their brokerage house and hang out their own shingle.

headline: Wall Street Tax Must Be International, Pelosi Says
text: Any tax imposed on financial transactions would have to take effect internationally to prevent Wall Street jobs and related business from moving overseas, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Thursday.

headline: Investors Sew Up Deal for Skype
text: §EBay said on Thursday it had completed its sale of its Skype to a consortium of investors as it had vowed to do before the end of the year, Reuters reported.

headline: Mixed Day For I.P.O.’s
text: Investors proved to be selective as four United States-listed initial public offerings priced either below or at their expected ranges on Thursday evening, Reuters reported.

headline: G.E. and Vivendi Said to Be $1 Billion Apart on NBC
text: A report saying that Vivendi was holding for more money in its negotiations to sell its 20 percent stake in NBC Universal to majority owner General Electric left industry observers wondering just how far apart the two firms were on price.

headline: Burkle Said to Buy Barneys New York Debt
text: The supermarket mogul Ronald Burkle and his investment arm, Yucaipa, have purchased a large amount of the debt owed by Barneys New York, the luxury retail chain, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Goldman Investors Want a Bigger Slice of Profits
text: Some of Goldman Sachs‘s largest shareholders have asked the company to cut the size of its bonus pool and pass along more of its profits to investors, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline: Ferrero Said to Eye Gum Unit in Cadbury Bid
text: Ferrero, the Italian chocolate maker, could be interested in Cadbury‘s gum and candy division, a unit worth about 5 billion euros ($7.4 billion), in a possible joint takeover bid, Il Sole 24 Ore reported.

headline: Satchmo, Blacks and Jews
text: Today’s idea: Louis Armstrong’s memoir of a Jewish family includes blunt criticisms of blacks that are “startlingly contemporary in tone” and “the source of considerable disquiet among his admirers, many of whom prefer to ignore them altogether,” a biographer says.

headline: S.E.C. Told to Change How It Chooses Inquiries
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission must tighten its process for deciding which investment advisers to inspect if it is to avoid colossal breakdowns like the one that allowed Bernard L. Madoff’s multibillion-dollar fraud to go undetected for 16 years, the agency’s inspector general said.

headline: Harbinger Again Trims Stake in Times Company
text: Harbinger Capital Partners has once again trimmed its stake in The New York Times Company.

headline: Week 11 N.F.L. Matchups
text: Chargers (6-3) at Broncos (6-3)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Chargers by 1

headline: Gartmore Plans $412 Million I.P.O. Next Month
text: The Gartmore Group, which manages about ₤21.8 billion ($36 billion) in hedge and mutual funds, is preparing an initial public offering of at least ₤250 million next month to reduce debt, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Suicide Bomber Strikes Afghan Market, Killing at Least 15 People
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber on a motorcycle attacked a crowded marketplace in a relatively peaceful part of western Afghanistan on Friday, killing at least 15 people, while a well-known former warlord and member of Parliament narrowly survived an assassination attempt on the outskirts of Kabul.

headline: Sampler: The U.C. Fee Increase and Reactions
text: The Fee Increase | The University of California Board of Regents raised fees by 32 percent.

headline: Volkswagen Board Moves Closer to Porsche Merger
text: Volkswagen said on Friday that its supervisory board had approved certain agreement contracts for the planned merger with the German sportscar builder Porsche, taking the companies one step closer to completing the deal.

headline: At Reunion, a Look Back at the Way It Was
text: The friends share a combined 494 years of life, 45 grandchildren and, as they demonstrated Thursday morning in a Manhattan diner, a seemingly bottomless well of stories about the colorful bygone days of this city.

headline: The Uproar Over Mammography
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline: Lunch in Mumbai, Packed and Delivered
text: Among the wonders of Mumbai are the dabbawallas, deliverymen who ferry home-cooked meals — contained in multicompartment metal lunch boxes called tiffins — from residences to offices (and back) every day. It used to be that the meals would originate only with a mother, a grandmother or, perhaps, a wife. But with the startup of a handful of businesses catering to the tiffin crowd, the options have expanded.

headline: Belkin Recalls iPhone Accessories for Fire Risk
text: Belkin International is recalling about 241,000 of its TuneBase devices sold in the United States and Canada because of a risk of fire if they are left in the lighter plug too long, such as overnight.

headline: Awaiting Oprah’s Announcement
text: On Friday morning, Oprah Winfrey will make it official.

headline: The Early Word: Weekend Health Work
text: It looks like the Capitol will be open for a little more weekend business.

headline: Can Soldiers Be Victims of Terrorism?
text: On Thursday in Washington, as my colleague David Johnston reports, several legislators declared at a Senate hearing that the murder of 12 soldiers and a retired guardsman at Fort Hood this month was “a terrorist attack.” Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, who opened the hearing, said, “We will look at the Fort Hood murders not as an isolated event, but as part of a larger pattern of homegrown terrorism that has emerged over the past several years.”

headline: U.N. Report Calls for More Environmental Protection in Wartime
text: A report released this month by the United Nations Environment Program and the Environmental Law Institute calls for stronger international laws to protect the environment during times of war.

headline: The Morning Feed
text: What we’re reading on Friday morning.

headline: Your MetroCard May Be Sending You a Secret Message
text: As part of an unannounced public art project, seven million MetroCards distributed this fall had a single printed word on the back: “optimism.” The work itself is the creation of Reed Seifer, a graphic artist and designer who first printed “optimism” on small buttons that he distributed as a college student.

headline: Brush with Olympic Glory
text: The 2010 Winter Olympics don’t start until Feb. 12, but fans can bask in the torch glow of games past at several resorts offering close encounters with prior medalists.

headline: Gasol’s Return Lifts Lakers Back to Normal
text: LOS ANGELES— At times, the Lakers have looked less than championship caliber in starting their bid to repeat last year’s title. That changed Thursday evening when Pau Gasol reclaimed his spot in the starting lineup and picked up right where he had left off in the N.B.A. finals.

headline: FIFA Denies Ireland a Replay
text: Early Friday, FIFA issued a statement denying Ireland’s request for a replay of its World Cup qualifying match against France, in which Thierry Henry handled the ball seconds before William Gallas scored the winning goal.

headline: Taking Time Off: An Option for California University Students
text: How do you cope with a 32 percent increase in tuition?

headline: Ask About the Volt and Other Hybrid and Electric Vehicles
text: In this week’s Automobiles section, Lindsay Brooke writes about his experience driving a prototype version of the Chevrolet Volt. The hybrid Volt, which General Motors plans to begin selling in 2010, has been the focus of a great deal of interest as G.M. shifts its strategy to vehicles that are not primarily powered by internal combustion engines. The Volt can run on electricity alone for about 40 miles, according to the company. After that, it relies upon a gasoline engine to run a generator that provides electrical power to the batteries.

text: BOCHUM, Germany  European law-enforcement officials said Friday that they had arrested the leaders of a far-reaching gambling cartel that is thought to have conspired to influence the outcome of 200 soccer games in nine countries across the continent.

headline: Shares Finish Lower on Doubts About Recovery
text: The stock market finished slightly lower on Friday as investors worried about the speed of the economic recovery and questioned the fast rise of technology stocks.

headline: Senator Snowe Proposes Killing Her Own Loan Program
text: On Monday, with little fanfare, Senator Olympia Snowe of Maine introduced legislation to put the America’s Recovery Capital loan program out of its misery. Her legislation would repeal the program immediately, and return the unobligated balance of the original $255 million appropriation — as of Tuesday, $153 million, according to the Small Business Administration — back to the Treasury.

headline: U.C. Fee Increase: Is Taking a Year Off Prudent?
text: How do you cope with a 32 percent increase in university fees? That is the question Ron Lieber asks on The New York Times Bucks blog.

headline: ‘The Twilight Saga: New Moon': Juiceless or Juicebomb?
text: After months of anticipation, the day has finally arrived when eager moviegoers can see the film that A. O. Scott of The New York Times called “a film noir potboiler of jealousy and revenge” that “reveals an intricate and enigmatic structure, full of twists and reversals.” But enough about Pedro Almodóvar’s “Broken Embraces.”

headline: A Rear Axle Pitches in to Steer
text: ENGINES, transmissions, chassis controls and cockpit infotainment systems have all had their turns as the must-have features that brought shoppers into showrooms. Could it now be time for the lowly differential  a vital drivetrain part seen by few drivers and understood by even fewer  to shine?

headline: Graphic Books Best-Seller List
text: If there is one thing that pop-culture aficionados have learned over the past year, it’s that young women like stories about vampires. A lot. In that vein, the latest volume of “Vampire Knight,” a series aimed at female readers, tops our manga list this week. Created by Matsuri Hino, Vampire Knight follows the goings-on at Cross Academy, a school where the day class is composed of humans, and the night class is — yup — vampires. The series has always enjoyed a certain popularity, but with the fervor for “Twilight” now rivaling Beatlemania, more and more readers are discovering Ms. Hino’s take on undead teenage drama. (Speaking of which, how long will it be before there’s a graphic-novel adaptation of “Twilight”? Oh, wait — it’s already been announced. Whew!)

headline: Doctors Debate: Should City Aid Growth in Palliative Care?
text: Just how far should medicine go in turning death and dying into a growth industry?

headline: Sticking to Game Plan, Knicks Pass on Iverson
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Allen Iverson spent three days in the Knicks’ consciousness, without ever entering their locker room. He lingered long enough to stir extreme fits of intrigue and trepidation.

headline: For the Soul
text: A FEW truths existed in my house growing up: baseball games were worth watching only when the Yankees won, lateness was inexcusable, and the chicken soup from Second Avenue Deli was the best cure for a cold.

headline: Fears for the Future of the University of California
text: The University of California system has long been one of the gems of American education — a first-rate research university that was one of the most affordable in the country. But it’s future is uncertain, my colleague Tamar Lewin reports.

headline: Senator Reid and the Power of Persuasion
text: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, having unveiled the Senate health care bill now needs 60 votes to stave off a Republican filibuster and begin formal floor debate. That means getting all 58 Senate Democrats and the two independents on board for a vote set for Saturday evening. But even among the Democrats, Senators Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas, Ben Nelson of Nebraska and Mary Landrieu of Louisiana have been cagey about whether they will support the bill.

headline: Ohio Sues Rating Firms for Losses in Funds
text: Already facing a spate of private lawsuits, the legal troubles of the country’s largest credit rating agencies deepened on Friday when the attorney general of Ohio sued Moody’s Investors Service, Standard & Poor’s and Fitch, claiming that they had cost state retirement and pension funds some $457 million by approving high-risk Wall Street securities that went bust in the financial collapse.

headline: Complaint Box | Picky Eaters
text: Having friends over for dinner used to involve a minimal and fairly unremarkable to-do list: There were groceries to buy, along with flowers and a couple of bottles of semi-respectable wine. I would put out some guest towels and a collection of fancy soaps that were off limits to blood relatives, and then — voilà! — dinner was served. Preparing for a dinner party these days is far more complex, thanks to a vast and bewildering array of dietary needs that seem to have suddenly overtaken everyone I know.

headline: Far From Field, Lawyer’s Blog Is Player in N.F.L.
text: Mike Florio refuses to fly, so he drove 15 hours last January to his first Super Bowl.

headline: P.&G. May Slow Down Deal-Making, Financial Chief Says
text: Procter & Gamble does not see acquisitions as a core part of its growth plan and has started to buy back shares again, the consumer products conglomerate’s chief financial officer said on Friday.

headline: Wanderlust | Istanbul
text: The international style crowd recently descended upon Istanbul for a three-day fashion extravaganza. Powerhouse labels like Roberto Cavalli, Salavatore Ferragamo, Vivienne Westwood and Missoni staged shows with A-list models like Jessica Stam and Lily Donaldson, and there was even the requisite celebrity appearance — Bruce Willis at Missoni. Still, one of the highlights was a student show by young Turkish designers from the ISMEK and LaSalle fashion academies, including up-and-coming stars like like Sule Simsek Yalcin and Rabia Koyun.

headline: MetroCard as Art
text: The latest phase of Reed Seifer’s Project Optimism may not solve world hunger, or add much to the history of Conceptual Art. But it could brighten the mood of some New York City commuters – if they happen to look at the back of their MetroCards. This is a rarer occurrence than you might imagine, but give it a try. You may find the word “optimism” printed in sturdy black sans-serif lowercase letters, along with tinier blocks of type that say “Arts for Transit” and “Reed Seifer, Artist.” The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has put seven million such cards in circulation since September, with another seven million to come.

headline: UC Fee Hike: Shouts and Murmurs Outside Wheeler Hall
text: I am on the campus of the University of California at Berkeley, on the west side of Wheeler Hall, a building housing classrooms and lecture halls. Near me, one crowd of protesters, students and faculty are chanting and others are linking arms to form an ersatz picket line around the hall.

headline: A Bully at Age 4?
text: Periodically readers will leave comments on posts from weeks or months earlier. These usually arrive in the middle of the night, and I imagine the writer, unable to sleep, turning to the wisdom of the Web for advice.

headline: Jets Q. and A. With Greg Bishop
text: Greg Bishop, who covers the Jets for The Times, answered readers’ questions on Friday.

headline: Friday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused articles appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: A Tearful Winfrey Explains Her Departure
text: “After much prayer and months of careful thought, I’ve decided the next season, season 25, will be the last season of ‘The Oprah Winfrey Show,'” the talk show host said on her television program Friday morning.

headline: Buffett Cuts Sweet Deal for Burlington Northern Loan
text: It’s no surprise that Warren E. Buffett can command enviable terms when it comes to bank loans. That’s the case with the $8 billion he is borrowing to take over the rest of the railroad operator Burlington Northern Santa Fe for $26 billion.

text: Following is the third and final set of answers from Lorie A. Slutsky, president of the New York Community Trust, on community philanthropy, the value of many different approaches to charitable giving and their importance in maintaining a strong democracy.

headline: Putting the Bite on ‘Twilight’
text: Among the ancillary businesses that have benefited from Friday’s release of “New Moon”: cosmetics companies that make mascara and eyeliner; manufacturers of plastic vampire fangs; and comedians who have delighted in satirizing the franchise’s moody Pacific Northwest atmosphere and breathless dialogue.

headline: No Special Requests
text: On the City Room blog, a hostess who will be telling her Thanksgiving guests no special requests, unless you face anaphylactic shock.

headline: Andre Agassi’s Hate of the Game
text: Even those not convinced that Andre Agassi was the best tennis player of his time will readily admit he outdid all others in attracting attention, beginning in the 1980s, when he was a teenage phenom from Las Vegas who blazed onto the pro tour in flamboyant, Nike-­sponsored plumage — stone-washed denim, skintight “Hot Lava” compression shorts, midnight-at-the-roulette-wheel shades — that blinded many to the granite consistency of his game: the compact, bludgeoning ground strokes, the lethal service return, the lightning reflexes.

headline: A Conversation With Andre Agassi
text: The tennis great talks candidly about his life on and off the court with Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review.

headline: E.U. Takes More Time to Review Oracle-Sun Deal
text: European Union regulators said Friday that they have extended until Jan. 27 a deadline to wrap up their antitrust review of Oracle‘s planned $7.4 billion takeover of Sun Microsystems, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Now Online | T’s Winter Travel Issue
text: In the new winter issue of T: Travel, our sights are set on the beach. (It’s winter, where else?) First we head to Tobago for a fashion cover shoot and a glimpse of the slow (and sustainable) life on one of the Caribbean’s least known islands. Then we go to Miami for sand and surf with a heavy side of scene, before heading way south of the border for a look at the real Buenos Aires through its food. But don’t think we’ve forgotten the season’s cooler pleasures: we make a trip to the booming and beautiful ski town of Geilo, Norway, as well as to the tiny winter wonderland of Holland’s Friesland, before we end up closer to home amid the lovable wackiness of Baltimore.

headline: Ohio Sues Credit Rating Agencies
text: Update | 2:39 p.m.  The New York Times’s David Segal provides more details of the Ohio lawsuit.

headline: Haleh Esfandiari: Prisoner of Tehran
text: In 2007, Haleh Esfandiari, the Iranian-American director of the Woodrow Wilson Center’s Middle East Program, told Iranian intelligence everything she knew. She was interrogated for almost eight months, nearly four of them inside Tehran’s notorious Evin prison. During that time, she explained the institutional structure of the Wilson Center, identified its board members and described her work organizing conferences. She translated reams of material from the center’s Web site into Farsi. But it was a dialogue of the deaf.

headline: De Waart, Not Levine, to Conduct Remaining ‘Rosenkavaliers’
text: James Levine has relinquished the remaining performances of “Der Rosenkavalier” at the Metropolitan Opera. Mr. Levine, the Met’s music director, canceled the first half of the run in October while recovering from back surgery. He is currently rehearsing “Tales of Hoffman,” which opens on Dec. 3, but the Met said he did not have time to rehearse properly for “Der Rosenkavalier,” which re-emerges Jan. 1, 6, 9 and 15. Edo de Waart, who took over for Mr. Levine in the October “Rosenkavaliers,” will conduct those performances.

headline: Weekly Matchups: Digging Deep
text: This Saturday Florida is almost a seven-touchdown favorite against Florida International. Alabama is hosting Chattanooga, which isn’t even a F.B.S. team. There haven’t been any blockbuster matchups over the last few weeks and Ohio State-Michigan isn’t exactly getting anyone excited this weekend. (That No. 1 vs. No. 2 matchup from 2006 seem like a long time ago?) The top of the rankings saw lots of change over the first few weeks of the season (five top-five teams lost in the first four weeks), but the top of the rankings have been holding steady throughout November. People are getting bored.

headline: Interest rates: the phantom menace
text: From various bat squeaks I’ve put together a view of what I think lies behind the surprising — and damaging — deficit squeamishness of the Obama administration. So here’s what I think they’re thinking — and why it’s wrong-headed. (Fairly wonkish stuff after the jump).

headline: CF Claims 3 Seats on Terra’s Board

text: Jennifer Gilmore is the author of two novels, “Golden Country” and the forthcoming “Something Red.”

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: A Night of Squandered Leads and Shootouts
text: Eight games on Thursday, and only three ended in regulation. The wildest match of the night was played in Raleigh, a basement bowl between cellar-dwelling Carolina and Toronto. The two teams battled mightily trying to throw away the game, and in the end it was the Maple Leafs who succeeded. In throwing away the game, that is. Home teams listed first:

headline: Double Agency
text: The British edition of “Typhoon” came out one year ago. I was living in China then and ordered a copy from London. It never arrived, though the Royal Mail’s tracking system showed that it had made its way as far as a Beijing shipping depot. Did it disappear into the routine chaos of Chinese life? Was this a purposeful, pinpoint strike by Chinese censors who figured out that it raises touchy political questions about their country?

headline: The Boundaries of a Breakup
text: WHEN I broke up with my live-in girlfriend of five years, we divvied up our things, helped each other move into our new apartments, and then stopped seeing each other altogether  a cold-turkey breakup that I was sure was for the best. We didn’t send e-mail messages, call or meet for coffee, and we certainly didn’t go out for drinks.

headline: Word Made Flesh
text: Mary Gordon’s “Reading Jesus” — a book of questions for, quibbles with and tributes to the sometimes inscrutable protagonist of the Gospels — begins in a cab stuck in New York City traffic and ends with the Resurrection. Gordon, the author of over a dozen works of fiction, memoir and nonfiction, is taken aback by the smooth haranguing of a radio preacher (“There seems to be something slightly sexually perverse in the unctuousness,” she writes) and realizes that as familiar as she is with the Bible thanks to a Catholic upbringing and an adulthood as an engaged — if skeptical — believer, she has never read the four Gospels recording Jesus’ life in succession: first Matthew, then Mark, then Luke and finally the polished late­comer, John.

headline: Recipes for a Healthy Thanksgiving
text: Thanksgiving favorites can all be made in healthful, flavorful ways, as the columnist Martha Rose Shulman writes in this week’s Recipes for Health:

headline: Disaster Epic ‘2012’ Splits Earth and Audiences
text: We interrupt our wall-to-wall coverage of “Twilight” to revisit last weekend’s No. 1 movie, “2012,” the last offering from the disaster auteur Roland Emmerich.

headline: Study Says Air Cars Are Inefficient
text: There’s no question that people love the idea of compressed-air cars, which have long been under development by the French company Motor Development International and, according to a company spokesman, could be on American roads (after many delays) by 2012.

headline: Answers on Community Colleges, Part 5
text: Each day this week, the Guidance Office — the forum on The Choice where readers ask questions of education experts — is featuring answers about community colleges by Kay M. McClenney. Dr. McClenney is the director of the Center for Community College Student Engagement, a research and service initiative of the Community College Leadership Program at the University of Texas at Austin.

headline: Travel Deals: European Hotels From $74
text: For two days, more than 400 Best Western hotels throughout Europe and Egypt are offering rooms starting at 49 euros a night (about $74 at $1.50 to the euro), including breakfast. Family-size rooms and triple-occupancy rooms start at about $104 a night.

headline: Disturbing the Comfortable
text: What can you remember from “The Brothers Karamazov”? Perhaps you recall the rampages of the drunken, leering father; the outraged pride of Katerina Ivanovna; the reeking wake of the saintly Father Zosima; or (the grad student’s choice) the speech of the Grand Inquisitor. The mind’s retention of plotlines, even those from the pillars of the literary canon, is often selective and uncertain. But here’s a different question: What can’t you forget? One paragraph has haunted English readers ever since Constance Garnett translated the novel from the Russian in 1912. Grushenka, a passionate “fallen woman,” tells the tale of a wicked peasant who dies and is dragged by devils into a lake of fire. The peasant’s guardian angel tries to save her by telling God of the single good deed the woman performed in her lifetime: she once pulled an onion from her garden and gave it to a beggar. “Take that onion then,” God replies, “hold it out to her in the lake, and let her take hold.” If the onion doesn’t break, God continues, “let her come to Paradise.” But as the angel draws the peasant out, other sinners cling to her, seeking their own rescue, and she selfishly kicks them away. The onion breaks, and down she sinks. Dostoyevsky didn’t invent this anecdote; a peasant told it to him. Lessons like this sometimes seem to emerge whole from the Russian soil, but not every writer has the instincts to grab on and hold tight when they surface. Ludmilla Petrushevskaya does.

headline: Meeting Mr. Trump, and Paying the Price
text: Don’t mess with the Donald.

headline: My True Story
text: Finally, on the second-to-last page of his history of memoir, a tale packed from beginning to end with scandals, liars and cheats, Ben Yagoda asks the question we’ve been waiting for: How do we know when we’re being duped? The answer is almost worth the delay, even though it’s a quotation from nearly a half-century ago: Think of the memoirist “as a person to whom you have just been introduced,” a Times Book Review columnist named Raymond Walters Jr. wrote. “Size up as best you can the personality of the man or woman who is talking and take it constantly into consideration as you judge the truthfulness of what he has to say.”

headline: City Hall Budget Maneuver Quietly Encourages Job Cuts
text: Even as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg says that he is trying to avert laying off city workers, his aides have quietly encouraged such job cuts through an internal budget maneuver, according to city documents and interviews with those who have viewed them.

headline: What to Watch This Weekend: Bill Moyers, Taylor Swift and the Prospect of Oblivion
text: With events in Afghanistan in mind, Bill Moyers looks back at President Lyndon B. Johnson’s decision-making as he stepped up the American involvement in Vietnam on “Bill Moyers Journal” (PBS, 9 p.m. Friday on most stations). Mr. Moyers served Johnson as White House press secretary.

headline: Taking No Prisoners
text: Civil War generals usually come easily packaged: the brilliant, well-mannered Robert E. Lee, stoically erect, boots polished, a model of Southern manhood and elegant savagery; Ulysses S. Grant, also brilliant but a slouching product of the West, his boots unblacked, the faint smell of alcohol on his disheveled jacket, his manner taciturn, as if wearied by butchery and death. But the Tennessee-­born Confederate general Nathan Bedford Forrest is harder to characterize, for even to this day he is a controversial figure. Widely regarded as an intrepid military genius, albeit barely literate and without formal training, whose mantra was to “get there first with the most men,” Forrest was at the same time the millionaire slave-trader considered personally responsible for the criminal atrocities in April 1864 at Fort Pillow, where black soldiers attempting to surrender were summarily shot and others were said to be burned alive in their barracks.

headline: EconoQuiz
text: Welcome to another installment of EconoQuiz, a regular quiz on economics issues in the news.

headline: How My Father Looked
text: I think I have a way of finding out what my father looked like. Yes, finally! Excuse my excitement. My father died when I was very young, and to this day, I have never seen a picture of him. My search for his face goes back to when I lived in a refugee camp in eastern Sudan.

headline: What to Do With the Boat
text: Friends staying at our lakeside house found a small paddle boat washed up on our property and, thinking it was ours, tied it to our dock. It is not. We posted an announcement about it on the community bulletin board, but no one responded. The boat is damaged, and we think it was abandoned on purpose. Rather than incur the expense of disposing of it, my husband took it to the middle of the lake and cast it adrift. Should we be ashamed? NAME WITHHELD, MICHIGAN

headline: Return to Progress
text: In August Barack Obama sought to reassure his supporters as they contemplated a plunge in the opinion polls, a possible defeat on health care reform and the nagging worry that Obama, master of the poetry of campaigning, was getting stuck governing in prose. The president recalled that there had been similar panic in the ranks a year earlier, when Sarah Palin’s nomination had delivered a Republican spike and the November election seemed to be slipping out of reach. “Every­body was, you know, obsessed with it,” the president said. “ ‘Obama has lost his mojo’ — and cable TV was, 24 hours a day. Do you all remember that?”

headline: Siemens Chief Discusses Green Initiatives
text: Siemens is going through a rough patch.

headline: The Pain That Binds
text: Twisted Tree, Kent Meyers’s fictional small town, is in rodeo country, somewhere on the eastern perimeter of the Black Hills in South Dakota, where the “creased and broken” land is vast and veined by dirt roads. Drive past ranches and mud lakes and bone-filled buffalo jumps and you’ll spot the local bar, Ruination. The town’s inhabitants are still deeply haunted by the massacre at nearby Wounded Knee, and now, in Meyers’s impressive third novel, their grieving continues with the disappearance of Hayley Jo Zimmerman, a onetime barrel racing champion and one of the town’s young daughters.

headline: Muffins From Mr. Reid, but Mum’s the Word
text: It was sort of like the message on one of those T-shirts that children get after mom and dad come home from a glorious weekend in the Caribbean.

headline: Barnes & Noble’s Nook Sold Out for the Holidays
text: Update | 1:56 p.m.  Added comment from a Forrester analyst on the e-reader shortage.Update | 3:00 p.m.  Added comment from Amazon.com.

headline: A Jaundiced View
text: Is life worth living? The corny old answer, that it all depends on the liver, is one that Will Self, in this smart, beguiling and occasionally stomach-turning book of four linked stories, finds only partly adequate. Certainly his characters’ lives and livers are in very bad shape, but it would take more than a good detox, or even a transplant, to return them to health.

headline: Ethics Panel Admonishes Senator Burris
text: Updated: The Senate ethics committee on Friday issued a sternly worded rebuke to Senator Roland Burris of Illinois, saying he had made misleading and inaccurate statements about the circumstances surrounding his appointment by disgraced Governor Rod Blagojevich. But it made no recommendation for punishment.

headline: Into the West
text: President James K. Polk has languished in obscurity long enough to have become the subject of an amusing — and remarkably accurate — rock ’n’ roll song. “In four short years he met his every goal,” the alt-rock band They Might Be Giants sings in “James K. Polk,” which the group first released on an EP in 1990. The man secured the Oregon Territory, slashed tariffs, reformed the national banking system and seized “the whole Southwest from Mexico.” And yet, the song concludes, “precious few have mourned the passing of / Mr. James K. Polk, our 11th president / Young Hickory, Napoleon of the Stump.”

headline: Watch The Big Brawl on ‘Today’
text: Kim Severson and Julia Moskin took their long-running Thanksgiving battle over the importance of turkey versus side dishes to television this morning. Watch for Kim’s “blah, blah, blah” gesture as Julia makes her case, and see how convincingly they pretend there are no hard feelings at the end.

headline: A Soldier’s Story
text: As he explains more than once in “The Remains of Company D,” James Carl Nelson is “haunted,” haunted by the experiences of his grandfather and the other soldiers of Company D, 28th Infantry Regiment, First Division, on the Western Front in 1918. John Nelson spoke little of his past; after he died, his grandson, fascinated by fragments, set off in search of his ancestor’s war, which he maintains has been forgotten. Nelson’s devotion led him to official histories and archives, small-town newspaper accounts and private papers inherited by descendants of members of the regiment.

headline: Trying to Sell Your Business? Think Like a Buyer
text: I hate making analogies between selling a business and selling a house. It offends me on many levels, but nevertheless, here I go. I was watching an episode of “The Property Ladder” on the Learning Channel, and it got me thinking about preparing for sale. I watched home owners spend months filled with 16-hour days of hard labor, ripping out walls, installing cabinets and laying tile. Every decision — from paint color to countertops to flooring — was made with a buyer and an asking price in mind.

headline: Gibson Guitars Plant Is Raided
text: The chief executive of the Gibson Guitar company will take a leave of absence from an environmental group after a federal raid on the company’s factory in Nashville, The Tennessean reported. On Tuesday, The Tennessean reported, agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service served a search warrant on company officials at a Gibson manufacturing plant where its acoustic and electric guitars are made. The agents did not say what they were searching for or if anything was removed from the plant. But some hardwoods used in making premium guitars, like rosewood from the rain forests of Madagascar and Brazil, have recently been banned under a federal law called the Lacey Act because of environmental concerns. In a statement to The Tennessean, Gibson said that it was “fully cooperating with agents of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service as it pertains to an issue with harvested wood.” The Rainforest Alliance, a conservation group, said the Gibson chief executive, Henry Juszkiewicz, would not rejoin its board until the federal investigation ends.

headline: The Morning Skate: More on Twitter and Hockey
text: Because hockey does not receive anywhere near equal attention from most of the established media in the United States when compared to other major sports, it has consistently found a home in new and emerging media. When network TV lost its interest in the N.H.L., the league pioneered bringing major league sports to cable TV in the early ’80s (and the teams followed on regional sports cable networks). If fans found that their local newspaper sports sections contained little news of hockey, they increasingly sought that news on the Internet, beginning on Web sites and then blogs.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: MOONLIGHT IN ODESSA  By Janet Skeslien Charles.  Bloomsbury, $25.

headline: In Iraq, a Blunt Civilian Is a Fixture by the General’s Side
text: BAGHDAD  RARELY does the hulking commander of American forces in Iraq meet with Iraqis or go to a news conference without a slight, dark-haired woman standing just a little to one side  as if to give him space, but almost always in his line of sight and within earshot.

headline: Sony Ericsson’s Infinite Hope for a Turnaround
text: Bored with the buttons on your current phone and their limited functions?

headline: Senator Nelson Will Vote to Start Health Debate
text: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, and one of three members of his party who had expressed reservations about starting debate on the major health care legislation, has issued a statement saying that he will vote to bring the bill to the floor.

headline: Payard Returns (Again!); L.A. Burdick Chocolate Shop Arrives
text: Pastry-loving Upper East Siders who have been bereft since François Payard closed his patisserie and restaurant in June can satisfy their sweet tooth once more. Many of his specialties, including macarons, cookies and chocolates are available at Butterfield Market. His büche de Noël, a Christmas mainstay for years, will reappear in December. (Mr. Payard started selling a more limited line of sweets in the Mauboussin jewelry boutique on Madison Avenue a few weeks ago.)Butterfield Market: 1114 Lexington Avenue (78th Street); (212)-288-7800.

headline: Turkey vs. Sides on 'Today'
text: Kim Severson and Julia Moskin debate whether the turkey or the sides are more essential to Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: Measy: Your Personal Shopper for Cameras
text: If you’re having trouble figuring out which digital camera to buy—or just want a second opinion—take a look at a new Web site called Measy. This site helps you make purchasing decisions on digital cameras by asking a series of questions and then presenting you with three top choices and professional reviews culled from a range of online publications.

headline: How Can We Help the World’s Poor?
text: The number of bleeding hearts has soared exponentially over the last decade. Celebrities embraced Africa, while conservatives went from showing disdain for humanitarian aid (“money down a rat hole”) to displaying leadership in the fight against AIDS and malaria. Compassion became contagious and then it became consensus.

headline: The Beatles Stick It to Us
text: The ubiquitous, pocket-sized USB stick, in itself only one of several forms of digital storage devices, has quickly risen above the category of gadget. It is now an uber-gadget.

headline: Michigan Again Has Highest Jobless Rate
text: Fourteen states and the District of Columbia had a least a 10th of their labor force unemployed in October, with Michigan’s rate of 15.1 percent leading the nation, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: Can Meditation Curb Heart Attacks?
text: When Julia Banks was almost 70, she took up transcendental meditation. She had clogged arteries, high blood pressure and too much weight around the middle, and she enrolled in a clinical trial testing the benefits of meditation.

headline: City Moves to Restrict Front-Yard Driveways
text: The Department of City Planning has proposed regulations that would restrict certain homeowners from paving over their front yards to create parking spaces, a move that could alter the residential streetscape, especially in boroughs like Queens and Brooklyn. Responding to residents’ complaints of unsightly concrete driveways and lost street parking, the new rules would restrict so-called curb cuts — the sidewalk indentations created to allow cars to move from the street onto the front yards of houses — and tighten front-yard “planting” requirements. They would also require certain residential building owners to add parking if they modify their buildings. These changes are “key to fostering inviting, walkable blocks,” the city planning commissioner, Amanda M. Burden, said when she announced the proposed new rules on Monday. Like the PlaNYC and other recent Bloomberg administration initiatives, the rules hold the potential for making the city more pedestrian friendly and create more green spaces. But if approved, they would inhibit homeowners who want to carve out parking spaces on their own properties.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: WHAT THE DOG SAW: And Other Adventures, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) This selection of articles from The New Yorker offers plenty of the indefatigably curious Gladwell’s stock in trade: counterintuitive findings from little-known experts.

headline: ‘A Waffle Shortage’
text: Monologue |  Aired Thursday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: The reason our Speidi senses are tingling, Heidi Montag and Spencer Pratt will be here to talk about their new book. It is — I tell ya — it’s a major week for literature. Heidi and Spencer, Sarah Palin.

headline: ‘She’ll Sell Enough’
text: Monologue |  Aired Thursday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: President Obama said he probably won’t read Sarah Palin’s new book, because she’ll sell enough copies without him. Meanwhile, President Bush said he probably won’t read Sarah Palin’s book, because it’s a book.

headline: ‘The Country’s First’
text: Monologue |  Aired Thursday night on NBC: President Obama has lifted his ban on doing interviews with Fox News. Well, yesterday, President Obama was interviewed by a reporter from Fox News. Yeah. And you could tell the reporter was from Fox News because the first question was, “How do you think you’re doing as president on a scale from minus one to minus 10?”

headline: ‘Confusing and Clumsy’
text: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: Welcome to New York City. Beginning Monday, you know who’s going to be here? Khalid Sheikh Mohammed will be here. He’s going on trial. And the time that he’s in New York City, he’s going to be very busy. Monday, for example — Monday morning — he’ll be on the “Today Show,” singing “I Dreamed a Dream.” Very busy schedule.

headline:
Pacquiao-Cotto Bout
Was a Hit for HBO
text: Manny Pacquiao’s 12th-round technical knockout of Miguel Cotto in their welterweight title fight last Saturday night generated 1.25 million pay-per-view buys, with gross revenue of $70 million, HBO said Friday.

headline: BofA’s Ideal Chief: The One Who’s Leaving?
text: It is no secret that Bank of America‘s board is having a tough time finding just the right person to run the company after the chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, announced he was leaving his position at the end of the year.

headline: (Not) Accepting Defeat in Egypt and Ireland
text: Updated | Saturday | 9:38 a.m. International relations continued to suffer on Friday from the reverberations over two soccer matches played on Wednesday.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE WORLD IS WHAT IT IS,   (Vintage, $17.)French’s biography, one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2008, is “fully worthy of its subject, with all the dramatic pacing, the insight and the pathos of a first-rate novel,” our reviewer, George Packer, said. “It is also a portrait of the artist as a monster.” It describes the sadomasochistic triangle — physical with his mistress, emotional with his first wife — that nourished Naipaul for 25 years. InA Writer’s People.Ways of Looking and Feeling: An Essay in Five Parts(Vintage International, $15), Naipaul looks, both bracingly and grandiosely, at some of the writers who influenced him.

headline: ‘The Geezer Bandit’
text: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: One week ’til Thanksgiving. Very excited about that. Back in Washington, our Congressional leaders all preparing for the big Thanksgiving meal. I read today, Nancy Pelosi already taking her turkey in to have its neck tightened up.

text: We will probably have debates about older drivers for as long as we use cars.

text: Stephen King, who reviews Carol Sklenicka’s biography of Raymond Carver and Carver’s “Collected Stories” on this week’s cover, had read most of those stories by the mid-1990s.

headline: Familiar Faces Chasing Perps and Plots

headline: New Play About Muhammad Ali
text: As Broadway waits to see if a new play about Vince Lombardi takes flight next season, the McCarter Theater Center is announcing a world premiere production of a play about another sports legend, Muhammad Ali, starring Ben Vereen and Evan Parke.

headline: Hospital Falters as Refuge for Illegal Immigrants
text: ATLANTA  Each had crossed the border years before, smuggled across the desert by a coyote, never imagining the journey would lead to a drab and dusty clinic on the ninth floor of Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta.

headline: Ringo Starr Gets New Help From an Old Friend
text: Though they get together now only for Transcendental Meditation-themed concerts and Beatles Rock Band promotional events, Ringo Starr and Paul McCartney have recently reunited for an actual new piece of recorded music. Mr. Starr told The Guardian that Mr. McCartney, his long-ago band mate, provided bass and backing vocals for a song called “Walk With Me” that appears on Mr. Starr’s coming solo album, “Y Not.” When Mr. McCartney visited his home around the time of the Grammy Awards, Mr. Starr said, “I played him this other track and Paul said: ‘Give me the headphones. Give me a pair of cans.’ And he went to the mike, and he just invented that part where he follows on my vocal. That was all Paul McCartney, and there could be nothing better.” The song was written by Van Dyke Parks and Mr. Starr, who added that Mr. McCartney’s contribution “makes the song like a conversation between us, and that was Paul’s idea to do his part one beat behind me.” The two surviving Beatles previously recorded together on Mr. Starr’s 1998 album, “Vertical Man,” which also featured contributions from George Harrison and George Martin.

text: From our friends at the Wheels blog:

headline: Serving Up Rockers, Out of Their Shells
text: OWEN PALLETT, who makes music under the name Final Fantasy, has eaten brain stew in Morocco, vegan country-fried steak in Atlanta and bibimbap in more places than he can remember. “If you do your research, you can eat really well,” Mr. Pallett said recently on the phone from his tour bus in Washington State. The occasional misfire notwithstanding (he once ate ham with Arcade Fire in Texas that “tasted and smelled like a toilet puck”), he said good meals on the road vastly outnumber stomach turners.

headline: A Tangible Times API
text: Our series of posts about external uses of Times APIs continues. Today we’re highlighting Infractor, a tangible user interface for the Times Article Search API.

headline: Citizen Welles as Myth in the Making
text: RICHARD LINKLATER is keen to point out that his new film, “Me and Orson Welles,” is not a biopic. For starters, he said in a recent phone interview: “Biopics are the lamest genre. No one should attempt them anymore.”

headline: Must See: Ancient and Imperiled
text: Former poachers save sea turtle eggs, a financial adviser turns shaman and filmmakers capture Egypt, Lebanon and South Africa.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Chicken Soup?
text: Recently, in the midst of this swine-flu fearing fall, I found myself home sick for the day (like so many others) and my body ached with craving for, what else, chicken soup. At first I considered ordering the elixir from Second Avenue Deli, my childhood go-to, but then chose Russ & Daughters for its proximity to my East Village apartment.

headline: The View From the Summit: Holding a Symposium on China
text: Overview | What are the implications of China’s growing strength and global power? Regarding China, what should the Obama administration’s policies be? In this lesson, students develop their understanding of and knowledge about key issues in U.S.-China relations, and participate in a symposium on the subject. They then develop policy and diplomacy recommendations.

headline: The House of Tolstoy, in His Winter
text: “I FEEL that the attitude of people toward me is no longer an attitude toward a man but towards a celebrity,” Leo Tolstoy wrote in his diary. “Either complete devotion and confidence, or, on the contrary, repudiation and hatred.” Tolstoy’s harried words, and the ripe melodramas they promise, come to life in “The Last Station,” a new film about his turbulent final months before his death nearly a century ago.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Chicken Soup?

text: PARIS  Senior officials from Western powers discussed the possibility on Friday of new sanctions on Iran for flouting the United Nations Security Council’s demands and expressed disappointment that Iran had not yet accepted a draft agreement to export most of its enriched uranium for nuclear fuel.

headline: ‘New Moon’ Midnight Shows Take In $26.3 Million
text: The numbers are in: Summit Entertainment said its supernatural heartthrob thriller “The Twilight Saga: New Moon” took in an estimated $26.3 million at midnight shows on Thursday night. The total, from 3,514 theaters, set a record, topping the midnight shows for “Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince,” which had $22.2 million in late-night ticket sales, and “The Dark Knight,” which had $18.5 million.

headline: Living in Astoria
text: Astoria, Queens, would seem to have something for everyone: rentals galore, row houses and co-ops, new condominiums and a few Victorian houses; a quick commute to Manhattan, and close to every kind of food that civilization has put forth.

headline: Student Charged in Fire at Stuyvesant High
text: A 16-year-old junior has been arrested and charged with starting a fire at Stuyvesant High School in Lower Manhattan, one of nine small blazes set in the last week during school hours in trash cans, stairwells and paper towel dispensers. The authorities are still investigating whether he is connected to the others.

headline: Comment of the Week
text: If anybody still has the delusion that life is fair, just think of these two. To be paid big bucks for having so much fun, for so long. The only smidgen of justice is that we get to watch, listen  and laugh.

headline: Corrections

Schoenberg Collection.” It is the Getty Research Institute, not the J. Paul Getty Museum. (Both are located at the Getty Center.)
