Rowan Williams, the archbishop of Canterbury and spiritual leader of the Anglican Communion, the Vatican said in a statement.

headline: High-Tech Devices Help Drivers Put Down Phone
text: Dede Haskins’s cellphone has been her constant companion for more than a decade. And she has always considered herself a careful driver  even using a hands-free set so she could keep both hands on the wheel.

headline: For Martin, Finishing Second Wouldn’t Mean Falling Short
text: The final event in a relatively unspectacular 36-race Nascar Sprint Cup season is likely to amount to little more than a 267-lap parade Sunday in Homestead, Fla., with Jimmie Johnson almost certain to cruise to an unprecedented fourth consecutive series championship.

headline: Letters: The Archbishop’s Blog, Paying for The Times and Bloomberg’s Blowout
text: Re “The Archbishop’s Blog” (Nov. 8):The explanation for The Times’s refusal to publish Archbishop Timothy Dolan’s letter is lame and defensive, as is the rest of your column. Your argument seems to be that because The Times gave the archbishop a lot of coverage and said some nice things about him when he first came to New York that it can with impunity publish imbalanced and biased articles about the Catholic Church.Likewise, you seem to argue that because some of the religion writers for The Times sometimes write articles that are not considered offensive, this makes the offensive ones O.K. With respect to Maureen Dowd, it’s difficult to see how The Times sponsors her vitriolic diatribes in general. Her work is short on reason and logic but long on venom and distortion, hardly a contribution to serious public discussion. It’s no secret that The Times is steadily losing readership. Remaining in denial about its skewed coverage of the Catholic Church is just the latest example of how badly out of touch with reality the editors and writers for The Times continue to be. I suspect many will find your attempt to defend The Times’s record on this matter to be thoroughly unpersuasive.MSGR. MICHAEL FITZGERALDPhiladelphia, Nov. 8, 2009 ●I write as a Catholic nun who is a daily reader of The Times, and I agree with your conclusion that The Times does not have a pattern of anti-Catholicism. Maureen Dowd’s column on nuns and the Vatican was compatible with my “anger and anguish about the moral crisis” in the church. If any group in the U.S. Catholic Church should be investigated, it is the bishops who presided over the pattern of moving “troubled” priests from parish to parish without disclosure — to parishioners or legal authorities — of actions that potentially constituted sexual abuse and required investigation. In January 2006, The Times wrote an editorial praising a Detroit auxiliary bishop, Thomas Gumbleton, for his advocacy of improved public policies to deal with sexual abuse by priests and others. Subsequent to the publication of this editorial, local church leaders remarked that the supportive editorial was proof that The Times had an anti-Catholic bias. This reactionary critique causes me to infer that the accusation of anti-Catholic bias on the part of The Times is an example of the Catholic Church’s being defensive and protective of itself, not an objective assessment of the attitude of the newspaper. SISTER SUE SATTLER, I.H.M.Detroit, Nov. 8, 2009 ●The New York Times has no sympathy toward the Roman Catholic Church and, in fact, is institutionally predisposed to find fault with the church wherever and whenever it may be found.The Times does not value churchgoing Roman Catholics as part of its constituency; as a result, we are fair game. The core audience of The Times — secularists, atheists, members of certain politically left-leaning Christian and non-Christian denominations, all enjoy it immensely when The Times uses its pages to kick the church. Archbishop Dolan is correct — other faiths (and, I might add, certain other favored segments of society) — get a “bye” from the writers and editors of The Times. Who knows? Maybe the Times and its Catholic-baiting political and cultural allies will eventually hound us into shutting down our charities, closing our hospitals, ending our school system and walking away from our colleges. But life in New York and this nation would be much poorer for it.THOMAS J. RICE Manhattan, Nov. 10, 2009 ● I see nothing in Archbishop Dolan’s screed that claims the facts of the reporting were wrong. He’s just upset that the wrongs were reported. It is asked: “What is fair to report and criticize about the leadership of a religion?” Everything is fair to be reported — the good, the bad, and the ugly, as long as the reporting is accurate. Dolan says that Dowd dug “deep into the nativist handbook to use every anti-Catholic caricature possible.” Virtually every Catholic in the country opposed the nativist anti-Catholic assault of the 19th century, but today’s Catholics, on the other hand, support and praise the secular press coverage of the crimes and cover-up of the crimes of Catholic clergy — coverage that is almost totally absent in the Catholic press. Nothing is being reported today that the clergy has not brought on itself. For centuries the Catholic clergy has impressed on the laity the image of a clergy so superior that there slowly emerged the perception of a real ontological difference between the two. Accurate reporting in the secular press about sexual abuse, larcenous pastors stealing millions from their parishes, and now a Vatican investigation of our nuns is rightly tearing down this myth. B.M. BYRNEVienna, Va., Nov. 9, 2009 ● It is not surprising to me that the Catholic archbishop would see anti-Catholicism in the article by Maureen Dowd, coverage of the pedophilia scandal and other stories that didn’t reflect well on Catholics or the Catholic Church. The church is and always has been an authoritarian hierarchy. As such, it is able to prohibit dissent or criticism from members of its hierarchy and, to a great degree, members of its congregations. It is reasonable for an archbishop to conclude that if he can’t criticize, no one else should be allowed to either.In a secular, liberal democratic state, the cherished right of freedom of speech includes the right to criticize anybody and everybody. I hope these values persist for a long time to come. I have little hope that religions that depend on blind obedience will embrace them anytime soon.STEPHEN JONESVenice, Fla., Nov. 10, 2009 ● I’m an 84-year-old Catholic who has been reading The Times since I was 17. I cannot agree with Archbishop Dolan’s outrage over Maureen Dowd’s column on the attitude of the church toward nuns. Women are just as intelligent and responsible as men. Many of them occupy the top positions in American business and serve in growing numbers in both houses of Congress as well as presidential cabinets. Indeed, one female recently almost achieved the office of president. What’s next — ordained female priests?TERRY ROEWarminster, Pa., Nov. 9, 2009 ● ● Re “Recession, Revolution and a Leaner Times” (Nov. 1):Doubtless the decision about charging online readers is an important one, but seldom are important business decisions arrived at by following a clear consensus. More often, when one finds a clear business consensus, it is often proved wrong and/or late, like American auto companies’ decision to play down smaller, fuel-efficient cars. No, this is a tough decision that will accurately be made by leadership choosing a path or paths that may appear questionable at the outset, but may be recognized as visionary later.GARY SWAYZEManchester, Mass., Nov. 1, 2009 ●Come on, throw us a bone here — give those of us who care about The New York Times an opportunity to support it. How about a “We Love the NYT” coffee mug, an “All the News That’s Fit to Print” umbrella, an “Honorary Times Cub Reporter” T-shirt, a “Members Only” spot on the Web site — you name it, we’ll probably donate to get it.Like many Times supporters, my home page is The New York Times, and I read it (for free) every day. I send articles (for free) to friends and family by e-mail probably once a week. I get the Sunday Times delivered to my Toronto home but I can’t justify getting the paper (or any newspaper) every day. But I rely on the kind of reporting that no one but The New York Times is doing, and I’d be willing, even thrilled, to support it in the same way I support Minnesota Public Radio, which I listen to (for free) online. Just give me a premium or two and a convenient way to send a hundred bucks or so to keep this kind of journalism alive while it finds a new economic basis for survival.GERSHON SILINSToronto, Nov. 2, 2009 ● I am among those who hate seeing new organizations die by a thousand self-imposed cuts. At 39, I am on the younger end of the cohort that can’t live without newspapers. But my wife and I have already dropped our subscription to The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, our local daily, because it has so deconstructed itself that there’s no point in paying for it.After the last price increase by The Times, I reluctantly gave up the print edition for Times Reader. It was a difficult decision and a hard adjustment; I’d still prefer to handle an actual newspaper, but it made no sense to pay over $800 per year when I can pay $15 per month for the same content. It seems to me that there ought to be something in between. I’d obviously be willing to pay far more than $15 per month.I continue to believe that in the long run, the best model for a news organization will be that of a nonprofit, public-service organization. There will always be a readership, an increasingly small and specialized niche for newspapers, but the old business model will not last. In my opinion, The Times should essentially junk its junky free site and develop more along the polished, clean subscription service represented by Times Reader.DAVID TALLMANAtlanta, Nov. 2, 2009 ●Like other dedicated readers, I am worried. There is so much talk of newsroom cuts and elimination of bureaus and newspaper sections, I open the Sunday Times fearful that some section will be missing, or there will be some subtle change in the quality of the articles. Yesterday I was reminded that change and technological innovation will not necessarily lead to the demise of newspapers. I read The Times using the Times Reader for the first time and I was impressed by how easily I could work my way through in an efficient yet leisurely way — as a Sunday read ought to be. While nytimes.com is useful and a site I’ll continue to use, it’s very different from the experience of actually reading the (print-version) paper. I tend to jump about, depending on what grabs my attention, and I rarely get through the day’s news. And I find pop-up ads irritating. But why is there no advertising in the Times Reader version of the paper? Wouldn’t this be a perfect vehicle for print-style ads (NOT pop-ups!!)? The beauty of in-paper advertising is that it is seen, but if it is of no interest the reader can skip over and ignore it. It does not detract from the pleasure of reading the paper. Old-fashioned, perhaps, but effective. Surely there remain some advertisers out there who would see value in placing their messages here.CHERISSE BANDY Foster, R.I., Nov. 2, 2009 ●This morning, like every Sunday morning, I went out to the little coffee shop that charges $1 per cup for any size coffee, and picked up my New York Times. Five dollars for the paper is a lot of money for me at the moment — I am 69 years old, have been unemployed for almost a year, and things are very tight. However, not having the Sunday Times is like giving up a part of my history (I grew up in New York, and along with bagels and lox, The Times is Sunday morning), and giving up on the great tradition of print news. So, I pay my $5, buy cheaper food for the cat (just kidding) and enjoy the luxury of Sunday with the Times.Weekdays I mostly catch you online — and for the past few months I have been wondering why you do not charge at least a nominal fee for this service. I would be happy to pay it (I’ll tell the cat to eat cake) if that fee would guarantee that the print version of The Times would stay with us. Our country needs real journalists — those guys that hold the governments feet to the fire and protect our interests. I hope you do go ahead with charging for online service, and I hope again to see reporters playing bridge and working crossword puzzles.SHARON RESNICKPrinceton, N.J., Nov. 1, 2009 ●Why don’t you ask for voluntary contributions from online readers? I would be very glad to pay $300 per year. It is wonderful to read the paper here in Edmonton at the same time that someone in New York can. And many of your readers understand well how important investigative journalism is in keeping governments honest.BILL KELLY Edmonton, Alberta, Nov. 1, 2009 ●I am a faithful reader of The New York Times online, but if it were not free, I would not have become so faithful. I used to go to many different sites to get all the news. Now I start at your site and believe it is by far the best in the United States. My recommendation is to allow a one-year free subscription to new users. Then try to keep the yearly charge as low as possible to encourage the widest readership. Like the woman in your column, I have my credit card ready. STEVE MARTIN Seattle, Nov. 1, 2009 ●I encourage the debate on charging for The Times online, which The Wall Street Journal and The Economist are doing. But I have a problem if a subscription Web presence will still involve cookies and the related spying on my Web activity. I have debated this with people at The Times and The Economist.The Times suggests that the cookies make the Web “easier to use.” But there is nothing in the cookies I found that improves my Web experience; many of them are tracking cookies that allow someone to build a marketable profile of me.The argument in your column is that millions of online advertising dollars are at stake if charging for access reduces the number of viewers. That may be, but the advertisers should be aware that many Web users, like myself, do not allow cookies and work diligently to avoid any tracking. And a growing number of Web users are learning about tracking and how to block the intrusion into personal privacy.The decision to charge or not is, in my view, a decision on the long-term survival of The Times. I am concerned that in time the loss of print revenue will force the online version to support more and more of the paper’s operations. My larger concern is that the work of powerful newspapers — in keeping our governments and corporations in line with investigative reporting — will disappear without a decent revenue stream to pay the costs of such reporting. So I am willing to pay for access to a robust online New York Times, but I am not willing to surrender my privacy to get it.RAYMOND C. GRAYEaston, Pa., Nov. 1, 2009 ● ●Re “About That Bloomberg Runaway” (Nov. 15):  Your column suggests the correct and inescapable point that polls can serve as self-fulfilling prophecies, discouraging those who would otherwise vote if the polls were more promising for their candidates. The important point left out, however, is that pollsters should ask directly regarding the intensity of support for candidates, rather than relying on whether respondents may “change their minds.” That is a good question, but it is no substitute for also inquiring about how strongly poll respondents support specific candidates. If all polls asked about both the strength of support and the likelihood of voters’ changing their minds, fewer large disparities between poll support and election support would occur.RICHARD E. VATZTowson, Md., Nov. 15, 2009 The writer is a professor of political rhetoric at Towson University.

headline: Republicans Eye the Tiger of Populism

headline: In Chant, Listening and Singing Become One
text: Chant, the practice of intoning sounds or words rhythmically and repetitively, has been a staple of spiritual systems for millenniums. Owing to the popularity of recordings like the 1993 album “Chant” by the Benedictine monks of Santo Domingo de Silos in Spain, and Enigma’s 1990 crossover hit, “Sadeness (Part I),” which juxtaposed chant with a dance beat, Westerners have become familiar with Gregorian chant, the early Christian liturgical genre.

headline: High-Wire Act, Above the Clouds
text: For Damian Cooksey, a walk on Mount Tamalpais is a barefoot balancing act. Mr. Cooksey, 32, the owner of Bridges Rock Gym in El Cerrito, has broken world records in slacklining  a sport developed by rock climbers that resembles tightrope walking, except the line stretches and sways  and was the first person to walk a line directly across the top of Yosemite Falls. He lives with his wife in Berkeley.

headline: Bay Area Report Highlights for Sunday, Nov. 22
text: Cannabis Conundrum | Bay Area doctors have begun recommending that some teenage patients take marijuana to alleviate some of the tension and anxiety associated with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Doctors’ responses range from “How many ways can you say ‘One of the worst ideas of all time?’ ” to “It’s safer than aspirin.” A state assemblyman wants it stopped. Katherine Ellison has a detailed report on a latest battle in the medical marijuana wars.

headline: The Senate’s Duty on Climate
text: The news that world leaders have abandoned hope for a comprehensive, legally binding climate change treaty in Copenhagen next month inspired no end of finger-pointing. Environmentalists blamed eight years of inaction under George W. Bush. The Europeans noted that the Chinese and several other big developing nations had done little to move the ball forward.

headline: A Ban on Genetic Discrimination
text: It is rare when antidiscrimination law is extended to a whole new group of people, but that happened on Saturday, when a federal ban on discriminating on the basis of genetic background took effect. The new law is an important step in protecting people who have inherited a predisposition to disease. It removes a significant obstacle to genetic testing, which can help prevent and treat serious illnesses.

headline: Roll Your Own Tax Rate
text: There are no records kept on how fast loopholes can be uncovered in new federal law, but the roll-your-own tobacco industry is making a breathtaking run for this year’s shabby laurels. No sooner had President Obama signed the new children’s health insurance law last spring than the industry pried open a lucrative escape from the 20-fold tax increase levied on roll-your-own cigarettes to help support the program.

Last Sunday Liz Cheney praised “Going Rogue” as “well-written” on Fox News even though, by her own account, she had sampled only “parts” of it. headline: Advice From Grandma

You know what they say: Britain owned the 19th century, America owned the 20th century, and, it’s all but certain that China will own the 21st century. Maybe, but I’m not ready to cede the 21st century to China just yet.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about “Tings Dey Happen,” a solo show about Nigerian oil politics, misattributed a quotation about the show’s playwright, Dan Hoyle. It was a Nigerian militant, Williams Ajayi — not Mr. Hoyle — who said, “When he met me, it was like a light to his life,” noting the effect Mr. Hoyle had had on his life. The article also may have left the incorrect impression that the writer and Mr. Hoyle discussed Mr. Hoyle’s being reunited with Mr. Ajayi in Abuja, Nigeria’s capital, during his recent visit. The conversation the writer was referring to was a post-performance conversation the writer had with the audience.

headline: Khodorkovsky’s Rise and Fall
text: Once Russia’s richest man, Mikhail Khodorkovsky is now the country’s most famous prisoner.

headline: Postscript
text: The Quick Bite feature in some editions on Nov. 1 referred to the Silver Spoon, an upscale deli that moved to Oradell, N.J., from Ridgewood, N.J., in July. The deli is now closed. The owner was contacted on Oct. 26 to confirm information about the deli; he now says he closed it on Oct. 31.

headline: Role reversal
text: Many people on Wall Street are now warning that there’s a huge bubble in government debt, that interest rates will spike any day now; it’s a warning that clearly has the Obama administration’s ear. A good sample is this piece from Morgan Stanley, according to which “Our US economics team expects bond yields to rise to 5.5% by the end of 2010 – an increase of 220bp that outstrips the 137bp increase in the fed funds rate expected over the same horizon.”

headline: In Berlin, a Sexy, TV-Style Take on Mozart
text: Inside a former club in Berlin, “Così fan Tutte,” Mozart’s tale of complicated love and the fickleness of women, has gotten a TV-style treatment in the hands of the director Christoph Hagel. Warning: subtitled “Sex, Lies & TV,” this updating is not recommended for Mozart purists.

headline: Advocacy Groups May Reshape Message During Holidays
text: The Senate debate on health care, set to begin the week after Thanksgiving, is now on course to collide with the holiday season. One question for advocacy groups on all sides will be whether to keep up their barrage of pointed commercials, even as chestnuts roast and stockings are hung.

headline: The Magic Pen: Mozart Operas Up Close
text: SCHOLARS wishing to examine the manuscripts of the masters must expect to go out of their way, but since World War II several Mozart operas have required more effort than many other such treasures. Of the principal scores only two have come down in one piece: “Don Giovanni” in Paris and “The Magic Flute” in Berlin. The others are dispersed among various owners.

headline: Street Smart
text: Chalk it up to rising rents in the Miami Design District, or the proximity to the Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA), but the stretch of NE 125th Street between NE Seventh and Ninth Avenues has emerged as the latest hub for collectible midcentury design, earning it the nickname 20th-Century Row.

headline: Senator Lincoln Votes for Overhaul
text: Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas promised to vote in support of a health care overhaul but also warned that she would oppose the Democratic plan in its current form. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: The Path to the Final Bill
text: As the Senate opens the health care debate, the path to the final bill is not entirely clear. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Nastia Liukin | High Flier
text: Watching the gymnast Nastia Liukin dismount the uneven bars, you’re almost too busy counting the flips — was that five ? — to notice her daintily perfect landing. Raised in Texas by two Soviet gymnasts, Liukin, 20, dominated Beijing last year, where she won the all-around gold. She’s been cooling her pummeled heels lately, which doesn’t mean she’s traveling any less. This fall she visited London to blog from the world championships for USA Today, and she was in Copenhagen to promote Chicago’s Olympic bid. Despite her past successes, Liukin is already dreaming about victory in the 2012 London games. ‘‘Not that many people have really competed after they won their Olympic gold,’’ she says. ‘‘I want to achieve something that nobody’s ever done.’’

headline: The Sunday Word, Nov. 22
text: The votes are in and the debate is on. Again.

headline: On the Question of Gravy
text: I know I said I’d be back Monday. But Thanksgiving looms and the questions are piling up. People demand answers! Answers they shall have.

headline: Live Analysis: Giants Beat Falcons, 34-31, in Overtime
text: Writers and editors for The New York Times will provide live updates and analysis throughout the Giants’ game against the Atlanta Falcons at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Centrist Senators Say They Oppose Health Care Bill
text: The morning after voting to commence debate on ground-breaking health care legislation, two centrist senators, Ben Nelson and Joseph I. Lieberman, said on Sunday that they were opposed to the bill as it is currently written, particularly its inclusion of a new government-run insurance program.

headline: Timing Is Everything
text: Q.

headline: Kennedy Discouraged From Communion by Bishop
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Patrick J. Kennedy of Rhode Island said on Sunday that the Roman Catholic bishop of Providence had instructed him to refrain from receiving communion because of his stance on abortion.

headline: Democrats Step Up Push for Votes on Health Care
text: WASHINGTON  Anxious that Saturday’s party-line Senate vote to open debate on a health care overhaul gives them little maneuvering room, Obama administration officials and their Congressional allies are stepping up overtures to select Senate Republicans in hopes of winning their ultimate support.

headline: Weis Says His Firing Would Be Understandable
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  There are essentially 66 programs in the Bowl Championship Series, which allows them to be among the big-money players in college football. Sixty-five of those teams are in the six so-called power conferences. The other is Notre Dame, a football independent with a role in the B.C.S. contract as a nod to its history, allure and ability to move the ratings dial and fill seats at bowl games.

headline: Vile Heroes and High-Seas Swagger
text: The jacket copy for “Pirate Latitudes” states ambiguously that this book was “discovered as a complete manuscript in his files” after its author, Michael Crichton, died last year. Crichton was well known for putting his medical training (as the creator of the television series “ER”) and deep interest in science to expert dramatic use. He successfully used the prehistoric (“Jurassic Park”), contemporary (“Disclosure”) and future (“Next”) as storytelling fodder with equal ease. He was even given a dinosaur namesake (Crichtonsaurus bohlini). But the quaint, boyish, gee-whiz exploits that make up “Pirate Latitudes” were not hallmarks of his best work.

headline: Son Objects to Moving Camus’s Remains
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy wants to transfer the remains of the writer Albert Camus to one of the most hallowed burial places in France, but the plan has run into opposition from the Nobel laureate’s son, who does not think his father would have wanted the honor.

headline: In Small Details, a Day That Stunned the Nation
text: Forty-six years after the fact it sometimes seems as if Nov. 22, 1963, were only 26 seconds long. That is roughly the length of the Zapruder film, the home movie that captured the shooting of President John F. Kennedy better than any other known footage.

headline: Desperate Woman Times 3
text: A wife bereft over the loss of her infant son seeks carnal comfort in the embrace of a lover. A nun pines for a child she bore out of wedlock, a disgrace for which she was banished to a convent by her family. A young girl pleads with her father for permission to marry the man she loves. The heroines of Puccini’s three one-act operas collectively known as “Il Trittico” have little in common; small wonder that the parts are rarely played by a single performer.

headline: Shortage Slows a Program to Detect Nuclear Bombs
text: WASHINGTON  The Department of Homeland Security has spent $230 million to develop better technology for detecting smuggled nuclear bombs but has had to stop deploying the new machines because the United States has run out of a crucial raw material, experts say.

headline: ‘Twilight’ Dawns Bright at the Box Office
text: Jaws are dropping all over Hollywood: “The Twilight Saga: New Moon,” an inexpensive sequel from a three-year-old independent studio, sold a supernatural $140.7 million in tickets over the weekend in North American theaters.

So, a lot of the fear about a surge in interest rates seems to be motivated by supposed parallels to the situation in 1994, when there was a big spike in rates. Then as now there was a large “carry trade” motivated by the spread between long rates and short rates; when the long rate started to rise, there was a balance sheet squeeze that caused a stunning, albeit short-lived spike:

headline: Joke Europeans
text: I gather that this chart confuses people:

headline: Live Analysis: Patriots Beat Jets, 31-14
text: Writers and editors from The New York Times will be providing live analysis during the Jets’ game against the New England Patriots in Foxborough, Mass.

headline: Paging Henry Higgins
text: I’m in London, at a veddy intellectual conference sponsored by UCL, the New York Review of Books, and The Guardian. Actually, it has been a lovely event.

headline: Crowded Streets, Hidden Gems
text: English, written and spoken, is scarce in Flushing, Queens. What’s plentiful is good food, and even opportunities to slow down, if you know where to look.

headline: Garnett Beats Buzzer, and Celtics Beat the Knicks
text: Over the course of five days, the Knicks have slowly forged a new identity, of a team that can in fact shoot, defend and play hard to the final buzzer, which was essentially the script they followed Sunday.

headline: Amnesty List Puts Pressure on Pakistan Leader
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In another blow to Pakistan’s president, Asif Ali Zardari, the authorities this weekend released the names of politicians, many from his own party, who benefited from an amnesty decree that dismissed past alleged crimes.

headline: More Antarctic Ice Loss and a CO2toon
text: The East Antarctic Ice Sheet, long seen as the stable side of Antarctica’s vast lode of ice, appears to have been losing mass, particularly in coastal regions, over the past three years, according to a new analysis using gravity measurements. The finding is preliminary and comes with substantial uncertainty, the researchers reported in Nature Geoscience. But the research is generally consistent with other recent studies on ice loss in Antarctica and Greenland using surface and satellite measurements. What this portends for sea levels remains somewhat murky in the short run (by 2100) but very clear over the long haul, polar specialists largely agree.

headline: Camels, Claus, Nativity and Oh, Those Rockettes
text: If it’s a promotional cliché to say that “The Radio City Music Hall Christmas Spectacular” is part of New York’s holiday season tradition, it’s also a fact. Now beginning the 77th edition of its unique blend of Santa Claus, the Nativity and the Rockettes, the show continues to dazzle its gleeful audience.

headline: Man of the Match, or Tottenham’s Man of the Year?
text: London is a big town, but it would be hard to argue that anyone had a better day there Sunday than Jermain Defoe.

headline: Refugees From a Flop, Broadway Bound Again
text: The actress Jessica Hecht was full of mixed emotions as the curtain rose for one of the final Broadway performances of Neil Simon’s "Brighton Beach Memoirs" this fall.

headline: Those Amorous Lyrics, Borrowed From the Birds
text: The singer Ann Hampton Callaway wasn’t always the pop-blues wailer who brought the house to its feet on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, where the New York Pops orchestra celebrated the centennial of the songwriter Johnny Mercer. Her rendition of “Blues in the Night,” with a lusty full-bodied arrangement by Harold Wheeler, gave this lament by Mercer and Harold Arlen the kind of top-to-bottom vocal coverage that few singers have the technical resources to deliver.

headline: The Strategy of Angling for That Extra Trick
text: On Thursday I highlighted the need to bid cautiously in a match-pointed pair event; do not push aggressively for game. When you get to the card play, though, you should try to win as many tricks as possible (unless you are in a high-scoring contract that you expect the other pairs to miss).

headline: Reuniting Lost Relations, Leaving Time for Tears
text: In June ABC ordered a new show called “Let’s Dance,” based on a British reality series, in which celebrities would replicate famous dance routines. A programming executive said, “The tone of this is fun.” On Nov. 4 ABC announced that “Let’s Dance” would make its debut this Monday, following “Dancing With the Stars.” Five days later ABC changed its mind and canceled “Let’s Dance.”

headline: The John Henry Who Might Have Been
text: Most listeners accept it as a given that folk song has been a powerful influence on composers of art music, from the authors of the parody Masses of the 1500s through Haydn, Beethoven and Bartok to Aaron Copland and George Crumb. Often composers drawn to folk melodies either provide accompaniments in their own styles or simply allude to them, weaving strands of their musical DNA into larger structures.

headline: A Showman of the Organ Pulls Back the Curtain
text: Churches are mysterious places where you learn to take certain things on faith. And solo organ recitals can seem esoteric and forbidding to the uninitiated. But everything the organist Cameron Carpenter did during his concert at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin near Times Square on Saturday afternoon was meant to show his audience exactly what he was up to, without compromising the serious music he played.

headline: Supple Limbs in a Sea of Energy
text: Back when Complexions Contemporary Ballet was known as Complexions  A Concept in Dance, it wasn’t a given that the troupe would last. Now, 15 years later, the company, formed by Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson, two former Alvin Ailey dancers, is still thrashing, spinning and kicking along its merry way.

headline: Au Revoir to the Old, Bonjour to the New
text: PARIS  Brigitte Lefèvre, director of the Paris Opera Ballet, didn’t let the grass grow under her feet when Wayne McGregor was appointed resident choreographer of the Royal Ballet in 2006. The next year Mr. McGregor created “Genus” for the French company, and the piece has been performed this month on a triple bill that ran at almost the same time as a Covent Garden program featuring Mr. McGregor’s new “Limen.”

headline: A Stylistic and Geographic Traveler Savors His Homecoming
text: From one angle, the career of the saxophonist Steve Grossman might seem to have unfolded in reverse. He came onto the radar in 1969, playing state-of-the-art jazz-rock with Miles Davis; he was all of 18. From that sideman perch, among the most visible in jazz, he went on to play rugged, horizon-scanning postbop in the style of John Coltrane, notably with Coltrane’s former drummer Elvin Jones. Then came a more traditionalist stretch, followed by relative obscurity after he moved to Europe. Before his run at the Jazz Standard, which ended on Sunday, he hadn’t played a New York club in well over a decade.

headline: Michael Jackson’s Glove, Saint Laurent’s Umbrella Stand
text: Items from Elvis Presley and the Beatles were on the block, but Michael Jackson was the star of a New York auction on Saturday. Fans cheered as bids for the bejeweled glove he wore when he introduced his moonwalk dance in 1983 rose higher and higher, finally reaching $350,000 (before taxes and fees) in a sale held by Julien’s Auctions, The Associated Press reported. The glove had carried a high estimate of $60,000. But Hoffman Ma, who bought the rhinestone-studded golf glove on behalf of the Ponte 16 Resort Hotel in Macau, China, called the price “a fairly good discount.” ... Also going beyond the auctioneer’s expectations were artworks and furniture belonging to the fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent and his partner, Pierre Bergé, which raised $13.22 million on Friday, twice the amount estimated by Christie’s, Reuters reported. This was the second of two sales of items that used to decorate various properties owned by Saint Laurent and Mr. Bergé. The first, in February, raised almost $550 million, one of the biggest auctions Paris has seen. Among the surprise standouts in the recent auction was an umbrella stand from the couple’s Paris apartment that was estimated at $742 and sold for more than $160,000. All the proceeds went to an AIDS research charity.

headline: Dreamworks Looks ‘Under the Dome’
text: Steven Spielberg, right, and DreamWorks Television are teaming up with the author Stephen King, below right, to produce a limited series for cable based on Mr. King’s latest novel, “Under the Dome,” Variety reported. Mr. Spielberg will serve as executive producer for the supernatural thriller about locals at a Maine vacation spot who battle one another when a force field suddenly surrounds their town. Producers are in the process of finding a screenwriter, after which the series will be offered to prospective buyers. Mr. King and Mr. Spielberg worked together to develop a feature film based on “The Talisman,” Mr. King’s 1984 novel, but that project was postponed because of a lack of financing.

headline: Winnie Mandela, by Jennifer Hudson
text: Jennifer Hudson has been cast in the title role of “Winnie,” a film about Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, the activist and former wife of Nelson Mandela, Variety reported. The screenplay, based on a biography by Anne Marie du Preez Bezdrob, was written by André Pieterse, Paul L. Johnson, and Darrell J. Roodt, a South African filmmaker who will also direct. Production will begin in May in South African locations, including Robben Island, where Mr. Mandela spent 18 of his 27 years in prison. The film will cover not only Ms. Mandela’s fight against apartheid but also her convictions for kidnapping, fraud and theft. Ms. Hudson told Variety, “This is a powerful part of history that should be told.”

headline: Footnote
text: Nitro and Lace will be back, and in full-length feature form. According to Variety, Peter Iliff has been hired to write a live-action film based on “American Gladiators.” The script will incorporate characters adapted from the original television show, first broadcast in the 1980s, and turn them into superheroes. Scott Mednick and the “Gladiators” creator, Johnny Ferraro, are producing, with a release date anticipated in 2011.

headline: Will Ferrell Tops Most Overpaid List
text: Using box-office returns and salaries among several other factors, Forbes has compiled a list of the 10 most overpaid Hollywood stars in the last five years, and the winner (or loser) is the comic actor Will Ferrell, right. Forbes said Mr. Ferrell’s films earned an average of $3.29 for every dollar he was paid. Successes like “Elf” and “Talladega Nights” raised Mr. Ferrell’s compensation in the last few years, but high-budget flops like “Land of the Lost” (which earned back only $65 million of an estimated $100 million budget) have lowered the value of this former “Saturday Night Live” star. Rounding out the list were Ewan McGregor, Billy Bob Thornton, Eddie Murphy, Ice Cube, Tom Cruise, Drew Barrymore, Leonardo DiCaprio, Samuel L. Jackson and Jim Carrey. By comparison, Shia LaBeouf, who topped the Forbes list of “best actors for the buck,” released in August, earned $160 at the box office for every dollar he was paid.

headline: Testing the Chevrolet Volt
text: Chevrolet's flagship hybrid sedan is headed to the marketplace in nine months.

headline: Oxfam and Booksellers Agree to Plan
text: Oxfam, the international charity that earns about $32 million annually from sales of used books, is trying to address the concerns of private bookstore owners, who in September accused the nonprofit group of taking away their business. According to The Guardian, representatives from Oxfam, the Provincial Booksellers Fairs Association and the Antiquarian Booksellers Association all met to create a plan to help redirect business back to the local secondhand booksellers. Oxfam, saying that not all of its staff members were qualified to evaluate rare books, agreed to contact either association when a valuable collection was donated and request that a bookseller make an offer. That sum of money would then go to Oxfam, while the bookseller could place the books privately. “It cannot be expected that the plan will operate entirely smoothly and efficiently from the start, but it has been entered into in good faith as a way of defusing the ill feeling between the book trade and Oxfam which has been evident in recent months,” said Peter Moore, the Provincial Booksellers chairman.

headline: Justin Bieber Fans in Melee at a Mall
text: A Long Island mall appearance by the 15-year-old pop singer Justin Bieber, below, ended in minor injuries and one arrest after fans became unruly, The Associated Press reported. Some 3,000 people had gathered for the Friday afternoon event at the Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City, N.Y., but pushing and shoving broke out, and the police ordered the crowd to disperse. “People started screaming, ‘Justin!’ ” 13-year-old Aimee Macchi, who was knocked to the ground, told The A.P. “And they ran forward, and the ropes collapsed.” The news service said five people were sent to a hospital with minor injuries. James Roppo, a vice president of Island Def Jam Records, which is releasing Mr. Bieber’s first album, “My World,“ this week, was charged with endangering the welfare of children and obstructing governmental administration for refusing to send a Twitter message asking the crowd to disperse. Mr. Bieber posted his own Twitter message to fans, saying that the police would not allow him to enter the building, and that they had threatened to arrest him if he did not leave. Island Records later apologized to fans in a written statement.

headline: The Supremes and Others
text: Doesn’t have a point of view,Knows not where he’s going to,Isn’t he a bit like you and me?

headline: Neediest | A New Job and a New Outlook
text: Dion Lewis recently completed his green contracting certification with help from The Neediest Cases fund.  Formerly unemployed, Mr. Lewis now works helping others save energy and money.

headline: Heisman Watch: No One Separates From the Pack
text: Tim Tebow, Florida quarterback

headline: New CDs
text: RIHANNA “Rated R” (Def Jam)

headline: BMW X6 M
text: The BMW X6 M looks like what Batman would drive, if Batman drove a crossover S.U.V.

headline: Hopeful Divas Back Where It All Began
text: As befits a work about the essential art of repackaging in show business, “Dreamgirls” has known several distinct incarnations. First, there was the 1981 Broadway musical. Then came the 2006 movie. And now there is “Dreamgirls,” the comic strip, which opened Sunday night at the Apollo Theater in Harlem.

headline: Fastback Cars
text: The fastback look may seem new to some consumers, but its origins go back decades.

headline: Justice on Location
text: On a new television show, "Street Court," arguments are heard and disputes are settled where they occurred rather than in a courtroom.

headline: At SAS, Taking Care of Employees Is Good Business
text: SAS Institute, the largest privately held software company in the world, is also widely known as one of the best places to work.

headline: Iran’s Death Penalty Is Seen as a Political Tactic
text: CAIRO  A flurry of executions and death sentences in Iran has raised concern that the government is using judicially sanctioned killing to intimidate the political opposition and quell pockets of ethnic unrest around the nation, human rights groups and Iran experts said.

headline: Haves vs. Have-Nots at Public Universities
text: The University of California, which has already received $716 million in federal stimulus funds to offset a $1 billion budget gap, announced on Friday that it is raising student fees by 32 percent. That works out to about $2,500 per student a year.

headline: From Oregon to Pasadena
text: There will be a “Civil War” in Oregon to determine which Pac-10 team will play Ohio State in the Rose Bowl on Jan. 1.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Deal Will Turn a Los Angeles Hospital Private
text: LOS ANGELES  The role of public hospitals in America has been remarkably consistent over the decades, in spite of health care policy debates, insurance trends and shifting medical advice. They were centers of last resort, where the quality of care could be inconsistent and the finances often a disaster, but where the poor could always be served.

headline: In Philippines Strife, Uprooting Is a Constant
text: DATU PIANG, Philippines  For most refugees here, the long-running conflict between the Philippine government and Muslim separatists on the island of Mindanao has become such a part of their lives’ rhythms that they have lost track of how often fighting has displaced them.

headline: Coming Out for ‘Going Rogue’
text: On her book tour, Sarah Palin has skipped the big cities authors usually visit in favor of smaller places where she and Senator John McCain performed well on the presidential ticket.

headline: Konstantin Feoktistov, a Soviet Spacecraft Engineer, Dies at 83
text: MOSCOW  Konstantin P. Feoktistov, a Soviet engineer who was one of the first civilian astronauts and a prominent spacecraft designer, died on Saturday in Moscow, the Russian space agency said. He was 83.

headline: Cornhuskers Stand in Longhorns’ Way
text: Nebraska will probably be the last team with a chance to stop Texas from playing in the Bowl Championship Series title game.

headline: Analysis: Voting With Bombs
text: BAGHDAD — Terrorism in Iraq has become the continuation of politics by other means. That came into sharp relief with last month’s bombing of three government buildings here by two suicide truck bombers. It was probably no accident that they chose to strike as Iraq’s leaders bogged down on attempts to draft an election law.

headline: White House Pushes Science and Math Education
text: To improve science and mathematics education for American children, the White House is recruiting Elmo and Big Bird, video game programmers and thousands of scientists.

headline: In 3 Tacks for Afghan War, a Game of Trade-Offs
text: WASHINGTON  Should President Obama decide to send 40,000 additional American troops to Afghanistan, the most ambitious plan under consideration at the White House, the military would have enormous flexibility to deploy as many as 15,000 troops to the Taliban center of gravity in the south, 5,000 to the critical eastern border with Pakistan and 10,000 as trainers for the Afghan security forces.

headline: Patriots Crush Jets’ Slim Playoff Hopes
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Woody Johnson, the Jets’ owner, walked toward the visitors’ locker room Sunday night, his head shaking more vigorously with each step. Behind him came the Jets, a team Johnson has paid handsomely to win games instead of lose them.

headline: General Says Canada Fears for Afghans
text: OTTAWA  Canada’s top military officer said Sunday that on more than one occasion, Canada did not turn over Afghan prisoners to the Afghan government, fearing for their safety. The acknowledgment by the officer, Gen. Walter Natynczyk, the chief of the defense staff, appeared inconsistent with Canada’s assertions that such prisoners had not been tortured.

headline: Hunting for Turkeys, for the First Time
text: YAPHANK, N.Y.  At around 5:45 a.m., armed with a Mossberg 835 12-gauge shotgun painted in camouflage colors and his “sippy cup,” a travel mug full of coffee, John T. Rauh pulled his big red Ford F-250 out of the driveway, his Navy dog tags swinging from the rearview mirror.

headline: A Translator Tool With a Human Touch
text: HOW hard can it be, as the joke goes, to speak Chinese? (Six-year-olds do it all the time.)

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: How World War II Wasn’t Won
text: Easton, Pa.

headline: Hope for the Wrongfully Convicted
text: In a recent 79-page decision, a Manhattan judge could well have stopped after the first four sentences of his concluding paragraph and still conveyed his main point: that Fernando Bermudez was no longer guilty of murder.

headline: Supercomputing for the Masses
text: PORTLAND, Ore.  For decades, the world’s supercomputers have been the tightly guarded property of universities and governments. But what would happen if regular folks could get their hands on one?

headline: AOL Revamping Its Logo, Hoping to Revive the Brand
text: AOL is taking a cue from Boy George, hoping to improve its karma by becoming a chameleon.

headline: Apology Opens Wounds of British Migrant Program
text: LONDON  Laurie Humphreys, at least, had the advantage of being a teenager  if anything about being uprooted from family and homeland in 1940s Britain and sent 12,000 miles to brutal and often sexually abusive orphanages in western Australia could be called advantageous.

headline: Reliance Makes Bid for Chemical Giant
text: MUMBAI, India  Reliance Industries, the largest private company in India, said that it had made an offer to acquire a controlling interest in the world’s third-largest chemical company, LyondellBasell.

headline: Looking for a Leader in the Post-Oprah Landscape
text: There is no single replacement for Oprah Winfrey.

headline: Calming Sign of Troubled Past Appears in Modern Offices
text: To propel themselves through this economic downturn, media and advertising executives are turning to a phrase meant to soothe another troubled populace: the British during World War II.

headline: Popular Author’s Audiobook Tries a New Format: Vinyl
text: As physical formats and devices have shrunk, revenues for the audiobook industry have grown, since it is more convenient to listen to an iPod while exercising and commuting than fiddling with CDs. Digital downloads grew to 21 percent of the industry’s total sales in 2008, from 6 percent in 2004, according to the Audiobook Publishers Association.

headline: Brazil Elbows U.S. on the Diplomatic Stage
text: BRASÍLIA  Brazil’s ambitions to be a more important player on the global diplomatic stage are crashing headlong into the efforts of the United States and other Western powers to rein in Iran’s nuclear arms program.

headline: The Phantom Menace
text: A funny thing happened on the way to a new New Deal. A year ago, the only thing we had to fear was fear itself; today, the reigning doctrine in Washington appears to be “Be afraid. Be very afraid.”

headline: Pressure on Region’s House Democrats to Back Health Care Overhaul
text: Union-backed groups are pressuring a handful of renegade House Democrats from New York and New Jersey to back the party’s efforts to overhaul the health care system.

headline: Some Rivals Weigh Bids for Cadbury
text: The contest for Cadbury could become a little more crowded.

headline: How to Be an Acrobat Without Joining the Circus
text: Cypher Zero keeps the floors of his school covered with mats  from the ordinary gym variety to some that are as thick as a mattress  but years of experience have made him hypersensitive to the sound of a fall.

headline: A Few Tight Spots, but Johnson Wins Fourth Title
text: HOMESTEAD, Fla.  Denny Hamlin drove his Toyota to victory in the Ford 400 on Sunday, but it was Jimmie Johnson who sped into Nascar history, winning a record fourth straight Cup series championship by surviving the season finale with a fifth-place finish at the Homestead-Miami Speedway.

headline: They Chose Celebrity
text: Before the 2008 election, almost nobody outside Alaska and Arkansas had heard of Sarah Palin or Mike Huckabee. But in a long and crowded campaign season, they were the only Republican politicians who inspired any genuine enthusiasm.

headline: Wave of Debt Payments Facing U.S. Government
text: WASHINGTON — The United States government is financing its more than trillion-dollar-a-year borrowing with i.o.u.’s on terms that seem too good to be true.

headline: Terrorism Trial May Point Way for 9/11 Cases
text: Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, suspected of being a Qaeda terrorist, was captured in Pakistan in 2004, held in secret prisons run by the C.I.A. and then moved to the naval base at Guantánamo Bay. During about five years of detention, he says, he was confined in harsh conditions, abused during interrogation and denied a lawyer.

headline: Giants Win in Overtime to End Losing Streak at Four
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Perhaps the Giants should budget another half a billion dollars for their new stadium to top it with a retractable roof or a fixed dome.

headline: Toxic Waters:  Polluted Harbors
text: Aging sewer systems and urban storm runoff are two of the worst sources of water pollution in the United States.  In Newport, R.I., residents live with regular beach closings and sewage overflows.

headline: As Sewers Fill, Waste Poisons Waterways
text: It was drizzling lightly in late October when the midnight shift started at the Owls Head Water Pollution Control Plant, where much of Brooklyn’s sewage is treated.

headline: The Church and the Capital
text: Gay people will eventually win full civil rights  including the right to marry  throughout the United States. Between now and then, there will be many more disputes like the one unfolding between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington and the District of Columbia City Council over a bill recognizing same-sex marriages that could be voted on as soon as next week.

headline: In Chicago, Ex-Editor Fights Back
text: James E. O’Shea spent most of his career at The Chicago Tribune, but he was ousted from the Tribune Company in a highly publicized clash over staff cuts, and these days he’s finding plenty of fault with his old paper.

headline: Week 11: Giants Win in Overtime
text: After losing a 14-point lead in the fourth quarter, the Giants win on a 36-yard field goal.

headline: N.F.L. to Shift in Its Handling of Concussions
text: In a shift in the National Football League’s approach to handling concussions, the league will soon require teams to receive advice from independent neurologists while treating players with brain injuries, several people with knowledge of the plan confirmed Sunday.

headline: Concern at Governing Magazine Over Its Sale to Scientologists
text: Over the last several months, The St. Petersburg Times published a series of scathing articles on the Church of Scientology under the rubric “The Truth Rundown.” In 1980, the newspaper won a Pulitzer Prize for an investigation of the church’s inner workings.

headline: Under Scrutiny, Rangel Is Frayed but Defiant
text: WASHINGTON  On the House floor during a debate over health care reform, he taunted a colleague who had been calling for his ouster. At a recent fund-raiser, he complained that the House speaker had made an end run around him and his committee. Confronted by a persistent conservative activist in a hallway, he let loose an expletive, telling the man to mind his own business.

headline: Jets’ Sanchez Needs Time to Learn to Be an N.F.L. Quarterback
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

headline: A Triumph of Avoiding the Traps
text: When you look at Oprah Winfrey’s multidecade run through daytime talk  most of it at No. 1  it’s easy to be impressed by what she did to make it happen. But her longevity and success (Forbes estimated her net worth at over $2.3 billion) probably has more to do with what she did not do.

headline: Week 11: Patriots Avenge Loss to Jets
text: Another bad day for Mark Sanchez and another Jets defeat.

headline: Two Cafes Mean Competition in Crown Heights
text: The coffee clash of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, began with an innocuous blog post promoting the opening of a new cafe on Franklin Avenue last month. That caught the eye of another business opening about the same time just two blocks away on the same avenue  by coincidence, it happened to be another cafe.

headline: Bill Would Aid Relatives of 9/11 Immigrant Dead
text: Fourteen immigrants who were in the country illegally when their relatives were killed in the World Trade Center attacks are still waiting to gain permanent residency, and their lawyer said their tenuous immigration status could be imperiled if Congress does not act.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Consumer Reports Warns of Price Add-Ons
text: Consumer Reports has a love-hate relationship with the holiday shopping season. If you are determined to spend a month’s income on a stove, for example, it wants to help you find the best one. But the magazine would just as soon warn you off inflated prices, features you do not need, credit card interest, extended warranties  in other words, caution against spending too much.

headline: Executives Kept Wealth as Firms Failed, Study Says
text: Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers paid their executives largely in stock, and that stock lost most or all of its value when those companies collapsed.

headline: Feeding a Hunger for Skills, and Finding a Future
text: This year, the numbers of those feeling themselves among the neediest have stretched, like the wallets of the city itself. To the ranks of those who have needed food, or clothing, or a place to live, or a prosthetic limb, or an electric wheelchair, add Dion Lewis. He needed a job. He needed training he could not afford. He needed to have his daughter see him reach a goal by sheer, stubborn persistence.

headline: In Mississippi Delta, a Promising Summer Washed Away by the Fall
text: LEXINGTON, Miss.  It was a long day for John Hart, a farmer in the hills just east of the Mississippi Delta.

headline: Your Dot: On Science and ‘Cyber-Terrorism’
text: In the new tradition of Dot Earth in which readers’ contributions are occasionally brought out front, I’m introducing Raymond T. Pierrehumbert of the University of Chicago and the (hacked) RealClimate.org blog. His comment touches on issues raised by many readers of all stripes in the heated comment thread related to the emails and documents on climate extracted from the University of East Anglia:

headline: Police Fatally Shoot Armed Man, 18, Near Queens Park
text: An 18-year-old Queens man was fatally shot by the police late Saturday after he pointed a loaded pistol toward three plainclothes officers who were pursuing him, the authorities said.

headline: Toll in Chinese Mine Explosion Rises to 104
text: HONG KONG  A gas explosion at a coal mine in northeastern China early Saturday killed at least 104 people, China’s worst mine disaster in nearly two years, Chinese official media said Monday.

headline: After Bailout, the Haggling
text: So far, the United States has negotiated privately to sell back to banks the warrants it received in exchange for injected funds. Now it is starting an auction process to bring in a market price for a handful of companies’ warrants, including JPMorgan’s. It’s sensible, but the Treasury will probably still be criticized.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Friday about a House committee’s approval of a measure that would expand Congressional oversight of the Federal Reserve misidentified the state represented by Paul E. Kanjorski, who offered an amendment that would expand government power over large financial institutions. It is Pennsylvania, not Ohio.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a letter last Tuesday from former Representative James W. Symington of Missouri about solar wind propulsion referred incorrectly to his legislative position in 1992 when he helped lead a competition to design three spacecraft with solar sails for a journey to Mars. He was no longer in Congress, having served from 1969 to 1977. (The trip to Mars never occurred.)

headline: Cracking Down on Drunken Driving
text: The national effort to reduce death and injuries from drunken driving has received a major boost from New York State. Gov. David Paterson signed a law that made New York among the first states to make it a felony to drive while intoxicated with a child in the vehicle. The new law also made New York one of a dozen states to require all convicted drunken drivers to use an ignition interlock device that prevents them from driving their cars if they are drunk.

headline: GPS and Privacy Rights
text: A federal appeals court in Washington, D.C., heard arguments last week about whether police should have to get a warrant before putting a GPS device on a suspect’s car. It is a cutting-edge civil liberties question that has divided the courts that have considered it. GPS devices give the government extraordinary power to monitor people’s movements. The Washington court should rule that a warrant is required.

headline: Old Soldiers Never Cash Out
text: For all the stars of ranking generals and admirals in Washington, it turns out there’s still a higher grade  “senior mentor.” These are retired brass enjoying lucrative compensation as part-time Pentagon advisers, who, in most cases, also draw V.I.P. pay from companies seeking defense contracts. The mentor cohort has quietly grown in recent years from a handful to at least 158 ranking retired officers  80 percent of whom hire on at the same time with defense contractors.

headline: Does a Teacher Own the Lesson Plan?
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Outbreak of Leprosy
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Zero Tolerance’ in Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama and Jobs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Behind Cancer Guidelines, Quest for Data
text: A few years ago, an independent group that issues guidelines on cancer screening decided to review its recommendations for breast cancer. It had last issued guidelines in 2002, but things had changed  there was new science and researchers had become more sophisticated in analyzing existing data.

headline: Corrections
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Accounts, People & Miscellany
text: Accounts

headline: Catching Tuna and Hanging On for the Ride
text: YARMOUTH, Mass.  Dave Lamoureux’s kayak, named Fortitude, must be the only one in Massachusetts registered as a motor vessel. That’s because a powerboat registration is required to get a permit to fish for tuna here.

headline: The Influence of Zealous Employees
text: Companies are minisocieties, and employees can have impressions of a company that differ sharply from those of its potential customers. For the last decade or so, academics have suggested that companies try to shrink this gap, arguing that a company’s public image and its organizational culture should be similar.

headline: L.P.G.A. Tour’s Finale Suspended by Darkness
text: RICHMOND, Tex.  Darkness chased Lorena Ochoa off the golf course Sunday before she was through, but she was not done. After making a bogey on the penultimate hole of a second round she had waited two days to start, Ochoa headed straight to the practice green and putted for several minutes.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about turmoil within the United States Chamber of Commerce over its opposition to climate change legislation erroneously included one company among those that have resigned from the chamber over the climate policy. A spokeswoman for Levi Strauss & Company said that although the company had differed with the chamber over labor and the environment, the main issue over which the company resigned was trade, not climate policy. The article also misstated the year the company resigned. It was in 2001, not this fall.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about a national surplus of energy misidentified the position and company affiliation of Bill Johnson, a utility executive who said that utilities would have to build new generating stations to replace old ones that were wearing out. Mr. Johnson is president and chief executive of Progress Energy in Raleigh, N.C.  not a planning executive at Florida Power and Light.

headline: Opposing Claims Cloud the Debate on an Overhaul
text: Corrected | 8:09 p.m., Nov. 23  An earlier version of this article inaccurately reported the percent of the population that would have medical coverage under the Senate health care, if people age 65 and older were included in the calculation. That number would be 94 percent, not 98 percent. The reference has been corrected below. For a fuller discussion of the error, and its original source, read here.

headline: Fehr Is Giving the N.H.L.’s Union Advice and Hope
text: As it tries to emerge from months of dismissals, resignations and internal turmoil, the N.H.L. Players’ Association has called upon perhaps the only person with the credibility and experience to restore a sense of order to the troubled union: Donald Fehr, the departing executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association.

headline: Rusty Kanokogi, Fiery Advocate for Women’s Judo, Dies at 74
text: Rusty Kanokogi, considered the mother of women’s judo after fighting for more than two decades to make it an Olympic sport, died Saturday at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn. She was 74.

headline: Europe’s Bank Tightens Loan Rules
text: The European Central Bank on Friday tightened the rules for the collateral it accepts against loans as it prepares to unwind emergency liquidity measures.

headline: Fixing Wall Street’s Spin Problem
text: Lloyd C. Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, the bank to bash on a resurgent Wall Street, is receiving a lot of advice lately, and it’s not just about money, The New York Times’s Graham Bowley writes in the Week in Review.

headline: Revisiting a Fed Waltz With A.I.G.
text: A ray of sunlight broke through the Washington fog last week when Neil M. Barofsky (pictured), special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program, published his office’s report on the government bailout last year of the American International Group, The New York Times’s Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest Fair Game column.

headline: Dell Hymes, Linguist With a Wide Net, Dies at 82
text: Dell H. Hymes, a prominent anthropologist, linguist and folklorist whose work mined the rich, often overlooked territory where language and culture intersect, died on Nov. 13 in Charlottesville, Va. He was 82 and lived in Charlottesville.

headline: Goldman’s Non-Apology
text: “Certainly, our industry is responsible for things. We’re a leader in our industry, and we participated in things that were clearly wrong and we have reasons to regret and apologize for.”

headline: N.F.L.’s Division Leaders Have Come a Long Way in a Year
text: Schoolchildren are taught to try, try again. Maybe teachers should just show a weekly N.F.L. highlight reel to get the message across. The nine teams that entered Week 11 as the division leaders (Denver and San Diego were tied for first in the American Football Conference West) were a combined 63-18 (.778). That record was 22 wins better than the same nine teams’ records from a year ago at this time.

headline: Showcase: Emptied but Still Secret
text: Society can be judged as much by what it abandons as by what it builds.
