headline: Week 11 in Quotations: The Good, the Bad and the Hard to Believe
text: The words of the winners and the losers of Week 11, including some who saw things differently than the rest of us.

headline: Giants Open Thread: A Win, but What About the Defense?
text: Ernie Palladino has been a Giants beat writer since 1989 and is the only fully credentialed independent blogger covering them. He writes about the team at erniepalladinosgiantsbeat.blogspot.com.

headline: Wall Street Finds Profits by Reducing Mortgages
text: As millions of Americans struggle to hold on to their homes, Wall Street has found a way to make money from the mortgage mess, The New York Times’s Louise Story writes.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Another Win Puts Blackhawks in 2nd Over All
text: Only two games on Sunday, but both were important. Atlanta and Tampa Bay met to try to break the nine-team logjam surrounding eighth place in the East. In the West, Vancouver faced the Blackhawks, who had taken maximum points from their six previous games and suddenly emerged as the league’s third best side. Home teams listed first:

headline: G.E. and Vivendi Halt Talks Over Stake in NBC
text: Talks between General Electric and Vivendi over the future of NBC Universal have stalled, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin and Tim Arango reported on Saturday, citing people involved in the discussions who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were part of confidential negotiations.

headline: Obama Seeks Time for Policies to Take
text: President Obama’s scramble for a health care overhaul, like his dash across Asia last week, obscures an irony of his first year in office.

headline: Mauer Expected to Win M.V.P., but That’s the Least of the Twins’ Concerns
text: Monday afternoon’s scheduled announcement of the winner of the American League Most Valuable Player award comes with limited drama. The Baseball Writers Association of America guards the voting results judiciously. But if Joe Mauer of the Minnesota Twins beats out the Yankees’ Mark Teixeira and Derek Jeter for the award, industry observers will not be surprised.

headline: Test Your Knowledge of First Lady Inaugural Gowns
text: Do you remember what Jackie Kennedy wore to the inaugural ball in 1961? Who designed Hillary Clinton’s gowns? Take a quiz on the first ladies’ inaugural gowns.

headline: AOL's New Look
text: Although the AOL logo itself will be constant, the backgrounds of the brand's new ads will change continuously in an effort to suggest the breadth of AOL’s content.

headline: AOL's New Look: Headbanger
text: Although the AOL logo itself will be constant, the backgrounds will change continuously in an effort to suggest the breadth of AOL’s content.

headline: Obama Seeks Time for Policies to Take
text: President Obama’s scramble for a health care overhaul, like his dash across Asia last week, obscures an irony of his first year in office.

headline: Ciena Said to Win Nortel Unit for $769 Million
text: Ciena will buy Nortel Networks‘ optical networking and carrier ethernet business for $769 million after outbidding Nokia Siemens Networks in a three-day auction, Reuters reported Sunday, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Robinson’s Progress Continues to Work Backward
text: Nate Robinson made seven shots on Sunday, all of them in the correct basket. For that, the Knicks were grateful. Yet his performance was marred again by impulsiveness and immaturity — the same issues that have dogged Robinson throughout his career.

headline: Word of the Day | stodgy
text: stodgy • \ˈstä-je\ • adjective

headline: Real Salt Lake Wins M.L.S. Cup
text: SEATTLE  Robbie Russell, the 14th man to step into the box for penalty kicks, drilled a shot into the lower left corner of the goal, turned, fell to his knees and pumped his fists.

headline: News Quiz | November 23, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Bunch of Jerks
text: WHO are the Ranger$, the New Boyz, the Bangz, the Cold Flamez, the Rej3ctz and Audio Push?

headline: Did You See ‘New Moon’ Over the Weekend?
text: “Jaws are dropping all over Hollywood,” reports Brooks Barnes about the weekend ticket sales of “New Moon.” It now ranks as the third-biggest movie opening on record, and its success was largely driven by teenage girls.

headline: Chieftain Capital Said to Split Amid Conflicts
text: Chieftain Capital Management, an investment firm with about $3 billion in assets, is breaking up following a rift among its managers, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Deficit hysteria
text: Urg. Big piece on the front page saying that, on the one hand, some people say that we’re going to have a debt crisis any day now, while on the other hand … well, actually we never hear from the other side.

headline: Miami Art Museum
text: Images of the proposed design for the museum.

headline: Khmer Rouge Tribunal Enters Final Phase
text: BANGKOK  Closing arguments began Monday in Cambodia in the trial of the former Khmer Rouge prison chief who is accused of crimes against humanity in the deaths of more than 14,000 people in the Tuol Sleng prison and torture house.

headline: Do a Lot for Doolittle
text: Do what you can to get tickets to the Pixies at Hammerstein Ballroom this week. Even if you saw the pioneering indie band at one of their last reunion tours , this one, writes Ben Sisario, is different: they’ll be playing Doolittle in its entirety. “Released 20 years ago, it’s a spiky and allusive thing that packs anxious, violent, erotic, religious and silly ideas  visions of the surrealist horror-comedy ‘Un Chien Andalou,’ Old Testament vengeance, sexy girls  into tight, short blasts of pop,” he writes. Hit Craigslist if you have to.

headline: Cyber Monday Prep
text: It’s Thanksgiving week, and you know what that means: shopping. (Also eating yourself into oblivion. Ask Sam Sifton about that here.) For shopping advice, follow David Pogue’s tips, which is to say, convene with Mark Bittman and David Carr for pointers on cooking thermometers and e-books. (More stuff here.) And then pop by the pop-up Wired Store  where you can get all sorts of futuristic gadgets.

headline: Dad Humor
text: Need material for your family get-together? Go see Robin Williams at Town Hall this week. The comedian is sober now, and ready to laugh at his sensitive side, writes Dave Itzkoff. Need material for your esoteric hipster friends? Go see Billy the Mime, best-known for his silent but x-rated routine in “The Aristocrats” and the alter-ego of a writer for “SpongeBob SquarePants” who moonlights as a choreographer of shadows. He performs tonight only at the UCB.

headline: After the Bailout, the Haggling
text: So far, the United States has negotiated privately to sell back to banks the warrants it received in exchange for injected funds. Now it is starting an auction process to bring in a market price for a handful of companies’ warrants, including JPMorgan Chase’s. It’s sensible, but the Treasury will probably still be criticized, Breakingviews.com says.

headline: China Broker Takes Over Hong Kong House
text: Haitong Securities, one of the largest Chinese stock brokerage houses, announced Monday that it would take a controlling stake in Taifook Securities of Hong Kong for 1.82 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $235 million — the first time a mainland broker has acquired a Hong Kong peer.

headline: British Treasury Official to Join Rothschild
text: John Kingman, the chief executive of the agency that manages the British government’s bank shareholdings, is set to join Rothschild in March as managing director, the investment bank said on Monday.

headline: Reliance Makes Bid for Chemical Giant
text: Reliance Industries, the largest private company in India, has offered to acquire a controlling interest in the world’s third-largest chemical company, LyondellBasell.

headline: Executives Will Testify in Airbus Inquiry
text: One of highest-profile insider-trading inquiries in Europe in recent years will enter its final phase Monday as more than a dozen current and former executives of the aerospace group European Aeronautics Defense & Space and its Airbus subsidiary testify before a French regulator that is weighing more than 12 million euros ($18 million) in fines, The New York Times’s Nicola Clark reported.

headline: Execs Kept Wealth as Banks Failed, Study Says
text: Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers paid their executives largely in stock, and that stock lost most or all of its value when those companies collapsed.

headline: Thread Counts | Comment of the Week
text: Every week we comb through the comments on The Moment, Facebook and our Twitter @replies to bring you something clever from readers.

headline: ‘Dreamgirls’
text: Photos from the revival at the Apollo Theater.

headline: AOL Revamps Its Logo, Hoping to Revive Brand
text: AOL is taking a cue from Boy George, hoping to improve its karma by becoming a chameleon.

headline: Some Rivals Weigh Bids for Cadbury
text: The contest for Cadbury could become a little more crowded.

headline: Go Ahead and Yell. He’s Everyone’s Punching Bag.
text: Norman J. Radow brings out the worst in some people. They scream at him. They sue him. He has even been punched in the face.

headline: Lloyds Sees ‘Strong’ Demand in Bond Exchange
text: Lloyds Banking Group said it had agreed to swap £8.78 billion of bonds as part of a deal aimed at paying for its exit from a costly state-backed insurance scheme for bad debts.

headline: Microsoft and News Corp. Said to Weigh Web Pact
text: Update | 2:03 p.m. Media Decoder provides more details of the talks between the News Corporation and Microsoft.

headline: Rio to Pocket $741 Million From Cloud Peak I.P.O.
text: Rio Tinto, the global miner, expects to receive at least $741 million from the flotation of its U.S. coal-mining unit, Cloud Peak Energy, on the New York Stock Exchange, Rio said Monday.

headline: Princess Prevails in Pincus Dispute
text: After years of legal wrangling, Princess Firyal of Jordan has gained control of the huge duplex apartment owned by the late Lionel Pincus, the financier, on the 30th and 31st floors of the Pierre Hotel, facing Central Park at East 61st Street, The New York Times’s Josh Barbanel reported.

headline: Goldman’s Response to Questions About A.I.G.
text: This memo from a Goldman Sachs spokesman, Lucas van Praag, was sent to Gretchen Morgenson, a business columnist for The New York Times, in response to questions she asked about the report issued Nov. 17 by the special inspector general for the Troubled Asset Relief Program (referred to in the memo as SIGTARP) on the government’s September 2008 rescue of the American International Group, the giant insurance company. (The memo cites Ms. Morgenson’s questions in boldface.) To read Ms. Morgenson’s take on the report, see her latest Fair Game column.

headline: Saving on Art the Old-Fashioned Way
text: For those of you with a desire to collect art despite the recessionary pinch, here is a solution that doesn’t require dipping into your wallet. The Art Barter Event, an art fair where you can pay in imaginative goods and services rather than cash, is taking place at the Rag Factory (16-18 Heneage Street, E1 5LJ; 44-20-7650-8749; www.ragfactory.org.uk), a former studio on Brick Lane, from Nov. 27 to 29.

headline: 21 Reported Dead and 22 Missing in Mass Kidnapping Linked to Philippine Election
text: MANILA  In one of the worst episodes of election-related violence in the Philippines in recent memory, a group of more than 40 people  including lawyers, journalists and relatives of a local politician  were kidnapped by armed men on Monday, and military officials said at least 21 of them had been killed.

headline: Dimon Seen as Successor to Geithner, Report Says
text: Several United States policy makers consider JPMorgan Chase‘s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, as a potential successor to Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner, The New York Post reported, citing sources.

headline: Achtung, Do-Gooder
text: News Parody | The blog Aid Watch turns the tables on anti-poverty rocker:

headline: How Melancholy Sold a War Video Game
text: Today’s idea: The public’s deep ambivalence about America’s current wars seems reflected in a TV commercial for an Xbox 360 war game, featuring very unwarlike music. This is marketing to young men in the age of Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: Jets Open Thread: Was Ryan Right to Stay With Sanchez?
text: As the Jets’ season plods on, each loss seems to result in the pass-the-blame baton landing in the hands of a different player. Yesterday it returned to Mark Sanchez, who threw four interceptions five weeks after he threw five in a loss to the Bills.

headline: Gunfire and Bombs Kill 4 G.I.’s in 24 Hours
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Four United States soldiers died fighting in Afghanistan during a 24-hour period, NATO said Monday, as the Obama administration continued deliberations on increasing the number of American forces here.

headline: School Construction Critic Gets Prison Term in China
text: BEIJING  A lengthy prison sentence for a rights activist shows the determination of Chinese officials to suppress any vestige of dissent related to shoddy construction and unnecessary deaths in last year’s devastating earthquake in Sichuan Province, fellow activists said.

headline: BofA May Extend C.E.O. Search into 2010, Report Says
text: Bank of America may extend its search for a new chief executive into next year if its board is unable to pick a candidate in the next four days, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: Concern at Magazine Over Sale to Scientologists
text: Over the last several months, The St. Petersburg Times published a series of scathing articles on the Church of Scientology under the rubric “The Truth Rundown.” In 1980, the newspaper won a Pulitzer Prize for an investigation of the church’s inner workings.

headline: Ask Jay: Are You Giving Out Holiday Bonuses?
text: Dear Jay,

headline: Qatar Fund and Deutsche Bahn Ink Railroad Deal
text: An investment company owned by Qatar’s sovereign wealth fund has signed a $26 billion joint venture with Germany’s national railway operator to build a railroad network in the natural gas-rich Gulf sheikdom.

headline: Sampler: BART Police Video, Gas Emitters, San Jose Youth Violence
text: BART Force | BART officials held a news conference on Sunday after a YouTube video of an arrest of a passenger appeared to show a BART officer smashing the passenger against a glass window.

headline: Whatchamacallit?
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have been sharing the … you know? … the whassit … the doohicky … the gazingus.

headline: Rival Web Sites Share Thorny History
text: On July 20, 2006, Sheila Marcelo and Nick Beim flew from Boston to Chicago to visit a company called Sittercity. The business, which charged parents to access an online database of sitters and nannies, had been introduced in Boston five years earlier.

headline: A Friend’s Tweet Could Be an Ad
text: Tuesday was another typical day for John Chow, blogger and Internet entrepreneur in Vancouver, British Columbia. Mr. Chow treated his 50,000 Twitter followers to a photograph of his lunch (barbecued chicken and French fries), discussed the weather in Vancouver and linked to a new post on his Internet business blog.

headline: E.U. Steered to Strict Hedge Fund Rules
text: Top parliamentarian Jean-Paul Gauzès has written to members of an influential European Union committee recommending strict rules for hedge funds that clamp down on pay and borrowing, according to Reuters, which cited his report.

headline: What to Watch Monday: The End of Jon and Kate
text: In the last episode of “Jon and Kate Plus 8″ (TLC, 9 p.m.), Kate takes the brood to a dairy farm for a lesson in cow-milking and Jon takes them to a firehouse. Then the two of them talk about the “recent life events” that have made this the last episode of “Jon and Kate Plus 8.”

headline: Speed Read for Monday, Nov. 23
text: Here are some highlights from Monday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Recession Siphons a Small-Town Vibe
text: Many New Yorkers have not heard of Royal Ranch — an enclave of just five or six streets on a hill in the farthest reaches of northeastern Queens — and the residents like it that way.

headline: Brett Favre, M.V.P.?
text: Forget the off-season drama. Forget the in-season drama of the two meetings with Green Bay.

headline: Barclays in Talks to Sell P.E. Arm, Report Says
text: Barclays has revived talks to sell its £3 billion ($5 billion) private equity arm, The Daily Mail reported.

headline: G.M. Is Taking Taxpayers for a Ride
text: General Motors raised more than a few eyebrows last week by announcing plans to repay what it describes as $6.7 billion in outstanding loans to taxpayers. So provocative was this announcement that it all but overshadowed the real news of the day: G.M. had lost $1.2 billion since exiting bankruptcy in July, and its fourth-quarter results were expected to be worse.

headline: Oprah’s Business Savvy Deserves Serious Study
text: In his Media Equation column in Monday’s paper, David Carr takes a look at Oprah Winfrey’s singular record as a businesswoman.

text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: Submit Your Funny Caption
text: Let’s Have a Hand | Tell us what’s going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned images we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Carbon Price Insufficient for Green Revolution, Group Warns
text: Putting a price on carbon dioxide emissions will not be enough to drive the innovation needed to clean up dirty energy systems, according to Bruegel, a think tank based in Brussels, and Harvard economists.

headline: China Asks Its Banks to Slow Down
text: Chinese banking regulators are putting pressure on the country’s banks to raise more capital and temper their rapid growth in lending, in the clearest signs yet of official concern about the sustainability of the nation’s credit boom, senior Chinese bankers said Monday.

headline: Prisoner Swap Appears Near in the Mideast

headline: The Way We Ate: The Year Harry Truman Passed on Pumpkin Pie

headline: Some Cities See Rebate Money for Efficient Toilets Drying Up
text: Austin, Texas, has recently received requests for nearly 4,000 efficient toilets, costing nearly $800,000, according to The Austin American-Statesman. The toilets cut water use by 63 percent compared with 1980s models, and have resulted in a 1 percent drop in water usage, the city claims.

headline: An Unsurprising Slide for Obama
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama returned from his trip to Asia facing some unsettling news: two new public-opinion polls showing that his approval rating has dipped below 50 percent for the first time. To many of his critics, who chafed as Mr. Obama enjoyed broad support among Americans even though many were critical of his handling of specific issues like the economy, this erosion is a tipping-point, the end of Mr. Obama’s perceived near-invulnerability.

headline: Fighting Back, Rangel Still Gloomy

At a recent fund-raiser, he complained that the House speaker had made an end run around him and his committee. Confronted by a persistent conservative activist in a hallway, he let loose an expletive, telling the man to mind his own business.

headline: Proud to Be an American: Remembering the 2009 American Music Awards
text: How will history record the pageant that was the 37th annual American Music Awards? Will the event, which took place on Sunday night in Los Angeles, be best remembered as the night that Michael Jackson picked up four posthumous awards (including favorite male artist)? The evening when Taylor Swift‘s acceptances speeches went uninterrupted as she picked up five statuettes of her own (including artist of the year)? The moment when audiences were treated to formidable performances by Lady Gaga and Whitney Houston, and got to see Jermaine Jackson share the stage with his sons Jeremy, Jaafar and Jermajesty?

headline: Stellar Design | Astronomy Posters
text: Now that water has been found on the moon, it seems even more fitting that 2009 has officially been designated the International Year of Astronomy (who knew?). But let’s be honest: space’s heyday was the summer of ’69, when Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong brought a rugged, clean-cut appeal to the final frontier. It was perhaps with this in mind that Simon Page, a self-taught graphic designer, created a series of posters for the Year of Astronomy that are modeled on textbook covers of the ’60s and ’70s. The result is a beautiful exercise in conceptual minimalism, with a clear geometric bent that betrays Page’s math-nerd origins. (He has a degree in applied mathematics and took up graphic design as a hobby two years ago.) It’s hard to choose which to like best, but I’m particularly fond of the deep blue poster, below, in which Page uses diagonal lines to create interstellar objects in relief — and calls to mind the gentle descent of a meteor shower.

text: The restaurant synonymous with leafy hippie cooking has a new cookbook: “The Moosewood Restaurant Cooking for Health.” Those who remember the original “Moosewood Cookbook,” by the onetime collective member Mollie Katzen, will recall the charming hand lettering, whimsical illustrations and casual instructions (“Ok, so, you take four modest slices of good rye bread. …”). The new book, published by the Moosewood Collective (members run the famous vegetarian eatery in Ithaca, N.Y.), is slicker, more comprehensive and, true to its title, healthier. That means more kale and less cheese.

headline: ‘Let Me Down Easy’ Extends Its Run
text: Second Stage Theater said on Monday that it is extending its production of “Let Me Down Easy,” a one-woman show written and performed by Anna Deavere Smith, in which various characters deal with medical care and end-of-life issues in the United States. The play, which was scheduled to run through Dec. 6, has been extended by three weeks. It will not, however, be performed from Dec. 14 through 20 so that Ms. Smith can perform “Hymn” with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at New York City Center as she had previously planned. The run of “Let Me Down Easy” is now scheduled to run through Jan. 3.

headline: Suspension Improbable: Bulls Interfere With Tom Cruise-Cameron Diaz Film
text: Shooting on a new film starring Tom Cruise and Cameron Diaz was halted by a stampede — not of paparazzi, autograph seekers or moviegoers who want their “Vanilla Sky” tickets refunded, but of bulls that accidentally got loose on the set. The Associated Press reported that seven bulls broke free on Sunday during rehearsals in the Spanish city of Cadiz for a film called “Knight & Day.” Mr. Cruise and Ms. Diaz were not on the set at the time, but two women, whose names were not given, were injured as the bulls ran through the city’s streets to a nearby beach. The film’s director, Jose Luis Escolar, said that he did not know how the bulls escaped. A spokesman for the local government told The A.P. that production on “Knight & Day” has been suspended until further notice.

headline: Featured Recipe: Make-Ahead Gravy
text: Another way to get ahead (see this week’s Minimalist for 101 others) on Thanksgiving dinner is to make the gravy the night before. Start with a good strong stock, one you have made well in advance, preferably with roasted meat, a few aromatic vegetables and a bay leaf or two. Then make a roux, heating butter and flour together until they darken. Whisk the stock into the roux until it’s thick, then refrigerate. When you are ready to serve, just reheat it. Presto! Gravy without hassle.

Sure, baseball still has the Cubs  although their curse is arguably more of an incurable disease  but curses are sprouting up all over the N.F.L., usually transported by disgruntled, egomaniacal players whose arrivals should have been accompanied by something like an air raid warning.

headline: Waiting For The Reformers
text: My column today uses Sarah Palin and Mike Huckabee as a springboard to talk about how the Republican Party’s biggest problem, increasingly, is less a dearth of creative conservative policy ideas than a dearth of politicians interested in embracing them and selling them. And by “sensible policy ideas,” I don’t mean idiosyncratic notions cooked up by a couple of twentysomething journalists working at non-conservative publications; I mean politically plausible ideas being proposed by economists and think tankers with impeccable right-wing bona fides. If the Republicans were associated with, say, Michael Boskin’s stimulus ideas, Nicole Gelinas’s proposals for handling Wall Street, and some combination of the Miller-Capretta and Troy-Anderson health care plans, they would be a party worth taking seriously on domestic policy. But they aren’t, so they aren’t. And on this front, the wonks can only do so much: In the end, you need politicians capable of picking up policy ideas and running with them. That’s what the G.O.P. is waiting for. Hopefully it won’t have to wait forever.

headline: Monday Puzzle: Whimsical Ahas!
text: The Fall Classic is done, the Yankees are World Champs, Thanksgiving’s round the corner, the Babe’s in His Heaven and all’s right with the world! So for this short working week, we’re going to do some whimsical problems that require no deep mathematical concepts. After all, it’s not fair to tax our brains too heavily, when all our blood supply is being diverted to our turkey-laden stomachs, turning us too, temporarily, into turkeys. Whimsical though these problems are, when you do solve them, you’ll nevertheless experience the absolute certainty that is characteristic of the aha! experience we’ve discussed recently. “Of course that is the answer,” you’ll say. “There can be no doubt.” Like Helen Keller discovering language, or Einstein discovering relativity, you’ll need no external authority to validate your answer: you’ll just know it is right.

headline: Sales Using Food Stamps Double at Greenmarkets
text: Food stamp purchases at the city’s Greenmarkets have more than doubled in the last year, due in large part to publicity campaigns and the addition of more farmers’ markets to the program.

headline: Beef Encounters
text: Fellow Americans: there’s good news and bad regarding our national pastimes — eating, snacking and pigging out. The Samurai Shopper respects our constitutional entitlement to life, liberty and the pursuit of voluptuously stacked hamburgers, but those entitlements weigh heavily on us. Literally. Carnivores run amok may soon be unable to run at all. Though looming Golden Arches offer insuperable proof of American entrepreneurial genius, they don’t exactly symbolize quality or nourishment. And we’ve systematically shoved these nasty little buns down everyone’s throats: we are the burger kings. You’re welcome, Finland!

headline: The Genes of Our Fathers
text: At my son’s very first check-up I had to fill out a form with his family history. As I scanned through the questions about cancer and heart disease and diabetes, and did a mental inventory of his relatives and their medical imperfections, I felt a rising sense of guilt — these were the genes I had passed along to this perfect baby boy?

Every so often, one survives to tell the tale, confirming the fact that Hollywood is not only the home of people paid to be the center of attention; it’s also the capital of bad parenting. (Coincidence?)

President Obama, the official said, will announce the specific target “in coming days.”

headline: On Our Radar …

headline: The Voice That Helped Remake Culture
text: Louis Armstrong, a k a Satchmo, a k a Pops, was to music what Picasso was to painting, what Joyce was to fiction: an innovator who changed the face of his art form, a fecund and endlessly inventive pioneer whose discovery of his own voice helped remake 20th-century culture.

headline: Core Values
text: Despite a record-setting, recession-proof box office, the movie business has lost its middle. Blockbusters, based largely on toys and comic books, which can be turned into hugely lucrative franchises for the studios, have all but replaced movies aimed at a smaller and perhaps more discerning audience. In the recent past, the studios wanted their slates to contain all sorts of movies at different budgets, but today certain equations seem to dominate. Will the movie have a star attached? (Add $20 million to your cost.) Will it play around the world? (Add a no-English-necessary action component.) Will it appeal to the widest possible audience? (Meaning, males 18-49.)

headline: Football Upsets Increase Domestic Violence, Study Finds
text: Besides being a big day for eating, Thanksgiving is a big day for another American tradition: football-watching. A new working paper, however, makes this ritual a bit more ominous than turkey-stuffing.

headline: Generation Gap
text: Ten days after Don Fisher’s death, it was not just the presence of the man you could feel in his office but also the power of his simple idea. The picture window on the 15th floor of the Gap’s corporate headquarters opened onto a giant bow-and-arrow sculpture that Fisher and his wife had commissioned for Rincon Park as well as a million-dollar view of San Francisco Bay, where cargo ships as brightly colored as Gap T-shirts crossed under the Bay Bridge. His desk, an uncluttered Jules Leleu knockoff, was bare but for a phone, a mechanical pencil and a pad scribbled with lunch dates and unreturned calls. Also reclining there: an atypical wooden figure by Alexander Calder, circa 1928, the earliest piece in Fisher’s major collection of contemporary art. The founder of the largest American clothing company was as eager to make a competition of art expertise as he had been of the apparel business, and any visiting curator or sculpture maven could expect a pop quiz: who do you think made that? In 13 years, only two people had guessed correctly.

headline: G.O.P. Considers ‘Purity’ Resolution for Candidates
text: The battle among Republicans over what the party should stand for — and how much it should accommodate dissenting views on important issues — is probably going to move from the states to the Republican National Committee when it holds its winter meeting this January in Honolulu.

headline: Louis Armstrong in 2 Minutes, 53 Seconds
text: Louis Armstrong, “Dinah,” filmed on a sound stage in Denmark, 1933: a very early item in his filmography. This is a short and efficient answer for why he was and is important. You sense he’s building his brand — the stuff with the handkerchief, getting up in the viewer’s grill, popping his eyes at .55 — but it’s still pretty extreme, and exciting. Look at how he felt music, and moved to it. (Especially .10-.20, that davening kind of thing: James Brown did that too.) Listen to the way he chopped up rhythm, sailing his phrases over the beat. You want to say he’s imitating a trumpet when he sings, but then you want to say vice versa, so neither can be true. He’s continuous, playing or singing something nearly all the way through, making his body part of the performance.

headline: As Charter Slots Dwindle, Competition Increases
text: In Albany, issues tend to get shunted aside until the last possible moment. The challenges facing charter schools are no different. As advocates have pressed lawmakers to raise the cap — that is, the maximum number allowed, now 200 — many have said that the state is years away from reaching it, so no immediate action is needed.

headline: A Simple Thanksgiving With Alice Waters
text: In many Thanksgiving side dishes, it can be tough to recognize the original vegetable. Can you find green beans in that casserole buried under the mushroom soup and crispy onions? Would you like a little sweet potato with your brown sugar and marshmallows?

headline: When Is a Pizza Too Well Done?
text: At Always Hungry, Arthur Bovino pays his five bucks and assesses the state of the slice at the Brooklyn pizza temple Di Fara. He says, as Adam Kuban has noted, that the pies, particularly the ones used for slices, are often burned. Have you been lately? What do you think?

headline: Michael Feinstein and Dame Edna Find a Home Together
text: Though we’ve been misled by them in the past, we’re fairly certain that Michael Feinstein and Dame Edna Everage are telling the truth when they say they have found a Broadway theater for their coming stage collaboration, “All About Me.” On Monday, publicists for the production said that it would be performed at the Golden Theater, with previews to begin on Feb. 19 and an opening night set for March 18. That theater has recently been home to the revival of David Mamet‘s “Oleanna” (as well as “Avenue Q”), and was also where Mr. Feinstein performed his show “Michael Feinstein in Concert – Piano and Voice.” “All About Me” will be written by Christopher Durang and directed by Jerry Zaks.

headline: A Missed Chance for a Ruling on Poison Pills

headline: Two Fewer Celebrities to Attend ‘Fela!’ Opening

headline: Health Bill Revives Abortion Groups
