headline: Readers Weigh In on Picky Eaters
text: Susan Goldberg’s Complaint Box on the vast and bewildering array of dietary needs drew a deluge of more than 300 comments (the most ever for a Complaint Box). Some commiserated with her frustration, but others tsk-tsked her for being a less than gracious host. Many people with dietary restrictions explained how they tried not to impose; others offered strategies, whether through buffets or very simple recipes.

headline: A Push for Science and Technology Learning
text: President Obama devotes a fair amount of time to sports. He plays golf most weekends. He filled out his N.C.A.A. championship bracket for all ESPN viewers to see. And he carefully follows his hometown Chicago teams: the White Sox, the Bulls and the Bears.

headline: Required Reading | Argentine Soul Food
text: Two very different pieces of travel writing loom large in “Cocina Confidential,” Stephen Metcalf’s foodie adventure story from our winter travel issue. The first, “The Return of Eva Perón” by V.S. Naipaul, was written more than 30 years ago, but it’s still talked about in more introspective quarters of the Argentine capital — and not always with affection. “To Naipaul,” Metcalf writes, “Argentina was less a country than a staging ground for absurdist public traumas that never add up to an actual history. From dictatorship to hyperinflation to, more recently, the currency crisis, which plunged the economy into chaos in 2001, cataclysm seems to come naturally to Argentines.”

headline: A Critique of ‘Helicopter Parents’
text: The cover story in the latest issue of Time magazine is titled “The Case Against Over-Parenting. Why Mom and Dad need to cut the strings.” Its target is helicopter parents. In it, the author, Nancy Gibbs, argues for laissez-faire parenting — a “let them grow by letting go” method — while acknowledging that over-involvement can feel irresistible.

headline: Thanksgiving Questions: A Monday Speed Round
text: Hope you got your shopping in this weekend, friends. We’re coming up to the big event now. I’ll be on hand on Thursday morning for all your last-minute freak-outs and emergencies. In the meantime, let’s take a quick couple of questions from the in-box, dispatch them as if they were heritage birds. Later today, I’ll be back with some more: “On the Question of Pies” and the like. Keep hitting “refresh.”

headline: Bent Offerings
text: Pity the poor mum, which dare not show its face. And cast a smile upon the friendless carnation that’s been permanently sidelined to the Korean markets. These are flowers, along with the stalwart daisy and the lowly gladiola (“People associate them with funerals,” says Todd Rigby, the co-owner of VSF, a tiny, charming floral outpost on West 10th Street), whose time has come and gone. Enter the calla lily, which can go for $35 a stem, and cymbidium orchids, which go for $60 to $75 a stem, the presence of which has become de rigueur in all the best arrangements.

headline: The Morning Skate: Georges’s Innocent Dance, Isles Move Forward and Holy Jumpin’ Santa!
text: The N.H.L. will most likely suspend Canadiens tough guy Georges Laraque today after this sequence, the early season contender for Bad Shift of the Year….

headline: China Gains in U.S. Eyes, and India Feels Slights
text: NEW DELHI  The statement, on its surface, seemed like any other bland missive released at the end of a polite visit by a head of state. It was put out by the United States and China after President Obama’s visit there, and said that the two countries would “work together to promote peace, stability and development” in South Asia.

headline: News of Hockey, 11/23/09: Kelly’s New Job to Raise College Hockey’s Profile
text: Paul Kelly, dismissed as executive director of the N.H.L. Players’ Association last summer, will be introduced at a news conference at Harvard University on Tuesday as head of a new organization, College Hockey Inc. The organization will operate under the supervision of the Hockey Commissioners Association, a grouping of the major N.C.A.A. hockey leagues.

headline: Lighter Thanksgiving Desserts
text: Thanksgiving dinner is a runner’s delight, a meal packed with carbs followed by more carbs. But it’s the pies that always do me in. If you’re not drunk on food by the time you get to them, you will be afterwards. There’s no resisting them.

headline: Sanford’s Ethics Charges Revealed
text: South Carolina’s Ethics Commission on Monday released the details of more than three dozen ethics charges it has filed against Gov. Mark Sanford in the wake of his extramarital affair this year.

headline: Handy Airline Surcharge Charts
text: Confused about the surcharges that airlines are tacking on for Christmas and other popular travel days? Farecompare.com, an airline shopping site, has created a handy breakdown of the new fees by date, airline and amount.

headline: Chinese Drywall Linked to Corrosion
text: Federal investigators reported on Monday that a “strong association” exists between chemicals in Chinese drywall installed in thousands of homes during the housing boom and electrical problems in those homes.

headline: An Ex-Quarterback’s Take on Cutler’s Struggles
text: As the rift between the Denver Broncos’ rookie coach, Josh McDaniels, and his star quarterback, Jay Cutler, widened last off-season, more than a few executives in the N.F.L. suggested that McDaniels should make nice with Cutler for the good of the team. But McDaniels, it became clear, had something else in mind, and now we know why.

headline: For Search, Murdoch Eyes Deal With Microsoft
text: From Ashlee Vance and Tim Arango at Media Decoder:

headline: Police and YouTube: Responding to Arrest Videos
text: The above YouTube video (in which obscenities are shouted) is called “Officer breaks window with drunks face.” But it goes by other names, including “BART POLICE PUT MANS HEAD THROUGH WINDOW.”

headline: White House Begins Campaign to Promote Science and Math Education
text: To improve science and mathematics education for American children, the White House is recruiting Elmo and Big Bird, video game programmers and thousands of scientists.

headline: Game-Fixing Scandal Makes Many Poor Performances Suspect
text: PARIS  After F.C. Thun, a second-tier professional soccer club in Switzerland, was routed by 5-1 in April by a rival, Yverdon, officials were scratching their heads trying to figure out why their team had lost so badly.

headline: Iraq’s January Elections Face Near Certain Delay
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s tortuous effort to hold its parliamentary election on schedule in January collapsed Monday, raising the prospect of a political and constitutional crisis next year as the United States begins withdrawing the majority of its combat troops.

headline: Shattered Glass on New Bay Area Video
text: The sound of shattering glass is the most chilling part of a video that has surfaced on YouTube, the latest one to raise questions about the use of excessive force by the Bay Area transit system’s police officers.

headline: Russian Leader Expresses Support for Nonprofits
text: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev called Monday for tax incentives and other measures to assist Russia’s beleaguered nonprofit groups, which have come under government pressure in recent years.

headline: Home Fires: Life Lessons
text: I’m occasionally asked what I’ve learned from my experiences in the military.

headline: Global Warming Basics
text: The role of newspapers and journalists is evolving as technologies and media markets change. Along with providing conventional coverage of the news, blogging, video reports and the like, media outlets are increasingly providing basic background on important enduring issues. The Times has put more effort recently into enriching and updating what are called topics pages — basic backgrounders on issues in the news. I recently had a go at our page on global warming. Here’s the introduction and a link to the full page. It’s followed by the steady feed of news articles and accompanied by links to other background. Henceforth, it’ll be a “living document,” with more features, links and content added as needed. I encourage you to identify any gaps and glitches. Our editors will keep track of the comments.

headline: Global Warning
text: Why have you, a conservative senator from Oklahoma who has dismissed global warming as “a hoax,” announced that you plan to attend the United Nations Climate Change Conference, which opens in Copenhagen on Dec. 7 and seeks to reach a new agreement on limiting carbon emissions globally?  I don’t want a group of people to tell the people of Copenhagen that the United States is going to pass some kind of a cap-and-trade bill. I want to be there, if I’m a one-man truth squad, to say: “No, that isn’t true. They don’t have the votes. We’re not going to pass it.”

headline: How to Monitor Frequent-Flier Miles
text: I recently learned via a telephone call that my United Airlines frequent-flier miles were going to expire if I didn’t use some of them immediately.

headline: Cadillac Previews CTS Coupe Ahead of Los Angeles Auto Show
text: The on-again, off-again Cadillac CTS Coupe is back on again. Cadillac officially announced the 2011 model Monday morning, promising to show the car publicly — for sure, this time — next week at the Los Angeles auto show.

headline: James Berg, 65, Dies; Negotiated Labor Peace for City’s Landlords
text: James F. Berg, who as the chief negotiator for most of New York City’s major landlords was given large credit for an era of labor peace in their buildings because of the trust he inspired on both sides of the bargaining table, died Nov. 18 in Manhattan. He was 65 and lived in Bay Shore, N.Y.

headline: Carl Kasell to Retire as NPR Anchor
text: The renowned National Public Radio newscast anchor Carl Kasell will retire from the job at the end of the year, the organization said Monday. But Mr. Kasell will continue to keep score for NPR’s weekly quiz show “Wait, Wait… Don’t Tell Me!” as that program’s official judge.

headline: Feingold Picks Up ‘Fleece’ Mantle
text: Senator Russ Feingold on Monday launched a new “Spotlight on Spending” that recalled the long-running — and better-named — campaign against perceived government waste by an earlier maverick Democrat from Wisconsin, the late William Proxmire of “Golden Fleece” fame.

headline: Gov. Sanford Faces 37 Ethics Charges
text: Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina will face formal ethics charges on 37 counts of using his office for personal financial gain, according to a list of accusations issued Monday by the State Ethics Commission.

headline: Blame the Academy: Marc Shaiman Is Oscars’ Musical Director
text: If the coming Academy Awards show turns out to be teeming with original musical numbers or dirty sexual puns, now you’ll know who to thank or vilify. On Monday, the producers of the Oscars telecast said that Marc Shaiman, the composer and lyricist, would be the show’s musical director. Mr. Shaiman, whose credits include the musical versions of “Hairspray” and “Catch Me If You Can,” is an Oscars veteran, having previously served as musical director of the show in 2004 and written musical medleys (with his longtime collaborator Scott Wittman) performed by the host Billy Crystal.

headline: European Puck: K.H.L. Clubs Balk at Joining Revived Champions League
text: Tuesday is the deadline for European domestic leagues to inform the International Ice Hockey Federation whether they will participate in the 2010-11 Champions Hockey League, the revived competition featuring regular-season and playoff victors from the continent’s “Top 7″ hockey-playing nations.

headline: Some Rediscover the Benefits of Business Travel
text: When the economy collapsed last fall, many companies had to make some quick decisions about travel, typically one of the first areas they trim when finances are tight. Should they cut back as most of their competitors were, continue business as usual or spend even more to get a leg up?

headline: Stephen Colbert’s Wild Winter Olympic Ride Continues
text: First, Stephen Colbert got on board the United States Speedskating team’s bandwagon as a team sponsor and then on Sunday Colbert went for an actual ride: in a four-man bobsled down Lake Placid’s course at Mount Van Hoevenberg.

headline: More Rain for Britain After Floods
text: Parts of Great Britain and Ireland, already reeling from their worst flooding in decades, braced for more storms on Monday, as some residents were allowed back home to assess the damage of torrents that inundated streets, knocked out bridges and displaced hundreds of people.

headline: War on Illegal Guns, Fought on Two Fronts
text: Against a backdrop of recent shootings of innocent bystanders, including a 13-year-old boy from Queens and a 15-year-old girl from the Bronx, city officials and activists each did their part on Monday in their fight against gun violence, albeit in different ways and at different venues.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: 1) Democratic elections in developing countries usually improve economic policy — except when they’re not, uhh, democratic.

headline: An Italian Lesson for the Overstuffed
text: CONSIDER your stomach. No, not as it is now, in repose before the feast, awaiting the pleasures to come. Consider it as it will feel Thanksgiving evening, after the nibbles and noshes, the hors d’oeuvres, the sides and the turkey, the rolls, the stuffing, all that wine, the second helpings, the “oh, just a little more,” the pies, the cookies and, of course, the chocolates without which no meal would be complete.

headline: Seeking New Sensations
text: There are four prima dancers  or, at times, prima donnas  in the latest collaboration by the Israeli artists Lee Sher and Saar Harari. At the start of “Prima,” performed at Performance Space 122 on Thursday, Hsin-Yi Hsiang arched her back and pressed her hands into her ribcage. With her rear sticking out in stark exaggeration, she made her way toward the back of the darkened stage by wiggling her hips in a manner more ferocious than sensual. At times it was as if she were possessed by outside forces or aftershocks; in other moments she seemed to be going through the motions.

headline: Stray Questions for: Roberto Bolaño?!
text: The novelist Roberto Bolaño died in 2003. What follows is an excerpt from his last interview, published in Playboy Mexico the month of his death and now appearing in English in “Roberto Bolaño: The Last Interview & Other Conversations” (Melville House Publishing), which goes on sale tomorrow. The interview was conducted by Monica Maristain and translated by Sybil Perez. (It is also reprinted in the current issue of Stop Smiling, though not available online.)

headline: Not Your Mother’s Noodles
text: (Ed makes a pizzocheri like dish — starting with the noodles. –MB)Buckwheat noodles with cabbage have been no stranger to The Times (see here, for instance), and when my wife, Jackie, recently remembered that a Savoy cabbage and some leeks were languishing in the refrigerator, that was what came to mind. It was a chilly, rainy day. We’d walked through a pleasant drizzle for an hour and a half and had just climbed into a taxi with our shopping bags when the drizzle turned to a downpour and finding a cab suddenly became impossible for other people – cause for smug triumphalism and hearty appetite.

headline: Twitter May Seek I.P.O., but No Sale, Founder Says
text: Twitter, the social network built on 140-character musings, may eventually go to the stock market for financing, but it is currently ruling out a sale, Biz Stone, a founder, said on Monday.

headline: Mauer Is Nearly Unanimous as A.L. M.V.P.
text: Not surprisingly, Joe Mauer of the Minnesota Twins was named most valuable player of the American League on Monday. Two Yankees followed him in the final results: Mark Teixeira was second and Derek Jeter was third.

headline: Lost in the Mail
text: Depending on your sympathy for the bugle-beaded tragedies of what have become broadly known as Dreamgirls, the Marvelettes are either a big sigh or a windfall. It’s hard to believe, but many people have had all they can take hearing about talented young black women having their lives shredded by greedy record labels in the 1960s. The same people find spending an evening with the Beatles video game more sustaining than putting the Marvelettes’ new three-CD set “Forever” on the changer and snuggling down with Marc Taylor’s tell-all “The Original Marvelettes: Motown’s Mystery Girl Group.” I guess there’s no accounting for how people spend their Tuesday nights.

headline: Making Music Mightier Than the Sword
text: There should be dancing in the streets. When you leave the Eugene O’Neill Theater after a performance of “Fela!,” it comes as a shock that the people on the sidewalks are merely walking. Why aren’t they gyrating, swaying, vibrating, in thrall to the force field that you have been living in so ecstatically for the past couple of hours?

headline: Helping the Hungry: Researching the Causes of Hunger and Related Charities
text: Overview | What has caused an increase in hunger in the United States? How can individuals help to alleviate this growing problem? In this lesson, students consider the causes of rising hunger and use The New York Times to research the issue. The class then works together to choose a charitable organization and develop a fund-raising strategy.

headline: Foundation Tied to Iran Donated to Columbia
text: Several months before the Iranian president made a controversial appearance at Columbia University in 2007, the Alavi Foundation — a nonprofit organization that had long supported educational programs related to Islamic and Iranian culture at schools and universities — donated $100,000 to Columbia.

headline: The Choices Faced by UC, Students and the Public
text: Over at Room for Debate, there is a good discussion about public universities nationwide and the difficulty balancing fiscal responsibility and access to higher education.

headline: Audience and Box Office Drops at ‘God of Carnage’ as New Cast Takes Over
text: Carnage indeed.

headline: A Vision Faces an Environmental Test
text: MICHES, Dominican Republic  From a development perspective, this town has a few problems.

headline: Now Playing | A Piano Bar Grows in Brooklyn
text: Uptowners have Bemelmans. Marie’s Crisis, in the West Village, caters to a gay crowd. But what about the Brooklyn hipsters? Now they have the Manhattan Inn, a new old-timey piano bar on Manhattan Avenue opened by Brooke Baxter and Rolyn Hu, the ladies who started Glasslands Gallery on Kent Avenue in 2006. But the Manhattan Inn is different. “It’s a little older crowd,” says Hu, “maybe looking to have a quieter night.” Instead of a massive art loft rocked by guitars and gritty marching bands, an intimate front bar opens to a larger back room, where, under a skylight and a chandelier, a lily-white baby grand — courtesy of Craigslist — awaits its player.

headline: All Those Lonely Souls, Each Under the Same Night Sky
text: If this is what a disaster looks like, bring on the apocalypse. The early word on “The Starry Messenger,” the new play by Kenneth Lonergan, was so appalling it seemed that instant euthanasia would be in order. The theater chat rooms were dense with complaints about the production’s excessive length, sloppy acting and fuzzy focus. Mr. Lonergan was reported to be overwhelmed by the unfamiliar task of directing his own work and changing the script daily. And the show’s star, Matthew Broderick, made headlines for not being able to remember his lines.

headline: How to Help a Baby With Colic
text: When we last heard from Kristina and Evan, they had just moved to a new town and were expecting their first child. Kristina wrote to Motherlode asking readers to share advice for a new parent, and you responded in force. (The collection of comments is a treasure trove for any new parent.)

headline: Politics and Clan Warfare in the Philippines
text: Update | Tuesday | 12:41 p.m. As my colleague Carlos Conde reports from the Philippines, the death toll in a massacre there on Monday has risen to 46, as the remains of more victims were discovered on Tuesday.

headline: The Dangers of Taking a Dip in the Hot Tub
text: A hot tub might not seem an especially dangerous place, but over a period of 18 years, 1990-2007, more than 80,000 people were injured in hot tubs or whirlpools seriously enough to wind up in an emergency room. Almost 74 percent of the injuries occurred at home.

headline: Salon Starts a Food Section
text: As the world of food journalism in print shrinks, online efforts grow. First The Atlantic expanded its culinary coverage with its online food channel.

headline: Norway Fires Peter Mueller as Speedskating Coach
text: Peter Mueller, who won a gold medal in the 1976 Olympics and went on to coach American skaters like Bonnie Blair and Dan Jansen to Olympic medals, was fired by Norway as its national speedskating coach on Monday after one of its skaters accused him of sexual harassment. It was startling for the timing — the Games begin in less than three months — and because Mueller was widely hailed for resurrecting a slumping program over the past six years.

headline: Opel Reopens German Debate Over Aid
text: As executives of General Motors met Monday with European officials to ask for financial help in restructuring its struggling auto operations on the Continent, Germany reopened a bitter public debate over state aid and job protections that has sharply divided its government, Judy Dempsey of The New York Times reports from Berlin.

headline: Toll in Chinese Mine Explosion Rises to 104
text: HONG KONG  A gas explosion at a coal mine in northeastern China early Saturday killed at least 104 people, China’s worst mine disaster in nearly two years, Chinese official media said Monday.

headline: Robinson’s Wrong-Basket Swish Would Not Have Counted
text: Much outrage has been spent and many brows furrowed over Nate Robinson’s bizarre decision to shoot at the wrong basket during the Knicks game against the Nets on Saturday. But it appears that the Knicks’ greatest concern -– that he might have scored 3 points for the Nets -– is misplaced.

headline: Dominican Town Explores Ecotourism
text: In the Dominican Republic, a small town long troubled by poverty is fighting to hold onto its beaches and transform them into a low-key, environmentally sustainable tourist destination.

headline: Back to the Vermont Inn Where the Snow Must Go On
text: Second-acters, those people who see half a show for free by sneaking in with the returning audience at intermission, might be kicking themselves for missing Act I of “Irving Berlin’s White Christmas” after they see the number that opens the second act, an eye-popping version of “I Love a Piano.” But no worries, cheapskates; you didn’t miss much. The high point of the first act of this tepid seasonal offering, now at the Marquis Theater, was a gag provided by a character who was snoring.

headline: A Nonbeliever Makes a Case Against Tempting Fate
text: I MIGHT run a network that focuses on science fiction and the extraordinary, but I’m a very practical guy. For example, I don’t believe in jinxes.

headline: Law Raises Age for Children to Remain in Safety Restraints
text: More New Yorkers should be buckling their sons and daughters into booster seats this holiday weekend after a new state law extends the age that children must ride in child restraint systems.

headline: Did the Pilgrims Serve Pork, Too?
text: I DIDN’T think it would surprise my family to learn that I planned, this Thanksgiving, to change the menu a tiny bit to cut calories.

headline: China Seeks to Slow Rapid Growth of Lending
text: Chinese banking regulators are putting pressure on the country’s banks to raise more capital and temper their rapid growth in lending, in a clear sign of official concern about the sustainability of the nation’s credit boom, senior Chinese bankers said on Monday.

headline: Kennedy’s Widow to Appear on Oprah
text: After avoiding the public eye for three months, Victoria Reggie Kennedy, the widow of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, will appear on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” on Wednesday.

headline: Judge Allows CIT to Borrow Up to $500 Million
text: The CIT Group, a leading commercial lender, won bankruptcy court approval on Monday to borrow as much as $500 million to issue letters of credit that guarantee its debt.

headline: They Died, and Lived to Tell All About It
text: Electric circuits will break your heart every time. Take my cellphone (please): it went out in the rain a few weeks ago and then lay neglected in a sopping wet coat pocket overnight. The next morning, it was dead.

headline: U.K. Documents Show Friction With U.S. on Iraq
text: LONDON  Official Defense Ministry documents leaked to a British newspaper have revealed a climate of stark animosity among senior British officers toward American military commanders after the 2003 invasion of Iraq, when Britain, as the second-largest troop provider, was cast as the United States’ principal ally among about 30 nations constituting the occupation force.

headline: G.M. Seeks Assistance From Europe for Opel
text: BERLIN  As executives of General Motors met Monday with European officials to ask for financial help in overhauling its struggling auto operations, Germany reopened a bitter public debate over state aid and job protections that has sharply divided its government.

headline: Exploring a Low-Acid Diet for Bone Health
text: The science of osteoporosis and its resultant fractures has long been plagued by some vexing observations. Why, for example, are osteoporotic fractures relatively rare in Asian countries like Japan, where people live as long or longer than Americans and consume almost no calcium-rich dairy products? Why, in Western countries that consume the most dairy foods, are rates of osteoporotic fractures among the highest in the world? And why has no consistent link been found between the amount of calcium people consume and protection against osteoporosis?

headline: More Speed-Round Thanksgiving Questions
text: You know who writes a mean recipe for pie crust, apparently off the top of his head? That guy Choire Sicha at The Awl. He writes dirty, and I write for The New York Times, so I can’t link to it. But you can find it through the magic of “search.” As we get closer to the madness of Thanksgiving Day itself, when control freaks start freaking and lazy cousins open another beer on the couch, or stand just outside the front door so that the smoke from their Vantages doesn’t drift harmlessly up into the slate-gray sky, but directly back into the living room where the baby crawls, it’s worth remembering: Be calm. It’s just dinner. Every little thing gonna be all right.

headline: Jane Brody Explains Low-Acid Eating
text: In this week’s Personal Health column, Jane Brody explores the science behind a low-acid diet, a diet laden with fruits and vegetables but relatively low in acid-producing protein and moderate in cereal grains.

headline: Near Geneva, Particles Finally Come Together With a Bang
text: Call it First Bang.

headline: Israel’s Gamble in a Prisoner Swap
text: Updated, Nov. 24, 12:20 p.m. | Ronen Bergman, an Israeli investigative journalist, and Steven Simon of the Council on Foreign Relations join the discussion.

headline: Adam Lambert Defends American Music Awards Performance
text: One day after Adam Lambert gave audiences an eyeful on the American Music Awards, ABC, which broadcast the awards show on Sunday night, is getting an earful from its viewers.

headline: Shifting Vaccine for Flu to Elderly
text: Federal health officials are trying to shift supplies of the seasonal flu vaccine away from chain pharmacies and supermarkets to nursing homes, hoping to counter a shortage that threatens to cause a wave of deaths this winter among the nation’s most vulnerable population.

headline: Artery Disease in Some Very Old Patients
text: The Book of Exodus in the King James translation of the Bible describes a pharaoh who “hardened his heart” against the exodus of the Jews from ancient Egypt. But if a research letter published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association is correct, the pharaoh may have been suffering from hardened arteries.

headline: Why Women Can’t Let Sarah Palin Go
text: Back before the Oprah interview and the resignation as governor of Alaska, before Tina Fey’s impersonation and the announcement of Bristol’s pregnancy, way back to the day John McCain named his running mate, Lisa Copeland was a Sarah Palin fan.

headline: The Women Left on Earth When Space Called Men
text: The 10 women striding into an Arizona resort for a reunion are a group guaranteed to turn heads. Handsome, sharp and sure of themselves, mostly in their 70s, they look as if they met in college or were the members of a particularly effective Junior League.

headline: How the West Was Worn
text: A few months ago, the men’s-wear designer Adam Kimmel found himself 150 miles off the coast of Mexico, underwater, with a group of great white sharks circling him. Kimmel was looking out from a protective cage, but the entertainer David Blaine, a friend, was swimming in the open, breathing only occasionally through someone else’s regulator. To make things more interesting, Blaine was wearing a black tuxedo and red cape made by Kimmel, and was being filmed by the director Bob Talbot as a diver pushed him toward the toothy behemoths.

headline: Bronfman Wins Lawsuit Over Warner Music
text: Score another court victory for Edgar Bronfman Jr., chairman of the Warner Music Group, in the $100 million lawsuit filed against him two years ago by Simon & Schuster‘s former chief, Richard Snyder.

headline: AIDS: Study in Rural Uganda Finds Benefits in Treating AIDS Patients at Home
text: Treating AIDS patients at home is just as effective as having them come into a clinic  and considerably cheaper, according to a new study being published in The Lancet this week.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Monday, Nov. 23
text: It’s uncommon to find so many visual parallels within a single show, but Monday’s Pictures of the Day presentation abounds in them. Unfiltered emotion is obvious in the two very different faces seen in Slide 3 and Slide 5. Foliage fills the frames of Slide 10, Slide 11 and Slide 12; playing a somber, ceremonial role in two of the pictures and a delightfully recreational role in the third. Then, there are three distinctive compositions that are largely white-on-white: Slide 9, Slide 13 and Slide 14, which also seems to have a coals-to-Newcastle theme, despite being set in Hamburg.

headline: A Survey Shows Pain of Recession for Artists
text: A major new survey of American artists and how they are weathering the economic downturn has found that slightly more than half experienced a drop in income from 2008 to 2009, a blow to an already struggling group, two thirds of whose members reported that they earned less than $40,000 last year.

headline: Yale-Harvard Fourth-Down Analysis
text: As we saw with Bill Belichick’s controversial decision against the Colts, going for it on fourth down is often a more sound decision, at least going by the math, than many people think.

headline: A Nuclear Reactor Shows Its Age
text: Almost every plan for limiting carbon dioxide output includes keeping old nuclear plants running. But as those plants age, they turn up new problems.

headline: Beer-Guzzling Bravado With a Tender Touch
text: Here’s a thought: What if the artists on future split bills were required to collaborate? If they couldn’t come up with something at least as interesting as what Ishmael Houston-Jones and Dan Safer managed on Thursday at Dance New Amsterdam, bye-bye split bill. Just think of all the odd-couple pairings the dance world would be spared.

headline: Varying Concerns About Climate Files
text: In response to Raymond T. Pierrehumbert’s “Your Dot” commentary on the hacked climate files, another reader, Geoff Smith, has weighed in with the following thoughts and questions.

headline: A White House Split-Screen: Jobs and Afghanistan
text: President Obama convened a meeting of his Cabinet on Monday afternoon to “generate good ideas” for a jobs summit next month, the latest sign that the White House is employing an all-hands-on-deck approach to the economy as the midterm election year approaches.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Aguirre: Wrath of God'
text: A. O. Scott reviews Werner Herzog's 1972 film about the brutality and indifference of nature.

headline: Renewing a Classic, Adventure Intact
text: LUDWIGSHAFEN, Germany  “Artifact,” the first ballet that William Forsythe created after becoming director of the Frankfurt Ballet in 1984, is a masterpiece, a work that definitively shows this choreographer as the most influential practitioner of the art form since Balanchine.

headline: Cuban Musical Pioneers Celebrate an Island’s Soul
text: There’s no antiquarian dust on Septeto Nacional Ignacio Piñeiro, the Cuban band that got started in 1927 and performed on Thursday night at S.O.B.’s on its first American tour in 76 years. The septet was a pioneer of the Cuban son (a dance style; son means sound), which is a foundation of modern salsa in this hemisphere and of Congolese soukous in Africa. The Septeto, which has replaced all its musicians through the years  Piñeiro died in 1969  still plays the Piñeiro repertory. Its Cuban son, and its rumbas and boleros, are music of transparency, tensile strength and phantom drive.

headline: Snake Eating a Right-Handed Snail
text: Researchers found that snakes with more teeth in their right mandibles compared to the left were more efficient in extracting right-handed snails from their shells.

headline: In Snails and Snakes, Features to Delight Darwin
text: Charles Darwin seems to have had a boundless interest in the many forms life takes on earth. He could find something about any animal or plant that piqued his insatiable curiosity, and masses of such observations fueled his prodigious output of books and scientific papers.

headline: Kansas Rep. Moore Plans to Retire
text: In his sixth term, Representative Dennis Moore, Democrat of Kansas, officially announced his retirement at the end of next year.

headline: BlogTalk: Grading Obama, Abortion Flares
text: On a day when news reports are out about President Obama’s public approval ratings falling below 50 percent in two polls, some bloggers are reacting to some strong critiques issued in the last couple of days about Mr. Obama’s trip to Asia and his overall job performance.

headline: Poll: Public Option Not Public’s Priority
text: Several lawmakers are staking their support for a health care overhaul on whether or not it creates a government-run health insurance plan — the so-called public option — to compete with private insurers. But a new poll by the Kaiser Family Foundation suggests that even as the public supports a public option, they have other, higher priorities for the health legislation.

headline: Music Awards Strong, but CBS Is Stronger
text: The American Music Awards drew its largest audience in seven years on Sunday as ABC attracted 14.2 million viewers, more than 2 million better than last year, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Despite the strong ratings, ABC did not lead the night over all as NBC finished in first place. Although final ratings for NBC’s live “Sunday Night Football” broadcast were not available on Monday, preliminary overnight figures show that the game earned higher ratings than any other program on the night. CBS had more than 20 million tuning in at the start of prime time to the final minutes of the network’s afternoon football coverage. Following it, CBS’s “60 Minutes” earned approximately 15.6 million viewers, while its “Amazing Race” (11.8 million), “Three Rivers” (9.2 million), and “Cold Case” (7.7 million) rounded out the rest of the schedule.

headline: ‘Jerusalem’ Wins Award
text: Jez Butterworth’s play “Jerusalem,” a three-hour-plus dark comedy, won two London Evening Standard Theater Awards, which were announced on Monday, Reuters reported. “Jerusalem,” which opened at the Royal Court Theater under Ian Rickson’s direction, was named best play, and Mark Rylance, who portrayed a tax-evading stoner nicknamed Rooster, received the best actor award. The New York Times critic Ben Brantley  called “Jerusalem” a “great sprawling brawl of a play,” and praised Mr. Rylance, right, for his “astonishing performance.” Mr. Rylance won a Tony Award last year for his performance in the Broadway revival of “Boeing-Boeing.” Rachel Weisz was named best actress for her performance in the Donmar Warehouse’s revival of “A Streetcar Named Desire.” The award was named after the actress Natasha Richardson, who died in March, and was presented by Ms. Richardson’s mother, the actress Vanessa Redgrave.

headline: Artist and Architect to Make Synagogue Window
text: The Museum at Eldridge Street has commissioned the artist Kiki Smith and the architect Deborah Gans to create a new east window for its 1887 synagogue, right, a National Historic Landmark on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. “We were interested to make a piece that integrated into the building but would not mimic the structure,” Ms. Smith said in an interview. The synagogue reopened in 2007 after a 20-year restoration, but there were no available records of the original window. “We decided not to try to recreate something when we did not know what that something really looked like,” said Bonnie Dimun, executive director of the museum. Instead Ms. Smith and Ms. Gans will reimagine the window, due to be completed by spring. While the design has yet to be released, Ms. Smith said it would feature the Star of David at the center “in a field of blue five-pointed stars.”

headline: ‘Carnage’ Hits a Bump
text: Carnage indeed. The new replacement cast of the Broadway hit play “God of Carnage” was off to a slow start at the box office last week, the first performances without the all-star lineup led by James Gandolfini and Marcia Gay Harden, who won the Tony Award for best actress for the production (which itself won best play). This new incarnation of “Carnage” grossed $497,779 last week, compared with $1,107,302 the previous week. The audience attendance last week was only 63 percent of capacity. Still, last week’s gross was among the largest for a play on Broadway (and bigger than grosses for some musicals last week). But by comparison, the play’s former cast had helped catapult “Carnage” into the million-dollar club of top-grossing Broadway shows. The new cast  Christine Lahti, Annie Potts, Jimmy Smits and Ken Stott  has not had the benefit of major new reviews, or anything like the rush of pre-opening media publicity that greeted the original cast. A spokesman for the production, Chris Boneau, said on Monday that the producers had expected the fall-off and noted that the new cast had higher grosses last week than the original “Carnage” cast had in its first full week of previews ($396,470) in March. He added that the producers had a “very healthy advance” in ticket sales and were “more than pleased.”

headline: NPR News Anchor to Retire
text: The National Public Radio newscast anchor Carl Kasell, right, will retire from the job at the end of the year, NPR said Monday. But Mr. Kasell will continue to keep score for NPR’s weekly quiz show “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” as that program’s official judge. A familiar voice for millions of morning listeners, Mr. Kassell has read the news on “Morning Edition” for 30 years. “After 30 years of waking up at 1:05 a.m.” to prepare for the newscasts, NPR said in a memo to employees, Mr. Kasell “has decided the time has come to sleep in.” He will anchor a final newscast on Dec. 30.

headline: Lawyer vs. Lawyer in Polanski Case
text: Concerned by the public statements of a French lawyer, Hervé Temime, about Roman Polanski’s intentions regarding his possible extradition from Switzerland, Mr. Polanski’s legal team in the United States said Mr. Temime was not authorized to speak for Mr. Polanski. Mr. Temime, who has represented Mr. Polanski in other matters, told Le Figaro newspaper last week that Mr. Polanski would not return voluntarily to the United States, which he fled in 1978 before sentencing for having sex with a 13-year-old girl. But three American lawyers who represent Mr. Polanski  Chad Hummel, Bart Dalton and Douglas Dalton  responded with a statement disavowing any statements by “lawyers in France” who purport to speak for Mr. Polanski. They said that only they and a Swiss lawyer, Lorenz Erni, represent Mr. Polanski in the case against him and in the Swiss extradition proceeding. “Any statements made in the press to the effect that Mr. Polanski will not accept lawful orders of the courts, including relating to extradition, are not true,” the lawyers said in their statement. They are preparing for a hearing scheduled before a California appeals court in Los Angeles on Dec. 10.

headline: New Musical Director for Oscars Show
text: If the Academy Awards show in March turns out to be teeming with original musical numbers or sexual puns, now you’ll know whom to thank or vilify. On Monday the producers of the Oscars telecast said that Marc Shaiman, the composer and lyricist, would be the show’s musical director. Mr. Shaiman, whose credits include the musical versions of “Hairspray” and “Catch Me if You Can,” is an Oscars veteran. He was the musical director of the show in 2004 and wrote for the musical medleys performed by the host Billy Crystal. In a phone interview on Monday, Mr. Shaiman said his job would entail being “in all the rooms where anything having to do with the show is being discussed, to figure out how can music and lyrics play a part in it.” He added that his longtime writing partner, Scott Wittman, would also be involved in composing original numbers and song parodies. “There’s just so much you can do in advance,” Mr. Shaiman said. “But I am trying to think of what words rhyme with ‘Precious.’ ”

headline: Rising Bill in Unwinding of Madoff’s Assets
text: The cost of unwinding Bernard L. Madoff’s estate for the benefit of his victims is climbing, with a total of almost $25 million in new fee requests filed on Monday with the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan.

headline: Food, Kin and Tension at Thanksgiving
text: For Thanksgiving dinner, what side dish would you prefer to accompany your turkey  a serving of well-marinated conflict over how much or how little you eat, or some nice, fresh criticism of your cooking skills?

headline: Against Camel Case
text: As you probably know, the California-based company Apple makes a portable communication device — a device that an acquaintance of mine whose first language is not English distinguishes as a “self” phone. Though proper nouns conventionally begin with a capital letter, Apple spells the device’s trademark with an initial lowercase i, followed by an uppercase P. Thus styled, the word has a hump in the middle. I could print it here to show you, but I refuse to allow my prose to be so disfigured.

headline: Losses Are Mounting for Oklahoma
text: Oklahoma is sinking towards a new low during the Bob Stoops era.

headline: Richard Branson to Open New Jersey Culinary Resort
text: Sir Richard Branson, the travel and entertainment mogul, is opening a resort in New Jersey next week with a cooking and wine school and a farm.

headline: Turkey, With Family Drama on the Side
text: As I explore in today’s Well column, many families gathering around the country this week for Thanksgiving dinner are bracing for the intense emotions of the holiday meal. There’s the mother who prepares a delicious spread, only to criticize her overweight daughter for eating it, a sister-in-law who refuses to serve seconds and a father on a campaign against all things chocolate.

headline: Artist Arrested for 42nd Time, This Time on the High Line
text: A self-promotional vendor who has successfully used the First Amendment to challenge New York City restrictions on artists’ rights to sell was arrested on Saturday by parks police for hawking his wares on the High Line.

headline: Morgan Stanley Hires Former Merrill Executive
text: Morgan Stanley has hired a former Merrill Lynch executive, David Moffitt, to prepare the firm’s capital markets division for a resurgence in securitized debt sales, according to an internal memo obtained by Bloomberg News.

headline: Depressed Woman Appears Happy on Facebook, Trouble Ensues
text: A 29-year-old Canadian woman who says she’s too depressed to do her job claims that her employer’s insurance company stopped paying her disability benefits because she posted some photographs of herself on Facebook in which she appeared to be happy.

headline: Matching Architecture to the Art in a New Miami Museum
text: Why is it so hard to design a great contemporary-art museum?

headline: On the Question of Pies
text: Pies? Check out this video made of me here at my desk at The Times, preparing to answer your questions about making Thanksgiving desserts.

headline: Travels in Cyberspace: The Monday Report
text: After her frenetic appearance at the American Music Awards last night — which featured a vocally shaky performance of the song “Louboutins,” a decidedly unflattering outfit and hairdo, and an awkward, mid-song tumble to the stage floor (landing smack on her celebrated derriere) — Jennifer Lopez probably needs a vacation.

headline: In Love Affair With Credit, It’s Business as Usual
text: Creating compelling television out of jacked-up interest rates, compounded penalty fees and software code rigged to rip off credit card customers is no mean feat. “The Card Game,” a new production in the long-running “Frontline” documentary series on PBS, does a fine job of it.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Aguirre: The Wrath of God’
text: This week, A. O. Scott gives thanks for the filmmaker Werner Herzog and his 1972 film “Aguirre, the Wrath of God,” which looks at the 17th Century conquests of Spanish conquistadors in Peru. It stars Mr. Herzog’s frequent collaborator Klaus Kinski. According to Mr. Scott, the film “paints an unsparing picture of colonial greed and the brutal encounter between human ambition and the wildness of nature.”

headline: Bask Country
text: They’d been sleeping on Pirate’s Bay beach for three days. About a dozen of them  white guys with dreadlocks, their bikinied girlfriends and a golden retriever. They had come from Tobago’s busy south end, where they lived, to this quiet corner of the island for a long weekend of sleeping under the stars. A few hammocks were strung up between the mangroves, and bottles of Beefeater, cigarettes, food and supplies littered a folding table. They said they were originally from Trinidad, Tobago’s sister island 22 miles away. A couple of them tended to the campfire while a group played Frisbee fetch with the dog. After a time, a few more friends showed up on a boat idling out in the pale green Caribbean water. “Hey!” one of them yelled from the deck. He held up a pair of flippers and a snorkel mask to the applause of the crowd onshore.

headline: Museum Is Displaying Treasures of the Other Evolution Pioneer
text: One day in spring 1979, Robert E. Heggestad walked into a small antique shop in Arlington, Va. Mr. Heggestad, a young lawyer from Iowa, was looking for Chinese carpets. The selection of rugs in the small back room was disappointing, and he was about to leave when he noticed a handsome rosewood cabinet behind the cash register.

headline: From Print to Film: Reflections on the Transition
text: Four Season Lodge – Trailer from First Run Features on Vimeo.

headline: Regulators Push Safety Standards for A.T.V.’s
text: For parents wanting to provide their children some good, clean off-roading fun, the Fushin, a smaller-than-normal all-terrain vehicle, seemed just the thing.

headline: Book Calls Jewish People an ‘Invention’
text: Despite the fragmented and incomplete historical record, experts pretty much agree that some popular beliefs about Jewish history simply don’t hold up: there was no sudden expulsion of all Jews from Jerusalem in A.D. 70, for instance. What’s more, modern Jews owe their ancestry as much to converts from the first millennium and early Middle Ages as to the Jews of antiquity.

headline: Price War Brews Between Amazon and Wal-Mart
text: Ali had Frazier. Coke has Pepsi. The Yankees have the Red Sox.

headline: Fact, Myth, History, Memory: New Book About Jews Stirs Old Debate
text: The book “The Invention of the Jewish People,” which spent months on the best-seller list in Israel, is now available in English. In an article in The New York Times on Tuesday Patricia Cohen writes:

headline: Plan Is Revived to Repay Some Lehman Creditors
text: The administrator for Lehman Brothers said on Monday that it planned to seek support to remove claims against the investment bank from British courts and distribute assets directly to creditors by the first quarter of next year, provided enough of Lehman’s hedge fund creditors go along with the plan.

headline: Mauer Near-Unanimous Pick as American League M.V.P.
text: Joe Mauer spent last weekend at his log cabin north of the Twin Cities in Minnesota. He woke up Monday at his home in St. Paul and spent the afternoon at the Metrodome in Minneapolis, where his teammate Justin Morneau joined him to celebrate Mauer’s near-unanimous selection as the American League most valuable player.

headline: Three Clergymen, Three Faiths, One Friendship
text: NASHVILLE  It sounds like the start of a joke: a rabbi, a minister and a Muslim sheik walk into a restaurant.

headline: The Train to the Plane
text: A television commercial from the M.T.A. praised the safety and frugality of using its airport train service.

headline: Enough to Make Your Hair Curl
text: Q. My son, who had pin-straight hair at birth, developed very curly hair at puberty. Is this because the hair follicles change shape, perhaps influenced by hormone shifts?

headline: Fun With Nicknames for Ancient Crocodiles
text: Paul C. Sereno, a paleontologist at the University of Chicago, has fun naming the fossil crocodiles he has dug up from the Sahara.

headline: A New Comment System for Opinionator
text: As part of the new Opinionator, we’ve made changes to the comment section intended to create richer and easier-to-navigate conversations among readers. Here’s what you need to know.

headline: By Happy Accident, Chemists Produce a New Blue
text: Blue is sometimes not an easy color to make.

headline: U.S. Says Lockheed Must Pay Part of F-35 Cost Overruns
text: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon’s top acquisition official said on Monday that Lockheed Martin, the prime contractor for the new F-35 fighter jet, would have to cover part of the increased costs of the huge program.

headline: Is a Warranty on Laptops Warranted?
text: A study by SquareTrade, an online vendor of extended warranties, says 20.4 percent of laptops fail over three years. The study found evidence that netbooks fail at a higher rate, 5.4 percent in the first year of use compared with 4.2 percent for a premium-level laptop. But netbooks haven’t been around long enough to provide solid three-year data.

headline: How Hummingbirds Get Their Nectar With Tiny ‘Straws’
text: It is harder to suck liquid through a thin straw than a wider one because of viscosity.

headline: In Awards Season, Mets Likely to Be Shut Out Again
text: By any measure, 2009 was a disaster for the Mets. The year is not over yet, so there is still time for it to get worse, as the awards season has proven. The Mets have been reminded of their futility every time a National League honor has been announced. So far, they have been shut out in voting by the Baseball Writers’ Association of America for rookie of the year (maybe in 2011, Josh Thole), manager of the year (keep trying, Jerry) and Cy Young Award (uhh …).

headline: Makeshift Home for Many
text: Fifty Afghans, from six families, share a damaged warehouse built in the 1980s in what has become a small, poor village.

headline: The Biology Behind the Milk of Human Kindness
text: As the festival of mandatory gratitude looms into view, allow me to offer a few suggestions on what, exactly, you should be thankful for.

headline: Data Show a Decline for Tigers in Russia
text: MOSCOW  Amid the torrent of bad environmental news in recent years, the story of Amur tigers in Russia offered a flicker of optimism. Nearly extinct half a century ago, the tigers rebounded when the government imposed protections, and their numbers remained more or less stable for much of the last decade.

headline: Google Adds Kid-Safe Filters to Search
text: Parents, teachers and librarians now have a new reason to like Google.

headline: Obama Issues Sharp Rebuke of Mugabe
text: WASHINGTON  In honoring Zimbabwe’s tenacious women protesters at the White House on Monday, President Obama gave his sharpest critique yet of President Robert Mugabe, the octogenarian who has ruled the southern African country with repressive zeal since 1980. Mr. Obama bluntly referred to him as a dictator.

headline: For the Hotel Industry, Recovery is a Long Way Off
text: IN these uncertain economic times, I am wary when I hear someone proclaiming, “We have finally bottomed out.” After all, who knows how long we may stay on the bottom?

headline: The Emotions of Hershey’s Bid
text: Hershey is smaller and brings less to the table than Kraft Foods in a potential takeover battle for Cadbury. But Hershey may have one distinct advantage over Kraft: a potentially irrational owner.

headline: Toy State Spot
text: A new ad campaign for Toy State, a Chinese toy company.

headline: The Auditor Disagrees With Overstock.com
text: When auditors and clients part ways, there is usually a dance in which they exchange letters that explain their actions, but do not question the veracity of the other side’s version.

headline: U.S.T.A. Head Was Paid More Than $9 Million in 2008
text: Arlen Kantarian was paid more than $9 million by the United States Tennis Association in his last year as its chief executive of professional tennis, according to tax documents filed by the organization and confirmed by the U.S.T.A.

headline: Russia: 8 Die in Blast at Weapons Depot
text: An explosion at a navy weapons depot killed at least eight soldiers and injured several others on Monday, less than two weeks after a similar blast at the same depot killed two and forced the evacuation of thousands. The explosion in the Ulyanovsk region in central Russia occurred while soldiers were disposing of unexploded munitions left over from the first explosion on Nov. 13, a Defense Ministry spokesman said on Russian television.

headline: Iran Sentences Journalist to Jail Time
text: Iran handed down a five-year jail term to Ahmad Zeidabadi, a prominent journalist and former student leader, an opposition Web site reported Monday, as part of a series of jail sentences the government has issued against activists and former officials in the past month.

headline: Fees in Madoff Case Rise Nearly $25 Million
text: The cost of unwinding Bernard L. Madoff’s estate for the benefit of his victims is climbing, with a total of almost $25 million in new fee requests filed on Monday with the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan, The New York Times’s Diana B. Henriques reports.

headline: Holiday on Thursday Thanksgiving
text: NEW YORK

headline: Runaway Spent 11 Days in the Subways
text: Day after day, night after night, Francisco Hernandez Jr. rode the subway. He had a MetroCard, $10 in his pocket and a book bag on his lap. As the human tide flowed and ebbed around him, he sat impassively, a gangly 13-year-old boy in glasses and a red hoodie, speaking to no one.

headline: Nimble on His Feet, and Doing What He Loves
text: “Ah, ha, ha, ha, stayin’ alive, stayin’ alive, ah, ha, ha, ha, stayin’ alive.” It is a Tuesday morning at the Educational Alliance, a 120-year-old social service agency at 197 East Broadway, on the Lower East Side, and seven women of various ages are line dancing to the haunting anthem of “Saturday Night Fever.” Leading the weekly classes since 2007, and choreographing New York City Housing Authority shows since 2002, is their fast-stepping dance instructor, the trim and pony-tailed, Fu Manchu-mustachioed, gold-earringed and bracelet-bangled Bernard Dove, 69, a fixture  no, a blur  at New York’s dance palaces since pre-disco days. He is divorced with grown children, none of them dancers.

headline: More on That ’98 Percent’ Coverage Claim
text: The Prescriptions blog has noted on several occasions that the Great Health Care Debate of 2009, on many levels, is a numbers game. And that makes it all the more crucial to get the numbers right.

headline: U.S. Moves to Confiscate a Fortune in Ponzi Case
text: MIAMI  Scott Rothstein, the Fort Lauderdale lawyer accused of a $1 billion Ponzi scheme, certainly spread the money around. On Monday, federal authorities filed court documents seeking to seize his 87-foot yacht, more than a dozen properties and 20 luxury cars, including a 2009 Bugatti Veyron that sells for $1.5 million.

headline: Judge Sees Vindication for a Man Jailed in Rape
text: A judge in Manhattan indicated on Monday that he would throw out the conviction and dismiss the indictment of a Bronx man who spent four years in prison for rape before his accuser admitted that her story had been a lie.

headline: Swine Flu Vaccinations Rise While Infections Remain Low
text: More than 11,000 people received swine flu vaccines at free clinics last weekend, city officials said, while overall infection rates remained relatively low.

headline: Start Date Is Critical in Ponzi Plan
text: Bernard L. Madoff’s enormous Ponzi scheme ended on Dec. 11, 2008, when he was arrested at his Manhattan penthouse. But for some early victims, the date his crime started could matter much more than when it stopped.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 914 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans over the past week:

headline: Whether Winning or Losing, Broncos Are Always Brash
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  During the Giants’ recent four-game losing streak, Coach Tom Coughlin did not exchange trash talk with opposing teams. His players were not seen arguing among themselves on the bench.

headline: Charges Detail Road to Terror for 20 in U.S.
text: Federal officials on Monday unsealed terrorism-related charges against men they say were key actors in a recruitment effort that led roughly 20 young Americans to join a violent insurgent group in Somalia with ties to Al Qaeda.

headline: Gun-Sales Ring in Brooklyn Broken Up, Officials Say
text: Against a backdrop of recent shootings of bystanders, including a 13-year-old boy from Queens and a 15-year-old girl from the Bronx, city officials and members of a civil rights group took action against gun violence on Monday, albeit in different ways and at different events.

headline: N.F.L. Quick Hits, Week 11: Cowboys Don’t Lose
text: Andy Benoit is the founder of NFLTouchdown.com.

text: ALBANY  Joseph L. Bruno: Tiny the Bully, or just Uncle Joe?

text: This is not how business has been done on the World Wide Web.

headline: Moving the Battlefield to the Page
text: He was a civilian again, four months back from Iraq. Yet he still wore his dog tags. The metal clinked against his chest, announcing that the Army remained part of him.

headline: Foundation Tied to Iran Has Donated to Columbia
text: Several months before the Iranian president made a controversial appearance at Columbia University in 2007, the Alavi Foundation  a nonprofit organization that had long supported educational programs related to Islamic and Iranian culture at schools and universities  donated $100,000 to Columbia.

headline: Signs of Hope
text: Detroit

headline: Iran Expanding Effort to Stifle the Opposition
text: DAMASCUS, Syria  After last summer’s disputed presidential election, Iran’s government relied largely on brute force  beatings, arrests and show trials  to stifle the country’s embattled opposition movement.

headline: Right and Left Join Forces on Criminal Justice
text: WASHINGTON  In the next several months, the Supreme Court will decide at least a half-dozen cases about the rights of people accused of crimes involving drugs, sex and corruption. Civil liberties groups and associations of defense lawyers have lined up on the side of the accused.

headline: Pressure Builds Over Obama’s Afghanistan Plan
text: WASHINGTON  As President Obama nears a decision on a troop increase for the war in Afghanistan, he is facing increasingly vocal criticism from senior Congressional Democrats over the war’s cost, the size of the United States troop commitment and the reliability of America’s allies.

headline: Shows Online, Brought to You by ...
text: Jennie Garth of “Beverly Hills 90210” fame has a new series. But don’t look for it on a broadcast network or a cable channel.

headline: Some Democrats Back Off Bid to Legalize Gay Marriage in New Jersey
text: It was not on the ballot, nor was it a top-tier issue in the New Jersey governor’s race this fall, but the push to legalize same-sex marriage in the state could become a casualty of the election results.

headline: Albany’s ‘Ethics’ on Trial
text: Former State Senator Joseph Bruno, who dominated Albany politics for more than a dozen years, is fighting federal charges that he deprived citizens of “the intangible right of honest services.” Mr. Bruno is arguing that he did nothing unusual and broke no laws during those years when he controlled or influenced billions of dollars in state spending  and made millions on the side as a consultant for private companies.

headline: Q. & A. With Kobe Bryant
text: The Los Angeles Lakers’ forward Kobe Bryant talked to Jonathan Abrams of The Times. Here is a transcript of the interview.

headline: Another Loss for Pfizer in Drug Suits
text: Pfizer has been ordered to pay a total of $103 million in punitive damages to two women who were found to have breast cancer after they used hormonal drugs, state court officials in Philadelphia said Monday.

headline: Beware the Result of Outrage
text: The biggest news story of last week?

headline: A Warehouse Holds Families’ New Memories in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  In his inaugural address last week, President Hamid Karzai proudly touted his country’s achievements in creating an Afghanistan with a “rehabilitated economic infrastructure” and “budding free-market economy.”

headline: 2.1 Million Cribs Are Recalled in U.S. and Canada
text: Citing cases of infants being trapped and suffocated, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced a voluntary recall of more than 2.1 million Stork Craft drop-side cribs on Monday, the largest recall ever of cribs.

headline: Ochoa Wins Player of Year in Battle That Lasted Until the Final Hole
text: RICHMOND, Tex.  Two of the more low-key players on the L.P.G.A. Tour turned into drama queens Monday, taking their battle for player of the year honors right down to the last hole of the final tournament on the 2009 schedule.

headline: Conservatives Make a List to Measure Candidates’ Commitment
text: WASHINGTON  A group of conservative Republican leaders is proposing a solution to the internecine warfare over what the party should stand for: a 10-point checklist gauging proper adherence to core principles like opposing government financing for abortion and, more generally, President Obama’s “socialist agenda.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
At 99, Bronx Woman Still Hears Life’s Joyful Noises
text: Sarah Gellert’s favorite word is wonderful. Her parents and friends growing up in the Bronx were wonderful. Her two husbands were wonderful. Her friends from the company where she worked for more than four decades were wonderful.

headline: Senate’s Women Could Sway Health Bill
text: When Senate Democratic leaders first went behind closed doors to complete the health care legislation, the only women in the room were either committee staff members or officials from the White House. The senators there — Harry Reid of Nevada, Max Baucus of Montana and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut — reflected the Senate’s predominant history as an old-boys’ club.

headline: Fine-Tuned With Age, Bryant’s Game Keeps Evolving
text: LOS ANGELES  En route to wedging himself between Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Jerry West among the Los Angeles Lakers’ leading scorers, Kobe Bryant connected with layups, free throws, jumpers, turnaround fadeaways and post-ups.

headline: Instead of Firing Coach, Northeastern Ends the Program
text: Boston

headline: Ex-Referee Donaghy’s Accomplice Says They Bet on Many Games
text: Tim Donaghy, the disgraced former N.B.A. referee, bet on far more games than previously disclosed and picked winners at a staggering 79 percent clip, according to a professional gambler who conspired with Donaghy.

headline: A Teacher and His Students, Joined by a Hard Road to the Kitchen
text: Before his students learn to sauté, braise and stir-fry, Keith Hill, a longtime cooking instructor, teaches them the basics of kitchen safety. It’s important in any kitchen, but perhaps more so for an instructor who witnessed one student go after another with an eight-inch cooking knife.

headline: And the Winner: ‘No Problem’
text: “I’m as mad as hell, and I’m not going to take this anymore!” That famous declaration by Howard Beale in the movie “Network” is the implicit and sometimes explicit message of the many hundreds of responses to last week’s column on phrases and announcements that make your heart sink and make you want to commit mayhem.

headline: The End Comes for Northeastern
text: Northeastern announced on Monday that it was ending its football program after 74 seasons, saying that it could not spend the money going forward that the team would need to be successful. Dan Shaughnessy, a columnist for The Boston Globe, says the move is reminiscent of Boston University’s decision in 1997 to disband its football team.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed essay on Monday, about General Motors, misspelled the author’s name in the byline and accompanying biography. The author is Edward Niedermeyer, not Niedermayer.

headline: Ryan Takes Lead Role in Guiding Sanchez
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Now that the Jets’ playoff hopes have all but vanished, the development of the rookie quarterback Mark Sanchez takes on paramount importance over the final six games.

headline: Paparazzi Help Convict Police Chief of Break-In
text: ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio — By his own admission, what the police chief of Martins Ferry, Ohio, did in May was at the very least stupid. On Monday, a jury concluded that it was also illegal.

headline: Public Database Is Urged to Monitor Drug Safety
text: What could be done to prevent another Vioxx? This pain medication for arthritis became a blockbuster after its introduction in 1999, only to be taken off the market in 2004 when a study linked the drug to an increased risk of heart attack and strokes.

headline: The Values Question
text: It’s easy to get lost in the weeds when talking about health care reform. But, like all great public issues, the health care debate is fundamentally a debate about values. It’s a debate about what kind of country we want America to be.

headline: Everything Considered
text: If you’re having problems downloading the current crossword from Premium Puzzles, this page on XWord Info always lists the latest as soon as they are published.

headline: Bloggingheads: Politics as Entertainment
text: Conor Friedersdorf, left, of True/Slant and Peter Suderman of Reason debate whether we should view American politics as entertainment.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about ballooning debt payments for the federal government misspelled, in some copies, the surname of an economist who noted that the bill for debt service would be even higher were it not for current low interest rates. He is Alan Levenson, not Levinson. And a chart with the continuation of the article misstated, in some editions, the size of debt payments due within a year that are currently paying no more than 1 percent in interest. It is $1.9 trillion, not $2.5 trillion.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing of American military deaths on Saturday misstated the number of confirmed dead in the war in Afghanistan as of then. It was 910, not 909. An updated list appears on Page A12 today.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about a report that the Washington school chancellor intervened on behalf of her fiancé, now the mayor of Sacramento, who was under investigation by a government watchdog, referred incompletely to a complaint filed against that watchdog, Gerald Walpin, the inspector general of AmeriCorps. Although the acting United States attorney for Sacramento sent a complaint last April to a federal panel, saying that Mr. Walpin had withheld information when conducting his investigation, the panel found in October that there was no merit to the complaint.

headline: Corrections
text: A Political Memo article on Friday about discussions among Republican governors on how the party could win elections in 2010 misstated the number of terrorism suspects facing trial in federal court in New York. The Justice Department has decided to place five  not four  suspects on trial, a decision that has been attacked by many Republicans.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about the National Book Award ceremonies, where the novelist Dave Eggers received an award for outstanding service to the American literary community, misstated his role in the founding of the independent publishing house McSweeney’s. He was the sole founder, not a co-founder.

headline: Yanks Film Is Shown; No Word Yet on Sequel
text: The two men stood next to the World Series trophy with a red carpet under their feet. As several flashes popped and photographers shouted their names, both men squinted. They wore jeans and sport coats and they did not smile.

headline: Down 2-0, Rangers Respond to Timeout
text: Almost midway into the first period Monday night, it looked like another dismal night for the Rangers. They trailed Columbus, 2-0, and seemed headed to their fifth defeat in six games.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Nov. 13 about Atavia Wilson of the Bronx, a part-time health care aide who received rent assistance through The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, referred imprecisely to the change in benefits that will take place once she returns to full-time work, and referred incorrectly to her current allotment of food stamps. She will no longer be eligible for Medicaid and unemployment benefits once her work hours increase, but she will in fact still qualify for food stamps. And she now gets $100 in food stamps per month, not per week.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption in some copies on Nov. 14 with an article about Penn’s football program in the years after a popular player killed himself misidentified the team’s opponent. The photograph showed the player, Kyle Ambrogi, being congratulated after scoring in a game against Villanova, not against Bucknell. (Ambrogi killed himself on Oct. 10, 2005, two days after a game against Bucknell.)

headline: A Moveable Fast
text: “IT’S Thanksgiving  time to put our feedbags on,” my family likes to say as we elbow for room next to the Pilgrim and Puritan ghosts the holiday summons to our table. Our colonial forebears probably would not disapprove of our having second and third helpings of sweet potatoes and stuffing, or even rushing off to watch football after the meal  the Pilgrims themselves played lots of games at that first Thanksgiving in 1621. But I imagine they would find fault with our binge for another reason: it is not accompanied by a fast.

headline: Corrections
text: The Critics’ Choice column on Monday about new CDs misstated the title of Adam Lambert’s album. It is “For Your Entertainment,” not “For Your Consideration.” The column, which included a review of Rihanna’s album “Rated R,” also misstated the timing of her beating by her former boyfriend, Chris Brown. It was after a pre-Grammy Awards party, not a post-Grammy party.

headline: Turkey and the Kurds
text: In a show of courage and good sense, Turkey’s government has announced a plan to grant long-denied rights to its Kurdish minority, and, it is hoped, finally end an insurgency that has cost more than 40,000 lives.

headline: No ‘No More Wilderness’
text: In 2003, Gale Norton, then the secretary of the interior, and Michael Leavitt, then the governor of Utah, struck a deal that removed federal protections from about 2.6 million acres of public land in Utah that the Clinton administration had designated as potential wilderness. At the same time, Ms. Norton disavowed her department’s longstanding authority to identify, study and recommend new areas for wilderness protection.

headline: Today IHOP, Tomorrow the World
text: Senator Charles Schumer of New York  undefeated in 35 years of electoral contests  is well known for championing his New York City constituents, from cut-rate ferry fares for Staten Island residents to his care and coddling of Wall Street. But he’s not all about downstate. Upstate, there’s the signature Schumer obsession with maple syrup  his resolve to make New York nothing less than the Saudi Arabia of syrup.

headline: Corrections
text: A film review on Friday about “The Twilight Saga: New Moon,” in which the actor Michael Sheen appears, misidentified the creature he has played in other films. It was a werewolf, not a vampire.
