text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Showcase: Kinship, Close Up
text: It would seem to be a long way from Hollywood and Washington to the home of the Hadza tribe in northern Tanzania. But for the portrait photographer Martin Schoeller, they are closer than you might think.

headline: Missionaries From Congo Confirm Atrocities
text: Wednesday, Nov. 24, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Economy Is Forcing Young Adults Back Home in Big Numbers, Survey Finds
text: For more young adults, there is no place like home for the holidays, and for the rest of the year, too. Ten percent of adults younger than 35 told the Pew Research Center that they had moved back in with their parents because of the recession.

headline: Slow Month for Retailers, but Strong Finish Is Seen
text: A few weeks into the holiday shopping season, consumers are still not reaching for their wallets.

headline: Word of the Day | inductive
text: inductive • \in-ˈdək-tiv\ • adjective

headline: Songs a Plenti
text: Julian Plenti is the alter-ego solo project of Paul Banks, the frontman of the dapper downtown band Interpol. “But Julian Plenti is a darker, brasher and more sinister,” writes Amanda PetrusichHe “bears more resemblance  vocally, at least  to a heavy-metal frontman than to a tailored-suit-wearing art star.” Otherwise, expect some of the post-punk sounds and adoring girls. Tonight at the Bowery Ballroom with I’m In You.

headline: ‘Double Dare’
text: “Wonder Woman” may flaunt her own jewelry, but she didn’t do her own stunts. The documentary “Double Dare” traces the lives of a pair of stuntwomen, Jeannie Epper, 64 and still kickin’, who filled in for Lynda Carter, and her colleague Zoe Bell, who landed “Xena, Warrior Princess” at just 19. “This preternaturally cheerful daredevil crashes through a plate-glass window like some Tinker Bell turned Ninja assassin,” Manohla Dargis wrote. And you’ll see it all in the film, “a story about women who like to roll cars, throw punches and jump from gaspingly tall heights,” while battling the Hollywood’s greatest opponents: sexism, agism and thin-ism. It screens tonight only at the IFC Center.

headline: Sexual Healing
text: Set in the 1880s, when doctors treated women’s “hysteria” by giving them orgasms, “In the Next Room, or the vibrator play” is “insightful, fresh and funny,” writes Charles Isherwood. Set in the office of a doctor who administers sexual cures, Sarah Ruhl, “one of the most gifted and adventurous American playwrights to emerge in recent years” illuminates “with a light touch  a soft, flickering light rather than a moralizing glare  how much control men had over women’s lives, bodies and thoughts, even their most intimate sensations,” he writes. It’s “a true novelty: a sex comedy,” not for teens, but “for adults with open hearts and minds.” Get your tickets now.

headline: Charis Wilson, Model and Muse, Dies at 95
text: Charis Wilson, who was lover, muse, model, amanuensis and wife of the photographer Edward Weston and the subject of many of his best-known nude portraits, died on Friday in Santa Cruz, Calif. She was 95.

headline: Icahn Outbids Penn for Fontainebleau Las Vegas
text: The financier Carl C. Icahn has offered $156.5 million to acquire the partially built Fontainebleau Las Vegas resort, which has been stalled in bankruptcy court since June, according to the resort’s chief operating officer.

headline: News Quiz | November 24, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Outshot by 61-21, Isles Win in OT as Roloson Stops 58
text: Ten games on Monday night, but one game stands head and shoulders above the rest, because of a veteran goalie who stood on his ear. Home teams listed first:

headline: Clemson Gets Money for Study of Wind Energy
text: Clemson University is getting nearly $100 million in federal stimulus money to study wind energy.

headline: Toll Rises to 46 in Philippine Election Unrest
text: MANILA  The death toll in Monday’s election violence nearly doubled to 46 on Tuesday, the Philippine authorities said, as the government declared a state of emergency in two southern provinces in an effort to head off further bloodshed.

headline: Fed Said to Ask Banks for TARP Repayment Plans
text: The Federal Reserve asked nine of the banks that were part of this year’s stress tests to submit plans for repaying the government’s capital injections, a person familiar with the situation told Bloomberg News.

headline: Google Buys Display-Ad Startup, Escalating Competition with Yahoo
text: Google, the leader in Web search, said it is buying the Silicon Valley display advertising technology startup Teracent, a move that expands its competition with display leader Yahoo, Reuters reported.

headline: Breaking Da Vinci’s Code
text: WHO was the “the artist, inventor and scientist for whom the term Renaissance man seems custom made”?

headline: Beware the Result of Outrage
text: A 300-page bill to reform the financial industry is making its way around the House of Representatives, its amendments intended to help quiet some of the outrage over the bailout, The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

headline: LinkedIn Aims to Show Up in More Places Online
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: After Chegg, BookRenter Pockets $6 Million
text: Less than a week after Chegg.com, the textbook rental site, said it had landed a hefty $57 million in financing, the rival BookRenter announced that it had also snagged new funding, albeit a more modest sum.

headline: KDIC Said to Offer $531 Million in  Woori Shares
text: The Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation was to offer as much as 614 billion won ($531 million) in Woori shares in a block transaction on Tuesday, according to an e-mail message to investors that was obtained by Bloomberg News.

headline: Corel Says Takeover Needed to Prevent Collapse
text: Corel , the maker of WordPerfect and other software, on Monday justified an offer to take the company private, saying that complete ownership is necessary to inject capital quickly and avert a default on its loans, The Associated Press reported.

headline: 2 Executed in China for Selling Tainted Milk
text: BEIJING  China executed two milk producers on Tuesday for selling more than three million pounds of contaminated milk products in connection with a food-safety scandal that killed six infants, shocking the country last year.

headline: ‘Fela!’
text: Photos from the Broadway musical about the Nigerian musician Fela Anikulapo-Kuti.

headline: Bizo, the B2B Platform, Lands $6 Million
text: Bizo, the business-to-business marketing platform, has nabbed $6 million in a round of funding, PaidContent reported.

headline: Do You Know Someone Who Texts While Driving?
text: The “Driven to Distraction” series looks at the dangers of driving while using electronic devices. Do you know people who text or do other dangerous things while driving? What do you think would change their behavior?

headline: Newmont Sells Additional Stake in Indonesia Mine
text: Newmont Mining has agreed to sell a 14 percent stake in an Indonesian gold mine for $494 million, ending a years-long dispute with the Indonesian government over how the mining company should sell shares as required under its contract to operate in the country, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Informa Talks Give Springer Owners Hope
text: Informa, the British media company, said it was in talks to buy Springer Science and Business Media, reigniting hope among Springer’s private-equity owners that they might finally offload the debt-ridden business.

headline: Obama Concept Stocks
text: “Green” stocks that traded well in China in the run up to Barack Obama’s visit, because they chime with the President’s attitude to the environment.

headline: J.C. Flowers Appoints 2 to Lead in Europe and Asia
text: J.C. Flowers & Company is adding big names to its team in Europe and Asia.

headline: The Emotions of Hershey’s Bid
text: Hershey is smaller and brings less to the table than Kraft Foods in a potential takeover battle for Cadbury. But, Breakingviews.com argues, Hershey may have one distinct advantage over Kraft: a potentially irrational owner.

headline: Wall Street Ends 3-Day Losing Streak
text: Wall Street held on to steep gains on Monday, channeling momentum from rallies in Europe and Asia and a renewed rush for gold.

headline: Start Date of Ponzi Scheme Is Critical to Claims
text: Bernard L. Madoff’s enormous Ponzi scheme ended on Dec. 11, 2008, when he was arrested at his Manhattan penthouse. But for some early victims, the date his crime started could matter much more than when it stopped, The New York Times’s Diana B. Henriques writes.

headline: Inside Out | Sweet Dreams
text: Rita Konig is a decorator based in New York who has written about style for British Vogue, The Telegraph and Domino.

headline: Ciena Wins Nortel Unit
text: Ciena agreed to buy the optical networking and ethernet equipment businesses of the bankrupt Canadian company Nortel Networks for $769 million after trumping a bid from Nokia Siemens Networks.

headline: Is John Paulson a Grump? Did It Make Him Billions?
text: Did the hedge fund manager John Paulson’s metamorphosis from a fairly sociable individual into a grump help him transform his career from relatively lackluster to very successful?

headline: Freddie Mac Says Loss at Home Lender May Grow
text: Freddie Mac, the American mortgage finance giant, said on Monday that it was seeking $595 million in loan payments and other funds hung up after the bankruptcy of the lender Taylor, Bean & Whitaker Mortgage Corporation, Reuters reported.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Triples Stock Buyback Plan
text: Hewlett-Packard tripled the size of its share repurchase program to $12 billion as China sales and better profit margins on its services boosted quarterly earnings.

headline: Lloyds Prices World’s Largest Cash Call
text: Update | 8:55 a.m.  The New York Times’s Julia Werdigier provides more details of the Lloyds rights offering.

headline: Panel Asks How Britain Got Involved in Iraq War
text: LONDON  A long-awaited inquiry into Britain’s role in the Iraq war began Tuesday and immediately homed in on the question that seems set to dominate its work: whether the former prime minister, Tony Blair, and his government were drawn into the conflict  over the objections of Britain’s defense, intelligence and foreign policy establishments  by an eagerness to please the United States.

headline: The Peseta Returns for One Menu Only
text: A turkey dinner might be just the thing for a pilgrim celebration, but if you happen to be in Madrid this Thanksgiving why not dine like a queen on stuffed partridge instead? The Westin Palace Hotel (Plaza de las Cortes 7; 34-91-360-8000; www.westinpalacemadrid.com) is offering a special celebratory menu in honor of the 200th anniversary of the peseta, which was first minted in 1809, only to be replaced by the euro in 2002. The seven-course menu, which is available through Dec. 19, is based on a banquet offered in 1866 by Queen Isabel II, the Spanish monarch whose paid mercenaries became known as “peseteros.”

headline: No-Huddle Makes the Browns Go
text: How does a team as offensively challenged as the Browns (five offensive touchdowns in their first nine games) end up playing in one of the highest-scoring games of the season?

headline: Revenge of an ‘Edsel’
text: Today’s idea: The much-maligned Pontiac Aztek — practically the Edsel of our day — could get the last laugh as prototype for the crossover vehicle of the future, an article says.

headline: Netanyahu Plays Down Talk of a Prisoner Exchange
text: JERUSALEM  Seeking to lower expectations of an imminent deal with the Islamic group Hamas to exchange a captured Israeli soldier for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Tuesday that no agreement had yet been reached.

headline: PPR to Unload European Retail, Report Says
text: François-Henri Pinault, chief executive of PPR, is looking to unload the firm’s European retail business to focus exclusively on global consumer and luxury brands, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Notes on the dollar panic
text: Atrios notes that according to the financial press the dollar is always falling, even though it isn’t. As Chris Hayes points out, hype about a falling dollar also feeds the story line that we mustn’t do anything to upset the Chinese, because terrible things would follow if they sold some of their dollar reserves.

headline: Why Are Some Cities More Entrepreneurial Than Others?
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.The success of a city is tied to the area’s entrepreneurship, but what explains why some places are more entrepreneurial than others?

headline: Sampler: Protests, Use of Force and Entrepreneurial Cities
text: U.C. Protest | A protest at the University of California’s administrative office in Oakland turned into a three-hour discussion between students and administrators about budget cuts and fee increases. (The university’s president, Mark Yudof, was off on a furlough day.)

headline: Milo, a Site to Help People Shop Offline, Attracts Investors
text: As more and more people shop online, one start-up is pursuing a contrarian idea. Milo is a Web site where people can find out where to buy things offline.

headline: Man Group Hit With Downgrade
text: Man Group, the publicly listed hedge fund giant, saw its shares take a hit Tuesday after Credit Suisse downgraded the firm to “neutral” from “outperform,” on valuation grounds.

headline: Traversing India’s Highest Highway
text: Twisting some 295 miles through Himalayan peaks, the Leh-Manali Highway in northern India is one of the world’s highest and most remote highways.

headline: Acid Attacks and IVAWA
text: The International Violence Against Women Act, IVAWA, is a fairly obscure piece of legislation that never gets anywhere. It has bipartisan backing — formerly Joe Biden and Richard Lugar, now John Kerry and Lugar — yet even this year it got nowhere. I think to most people it seems a bit remote or irrelevant.

headline: Osmotic Power Debuts in Norway
text: The world’s first osmotic plant opened today in Tofte, Norway, harnessing the saltiness of the sea, along with freshwater, to produce electricity through a polymer membrane.

headline: ‘The Sound of Music’ at 50: Readers Respond
text: Last Monday was the 50th anniversary of the Broadway opening of Rodgers and Hammerstein’s “The Sound of Music.” In an interactive feature, four people with ties to the original production — the actors Theodore Bikel, Lauri Peters and Brian Davies, and Sam von Trapp, the grandson of Baroness Maria von Trapp — talked about their memories of the show.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday: Mya by a Sequin?
text: Donny Osmond will dance for the honor of middle-aged men everywhere in the season finale of “Dancing With the Stars” (ABC, 9 p.m.). Of course, some of those middle-aged men may be inclined to vote for the athletic and extremely well-toned Mya. (She can also pull the female demographic with the frequently bare chest of her partner, Dmitry Chaplin.) The vote here is for the also-ran with the million-dollar smile, plucky, relatable Kelly Osbourne, but her fall in the freestyle Monday night may have made third place inevitable.

headline: Answering Your Questions About the Chevy Volt

headline: Third-Quarter U.S. Growth Revised Lower
text: The United States economy grew at slower pace in the third quarter than previously reported, the government said Tuesday, as weak consumer spending and rising imports offset stimulus efforts.

headline: Runaway, 13, Was Lost in Subway for 11 Days
text: A 13-year-old Brooklyn boy with Asperger’s syndrome vanished in the New York subway system for 11 days despite frantic search by his parents, relatives, police and the Mexican consulate to find him.

headline: Rajaratnam Attacks Wiretap Use
text: Update | 8:58 a.m. Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund executive accused of masterminding a $20 million insider trading ring, responded to civil fraud charges on Tuesday, attacking investigators’ use of wiretaps and arguing that prosecutors omitted crucial facts in their original complaint.

headline: Russia to Investigate Fund Lawyer’s Death
text: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev ordered an inquiry on Tuesday into the death of a 37-year-old lawyer who died in pretrial detention last week after being swept up in a battle between the Russian authorities and the international investment fund he was representing.

headline: Gee, that’s De Pressing
text: Second estimate of third-quarter GDP out; growth rate marked down to 2.8%.

headline: Tavern Creditors Say the City Is Hurting Their Interests
text: There are 452 of them — ranging from a powerful labor union to humble butchers, bakers and even balloon-animal artists. They are owed $8 million. Now, for the first time, they have a voice.

headline: Interrogated About ‘The Daily Show’ in Iran
text: As Politico’s Laura Rozen points out, there is a remarkable moment of black comedy in the Newsweek reporter Maziar Bahari’s personal account of his recent captivity and interrogation in Tehran’s Evin prison. Mr. Bahari, an Iranian-Canadian filmmaker and writer whose detention we discussed last month on The Lede, writes that during his confinement, at one point his interrogator asked him to explain his appearance in a fake news report (embedded above) that was filmed by Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show” in the run-up to June’s disputed presidential election.

headline: Money, mouth
text: All the serious people agree that the United States faces a debt time bomb. Never mind those low, low interest rates — big trouble is just over the horizon.

headline: Ruling Lets Atlantic Yards Seize Land
text: After enduring three years of delays, several lawsuits and the collapse of the real estate market, the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn took a major step forward on Tuesday when New York’s highest court ruled that the state can seize private property for the 22-acre development.

headline: In Bush’s Footsteps
text: It should probably give liberals pause that the most persuasive case for trying Khalid Sheikh Mohammed as a civilian is that doing so is consistent with Bush administration precedent. Thus Jim Comey and Jack Goldsmith:

headline: Home Prices May Be Nearing a New Dip
text: Home prices are enduring an early winter chill, raising the odds that the economy may suffer another jolt while it is still weak.

headline: Homeless Organization Is Called a Fraud
text: Updated, 12:17 p.m. | They are a familiar sight on street corners across the five boroughs: Men and women standing behind folding card tables, urging passers-by to throw a little change into the empty plastic water jug marked “U.H.O.”

headline: ‘Can You Believe That?’
text: Monologue |  Aired Monday night on “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on NBC: Over the weekend, the Senate voted to allow debate on the health care bill. Can you believe that? It’s like fighting over whether or not to fight.

headline: Fark and USA Today: Bedfellows in Oddity
text: Cube surfers have long turned to Fark.com for a break from the mundane. A news aggregator and a social networking news site, Fark has always placed an emphasis on idiosyncrasy when it comes to the day’s events. By its own definition, Fark is where you go for news that is not really news.

headline: ‘Viewers Who Saw Both’
text: Monologue |  Aired Monday night on NBC: The ratings just came in for Sarah Palin’s appearance on “The Oprah Winfrey Show.” It earned Oprah her highest ratings since the episode where she reunited the Osmond family. Yeah, viewers who saw both episodes say Palin’s more likable but that Donny and Marie are more qualified to be president.

headline: ‘Nothing But Evil’
text: Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: That evil guy, the evil masterminding terrorist Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, he is going on trial here in New York City. I will tell you something, this guy is nothing but evil. One time he called CNN and told him that his son was floating away in a balloon.

headline: Recipes for a Vegan Thanksgiving
text: These days, it isn’t enough to offer vegetarian dishes at Thanksgiving — some of your guests may adhere to a vegan diet. Vegan foods are meatless dishes prepared without dairy, eggs or any animal products.

headline: ‘The White House Turkey’
text: Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC: President Obama is getting ready to pardon the White House turkey, the Treasury Secretary, Tim Geithner.

headline: The Adam Lambert Fallout: Were You Not Entertained?
text: In what is probably a huge relief for Jennifer Lopez, the spotlight has remained firmly trained on Adam Lambert following his sexually charged performance at the American Music Awards.

headline: Expert Answers on Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
text: Denise Grady, a science writer for The New York Times, recently explored the link between a recently discovered virus called XMRV and chronic fatigue syndrome, in “Is a Virus the Cause of Fatigue Syndrome?” Here, Dr. Nancy G. Klimas, who serves on the board of the International Association for Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, responds to readers’ questions. Dr. Klimas is a director of the department of immunology of the University of Miami School of Medicine and director of research for clinical AIDS/H.I.V. research at the Miami Veterans Affairs Medical Center. See her earlier responses in “Readers Ask: A Virus Linked to Chronic Fatigue Syndrome” and Fred Friedberg’s responses to behavior-related questions in “Behavioral Treatments for Chronic Fatigue Syndrome.”

headline: As Bank Failures Rise, F.D.I.C. Fund Falls Into Red
text: The government-administered insurance fund that protects depositors fell into the red for the first time since the fallout from the savings-and-loan crisis of the early 1990s as the pace of bank failures accelerated.

headline: Tuesday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Some Days, You Eat the Fish. Other Days …
text: I am having a bad day.

headline: Home Green Home: Reality Check
text: The following is the latest in a series exploring the ways Americans are improving the efficiency and reducing the footprint of their homes. Green Inc. readers are encouraged to share their thoughts and experiences in the comments section or by sending e-mail messages to greeninc@nytimes.com.

headline: A Closer Look at Rajaratnam’s Legal Defense
text: Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, occasionally writes as a guest blogger for the Deal Professor. Mr. Henning specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and is a former editor of the White Collar Crime Law Prof Blog.

headline: Thanksgiving Fill-In
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first four paragraphs of this Op-Ed from the Opinion section, “A Moveable Fast”. Use your own words, or click “read more” to choose from a scrambled list of the words that were removed.

headline: U.S. Fund for Bank Deposit Insurance Falls Into the Red
text: The government-administered insurance fund that protects depositors fell $8.2 billion into the red for the first time since the fallout from the savings-and-loan crisis of the early 1990s as the pace of bank failures accelerated in the third quarter.

headline: Google Chief Announces Plan in Baghdad to Put Iraqi Artifacts Online
text: BAGHDAD  Amira Edan, the director of Iraq’s National Museum, says that soon she will no longer have to worry so much that the famous institution remains closed to the public for fear of violence.

headline: New BMW 5 Series Has Hints of the 7 Series
text: What does the new BMW 5 Series have to do with a new Rolls-Royce Ghost? Each is being built on a modified BMW 7-Series chassis.

headline: More Si ns Revealed by Readers
text: Last week’s article describing how a few dark letters on a sign at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens created the message “I’m Hurt” attracted quite a few comments — and most of those were from readers who provided examples of what they claimed were other sign malfunctions, and the whimsical results. We could not publish more than half of them because they were, well, inappropriate for a family newspaper. (Or the Web site of a family newspaper.) But here are some of our favorites:

headline: Play by British Wunderkind Gets New York Staging
text: The argument to stay in school and finish that college degree just got a whole lot harder to make: the 23-year-old British playwright Polly Stenham, who was just 19 years old when she dropped out of University College London to finish her critically acclaimed play “That Face,” will soon see the drama performed in New York, in a production staged by Manhattan Theater Club. In a news release, publicists for Manhattan Theater Club said that its production of “That Face,” about a family struggling with drugs, alcohol and dissolution, will star Elizabeth Marvel (above, of Broadway’s “Top Girls”) as the family matriarch, Martha, and will be directed by Sarah Benson (who directed “Blasted” for the Soho Rep, where she is artistic director). The play is scheduled to begin previews at New York City Center – Stage I on April 29, with an opening night planned for May 18. Additional casting is expected to be announced shortly.

headline: Scandal and Corruption Cloud Champions League Restart
text: Update | 4:43 p.m. Barcelona defeated Inter Milan on Tuesday, 2-0, at the Camp Nou  in Spain. The victory, coupled with a 0-0 draw between Rubin Kazan and Dynamo Kiev, catapults the Catalan side to the top of Group F with 8 points and helps save the European champion from embarrassment. (The day’s results are here.)

headline: G.M. to Decide Saab’s Fate Next Week
text: DETROIT  General Motors said it could decide next week to close its Saab Automobile unit after the Swedish company that planned to buy the brand backed out.

headline: Debating Haves vs. Have-Nots at Public Universities
text: The decision Friday by the University of California to raise student fees by 32 percent even as it is cutting its budget continues to reverberate in homes and classrooms across the state and around the country.

headline: Clausen Is Punched, Reports Say
text: How frustrated are Notre Dame fans? Well, one was apparently upset enough about the Fighting Irish’s season that he decided to take it out on quarterback Jimmy Clausen.

headline: Obama Plans Afghan Address Next Week
text: President Obama plans to announce details of his strategy for the war in Afghanistan early next week in an address to the nation. Here’s a look at Tuesday’s developments as they unfold at the White House and beyond.

headline: Crime Down, but Oakland Up in the Dangerous City Rankings
text: It’s not a ranking you want to win or even place in the top 10. A new study by the CQ Press ranks Oakland as having the third highest crime rate among cities in the U.S. Camden, N.J. was ranked first followed by St. Louis, Missouri. (Richmond ranked 14th, an improvement from 9th).

headline: Travel Deals: Holiday Hotel Discounts Near D.C.
text: Heading to the D.C. area for the holidays? Kimpton Hotel’s Lorien Hotel & Spa, in Alexandria, Va., is offering rooms for $119 a night through Jan. 31. The Spare Bedroom package also includes a $25 daily hotel credit. Use the code PSBR to book.

headline: Green Business and Indigenous Rights
text: A new report released over the weekend calls attention to the plight of indigenous communities affected by climate change mitigation measures.

headline: Swedish Buyer Terminates Deal to Buy Saab
text: General Motors confirmed Tuesday that the deal to sell its loss-making Saab Automobile unit in Sweden was off, The New York Times reported.

headline: Adam Lambert Concert, Planned for ‘Good Morning America,’ Is Canceled
text: Update | 1:02 p.m.  The fallout from Adam Lambert’s provocative act on the American Music Awards continues: on Tuesday, ABC said that it had canceled a performance by Mr. Lambert scheduled for Wednesday on “Good Morning America.” An ABC spokeswoman said, “Given his controversial American Music Awards performance, we were concerned about airing a similar concert so early in the morning.” Mr. Lambert previously appeared on “Good Morning America” in August, when he performed the Muse song “Starlight,” and discussed his sexuality in an interview with “20/20″ in June. The American Music Awards show was broadcast on ABC on Sunday night.

headline: Waiting On Weis at Notre Dame
text: In the dwindling days of college football season, the usual topics of discussion have hardly captivated us. We should be busy parsing Urban Meyer’s proclamations about staying at Florida or squawking about the befuddling permutations  and maddening existence  of the Bowl Championship Series. Instead, there is a strange fixating pull to the implosion at Notre Dame, where Coach Charlie Weis’s imminent demise has become the slow-motion car crash no one can stop craning their necks to watch.

headline: The Way We Ate: The Americanization of The State Dinner
text: For more than a century and a half, The New York Times has been recording the pleasures and prejudices of the American palate. “The Way We Ate” is a weekly tasting menu of vintage food writing from the Times archives, with an extra installment this week in honor of tonight’s state dinner at the White House.

headline: Tavern Creditors Say the City Is Hurting Their Interests
text: There are 452 of them — ranging from a powerful labor union to humble butchers, bakers and even balloon-animal artists. They are owed $8 million. Now, for the first time, they have a voice.

headline: ‘Jon & Kate Plus 8’: The End
text: One thing never changed about “Jon & Kate Plus 8″: the kids were always a good time. Only the steeliest misanthrope could fail to be charmed by their squeals and romps. How you felt about the show, though, depended on how you felt about Jon and Kate Gosselin. If you found them boring, except for when they were irritating — what I like to think of as the silent majority position — then the show ran the gamut from vaguely embarrassing to borderline unwatchable.

headline: What, No Flannel? | The Real Look of Grunge
text: There’s a perception that grunge emerged in the early 1990s. But with his photos in the new book “Grunge,” Michael Lavine shows us that the ’90s wasn’t the beginning of grunge; it was the end. That’s when Seattle’s best cultural brew was watered down, piped out to the masses and sold at a steep profit. Marc Jacobs appropriated flannel. The music of the Pacific Northwest commingled with So-Cal skate culture. And you could don the ready-made trappings of this amorphous “alternative” movement simply by slinking into the nearest Pacific Sunwear.

headline: Twins in ‘2012’ Slam in Manhattan
text: Let it never be said that Alexandre and Philippe Haussmann have forgotten the little people who helped get them to where they are today. There they were on Friday putting in a cameo at the Manhattan Monologue Slam in the West Village, just a week after the movie in which they have featured roles, Roland Emmerich’s “2012,” had opened with a dominating box-office performance.

headline: Botax
text: A proposed tax to be levied on voluntary cosmetic surgery.

headline: Giants Stadium Countdown: Loss Is a Victory
text: John Maxymuk, author of “The 50 Greatest Plays in New York Giants Football History,” is helping us count down to the final game at Giants Stadium. His latest book is “Quarterback Abstract.”No. 6: We Can Play With These Guys

headline: American Symphony Orchestra Will Return to Carnegie Hall
text: The American Symphony Orchestra is headed back to Carnegie Hall, its longtime home. Beginning with its 2010-11 season, the orchestra, led by the conductor Leon Botstein, will resume playing its concerts at Carnegie Hall, a press representative for the orchestra said. At its founding in 1962 by the conductor Leopold Stokowski, the orchestra performed its concerts at Carnegie Hall. But in 1992, the orchestra moved to Lincoln Center, where it was invited by Nathan Leventhal, Lincoln Center’s president at the time, to participate in the Great Performers series. In a news release, the orchestra said that all tickets to its 2010-11 season at Carnegie Hall will cost $25. The orchestra will also remain in residence at the Richard B. Fisher Center for the Performing Arts at Bard College, where Mr. Botstein is president.

headline: Joost Sells Its Name and Most of Its Assets
text: Joost, the struggling video Web site, said on Tuesday that it was selling most of the company to the Adconion Media Group, an online advertising and marketing company, for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition ends a long sales process that at one point was thought to involve possible interest from the cable television operators like Time Warner Cable and Comcast.

headline: Days After Hairstylist’s Death, Her Baby Dies, Too
text: Joselin Castro did not live long enough to cradle her baby girl. But on Tuesday, mother and child will be united at a Washington Heights funeral parlor.

headline: The Sun Is Shining on Norwegian Skier Again
text: MIAMI BEACH  The nearest snow was more than a thousand miles away. The rest of the Norwegian Alpine ski team was training in Canada.

headline: Father and Son Bond in Gloomy Aftermath of Disaster
text: Bang or whimper? Fire or ice? Happily, holiday moviegoers interested in pondering the end of the world can select scenarios far more elaborate than those simple, traditional choices.

headline: A Professionally Funny Family
text: Abby Elliott claims that she dropped out of college because mice were urinating on her eyeballs. After graduating from high school in Danbury, Conn., in 2005, she enrolled at a college in New York City, where she was so unhappy to find mice in her dormitory — mice she blamed for giving her a case of conjunctivitis (via said urine) — that she quit before the first semester was over to move to Los Angeles and try to get into show business.

headline: Murray’s Cheese Will Open 50 Locations in Kroger Markets
text: People who complain about the lines at Murray’s Cheese might want to just head to the supermarket instead.

headline: Obesity and Health Care Spending
text: In the past we’ve talked about the connection between unhealthy lifestyles (in particular, obesity rates) and health care spending. Here are two maps that might further complicate that discussion a bit.

headline: How to Compare Prices in Retail Price Wars
text: As part of their fight over the future of retailing, Amazon.com and Wal-Mart are engaged in an online price war this holiday season, according to an article in The New York Times on Tuesday.

headline: Blog Posts for the Holiday
text: (From Mike Licht at Blogs With Bite. –MB)

headline: For Bruno, Politics and Business Intersected on the Golf Course
text: ALBANY  For Joseph L. Bruno, once one of the most powerful politicians in New York, the road to trouble was soft, grassy and green.

headline: 'Fela!'
text: Sahr Ngaujah plays the title character in this excerpt from the new Broadway musical. (Video courtesy of "Fela!" on Broadway)

headline: Whatever Works: Sarkozy Says She Is Cast in New Woody Allen Movie
text: Boy, if life were only like this. Woody Allen has landed another, shall we say, vivacious young actress to appear in one of his movies — in this case, the first lady of France. Bloomberg News reported that Carla Sarkozy, the model, singer, actress and wife of the French president Nicolas Sarkozy, said in a television interview that she had agreed to appear in Mr. Allen’s next film. “He offered me a role in his next movie,” Mrs. Sarkozy said in the interview with Canal Plus television. “I don’t know for what character, but I said yes. I’m not an actress at all,” she said, according to Bloomberg News. “Maybe I will be terrible. But, in my life, I cannot let such a chance go.” Under her maiden name, Bruni, Ms. Sarkozy has recorded three albums of music and contributed songs to the soundtracks of films including “(500) Days of Summer.”

headline: Asana Aims to Change the Way We Work
text: Office work, filled with overflowing e-mail inboxes and pointless meetings, could be a lot more efficient and productive. One start-up, Asana, is trying to fix the problem. How? Well, that is still a secret.

headline: There’s No Celery in Monrovia, Help!
text: Today’s first question comes from someone posted abroad, looking for a taste of home, worried about provisions, worried about sterility, worried. Did you read my man Mark Bittman in the Week in Review on Sunday? Breathe deep. Be calm. Make like these dudes.

headline: Raising Vegetarian Children
text: Surrounded as we are this week by yams and brussels sprouts and cranberries and turkey (and those mini hot dogs that have somehow also become a tradition at our family’s Thanksgiving table), the moment seems right to write about vegetarian parents and children.

headline: Obama May Add 30,000 Troops in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Tuesday that he was determined to “finish the job” in Afghanistan, and his aides signaled to allies that he would send as many as 25,000 to 30,000 additional American troops there even as they cautioned that the final number remained in flux.

headline: Farm Union Aims Health Pitch at Key States
text: In a news conference on Tuesday aimed at pressuring swing-vote senators, leaders of the National Farmers Union, which represents about 250,000 farm and ranch families, stressed the importance of major health care legislation to agricultural workers in Arkansas, Maine and Nebraska.

headline: G.O.P. ‘Purity’ Test Could Trip Up Castle
text: One of the bright lights on the political horizons for Republicans in 2010 is the United States Senate seat that opened up in Delaware when Joseph R. Biden Jr. became vice president.

headline: Pear and Apple Soufflé
text: Fruit soufflés are dramatic and impressive yet so easy to make. This one will impress everyone at your table. Make the fruit puree well in advance, and beat the egg whites before you sit down to dinner. Then, when you’re too full to eat anything more, fold the two together and put the soufflés in the oven. Just when you’re beginning to think you could eat a little dessert, they’ll be ready.

headline: A New President at Disney Channels
text: Carolina Lightcap is the new president of Disney Channels Worldwide. She succeeds Rich Ross, who was named chairman of Walt Disney Studios last month.

headline: Q&A: The Christmas Markets of Europe
text: Q.

headline: Muti to Conduct Shanghai Symphony Orchestra
text: Riccardo Muti will be making his first conducting foray into China, which has become a major destination for Western musicians and orchestras in recent years. He will conduct the Shanghai Symphony Orchestra on Dec. 31 in what is billed as a New Year’s Eve concert (27 days before the Chinese New Year), an orchestra spokeswoman said. The program will consist of Verdi’s overture to “La Forza del Destino,” the ballet music from his “Vêpres Siciliennes,” Martucci’s “Notturno” and Respighi’s “Pines of Rome.” The concert will take place at the Shanghai Grand Theater.

headline: Soccer in Iraq: Another Field for Argument
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s national soccer team has certainly endured hardship. Saddam Hussein had players beaten after losses. And the war that deposed him forced them into exile, after extremists started killing sports figures. Their first game at home in years was just this summer  against the Palestinians, the only team willing to come here during a war.

headline: A Site to Help People Shop Offline Attracts Investors
text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: A familiar feeling
text: There’s something disturbingly familiar about the current deficit hysteria. There’s the way that fear, and a demand for action against a supposed threat, has spread despite the lack of any solid evidence to support it. There’s the way that many news stories seem to present only one side of the argument, and suppress or neglect contrary evidence (e.g., writing articles about how nervous investors are turning on Japan while never mentioning that the current interest rate on Japanese long-term debt is, um, 1.3 percent).

headline: A bizarre complacency
text: Even as the conventional wisdom seems to have converged on the view that despite the continuing willingness of bond investors to buy US debt at low interest rates, the deficit is terrible, scary, awful — you know we’re in herd behavior mode when phrases like “time bomb” start appearing in news stories — a weird complacency has settled in on the state of the actual economy. We’re recovering, everyone says — no need to do anything more.

headline: London Philharmonic Says Former Finance Director Embezzled $928,000
text: The London Philharmonic Orchestra said Tuesday that its former finance director embezzled $928,000 over four years. The executive, Cameron Poole, who also held the title of general manager, is accused of using the money for antiques, vacations and renovations to his London townhouse, according to British newspapers.

headline: German Banker Sees Risk, Not Size, as Problem
text: Andreas Schmitz, president of the Federal Association of German Banks, said in a statement Monday in Frankfurt that a central problem of the financial crisis, in Europe at least, was not that certain banks were “too big to fail,” but that they were “too connected to fail,” or simply “too risky.”

headline: Adam Lambert Headed to CBS ‘Early Show’ After ABC Cancels His Concert
text: Hours after ABC said that it canceled a concert by Adam Lambert planned for its “Good Morning America” program on Wednesday, CBS said that Mr. Lambert would appear on its “Early Show.” In a statement, CBS said that Mr. Lambert, an “American Idol” finalist, will perform live on “The Early Show” on Wednesday and discuss his recent performance on the American Music Awards. That awards show was broadcast Sunday on ABC, which said it was concerned that Mr. Lambert would give another “controversial” performance if he appeared on “Good Morning America.”

text: 1.) How worried should we be about the deficit?

headline: Web Site Honors Sustainable Cooking
text: Following its list of top young farmers “bringing local, sustainable food back to the table,” the environmental Web site Mother Nature Network has compiled a list of young chefs exemplifying sustainable cooking.

headline: An Outlaw Street Race, for a Good Cause
text: Stepping off the Long Island Rail Road with his custom-made fixed gear folding bike early Saturday afternoon, Robert A. Butler planned a bit of riding before heading to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Consumers Are Still Glum
text: Consumer confidence rose slightly in November, but consumers are still looking quite depressed, according to the Conference Board Consumer Confidence Index.

headline: Queens Murder Suspect Says He Has a Personality Disorder
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today …

headline: Terra Stands Firm in the Forever War
text: Update | 3:08 p.m. Terra Industries shows no signs of running out of breath in the Forever War.

headline: Now Booking | A Boston Hotel Double-Play
text: Boston is one of those cities that can’t seem to shake its reputation: forget all the cutting-edge biotech and the newfound fashion consciousness and the burgeoning food culture — for many this will always be America’s capital of the buttoned-up, where kicking it old school trumps looking to the future. Yet in the space of less than a month two important new hotels have arrived here, the W and the Ames, and between them they’ve injected a healthy dose of the kind of modernity and style that typifies the new Boston.

headline: After a Humbling Spiral, Kerry Returns to Form
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John Kerry was sounding almost giddy  and, as a general rule, John Kerry does not do giddy.

headline: Higher Tide
text: Like the little black dress, the beach vacation will never go out of style. Indeed, the more uncertain the times, the more necessary it becomes to sun yourself beside a book and a piña colada. Only nowadays, travelers looking to get something extra out of their tropical idylls — a little more value with their vegging — are combining beach time with volunteer programs, spiritual discovery or immersion in a new culture. “This trend has been going on for a while, but since the recession it’s even more pronounced,” says Ann Mack, director of trend-spotting at the ad agency JWT. “People are vulnerable and they’re seeking answers. Life-enriching trips can help put things in perspective.”

headline: Cowher Passes on Interview With the Bills
text: Bill Cowher, the former Pittsburgh Steelers coach, declined the opportunity to interview for the Buffalo Bills’ head coaching job last weekend, according to The Buffalo News, among other news organizations.

headline: Let Me Cut Budget, Paterson Says; No, Lawmakers Reply
text: New York’s budget impasse continues.

headline: On Our Radar …
text: 1.) An update on those hacked global warming e-mail messages.

headline: Lots of Ritual, With Some Substance
text: Last week, the Obama administration hosted the first state dinner for a foreign visitor, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India. It is mostly ritual activities, but there is some chance for progress on issues.

headline: The Morning Skate: Concussions, DiPietro’s Return and Sticks
text: Sports fans and observers often point to the N.F.L. as the industry leader in all sorts of things, but in some areas, the N.H.L. is ahead of pro football. One of those areas is video replay. Another is the N.H.L.’s protocol on clearing players who return from concussion injuries.

text: From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:

headline: A Big Crowd for ‘Jon & Kate’ Finale
text: About 4.3 million viewers watched the final installment of “Jon & Kate Plus 8″ on Monday, Nielsen said, marking an emotional end to the TLC series about the Gosselin twins and sextuplets and their parents Jon and Kate.

headline: Koons Sculpture for Los Angeles Museum on Hold
text: A train that is supposed to go nowhere seems to be going nowhere, at least for the time being. Plans by the artist Jeff Koons and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art to create an eye-popping piece of public art — a 70-foot replica of a 1943 locomotive engine designed to dangle nose down from a 161-foot crane — are in limbo because the museum cannot pay for it, Bloomberg reported.

headline: Industrial Real Estate, a New Jersey Bulwark, Shows Some Cracks
text: Over the years, as the real estate markets for offices, residences and stores in New Jersey have gone through peaks and valleys, the market for industrial real estate has been like the buildings themselves  not flashy, but big, solid and reliable.

headline: Airlines Pay for Stranding Passengers
text: WASHINGTON  The Transportation Department imposed its first penalties for runway delays Tuesday, collecting $175,000 from three airlines for leaving 47 passengers of a regional jet stranded overnight in Rochester, Minn.

headline: The State Dinner Menu
text: Obama Foodorama has it.

headline: Lessons From the Man in a Kilt
text: Readers may remember my longtime friend Brian Nelson as the moon-faced man in the kilt – his photo and an accompanying essay appeared on the Well blog in August. Cancer treatment had changed his appearance, leaving his face and eyes swollen and unrecognizable, his voice muffled and sometimes unintelligible.

headline: America’s Next Top Stock Model
text: Let’s say you’re an investor who has been following Hewlett-Packard for ages. The company’s slowing printer sales concerns you, largely because you think this may be a long-term issue rather than a short-term blip. Meanwhile, you’re bullish as all get out about H.P.’s services business.

headline: The Reunion Tour, for Clothes Only
text: WHEN consumerism spends itself to death and the arteries of fashion are clogged with cheap, disposable and boring designs, it’s time to rediscover one-of-a-kind relics from bygone fashion eras.

headline: Can A Wonk Win?
text: Matt Yglesias and Isaac Chotiner both suggest that if a Republican politician were to embrace serious domestic policy ideas, Republican voters wouldn’t want anything to do with him. The conservative movement tends to “fetishize stupidity,” Yglesias writes, and believes that there’s “something actually un-American about being thoughtful, having respect for scholarship, or incorporating any kind of nuance into your discussion.” If Sarah Palin and Mike Huckabee “were interested in policy, then they would not be so appealing to the GOP base,” Chotiner argues, adding that since movement conservatism “sneers at intellectuals and elites,” a conservative candidate “who was interested in learning the ins and outs of the welfare state and health care policy is unlikely to ever achieve Palin/Huckabee levels of popularity with the grassroots.”

headline: Fed Cautious About Strength of Recovery
text: WASHINGTON  Policy makers at the Federal Reserve have become slightly more optimistic about the pace of the economic recovery, but they continue to predict that unemployment will remain well above 9 percent through 2010, according to new forecasts released on Tuesday.

headline: Is There a Danger in Pestering an Admissions Officer?
text: The folks over at College Confidential are engaging their readership today on the question, “What if you pester an admissions counselor?” The thread began with someone who identifies herself as “Wendy aka sometimes-hyper-mom” asking, “Is it possible to negatively impact a college’s impression of my daughter by sending too many emails to the admissions counselor.”

headline: After Cheney
text: When Vice President Biden travels to Iraq, which he does every two months or so, he flies on Air Force Two to an airbase in southern England and then transfers to a cargo plane, a C-17, retrofitted for vice-presidential comfort with an Airstream trailer bolted on to tracks in the center of the hold. With its porthole and shiny rivets and gleaming chrome, this strange conveyance looks like something out of Jules Verne. Captain Biden holds court in a wood-paneled galley just large enough for his half-dozen or so aides to pile into. Unlike Nemo, he is a gregarious knee-squeezer who has to be ordered by his staff to stop talking so he can get some rest.

headline: Women Who Want to Want
text: At her group therapy sessions for women despairing of low sexual desire, Lori Brotto likes to pass around a plastic tub of raisins. The women, usually six to a group, sit around two pushed-together beige tables in a fluorescently lighted conference room at the British Columbia Center for Sexual Medicine in Vancouver. A little potted tree is jammed randomly in one corner. Ragged holes scar one wall where a painting used to hang. The décor doesn’t speak of sensuality. That is the job of the raisin.

headline: Video: State Dinners, Past and Present
text: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India is making his way around Washington this week. Official visits like his are one of the most tradition-bound of all Washington rituals, complete with a state dinner on Tuesday night.

headline: 7 Charged for False Building Documents
text: Federal and local authorities arrested seven people on Tuesday  including the owners of two construction testing companies, officials from three contracting companies, and an engineer  on charges they falsified testing documents at four New York construction projects.

headline: State Dinner Highlights
text: The Fashion | 8:25 p.m.  For the dinner, Michelle Obama chose a sleeveless golden gown designed by the Indian-American designer Naeem Khan.

headline: Now Showing | ‘Art Dealer Archipelagoes’
text: For his latest exhibition, the abstract painter John Zinsser has turned to representation. Gallery representation, that is. “Art Dealer Archipelagoes,” at James Graham & Sons Gallery through Jan. 5, is an installation of finely detailed drawings of maps that viewed together form an atlas of the artist’s 25-year love affair with the New York gallery scene. Several of the dealer “states” included in the installation are now defunct — including Holly Solomon and John Good — but Zinsser’s geographical juxtapositions remind viewers of their place in the pantheon. “There is something inherently funny about the whole undertaking,” Zinsser says about the exhibit. “The groupings, the borders and implied territories, and a sense of the larger triumph and pathos — those artists who made it, and those who didn’t.” Also in the show: a series of “Auction Lot” drawings that trace the paths of iconic artworks into the market and, for better or worse, highlight the influence of auction houses and collectors on contemporary art history.

headline: Again, a Question of What to Do With Pier A
text: Having lost the National Park Service as a prospective tenant, the city is now seeking ideas on what to do with Pier A, a dilapidated 123-year-old structure at the northern edge of Battery Park.

headline: The Self-Manufacture of Megan Fox
text: Megan Fox is trying to reposition herself as everygirl, but she seems to have overlooked an important point: trash-talking women, while using the most tired and retrograde of stereotypes, sound stupid and hateful, and Fox can’t do an interview without engaging in this sort of commentary. Half the ink Fox gets comes from putting down other women. She will never build a female fan base if she continues to do so.If moviegoers question Fox’s intelligence, it’s not because of her beauty. Megan, here’s some career advice: Turn off “Say Yes to the Dress,” and go out and make some female friends; you’ll be so glad you did.

headline: How to Handle Adult Children Who Move Back Home
text: The economy has forced 10 percent of adults younger than 35 to move back home, according to a new survey from the Pew Research Center covered in this article in The New York Times on Tuesday.

headline: New ‘Spider-Man’ Producer Reaches Out
text: Update | 4:56 p.m. Michael Cohl, the new lead producer of the Broadway musical project “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark,” has approached Kevin McCollum and Jeffrey Seller, the Tony Award-winning producers of Broadway musicals and revivals including “West Side Story,” “In the Heights,” “Avenue Q,” “La Boheme” and “Rent,” about investing in the show, according to three Broadway producers with knowledge of the conversations.

headline: Octomom in Production
text: In 1934, five identical baby girls were born to a poor family in Canada; the world came to know them as the Dionne quintuplets. Within days of their birth, they became an international phenomenon and were placed in a “human zoo” known as Quintland, where curious people could come and ogle them while their parents and the community grew rich. The psychological damage inflicted by their freak-show existence was chronicled in two memoirs and in several other books and films. Self-esteem issues, depression and the inability to fashion normal lives plagued the girls. Their story should have served as a lesson to the world that multiples ought not to be treated as commodities. Yet, as John Bowe suggests, we continue to exploit them with a modern human zoo — the so-called reality show. Have we learned nothing from history?

headline: 30 Thanksgivings
text: Few things are as predictable in the life of a food writer as this: sometime in October, September if your editor is on the ball (November if he or she is not), you will be asked, “What are you writing about for Thanksgiving?”

headline: Dr. James Will Make It Better
text: In David Leonhardt’s article (Nov. 8), readers learn about standards of care to which all medical providers should aspire. Short shrift was given, however, to the role of the patient. Consumeruse of online quality-rating sites is not an accurate measure of interest regarding health care choices. Patients and families must become the center of care if we are to reform our system. Massachusetts is starting down a path toward health care payment reform and consumer engagement in their care through programs like shared decision making and chronic-disease management. Our health care system can only improve if medical providers learn how to engage patients so that they can make treatment decisions together.

headline: Where Do You Stand? Responding to the Pending Health Care Legislation
text: Overview | What values are evident in the policy proposals coming out of the current health care debate? How do our own values shape our views on health care reform? How do the proposals now pending in Congress compare? In this lesson, students express their views about the pending health care reform and examine comparisons of the House and Senate bills.

headline: The Price of Free
text: What surprised me about Nicholas Carr’s analysis of the potential breakdown of broadcast TV as we know it was that he never considered how ads may factor into the equation. One of the few growth areas in media spending is in broadband TV ads. So-called preroll ads (15-to-30-second ads usually repurposed from TV) dominate the content on Hulu. Hulu has also been in testing mode on enabling users to choose which ads they watch or to answer a market-research survey rather than view the ads. Some of the most compelling ads have been from packaged-goods companies that appear as single-sponsor units for a program. The ads bookend the content and may appear within it too, and they have a story arcthat continues and pays off with the final ad after the episode.

headline: Stimulus Funds Stock Pantries and Soup Kitchens
text: Thanks to federal stimulus funds, fewer New York City food pantries and soup kitchens have had to turn people away in the past year, reversing the trend of the past several years, according to a survey released by the New York City Coalition Against Hunger. However, much of that financing is scheduled to sunset within a year, potentially creating an even greater shortfall as the demand for food benefits soars in the downturn.

headline: The Score: The End of Music
text: We seem to be on the edge of a paradigm shift. Orchestras are struggling to stay alive, rock has been relegated to the underground, jazz has stopped evolving and become a dead art, the music industry itself has been subsumed by corporate culture and composers are at their wit’s end trying to find something that’s hip but still appeals to an audience mired in a 19th-century sensibility.

headline: Quote Unquote | Carry On
text: — Carolina Herrera, explaining the reality of real women wearing her signature creations. Thus explaining her longevity in the biz.

headline: Can Modern Dance Be Preserved?
text: As a person who has dedicated her life to preserving movement and music — not specifically modern dance but African dance — I disagree with Arthur Lubow’s (Nov. 8) statement that “dance is the most fragile of the arts. Happening in the moment, it evaporates after every rendering. Unlike drama and music, which also unfold in time, dance is not dictated by a written script or score.” I emphatically state that any movement can be written with Labanotation, the leading system to document movement.

headline: Correction
text: An article on Nov. 15 about streaming TV programs directly from the Web, thereby bypassing cable service, referred incorrectly to Starz, a movie network. It is owned by Liberty Media Corporation — not by Showtime, which is owned by CBS.

headline: The China Flu Blues
text: Late in August, while our 747 circled the Beijing haze, I prepared to ply both my boys with pink, chewable Tylenol. I’d heard from friends that the capital had gone H1N1-quarantine-mad: locking up tourists in policed hotels, isolating children in hospital rooms. It was the start of our third year in China. We’d first come on my sinophile husband’s consulting visa, and happily stayed, learning Mandarin and walking the hutongs.

headline: ‘We Are All Prisoners,’ Iranian Blogger Says
text: In Iran, as my colleague Robert Worth reported on Tuesday, the government seems to be expanding its efforts to crack down on even the virtual freedom of its population, creating “a new police unit to sweep the Internet for dissident voices,” trying to assert greater control over the media and stationing paramilitaries at kindergartens across the country.

headline: Saab Deal Collapses
text: From our colleagues at DealBook:

headline: The High Low | A Détacher Knee Socks
text: Good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant but affordable gets. In this column, T’s fashion team finds the cheap and the chic.What: A Détacher ribbed woolen knee socksHow Much: $45 at A Détacher (262 Mott Street; 212-625-3380) and Project No. 8 (138 Division Street; 212-925.5599)Who: Melissa Ventosa Martin, senior market/fashion editor

headline: Thanksgiving 911: A Point of Reference
text: The AP just moved a story saying Butterball has 55 operators lined up to work the Thanksgiving rush; they expect to answer some 12,000 calls about turkey cooking on Thanksgiving Day. Well now! The Times has me and my Internet, my phone list (n.b., DO NOT CALL FLORENCE FABRICANT BEFORE 8 a.m.!),the books in the Charles Klaveness Library room, and a couple of duty editors and Web producers. And we’ll be on duty from dawn on Thursday through to 3 p.m., which is when mom says I have to go home. Have a question before then? Post it here, or on one of my other question chains here, here or here.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Tuesday, Nov. 24
text: It seemed last Friday as if it would be difficult to find a much more disturbing photograph from this period of the war in Afghanistan than that of a young boy who had been injured and hospitalized by a suicide bomber. But just such a photograph, by Nishanuddin Khan for The Associated Press, was transmitted Tuesday (Slide 8).

headline: U.S. Looks to Australia on Credit Card Fees
text: SYDNEY  When Steve Franklin bought four plane tickets on Qantas last June, he faced an unexpected expense: a surcharge of 7.70 Australian dollars on each of the 136.70 dollar ($126) tickets  just for using his Visa credit card.

headline: Activists Take Aim at ‘Insurance Democrats’
text: Despite pleas from the White House, some Democratic activists are gearing up for a renewed onslaught against … Democrats.

headline: A Body Transformed Through Dance
text: The choreographer Tamar Rogoff rehearses her new piece, “Diagnosis of a Faun,” with Gregg Mozgala, who has cerebral palsy. After a year of working with Ms. Rogoff, Mr. Mozgala has changed how he moves.

headline: Barn-Raising
text: When a brush fire destroyed two chicken houses at Soul Food Farm in Vacaville, Calif., in September, killing 1,200 chicks that would have been cooked rather differently at Chez Panisse, Alexis Koefoed was sure her business wouldn’t survive. The loss of two weeks’ income would put her young farm over the edge, especially since her husband had lost his job in June.

headline: Chicken Soup
text: Recipes adapted from Camino in Oakland, Calif.

headline: Learning His Body, Learning to Dance
text: Gregg Mozgala, a 31-year-old actor with cerebral palsy, had 12 years of physical therapy while he was growing up. But in the last eight months, a determined choreographer with an unconventional résumé has done what all those therapists could not: She has dramatically changed the way Mr. Mozgala walks.

headline: BlogTalk: Taking Sides on Afghanistan
text: In the next couple of days, as we prepare and then devour our sage and cornbread stuffing and cranberry relish, many of us will decide if we’re for the war in Afghanistan or against it, or whether we were for it before we were against it, or … Well, you get the picture.

headline: Tax Burdens, Around the World
text: Think you pay a lot of taxes in the United States? Try moving to Denmark.

headline: Census Worker’s Hanging Death Called Suicide
text: The Kentucky census worker found hanging from a tree with the word “fed” scrawled on his chest staged his death to look like a homicide so that his son could collect his life insurance, the authorities said Tuesday.

headline: Boho Tokyo
text: STYLE MAP DAIKANYAMA While Tokyo’s Aoyoma district is the place for supercharged shopping (Prada! Comme des Garçons! Gucci!) and Harajuku is devoted to fast fashion (H&M, Topshop), this hilly neighborhood offers a more mellow experience, with smaller shops on quiet, mazelike streets. The low-key backdrop is perfect for the country’s current obsession with all things earthy and indie. MAURA EGAN

headline: Avoiding Thanksgiving Travel Hassles
text: Traveling during Thanksgiving doesn’t have to be a nightmare if you know what to expect and what to avoid.

headline: Must Haves | Power Puff
text: Chanel bag, $1,295. Go to chanel.com.

headline: Violence in the Philippines
text: The death toll in Monday's election violence is 46. President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo has declared a state of emergency in two southern provinces.

headline: Injury to Bradshaw’s Other Foot May Limit Him More
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants running back Ahmad Bradshaw has a new injury. The Giants announced Tuesday that Bradshaw, who was on crutches and not in uniform when the team’s practice began, has a sprained left ankle that forced him out of last Sunday’s 34-31 victory over Atlanta.

headline: How to Cut Costs in Bad Times (and Good)
text: It doesn’t matter if the economy is going to improve quickly, slowly or not at all for the foreseeable future, saving money on the costs of running your business is always a good thing.

headline: Apps for the iPhone: A Traveler’s Companion, Pocket Size
text: IT’S a quarter to five in the morning, and I have a plane to catch in two hours. But why rush out the door if my flight is already delayed? To check its status, I turn to my iPhone, tap on an application called FlightTrack and pull up my flight. It’s on time. Better get out of bed. At the airport, I check for Wi-Fi and update all my newspaper apps (NYTimes, WSJ, USA Today and so on) so I have something to read onboard. And when I arrive at my destination, I use the iPhone to pull up the Yelp app, and its built-in mapping feature, to find the most highly user-rated bars and restaurants.

headline: In Iran, Fending Off Accusations of Ties to … New Jersey?
text: So now we know what really gives the Iranian regime nightmares.

headline: Short List | Claus Sendlinger
text: With his network of 180 independent lodgings, the founder of Design Hotels (designhotels.com) has created a one-stop shop for savvy travelers on the hunt for cool accommodations. When he’s not scouting new members (next up: the Park Hyderabad, India) and publishing glossy books (the newest is out next month), Sendlinger decompresses on Koh Tao, in Thailand. T asked him for a quick guide to the island’s charms.

headline: Sanford Impeachment Considered
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Over the protests of Gov. Mark Sanford’s lawyers, South Carolina lawmakers on Tuesday began the preliminary steps of a process that could lead to the governor’s impeachment and removal from office.

headline: Ski Patrol | Whet Your Whistler
text: The hordes won’t descend on Whistler and Blackcomb mountains until February, when the 21st Winter Olympic Games get under way. But the event has spurred a renaissance in the British Columbia resort town that the rest of us can enjoy before — and long after — the pros have come and gone.

headline: Right Anglo
text: Camden Passage, a narrow, stone-paved street in London’s Islington neighborhood, was once one of the city’s main antiques hubs, home to more than 350 shops. But in 2001, “trading in antiques hit a wall,” as one local proprietor put it, and businesses shut down or moved away. Then slowly the street came back to life, with a restaurant here, a chocolate shop there. (And not without controversy, as many Passage settlers feared that newcomers would mean higher rents.) Now Camden Passage has fully diversified, with a mix of stylish new shops and restaurants snug against the handful of antiques stores that held on.

headline: Atlas Shrugged
text: Artists have toyed with maps before  there’s Salvador Dalí’s Surrealist “Map of the World” and Jasper Johns’s splotchy sendup of the Lower 48, for starters. But “The Map as Art” (Princeton Architectural Press; $45), a new coffee table curiosity by Katharine Harmon, shows how much traction the idea has with artists today. “There’s been an exponential increase in map-related art in gallery and museum shows.” Harmon says. “The reason, I think, is that this is a time when we’re all disoriented.” Instead of collecting real maps, she compiled more than 350 works that deal with representations of place: Maya Lin’s Baltic birch plywood sculpture of the Caspian Sea, Ruth Watson’s globe made of animal tissue (with Antarctica done in brains), Vik Muniz’s six continents forged from old computer parts. Rand McNally seems a world away. [?][?][?] STEPHEN HEYMAN

headline: Gentry Points
text: IN-STORE F. M. ALLEN Those in the know call Franklin, Tenn., just outside Nashville, the “Malibu of Tennessee.” A small city with a lot of spending power  thanks to locals with names like Keith, Nicole and Wynonna  Franklin recently got a boost with the arrival of Will Woods’s men’s-wear shop F. M. Allen. (He also has a New York store.) Woods calls the brand “rugged yet elegant,” just right for the genteel country life. RIMA SUQI

headline: Bavarian Rhapsody
text: In 1914, The New York Times reported that Mary Portman, a freewheeling English aristocrat living in Germany, faced prison in Munich for unpaid debt on a lavish Arts and Crafts house in the Bavarian countryside. (British wartime laws prevented her from paying the $100,000 bill.)

headline: Now Ticking Earth Watch
text: When Charles Darwin landed on the Galápagos Islands in 1835, the 19 islands had a few hundred settlers. Today, the 30,000 people who live there pose a threat to its fragile biodiversity. In an effort to help pause time, if not reverse it, the Swiss watchmaker IWC Schaffhausen has pledged $500,000 per year to the Galápagos conservation group the Charles Darwin Foundation, and to raise awareness has created the Aquatimer Chronograph Edition Galápagos Islands ($6,500). It’s one of six new diver’s watches in the Aquatimer family, which was born in 1967  the same year tour groups first visited the islands. [?][?][?] JOSEPH PLAMBECK

headline: Talk
text: Value/ (val´ y) /n. / A principle or quality that someone holds dear. In the world of travel, “value” is often used in its monetary sense (i.e., a good experience at the right price), but increasingly it speaks to an even more important trend: people choosing trips that tie into their personal value systems, as in,‘We went to Tobago for our beach vacation because it reflects our values  local ownership, ecological preservation, sustainable development.

headline: Oriole Kooky
text: Barack Obama, microphone in hand, stares off into the distance of a nearly empty room, a bemused grin on his face that seems to say, “Where is everybody?” Suddenly, a woman beelinesto the president, climbs to join him on his platform  there’s no security around to stop her  and leans in for a kiss. The guy she’s with laughs and says, “Don’t mess up his face!” before snapping a picture. I’m at the National Great Blacks in Wax Museum in Baltimore, where Obama recently joined figures like Colin Powell, Zora Neale Hurston and Malcolm X, amid three floors of displays.

headline: Duly Noted
text: When I quit my job to work on a novel, my partner, Adam, agreed to support me — which was great, until his birthday loomed on the horizon. I didn’t exactly relish buying him presents with his own money. I’d have to get creative, but my last artsy phase ended in college, notwithstanding a glass-blowing workshop that yielded a pair of dysmorphic paperweights. Then I remembered our collection of hotel notepads.

headline: White Party
text: Correction Appended

headline: Miami Social
text: Editors' Note Appended

headline: Brand New Heavies
text: In addition to real-estate-market chaos, Miami’s construction boom also ushered in nine important new hotels. From boutique to behemoth, these new properties all have one thing in common: vacancies.

headline: Cuba Libre
text: Nowhere in Miami is the Latino flavor as strong as in Little Havana. The long, sometimes chaotic Calle Ocho (SW Eighth Street) is the neighborhood’s heart  and not for the unprepared. Here’s a primer:

headline: Chino Latino
text: A host of high-end Asian restaurants have opened around town in recent months  almost as many as the city’s dozens of divey but delicious Latino-food joints. Here, a dish-by-dish comparison of Miami’s two great international cuisines, and where to sample the best of each.

headline: The Late Show
text: If New York is the city that never sleeps, then Miami just disco-naps. Whatever your idea of a party, there’s a spot to boogie or imbibe right through to breakfast.

headline: Prep School
text: BOOKS “Miami Babylon: Crime, Wealth, and Power  A Dispatch From the Beach,” by Gerald Posner (Simon & Schuster, 2009). An in-depth history of one of the weirdest cities in the world. “Fool’s Paradise: Players, Poseurs, and the Culture of Excess in South Beach,” by Steven Gaines (Crown, 2009). A snapshot of the vibrant characters  love them or loathe them  who made Miami Beach what it is today.

headline: ABC Drops Adam Lambert, and CBS Picks Him Up
text: Two days after giving a sexually charged performance at the American Music Awards, the singer Adam Lambert found himself abruptly dropped by one network morning show and just as abruptly booked on another.

headline: ‘Emperor Jones’ to Transfer Off Broadway
text: The reign of “The Emperor Jones” continues. The Irish Repertory Theater‘s production of that Eugene O’Neill play will transfer Off Broadway to the Soho Playhouse next month, its press representatives said on Tuesday. The play, which stars John Douglas Thompson as Brutus Jones, the prison convict turned island autocrat, will have a seven-week run at the Soho Playhouse, with previews scheduled to begin on Dec. 15 and an opening night set for Dec. 22. The production, directed by Ciaran O’Reilly, is slated to end its run at the Irish Rep on Dec. 6.

headline: This Is Your No-Hitter on Drugs
text: Animation |  An animated retelling of Dock Ellis’s legendary 1970 “LSD no-hitter.” The creators say the narration comes from an NPR interview the former major league pitcher gave a year before his death last December.

headline: Real Estate Executive Returns to Morgan Stanley
text: Devin Murphy has returned to Morgan Stanley‘s real estate division five years after he left to run Deutsche Bank‘s real estate investment banking division. Mr. Murphy will serve as a managing director and vice chairman in the investment banking division of the firm.

headline: From McSweeney’s, Part Newspaper and Part Ode to Newspapers
text: Due out on Dec. 8, the publication San Francisco Panorama promises to be part newspaper, part extravagant ode to newspapers. The 320-page broadsheet will include a magazine, food and art sections, comics and fiction, a 96-page book section and work by notable writers like Michael Chabon, Stephen King, Andrew Sean Greer, William T. Vollmann and Junot Díaz.

headline: Chris Bangle Recalls Controversial BMW 7 Series Design
text: Since leaving BMW’s top design post in March, Chris Bangle has been uncharacteristically quiet and out of the spotlight. He has been renovating a house near Turin, Italy, and setting up a design consultancy. But recently he emerged to speak at an event for the Wolfsonian-Florida International University Museum in Miami.

headline: GLAAD Reacts to Adam Lambert Controversy
text: Following the announcements on Tuesday that Adam Lambert had been dropped as a performer on ABC’s “Good Morning America” and subsequently booked as a guest on CBS’s “Early Show,” the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation has issued the following statement from its president, Jarrett Barrios:

headline: The N.F.I.B. Reconsiders Credit Card Reform
text: A couple of weeks ago, The Agenda reported that a measure intended to extend recently enacted consumer credit card protections to small business borrowers had been stymied by none other than the chair of the House Small Business Committee, Representative Nydia Velázquez. But Ms. Velázquez was not the only small-business advocate reluctant to get on board: The National Federation of Independent Business also declined to endorse the latest effort, a bill proposed by Representative Neil Abercrombie, of Hawaii.

headline: Facebook Will Form 2 Classes of Stock
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebook is taking a rudimentary step down the path to becoming a public company.

headline: Dancing to the Top
text: For the sixth time in seven weeks, ABC earned the most viewers on Monday night as “Dancing With the Stars” drew a season best: 20.5 million from 8 to 9:30 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. But that reality show’s ratings could not lift the debut of ABC’s new comedy “Find My Family” (12.9 million) ahead of its 9:30 competitor, “The Big Bang Theory” on CBS (14.2 million). CBS also won the 10 p.m. hour with “CSI: Miami” (13.2 million), which easily outperformed both “Castle” (10.5 million) on ABC and “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC (4.5 million). CBS was runner-up on the night, garnering strong ratings at 9 for “Two and a Half Men” (13.9 million). Fox was third and NBC was fourth.

headline: Curtains Are Drawn at the Gosselin House
text: For now, we’ll will see the Gosselin children only in repeats. About 4.3 million viewers watched the final installment of “Jon & Kate Plus 8” on Monday, Nielsen said; it was the end of the TLC series about the Gosselin twins and sextuplets and their parents, Jon and Kate Gosselin. Millions of new viewers flocked to TLC as the parents’ marriage unraveled earlier this year, temporarily creating a reality-TV sensation that some critics said was exploitative of the young children. The dispute between the Gosselins led to dueling lawsuits and a halt in production that all but forced TLC to pull the plug. “It’s sad it’s cut short,” Ms. Gosselin said on the episode that was shown Monday. “It’s been a great run.” TLC had planned to produce a new show, “Kate Plus Eight,” with a limited role for Mr. Gosselin, but the lawsuits have placed that idea on hold. The channel is still developing a separate project with Ms. Gosselin. It has not announced details, but the program is scheduled to have its premiere in the spring.

headline: A Hanging Locomotive Needs a Rich Friend
text: A train that is supposed to go nowhere seems to be going nowhere, at least for now. Plans by the artist Jeff Koons and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art to create an eye-popping piece of public art, a 70-foot replica of a 1943 locomotive engine designed to dangle nose-down from a 161-foot crane  are in limbo because the museum cannot pay for it, Bloomberg reported. The sculpture, estimated at $25 million, shown at right in a model, was expected to be completed in 2011 or 2012 in the museum’s entrance plaza. But the museum said the project had been pushed to 2014-15 because of the damage the economic downturn had done to its finances.
