Figures recently released show that its investment portfolio lost nearly a quarter of its value during the 2008-9 fiscal year, shrinking to $196 million from $254 million the previous year. Barbara Pflaumer, the museum’s associate vice president for communications and marketing, speaking of Mr. Koons’s engine project, told Bloomberg: “We wouldn’t do it unless someone funds it. Someone has to write us a check.” She added: “This is a very tough economy. Everyone has revised timetables.”

headline: Singing, Leaping Spider-Man Goes for Help
text: Michael Cohl, the new lead producer of the Broadway musical project “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark,” has approached Kevin McCollum and Jeffrey Seller, the Tony Award-winning producers of Broadway musicals and revivals including “Avenue Q,” “La Bohème” and “Rent,” about becoming producers of the show, according to three Broadway producers with knowledge of the conversations. The producers, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the conversations were private, said Mr. Cohl’s communications were in an initial phase and that Mr. McCollum and Mr. Seller did not have full financial details of the show. They have expertise in mounting large-cast shows (including Mr. McCollum’s new revival of “Ragtime”) and entertainment spectacles like “Avenue Q,” which features puppets. “Spider-Man,” which has had work stoppages this fall because of cash-flow problems that preceded Mr. Cohl, has been conceived as an extravaganza, complete with the S-Man himself swinging above the audience. Mr. Cohl, asked about Mr. McCollum and Mr. Seller in a telephone interview, said he was talking to “a lot of people,” and hoped to have news in December.

headline: In Stock Shift, Facebook Lays Ground for I.P.O.
text: Facebook is taking a rudimentary step down the path to becoming a public company, The New York Times’s Brad Stone reports from San Francisco.

headline: Sharing Family Tales on Thanksgiving
text: At their core, families are collections of stories. As generations disappear and as relatives spend more time apart than together, what makes a family are shared histories, shared tales.

headline: Ureña Is Heading Out of Town
text: Alex Ureña, who made a name for himself at Suba and Blue Hill, but couldn’t make a go of it at his restaurants Ureña and Pamplona, is heading to Philadelphia.

headline: Kelsey Grammer Is in Talks for ‘La Cage aux Folles’
text: Kelsey Grammer, best known as the star of the former NBC hit “Frasier,” is in talks to play Georges in the coming Broadway revival of “La Cage aux Folles,” according to two executives involved in the production. The British actor Douglas Hodge is set to reprise his role as Albin from the current London production of the show. The executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity because no contract had been signed, said they were optimistic that Mr. Grammer would be on board in the role, which was played by Robin Williams in the 1996 movie adaptation, “The Birdcage.”

headline: Report Aims to Clarify Climate Risk for Diplomats
text: A team of climate scientists, seeking to remind the negotiators who will hammer out a new climate treaty of what is at stake, has produced The Copenhagen Diagnosis, a summary of the latest peer-reviewed science on the anticipated impacts of human-driven global warming. In an interview, Richard Somerville, a climatologist at the University of California, San Diego, and a past contributor to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said the case for climate change as a serious risk to human affairs was clear, despite recent firestorms over some data sets and scientists’ actions.

headline: Not Pictured: African-American Customers
text: I am a consultant on the redesign of the Web site of a company with local franchises across the United States. A franchisee in San Diego mentioned that posting a generic picture of an African-American customer could deter potential business. He has never had an African-American client nor does he anticipate one. His clientele is 70 percent white, 29 percent Hispanic and 1 percent Asian. Each local office will have a Web page and could have its own generic customer photo. May race be a factor in choosing it? TERRY KAVANAUGH, BIRMINGHAM, MICH.

headline: Extra, Extra
text: The buzz is building for McSweeney’s Issue 33 — or, as they’re calling it, The San Francisco Panorama, a Sunday-edition-sized newspaper with reporting from William Vollmann and Nicholson Baker, comics from Chris Ware and Daniel Clowes, and a book review section to make us advertising-based life forms jealous: 100-plus pages, including new fiction from George Saunders and a report about romance-novel cover models.

headline: CNN Explains Policy on Political Consultants
text: CNN responded Tuesday to criticism about one of its political commentators, Alex Castellanos, by saying it maintained the same policy for him that it has had for other paid political analysts.

headline: Let’s Not Get Crazy, Now
text: Tuesday afternoon and reality’s starting to kick in a little: those people related to you are preparing to come to your house, expecting to be fed. Those friends you invited because…? They’re coming too. Day after tomorrow. It’s time. Don’t lose it now.

headline: In Mumbai, Reinforcing a Resilient Spirit
text: Mumbai, India  Divya Thakur, the founder of Design Temple, a product, furniture and graphics firm based in Mumbai, lives in a three-bedroom three-bathroom apartment behind the Taj Mahal Palace & Tower hotel. A year ago, the hotel and several other city landmarks were the targets of terrorist attacks. Some people living so close to such tragedy and violence may have considered moving, but Mumbai and its people are known for their hardy spirit. Ms. Thakur, 38, didn’t let it faze her.

headline: What You Get for ... $300,000
text: STUYVESANT, N.Y.

headline: Inhofe Seeks Probe of Climate Science
text: After hackers obtained and disclosed the e-mail correspondence of numerous prominent climate scientists last week, Senator James Inhofe of Oklahoma, the most outspoken global warming skeptic in Congress, said Tuesday that he’d begun an investigation into what he alleges to be the manipulation of global warming research.

headline: With New Route, Thanksgiving Parade Gets a Few New Twists
text: Three hundred extra steps. Three extra turns. Two new avenues.

headline: Confirmed Black Friday Phone Deals
text: With Black Friday on the horizon, the seasonal deals are begging to leak out. Here are some of the Friday phone offers I have confirmed.

headline: Magazine Publishers to Build an Online Newsstand
text: A consortium of magazine publishers including Time Inc. and Condé Nast are jointly building an online newsstand for magazines in multiple digital formats, according to people familiar with the plans.

headline: A Widget for Sky-High Wi-Fi
text: Airlines have made it easy for travelers to do just about everything on line except reserve seats for Red Sox games, and now American has added a new twist for flyers with laptop computers.

headline: Zagat Releases 2009 Airline Survey
text: “If there was any less legroom, I’d have to check my legs,” said one reviewer. Another wrote, “”Should I have to pay extra for my knees?”

headline: A Story So Complicated It Needs Two Playwrights
text: The Trojan War, the monumental conflict that spanned a decade (doesn’t seem so long at the moment, does it?) and has inspired artists for a few millenniums, essentially boils down to a lot of smack talked in a sandbox in “The Age of Iron,” a labored epic adapted and directed by Brian Kulick for the Classic Stage Company from two separate plays from the early 17th century.

headline: Bay Bridge Shows Literal Signs of Life
text: The Bay Bridge never ceases to preoccupy Bay Area minds. In the extreme, The Chronicle wrote yesterday, bad thoughts about the bridge may seriously affect your life by forcing some to take the long way around (an extra 16 miles) every time they want to go from the city to the East Bay or Oakland to the West Bay (as some in Oakland call San Francisco).

headline: Pixies Celebrate Milestone for Fans of a Cult Album
text: “Doolittle,” a 1989 album by the Pixies, is an arty, violent, candy-striped record. It has surf music’s reverb serenity, backed by cool and steady-drip eighth-note rhythm patterns. Its singing comes in babbles, yells and coos, its lyrics in drownings, bleedings and hangings. Compressed into short songs, those eerie elements become eerier still.

headline: State Dinner: List of Attendees
text: Approximately 300 people were expected to attend Tuesday night's state dinner in honor of Manmohan Singh, the prime minister of India. The following list of attendees was released by the White House:

headline: A Three-Bedroom Apartment in Mumbai
text: Divya Thakur, the founder of the Design Temple, created her own rendition of an Indian courtyard, with plenty of natural light.

headline: Spare Change for Homeless? Cuomo Sees a Sham and Sues
text: In Manhattan, they are as common a sight as the homeless themselves: the United Homeless Organization’s street-corner donation tables, operated with little more than a large plastic jug and a worker pleading for coins and bills for the needy.

headline: 1 New Car = 30 Vacations
text: In honor of the approaching holiday shopping season, Dan Ariely, a behavioral economics professor at Duke, explains how to think about your purchases in terms of opportunity costs. He also offers a few tips for ways to become a more conscientious penny-pincher:

headline: Rihanna: Fiercely Introspective
text: LOS ANGELES  “Barf!” Rihanna squealed, at the sight of a pair of pale pink satin Brian Atwood stilettos. In her world this is a compliment. “Usually it’s ‘ill’ or ‘I want to throw up on it,’ ” she explained. “But barf is the worst,” meaning the best. “Barf is 10 out of 10.”

headline: Philippine Government Blamed for Creating ‘Monster’ to Battle Insurgents
text: As more bodies were recovered after a massacre on Monday on the Philippine island of Mindanao, bringing the death toll to 46, an expert on the region blamed the government of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo for arming the powerful clan accused of carrying out the killings in the country’s southern region.

headline: When a Bombastic Young Man Bestrode the Boards of the Mercury Theater
text: The action in “Me and Orson Welles” takes place in 1937 during a single hectic week bookended by two moments of relative tranquillity in which a boy (Zac Efron) meets a girl (Zoe Kazan). In the film’s final scene, as they stroll out of the New York Public Library, the girl, an aspiring writer, bubbles with enthusiasm about the world of music, art and literature that seems to be opening up all around them. So much is going on! So much to be part of!

headline: For Samsung, It’s Black Week. But is it a Bargain?
text: Black Friday may come only once a year, but that day of seemingly extra-low prices is getting longer and longer. Samsung, Amazon, Costco, and others are now offering lower-than-usual prices for several days surrounding Thanksgiving.

headline: The Remains of the Day
text: SUE MADEN was peeling and slicing apples for the double-crusted pie she planned to take as her contribution to dinner at a friend’s house, but a worry was nagging her.

headline: The Urban Deerslayer
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.

headline: Trailer: Borderlands
text: The combat shooter game, developed by Gearbox Software and published by 2K Games for the PlayStation 3, Xbox 360 and Windows, is not edifying but it is hardly mindless either.

headline: House Hunting in ... Germany
text: A SIX-BEDROOM 17TH-CENTURY HOUSE IN HATTINGEN

headline: Hero Who Can’t Keep His Shirt On
text: The best thing about “Ninja Assassin” is its refreshingly honest title: unlike those few, unwary souls who rush to “Precious” solely on the strength of its twee title and happy-go-lucky television trailers, no one who sees “Ninja Assassin” can reasonably complain about the violence.

headline: Power and Style, in the Ring and the World
text: In the late 1930s, when he was still an amateur fighter, Sugar Ray Robinson began lugging an old Victrola record player around with him on the road. He’d bring a stack of records too, the good stuff: some Jelly Roll Morton and Duke Ellington and Fats Waller.

headline: The Thrill’s in the Gunplay, With Lots of Guns to Play With
text: People go through life looking for different things. Some want money. Others crave fame or are driven by sex. Many are motivated by family. And a few just want love.

headline: Chief of I.M.F. Urges Continued Stimulus Efforts
text: PARIS  The chief of the International Monetary Fund urged the world’s major economies on Tuesday to retain their economic stimulus programs until there were durable signs of a recovery, including an end to rising unemployment.

headline: The Insider | Luis Venegas
text: The Insider profiles emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here, Luis Venegas, the Madrid-based publishing phenom behind the magazines Fanzine137 and Electric Youth, shares his essentials. Last week, Venegas introduced Candy, which is billed as the world’s first “transversal” (a catchall for transvestism, transsexualism and androgyny) style magazine. The cover features Luke Worral, a k a Mr. Kelly Osbourne, in drag.

headline: A Bit Mangy, but Up for New Tricks
text: To describe the knockabout family comedy “Old Dogs” as a ramshackle mess doesn’t begin to evoke the confusion and sloppy continuity of a movie whose disconnected parts sometimes appear to have been randomly assembled from a cutting-room scrap heap. “Chaos reigns,” the apocalyptic catchphrase from Lars von Trier’s “Antichrist,” might be more accurate. Even those professional charmers John Travolta and Robin Williams have their hands full trying to infuse some levity into their stick-figure characters.

headline: Triathletes, on Your Mark ...Whoa!
text: RICK MOTTER remembers the first twinge.

headline: Teenage Hero Wears His Powers on His Wrist
text: MTV and VH1 gave up on music. The Learning Channel gave up on learning. Lately, Cartoon Network has been giving up on cartoons. Chunks of its schedule are consigned to nonanimated fare like “Survive This” (“Survivor” for teenagers), “The Othersiders” (“Ghost Hunters” for teenagers) or “Dude, What Would Happen?” (“Mythbusters” for teenagers).

headline: Phone Deals From a Store You Have Never Heard Of
text: Traditionally, mobile phone carriers like T-Mobile, AT&T, Verizon and Sprint don’t offer many Black Friday specials. After all, phones aren’t especially seasonal, and if you’ve got a two-year contract, unless you purchased the phone during the holidays originally, you’re not in the market now.

headline: A Voce Columbus
text: THERE are two A Voce restaurants in New York City. One opened in 2006, off Madison Square Park. It is dark and almost romantic, loud when crowded, pretty after a fashion, perfectly good. The other opened in September on the third floor of the Time Warner Center, in the space that used to be Café Gray. The second restaurant is bright and airy, loud when crowded, pretty after a fashion, also perfectly good.

headline: That Old Bayou Magic: Kiss and Ribbit (and Sing)
text: It’s not easy being green, the heroine of “The Princess and the Frog” discovers. But to judge from how this polished, hand-drawn movie addresses, or rather strenuously avoids, race, it is a lot more difficult to be black, particularly in a Disney animated feature. If you haven’t heard: Disney, the company that immortalized pale pretties like Snow White and the zip-a-dee-doo-dah of plantation living in “Song of the South,” has made a fairy tale about a black heroine, a character whose shoulders and story prove far too slight for all the hopes already weighing her down. It’s no wonder she’s soon jumping into the bayou, green legs and all.

headline: With Stent’s Help, Medtronic’s Profit Increases 59%
text: Medtronic, a maker of heart rhythm devices, said its quarterly profit rose 59 percent, helped by sales of a new heart stent, and it raised its forecast for full-year earnings.

headline: The State Dinner Guest List
text: The official guest list is out. Many of the names have already leaked out – Katie Couric, for example, sent the news out herself hours ago via Twitter – but the roster released by the White House contains several names not previously known.

headline: A.I.G. Moves Ahead With Pay Package for Chief
text: The American International Group said Tuesday that it had moved ahead with a previously announced compensation package for its new chief executive, Robert H. Benmosche, giving him $7 million in cash and stock, after he reaffirmed his commitment to stay at the bailed-out insurance company.

headline: Closer to the Bone
text: Urban food lovers learn how to hunt, butcher and cook venison in a class called "Deer Hunting for Locavores" taught in Charlottesville, Va.

headline: 3rd M.V.P. Puts Pujols in Select Company
text: Albert Pujols said he does not think about his place in history. But whether he worries about it or not, he has already entered velvet-rope territory, a realm occupied by the sport’s elite.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 4,356 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

headline: A Bed Where Comfort Is Not the Point
text: STOCKHOLM  A Hindu spirit is stalking the streets of Stockholm, armed with this Nordic capital’s latest fad: the nail bed.

headline: Bill’s Bar and Burger
text: Bill’s Bar and Burger

headline: Gulluoglu
text: Gulluoglu

headline: India’s Guard Is Up, but Weaknesses Remain
text: MUMBAI, India  A year after the deadly assault here by Pakistan-based militants that killed 163 people, this sprawling mega-city is a more cautious and safer place, but it remains vulnerable despite government pledges to overhaul security.

headline: App of the Week: TGI Black Friday
text: I have a friend who awaits the annual e-mailing of the Black Friday Excel Spreadsheet with greater anticipation than the gifts that may come from it. The coveted list is a compilation of leaked deals coming up on the Friday after Thanksgiving.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Sushi Class With Sake

headline: Off the Menu
The Word of Mouth
text: Remember restaurants? I review them for a living, when I’m not answering readers’ questions about cooking for the forthcoming Thanksgiving holiday. This week I write about A Voce Columbus. It’s an Italian place on the third floor of the Time Warner Center, an uptown version of the A Voce off Madison Square Park where Andrew Carmellini was chef. Mr. Carmellini left before the new restaurant opened (he’s now at Locanda Verde); the chef at both A Voce restaurants is Missy Robbins. She’s very good — better perhaps than the stage upon which she cooks. Have you been to either A Voce? To both of them? Which do you prefer? Let’s talk about food this week, restaurant locations and the culture of dining out. Post a comment below.

headline: Putting Her Baking Skills to the Test
text: When ciabatta, the chewy yet airy Italian bread, became a food trend in New York 15 years ago, Sarah Black, above, was busy turning the loaves out at her company, Campanio, in Queens. She sold the bakery 10 years ago and is now in charge of the baking at Fairway markets. She is training the stores’ 30 bakers in her artisanal techniques, like being picky about ingredients and hand-shaping breads. They are now baking muffins, scones, cookies, brownies and yes, ciabatta, and have turned out 12,000 Thanksgiving pies.

headline: Potato Tortillas
text: EDER MONTERO would like to set one thing straight regarding potato tortillas: they should not be as brown as, well, a plate of hash browns.

headline: A Pretzel Shop With a Zesty Twist
text: Lina Kulchinsky, a lawyer turned pastry chef, did not want to open an everyday bakery. One day her husband brought her a pretzel from a street cart and an idea clicked.

headline: Comfort in a Pot
text: Steaming bowls sustain body and soul in the cold months. Your grandmother probably knew how to fill this need and the Japanese certainly do, as Tadashi Ono and Harris Salat so deftly demonstrate in “Japanese Hot Pots: Comforting One Pot Meals” (Ten Speed Press, $25).

headline: Lou Dobbs Weighs Senate Run, as a Steppingstone
text: The Lou Dobbs-for-Senate rumor had barely crested when the Lou Dobbs-for-president rumor suddenly overtook it this week.

headline: Modern Flourishes at Obamas’ State Dinner
text: WASHINGTON  It is an old tradition, a White House dinner governed by ritual and protocol that happens to be this city’s hottest social event. But at their first state dinner on Tuesday night, President Obama and his wife, Michelle, made sure to infuse the glittering gala with distinctive touches.

headline: Obama Writes to Brazil’s Leader About Iran
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  President Obama sent a letter on Sunday to President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil reiterating the American position on Iran’s nuclear program, a day before Iran’s president made his first state visit to Brazil, an aide to Mr. da Silva said Tuesday.

headline: Citation for Gesture Costs Pittsburgh
text: PITTSBURGH  The City of Pittsburgh has agreed to pay $50,000 to a man who sued after being issued a disorderly conduct citation for gesturing offensively at a police officer.

headline: Bar Owner Stood Firm and Won Lower Fees
text: SYDNEY  The Merivale Group, Sydney’s largest operator of upscale restaurants and bars, sees itself as the company that fought American Express and won.

headline: Schumer Faults Adidas for Overseas Production
text: Adidas is planning to move most production of N.B.A. players’ official jerseys and shorts out of the United States, managers of the main factory producing the gear said on Tuesday.

headline: Washington Post to Shut U.S. Bureaus
text: The Washington Post will close its last three remaining national bureaus in a cost-cutting move, Kris Coratti, the paper’s director of communications, said Tuesday.

headline: Can’t Cut the Budget? Let Me Do It, Paterson Tells an Unmoved Legislature
text: ALBANY  New York’s budget impasse will last at least another week.

headline: Giants Find Something Elemental Is Missing
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Last season, the consistent strength of the Giants’ offense was a combination of three running backs known as Earth, Wind and Fire.

headline: In Holiday Season Adjusted for Recession, Chicago Finds a Tree to Fit
text: CHICAGO  This city’s Christmas tree, which by tradition will be lighted by Mayor Richard M. Daley on Wednesday, has already suffered slights.

headline: Abe Pollin, Team Owner and Philanthropist, Dies at 85
text: Abe Pollin, the owner of the N.B.A.’s Washington Wizards, who built the sports arena that revitalized downtown Washington and was known for his wide-ranging philanthropy, died Tuesday. He was 85.

headline: A Pretty Darn Valuable Player
text: Chase Utley, the Philadelphia Phillies second baseman, might very well be considered the National League’s best player but for the presence of Albert Pujols. Utley, who hit five home runs in the World Series, finished eighth in the voting for this year’s N.L. Most Valuable Player award, won by Pujols, and that is nothing new. He and Pujols are the only two players who have finished in the top 15 of the N.L. voting in each of the past five seasons. Pujols has three awards, Utley none.

headline: Theodore Roosevelt IV Opts Out of G.O.P. Race for Senate
text: Few people knew that he was thinking about it in the first place, but Theodore Roosevelt IV, a wealthy investment banker with serious credentials on environmental issues and in foreign policy  and of course, that famous name  now says he will not seek the Republican nomination for the Senate from New York in 2010.

headline: Johnson and Damon, a Nascar Fan, Share a Victory Lap in Manhattan
text: Less than 48 hours after winning an unprecedented fourth consecutive Nascar Sprint Cup championship in Homestead, Fla., Jimmie Johnson took a private elevator Tuesday to the observation deck of the Empire State Building with Johnny Damon, the stock-car racing fan (and Yankees left fielder).

headline: Contenders Are Circling, Even Before Fight Is Set
text: The calls started two days after Manny Pacquiao bloodied and battered Miguel Cotto to capture his record seventh title in seven weight divisions. They came from representatives of sites across the country, from stadiums in Los Angeles, Texas, Louisiana and New York.

headline: Seeking Deals, Holiday Fliers Get Early Start
text: CHICAGO  Airports big and small will be packed on Wednesday, just as they are every year on the day before Thanksgiving.

headline: Mets Complete Coaching Staff
text: A busy day in Mets-land on Tuesday. No, they didn’t make any trades or sign any free agents. Rather, they announced a new retro pinstripe home uniform and completed the coaching staff that will assist Jerry Manuel in 2010.

headline: From the Hospital to Bankruptcy Court
text: NASHVILLE  Some of the debtors sitting forlornly in this city’s old stone bankruptcy court have lost a job or gotten divorced. Others have been summoned to face their creditors because they spent mindlessly beyond their means. But all too often these days, they are there merely because they, or their children, got sick.

headline: After Some Requests, Bruno Jury Chooses to Reconvene Monday
text: ALBANY  After one day of deliberation, the jury in the corruption trial of Joseph L. Bruno, the former State Senate majority leader, left the federal courthouse here on Tuesday without reaching a verdict, and opted to resume on Monday.

headline: When Dreams Take Flight
text: Weston, Conn.

headline: James Berg, Landlords’ Peacemaker, Dies at 65
text: James F. Berg, who as the chief negotiator for most of New York City’s major landlords was given large credit for an era of labor peace in their buildings because of the trust he inspired on both sides of the bargaining table, died Nov. 18 in Manhattan. He was 65 and lived in Bay Shore, N.Y.

headline: Even in Recession, Some Small Businesses Grow
text: Many small businesses have found themselves treading water, at best, during the recession. But, that is not true for everyone. In fact, a significant minority of resilient companies have been able to do the seemingly impossible and increase revenue in these troubled times. According to a recent survey of 300 small-business clients conducted by SurePayroll, a payroll service based in Chicago, about 30 percent of respondents said their sales increased over the last year.

headline: N.F.L. Head Injury Study Leaders Quit
text: In the latest indication that the National Football League will redirect its approach to players’ concussions, the co-chairmen of the league’s committee on brain injuries resigned from the group Tuesday, the league announced.

headline: Housekeeping
text: UrbanEye will be in a food coma until (at least) Friday, and will return on Monday. And when it does, it will have new hands on deck: Melena Ryzik will be off bagging carpets, and the inimitable Julie Bloom will be taking over e-mail duties. Send her a wink at urbaneye@nytimes.com.

headline: Breaking It Down
text: “There has never been anything on Broadway,” writes Ben Brantley, like “Fela!” about the Nigerian musical revolutionary Fela Anikulapo-Kuti. Choreographed and conceived by Bill T. Jones, produced by Jay-Z and Jada Pinkett Smith, this musical “throbs with a stirring newness that is not to be confused with novelty,” Mr. Brantley writes. In transferring from Off Broadway, it “acquired greater focus, clarity and intensity,” but its Afrobeat sound, as performed by Antibalas still makes you want to dance in the street. Get your tickets now.

headline: Brush With Greatness
text: “Me and Orson Welles,” the story of a teenager (Zac Efron, avec hair) who encounters Welles at work in a theater in 1937, “is necessary viewing for anyone whose imagination has been seduced by the charms of art,” writes A.O. Scott. Directed by Richard Linklater, the movie deals with some classic scenarios: boy meets girl, the vagaries of backstage life and the fun of having an oversize ego. “Art is a fairy tale we choose to believe in,” Mr. Scott writes, “and this movie, a fiction confected about real people, is too good not to be true.”

headline: Pre-Feast Fete
text: You may not be able to volunteer on Thanksgiving, but you can party on Thanksgiving eve. Head to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, tonight for a “proper warehouse party” courtesy of MeanRed. There will be D.J.’s and drinks and, you know, space  all the things you won’t get when you visit your family.

headline: Notre Dame Athletic Director Welcomes the Glare
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  As dusk gave way to darkness here Saturday night, Athletic Director Jack Swarbrick sang the alma mater on the field at Notre Dame Stadium in the aftermath of the Fighting Irish’s double-overtime loss to UConn.

headline: Afghan Strategy Will Contain Messages to Several Audiences
text: WASHINGTONIn declaring Tuesday that he would “finish the job” in Afghanistan, President Obama used a phrase clearly meant to imply that even as he deploys an additional 30,000 or so troops, he has finally figured out how to bring the eight-year-long conflict to an end.

headline: These Rates Would Shock a Loan Shark
text: Just in time for Thanksgiving last year, a credit card offer arrived in the mail. The (introductory) rate was 2 percent. Malcolm S. jumped. A student at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn, Malcolm was looking after the affairs of a grandfather in a nursing home.

headline: Uzbekistan: Opposition Leader Sent to U.S. After Early Release From Prison
text: Sanjar Umarov, an Uzbek opposition leader imprisoned on charges that his supporters said were fabricated, returned to freedom in the United States over the weekend. Mr. Umarov, who led the Sunshine Uzbekistan opposition movement, was granted amnesty and released from a labor camp on Nov. 7. His wife and three of his children are American citizens, and he is recuperating at a family home in Tennessee, his family said. After the crackdown on antigovernment demonstrators in Andijon in 2005, Mr. Umarov emerged as a vocal critic of President Islam A. Karimov. He was arrested that fall and charged with tax fraud and other violations and was sentenced to more than 12 years in prison. His lawyers and family said he was tortured and perhaps drugged during the trial. His release followed extensive lobbying by his family, human rights groups and the American government.

headline: Crack Pipes Found After Fire That Hurt Ex-Knicks Player
text: Fire marshals are investigating whether crack pipes discarded in a Bronx row house played a part in sparking a fire on Sunday that critically injured Dean Meminger, a former player for the New York Knicks.

headline: California Takes Step to Limit Emissions
text: WASHINGTON  California has taken a major step toward creating a broad-based trading system to limit emissions of pollutants blamed for harmful climate change.

headline: Galleon Chief Attacks Government’s Case Against Him
text: Five weeks after he was arrested on charges of masterminding a vast insider-trading scheme, Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire money manager, answered his accusers on Tuesday with a sharp-edged attack on the government’s case against him.

headline: Lottery Numbers
An Evolve-By Date
text: Yesterday, Tuesday, Nov. 24, was The Big Day: it was exactly 150 years since Charles Darwin’s “On the Origin of Species” was first published. In this book, Darwin described how evolution by natural selection works — and presented a huge body of evidence, drawn from every field of biology then known, that evolution can account for the patterns we see in nature.

headline: Poland: Former Leader Sues President
text: Lech Walesa, Poland’s former president and leader of the Solidarity movement, took President Lech Kaczynski to court on Tuesday. Mr. Walesa is seeking about $36,000 in damages over Mr. Kaczynski’s charge that Mr. Walesa collaborated with the state secret service under Communism. Neither man was in court. The proceedings were adjourned until Dec. 18, the newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reported on its Web site. A court cleared Mr. Walesa in 2000 of the persistent charge that he had worked as an agent known as “Bolek” for the secret police.

headline: Counting Blessings
text: A fire, deliberately set, at Hope for the Future Ministries in East Farmingdale, N.Y., took away a reliable source of food for the needy in Manhattan and on Long Island. But word of the fire brought in a host of donations.

headline: Same Team, Dressed Differently
text: First minor league coaches, then planters with orange and blue flowers, and now new old uniforms: The Mets haven’t signed any players this off-season, but they are busy nonetheless.

headline: Nets Have Dug a Big Hole, but Their Foundation Is in Place
text: The Nets have lost their first 14 games in a start that is threatening to make their season irrelevant before the calendar turns to 2010. The long-term future, however, looks a lot brighter.

headline: On ‘The Biggest Loser,’ Health Can Take Back Seat
text: LOS ANGELES  When more than 40 former contestants from “The Biggest Loser” gather Wednesday for a reunion television special, the winner of the program’s first season, Ryan C. Benson, who lost 122 of his 330-pound starting weight, will be absent. Mr. Benson is now back above 300 pounds but he thinks he has been shunned by the show because he publicly admitted that he dropped some of the weight by fasting and dehydrating himself to the point that he was urinating blood.

headline: Toasts by the President and the Prime Minister
text: Following is a transcript of toasts by President Obama and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India at the state dinner on Nov. 24, provided by the White House.

headline: M*A*S*H Extra
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — There was a recent discussion among some crossword constructors about how to clue the word NURSE. Past descriptions have included “Surgeon’s assistant” or “M*A*S*H extra.” The former clue seems to relegate the nurse to a mere supporting role. The latter is particularly troublesome because in both the movie and the TV show, some of the main characters were nurses and extras could be found with any job description. The implication was that all this was borderline demeaning to a noble profession and perhaps even sexist. (Constructors are overwhelmingly male. Solvers, as far as I can tell, split more or less evenly.)

headline: Redevelopment Project Doubles as Social Experiment
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  This city of elegant luxury condominium towers and grand public spaces won the right to hold the 2010 Winter Olympic Games in part because of a promise to create “the inclusive Olympics.” But critics have long complained about a blotch on the city’s self-image as an urban utopia: the Downtown Eastside, a notorious high-poverty neighborhood known for its concentration of homeless people and drug and crime problems.

headline: Independent Skype Set for Executive Shakeup
text: Last week, Skype became a newly independent company, formally separating from its parent of the last four years, eBay. Now the Internet phone company, with major offices in Luxembourg and London, is set for a significant reorganization of its management team.

headline: Overcoming Fire and Ice, a Food Pantry Perseveres
text: When a church food pantry burns down 10 days before Thanksgiving, many problems arise  most of them bad, a few of them good, though problems just the same.

headline: Holiday on Thursday: Thanksgiving
text: NEW YORK

headline: Corrections
text: Because of editing errors, an article on Saturday about an increase in test preparation programs for New York City preschoolers misstated the occupation of Meredith Resnick of Bright Kids NYC, who helped a 3-year-old with a visual analogy, and referred incorrectly to Robin MacFarlane, who said she expected to sell more than a thousand prep kits for a reasoning exam this year. Ms. Resnick is a supervisor of tutors, not a tutor herself, and Dr. MacFarlane developed a test study system for kindergartners; she does not work for Thinking to Learn, a company that sells enrichment materials.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about President Obama’s strategy for committing more American troops to the war in Afghanistan misidentified the office held by Angela Merkel of Germany, whose country supplies troops for the American-led coalition. She is chancellor, not prime minister.

headline: Q. & A. With Jack Swarbrick
text: Notre Dame Athletic Director Jack Swarbrick talked to Pete Thamel of The Times. Here is a transcript of the interview.

headline: Official Charged With Closing Guantánamo Quits
text: WASHINGTON  The Defense Department official in charge of closing the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, has resigned after only seven months in the job, the Pentagon said Tuesday.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Habs Tattoo Blue Jackets
text: Only one game on Tuesday night, and it was hardly a classic matchup: the Canadiens, with their grim 3-11-9 regulation record, playing host to the Blue Jackets, who had taken at least a point from eight of their previous 10 games. Unfortunately, the Jacks’ two fruitless outings were a 9-1 loss at home to Detroit and a 7-4 loss in New York on Monday.

headline: Budget Hawks Have a Buffet of Options With Health Bill
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Monday about the second round of the rain-shortened L.P.G.A. Tour Championship in Richmond, Tex., misidentified the home state of Kristy McPherson, who was the leader in the clubhouse after play was suspended on Sunday. McPherson was born in Conway, S.C., and now lives in Tampa, Fla.; she is not a Texan.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing of credits and schedule information on Tuesday with a review of “Fela!” at the Eugene O’Neill Theater misstated the timing of its run. It is open-ended; it is not scheduled to close on April 4.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in the Escapes pages on Friday about theater in Seattle, where the playwright August Wilson lived for more than a decade and worked at the Seattle Repertory Theater, misstated the history of the production of his 10-play cycle about African-American life in the 20th century. The Seattle Repertory Theater is not the only one in the nation to have produced the entire cycle. The article also misstated the name of one of the small and midsize theaters that have closed in Seattle. It was the Empty Space Theater, not the Empty Stage.

headline: Corrections
Spotlight on Schwarzenegger’s No. 2
text: It was the type of Must See TV that NBC was no doubt hoping for when it handed over its 10 p.m. slot to Jay Leno. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, a big star facing an even bigger state deficit, was there on the Leno show on Monday, smiling, as he announced his selection for lieutenant governor.

headline: State Courts at the Tipping Point
text: State courts are not just another government agency. They are at the center of the nation’s legal system and enforcement of the rule of law, handling more than 95 percent of all civil and criminal litigation. This vital institution  constitutionally, an independent, co-equal branch of government  has been spiraling into crisis as cash-starved states struggle with huge deficits.

headline: Keeping Personal Data Private
text: In 2006, a Veterans Affairs Department analyst lost a laptop and external drive with Social Security numbers and other personal data from more than 26 million veterans and active duty troops. There was a national call for a federal law to protect this sort of data  as there has been after other big data breaches  but nothing was done. Finally, a bill is moving in the Senate that would put more protections in place for personal data.

headline: Don’t Forget the Gulf States
text: The recession has wreaked a special kind of havoc in the Katrina-ravaged Gulf states, where the effort to rebuild housing for low-income workers and their families is in danger of coming to a halt. Unless Congress acts quickly, more than 70 different housing developments totaling more than 6,000 units might never get built. That would be terrible for the Gulf region, which needs a lot more affordable housing and a large low-wage work force to drive its recovery.

headline: At Año Nuevo Point
text: Something about a sea otter looks so insouciant. Drifting on its back, bobbing up and down in the waves, it looks over at the humans standing on the rocks as if to exaggerate its ease in the water, its complacent, buoyant virtuosity. There is not merely one sea otter here on the north side of the point at Año Nuevo State Park, a couple of dozen miles north of Santa Cruz, Calif. There are perhaps 20 in sight, parents and young.

headline: Fighting Hunger in Difficult Times
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rep. Kennedy, Not Welcome to Receive Communion
text: To the Editor:

headline: Governor Paterson and the 9/11 Trial
text: To the Editor:

headline: Thanks for the Memories
text: WASHINGTON

headline: You Say Potato, I Say Yam
text: ON Oct. 3, 1863, President Abraham Lincoln declared the final Thursday of November to be a national holiday of Thanksgiving. That came just over a year after Lincoln made another more historic proclamation, one that directly concerned my family and their future: the Emancipation Proclamation, which had freed the enslaved in any territory “in rebellion.”

headline: False Alarm on Abortion
text: Wellesley, Mass.

headline: Corrections
text: An obituary and a headline on Saturday about Albert V. Crewe, the University of Chicago physicist who in 1970 designed an electron microscope that captured images of individual atoms, attributed a distinction to him erroneously. While he was indeed a pioneer in showing individual atoms, he was not the first physicist to do so. That feat had been accomplished at least once before, in 1955, when the Pennsylvania State University physicist Erwin Wilhelm Müller, with his graduate student Kanwar Bahadur, used a field ion microscope to view images of single atoms. Because of an editing error, the obituary also referred incorrectly to the Chicago Cyclotron, to which Dr. Crewe contributed. It did not contain superconducting components.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Nov. 8 with an obituary about Robert Rines, a scientist and inventor who pursued the Loch Ness monster, misstated the source of the photograph that he believed showed evidence of the monster’s existence. It was taken automatically by a camera connected to a strobe-light system; it was not taken by his wife, Carol Rines.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Cheap and Cheerful for the Holidays
text: MADISON AVENUE is dancing the limbo for the holiday shopping season as advertisers ask each other, “How low can you go?”

headline: Former Leader of Troopers Admits Guilt
text: ALBANY  One of four former Spitzer administration officials implicated in what became known as the Troopergate scandal resolved his case before a state ethics panel on Tuesday and agreed to admit that he had violated the conduct laws governing public officials.

headline: Alone in the Past, but Not Anymore
text: Serenity, in the form of a baby girl, finally arrived in the life of Melissa Rosa, who was orphaned as a child, bounced in and out of foster care and group homes as a teenager and struggled to balance work and school as a young woman.

headline: Group of Magazine Publishers Is Said to Be Building an Online Newsstand
text: A consortium of magazine publishers including Time Inc. and Condé Nast plan to jointly build an online newsstand for publications in multiple digital formats, according to people with knowledge of the plans.

headline: Lloyds Group Stock Sale to Be Britain’s Largest
text: The Lloyds Banking Group, the troubled British lender, said Tuesday that it planned to raise £13.5 billion to keep the government from taking a controlling stake.

headline: Corrections
text: The Minimalist column last Wednesday, about 101 suggestions for Thanksgiving dishes that can be made in advance, omitted an ingredient for recipe No. 12, for garlic-rosemary figs. Rosemary should be added to the garlic and olive oil, then heated.

headline: The Swaps Market Is Too Big to Ban
text: Is the market for credit-default swaps in for a renaissance? George Soros, for one, reckons credit derivatives should be banned. But trading in swaps has so far survived the crisis and market reforms are on the way. Barring unexpectedly draconian regulatory changes, a comeback looks likely.

headline: Corrections
text: A recipe for caramelized apple-pecan cake last Wednesday omitted instructions for using one-half teaspoon vanilla extract. In Step 4, add the vanilla after beating the eggs into the butter and sugar. A corrected recipe is at nytimes.com/dining. And a picture with the recipe depicted the cake incorrectly. As the recipe said, the cake should be inverted after it is unmolded, with the apples and pecans on top; it should not be served crust-side up as shown.

headline: Chief Reinforces Commitment to A.I.G.
text: Robert Benmosche, chief executive of the American International Group, reaffirmed his commitment to the bailed-out insurer and signed a noncompete agreement with the company.

headline: Showcase: This Wall, Too?
text: In 1953, when Ronald Reagan was born, the other Ronald Reagan was a reasonably well known Hollywood actor who was about to ascend to national fame as a television show host — still more than a decade away from beginning his political career. In any case, Mr. Reagan, a retired auto worker and union member in Syracuse, said he didn’t mind sharing the name of the 40th president.

headline: Phys Ed: How Necessary Is Stretching?
text: For research published earlier this year, physiologists at Nebraska Wesleyan University had distance-running members of the school’s track and field team sit on the ground, legs stretched before them, feet pressed firmly up against a box; then the runners, both men and women, bent forward, reaching as far as they could past their toes. This is the classic sit-and-reach test, a well-established measurement of hamstring flexibility. The runners, as a group, didn’t have exceptional elasticity, although this varied from person to person.

headline: Sleeper Team of 2009: The Ravens?
text: New Orleans, New England, Minnesota and Indianapolis are the runaway leaders in point differential through 10 games.

headline: Wright Brothers to Open Aeroplane Factory
text: Thursday, Nov. 25, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Efforts to Defuse Tensions Between Algeria and Egypt
text: Updated | 7:43 a.m. As readers of The Lede will be aware, North Africa has been facing a new source of strife in recent weeks — soccer. Last Wednesday, after the Egyptian national soccer team lost its World Cup bid to rival Algeria 1-0 in Sudan, 32 police officers and 21 Egyptian fans were reportedly injured in violence. The next day, Egyptian demonstrations outside the Algerian embassy in Cairo turned violent.

headline: Families Declare Medical Bankruptcy
text: At the bankruptcy court in Nashville, lawyers provided a spectrum of estimates for the share of cases in Middle Tennessee where medical debt was decisive, from 15 percent to 50 percent. But many said they felt the number had been growing.

headline: Congo Army Helps Rebels Get Arms, U.N. Finds
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan  A new United Nations report says that the Congolese Army continues to funnel weapons to rebel groups that are smuggling millions of dollars in gold and other minerals out of Congo, helping sustain one of Africa’s bloodiest and most complicated wars.

headline: Word of the Day | effusion
text: effusion • \i-ˈfyü-zhən, e-\ • noun

headline: A Stylish State Dinner, With Typos
text: The White House pulled out all the stops in preparation for President Obama’s first state dinner on Tuesday night, hiring a new florist, selecting a renowned guest chef and even inviting a number of high-profile musicians to perform.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Nov. 15 about what’s new this year in the Caribbean misspelled the name of an island and referred incorrectly to the location of a resort. The Sandals Emerald Bay resort is in Great Exuma in the Bahamas, not Exhuma. And the Renaissance Aruba Resort & Casino is situated in Oranjestad, Aruba, and has a 40-acre private island. It is not on a 40-acre island.

headline: Hot Holiday Hamsters
text: WHO do you know who might want a Zhu Zhu Pet, the toy pictured here and described as “the hottest toy this holiday season”?

headline: Canada: Bank of Montreal Buys Diners Club
text: Citigroup agreed to sell a credit card unit, Diners Club North America, to Bank of Montreal for an undisclosed price, ending its 28-year-old ties to the world’s first charge card. The sale will reduce Citigroup’s assets by about $1 billion, representing about 0.05 percent of the lender’s total global assets of $1.89 trillion. The deal will not have a material impact on Citigroup’s net income or capital ratios, the bank said. Bank of Montreal said in a separate statement that the acquisition would more than double its business in corporate credit cards, adding $7.8 billion in card transactions and net receivables of $1 billion.

headline: India: Satyam Managers in Fraud Bought Property
text: Managers and insiders who orchestrated an extensive fraud at the Indian outsourcing company Satyam Computer Services bought more than 1,000 pieces of property with the money they diverted, the Central Bureau of Investigation in India said. The bureau also said the 10 people accused in the case had forged board resolutions, obtained unauthorized loans and created more fake customers and generated more fake invoices than previously discovered. Satyam’s founder admitted in January to faking $1 billion in cash on the company’s balance sheet.

headline: Vietnam: Export of Puffer Fish Is Approved
text: A government ministry in Vietnam is starting a pilot project to revive the export of puffer fish, known for its toxic skin and internal organs, after a ban of six years, according to The Vietnam News, an official newspaper in English. The goal of the project is to produce 800 to 1,000 tons of products worth up to $10 million by the end of 2012. In 2003, the government prohibited the processing, trade and use of puffer fish because of a high number of poisoning cases.

headline: Knicks Arrive Late, and Leave Disappointed
text: LOS ANGELES  Mike D’Antoni entered Staples Center at a jogger’s pace Tuesday evening, hurrying into the locker room. He preached calmness and readiness to his players, but his gallop and arrival time hinted otherwise to reporters.

headline: Magazine Publishers Team Up for Online Newsstand
text: A consortium of magazine publishers including Time and Condé Nast are plan to jointly build an online newsstand for publications in multiple digital formats, The New York Times’s Brian Stelter reported, citing people with knowledge of the plans.

headline: News Quiz | November 25, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Suspect in Philippine Election Killings Surrenders
text: SALMAN, the Philippines  As the toll in what is now considered the Philippines’ worst case of election violence rose to 57, the authorities on Wednesday focused their suspicions on a powerful clan allied with President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

headline: Dancing in Kabul
text: French soldiers dance to Michael Jackson’s “Billie Jean” on the military side of the Kabul airport.

headline: A Postwar City Emerges
text: The Courtauld Gallery’s exhibition of Frank Auerbach’s paintings from the 1950s and early ’60s conjures up early postwar London.

headline: Newly Independent, Skype Set for Executive Shake-Up
text: From Brad Stone at Bits:

headline: G.M. to Decide Saab’s Fate Next Week
text: General Motors said it could decide next week to close its Saab Automobile unit after the Swedish company that planned to buy the brand backed out.

headline: Do You Find Family Holiday Gatherings Fun or Stressful?
text: Do you gather with your family this time of year? What traditions or rituals do you have? Do you generally look forward to them or dread them? Why?

headline: Correction: Mau-Mauing the Flesh Eaters
text: An essay on Nov. 15, about books that explore the ethics of eating meat, misstated the publishing history of “The Sexual Politics of Meat,” by Carol J. Adams. It has been available ever since it appeared in 1990; it isn’t “coming back into print next March.” (An expanded 20th-anniversary edition will be published then.)

headline: Is the Swaps Market Too Big to Ban?
text: Is the market for credit-default swaps in for a renaissance? George Soros, for one, reckons credit derivatives should be banned. But trading in swaps has so far survived the crisis and market reforms are on the way. Barring unexpectedly draconian regulatory changes, a comeback looks likely, Breakingviews.com says.

headline: Warner Music Posts a Surprise Loss
text: Warner Music Group, one of the largest American record companies, on Tuesday posted an unexpected loss in the fourth quarter as severance costs weighed on results despite a strong slate of music releases from artists including Jay-Z and Madonna.

headline: G.M. to Present Unions With Strategy for Opel
text: General Motors will present to unions on Wednesday a restructuring plan for its Opel unit, with up to 9,500 jobs expected to be cut, the carmaker’s top official in Europe said Tuesday.

headline: Wall Street Struggles to Find Traction
text: A disappointing report on consumer confidence and a more sober read on the economy pulled stocks down on Tuesday from 13-month highs, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Ex-Fund Manager Pleads Guilty to Fraud
text: The former manager of a shuttered hedge fund pleaded guilty Tuesday to charges of fraud that cost investors more than $10 million, The Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune reported.

headline: Ji-Hobbyists
text: Jihad hobbyists – those who seek out “jihadi” content online, becoming more radical as they do so.

headline: China Ship Parts Maker Plans Shanghai I.P.O.
text: China Shipbuilding Industry, the nation’s largest maker of vessel equipment, plans to raise at least 6.4 billion renminbi ($937 million) selling shares as China tries to pare its reliance on Japanese and Korean marine engines.

headline: Gruner + Jahr Sells Russia Operations to Springer
text: Gruner + Jahr, the German publisher, said Tuesday that it was selling its Russian operations to Axel Springer after concluding that it would need to make too many expensive acquisitions to gain a leading market position.

headline: E.U. Drops Antitrust Case Against Qualcomm
text: The European Commission closed antitrust proceedings against Qualcomm as big technology companies dropped their four-year old complaints against the United States mobile chip supplier, Reuters reported.

headline: S.E.C. Wins Insider Case Against Ex-Fidelity Trader
text: Federal securities regulators won an insider trading case when a jury in Boston ruled that a former employee of Fidelity Investments illegally profited from trading stocks that the mutual fund company was buying, Reuters reported.

headline: Half of Bank Losses May Be Hidden, I.M.F. Chief Says
text: Half of the losses suffered by banks could still be hidden in their balance sheets, more so in Europe than in the United States, the International Monetary Fund‘s managing director, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, told the French newspaper Le Figaro.

headline: J.C. Flowers in Pursuit of U.K. Bank Assets
text: J.C. Flowers is circling Britain’s weakened banking industry, prepared to swoop down on forced divestments over the next 12 months, according to the U.S. private equity investor’s new boss for Europe and the Asia-Pacific region.

headline: Tesla to Build Model S in a Plant Near Los Angeles
text: Tesla Motors is close to a deal to build an electric car factory at the site of a former NASA manufacturing plant in Downey, Calif, a blue-collar city south of Los Angeles, Mayor Mario Guerra said Tuesday.

headline: Designer Sweet | Papabubble x Cappellini
text: The cherry-red interior of the Cappellini flagship store in SoHo has always reminded me of candy — it’s the color of Red Vines, Swedish Fish, Atomic Fireballs, Hot Tamales, Abracabubbles, Cinnamon Discs, Red Hots and candy apples. So it seems fitting that from now until Jan. 3, the Italian furnishings shop will also be in the sweets business. “The Candy Shoppe: Papabubble x Cappellini” is this year’s holiday installation by the curators Tobias Wong and Josee Lepage, who asked the artisanal candy makers Papabubble to create what they call a “shoppe-in-shop” just inside Cappellini’s front doors. At an opening party last weekend, filled with fashionably dressed tots and their design-loving parents, limited-edition confections were stored in jars and honey pots on Cappellini’s Passepartout shelves and piled high in the polished acrylic drawers of a staircase-like cabinet by Shrio Kuramata.

headline: F.B.I. Raids Midwest Offices of Investment Firms
text: Federal agents have searched the Indiana and Ohio offices of two companies owned by an Indianapolis businessman, serving warrants a month after a newspaper questioned whether the Ohio firm is capable of repaying some $168 million owed to investors, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Set For Rebound to Pre-Crisis Levels?
text: Investment flows into hedge funds have turned net positive and the sector is heading toward having assets under management of around $1.75 trillion by year-end, according to Morgan Stanley.

headline: Adding Third-Down Proficiency to a Passer Rating
text: Luis DeLoureiro is building a better passer rating, among other statistical pursuits, at NFLStatAnalysis.net:

headline: An Indie Epicenter in Paris Reopens
text: PARIS | Six months of tranquil nights for neighbors of Paris’s most famous indie rock venue are over. The Flèche d’Or (102 bis, rue de Bagnolet, 75020; 33-1-44-64-01-02; www.flechedor.fr; Metro: Gambetta or Alexandre Dumas), a longtime meeting point for unsigned bands and music lovers, opened Monday night with a celebration that included performances by Evan Dando, Chris Brokaw and Anoraak.

headline: Nomura Fined £1.75 Million by Britain
text: Nomura, the Japanese brokerage, has been fined £1.75 million, or $2.92 million, by Britain’s Financial Services Authority after one of its Hong Kong traders helped trigger an overvaluation of complex financial instruments.

headline: Calpers May Jettison BlackRock as Adviser
text: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System is considering jettisoning BlackRock, its real estate adviser, after the firm steered the pension plan into an investment in Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, a pair of gigantic Manhattan apartment complexes now considered to be one of the biggest real estate flops of the boom, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: The Tajik Way for Afghanistan?
text: Today’s idea: Foreign peacekeepers and outside powers helped stabilize Tajikistan by cutting deals with warlords, scaling back their aims and concentrating on order. The same “cheap, simple approach” could work in neighboring Afghanistan, an article says.

headline: UBS and Ernst & Young Sued Over Madoff
text: UBS and Ernst & Young may face hundreds of damage claims if investors who lost millions of dollars in mutual funds linked to Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme win a group of Luxembourg test cases, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: The Frugal Traveler’s Holiday Gift Guide
text: As you may have gathered from my souvenir-hunting post last week, the Frugal Traveler is somewhat reluctant to buy, well, things. It’s not stinginess on my part — it’s that I dislike spending money on needless, often useless objects. Waste is the antithesis of frugality, and unnecessary belongings can make travel more difficult than it already is.

headline: Australia Serves TPG With $628 Million Tax Bill
text: TPG has been slapped with a $628 million tax bill by Australian authorities in a dispute over how to tax the United States private equity firm’s gains from the initial public offering of the department store Myer.

headline: Sampler: Golden Gate Bridge Climb, Growing Dumps, Bird Watchers Wanted
text: Competition’s Victims | The more than 4,500 workers at New United Motor Manufacturing, which is co-owned by General Motors and Toyota and is based in Fremont, are victims of foreign competition and eligible for federal financial help, said Labor Secretary Hilda Solis.

headline: One Minimum Wage Increase With a Side of Fries, Please
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Emergency Loans Secrecy Defended in Britain
text: The British government defended the right of the Bank of England to make secret loans to struggling banks after belatedly disclosing that the Bank of England had lent almost 62 billion pounds to two institutions last year.

headline: Calpers Investigates Hedge Fund Oversight
text: The California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the nation’s biggest pension fund, with $200 billion, has started an internal investigation into its own oversight of hedge fund deals, The Los Angeles Times reported.

headline: Ericsson Buys Another Part of Nortel
text: Ericsson and Kapsch CarrierCom will buy the GSM business of Nortel Networks of Canada, which is bankrupt, for $103 million in cash, the giant Swedish maker of telecommunications equipment said Wednesday.

headline: London Exchange’s First-Half Net Profit Drops 40 Percent
text: The London Stock Exchange posted a 40 percent drop in first-half earnings on Wednesday on the back of lower trading and warned that market conditions remain uncertain.

headline: If You Took the Train to the Plane, Sing the Jingle
text: Imagine Midtown to J.F.K. in one hour, eight stops, for $3.50 a ride. This Shangri-La of New York City travel was once a reality — and it came with its own catchy theme song. So on this, traditionally known as the biggest travel day of the year, let’s take a look back.

headline: Toyota Is Recalling Tundras for Rust Problem
text: Toyota said it was recalling 110,000 of its 2000-3 full-size Tundra pickups because of rust problems with the frames, the second time the automaker has had such a problem on its pickups.

headline: What to Watch Wednesday: Losers and Lambert
text: “The Biggest Loser” (NBC, 8 p.m.) offers a “Where are they now?” episode, revisiting more than 40 contestants from previous seasons to see what they’ve been doing since their appearances and, of course, how they look.

headline: Speed Read for Wednesday, Nov. 25
text: Here are some highlights from Wednesday’s The New York Times:

headline: Travel Forms for All Occasions
text: Is your child flying overseas? Or are you taking a business trip, and want to leave behind a medical consent form?

headline: Toyota Will Fix or Replace 4 Million Gas Pedals
text: DETROIT  Toyota said Wednesday it would have to fix the gas pedals of about four million vehicles, including the Camry, to resolve a widespread problem with unintended acceleration.

headline: Adam Lambert: ‘I’m Not a Baby Sitter. I’m a Performer.’
text: As his performance at the American Music Awards continues to stoke controversy, even costing him a booking on “Good Morning America,” Adam Lambert acknowledged in a television interview that he “did get carried away” during his awards show appearance. But the singer declined to apologize for his act, saying that it was ultimately “up to the parents to discern what their child’s watching on television.”

headline: Agribusiness Chief Slams Organics
text: When Michael Mack, the chief executive of Syngenta, a Swiss agribusiness giant that makes pesticides and seeds, hears people say that organic food is better for the planet, he has one response: “Au contraire.”

headline: Pakistan Charges 7 Terrorism Suspects a Year After Attacks That Shocked Mumbai
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Seven Pakistanis accused of planning last year’s attacks in Mumbai, India, were formally charged Wednesday, the eve of the first anniversary of the assault. The attacks left 163 people dead and have become a major sticking point in relations between India and Pakistan.

headline: Early Word: Afghan Rollout
text: President Obama is finalizing his decision on how to proceed in Afghanistan. Now, he gets to explain it.

headline: No exit
text: The latest Fed minutes, together with the forecast, are out. What do they tell us?

headline: State Emergency Alert System Now Includes Xbox and Wii
text: In the event of an emergency, the state of New York may seize control of your Xbox or Wii, under a new notification system set to go live next year, The New York Post reports. Video games will pause and warnings about imminent danger, severe weather or Amber alerts will appear on the screen, under a new voluntary notification system for Xbox, Wii and PlayStation.

headline: New-Home Sales Rise, but Factory Orders Slip
text: Sales of new homes reached their highest level in October in more than a year, the government said Wednesday, but the pace was sluggish and unsold homes lingered for the longest time on record.

headline: Ramsay MacDonald
text: Ramsay MacDonald was Britain’s first Labour Prime Minister. After a brief first stint in the first half of the 1920s, he led a more solid coalition to power in 1929. One might have expected big changes in a country that was, at that time, still deeply class-ridden and marked by huge inequality.

headline: Thursday’s N.F.L. Matchups
text: Packers (6-4) at Lions (2-8)Thursday, 12:30 p.m.Line: Packers by 10 1/2

text: What we’re reading on Wednesday morning.

headline: Rethinking Clean Energy Innovation
text: Meeting the challenges of global climate change will require a more open and collaborative approach to technology innovation, according to a new report from two public policy groups focused on clean energy and development strategies.

headline: As Travelers Cut Costs, Holiday Jaunts Grow Longer
text: The holiday crush at the nation’s airports has taken hold several days earlier as travelers sought less expensive flights. Read the full story.

headline: Bryant Believes Knicks Will Get a Star, Just Not Him
text: LOS ANGELES — Kobe Bryant has avoided discussion of free agency in 2010, saying he will not discuss scenarios hypothetically.
