text: France Télécom said Wednesday that it would pay 1.5 billion euros ($2.27 billion) to merge its Swiss subsidiary with Sunrise, Switzerland’s No. 2 operator, in an effort to challenge the state-owned market leader, Swisscom.

headline: In Kentucky, a Senate Candidate With a Pedigree for Agitation
text: FRANKFORT, Ky.  Representative Ron Paul proved to be a surprising presence in the presidential race in 2008. Now his son, Dr. Rand Paul, has become an unexpected contender in the 2010 Senate race in Kentucky.

headline: A Stylist, Inside the Ring and Out
text: At a reading for a new book on Sugar Ray Robinson, friends and fans of the legendary boxer discuss his importance to Harlem.

headline: Sugar Ray’s Harlem, Back in the Day
text: When Sugar Ray Robinson ruled the ring as a champion welterweight and middleweight in the 1940s and ’50s, the most important member of his team of corner men was neither his trainer nor his cut man.

headline: Miami-Dade Hopes Online Auctions Will Help Reduce Backlog of Foreclosures
text: MIAMI  Buying into Miami’s foreclosure glut will soon be a whole lot easier.

headline: Retailers Extend Deals Beyond Black Friday
text: Attention shoppers: It might pay to just sleep in this Black Friday.

headline: Businesses in U.S. Brace for New Rules on Emissions
text: The nation’s corporations have long been bracing for the day when they would be required to carry out sharp cuts in the emissions that cause global warming. That day seemed to move a bit closer on Wednesday, when President Obama outlined a national target for such reductions.

headline: Kentucky’s Highest Court Halts Executions in State
text: The Supreme Court of Kentucky suspended executions in the state Wednesday, ruling that officials did not follow state law in adopting its procedures for killing inmates.

headline: Heritage Turkeys Selling Briskly, Even at $10 a Pound
text: Handmade chocolates, artisanal cheeses, vintage Champagne  consumers are thinking twice about splurging on such luxurious goods during the tough economic times. But sales of at least one fancy food item have held up: gourmet turkeys that easily cost $100 or more.

headline: From Yanks’ Core to Pacquiao, Plenty of Cheers
text: For all the scandals and scoundrels, on Thanksgiving there are always good names to be thankful for:

headline: Obama Will Use West Point as Backdrop to Present Afghan Strategy
text: WASHINGTON  President Obama will formally unveil his Afghanistan strategy on Tuesday night in a prime-time televised address before a group of cadets and soldiers at the United States Military Academy at West Point, White House officials said Wednesday.

headline: In Curry’s Latest Setback, Hint of New Resolve
text: LOS ANGELES  Any Eddy Curry aches and pains are met with care, caution and held breaths within the Knicks organization. Too often, Curry has made only guest appearances in Knicks games because of injuries that appear to be mild afflictions but turn out to be more problematic.

headline: U.S. Seeks More Allied Troops for Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  The United States is scrambling to coax NATO allies to send 10,000 additional troops to Afghanistan as part of President Obama’s strategy for the region. Those countries appear willing to provide fewer than half that number, American and allied officials said Wednesday.

headline: Jets’ Kerry Rhodes Says His Demotion Is a Timeout
text: In 10 games this season, safety Kerry Rhodes has recorded an equal number of interceptions, sacks, forced fumbles and fumble recoveries  zero. Because of that, and because the Jets are 4-6, Coach Rex Ryan has demoted Rhodes for their game Sunday against Carolina.

headline: The Turkey Day Trot, Explained
text: Every Thanksgiving, I get the urge to chase something. Like a dog after a bird. Or a Neanderthal in search of prey. It’s very primitive, I admit, and harder still to say with a straight face. But just before the big feast, I feel the need for biped speed over a moldering carpet of leaves.

headline: From Footnote to Fame in Civil Rights History
text: On that supercharged day in 1955, when Rosa Parks refused to give up her bus seat to a white passenger in Montgomery, Ala., she rode her way into history books, credited with helping to ignite the civil rights movement.

headline: Soul-Searching in Turkey After a Gay Man Is Killed
text: ISTANBUL  For Ahmet Yildiz, a stocky and affable 26-year-old, the choice to live openly as a gay man proved deadly. Prosecutors say his own father hunted him down, traveling more than 600 miles from his hometown to shoot his son in an old neighborhood of Istanbul.

headline: Limelight Lives, Burned by Booze
text: Robert Sellers’s “Hellraisers” is completely unapologetic about its party-hearty premise. He has slapped together a string of outlandish stories about four of the British Isles’ most stylish drunken actors, and he doesn’t even pretend to have turned those stories into a coherent book. “Hellraisers” wants only to be a rowdy collection of greatest hits, and it lives up to that fun-loving ambition. It reels off riotous tales about Richard Burton, Richard Harris, Peter O’Toole and Oliver Reed without giving a moment’s thought to what those tales might mean.

headline: Listening In on the Mumbai Attackers’ Phone Calls
text: As my colleagues Sahar Habib Ghazi and Sabrina Tavernise reported from Pakistan, seven Pakistanis accused of planning last year’s attacks in Mumbai, India, were formally charged Wednesday, the eve of the first anniversary of the assault.

headline: N.F.L.’s Moves Signal a Truce on Concussions
text: Andre Waters, a former N.F.L. defensive back, put a pistol in his mouth, pulled the trigger and  however unknowingly  sounded an alarm on the seriousness of football brain injuries.

headline: In Welcoming Iranian President, Chavez Blasts Israel
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chávez rolled out the welcome mat here on Wednesday for President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, using the visit to strengthen Venezuela’s political alliance with Iran and to lash out at Israel, which Mr. Chávez described as “the murderous arm of the Yankee empire.”

headline: Costumes by Rabanne
text: On fields o’er which the reaper’s hand has pass’dLit by the harvest moon and autumn sun,My thoughts like stubble floating in the windAnd of such fineness as October airs,There after harvest could I glean my lifeA richer harvest reaping without toil,And weaving gorgeous fancies at my willIn subtler webs than finest summer haze.

headline: 2 Journalists Are Freed in Somalia After 15 Months as Captives
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan  After more than a year in captivity at the hands of Somali gunmen, two young Western journalists who were kidnapped in August 2008 were freed on Wednesday, according to Somali officials and the Canadian media.

headline: Detentions at Border Are Down
text: Detentions of migrants trying to cross the border illegally dropped to 556,000 in the 2009 fiscal year, a decline of 23 percent over 2008 and the lowest number since the early 1970s, according to official figures released this week.

headline: Butterballs or Cheese Balls, an Online Barometer
text: If you are in Oregon this Thanksgiving, you stand a better than average chance of encountering Tofurkey. More people in New York are looking for caterers to prepare the holiday meal than anywhere else in the country. Live in the Southeast? Brace yourself for a big scoop of broccoli casserole.

headline: Thompson Is Said to Mull a Run Against Gillibrand
text: ALBANY  City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., weighing his options in the wake of a surprisingly close loss in the mayoral race, is seriously considering challenging Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in next year’s primary elections, according to people who have spoken to Mr. Thompson and his advisers.

headline: Homeless and Begging, Despite Bad Publicity
text: One man walked in silence, making a shame-on-you gesture. Another muttered a skeptical “uh, huh” beneath his breath. A woman stage-whispered to her friend about “the scam that was on TV last night.” Two men in suits wanted to inspect the paperwork. One man, clearly agitated, yelled: “Didn’t you get busted? How do you hold your head up?”

headline: Bloggingheads: Defending the Filibuster
text: Timothy Noah, left, of Slate and Byron York of The Washington Examiner debate the Senate filibuster.

headline: Lottery Numbers
UConn Will Face Duke in the N.I.T. Final
text: For a few fleeting moments in its 81-55 victory over Louisiana State on Wednesday night, Connecticut looked as if it had not skipped a beat since the Final Four.

headline: In Debt to Start, and Sinking Even Deeper
text: Theodora Roach’s subprime journey started with a knock at the door.

headline: A Landlord’s Foreclosure Puts a Tenant in Trouble
text: Foreclosure has touched Alice Garvin’s life twice. The first time, four years ago, she came home to find a notice on the front door of the East New York, Brooklyn, apartment building in which she, her sons and two of her grandchildren had lived for two years.

headline: Finding a Surprise After Refinancing a Mortgage
text: To Carol Schlossman, Wachovia is a four-letter word.

headline: At Obama’s First State Dinner, the First Crashers
text: WASHINGTON  This much is known: About 7:15 Tuesday night, a glittering blonde, decked out in a red and gold sari, holding the hand of her black-tuxedoed escort, swept past the camera crews and reporters camped out to catch the red-carpet arrivals for the first state dinner given by President Obama.

headline: Corrections
text: National

headline: A Truce in the Religious Wars?
text: My Thursday column looks at the literary battles over God in recent years, focusing on recent books such as Karen Armstrong’s “The Case for God” and Robert Wright’s “The Evolution of God.” I found Wright’s particularly provocative, although it’s more popular than scholarly. Then my colleague Nicholas Wade’s new book, “The Faith Instinct,” doesn’t focus on God so much as on the evolutionary advantages conferred by faith, creating a genetic predisposition to believe in divinity — but it’s just as fascinating.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a proposed 10-point checklist devised to test Republicans on their commitment to their party’s core principles misstated the number of points that candidates would be required to support in order to be endorsed by the Republican National Committee. They would need to agree with at least eight  not seven  of the 10 points.

headline: Corrections
text: A chart on Wednesday with an article about President Obama’s first state dinner referred imprecisely to the occupation of one of the guests, Jhumpa Lahiri. While she is a Pulitzer Prize-winning writer, she writes fiction; she does not write for the media.

headline: A Thanksgiving Toast
text: Sitting down with friends and family today, there will be thanks for the steady currents, flowing out of the past, that have brought us to this table. There will be thanks for the present union and reunion of us all. And there will be prayerful thanks for the future. But it’s worth raising a glass (or suspending a forkful for those of you who’ve gotten ahead of the toast) to be thankful for the unexpected, for all the ways that life interrupts and renews itself without warning.

headline: Iran Punishes Its People
text: Iran’s fraudulently elected president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, will clearly stop at nothing to stifle legitimate dissent and hold on to his illegitimate power. The most recent horror is the sharp rise in executions since the June presidential elections.

headline: New Jersey’s Marriage Moment
text: There can come a moment in a politician’s career when doing the right thing requires summoning the courage to buck strong voter sentiment. The drama over same-sex marriage in a lame-duck session of the New Jersey State Legislature is not that kind of moment.

headline: A Theater Illuminates an Immigration Battlefield
text: Can a play called “What Killed Marcelo Lucero?” rescue suburban Long Island from its immigration agonies?

headline: The Obama Strategy in Afghanistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Kabul, European Police See Progress
text: To the Editor:

headline: Our Health Care Choices, and Our Values
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Tale of Two Turkeys
text: On Wednesday, President Obama pardoned his first Thanksgiving turkey.

headline: The Religious Wars
text: Just a few years ago, it seemed curious that an omniscient, omnipotent God wouldn’t smite tormentors like Richard Dawkins, Christopher Hitchens and Sam Harris. They all published best-selling books excoriating religion and practically inviting lightning bolts.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Nov. 14 about a decision to try five suspects in federal court in New York for the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks referred imprecisely to the deaths at the World Trade Center. About 2,750 people died there  not “nearly 3,000,” the estimated total number of deaths in the attacks that day.

headline: South Africa: President Zuma Will Serve as Zimbabwe’s Mediator
text: President Jacob Zuma has taken over as the regional mediator in Zimbabwe’s political crisis. His predecessor, Thabo Mbeki, was mistrusted by Zimbabwe’s prime minister, Morgan Tsvangirai. Mr. Tsvangirai said he believed that Mr. Mbeki was biased in favor of President Robert Mugabe. According to a statement from Mr. Zuma’s office, he appointed a new Zimbabwe team: Charles Nquakula, his political adviser; Mac Maharaj, his special envoy; and Lindiwe Zulu, his international relations adviser. The team will visit Zimbabwe soon and report back to Mr. Zuma, above.

headline: Flu Fears May Curtail Pilgrimage
text: The number of pilgrims to Mecca this year may be down substantially because of fears of swine flu, the BBC and CNN reported Wednesday, citing remarks by government officials. The hajj, an annual pilgrimage, began Wednesday, but an official count of arrivals will not be issued until later. Earlier this year, Saudi Arabia asked pilgrims over 65 or under 12 to stay home, to try to prevent any flu outbreak from overwhelming the hospitals set up for the hajj.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Nov. 18 about Goldman Sachs’s response to criticism of its high pay and its role in the financial crisis, using information from a Bloomberg News article, quoted imprecisely from remarks by its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, at a conference in New York. Mr. Blankfein said, “We participated in things that were clearly wrong and we have reasons to regret and apologize for.” He did not say: “We participated in things that were clearly wrong and have reason to regret. We apologize.” The imprecise quotation was repeated in an article in Week in Review on Sunday. (The quotation appeared correctly in an editorial on Sunday.)

headline: At Valdosta High, Times Change but Expectations Don’t
text: VALDOSTA, Ga.  Players still bang their helmets against the corrugated metal roof of the walkway outside the locker room before rushing onto the field here, the collective rumble like a storm coming up from the Gulf. An end-zone billboard continues to welcome visitors to Death Valley, a bold declaration of trouble ahead.

headline: Thanksgiving Pulpit Used to Attack Suffrage
text: Friday, Nov. 26, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about a response by the money manager Raj Rajaratnam to charges brought against him by the Securities and Exchange Commission misidentified the federal authority that sought to use wiretaps in an investigation of insider trading at his hedge fund. And the headline also misidentified the authority that Mr. Rajaratnam had accused of illegal wiretaps. In both instances, it was the United States Attorney’s office, not the S.E.C.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the Sports Briefing column on Wednesday about the sale of the Pontiac Silverdome, outside Detroit, misstated the year that Super Bowl XVI was played there. It was 1982, not 1983.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption on Monday with a dance review of a ballet company at the Joyce Theater misstated part of the company’s name. It is Complexions Contemporary Ballet, not Complexions Temporary Ballet.

headline: Van Kills Man in Staten Island Hit-and-Run
text: A couple in their 70s were hit by a van in a hit-and-run accident while on their way to Mass on Staten Island on Wednesday night, killing one and seriously injuring the other, the police said.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Nov. 10 about garbage patches in the world’s oceans referred incorrectly to the travels of a graduate student researching a master’s thesis on plastic accumulation in the oceans. The student, Bonnie Monteleone, visited the Sargasso Sea, which is part of a feature known as the Atlantic gyre. Thus, it was not the case that she “might not have found” the gyre. (Ms. Monteleone said instead that she might not have found the zone with the highest concentration of trash.)

headline: Corrections
text: A listing in the Calendar on Wednesday about a sake tasting and sushi class scheduled for Monday and Dec. 21 at Sushi Samba misstated the restaurant’s phone number. It is (212) 691-7885.

headline: Corrections
text: A capsule summary on Wednesday for a Books of The Times review of “Sweet Thunder,” by Wil Haygood, about the flamboyant life of the fighter Sugar Ray Robinson, misidentified the weight class in which Robinson won five titles. He was a middleweight, not a heavyweight. (He won one title as a welterweight.)

headline: H. C. Robbins Landon, Haydn and Mozart Scholar, Dies at 83
text: H. C. Robbins Landon, an American musicologist whose research helped to restore many of Haydn’s works to the active repertory after more than a century of neglect, and whose popular books about Mozart countered many popular myths about that composer’s life, died on Friday at Rabastens, near Toulouse, France. He was 83.

headline: Kings Make the Most of the Knicks’ Shortcomings
text: SACRAMENTO  The Sacramento Kings’ Donte Greene matched his career high of 24 points and blocked six shots, and the Knicks were outmuscled inside, outshot outside and outhustled in all points in between during their third consecutive loss.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 918 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Hawks Crush Sharks in Season’s Biggest Game So Far
text: A crowded schedule on Wednesday night, with 28 of the league’s 30 teams in action. But it mostly served as mere prelude to the last game on the slate, the biggest clash of the season so far: the Sharks, No. 1 in the N.H.L., playing host to the red-hot Blackhawks, No. 2 in the league and with $62.8 million signing Marian Hossa in the lineup for the first time.

headline: Waldo Hunt, King of the Pop-Up Book, Dies at 88
text: On the flat, foursquare pages of a printed book, Waldo H. Hunt could part the Red Sea. He could make hearts beat, lungs fill and bones rattle. He could make dinosaurs rear up, ships set sail and bats quiver in belfries.

headline: South Korea Admits Civilian Killings During War
text: SEOUL, South Korea  In the opening months of the Korean War, the South Korean military and the police executed at least 4,900 civilians who had earlier signed up  often under force  for re-education classes meant to turn them against Communism, the country’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission announced Thursday.

headline: Suspect in Philippine Election Killings Surrenders
text: SHARIFF AGUAK, the Philippines  A politician identified as the prime suspect in the massacre of more than 50 people this week who surrendered to the authorities on Thursday is expected to be charged Friday with multiple murders in the worst carnage in the country’s long history of election-related violence.

headline: China Joins U.S. in Pledge of Hard Targets on Emissions
text: BEIJING  The Chinese government announced Thursday that it had set a target to slow the growth of its greenhouse gas emissions by 2020, a day after the Obama administration set a provisional target for reducing United States emissions.

headline: NIMHOA and NIMROD
text: Two dubious acronyms for advanced NIMBYism – Not In My Home Owner’s Association and Not In My Range Of Desert.

headline: Q. & A. With Simon Kuper, Author of ‘Soccernomics’
text: The British author Simon Kuper was born in Uganda in 1969 and grew up in London and Leiden, the Netherlands. He is currently a Paris-based sports columnist for The Financial Times. His book “Football Against the Enemy” won the William Hill Sports Book of the Year award for 1994. He is also the author of “Ajax, the Dutch, the War.” His most recent book, “Soccernomics: Why England Loses, Why Germany and Brazil Win, and Why the U.S., Japan, Australia, Turkey — Even Iraq — Are Destined to Become the Kings of the World’s Most Popular Sport,” written with the economist Stefan Syzmanski, was published in the United States in early November.

headline: Jellyfish and All, a Gem in Rome’s Chinatown
text: Forget streets brightly lit with quaint lanterns and hordes of tourists, Rome’s Chinatown is an undefined crisscrossing of roads running from the Termini train station to the Esquiline Hill, ripe with cheap but trendy clothing, jewelry and shoes. It’s also where you’ll find some of the city’s more adventurous dining.

headline: Seeing Things | Studio Visit With David Wiseman
text: Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, a design writer and curator based in Los Angeles.

headline: German General Quits Over Airstrike
text: BERLIN  The chief of staff of the German armed forces resigned Thursday over accusations that the military withheld information on a deadly airstrike in Afghanistan in September that killed civilians as well as insurgents.

headline: What Killed F.D.R.?
text: Today’s idea: Cancer, not the presumed hypertension, caused the brain hemorrhage that killed President Franklin D. Roosevelt, a new book argues. If widely known at the time, cancer might have prevented F.D.R. from seeking a fourth term, shifting the course of postwar history.History | Writing in Slate, Barron H. Lerner lays out the case set forth in “F.D.R.’s Deadly Secret,” a book due out in January by Steven Lomazow, a neurologist, and Eric Fettman, a journalist. Looking at the president’s secretive medical history, the two theorize that a skin lesion above Roosevelt’s left eye, which disappeared in photographs after 1940, was in fact a melanoma, the deadliest of skin cancers, and that the disease eventually spread to Roosevelt’s abdomen and brain:

headline: Waiter, There’s Some Grebeshki in My Turtle Soup
text: Hungry for a Tolstoy fix? Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky, the dynamic duo of Russian translation, are back with a new rendering of “The Death of Ivan Ilyich and Other Stories,” in bookstores this week.

headline: The Leon Lett Thanksgiving Game
text: (Recommended: A funny story from Bill Bates at the end of this video clip)

headline: Early Morning Thanksgiving Questions
text: Here we go. Been listening to this for inspiration.

headline: How Big Is Too Big?
text: Two economists propose a way to prevent any bank from ever becoming “too big too fail.”

headline: Could I Be Killing My Guests? (And Other Thanksgiving Queries)
text: If I cook the stuffing inside the turkey, is there a chance I could kill my guests? I’m not saying that’s necessarily a deal-breaker. Joe Bethersonton, Fargo, N.D.

headline: Taillight in the Spotlight
text: Volvo’s sensuously styled XC60 is a far cry from the company’s old boxy station wagons, right down to its writhing, wriggling taillights. With their LEDs positioned in a pattern so the car is easily recognizable from the rear at night, the XC60’s taillights shun the straight edges or smooth circles of traditional taillights in favor of a wavy shape — a distinction that is now being honored in a design exhibition at the Serpentine Gallery in London.

headline: News Quiz | November 26, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: ‘Mom’s the President, and I’m Outta Here’
text: That was the headline on an article earlier this week on the Web site of the Chronicle of Higher Education. The writer, Emma L. Carew, did such a lovely job unfurling this yarn that I’m going to get out of the way and let her tell the first few paragraphs:

headline: Europe Reacts to Obama’s Copenhagen Trip
text: The reaction in Europe has been mixed to a decision, announced on Wednesday, that President Obama will attend the Copenhagen climate conference as the event gets underway next month.

headline: Torn Skin, Not Enough Sweet Potatoes and Other Questions
text: I want to know how the heck to get the butter under the skin of my pastured turkey. That skin is adhered! Janet M., Kansas.

headline: Leisurely Read for Thanksgiving, Nov. 26
text: No Speed Read today. It’s a holiday. Take your time. Put your feet up. And don’t forget to leave room for pie.

headline: Do I Need to Panic and Other Questions
text: I have been brining a fresh 14-pound turkey for 12 hours. According to the instructions. I have 2 more hours. Problem is, my fridge is very small, so I put the turkey on the back porch. The temp this morning is 45 degrees, so now I moved everything around in the fridge to make room for the turkey. We’ll be eating around 4:30. Is the turkey okay to eat or do I need to panic? Karen, Cleveland, Ohio

headline: Five Questions for a Rockette
text: Being a Rockette is more than high kicks, ivory smiles and precision spot-turns. There are six-show days, slippery tap shoes and Santas who miss their cues.

headline: Sitting Down to Dinner, Afghan-Style
text: As with Thanksgiving dinner in America, the act of sharing a meal is at the core of Afghan hospitality. It is a common trait among the different ethnic groups and factions that make up this war-torn country.

headline: Ministry Won’t Challenge Polanski Bail Ruling
text: PARIS — Swiss judicial authorities said on Thursday that they would not challenge a court ruling permitting filmmaker Roman Polanski to be freed on bail as he fights extradition to the United States to face sentencing on charges of having sex with a 13-year-old girl.

headline: Carving Queries and Other Matters
text: We’re trying to make it look easy, sitting back in our Aeron chairs here at Diner’s Journal HQ and drinking chai, answering your questions as if we’re the most knowledgeable home cooks in the land. The reality is: every question a tiger, and us mounted high on the elephant, armed with only a switch.

headline: Films to Be Projected Around Coit Tower Again
text: A two-day outdoor cinematic event that wraps a San Francisco landmark in projected images of Native Americans began Wednesday and will start again at dusk on Thursday. It will continue until 7 A.M. Friday morning.

headline: Early Word: Gobble Gobble
text: President Obama pardoned a turkey named Courage , handed out Thanksgiving groceries to the poor and oversaw major announcements on two of the administration’s most significant issues — the war in Afghanistan and climate change — all as Washington hunkered down for the holiday feast.

headline: Russia Admits Lapses in Case of Sick Lawyer
text: MOSCOW  A top Russian prison official on Thursday acknowledged wrongdoing in the case of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a 37-year-old lawyer whose death in pretrial detention last week has provoked a groundswell of anger.

headline: ‘Glee’ Watch: True Lies
text: This post contains spoilers.

headline: Questions on Sides, Stores and More
text: Let’s take a moment here for some inspiration: Bill Monroe playing “Southern Flavor” on TNN’s “American Music Shop” with Marty Stuart. Thanksgiving! America’s best holiday.

headline: Voice of a Fan on Concussions
text: Should Ben Roethlisberger play this Sunday? Should Brian Westbrook play at all this season? Walt Bennett, a frequent Fifth Down commenter, shared his thoughts on being a fan in an age of concussion awareness, and added his view on the minimum the N.F.L. should be doing about it. Take it away, Walt:

headline: Package Tour: Driving a FedEx Hybrid
text: THE first thing I noticed when I got behind the wheel of a hybrid FedEx Express delivery truck was the lack of an ignition lock. Instead of using a key, I borrowed one of the radio frequency ID tags that drivers swipe over a reader, and I hit the “engine start” button to get rolling.

headline: Heinz Tallies Cuts in Emissions
text: Two years ago, executives at the Pittsburgh-based food giant Heinz met to hash out sustainability goals that they characterized as “aggressive but achievable,” according to Michael Mullen, the company’s vice president for corporate affairs.

headline: Head of Climate Panel Discusses Climate Files
text: Rajendra K. Pachauri, the chairman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, has distributed a statement on the unauthorized disclosure of thousands of e-mail messages and documents involving a variety of contributors to the panel’s reports. One e-mail message from July 8, 2004, particularly related to the workings of the climate panel, has been the subject of much discussion.

headline: Thursday (Thanksgiving) Reading
text: Several consumer-focused stories appear today in various sections of The New York Times and online. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Half-Truths Dim Chances for Renewing Mideast Talks
text: JERUSALEM  In recent years, the international community has made one central demand of Israel and one of the Palestinians to create conditions for a two-state solution: Israel must stop building settlements on land the Palestinians want for their state, and the Palestinians must dismantle terrorist networks and end violent attacks on Israelis.

headline: Readings and Resources for Planning Your Black Friday
text: While the turkey is in the oven, you may be planning your shopping strategy for Friday. A host of stories in today’s New York Times and elsewhere may be of some help.

headline: What to Watch on Thursday
text: The Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade was covered live by both NBC (Meredith Vieira, Matt Lauer and Al Roker) and CBS (Maggie Rodriguez and Dave Price) beginning at 9 a.m. NBC then moves to real animals with the National Dog Show (noon) from Oaks, Pa., hosted by John O’Hurley.

headline: Deletionists
text: Wikipedia editors who are quick to delete new or controversial postings.

headline: Questions About (Among Other Things) Integrity, Stuffing, Cranberries
text: Dear Sam: Is it possible that by manning the help desk you are cunningly avoiding kitchen duty on Thanksgiving morning? In any case, I have a question. Every year, preparing a meal for 20, we cooked a turkey so large that it monopolized the oven. But we also needed large casseroles of dressing, sweet potatoes and other sides to fit in there. How to solve this dilemma? We decided to move to Berlin, Germany. What’s your solution? Maria, Berlin

headline: Broadway Menu to Lose ‘Donuts’
text: The Broadway production of “Superior Donuts,” the bittersweet comedy by Tracy Letts, will close on Jan. 3, the lead producer Jeffrey Richards said on Thursday.

headline: Radio, Radio
text: Want some good Thanksgiving advice from The New York Times? Listen to this embedded radio device gizmo!

headline: Seeing San Francisco From a Different Angle
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As fires raged downtown after the 1906 earthquake, residents of this city fled to two nearby districts to the south, Bernal Heights and Glen Park. Though part of San Francisco, both areas looked more like countryside then, with open ranchland, vineyards and orchards, dirt roads and wetlands, and a few houses. The windswept peaks above Glen Park were called Little Switzerland.

headline: Balcones del Atlántico
text: WHAT Residential beachfront resort.

headline: Chief Sponsor Defends G.O.P. Litmus Test
text: In a post on Wednesday, conservative and liberal bloggers alike criticized a proposed resolution that would deny funding and endorsements to Republican candidates who failed to adhere to many core principles. Why, even Ronald Reagan wouldn’t pass, some pundits remarked.

headline: You Taking Care of Yourself? Getting Some ‘Me’ Time?
text: We haven’t talked much about feelings today, about how annoying it is that your sister always has something critical to say, or about how your mom’s voice gets thick two bourbons into the afternoon and you know that means a fight’s coming later, or about how unbelievably tired the whole business of putting together a meal for your deadbeat children can make you.

headline: Water Funds Proliferate in Latin America
text: Despite an abundance of water in Latin America, 77 million people in the region still lack access to safe drinking supplies, according to the World Water Council — particularly in areas with poor farming practices, unregulated industrialization and urban poverty.

headline: From Lancaster to Iraq: A Thanksgiving Day Racing Tradition
text: Among the hundreds of things I miss about home during my year in Iraq is the Turkey Day bike race in Lancaster County, Penn. This unofficial final race of every season draws 50 or more racers from around the county, and it shows which cyclists kept up with their fitness routines since the end of the season in September. So when I finally got a chance to organize a bike race on Tallil Ali Air Base after six months here, I wanted it to be on Thanksgiving Day.

headline: U.N. Nuclear Agency Calls Iran Inquiry ‘Dead End’
text: The director general of the United Nations nuclear watchdog declared in unusually blunt language on Thursday that Iran had stonewalled investigators about evidence that the country had worked on nuclear weapons design, and that his efforts to reveal the truth had “effectively reached a dead end.”

headline: Iraqi Lawmakers Hunt for Election Compromise
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s political leaders sought a compromise that would avoid further delay in the country’s national election, officials said on Thursday, warning that fierce disagreements on how to conduct the election could still undo any deal.

headline: Filmmaking Workshops at the Museum of the Moving Image
text: The movies are a favorite pastime during the Thanksgiving break, but it’s a rare cinema that allows children to make films as well as watch them.

headline: The Flexible Nature of Time, and Other Questions
text: Many are writing in now to say that the turkey’s almost done and that’d be great if the guests were coming in a half-hour. But they’re not! They’re coming in two hours, three hours, four. What do to? Is there a way to slow the process? This is a disaster!

headline: On the Question of Drinks
text: I’d like to have your recommendation for a wine for Thanksgiving turkey dinner. Thank you! Glen Cheney, Macungie, Pa.

headline: Three Crooked Gangs, See How They Bumble
text: Simultaneously channeling Scorsese, Jarmusch and Wayans, the first-time feature director Julian Mark Kheel films each story line of his indie comedy “The Brooklyn Heist” in a different mode. As three bumbling gangs of crooks plan to hit the same pawnshop on the same night, the old friends from the neighborhood are shot “Mean Streets” style, the buppie gangsters appear in mock rap videos and the solemn Chechnyan siblings perform in art-house black and white.

headline: Time to Go Home
text: We’ve been at it since early this morning here at the Diner’s Journal Thanksgiving Help Desk, and it’s now just about time to close up shop and head over to Emmett’s for about five straight vodkas home to the loving family. You can continue to post comments on this or any other post in the series; I hope you do. But questions will now only be answered by your peers. I really do have to knock off, eat, go watch some football. Thanks for reading, and writing. I am very grateful to you all for your time.

headline: In a Wife’s Crème Brûlée, Visions of a Stormy Past
text: Almost everybody who arrives at age 50 more or less intact carries memories of an earlier stage of life in which a wilder, unformed self lurched and blundered through young adulthood before making a fateful decision to settle. It could be a career choice or a long-term relationship, or both. For the title character of Rebecca Miller’s wry, acutely observant drama “The Private Lives of Pippa Lee,” her comfortable landing is her marriage to a successful book publisher 30 years her senior, whom she describes in a candid running voice-over as her rescuer from a life adrift.

headline: Longing for the Old Days and Looking for Meaning
text: Early in “Ward No. 6,” an updated adaptation of Chekhov’s famous short story set in a Russian provincial mental hospital, the chief doctor, Hobotov (Evgeny Stychkin), leads a documentary film crew through the halls of the shabby institution. In a movie that deliberately blurs the line between fiction and reality, present and past, the sane and the crazy, interviews with actual mental patients (one of whom claims to have killed John Lennon on orders from the Soviet leader Yuri Andropov) are interspersed with actors playing residents speaking Chekhov’s dialogue.

headline: A Coaching Tree’s Fruits Could Spoil
text: Charlie Weis is a compelling twist on Abraham Lincoln’s observation that “you can fool all of the people some of the time and some of the people all of the time, but you cannot fool all of the people all of the time.”

headline: Contestants in the ‘Climate Slamdown’
text: Marc Roberts, my favorite environment blogtoonist (then again, that’s not exactly a review considering there’s only one such person, I think), has tried to capture what he foresees happening in Copenhagen in less than two weeks. Click here for the full set of panels. I particularly like the sequence below, which introduces the “teams” vying for victory in the halls of the Bella Center. Among them, developing countries — “small but they’re plucky, and they’re fighting for their lives” — and the corporate lobby team — “the overwhelming favorites to win…”

headline: Theater Listings: Nov. 27 — Dec. 3
text: THEATER

headline: An Isolated Family Hears Outside World Knocking
text: Home is where the heart is and sometimes the pathologies too. In “Home,” an art-house domestic comedy with a tragic undercurrent about a family and its idiosyncratic cohabitation, home is fun house and fortress both, a bright spot, a dark corner, a place of play, a place apart. Mostly, though, it’s a state of mind.

headline: Obamas’ Uninvited Guests Prompt an Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON  The Secret Service is investigating how a couple aspiring to be reality-show celebrities managed to appear at President Obama’s first state dinner without being on the guest list, provoking questions about security at the White House.

headline: Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade
text: The procession made its way down Seventh Avenue rather than Broadway.

headline: Increased Role for Boss Puts Target on His Back
text: DENVER  Giants tight end Kevin Boss chuckled softly as he discussed a photograph recently sent to him. It showed Boss after he caught a pass against Arizona at Giants Stadium on Oct. 25.

headline: Weekend Matchups: Turducken for the College Fan
text: For some reason, a couple of pro football games on Thanksgiving Day get all the credit. That’s what people think of when they think of football and Thanksgiving. I would argue that Thanksgiving pro football is like turkey. It’s good enough, but needs some accoutrement to go with it. Maybe some cranberry sauce, or at the very least some stuffing and sweet potatoes. A weekend of rivalry games like this one coming up? That’s something a little more nuanced for a more delicate and refined palate. I would argue that this weekend of college games is more like the turducken, a complex and multi-layered Russian doll of food, that never fails to surprise with it’s confusing flavor juxtapositions and horrific caloric implications.

headline: A Tradition That Cherishes Poker, Not Pumpkin Pie
text: UNCASVILLE, Conn.  Some traditions are indelibly carved into the nation’s psyche, among them tucking in late each November to inadvisable amounts of mashed potatoes, turkey and pie. Then there are the traditions that spring from an indifference to all that, which is how Jennifer Bi, 41 years old, mother and manicurist, daughter of China and denizen of Flushing, Queens, found herself staring down a baccarat table in a Connecticut casino at 3 a.m. on Thanksgiving.

headline: Sounds of Contentment (Words Are Optional)
text: Whenever she could, Bebel Gilberto happily left words behind as she performed at Hiro Ballroom on Wednesday night. She cruised through the verses of songs until words gave way to nonsense syllables: oohs and ahs and ba-da-das; or the onomatopoeia of “Chica Chica Boom Chic,” a song from Carmen Miranda; and “Bim Bom,” a song from her father, the bossa nova sage João Gilberto. Setting aside verbal messages brought her closer to the bliss her music seeks, in an imagined Brazil filled with love.

headline: A Rare Chinese Look at Secret Detentions
text: BEIJING  In a rare dose of candor that contradicts past official statements, a state-run magazine has published an article that details a secret network of detention centers used to prevent aggrieved citizens from lodging complaints against the Chinese government.

headline: To Pay for Longer School Days, Some Parents Try Raising Money
text: After raising $35,000 for gym mats, musical instruments and other extras last year, parents at Disney II Magnet School in Chicago now face a more daunting price tag  $100,000  to keep their children in class an extra hour each day.

headline: Little Love for Turkeys
text: TURKEYS Behind the birds’ expanding colonization of local hills and backyards is the National Wild Turkey Federation, a powerful hunters’ organization. In 1973, there were just over a million turkeys in North America. Today, there are seven million.

headline: Report Says Irish Bishops and Police Hid Abuse
text: LONDON  The Roman Catholic Church and the police in Ireland systematically colluded in covering up decades of child sex abuse by priests in Dublin, according to a scathing report released Thursday.

text: Boston

headline: Millions of Pounds of Dead Carp for Sale in Utah
text: DENVER  The disposal problem? Ten to 20 tons of decaying carp every day. The solution? Unresolved. But wildlife managers in Utah would love to hear from anyone who thinks big  or at least creatively  and does not mind the smell.

headline: A Remote Island Seeks a Boom Without a Bust
text: CHRISTMAS ISLAND, Australia  “The good times are back on Christmas Island,” said Trish O’Donnell, this island’s sole real estate agent. “Three-quarters of Australians probably didn’t know Christmas Island belonged to Australia, but now it’s a speculators’ market. All thanks to the I.D.C.”

headline: Rootless for the Holidays
text: IN my early 20s, I worked for a tree care company as a climber and spent many happy hours pruning in upper branches. The company was often hired by homeowners to remove trees to open up a view or make way for a pool or driveway.

headline: Oprah to Film at White House
text: Oprah Winfrey will film a one-hour Christmas special at the White House that will include an interview with President Barack Obama, her first with him since he took office, Ms. Winfrey announced on her blog late Wednesday. The ABC special, to run on Dec. 13 at 10 p.m., will include a sit-down with President Obama and the first lady, and feature behind-the-scenes preparations for the holidays at the White House. Ms. Winfrey had not endorsed a presidential candidate until December 2007, when she came out for Mr. Obama, a fellow Chicagoan, just weeks before the crucial presidential caucuses in neighboring Iowa, which he went on to win.

headline: Tyler Perry Makes Donation
text: Tyler Perry, the director of “Diary of a Mad Black Woman” and several other films featuring his popular screen character Madea, has donated $1 million to the N.A.A.C.P., the largest gift to date by an individual to that civil rights organization. Mr. Perry said in a statement that he had made the gift to honor the group for its 100th anniversary this year. The donation will be paid over the next four years, the N.A.A.C.P. said.

headline: CBS Takes First Place
text: On the Wednesday night before Thanksgiving, “Criminal Minds” and “CSI: NY” lifted CBS into first place as the most-watched network in prime time. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 13.5 million viewers tuned in at 9 p.m. for “Criminal Minds,” making it the night’s top-rated show, while “CSI: NY” won the 10 p.m. hour with 12.7 million viewers, outpacing “The Jay Leno Show” on NBC (5.1 million) and “Eastwick” on ABC (3.7 million). NBC ranked second, with 7.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 for a special of “The Biggest Loser.” Fox was third with “So You Think You Can Dance” at 8 (4.9 million) and “Glee” at 9 (6.1 million), while ABC was fourth with “Modern Family” at 9 (7.1 million) and “Cougar Town” at 9:30 (5.5 million). CBS’s comedies during the 8 p.m. hour, “The New Adventures of Old Christine” (7 million) and “Gary Unmarried” (6.8 million), fared better than ABC’s sitcoms, “Modern Family” at 8 (5.5 million) and “The Middle” at 8:30 (6 million).

headline: Disney Is Developing ‘High School Musical’ in China
text: Disney is developing a Chinese film version of its original “High School Musical” television movie to be released there next summer, a Disney spokeswoman told Agence France-Presse. “Disney High School Musical: China” will rework parts of the story about high school students dealing with rivalry, romance and peer pressure as they try out for a school show. The new version will be set at a university, for instance, since Chinese high school students are so focused on academics that they would not have time to devote to singing and dancing, the report said. The movie has begun filming in Shanghai and stars six young actors drawn from across China.

headline: ‘Superior Donuts’ to Close
text: Another Broadway play lacking a big-name star is closing. “Superior Donuts,” a bittersweet comedy by Tracy Letts, will end its run on Jan. 3, the lead producer Jeffrey Richards said on Thursday. Starring Michael McKean and Jon Michael Hill as men who become friends while working in a Chicago doughnut shop, the play is Mr. Letts’s follow-up to “August: Osage County,” which won a Pulitzer Prize and the Tony Award for best play and closed on Broadway in June after 648 performances. “August” didn’t have stars, either, but its award pedigree and strong critical support helped give it life. “Donuts” opened on Oct. 1 and will have run about 100 performances at the Music Box Theater. Last month a revival of “Brighton Beach Memoirs,” also without celebrities in the cast, closed after only a week.

headline: ‘Hairspray’ With Handsets
text: The London production of the musical “Hairspray” has begun offering a hand-held wireless device that translates dialogue and lyrics into eight languages for audience members who do not speak English or are hard of hearing, Agence France-Presse reported. The battery-powered handset, called AirScript, provides real-time subtitles in English, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Russian, Japanese and Chinese. Cambridge Consultants, which developed the technology, said the device could raise revenue for theaters by drawing in new audience members. The company hopes to widen the use of the devices to other productions on the West End and perhaps beyond.

headline: Footnotes
text: Mandy Patinkin will play Benedict in an act from “Much Ado About Nothing” as part of Classic Stage Company’s Monday-night rehearsal series. Mr. Patinkin will perform on Dec. 7 and Dec. 14 in the program, which lets performers explore an act from a classic play. ... Julie Andrews will perform on the London stage for the first time in 30 years on May 8, according to the Web site for the O2 Arena, where the revue of musical theater standards will take place. Her singing voice was damaged during an operation 12 years ago, but her manager told The Times of London that she has “been able to regain some of the notes she was once well known for.” ... The opening nights of Parts 2 and 3 of Horton Foote’s “Orphans’ Home Cycle” at the Signature Theater have been changed because of conflicts with other openings; the changes increase the chance for prominent coverage by news outlets. The new openings are Dec. 17 for Part 2 (instead of Dec. 13, when “A Little Night Music” is to open) and Jan. 26 for Part 3 (instead of Jan. 24, when “A View From the Bridge” is to open).

text: As he sought to persuade wary voters that he deserved a third term as mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg sold himself as a no-nonsense financial watchdog who was ready to swing the budget ax.

text: WASHINGTON  Senator Bob Casey of Pennsylvania wants to talk about health care, Medicare, children’s insurance, a public option  anything but abortion.

text: MADISON, Wis.  Seven and a half months into Ta-Shai Pendleton’s first pregnancy, her child was stillborn. Then in early 2008, she bore a daughter prematurely.

headline: Retailers Take a Wait-and-See Approach to Holiday Hiring
text: The traditional kickoff of the holiday shopping season normally coincides with a flurry of seasonal hiring in the city, amounting to as many as 25,000 extra jobs. But last year’s financial crisis caused holiday hiring to fall off, and this year’s recession had a similar effect

headline: HSBC Returns to Its Roots in Hong Kong
text: HSBC is so tied to Hong Kong that when the bank’s shares dropped sharply earlier this year a local television commentator burst into tears while reporting the news.

headline: Unforgettable Books for Those You Remember
text: There’s a good reason why the three daily book critics for The New York Times don’t make 10-best lists at the end of the year: we can’t. None of us has read everything. Our reviewing assignments don’t overlap. None of us has an objective overview of the year’s best and most important books, but this is what we do have: favorites. They are books we have not only admired in the abstract but also enjoyed, recommended and given to friends.

headline: Dollar Hits a 14-Year Low Versus the Yen
text: TOKYO  The dollar tumbled to a 14-year low against the yen on Thursday, reinforcing concern in Tokyo that America’s already-strapped consumers would buy even fewer Japanese cars and gadgets.

headline: Taliban Open Northern Front in Afghanistan
text: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  Far from the heartland of the Taliban insurgency in the south, this once peaceful northern province was one place American and Afghan officials thought they did not have to worry about.

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Seeks Billions for Blowing Whistle

headline: Taxing the Speculators
text: Should we use taxes to deter financial speculation? Yes, say top British officials, who oversee the City of London, one of the world’s two great banking centers. Other European governments agree  and they’re right.

headline: No Rookie of the Year, but a Cornerstone Player
text: As a San Francisco Giants rookie in 1982, Chili Davis batted .261 with 19 home runs, 76 runs batted in, 24 stolen bases and 16 outfield assists in 154 games. As a Giants beat writer that year, I saw every one of them.

headline: Poverty Could Imperil the Amnesty in Niger Delta
text: ALUU, Nigeria  A wary peace has settled over this strategic region, a major world oil supplier and for years a combustible nexus of third world militancy, deprivation and government corruption.

headline: The Other Education
text: Like many of you, I went to elementary school, high school and college. I took such and such classes, earned such and such grades, and amassed such and such degrees.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Dubai’s Move on Debt Rattles Markets Worldwide
text: Global financial markets swooned Thursday, with London seeing its most precipitous drop in nearly nine months, a day after Dubai stunned investors with the news that it was asking banks to allow its main investment vehicle, Dubai World, to suspend its debt repayments for six months.

headline: On a Mission to Banish the Saggy Bottom
text: WHEN women try on pants, the first thing they do is turn around and look over their shoulders into the mirror. If Andy Dunn has his way, men will soon do the same.

headline: The Names Ring a Few Bells
text: Whitney Houston and Brittany Spears shared a college dorm room two years ago. It was a unique pairing that quickly evolved into a strong friendship, but there were no albums or Grammy Awards to show for it, and no paparazzi lurking when they went out to eat.

headline: U.S. Unlikely to Use the Ethanol Congress Ordered
text: WASHINGTON  Two years ago, Congress ordered the nation’s gasoline refiners to do something that is turning out to be mathematically impossible.

headline: Hope Born of Desperation
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Ed Sessa’s fine previous puzzle was about dropping letters from theme clues (Across Lite, Solution). This seems to be a personal theme for him as well. In his debut puzzle, a Monday I also enjoyed (Across Lite, Solution), he billed himself as Edward M. Sessa. By puzzle No. 2 he was down to Edward Sessa, and today he’s a mere Ed Sessa. Letters are starting to get critical at this point, so who knows what he’ll be next. In any case, you now have links to all his puzzles and you can solve his entire oeuvre. And remember, you can find the entire New York Times daily and Sunday puzzle archive organized by constructor here, so look up your favorite and print out a set of puzzles for a rainy weekend.

headline: Subway Killing Captured by a Photo Student
text: It began with a startling, inexplicable explosion of anger over a seat on a D train. And then the passenger who had resisted giving up his seat was bleeding from stab wounds, staggering through the car, collapsing, dying.

headline: Knicks Feel Young Players’ Growing Pains
text: SACRAMENTO  Mike D’Antoni has played his rotation like an accordion, compressing it sometimes and widening it at others in search of a middle ground with his veteran placeholders and younger players.

headline: Keeping Derivatives in the Dark
text: Opaque markets breed insider profits and abuse of investors. Sunshine can bring competition and lower costs even if regulators do little beyond letting the sunlight shine.

headline: Again, Debt Disqualifies Applicant From the Bar
text: Mind how you handle your student loans aspiring lawyers, or you could find your debt hurting more than your bank accounts. Loans could derail your career before it can start.

headline: Career Begun in London Is Flourishing in Desert
text: The ball was in Eric Boateng’s hands near the basket, but he shuffled his feet before he could go up against the defender and was whistled for a walk. His pass from the lane toward a teammate on the baseline sailed out of bounds. His hook shot hit nothing but air.

headline: Limit on Bank Fee Won’t Be Painless
text: Regulators and politicians are competing to rein in bank overdraft fees. The Federal Reserve decided this month that banks must receive customers’ consent before allowing them to overdraw their accounts. Other proposals in Congress go even further, limiting charges or prescribing the structure of fees.

headline: Doormen and Residents: Under One Roof, Yet Far Apart
text: The contradictory relationship between building residents and doormen is an unspoken reality under the awnings of East 74th Street. Doormen have an intimate knowledge of residents’ comings and goings. They are trusted not only with security but often with confidences from weary residents at the end of a work day. They watch the building’s children grow up.

headline: Weekly Pick ‘Em: A Thanksgiving Rivalry Weekend
text: On a holiday rivalry weekend like this one, one game seems to stand out above the rest: Alabama at Auburn. But, since the No. 2 Crimson Tide are favored and a victory by the Tigers, while possible, would be a major upset, we’re staying away from that matchup in this week’s picks. Besides, there are plenty of other intriguing games this weekend, beginning with Friday’s Backyard Brawl between Pittsburgh and West Virginia. Oklahoma and Oklahoma State, and B.Y.U. and Utah will face off in tense in-state rivalry games, while Les Miles will try to put his last-minute time mismanagement debacle behind him when Louisiana State faces Arkansas. But the coach whose seat is at the highest temperature right now is Charlie Weis. Notre Dame faces Stanford on Saturday, and has a chance to get a victory for Weis in what may be his last game as the Irish’s coach. Will Jimmy Clausen and crew come through for Weis? Our prognosticators have made their selections, and you can let us know what you think of them. If you agree, disagree or merely find the picks laughable, feel free to drop a comment below.

headline: Bay Area Chefs Dodge New York Knives
text: Bay Area foodies have been up in arms lately over a series of critical comments from chefs in New York. Most recently, Momofuku’s David Chang, in a New York conversation with Anthony Bourdain, said of Bay Area chefs: “They don’t manipulate food, they just put figs on a plate.” Food blogs exploded; the San Francisco Asia Society even canceled a cookbook signing by Mr. Chang.

text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction.
