headline: Man Charged in Hit-and-Run That Killed Couple Outside Staten Island Church
text: A Staten Island man with a history of traffic violations was charged on Thursday in a hit-and-run accident that killed an elderly couple, who were struck outside their church the night before as they walked to a Thanksgiving Mass with cans of food for the poor, the authorities said.

headline: Hugh Morgan Hill, the Storyteller Brother Blue, Dies at 88
text: Hugh Morgan Hill, who as the storyteller known as Brother Blue captivated passers-by on the streets of Boston and Cambridge, Mass., with his parables, life stories and idiosyncratic retellings of Shakespeare’s plays, and who became a fixture at storytelling conferences and gatherings in the United States and abroad, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Cambridge. He was 88.

headline: Chronicling a Life and Honing Job Skills
text: A lot of people cry over their hard-luck stories. Dominique Wright wants to write about hers.

headline: Bay Area Highlights for Nov. 27
text: Powerful Force | Terrance Alan and the San Francisco entertainment commission have taken day-to-day control over the rowdy, popular clubs that, owners estimate, represent $1 billion of the city’s $8 billion in annual tourist revenue.

headline: Yes, You Owe That Tax
text: As many Americans gird themselves for the Black Friday shopping crush, we can think of a lot of reasons to stay home and do holiday shopping online. Not having to pay sales taxes should not be one of them.

headline: Immigrants, Criminalized
text: A bedrock premise of smart immigration reform is the sharp distinction it draws between criminal aliens and Americans-in-waiting. While it acknowledges that illegal immigrants need to get right with the law, it treats illegal status as a civil matter to be resolved by the machinery of naturalization, not by the police and prisons.

headline: A Big Loss for Big Tobacco
text: A Florida jury has ordered Philip Morris USA to pay $300 million to a former smoker who developed severe emphysema and may need a lung transplant. The verdict may encourage more plaintiffs and lawyers to bring similar claims. There should be more lawsuits seeking not only monetary damages, but changes in how the tobacco industry markets its products.

headline: Fly the Sleazy Skies
text: The Federal Election Commission  the supposed referee of fair campaigning  has just created an ethics loophole big enough for lobbyists to fly a corporate jet through. The commission has taken upon itself to reverse the Senate’s self-restriction against lawmakers’ cozy cut-rate travels on corporate jets.

headline: No Appeal on Polanski Bail
text: Swiss officials said on Thursday that they would not challenge a court ruling permitting Roman Polanski to be freed on bail as he fights extradition to the United States to face sentencing for having sex with a 13-year-old girl. On Wednesday the Swiss Federal Criminal Court granted Mr. Polanski’s appeal against detention in exchange for $4.5 million, along with other guarantees like the surrender of his identity papers to ensure he does not leave the country. Still, Interpol issued an advisory to its 188 member countries saying that Mr. Polanski should be arrested if he tried to travel. He fled the United States in 1978 before being sentenced. The Justice Ministry had 10 days to submit an appeal to the Swiss Federal Supreme Court, but said on Thursday that it had decided not to. The development means that Mr. Polanski may leave his jail cell and remain under house arrest and electronic monitoring at his holiday chalet, above, in Gstaad, a Swiss resort town.

headline: Insured, but Not Covered
text: Adrienne Schroeder recently moved to Richmond, Va., from Bozeman, Mont., to care for her aging father. Medical expenses  not his, but hers  are a concern.

headline: Broncos Beat Giants, 26-6.
text: Denver passed and ran effectively while also harassing Eli Manning.

headline: Taking the Health Care Debate to the Mall
text: Advocates of health care legislation are facing many challenges in getting their messages across to the public over the holidays. So one advocacy group is essentially moving its campaign to where the consumers are: stores and shopping malls.

headline: Black Friday 2009
text: For Black Friday this year, some stores increased security for the anticipated holiday shopping frenzy.

headline: If It Looks Like Poe and Sounds Like Poe . . .
text: Saturday, Nov. 27, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Broncos Bury the Giants
text: DENVER  With five games remaining in the Giants’ deteriorating season, defensive end Justin Tuck offered an optimistic take on the team’s chances in the race for the N.F.C. East title.

headline: One Foot in the Past
text: Inwood, the northernmost neighborhood in Manhattan, is a place of hills and history. Inwood Hill Park, 196 acres of tree-filled landscape, dominates the scene, and traces of Lenape Indians and Dutch settlers abound. But there are relative newcomers, too, including opera singers and others who are attracted to Inwood’s burgeoning arts community. One artist who lives there  and grew up there  is Lin-Manuel Miranda, the Grammy- and Tony-winning creator of the Broadway musical “In the Heights.” The expedition begins at the 207th Street station, the terminus of the A train.

headline: Rogers Communications to Cut 900 Jobs in Canada
text: Rogers Communications, the largest wireless carrier in Canada, said it was eliminating about 900 jobs nationwide as the company reorganized its wireless and cable units. The company, based in Toronto, said the cuts affected about 3 percent of its 30,000 employees. Rogers made the move to adapt to the way consumers buy and download entertainment, using wireless devices like Apple’s iPhone to watch movies and TV shows.

headline: Reader’s Digest Turnaround Plan Advances
text: The Reader’s Digest Association won bankruptcy court approval for an outline of its turnaround plan after revisions prompted bondholders, a pension trustee and the United States to withdraw their objections. Judge Robert D. Drain of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan said on Tuesday that he would approve the so-called disclosure statement, which explains terms of the reorganization to creditors.

headline: Scenes From Around the Bay
text: Chloe Veltman, our Bay Area culture correspondent, took this photo on Market Street in San Francisco. Can you name the people in this impromptu mural?

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Foligno’s Goal Boosts Senators
text: Thursday was American Thanksgiving, so there were only two games on the schedule, both in Canada and both involving exclusively middle-of-the-pack clubs. Home teams listed first:

headline: Take 5: Things to Do This Weekend
text: Wondering what to do this weekend? We’ve got you covered:Festival: The Great Dickens Christmas FairNow 30 years old, a favorite Bay Area Yuletide tradition returns to the Cow PalaceThrough December 20, the Cow Palace, San Francisco

headline: Longhorns Slip by Aggies, but Maybe Not by Critics
text: COLLEGE STATION, Tex.  The weakened Big 12 has been more of a coronation tour than a challenge for Texas this season.

headline: News Quiz | November 27, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: Khmer Rouge Warden Asks to Be Freed
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Testimony in the nine-month trial of a former prison chief for the communist Khmer Rouge ended Friday when the defendant unexpectedly asked to be set free despite his repeated admissions of guilt.

headline: Fine Print | A Love Letter to the Letterpress
text: The first time I met the bookmaker Jon Beacham, he was living in Beacon, N.Y., with a woman who was then his girlfriend, in a century-old house on the wrong side of the tracks from Dia/Beacon. The pair ran the Hermitage, a combination bookstore, press and gallery specializing in small-press American poetry from the 1950s through the 1970s. But Beacham recently moved back to the city to reopen the Hermitage in a desolate stretch of Bushwick, Brooklyn. “It was too hard to be doing something so esoteric and to be stuck in a small town on the Hudson,” he explained. Oh well. Beacon’s loss is Brooklyn’s gain.

headline: Celebrating Miles Davis in Sight and Sound
text: PARIS | Examining music in a museum space is no simple task; exhibitions about musicians tend to downplay the music itself. But “We Want Miles,” an ambitious show about the life and music of the jazz great Miles Davis, at Cité de la Musique through Jan. 17, is a remarkable exception. In this exhibition, the music is central.

headline: Q. & A. on Match Fixing With Declan Hill, Author of ‘The Fix’
text: It wasn’t until after Declan Hill published “The Fix: Soccer and Organized Crime” in September 2008 that European soccer authorities were ready to confront head-on the scourge of match fixing.

headline: Giants Open Thread: The Denver Debacle
text: Ernie Palladino has been a Giants beat writer since 1989 and is the only fully credentialed independent blogger covering them. He writes about the team at erniepalladinosgiantsbeat.blogspot.com.

headline: Philippine Official Says Victims Were Sexually Mutilated
text: DAVAO CITY, the Philippines  Most or all of the 22 women among the 57 people massacred Monday in the southern Philippines were sexually mutilated, the authorities said Friday, adding grim details to the catalog of horrors that has already emerged.

headline: ‘The Death of Uncool’
text: Today’s idea: There are so many cultural trends today that the distinction between cool and uncool doesn’t matter anymore, says Brian Eno. We’re all hipsters now.

headline: Russia and China Endorse Agency’s Rebuke of Iran
text: WASHINGTON  The United Nations nuclear watchdog demanded Friday that Iran immediately freeze operations at a once secret uranium enrichment plant, a sharp rebuke that bore added weight because it was endorsed by Russia and China.

headline: Palinized
text: A term used to describe the vilification of female Republicans (as well as other associations with Sarah Palin).

headline: Health Care Rationing, American-Style
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline: Some Jostling, but Less of a Frenzy Among Shoppers
text: A year after an unfolding economic crisis sent consumers into shock, they ventured out Friday and opened their wallets a bit  still hunting bargains, but no longer quite so afraid to spend.

headline: A University Takes Aim at Obesity
text: You might worry about your body weight fluctuating in college, but did you ever think that gaining the notorious freshman 15 could keep you from graduating?

headline: Saab Faithful Remember Some Favorites
text: The announcement that General Motors‘ proposed sale of Saab to Koenigsegg has fallen through may mean the death of the Swedish automaker. Talking to the Saab faithful following the news was like discussing the death of a favorite relative who had experienced a long decline before the inevitable end.

headline: Seeking a Statue Fit for a Star … Again
text: Louis Moreau Gottschalk was the 19th century’s idea of a rock star: a composer and performer so famous that when he went on tour, he took two pianos with him, size extra long. He called them “my mastodons.”

headline: Dubai’s Investment Fund Crisis Unnerves Investors for a Second Day
text: The debt crisis facing the Dubai investment fund rattled investors for a second day on Friday, rekindling doubts about the vitality of emerging economies. Investors, however, said they had anticipated the deterioration of the country’s real estate bubble, and they considered Dubai’s troubles an isolated case.

headline: Speed Read for Friday, Nov. 27
text: Here are some highlights from Friday’s edition of The New York Times:

headline: Sampler: Football Player Head Injury, Same-Sex Couple Benefits, Panhandlers’ Pets
text: Football Head Injury | A 16-year-old San Jose high school football player was in critical condition Thursday night after suffering a head injury at a Thanksgiving Day football game between two rival San Jose schools.

headline: German Minister Resigns Over Afghan Airstrike
text: BERLIN  A German cabinet official resigned Friday, saying he accepted “political responsibility” for accusations that the military withheld information about an airstrike in Afghanistan in September that killed civilians as well as insurgents.

headline: Assessing Algal Blooms’ Economic Impact
text: Toxic algae is not only physically harmful, it can do major damage to local economies, according to a new study by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the University of Washington.

headline: Big States Dominate European Commission Posts
text: BRUSSELS  The biggest European countries on Friday scooped up the most sought-after leadership positions in a new commission that is expected to press for more regulation in areas like financial services.

headline: Obama’s Climate Goals vs. the Senate’s
text: Updated, Nov. 27, 4:50 p.m. | Ryan Alexander, the president of Taxpayers for Common Sense, joins the discussion, arguing against new subsidies for energy producers.

headline: Week 12 N.F.L. Matchups
text: Steelers (6-4) at Ravens (5-5)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.No line

headline: The Morning Feed
text: What we’re reading on Friday morning.No Release Yet for Polanski: A spokesman for Switzerland’s Justice Ministry said that the director Roman Polanski will not be released from a prison near Zurich until at least Monday because the jailed filmmaker has not yet met all the conditions of his bail, The Associated Press reports. Under the bail agreement that was accepted on Wednesday, Mr. Polanski must post $4.5 million, which he has not yet paid; the director must also surrender his identity papers and be fitted with a monitoring bracelet.Not Ready for Prime Time: If an American television presentation can be edited for showing two men kissing, what does it take for a British television broadcast to provoke the scissors of the censors? The BBC reports that BBC4 has dropped its plans to show the ballet “Eternal Damnation to Sancho and Sanchez” by the Venezuelan choreographer Javier de Frutos because it depicted, among other things, a hunchback Pope strangling a pregnant nun with rosary beads. (The ballet also features nude scenes.) “When we announced we were showing it, at the time we weren’t fully aware of the details of the ballet,” a BBC spokesman said.Snowin’ in the Wind: In an interview in a British magazine called The Big Issue, Bob Dylan explained his motivation for recording his first holiday-themed album, “Christmas in the Heart,” Reuters reports. Though Mr. Dylan was raised Jewish in Minnesota, Christmas was one of his favorite holidays — a time, he recalled, of “plenty of snow, jingle bells, Christmas carolers going from house to house, sleighs in the streets, town bells ringing, nativity plays.” Asked what faith he practices now, Mr. Dylan told the magazine, “I am a true believer.”Had Your Fill of Turkey Yet? On this day after Turkey Day, it seems only appropriate for The Guardian to recount the tale of “Divine Rapture,” a notorious 1995 film project that never got off the ground. The movie was to star Johnny Depp, Marlon Brando and Debra Winger in the story of a woman who is hailed as a saint in her village when she miraculously rises from her coffin during her own funeral. (It turns out she had a rare disorder that slowed her heart-rate.) After six weeks of preparation in the Irish town of Ballycotton, the production ran out of money; Mr. Brando was nonetheless paid $1 million for his time.

headline: When Your Spouse Is Your Business Partner
text: If you have to be a little crazy to be an entrepreneur, going into business with your spouse must represent a special kind of lunacy. My husband, Chris, and I have been business partners for more than six years. In that time we’ve started two businesses, sold one of them, had two kids and gotten more or less used to the daily roller coaster ride of entrepreneurial life.

headline: The Wagon of Cadillacs
text: FOR most of us, the classic American station wagon  with its acres of fake woodgrain siding, sticky vinyl bench seats and lazy-revving V-8 engine  is a fixture of our collective automotive consciousness. It is also extinct. The gas crises of the ’70s hobbled it, the minivans of the ’80s dealt a knockout blow and the S.U.V.’s that followed stomped on its grave.

headline: Rashomon in the desert
text: Dubai or not Dubai — that is the question. Dubai’s sorta-kinda default (a state-owned enterprise seeking a rescheduling of its debts) is, by itself, not that big of a deal. But who else looks like Dubai? What kind of omen is this for the next stage in the financial crisis?

headline: Which New Hybrid Has 10 Wheels and Flies?
text: IT sounded like a garbage truck and smelled like one, too. Aside from the giant pastoral scene on its side, it even looked like a standard-issue New York City garbage truck.

headline: Cures for Noises That Nag
text: STICKY Ford and General Motors ignition keys and trouble with Infiniti air-bag connectors are among the maladies listed in recent technical service bulletins.

headline: What We’re Reading…
text: 1) How your religious identity affects your economic behavior.

headline: Inaction Brings State to Brink of Cash Crisis
text: New York State is running out of cash.

headline: When ‘Black Friday’ Comes
text: Don’t know how you’re spending your Black Friday – and we’re not talking about the stock market – but we’re heeding the advice of Steely Dan: we’ve dug ourselves a hole and are about to spend the day lying in it.

headline: Graphic Books Best-Seller List
text: “Green Lantern: Agent Orange,” written by Geoff Johns and illustrated by Philip Tan, is the top-ranking new hardcover on our list this week. It arrives at No. 2 and tells the story of Agent Orange, the latest light-based warrior to encounter Green Lantern. The story can be enjoyed on its own merits, but it also serves as a tie in to “Blackest Night,” the latest event mini-series from DC Comics, in which many of its long dead superheroes mysteriously (and unpleasantly) rise from the dead. Though some comic-book fans say they are coming down with “event fatigue,” that eight-issue mini-series, also written by Mr. Johns, is proving popular. The first issue, which went on sale in July, sold over 175,000 copies. It’s also proving to be the gift the keeps giving: other titles connected to the storyline have also received a boost in sales.

headline: Deficits: the causes matter
text: Jim Hamilton has a post challenging my optimistic view about current deficits. I won’t go through it in detail, except to notice that Jim seems to be slightly rewriting history about his earlier analysis, which I critiqued back in August. What was then a seeming demonstration of the impossibility of servicing the debt — but in fact demonstrated no such thing — has now become just an effort to “personalize” the issue. OK, I guess.

headline: ‘I Think the Death Panels Are Back’
text: Your Jokes | Use the comment link below:

headline: Jackman, Craig Unload Their Garments for Charity
text: How much would you pay for two sweaty vests that have been worn out by weeks of use in a Broadway play? Wait, don’t answer yet: How much would you pay if those two sweaty vests had been worn for weeks by Daniel Craig and Hugh Jackman, the stars of “A Steady Rain”? Audiences got their answer on Wednesday when Mr. Craig and Mr. Jackman sold their apparel (and any lingering pheromones they might contain) at a post-performance auction at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. BBC News reported that the vests were sold for $3,500 each; originally only one vest was going to made available, until a female audience member shouted at Mr. Jackman, “How much for the pants?” (Mr. Jackman offered up a second vest instead of his trousers.) The clothing and other items, including autographed posters and programs, were sold to raise money for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

headline: Seeking the Best Medical Care Prices
text: CAN you really shop for doctors and hospitals the way you would for airfares and flat-screen TVs?

headline: Israeli Military Says Air Force Thwarted a Gaza Rocket Attack
text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military said the air force attacked a group of Palestinian militants in northern Gaza early Friday as they were about to fire rockets at Israel, a week after the Hamas rulers of Gaza announced that they had secured the agreement of other groups to halt rocket fire in order to prevent retaliatory attacks.

headline: Short Film Wins Huge Audience on Giant Screen
text: As a student filmmaker, Fred Guerrier usually sees what he does through the camera’s tiny viewfinder or the editor’s smallish screen — or on YouTube. But for the last couple of weeks, a short film he made has been showing on a screen bigger than the ones in most movie theaters.

headline: The BMW Sauber Move
text: The announcement today that BMW has decided to sell the team back to Peter Sauber is good news for anyone concerned about the direction the buying of new teams may be going in F1. It’s also reassuring to see a car manufacturer behaving a little more responsibly than we have begun to expect. BMW has dropped the deal with the previous somewhat shady buyer, and has decided to accept a sale of the team back to Peter Sauber, the original owner.

headline: Weekend Competition: Novel Eponyms
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to devise new eponyms – words named after people.

headline: Bargain Shopping for Medical Care
text: Recently, while scheduling a doctor’s visit for my daughter, the receptionist asked for a credit card to secure the appointment. The specialist didn’t take insurance, charged $600 a visit and would charge my credit card if I canceled with less than 48 hours notice.

headline: When the Air Must Be Spared: Fireplaces as Art Installations
text: Gathering around a warm hearth did not happen in many Bay Area homes on Thanksgiving Day, due to a Spare the Air warning that banned wood burning both inside and outside the home. The ban applied to the 1.4 million fireplaces and wood burning devices in the Bay Area; violators risked receiving a warning (for first-time offenders) and a fine of up to $400 for subsequent violations.

headline: Alice Munro’s Object Lessons
text: The Germans must have a term for it. Doppel­gedanken, perhaps: the sensation, when reading, that your own mind is giving birth to the words as they appear on the page. Such is the ego that in these rare instances you wonder, “How could the author have known what I was thinking?” Of course, what has happened isn’t this at all, though it’s no less astonishing. Rather, you’ve been drawn so deftly into another world that you’re breathing with someone else’s rhythms, seeing someone else’s visions as your own.

headline: More Adam Lambert Fallout
text: When CBS had Adam Lambert as a guest on its “Early Show” Wednesday morning, it may have believed it would placate viewers who were upset when Mr. Lambert had his invitation withdrawn by ABC’s “Good Morning America.” Instead, the booking has led to further complaints from those who say Mr. Lambert has been subjected to a double standard.

headline: The Holiday Shopping Crush
text: Bargain-hunters amassed outside stores with dreams of discounts -- and electronic pets -- in their heads.

headline: A Climate Scientist Who Engages Skeptics
text: A climate scientist offers advice on how to assess and engage climate skeptics.

headline: Iranians Defend Freezing of Assets of Nobel Laureate
text: TORONTO  Iran denounced charges by the Norwegian government that it had illegally confiscated a Nobel Peace Prize winner’s medal and frozen her bank account, the IRNA news agency reported Friday.

headline: Would G.M.O. Apples by Another Name Taste Sweeter?
text: Consumers might be more willing to bite into genetically modified apples if they were labeled differently, according to research published this month in The Journal of Food Distribution Research.

headline: Special Op: A Postwar Tale Retold
text: THE director Jim Sheridan approached his new film, “Brothers,” with a Hippocratic attitude: “Do no harm,” he said with a laugh. “Like a doctor, you know?” Fitting enough, since he was delivering a twin.

headline: Celebrating Id al-Adha
text: This holiday weekend Afghans and Iraqis — like millions of Muslims around the world — will be celebrating Id al-Adha.

headline: The Reading Life: Out of Louisville, a Letterpress Magazine
text: The Louisville-based literary magazine The Lumberyard, the most physically beautiful new journal I’ve seen this year, is a brother-and-sister operation. It’s the product of Jen and Eric Woods, collaborators who describe themselves on the magazine’s Web site as rural kids —– their father was a carpenter — who grew up “climbing the rafters and rolling in the sawdust of a lumber supply shed in the 1970s.”

headline: Voluptuary Stuck in a Box
text: IT’S odd and amusing  in a dry, British sort of way  that James Whale, the best director of Hollywood horror movies in the 1930s, was born and raised in a Midlands mining district known as the Black Country. (Would romantic comedy have been his destiny if he’d grown up in, say, Mayfair?) But everything about his life and career was  as a man of the theater, like Whale himself, might say  passing strange. Between 1930 and 1941 he directed 20 feature films, including the hit spooky-movie classics “Frankenstein” (1931), “The Invisible Man” (1933), and “Bride of Frankenstein” (1935); a lone musical, “Show Boat” (1936); and the period swashbuckler “The Man in the Iron Mask” (1939). And then he quit.

headline: Reverse Mortgages for Co-op Owners
text: Q.

headline: Ferrari’s Unusual Recall
text: Last week, Ferrari issued a recall on about 2,400 1995–99 355 and 355F1s in the United States. The reason? A nonfactory mechanic improperly installed “certain screw clamps that are located in close proximity to the fuel lines and that fasten the water sleeve to the thermostat connection.”

headline: A Restriction on Front-Door Keys
text: Q.

headline: Imposing Limits on Co-op Sublets
text: Q.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: RAYMOND CARVER: A Writer’s Life,  by Carol Sklenicka (Scribner, $35.) Sklenicka’s biography is invaluable as a chronicle of Carver’s growth as a writer, particularly in its account of his difficult, ultimately poisonous relationship with the editor Gordon Lish.

headline: Who’s Playing the Super Bowl? Yes.
text: To you football fans who were hoping that Super Bowl XLIV would be headlined by Lady Gaga: better luck in 2011. The National Football League announced that The Who, the long-lived British rock act led by Roger Daltrey and Pete Townshend, will perform at the halftime show, that annual occasion for bathroom breaks and (hopefully) not ripping off anyone’s clothes. The Who’s booking had been reported on Sports Illustrated’s Extra Mustard blog, but the N.F.L. did not officially confirm it until Thursday, during a game between the Oakland Raiders and the Dallas Cowboys. Super Bowl XLIV is scheduled for Feb. 7 in suburban Miami; previous halftime performers have included Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, and Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, though the only ones you probably remember are Janet Jackson and Justin Timberlake.

headline: H. Henry Elghanayan
text: Mr. Elghanayan, 69, is the chief executive of the Rockrose Development Corporation, which he ran, until recently, with his younger brothers, K. Thomas and Frederick. The company’s assets were split among the three, with Henry receiving several apartment buildings and development sites. He also kept the Rockrose name.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE ASCENT OF MONEY: A Financial History of the World,  by Niall Ferguson (Penguin, $16.) “Behind each great historical phenomenon there lies a financial secret,” Ferguson writes. “It was Nathan Rothschild as much as the Duke of Wellington who defeated Napoleon at Waterloo” by selling bonds for the British Army, and Continental bankers’ unwillingness to invest in Confederate cotton that assured the South’s Civil War defeat. “The ascent of money has been essential to the ascent of man,” Ferguson says in this tour of the under­side of great events, and he worries that American financial overreach and the global crisis may represent a “ ‘great dying’ in the financial world — one of those mass extinctions of species.”

headline: Nutty Professor in Prime Time
text: The Jerry Lewis Show

headline: Working With Andy the Auteur
text: “WARHOL and I were very uncomfortable together,” the playwright, novelist, screenwriter and professional wit Ronald Tavel said of Andy Warhol, who often seemed uncomfortable with everyone. “I never knew what to say to him, and he never knew what to say to me. In fact we almost never said anything.” Whether this discomfort was real, the words he wrote for Warhol films  hilarious, abrupt, lewd, illogical, artlessly artful words  contributed to a sense of unease that even now makes the films seem radical, even a bit dangerous.

headline: Google’s Earth
text: I’m fond of Google, I have to say. I like Larry Page, who seems, at least in the YouTube videos I’ve watched, shy and smart, with salt-and-pepper bangs; and Sergey Brin, who seems less shy and jokier and also smart. Ken Auletta, the author of this absorbing, shaggy, name-droppy book, doesn’t seem to like either of them much — he says that Page has a “Kermit the Frog” voice, which isn’t nice, while Brin comes off as a swaggering, efficiency-obsessed overachiever who, at Stanford, aced tests, picked locks, “borrowed” computer equipment from the loading dock and once renumbered all the rooms in the computer science building. “Google’s leaders are not cold businessmen; they are cold engineers,” Auletta writes — but “cold” seems oddly wrong. Auletta’s own chilliness may be traceable in part to Brin’s and Page’s reluctance to be interviewed. “After months of my kicking at the door, they opened it,” he writes in the acknowledgments. “Google’s founders and many of its executives share a zeal to digitize books,” he observes, “but don’t have much interest in reading them.”

headline: Up Front: Nicholson Baker
text: “Surely no other software company has built a cluster of products that are anywhere near as cleverly engineered, as quick-loading and as fun to fiddle with as Google has, all for free,” Nicholson Baker writes in his review of Ken Auletta’s “Googled.”

headline: Please Mr. Postman
text: Sometimes you write an elegy without meaning to. In the early 1990s, when Thomas Mallon began his book on people and their letters, you were marveling at your spiffy new dial-up modem, if you so much as knew what one was. His fine meditation on the art of ­letter-writing — he intended it as a companion to “A Book of One’s Own,” his study of people and their diaries — naturally reads differently today: The very physics of our universe, Mallon notes, have fundamentally altered. Time and distance are no longer what they once were. With them have gone, to varying degrees, privacy, eccentricity, suspense, your local stationer and, very nearly, the United States Postal Service. Intimacy has yielded to oversharing.

headline: Judge O.K.’s Some Parts of S.F. Bike Plan
text: In a ruling (PDF) issued on Wednesday, California Superior Court Judge Peter Busch gave San Francisco the go-ahead to proceed with several aspects of the city’s proposed bike plan to make its streets more hospitable to bicyclists.

headline: Chile Saved From World Cup Expulsion
text: Chile has saved its spot in the 2010 World Cup in South Africa after a domestic relegation dispute threatened FIFA action.

headline: Friday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Domestic Dysfunction
text: Every family is charged with small acts of brutality. One child will flail about with scissors, another must bite or shove, and there’s always the pulling of hair or the tearing of skin. Someone will decide to experiment with matches or lock the door of a dark closet and abandon the sister cowering inside. A grown-up might pretend to be a lion and roar so hard that a child wets himself in panic. Banal but terrifying things happen. Then we forget them. Somehow, though, they don’t forget us. Memories lie buried, yet remain forceful enough to shape our lives. In its infinite dimensions, this is the subject Penelope Lively, the British author of more than two dozen children’s books and numerous adult novels, has explored throughout her long and impressive career. In her haunting new novel, “Family Album,” the act of forgetting is as strange and interesting as the power of remembering.

headline: When Detroit Never Slept
text: One of the challenges inherent in writing about Detroit, especially its past, is that the overwhelming nostalgia for everything — the once ­bustling downtown, shopping at Hudson’s, streetcars, corner drugstores, work — can overwhelm the narrative. Imagine Pliny the Younger writing about post-Vesuvius Pompeii without occasionally veering into the realm of the sentimental. It can’t be done.

headline: Accessorized With Stroller and Rake
text: JULIE SIMONSON, a research pharmacist whose flat accent reveals her Chicago-area roots, grew up in a forest. Her childhood home was surrounded as far as the eye could see by towering deciduous trees whose names and characteristics she knew so well that she could identify virtually every one by its leaf.

headline: A College’s Effort to Fight Obesity: One Student’s View
text: This morning’s post on Lincoln University’s fitness requirement, one linked to a student’s body mass index, has drawn more than 40 comments. Some readers are outraged by what they see as a discriminatory policy; others are heartened by the university’s efforts to promote healthy habits.

headline: Couple’s Retreat
text: Like the great British wits her writing recalls, Jane Gardam has a talent for picking names. “The Man in the Wooden Hat” features the fastidious Sir Edward Feathers, an expatriate judge known as Filth (for “failed in London, try Hong Kong”); a striver called Terry Veneering (whose last name is borrowed from Dickens); a Chinese dwarf, Albert Ross, known suggestively as Albatross; and Betty Feathers, née Elisabeth ­Macintosh. To those who know her later in life, she’s as sturdy and dependable as a raincoat, the perfect judge’s wife. But Macintosh turns out to be as deceptive a descriptor of Betty as Filth is of the spotless Feathers. Underneath that impervious surface is a woman cut from unusual cloth.

headline: Arts & Leisure Preview: James Spader, ‘Up in the Air,’ Ray Romano and More
text: Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)“I’m most drawn to characters who are compelling and repellent at the same time, very often right at the same moment, and who are frightening and funny all at once. Mamet writes these characters better than anyone.”—James Spader explains what attracts him to his roles, including the character he portrays in the new David Mamet play “Race”

headline: One Foot in the Past
text: Inwood, the northernmost neighborhood in Manhattan, is a place of hills and history. Inwood Hill Park, 196 acres of tree-filled landscape, dominates the scene, and traces of Lenape Indians and Dutch settlers abound. But there are relative newcomers, too, including opera singers and others who are attracted to Inwood’s growing arts community. One artist who lives there — and grew up there — is Lin-Manuel Miranda, the Grammy- and Tony-winning creator of the Broadway musical “In the Heights.” The expedition begins at the 207th Street station, the terminus of the A train.

headline: Improv Tonight
text: According to the actor and director Betty Thomas — one of two women who were members of Chicago’s Second City comedy troupe in 1973 — if nature called in the midst of the group’s manic brainstorming, she had no qualms about leaving the restroom door open while she answered. “You don’t want to miss a single thing!” she says. “You have to be able to shout out!”

headline: A New Nation
text: In the aftermath of the American Revolution, no question haunted the founders more than whether the young, precarious United States could survive. Would the country last in perpetuity? Or was it fated to be a bold experiment in republicanism that would ignominiously fail?

headline: One Moment in Time
text: The images that make it into our long-term collective memory are few. One that has escaped the maws of oblivion, though, dates from the athletic circus that was the 1968 Summer Olympics. I am, of course, referring to the photos of Tommie Smith and John Carlos standing shoeless at a medal ceremony. On Oct. 16, Smith won the gold and Carlos the bronze in the 200-meter race. There they stood on the podium, heads hanging almost humbly and gloved fists raised in a defiant black power salute. “Something in the Air,” Richard Hoffer’s skillfully told tale of the Mexico City Olympics, revolves around this arresting image.

headline: More Museums Facing Strike in France
text: PARIS – France’s major tourist attractions, including the Louvre, the Musée d’Orsay, the Cathedral of Notre-Dame and Versailles, could be shut down next week because of a strike over planned job cuts, the General Confederation of Labor union warned on Friday.

headline: Helicopter Service to Airports Faces Uncertain Future
text: Scheduled helicopter service between Manhattan and local airports will not resume before early next year — if ever.

headline: Report Outlines Best Practices for Connecting Renewables to the Grid
text: A new report on state renewable energy regulations gives California, Colorado, New Jersey and Oregon top marks and failing grades for Georgia, Idaho and Texas.

headline: A Home Among Trees
text: Julie Simonson, her husband, Jesse Nover, and their year-old daughter, Maya, live in Sunnyside Gardens, Queens, surrounded by considerably more in the way of trees and other greenery than many New York dwellings.

headline: Beyond the Absurd
text: Images from the retrospective of Andy Warhol and Ronald Tavel's films.

headline: The Story of a Landing
text: Few words are more overworked than “hero,” but try avoiding it when talking about US Airways Flight 1549 and its dominant figure, Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III. By now you surely know the highlights of what instantly came to be called the miracle on the Hudson: How on Jan. 15, 2009, Sullenberger’s plane, bound for Charlotte, N.C., smacked into a flock of Canada geese less than two minutes after taking off from La Guardia Airport. How both its engines conked out. How Sullenberger, with mere seconds available to make a decision and act on it, glided the plane to a flawless landing on the river. How all 155 on board got out alive.

headline: Spin of Wheel May Determine Judge in 9/11 Case
text: At first glance, the wooden wheel looks as if it might have been used to call out bingo numbers in a church fund-raiser. But sometime soon, a federal magistrate judge in Manhattan could be spinning the wheel in open court, unlocking a small door on one of its sides, and pulling out a sealed envelope containing the name of a judge.

headline: Justice Department Says Acorn Can Be Paid for Pre-Ban Contracts

headline: She Who Must Be Obeyed
text: There is a bull market these days in Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek (1887-1975) and his wife, Soong Mei-ling (1897-2003), usually called Madame Chiang Kai-shek. When I was studying in Taiwan in the late 1950s, then-President Chiang was regarded by most of the Western students on the island — and many of the Chinese as well — as the remote, cruel man who lost China; his wife was the austere, once-glamorous Dragon Lady who had helped him lose it. Although Chiang alone, or both Chiangs, had appeared numerous times on the cover of Time magazine, those illustrious days seemed over. But now that Jay Taylor has written his comprehensive book “The Generalissimo: Chiang Kai-shek and the Struggle for Modern China,” we are able to see Chiang as a man of considerable cunning, brutality and patience who skillfully played a weak hand against the Japanese and Mao’s forces while extracting huge sums from the Americans. Similarly, in her latest biography, “The Last Empress,” Hannah Pakula presents Madame Chiang as far more complex, awful and brilliant than we had imagined.

headline: You Be the Judge
text: Not long ago, at a reception in Washington, I found myself talking to a prominent conservative commentator who was spitting mad because, he said, the Obama administration had blatantly, possibly criminally, favored unions over bondholders when dictating bailout terms to the automotive industry. Just the kind of lawless cronyism that had given liberalism a bad name!

headline: Battling the Skeptics
text: The optimistic view of science is that the theories advanced with its methods will have self-evident appeal to an educated public. Why, then, do people so often behave unscientifically? A sitting congressman claims he’s seen a U.F.O.; a former Playboy model insists, against overwhelming evidence, that childhood vaccines cause autism; Las Vegas vacationers expect to beat the casinos; former British Prime Minister Tony Blair treats his children with homeopathic remedies.

headline: Mr. Pamuk’s Neighborhood
text: Most tourist trips to Istanbul center on Sultanahmet, the neighborhood of the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace. Although visitors may imagine a magical age of sex slaves and tulips, Sultanahmet often feels like a modern Ottoman theme park: Turkish hustlers screaming in precise English, enormous buses disgorging tourists in red fezzes. But Sultanahmet is a center of the city’s religious life and home to many of its most observant citizens. During Ramadan, it is the site of a vast public picnic, where hundreds of Turks break the fast every night. This year I saw conservative ladies sitting cross-legged on the grass with pizza boxes, and ­nonreligious people munching cheap kebabs and humming to live Turkish bands. It felt so much like an American county fair, I half expected to see face-painting booths. Then I saw a girl with her face painted, a guy selling cotton candy and teenagers who’d clearly used the holiday as an excuse to go on a triple date.

headline: Inside the List
text: SECRET SANTA: Planning on stimulating the literary economy this holiday season but at a loss for ideas? We asked a few best-selling novelists what books they’ll be giving as gifts this year. Kathryn Stockett replied: “David Benioff’s ‘City of Thieves’ is the book I have been raving about to everyone. It is a brilliant killer adventure.” Michael Connelly is going to be wrapping up Joseph Wambaugh’s “Hollywood Moon,” “the last and best entry in his fabulous Hollywood Station trilogy.” Patricia Cornwell is bullish on Bruce Lipton’s “Biology of Belief,” a favorite of her heroine Kay Scarpetta. It’s “a fascinating and inspiring look at the connection between science and spiritual principles, reminding us of the enormous power we have to change ourselves and the world,” Cornwell said.

headline: Pilots Were ‘Distracted,’ Transcripts Show
text: WASHINGTON  After radio contact was finally re-established with the Northwest Airlines plane that flew 150 miles past its destination last month, a controller twice asked the pilots why they had stopped answering radio calls, according to transcripts and audio files released Friday by the Federal Aviation Administration.

headline: Feeling for … C’H’C’M’
text: This past Sunday I stopped by the Pop-Up Flea, a temporary men’s-wear-centric collection of clothing and accessories stands curated by the guys at the blog A Continuous Lean. The vibe was decidedly vintage Americana, with temporary “stores” by brands like Gitman Brothers, Jack Spade, Rogues Gallery, Schott, J. Crew, Bill Amberg and Alexander Olch. The wares were cool and the shoppers even cooler: off the charts in hip per square inch. Tucked away in a corner among all the old favorites was a booth whose name I didn’t recognize. I went in for a closer look after spotting some camel toggle coats from Gloverall and heavy knit cardigans from the obscure Danish seafaring knitting company SNS Herning. The stand belonged to a brand new online-only men’s-wear shop called C’H’C’M’, which stands for Clinton Hill Classic Menswear. It was started in March 2009 by Sweetu Patel, a former furniture designer whose selection is skewed heavily toward classic brands like Borsalino, Saint James, Mackintosh and Drakes, as well as other finds like Northern Waters, a Canadian-based knitwear company, and Individualized Shirts. Look for a pop-up shop of its own in January at Audiovisual Arts on First Street in the East Village, where it will break out new spring merchandise. Kick off your shoes because I’m feeling for online shopping at C’H’C’M’.

headline: Asked and Answered | Annie
text: For loyal fans of the Norwegian pop star Annie, it’s been a long four years since the electro-songstress won critical acclaim and achieved cult status with her debut album, “Anniemal.” But the dry spell is over: Annie is back with “Don’t Stop,” a record that manages to move her into more musically complicated territory while still keeping her firmly planted on the dance floor. As she juggled D.J. gigs and rehearsals for her spring tour (“Maybe in March or April,” she says. “I’m not sure if I’m starting in Europe or the U.S., but I’m definitely coming back to the U.S. for some shows”), The Moment sat down with the Scandinavian chanteuse to talk about inspirations in and out of the studio.

headline: Bloomberg Spent $102 Million to Win 3rd Term

headline: The Sunday Preview
text: In summer, the Grand Canyon is the Disney World of national parks, with crowds and traffic jams. But as Henry Shukman discovers in this week’s cover story, it’s a different word in the winter, a peaceful retreat with a small smattering of visitors hiking down to the canyon floor to spend the night in a rustic lodge. It’s a place where the ranch bell rings for dinner and where guests while away the evening playing card games, swapping life stories and congratulating themselves for being here in December and not July.

headline: Stage Performance in Search of a Miracle
text: It would be nice, in this holiday season, to report a miracle on Main Street in Northport, where a musical version of “Miracle on 34th Street” is playing at the John W. Engeman Theater. A talented cast under the considered direction of Erick Devine almost pulls off the wondrous task of making a silk purse out of a sow’s ear  or, in this case, a tin ear. But Douglas M. Smith’s tuneless music and Vernon L. Stefanic’s meandering book and flat lyrics prove difficult to transcend.

headline: Divergent Styles and Inspirations of Coastal Art Colonies
text: The art colonies of New England played a valuable role in fostering Modernism in American art in the early 20th century. But they also contributed to the creation and promotion of a sense of regional identity, the subject of “Call of the Coast: Art Colonies of New England,” a delightful exhibition at the Florence Griswold Museum developed in collaboration with the Portland Museum of Art in Maine.

headline: Romeo and a Boy Named Juliet
text: You have to buy in. Whether you’re watching a singing nun in prewar Austria or a mad old king on a stormy heath, theater depends on your buying into what the actors onstage are telling you. And experienced playgoers know how little it takes  the old definition of theater as “two planks and a passion” still applies.

headline: Keys, Wallet, Phone... Where’s My Phone?
text: Deep underground, in locked, windowless chambers below 34th Street, hundreds of cellphones are waiting. Dozens of pairs of eyeglasses, 20 or so musical instruments, a half dozen bicycles and a four-foot-long space heater. They tumbled out of your bag as you fought your way off a crowded bus or got left behind as you leapt for the subway doors. And now they’re sitting on a shelf in the M.T.A.’s Lost Property Unit, waiting for you to redeem them, reunite with them, set them free.

headline: Leora Skolnik, Yonatan Warren
text: Leora Sabena Skolnik, a daughter of Robin Segal Skolnik and Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik of Forest Hills, Queens, is to be married Sunday to Yonatan Moshe Warren, the son of Tova R. Warren and Jay C. Warren of Hampton, Va. The brideâ€™s father is to officiate and Rabbi Steven Lindemann is to take part in the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

headline: Marisa Levine, Douglas Regal
text: Marisa Faryn Levine and Douglas Simon Regal were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Seth M. Limmer at Bridgewaters in New York.

headline: Trish Ramirez, John Whitehill
text: Patricia Butler Ramirez and Sigmond John Whitehill were married Saturday evening at Rodef Shalom Congregation in Pittsburgh. Dr. Walter Jacob, who is the rabbi emeritus at the synagogue, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jenna Fein, Rusty Elinson
text: Jenna Lauren Fein, a daughter of Sheila Fein and Steven Fein of Agoura, Calif., was married Saturday evening to Rusty Kyle Elinson, the son of Patty K. Elinson and Leo Elinson of Manhattan Beach, Calif. Rabbi Mark A. Hyman officiated at the Casa Del Mar, a hotel in Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Melissa Dlin, Chris Mottola
text: Melissa Dlin and Chris Mottola were married Saturday by Ronald D. Castille, the chief justice of Pennsylvania, at the Ritz Carlton in Philadelphia.

headline: Anne Mazzeo, Nicholas Baldwin
text: Anne Letizia Mazzeo, a daughter of Carol Shaw Mazzeo and Joseph M. Mazzeo of Clarkston, Mich., was married Saturday to Nicholas Horatio Baldwin, the son of Roberta Plutzik Baldwin and Neil E. Baldwin of Glen Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Christopher Maus, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Daniel Catholic Church in Clarkston. Later in the evening, Rabbi Tamara Kolton led a symbolic ceremony that incorporated Jewish traditions at the Indianwood Golf and Country Club in Lake Orion, Mich.

headline: Lynn Brouwers, Mark Upfal
text: Lynn Brouwers and Dr. Mark Joe Upfal were married Friday evening at their home in Detroit. Rabbi Miriam S. Jerris officiated.

headline: Some Indians Find It Tough to Go Home Again
text: NEW DELHI  When 7-year-old Shiva Ayyadurai left Mumbai with his family nearly 40 years ago, he promised himself he would return to India someday to help his country.

headline: Alabama Rallies Late and Remains Unbeaten
text: AUBURN, Ala.  The machinery of college football  the polls, the projections and the politics surrounding the Bowl Championship Series  could not distract or unsettle No. 2 Alabama during the regular season. The Crimson Tide always seemed steady and poised, but that was before it ran up against the slot-machine offense of the Auburn Tigers, with its unpredictable misdirection.

headline: Got Zombies? You Need Your Friends
text: When someone starts talking about a sequel, the last thing you usually want to hear is “more of the same.” That is, unless your idea of a good time is mowing down thousands of preternaturally fast, agile and of course ravenous undead as you and three friends try to escape the zombie apocalypse.

headline: To Light the Nights
text: THE designer Jonathan Adler is known for bringing whimsy and exuberance to the interiors and objects he creates. But when it comes to decorating his home for the holidays, he takes a more minimalist approach. Because both he and his partner, Simon Doonan, the creative director of Barneys New York, “work in the world of stuff and holiday décor,” he said, they tend to express most of their seasonal creativity at the office.

headline: Classic Ad: 1969 Plymouths
text: This being Thanksgiving week, it might seem an appropriate time to post a vintage commercial for one of the auto industry’s fabled turkeys. But that would be too easy, and a cheap shot to boot.

headline: A Salsa Star Is Reborn After a Break for Politics
text: Rubén Blades has a very specific reason for calling his current tour “Todos Vuelven,” or “Everybody Returns.” After suspending his music and film career for five years to serve as a cabinet minister in Panama, his homeland, Mr. Blades is back, on the road and with a new album, testing the waters and trying to figure out whether the entertainment business still has a place for him.

headline: Long-Distance Romance
text: To the Editor:

headline: Vows: Boris & Lauren
text: Lauren met tall, boisterous Boris on the first day of her freshman year at Georgetown. The two quickly began dating and have been together ever since.

headline: When Trees Fall Next Door, Neighbors Make the Noise
text: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y.

headline: New Jersey Rules Differ
text: The town of Madison has rejected a proposed ordinance to protect trees on private property. But the adjacent town of Chatham has taken the opposite route.

headline: Few Rules for City Residents
text: Trees might seem especially rare and precious in New York, but unlike many suburbs, the city generally imposes no restrictions on its residents’ removal of them.

headline: A Westchester Patchwork
text: The regulations governing privately owned trees in Westchester County are a patchwork. The village of Mamaroneck has no such rules, for example, but the town of Mamaroneck does.

headline: City Critic | Lost in Transit
text: Deep in Penn Station, Ariel Kaminer seeks out New York City Transit's elusive Lost Property Unit, and finds it surprisingly organized and efficient.

headline: On L.I., Approaches Vary
text: In Nassau County, restrictions on the removal of trees on private land vary greatly by town. Some towns have no rules, some towns that do have rules take different approaches, and some towns are revising their rules.

headline: Efforts in Connecticut
text: Greenwich has no regulations on the removal of trees on private property, except for trees in or around wetlands, said Bruce Spaman, the town’s superintendent of parks and trees.

headline: Significant (Little) Moments Pulled From Obscurity
text: A glass of wine had just arrived when Colum McCann, who won the National Book Award for fiction last week with “Let the Great World Spin,” leaned forward with a story to tell.

headline: Montreal Grand Prix Is Back On for 2010
text: Automakers may be leaving Formula One, but Montreal wants to come back on board.

headline: Montreal Grand Prix Is Back On for 2010
text: From our colleagues at the Formula One blog:

headline: From 1994, a Prime Example of Knowing When to Duck
text: The Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams is the premier event at the Fall North American Championships taking place in San Diego. The 2008 winners were Nick Nickell, Richard Freeman, Bob Hamman, Zia Mahmood, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell. They will be defending the title, except that Ralph Katz will replace Freeman, who died in June.

headline: Shuttle Ends 11-Day Mission With a Perfect Landing
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The shuttle Atlantis glided to a flawless landing in Florida on Friday, wrapping up an 11-day space station delivery mission and bringing a flight engineer, Nicole P. Stott, back to Earth after 91 days in space.

headline: The Cheesecake Lightens Up
text: Stockbridge’s Gourmet Cheesecake carries 10 types of cheesecake at a time  and that’s only a quarter or so of its repertoire. Recent efforts included eggnog and pumpkin, but its New York style outsells all the others by two to one.

headline: Giving Us Their Daily Flatbread
text: Newark Avenue in the area of Jersey City known as Little India is crowded with confectioners’ shops, small groceries and clothing stores selling colorful saris. Here Paratha Junction, a sleek storefront restaurant that opened in May, is already popular for its classic yet modern take on the dense flatbread called paratha.

headline: Three Cheers for Cheese
text: Most grand openings involve a ribbon-cutting and dignitaries, but in early November at Dobbs & Bishop, a new cheesemonger in the village of Bronxville, not only was the mayor on hand with a pair of scissors, but so was a Guernsey cow named Annie (and an assortment of goats and sheep).

headline: In Search of Their Own Elixir of Love
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Mike D’Antoni Searches for a Winning Formula for the Knicks
text: MIKE D’ANTONI, the head coach of the New York Knicks, started a tradition this season: a catered dinner in a private room at Madison Square Garden, players and coaches only, a couple of hours before each game.

headline: Would My Heart Outrun Its Pursuer?
text: I AM near quadriplegic, a result of polio, and I cannot stand. I have limited strength in my arms, enough to function once I’m in my chair but not enough to get into or out of the chair.

headline: Las Vegas Wins U.F.L. Title
text: Did you even know there was a U.F.L. season?

headline: No Autographs. Just Initials, Please.
text: IN a city where stargazing is a ruthless sport, the prey are always in search of a hideout to escape prying eyes, a place to cavort with their own oh-so-fabulous kind. These days, that place is Simyone Lounge, or simply SL to those in the know.

headline: My Rich Stepdaughters
text: My husband’s ex-wife is extremely wealthy, and his daughters have recently come into multimillion-dollar trust funds. We, on the other hand, are struggling; my husband has been out of work since the economy fell apart. My stepdaughters visit regularly, in expensive clothes and accessories. I can’t help but resent that they will never have to work a day in their lives. And I fantasize about asking for financial help, but don’t want to seem like a beggar. What to do? Anonymous

headline: Hello, Collections? The Worm Has Turned
text: The phone rang. A woman from a law firm representing a collection agency wanted to know if Mark Hoyte was Mark Hoyte, and he said he was. They were calling to collect $919 on a Sears-Citi card.

headline: Forget Car Insurance, Does It Have Medicare?
text: MY son, Jordan, who is 9, desperately wanted a pet that might be more interactive than the fish in his aquarium. But I am severely allergic to most animals with fur. I am so asthmatic that, unlike the Obamas, who went with famously hypoallergenic Bo, our family wound up choosing something less huggable though no less lovable: a gecko.

headline: Easing Into the Day Where Night Life Reigns
text: When you serve breakfast in a neighborhood known more for late-night prowling than early rising, things start slowly some days. But Life Café, which opened in 1982, when Alphabet City was a drug-fueled frontier town all its own, has seen worse than slow mornings. A haven for vegans and baconistas alike, Life Café displays work by local artists and maintains an homage to “Rent”  a scene in the musical was set there  on a side wall. On Tuesday at the crack of 10 a.m., a bustling HBO film crew shot a scene for a planned series across the street, but the first two customers were tourists, followed, more than an hour later, by two locals.

text: Comedy

text: Comedy

headline: Alomar Heads 2010 Hall of Fame Ballot
text: Roberto Alomar was a slick-fielding second baseman who was proud of the way he could beat teams with his bat, his glove and his legs. Alomar will soon learn if what he accomplished in a 17-year career will be enough to earn him election into the Baseball Hall of Fame on his first ballot.

headline: Happy Campers Command Stage in Macy’s Parade
text: Everything was fine with Macy’s Santa-sleigh float until the elves showed up.

headline: On NYTimes.com
text: In San Francisco, the ice cream wizard Jake Godby, of Humphry Slocombe, and offal-meister Chris Cosentino, of the restaurant Incanto and the salumeria Boccalone, have pooled their talents to create lard caramels.
