headline: Salaries Cut for 2 Bank of America Executives
text: Bank of America said its chief financial officer, Joe L. Price, and head of mortgages, Barbara J. Desoer, would receive less in salary for 2009, citing a review by the government’s special master for compensation, Kenneth R. Feinberg. Mr. Price and Ms. Desoer had their annual salaries set at $500,000, the company said in a regulatory filing. The two executives also received “stock unit awards” valued at $5.25 million for Mr. Price and $3.95 million for Ms. Desoer. The bank’s March 18 proxy statement said their 2008 salaries were $800,000.

headline: Peru Signs Free Trade Deal With European Countries
text: Peru formally concluded a joint free trade agreement with Switzerland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Iceland, the trade and tourism minister, Martin Perez, said Friday. The four countries make up the European Free Trade Agreement trading bloc. Peruvian exports to the block were worth $3.4 billion last year, Mr. Perez said in a statement. Imports from the bloc totaled $1.3 billion. In the first nine months of the year, Peruvian exports to those countries rose by 18 percent, compared with the same period last year, Mr. Perez said. Sectors that will benefit the most from the new agreement are fishing and industry, Mr. Perez said.

headline: Evangelical, and Young, and Active in New Area
text: WHEATON, Ill.

headline: Madonna’s Man-tourage
text: Madonna’s love interests have always attracted media attention, but not all of it wanted.

headline: In Matchup of Top Coaches, Duke Easily Handles UConn
text: Mike Krzyzewski and Jim Calhoun, the elder statesmen of college basketball coaches, stood together, smiling on the court Friday evening before they stood apart, scowling on the sidelines.

headline: For Grace in Motion, Look to the Canvas
text: Frederick Wiseman’s new documentary film “La Danse” has been widely praised by movie critics as one of the finest dance films ever made. A. O. Scott was absolutely right in these pages when he said that “its greater virtue, and the substance of Mr. Wiseman’s particular genius, is the way it transfixes you with the inner workings of an institution you may not otherwise care about.”

headline: For Madonna’s Boyfriend, Fame by Association
text: THROUGH the penthouse windows, New York City, foggy and soft-looking, was spread out in every direction. Jesus Luz, best known as the 22-year-old Brazilian model who is dating Madonna, was about to step up to the D.J. station in a club atop a Lower East Side hotel.

headline: CBS Is Criticized for Blurring of Video
text: An appearance by the singer Adam Lambert, below, on “The Early Show,” the CBS morning program, on Wednesday has led to further complaints from those who say Mr. Lambert has been subjected to a double standard. At issue is a video package that was used to introduce the interview with Mr. Lambert, the “American Idol” finalist who gave a sexually charged performance at the American Music Awards on Sunday. When CBS rebroadcast a clip from that show, it blurred a scene of Mr. Lambert kissing his male keyboardist. But it did not blur a scene of Madonna and Britney Spears kissing at the 2003 MTV Video Music Awards. In a statement, Jarrett Barrios, the president of the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, said, “I would have hoped CBS would provide the same treatment for images of gay and lesbian people and not create an unfair double standard that treats our community differently.” A representative for CBS told the entertainment program “Extra” that the image of Madonna kissing Ms. Spears “is very familiar and has appeared countless times including many times on morning television.” He added, “The Adam Lambert image is a subject of great current controversy, has not been nearly as widely disseminated, and for all we know, may still lead to legal consequences.”

headline: Jackman and Craig Offer Charity Items
text: How much would you pay for two sweaty vests that have been worn out by use in a Broadway play? Wait, don’t answer yet: How much would you pay if those two sweaty vests had been worn by Hugh Jackman, above left, and  Daniel Craig, above right, the stars of “A Steady Rain”? The answer came on Wednesday when Mr. Craig and Mr. Jackman sold their apparel (and any lingering pheromones those items might contain) at a post-performance auction at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater. BBC News reported that the vests were sold for $3,500 each; originally only one vest was going to be made available, until a female audience member shouted at Mr. Jackman, “How much for the pants?” (Mr. Jackman offered a second vest instead of his trousers.) The clothing and other items, including autographed posters and programs, were sold to raise money for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

headline: More Museums Facing Possible Strike in France
text: France’s major tourist attractions, including the Louvre, the Musée d’Orsay, the Cathedral of Notre-Dame, in the background at right, and Versailles, could be shut down next week because of a strike over planned job cuts, the Confédération Générale du Travail union warned on Friday. “We think awareness is growing in all the major public institutions,” said Franck Guillaumet, who heads the culture section of the union, France’s second largest. “This includes the Louvre, the Musée d’Orsay, the palace of Versailles, the Arc de Triomphe and Notre Dame church.” The Confédération Générale du Travail and seven other unions sent a letter to the Culture Ministry on Thursday evening, warning that they would go on strike on Wednesday if the government pursued its plan to reduce the budget deficit by replacing only one out of every two retiring civil servants. The announcement came after a strike that kept the Georges Pompidou Center closed for a fifth day on Friday. Workers at that museum are protesting the government’s plan to cut more than 400 jobs there over the next 10 years. More than 40 percent of the workers at the Pompidou Center are older than 50, and the legal retirement age in France is 70.

headline: Polanski Will Not Be Released Before Monday
text: A spokesman for Switzerland’s Justice Ministry said the director Roman Polanski would not be released from a prison near Zurich until at least Monday because the conditions of his bail had not yet been met, Agence France-Presse reported. Under the terms of a bail agreement that was accepted by the Swiss Federal Criminal Court on Wednesday, Mr. Polanski, 76, must post $4.5 million, surrender his identity papers and be fitted with a monitoring bracelet. (He will spend his house arrest in his chalet in the Swiss resort town of Gstaad.) The justice ministry spokesman, Folco Galli, told Agence France-Presse that the authorities had not yet received Mr. Polanski’s bond, and that his transfer from a prison in Winterthur, northeast of Zurich, would not happen on Friday or over the weekend. Mr. Polanski is awaiting possible extradition to the United States, which he fled in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl.

headline: Thanksgiving Parade Draws Viewers for NBC
text: NBC’s morning broadcast of the “Macy’s Thanksgiving Parade” delivered the highest ratings for that program in three years, according to preliminary overnight figures. Although Nielsen’s final audience figures were unavailable on Friday, NBC estimated that more than 45 million viewers tuned in for at least some portion of the broadcast. In prime time a new installment of CBS’s “Survivor: Samoa” earned the night’s largest audience with 10 million viewers. Fox was second with the 2006 movie “Night at the Museum” (6.6 million). ABC ranked third with “A Charlie Brown Thanksgiving” (6.4 million), followed by specials featuring performances by Beyoncé (5.1 million) and Paul McCartney (4.7 million). NBC was fourth with a repeat of “The Office” (2.8 million), followed by a news special, “People of the Year” (5.2 million) and “The Jay Leno Show”(5 million).

headline: Boos Cap a Bad Week for British Rapper
text: Nothing seems to have gone right for Speech Debelle, below, the British rapper, since she won pop music’s prestigious Mercury Prize in September. On Tuesday, BBC News reported, the hip-hop performer (whose real name is Corynne Elliot) said in a radio interview that she had quit the independent record label Big Dada after her Mercury Prize victory did not significantly increase sales for her debut album, “Speech Therapy.” “I wasn’t disappointed that it didn’t sell well,” she told the BBC. “I was disappointed in the people I was working with.” And on Thursday, BBC News reported, she was booed by audience members at a promotional event honoring the British boy band Take That, when she tried to perform that group’s love ballad “Pray” as a rap. In October, Speech Debelle canceled a planned United States tour, including appearances at the CMJ Music Marathon, because of visa problems.

headline: John Burns Q. and A. on Obama’s Options in Afghanistan
text: John Burns, the chief foreign correspondent for The New York Times, is answering questions about a New York Times primer on some possible force options available to President Obama as he considers bolstering the 68,000 American troops already in Afghanistan.

headline: Bloomberg Spent $102 Million to Win 3rd Term
text: To eke out an election victory over the city’s low-key comptroller, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent $102 million of his own fortune  or about $174 per vote  according to data released Friday, making his bid for a third term the most expensive campaign in the city’s history.

headline: At Odds Over Land, Money and Gas
text: CHENANGO, N.Y.  Chris and Robert Lacey own 80 acres of idyllic upstate New York countryside, a place where they can fish for bass in their own pond, hike through white pines and chase deer away.

headline: Some Help in a Transition and a Recovery From Eye Surgery
text: There are moments in the telling of his story, particularly when he tries to describe the excruciating pain he suffered as a result of eye surgery gone awry, that Raul Mejia must stop and gather himself before going on.

headline: From Shadow to Limelight for a Governor’s Wife
text: As the political standing of Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina continues to crumble, the career of his wife, Jenny Sanford, seems to be taking off.

headline: In New York, a Parking Gift on a Holiday
text: For many in New York City, the Friday after Thanksgiving is a day to digest turkey, jostle with shopping hordes  and curse the fresh parking tickets tucked beneath untold thousands of windshield wipers.

headline: Experts Say Swine Flu Mutations Do Not Warrant New Alarm
text: The World Health Organization tried this week to dampen fears about mutations seen in the swine flu virus in several countries, noting that both mutations had been found in very few people.

headline: China Jails Environmentalist Wanted in U.S.
text: DALI, China  Justin Franchi Solondz, an environmental activist from New Jersey who spent years evading charges of ecoterrorism in the United States by hiding out in China, was sentenced to three years in prison by a local court on Friday on charges of manufacturing drugs in this backpacker haven.

headline: On the Street | Thanksgiving Week
text: This year New Yorkers could show off their autumn finery before the weather called for coats.

headline: China’s Impolitic Artist, Still Waiting to Be Silenced
text: BEIJING

headline: Dubai Debt Woes Raise Fear of Wider Problem
text: Of the many economies that gorged on debt in the boom years, Dubai stood out. In the space of a few years the emirate’s investment arm, Dubai World, racked up $59 billion in debt, borrowing to build lavish developments like a giant island shaped like a palm tree to entice celebrities like Brad Pitt, and to invest in glittery properties like the MGM Grand Casino in Las Vegas.

headline: In a Home to Free Speech, a Paper Is Accused of Anti-Semitism
text: BERKELEY, Calif.  For the last six years, The Berkeley Daily Planet has published a freewheeling assortment of submissions from readers, who offer sharp-elbowed views on everything from raucous college parties (generally bad) to the war in Iraq (ditto).

headline: Serenity Prayer Skeptic Now Credits Niebuhr
text: A Yale librarian who cast doubt last year on the origins of the Serenity Prayer, adopted by Alcoholics Anonymous and reprinted on countless knickknacks, says new evidence has persuaded him to retain the famed Protestant theologian Reinhold Niebuhr as the author in the next edition of The Yale Book of Quotations.

headline: To Get Halladay, Mets Should Offer to Take Wells, Too
text: The Mets need many things this holiday season — a left fielder, a catcher, a healthy Jose Reyes and, perhaps most important, a really good starting pitcher to team up with Johan Santana and give the team some renewed credibility.

headline: Zimbabwe: Trial of Opposition Leader Suspended
text: As the High Court shut down Friday for the holiday season, the judge in the trial of Roy Bennett, a senior leader in the opposition Movement for Democratic Change who is facing terrorism charges, suspended proceedings until Jan. 12. Though both the prosecution and the defense were prepared to work during the vacation, the judge said he was not willing to do so after a key witness for the state did not show up in court, said Beatrice Mtetwa, Mr. Bennett’s lawyer.

headline: Championship Skiers, Bound as Rivals and Friends
text: ASPEN, Colo.  Lindsey Vonn talks about her friendship with Maria Riesch in simple terms.

headline: Bringing Big Band Jazz Back to the Theater District
text: There you are, texting away as you walk down West 46th Street in Midtown, and you nearly bump right into the big, bright gramophone on the sidewalk outside the Hotel Edison.

headline: Buying, Selling and Twittering All the Way
text: Once upon a time, people mailed their holiday wishes to the North Pole and hoped for a reply on Christmas Day. Nowadays they are sending their wishes into cyberspace and are apt to get a reply in minutes.

headline: 4 Killed at Dinner; Florida Police Seek Gunman
text: JUPITER, Fla.  The police and federal marshals fanned out across South Florida on Friday in the hunt for a man they said had left a Thanksgiving dinner crowded with relatives in this upscale beachfront community and returned with a handgun, opening fire and killing his twin sisters, an aunt and a 6-year-old cousin. Two other people were wounded.

headline: B.C.S. Just Ho-Hums Along
text: With Texas looking shaky in giving up 39 points to Texas A&M on Thursday night and Alabama looking mortal in a come-from-behind victory at Auburn on Friday, two thirds of college football’s so-called Big Three were threatened in a 24-hour span.

headline: For Some, a Search for Celebrity Is Worth Any Risk
text: In totalitarian regimes, some people take huge risks for the freedom to be themselves; in this democracy, some people take huge risks for the freedom to be someone else  a celebrity.

headline: A Day of Discounts, Even for Knockoffs
text: The best, or at least the most unbelievable, day-after-Thanksgiving deals in New York this year were not at Macy’s or Saks Fifth Avenue. There were a few little places on Canal Street  you may have heard of them  where $100 Swatch watches sold for $15, and so did the $15,000 Patek Philippe models.

headline: Fully Feather-Footed Flier
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — “Donkey, two things, O.K.? Shut … up!” Hey, I know that movie. In fact, I was able to get several answers first time through, which is unusual for a Karen Tracey puzzle. Pooh-Bah is from a delightful operetta. The libretto is worth reading even without the music. W.S. Gilbert was a genius. Topsy-Turvy is an entertaining film about the creation of 32 Down.

headline: Afghans Offer Jobs to Taliban Rank and File if They Defect
text: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  The American-backed campaign to persuade legions of Taliban gunmen to stop fighting got under way here recently, in an ornate palace filled with Afghan tribal leaders and one very large former warlord leading the way.

headline: Hale Smith, Who Broke Borders of Classical and Jazz, Is Dead at 84
text: Hale Smith, a classical composer who also worked as a performer and arranger with jazz greats like Dizzy Gillespie and Chico Hamilton, died Tuesday at his home in Freeport, L.I. He was 84.

headline: Region Finds U.S. Lacking on Honduras
text: WASHINGTON  Drug cartels are running amok in Mexico, Raúl Castro is tightening his grip on Cuba and Hugo Chávez of Venezuela is making mischief with Russia and Iran, but it is a relatively obscure backwater, Honduras, that has provided the Obama administration with its first test in Latin America.

headline: U.S.C.-U.C.L.A.: Rivalry Crosses Family Borders
text: LOS ANGELES  For years, recruiting trips to the University of Southern California included dinner at Papadakis Taverna, where, between the souvlaki, dancing waiters and the obligatory smashing of plates, prospective football players would be served an impassioned speech from the proprietor, John Papadakis, about how wonderful it was to be a Trojan.

headline: Jan Leighton, Actor Who Played Everyone, Dies at 87
text: Jan Leighton, an actor who conjured a career by dressing up as historical figures, appearing in so many commercials, print advertisements and industrial films as George Washington, William Shakespeare and Christopher Columbus that he was both ubiquitous and anonymous, died on Nov. 16 in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: At a Yankees Shop, Buzz; At a Mets Store, a Hush
text: It was a tale of two Black Fridays for New York’s baseball teams.

headline: Diplomacy 101
text: We were thrilled when President Obama decided to plunge fully into the Middle East peace effort. He appointed a skilled special envoy, George Mitchell, and demanded that Israel freeze settlements, Palestinians crack down on anti-Israel violence and Arab leaders demonstrate their readiness to reach out to Israel.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Hand That Moves the Masses
text: The international sign language for “stop” does not seem to mean much to Wall Streeters trying to charge across Vesey Street, the busiest pedestrian thoroughfare in all of New York City.

headline: Six Degrees of Climate Separation
text: Graphics wizards map all of the e-mail connections disclosed in the hacked climate files.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Nov. 27
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: A Strength of the Giants Is Slowed by Injuries
text: With big running backs and small ones, through perennial playoff appearances and a Super Bowl season, the Giants could trust one element of their game to lead them toward the top of the standings: running the ball.

headline: The Department of Lucrative Athletics
text: Cherry Hill, N.J.

headline: Who Has a Chance in the B.C.S.?
text: Both No. 3 Texas and No. 2 Alabama remained on track for a possible appearance in the Bowl Championship Series title game with uninspired victories this week.

headline: Hacked E-Mail Data Prompts Calls for Changes in Climate Research
text: Some prominent climate scientists are calling for changes in the way research on global warming is conducted after a British university said thousands of private e-mail messages and documents had been stolen from its climate center.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Letdown for Chicago, Recovery for San Jose
text: Twelve games on Friday night, including a record-setting performance for the Devils, a huge win for the Islanders and yet another frustrating loss for the Rangers. But perhaps the biggest eyebrow-raisers involved the Blackhawks and Sharks, fresh off a seemingly apocalyptic clash just two nights ago. Home teams listed first:

headline: Readers’ Photos: Burning, but Breathing
text: A Hunts Point sunset. A slender, wrinkled hand gently tugging at an overcoat. Fires and smoke. Kids dashing down the street. The boardwalk at Orchard Beach.

headline: Corrections
text: A photograph on Wednesday with an article about Senator John Kerry carried an incorrect credit. The photograph, of Mr. Kerry with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, was taken by Paula Bronstein of Getty Images, not Paul Bronstein.

headline: U.S. Is Said to Land Force in Nicaragua
text: Sunday, Nov. 28, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Corrections
text: An article on the Personal Tech pages on Thursday about digital tools to enhance the iPhone camera misstated the features of one such app, Best Camera. It has a variety of filters and special effects and a sharing feature; it does not have a full-screen shutter release, an antishake feature or a shutter timer.

headline: Housing Weighs on the Economy
text: All roads into and out of the recession run through the housing market. During the summer, that road seemed to be heading toward recovery. These days, it seems to be headed back toward hard times. A reversal would have big implications for the economy and, by extension, the policies now being pursued by the administration, Congress and the Federal Reserve.

headline: Even a Penny Helps
text: We doubt that too many New Yorkers were shocked to be told that the United Homeless Organization, which collects coins in those big blue jugs on card tables in mid-Manhattan, was not a humble charity using direct appeals by disadvantaged workers to aid and empower the poor, but something simpler: a scam. Sidewalk transactions in the city, like sidewalk wristwatches and handbags, usually look more legitimate than they are.

headline: When Prisoners Phone Home
text: New York State’s highest court has rejected the last vestiges of a lawsuit by families of inmates who claimed that the prison system overcharged them for telephone calls from their loved ones. The good news is that this suit  and an accompanying lobbying effort  has already succeeded in reforming a terribly unfair system.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column on Tuesday, about online series created specifically for certain advertisers, referred incorrectly to the profession of Candace Bushnell, who is involved in one such series. She is a writer, not an actor. The column also misspelled part of the name of a product that sponsors one such series. It is Marie Callender’s, not Callendar’s.

headline: Corrections
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Nov. 16 about plans by some members of the recently defunct band Oasis to form a new group included several errors. Liam Gallagher was the lead vocalist for Oasis, not guitarist and vocalist. Noel Gallagher, his brother, was the lead guitarist and main songwriter, not lead singer and songwriter. And while Colin Archer, known as Gem, did at times play keyboard, he was primarily the rhythm guitarist and sometimes played lead guitar.

headline: Corrections
text: A dance review on Nov. 9 about the Paul Taylor Dance Company’s premiere of the work “Brief Encounters,” at Syracuse University, misidentified the dancer who used a mirror in the “Serenade for the Doll” section. She was Amy Young, not Annmaria Mazzini.

text: NATIONAL

headline: Benchmarks in Wartime: As Reliable as Promises
text: BAGHDAD — Watching Iraq’s Parliament debate an election law last week, inside a conference center still decorated with mosaics of Saddam Hussein’s wartime delusions, ought to have been reassuring to those who wish the country’s nascent democracy well. It wasn’t.

headline: A Conflicted Celebration
text: Muslims in Afghanistan, Iraq and Pakistan find ways to celebrate Id al-Adha.

headline: In Support of Abortion, It’s Personal vs. Political
text: WASHINGTON — In the early 1950s, a coal miner’s daughter from rural Kentucky named Louise McIntosh encountered the shadowy world of illegal abortion. A friend was pregnant, with no prospects for marriage, and Ms. McIntosh was keeper of a secret that, if spilled, could have led to family disgrace. The turmoil ended quietly in a doctor’s office, and the friend went on to marry and have four children.

headline: Health Care Savings Could Start in the Cafeteria
text: Steven Burd isn’t a doctor or a medical specialist. But he sure can talk like one.

headline: Comment of the Week
text: We saw Robin in Syracuse this past week and laughed for two straight hours. We all have issues. To be able to give joy to other people is a gift. To utilize one’s own issues in order to bring joy to other people is the mother lode. I think we can all learn a little something when we see someone crash and burn, then arise from the ashes a better person.

headline: Yang Xianyi, Translator of Chinese Works, Dies at 94
text: Yang Xianyi, a translator renowned for his skill at rendering both classic and contemporary Chinese literature into English, died on Monday in Beijing. He was 94.

text: DENVER  As Carmelo Anthony transformed from pudgy prodigy to the refined basketball player with the body to showcase it, he shed his quest for a scoring trophy in favor of one for an N.B.A. title.

text: Firefighters found two men dead in a van that had caught fire in Brooklyn on Friday near the Gowanus Expressway.

headline: Afghans Detail Detention in ‘Black Jail’ at U.S. Base
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  An American military detention camp in Afghanistan is still holding inmates, sometimes for weeks at a time, without access to the International Committee of the Red Cross, according to human rights researchers and former detainees held at the site on the Bagram Air Base.

headline: Puns and Anagrams for the W = E
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Mel Taub is back with another PandA puzzle. If you’re not used to these cryptic-like conundrums, give this one a try. This is the favorite variety puzzle for many people.

headline: Growing, Yes, but India Has Reasons to Worry
text: PONDICHERRY, India — During President Obama’s recent visit to China, many in India speculated that an emerging “G2” would leave their nation out in the cold.

headline: Thoughts on Alabama’s Victory
text: AUBURN, Ala. — Some more thoughts on the Iron Bowl and Alabama’s 26-21 win over rival Auburn on Friday.

headline: Roethlisberger Out With Concussion Symptoms
text: Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger will miss Sunday night’s critical game against the Baltimore Ravens with symptoms from the concussion he sustained last week. Roethlisberger passed concussion tests early in the week, according to Coach Mike Tomlin, and he practiced Wednesday and Thursday. But he apparently started having headaches after the practices, and he took very few snaps at Friday’s practice.

headline: Senate Report Explores 2001 Escape by bin Laden From Afghan Mountains
text: WASHINGTON  As President Obama vows to “finish the job” in Afghanistan by sending more troops, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has completed a detailed look back at a crucial failure early in the battle against Al Qaeda: the escape of Osama bin Laden from American forces in the Afghan mountains of Tora Bora in December 2001.

headline: Entering the Superproject Void
text: Generation after generation, giant public works projects have altered the American landscape. The Erie Canal and the transcontinental railroad come to mind. So do massive urban sewer and sanitation systems, the Tennessee Valley Authority, rural electrification, the Hoover Dam, the Interstate System, the subway networks in San Francisco and Washington, the Big Dig in Boston ... and the list abruptly stops.

headline: Winning Lower Payments Takes Patience, and Luck
text: On the day in June when her mortgage company finally agreed to lower her monthly payments, Yolanda Thomas felt a twinge of hope that she would hold on to her Queens apartment, the first home she had ever owned. The loan modification extended by Chase Home Finance was technically a trial, not a permanent alteration, but this fact seemed of lesser significance.

headline: U.S. Will Push Mortgage Firms to Reduce More Loan Payments
text: The Obama administration on Monday plans to announce a campaign to pressure mortgage companies to reduce payments for many more troubled homeowners, as evidence mounts that a $75 billion taxpayer-financed effort aimed at stemming foreclosures is foundering.

headline: Higher Schooling in Michigan
text: Last November, Michigan became the 13th state to legalize medical marijuana. One young entrepreneur sees it as a business opportunity.

headline: Prime Numbers
text: 26.9: The total tax revenue of the United States as a percentage of its gross domestic product, according to the Organization for Economic Development and Cooperation. Denmark had the highest tax burden, at 48.3 percent; Mexico, the lowest, at 21.1 percent. The overall tax burden for the 30-member economic-development organization was estimated at 35.2 percent of G.D.P.

headline: The Wild Boar Is Multiplying and Less Lovable

headline: At This School, It’s Marijuana in Every Class
text: SOUTHFIELD, Mich.  At most colleges, marijuana is very much an extracurricular matter. But at Med Grow Cannabis College, marijuana is the curriculum: the history, the horticulture and the legal how-to’s of Michigan’s new medical marijuana program.

headline: Get Ready for Half a Recovery
text: A ROBUST economic recovery in 2010 is certainly on most investors’ wish lists as this year draws to a close. A return to prosperity would not only mean an end to our long financial nightmare, but it would also buttress a rebounding stock market, one of 2009’s few bright spots.

headline: South Carolina Rift Highlights Debate Over G.O.P.

headline: From Fritos to Cranberries

headline: Over 60, and Proud to Join the Digerati
text: IN the summer of 2008, just before I turned 61, I went to work at FLYP, an online digital publication that combines text with Flash animation, motion graphics and streaming audio and video to tell stories. It’s part of a larger effort to explore new forms of multimedia journalism.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Nov. 29, 2009
text: After weeks of talk about health care, the Sunday shows turn to the speech President Obama will deliver at West Point on Tuesday night detailing his plan for Afghanistan with legislators from the armed services and foreign relations committees in both chambers weighing in.

headline: Road Rage at the Kremlin
text: MOSCOW — Every society has a breaking point. In Boston it was the tea tax; in France it was Marie Antoinette’s wigs. If you’re curious where the breaking point may lie in Russia, try slamming the door as you get out of a taxicab — even the most rickety Soviet-era Lada. What will pass across the driver’s face is an expression of such exquisite suffering that you will first apologize and then run. Russians love their cars.

headline: When Names Change to Protect the Future
text: APPLE dropped the word “computer” from its name in January 2007, soon after it introduced the iPhone. Likewise, Fuji Photo Film shortened its name to Fujifilm in 2006, when sales of its photography products slipped to less than one-third of total revenue.

headline: Bernanke Warns of Risks in Push to Revamp Fed
text: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board warned bluntly on Saturday that provisions in financial legislation before the House and Senate would “seriously impair” the Fed as it struggled to maintain financial and economic stability.

headline: A Reality TV Head Count
text: It’s Jimmy Durante’s worst nightmare: everybody does want to get into the act.

headline: The Manly Art of Museum Curating
text: The other week I took my son Dean to see the “Arts of the Samurai” show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. As we walked around admiring the many gleaming sword blades, fantastic helmets and braided suits of iron armor, I detected something unfamiliar in the air, at least in this museum. I couldn’t quite figure out what it was until we were standing at the cash register in the gift shop.

headline: Large Victory Likely for Namibia Governing Party
text: JOHANNESBURG  Voters in Namibia went to the polls on Saturday for the second and final day of national elections, a balloting most likely to lead to another landslide victory for the South-West African People’s Organization, or Swapo, the party that has governed since independence in 1990.

headline: Civil Suit Hearing Held in China’s Milk Scandal
text: BEIJING  A hearing began Friday in the first civil suit to be heard in court involving parents suing a dairy company and a supermarket over selling tainted milk, The China Daily, an official English-language newspaper, reported Saturday.

headline: Golfer Is Ready for One More Comeback
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Ken Green knows comebacks. In three tumultuous decades as a professional golfer, he has been a star and star-crossed. He has basked near the top of the money list and has cleaned out his checking and savings accounts. He divorced his first wife and started winning; he was divorced by his second wife and lost everything.

headline: Don’t Take This Bait (but You’re Safe if You Do)

headline: A Rally That Needs More ‘E’

This faith manifests itself not just in rising share prices, but also in rising price-to-earnings ratios.

headline: Dangers of an Overheated China
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA’S recent trip to China reflects a symbiotic relationship at the heart of the global economy: China uses American spending power to enlarge its private sector, while America uses Chinese lending power to expand its public sector. Yet this arrangement may unravel in a dangerous way, and if it does, the most likely culprit will be Chinese economic overcapacity.

headline: Baby Boom of Mixed Children Tests South Korea
text: YEONGGWANG, South Korea  Just a few years ago, the number of pregnant women in this city had declined so much that the sparsely equipped two-room maternity ward at Yeonggwang General Hospital was close to shutting down. But these days it is busy again.

headline: Volunteering? It’s Easy to Avoid the Waiting List

headline: Addressing Spending in College Athletics

headline: With Fourth Concussion, Roethlisberger to Sit Out
text: The Pittsburgh Steelers’ starting quarterback, Ben Roethlisberger, will miss Sunday night’s critical game against the Baltimore Ravens because of symptoms from the concussion he sustained last week. Roethlisberger passed concussion tests early in the week, according to Coach Mike Tomlin, and he practiced Wednesday and Thursday. But he apparently started having headaches after those practices, and he took few snaps Friday.

headline: Lino Lacedelli Dies at 83; One of First to Scale K2

headline: The Penguins of Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO    I had set my umbrella and chair near the water in the early hours of what would soon become a perfect summer day. Like most people, I prefer the beach when it is deserted, and I had the place all to myself, no vendors to be seen, parading their sunglasses and suntan oils; no drinks, sandwiches or sweets offered in singing voices. Above all, no kids kicking balls or sand in my face. I held a book and was intent on doing some serious reading.

headline: Villagers Rushed to Help in Frigid Russian Crash

headline: Correction: Review of ‘Cowboys Full’

text: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Like fishing stories told on front porches at dusk or tall tales traded around bar stools after last call, the legend of Tim Tebow seems likely to only grow larger in this part of the country.

headline: Kicking Back and Kicking Off the Heels
text: Vicki Marlane, 75, is a transgender drag queen. Every Friday and Saturday night she performs with The Hot Boxxx Girls at Aunt Charlie’s Lounge, a postage-stamp-sized bar in the city’s Tenderloin District, where she is known as “The Girl with the Liquid Spine.” Ms. Marlane started entertaining as a female impersonator at 17. (Her words have been edited and condensed.)

headline: An American Export Comes Home, Still Popping
text: Krumping, clowning, strobing, turfing, breaking, locking. Few art forms boast as many subgenres as hip-hop dance. Though the differences between its various styles may be inscrutable to most people, mavens like Popin Pete of the seminal West Coast hip-hop dance crew the Electric Boogaloos have been known to split hairs over its terminology. “There are people who wave, and there are people who tut,” he told Dance Spirit Magazine last year. “They’re not popping.”

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Sunday about Grand Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri of Iran, who has emerged as the spiritual leader of the political opposition, misstated, in some editions, the surname of an Iranian scholar who said Ayatollah Montazeri’s criticisms were especially hurtful to the government because they attacked its assertion of Islamic legitimacy. The scholar, a former seminary student who is now senior fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, is Mehdi Khalaji, not Khaliji.

headline: Corrections
text: A listing in the Long Island Calendar in some editions on Nov. 15 and last Sunday misidentified the version of “Miracle on 34th Street” being performed at the John W. Engeman Theater in Northport. It is the musical adaptation by Douglas M. Smith and Vernon L. Stefanic  not the play by Will Severin, Patricia Di Benedetto Snyder and John Vreeke. Both are based on the story by Valentine Davies.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture on Nov. 15 with a Sports of The Times column, about Andre Agassi’s recent tour to promote his new memoir, “Open,” carried an erroneous credit in some editions. The photograph showing Agassi and his collaborator on the book, J. R. Moehringer, was by Isaac Brekken for The New York Times, not by Stuart Isett for The New York Times.

headline: Bay Area Highlights for Nov. 29
text: A Good Deal | Some in the Bay Area who have seen paying jobs vanish with the recession have turned to barter to keep themselves employed and to be able to shop. Groups like International Monetary Systems are making a comeback, and with the Christmas shopping season officially under way, the shadow economy, with its ersatz currency, is a growing force in the Bay Area.

headline: Home Course Holds No Advantage for the American Team in Aspen
text: ASPEN, Colo.  Julia Mancuso received a winner’s welcome when she skied into the finish corral here Saturday afternoon after her second giant slalom run in a World Cup event.

headline: Neediest | Project Feed Me
text: Patrick Alvarez and Isaias Garcia overcame odds that would overwhelm most teenagers.  Together they help feed the needy through a nonprofit group Mr. Alvarez founded, Project Feed Me.

headline: Bowden Contemplates His Future
text: Florida State Coach Bobby Bowden took some of the attention away from the Tim Tebow love-fest on Saturday by saying that he was contemplating retirement.

headline: The Human Toll of our Health System
text: Opponents of health care reform periodically argue that legislation is unnecessary because anybody can get medical assistance through the emergency room — or that those who get in trouble have only themselves for blame by not buying insurance. My Sunday column tells the story of John Brodniak, a young man who had insurance with his job, but lost both when he developed a benign tumor in his brain. Read his story and see if you still think the need for universal coverage isn’t urgent. His story seems to me the best rebuttal of the skeptics.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Corrections
text: A report on Nov. 15 in the In Transit column, about the new Cruise Terminal 18 at Port Everglades, Fla., misstated the month that the Oasis of the Seas, heading for the terminal on its maiden voyage, departed Finland. It left on Oct. 30, not “earlier this month.”

headline: Art by the Blind
text: Now in its 20th year, "Insights" is the country's pre-eminent selected exhibition of paintings, photographs and mixed-media pieces by legally blind artists.

headline: Mother Jones Speaks Out for Convicted Caricaturist
text: Monday, Nov. 29, 1909(use this link to access today’s entire issue)

headline: Nov. 28: College Football Slide Show
text: The day in college football included big hits, clutch kicks and one team wrapping up a surprising regular season.

headline: Mavericks’ Gooden Doesn’t Fancy Passing
text: In his long N.B.A. career, Jason Kidd, the Dallas Mavericks point guard, has proved to be among the best rebounding point guards, one of only three players, along with Magic Johnson and Oscar Robertson, to record 100 or more triple-doubles.

headline: Wild End to Weis’s Likely Finale With the Irish
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.  The Charlie Weis era at Notre Dame most likely ended Saturday night with same disappointment that has defined his tenure.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Rangers Fall on Night of Blowouts and Shootouts
text: Thirteen games on Saturday, and most of them weren’t pretty. There were blowouts, shootouts and continuing tales of woe from clubs like the Rangers, Hurricanes, Canadiens, Blue Jackets, Avs, Oilers, etc. etc. Home teams listed first:

headline: And the Heisman Should Go To …
text: A crowded and indistinct Heisman Trophy race did not get much clearer this weekend.

headline: Above Manhattan
text: A photographer records an ever-changing view of the city’s skyline.

headline: ‘Pop!’
text: Images from the new musical about Andy Warhol.

headline: Traumatized Russians View Their Dead After Luxury Train Bombing
text: TVER, Russia  All day on Sunday, families from Moscow and St. Petersburg arrived at the salmon-colored morgue here where their dead had been laid out. They clutched one another’s hands on the way in, and on the way out they looked different, whether from relief or dread, it was not always clear.

headline: Let the Games Begin! (No, Not the Olympics.)
text: Hong Kong is not exactly a city of sport-lovers. Sure, there’s the Hong Kong Rugby Sevens and horse racing at the Jockey Club, but competitive shopping is typically how locals show off their athletic endurance. So it was hardly surprising that Hong Kong seemed to emit a collective yawn upon hearing the news that the city would host the 2009 East Asian Games from Dec. 5 to 13.

headline: Matthew Stafford Had ‘Most Dramatic Player Wiring’
text: NFL Films has been putting microphones on players since 1965. Its president, Steve Sabol, said recently that no player’s wiring had ever been as dramatic as Matthew Stafford’s in a comeback victory against the Browns.

headline: International Firsts, and Foot-in-Mouth Play-by-Play
text: The N.B.A. is one of the most international of the North American leagues, and as more and more nationalities are represented there are inevitably going to be some interesting juxtapositions as well as some growing pains.

headline: Woods Says Car Accident Is His Fault, but Private
text: Tiger Woods said on Sunday that the car accident that sent him to the hospital early Friday was his fault and it was “embarrassing” to him and his family.

headline: The Creepy Id
text: Images of some of James Spader’s film and TV performances.

headline: Final: Jets 17, Panthers 6
text: David Waldstein provided live analysis from the Jets’ game against the Carolina Panthers at the Meadowlands.

headline: Keeping the Warriors’ Lineup Trim
text: Don Nelson, the coach of the Golden State Warriors, has been playing around with his lineup all season, averaging 9.3 players a game, including 11 in a loss to the Kings on Nov. 8. That served to make his absence because of pneumonia all the more noticeable during Tuesday’s win over the Dallas Mavericks. Filling in for Nelson, the assistant Keith Smart had only eight healthy players. He apparently considered that two too many; he used just six in beating Dallas, 113-103.

headline: Giants’ Manning Dealing With Injury
text: Giants quarterback Eli Manning has been treated for a stress reaction in his right foot that is a result of a continuing problem with plantar fasciitis, a person with knowledge of the condition confirmed Sunday.

headline: Moving Beyond Khmer Rouge’s Ghosts
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  The first trial to showcase the atrocities of the Khmer Rouge three decades ago concluded with the regime’s chief torturer still seemingly unable to grasp the magnitude of his actions. Yet despite that surprising end, the trial may have helped Cambodia begin to move beyond the horrors of its past.

headline: Israel to Recruit More Building Inspectors to Enforce a Freeze on West Bank Construction
text: JERUSALEM  Israel’s defense minister, Ehud Barak, instructed his staff on Sunday to recruit dozens of new building inspectors to supervise the government’s temporary construction freeze in West Bank settlements, while some settler leaders vowed to defy the building ban.

headline: Senators Show Doubts on Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  With President Obama scheduled on Tuesday to explain his new Afghan strategy  calling for up to 35,000 additional American troops to battle insurgents, stabilize the government and help train Afghan security forces  senators of both parties laid out on Sunday a range of reservations. They cited the questionable reliability of the Afghan government and security forces, the steep costs of a larger involvement, and the advisability of any exit strategy.

headline: The Delicate Arithmetic of Love and Independence
text: “Too Much Happiness,” the title story of Alice Munro’s latest collection, is a brilliant distillation of her Chekhovian art. Though it’s based on the life of the 19th-century Russian mathematician Sophia Kovalevsky, and takes place in Europe rather than the author’s native Canada, the tale showcases all of Ms. Munro’s gifts as a master of the short story form, while recapitulating many of the themes that have animated her fiction over four decades: the complicated arithmetic of familial relationships, the freedoms and constraints imposed by marriage, the competing claims of love and independence that women must balance in trying to forge identities of their own.

headline: Sri Lankan Who Led Fight Against Tamil Tigers Seeks Presidency
text: NEW DELHI  The former chief of Sri Lanka’s army formally announced Sunday that he would seek to replace his onetime ally, President Mahinda Rajapaksa, in elections to be held in January.

headline: ‘New Moon’ Leads at Box Office; ‘The Blind Side’ Surprises at No. 2
text: LOS ANGELES  As expected, “The Twilight Saga: New Moon” led at the movie box office for the second weekend in a row, with $42.5 million in domestic ticket sales for a 10-day total of $230.7 million. But the week’s surprise came from “The Blind Side,” a sports and family drama that was close behind with an estimated $40.1 million in sales, making it poised to become Sandra Bullock’s highest-grossing film to date.

headline: Singing for Their Supper Underground
text: Mando Alvarado doesn’t have nearly as much to say as he thinks he does in “Post No Bills,” his new play with music at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater. And his director, Michael Ray Escamilla, is in no hurry to have him say it, which makes the two-plus hours seem awfully long.

headline: Swiss Ban Building of Minarets on Mosques
text: GENEVA  In a vote that displayed a widespread anxiety about Islam and undermined the country’s reputation for religious tolerance, the Swiss on Sunday overwhelmingly imposed a national ban on the construction of minarets, the prayer towers of mosques, in a referendum drawn up by the far right and opposed by the government.

headline: Visions of Sugar Plums
text: All real ballets, W. H. Auden wrote in his essay “Ballet’s Present Eden,” take place in a world where there is no memory and no anticipation; the joys of life are those of the immediate and eternal present. Auden, a friend of George Balanchine, was referring to “The Nutcracker,” but he might as well have been talking about childhood. Drawing us into that pure present state of being is just part of what Balanchine’s “Nutcracker,” which opened Friday night at the David H. Koch Theater for New York City Ballet’s annual run, does so brilliantly.

headline: At 0-17, the Nets Tie an Unwanted Record
text: LOS ANGELES  As the Nets have become a team in transition, from conference contender to doormat, from established stars to burgeoning ones and from their Meadowlands home toward Brooklyn, they had few constants.

headline: She’s Writing Her Tell-All Memoirs, Guys
text: Was S. N. Behrman one of those women who wrote under a masculine pen name? Of course not. But you might think so, considering the strong feminist viewpoint in his 1932 play “Biography.”

headline: B.U.’s Six-on-Three Advantage
text: There was a full house at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night to watch Boston University, the defending national champions, and Cornell play to a 3-3 draw. For those in the crowd who mainly follow professional hockey, it was indeed a pleasure to see a game end without a penalty shootout, as well as some other advantages of the college game: enthusiastic crowds that don’t need prompting from scoreboards, touch-up icing, officials who jump in immediately to stop fights and, of course, pep bands.

headline: That Bellow, That Beard: An Actor’s Life and Hair
text: In a biographical solo play about a celebrity, you can usually count on a few things. The conceit designed to get the famous person to narrate a highlights reel of a lifetime is going to be strained. The performance will be theatrical. And at some point the actor will pause dramatically, holding back something that the author has no intention of keeping hidden.

headline: The First Winners Are Crowned at the Fall Championships
text: At the Fall North American Championships in San Diego, the first two national championships were decided on Saturday. The winners of the Helen Sobel Smith Life Master Women’s Pairs were Sue Picus and Shawn Quinn. Picus lives in Manhattan, and Quinn is temporarily in Texas. She lived the last few years in Poland and is about to relocate to Switzerland. They finished one-sixth of a board ahead of Victoria Gromova and Tatiana Ponomareva from Moscow. Third were Margie Gwozdzinsky of New York and Kathleen Sulgrove of Twinsburg, Ohio.

headline: New CDs
text: R. KELLY “Untitled” (Jive)

headline: Exit, Pursued by Swells and Lowlifes
text: Laura’s horrible secret has been exposed. Beautiful in her white 19th-century gown, she exits the party, stricken. Spontaneous applause breaks out at the Metropolitan Playhouse. Clearly, 142-year-old melodrama can still be fun.

headline: Coming Next Year: ‘Nutcracker’ Competition
text: In this ring, the Mouse King takes on the Nutcracker Prince.

headline: An American in Zurich, or Don’t Let the Door Hit You in the Back
text: A 12-man-strong American contingent is headed to Cape Town, South Africa, for Friday’s World Cup draw. The United States will be playing in its sixth consecutive World Cup and is regarded as an emerging power, on the field and economically, in the world’s game.

headline: A Tabletop Conjurer, Rediscovered
text: We lose good artists to the past all the time, because their work was ephemeral, or difficult, or fashion wasn’t on their side. The performance artist Stuart Sherman, who died of AIDS in 2001, was a candidate for disappearance on all three counts. But thanks to two exceptional exhibitions, one at the New York University 80WSE gallery, the other at Participant Inc., an alternative space on the Lower East Side, he’s back in a big way, big at least for him.

headline: A Night Curtain at Baghdad’s National Theater
text: With “He Who Seeks Sweet Things Must Also Endure Bitterness,” the Iraqi National Theater in Baghdad is trying to return to the evening performance schedule it maintained before the American invasion in 2003, Reuters reported. The play, which follows two tribes opposed to a marriage, is also about “loving Iraq and returning to it,” its producer, Issam al-Abbasi, told Reuters. “In the past, of course, when there was stability in the country, there was always a big turnout. Now just being able to stage a play is an achievement.” The 1,300-seat theater tried to reopen last year with a comedy, but that effort lasted two months. A recent decrease in sectarian violence as well as sealed blast walls and police protection have encouraged performers and audiences to try again. “On days when huge bombs kill dozens, the theater is all the more packed,” said one actress, Inaam al-Rubaie. “It’s as if the spectators want to send a message to the attackers they are not afraid, and life goes on.” (Above, the actors Zuhoor, left, and Majid Yaseen.)

headline: Queen of the Muppets
text: Miss Piggy, above, has finally received the popular acclaim she has always believed she deserved. As a tribute to Freddie Mercury, the Queen frontman who died 18 years ago, the Muppet clan covered his band Queen’s hit “Bohemian Rhapsody.” The new clip, produced and posted by the Disney unit Muppets Studio at youtube.com/user/MuppetsStudio, was the most-watched video on YouTube last week, with more than 4.5 million views, according to The Independent, the British newspaper. Besides Miss Piggy, who contributed her own flourish  “Nothing really matters but moi”  the video’s cast of dozens includes Gonzo leading his chorus of “chicks,” accompanied, of course, by the Dr. Teeth and the Electric Mayhem band, Fozzie Bear, Statler and Waldorf, Sam the Eagle and the Swedish Chef. But Animal sums it up best with his repetitive cries of “Mama!” We know how you feel, Animal.

headline: A Defiant Iran Vows to Build Nuclear Plants
text: WASHINGTON  Iran angrily refused Sunday to comply with a demand by the United Nations nuclear agency to cease work on a once-secret nuclear fuel enrichment plant, and escalated the confrontation by declaring it would construct 10 more such plants.

headline: One Is the Loneliest Number
text: And then there were none.

headline: 35 Across: Not Too Soft, as Pasta
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Themes that require a clue like “Word that can follow the ends of …” are not the most intriguing ones in the crossword construction bag of tricks. However, any puzzle that can weave BLUE-FOOTED BOOBY into its theme is O.K. by me. The other theme phrases are nice as well, and the fill seems especially crisp and interesting, so the arrow on the cruciverbal meter is pointing solidly into the green zone for this Oliver Hill creation.

headline: Leftist Wins Uruguay Presidential Vote
text: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay  José Mujica, a brash former guerrilla fighter, was elected president of Uruguay on Sunday, further cementing the hold of a leftist government credited with improving economic conditions in one of South America’s smallest countries.

headline: Local Stop: Inwood
text: Nestled in the northern reaches of Manhattan, the neighborhood of Inwood is a place of hills and history.

headline: Selling Wine With Notes of M.B.A.
text: A wave of M.B.A.'s, bankers, chemists and others are taking over or starting wineries and infusing them with a level of business expertise usually found only at big brands.

headline: Conservative Poised to Win in Honduras
text: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras  Porfirio Lobo, a longtime conservative politician, appeared headed toward victory on Sunday in the Honduran presidential election, which many hoped could help the country emerge from the crisis caused by last summer’s coup and end its isolation.

headline: Dylan on the Record About Christmas
text: Bob Dylan, below, surprised fans and critics in October when he released a holiday album, “Christmas in the Heart,” a compilation of carols and traditional songs. But in an interview with The Big Issue, a British weekly entertainment and current affairs magazine that benefits the homeless, Mr. Dylan said the tunes on the album were “part of my life, just like folk songs,” Reuters reported. Mr. Dylan spoke about why he wanted to donate the proceeds of his album to charities for the homeless in the United States, Britain and 80 other countries: “They get food straight to the people. No military organization, no bureaucracy, no governments to deal with,” he said. Mr. Dylan, who was raised Jewish and embraced Christianity in the late 1970s and early 1980s, would not discuss his faith other than to say, “I am a true believer.” He did talk about his boyhood, saying his memories include “snow, jingle bells, Christmas carolers going from house to house, sleighs in the streets, town bells ringing, nativity plays.”

headline: Footnote
text: It didn’t take long for the producer’s of Howard Shore’s live music version of Peter Jackson’s “Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring” to book the next installment. “The Lord of the Rings: the Two Towers” will open at Radio City Music Hall for two performances on Oct. 8 and 9 next year. Beneath a 60-foot screen showing the film, Mr. Shore’s original score will be performed by more than 300 musicians, conducted by Ludwig Wicki. Tickets go on sale Monday at ticketmaster.com.

headline: ‘Area 51’ at Paramount
text: “Area 51,” the next film from Oren Peli, who directed the horror hit “Paranormal Activity,” has been acquired for distribution in the United States by Paramount Pictures, the studio said Sunday. Paramount made a hit of “Paranormal Activity” by using unconventional marketing tactics, including a Web campaign urging fans to “demand” the film before it was shown. That movie has taken in about $107.1 million at the domestic box office. A studio spokeswoman, Katie Martin Kelley, said last month that Paramount was not involved in discussions for “Area 51,” a thriller about a military base at the center of U.F.O. conspiracy theories. The Creative Artists Agency and IM Global, an international sales company, were seeking about $10 million  far more than the $300,000 Paramount paid for “Paranormal Activity.” Reached on Sunday Ms. Kelley declined to discuss terms of the deal. But a person briefed on the sale, who spoke on condition of anonymity because the studio has not authorized comment, said the final price approached the $10 million originally sought.

headline: Bilbao Museum Official Sentenced
text: The former financial director of the Guggenheim Bilbao Museum was found guilty of embezzlement and falsifying documents last week and was sentenced to 32 months in jail, Agence France-Presse reported. After an audit in 2008 revealed that money was missing from accounts, the official, Roberto Cearsolo Barrenetxea, confessed to having stolen more than $750,000 from two museum funds. The money was taken in small amounts between 1998 and 2008, through forged checks and bank transfers. Mr. Barrenetxea, who had been in the job since the Spanish branch of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum opened in 1997, also made changes to the 2005 annual accounts report as well as other documents to disguise his theft. After the audit last year Mr. Barrenetxea wrote to the museum’s director, saying, “Since I could no longer live with this situation, I have decided to confess the facts to you.”

headline: BBC Cuts ‘Lurid’ Ballet
text: Scenes from a Venezuelan ballet have been pulled from a British program to be broadcast by the BBC because of what critics called their “lurid” and “deliberately offensive” nature. According to BBC News online, a scene from Javier de Frutos’s “Eternal Damnation to Sancho and Sanchez,” in which a pope abuses an altar boy and strangles a pregnant nun, was cut from a program of four works titled “In The Spirit Of Diaghilev,” part of a celebration of the centennial of Sergei Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes. Scenes from other works will be televised from Sadler’s Wells Theater in London in December.

headline: Joyce Theater Lists Spring Season Works
text: Four world premieres will be on the schedule when the Joyce Theater’s spring season gets under way on Feb. 23. Besides the new works  from Keigwin & Company, the Lyon Opera Ballet, Lar Lubovitch and Stephen Petronio  the season will feature the latest pieces by Dance Brazil, the John Jasperse Company and Pilobolus. The choreographers Monica Bill Barnes, Camille A. Brown, Andrea Miller and Kate Weare will make their individual Joyce debuts during a week of alternating programs, ending with a collaborative performance by all four women on Aug. 14. Other highlights include a centennial celebration of the choreographer Alwin Nikolais, three weeks of Savion Glover and the Martha Graham Dance Company’s 21st century adaptation of “American Document,” her 1938 work inspired by works like the Declaration of Independence, to be directed by Anne Bogart.

headline: In Rain, in Snow, but Not on Saturdays?
text: Although your mailbox may be overflowing with catalogs and a few holiday cards may have started to appear, the United States Postal Service is in crisis. For fiscal year 2009, the Postal Service reported a net loss of $3.8 billion, despite more than $6 billion in cost cuts. Meanwhile, total mail volume fell by nearly 26 billion pieces, or 13 percent.

headline: Muti Indulges a Love of Honegger: Who’s to Say No?
text: If you are the New York Philharmonic, and you hire a guest conductor with a big enough name, you don’t need a fancy soloist. And if that name is Riccardo Muti, you don’t even need an overture. What’s more, if one of the two works on the program is going to be Beethoven’s sure-fire “Eroica” Symphony, you can let Mr. Muti indulge his fondness for relatively obscure 20th-century works with the other. (But expect some muttering in the aisles at intermission.)

headline: An Artist Turns People Into His Marionettes
text: In the short video “80064,” the artist who made it, Artur Zmijewski, persuades an elderly Auschwitz survivor to have the faded number on his forearm refreshed by a tattoo artist. The befuddled old gentleman had evidently agreed beforehand to have this done, but on camera he is having second thoughts. He doesn’t see the point and worries about the consequences. But he eventually surrenders to Mr. Zmijewski’s implacable urging, and the tattooist retraces the digits. Afterward the old man seems ambivalent; it’s hard to tell whether he’s glad he let it be done or not. Maybe he is just relieved that the ordeal is over.

headline: Secret Service Agents Interview Intruders
text: WASHINGTON  As part of a broadening inquiry into presidential security, Secret Service agents have interviewed the Virginia couple who sneaked into a White House state dinner last week, a senior federal official involved in the investigation said Sunday.

headline: Forest Kindergarten
text: The 23 pupils at the Waldorf School of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., spend three hours a day outdoors, rain or shine, in what the school calls a forest kindergarten.

headline: Online Shoppers Spend Over the Weekend, but Will It Last?
text: After finishing the turkey and doing the dishes, many more people than last year turned on their computers and went shopping. But will Thanksgiving weekend spending continue through the holiday season?

headline: Crashing the B.C.S.
text: The once unthinkable could be on the verge of happening in the Bowl Championship Series.

headline: A Museum Hails Caesar, Even if Some Antiquarians Don’t Agree
text: ARLES, France  Dredged up from the murky depths of the Rhône River, beneath a heap of wrecked cars, rotting tires and more than 20 centuries of silt, the statue’s white marble visage was plain as day.

headline: A Tax on Nips and Tucks Angers Patients, Surgeons
text: Last week, a 41-year-old woman who had recently had her first child walked into the office of Dr. Steven Teitelbaum in Santa Monica, Calif., for an operation that tens of thousands of women like her have undergone this year: a breast lift.

headline: Tree Harvester Offers to Save Indonesian Forest
text: TELUK MERANTI, Indonesia  From the air, the Kampar Peninsula in Indonesia stretches for mile after mile in dense scrub and trees. One of the world’s largest peat swamp forests, it is also one of its biggest vaults of carbon dioxide, a source of potentially lucrative currency as world governments struggle to hammer out a global climate treaty. The vault, though, is leaking.

headline: Sanchez Limits Risk; Color Jets Impressed
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As the Jets plod their way through the first year of the Mark Sanchez era, perhaps the best they can hope for are games like Sunday’s.

headline: Open Source as a Model for Business Is Elusive
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In many ways, MySQL embodies the ideals of the populist software movement known as open source, in which a program’s creator releases it to the world free of charge, and legions of volunteers contribute improvements that are also freely shared.

headline: Britain Presses Pakistan and Afghanistan on Militants
text: LONDON  Highlighting themes likely to be taken up by President Obama in his military policy speech on Tuesday, Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain has demanded that Afghanistan and Pakistan match plans for increased allied troop levels in Afghanistan by taking tough actions of their own, including, in Pakistan, a stepped-up effort to capture Osama bin Laden.

headline: After War, Finding Peace and Calm in a Garden
text: EAST ORANGE, N.J.

headline: Stressing the Web, ‘NewsHour’ Begins an Overhaul
text: ARLINGTON, Va.  Until recently, the employees who worked on the Web site of “The NewsHour With Jim Lehrer” on PBS were based in a building a brisk five-minute walk through city traffic from their on-air colleagues. The Web and television staffs interacted only at Mr. Lehrer’s annual holiday party. “They were all the recognizably young ones,” said Linda Winslow, the show’s executive producer.

headline: Heisman Polling: Is McCoy in the Lead?
text: In a very informal and unscientific quest for some insight on the Heisman Trophy race, I queried a jury of my peers Sunday. The basic feel I have for the Heisman race right now is that Colt McCoy is in the lead, but most voters are still undecided. (Kirk Bohls in Austin and the famed Heisman Pundit, Chris Huston, echoed this thought. Huston said he was tempted to declare McCoy the winner.) Here are 10 other journalists I polled about the Heisman and their thoughts on where they were with their vote.

headline: Vital Tests for Obama on Mandate for Change
text: WASHINGTON  In a narrow sense, President Obama’s handling of the critical issues of health care and Afghanistan in the weeks ahead will test the depth of his support among Democrats and determine whether he can draw Republicans to his foreign policy.

headline: In Japan, an Odd Perch for Google: Looking Up at the Leader
text: TOKYO  In 2001, a fledgling Internet company named Google opened its first overseas office in Japan, eager to tap a huge technology market.

headline: Ready for an SEC Rematch
text: The hype for a rematch of the Southeastern Conference title game Saturday really began before the season, when it was obvious that Florida and Alabama were again the class of the league.

headline: The Fall and Rise of Media
text: Historically, young women and men who sought to thrive in publishing made their way to Manhattan. Once there, they were told, they would work in marginal jobs for indifferent bosses doing mundane tasks and then one day, if they did all of that without whimper or complaint, they would magically be granted access to a gilded community, the large heaving engine of books, magazines and newspapers.

headline: Tying Up Loose Ends With ‘Oprah,’ ‘Mad Men,’ Wine Clubs and More
text: IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing, the media and popular culture.

headline: For Forest Kindergartners, Class Is Back to Nature, Rain or Shine
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Fat, cold droplets splashed from the sky as the students struggled into their uniforms: rain pants, boots, mittens and hats. Once buttoned and bundled, they scattered toward favorite spaces: a crab apple tree made for climbing, a cluster of bushes forming a secret nook under a willow tree, a sandbox growing muddier by the minute.

headline: Business Titans, and Others, Expected at Jobs Summit
text: The invitations went out just before Thanksgiving, but by the end of the holiday weekend the White House has confirmed that President Obama’s jobs summit on Thursday will include about 130 business leaders, union chiefs, academics, mayors and representatives of nonprofit groups.

headline: Debate on Creating Jobs, Without Raising Deficit
text: WASHINGTON  As Democrats renew their push to create jobs, they are at odds over the timing, cost and scope of additional measures, with the White House’s concern about high budget deficits pitted against the eagerness of many in Congress to spur hiring before next year’s elections.

headline: A Takeover Movie for Hollywood to Watch
text: LOS ANGELES  Not long ago, a first meeting between Hollywood executives and the potential new owners of their studio might have turned on Oscar prospects, this year’s ingénue or the exact dimensions of Russell Crowe’s salary.

headline: City’s Schools Share Their Space, and Bitterness
text: Suzanne Tecza had spent a year redesigning the library at Middle School 126 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, including colorful new furniture and elaborate murals of leafy trees. So when her principal decided this year to give the space to the charter high schools that share the building, Ms. Tecza was furious.

headline: Vote Recount in Nassau Approaches Completion
text: MINEOLA, N.Y.  Nearly three weeks after Election Day, the recount in the race for Nassau County executive is expected to conclude on Monday. Edward P. Mangano, the Republican challenger, has a slight lead over the Democratic incumbent, Thomas R. Suozzi.

headline: Rough Race to the Finish for Senate Democrats
text: WASHINGTON — Even if lawmakers do not take a day off until Christmas, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, has just 25 days to meet his own goal of finishing the Senate version of the bill by the holiday. And then he must iron out differences with the House bill.

headline: Cosby Takes a Web Plunge, Sweaters in Tow
text: At the end of the first decade of the third millennium, it is not unexpected that a veteran comic would plant a flag on the Internet: Shecky Greene has a Web site, and Shelley Berman has a Facebook fan page.

headline: Shoppers Fill Streets, if Not Their Bags
text: So much for the job losses, the foreclosures and the disintegrating dollar. Standing on the corner of Prince and Mercer Streets in SoHo, you might think the recession had never happened.

headline: Upstart Chinese Telecom Company Rattles Industry as It Rises to No. 2
text: When the telecommunications company Telenor decided to upgrade its mobile phone network in Norway, the job drew bids from the companies that had built its original grid: Ericsson and Nokia Siemens Networks.

headline: Less Diversity in Supervisors of Foster Care
text: More than two decades ago, New York started down a path that was considered a hallmark of child welfare reform by creating and strengthening its minority-governed, neighborhood-based foster care agencies.

headline: Shoppers Showed Up, but Spent on Bargains
text: More consumers flooded the nation’s stores on Thanksgiving weekend in search of bargains. But with retailers dangling rock-bottom prices and consumers only biting at less expensive merchandise like small appliances and winter clothes, the average amount spent by each shopper declined from last year.

headline: Bad Times Do Not Bring More Crime (if They Ever Did)
text: Unemployment has reached 10.3 percent in New York City, higher than it is in the state and nationally. The Bloomberg administration is weighing cuts from every city agency to help close a $4.1 billion deficit next year. Homelessness among families is at a record high, with more than 28,000 men, women and children now in the city’s shelter system.

headline: A Bumpy Road for Alligator Farms
text: Alligator farmers in Louisiana are struggling with lower prices for the raw material that often ends up in expensive handbags.

headline: For Novice Journalists, Rising Risks in Conflict Zones
text: OTTAWA  Amanda Lindhout was a waitress at an Irish pub in Calgary, Alberta, with a dream of becoming a journalist. But Ms. Lindhout, who has no formal journalistic training, did not join the ranks of citizen journalists who blog about their communities. Instead, she used her earnings from the bar to finance reporting trips to several of the world’s most dangerous war zones.

headline: It’s All About the Money
text: Twenty years ago, the widely respected Feerick Commission on Government Integrity declared that “campaign finance laws in New York are a disgrace.”

headline: Metropolitan Diary
