headline: New Name for the Oregon-Oregon State Game
text: Thursday night’s Civil War between No. 13 Oregon State and No. 7 Oregon has a new name.

headline: Reversal Haunts Federal Health Agency
text: Earlier this month, a federal health agency backed away from its earlier findings that decades of explosive detonations by the Navy on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques posed no health hazards to residents.

headline: LED Bulbs Save Substantial Energy, a Study Finds
text: Does the latest generation of energy-saving light bulbs save energy? A comprehensive study conducted by Osram, the German lighting company, provides evidence that they do.

headline: Helping Dubai, but Only So Far
text: Abu Dhabi is preparing a pick ’n’ mix bailout of Dubai. The richest of the United Arab Emirates seems set to support its struggling neighbor, which shocked markets worldwide last week by calling for a standstill on $59 billion of debt at Dubai World, its investment arm. But helping only on a case-by-case basis sounds sensible. Abu Dhabi’s priority is to stop a bank run, rather than undertake a wholesale rescue of Dubai World.

headline: Obama’s Speech on Afghanistan to Envision Exit
text: WASHINGTON    President Obama plans to lay out a time frame for winding down the American involvement in the war in Afghanistan when he announces his decision this week to send more forces, senior administration officials said Sunday.

headline: Advocating for Girls’ Sports With a Sharp Tongue
text: HAVERFORD, Pa.  Few girls who play sports in suburban Philadelphia would recognize Robert H. Landau, but many coaches and athletic directors know that spotting him in the bleachers could spell trouble.

headline: A Fall Was Instant, but Recovery Drags On
text: Leslie Jackson is ready for her close-up.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Arab Emirates Aim to Limit Dubai Crisis in Pledge to Banks
text: Trying to prevent a run on its banks and stem financial turmoil that some fear could spread globally, the United Arab Emirates helped calm markets Monday by pledging to lend money to banks operating in Dubai. But the action comes amid concerns about excessive borrowing around the world.

headline: As Sales Vanish, Skins Stay on Alligators
text: RACELAND, La.  After five years, Tommy Fletcher and his alligator farming business are facing irreconcilable differences.

headline: Crisis Puts Focus on Dubai’s Complex Relationship With Abu Dhabi
text: This article is by Robert F. Worth, Heather Timmons and Landon Thomas Jr.

headline: For Golf’s No. 1 Pitchman, Silence Doesn’t Sell
text: Tiger Woods is not available. He will talk in his own sweet time.

headline: New Jersey Man Who Shot Family Had Been Barred From Seeing Wife
text: A New Jersey man who was killed by an off-duty police officer after he shot his estranged wife and two sons, one fatally, on Saturday morning in Paterson, had been barred from seeing his wife since September because of a restraining order, the authorities said on Sunday.

headline: Man Who Spoke About His Father Being a Priest Dies at 22
text: Nathan Halbach, who decided to speak out as he was terminally ill with brain cancer about how it felt to grow up knowing that his absentee father was a Roman Catholic priest, died at home in Missouri on Friday. He was 22.

headline: In Kansas, Affirmation of Values Even as Winning Streak Ends
text: HAYS, Kan.  The standing ovation erupted as soon as the Centralia defender emerged from the pile with the ball. It was over, finally, in overtime: the Panthers had defeated Smith Center to win the Kansas state Class 2-1a championship game, 20-12, and had ended the longest active winning streak in high school football at 79 games.

headline: Still Outnumbered, but Council Republicans Count on More Clout
text: One minute, Councilman Lewis A. Fidler, a Brooklyn Democrat, drops by. The next, two other Democrats from Brooklyn, Simcha Felder and Domenic M. Recchia Jr., show up. Then, a couple of Democrats from Queens: Melinda R. Katz, who is leaving office soon, and Leroy G. Comrie Jr., who may replace Ms. Katz as the leader of the Land Use Committee.

headline: Bears, Bugs and More Bumbling
text: A few weeks ago I had a Dr. Doolittle encounter with the local bear. A solitary two-year old was sitting in the middle of my dirt road as I drove to work. I slowed down, turned off the radio, rolled down the window and had a three-minute conversation with this potential hoodlum. It went something like this: “I hope you have a nice day. I hope you find mushrooms and plenty of grubs and apples. But leave the beehives alone. The bees have their own issues to deal with and don’t need any interference from you….”

headline: A Generation in the Balance
text: Do downturns create Democrats? The Great Depression certainly did: The generation that came of age in the 1930s has cleaved to the Democratic Party like no population before or since. And it makes intuitive sense that experiencing a recession at a formative age could inspire lifelong sympathy for the party of the welfare state and lifelong suspicion toward the party of free markets.

headline: Media Equation: All the Young News
text: In today’s Media Equation, David Carr writes:

headline: Saints’ Brees Debunks Notions of the Quarterback Prototype
text: Drew Brees stepped onto the scale at the N.F.L.’s scouting combine in 2001 and was quickly reminded of his biggest  and smallest  problem.

headline: Week 12: Jets End Three-Game Losing Streak.
text: Mark Sanchez did just enough and the Jets defense did the rest in a victory over Carolina.

headline: Elections in Honduras
text: Hondurans went to the polls in a presidential election that many voters hoped would allow the country to emerge from the political crisis caused by last summerâ€™s coup.

headline: Cash in the Forefront for the Holidays
text: Holiday shoppers say they have put away their credit cards and pared down their ambitions on gifts, so there might be more fruitcakes than diamonds under the tree this year.

headline: Wine and Song
text: Diane Birch’s songs “are retro-leaning in a nonspecific way (think Zooey Deschanel meets Joni Mitchell, with the tiniest dash of Norah Jones),” writes Amanda Petrusich and “her rich, husky vocals go down soft and easy.” Sip slowly while Ms. Birch plays City Winery at 8 Monday night. The set will likely feature songs from her new album, “Bible Belt” (S-Curve), “a promising debut, full of honest proclamations and golden horns.”

headline: Lights, Please
text: The lighting of the Christmas Tree in Rockefeller Center won’t happen until next Wednesday, but for those of you who can’t wait until then for an extravagant public display of fir and electricity, head to the Upper West Side Monday night for Winter’s Eve at Lincoln Square. The free program along Broadway from Columbus Circle to 68th Street includes music, street performances, food tastings from local restaurants and activities for children. The festivities begin at 5:30 p.m. with a tree lighting, hosted by Joy Behar of “The View,” at Dante Park. Stay to listen to the hot sounds of the Brooklyn Afrobeat band Antibalas, on break from the hit show “Fela!” and the cool jazz of the bassist and composer Ben Allison, who will be holding court at the American Folk Art Museum. Part of the proceeds will benefit City Harvest.

headline: All the Lonely People
text: “If this is what a disaster looks like, bring on the apocalypse,” Ben Brantley writes in his review of “The Starry Messenger.” The new play by Kenneth Lonergan was plagued by bad publicity before it opened, with particular scorn directed at Matthew Broderick for his apparent inability to remember his lines. But that’s all just water under the bridge now. Mr. Brantley writes that “the gentle, compassionate comic drama” at the Acorn Theater “has the sweet taste of redemption.” The story about a middle-aged man swept up in a affair with a younger woman, “re-establishes Mr. Lonergan, who hasn’t had a new play on the boards since 2001, as a possessor of all the crucial parts of a good dramatist’s anatomy: a critical mind, an empathetic heart and a musical ear that hears whole lives in sentences. And Mr. Broderick delivers his finest, most affecting performance in years.” Redemption indeed.

text: Accounts

headline: With a Week to Go, the Heisman Trophy Is Up for Grabs
text: The most storied award in college sports, the Heisman Trophy, has fully embraced the digital age just in time. This is the first year that the Heisman voting will be completely done electronically; the 925 voters are required to cast their ballots online by 5 p.m. Dec. 7.

headline: Bemidji State Gets Its Revenge
text: Nobody expected great things from Bemidji State when they entered the N.C.A.A. tournament last April as the 16th and lowest seed, but with upsets over Notre Dame and Cornell the Beavers played the underdog role right into the Frozen Four. Unfortunately for them, another team making a sudden rise to the top was waiting in the semifinals, as Miami University sent Bemidji home early from Washington.

headline: Unemployment and Midterms
text: If they crave comfort, Democratic candidates can grab onto this: political science research finds little historical connection between unemployment and midterm Congressional elections.

headline: Ari Kiev, a Psychiatrist, Dies at 75
text: Ari Kiev, a psychiatrist whose early work on depression and suicide prevention led to a career helping athletes and Wall Street traders achieve peak performance, died Nov. 18 in Manhattan. He was 75 and lived in Park Ridge, N.J.

headline: News of Hockey, 11/29/09: Tretiak Sees K.H.L.-N.H.L. Olympic Team
text: Vladislav Tretiak, the G.M. of the Russian Olympic team, visits Montreal to watch Alex Ovechkin and says the Sbornaya at Vancouver will be “maybe half and half, 12 and 12″ composed of K.H.L. players and N.H.L. players. While Tretiak’s statement creates surprise in Canada, that makeup of the roster has pretty much been Russian national team procedure in winning the last two I.I.H.F. World Championships, in 2009 and in 2008.

headline: Commuters Beware
text: The train wreck last summer that killed nine commuters and injured 80 in the nation’s capital laid bare a deadly paradox: the safety failures at the heart of the collision occurred on a subway track devoid of the strong federal crashworthiness standards in place on Amtrak’s immediately adjacent railroad line. Regional systems of light-rail and subways are not subject to the federal government’s more stringent safety requirements.

headline: Kevon’s Choices
text: Kevon Simpson was 10 months old when his mother was gunned down. His grandmother, who raised him, was determined that he transcend the low expectations of so many people in their Bronx neighborhood.

headline: The Jobs Imperative
text: If you’re looking for a job right now, your prospects are terrible. There are six times as many Americans seeking work as there are job openings, and the average duration of unemployment  the time the average job-seeker has spent looking for work  is more than six months, the highest level since the 1930s.

headline: Week 12 in Quotations: Staying in the Moment
text: A look back at Week 12, and in the case of Michael Vick, ahead to Week 13.

headline: As Signs of Concern Spread, N.F.L. Revisits Concussions
text: BALTIMORE  In this crucial division contest, in a game full of playoff implications, it was whom the Pittsburgh Steelers did not start that highlighted the increased awareness of concussions across the N.F.L.

headline: Wins Count; D’Antoni Isn’t Counting
text: Mike D’Antoni acknowledged the two sides of his situation with a scrunching of his forehead and laughter Sunday. He finds himself in the N.B.A.’s version of being between a rock and a hard place. His record has been mostly in a tailspin since he began coaching the Knicks last season, but D’Antoni said he cared little about it.

headline: Showcase: Iran, Beyond Stereotype
text: Paolo Woods arrived in Tehran in 1999 with a bag full of black-and-white film. Like many photojournalists before him, he headed to the former American embassy, where the hostage crisis had begun 20 years earlier; a landmark of Iran’s tumultuous political past.

headline: For Vonn and U.S., a Disappointing Trip to Aspen
text: ASPEN, Colo.  World Cup skiers are accustomed to hard, icy tracks, but the women’s slalom on Aspen Mountain on Sunday gave rise to the argument that there can be too much of a hard thing.

headline: N.H.L. Scoreboard: Sharks Mending From Blackhawk Debacle
text: Last week the league-leading San Jose Sharks were clobbered by the No. 2 Chicago Blackhawks, 7-2, in a game that seemed to crush the Sharks’ spirit as soundly as they were crushed on the scoreboard. But since then the Hawks were shut out in one game and beaten on penalty shots in another, while San Jose prevailed on penalties in their one outing. Does that mean the Sharks have recovered from their beating? Hard to say, but a good result on Sunday night would help. Home teams listed first:

text: A preview of the Super Bowl? A carnival of offense? An excuse for ESPN excess?

headline: Arab Emirates Move to Limit Crisis in Dubai
text: Update | 7:43 a.m. Trying to prevent a run on its banks, and financial turmoil that some fear could spread globally, the United Arab Emirates helped calm financial markets Monday with its pledge to lend money to banks operating in Dubai, an action that came amid concerns about excessive borrowing around the world, Vikas Bajaj and Graham Bowley reported in The New York Times.

headline: News Quiz | November 30, 2009
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s front page.

headline: France Telecom and Sunrise Merge Swiss Mobile Units
text: France Telecom said Wednesday it would pay 1.5 billion euros to merge its Swiss subsidiary with Switzerland’s No. 2 mobile phone operator, Sunrise, in an effort to challenge the state-run market leader, Swisscom.

headline: Markets Rally Across Asia as Dubai Fears Recede
text: Asian stock markets rallied Monday as investors’ nervousness over potential fallout from a debt-repayment delay in Dubai faded, Bettina Wassener reports in The New York Times.

headline: Frenzied Friday?
text: WHOM do you know who went shopping on Black Friday?

headline: C&C to Buy Constellation’s British Cider Brands
text: C&C, the Irish drinks group, said it agreed to buy all the British cider assets of Constellation Brands — including the Blackthorn, Olde English and Gaymers brands — for £45 million ($74 million) in cash.

headline: Sina Managers Win Backing for Investment Plan
text: A trio investors including Sequoia Capital are backing a management-led plan to invest $180 million in China’s leading Web portal, Sina, Reuters reported, citing two people familiar with the plan.

headline: Dropbox Says It Raised $6 Million Last Year
text: Dropbox, a start-up that allows users to back up, synchronize and share files, revealed that it has raised $6 million in a first round of funding.

headline: Is Tackle Football Too Dangerous For Kids to Play?
text: Have you been following news accounts about professional football players and head injuries? Do you know anyone who plays football and has had a concussion?

headline: Open Source as a Model for Business Is Elusive
text: In many ways, MySQL embodies the ideals of the populist software movement known as open source, in which a program’s creator releases it to the world free of charge, and legions of volunteers contribute improvements that are also freely shared.

headline: Will Abu Dhabi Impose Conditions for Dubai Bailout?
text: It was the most subtle of gestures, but looking back, many in Dubai now see it as a sign of their salvation. At the grand opening of the Dubai Air Show this month, the crown prince of Abu Dhabi, Sheik Muhammad bin Zayed al-Nahyan, placed his hand over the hand of Dubai’s ruler, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum. That was widely viewed among people here as a sign that Abu Dhabi, by far the largest and richest member-state of the United Arab Emirates federation, would take care of Dubai.

headline: A Takeover Movie for Hollywood to Watch
text: Not long ago, a first meeting between Hollywood executives and the potential new owners of their studio might have turned on Oscar prospects, this year’s ingénue or the exact dimensions of Russell Crowe’s salary.

headline: Dubai Woes a Blow to Banks’ Pride?
text: British banks have always fancied their chances in the gulf region. So it is no surprise they would be more exposed than counterparts in the United States to Dubai World, the Dubai government vehicle whose ability to repay $59 billion of debt was called into question in a Thanksgiving eve bombshell, Breakingviews says.

headline: Philippine President to Run for Congress
text: MANILA  Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, the deeply unpopular Philippine president, announced Monday that she would run for a seat in Congress in elections scheduled for next year, ending months of speculation about her plans when her term ends in June but also raising questions about her long-term intentions.

headline: Ari Kiev, Psychiatrist to Traders, Dies
text: Ari Kiev, a psychiatrist whose early work on depression and suicide prevention led to a career helping Wall Street traders and athletes achieve peak performance, died Nov. 18 in Manhattan. He was 75.

headline: Six Flags Bondholders Submit Alternative Plan
text: A group of noteholders of the bankrupt regional theme park operator Six Flags said on Sunday it had submitted an alternative reorganization plan that transfers most of the equity to them.

headline: Hochtief Reserves Right to Delay Unit’s I.P.O.
text: Hochtief reserves the right to postpone the initial public offering of its infrastructure unit if stock markets remain unsettled because of the Dubai debt crisis, its chief executive said in an interview on Sunday.

headline: Nakheel Seeks Trading Suspension For Bonds
text: Nakheel of Dubai asked for three of its listed Islamic bonds worth $5.25 billion to be suspended pending details of restructuring plans at its parent company, a move that appeared to be aimed at dampening speculation on the bonds.

headline: Man Tied to Death Camp Goes on Trial in Germany
text: MUNICH John Demjanjuk, a retired American autoworker, went on trial here Monday, accused of helping to force 27,900 Jews to their deaths during the Holocaust.

headline: Lachlan Murdoch Said to Bid for Nielsen
text: Lachlan Murdoch, the eldest son of Rupert Murdoch, is joining a swath of media investors preparing to bid for the lion’s share of Nielsen Business Media, which includes The Hollywood Reporter, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Fed Tightens Regulations on Its Regional Directors
text: The Federal Reserve, under attack in Congress for being too entwined with big banks, closed a loophole on Wednesday that allowed a director at Goldman Sachs to be a director of the New York Fed as the agency was bailing out Wall Street during the financial crisis.

headline: Tough Times Turn Newspaper Lenders into Owners
text: Newspaper headlines have skewered money lenders for dubious decisions that stoked the recession. Now, The Associated Press writes, the financiers are starting to headline newspapers in a new way — as the owners.

headline: UBS Threatens to Leave Switzerland, Report Says
text: UBS is threatening to move its headquarters out of Switzerland if the authorities impose too many new regulations after the global financial crisis, the Swiss weekly newspaper Sonntag CH reported.

headline: Eponymns
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have been hard at work inventing novel eponyms.

headline: Regulators Said to List Systemic Risk Institutions
text: Thirty global financial institutions have been selected for crossborder supervision exercises by regulators, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Jets Open Thread: Can They Make December Meaningful?
text: When a team wins only two games in October and November – as the Jets did this season — it is hard to call it a playoff contender.

headline: China Charges 58 With Covering Up Deadly Mine Blast
text: BEIJING  Ten journalists and 48 officials have been charged with taking bribes to cover up a mining disaster last year, according to a report published on Monday in China Daily, an official English-language newspaper.

headline: London’s Oyster Cards Now Available Online
text: Heading for London and want to avoid the queues for tickets on the city’s bus and tube lines? Now you can be ready to roll — literally — with a new online service that allows overseas visitors to purchase passes in advance of a trip and have them delivered to their home.

headline: Irish Banks Set to Unload $42.5 Billion in Bad Loans
text: Bank of Ireland and Allied Irish Banks may receive a combined 28.2 billion euros ($42.5 billion) for the faulty property loans they are selling to the country’s bad bank, the National Asset Management Agency, Blooomberg News reported.

headline: M&B Says Rebel Shareholders Trying to Take Control
text: Mitchells & Butlers, the British pubs operator, will ask the country’s takeover watchdog to rule whether rebel shareholders are trying to gain control of the group after they blocked the appointment of a chairman.

headline: Sands Falls 10% on Hong Kong Debut
text: Sands China‘s weak stock market debut in Hong Kong on Monday signals a lack of investor appetite for a casino gaming company with a high valuation and an uncertain outlook, with mixed interest in the sector’s long-term prospects, Reuters reported.

headline: The Latest Business Plan: Cupcakes
text: Move over restaurants and bed-and-breakfasts. A new fantasy seems to have taken hold for people who long to own their own business: the cupcakery.

headline: Bid May Be Close for A.I.G. Unit, Report Says
text: A group of private equity investors may be close to making a bid for half of the International Lease Finance Corporation, a unit of the American International Group, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Reality TV Makes Reality Its Victim
text: Today’s idea: Reality TV degrades real life itself, an article says. It has “not only ruined network values, destroyed the classic documentary, and debased the art of bad acting, but also fomented class warfare, antisocial behavior and murder.”

headline: A Defiant Iran Vows to Build Nuclear Plants
text: WASHINGTON  Iran angrily refused Sunday to comply with a demand by the United Nations nuclear agency to cease work on a once-secret nuclear fuel enrichment plant, and escalated the confrontation by declaring it would construct 10 more such plants.

headline: Government Not Guaranteeing Dubai World Debt
text: Dubai World‘s debt is not guaranteed by the government, Abdulrahman al-Saleh, director general of the emirate’s Department of Finance, said in an interview with the state-run Dubai TV on Monday, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Salaries Cut for 2 Bank of America Executives
text: Bank of America said its chief financial officer, Joe L. Price, and its head of mortgages, Barbara J. Desoer, would receive less in salary for 2009, citing a review by the government’s special master for compensation, Kenneth R. Feinberg.

headline: Tacoma Suspect Said to Threaten to Shoot Officers
text: SEATTLE  The search for a man suspected of fatally shooting four uniformed officers south of Tacoma, Wash., expanded to this city and beyond on Monday with a flurry of police sweeps and SWAT team investigations. Details also emerged that the suspect had told people that he planned to “shoot some cops,” the police said.

headline: Dubai Crisis Could Give Investors Control of Barneys
text: Dubai’s debt crisis could end up being good news for the hedge fund manager Richard Perry and the supermarket mogul Ronald Burkle, two United States investors in the Dubai-owned Barneys New York, The New York Post reported.

headline: Talk to The Times: Deputy Metro Editor for the Web
text: Wendell Jamieson, deputy metropolitan editor for the Web, is answering questions from readers Nov. 30-Dec. 4, 2009. Questions may be e-mailed to askthetimes@nytimes.com.

headline: On Climate Data, Trends and Peer Review
text: The reverberations continue from what the University of East Anglia says was the illegal dissemination of thousands of files from its Climatic Research Unit (CRU). Over the weekend university officials put out an update saying 95 percent of the raw land-surface temperature data in question have been available to scientists and skeptics for several years, although Roger A. Pielke Jr. of the University of Colorado, Boulder, said he was told differently as recently as August. (Realclimate.org posted the locations of various data sets.) He credited the university and climate center for moving now to be clearer about the data archives and to provide more access. “When the data is available in its original form those skeptical of climate science can then do the temperature math themselves out in the open where everyone can see their work,” Dr. Pielke wrote on Sunday. “If the global numbers come out as CRU has presented over the years, then it will strike a blow to skepticism about global temperature trend records produced by CRU and restore a good deal of credibility to this area of climate science.”

headline: Frederick Joseph, 72, Former Drexel Chief, Dies
text: Frederick H. Joseph, who as the chairman and chief executive of the investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert helped create the modern junk-bond market in the 1980s before the firm’s collapse, has died. He was 72.

headline: Submit Your Funny Caption
text: On, Francis! | Tell us what’s going on in the picture above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned images we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Congress Faces Busy Legislative Month
text: Congress would be returning from its Thanksgiving break this week for a legislative pileup even if the Senate was not beginning its landmark debate on a health care overhaul.

headline: Bernanke Warns of Risks in Push to Revamp Fed
text: The Federal Reserve‘s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, warned bluntly over the weekend that provisions in financial legislation before the House and Senate would “seriously impair” the Fed as it struggled to maintain financial and economic stability.

headline: Travel Deals: Cyber Monday Sales
text: Missed the travel deals for Black Friday? Thanks to the marketing gurus who cooked up Cyber Monday, the kick-off to the online shopping season, there’s still time to book a discounted winter getaway.

headline: Hydro-Quebec’s Green Power Export Plans
text: Hydro-Quebec’s move last month to boost its power exports to the United States by acquiring New Brunswick Power‘s transmission lines has raised eyebrows in New England, where renewable energy ventures would face stiff competition from low-cost hydro generated north of the border.

headline: The Early Word: Speech Prep
text: Washington emerges from the Thanksgiving holiday on Monday with health care and Afghanistan on the mind.

headline: What to Watch Monday: Wilson vs. House
text: Joshua Malina (“Sports Night,” “The West Wing”) guest stars as the patient of the week in an episode of “House” (Fox, 8 p.m.) devoted to House’s best friend and punching bag, Wilson (Robert Sean Leonard). Wilson, working with House’s team, tries to outdiagnose House; we’re guessing that House will, as usual, be both wrong and right.

headline: Markets Rise, With Spending and Dubai Weighing In
text: Wall Street spent Monday trading in a narrow range but managed to push higher at the close.

headline: The Morning Feed
text: What we’re reading on Monday morning.Preparing for Polanski: Roman Polanski could be released as soon as Monday from a Swiss prison and be placed under house arrest at his 19,000-square-foot chalet in Gstaad, The Associated Press reports. Mr. Polanski, the 76-year-old filmmaker who is awaiting possible extradition to the United States, still needs to pay $4.5 million in bail; he’ll also have to pay a $2,000 installation fee and and a $200 monthly maintenance cost for the security monitoring device he will wear. “He will have no prison regime,” a Swiss justice ministry spokesman told The A.P. “He is completely free to determine his daily schedule. It’s also up to him to get in food and other supplies.” Mr. Polanski fled the United States in 1978 before his sentencing for having sex with a 13-year-old girl.Stephen Gately Is Remembered: Agence France-Presse reports on a tribute concert held in London on Sunday night for Stephen Gately, a member of the Irish pop band Boyzone, who died in October. Among the notables who came to pay tribute to Mr. Gately, 33, who died from natural causes stemming from excess fluid in his lungs, were Cherie Blair, Ian McKellen and Graham Norton, as well as the singer’s former bandmates Ronan Keating, Mikey Graham, Keith Duffy and Shane Lynch. “I am just still walking around in a daze really,” the British pop singer Chesney Hawkes told Agence France-Presse. “Such a shock, so young, so vibrant, such a lovely guy.”Gaga as Theater: Is a Lady Gaga concert a pop-music event or a work of theater? To answer this question, The Guardian enlisted Kelly Nestruck, the theater critic for The Globe and Mail in Canada, to review Lady Gaga’s new tour, called the Monster Ball, in Toronto. His verdict? “The Monster Ball ain’t ‘Gypsy,’ ” Mr. Nestruck writes. During a performance of her song “Boys, Boys, Boys,” he writes that Lady Gaga “removed tufts of her costume until she was down to a thin landing strip of apparel. Not even ‘La Cage Aux Folles’ and ‘Priscilla: Queen of the Desert’ could beat this wardrobe.”Everyone Wants to Get Into the Act: In The New Yorker, Michael Schulman reports on the resourceful staff members at Orso, a restaurant in Manhattan’s theater district, who have joined together to stage a production of the S. N. Behrman comedy “Biography” while they await other acting jobs. (Anita Gates’s review of the play for The New York Times can be found here.) “I wish them well,” Joe Allen, the restaurant’s owner, tells The New Yorker. “And, if they get, as they say, discovered, good for them. There’ll be someone else to take their jobs.”

headline: Pirates Seize Oil Tanker, U.S.-Bound, Off Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Somali pirates have struck again, seizing an oil tanker loaded with $150 million in crude that was headed from Saudi Arabia to the United States, naval authorities said Monday.

headline: Growth in Charter Schools Leads to Tensions Over Space
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made charter schools one of his third-term priorities, and that means that in New York, battles and resentment over space — already a way of life — will become even more common. He and his schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, have allowed nearly two-thirds of the city’s 99 charter schools to move into public school buildings, officials expect two dozen charter schools to open next fall, and the mayor has said he will push the Legislature to allow him to add 100 more in the next four years.

headline: Citigroup Hires Buiter as New Chief Economist
text: Citigroup said on Monday that it had hired Willem Buiter, a professor at the London School of Economics, as its chief economist, effective in January.

headline: Rising Temperatures and African Conflict
text: A new study has found evidence of a link between temperature and conflict in Africa.

headline: Netherlands Bolsters Search for Tax Evaders
text: The Netherlands is adding 200 new employees to sniff out undeclared assets outside the country, Jan Kees de Jager, the finance minister, told the Dutch financial daily Het Financieele Dagblad in an interview published Monday.

headline: Q. and A.: On the Death and Life of Languages
text: According to the French linguist Claude Hagège, twenty-five languages die each year; if this rate of decline continues, half the world’s current languages will disappear by 2100.

headline: The Dogbert theory of the debt
text: When I was on This Week yesterday, George Will tried his hand at the debt scare thing, saying that we’re in terrible shape because by 2019 the interest on the debt will be SEVEN HUNDRED BILLION DOLLARS. (That should be read in the voice of Dr. Evil). I get that a lot — people who talk about the big numbers which are supposed to imply that things are terrible, impossible, we’re doomed, etc.

headline: Protectionism and the Great Depression
text: One thing you hear all the time is that protectionism caused the Great Depression. I’ve always seen this as an attempt at a Noble Lie; there’s no good reason to believe that it’s true, but it has been used to scare governments into maintaining relatively free trade.

headline: Is It Too Early to Start Thinking About a Rebound?
text: I have a friend who recently told me that, as the recession took hold, he was forced to stop all capital expenditures for his wholesale distribution company, and I mean all. He even put off spending $2,500 to replace the server that runs his entire company. He has been hit hard, and I understand why he stopped all expenditures. He had no choice. But I suggested to him that if the old server went down, it would be the most expensive $2,500 that he ever “saved.” Clearly, the damage caused would far exceed the money saved. He agreed, and he’s now setting aside cash to get a new one.

headline: The Music of the Rides: ‘Phantom’ Does Coney Island
text: The last time we checked in on “Love Never Dies,” Andrew Lloyd Webber‘s long-gestating sequel to “The Phantom of the Opera,” we offhandedly remarked that the new musical (which is set in Coney Island) probably would not see the Phantom and Christine reunited while waiting in line for the Cyclone.

headline: Monday Reading
text: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Poli-Book Best Sellers
text: To no surprise, Sarah Palin’s book “Going Rogue” debuts at No. 1 on the Caucus’ Poli-Books list and The Times’s overall national best-seller list. Advance sales and the small-cities tour by Ms. Palin, the former Republican vice-presidential nominee, have helped set a brisk pace for moving thisautobiography off the shelves.

headline: Two Veterinary Products Distributors to Merge
text: Henry Schein, the health care products distributor, and Butler Animal Health Supply agreed to merge their animal health businesses on Monday, creating a big new distributor of veterinary products.

headline: Russian Police Release Sketch of Bombing Suspects
text: MOSCOW  The police on Monday released the sketch of a suspect in the bombing of a luxury train that killed 26 people, along with a description of an accomplice. Both were spotted in the remote area of the attack in the days before it occurred, officials said.

headline: Has Holiday Entertainment Become a Luxury Item?
text: As the dancing toys, fairies and rodent royalty of “The Nutcracker” arrive at the David H. Koch Theater for New York City Ballet’s annual production of the classic Balanchine version of that Tchaikovsky work (which Roslyn Sulcas reviews here in The New York Times), many of the city’s best known — and most expensive — holiday-themed shows have started their year-end runs.

headline: Monday Puzzle: Remember Your Password
text: In these days of heightened computer security, an average computer user has to manage a hundred passwords in his or her head, or so it seems. Every computer system you use at work, and every Internet site you use regularly (or even once in a blue moon) wants you to create an account with a password. Not only that, the requirements for the passwords are becoming more stringent: mix up letters and numbers they say, and sometimes non-alphanumeric symbols too. Don’t include any words that can be found in the dictionary, or the names of your children and pets. Change the password every ninety days. And don’t write it down anywhere.

text: Q: (Reader)

headline: San Leandro Seeks to Name a New School
text: San Leandro’s newest learning institution, a campus for high school freshman opening next year to ease overcrowding at San Leandro High, is looking for an identity. To that end, they are thinking about naming the new campus after a famous figure.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Catherine Balsam-Schwaber joined iVillage, New York, in a new post, senior vice president for marketing. She had been vice president for integrated marketing at MTV Networks, New York, part of Viacom. IVillage is part of the NBC Universal Women and Lifestyle Entertainment Networks Group division of NBC Universal, part of the General Electric Company.

headline: For Sesquicentennial, Cooper Union Puts Artifacts on View
text: An 1852 contract — a delicate sheet of paper, with tinges of yellow — outlined plans for the Cooper Union foundation building. On it are the signatures of the college’s founder, Peter Cooper, and the architects Frederick A. Petersen and F. H. Knevitt.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Consumer Reports finds that most chickens are still not safe to handle. “In our latest analysis of fresh, whole broilers bought at stores nationwide, two-thirds harbored salmonella and/or campylobacter, the leading bacterial causes of foodborne disease. That’s a modest improvement since January 2007, when we found that eight of 10 broilers harbored those pathogens. But the numbers are still far too high, especially for campylobacter. Though the government has been talking about regulating it for years, it has yet to do so.”

headline: The Krauthammer Prescription
text: “Insuring the uninsured is a moral imperative,” Charles Krauthammer wrote last week. But “the Democrats,” he went on, “have chosen the worst possible method — a $1 trillion new entitlement of stupefying arbitrariness and inefficiency.” What should we do instead? Krauthammer’s answer: Pass “targeted measures that attack the inefficiencies of the current system one by one — tort reform, interstate purchasing and taxing employee benefits.”

headline: Chelsea Clinton Is Engaged

headline: British Banks May Feel Most Pain if Dubai Defaults

headline: Bad Reviews? Blame the Booze
text: In the latest round of the continuing dispute known as Artists vs. Critics, a British playwright has suggested that reviewers who gave bad notices to her latest show had spent the afternoon drinking before seeing the play that night. The playwright, Timberlake Wertenbaker, told The Guardian that several of the critics who reviewed her play “The Line,” which began performances on Nov. 18 at the Arcola Theater in London, attended an evening performance that followed the presentation of the London Evening Standard theater awards that afternoon -– a four-hour ceremony at the Royal Opera House that included a Champagne reception and wine service at lunch. Ms. Wertenbaker said that the critics “weren’t all drunk but it’s hard to get through something like that without being tired,” adding that “The Line” “is a complicated play, it’s difficult, you have to pay attention to it.”

text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve said Monday that it would begin testing its strategy to shrink its trillion-dollar portfolio of mortgage-backed securities and eventually unwind its biggest program to prop up financial markets.

text: The Federal Reserve said Monday that it would begin testing its strategy to shrink its trillion-dollar portfolio of mortgage-backed securities and eventually unwind its biggest program to prop up financial markets, The New York Times’s Edmund L. Andrews reports from Washington.

headline: The Claim: Exercise More During the Day, and You Will Sleep Better at Night
text: THE FACTS It has long been said that regular physical activity and better sleep go hand in hand. Burn more energy during the day, the thinking goes, and you will be more tired at night.

text: After Tiger Woods said in a statement on Sunday that his Friday morning car accident was his fault but private, media outlets have demonstrated it considers the episode anything but private. And the Internet did not exactly roll up its tubes and go away.

text: Jenna Wortham, a Times technology reporter who contributes regularly to Bits, writes a technology etiquette column for our sister blog, Gadgetwise.

headline: Nine Inch Nails Auctions Its Equipment
text: Though it is the prerogative of rock stars to announce that they are breaking up their band and then reconstitute it months (or weeks or days) later, Nine Inch Nails seems to be serious when it says that it will no longer perform as a group. After playing what it said were its final shows in August and September, the hard-core rock group led by Trent Reznor said on its Web site, nin.com, that it was auctioning off its instruments and other touring equipment on eBay, The Guardian reported. “We’ve been going through the NIN touring and studio rigs and are getting rid of a large selection of gear and equipment the band is no longer in need of,” the band said in a statement on its site, adding: “We do not know which (if any) tour these items are from unless specified, nor can we get any items autographed, so please do not ask.” Among the pieces that the band has put up for sale are a Gibson banjitar (a half-banjo, half-guitar hybrid) that was selling for more than $1,500, and a guitar decorated with artwork from the Nine Inch Nails album “The Fragile,” whose bidding price had passed $2,250.

headline: Regimens: Cancer Concerns in Big Doses of Folic Acid
text: Grains and cereals have been fortified with folic acid in the United States since 1998, as part of an effort to reduce the incidence of neural tube birth defects in babies. But a new study has raised safety concerns, linking megadoses of the vitamin to increased cancer rates, particularly lung cancer.

headline: Will Bryant Enter the Free-Agent Market in 2010?
text: Many N.B.A. teams are preparing to go on a spending spree next summer, some with the objective of landing two or even three blockbuster free agents. The list of potentially available players reads like an All-Star roster, and includes LeBron James, Dwyane Wade, Chris Bosh, Amar’e Stoudemire, Dirk Nowitzki, Yao Ming, Ray Allen, Paul Pierce and Carlos Boozer.

headline: Patterns: Teaming Up to Control High Blood Pressure
text: Most patients with high blood pressure have a hard time keeping it under control, and a new study suggests they may get better results if a team of a physician and a pharmacist manage their care.

headline: Appetizer-Size Spa Treatments

headline: Probation and Fine for Serena Williams’s Tirade
text: Fair or too lenient? The question was worth posing after the announcement Monday that Serena Williams would be fined but not suspended for her threatening, profanity-laced tirade against a lineswoman at this year’s United States Open.

headline: Prognosis: Numbers Rise in a Diabetes Forecast
text: The number of Americans with diabetes will nearly double over the next 25 years, while the cost of care will almost triple, as patients live longer and develop more of the disease’s long-term complications, a new analysis said.

headline: Collaborative Video Editing, Without Software
text: Peer deep into the recesses of that closet in the hallway, and you’ll probably find a pile of old VHS home videos from the 1980s. Several years ago, you and your good intentions may have considered sending these tapes to a video-conversion service to transfer them to DVD. You might have even thought about converting them to digital yourself.

headline: A Times Reporter’s Stormy Friendship With Georgia O’Keeffe

headline: Europe Reacts to the Swiss Minaret Ban
text: When Swiss voters overwhelmingly approved a ban on construction of minarets in a referendum on Sunday, they surprised some pollsters and disappointed many European leaders, including those of their own government, who opposed the ban and now must find a way to implement it.

headline: Taking Stock After Thanksgiving
text: After Thanksgiving, I use the turkey carcass to make a rich-tasting stock that I can pull out of the freezer in the months ahead to use in risottos, soups and stews. The stock is easy to make but requires a long simmer, six hours if possible. So during the long weekend following Thanksgiving, I try to set aside an afternoon at home to simmer a pot of turkey stock on the stove.

headline: One More Reason to Be Thankful: NCOs
text: The U.S. Army named this year  the year of the noncommissioned officer (NCO).

headline: Christopher Walken and Kelsey Grammer Returning to Broadway
text: One of Christopher Walken‘s trademark performances was his monologue as Captain Koons in Quentin Tarantino’s “Pulp Fiction,” where his character described hiding a gold watch in his rectum for two years as a prisoner of war in Vietnam. Mr. Walken, veteran of the spooky and the strange, sure can tell a good body-part story — which he’ll be doing in his return to Broadway this winter after 10 years, as a man searching for his missing hand in the play “A Behanding in Spokane.”

headline: City Hall Aide Is Named Environmental Protection Commissioner
text: After a 13-month nationwide search for a new commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday appointed a City Hall insider who sits just a couple desks away from him: Caswell F. Holloway IV, the chief of staff to Edward Skyler, deputy mayor for operations.

headline: Vietnamese-Style Turkey (or Chicken) Noodle Soup
text: This soup is inspired by a classic Vietnamese chicken phô. You can give it a Thai twist by adding minced green peppers to the list of condiments.

headline: ‘Pulp Fiction’ Writer Sent From Furlough Program to Prison
text: Was Roger Avary, the incarcerated screenwriter of “Pulp Fiction,” moved from a prison work furlough program to a county jail because he was Tweeting about his prison experience? Depends on whom you ask. Mr. Avary, who, with Quentin Tarantino, shared an Academy Award in 1995 for “Pulp Fiction,” was sentenced in September to one year in prison after pleading guilty in August to charges of vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving that stemmed from a 2008 car accident. In October, posts began appearing on Mr. Avary’s Twitter account, in which he described his jail setting (“The building is an imposing example of the Brutalist architectural movement,” he wrote) and details of his furlough program.

headline: Ravioli or Tortellini in Broth
text: There are many different kinds of freshly made ravioli available, and this is a great way to present any of them. I prefer this approach over a tomato sauce, because a reduced broth doesn’t have a strong flavor that competes with the ravioli filling. This is an easy way to put together an elegant meal.

headline: Featured Recipe: Simple Chocolate Layer Cake
text: When it’s my turn to make a dessert for a holiday gathering I head straight for chocolate layer cake. Since I refuse to compromise on ingredients, a certain amount of work is involved, but I streamline the process as much as possible.

headline: Comprehending a Deadly Crash
text: The Bay Area is reeling over a car crash Saturday night in Sonoma County that left a family of four dead. The driver of another car, who appears to have been the cause of the crash at the intersection of Highway 37 and Lakeville Highway, was also killed.

headline: How Woods Wins a Major
text: While most players succumb to the tougher courses and heightened nerves, Tiger Woods shows less of a decline.

headline: Readers Speak Out About a Missed JetBlue Flight
text: Charles DeLaFuente’s account of paying a stiff penalty for missing a JetBlue flight drew more than 100 comments, though they were noticeably critical of the complainer, saying he pulled it much too close by arriving only 30 minutes before departure time. Still, some sympathized with him for having to pay extra to be booked on the next flight, which had many free seats, though at least one reader noted that the discount carriers have different rules.

headline: Continental Showcase
text: To get a better sense of place, some armchair travelers eat ethnic food or page through coffee-table books of glossy photographs; I have one uncle who likes to read geographical histories of any area before he visits. But I’m a fiction reader, so I was thrilled to learn that Dalkey Archive Press — the Illinois publisher that specializes in (among other things) high-quality translations of challenging fiction — has started a “Best European Fiction” series modeled on the familiar “Best American” books. “Best European Fiction 2010” went on sale last week, featuring 35 stories from 30 countries, and it offers an appealingly diverse look at the Continent’s fiction scene: from prominent authors like Hungary’s George Konrad and Spain’s Julián Ríos to relative newcomers like Croatia’s Neven Usumovic and Ireland’s Julian Gough. The book was edited by the Bosnian Aleksandar Hemon, who now lives in Chicago and says he considers himself both a European writer and an American one. In an e-mail exchange last week, Paper Cuts asked him about “Best European Fiction 2010.”

In this lesson, students learn terms associated with polling as well as how to read and evaluate poll methodologies and results. They then practice administering and interpreting polls.

headline: Premiums for Employee Health Coverage May Change Little, Budget Study Finds
text: The large number of Americans who currently have employer-sponsored medical insurance would not see much change in their premium costs as a result of the health care legislation pending in Congress, according to a widely awaited budget analysis.

headline: Things to come
text: What’s going to happen, economically and politically, over the next few years? Nobody knows, of course. But I have a vision — what I think is the most likely course of events. It’s fairly grim — but not in the approved way. This vision lies behind a lot of what I’ve been writing, so it might clarify things for regular readers if I laid it out explicitly.

headline: Humanities Chairman Starts ‘Civility Tour’
text: While Rocco Landesman, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, has grabbed the lion’s share of headlines for his travels to Peoria, Ill., his colleague Jim Leach, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, is planning a road trip of his own. On Monday, the N.E.H. said that Mr. Leach would begin a 50-state civility tour on Tuesday in Concord, N.H., where he plans to address a group of civic, political and academic leaders on the subject of hate speech and its dangers. Mr. Leach, the former Republican congressman from Iowa, mentioned the tour in a speech he delivered on Nov. 6 in Omaha, in which he lamented “a political setting that is bordering on a civility crisis at home and a civilization crisis abroad.” Following his appearance Tuesday at the Lincoln Financial Group Insurance Company auditorium, Mr. Leach plans to visit Augusta, Me., on Wednesday, and to visit all 50 states over the next 18 months to discuss civil discourse in American society.

headline: Jeter Wins ‘Sportsman of the Year’
text: The first Sports Illustrated issue I ever received was the last one of 1984. It was a “Sportsman and Sportswoman of the Year” issue, celebrating Edwin Moses and Mary Lou Retton. Ever since, I’ve looked forward to that issue because I love the whole concept.

headline: With Futility Record at Stake, Ticket Sales Are as Cold as the Nets
text: The Nets are on the verge of establishing an N.B.A. record, yet their fans want no part of it. If the Nets lose Wednesday night’s showdown against the Dallas Mavericks, they will have the most losses to start an N.B.A. season (18).

headline: U.S.A. All the Way
text: American style — basic American style, the American style that goes back to Henry Ford’s cars, James Dean’s T-shirt and the Timex watch — is not a pose but an adaptation to basic, fundamental challenges. Take jeans, our sartorial signature and our most influential contribution to the modern global wardrobe. They may sell for hundreds of dollars in swank boutiques from Boston to Buenos Aires, but it must be remembered that they originated as work wear for 19th-century laborers who valued them not for their color or silhouette but for their riveted ruggedness. Cowboy hats, truckers’ wallets, nylon windbreakers and Converse high-tops, to mention just a random sampling of the wearable artifacts that have come to define our nation’s aesthetic, were inspired by necessity rather than an intent to catch the eye. Design for design’s sake, our history suggests, is not an American priority. Instead, we design things to do a certain job (whether it’s in a mine, an office or a basketball arena), and when we devise a solution to the challenge, especially one that’s ingenious, simple or cheap, the result is a forward leap in style that may not even seem like one at first. (Until the Japanese trend scouts come along and hawk it in Tokyo department stores.)

The show’s previous record of $1,839,950 was set during New Year’s week during the 2007-08 season.

text: The big topic of discussion on the political blogs this morning, especially conservative ones, is the news that the man suspected of gunning down four uniformed officers on Sunday near Tacoma, Washington, was granted clemency nine years ago by Mike Huckabee, when he was the governor of Arkansas. And many have been wondering whether this will be one of those events that would haunt Mr. Huckabee far into the future.

headline: Comedy Will Close to Make Way for ‘Emperor Jones’
text: The producers of the Off-Broadway play “Made in Heaven” have relented on their claim to the Soho Playhouse, announcing on Monday that they would close down their show so that the theater can host a transfer of the Eugene O’Neill play “The Emperor Jones.” Last week, the Irish Repertory Theater said that it planned to bring its production of “The Emperor Jones,” starring John Douglas Thompson in the title role, to the Soho Playhouse beginning on Dec. 15 — an announcement that startled the producers of “Made in Heaven,” a comedy about conjoined twins that opened at that theater on Nov. 2. The “Made in Heaven” producers said last Wednesday that their contract with the Soho Playhouse gave them the discretion to close down their show after giving four weeks’ notice. But on Monday, they said they would close the show after its Dec. 7 performance. In a statement, Barbara Ligeti, the lead producer of “Made in Heaven,” said, “We agonized over this decision,” adding: “The Soho Playhouse made us a very favorable offer, and we felt that sparring with them, to the detriment of the Irish Rep’s wonderful production, would be counterproductive and mean-spirited.”

text: If you listen to any pop music, you’d probably conclude that Mondays are really, really awful. But you’d be misguided: according to a new economic study, Sundays are actually much worse — at least in Germany.

text: IN the last year I haven’t spent much alone time with my sister, which is no surprise considering she is the mother of a 5-year-old and a 2-year-old. We’ve grabbed a bite or a cup of tea around town, but to hunker down for serious yakking and snacking, no. One reason is we aren’t eating the same things. Phoebe has been vegan on and off for years, and recently, she’s been more on.

text: The Great Health Care Debate of 2009 is under way on the Senate floor, and it took just a scant few minutes for the partisan skirmishing to begin in full force.

text: Lewis H. Lapham leans forward behind his wide wooden desk and within minutes of speaking has mentioned Mark Twain, Arthur Schlesinger Jr., Goethe, Cicero, John Locke, Hamilton, Adams and Madison. A laptop on a side table is piled high with papers.

headline: For the Holidays, White House Uses Barneys Decorator
text: Simon Doonan, famous for creating naughty yuletide window displays of Margaret Thatcher (as a dowdy dominatrix) and Madonna (not the holy one), has a new stage on which to present his brand of mistletoe mischief: he is decorating the White House for Christmas.

headline: Report Cites $11 Billion Shortfall in A.I.G. Business
text: An independent analysis of whether the insurance industry has been setting aside enough money to pay claims has found that the American International Group has a shortfall of about $11 billion in its all-important property and casualty business, The New York Times’s Mary Williams Walsh reports.

headline: Bewitched by Bach, Bewildered by His Masterpiece
text: There is a good reason Johann Sebastian Bach’s six cello suites strike Eric Siblin as irresistibly exotic. Mr. Siblin is not a seasoned Bach aficionado. He spent years as a pop music critic before suddenly becoming bewitched by the Cello Suites, their mysterious provenance and the manner in which Pablo Casals famously rediscovered, recorded and popularized this long-forgotten music. Thus mesmerized, Mr. Siblin has written about the Cello Suites from a wide-eyed newbie’s point of view.

headline: Mr. Bayh Reassured by Budget Office Study
text: It was Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, who insisted that the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office study the potential effect of health care legislation on premium costs for the majority of Americans who already have health benefits. Mr. Bayh has issued a statement saying that he is reassured by the analysis unveiled by the budget office earlier Monday.

headline: The Joys, and Lessons, of Traveling to Brazil
text: I’VE been flying since I was a child. I was only 8 years old when I had my first solo flight to Europe. I had to wear my passport around my neck, and I always got a lot of attention from the flight attendants. Many of them would put me in the business-class section, even though I belonged in economy.

headline: Disabled, and Seeking Acceptance in Fashion
text: The fashion world may be the last bastion of prejudice, a field that overtly discriminates against people because of their looks. So there is something both bold and troubling about “Britain’s Missing Top Model,” a reality show that begins on Tuesday on BBC America that pits disabled women against one another to compete for a photo spread in the U.K. edition of Marie Claire magazine.

headline: A Conversation With Ken Salazar
text: John Broder of The New York Times interviewed Ken Salazar, the secretary of the interior, about the challenges facing the federal agency.

headline: Senators Begin Offering Amendments
text: Senators are beginning to submit a torrent of amendments to the big health care legislation.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'La Jetee'
text: A. O. Scott looks at Chris Marker's 28-minute rumination on time, love and the apocalypse.

headline: Travels in Cyberspace: The Monday Report
text: Thrill-seeking travelers already making their vacation plans for next year might want to check out what Gadling picks as its “Top 10 (+2) Adventure Destinations for 2010.” The list isn’t exactly revelatory (Antarctica, New Zealand and Peru all make the cut), but the travel blog makes a strong case that its top-rated pick — the Himalayas —– is well worth the trouble and expense of getting there.

headline: Christmas ‘Dog’ Trampled by Football
text: A warmhearted holiday-themed movie  with a dog, no less  showed no teeth on Sunday night against that other seasonal tradition: football. According to Nielsen’s estimates, NBC ranked first for the night with its “Sunday Night Football” coverage of the Pittsburgh Steelers playing the Baltimore Ravens. Preliminary overnight estimates show it drew more viewers than last week’s game between the Philadelphia Eagles and the Chicago Bears, which averaged 17.3 million. CBS was second with “60 Minutes” (14.3 million), “The Amazing Race” (11.7 million) and “A Dog Named Christmas” (12.3 million). Best in show for ABC was “Desperate Housewives” (12.6 million), while Fox drew 9 million for “The Simpsons” and 8.5 million for “Family Guy.”

headline: Nine Inch Nails Auctions Its Equipment
text: Though it is the prerogative of rock stars to announce that they are breaking up their band and then reconstitute it months (or weeks or days) later, Nine Inch Nails seems to be serious when it says that it will no longer perform as a group. After playing what it said were its final shows in August and September, the hard-core rock group led by Trent Reznor said on its Web site, nin.com, that it was auctioning off its instruments and other touring equipment on eBay, The Guardian reported. Among the pieces put up for sale are a Gibson banjitar (a banjo-guitar hybrid) that was selling for more than $1,500, and a guitar decorated with artwork from the Nine Inch Nails album “The Fragile,” whose bidding price had passed $2,250.

headline: ‘Pulp Fiction’ Writer Is Sent to Jail
text: Was Roger Avary, a screenwriter of “Pulp Fiction,” moved from a prison work furlough program to a county jail in California because he was tweeting about his prison experience? Depends on whom you ask. Mr. Avary, who shared an Academy Award in 1995 with Quentin Tarantino for “Pulp Fiction,” was sentenced in September to one year in prison after pleading guilty to charges of vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving. In October posts began appearing on Mr. Avary’s Twitter account in which he described his jail setting (“The building is an imposing example of the Brutalist architectural movement,” he wrote) and details of his furlough program. On Friday, The Ventura County Star reported, Mr. Avary was taken off the work furlough program, owing to what Capt. Ross Bonfiglio of the Ventura County Sheriff’s Department called a “security-related” issue. “I wouldn’t doubt that it had something to do with those tweets,” Captain Bonfiglio told The Star. But on Monday he told The Associated Press that Mr. Avary’s Twitter posts had not played a major role in Mr. Avary’s incarceration.

headline: A Show Doesn’t Go on So That Another Might
text: Producers of the Off Broadway play “Made in Heaven” have relented on their claim to the SoHo Playhouse, saying on Monday that they would close their show so the theater could host a transfer of the Eugene O’Neill play “The Emperor Jones.” Last week the Irish Repertory Theater said it planned to bring its production of “The Emperor Jones,” starring John Douglas Thompson, to the SoHo Playhouse beginning on Dec. 15  an announcement that startled the producers of “Made in Heaven,” a comedy about conjoined twins that opened at that theater on Nov. 2. The “Made in Heaven” producers said that their contract with the theater gave them the discretion to close their show after giving four weeks’ notice. But on Monday they said they would close after the Dec. 7 performance. In a statement, Barbara Ligeti, the lead producer of “Made in Heaven,” said, “The SoHo Playhouse made us a very favorable offer, and we felt that sparring with them, to the detriment of the Irish Rep’s wonderful production, would be counterproductive and mean-spirited.”

headline: Walken and Grammer Returning to Broadway
text: Christopher Walken, a veteran of the spooky and the strange, sure can tell a good body-part story  which he’ll be doing in his return to Broadway this winter after 10 years, as a man searching for his missing hand in the play “A Behanding in Spokane.” Mr. Walken will be joined by Zoe Kazan and Anthony Mackie as two con artists, and Sam Rockwell as a hotel clerk, in the new black comedy by Martin McDonagh, whose plays on Broadway have included “The Lieutenant of Inishmore,” “The Pillowman” and “The Beauty Queen of Leenane.” Mr. Walken last appeared on Broadway as Gabriel Conroy in “James Joyce’s The Dead,” for which he was nominated for a Tony Award for best actor in a musical. “A Behanding in Spokane” is scheduled to run for 16 weeks, with previews beginning on Feb. 15 and the opening scheduled for March 4 at the Schoenfeld Theater. ... The producers of next spring’s revival of “La Cage aux Folles” confirmed that the Emmy Award-winning actor Kelsey Grammer (“Frasier”) would play the nightclub owner Georges opposite the British actor Douglas Hodge as Albin, his partner and the club’s leading drag queen. Mr. Grammer’s last outing on Broadway was as the title character in the 2000 revival of “Macbeth,” which received poor reviews and closed after 8 previews and 13 regular performances. “La Cage aux Folles” is to start previews on April 6 and open on April 18 at the Longacre Theater.

headline: After Lambert, Disney Seeks Fewer Surprises
text: Whether or not the singer Adam Lambert is booked on another ABC television show, that network’s parent company has said that his sexually provocative performance at the American Music Awards has changed the way it will approach live television broadcasts. In an interview with Reuters, Anne Sweeney, the co-chairwoman of Disney Media Networks and president of the Disney-ABC Television Group, said that Disney would seek assurances  as well as contractual stipulations  that artists’ on-air performances will closely mirror their rehearsals. “We certainly don’t want to suppress artistry at any level, but we also have to be very cognizant of who our audience is,” Ms. Sweeney told Reuters. Mr. Lambert, the “American Idol” finalist, set off a torrent of criticism with his Nov. 22 appearance at the American Music Awards, which were broadcast on ABC, in which he simulated sex acts, kissed his male band mate, above, and extended his middle finger to a television camera. Mr. Lambert later said that he got “carried away” and that he had not performed those same moves during a rehearsal for the awards show. In the fallout over his performance, ABC’s “Good Morning America” withdrew its invitation to host a free concert for Mr. Lambert last Wednesday.

headline: No Country for Old Typewriters: A Well-Used One Heads to Auction
text: Cormac McCarthy has written more than a dozen novels, several screenplays, two plays, two short stories, countless drafts, letters and more  and nearly every one of them was tapped out on a portable Olivetti manual typewriter he bought in a Knoxville, Tenn., pawnshop around 1963 for $50.

headline: For Poe, This Has Been the Year to Die For
text: RICHMOND, Va.  Edgar Allan Poe took good care of his corpses. They are neatly cut up and craftily stowed beneath floorboards (“The Tell-Tale Heart”); they are walled into ancient catacombs where nothing is likely to disturb their well-earned eternal slumber (“The Cask of Amontillado”); they are encased in coffins that somehow permit them to emerge to take care of unfinished business (“The Fall of the House of Usher”). But the living  some of whom become those corpses  have a much harder time of it. They obsess, brood and hate; they are possessed by bizarre impulses; they wrestle with inchoate forces and often succumb, scarcely knowing the scope of their perversities.

headline: F.A.A. Clarifies What Can Be Stowed in Seat Back
text: COMMON sense has prevailed, for once. The Federal Aviation Administration recently issued new guidelines that clarify formerly confounding policies on whether passengers may put personal items in airplane seat-back pockets.

headline: One Microbe as a Group of 200 Protein Machines
text: Molecular biology for years meant breaking down living cells to their smallest component parts, the genes and proteins that govern what a cell does. But a list of parts tells only so much. To understand how living cells really work, biologists are now trying to visualize how the parts are assembled into operational units.

headline: Dubai Inc.’s Holdings May Go Up for Auction
text: Much of the billions of dollars that Dubai borrowed during the boom years went to help build grandiose trophy real estate projects at home like an indoor skiing arena, the world’s largest airport, artificial palm-shaped islands and the world’s tallest building. But the emirate’s state-owned companies also went on a spending spree abroad, acquiring properties and companies that could now wind up on the auction block — potentially at fire-sale prices — to pay off its creditors.

headline: Critics’ Picks: ‘La Jetee’
text: This week, A. O. Scott discusses the abundance of apocalyptic films that have made their way to theaters in recent years. “But none of these visions of catastrophe,” he says, “is quite as haunting or as effective as one put forward in a movie called ‘La Jetee.’” The 28-minute film consists of voice-over narration, a score and a series of photographs. Please share your thoughts on “La Jetee” and what you consider to be the best apocalyptic film.

headline: Council Curtails Stores’ Use of Roll-Down Security Gates
text: Citing high rates of graffiti, the City Council voted unanimously on Monday to gradually ban the use of roll-down metal security gates, a move that would eliminate what has been an enduring if forbidding feature of the urban streetscape.

headline: Subject, Meet Verb
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

headline: Subject, Meet Verb
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.

headline: Marion Jones Aims for a Comeback, in Basketball
text: SAN ANTONIO

headline: And Now They Sing the Fiddle Electric
text: As a member of the enterprising new-music ensembles Ne(x)tworks and Ethel, the violinist Cornelius Dufallo runs into plenty of composers. He has coaxed new solo works from some and taken up older scores by others. He is also a composer himself: “Dream Streets,” his new CD (for Innova), is devoted to his own imaginative works for violin and electronics.

headline: Looking for Balloons and Insights to Online Behavior
text: The prize is $40,000, and it goes to the first person or group to determine the locations of 10 red balloons that can be anywhere in the continental United States.

headline: A Beetle, Its Eggs and the Secrets of a Glue
text: Wax is slippery stuff, a characteristic that many plants employ to keep nasty things off them. The needlelike branches of asparagus plants, for example, are covered with wax crystals, which make the branches practically unwettable and keep things from sticking.

headline: A Program of Songs to Explore the Shades of Love
text: The appealing Austrian mezzo-soprano Angelika Kirchschlager is in New York to prepare for her overdue return to the Metropolitan Opera. She will sing Hansel in Humperdinck’s “Hansel and Gretel” this month. If she has been missing in action from the Met since 2002 (when she appeared as Cherubino in Mozart’s “Nozze di Figaro”), Ms. Kirchschlager, a vivid interpreter of lieder, has made New York a regular stop on her song recital tours.

headline: Plume of Pollutants From a Small Airport
text: For people who live near an airport, noise is a major concern. But air quality can be an issue, too: after all, aircraft engines produce emissions on the ground as well as in the air.

headline: ‘Emperor Jones’ Director Says Misunderstanding Almost Halted Transfer
text: Ciarán O’Reilly, the producing director of the Irish Repertory Theater, said on Monday that “a massive communications breakdown” between the owners of the Soho Playhouse and the producers of the comedy “Made in Heaven” had nearly prevented Mr. O’Reilly’s company from transferring its production of “The Emperor Jones” to that theater.

headline: Afghanistan Vets: Send Your Thoughts on Obama’s Plans
text: At War is looking for American service members who have spent time in Afghanistan, preferably on more than one deployment, for a Times article about President Obama’s decision on troop levels there. If interested, please use the comment box below to tell us a little about yourself, your time in Afghanistan and the best way to reach you. The comments will not be published but will be forwarded to the Times reporter writing an article that will appear later this week. Some of those who respond will be asked if they are willing for their reactions to be taped for an audio presentation on the Web.
